{"url": "https://www.stalbertgazette.com/local-news/red-dresses-in-healing-garden-reminder-of-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-6968619", "title": "Red dresses in healing garden reminder of missing and murdered Indigenous women - St. Albert News", "body": "Skip to content\n2024 Readers' ChoiceJoin Our Newsletters Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nFeatures\nObits\nEvents\nDiscover Local\nJobsPublic Notices\nOpen HousesConnect\n21.9 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nRed dresses in healing garden reminder of missing and murdered Indigenous women\nAbout 84 per cent of cases in Alberta are murder cases, according to the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC). That number is considerably higher than the national average of 67 per cent.\nJackie Carmichael\nMay 8, 2023 11:43 AM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 2 St. Albert's Alanna Tyler(l) and Rhonda Wood-Viscarra (r) pose outside city hall in Edmonton on Red Dress day to remind Albertans of missing and murdered Indigenous women who have not returned home . JACKIE CARMICHAEL/ St. Albert Gazette\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:05:01\n\nOn the river behind St. Albert Place, at the Healing Gardens, red dresses wafted on the Friday breeze, their fabric billowing then going slack as if haunted by memories of the missing and slain.\n\nIt was Red Dress Day\u2014a reminder of the nation\u2019s missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nIt\u2019s the second year of\u00a0co-organizing the display for St. Albert\u2019s Cheryl Lundy-Stuart.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very powerful to see them flow in the wind, they seem to come alive,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s really quite overwhelming.\u201d\u00a0\n\nThe dresses tell stories, with attached photos and remembrances.\n\n\u201cEach dress tells the story of one of the many women who never had a chance to live,\u201d she said.\u00a0\n\nLast year, a similar display at the site stayed up from May 5 to the July 1 Run for Reconciliation.\n\nA book in a plastic container invites site visitors to record their thoughts on seeing the moving display.\n\nDisplay co-organizer and St. Albert resident Amanda Patrick was raised with some Indigenous culture in her M\u00e9tis\u00a0family.\n\n\u201cI spent the last few years trying to find my place as a M\u00e9tis\u00a0woman,\u201d Patrick said.\n\nThe red dress display came from that impulse, she said.\n\nPatrick has had a family member living a high-risk lifestyle, who went missing but then was found safely. She\u2019s shocked by the statistics.\u00a0\n\n\u201cOnce you start reading, the facts are crazy,\u201d Patrick said.\n\n\u201cIn 2022, there were over 600 missing alerts\u2014two-thirds of the missing alerts were for Indigenous people,\u201d she said.\n\nAbout 84 per cent of cases in Alberta are murder cases, according to the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC). That number is considerably higher than the national average of 67 per cent.\n\nAbout 70 per cent of the Alberta cases involve women between the ages of 18 and 44.\n\nToo often cases of missing Aboriginal women are stereotyped and/or dismissed as involving only \u2018run-aways,\u2019 the NWAC release said.\n\n\u201cNot only is this untrue, it implies that young girls that do \u2018run-away\u2019 are somehow undeserving of attention or protection,\u201d it said.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of known individuals in Alberta (almost 90 per cent) involve mothers.\n\nSome 76 per cent of Alberta\u2019s missing women and girls disappeared from an urban area, which is higher than the national average.\n\n\u201cIn Alberta, only 42 per cent of murder cases in NWAC\u2019s database have been cleared by charges of homicide. This is far lower than the national average of 53 per cent,\u201d the release said.\n\nHowever the percent of cases cleared by suicide is among the highest in Canada\u2014almost three times higher than the national average.\n\nOverall, the percentage of unsolved cases in Alberta is still comparable to the national average\u2014 42 per cent in Alberta.\n\nIndigenous women in beautifully adorned traditional red skirts on Friday morning at City Hall in Edmonton for National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit people.\u00a0\n\nA long name to address longstanding injustices, the day brought Rhonda Wood-Viscarra out to bring attention to entrenched and shameful truths. A member of the St.Albert-Sturgeon County Metis Local #1904, she cited numbers from the NWAC that show provincial statistics here are worse even than the still-shocking Canadian averages for Aboriginal women and girls in Alberta who go missing or are murdered.\n\n\u201cThere are 93 cases of missing and murdered Aboriginal women and girls in Alberta. This accounts for 16 per cent of all cases in NWAC\u2019s database,\u201d a NWAC release said.\n\nThe number of cases in Alberta is second only to British Columbia (which accounts for about 28 per cent of all cases)\n\n\u201cNinety-three cases in Alberta, that\u2019s unacceptable,\u201d Wood-Viscarra said, the morning sun glinting off her traditionally beaded earrings in the shape of red dresses.\n\n\u201cAs Indigenous women, we have to stand up for our sisters who have gone missing,\u201d\n\nIndigenous women who go missing are just as important as non-Indigenous, she said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important for Alberta to take a stand, and not just talk. We need action,\u201d Wood-Viscarra said.\n\nAlanna Tyler, also of the Metis Local #1904 for St. Albert/Sturgeon County, said attention must be paid.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s not enough recognition in Alberta and Canada when our indigenous people go missing. You don\u2019t get the same response,\u201d Tyler said. \u201cWe need to see follow-ups, we need to see action. That\u2019s what today is all about.\u201d\n\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nNot Very\n\t\nSlightly\n\t\nFairly\n\t\nVery\n\t\nExtremely\nComments {"url": "https://www.peacearchnews.com/community/alex-house-stories-from-our-neighbourhood/", "title": "ALEX HOUSE: Stories from our neighbourhood - Peace Arch News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.3 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Community\nALEX HOUSE: Stories from our neighbourhood\nNew Alex House columnist Penny Bradley is ready to share\nBlack Press Media\nMay 4, 2023 8:30 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nI am excited to write my first column under the Alex House byline, and look forward to sharing our stories with our wider community.\n\nIt also happens to be Neighbourhood House week in Metro Vancouver, a week to celebrate our place-based approach, and the stories of our neighbourhoods.\n\nThis year\u2019s theme, \u201cHow We Grow Together,\u201d is about cultivating an environment in which people from all cultures and backgrounds can grow both personally and collectively \u2013 alongside their community. There is also a contest, share your stories with us \u2013https://tinyurl.com/NHWeek-Contest\n\nSome of you may have noticed a slight adjustment of our name to Alex House. While our team and volunteers often use Alex House as our nickname, we decided to embrace it formally in an effort to move away from the colonizing history of our historic namesake Queen Alexandra.\n\nPeople often ask me why we made this change, and I share that it stems from learning about our history.\n\nAs a neighbourhood house our history is steeped in the social justice movement.\n\nJust prior to the turn-of-the-century, the settlement movement began in London, where settlement workers lived in community with the people they served. At the time this was a radical new way of working with people.\n\nFrom this work Toynbee Hall, the first settlement house/neighbourhood house, was established. The movement grew across the U.S., Canada, and throughout the world.\n\nHowever, the good intentions of the settlement movement also inadvertently contributed to colonization. This is the Truth that needs acknowledgement before Reconciliation can happen.\n\nOver the past few years we, at Alex House, have been actively learning about the impact of colonization, and are working to decolonize our approach. While we are learners in this work we are deeply committed to seeing our work through a decolonized lens. We have had Indigenous teachers along the way, helping us to build understanding, while holding us accountable. Ta7tal\u00edya Nahanee of S\u1e35wx\u0331w\u00fa7mesh \u00daxwumixw, helped kick start this journey for us through her work with Nahanee Creative, while her daughter Ta7tal\u00edya-men Paisley Nahanee created our new logo, which includes Coast Salish lines, serving as an aspirational image for all of us at Alex House.\n\nOver the next few months I will be sharing our decolonizing journey, interwoven with stories from our neighbourhood, with the hope that it will demystify this work, and encourage our community to learn alongside us at Alex House.\n\nYou can also check out our website for additional background and resources www.alexhouse.net. With respect, and gratitude we operate on the stolen land of the Coast Salish people, locally the Semiamha (Semiahmoo), Katzie, and Kwantlen people. We do not use the word stolen to be provocative, but rather to state the truth of what unceded means.\n\nPerhaps one day we will simply state we are on the land of the Coast Salish people, but today we feel it is important to state the truth, in order to move towards reconciliation.\n\nI understand the word stolen stings, but our job as settlers is to fully understand the impact of colonization and sometimes it is uncomfortable.\n\nIn light of this work, it is important to note that May 5 is Red Dress Day, also known as National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and 2S People. Since 2010 May 5 has been a day to bring awareness to the lost lives of Indigenous women, girls and 2S people in Canada. Red Dress Day was inspired by Metis artist Jamie Black\u2019s REDress Project installation which displayed red dresses to represent the missing Indigenous women and girls who have been disproportionately impacted by violence.\n\nA 2019 Inquiry highlighted 231 Calls for Justice, and section 15 outlines Calls for Justice for all Canadians. To honour the Indigenous women whose lives have been lost due to violence, start by reading section 15, and begin taking action. To get you started \u2013 15.1 Denounce and speak out against violence towards Indigenous Women, Girls and 2S people.\n\nWe all have an important part to play in the effort to reduce violence and oppression against Indigenous people.\n\nAnd on a lighter note, on May 27 and 28, we will host the 47th Alex Festival. It is hard to believe that this grassroots, volunteer-driven festival has been hosted in Crescent Beach for over 47 years.\n\nThis year the festival will be held over two days.\n\nOn Saturday, May 27, we will host our traditional event for families with performances, a marketplace, children\u2019s activities, and food vendors, while on Sunday, May 28, we will be offering a music festival for people 19-plus, with a beer garden, food and vendors.\n\nBoth days are by donation/pay what you can, and we hope you will join us, and help celebrate our community!\n\nPenny Bradley (she/her) is a third generation settler of Welsh descent, living and working on the stolen land of Semiahmoo Nation, with her partner, son, and very needy dog. Working as the Executive Director at Alex House she works with a team to contribute to a vibrant, inclusive, and caring community.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tSouth Surrey pub earns heritage distinction\n\t\tSouth Surrey parents urge change to suicide language\n\t\t'Colonization 2024': Semiahmoo chief responds to criticism on land\n\t\tProtesters 'denounce' presence of Israel at Canada Cup in South Surrey\n\t\tCulprits in 'complex shoplifting scheme' sentenced in Surrey\nFacebook Comments (0) \nHead-on crash kills 2, blocks access to BC Ferries terminal\nBlack Press Media\nSouth Surrey farming family reacts after First Nation announcement\nBlack Press Media\nAlways Keep a Bread Clip in Your Wallet, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly!\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nSurrey man charged in allegedly trafficking over 400 catalytic converters\nBlack Press Media\nSafe Surrey Coalition accuses mayor of 'cronyism'\nBlack Press Media\nScatter Soap in Your Yard, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians Born 1944 - 1983 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nB.C. man killed in motorcycle crash in Washington State\nBlack Press Media\nRCMP continue to follow up on Ocean Park community concern\nBlack Press Media\nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. {"url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/9677404/red-dress-day-missing-murdered-indigenous-abbotsford/", "title": "\u2018We have a voice\u2019: Missing, murdered Indigenous women and girls honoured in Abbotsford - BC | Globalnews.ca", "body": "SKIP TO MAIN CONTENT\nSUBSCRIBE\nRADIO\nLIVE\nSite theme toggle. Switch between light or dark mode\nLIGHT\nDARK\nGlobalNews home\nWatch\nWorld\nCanada\nLocal\nPolitics\nMoney\nHealth\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nPerspectives\nSports\nCommentary\nContests\nPodcasts\nU.S. News\nShopping\nFull Menu\nSearch Menu\nCANADA\n\u2018We have a voice\u2019: Missing, murdered Indigenous women and girls honoured in Abbotsford\nBy Elizabeth McSheffrey  Global News\nPosted May 5, 2023 4:40 pm\n Updated May 5, 2023 7:38 pm\n 4 min read\nWATCH: Red garments are being hung up around the province and country as people honour the memory of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people. May 5th marks Red Dress Day and as Julie Nolin reports, it's not only a time of reflection, but a call to action \u2013 May 5, 2023\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nWarning: This story contains details that may upset and trigger some readers. Anyone affected by the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQI+ people needing support can call a national toll free crisis line at 1-844-413-6649.\n\nDozens of red dresses hung from tents and trees in Abbotsford Friday, honouring countless Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people who have gone missing or been murdered over decades.\n\nAcross the country, May 5 is known as Red Dress Day, a day of mourning, remembrance and action on the MMIWG2S crisis that has plagued Canada for generations.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important, first off, because of all the genocide in our country put on our people,\u201d said Vanessa Fleury, an Indigenous support worker in Abbotsford.\n\n\u201cNow we have a voice, now we can speak, now we can honour these missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls as well as the two-spirited who were taken from us too soon.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n4:22\nRed Dress Day in Vancouver honours memories of murdered and missing Indigenous women\n\nRed Dress Day began in 2010, inspired by Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project\u00a0\u2014 an art installation and visual reminder of the \u201cstaggering\u201d number of Indigenous women who are victims of violence.\n\nIn 2019, a national inquiry into the MMIWG2S crisis found more than six in 10 Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people have experienced physical or sexual violence. They are also 12 times more likely to be missing or murdered than non-Indigenous women.\n\nA 2014 RCMP report suggested some 1,200 Indigenous woman and girls have gone missing or been killed in Canada, but underreporting and a lack of data means that number is likely inaccurate.\u00a0Other estimates have since pegged the true number at more than 4,000.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\n\u201cWe all know somebody who is either gone missing or has been murdered,\u201d Kelly Penner, vice-president of the Fraser Valley M\u00e9tis Association, told Global News.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nAn important part of Red Dress Day is generating meaningful discussion about what needs to change, and what actions can be taken to break the cycle of violence, she added.\n\n2:03\nSewing red ribbon skirts in honour of MMIWG\n\nThe national inquiry called the MMIWG2S crisis a \u201cgenocide,\u201d and released 231 calls for justice from governments, institutions, service providers and individuals that would address its root causes. The calls, described as \u201clegal imperatives,\u201d target\u00a0governments, institutions, social service providers, industries and all Canadians.\n\nIn the nearly four years that have passed since then, as critics \u2014 including the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada \u2014 have said little has been done to implement them and the outcomes haven\u2019t changed.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s not enough being done,\u201d said Fleury. \u201cThere should be more investigations, it should be more lengthy \u2026 I think it stems, honestly, from our system still being systemically racist.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n2:28\nFinal MMIWG report released and calls for systemic change\n\nIn June 2021, the federal government released its national action plan for addressing the inquiry\u2019s calls. Creating such a plan was one of the inquiry\u2019s imperatives.\n\nLast year, it released a progress report outlining more than 50 initiatives undertaken, including new laws on Indigenous languages and expanded funding for culturally-relevant violence prevention and health services.\n\nThis week, the House of Commons also unanimously backed a motion declaring the deaths and disappearances of\u00a0Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency, and called for funding for a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\n\n2:58\nWoman from B.C. tried to raise awareness during Papal talks of an often-ignored issue\n\nIn B.C., dozens of Indigenous women and girls have gone missing or been killed on or near the 725-kilometre stretch of Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert, known as the Highway of Tears, since the 1950s.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nOn Friday, the Union of BC Indian Chiefs (UBCIC) called on all levels of government to end all forms of discrimination, sexism and violence enacted by justice systems against Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people.\n\nThe push comes as disturbing new data from the Vancouver Police Department found that Indigenous girls are the most over-represented group of victims of violent crime, followed only by Indigenous women over the age of 35.\n\nMORE ON BC\n2 prominent B.C. MLAs announce they will not seek re-election this fall\nCurtains for protected views? Vancouver may end \u2018view cones\u2019 to make room for housing\nVideo: Man accidentally sets himself on fire at suspected arson in Richmond\nBC Ferries cancels two sailings between Tsawwassen, Swartz Bay\n\n\u201cFamily members are continually left to conduct and resource missing person searches alone, all while having to navigate a broken justice system, battling police apathy and jurisdictional mismanagement, robbing them of the space to heal from these immense traumas,\u201d said UBCIC vice-president Chief Don Tom in a news release.\n\n\u201cThe UBCIC calls for full capacity supports, high-tech investigative and First Nations-led search and rescue services, justice system navigator positions, and cooperation from justice authorities, police, and governments across all jurisdictions to bring our loved ones home \u2013 and further, healing supports, victim and family services, accountability and justice in cases when they do not.\u201d\n\nBattered Women\u2019s Support Services is available to assist those in need with emotional support, safety planning, and legal advocacy at 604-687-1867 or toll free at 1-855-687-1868. Those who cannot speak safely can text 604-652-1867.\n\nThe Hope for Wellness Help Line offers culturally competent counselling and crisis intervention to all Indigenous peoples experiencing trauma, distress, strong emotions and painful memories. The line can be reached anytime toll-free at 1-855-242-3310.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2023 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nWildfire burns out of control near Suncor oilsands site in Alberta\nCanada Post worker saves the day after child forgets stamp on postcard to grandma\nADVERTISEMENT\n630 CHED Afternoons with Bryn Griffiths & Reid Wilkins\n2:00 PM - 5:00 PM\n630CHED\nTrending\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. {"url": "https://www.newsoptimist.ca/community/local-culture/red-dress-pins-to-be-created-at-bead-ins-1.23587388", "title": "Red Dress Pins to be created at bead-ins - SaskToday.ca", "body": "Skip to content\nSign in or register for your free account  \nHomeWest Central & North\nEast Central\nSouthwest\nSoutheast\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nConnect\nHOME NORTH IN THE COMMUNITY\nRed Dress Pins to be created at bead-ins\nVolunteers are encouraged to meet up at the Allen Sapp Gallery to make Red Dress Pins and Heart Pins in time for the Walking With Our Sisters Round Dance on Jan. 31.\nSaskToday\nJan 13, 2019 12:53 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nVolunteers are encouraged to meet up at the Allen Sapp Gallery to make Red Dress Pins and Heart Pins in time for the Walking With Our Sisters Round Dance on Jan. 31.\n\nThe round dance is in remembrance of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Red Dress Pins will be given out at the event. Volunteers may also make pins for themselves.\n\nThe bead-ins will be hosted at the Allan Sapp Gallery on the evenings of Thursday, Jan. 17, Wednesday, Jan 23 and Thursday, Jan 24 from 6 to 8 p.m.\n\nThey are also looking for volunteers to make sandwiches and clean up during and after the event. Call Raven at 306-445-1760 to volunteer.\n\nThe use of red dresses to represent Missing and Murdered Indigenous Woman and Girls originated with M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black in 2010. At her exhibit, the REDRess Project. Black dispayed more than 100 red dresses around the University of Winnipeg campus to raise awareness about the issue.\n\nInspired by the art installation, Walking With Our Sisters Thunder Bay first created Red Dress Pins in 2016 for families meeting with the national MMIWG inquiry in their community.\n\nToday, red dresses continue to be used across Canada as a representation of the Indigenous women and girls lost to violent crime and as a call for action to prevent future violence.\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nGet your daily Saskatchewan news briefing\nEmail\nSign Up\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://theconversation.com/from-red-dresses-to-memory-stones-collaborative-and-replicable-activism-can-help-causes-gain-momentum-180645", "title": "From red dresses to memory stones: Collaborative and replicable activism can help causes gain momentum", "body": "Edition:\nAvailable editions\nCanada\nDonate\nGet newsletter\nBecome an author\nSign up as a reader\nSign in\nAcademic rigour, journalistic flair\nPodcasts\nArts\nBusiness + Economy\nCulture + Society\nEducation\nEnvironment + Energy\nHealth\nPolitics\nScience + Tech\nEn fran\u00e7ais\nThe REDress Project sees red dresses suspended where you would least expect them. The project was created by Jaime Black. (The REDress Project/Facebook)\nFrom red dresses to memory stones: Collaborative and replicable activism can help causes gain\u00a0momentum\nPublished: May 4, 2022 2.04pm EDT Updated: May 5, 2022 8.35am EDT\nAuthor\nNicolette Little, PhD\n\nCritical Media Studies Instructor and PhD Candidate, University of Calgary\n\nDisclosure statement\n\nNicolette Little receives funding from the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC)\n\nPartners\n\n\t\n\nUniversity of Calgary provides funding as a founding partner of The Conversation CA.\n\nUniversity of Calgary provides funding as a member of The Conversation CA-FR.\n\nView all partners\n\nWe believe in the free flow of information\nRepublish our articles for free, online or in print, under Creative Commons licence.\nRepublish this article\n Email\n X (Twitter)\n5\n Facebook\n247\n LinkedIn\n Print\n\nWe\u2019ve all heard of the #MeToo movement, founded by Tarana Burke. And in 2017, actress Alyssa Milano tweeted, \u201cif you\u2019ve been sexually harassed or assaulted write \u2018me too\u2019 as a reply to this tweet.\u201d Her tweet sparked a whirlwind of social media posts that highlighted a gender-based violence crisis.\n\nWhile hashtag activism and Hollywood are synonymous with gender-based violence advocacy, there are dynamic projects raising awareness across Canada. M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project and Leah Parsons\u2019 Memory Stones Project are examples of such creative and collaborative anti-violence efforts.\n\nThe REDress Project sees red dresses suspended where you would least expect them. Black is an artist-activist \u2014 or \u201cartivist\u201d \u2014 from Winnipeg, Man., who started the project in order to call attention to Canada\u2019s Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) crisis. The crisis has seen thousands of Indigenous women go missing or be killed since the 1970s.\n\nIn the Memory Stones Project, Parsons collects stones from the shores of the Atlantic Ocean, then paints them with bright colours and cheerful symbols to honour her daughter, Rehtaeh. Rehtaeh died by suicide after she was allegedly sexually assaulted by four boys and relentlessly victim-blamed. Each memory stone is hidden outdoors with a note that describes Rehtaeh\u2019s experience. It urges anyone who finds the stone to \u201cshow kindness not hate\u201d to survivors and \u201cleave the stone\u201d to share Rehtaeh\u2019s message with others.\n\nPeople across the globe have gotten involved in the Memory Stones Project. (Angel Rehtaeh Parsons), Author provided\n\nAs the Government of Canada points out, certain people including \u201cwomen; young women and girls; Indigenous women and girls; LGBTQIA2S+; transgender and gender diverse people; women living in Northern, rural and remote communities; and, women living with disabilities\u201d are more likely to experience gender-based violence.\n\nIn Canada, one in four women report gender-based violence to authorities, while many cases go unreported due to fear of stigma and victim-blaming. Indigenous women in particular face gender-based violence 16 times more than white women in Canada do. They also experience more severe assaults.\n\nAfter interviewing Black and Parsons for my research, studying their projects and speaking with people who engaged with them, what stands out is how both projects attract eager co-operation from everyday people \u2014 which is important for raising awareness.\n\nWhen activists use materials that anyone can acquire, and invite citizens to co-create alongside them, it inspires people to jump on board.\n\nCollaborative activism\n\nDuring my conversations with Black and Parsons, they both mentioned being fed up with the normalization of gender-based violence, so they struck out on their own to address it. While these acts appear to be singular undertakings, they\u2019ve both inspired impressive participation.\n\nThe REDress Project gained international attention, but its collaborative origins are little known. In 2010, Black called on Canadians to donate dresses and received over 600 garments. She told me that people have donated every dress she\u2019s used since.\n\nREDress-inspired projects regularly pop up. An Edmontonian started a \u201cREDress Photography Project\u201d in 2015, while Inuit installed a Red Amautiit Project in Nunavut in 2019. These creators, who were inspired by Black\u2019s work, ensured first that she would be comfortable with them building on her idea. In fact, Black tells me she believes in \u201cdecolonizing the idea of art being exclusive.\u201d She believes that this helps it \u201cgrow and evolve beyond its maker.\u201d\n\nThe National Museum of the American Indian showcases The REDress Project.\n\nParsons\u2019 Memory Stones Project also inspires engagement. After seeing memory stones on the Angel Rehtaeh Parsons Facebook page, people request stones so they can place them too.\n\nParsons tells me she\u2019s painted thousands of memory stones to date, mailing them to people in \u201cmany places \u2026 Africa, China, Alaska, British Columbia, California, Germany, New Zealand, Dakar, Cambodia and more\u201d. She instructs recipients to place the stone somewhere that speaks to them and send Parsons a photograph.\n\nMy interviews with people who have come across Parsons\u2019 stones revealed that finding the stone helped them reflect on the importance of consent. By placing stones and sharing Rehtaeh\u2019s story, people are helping draw attention to gender-based violence.\n\nReplicability\n\nThese activisms\u2019 uptake, in part, relies on the fact that they are easy to replicate. Black uses an everyday item, dresses, to raise awareness. Parsons uses stones, paint and varnish, which are easily acquired.\n\nThese projects demonstrate that with inspiration, people can use accessible objects and skills they already have to participate in anti-violence activism.\n\nBlack\u2019s and Parsons\u2019 initiatives were meant to inspire involvement. Black invites Canadians to hang their own red dresses to raise awareness and Parsons not only provides stones to people who request them, but encourages them to get involved through social media. On her Facebook page, she gives a blessing and instructions to those who want to paint stones at home and asks people to post photos online.\n\nBecause gender-based violence kills a woman every second day in Canada, it can feel overwhelming to try to address it. This is one of the reasons projects that are easy to participate in and reproduce, and that make people feel like they are part of a community that cares, are important.\n\nThis is an updated version of a story originally published on May 4, 2021. The earlier story failed to mention Tarana Burke\u2019s name after the #MeToo Movement.\n\nIndigenous\nGender-based violence\nviolence and children\nMMIWG\nListen to this article\nWant to write?\n\nWrite an article and join a growing community of more than 186,300 academics and researchers from 4,990 institutions.\n\nRegister now\n\nEditorial Policies\nCommunity standards\nRepublishing guidelines\nAnalytics\nOur feeds\nGet newsletter\nWho we are\nOur charter\nOur team\nOur blog\nPartners and funders\nResource for media\nContact us\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\nPrivacy policy\nTerms and conditions\nCorrections\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2010\u20132024, Academic Journalism Society"},

(Angel Rehtaeh Parsons), Author provided\n\nAs the Government of Canada points out, certain people including\u201cwomen; young women and girls; Indigenous women and girls; LGBTQIA2S+; transgender and gender diverse people; women living in Northern, rural and remote communities; and, women living with disabilities\u201d are more likely to experience gender-based violence.\n\nIn Canada, one in four women report gender-based violence to authorities, while many cases go unreported due to fear of stigma and victim-blaming . While these acts appear to be singular undertakings, they've both inspired impressive participation.\n\nThe REDress Project gained international attention , but its collaborative origins are little known. In 2010, Black called on Canadians to donate dresses and received over 600 garments. She told me that people have donated every dress she's used since.\n\nREDress-inspired projects regularly pop up. By placing stones and sharing Rehtaeh's story, people are helping draw attention to gender-based violence.\n\nReplicability\n\nThese activisms' uptake, in part, relies on the fact that they are easy to replicate. Black uses an everyday item, dresses, to raise awareness. Parsons uses stones, paint and varnish, which are easily acquired.\n\nThese projects demonstrate that with inspiration, people can use accessible objects and skills they already have to participate in anti-violence activism.\n\nBlack's and Parsons' initiatives were meant to inspire involvement. {"url": "http://www.netnewsledger.com/2018/10/04/premier-rachel-notley-statement-on-the-sisters-in-spirit-vigils/", "title": "Premier Rachel Notley Statement on the Sisters in Spirit Vigils - NetNewsLedger", "body": "  \nNews\nLocal News\nRegional News\nNational News\nInternational News\nBusiness\nLocal Business\nRegional Business\nNational Business\nInternational Business\nMining\nInternational Mining\nNational Mining\nRegional Mining\nMining Press Releases\nIndigenous\nLocal Indigenous\nRegional Indigenous\nNational Indigenous\nInternational Indigenous\nSports\nLocal Sports\nRegional Sports\nNational Sports\nInternational Sports\nHealth\nLocal Covid-19\nRegional Covid-19\nNational Covid-19\nInternational Covid-19\nWeather\nLocal Weather\nRegional Weather\nNational Weather\nInternational Weather\nClimate News\nLiving\nGas Prices Across the Region\nTechnology\nTravel\nEntertainment\n 24 C \nThunder Bay\nNetNewsLedger\nAdvertisement\nNEWS\nBUSINESS\nMINING\nINDIGENOUS\nSPORTS\nHEALTH\nWEATHER\nLIVING\n  \nHome  Anishinaabe  Alberta  Premier Rachel Notley Statement on the Sisters in Spirit Vigils\nAnishinaabeAlbertaTop Stories\nPremier Rachel Notley Statement on the Sisters in Spirit Vigils\nBy Amanda Perreault -\nOctober 4, 2018\n927\nThe Sisters in Spirit vigils bear witness to this national tragedy\nMissing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\n\n\u201cToday, across Canada, survivors of violence, mothers and fathers, sisters and brothers, daughters and sons, grandmothers and grandfathers, friends and community supporters will extend hearts and hands across the chasm of loss in an emotional act of remembrance and resolve.\n\nAlberta Premier Rachel Notley acknowledging Sisters In Spirit-MMIWG\n\n\u201cThey will come together at candlelight vigils, rallies and community gatherings to honour the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. The Sisters in Spirit vigils bear witness to this national tragedy and offer solace to families and communities that have suffered the devastating loss of so many loved ones.\n\n\u201cOur government takes this issue to heart. We\u2019ve invested in women\u2019s shelters so that no one will be turned away, and in sexual assault centres and violence-prevention programs so that survivors have greater access to counselling, police and court supports.\n\n\u201cWe also passed the Residential Tenancies Amendment Act so that survivors of domestic violence can legally break a residential lease. And we\u2019ve given survivors of sexual violence better access to the legal system by removing the time limit to bring forward civil claims.\n\n\u201cIn the spirit of reconciliation, our government apologized in 2015 for the legacy of residential schools. In May of this year, we apologized to survivors of the Sixties Scoop.\n\n\u201cOur greatest hope is that these vigils, along with better supports for women, the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Alberta\u2019s Taking Action Against Racism plan and resolute efforts at every level of society, will help achieve meaningful action to ensure the safety and security of Indigenous women and girls here in Alberta and across Canada.\n\n\u201cI ask Albertans to join me in taking time to remember these women and girls \u2013 cherished sisters, mothers, daughters, granddaughters \u2013 and all who seek and mourn for them. In their ever-present memory, let us make the world a safer place.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\n\nTAGS\nAlberta\nfamilies of sisters in spirit\nMMIWG\nPremier Rachel Notley\nRacism\nSisters in Spirit\nTurtle Island\nWalking with Our Sisters\nPrevious article\nFirst Degree Homicide Charges Laid in Justin Duncan Death\nNext article\nORC Archibald \u2013 \u201cWe keep the MMIWG2ST in our hearts\u201d\nAmanda Perreault\nhttp://www.netnewsledger.com\nNetNewsledger.com or NNL offers news, information, opinions and positive ideas for Thunder Bay, Ontario, Northwestern Ontario and the world. update: July 2, 2024\n\nCONTINUOUS PLAY: ON OFF\nMORE VIDEO\nCOMPANY NEWS\n\nAug 19, 2016\n\nVia Rail plans to offer $5 fares for 'vulnerable' people along Highway of Tears\n\nCamille Bains , The Canadian Press\n\nA VIA Rail sign at the train station in Halifax. , (THE CANADIAN PRESS/Andrew Vaughan)\n\nVANCOUVER -- Via Rail has joined discussions with the British Columbia government, First Nations and social service agencies to offer rock-bottom fares to \"vulnerable\" people who can't afford to travel along the so-called Highway of Tears.\n\nThe railway is collaborating with mayors and multiple groups to determine the criteria for $5 fares along a northern B.C. corridor where 18 girls and women have been murdered or have disappeared since the 1970s.\n\nIn June, following a decade of pleas from women's groups and First Nations, B.C. Transportation Minister Todd Stone announced that bus service would begin in the area by the end of the year.\n\nChief Joseph Bevan of the Kitselas First Nation near Terrace said he's part of an advisory group concerned about the safety of people along the 750-kilometre route and that it came together for regular meetings last November after months of discussions.\n\nHe said it's common for people to take a risk and hitchhike in the notorious area because they're too poor to take the train or a Greyhound bus.\n\n\"It's non-aboriginals as well. It's everyone who is on social assistance, people with disabilities, who are having trouble moving around. It makes them vulnerable when they're jumping into a vehicle with somebody else.\"\n\nBevan said that at a meeting in March, a Via Rail official made the proposal to offer a $5 fare along the highway that stretches between Prince Rupert and Prince George.\n\nMichael Woelcke, the railway's general manager for remote services, said in minutes of the meeting held in Prince George on March 30 that the company would offer the low fare \"regardless of origin or destination along the route.\"\n\nHe said Via Rail provides train service three times a week between Prince Rupert and Prince George, and it's open to suggestions on determining eligibility for the $5 fare that would be available to \"at risk\" and \"vulnerable\" people including youth and \"elders.\"\n\n\"We need to identify who would qualify for this program, as we cannot provide everyone with these reduced fares,\" he said in the minutes.\n\nWoelcke said a minimum $75 one-way fare would be reduced by a third for aboriginal passengers.\n\nWoelcke was not available for comment, and the company said an official would provide details if and when an arrangement is worked out with the province.\n\nVia Rail said in an emailed statement that a discounted fare for \"vulnerable\" people is one of the options being studied and that discussions with the Transportation Ministry and the advisory group are ongoing.\n\nThe ministry said interconnectivity of services along Highway 16 has been part of discussions and that Via Rail was included to determine what role it could play to increase transportation options.\n\n\"We continue to engage with Via Rail on the idea of offering a discounted train fare to vulnerable First Nations people,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe group is slated to meet again next month.\n\nAs for the promised new bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert, the ministry said the first of more than 20 public information sessions hosted by BC Transit will start Saturday.\n\nBC Transit said Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada, which is part of the advisory group, has provided $1 million in funding for features including enhanced bus stop shelters and CCTV cameras to ensure passengers' safety along the corridor.\n\nThe route provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nMost of the cases of murdered and missing women remain unsolved, but police have said it's believed that more than one killer is involved.\n\n \nTop Picks\n6:00\n \n\nKeith Richards' Top Picks: July 4, 2024\n\n5:27\n \n\nCole Kachur's Top Picks: Signup\nPrince Albert Daily Herald\nPrince Albert's only locally-owned daily newspaper\nLOCAL NEWS\nNEWS\nCIVIC AFFAIRS\nSPORTS\nARTS\nCOLUMNISTS\nOPINION\nOBITUARIES\nFLYERS\nRURAL ROOTS\nNORTHERN ADVOCATE\nWOMEN\u2019S MONTH\nBOOK YOUR AD\nDIGITAL SUBSCRIPTION\nNEW LANGUAGE\nHome  News  Feds start consultations on Red Dress Alert\nNews\nFeds start consultations on Red Dress Alert\nBy Daily Herald Contributor -\nDecember 19, 2023\n\nby Isaac Nay\nLocal Journalism Initiative Reporter\nCanada\u2019s National Observer\n\nThe federal government is taking the first step to build an alert system for missing Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nFor the better part of a year, MP Leah Gazan, federal NDP critic for women and gender equity, has called for an alert \u2014 similar to an Amber Alert \u2014 to help find Indigenous people when they go missing. She\u2019s suggested calling the system the \u201cRed Dress Alert.\u201d Now, the federal government is starting to consult civil groups about making the alert a reality.\n\n\u201cEvery day that we don\u2019t have a red dress alert, Indigenous women, girls, diverse-gendered folks and two-spirit people go missing,\u201d Gazan said. \u201cThere are not currently systems in place to properly protect or search for loved ones who do go missing. So it\u2019s urgent, and it needs to be put in place.\u201d\n\nThe rate of homicide against Indigenous women and girls is about six times higher than non-Indigenous women and girls, according to Statistics Canada. In March, the federal budget included funding for an alert system to help find missing Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people. Not long after, Ottawa recognized the crisis as a national emergency.\n\nThis month, the federal government started discussions with front-line workers, community organizations and families of Indigenous people who have gone missing.\n\nKarine Duhamel, former director of research for the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, said she\u2019s happy to see the alert moving forward.\n\n\u201c[The alert] strongly asserts that these lives matter and that Indigenous women and girls, two-spirit and transgender people have a right to safety,\u201d Duhamel said.\n\nThe federal system should also consider how an alert system serves people fleeing unsafe circumstances, aging out of care, or moving to a different community, she added.\n\n\u201cIt might not be kind of a one-size-fits-all approach,\u201d Duhamel said. \u201cThe engagements and consultations that are part of this project need to reflect the very broad diversity of folks who may be kind of included in such an alert system.\u201d\n\nIn Canada, Amber Alerts for missing children are delivered through the Alert Ready system, which sends messages to television, radio and cell-service devices. At present, Amber Alerts are issued by police services in Canada.\n\nBut there are other ways to deliver the alert, said Jennifer Jesty. As emergency resilience manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi\u2019kmaq and a member of the Eskasoni First Nation, Jesty worked with software company Everbridge to create the Unama\u2019ki Emergency Alert System.\n\nThe system now serves five Mi\u2019kmaq nations and has sent out alerts about dangerous individuals, extreme weather and missing persons. Since its inception in September 2020, the Unama\u2019ki Emergency Alert System has issued more than 150 alerts. According to Jesty, in 96 per cent of missing person alerts, the person was reunited with family in less than an hour. The service could help find missing Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people across Canada, she said.\n\n\u201cWhy reinvent the wheel? What we have going on over here at Unama\u2019ki has been wildly successful,\u201d Jesty said.\n\nJesty, a chief or community leader can send emergency alerts over text, email or landline so they reach people out of cell service range. Senders can also include voice recordings in their language.\n\n\u201cIf [alerts] go out about a critical event, it\u2019s important to make sure there\u2019s no language barrier,\u201d Jesty said.\n\nBack in Parliament, Gazan said consultations are the first step to make sure the alert is effective. She hopes to see the system active by the end of the next budget cycle.\n\n\u201cThere has to be a very clear end date to this,\u201d Gazan said. \u201cWe can\u2019t consult forever. Women, girls, two-spirit and gender-diverse people are going missing and being murdered, and that\u2019s unacceptable.\u201d\n\n-Advertisement-\nTAGS\nCanadasNationalObserver\nFederalGovernment\nIsaacNay\nLJIR\nNationalInquiryOnMissingAndMurderedIndigenousWomenAndGirs\nRedDressAlert\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedin\nCopy URL\nPrevious article\nCanada\u2019s international students relieved after federal government allows longer work hours\nNext article\nCatholic Division reports focus on early learning development\nDaily Herald Contributor\nDaily Herald contributors, including columnists, share this byline.\nFOLLOW US\n\nAccess our archives, 1910 to today's date, with your digital subscription. {"url": "https://www.campbellrivermirror.com/community/bestselling-indigenous-author-discusses-powerful-book-unbroken-online-7346660", "title": "Bestselling Indigenous author discusses powerful book, Unbroken, online - Campbell River Mirror", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.8 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Community\nBestselling Indigenous author discusses powerful book, Unbroken, online\nBlack Press Media\nApr 18, 2024 3:30 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nAngela Sterritt\u2019s book, Unbroken, will be the subject of a virtual presentation by the Vancouver Island Regional Library (VIRL) on Tuesday, April 30 from 7:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. Photo contributed\nListen to this article\n00:02:13\n\nPart memoir and part investigation into the murders and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls, Angela Sterritt\u2019s book, Unbroken, will be the subject of a virtual presentation by the Vancouver Island Regional Library (VIRL) on Tuesday, April 30 from 7:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.\n\nSterritt\u2019s book became an instant national bestseller and is nominated for the Hilary Weston Writers\u2019 Trust award for best non-fiction book in Canada.\n\n\u201cHaving Angela with us days ahead of Red Dress Day on May 5 is a powerful tribute to the many Indigenous women and girls who have been victims of a system that has failed them,\u201d says VIRL Librarian, Dalia Levy. \u201cI believe it is important for everyone to hear Angela\u2019s personal stories and the stories she has reported on.\u201d\n\nSterritt is an award-winning investigative journalist and national bestselling author from the Wilp Wiik\u2019aax (we-GAK) of the Gitanmaax (GIT-in-max) community within the Gitxsan (GICK-san) Nation on her dad\u2019s side and from Bell Island Newfoundland on her maternal side. Sterritt worked as a television, radio, and digital journalist at CBC for more than a decade. She hosted the award-winning CBC original podcast Land Back. She lives on the territories of the S\u1e35wx\u0331w\u00fa7mesh, Musqueam and Tsleil-Waututh, Vancouver, Canada.\n\nParticipants should note that the talk will address issues of trauma, systemic racism, and other themes that could be traumatizing or triggering for some viewers. KUU-US First Nations and Indigenous Crisis Line is available 24/7 Toll Free @ 1-800-588-8717 across BC.\n\nThis event is free, and all are welcome to attend. RSVP at https://virl.bc.ca/event/angela-sterritt/ to receive the zoom link prior to the vent.\n\nCan\u2019t make it to the live event on April 30? A recording will be made available in early May 2024. Visit virl.bc.ca/angela-sterritt or VIRL\u2019s Facebook page for more information.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tEverybody loves a parade! {"url": "https://www.kimberleybulletin.com/news/billboard-posted-along-b-c-s-highway-of-tears-to-remember-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Billboard posted along B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears to remember missing and murdered Indigenous women - Kimberley Bulletin", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.3 \u00b0C\nHome News\nBillboard posted along B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears to remember missing and murdered Indigenous women\nBillboards featuring Indigenous artwork to be placed in Surrey, Kamloops and near Prince George\nAshley Wadhwani-Smith\nJun 19, 2019 11:20 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nMaxine Noel\u2019s \u2018Not Forgotten\u2019 pictured on a billboard in Toronto in June 2019, as part of a Canada-wide campaign by group Artists Against Racism. (Artists Against Racism photo)\n\nThree billboards are being raised in B.C., including along the Highway of Tears, to bring attention to the thousands of missing and murder Indigenous women and girls.\n\nCreated by Artists Against Racism, the project follows the final report from the inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls released earlier this month, which detailed a deliberate and persistent pattern of abuses against Indigenous women, girls, two-spirited people and LGBTG2+ individuals that can only be described as a genocide.\n\nEach billboard features work by Indigenous artists, including pieces by Loretta Gould and Colleen Gray. A total of 12 signs will appear across Canada for a week, coinciding with National Indigenous Peoples Day on Friday.\n\nREAD MORE: Sharing truth with art at inquiry into missing, murdered Indigenous women\n\nTwo billboards have been erected in the province already: The first along Highway 5 in Kamloops, and the second on Scott Road, south of Larson Road, in Surrey.\n\nThe third, in Prince George, will be installed on Monday along Highway 16, also known as the Highways of Tears for its link to the disappearances and murders of dozens of Aboriginal women along its 720 kilometres between Prince George and Prince Rupert.\n\nThat billboard features Maxine Noel\u2019s Not Forgotten, which she created to remember and honour the spirits and presence of Aboriginal women and girls.\n\nREAD MORE: All Canadians have a role to play in ending MMIW \u2018genocide,\u2019 report says\n\nAccording to her website, Noel\u2019s piece of art is her way fighting to end violence against Aboriginal women and girls throughout Canada.\n\n\u201cIn this painting, Not Forgotten, I speak to that wonder and beauty and tragedy,\u201d Noel, who is a member of the Sioux Nation, says on her website. \u201cTo capture both the wonder and the tragedy, I wanted to include motifs which connect with all the places and our peoples live.\u201d\n\nOther billboards can be seen in Halifax, Montreal, Toronto, Thunder Bay and Winnipeg.\n\nWith a file from The Canadian Press\n\n@ashwadhwani\nashley.wadhwani@bpdigital.ca\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\nAbout the Author: Ashley Wadhwani-Smith\n\nI began my journalistic journey at Black Press Media as a community reporter in my hometown of Maple Ridge, B.C.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share {"url": "https://www.stratfordbeaconherald.com/news/local-news/sisters-in-spirit-vigil-to-be-held-in-stratfords-market-square-thursday", "title": "Sisters in Spirit vigil to be held in Stratford's Market Square | The Stratford Beacon Herald", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nLocal News\nSisters in Spirit vigil to be held in Stratford's Market Square Thursday\n\nThe Stratford chapter of Amnesty International, and members of local Indigenous communities will hold a day-long Sisters in Spirit event Thursday, honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nAuthor of the article:\nGalen Simmons\nPublished Oct 02, 2018 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nVolunteers Seana-Lee Wood, Mary Beth Jantzi, and Anne Carbert spent Tuesday afternoon sorting and tagging the red dresses that will be on display at downtown businesses and organizations on Thursday during the day-long Sisters in Spirit event at Market Square. (Galen Simmons/The Beacon Herald)\nArticle content\n\nIn line with the national movement, local women\u2019s groups, the Stratford chapter of Amnesty International, and members of local Indigenous communities will hold a day-long Sisters in Spirit event Thursday, honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBeginning with a sunrise smudging ceremony and the lighting of a sacred fire at 7:15 a.m. in Market Square, the event will see more than 20 local businesses and organizations displaying red dresses throughout the day to raise awareness of the cause.\n\nInspired by the REDress Project by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black, the dresses symbolize the absence of over 1,000 Indigenous women across Canada. Information on the red dresses downtown will invite the public to attend a vigil that will begin in Market Square at 7 p.m.\n\nDuring the vigil, Patsy Day and Winona Sands, both Indigenous women, will speak to the cause.\n\nDay, of the Turtle Clan, Oneida Nation, is a teacher who was orphaned at the age of six as a result of the assimilation policies in the federal government\u2019s Indian Act. Having reconnected with her family as an adult, Day regained her native status and now teaches people of all ages about Indigenous people in Canada.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSands, a member of the Bkejwanong Band on the Walpole Island First Nations Reserve on Lake Erie, is the community chef at the Local Community Food Centre in Stratford. Sands, who has been cooking for most of her life, has also worked as an addictions counsellor, social worker, and support worker for Indigenous women and children, and as a women\u2019s advocate at the Atlohsa Native Family Healing Centre in London.\n\n\u201cAs the Native Women\u2019s Association emphasizes, this is a national tragedy \u2014 the disproportionate violence that Indigenous women and girls face and the disproportionate risk of murder,\u201d said Anne Carbert, a volunteer with the Stratford chapter of Amnesty International, one of a few groups working to orchestrate Thursday\u2019s event.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThis is something that the national inquiry is looking into currently, and our governments are needing to figure out how to respond. I think bringing awareness to that, paying attention to that process, showing support for families that are suffering\u2026 is very important.\u201d\n\nAccording to Statistics Canada, Indigenous women and girls in Canada are at least three times more likely to experience violence, and at least six times more likely to be murdered than any other woman or girl in Canada.\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) has\nworked for more than four decades to document the systemic violence impacting Indigenous women, girls, their families, and communities.\n\nThe association is a lead organizer of the Sisters In Spirit Vigils, a national movement that encourages concerned citizens and\nIndigenous community members to gather on October 4th.\n\nFor more information on the Sisters in Spirit Vigils, visit\u00a0www.nwac.ca/home/policy-areas/violence-prevention-and-safety/sisters-in-spirit/october-4th-vigils/.\n\nTo learn more about the Stratford vigil, visit the event\u2019s Facebook page at\u00a0www.facebook.com/events/519166718495072/.\n\ngsimmons@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR STRATFORD\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://www.simcoereformer.ca:443/news/local-news/red-dresses-displayed-in-tillsonburg-honour-mmiwg2s", "title": "Red dresses displayed in Tillsonburg honour MMIWG2S+ | Simcoe Reformer", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nBusiness Ads\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nRed dresses displayed in Tillsonburg honour MMIWG2S+\nAuthor of the article:\nChris Abbott\nPublished May 16, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 16, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nPatricia Marshal and her daughter Hera wore red on May 6 during the first Honouring MMIWG2S+ event in Tillsonburg organized by the Ingersoll and Area Indigenous Solidarity & Awareness Network. The empty red dresses and scarves served as a symbol of lost lives, raising awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. SUBMITTED jpg, TN\nArticle content\n\nCanada\u2019s House of Commons unanimously backed a motion on earlier this month declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a national emergency.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe May 2 motion also called for funding a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\n\nOn Friday, May 5, red dresses were displayed across the country to recognize National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. Known as Red Dress Day, the empty garments served as a symbol of lost lives.\n\nIn Tillsonburg, the Ingersoll and Area Indigenous Solidarity & Awareness Network hosted its first two-hour Honouring MMIWG2S+ event on May 6, displaying red dresses and scarves at Participark. They chose Saturday evening to avoid scheduling conflicts with healing ceremonies or pre-established marches.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to make sure Oxford (County) was doing something to recognize it because we do have an Indigenous presence here, it\u2019s just not as noticeable because we don\u2019t feel as accepted,\u201d said Patricia Marshal, director of Ingersoll & Area\u2019s Indigenous Solidarity and Awareness Network (IISAN). \u201cWe\u2019re trying to change that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMarshal said IISAN, organizers of Oxford\u2019s annual March for Truth and Reconciliation in Ingersoll, is taking steps toward that goal. There are specific issues they feel Canadians, and specifically people in Oxford County, have the power to do something about. They are the Every Child Matters Movement, reconciliation for residential schools and \u201cjust being there for survivors and making sure that we\u2019re moving forward taking into account the genocide that has been experienced,\u201d Marshal said.\n\nThe second is Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People, \u201csomething that has been going on since the establishment of what we now know as North America. And it\u2019s still going on to this day.\u201d\n\nThe third issue is lack of basic resources in Indigenous communities, and encouraging people to write their MPs and MPPs. \u201cWe all have that power at any time about any of these issues,\u201d Marshal said.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cSome of the women that were at Participark shared about how when they were little, there were friends that just went missing \u2013 and nobody knew where they went,\u201d said Tillsonburg Councillor Kelly Spencer, who attended the event with her mother. \u201cThe number is quite staggering \u2013 and that\u2019s only the number that is reported\u2026. This is the harsh reality for Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u201cIt was kind of a wakeup call,\u201d said Spencer. \u201cIt\u2019s bizarre to me that we don\u2019t talk about this.\u201d\n\nIISAN\u2019s Honouring MMIWG2S+ event, co-organized by Marhsal and Lisa Scott, had been planned since last November. They started asking for red dress donations in January, and purchased more dresses at Salvation Army to reach their goal of 50.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to have at least one dress (or scarf) that could represent at least 10 years of the 500 years that we\u2019ve been dealing with this, to kind of give a visual impact. It\u2019s a spiritual thing to use red dresses because it\u2019s a colour the spirits can see, to show them that we still love them, where home is and where their loved ones are.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe event was respectful and introspective, said Marshal, and full of facts to help people understand why MMIWG2S+ is a national issue.\n\n\u201cPeople don\u2019t understand why this is a problem, even when we put out stats like 10,000 Indigenous people go missing every year and 8,000 of those are children. It\u2019s truly heartbreaking.\u201d\n\nMarshal said the goal is to improve awareness for IISAN\u2019s annual event and improve the attendance. About 10 people participated in their first Honouring MMIWG2S+ and they want more next year. Dozens more. Hundreds more.\n\n\u201cThe inspiration to do it on the Trans Canada Trail was that it connects all of Canada and this issue connects coast to coast.\u201d\n\nIISAN is aiming to host events in each of the three main urban centres in Oxford County, which means Woodstock is on the radar to launch a future event. Follow the IISAN Facebook page to learn more.\n\n\u201cIISAN has been trying very hard to make sure we are doing what we can in our community to help make sure people understand what has happened, what is happening, and what they can do to help solve it.\u201d\n\nThe next March for Truth and Reconciliation in Ingersoll is Sept. 30, 2023. IISAN will also be at the June 17 Oxford Family Pride Day event in Woodstock.\n\n\u2013 With files from Kelly Geraldine Malone, Canadian Press\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR SIMCOE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://winnipegsun.com/travel/usa/historic-st-augustine-and-cozy-amelia-island-offer-contrasting-florida-options", "title": "St. Augustine and Amelia Island offer contrasting Florida options | Winnipeg Sun", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nePaper\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nJets add to depth with two-way signings\nTRENDING\nBombers' Collaros to miss first start of season vs Redblacks\nTRENDING\nTrump trashes \u2018broken down pile of crap\u2019 Biden in viral video\nTRENDING\nEmergency responders rescue individual from Assiniboine River\nTRENDING\nManitoba First Nation reports 150 anomalies at residential school site\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nTravel USATravel\nHistoric St. Augustine and cozy Amelia Island offer contrasting Florida options\nAuthor of the article:\nDave Pollard\nPublished May 06, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 8 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nThe legendary, and haunted, St. Augustine lighthouse dominates the shoreline. PHOTO BY DAVE POLLARD /Toronto Sun\nArticle content\n\nFew Florida destinations hold as much historic appeal as St. Augustine, the dazzling little jewel of the Sunshine State tucked away in its northeast corner.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBy contrast, sleepy Amelia Island, a laid-back old-Florida-style seaside town, offers a chance to decompress while doing as much \u2014 or as little \u2014 as you want.\n\nAnd while you\u2019ll have a chance to look into the checkered past of St. Augustine \u2014 founded in 1565 by the Spanish, it is billed as the oldest continuously inhabited settlement in the continental United States and has flown six different flags during its five centuries of existence \u2014 you\u2019ll also have the opportunity, maybe, to feel young again by sipping from the world-famous Fountain of Youth.\n\nMost sun seekers head south for the beaches\u2019 warm rays and basic seaside downtime. And, sure, the St. Augustine and Ponte Vedra Beach area can offer you typical Florida fun with its nearly 70 kilometres of sugar sand shores, but, wow, does it have so much more to offer.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHistory and hauntings (if you believe in such things, just about everywhere in the city is home to the ghosts of the long dead) are first on the menu in this glorious little city, which quickly rose to the top of my list of places in Florida I must spend more time in. A quick, three-day visit isn\u2019t nearly enough time to explore the old-world charm of St. Augustine, first made famous by Spanish conquistador Juan Ponce de Leon and his discovery of the mythical Fountain of Youth nearly 500 years ago and later put on the map by industrialist Henry Flagler.\n\nThe world-famous Fountain of Youth, discovered by Spaniard Ponce de Leon. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun) PHOTO BY DAVE POLLARD /Toronto Sun\n\nOnce you\u2019ve hit the ground in St. Augustine, the best way to get a lay of the land is to take a tour aboard the Old Town Trolley, which stops at many of the area\u2019s most famous attractions, including the 17th-century Castillo de San Marcos, the Fountain of Youth Park, the Old Jail and the colonial quarter. It\u2019s a 90-minute narrated round trip but your ticket is good for the day and allows you to hop on and off at whatever stops you like.\n\nTravel Time\n\nPlan your next getaway with Travel Time, featuring travel deals, destinations and gear.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBeing a history buff, my first stop on the trolley tour was at the Castillo, a massive fortification that once protected the city\u2019s coastline from invaders and the oldest masonry structure of its kind in the U.S. It\u2019s fascinating wandering around the star-shaped fort, poking my nose into every nook and cranny, while imagining what has gone on inside its historic coquina walls over the centuries.\n\nFlagler College in St. Augustine, once the site of Henry Flagler\u2019s Ponce de Leon Hotel. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nNext up was a stop at Ponce de Leon\u2019s Fountain of Youth Archaeological Park, a 15-acre site that commemorates the Spaniard\u2019s exploration of the area in 1513 and subsequent discovery of a natural fresh-water spring. Located alongside the Matanzas River and St. Augustine Inlet, the park is home not only to the famous spring, which you can drink from, but also a recreation of a Timucuan village that was home to the area\u2019s Indigenous people, and historical actors who depict life from when the city was settled.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nTry to time it right to see the cannon firing but it\u2019s also cool to see a talk about the period arquebus gun and its firing along with crossbow demonstrations. Or just wander through the stately oaks and cedars, breathing in history, while walking alongside the many peacocks on site.\n\nI stopped to see the Old Jail in daylight but the real fun here happened after dark on the guided Ghosts and Gravestones Tour aboard the \u2018Trolley of the Doomed,\u2019 which has been dubbed St. Augustine\u2019s premier \u2018Frightseeing Tour.\u2019\n\nAn actor portrays a condemned prisoner under the gallows at St. Augustine\u2019s Old Jail. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nThe host and other actors involved in the tour were dressed in period costumes, which enhanced the experience and made it a ton of fun. At the Old Jail, an actor dressed as a condemned man took our group through the cell block after making a, ahem, dramatic entrance and finished up at the outdoor gallows.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nEarlier in the day, I boarded the Victory III, part of the St. Augustine Scenic Cruise fleet, for a cruise around the Matanzas River and out towards the city\u2019s legendary lighthouse. Seeing the Castillo from the water made it more imposing and getting a photo of the lighthouse (did I mention it\u2019s haunted?) from the boat made it a worthwhile trip.\n\nCannons point to sea at the Castillo San Marcos in St. Augustine, Fla. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nOther things you might want to see in St. Augustine are the Ximenez Fatio House that depicts life in the 18th century, and picturesque Aviles Street plus St. Augustine Distillery, an option for adult readers who enjoy artisanal spirits.\n\nOne last stop was at Flagler College for a tour of the school that was once Henry Flagler\u2019s luxurious Ponce de Leon Hotel. The college offers guided tours that explore the history of the campus dating back to the golden days of the Ponce hotel.\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIf you\u2019re looking for some varied dining options, try Columbia Restaurant in the city\u2019s historic district, a local favourite that serves Cuban-Spanish influenced dishes, the Cordova Coastal Chophouse in the Casa Monica Hotel, and Meehan\u2019s Irish Pub and Seafood House, another busy place that is a bit more casual.\n\nHistoric, and reportedly haunted, St. Francis Inn in St. Augustine, Fla. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nAMELIA ISLAND\n\nHeading out of St. Augustine, I drove the A1A Scenic and Historic Coastal Byway and stress seeped away the closer I got to Amelia Island for a relaxing two-night stay. Just a 90-minute drive, the coastal route gave me a chance to check out the seaside dunes and smaller towns like Ponte Vedra Beach (headquarters of the PGA Tour) and Sawgrass, home of the famous TPC Sawgrass golf course that hosts The Players Championship annually.\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAfter the bustling tourist town of St. Augustine, my stay on Amelia Island was like a breath of relaxing air. If you\u2019re looking for a laid-back vacation in sunny Florida, where you can clear your head and avoid the massive crowds, Amelia Island is a perfect choice.\n\nCenter Street is the main drag in Fernandina Beach, Fla. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nFernandina Beach is the island\u2019s main town and, in many ways, showcases the old Florida lifestyle as a Victorian seaport village. It\u2019s a snapshot of small-town Florida, with a tree-lined main drag filled with boutique shops and other places \u2014 like, for instance, the Palace Saloon, reputedly Florida\u2019s oldest bar \u2014 to poke around while decompressing.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t always that way though. Fernandina Beach was once home to pirates, bootleggers and other, uh, colourful characters as well as Gilded Age millionaires and shrimpers looking to get rich. Now, though, the town is much quieter.\n\nAdvertisement 9\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nA walk through Amelia Island State Park will enhance the chill vibe of the area. Stroll along the beach and look for shark\u2019s teeth and shells, try to spot the wildlife and explore the salt marshes and coastal forests for a \u2018Real Florida\u2019 experience. Heck, you can even wet a line on the George Crady Bridge Fishing Pier and take advantage of the amazing fishing conditions.\n\nA U.S. Navy submarine sails past Fort Clinch State Park on Amelia Island, Fla. en route to a sea deployment. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nOr if you want to dip your toe back into the historical aspect of the island, visit Fort Clinch State Park. The park is home to Fort Clinch, one of the best-preserved 19th-century forts in the U.S. It might even give you a classic wow-that\u2019s-cool photo moment like I had, when an American submarine and its entourage sailed up the Cumberland Sound past Fort Clinch on its way to a sea deployment from King\u2019s Bay sub base.\n\nAdvertisement 10\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nI got to explore Cumberland Sound myself during a 75-minute trip with Amelia River Cruise. Highlights were getting the chance to see Georgia\u2019s Cumberland Island, a 28-km island that is home to some 200 wild horses that can often be seen roaming the beaches, many types of birds, and the remains of Dungeness Mansion, once owned by the Carnegie family. Your cruise guide will even point out the copper-roofed house used in The New Adventures of Pippi Longstocking, a 1988 film based on the character created by a Swedish author.\n\nFort Clinch is seen from the water during a cruise around Cumberland Sound on Amelia Island, Fla. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nI wound down even further with a drink while enjoying a half-hour session of miniature bowling, a variation of Canadian five-pin bowling, at Duck Pinz Fernandina. It was fun but would have been even better with a group of friends.\n\nAdvertisement 11\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThere were plenty of dining options in the Amelia Island area. If you\u2019re looking for a higher-end restaurant with fine dining, try POGO\u2019s Kitchen, which got a four-star review from the New York Times. Simpler fare can be found at Salt Life Food Shack near the entrance to Fort Clinch State Park, a casual beachside eatery, and the Salty Pelican, a personal fave (I ate there twice!) in downtown Fernandina Beach.\n\nAfter saying my farewells to fantastic Fernandina Beach, I hopped in the car for a short 45-minute drive to Jacksonville airport and my flight home.\n\nMiniature bowling, a variation of Canadian five-pin bowling, at Duck Pinz Fernandina. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nWHERE TO STAY IN ST. AUGUSTINE\n\n\nI spent two nights at the St. Francis Inn, a quiet bed and breakfast in the heart of the city\u2019s historic district that is within easy walking distance of many restaurants, museums, antique shops and steps from other tourist attractions, including the Gonzalez-Alvarez House, billed as the oldest (1723) surviving house in St. Augustine and now open as a museum.\n\nAdvertisement 12\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Inn itself dates back more than 230 years \u2014 it was built in 1791 \u2014 but has all the modern comforts despite its sometimes quirky (and did I mention haunted?) interior. I stayed in the Ballerina Room and, fortunately, did not get a visit from any apparitions.\n\nSt. Francis Inn is a member of Select Registry, a distinguished group of luxury inns across North America, and well worth booking for your visit.\n\nThe Salty Pelican is a popular spot with locals and tourists in Fernandina Beach, Fla. (Dave Pollard/Toronto Sun)\n\nWHERE TO STAY ON AMELIA ISLAND\n\nMy beachside condo at the Amelia Surf and Racquet Club, which was provided by Coastal Wave Properties, offered the perfect base of operations. I\u2019d highly recommend it for anyone, but particularly families due to the secure location, multiple bedrooms, full kitchen and laundry, and many amenities, including an outdoor pool and beach. You might even see some endangered beach turtles hatching!\n\nHOW TO GET HERE\n\nAir Canada offers non-stop flights from Toronto Pearson to Jacksonville, which is a one-hour drive from St. Augustine and slightly less from Amelia Island. You\u2019ll obviously need to rent a car if you decide to fly. But driving to the area isn\u2019t a bad idea, either, being one of the closer Florida destinations for anyone from Ontario.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This.
