{"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/local-news/on-red-dress-day-victoria-police-re-issue-plea-for-information-about-missing-woman-5337106", "title": "On Red Dress Day, Victoria police re-issue plea for information about missing woman - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n21.8 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Local News\nOn Red Dress Day, Victoria police re-issue plea for information about missing woman\nPolice consider the disappearance of Belinda Cameron, who was last seen on May 11, 2005, to be suspicious.\nAndrew Duffy\nMay 6, 2022 3:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 2 Belinda Cameron was 42 when she was last seen on May 11, 2005, in Esquimalt. VIA VICTORIA POLICE DEPARTMENT\nExpand\n\nBelinda Cameron has not been forgotten.\n\nThe Indigenous woman, who went missing on May 11, 2005, remains in the hearts and minds of her family \u2014 including her two adult daughters, who were just young girls when their mother disappeared.\n\nAnd she\u2019s not been forgotten by the Victoria police, who on Thursday issued another plea for public assistance in piecing together information on what happened to Cameron.\n\nThursday was the National Day of Awareness for Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, also known asRed Dress Day, and police said it was a day to recognize and remember all Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people who have gone missing or have been murdered. The department also said it was a day to honour the families, loved ones and communities of those women.\n\n\u201c[We\u2019re] continuing our search for Belinda in our effort to help her family find answers,\u201d it said in a statement.\n\nThe police are asking anyone with information about the missing Esquimalt woman to come forward and share what they know.\n\nCameron was 42 when she last seen in 2005 at the Esquimalt\u2019s Shoppers Drug Mart in the 800-block of Esquimalt Road.\n\nShe was reported missing nearly a month later. Despite an extensive investigation and a series of searches, she was never found.\n\nThe police consider the disappearance suspicious and presume Cameron was the victim of foul play. Her disappearance continues to be investigated as a homicide.\n\nAt the time, Cameron stood five-foot-eight with a medium to large build, and weighed about 170 pounds. She had dark brown eyes and long, dark brown hair that she wore parted in the middle. She wore silver-framed glasses.\n\nCameron\u2019s daughters are now adults and want to understand their mother\u2019s disappearance.\n\nPolice ask anyone with information about this case to contact VicPD\u2019s historical case review office at 250-995-7390 or Greater Victoria Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.\n\naduffy@timescolonist.com\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has been shared 42 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tNanaimo RCMP find illicit drugs, weapons after stopping suspected prohibited driver\n\tPolice seize 20 guns, 20,000 rounds of ammo in raid on Bear Mountain home\n\tMLA Rob Fleming says he won't run in fall provincial election\nTimes Colonist - Featured\nInjuries reported in Highway 4 crashes on Canada Day weekend\nRead More\nTRENDING TODAY\n6292\t\nFirst heat wave of the summer on the way to Vancouver Island and B.C.\n\n2633\t\nFairway grocery store closing at Westshore Town Centre\n\n2569\t\nSuspect's pants catch fire in arson attempt gone wrong: B.C. X/TODD SMITH\nArticle content\n\nInclement weather didn\u2019t dissuade Mohawks of Bay of Quinte members and local politicians from gathering Sunday evening in Belleville Market Square for a vigil to remember lost sisters, daughters and mothers.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMay 5 marked National Day of Awareness and Action for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\nA large gathering wearing symbolic red for Red Dress Day carried a large banner declaring, \u201cNo more stolen sisters.\u201d\n\nMohawks of the Bay of Quinte said: \u201cOn this day, we aim to raise awareness about this ongoing crisis and take action. On this day, we remember the people who have lost their lives to colonial, gender-based violence and their families and communities that live daily with the grief of losing loved ones.\u201d\n\nMohawks noted that a final federal inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women was released in June 2019.\n\n\u201cThere were 2,836 individuals who participated in the truth-gathering process and 231 calls to justice were recommended. To date, there has been little action on the calls for justice,\u201d said the MBQ.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nLocal politicians attended the vigil to lend their support for more action.\n\nTodd Smith, Bay of Quinte MPP, spoke at the gathering and noted online, the vigil was \u201cto honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and to continue to advocate for systemic change and a future where everybody feels safe in their communities.\u201d\n\nRic Bresee, MPP for Hastings-Lennox and Addington, said he attended the vigil to stand \u201cwith my federal, provincial, municipal, and First Nations colleagues for the #RedDressDay walk and ceremony in Belleville. When someone loses their mother, daughter, or sister, we grieve. But when a whole community loses their girls and women, we all grieve.\u201d\n\nBoth MPPs were joined by Ryan Williams, Bay of Quinte MP, at the event.\n\nAccording to Amnesty.ca, a 2021 report by the RCMP found, \u201c1,017 women and girls identified as Indigenous were murdered between 1980 and 2012\u2014a homicide rate roughly 4.5 times higher than that of all other women in Canada.\u201d\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR PICTON\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

PHOTO BY JENNIFER HAMILTON-MCCHARLES, THE NUGGET\nArticle content\nA string of red dresses swayed in the wind at the Kiwanis Bandshell Sunday morning.\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe day hit hard for Traci Koritsaris.\n\nHer aunt was murdered. She was 45. Her aunt\u2019s sister was also murdered.\n\n\u201cRed Dress Day is for murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls. We\u2019re just trying to honour them. Make sure their presence is known,\u201d said Koritsaris, event planner for the North Bay Indigenous Centre.\n\n\u201cThe message has totally been lost \u2013 that\u2019s why we\u2019re trying to make it more present.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day, otherwise known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People, is a day to raise awareness and take action against the ongoing genocide that Canadian lawmakers continue to allow and ignore.\n\nThe North Bay Indigenous Centre held a special feast, march and then ceremony at the waterfront, which included more than 100 attendees including guest speakers and drummers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re trying to shed light on the situation,\u201d Koritsaris said.\n\n\u201cWe hope the North Bay community will honour and respect the day. A lot of our sisters, mothers, my aunt were murdered.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\nToggle full screen mode\nPrevious Gallery Image\nPhoto by Jennifer Hamilton-McCharles, The Nugget\nNext Gallery Image\nToggle gallery captions\nView All 3 Photos\n\n1 of 3\n\nGuests were also encouraged to use small red cloth dresses provided by the Indigenous Centre to wipe their tears during their ceremony.\n\n\u201cThey can put them into the white paper bags, and we\u2019re going to collect them. We own land and will do an honour burning of all the tear drops. It\u2019s very special.\u201d\n\nThe Congress of Aboriginal Peoples is encouraging all Canadians to support Red Dress Day and the 231 Calls for Justice, produced by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cThis issue has the world\u2019s attention,\u201d says CAP national youth representative Jessica Savoy.\n\n\u201cCanada should be reminded of the United Nation\u2019s Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) that says, \u2018States shall take measures, in conjunction with Indigenous Peoples, to ensure that Indigenous women and children enjoy the full protection and guarantees against all forms of violence and discrimination.\u2019\u201d\n\nSavoy said with every statistic, there\u2019s countless family members and friends that are left heartbroken, without answers or justice.\n\n\u201cThere are Indigenous women murdered, laying in a landfill in Manitoba, and it took years and a change in government to take action.\u201d\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR SAULT STE. But one homeowner in the Lake Tahoe area has discovered just how resourceful some bears can be when their curiosity is piqued at snack time.\n\nThe video below, uploaded to YouTube by the media juggernaut named ViralHog, shows a couple of bears sniffing around a Ram 1500 and Jeep Grand Cherokee. In short order, one of the bruins stands on its hind legs and easily uses its two front paws to manipulate the exterior door handles of both vehicles, opening the doors and jumping inside for a sniff.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAnd we all laughed in Jurassic Park when the raptors opened that door to the kitchen.\n\nJokes aside, your author has stashed food inside an unlocked vehicle whilst camping, a task he will no longer undertake without thumbing the \u2018lock\u2019 button on its keyfob. {"url": "https://news.vice.com/article/life-and-death-along-canadas-highway-of-tears", "title": "Life and Death Along Canada's Highway of Tears", "body": "+ ENGLISH\nWatch\nWorld News\nCanadian News\nTech\nEntertainment\nTake Care\nFood\nFYI.\nThis story is over 5 years old.\nLife and Death Along Canada's Highway of Tears\nJustice is difficult to find on the 450-mile stretch of Highway 16 that winds through central British Columbia, connecting Prince Rupert and Prince George. In 1994 alone, three teenage girls were killed along this route.\nCB\nBy chantelle bellrichard\nOctober 16, 2015, 11:30am\nShare\nTweet\nSnap\nIMAGE VIA VICE CANADA\n\nThe red flowers have worn off.\n\nFootage shared on Telegram shows floral tributes to Russian opposition leader, and outspoken critic of Vladimir Putin, Alexei Navalny, being removed by authorities in Yekaterinburg.\n\nStill, seven stones are embedded in the dreamcatcher hanging in the back window of Brenda Wilson's car. In the center is a high school photo of her little sister Ramona trimmed into a circle. Long dark hair pulled to one side. A familiar blue backdrop. It's the Gitxsan teen's last school photo.\n\n\"I just always keep it with me,\" said Brenda. \"It was actually on my sister's casket when she was buried.\"\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nRamona was just 16 when she disappeared. It was the summer of 1994. Somehow, she never made it to the graduation parties she was going to that night. Ten months went by before her body was found in a wooded area near the local airport. For 21 years Ramona's family has been advocating for her, but her murder remains unsolved.\n\nJustice is difficult to find on the 450 mile stretch of Highway 16 that winds through central British Columbia, connecting Prince Rupert and Prince George. In 1994 alone, three teenage girls were killed along this route: Ramona Wilson, Roxanne Thiara, and Alishia Germaine. No one was ever charged.\n\nThis is the Highway of Tears.\n\nFamilies and communities have walked the highway's entire length, and then some, demanding justice. Brenda says Ramona's dreamcatcher is in her car for an upcoming walk.\n\n\"We don't want people to forget who she was as an individual person.\"\n\nBRENDA WILSON SAYS THE STONES IN THE DREAMCATCHER REPRESENT RAMONA, HER SIBLINGS AND MOTHER/VICE CANADA\n\nA Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)\u00a0report released in 2014 revealed that British Columbia had the highest number of unsolved cases of murdered and missing indigenous women and girls in the country: 76.\n\nMany of those disappearances and deaths occurred around the highway.\n\nThe numbers have changed, but the RCMP's latest report doesn't give a provincial breakdown.\n\nIn the absence of convictions, families are often the ones serving time. Organizing vigils, walks and rallies, contributing to conferences, research and prevention programs. They're leading calls to stop the violence, demanding the government support them in holding a national inquiry.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nA collective grief is echoing across the country, as the toll climbs. According to the RCMP,\u00a01,107 Aboriginal women were murdered and another 164 went missing between the years 1980 and 2012.\n\nRelated:\u00a0Harper Rejects Call For Inquiry Into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\u00a0\n\n\"You are in Highway of Tears Country,\" is the headline on a pocket-sized flyer at the Carrier Sekani Family Services office in Prince George. It's not actually clear how many women and girls are unaccounted for in the region.\n\nMore than 30, says the flyer. More than 40, suggests a Human Rights Watch report.\n\nToo many.\n\nThe Family Services office is located in Prince George, the province's so-called gateway to the north. Brenda Wilson works there under the title Highway of Tears Initiative Coordinator. Part of her job involves visiting communities along the highway, hosting workshops, and supporting victim's families.\n\n\"You know, I accept the fact that my sister is no longer here on this Earth,\" said Brenda.\u00a0\"But I also accept the fact that I am here, not to take her place, but I'm here as her voice. To let people know what happened to her and to bring awareness to the issues.\"\n\nConcrete solutions are out there; they've been on the books for nearly a decade.\n\nWatch the VICE Canada documentary, Searchers: Highway of Tears, here:\u00a0\n\n\"I think it's very, very, very slow,\" Mary Teegee says about the implementation of 33 recommendations to come out of the Highway of Tears Symposium that followed the death of 14-year-old Aielah Saric Auger. She was dumped on the side of the highway just west of Prince George in the winter of 2006.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nTeegee is an executive director at Carrier Sekani Family Services and was also Ramona Wilson's cousin. She runs through some of the work they've been able to accomplish. But, she says government funding is an ongoing issue.\n\n\"We've always maintained that work regardless of the funding because it's something that we believe in. It's something that our communities want us to do. But it's very difficult when there isn't the resources to keep going,\" said Teegee.\n\nBy the time the Highway of Tears Symposium launched, an RCMP task force called E-PANA had been put together to investigate whether a serial killer (or killers) was responsible for the deaths and disappearances along the highway. E-PANA's caseload would eventually double to 18 cases and was expanded to include other highways in the province.\n\nBreakthroughs have come in a few cases. Still, most of the Highway of Tears cases remain unsolved.\n\nAielah Auger's murder was the last, and most recent case added to the E-PANA task force.\n\nLike so many families, her mom became an outspoken advocate for missing and murdered indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\"Justice is what I want,\" Audrey Auger was quoted as saying in 2006.\n\nShe\u00a0died on the same highway, in a car accident in 2013.\u00a0Aielah's murder is still unsolved.\n\nClaudia Williams has been waiting for someone to solve her sister's murder since 1989.\n\n\"It goes through my mind every day,\" she says, recounting her last moments with her younger sister Alberta. It was a summer night. The sisters had been working in a cannery in Prince Rupert.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nPayday came and they decided to go to a cabaret with a group of friends.\n\nAfter the place closed Claudia says people were milling about trying to figure out where to go next. Claudia got caught up in a conversation with her boyfriend - and says Alberta, 24, was calling for her: 'Claudia! Claudia! Come on, we're going to a party!'\n\n\"I looked at her and said, 'Just a minute.'\"\n\nMoments later Alberta was gone. A month later her body was found. And 26 years later, no one has been charged. Her contact with the police is virtually non existent. Shortly after speaking to VICE News, the RCMP phoned her for the first time in years. (The RCMP declined to be interviewed for this story.)\n\nMuch of Claudia's faith is placed in a former cop\u00a0faith is placed in a former cop, Ray Michalko, who has been investigating a number of Highway of Tears cases for years. He's studied the victims, traversed hundreds of miles, rummaged through the bush, and run down leads, all on his own time and seemingly at his own expense.\n\n\"People are going missing. Kids are going missing. Women are going missing. It doesn't matter who they are or what their race is or anything,\" he said. \"It shouldn't matter. Especially in Canada. But, you know, there's a lot of people who'd tell you it does.\"\n\n**\n\nWhen you get to the second floor of the Carrier Sekani Family Services office there's a piece of art on the wall. Tears fall from a woman's face onto the silhouette of a person below.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\n\"I think that in general our communities have a lot of grief. We have a lot of grief and we have a lot of healing to do.\"\n\nMary Teegee isn't just talking about the women and girls that are gone.\n\nShe's talking about things like colonization, residential schools and loss of land. Things that have undoubtedly contributed to the disproportionate number of missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada.\n\n\"I think that's why when we look at something like the [Highway of Tears] recommendations report, there's 33 recommendations, and it's just one step in for us to get to that place where you know, our communities are getting stronger.\"\n\nRamona Wilson's family has spent 21 years keeping her story alive - more years than Ramona got to live on this Earth.\n\nBrenda Wilson has made it her job to protect those who are still living.\n\n\"You know it's really painful to every day to talk about your loved one, but you know it has to be done,\" Brenda said.\n\n\"What motivates me and what keeps me going \u2026 to do interviews, to do presentations\u2026 I want my sister's murder to be solved and also, I want there to be safety in our communities.\"\n\nFollow Chantelle Bellrichard on Twitter: @pieglue\n\nWatch another segment in VICE Canada's Searchers series, Misty Potts, here:\u00a0\n\nTAGGED:\nABORIGINALAIELAH AUGERBRITISH COLUMBIACANADACRIME & DRUGSMISSING AND MURDERED INDIGENOUS WOMENMMIWRAY MICHALKORCMPROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICEVICE NEWS\nSUBSCRIBE TO THE VICE NEWSLETTER.\nYour Email:\nSubscribe\nMORE\nLIKE THIS\nNews\nThe Very Best of VICE News Reporting\nVICE STAFF\n04.30.24\nNews\nInside the Christian Nationalist Church Where Proud Boys Go to be Baptized\nTESS OWEN\n02.22.24\nNews\nWhat We Know About the Death of Nonbinary Teen Nex Benedict\nTESS OWEN\n02.21.24\nNews\nFBI Investigating an Insular, Nameless Religious Group Undergoing Sexual Abuse Reckoning\nANNA MERLAN\n02.21.24\nNews\nRussian Pilot Who Stole Helicopter to Defect Found Shot to Death in Spain\nMITCHELL PROTHERO\n02.20.24\n0\nMORE\nFROM VICE\nNews\nWhere's Navalny's Body?\n\nAlexei Navalny's mother is still being denied access to her son's body after Vladimir Putin's foremost critic died under suspicious circumstances in a Russian prison on Friday.\n\nMITCHELL PROTHERO\n02.19.24\nNews\nMan Who Showed Father\u2019s Decapitated Head in a YouTube Video Charged With Terrorism\n\nPolice say that when they arrested Justin Mohn they found a USB drive with a folder that indicated he wanted to blow up Federal Buildings.\n\nMACK LAMOUREUX\n02.16.24\nNews\nPutin Critic Alexei Navalny Dies in Russian Prison\n\nAlexei Navalny died on Friday in one of Russia's toughest prisons. {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/bc-documents-on-highway-of-tears-open-wounds-as-missing-women-inquiry-looms/it24793", "title": "B.C. documents on Highway of Tears open wounds as missing-women inquiry looms | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Penticto|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 27.0\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nKelowna News\nB.C. documents on Highway of Tears open wounds as missing-women inquiry looms\nDirk Meissner\nThe Yellowhead, Highway 16, near Prince George, B.C., is pictured on October 8, 2012. The small British Columbia Cheslatta Carrier Nation has a decades-long anguished relationship with Highway 16, or the so-called Highway of Tears.Five people from the community of less than 350 near Burns Lake in central B.C. have disappeared along the route, including an entire family of four, says Chief Corrina Leween.\nImage Credit: THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jonathan Hayward\nNovember 08, 2015 - 4:30 PM\n\nVICTORIA - The small British Columbia Cheslatta Carrier Nation has a decades-long anguished relationship with Highway 16, or the so-called Highway of Tears.\n\nFive people from the community of less than 350 near Burns Lake in central B.C. have disappeared along the route, including an entire family of four, says Chief Corrina Leween.\n\nAt least 18 women went missing or were murdered along Highway 16 and the adjacent Highways 97 and 5 since the 1970s. Most cases remain unsolved, though investigators don't believe a single killer is responsible.\n\nThe sorrow deepened recently with a damning report over deleted Transportation Ministry emails about the highway and its missing.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone has said he agrees with the opinions of some locals that a shuttle bus service along the route isn't practical. However, the Opposition New Democrats say recently released documents contradict Stone and highlight the concerns of local officials who say a bus service should be considered.\n\nThe controversy could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada's murdered and missing women. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised the inquiry during the election campaign.\n\n\"I would expect that because a number of women have gone missing, and or have been known to have been murdered along Highway 16, that Highway 16 will figure in the national inquiry,\" said Stone. \"Our government has been on the record for quite some time in supporting a national inquiry.\"\n\nB.C.'s Attorney General Suzanne Anton said she also expects an inquiry would focus on the highway.\n\n\"I'm not trying to second-guess the federal inquiry, but there probably will be an aspect about the north all across the country,\" she said.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nHighway 16 stretches more than 700 kilometres between Prince George and Prince Rupert. It follows rivers and mountains and connects remote communities. Its route is dark, lonely and blood stained.\n\n\"Within (our) community, we have had an entire family that went missing, the Jack family,\" said Leween. \"One of our elders is missing.\"\n\nCasimel Jack, 70, was last seen a decade ago, walking along a road that connects to Highway 16 south of Burns Lake. He was hunting and carrying a rifle when he disappeared Sept. 18, 2005.\n\nRonald Jack, his wife, Doreen, and their two sons, Russell, 9, and Ryan, 4, vanished Aug. 1, 1989. The last anybody heard from the family was when Ronald called a family member from a Prince George pub to say he and his wife found jobs.\n\n\"They just simply disappeared. Mom, dad and the two boys,\" Leween said.\n\nShe said successive B.C. governments have refused to move on First Nations' requests to provide a regional transportation network. Leween described government consultations attempts as sophisticated stalling tactics.\n\n\"I, as a leader, don't feel the government is doing enough to addresses the issue,\" she said.\n\nLeween rejected Stone's claim that leaders across the north agree a large-scale transit service won't work.\n\n\"It's absolutely untrue,\" she said. \"The bus is desperately needed in our area. I go to Prince George quite often to meetings and I see the young women hitchhiking on that highway. It's needed.\"\n\nStone said the government is looking to develop shorter transportation connections between communities, but a region-wide transportation service is not workable.\n\n\"It's difficult for many folks to comprehend, myself included, how a scheduled shuttle bus service across an 800 kilometre stretch of highway that's very sparsely populated would meet the needs of people who live along the highway.\"\n\nStone said his ministry is holding a transportation symposium in Smithers Nov. 24 to discuss practical, affordable and sustainable solutions for communities along Highway 16.\n\nOpposition New Democrat Jennifer Rice, whose North Coast riding includes a section of Highway 16, said she has not been invited to the symposium but plans to attend.\n\n\"I've been here (in Victoria) two years, and I've been asking this question numerous times around improving the transportation and safety along Highway 16, and I've been shrugged off and told basically to move on and get a new idea,\" she said.\n\nRice said two years ago when she accidentally locked herself out of her car on a stretch of the highway she felt the chill of being alone in the middle of nowhere.\n\n\"I was in a pull out, and I had no cell service and I was the only one there,\" she said.\n\n\"I had just come back from Victoria and I had been asking questions about the Highway of Tears. Then this happened to me. I felt extremely vulnerable.\"\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2015\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are emailed reader responses to stories or letters {"url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/documents-on-highway-of-tears-open-wounds-as-missing-women-inquiry-looms-1.2648184", "title": "Documents on Highway of Tears open wounds as missing-women inquiry looms | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFOLLOW ON\n\n    \n\nAdvertisement\n\nCANADA\nDocuments on Highway of Tears open wounds as missing-women inquiry looms\nDirk Meissner\nThe Canadian Press\n\n\nPublished Sunday, November 8, 2015 7:40AM EST\nLast Updated Sunday, November 8, 2015 9:31PM EST\nCTV Vancouver: Calls for bus service\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nAt least 18 women went missing or were murdered along Highways 16, 97 and 5 since the 1970s.\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nVICTORIA -- The small British Columbia Cheslatta Carrier Nation has a decades-long anguished relationship with Highway 16, or the so-called Highway of Tears.\n\nFive people from the community of less than 350 near Burns Lake in central B.C. have disappeared along the route, including an entire family of four, says Chief Corrina Leween.\n\nAt least 18 women went missing or were murdered along Highway 16 and the adjacent Highways 97 and 5 since the 1970s. Most cases remain unsolved, though investigators don't believe a single killer is responsible.\n\nRelated Stories\nB.C. to pay former privacy commissioner $50K to review deleted emails report\nB.C. premier orders cabinet, staff to save all emails in wake of deleted records scandal\nRCMP warned budget cuts would hamper Highway of Tears probe\n\nThe sorrow deepened recently with a damning report over deleted Transportation Ministry emails about the highway and its missing.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone has said he agrees with the opinions of some locals that a shuttle bus service along the route isn't practical. However, the Opposition New Democrats say recently released documents contradict Stone and highlight the concerns of local officials who say a bus service should be considered.\n\nThe controversy could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada's murdered and missing women. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised the inquiry during the election campaign.\n\n\"I would expect that because a number of women have gone missing, and or have been known to have been murdered along Highway 16, that Highway 16 will figure in the national inquiry,\" said Stone. \"Our government has been on the record for quite some time in supporting a national inquiry.\"\n\nB.C.'s Attorney General Suzanne Anton said she also expects an inquiry would focus on the highway.\n\n\"I'm not trying to second-guess the federal inquiry, but there probably will be an aspect about the north all across the country,\" she said.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nHighway 16 stretches more than 700 kilometres between Prince George and Prince Rupert. It follows rivers and mountains and connects remote communities. Its route is dark, lonely and blood stained.\n\n\"Within (our) community, we have had an entire family that went missing, the Jack family,\" said Leween. \"One of our elders is missing.\"\n\nCasimel Jack, 70, was last seen a decade ago, walking along a road that connects to Highway 16 south of Burns Lake. He was hunting and carrying a rifle when he disappeared Sept. 18, 2005.\n\nRonald Jack, his wife, Doreen, and their two sons, Russell, 9, and Ryan, 4, vanished Aug. 1, 1989. The last anybody heard from the family was when Ronald called a family member from a Prince George pub to say he and his wife found jobs.\n\n\"They just simply disappeared. Mom, dad and the two boys,\" Leween said.\n\nShe said successive B.C. governments have refused to move on First Nations' requests to provide a regional transportation network. Leween described government consultations attempts as sophisticated stalling tactics.\n\n\"I, as a leader, don't feel the government is doing enough to addresses the issue,\" she said.\n\nLeween rejected Stone's claim that leaders across the north agree a large-scale transit service won't work.\n\n\"It's absolutely untrue,\" she said. \"The bus is desperately needed in our area. I go to Prince George quite often to meetings and I see the young women hitchhiking on that highway. It's needed.\"\n\nStone said the government is looking to develop shorter transportation connections between communities, but a region-wide transportation service is not workable.\n\n\"It's difficult for many folks to comprehend, myself included, how a scheduled shuttle bus service across an 800 kilometre stretch of highway that's very sparsely populated would meet the needs of people who live along the highway.\"\n\nStone said his ministry is holding a transportation symposium in Smithers Nov. 24 to discuss practical, affordable and sustainable solutions for communities along Highway 16.\n\nOpposition New Democrat Jennifer Rice, whose North Coast riding includes a section of Highway 16, said she has not been invited to the symposium but plans to attend.\n\n\"I've been here (in Victoria) two years, and I've been asking this question numerous times around improving the transportation and safety along Highway 16, and I've been shrugged off and told basically to move on and get a new idea,\" she said.\n\nRice said two years ago when she accidentally locked herself out of her car on a stretch of the highway she felt the chill of being alone in the middle of nowhere.\n\n\"I was in a pull out, and I had no cell service and I was the only one there,\" she said.\n\n\"I had just come back from Victoria and I had been asking questions about the Highway of Tears. Then this happened to me. I felt extremely vulnerable.\"\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n\nHighway 16 near Prince George, B.C., is pictured Oct. 8, 2012. (The Canadian Press/Jonathan Hayward)\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport an error\nEditorial standards and\u00a0policies\nWhy you can trust CTV\u00a0News\nMORE NEWS FROM CANADA\nBorder workers who nearly went on strike in June ratify new contract\n'Finally I know who I am': Holocaust survivor\u2019s daughter reunited with long lost brother in Poland\n'It's a lot to digest': Calgary man wins $66M on Lotto 6-49 draw\n'Not my finest moment:' Police called to dispute between Ottawa city councillor and daycare owner\nWhat you need to know about a possible LCBO strike on Friday\nInstant noodle products sold in B.C., Alta., Ont. recalled due to undeclared peanut\nTOP VIDEOS\nfalse\nQue. students accuse teacher of profiting off their artwork\nfalse\nCar thefts in Canada: Insurance companies face criticism\nfalse\n$50K reward offered in case of missing Barrie, Ont. woman\nCTVNEWS.CA TOP STORIES\nTrying to sell or buy a home this summer? {"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/BC/330274/B-C-and-federal-governments-promise-unbroken-cell-service-on-Highway-of-Tears", "title": "B.C. and federal governments promise unbroken cell service on 'Highway of Tears' - BC News - Castanet.net", "body": "26\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nBC\u00a0\u00a0\nB.C. and federal governments promise unbroken cell service on 'Highway of Tears'\nCELL SERVICE ON HWY OF TEARS\nThe Canadian Press - Apr 7, 2021 / 1:21 pm | Story: 330274\nPhoto: The Canadian Press\nA cell tower is pictured in rural Ontario on Wednesday, July 15, 2020. The federal and British Columbia governments in partnership with Rogers Communications say a 15-year-old pledge to provide seamless cellular coverage along a remote B.C. highway will be fulfilled by October 2022. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\n\nThe federal and British Columbia governments say seamless cellular coverage will be provided along the Highway of Tears by October 2022.\n\nSeventy per cent of Highway 16 already has some coverage, but Lisa Beare, B.C.'s minister of citizens' services, says the $11.7-million project will bring cell service to the remaining 252 kilometres between Smithers and Prince Rupert.\n\nThe project is set to begin this spring and will add 12 cell towers as well as improve connectivity at three rest stops, with the province and Ottawa each contributing just over $2 million and Rogers Communications picking up the remainder of the bill.\n\nHighway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert became known as the Highway of Tears more than two decades ago, a reference to the many Indigenous women who have gone missing or been murdered along the route since the 1970s.\n\nIn a separate announcement, the B.C. government says nearly $5 million in cell service upgrades is coming to Highway 14 on Vancouver Island between Sooke and Port Renfrew, with work expected to be complete by late October.\n\nThe Highway 14 improvements will bring cell service to Port Renfrew, Shirley, Otter Point, Jordan River and some Pacheedaht First Nation communities.\n\nMaryam Monsef, the federal minister for women and gender equality and rural economic development, says the Highway 16 upgrade marks a milestone for Aboriginal communities.\n\nShe told an online news conference it is the first universal broadband cell project being funded that will \"primarily benefit Indigenous communities, but it will not be the last.\"\n\nBoth Beare and Monsef said better cell service makes everyone safer.\n\n\"Knowing that people will be able to travel Highway 16 without worrying about gaps in coverage is exactly the kind of result we want to see on every community highway and in every rural and Indigenous community,\" Beare said.\n\nThe Highway of Tears Symposium Report made 33 recommendations in 2006, including solving the problem of cellular gaps between the handful of communities along the 725-kilometre corridor.\n\nRCMP files link a total of 18 murders or disappearances to the region, but Carrier Sekani Family Services in Prince George says on its website that the number likely exceeds 40.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/greyhound-bus-route-on-bcs-highway-of-tears-one-of-five-that-could-be-axed/it45735", "title": "Greyhound bus route on B.C.'s Highway of Tears one of five that could be axed | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kamloops, Merritt and Areas|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 27.7\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nKamloops News\nGreyhound bus route on B.C.'s Highway of Tears one of five that could be axed\nCamille Bains and Beth Leighton\nA Greyhound logo is shown at the Greyhound Terminal at the James Richardson International Airport in Winnipeg on September 3, 2009. Greyhound Canada has applied to regulators in British Columbia to drop five routes, four of them in northern B.C., as the company deals with plunging ridership.\nImage Credit: THE CANADIAN PRESS/John Woods\nAugust 31, 2017 - 8:45 PM\n\nVANCOUVER - Greyhound Canada has applied to regulators in British Columbia to drop five routes, four of them in northern B.C., as the company deals with plunging ridership.\n\nGreyhound calls the decision \"regrettably unavoidable\" but said there has been a 51 per cent drop in riders since 2010, along with higher costs and increased competition from publicly subsidized services.\n\nRoutes that would be eliminated include a 718-kilometre run along Highway 16, the so-called Highway of Tears, between Prince George and Prince Rupert.\n\nAfter dozens of murders and disappearances of women along that highway, the province, local governments and BC Transit launched a subsidized route in June connecting Burns Lake, Prince George and Smithers, mirroring portions of the Greyhound route.\n\nThe company has also applied to drop its routes from Prince George to Valemount, Prince George to Dawson Creek, Dawson Creek to Whitehorse and Victoria to Nanaimo.\n\nStuart Kendrick, senior vice-president at Greyhound, said the application was filed with the Passenger Transportation Board earlier this month and the process normally takes about 90 days but could be longer because of the proposal to cut five routes.\n\n\"We can't continue to operate these routes at a loss,\" he said, adding Greyhound can't compete with subsidized BC Transit.\n\n\"We've communicated to the provincial government for several years that this is eroding our business. It does create an unfair playing field and when you have subsidized transit they're able to offer fares that are much lower than ours,\" Kendrick said.\n\n\"Connectivity from northern B.C. into the main corridors is really what the customer needs and right now it's not a viable option for a private carrier.\"\n\nGreyhound is continuing its discussions with provincial and federal officials regarding viable options for transportation in rural areas, Kendrick said.\n\nTerry Teegee, tribal chief of the Prince George-based Carrier Sekani First Nation, said other private companies also would be unlikely make a profit for the same reasons but rural residents need reliable transportation between communities that are geographically spread out.\n\nHe said existing subsidized services would have to be expanded or new ones would be needed to take over so people in northern B.C. have options that are readily available elsewhere in the province.\n\n\"Why aren't we a priority?\" he asked. \"There's no reason why there couldn't be a transit system up here as well that could (provide) service like in Vancouver, or any other place.\"\n\nFirst Nations leaders, mayors and advocates pushed the province for a decade to fund transportation along Highway 16.\n\nThe B.C. government finally came up with a transportation plan last year, but only after a 2012 report from a missing women inquiry that had commissioner Wally Oppal recommending bus service along the corridor where people often hitchhike to get around.\n\nService is being rolled out separately in various communities and started in January with a 30-minute, six-days-a-week shuttle along a small section of the highway, from Moricetown and Smithers.\n\nThe Passenger Transportation Board could call public consultations as part of its decision process on Greyhound's application.\n\nNote to readers: This is a corrected story. A previous version said the passenger transportation branch would decide whether to eliminate the routes.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2017\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have PHOTO BY JONATHAN HAYWARD /THE CANADIAN PRESS\nArticle content\n\nVICTORIA \u2014 The small British Columbia Cheslatta Carrier Nation has a decades-long anguished relationship with Highway 16, or the so-called Highway of Tears.\n\nFive people from the community of less than 350 near Burns Lake in central B.C. have disappeared along the route, including an entire family of four, says Chief Corrina Leween.\n\nAt least 18 women went missing or were murdered along Highway 16 and the adjacent Highways 97 and 5 since the 1970s. Most cases remain unsolved, though investigators don\u2019t believe a single killer is responsible.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\n'You just can't snap your fingers and move out Evander Kane': Edmonton Oilers insider\nSecret weapon helps Edmonton Oilers convince top players to sign and stay here\nInjured woman dies in deep southeast Edmonton, man arrested: Police\nOilers Stanley Cup playoff run nets $280M for Edmonton: OEG, Explore Edmonton\nThursday's letters: Edmonton must end its urban sprawl\nArticle content\n\nThe sorrow deepened recently with a damning report over deleted Transportation Ministry emails about the highway and its missing.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone has insisted that locals don\u2019t want a bus service, but recently released documents highlight the concerns of local officials and contradict the minister.\n\nThe controversy could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada\u2019s murdered and missing women. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised the inquiry during the election campaign.\n\n\u201cI would expect that because a number of women have gone missing, and or have been known to have been murdered along Highway 16, that Highway 16 will figure in the national inquiry,\u201d said Stone. \u201cOur government has been on the record for quite some time in supporting a national inquiry.\u201d\n\nB.C.\u2019s Attorney General Suzanne Anton said she also expects an inquiry would focus on the highway.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not trying to second-guess the federal inquiry, but there probably will be an aspect about the north all across the country,\u201d she said.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nHeadline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHighway 16 stretches more than 700 kilometres between Prince George and Prince Rupert. It follows rivers and mountains and connects remote communities. Its route is dark, lonely and blood stained.\n\n\u201cWithin (our) community, we have had an entire family that went missing, the Jack family,\u201d said Leween. \u201cOne of our elders is missing.\u201d\n\nCasimel Jack, 70, was last seen a decade ago, walking along a road that connects to Highway 16 south of Burns Lake. He was hunting and carrying a rifle when he disappeared Sept. 18, 2005.\n\nRonald Jack, his wife, Doreen, and their two sons, Russell, 9, and Ryan, 4, vanished Aug. 1, 1989. The last anybody heard from the family was when Ronald called a family member from a Prince George pub to say he and his wife found jobs.\n\n\u201cThey just simply disappeared. Mom, dad and the two boys,\u201d Leween said.\n\nShe said successive B.C. governments have refused to move on First Nations\u2019 requests to provide a regional transportation network. Leween described government consultations attempts as sophisticated stalling tactics.\n\n\u201cI, as a leader, don\u2019t feel the government is doing enough to addresses the issue,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nLeween rejected Stone\u2019s claim that leaders across the north agree a large-scale transit service won\u2019t work.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s absolutely untrue,\u201d she said. \u201cThe bus is desperately needed in our area. I go to Prince George quite often to meetings and I see the young women hitchhiking on that highway. It\u2019s needed.\u201d\n\nStone said the government is looking to develop shorter transportation connections between communities, but a region-wide transportation service is not workable.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s difficult for many folks to comprehend, myself included, how a scheduled shuttle bus service across an 800 kilometre stretch of highway that\u2019s very sparsely populated would meet the needs of people who live along the highway.\u201d\n\nStone said his ministry is holding a transportation symposium in Smithers Nov. 24 to discuss practical, affordable and sustainable solutions for communities along Highway 16.\n\nOpposition New Democrat Jennifer Rice, whose North Coast riding includes a section of Highway 16, said she has not been invited to the symposium but plans to attend.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been here (in Victoria) two years, and I\u2019ve been asking this question numerous times around improving the transportation and safety along Highway 16, and I\u2019ve been shrugged off and told basically to move on and get a new idea,\u201d she said.\n\nRice said two years ago when she accidentally locked herself out of her car on a stretch of the highway she felt the chill of being alone in the middle of nowhere.\n\n\u201cI was in a pull out, and I had no cell service and I was the only one there,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cI had just come back from Victoria and I had been asking questions about the Highway of Tears. Then this happened to me. {"url": "http://www.news957.com/national/2017/09/25/highway-of-tears-walk-to-wrap-in-smithers-b-c-ahead-of-mmiw-inquiry-hearing/", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears before missing, murdered Indigenous women hearing", "body": "Halifax\nAbout\nContact\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nContests\nCommunity\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nFamilies walk Highway of Tears before missing, murdered Indigenous women hearing\n\nBy Laura Kane, The Canadian Press\n\nPosted Sep 25, 2017 05:00:04 AM.\n\n \n\nLast Updated Sep 26, 2017 10:00:23 AM.\n\nThis article is more than 5 years old.\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2013 Gladys Radek raised a fist in the air and wept as she reached the end of her 350-kilometre journey along British Columbia\u2019s Highway of Tears.\n\nThe Indigenous grandmother finished her walk along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 for the seventh and final time on Monday. It is the same highway where her beloved niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared.\n\nOutside a community centre in Smithers, B.C., her voice shook as she spoke to those who had walked alongside her, including commissioners from the national inquiry into missing and murdered women.\n\n\u201cI want to thank you all for standing so proud and loud, to show our commissioners that we have love for our missing and murdered women,\u201d she said through tears.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very proud of this moment right now because when Tamara went missing, nobody cared. When Tamara went missing, there were many others who were already missing, many others who had been murdered.\u201d\n\nDozens of women have disappeared or been killed along the highway between Prince Rupert and Prince George in central B.C.\n\nRadek and other family members and advocates left Prince Rupert on Thursday and arrived Monday in Smithers, where the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls will hold hearings starting Tuesday.\n\nThe walkers were accompanied by vehicles and have covered sections of the route in a relay fashion, allowing them to complete the walk of hundreds of kilometres over the span of a few days.\n\nDuring the final stretch through the town of Smithers, Radek, who is missing a leg, drove a car covered in photographs of women who have disappeared or been killed. She wept behind the wheel as passersby waved and honked their horns.\n\nInquiry commissioner Michele Audette joined the group three days ago, while Chief Commissioner Marion Buller joined on Monday. Commissioner Qajaq Robinson was supposed to attend the hearings but had to bow out due to a family emergency.\n\nAudette said she walked to honour the resilience and strength of the families who will be speaking for the first time to the inquiry. The hearings will be powerful, she said.\n\n\u201cI feel it since I arrived, there\u2019s a lot of emotion, lots of anxiety also or stress, because it\u2019s the first time for them,\u201d she said. \u201cJust being there beside them and listening, maybe it\u2019s helped.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry has been plagued by controversy, including the resignation of commissioner Marilyn Poitras this summer and complaints from families about poor communications and delays.\n\nBuller told a Senate committee last week that the inquiry\u2019s work has been hampered by federal bureaucracy.\n\nRhonda Lee McIsaac, who lives in Haida Gwaii and has Ojibway heritage, participated in the walk for the first time and said it was a moving experience.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m walking for everybody who cannot walk,\u201d said McIsaac. \u201cI have lost a loved one. I grew up in foster care and I was adopted out. This is part of my story.\u201d\n\nMore than 40 people have signed up to speak at the Smithers hearings, which run through Thursday. They are the second hearings held by the inquiry after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nThe inquiry is set to visit nine communities this fall, including Edmonton, Winnipeg and Thunder Bay, Ont.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nImpaired youth arrested after ATV ended up in a ditch, passenger injured\nBirch Cove and Shubie Park closed until further notice\nHurricane Beryl churns toward Mexico after leaving destruction in Jamaica and eastern Caribbean\nThe todd veinotte show july 4th 11am\nFire at popular Halifax deli\nTop Stories\nImpaired youth arrested after ATV ended up in a ditch, passenger injured\n\n1h ago\n\nWentworth man wanted on two province-wide arrest warrants\n\n1h ago\n\nFire at popular Halifax deli\n\n45m ago\n\nBirch Cove and Shubie Park beaches closed to swimmers\n\n5h ago\n\nMost Watched Today\n2:32\nCanada risks \u201cmuch more censored & surveilled\u201d internet\n\nThe suite of internet regulation bills in Parliament are intended to protect people - but activists warn it could mean a much more surveilled & censored internet. {"url": "https://news.vice.com/article/bcs-highway-of-tears-email-scandal-raises-doubts-for-families-of-murdered-women", "title": "BC's Highway of Tears Email Scandal Raises Doubts for Families of Murdered Women", "body": "+ ENGLISH\nWatch\nWorld News\nCanadian News\nTech\nEntertainment\nTake Care\nFood\nFYI.\nThis story is over 5 years old.\nBC's Highway of Tears Email Scandal Raises Doubts for Families of Murdered Women\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police has been asked to step in after a BC government worker \u201cfailed to tell the truth,\" under oath, about deleting Highway of Tears records.\nCB\nBy chantelle bellrichard\nOctober 24, 2015, 2:45pm\nShare\nTweet\nSnap\nIMAGE VIA VICE CANADA\n\nDelete, delete, delete.\n\nFootage shared on Telegram shows floral tributes to Russian opposition leader, and outspoken critic of Vladimir Putin, Alexei Navalny, being removed by authorities in Yekaterinburg.\n\nOn May 18th, a former staffer in the British Columbia Ministry of Transportation sent a letter of complaint to the BC Information and Privacy Commissioner. He was concerned about how a freedom of information request was handled. He hand-signed the letter in blue pen.\n\nEmails had been deleted, instead of being reported, Tim Duncan alleged.\n\nIt turns out that request was related to missing women and government meetings about Highway 16. More specifically, the 450-mile stretch of Highway 16 that connects Prince George to Prince Rupert -\u2014 commonly referred to as the Highway of Tears. People who live in the region will tell you more than 30 women and girls, mostly indigenous, have gone missing or been murdered there.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe information request that came through Tim Duncan's department ultimately resulted in \"no responsive records.\" But Duncan says when he searched his computer, there were over a dozen emails that could have been relevant.\n\nHe says he called over a coworker, a man named George Gretes, to report the emails. And then, Duncan alleges Gretes took control of his computer, deleted the emails, and said:\n\n\"It's done, now you don't have to worry about it anymore.\"\n\nAfter months of investigation, BC Privacy Commissioner Elizabeth Denham released her findings this week in a report titled Access Denied: Records Retention and Disposal Practices of the Government of British Columbia.\n\n\"It is difficult to overstate the seriousness of the problems that my office discovered in the course of this investigation and the resulting effect on the integrity of the access to information process in our province,\" Denham wrote.\n\nRecommendations have been made and now the RCMP has been asked to step in after Gretes \"failed to tell the truth,\" under oath, about deleting\u00a0Highway of Tears emails.\u00a0Gretes has disputed Duncan's version of what happened, but the truth-telling part goes beyond who hit delete on that one particular day.\n\nThe Access Denied report goes into detail about how government staff have been expunging email records through a three-step process of deletion that includes manually overriding\u00a0a backup that can recover deleted files.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nVariations of the term \"triple delete\" appear 58 times in Denham's report. There are actually three freedom of information requests reviewed in the investigation and they all involve emails and record keeping/destruction in some way.\n\nRelated:\u00a0Life and Death Along Canada's Highway of Tears\n\nResponding to the report yesterday, BC Premier Christy Clark called for government ministries and political staff to stop deleting their sent emails and also committed to making the changes recommended in Denham's report.\n\n\"For me, the most important thing is the public has an expectation that their government is transparent and we're going to make sure that we act on all those recommendations, so it is,\" said Clark.\n\nBrenda Wilson has been watching the week's events unfold from Prince George, where she lives and works as the Highway of Tears Initiative Coordinator. Brenda's sister Ramona was found murdered along the highway in 1995. No one has been charged in her death.\n\n\"To me as a family member it just shows why a lot of the things that were promised in the past have not been fulfilled,\" she said.\n\n\"When they can't find a solution they just push it under the rug. It's not important enough for them to try to make it work.\"\n\nOne of the solutions communities along the Highway of Tears have been demanding, for years, is better transportation along the route with a shuttle bus.\n\nIt was the number one recommendation made in the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium Recommendations Report and is seen as a way to prevent women and girls from being victimized.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe freedom of information request detailed in Tim Duncan's complaint and Denham's subsequent report is directly connected to this issue. The request was written as follows:\n\n\"Pursuant to the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act, I request all government records that make reference to the issue of missing women along Highway 16/the Highway of Tears and specifically including records related to meetings held by the ministry on this issue. The time frame for my request is May 15 to November 19, 2014.\"\n\nLast summer the ministry did meet with communities and First Nations leaders along the route to discuss transportation challenges and possible solutions.\n\nAccording to the report, It seems the \"no responsive records\" result came down to the ministry interpretation of the request - making a distinction that the meetings were about transportation options, not missing women.\n\n\"I don't know how they could say that when that's what it all evolved around, the missing women,\" said Wilson, who is also an advocate for missing and murdered women.\n\n\"That's why the whole transportation issue came about was because of the missing women along Highway 16. I don't know how they could say stuff like that when it's not the truth.\"\n\nDenham was also critical about how the ministry interpreted the request and that it appeared the ministry \"fully understood\" what meetings the applicant was referring to.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nWilson says she'll be watching to see how the government and RCMP handle the situation moving forward.\n\n\"I hope that there's accountability for the actions that happened. You know, that they rectify the issue so that we can go on to mend our thoughts of a good government, a clean government that we can count on,\" she said.\n\n\"All we want is to be able to work together and to keep our communities safe\u00a0\u2026 We just want to keep everybody safe.\"\n\nFollow Chantelle Bellrichard on Twitter:\u00a0@pieglue\n\nWatch the VICE Canada documentary, Searchers: Highway of Tears, here:\u00a0\n\nTAGGED:\nBC PRIVACY COMMISSIONERBRITISH COLUMBIACANADACHRISTY CLARKELIZABETH DENHAMGEORGE GRETESHIGHWAY OF TEARSINDIGENOUSMISSING AND MURDERED ABORIGINAL WOMENPOLITICSTRIPLE DELETEVICE NEWS\nSUBSCRIBE TO THE VICE NEWSLETTER.\nYour Email:\nSubscribe\nMORE\nLIKE THIS\nNews\nThe Very Best of VICE News Reporting\nVICE STAFF\n04.30.24\nNews\nInside the Christian Nationalist Church Where Proud Boys Go to be Baptized\nTESS OWEN\n02.22.24\nNews\nWhat We Know About the Death of Nonbinary Teen Nex Benedict\nTESS OWEN\n02.21.24\nNews\nFBI Investigating an Insular, Nameless Religious Group Undergoing Sexual Abuse Reckoning\nANNA MERLAN\n02.21.24\nNews\nRussian Pilot Who Stole Helicopter to Defect Found Shot to Death in Spain\nMITCHELL PROTHERO\n02.20.24\n0\nMORE\nFROM VICE\nNews\nWhere's Navalny's Body?\n\nAlexei Navalny's mother is still being denied access to her son's body after Vladimir Putin's foremost critic died under suspicious circumstances in a Russian prison on Friday.\n\nMITCHELL PROTHERO\n02.19.24\nNews\nMan Who Showed Father\u2019s Decapitated Head in a YouTube Video Charged With Terrorism\n\nPolice say that when they arrested Justin Mohn they found a USB drive with a folder that indicated he wanted to blow up Federal Buildings.\n\nMACK LAMOUREUX\n02.16.24\nNews\nPutin Critic Alexei Navalny Dies in Russian Prison\n\nAlexei Navalny died on Friday in one of Russia's toughest prisons. Highway of Tears - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nVia in talks to offer $5 fares to \u2018at risk\u2019 groups along B.C. Highway of Tears\nCAMILLE BAINS\nVANCOUVER\nTHE CANADIAN PRESS\nPUBLISHED AUGUST 19, 2016\n\nThis article was published more than 7 years ago. Some information may no longer be current.\n\nA sign warning that a killer is at work along the Highway of Tears stands in Moricetown, B.C., March 20, 2011.\nRAFAL GERSZAK/THE GLOBE AND MAIL\n\nCOMMENTS\nSHARE\n\nVia Rail has joined discussions with the British Columbia government, First Nations and social service agencies to offer rock-bottom fares to \"vulnerable\" people who can't afford to travel along the so-called Highway of Tears. The railway is collaborating with mayors and multiple groups to determine the criteria for $5 fares along a northern B.C. corridor where 18 girls and women have been murdered or have disappeared since the 1970s.\n\nIn June, following a decade of pleas from women's groups and First Nations, B.C. Transportation Minister Todd Stone announced that bus service would begin in the area by the end of the year.\n\nRelated: Disappeared: Reconstructing a life to find a missing mother\n\nChief Joseph Bevan of the Kitselas First Nation near Terrace said he's part of an advisory group concerned about the safety of people along the 750-kilometre route and that it came together for regular meetings last November after months of discussions.\n\nHe said it's common for people to take a risk and hitchhike in the notorious area because they're too poor to take the train or a Greyhound bus.\n\n\"It's non-aboriginals as well. It's everyone who is on social assistance, people with disabilities, who are having trouble moving around. It makes them vulnerable when they're jumping into a vehicle with somebody else.\"\n\nBevan said that at a meeting in March, a Via Rail official made the proposal to offer a $5 fare along the highway that stretches between Prince Rupert and Prince George.\n\nMichael Woelcke, the railway's general manager for remote services, said in minutes of the meeting held in Prince George on March 30 that the company would offer the low fare \"regardless of origin or destination along the route.\"\n\nHe said Via Rail provides train service three times a week between Prince Rupert and Prince George, and it's open to suggestions on determining eligibility for the $5 fare that would be available to \"at risk\" and \"vulnerable\" people including youth and \"elders.\"\n\n\"We need to identify who would qualify for this program, as we cannot provide everyone with these reduced fares,\" he said in the minutes.\n\nWoelcke said a minimum $75 one-way fare would be reduced by a third for aboriginal passengers.\n\nWoelcke was not available for comment, and the company said an official would provide details if and when an arrangement is worked out with the province.\n\nVia Rail said in an emailed statement that a discounted fare for \"vulnerable\" people is one of the options being studied and that discussions with the Transportation Ministry and the advisory group are ongoing.\n\nThe ministry said interconnectivity of services along Highway 16 has been part of discussions and that Via Rail was included to determine what role it could play to increase transportation options.\n\n\"We continue to engage with Via Rail on the idea of offering a discounted train fare to vulnerable First Nations people,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe group is slated to meet again next month.\n\nAs for the promised new bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert, the ministry said the first of more than 20 public information sessions hosted by BC Transit will start Saturday.\n\nBC Transit said Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada, which is part of the advisory group, has provided $1 million in funding for features including enhanced bus stop shelters and CCTV cameras to ensure passengers' safety along the corridor.\n\nThe route provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nMost of the cases of murdered and missing women remain unsolved, but police have said it's believed that more than one killer is involved.\n\nSign up for the B.C. {"url": "http://www.660news.com/2017/09/25/highway-of-tears-walk-to-wrap-in-smithers-b-c-ahead-of-mmiw-inquiry-hearing/", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears before missing, murdered Indigenous women hearing", "body": "Calgary\nAbout Us\nSubmit News Tips\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nTraffic\nGas Prices\nContests & Events\nWATCH LIVE\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nFamilies walk Highway of Tears before missing, murdered Indigenous women hearing\n\nBy News Staff\n\nPosted Sep 25, 2017 2:00 am.\n\n \n\nLast Updated Sep 26, 2017 7:00 am.\n\nThis article is more than 5 years old.\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2013 Gladys Radek raised a fist in the air and wept as she reached the end of her 350-kilometre journey along British Columbia\u2019s Highway of Tears.\n\nThe Indigenous grandmother finished her walk along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 for the seventh and final time on Monday. It is the same highway where her beloved niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared.\n\nOutside a community centre in Smithers, B.C., her voice shook as she spoke to those who had walked alongside her, including commissioners from the national inquiry into missing and murdered women.\n\n\u201cI want to thank you all for standing so proud and loud, to show our commissioners that we have love for our missing and murdered women,\u201d she said through tears.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very proud of this moment right now because when Tamara went missing, nobody cared. When Tamara went missing, there were many others who were already missing, many others who had been murdered.\u201d\n\nDozens of women have disappeared or been killed along the highway between Prince Rupert and Prince George in central B.C.\n\nRadek and other family members and advocates left Prince Rupert on Thursday and arrived Monday in Smithers, where the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls will hold hearings starting Tuesday.\n\nThe walkers were accompanied by vehicles and have covered sections of the route in a relay fashion, allowing them to complete the walk of hundreds of kilometres over the span of a few days.\n\nDuring the final stretch through the town of Smithers, Radek, who is missing a leg, drove a car covered in photographs of women who have disappeared or been killed. She wept behind the wheel as passersby waved and honked their horns.\n\nInquiry commissioner Michele Audette joined the group three days ago, while Chief Commissioner Marion Buller joined on Monday. Commissioner Qajaq Robinson was supposed to attend the hearings but had to bow out due to a family emergency.\n\nAudette said she walked to honour the resilience and strength of the families who will be speaking for the first time to the inquiry. The hearings will be powerful, she said.\n\n\u201cI feel it since I arrived, there\u2019s a lot of emotion, lots of anxiety also or stress, because it\u2019s the first time for them,\u201d she said. \u201cJust being there beside them and listening, maybe it\u2019s helped.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry has been plagued by controversy, including the resignation of commissioner Marilyn Poitras this summer and complaints from families about poor communications and delays.\n\nBuller told a Senate committee last week that the inquiry\u2019s work has been hampered by federal bureaucracy.\n\nRhonda Lee McIsaac, who lives in Haida Gwaii and has Ojibway heritage, participated in the walk for the first time and said it was a moving experience.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m walking for everybody who cannot walk,\u201d said McIsaac. \u201cI have lost a loved one. I grew up in foster care and I was adopted out. This is part of my story.\u201d\n\nMore than 40 people have signed up to speak at the Smithers hearings, which run through Thursday. They are the second hearings held by the inquiry after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nThe inquiry is set to visit nine communities this fall, including Edmonton, Winnipeg and Thunder Bay, Ont.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nCalgary daycare closes due to E. coli case\nCalgarian says 'no more work' after record-breaking lotto win\nCalgary taekwondo instructor facing child pornography charges\nCalgary mayor says residents can return to normal water use\nWhat to know ahead of the 2024 Calgary Stampede Parade\nTop Stories\nCalgary taekwondo instructor facing child pornography charges\n\n4h ago\n\nCalgary daycare closes due to E. coli case\n\n4h ago\n\nRoad closures, transit detours and more: What to know for Calgary Stampede Parade day\n\n3h ago\n\nFirst Flip breakfast unofficially begins 2024 Calgary Stampede\n\n35m ago\n\nMost Watched Today\n1:05\nCalgary unveils 'Blue Sky City' logo\n\nMonths after the City of Calgary dumped \u2018Be Part of the Energy\u2019 for \u2018Blue Sky City\u2019 \u2014 a new logo with a sunny disposition has been unveiled to accompany the new slogan. The route also provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nA list of the victims along B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears\n\nMost cases of murdered and missing women remain unsolved, though investigators don\u2019t believe a single killer is responsible.\n\nThe daily email you need for Edmonton's top news stories.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone says agreements between 16 communities along the highway will allow B.C. Transit to operate a scheduled bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert.\n\n\u201cAbsolutely, this initiative is all about safety,\u201d he said.\n\nMORE ON BC\n2 prominent B.C. Transit must still develop service schedules and provide extra buses for the route.\n\nStone said plans for the Highway 16 area also include offering bus driver training programs for First Nations to provide transportation service from their remote villages to other major communities along the highway.\n\nChief Corrina Leween of the Cheslatta Carrier Nation said the bus service helps many living in towns on or near the highway, but it offers little comfort to those off the main road.\n\nREAD MORE:\u00a0B.C. commits $3 million to improve safety along Highway of Tears\n\n\u201cThe work they are 'Highway of Tears'", "body": "Toronto\nAbout\nContact\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nTraffic\nGas Prices\nContests & Events\nWATCH LIVE\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nB.C. and federal governments promise unbroken cell service on \u2018Highway of Tears\u2019\n\nBy The Canadian Press\n\nPosted April 7, 2021 3:08 pm.\n\n \n\nLast Updated April 7, 2021 3:24 pm.\n\nThe federal and British Columbia governments say seamless cellular coverage will be provided along the Highway of Tears by October 2022.\n\nSeventy per cent of Highway 16 already has some coverage, but Lisa Beare, B.C.\u2019s minister of citizens\u2019 services, says the $11.7-million project will bring cell service to the remaining 252 kilometres between Smithers and Prince Rupert.\n\nThe project is set to begin this spring and will add 12 cell towers as well as improve connectivity at three rest stops, with the province and Ottawa each contributing just over $2 million and Rogers Communications picking up the remainder of the bill.\n\nHighway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert became known as the Highway of Tears more than two decades ago, a reference to the many Indigenous women who have gone missing or been murdered along the route since the 1970s.\n\nIn a separate announcement, the B.C. government says nearly $5 million in cell service upgrades is coming to Highway 14 on Vancouver Island between Sooke and Port Renfrew, with work expected to be complete by late October.\n\nThe Highway 14 improvements will bring cell service to Port Renfrew, Shirley, Otter Point, Jordan River and some Pacheedaht First Nation communities.\n\nMaryam Monsef, the federal minister for women and gender equality and rural economic development, says the Highway 16 upgrade marks a milestone for Aboriginal communities.\n\nShe told an online news conference it is the first universal broadband cell project being funded that will \u201cprimarily benefit Indigenous communities, but it will not be the last.\u201d\u00a0\n\nBoth Beare and Monsef said better cell service makes everyone safer.\u00a0\n\n\u201cKnowing that people will be able to travel Highway 16 without worrying about gaps in coverage is exactly the kind of result we want to see on every community highway and in every rural and Indigenous community,\u201d Beare said.\n\nThe Highway of Tears Symposium Report made 33 recommendations in 2006, including solving the problem of cellular gaps between the handful of communities along the 725-kilometre corridor.\n\nRCMP files link a total of 18 murders or disappearances to the region, but Carrier Sekani Family Services in Prince George says on its website that the number likely exceeds 40.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published April 7, 2021.\n\nCompanies in this story: (TSX:RCI.B)\n\nThe Canadian Press\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nTorontonians can now toss their "Vancouver\nAbout\nContact\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nTraffic\nContests & Events\nWATCH LIVE\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nHighway of Tears bus service to run from Prince George to Prince Rupert\n\nBy Kenny Mason\n\nPosted June 15, 2016 2:26 pm.\n\nThis article is more than 5 years old.\n\nPRINCE GEORGE \u2013 The British Columbia government says a bus service will be available between Prince George and Prince Rupert by the end of the year on a notorious stretch of road known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or have disappeared along Highway 16 and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone says agreements between 16 communities along the highway will allow BC Transit to operate a scheduled bus service, slated to start at the end of the year.\n\nFirst Nations, social service agencies and women\u2019s groups have called for a shuttle bus service in the area to provide safe, regular transportation for people who live in communities along the highway.\n\nThe provincial government announced a five-point transportation plan late last year that promised regular BC Transit service and programs to train bus drivers from area First Nation communities.\n\nStone says the BC government is providing an extra $1 million to run the bus service while the federal government is contributing $1 million to fund bus shelters, lights and webcams along the route.\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nTwo young Indian men identified as victims of West
