By continuing to browse, you accept the use of cookies and other technologies.\n\nI\u00a0UNDERSTAND\nLEARN\u00a0MORE\nBIZARRE\nFILM AND TV\nBOOKS\nMYSTERY\nTRUE CRIME\nCREEPY CRATE\nPODCAST\nABOUT US\nSHOP\nDEALS\nSUBSCRIBE\nHOMETRUE CRIME\nThe Highway of Tears: Canada\u2019s Killing Fields\n\nBy did you know? | Published Mar 17, 2017\nPhoto Credit: Wikimedia Commons\n\nBritish Columbia is known for its beautiful mountains and picturesque landscapes, but something sinister has been lurking beneath the pristine scenery of a remote, sparsely populated section of the Canadian province for decades. Authorities believe a serial killer\u2014or serial killers\u2014has been at work in an isolated part of British Columbia since 1969. Since then, dozens of women have disappeared or been murdered by unknown killers stalking victims along the highway.\n\nA 450-mile stretch of road between Prince George and Prince Rupert along Highway 16 is known as the \u201cHighway of Tears\u201d because of the high number of women who have disappeared or been murdered along the road. The highway cuts through rural logging towns and impoverished Native American\u00a0reservations with vast swaths of wilderness in between. Many of the missing and murdered women along the Highway of Tears are indigenous.\n\nThe Royal Mounted Canadian Police has a special unit dedicated to the area, and it has linked 18 cases along the highway from 1969 to 2006. But local indigenous leaders estimate that up to 50 girls and women have been murdered or have gone missing along the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe indigenous people living around the Highway of Tears believe the killings never received the attention they deserved because of the low socioeconomic and social standing of native peoples within Canadian society.\n\nRelated: A Walk in the Woods: 7 of the World\u2019s Most Haunted Forests and Woodlands\u00a0\n\nPhoto Credit: Wikimedia Commons\n\nWant more unsolved cases? Sign up for The Lineup's newsletter, and get the strangest tales delivered straight to your inbox.\n\nSubscribe\nYes! I also want to get the Early Bird Books newsletter featuring great deals on ebooks.\n\nIndeed, indigenous communities in Canada have higher than average levels of poverty, alcoholism, and substance abuse compared to the rest of Canadian towns and cities. Carolyn Bennett, the minister of indigenous and northern affairs, says that the families of the murdered and missing women believe that the police treat their loved ones\u2019 deaths \u201cas inevitable, as if their lives mattered less.\u201d\n\nRelated: 20 Unsolved Murders That Will Send Shivers Down Your Spine\u00a0\n\nBritish Columbia\u2019s government plans to improve safety along Highway 16 by installing safety cameras and giving indigenous communities funding for vehicles. Right now the remote communities along Highway 16 have very little lighting on the road, and the only public transportation available is infrequent Greyhound buses.\n\nIn October, CBC Radio One\u2019s The Current released a virtual reality documentary called Highway of Tears. The documentary focuses on the case of Ramona Wilson, a 16-year-old girl from Smithers, British Columbia, who disappeared on her way to a nearby town in 1994. Wilson\u2019s body was found the following year, but, like many others along Highway 16, her murder remains unsolved.\n\nRelated: Creepy Drive: 6 Haunted Roads from Around the World\n\nTo this day, police are confounded at their lack of progress in catching the serial killer\u2014or killers\u2014who has left this path of destruction along Highway 16. A staff sergeant in the Royal Mounted Canadian Police recently told the CBC that many of the killings may never be solved: \u201cThat\u2019s the reality, and that\u2019s what I tell the families.\u201d\n\nPolice have keyed in on several suspects, including a deceased American rapist and murderer named Bobby Jack Fowler, and they have actually charged serial killer Cody Legebokoff with one of the murders, but the overwhelming majority of the killings along Highway 16 remain a mystery.\n\nRelated: 6 Scary Serial Killers Who Were Never Caught and May Still Be on the Loose\u00a0\u00a0\n\nFeatured photo: Wikimedia Commons\n\nThis story was first published on did you know?\n\nRead More:\n\nAmelia Earhart May Not Have Died in a Plane Crash After All\n\nThe Real Life Inspiration for Pigman in American Horror Story: Roanoke\n\n12 of the Coolest Things People Found with Metal Detectors\n\ndid you know?\nMysterious Death\nUnsolved Crimes\nDisappearances\n\n\n\n\nGet our eeriest tales and best book deals delivered straight to your inbox.\nSubscribe\nYes! {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/highway-of-tears/cp35419018", "title": "Smithers Highway of Tears gathering: another roadblock or road to bus line? | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kelowna and |\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nSunny\u00a0 26.4\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nSmithers Highway of Tears gathering: another roadblock or road to bus line?\nDirk Meissner\nNovember 22, 2015 - 1:00 AM\n\nVICTORIA - Community leaders along British Columbia's notorious Highway of Tears meet this week to debate the highly charged issue of improving safety along the route that cuts across the centre of the province.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or disappeared along Highway 16 and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nFirst Nations' leaders and the Opposition New Democrats say government roadblocks in the form of endless meetings over transportation solutions that go nowhere must come down to improving safety.\n\nUp to 100 people are expected to be in Smithers to review locally developed transportation options along the 750-kilometre highway corridor, but Transportation Minister Todd Stone won't attend and said he would leave the discussion up to local officials.\n\nStone describes the Tuesday meeting as information gathering and non-political.\n\nNorth Coast New Democrat MLA Jennifer Rice, who represents the Prince Rupert area, wanted to go to the meeting, but said she wasn't invited.\n\n\"I understand the chief administrative officers (from communities) are invited because those are the practical people. Minister Stone is always talking about practical solutions, and I guess those are the practical people who implement practical things.\"\n\nRepresentatives from 23 First Nations along the corridor, municipal governments and the B.C. government will attend the day-long meeting.\n\nA government statement said the gathering will review previous community transportation reports, including a 2006 report that called for bus service between communities and the 2012 Missing Women Commission of Inquiry that recommended enhanced transportation in the area.\n\nRegional politician Bill Miller said many agree that Highway 16 is too geographically challenged for a region-wide bus service, but there's concern about government stalling.\n\n\"Sometimes it seems like we've just been put on a treadmill,\" said Miller, an elected member of the Bulkley-Nechako Regional District. \"We have some cost-effective and efficient solutions.\"\n\nHe said a more workable system would link neighbours like Vanderhoof, Fort St. James and Fraser Lake and would ease safety concerns for those who have to travel the route.\n\n\"The underlying issue is vulnerability of women in general, First Nations women in specific.\"\n\nBut he said local governments need the province to help communities get the locally driven transportation system.\n\n\"We're going to send some people to the symposium in Smithers and hopefully get them to understand that this is a significant issue.\"\n\nStone said he agrees with some locals that a shuttle-bus service along the entire route isn't practical. But the NDP said that recently released documents contradict Stone and highlight the concerns of local officials who say a bus service should be considered.\n\n\"A lot of people are feeling this is past due and this is time to take action,\" said Rice.\n\nAmong the more than 600 pages of recently released government documents are bus service estimates, pegging costs of a six-day-a-week, Prince Rupert to Prince George bus at less than $1 million annually.\n\nFinance Minister Mike de Jong said last week he expects to deliver a quarterly financial update that includes improved financial forecasts, fuelling speculation the government has some money for targeted initiatives.\n\nStone recently acknowledged the highway issue could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada's murdered and missing women.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2015\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are emailed reader responses to stories or letters to...\nChefs mourn for Okanagan's peaches but adapt to stone Minister Stone is always talking about practical solutions, and I guess those are the practical people who implement practical things.\"\n\nRepresentatives from 23 First Nations along the corridor, municipal governments and the B.C. government will attend the day-long meeting.\n\nA government statement said the gathering will review previous community transportation reports, including a 2006 report that called for bus service between communities and the 2012 Missing Women Commission of Inquiry that recommended enhanced transportation in the area.\n\nRegional politician Bill Miller said many agree that Highway 16 is too geographically challenged for a region-wide bus service, but there's concern about government stalling.\n\n\"Sometimes it seems like we've just been put on a treadmill,\" said Miller, an elected member of the Bulkley-Nechako Regional District. \"We have some cost-effective and efficient solutions.\"\n\nHe said a more workable system would link neighbours like Vanderhoof, Fort St. James and Fraser Lake and would ease safety concerns for those who have to travel the route.\n\n\"The underlying issue is vulnerability of women in general, First Nations women in specific.\"\n\nBut he said local governments need the province to help communities get the locally driven transportation system.\n\n\"We're going to send some people to the symposium in Smithers and hopefully get them to understand that this is a significant issue.\"\n\nStone said he agrees with some locals that a shuttle-bus service along the entire route isn't practical. But the NDP said that recently released documents contradict Stone and highlight the concerns of local officials who say a bus service should be considered.\n\n\"A lot of people are feeling this is past due and this is time to take action,\" said Rice.\n\nAmong the more than 600 pages of recently released government documents are bus service estimates, pegging costs of a six-day-a-week, Prince Rupert to Prince George bus at less than $1 million annually.\n\nFinance Minister Mike de Jong said last week he expects to deliver a quarterly financial update that includes improved financial forecasts, fuelling speculation the government has some money for targeted initiatives.\n\nStone recently acknowledged the highway issue could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada's murdered and missing women.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The {"url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/b-c-commits-3-million-to-improve-safety-along-highway-of-tears-1.2700281", "title": "B.C. commits $3 million to improve safety along Highway of Tears | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFOLLOW ON\n\n    \n\n\nPOLITICS\nB.C. commits $3 million to improve safety along Highway of Tears\nGeordon Omand\nThe Canadian Press\n\n\nPublished Monday, December 14, 2015 7:49PM EST\nLast Updated Monday, December 14, 2015 9:04PM EST\n\nThe Yellowhead, Highway 16, near Prince George, B.C., is pictured on October 8, 2012. (Jonathan Hayward / The Canadian Press)\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nVICTORIA -- Enhanced transit routes, expanded driver-training programs and more roadside webcams make up the core of a multimillion-dollar plan aimed at improving safety along a stretch of British Columbia highway renowned for missing and murdered women.\n\nB.C.'s Transport Minister Todd Stone announced a long-awaited $3-million strategy for the so-called Highway of Tears on Monday, saying delays in government action were the result of extensive consultation with local stakeholders.\n\n\"I would have liked to have been making this announcement many, many, many months ago, but we needed to go through this rigorous process of engagement and discussion,\" said Stone. \"Today is about transitioning from the discussion to action.\"\n\nRelated Stories\nB.C. community leaders meet to discuss safety on notorious Highway of Tears\nDocuments on Highway of Tears open wounds as missing-women inquiry looms\nB.C. transportation minister says changes coming to Highway of Tears\n\nEighteen women, many of them aboriginal, have disappeared or been murdered along Highway 16 or adjacent routes since the 1970s. The infamous 750-kilometre span of road meanders through an isolated region of B.C.'s Interior, between Prince Rupert and Prince George.\n\nStone's announcement comes shortly after the federal government went public with plans to launch a national inquiry into missing and murdered indigenous women. Many who have called for the inquiry have highlighted the tragic history of the Highway of Tears.\n\nAn RCMP report stated last year nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing across Canada between 1980 and 2012.\n\nMonday's announcement in B.C. committed $1.6 million over two years on a cost-sharing basis with communities to extend pre-existing transit along Highway 16.\n\nAn additional $750,000 over three years will go towards helping communities buy and operate transit vehicles, as well as $150,000 over three years to increase the number of licensed drivers in First Nations communities.\n\nThe province earmarked a final $500,000 in infrastructure funding over two years to install more transit shelters and highway webcams.\n\n\"In addition to enhancing the actual transportation options that people have in the corridor, we want people to also know that we have an eye on safety as well,\" said Stone.\n\nOverseeing the program's implementation is an advisory panel, made up of representatives from the province, local governments, health authorities and First Nations.\n\nBurns Lake Mayor Luke Strimbold, who is part of the advisory group, said the $3-million funding announcement marks historic progress in improving safety along Highway 16.\n\n\"Our communities now have a framework we can work towards to implement transportation solutions,\" said Strimbold.\n\nFirst Nations Health Authority spokesman Richard Jock is also on the board and shared Strimbold's optimism. He emphasized the opportunity to improve access to health care for people living in remote communities.\n\n\"We're looking forward to working in particular with our northern health partners to see how this can really be part of effective transportation response in the North,\" he said.\n\nSmithers Mayor Taylor Bachrach spoke positively about the government's plan, but at the same time raised concerns.\n\n\"The key question is whether the amount of resources that are being put on the table are going to be adequate to fix the problem,\" he said.\n\n\"I'm not sure that $1.6 million over two years is going to provide affordable, accessible transportation for all of the small communities in our region. The problem is somewhat larger.\"\n\nNew Democrat member of the legislature and northern health critic Jennifer Rice questioned if the plan's cost-sharing approach would be financially feasible for all northern communities.\n\n\"Families of murdered and missing women have been waiting for some action for well over a decade,\" she said.\n\n\"But having some money put towards improving transportation in the North is positive.\"\n\nStone said the government will have a better idea about how the funding will be distributed after the advisory panel meets with local groups and reports back to him by early March.\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport an error\nEditorial standards and\u00a0policies\nWhy you can trust CTV\u00a0News\nREAD MORE POLITICS NEWS\nMontreal MP, Jewish group condemn antisemitic poster telling him to 'get out of Canada'\nDeputy prime minister says 'vast, vast majority' of Liberal caucus supports Trudeau\nConservatives paid $8.5M on advertising in 2023, trouncing Liberals, NDP\nStreaming services challenge Canadian rules on revenue-sharing for news\nSask. files injunction in light of federal carbon tax dispute\nNewfoundland and Labrador premier takes aim at Ottawa over reopened cod fishery\nWATCH MORE POLITICS STORIES\nfalse\nCTV National News: What would make PM step aside?\nfalse\nCTV National News: Trouble for Trudeau?\nfalse\nPower Play: Plays and misplays\nfalse\nPower Play: Panel discusses PM's future\nfalse\nCTV National News: Growing calls to step down\nfalse\nTrend Line: New data from Nik Nanos\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSubscribe to our election alerts. But the NDP said that recently released documents contradict Stone and highlight the concerns of local officials who say a bus service should be considered.\n\n\u201cA lot of people are feeling this is past due and this is time to take action,\u201d said Rice.\n\nAmong the more than 600 pages of recently released government documents are bus service estimates, pegging costs of a six-day-a-week, Prince Rupert to Prince George bus at less than $1 million annually.\n\nFinance Minister Mike de Jong said last week he expects to deliver a quarterly financial update that includes improved financial forecasts, fuelling speculation the government has some money for targeted initiatives.\n\nStone recently acknowledged the highway issue could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada\u2019s murdered and missing women.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2015 The Canadian Press\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nADVERTISEMENT\n630 CHED Afternoons with Bryn Griffiths & Reid Wilkins\n2:00 PM - 5:00 PM\n630CHED\nTrending\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. {"url": "http://dyingwords.net/is-a-serial-killer-loose-on-the-highway-of-tears/", "title": "IS A SERIAL KILLER LOOSE ON THE HIGHWAY OF TEARS? - Dying Words", "body": "Dying Words\nProvoking Thoughts on Life, Death, and Writing\nSkip to content\nHOME ABOUT\nCHATGPT4 BIO\n \nTOE TAGS\n BOOKS TWENTY-SECOND CENTURY ENTERTAINMENT CITY OF DANGER DYINGWORDS BLOG WRITING RESOURCES FAMOUS DYING WORDS TOP 50 NAPOLEON HILL QUOTES CONTACT\nIS A SERIAL KILLER LOOSE ON THE HIGHWAY OF TEARS?\nThere\u2019s a lonely road stretch in remote northwestern British Columbia, Canada having a huge number of unsolved missing and murdered women cases. It spans 450 miles between the small cities of Prince George in the province\u2019s interior and Prince Rupert on the Pacific coast. Over the past 40 years, more than 40 women mysteriously disappeared or died from foul play in that area. Most of their circumstances remain unknown. The road\u2019s geographically known as #16 or the Yellowhead Route but\u2014for good reason\u2014locals call it the Highway of Tears.\nThe Highway of Tears murders and the women\u2019s suspicious disappearances began in 1969. They continue today with the last case of modus operandi (MO) similarities happening in December 2018. Although police officially remain cautious about confirming links, many in-the-know suspect there may be many more crimes with victims fitting the mold.\n\nIn 2005, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) formed a task force called E-Pana to look at the area\u2019s unsolved missing and murdered women cases. The RCMP is Canada\u2019s federal force having jurisdiction across the nation and in the region. The task force initially identified 18 cases but soon expanded their investigation to include similar files eastward along Route 16 to Hinton, Alberta as well as south along Highway 97 to Kamloops, BC and along Highway 5 from Merritt to Clearwater.\n\nTwo significant independent government inquiries or investigations into the Highway of Tears and related matters also happened. One was a British Columbia Provincial Symposium held in 2006. The other\u2014a recent, national commission called the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women Inquiry. It\u2019s called that because many victims were of indigenous or First Nations ethnicity.\n\nDespite the massive police and public effort, no one\u2019s been caught for most of the crimes. As well, many of the victim\u2019s bodies remain hidden and undiscovered. That leaves people wondering if there\u2019s a serial killer loose on the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe Highway of Tears Victims\n\nWithout exception, every victim in the Highway of Tears (HOT) sphere is female. That includes confirmed murders as well as unsolved disappearances. Another harsh fact is many victims originated from aboriginal or First Nations backgrounds. It\u2019s a reality that can\u2019t be overlooked.\n\nProject E-Pana (named so after the Inuit spirit that guides souls to the afterlife) used four criteria to qualify a murder or suspicious disappearance as a Highway of Tears or HOT case. These parameters were sound and valid, as many homicide and missing persons cases in the north have other circumstances that don\u2019t suggest a commonality the HOT files have. Out of great precaution, HOT investigators are very careful about using the \u201cSK-word\u201d\u2014Serial Killer. To be on the HOT list, the E-Pana victim profiles are:\n\nFemale\nHigh-risk lifestyle\nKnown to hitchhike\nFound or last seen near Highways 16, 97 & 5\n\nFemales who hitchhike and practice a high-risk lifestyle around this remote road network are easy prey. Many come from physical, sexual and substance abusive backgrounds. Many are sex workers and drug users as well as having alcoholic tendencies and serious mental/emotional disorders. And, many women victims are from indigenous communities with a host of social problems.\n\nPolice investigators feel most, if not all, Highway of Tears cases are stranger-to-stranger relationships. Police don\u2019t like the serial killer term because of public ramifications, but it\u2019s a classic serial killer pattern to pick up strangers and have their way. Most lone-operating killers leave little evidence behind at their crime scenes, take little with them, make sure there are no independent witnesses and they rarely confess. That combination makes these predators so hard to catch.\n\nFirst Nations women are particularly vulnerable. Along the main Highway of Tears stretch from Prince Rupert to Prince George there are 23 different indigenous communities or reserves. Most of these little places have few facilities like medical services, educational outlets and recreational opportunities. As well, poverty is a gigantic problem in Canada\u2019s First Peoples settlements. They simply can\u2019t afford private transportation.\n\nCombined with personal issues and the need to be mobile, many at-risk women are alone on side of the road with their thumb out. They\u2019re perfect opportunities for men with deviant desire. Here is a list of who fell victim in the deadly web called the Highway of Tears and throughout the entire region.\n\nGloria Moody \u2014 27, Murdered near Williams Lake, October 1969\nMicheline Pare \u2014 18, Murdered near Hudson\u2019s Hope, July 1970\nHelen Claire Frost \u2014 15, Missing from Prince George, October 1970\nJean Virginia Sampare \u2014 18, Missing from Hazelton, October 1971\nGayle Weys \u2014 19, Murdered near Clearwater, October 1973\nPamela Darlington \u2014 19, Murdered at Kamloops, November 1973\nColeen MacMillan \u2014 16, Murdered near Lac La Hache, August 1974\nMonica Ignas \u2014 15, Murdered near Terrace, December 1974\nMary Jane Hill \u2014 31, Murdered at Prince Rupert, March 1978\nMonica Jack \u2014 12, Murdered near Merritt, May 1978\nMaureen Mosie \u2014 33, Murdered near Salmon Arm, May 1981\nJean May Kovacs \u2014 36, Murdered at Prince George, October 1981\nRoswitha Fuchsbichler \u2014 13, Murdered at Prince George, November 1981\nNina Marie Joseph \u2014 15, Murdered at Prince George, August 1982\nShelley-Anne Bascu \u2014 16, Missing from Hinton, May 1983\nAlberta Gail Williams \u2014 24, Murdered near Prince Rupert, August\u00a0 1989\nCecilia Anne Nikal \u2014 15, Missing from Smithers, October 1989\nDelphine Anne Nikal \u2014 15, Missing from Smithers, June 1990\nTheresa Umphrey \u2014 38, Murdered near Prince George, February 1993\nMarnie Blanchard \u2014 18, Murdered near Prince George, March 1993\nRamona Lisa Wilson \u2014 16, Murdered near Smithers, June 1994\nRoxanne Thiara \u2014 15, Murdered near Burns Lake, November 1994\nAlishia Leah Germaine \u2014 15, Murdered at Prince George, November 1994\nLana Derrick \u2014 19, Missing from Terrace, October 1995\nDeena Braem \u2014 16, Murdered near Quesnel, September 1999\nMonica McKay \u2014 18, Murdered at Prince Rupert, December 1999\nNicole Hoar \u2014 24, Missing from Prince George, June 2002\nMary Madeline George \u2014 25, Missing from Prince George, July 2005\nTamara Lynn Chipman \u2014 22, Missing from Prince Rupert, September 2005\nAielah Saric Auger \u2014 14, Murdered at Prince George, February 2006\nBeverly Warbick \u2014 20, Missing from Prince George, June 2007\nBonnie Marie Joseph \u2014\u00a032, Missing from Vanderhoof, September 2007\nJill Stacey Stuchenko \u2014 35, Murdered near Prince George, October 2009\nEmmalee Rose McLean \u2014 16, Murdered at Prince Rupert, April 2010\nNatasha Lynn Montgomery \u2014 23, Murdered at Prince George, August 2010\nCynthia Frances Maas\u2014 35, Murdered near Prince George, September 2010\nLoren Dawn Leslie \u2014 15, Murdered near Prince George, November 2010\nMadison \u201cMaddy\u201d Scott \u2014 20, Missing near Vanderhoof, May 2011\nImmaculate \u201cMackie\u201d Basil \u2014 26, Missing near Fort St. James, June 2013\nAnita Florence Thorne \u2014 49, Missing from Prince George, November 2014\nRoberta Marie Sims \u2014 55, Missing from Prince George, May 2017\nFrances Brown \u2014 53, Missing near Smithers, October 2017\nChantelle Catherine Simpson \u2014 34, Suspicious Death at Terrace, July 2018\nJessica Patrick \u2014 18, Murdered near Smithers, September 2018\nCynthia Martin \u2014 50, Missing near Hazelton, December 2018\nThe Case for a Highway of Tears Serial Killer\n\nThese 40+ known cases all have a similarity beyond the E-Pana parameters. That\u2019s the peculiar pattern of how they met their fate. Investigators assume most victims did not know their assailant and unsuspectingly fell into a fatal trap. And that trap may have been set by a serial offender.\n\nBefore assuming that one or more serial killers have been on the loose in the E-Pana project and the entire cases associated to the general Highway of Tears area, it\u2019s necessary to define what a serial killer is. According to the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), a serial killer is an offender who commits \u201ca series of two or more murders, committed as separate events, usually, but not always, by one offender acting alone.\u201d Serial murder is defined as \u201cthe unlawful killing of two or more victims by the same offender(s), in separate events.\u201d\n\nThis is a fairly tight description for a multiple killer. It fits someone on a path or destiny rather than a mass-murderer who goes on one rampage and causes numerous deaths. Most people associate serial killers with notorious Americans like Ted Bundy, Gary Ridgway or Albert DeSalvo. They were particularly nasty people. But, British Columbia had its share of these vicious villains. Noteworthy BC serial killers were Clifford Olson who killed 10 or more children and Robert \u201cWillie\u201d Pickton who did-in 49 women and fed them to his pigs.\n\nMost serial killers operate alone and have a distinctive pattern or modus operandi. Experienced police investigators know to look for crime patterns and identify similarities. One of the main indicators is victim profiling. In almost all of the cases brought under the Highway of Tears investigation umbrella, the victim\u2019s background and vulnerability stand out. Other indicators are the time frame and location.\n\nIn missing persons cases, investigators naturally start with where and when the victim was last seen. They also look for abandoned items such as a vehicle, their purse and contents or their phone. Where bodies are found, investigators look for the mechanism or means of death. Most of the Highway of Tears and related victims were strangled\u2014the exact strangulation method being held back as it\u2019s known only to the police and the perpetrator.\n\nIn the Highway of Tears periphery\u2014and it is a periphery because what started as an investigation along the Prince George to Prince Rupert road quickly branched off to a much bigger area where a mobile serial killer could have easily traveled within a day. What\u2019s really notable in this overall murder and missing persons combined investigation are the time periods. There are nine distinct activity calendar groups:\n\n1969-1974\n1978\n1981-1983\n1989-1990\n1993-1995\n1999-2002\n2005-2007\n2009-2014\n2017-2018\n\nThis date grouping shows a burst of start-stop, start-stop and start-stop. There could be many reasons for this such as the perpetrator being repeatedly incarcerated, moving out of the geographical area or, in the case of Gary Ridgway\u2014the Green River Killer from Seattle\u2014he nearly got caught and thought he\u2019d give it a rest for a while. But, it seems more likely there are multiple offenders in the overall Highway of Tears file. In fact, police have already caught, convicted or identified five different HOT-profile men.\n\nThe Police Catch or Identify Serial Killers in the Highway of Tears Investigation\n\nTo be fair, not all the murdered or missing women in the previous list are true Highway of Tears victims from BC Highways 16, 97 & 5. As the investigation grew, it expanded to include a wide net of confirmed or suspected murders across the mid-section of semi-rural British Columbia. That was a natural progression. It\u2019s a logical and competent way of investigating a broad range of offense dates and locations.\n\nLong before the E-Pana probe in 2005, which started as a look at the cases on Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert, the RCMP knew there was a pattern emerging. In 1981, they held a multi-jurisdictional meeting called The Highway Murders Conference to look at commonalities of historic unsolved murders and missing persons cases. Over 40 detectives from across BC and Alberta met in Kamloops and presented their case facts. This was the original start to a massive investigation that\u2019s still highly-active today.\n\nIn the years following the Highway Murder Conference, the RCMP and other law enforcement agencies solved some of the \u201cHOT\u201d killings and disappearances. They were able to profile offenders under the FBI\u2019s serial killer definition. Here are the five serial killers known to have committed murders on the overall HOT list.\n\n1. Cody Alan Legebokoff\u00a0 \u2014 He was convicted of the 2009/2010 Jill Stuchenko, Natasha Montgomery, Loren Leslie and Cynthia Maas murders near Prince George. Legebokoff is serving life in prison.\n\n2. Brian Peter Arp \u2014 He was convicted of the 1989 near-Prince George murders of Theresa Umphrey and Marnie Blanchard. Arp is also serving a life sentence.\n\n3. Edward Dennis Issac \u2014 He was convicted of the 1981/1892 murders of Nina Joseph, Jean Kovacs and Roswitha Fuchsbichler in Prince George. Issac is still serving out his life sentence\n\n4, Gary Wayne Hanlin \u2014 He was convicted of the 1978 Monica Jack murder at Merritt and faces new charges for killing another pre-teen girl. Hanlin got a life sentence, as well.\n\n5. Bobby Jack Fowler \u2014 This known serial killer died in an Oregon prison in 1986. Post-death DNA analysis linked Fowler to causing the 1973/1974 Kamloops area murders of Coleen McMillan, Gail Weys and Pamela Darlington. Given the time frame pattern and location, Fowler may also have killed Monica Ignas in Terrace.\n\nKnown Highway of Tears Serial Killer Bobby Jack Fowler \u2013 MacMillan, Weys & Darlington murders\n\nThe Highway of Tears Public Investigations and Inquiries\n\nOver the years, the mass of unsolved murders and missing women\u2019s cases have been front and center in British Columbia and Canadian spectrums. Local, national and international interest spread, and took on a scope much larger than the cases committed along the original roadway called the Highway of Tears. Hundreds of thousands of hours and millions of dollar have been exhausted trying to rectify what went wrong and how future tragedies could be prevented.\n\nIn 2006, the British Columbia probe called the Highway of Tears Symposium released a report with an objective look at the entire factors causing victim vulnerability. They made rational and constructive recommendations that, if correctly implemented, could drastically reduce the potential for other women to end up on the HOT list. The symposium divided their solution into these four categories:\n\nVictim Prevention\nEmergency Planning and Team Readiness\nVictim Family Counselling and Support\nCommunity Development and Support\n\nThe Highway of Tears Symposium offered 33 separate recommendations on how to reduce victim risk and how to organize a holistic crime prevention program throughout the at-risk region. Most of the recommendations were solid, common-sense steps that could be practically implemented. One of the primary actions was to increase public transit along Highway 16 so the women wouldn\u2019t need to hitchhike.\n\nOther smart points in the action plan were making the police and public officials more responsible for spotting women placing themselves at risk and intervening on the side of the road. The report recommended a network of safe houses and a community watch program be integrated across the area. Many more recommendations addressed education and economic support for vulnerable women.\n\nIt\u2019s been 13 years since the Highway of Tears Symposium did its necessary and valuable work. Sadly, very few of their well-thought-out suggestions ever materialized. An example is that it took 11 years before a simple and reliably-scheduled public transit bus service hit the Yellowhead Highway. Some of the risk prevention literature has been well written and promoted, though.\n\nThe Canadian Federal Government\u2019s cross-country consortium called the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (IMMIWG) took public problem probing to a whole new level. What started as a Highway of Tears inquiry expanding the plight of First Nations women turned into a f-fest where three of the leading commissioners quit in frustration and disgust. It seemed everyone with a grievance to grind and an agenda to advance hijacked the focus and spun it around. By the time the $53.8 million off-track inquisition ended, the indigenous women core concern expanded to include every fringe interest lumped into a category called 2SLGBTQQIA. That\u2019s an acronym for 2 Spirit, Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Questioning, Intersex and Asexual.\n\nOn June 4, 2019, the Canadian Prime Minister championed the IMMIWG report release with this quote, \u201cEarlier this morning, the national inquiry formally presented their report, in which they found that the tragic violence that Indigenous women and girls have experienced amounts to genocide\u201d. The Prime Minister\u2019s critics were quick to point out the United Nations definition of genocide:\n\n\u201cAny of the following acts committed with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, as such: killing members of the group; causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group; deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life, calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part; imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group; [and] forcibly transferring children of the group to another group.\u201d\n\nWhat started as a well-intentioned review of what happened to cause the Highway of Tears-related murders and suspicious disappearances totally missed the mark in the Canadian Federal Government\u2019s sights. While the HOT Symposium operated with honorable intentions, the IMMIWG was a farce. It contributed little, if nothing, to the cause and likely did more harm than good. The IMMIWG failed to make positive recommendations for future harm prevention and investigation improvements. Ultimately, the IMMIWG blamed colonialism for oppressive behavior on margins of society. It seems the IMMIWG forgot many of the Highway of Tears victims were white heterosexual women born and raised in mainstream Canada.\n\nIs a Serial Killer Loose on the Highway of Tears?\n\nThe answer is yes and no. There isn\u2019t , and never has been, one lone serial killer continually at work on the Highway of Tears or in the surrounding geographical area. The right answer is there are many serial killers out there who\u2019ve traveled those remote highways for years. Without a doubt, at least five separate serial killers contributed to some of the forty-year carnage. It\u2019s highly-likely a large number of the yet-unsolved cases are the work of still-to-be-caught perpetrators. And, it\u2019s also highly-likely some murders and abductions are one-offs.\n\nWill all the Highway of Tears related murders eventually be solved? It\u2019s highly-unlikely that\u2019ll happen given the time gone by and the limited evidence available. However, there\u2019s good reason to be optimistic some old and cold cases will be cleared. Back in the 70s, no one saw how powerful forensic DNA typing would be. We\u2019re only now starting to tap the new familial database mines. Back in the 70s, no one saw how effective the Mister Big undercover sting would work on serial killers. And, back in the 70s, information sharing was nothing like what\u2019s happening today.\n\nSo, no one knows what\u2019s to come. Thanks to high-tech science combining with cool cop creative minds, we\u2019re in for an interesting crime-solving drive down the Highway of Tears.\n\nFacebook\nMastodon\nEmail\nShare\nThis entry was posted in Forensics, Life & Death and tagged Bobby Jack Fowler, Brian Peter Arp, British Columbia, Canada, Canadian, Cody Legebokoff, Edward Dennis Isaac, FBI Definition, Gary Wayne Hanlin, Highway of Tears, Missing Murdered Indigenous Women Girls, Murders, National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Project E-Pana, RCMP, Serial Killer, Serial Killings, Symposium, Yellowhead 16 on August 24, 2019.\nPost navigation\n\u2190 IS MISSING MALAYSIA AIRLINES FLIGHT 370 A MASS MURDER?\nIS THE MEANING OF LIFE A HAM SANDWICH? {"url": "http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/bc-community-meeting-to-focus-on-improving-safety-on-highway-of-tears/article27434563/", "title": "B.C. community meeting to focus on improving safety on Highway of Tears - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nB.C. community meeting to focus on improving safety on Highway of Tears\nDIRK MEISSNER\nVICTORIA\nTHE CANADIAN PRESS\nPUBLISHED NOVEMBER 22, 2015\n\nThis article was published more than 8 years ago. Some information may no longer be current.\n\nA stretch of the Highway of Tears runs through a small Aboriginal community east of Prince Rubert, British Columbia, pictured on March 21, 2011. There are 18 unsolved cases involving women reported missing or found dead along the highway.\nRAFAL GERSZAK/THE GLOBE AND MAIL\n\nCOMMENTS\nSHARE\n\nCommunity leaders along British Columbia's notorious Highway of Tears meet this week to debate the highly charged issue of improving safety along the route that cuts across the centre of the province.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or disappeared along Highway 16 and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nFirst Nations' leaders and the Opposition New Democrats say government roadblocks in the form of endless meetings over transportation solutions that go nowhere must come down to improving safety.\n\nUp to 100 people are expected to be in Smithers to review locally developed transportation options along the 750-kilometre highway corridor, but Transportation Minister Todd Stone won't attend and said he would leave the discussion up to local officials.\n\nMr. Stone describes the Tuesday meeting as information gathering and non-political.\n\nNorth Coast New Democrat MLA Jennifer Rice, who represents the Prince Rupert area, wanted to go to the meeting, but said she wasn't invited.\n\n\"I understand the chief administrative officers (from communities) are invited because those are the practical people. Minister Stone is always talking about practical solutions, and I guess those are the practical people who implement practical things.\"\n\nRepresentatives from 23 First Nations along the corridor, municipal governments and the B.C. government will attend the day-long meeting.\n\nA government statement said the gathering will review previous community transportation reports, including a 2006 report that called for bus service between communities and the 2012 Missing Women Commission of Inquiry that recommended enhanced transportation in the area.\n\nRegional politician Bill Miller said many agree that Highway 16 is too geographically challenged for a region-wide bus service, but there's concern about government stalling.\n\n\"Sometimes it seems like we've just been put on a treadmill,\" said Miller, an elected member of the Bulkley-Nechako Regional District. \"We have some cost-effective and efficient solutions.\"\n\nHe said a more workable system would link neighbours such as Vanderhoof, Fort St. James and Fraser Lake and would ease safety concerns for those who have to travel the route.\n\n\"The underlying issue is vulnerability of women in general, First Nations women in specific.\"\n\nBut he said local governments need the province to help communities get the locally driven transportation system.\n\n\"We're going to send some people to the symposium in Smithers and hopefully get them to understand that this is a significant issue.\"\n\nMr. Stone said he agrees with some locals that a shuttle-bus service along the entire route isn't practical. But the NDP said that recently released documents contradict Stone and highlight the concerns of local officials who say a bus service should be considered.\n\n\"A lot of people are feeling this is past due and this is time to take action,\" Ms. Rice said.\n\nAmong the more than 600 pages of recently released government documents are bus service estimates, pegging costs of a six-day-a-week, Prince Rupert to Prince George bus at less than $1-million annually.\n\nFinance Minister Mike de Jong said last week he expects to deliver a quarterly financial update that includes improved financial forecasts, fuelling speculation the government has some money for targeted initiatives.\n\nMr. Stone recently acknowledged the highway issue could be swept up in a call by the federal Liberal government for an inquiry into Canada's murdered and missing women.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nSign up for the B.C. Insider Newsletter.\n\nB.C. {"url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10469583/red-dresses-fashion-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Red dresses to make fashion statement about missing and murdered Indigenous women | Globalnews.ca", "body": "SKIP TO MAIN CONTENT\nSUBSCRIBE\nRADIO\nLIVE\nSite theme toggle. Switch between light or dark mode\nLIGHT\nDARK\nGlobalNews home\nWatch\nWorld\nCanada\nLocal\nPolitics\nMoney\nHealth\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nPerspectives\nSports\nCommentary\nContests\nPodcasts\nU.S. News\nShopping\nFull Menu\nSearch Menu\nCANADA\nRed dresses to make fashion statement about missing and murdered Indigenous women\nBy Kelly Geraldine Malone  The Canadian Press\nPosted May 4, 2024 7:47 am\n Updated May 5, 2024 3:02 pm\n 3 min read\nThe Tsleil-Waututh Nation held the annual Red Dress Day outside the North Vancouver RCMP detachment on Friday morning. Members of the First Nation spoke, danced and drummed in red dresses \u2013 May 3, 2024\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nModels in uniquely designed red dresses are taking to the runway in British Columbia this weekend to make a powerful fashion statement about missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\n\n\u201cThe stories that come out through the fashion are deeply moving,\u201d says Kim Coltman, organizer of the two-day Revolutions Red Dress Fashion Festival in Kamloops.\n\nThe 63-year-old former model says the eight designers taking part in the festival have created items to honour Red Dress Day, the national day of awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls observed annually on May 5.\n\n\u201cFor the majority of them, they have been touched by this issue personally,\u201d Coltman says.\n\n0:52\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\n\nRed Dress Day was inspired by M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black\u2019s installation project, which saw red dresses hung in public spaces throughout Canada and the United States as visual reminders of the number of Indigenous women who have been killed or are missing.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe movement has grown, with local communities hosting walks, events and educational gatherings.\n\nThe daily email you need for Edmonton's top news stories.\n\nColtman\u2019s mother was a residential school survivor from Red Pheasant Cree Nation in Saskatchewan.\n\nColtman also describes herself as survivor. Her childhood was marred by stays in foster care. She was abducted and assaulted as a teen. She says she knows all too well the world that Indigenous women can live in.\n\nIt was fashion that empowered Coltman. She signed with a modelling agency in 1972 and later created her own.\n\nBut the issue of violence toward Indigenous women and girls remained close to her heart.\n\nWhen she saw the red dress movement, Coltman says she was inspired, and in 2015 she founded Fashion Speaks International. The organization has produced fashion shows in Canada, Australia and France highlighting Indigenous designers, models and artists. Each show also brings attention to missing women through stories and photos.\n\n0:50\nOttawa protesters demand search for missing, murdered Indigenous women in Winnipeg landfills\n\nColtman says it\u2019s powerful watching Indigenous models hold their heads high as they walk the runway. It breaks behaviours pushed on the estimated 150,000 Indigenous children who were forced to attend residential schools, she says.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cThe residential school taught them that they were to be seen not heard, and they were to look at their feet when they walk,\u201d she says. \u201cWe need to make our people less invisible.\u201d\n\nIndigenous women and girls in Canada remain highly overrepresented as victims of violence. Between 2009 and 2021, the homicide rate among Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than their non-Indigenous counterparts, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\n\nCanada and Manitoba announced a partnership Friday for a Red Dress Alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl is reported missing. The pilot project is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nMORE ON CANADA\nHurricane Beryl forces Canadian airlines to cancel flights. What to know\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. Could Canada follow?\nCanada Post worker saves the day after child forgets stamp on postcard to grandma\nThis chicken rides the bus to school. Now it\u2019s been declared world\u2019s smartest\n\nDarlene Okemaysim-Sicotte has been on the front lines working to end violence against Indigenous women in Saskatchewan for nearly two decades. {"url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/highway-of-tears-bus-service-to-run-from-prince-george-to-prince-rupert-1.2947450", "title": "Highway of Tears bus service to run from Prince George to Prince Rupert | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFOLLOW ON\n\n    \n\nAdvertisement\n\nCANADA\nHighway of Tears bus service to run from Prince George to Prince Rupert\nDirk Meissner\nThe Canadian Press\n\n\nPublished Wednesday, June 15, 2016 5:27PM EDT\nLast Updated Thursday, June 16, 2016 1:15AM EDT\n\nThe Yellowhead, Highway 16, near Prince George, B.C., is pictured on Oct. 8, 2012. (Jonathan Hayward / THE CANADIAN PRESS)\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nPRINCE GEORGE, B.C. - A bus service that links communities along a notorious stretch of highway in northern British Columbia known as the Highway of Tears will carry passengers by the end of the year, the province's transportation minister said Wednesday.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or have disappeared along Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nFirst Nations, social service agencies and women's groups have been calling for a shuttle bus service in the area for several years to provide regular transportation for people who live in communities along the 750-kilometre route.\n\nThe highway cuts through the centre of the province and follows rivers and mountains, passing through numerous small communities, including Houston, Smithers and Burns Lake. The route also provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nMost cases of murdered and missing women remain unsolved, though investigators don't believe a single killer is responsible.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone says agreements between 16 communities along the highway will allow B.C. Transit to operate a scheduled bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert.\n\n\"Absolutely, this initiative is all about safety,\" he said.\n\nHe said the communities, the province and B.C. Transit must still develop service schedules and provide extra buses for the route.\n\nStone said plans for the Highway 16 area also include offering bus driver training programs for First Nations to provide transportation service from their remote villages to other major communities along the highway.\n\nChief Corrina Leween of the Cheslatta Carrier Nation said the bus service helps many living in towns on or near the highway, but it offers little comfort to those off the main road.\n\n\"The work they are doing for the core group on the corridor is good, but for us it really doesn't work because we're off the beaten trail,\" she said.\n\nLeween said the main Cheslatta community of about 300 people is located about 25 kilometres south of Burns Lake and getting to the highway requires a ferry trip and travel on a dirt road.\n\nFive Cheslatta people, including a family of four and a male elder, have disappeared from the area over the years, she said.\n\nNew Democrat Maurine Karagianis, the Opposition's critic for women, said area residents and local politicians have called for improved transportation services for years, but the government has been stalling while many people hitchhike for rides with strangers.\n\n\"I say get on with it,\" she said.\n\nFirst Nations advocate Mary Teegee said a decade ago, dozens of people walked from Prince Rupert to Prince George to call for better transportation service along the highway.\n\n\"It has been 10 years since of the Highway of Tears recommendations report came out and we are finally making progress,\" she said in a statement. \"I view transportation as a human rights issue in the north and we are working toward making sure everyone has access.\"\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport an error\nEditorial standards (Photo by Alex Kozroski)\n\nByron Watson is a 23-year-old who went missing from the community of Maple Creek over five months ago, which has come together to honour him.\n\nWatson\u2019s disappearance shook Nekaneet First Nation and the town of Maple Creek, both of which gathered on Sunday, national Red Dress Day, to show they had not forgotten him. Members of Watson\u2019s family organized a walk around Maple Creek, bringing together the two communities to which he once belonged.\n\nLori Watson, Byron Watson\u2019s Aunt, played an important role in organizing the event.\n\n\u201cMy sister Arlene wanted to honour her son who went missing; she just didn\u2019t want people to forget about him,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re really happy with all the support people have shown, like even for them showing up, walking with us, and honouring Byron.\u201d\n\nBeginning at the place where Byron Watson was last seen, the walk commenced after a traditional prayer and smudging ceremony. Over 100 participants joined in the walk, many donning red clothing with Watson\u2019s photo for Red Dress Day, the concurrent national event which raises awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nRailey Mosquito, another aunt of Byron Watson, joined in on the walk and spoke to the level of participation.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a really proud moment as a community member,\u201d stated Mosquito. \u201cIt\u2019s nice to see the movement, and that he\u2019s bringing awareness to this subject as well because we don\u2019t want him to feel like he\u2019s forgotten.\u201d\n\nThe event concluded with a barbecue, serving hotdogs and hamburgers to many of the walk\u2019s participants.\n\nAnyone with any information regarding the 23-year-old's whereabouts is asked to contact Maple Creek RCMP or Crime Stoppers to remain anonymous.\n\nA Facebook group has been created to share information on the case and can be accessed here.\n\nNEXT STORY\nRainfall warning triggered for southwest\nLATEST IN LOCAL NEWS\nSafety, health, and the work place a focus this week in Swift Current\nLocal women rally for Red Dress Day\nChamber on Tap taps into the secret behind rural community growth\nKindersley man charged with sexual assault of teenager\nLATEST STORIES ON SWIFTCURRENTONLINE\nThe Simon & Garfunkel Story\nSpring Fling continues to grow into the next big thing\n14U Sundogs win Montana tournament\nBusy weekend for Rampage Lacrosse squads\nEvents\nSwift Current 57\u2019s Baseball Club Home Game\nThu, Jul 4, 7:00 PM\nPride Centre Grand Reopening!\nSat, Jul 6, 9:00 AM\nCountry Pleasures TEAHOUSE\nSat, Jul 6, 1:38 PM\nSwift Current 57\u2019s Baseball Club Home Game\nSat, Jul 6, 7:00 PM\nSaskatchewan Motocross Round 4 Located in Swift Current.\nSun, Jul 7, 9:15 AM\nView more \nJobs\nPowered by\nLumber Yard Office Manager\nFull-time, Salary, Administrative, Retail, Sales\nFeatured\nTruck or Combine Operator\nHourly, Seasonal, Agriculture, Labour\nOffice Clerk I - {"url": "http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/new-highway-of-tears-documents-reveal-residents-transit-concerns/article27090219/", "title": "New Highway of Tears documents reveal B.C. residents\u2019 transit concerns - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nNew Highway of Tears documents reveal B.C. residents\u2019 transit concerns\nDIRK MEISSNER\nVICTORIA\nTHE CANADIAN PRESS\nPUBLISHED NOVEMBER 3, 2015\n\nThis article was published more than 8 years ago. Some information may no longer be current.\n\nAt least 18 women and girls, many of them aboriginal, have disappeared or have been murdered along Highway 16 and the adjacent routes, Highway 5 and Highway 97, since 1969.\nJOHN LEHMANN/THE GLOBE AND MAIL\n\nCOMMENTS\nSHARE\n\nNewly released documents reveal northern British Columbia residents have deep concerns about transportation services along the so-called Highway of Tears despite government statements about improved safety, Opposition New Democrats say.\n\nMaurine Karagianis, the NDP critic for women, said Tuesday a year-old freedom-of-information request reveals residents want better public transportation on Highway 16, which runs more than 700 kilometres, between Prince George to Prince Rupert.\n\nAt least 18 women and girls, many of them aboriginal, have disappeared or have been murdered along Highway 16 and the adjacent routes, Highway 5 and Highway 97, since 1969.\n\nMs. Karagianis said Transportation Minister Todd Stone has said public consultations in the area determined improved transportation along the corridor was not deemed practical by area residents.\n\n\"The minister has continued to tell us for a year there wasn't a big desire for a bus, that it wasn't a practical solution,\" Ms. Karagianis said. \"Certainly, looking at the FOI documents on the consultation that we have recently read, that is not true.\"\n\nThirty-six pages of documents posted on the government's Open Information website include reports about meetings that covered topics including missing women, hitchhiking and bus service.\n\nThe meetings were held last year with 12 First Nations, 13 municipalities and 70 leaders in the area.\n\nSome of the documents are in the form of briefing notes to high-level ministry bureaucrats. One briefing note said communities view naming Highway 16 as the Highway of Tears \"as negative.\"\n\nAnother note from a meeting in Smithers states, \"missing women must be part of the conversation as that is the only reason the Ministry of Transportation is in the room.\"\n\nJennifer Rice, the New Democrat member for Prince Rupert, told the legislature Tuesday that the documents show that the government has been denying that First Nations women and local residents have concerns about lack of safe transportation alternatives on the highway.\n\nMr. Stone said the highway is safer than it was 15 years ago. He pointed to government efforts to improve cellular service in the area and the introduction of a health bus that helps take people living in rural areas to medical appointments.\n\n\"The important thing here, I think, for people on Highway 16, is that we continue to focus on how we can make this corridor safer, and that's the work I'm pouring myself into. That's the work my officials are putting their shoulders into,\" said Mr. Stone.\n\nHe said the government has released 600 pages of information on Highway 16 since 2012.\n\nThe government has come under fire recently after a Transportation Ministry employee deleted potentially sensitive e-mails about the Highway of Tears investigation. A whistle-blower later complained and that set off an investigation by B.C.'s privacy commissioner.\n\nLast's month's report by Commissioner Elizabeth Denham highlighted a failure by the government to keep adequate e-mail records or document searches and the willful destruction of records in response to a freedom-of-information request.\n\nHer report, Access Denied, said high-ranking officials in the premier's office were found to have no e-mail records during freedom-of-information requests and attempts to obtain Premier Christy Clark's e-mail records also found nothing on her e-mail account.\n\nClark has since directed ministers and government staff to save the e-mails they send until the completion of a review of Ms. Denham's report.\n\nSign up for the B.C. Insider Newsletter.\n\nB.C. {"url": "https://www.interior-news.com/community/highway-of-tears-public-transit-plan-wins-safety-and-security-awards/", "title": "Highway of Tears public transit plan wins safety and security awards - The Smithers Interior News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAutos\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.3 \u00b0C\nHome Community\nHighway of Tears public transit plan wins safety and security awards\nAdvocate for the missing and murdered says recognition deserved, \u201cvery very happy\u201d with service\nQuinn Bender\nNov 30, 2018 2:54 PM\nDec 4, 2018 11:17 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRepresentatives of local government, the province, BC Transit and local First Nations celebrate the arrival of a BC Transit bus to Terrace in November 2017. The new service between the city and the Hazeltons filled the last-remaining gap in the Highway 16 Transportation Action Plan. (File photo)\n\nBC Transit\u2019s new service connecting communities along the Highway of Tears has earned high praise from both the Canadian Urban Transit Association (CUTA) and B.C.\u2019s premier, John Horgan.\n\nLast week CUTA recognized the Highway 16 Transportation Action Plan with a 2018 Award for Safety and Security, in recognition of the project\u2019s \u201ccommitment to enhancing the safety and security of employees and customers through the development of an effective safety and security program.\u201d\n\nAlso last month, the plan received a regional and provincial Premier\u2019s Award for Partnerships, recognizing the collaborative efforts of BC Transit, the provincial government, First Nations communities, local governments and regional districts, and the families involved with the Highway of Tears initiative.\n\n\u201cPeople in northern B.C., and in particular women and teenaged girls, need to feel safe travelling between communities, and that\u2019s what the Highway 16 Transportation Action Plan is now providing,\u201d said Transportation and Infrastructure Minister Claire Trevena in a press release. \u201cIt\u2019s wonderful to see how the increase in bus service, community vehicles and other aspects of the plan have come together and provided a significant boost to safe and reliable travel for people in northern B.C.\u201d\n\nSince November of last year, BC Transit began offering contiguous service from Terrace to Prince George \u2014 a route of almost 600 kilometres. The schedule was designed to allow for return travel from small communities to the nearest large centre on the same day.\n\nPrior to their pullout of the north, Greyhound was often criticized by Highway of Tears advocates for its inconvenient scheduling, often dropping off passengers at Hwy 16 destinations late at night.\n\nHighway of Tears safety and justice advocate Gladys Radek, and aunt of Tamara Chipman, last seen hitchhiking near Prince Rupert in 2005, also offered praise for BC Transit\u2019s program.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s always room for improvement, but I\u2019m actually very, very happy with having our own transit system up here.\u201d\n\nShe says some of the smaller on-reserve communities could still benefit from the service, but overall she\u2019s heard only positive feedback from female riders.\n\nBecause all drivers are local, who know the area and the people, Radek believes the plan fosters a safer environment for passengers.\n\n\u201cGreyhound wasn\u2019t there for the people anymore. Their focus, in the end, was only on parcel delivery. With BC Transit, I\u2019m hearing nothing but good things. It\u2019s good for all of us and it\u2019s keeping local eyes on our girls.\u201d\n\nThe province has committed to five years of transit funding to the Highway 16 Transportation Action Plan, a project worth $6.4 million. The funding covers the cost of buses and two-thirds of operating costs. Local governments and First Nations partners are responsible for the remaining third of costs.\n\n\u00a0\n\n\nquinn@terracestandard.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\nAbout the Author: Quinn Bender\n\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tNorthwest B.C. author pens book about logging\n\t\tTeen dies after overdose involving fentanyl in northern B.C.: RCMP\n\t\t'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\n\t\tMan dies throwing candy during Alberta Canada Day parade\n\t\tTom Havard is this year\u2019s Hudson Bay Mountain Legendary Local\nFacebook Comments (0) \nMan who stabbed Mexican tourist at B.C. Jeremy Skibicki is behind bars charged with four counts of first-degree murder.\n\nThe remains of Rebecca Contois, one of the women Skibicki is alleged to have killed, were discovered in the Brady Road Landfill earlier this year, while WPS said they believe the remains of victims Morgan Harris and Mercedes Myran are in the Prairie Green Landfill near Stony Mountain.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nPictures of Morgan Harris were displayed at a vigil held last December in Winnipeg to mourn the woman, who is one of four Indigenous women alleged to have been killed by an alleged serial killer. On Monday, Harris\u2019 daughter Cambria Harris spoke to students at Grant Park High School and asked them to be \u201callies\u201d to Indigenous women and girls. Dave Baxter/Winnipeg Sun/Local Journalism Initiative PHOTO BY DAVE BAXTER/LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE /Winnipeg Sun\n\nSkibicki is also accused of killing a fourth woman who remains unidentified and who community members have been referring to as Buffalo Woman.\n\nAnd as Indigenous women and girls in Manitoba and across Canada continue to deal with disproportionally high rates of violence and abuse, Harris told students on Monday that it is up to all people of all backgrounds and ages to \u201cget involved\u201d with the issue, and she said that could involve doing things and going places that would take some out of their \u201ccomfort zone.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one thing to talk about being an ally, but it\u2019s another thing to actually be one,\u201d Harris said. \u201cBe present, volunteer at shelters so you can see the troubles some of our people face. Then you can get to know them and understand why they got to where they did.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe also called on non-Indigenous students to educate themselves about Indigenous issues, and some of the challenges that Indigenous people face and have faced over generations.\n\n\u201cMany people only see what society calls the ugly side, but many fail to realize that as Indigenous people we are so much more. Go to celebrations and pow-wows where you can experience the culture,\u201d Harris said.\n\n\u201cMost importantly, if you are unsure ask questions respectfully. Understand, acknowledge and listen to what we have to say, so that we may find a way to help you understand.\u201d\n\nHarris called for Canadians to do more to push elected officials to find ways to keep Indigenous women and girls safe and free from abuse and violence.\n\nCambria Harris, the daughter of Morgan Harris, one of four Indigenous women who police believe was murdered by an alleged serial killer, spoke to students at Grant Park High School in Winnipeg on Monday, and asked them to be \u201callies\u201d to Indigenous women and girls. Handout PHOTO BY HANDOUT /Winnipeg Sun\n\n\u201cWrite letters to the government, and put pressure on them to protect Indigenous people,\u201d Harris said.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe said she also believes young people have to learn to have \u201cdifficult conversations\u201d about some of the issues facing Indigenous people in Canada.\n\n\u201cTalk about this with other people, your peers, and acknowledge what is happening, it really is that simple,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cAnd if it is uncomfortable for you to speak about it, then just imagine how uncomfortable it is for an Indigenous person to live through every day.\u201d\n\nSaturday marked the fourth anniversary of the release of Reclaiming Power and Place: The Final Report of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u2014 Dave Baxter is a Local Journalism Initiative reporter who works out of the Winnipeg Sun.
