{"url": "https://www.mbcradio.com/2024/03/prrc-and-navigating-the-journey", "title": "PRRC and Navigating the Journey - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nPRRC and Navigating the Journey\n\nby MBC News | Mar 8, 2024 | Current News\n\nBy: Carol Baldwin, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter, Wakaw Recorder\n\nA Reconciliation Declaration committing the members of the Prairie Rivers Reconciliation Circle to travel the path of reconciliation together was signed on February 6, 2020, at One Arrow First Nation, but that was not the first step of the journey.\n\nThe Prairie Rivers Reconciliation Circle has been meeting regularly since 2018 and has made education and relationship building their priorities \u2013 for the circle members and the organizations and communities they represent. The group formed around individuals of a like mind desiring to build strong relationships and advance a long-term commitment toward Reconciliation. An educational session is provided at each meeting and has delved into everything from the teachings of Elders and Residential School Survivors to sessions on anti-racist education, creating a land acknowledgement statement and an inclusion and diversity strategy. PRRC hosts an annual educational gathering and this year\u2019s event will be held in Hepburn, SK at Heritage Common on April 11th from 9 am to 4:30 pm. This year\u2019s theme, \u201cNavigating the Journey Together,\u201d embraces the significance of rivers. With the majority of the members of the Circle coming from the lands between the two branches of the Saskatchewan River, its presence naturally stands forefront in the awareness of this geological space, but water and rivers are principal elements in Indigenous culture. As shared by Shirley Williams, an Anishinaabe elder from Wikwemikong Unceded Territory on Manitoulin Island, to CBC Radio in April 2023, \u201cWater is the first thing that the Creator made, and it\u2019s the water where we were born. We pray for that water because water is a living thing. It\u2019s not a commodity. We look at it as a spiritual element.\u201d\n\nWater is alive and holds a spirit. It is sacred. It is the lifeblood that flows through lakes, rivers, and oceans, fosters important ecosystems, and has been used for transportation since time immemorial. Therefore, the imagery of two canoes paddling the river of reconciliation side-by-side is significant. As a river has many bends in it, so too does the path of reconciliation. There are seasons of rapid flow and movement forward, and then there are seasons when the flow is slower, and movement forward takes much more effort. It can feel like being trapped in an eddy, where the muddied sluggish water impedes forward movement. The work of paddling through those \u2018seasons\u2019 cannot be done alone.\n\nThe Conference registration is live on Eventbrite and there are links on the Prairie Rivers Reconciliation Circle Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn pages. Sponsorships are still being sought for the conference as it is a free event for anyone to attend and sponsorship is key for that very reason. Sponsorship commitments need to be in by March 14th. If there are organizations or individuals interested in sponsorship opportunities, more information is available by reaching out through social media or by contacting a member. The following are just a few of the businesses and organizations that have representatives in the PRRC: Carlton Trail College, Great Plains College, Mennonite Central Committee, Town of Osler, Town of Hepburn, Town of Rosthern, Station Arts, Wheatland Regional Library, Federated Co-operatives, Dakota Dunes Community Development Corp., and the Wakaw Recorder. Details about breakout sessions for the conference and keynotes are still being finalized.\n\nDiscussion at the meeting involved the housekeeping issues regarding treasurer, tri-chair positions, and administrative assistance for the tri-chairs. A reminder was given that the PRRC will provide funding support for community activities around reconciliation via a simple application process before the event giving a brief description of what it is and how it supports reconciliation. At the next meeting, which will be an in-person one, as many members who can attend as possible will revisit the Vision and Mission Statements, the guidelines, and the Circle\u2019s general definitions and defining statements. The next meeting will be held on March 27 in Warman.\n\nGuest Neal Kewistep joined the meeting to discuss the vision he has for reconciliation moving forward. Kewistep has spent most of his career fostering relationships with government, community-based organizations, Indigenous organizations, and educators. As the former Interim Director of the Population Public Health (PPH) in the Saskatchewan Health Authority (SHA), his leadership led to increasing the infant and childhood immunization rates to close the gap between the most affluent neighbourhoods and the inner-city neighbourhoods and to address safe housing issues in a new way within the scope of the Public Health Act. He was also the strategic lead for cultural competency and Truth and Reconciliation Commission activities for PPH, which was a role he was proud to take on.\n\nIn addition to his time with the provincial health authority, Mr Kewistep has served as the Director of Operations for the Native Counselling Services of Alberta, as a Community Development Advisor with Yellow Quill First Nation and has provided consulting services to the Saskatoon Tribal Council and the Greater Saskatoon Catholic Schools. He has also served as a board member on the Good Food Junction and the Speakerbox Aboriginal Advisory Group, and as an advisory committee member for the Saskatoon Community Foundation and the Saskatoon Urban Aboriginal Strategy.\n\nReconciliation, he said, has had big moments like the Calls to Action and the discovery of the unmarked graves, where people get invested in reconciliation. The movements this investment has birthed, like Orange Shirt Day and Red Dress Day, while being especially important, are over quickly, but the impacts of residential schools are ongoing for families and individuals. Reconciliation needs to be ongoing. Putting on an orange shirt should not be the end of one\u2019s reconciliation story, it should be the beginning of the conversation\u2026the start when we introduce others to the history, to the new conversations. The reconciliation movement needs to keep going and people need to keep \u201csticking their neck out\u201d for others, and standing up for others, and that is tougher than just putting on an orange shirt. Reconciliation really means achieving the same, not more, just the same.\n\nSaskatchewan, Kewistep said, has a big geography and a small community, and it is a challenge to overcome that big geography. The will to make change, to be welcoming to each other, to hear others, and the willingness to bring people alongside to navigate those twists and turns together needs to continue so the momentum of reconciliation keeps moving forward and does not get stuck in one of those eddies, swirling around and going nowhere. The canoes that are navigating the journey of reconciliation need to be side-by-side not one ahead of the other.\n\nWhen asked for his thoughts on how to encourage and engage more First Nations in the PRRC, Neal said to first determine what value they would gain through their involvement. Then, he said, look to the young people. Show them how they could benefit from the engagement. Young people have a lot of ideas but lack the experience to navigate through systems. Show them opportunities. Show them what they can achieve.\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},
{"url": "https://thegatewayonline.ca/2017/02/red-dresses-campus-remain-march-missing-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Red dresses on campus remain after march for missing and murdered indigenous women - The Gateway", "body": "News\nOpinion\nArts & Culture\nSports\nFeatures\nGuest Columns\nMultimedia\nFacebook\nX\nFlickr\nYouTube\nInstagram\nTikTok\nRSS\nSwitch skin\nSearch for\nVolunteer\nMerch\nAdvertising\nDonate\nFinances\nJob Postings\nArchives\nAbout\nContact Us\n Home/News/Red dresses on campus remain after march for missing and murdered indigenous women\nRed dresses on campus remain after march for missing and murdered indigenous women\n Nathan FungFebruary 25, 2017\n2 2 minutes read\nNathan Fung\n\nStudents passing the Central Academic Building can see a number of red dresses meant to bring awareness to missing and murdered indigenous women.\n\nThe dresses remain on campus after the Memorial March for missing and murdered indigenous women was held on February 14. The march, organized by the Native Studies Student Association (NSSA), aimed to bring attention to the issue.\n\nThe march started and ended at Pembina Hall.\nNathan Fung\n\nThe march began in front of Pembina Hall with a smudging ceremony and song where moose hide squares were given out for the Moose Hide campaign, in which Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal men pledge to protect women in their lives. Participants then marched to Rutherford Library and back to Pembina Hall where indigenous leaders and activists shared stories of missing loved ones.\n\nMelanie Dene, a second-year Native Studies student and a member of the Mikisew Cree First Nation, began planning the march in January. She approached the NSSA about creating an event to generate greater awareness for missing and murdered indigenous women on campus.\n\n\u201cI felt that this issue has kind of fallen off the table, out of the public eye, ever since the national inquiry has come about,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I wanted to raise the awareness so that people know that this is still an ongoing issue.\u201d\n\n1,200 felt hearts were strung before the Sweetgrass Bear to represent Canada\u2019s missing and murdered indigenous women.\nNathan Fung\n\nThe march passed 1,201 felt hearts strung up in quad, which represented the 1,200 missing and murdered indigenous women in Canada, with one more added to represent that there is always one more on the go. But while 1,200 is the figure the RCMP arrived at, groups such as the NWAC puts the number closer to 4,000. The one additional heart was meant to signify that there are more victims than those in the report, according to Rhianna Arcand from the NSSA.\n\nDespite the dispute about the numbers, the display in quad was still a profound exhibit, according to Dene.\n\n\u201cAs you\u2019re cutting (the hearts), you\u2019re thinking of those women that have been subjected to this, and when you see it\u2019s there it\u2019s when it hits you\u201d Dene said.\n\nScheduling the march on Valentine\u2019s Day wasn\u2019t just a coincidence. According to Dene, the event was meant as a celebration of love.\n\nAccording to Facebook, almost 170 people joined the march.\nNathan Fung\n\n\u201cWhat we did here on campus was about love, that they will never be forgotten,\u201d Dene said.\n\nMarch attendees included April Wiberg, founder of the Stolen Sisters Awareness Walk and Movement, Marilyn Buffalo, former president of the Native Woman\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC), and Chief Tony Alexis of Alexis Nakota Sioux Nation.\n\nLike some of the attendees at the march, Dene\u2019s family has been a victim of violence. Her family has lost four relatives, including Shelly Tannis Dene, missing since 2013; Shirley Ann Waquan, missing since 2007; and Amber Alyssa Tuccaro, whose remains were found in 2012.\n\n\u201cWhen it becomes personal, you become more engaged,\u201d Dene said. \u201cYou start to begin to see the racial division in this country, especially in the judicial system that you\u2019ve always thought was there to protect you.\u201d\n\nAccording to the Facebook event page, 166 people attended the rally, which was more than what Dene thought it would be.\n\n\u201cThat made me very happy to see that it\u2019s not our issue anymore,\u201d Dene said. \u201cCanadians need to realize that this isn\u2019t just an indigenous problem, but that this is a Canadian problem.\u201d\n\nNathan Fung\n Share\nFacebook\n \nX\n \nPrint\nNathan Fung\nNathan Fung is a sixth-year political science student and The Gateway's news editor for the 2018-19 year. He can usually be found in the Gateway office, turning coffee into copy.\n2 Comments\nIH8Aboriginals\nsays:\nApril 26, 2017 at 8:57 am\n\nWTF is wrong with Aboriginals? {"url": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/nyt/calls-of-justice-for-aboriginal-women-echo-down-canadas-highway-of-tears/", "title": "Calls of justice for aboriginal women echo down Canada\u2019s Highway of Tears | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Opens in a new tab\nOpens in a new tab\nSubscribe\u00a0\nOpens in a new tab\nLog In\nHome\n \nTop News\n \nHawaii News\n \nSports\n \nEditorial\n \nObituaries\u00a0\nOpens in a new tab\n \nCrave\n \nVideos\n \nPrint Replica\n \nLegal Ads\u00a0\nOpens in a new tab\n \nWeather\n\nThursday, July 4, 2024\n 82\u00b0\nToday's Paper\n\nNEWS\nCalls of justice for aboriginal women echo down Canada\u2019s Highway of Tears\n\nBy Dan Levin New York Times\n\nMay 25, 2016\n\nSMITHERS, British Columbia >> Less than a year after her 15-year-old cousin vanished, Delphine Nikal, 16, was last seen hitchhiking from this isolated northern Canadian town on a spring morning in 1990.\n\nRamona Wilson, 16, a member of her high school baseball team, left home one Saturday night in June 1994 to attend a dance a few towns away. She never arrived. Her remains were found 10 months later near the local airport.\n\nTamara Chipman, 22, disappeared in 2005, leaving behind a toddler. \u201cShe\u2019s still missing,\u201d Gladys Radek, her aunt, said. \u201cIt\u2019ll be 11 years in September.\u201d\n\nDozens of Canadian women and girls, most of them indigenous, have disappeared or been murdered near Highway 16, a remote ribbon of asphalt that bisects British Columbia and snakes past thick forests, logging towns and impoverished Indian reserves on its way to the Pacific Ocean. So many women and girls have vanished or turned up dead along one stretch of the road that residents call it the Highway of Tears.\n\nA special unit formed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police officially linked 18 such cases from 1969 to 2006 to this part of the highway and two connecting arteries. More women have vanished since then, and community activists and relatives of the missing say they believe the total is closer to 50. Almost all the cases remain unsolved.\n\nThe Highway of Tears and the disappearances of the indigenous women have become a political scandal in British Columbia. But those cases are just a small fraction of the number who have been murdered or disappeared nationwide. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have officially counted about 1,200 cases over the past three decades, but research by the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada suggests the total number could be as high as 4,000.\n\nIn December, after years of refusal by his conservative predecessor, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a long-awaited national inquiry into the disappearances and murders of indigenous women.\n\nThe inquiry, set to cost 40 million Canadian dollars ($31 million), is part of Trudeau\u2019s promise of a \u201ctotal renewal\u201d of Canada\u2019s relationship with its indigenous citizens, and it comes at a critical time.\n\nAboriginal women and girls make up about 4 percent of the total female population of Canada but 16 percent of all female homicides, according to government statistics.\n\nCarolyn Bennett, the minister of indigenous and northern affairs, has spent months traveling across the country to consult with indigenous communities. During her meetings, families and survivors have complained of racism and sexism by the police, who she said treated the deaths of indigenous women \u201cas inevitable, as if their lives mattered less.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s clear is the uneven application of justice,\u201d Bennett said.\n\nOne reason to doubt the estimate by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, she said, is that the police often immediately deemed the women\u2019s deaths to be suicides, drug overdoses or accidents, over the protests of relatives who suspected foul play. \u201cThere was no investigation,\u201d she said, citing one recent case. \u201cThe file folder\u2019s empty.\u201d\n\nA U.N. report last year described measures by the previous government to protect aboriginal women from harm as \u201cinadequate\u201d and said that the lack of an inquiry into the murders and disappearances constituted \u201cgrave violations\u201d of the women\u2019s human rights. Failures by law enforcement, it added, had \u201cresulted in impunity.\u201d\n\nRadek, a co-founder of Tears4Justice, an advocacy organization, said, \u201cWhen it comes to the missing, racism runs deep.\u201d\n\nThe federal government has allocated 8.4 billion Canadian dollars ($6.4 billion) over five years to aid indigenous communities, which have disproportionately high levels of poverty, incarceration, alcoholism and substance abuse, and often lack basic necessities like safe drinking water.\n\nBennett said the breakdown in aboriginal communities was the product of generations of socioeconomic marginalization and trauma tied to government policies. Particularly damaging was a state-financed, church-run boarding school system for aboriginal children who were forcibly taken from their families by officers of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Many of the 150,000 children who were sent to residential schools over a century became victims of physical and sexual abuse. The program was fully shut down in the mid-1990s.\n\nCovering 450 miles between the city of Prince George and the Pacific port of Prince Rupert, the Highway of Tears is both a microcosm of Canada\u2019s painful indigenous legacy and a serious test for Trudeau as he tries to repair the country\u2019s relationship with aboriginal people.\n\nOn a recent journey along Highway 16, scenes of stunning wilderness were flecked by indigenous communities reeling from economic decay and the anguished memories of missing and murdered women.\n\nA few miles outside Prince George, the highway plunges into thick forests veined with logging roads and the occasional \u201cmoose crossing\u201d sign. \u201cGirls Don\u2019t Hitchhike on the Highway of Tears,\u201d reads a large yellow billboard alongside the road farther north. \u201cKiller on the Loose!\u201d\n\nAs a bald eagle soared overhead, Brenda Wilson, 49, the Highway of Tears coordinator for Carrier Sekani Family Services and the sister of one of the victims, gestured to the wall of evergreens that flank the road. \u201cThe trees are really dense here, so if you\u2019re looking for someone, it\u2019s pretty hard to find them,\u201d she said, listing the names of several women who are still missing.\n\nThe perils do not stop desperate people from thumbing rides. Just outside the village of Burns Lake, Drucella Joseph, 25, an unemployed aboriginal woman, eagerly climbed into the back of a passing car along with her boyfriend, Corey Coombes. \u201cFriends will drive me when I really need a ride, but other than that, we just hitchhike,\u201d she told the driver. The couple gets by on his disability payments and on donated food from food banks. Neither has a cellphone. When hitchhiking, Coombes says he protects himself by carrying a club or a screwdriver.\n\nBritish Columbia is infamous for serial killers and criminals who often targeted aboriginal women. In 2007, Robert William Pickton, a pig farmer, was convicted of killing six women, though the DNA or remains of 33 women were discovered on his land. Many of them were aboriginal. One of Canada\u2019s youngest serial killers, Cody Legebokoff, was 24 when he was convicted in 2014 of killing four women near the Highway of Tears. David Ramsay, a former Prince George provincial court judge and convicted pedophile, was imprisoned in 2004 for sexually and physically assaulting indigenous girls as young as 12.\n\nAnguished family members said they received little help from the authorities, a sharp contrast to the cases of missing white women. After Chipman vanished in 2005, her aunt, Radek, said the police objected to the family putting up its own missing posters. \u201cThey knew we were searching day and night, and they did nothing to help us,\u201d she said. The next day, she said, a white woman disappeared near Vancouver \u201cand the police were out in the streets putting up posters.\u201d\n\nAfter her daughter Ramona disappeared in 1994, the police refused to act, said Matilda Wilson, a member of the Gitxsan First Nation. \u201cThey gave us all these different excuses that she might be back tomorrow or next week,\u201d Wilson said. \u201cThere was no hurry or alarm about it, so we started looking ourselves.\u201d\n\nDespite multiple searches, Wilson, a single mother of six who is now 65, said there was no sign of Ramona until she had been gone for seven months, when Wilson received an anonymous phone call telling her that the girl\u2019s body was near the airport. Police officers searched the area but found nothing, she said. In April 1995, two men riding all-terrain vehicles by the airport discovered Ramona\u2019s remains buried under some trees. Plastic flowers and a glass cross now decorate her grave in a Smithers cemetery, a few blocks from Wilson\u2019s tidy trailer-park home.\n\nAngry with the police for failing to find the teenager or to alert people to the history of missing women near Highway 16, Wilson and her family organized a memorial walk in June 1995 that has become an annual event, garnering attention from the media and inspiring activism from families of other missing women.\n\n\u201cWe want closure, and we\u2019re not going to give up,\u201d Wilson said as she swept leaves from her daughter\u2019s gravestone.\n\nOne recent afternoon, three young aboriginal sisters and their female cousin were walking across the Moricetown Indian Reserve, which abuts the highway. Asked about the Highway of Tears, one of the women, Rochelle Joseph, an unemployed 21-year-old, said the sisters never hitchhiked because they grew up hearing about the victims, including their cousin, Chipman.\n\nStill, the menace of the highway haunts their lives.\n\n\u201cThe stories made us cautious,\u201d Joseph said quietly, voicing their fear of a serial killer lurking behind the steering wheel of any strange car. \u201cHe\u2019s probably still out there.\u201d\n\nLeave a Reply\n\nYou must be logged in to post a comment.\n\nHurricane Beryl batters Jamaica as 2 other islands lie in ruin | Honolulu Star-Advertiser\nStar-Advertiser\nSeniors In Alberta Are Eligible For A Free Hearing Test\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nLetter: Visitor\u2019s confrontation in Waikiki was unnecessary | Honolulu Star-Advertiser\nStar-Advertiser\nWoman describes captivity in alleged kidnapping | Honolulu Star-Advertiser\nStar-Advertiser\nHere's Why Seniors Are Rushing to Claim Their Free Hearing Tests\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nStop scratching these, and try this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nAlberta Seniors Born Before 1971 Wanted To Test Hearing Aids\nBest Hearing Aids\n|\nSponsored\nRoofers Tested 17 Gutter Guards\u2026 Here\u2019s What They Discovered\nLeafFilter Partner\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nStop scanning your lottery ticket, do this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nFix Grammatical Errors and Typos With this Desktop App\nGrammarly\n|\nSponsored\nInstall Now\nSUBSCRIBER FAVORITES\n1\nTrump widens lead after Biden\u2019s debate debacle, Times/Siena poll finds\n2\nTow company remains silent on overcharges\n3\nGov. LGBT\u2026 but doesn't start with it.\n\nTrudeau decided to commemorate the Sisters in Spirit vigil, an event dedicated to people of specific sexual identities who had gone missing or had been murdered.\u00a0\n\n\"People across the country are lighting candles to honour Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people who are missing or have been murdered,\" Trudeau posted on Facebook and and asexual (2SLGBTQQIA+) people who are missing or have been murdered,\" Bennett said in a statement on Monday. \"We offer support to the families and communities who bear the grief of their loss and to the survivors whose lives have been forever changed.\"\n\nWhile most Americans and Canadians may be more familiar with the LGBTQ acronym, the \"2S\" at the beginning of Trudeau's latest version {"url": "https://www.kelownacapnews.com/news/school-briefs-central-okanagan-students-celebrate-indigenous-culture/", "title": "School briefs: Central Okanagan students celebrate Indigenous culture - Kelowna Capital News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n26.4 \u00b0C\nHome News\nSchool briefs: Central Okanagan students celebrate Indigenous culture\nShining a light on dark aspect of Canadian history\n\tBarry Gerding\n\nMay 13, 2023 10:00 AM\nMay 13, 2023 12:44 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRutland Middle School marched for Moose Day Campaign Day on Thursday, May 11. (Rutland Middle School/Contributed)\n\nThe growing synergy between Central Okanagan Public Schools and the local Indigenous culture was reflected in a presentation to school trustees at the board of education meeting on Wednesday ( May 17).\n\nTwo teachers and a student from Mount Boucherie Secondary talked about the significance of the recent Red Dress Day, also recognized as Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Day.\n\nXavier Robinson, an Indigenous student who recently moved to Kelowna from Prince Rupert, spoke about the significance of the colour red, and how it is worn to pause and remember and reflect on the lost lives from the Highway of Tears unsolved Indigenous women murders.\n\n\u201cIt is important to teach others about it,\u201d said Robinson, who was assisted in his presentation by Indigenous Academy teacher Mary Redfearn.\n\nTeacher Carlee Mills-Doherty told trustees about how a seven-part CBC podcast entitled Who Killed Alberta Williams, a 24-year-old woman found dead along the Highway of Tears near Prince Rupert in 1989, has become a teaching tool for her classes since 2016 about Indigenous culture history.\n\nMills-Doherty said the podcast has served as an effective entry point to access different discussion points with students about the history of Indigenous culture in Canada, about bias, justice and fair representation.\n\n\u201cRather than write essays about this, we sit in a circle and allow students to discuss these sometimes difficult social justice issues,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIt is easy to be overwhelmed by the Indigenous culture topic, but using the podcast as a discussion point eases some of the anxiety students might feel\u2026and help them gain a greater sense of knowledge.\u201d\n\n***\n\nThe board of education has declared the month of May as Food Allergy Awareness Month in Central Okanagan Public Schools.\n\n***\n\nTwo noteworthy events came out of the annual general meeting of the B.C. School Trustees Association held in Vancouver.\n\nOne was the election of trustee Julia Fraser as vice-president of the BC Thompson Okanagan branch of the BCSTA.\n\nThe other was an opportunity by the board of education chair Lee-Ann Tiede to meet with the provincial education and childcare minister and address various rising enrolment issues facing Central Okanagan Public Schools.\n\nTiede reported the minister was invited to tour the school district schools at a future date.\n\n***\n\nThe Central Okanagan Bursary and Scholarship Society recently celebrated 52 years of financially assisting local grads in pursuit of their post-secondary education by hosting a donor appreciation tea on May 1.\n\nIn 2002, donation support resulted in 585 bursary and scholarship awards with a value of $545,315.\n\n***\n\nTwo other days of recognition significance acknowledged by the board of education during the month of May \u2013 May 12 is Child Care Provider Appreciation Day and May 12 is Celebration of Women in Math Day.\n\n***\n\nMount Boucherie Secondary will host the school\u2019s first student community visual art show at the Peachland Art Gallery, which opens May 27 and continues until the end of June.\n\nThe art gallery is located at 5684 Beach Ave. in downtown Peachland.\n\n***\n\nCentral Okanagan Public Schools welcomed a group of nine educators from Sweden, who spent a day visiting three schools to gain some professional inspiration and how to learn how to better engage children in reading and writing.\n\nThe Swedish educators met with teachers, sat in on classes, took part in assemblies and attended staff support meetings during their visit.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Barry Gerding\n\nSenior regional reporter for Black Press Media in the Okanagan. {"url": "https://www.cowichanvalleycitizen.com/opinion/editorial-haunting-red-dresses-the-first-step/", "title": "Editorial: Haunting red dresses the first step - Cowichan Valley Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n23.7 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Opinion\nEditorial: Haunting red dresses the first step\nHere was a graphic representation of loss, tragedy and mystery.\nBlack Press Media\nFeb 16, 2018 6:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRed dresses fluttering in the breeze were a haunting sight Saturday in Charles Hoey Park in Duncan. (Lexi Bainas/Citizen)\n\nFluttering in the breeze, flashes of red grabbed the eye and wouldn\u2019t let go at Charles Hoey Park in Duncan on Saturday.\n\nCloser examination revealed to the viewer red dresses of all sizes and shapes suspended from the barren February tree branches. It was a disquieting image.\n\nWithout arms, legs, faces and life filling them, the dresses presented a haunting tableau. Here was a graphic representation of loss, tragedy and mystery. Fittingly, here, too, was the faceless anonymity that has for too long hidden away the problem of Canada\u2019s missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and marred any quest for justice in the violence that disproportionately affects them. You must first see them before you can go about fixing the problem.\n\nThis was not Cowichan\u2019s first installation of the REDress Project. Our community certainly isn\u2019t immune to the larger problems facing Indigenous people in this country.\n\nAnd nobody seems as vulnerable as women. Though Indigenous women make up four per cent of Canada\u2019s female population, Kendra Thomas reminded us in her article before the event, 16 per cent of all women murdered in the country between 1980 and 2012 were Indigenous.\n\nAnother tragic statistic: In 2014 RCMP identified 1,181 missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nAs the REDress Project hung in the park, Cowichan Tribes hosted their 1st Annual Walk for Missing and Murdered Men, Women and Children. A big crowd turned out for this inaugural event, again showing just how many people, right here in the Cowichan Valley, are affected by this ongoing problem.\n\nMaking it visible, acknowledging it is there, is just the first step.\n\nThe next steps are many and complicated. But we must put one foot in front of the other and keep moving.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tEditorial: Bypass of Duncan corridor not worth it\n\t\tDuncan to get new $7-million urgent and primary care centre\n\t\tPolice ask for help to find man missing from Youbou\n\t\tBig Brothers Big Sisters Cowichan chapter forced to shut down\n\t\tCongratulations to the Cowichan Secondary Class of 2024\nFacebook Comments (0) \nTODAY IN B.C.\n\nThere are no items to show.\n\n \nCowichan Valley Citizen\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nAdvertising\nSupport Centre\nTerms of Service\nPrivacy Policy\nJoin our Team\nNews\nLocal News\nNewsletters\nSubscribe\nToday in BC\nCanadian News\nWorld News\nEntertainment\nSports\nBusiness\nTrending Now\nOpinion\nSubmit News Tips\nNeighbours\nAlberni Valley News\nParksville Qualicum Beach News\nTofino-Ucluelet Westerly News\nChemainus Valley Courier\nLadysmith Chronicle\nLake Cowichan Gazette\nNanaimo News Bulletin\nMore\nOur Community\nPublic Notices\nVideo\nPhoto Galleries\nTravel\nWest Coast Traveller\nCannabis\nToday's Home\nPodcasts\nFood\nLife\nContact Us\nContests\nPuzzles\nContests\nShop\nImpress Stories\nSavvy Shopper\nImpress TV\nAdd Your Business\nE-Editions\nClassifieds\nAll Classifieds\nBook a Print Ad\nAuto\nToday's Drive\nAuto Showcase\nJobs\nLocalWork\nJoin Our Team\nObituaries\nCelebrations of Life\nFuneral Care Services\nIn Memory\nPlace an Obituary\nGood News\nLocal Good News\nSocial Media\nCowichan Valley Live\nToday in BC\nYoutube\nI love British Columbia\nI love Alberta\nI love Nunavut\nI love Yukon\nI love Northwest Territories\n\u00a9 2024 Cowichan Valley Citizen and Black Press Media Publications Contact"},
{"url": "https://calgary.ctvnews.ca/opportunity-to-create-awareness-dozens-gather-for-red-dress-day-in-lethbridge-1.6386630", "title": "Dozens gather for Red Dress Day in Lethbridge | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nCALGARY\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nCALGARY\nNews\n'Opportunity to create awareness': Dozens gather for Red Dress Day in Lethbridge\nKarsen Marczuk\nCTV News Lethbridge Video Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2023 8:21 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2023 4:47 p.m. MDT\nShare\nLETHBRIDGE -\n\n Adding to a Canada-wide movement, Lethbridge remembered and honoured missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people on Friday.\n\n\"When we think of the day, it's not a celebration, but it's an opportunity to create awareness and bring the community together in a positive way,\" said Charlene Bruised Head-Mountain Horse, the Indigenous relations advisor with the City of Lethbridge.\n\nRed Dress Day is meant to bring awareness to, and calls for all Canadians to speak out on, violence against Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nHundreds march as Red Dress Day is marked across Manitoba\nSaskatoon marks Red Dress Day 2023\n\nSelena Medicine Shield spoke and danced at a fireside connection hosted in Galt Gardens on Friday afternoon in honour of her grandmother, whose murder in 1999 remains unsolved.\n\n\"To me, it is being able to be a voice for all Indigenous people who have gone missing or have been murdered, especially my grandmother and just being able to represent her and tell her story,\" Medicine Shield said.\n\nEmpty red garments -- a symbol for each life that has been lost -- surrounded the fireside connection.\n\nThe event, hosted by the City of Lethbridge, Alberta Health Services and other community partners, featured drumming, dancing and the sharing of memories and stories.\n\nDespite an increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, Indigenous leaders say the situation remains a crisis.\n\n\"People like to believe that it's not in our town, it's not in our city, it's not happening to us, but we need to make people aware that it is,\" said Echo Nowak, an Indigenous relations specialist with the City of Lethbridge and co-organizer of the fireside connection.\n\n\"It is our sisters, our brothers, our family members that are going missing and we need to do something about it and the only way we can do something about it is by coming together as a community and making our voices heard.\"\n\nIt's not known exactly how many Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people have been murdered or have disappeared, but the Native Women's Association of Canada believes it's at least 4,000.\n\nAs part of the work plan, a toolkit was developed by the City of Lethbridge to help residents and community members learn more about the traditional concepts of family and community life for Niitsitapiiaakiiks (Blackfoot women), Saip\u00e1\u00ed\u2019tapiiaakiiks (Indigenous, non-Blackfoot women) and two-spirit people.\n\nThe toolkit features actions individuals, businesses and media partners can take to support Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people in the community.\n\n\"There's different opportunities to lobby leadership, empower our local circles,\" Bruised Head-Mountain Horse said.\n\nA few dozen people gathered on Friday and while Medicine Shield says the support is great to see, she hopes one day she won't have to attend these kinds of ceremonies.\n\n\"In the future, I don't want my kids to be afraid to walk to the store or go to a friend's house when they are alone,\" she said.\n\n\"I want them to be safe.\"\u00a0\n\nRed Dress Day in Lethbridge, hosted by the City of Lethbridge, Alberta Health Services and other community partners, featured drumming, dancing and the sharing of memories and stories.\n\nRELATED {"url": "https://bc.ctvnews.ca/remains-of-missing-woman-chelsea-poorman-found-at-vacant-vancouver-home-1.5892309", "title": "Missing woman Chelsea Poorman's body found | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nVANCOUVER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nVANCOUVER\nNews\nRemains of missing woman Chelsea Poorman found at vacant Vancouver home\n02:44\nRemains of missing woman discovered\n03:04\nTragic end to search for missing woman\nAndrew Weichel\nCTVNewsVancouver.ca Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPenny Daflos\nCTV News Vancouver Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 7, 2022 10:19 a.m. MDT\nPublished May 6, 2022 1:48 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nThe search for a young Indigenous woman has ended in tragedy after her remains were found at a vacant home in Vancouver's Shaughnessy neighbourhood.\n\nFor 24-year-old Chelsea Poorman's grieving family, the discovery brought little closure \u2013 only new questions.\n\n\"We still don't know what happened to her,\" said Sheila Poorman, the young woman's mother. \"I don't know if we'll ever find out.\"\n\nContractors spotted Chelsea's remains on April 22, while working on a property near Granville Street and West 37th Avenue, an expensive part of the city lined with multimillion-dollar homes.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nMissing woman Chelsea Poorman's father on relentless quest to find her\nA young Indigenous woman vanished a year ago. There's a $10K reward in her case, but there's been no sign of her since that day.\n$10,000 reward offered by family of young Indigenous woman who vanished in Vancouver\n\nHer identity was later confirmed through DNA testing, and authorities notified her family on Friday morning before making a public announcement.\n\n\"This is not the outcome anyone wanted. We always hoped Chelsea would be found alive, and our sympathies go out to everyone who knew Chelsea, loved her, and hoped she would come home safely,\" Sgt. Steve Addison of the Vancouver Police Department said in a statement.\n\nHe later told reporters that Chelsea\u2019s skeleton had been found outside the home in a heavily wooded area, and that toxicology and other analysis would not be possible on her remains, but that Vancouver police would be providing \"personal details\" to the family in the coming days.\n\nThe news came one day after the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, also known as Red Dress Day, which saw ceremonies held across the country, including in Vancouver.\n\nChelsea was a member of the Kawacatoose First Nation in Saskatchewan, but was living on the West Coast when she disappeared.\n\nPolice do not consider her death to be suspicious, but have not provided any further details, except that they have reviewed the findings of a coroner's investigation.\n\nHer mother, who spoke with the coroner on Friday, told CTV News she doesn't understand how police came to that conclusion.\n\n\"I don't know why they would say that,\" Sheila said. \"They don't even have a cause of death. They don't know what happened. Somebody just doesn't \u2013 they don't just die for no reason.\"\n\nIn a news release, Vancouver police said they believe Chelsea \"likely died on the property the night she disappeared or shortly thereafter, but went undiscovered because the house has been vacant for years.\"\n\nWhen addressing reporters, police acknowledged that squatters had often been on the property, but said they would not speculate as to how she died.\n\nHer mother believes someone must have been there when it happened, in part because her daughter was found covered in a blanket.\n\n\"People must have been in that place,\" she said. \"Squatters, somebody would know something.\"\n\nChelsea went missing after leaving a friend's apartment in Vancouver's downtown core on the night of Sept. 6, 2020.\n\nLate that night, she spoke with her sister on the phone, and suggested she was with a new love interest.\n\nHer family never heard from her again.\n\nThey have previously expressed frustration with the police department's handling of her case. While they reported Chelsea missing on Sept. 8, authorities did not announce her disappearance until Sept. 18.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been nothing but a major fail from the beginning \u2013 the first 10 days there was nothing done,\" said her father, Michael Kiernan, who believes Chelsea's Indigenous heritage played a role.\n\n\u201cThis (issue) is not going away, this is only going to grow and I\u2019m going to see this through the end.\u201d\n\nCTV News asked Vancouver police about those concerns and they insisted they have dedicated considerable resources to the case.\n\n\u201cWe worked as hard as we could,\" said Addison. \"Missing persons, the major crimes section is consistently reviewing tips, reviewing old leads, interviewing witness, looking for clues up until the day she was discovered, in an attempt to locate her and bring her home.\u201d\n\nSheila said her daughter deserved a better life. She remembered Chelsea as a kind and caring person who watched out for others.\n\n\"When we lived in Saskatoon, she would want to go for a drive so we could make sure people on the street were OK. She wanted to make sure that people on the street were warm and had a place to go. That's who Chelsea was,\" she said, crying.\n\n\"So if anybody knows anything about what happened to Chelsea, I wish they'd speak up and let us know.\"\n\nLate Friday afternoon, dancers from Butterflies in Spirit\n(opens in a new tab)\n laid flowers and incense outside the home where Chelsea's remains hid, unknown to her family and loved ones. They're planning a memorial gathering there for Sunday.\n\nUPDATE: A small memorial now sits outside the house, set up by @ButterfliesBIS\nThey\u2019re now planning to hold a vigil for Chelsea on Sunday@CTVVancouver https://t.co/6reaG1gQF2 pic.twitter.com/dAwFQcfwra\n\n\u2014 Penny Daflos (@PennyDaflos) May 7, 2022\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nChelsea Poorman is pictured in photos posted on a website about her disappearance. {"url": "https://bc.ctvnews.ca/remains-of-missing-woman-chelsea-poorman-found-outside-vancouver-home-1.5892309", "title": "Missing woman Chelsea Poorman's body found | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nVANCOUVER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nVANCOUVER\nNews\nRemains of missing woman Chelsea Poorman found at vacant Vancouver home\n02:44\nRemains of missing woman discovered\n03:04\nTragic end to search for missing woman\nAndrew Weichel\nCTVNewsVancouver.ca Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPenny Daflos\nCTV News Vancouver Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 7, 2022 10:19 a.m. MDT\nPublished May 6, 2022 1:48 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nThe search for a young Indigenous woman has ended in tragedy after her remains were found at a vacant home in Vancouver's Shaughnessy neighbourhood.\n\nFor 24-year-old Chelsea Poorman's grieving family, the discovery brought little closure \u2013 only new questions.\n\n\"We still don't know what happened to her,\" said Sheila Poorman, the young woman's mother. \"I don't know if we'll ever find out.\"\n\nContractors spotted Chelsea's remains on April 22, while working on a property near Granville Street and West 37th Avenue, an expensive part of the city lined with multimillion-dollar homes.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nMissing woman Chelsea Poorman's father on relentless quest to find her\nA young Indigenous woman vanished a year ago. There's a $10K reward in her case, but there's been no sign of her since that day.\n$10,000 reward offered by family of young Indigenous woman who vanished in Vancouver\n\nHer identity was later confirmed through DNA testing, and authorities notified her family on Friday morning before making a public announcement.\n\n\"This is not the outcome anyone wanted. We always hoped Chelsea would be found alive, and our sympathies go out to everyone who knew Chelsea, loved her, and hoped she would come home safely,\" Sgt. Steve Addison of the Vancouver Police Department said in a statement.\n\nHe later told reporters that Chelsea\u2019s skeleton had been found outside the home in a heavily wooded area, and that toxicology and other analysis would not be possible on her remains, but that Vancouver police would be providing \"personal details\" to the family in the coming days.\n\nThe news came one day after the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, also known as Red Dress Day, which saw ceremonies held across the country, including in Vancouver.\n\nChelsea was a member of the Kawacatoose First Nation in Saskatchewan, but was living on the West Coast when she disappeared.\n\nPolice do not consider her death to be suspicious, but have not provided any further details, except that they have reviewed the findings of a coroner's investigation.\n\nHer mother, who spoke with the coroner on Friday, told CTV News she doesn't understand how police came to that conclusion.\n\n\"I don't know why they would say that,\" Sheila said. \"They don't even have a cause of death. They don't know what happened. Somebody just doesn't \u2013 they don't just die for no reason.\"\n\nIn a news release, Vancouver police said they believe Chelsea \"likely died on the property the night she disappeared or shortly thereafter, but went undiscovered because the house has been vacant for years.\"\n\nWhen addressing reporters, police acknowledged that squatters had often been on the property, but said they would not speculate as to how she died.\n\nHer mother believes someone must have been there when it happened, in part because her daughter was found covered in a blanket.\n\n\"People must have been in that place,\" she said. \"Squatters, somebody would know something.\"\n\nChelsea went missing after leaving a friend's apartment in Vancouver's downtown core on the night of Sept. 6, 2020.\n\nLate that night, she spoke with her sister on the phone, and suggested she was with a new love interest.\n\nHer family never heard from her again.\n\nThey have previously expressed frustration with the police department's handling of her case. While they reported Chelsea missing on Sept. 8, authorities did not announce her disappearance until Sept. 18.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been nothing but a major fail from the beginning \u2013 the first 10 days there was nothing done,\" said her father, Michael Kiernan, who believes Chelsea's Indigenous heritage played a role.\n\n\u201cThis (issue) is not going away, this is only going to grow and I\u2019m going to see this through the end.\u201d\n\nCTV News asked Vancouver police about those concerns and they insisted they have dedicated considerable resources to the case.\n\n\u201cWe worked as hard as we could,\" said Addison. \"Missing persons, the major crimes section is consistently reviewing tips, reviewing old leads, interviewing witness, looking for clues up until the day she was discovered, in an attempt to locate her and bring her home.\u201d\n\nSheila said her daughter deserved a better life. She remembered Chelsea as a kind and caring person who watched out for others.\n\n\"When we lived in Saskatoon, she would want to go for a drive so we could make sure people on the street were OK. She wanted to make sure that people on the street were warm and had a place to go. That's who Chelsea was,\" she said, crying.\n\n\"So if anybody knows anything about what happened to Chelsea, I wish they'd speak up and let us know.\"\n\nLate Friday afternoon, dancers from Butterflies in Spirit\n(opens in a new tab)\n laid flowers and incense outside the home where Chelsea's remains hid, unknown to her family and loved ones. They're planning a memorial gathering there for Sunday.\n\nUPDATE: A small memorial now sits outside the house, set up by @ButterfliesBIS\nThey\u2019re now planning to hold a vigil for Chelsea on Sunday@CTVVancouver https://t.co/6reaG1gQF2 pic.twitter.com/dAwFQcfwra\n\n\u2014 Penny Daflos (@PennyDaflos) May 7, 2022\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nChelsea Poorman is pictured in photos posted on a website about her disappearance. {"url": "https://www.cornwallseawaynews.com/ontario-news/indigenous-leaders-want-corporate-reconciliation-efforts-to-extend-beyond-sept-30/", "title": "Indigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30", "body": "Skip to content\nNews\nDeath Notices\nJobs\nMagazines\n 29\u00b0\nIndigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30\nSeptember 30, 2022 at 15 h 32 min\nReading time: 4 min 30 s\nTara Deschamps, The Canadian Press\nComment count:\n\nTORONTO \u2014 Chelsee Pettit spent much of the summer collaborating with designers to create and manufacture apparel reflective of the Indigenous values she hoped would be on people\u2019s minds when Canada marks its second National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.\n\nBut in the days leading up to Sept. 30, she noticed many companies had not had the same forethought and were scrambling to place bulk orders with her store, Aaniin.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a little funny how last-minute other organizations that are all non-Indigenous are, and they\u2019re pushing that (work) back onto Indigenous people,\u201d said Pettit, an Anishinaabe woman.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not like big box stores that just have disposable T-shirts and are at everybody\u2019s beck and call. Working with us ahead of time as opposed to just laying it on us a week before the day, I think would be super helpful.\u201d\n\nPettit has tried her best to accommodate last-minute orders, but she and other members of the Indigenous business community see the trend as a sign of how much more work corporate Canada has to do to turn support for Indigenous communities into a 365-day-a-year effort.\n\nWhile many businesses encourage staff to don orange shirts \u2014 a tradition started by residential school survivor Phyllis Webstad in 2013 \u2014 or to sell wares in the bright hue on Sept. 30, those efforts quickly fade. Companies often don\u2019t do much more to elevate Indigenous voices and causes.\n\n\u201cIt is positive that we are seeing education happen and awareness-building happen, but it can be quite triggering and harmful for Indigenous Peoples who see it as one day of performative action and nothing throughout the rest of the year,\u201d said Tabatha Bull, president and chief executive of the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business (CCAB).\n\nBull and Pettit say if an employer is looking to make a mark on truth and reconciliation goals, they should also be doing that work all year round.\n\nThose efforts should begin with educating staff about both long-standing and new traumas Indigenous Peoplesface and how to support those affected.\n\nPettit recallsbeing at work in 2021, when the remains of 215 children were found at a former residential school site in British Columbia.\n\n\u201cMy boss at the time was like, \u2018Oh, well, everybody knew about that already\u2019 and just like kind of brushed it off, but I was feeling very emotional that day for obvious reasons, so there\u2019s tons of work that has to be done,\u201d she said.\n\nThat\u2019s borne out in studies too.\n\nA 2021 report from equity organization Catalyst Canada found about 52 per cent of the 86 Indigenous respondents surveyed are \u201con guard\u201d at work and about 60 per cent feel psychologically unsafe on the job.\n\nThe study was based on a survey of 820 Canadian workers from various under-represented groups, but Catalyst isolated results from Indigenous respondents for this report because their need to feel on guard was so significant.\n\nKrystal Abotossaway, president of the Indigenous Professional Association of Canada, said she has seen more companies move toward reflecting on what they can do to improve their corporate culture and support Indigenous communities in recent years.\n\nLand acknowledgments, which note which Indigenous Peoples lived and took care of a site events are being held on, are an increasingly common and good start, she said.\n\nBull counts at least 200 companies, including Bank of Montreal, Uber, Walmart and Rogers, as members of the CCAB\u2019s Progressive Aboriginal Relation program \u2014 an initiative helping them build cultural awareness and make progress on reconciliation plans.\n\nOthers have yet to take on such work. Bull thinks they\u2019re slower to act because they feel overwhelmed and afraid of having difficult conversations.\n\n\u201cSome corporations are just not even knowing what the right question is to ask,\u201d she said. \u201cI think we need to move beyond that, if we\u2019re going to really progress as a country.\u201d\n\nAbotossaway said they can start by marking other Indigenous days and use them as an opportunity to educate.\n\nAmong those she suggested are Red Dress Day, which commemorates the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and International Inuit Day, National Indigenous Peoples Day and Louis Riel Day, which celebrates the life of the late M\u00e9tis leader.\n\nThe efforts shouldn\u2019t stop there, she added. Companies should reflect on how their governance structures, hiring policies, talent pipelines and workforce education programs align with Indigenous needs, she said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve seen a lot of learning and development content come out, but that\u2019s usually just one course and it might be just an hour long,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIs it mandatory or is it not mandatory? And then how many of your employees or workforce are participating in it?\u201d\n\nAbotossaway and Bull agree any corporate actions on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation or other days should involve Indigenous Peoples at every step \u2014 even if the action is selling orange apparel.\n\nBull said, \u201cIf you\u2019re going to create an orange shirt, ensure that you\u2019re working with an Indigenous artist, ensure that the Orange Shirt Society or an Indigenous organization benefits from that and you\u2019re not making a profit off of the orange shirt or Sept. 30.\u201d\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Sept. 30, 2022.\n\nCompanies in this story: (TSX:BMO, TSX:RCI)\n\nShare this article\nSUGGESTED ARTICLES\nONTARIO NEWS\nNew centre in the works to track Indigenous data on businesses, land and resources\n\nOTTAWA \u2014 A new institute is in the works that would track Indigenous economic prosperity in Canada\u2026\n\nONTARIO NEWS\nRCMP adds ribbon skirt to uniform in effort to build bridges with Indigenous people\n\nOTTAWA \u2014 The RCMP has added a traditional Indigenous ribbon skirt to its uniform. PHOTO BY JUSTIN TANG /THE CANADIAN PRESS\nArticle content\n\nThe federal Treasury Board Secretariat decreed last week that civil servants would be required to spend a minimum of three days a week in the office. That\u2019s a surprise. The pandemic is over. Most people assumed federal public servants were already back in the office \u2013 full time.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nUnsurprisingly, there\u2019s pushback from the unions.\n\nSharon DeSousa, National Executive Vice-President of the Public Service Alliance of Canada told an Ottawa radio station that, \u201cWithout a doubt, we are going to take legal recourse and we will be fighting it,\u201d she said.\n\nWill they strike? If so, will they picket their workplace \u2013 which in this case is their own homes?\nEmployers \u2013 that is, taxpayers \u2013 have every right to tell workers where they should report to work.\n\nIn many cases, work from home is effective. That doesn\u2019t seem to be the case in the public service, where the government has added 100,000 employees since 2015, with nearly 70% of that growth happening since 2019 \u2013 coincidentally when the pandemic hit and workers went home.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe more civil servants work from home, the more civil servants we need, which suggests a productivity problem.\n\nThis is a classic case of do as I say, not as I do. It will be hard for the government to argue that working from home is inefficient, since Parliament itself is in a hybrid mode.\n\nIn February, several Liberal MPs were quoted in the online publication Politico saying they don\u2019t intend to return to Parliament Hill any time soon, preferring the flexibility of working from home.\n\nToronto area MP Nate Erskine-Smith said he spends a lot time in his constituency. \u201cIf you want serious people, younger people, people who want to be good spouses and be good parents to do this job \u2026 there has to be a certain level of flexibility to work remotely.\u201d\n\nIf Parliament returned to a full in-person proceeding, \u201cthere\u2019s no chance I\u2019d run again,\u201d he said.\n\nWell, so long. Farewell. Auf wiedersehen and goodbye, Mr. Erskine-Smith. It used to be an honour to stand in the hallowed halls of the House of Commons and vote on behalf of your constituents.\n\nGreat leaders lead by example \u2013 and not in their pyjamas. If you want civil servants to return to work, MPs must show the way.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10158270/bc-police-watchdog-investigating-chelsea-quaw-death/", "title": "B.C. police watchdog investigating death of Saik\u2019uz First Nation woman - BC | Globalnews.ca", "body": "SKIP TO MAIN CONTENT\nSUBSCRIBE\nRADIO\nLIVE\nSite theme toggle. Switch between light or dark mode\nLIGHT\nDARK\nGlobalNews home\nWatch\nWorld\nCanada\nLocal\nPolitics\nMoney\nHealth\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nPerspectives\nSports\nCommentary\nContests\nPodcasts\nU.S. News\nShopping\nFull Menu\nSearch Menu\nCANADA\nB.C. police watchdog investigating death of Saik\u2019uz First Nation woman\nBy Elizabeth McSheffrey  Global News\nPosted December 8, 2023 8:20 pm\n Updated December 14, 2023 6:06 pm\n 4 min read\nThe search for a missing Indigenous woman in northern B.C. has had a tragic ending. RCMP say Chelsey Heron (Quaw) was found dead in a wooded area of the Saik'uz First Nation in Vanderhoof \u2013 Nov 6, 2023\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nWarning: This story contains details that may upset and trigger some readers. Anyone affected by the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQIA+ people needing support can call a national toll free crisis line at 1-844-413-6649.\n\nBritish Columbia\u2019s civilian-led police watchdog has launched an investigation into the death of a beloved Saik\u2019uz First Nation woman whose remains were found, tragically, in a wooded area of the community last month.\n\nChelsey Heron (Quaw), 29, was last seen leaving her father\u2019s house on the nation near Vanderhoof, B.C. on Oct. 11 \u2014 the same day Vanderhoof RCMP were called to conduct a wellness check on Chelsey at a private home.\n\nAccording to B.C.\u2019s Independent Investigations Office (IIO), Mounties took steps to find the woman, but were unsuccessful.\n\nChelsey was found dead on Nov. 5.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n1:49\nNational Day of Action for MMIWG\n\nLater that month, the watchdog received several concerns from the public about the police response to the request for a wellness check. The IIO doesn\u2019t use victims\u2019 names in its releases in order to protect the privacy.\n\n\u201cWhat we would look at in a case like this is, was there a failure of police to take the appropriate steps in the circumstances that they were facing?\u201d explained Ronald MacDonald, IIO chief civilian director.\n\n\u201cThe police have a duty at law to protect human life, so if they\u2019re given information about a situation where someone\u2019s life may be impacted or in danger, they have a duty to take reasonable steps to do what they can to help that person.\u201d\n\n2:02\nRed Dress Day honours memory of MMIWG2S\n\nThe IIO is charged with investigating what role any police action \u2014 or inaction \u2014 has had when a civilian is seriously hurt or killed in relation to a police-involved incident. If it believes a criminal offence has been committed, it may refer the matter to the BC Prosecution Service.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nMacDonald said he hopes to have findings in this case within six months.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\nThe BC Coroners Service and RCMP are still conducting their own investigations into Chelsey\u2019s death.\n\n2:03\nSewing red ribbon skirts in honour of MMIWG\n\nIn November, after Chelsey\u2019s remains were found, her mother Pam issued a public statement described her daughter as \u201cloved cared for deeply by her family, friends and community.\u201d\n\n\u201cChelsey had the most amazing spirit, beautiful strength and independence. Most importantly, she had an incredible impact on those in her life. We will not rest until we get answers,\u201d Pam said.\n\nIn previous comments, Pam has said Chelsey was deeply connected to her culture and to nature, and loved to walk her dog Pepper outdoors.\n\nSaik\u2019uz First Nation Chief Priscilla Mueller referred a request for comment on this story to Mary Teegee, director of child and family services at Carrier Sekani Family Services. Teegee was not available on Friday.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n7:03\nCanada begins consultations on alert system for missing Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people\n\nChelsey was the second citizen of Saik\u2019uz First Nation to go missing in 2023.\n\nJay Raphael went missing on Feb. 26, with his disappearance described as \u201cvery uncharacteristic\u201d by his family.\n\nChelsey\u2019s family repeatedly advocated for support finding Raphael, whose whereabouts are still unknown, using attention around Chelsey\u2019s disappearance as a platform.\n\n5:17\nOrganization launches scholarship ensuring gender equality\n\nMeanwhile, Carrier Sekani Family Services and the Highway of Tears Governing Body have called on the B.C. government to rename Highway 16, the \u201cHighway of Hope.\u201d More than 40 women and girls, mostly First Nations, have gone missing or been murdered along the notorious 725-kilometre stretch of road, which passes through Vanderhoof and is sometimes called the Highway of Tears.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nThis month, Canada launched public consultations on developing a public alert system for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people (MMIWG2S), in recognition of the crisis of violence and crime that has disproportionately affected them for generations.\u00a0Earlier this year, the House of Commons unanimously backed a motion declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nIn 2019, a national inquiry into the MMIWG2S crisis\u00a0found more than six in 10 Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people have experienced physical or sexual violence. They are also 12 times more likely to be missing or murdered than non-Indigenous women.\n\nAnyone with information on Chelsey\u2019s death is asked to contact the IIO\u2019s witness line at 1-855-446-8477 or fill out the contact form on the watchdog\u2019s website.\n\n\u2014\u00a0with files from Catherine Urquhart\n\nThe Hope for Wellness Help Line offers culturally competent counselling and crisis intervention to all Indigenous peoples experiencing trauma, distress, strong emotions and painful memories. The line can be reached anytime toll-free at 1-855-242-3310.\n\nSign up to receive newsletters and breaking news email alerts.\u00a0\n\nMORE ON BC\n2 prominent B.C. TRREB\nHudson's Bay Co. buying Neiman Marcus for US$2.65 billion\nECONOMICS\n\nSep 30, 2022\n\nIndigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30\n\nTara Deschamps, The Canadian Press\n\nNow Showing\n2:57\n\nCorporate Canada\u2019s long road ahead for Indigenous economic inclus...\n\nUp Next\n7:20\n\nHow Raven Indigenous Capital Partners is closing the funding gap\n\nChelsee Pettit spent much of\u00a0the\u00a0summer collaborating with designers to create and manufacture apparel reflective of\u00a0the\u00a0Indigenous values she hoped would be on people's minds when Canada marks its second National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.\n\nBut in\u00a0the\u00a0days leading up to Sept. 30, she noticed many companies had not had\u00a0the\u00a0same forethought and were scrambling to place bulk orders with her store, Aaniin.\n\n\"It's just a little funny how last-minute other organizations that are all non-Indigenous are, and they're pushing that (work) back onto Indigenous people,\" said Pettit, an Anishinaabe woman.\n\n\"We're not like big box stores that just have disposable T-shirts and are at everybody's beck and call. Working with us ahead of time as opposed to just laying it on us a week before\u00a0the\u00a0day, I think would be super helpful.\"\n\nPettit has tried her best to accommodate last-minute orders, but she and other members of\u00a0the\u00a0Indigenous business community see\u00a0the\u00a0trend as a sign of how much more work corporate Canada has to do to turn support for Indigenous communities into a 365-day-a-year effort.\n\nWhile many businesses encourage staff to don orange shirts \u2014 a tradition started by residential school survivor Phyllis Webstad in 2013 \u2014 or to sell wares in\u00a0the\u00a0bright hue on Sept. 30, those efforts quickly fade. Companies often don't do much more to elevate Indigenous voices and causes.\n\n\"It is positive that we are seeing education happen and awareness-building happen, but it can be quite triggering and harmful for Indigenous Peoples who see it as one day of performative action and nothing throughout\u00a0the\u00a0rest of\u00a0the\u00a0year,\" said Tabatha Bull, president and chief executive of\u00a0the\u00a0Canadian\u00a0Council for Aboriginal Business (CCAB).\n\nBull and Pettit say if an employer is looking to make a mark on truth and reconciliation goals, they should also be doing that work all year round.\n\nThose efforts should begin with educating staff about both long-standing and new traumas Indigenous Peoples\u00a0face and how to support those affected.\n\nPettit recalls\u00a0being at work in 2021, when\u00a0the\u00a0remains of 215 children were found at a former residential school site in British Columbia.\n\n\"My boss at\u00a0the\u00a0time was like, 'Oh, well, everybody knew about that already' and just like kind of brushed it off, but I was feeling very emotional that day for obvious reasons, so there's tons of work that has to be done,\" she said.\n\nThat's borne out in studies too.\n\nA 2021 report from equity organization Catalyst Canada found about 52 per cent of\u00a0the\u00a086 Indigenous respondents surveyed are \u201con guard\u201d at work and about 60 per cent feel psychologically unsafe on\u00a0the\u00a0job.\n\nThe\u00a0study was based on a survey of 820\u00a0Canadian\u00a0workers from various under-represented groups, but Catalyst isolated results from Indigenous respondents for this report because their need to feel on guard was so significant.\n\nKrystal Abotossaway, president of\u00a0the\u00a0Indigenous Professional Association of Canada, said she has seen more companies move toward reflecting on what they can do to improve their corporate culture and support Indigenous communities in recent years.\n\nLand acknowledgments, which note which Indigenous Peoples lived and took care of a site events are being held on, are an increasingly common and good start, she said.\n\nBull counts at least 200 companies, including Bank of Montreal, Uber, Walmart and Rogers, as members of\u00a0the\u00a0CCAB's Progressive Aboriginal Relation program \u2014 an initiative helping them build cultural awareness and make progress on reconciliation plans.\n\nOthers have yet to take on such work. Bull thinks they're slower to act because they feel overwhelmed and afraid of having difficult conversations.\n\n\"Some corporations are just not even knowing what\u00a0the\u00a0right question is to ask,\" she said. \"I think we need to move beyond that, if we're going to really progress as a country.\"\n\nAbotossaway said they can start by marking other Indigenous days and use them as an opportunity to educate.\n\nAmong those she suggested are Red Dress Day, which commemorates\u00a0the\u00a0lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and International Inuit Day, National Indigenous Peoples Day and Louis Riel Day, which celebrates\u00a0the\u00a0life of\u00a0the\u00a0late M\u00e9tis leader.\n\nThe\u00a0efforts shouldn't stop there, she added. Companies should reflect on how their governance structures, hiring policies, talent pipelines and workforce education programs align with Indigenous needs, she said.\n\n\"We've seen a lot of learning and development content come out, but that's usually just one course and it might be just an hour long,\" she said.\n\n\"Is it mandatory or is it not mandatory? And then how many of your employees or workforce are participating in it?\"\n\nAbotossaway and Bull agree any corporate actions on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation or other days should involve Indigenous Peoples at every step \u2014 even if\u00a0the\u00a0action is selling orange apparel.\n\nBull said, \"If you're going to create an orange shirt, ensure that you're working with an Indigenous artist, ensure that\u00a0the\u00a0Orange Shirt Society or an Indigenous organization benefits from that and you're not making a profit off of\u00a0the\u00a0orange shirt or Sept. 30.\"\n\nSubscribe to BNN Bloomberg Newsletters BNN Bloomberg Personalities Weekly Guest Schedule Channel Guide Contact Us Privacy Policy Accessibility Political Ad Registry Terms & Conditions FAQ\n\u00a9 2024All Rights Reserved\nCTV News Sites"},
{"url": "https://www.brainerddispatch.com/news/local/red-sand-project-highlights-human-trafficking-issue", "title": "Red Sand Project highlights human trafficking issue - Brainerd Dispatch | News, weather, sports from Brainerd and Baxter", "body": "Sections\nShow Search\n99\u00a2/month for 3 months\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\n9+\nLog in\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nNEWS LOCAL\nRed Sand Project highlights human trafficking issue\nThe REDress Project, recognized at the same time, brings awareness to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women.\nJordan Christian, prevention educator at Sexual Assault Services, sprinkles red sand on the sidewalk outside Central Lakes College on Wednesday, May 1, 2024, as part of the Red Sand Project, which serves to raise awareness for human trafficking.Tim Speier / Brainerd Dispatch\nBy Theresa Bourke\nMay 03, 2024 at 5:57 AM\n \n Comments\n Share\n News reporting\n\nBRAINERD \u2014 Cracks in the sidewalks in front of Central Lakes College are red.\n\nThe brightly colored sand carefully placed there Wednesday, May 1, symbolizes human trafficking victims who fall through the cracks.\n\nCLC takes part in the international Red Sand Project on the first Wednesday in May each year.\n\nKarole Wagner, with WeARE-The Clinic, stops to spread some sand through the cracks of the sidewalks on Wednesday, May 1, 2024, at Central Lakes College.Tim Speier / Brainerd Dispatch\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just to get people talking about it \u2014 to raise awareness about the victims,\u201d said Megan Bistodeau, director of accessibility services at CLC.\n\nRed sand handprints glistened on the sidewalk as Bistodeau spoke about the project.\n\nThe college partners with WeAre, Sexual Assault Services and local law enforcement to bring awareness to the issue of human trafficking, which affects 50 million people per year. By participating in the project, Bistodeau hopes to get the word out about the issue of human trafficking and help people realize that it happens in Minnesota and even Brainerd.\n\nJordan Christian, prevention educator and advocate at Sexual Assault Services, was on hand to answer questions and promote the project, too.\n\n\u201cI had a couple of students come up, and they were like, \u2018That\u2019s happening in our country?\u2019\u201d Christian said. \u201cAnd I was like, \u2018Yeah, this happens in our country; it happens in our community.\u201d\n\nPackets of red sand sat on tables outside the college\u2019s front doors Wednesday, inviting students, staff and visitors to learn about the initiative and sprinkle their own sand in and around the sidewalk cracks.\n\nRed sand art projects were on display inside, along with posters bringing awareness to sexual assault, picturing people reiterating common excuses for the crime.\n\nCentral Lakes College looked to raise awareness on Wednesday, May 1, 2024, about human trafficking and the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women by spreading red sand through the cracks of the sidewalks and hanging red dresses around campus.Tim Speier / Brainerd Dispatch\n\nIn a video created to promote the Red Sand Project, Kate LePage, a regional navigator for Safe Harbor in central Minnesota, spoke of what constitutes trafficking.\n\n\u201cWhen we talk about what commercial sexual exploitation is, it\u2019s the exchange of something of value or the promise of something of value for a sexual act,\u201d she said. \u201cThat something of value can be money \u2026 transportation, food, drugs, alcohol, housing. It can even be intangible \u2014 status in a community. Anything that\u2019s perceived of value qualifies under that commercial sexual exploitation and then sex trafficking.\u201d\n\nThere is a grooming process, she said, often initiated online or by someone who is known to the victim.\n\n... It\u2019s time that we bring attention to those that have been missing and those that have been murdered.\nMary Sam, dean of student equity and inclusion at CLC\n\nCrow Wing County Sheriff\u2019s Office Lt. Craig Katzenberger spoke in the video of law enforcement\u2019s goal to make their departments aware of the potential of trafficking and how to look for red flags.\n\n\u201cIt could involve just short-term trafficking at hotels and motels. It could be several young girls in a vehicle with maybe an older male,\u201d he said. \u201cIf there\u2019s any red flags that come up, just to separate the individuals, ask some questions and just get the stories from everyone involved.\u201d\n\nMORE BY THERESA BOURKE\nSchool board aims to nix phones by 2025\n21h ago\nBourke's Bookshelf: Grilled cheese and a stolen hoodie\n1d ago\nBPU union files intent to strike\n2d ago\n\nBack outside at CLC, red dresses hung from trees outside CLC, as the event worked in conjunction with the REDress Project as well. Every year on May 5, Red Dress Day brings awareness to the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women epidemic in the U.S. and Canada.\n\nMary Sam, dean of student equity and inclusion at CLC, spoke to that epidemic in the video.\n\n\u201cIn Ojibwe culture, we\u2019re taught that the color red represents the relationship between the physical world and spiritual world and our connection to our ancestors,\u201d Sam said. \u201cMissing and Murdered Indigenous Women is near and dear to my heart as a grandmother of a missing and murdered young woman \u2014 my granddaughter in 2016.\u201d\n\nNative American women are up to 10 times more likely to be murdered or sexually assaulted than white women, Sam added.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s wrong, and it\u2019s time that we bring attention to those that have been missing and those that have been murdered,\u201d she said in the video. \u201cWe are their voices, right? And we will not be silenced. I will not be silenced.\u201d\n\nTHERESA BOURKE may be reached at theresa.bourke@brainerddispatch.com or 218-855-5860.
