{"url": "https://www.interior-news.com/news/more-tears-shed-as-indigenous-leaders-family-search-for-2-missing-along-highway-of-tears/", "title": "More tears shed as plea made to find 2 more missing on B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears - The Smithers Interior News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAutos\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.3 \u00b0C\nHome News\nMore tears shed as plea made to find 2 more missing on B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears\nMary Teegee of Carrier Sekani Child & Family Services says society must do better\n\tRuth Lloyd\n\nNov 3, 2023 3:47 PM\nNov 3, 2023 4:05 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 8 Chief Priscilla Mueller, with mic, of Saik\u2019uz First Nation, speaks at a press conference calling for more action and resources to help find two young people missing from the community west of Prince George, while family members of the missing, other leaders, sit nearby. (Carrier Sekani Child & Family Services photo)\nExpand\n\nFirst Nations leaders and the parents of two missing members of the Saik\u2019uz First Nation are calling for more resources and action to find the missing young people. Indigenous leaders and family spoke at a press conference in Vanderhoof today to request information and action by government.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been 24 days since my daughter Chelsea went missing, and we still don\u2019t have any answers,\u201d said a tearful Pam Heron, mother of missing woman Chelsey Quaw (Heron).\n\n\u201cI\u2019m trying as hard as I can. I have to fight just because his boys deserve to know where he\u2019s at,\u201d said Angie Raphael, mother of missing man Jay Raphael.\n\nChelsey Quaw (Heron) and Jay Preston Raphael are both missing members of the Saik\u2019uz First Nation, located 120 km west of Prince George, just outside Vanderhoof, B.C. and just 14 km south of Highway 16.\n\nHighway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears, due to the high number of missing and murdered women in the area, the majority of whom over the years have been Indigenous.\n\nCommunity leaders also shed tears as they spoke at a press conference in Vanderhoof, urging for more resources to be brought to the investigation into the two missing young people.\n\nChief Priscilla Mueller of Saik\u2019uz First Nation thanked all the volunteers who came to participate in the search so far, and said the Saik\u2019uz community had taken the search to Prince George and Vanderhoof as well.\n\nBut she said more needs to be done and more resources are needed.\n\n\u201cThere is only so much the local RCMP can do,\u201d she said, noting they need help from government.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not too sure how we\u2019re going to move forward with the search,\u201d she said.\n\nMary Teegee, executive director of Carrier Sekani Child & Family Service expressed frustration at the lack of action on the 33 recommendations from the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium Report, which she was also a part of.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m upset that we have to be here again,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThere are things we need to think about as a society, how much value are we placing on our Indigenous women, our Indigenous men.\u201d\n\nShe called for more action from both the government, law enforcement and the media to help draw attention to the ongoing issues surrounding missing and murdered Indigenous women and the Highway of Tears. She also referenced the missing women in Manitoba whose remains are believed to be in a landfill.\n\n\u201cIn Canada we\u2019re having to check the landfills for bodies of our missing Indigenous women. Think about that. As a society we have to do better.\u201d\n\nChelsey Quaw is a 29-year-old Indigenous woman with brown hair, brown eyes who vanished from her community last month.\n\nShe stands five feet, 10 inches tall and weighs about 120 pounds. She was possibly wearing blue jeans and a purple winter jacket when she went missing in the early morning hours of Oct. 11, 2023 from a residence on the Saik\u2019uz First Nation.\n\nSeveral search and rescue teams as well as community groups formed search parties to look for Quaw with no results.\n\nJay Preston Raphael has been missing from the community just over eight months.\n\nRaphael is a 28-year-old male with black hair and brown eyes, and unique tattoos on his neck, chest and arm.\n\nHe is five feet, nine inches tall and weighs approximately 143 pounds.\n\nRaphael was last seen on Feb. 25, 2023 at Saik\u2019uz First Nation wearing a black coat, blue jeans black runners and a baseball hat.\n\nSaik\u2019uz First Nation has an on-reserve population of about 400.\n\nLeaders also frequently referenced other missing women from the area. This included Mackie Basil, missing from Tl\u2019azt\u2019en Nation Nation, since 2013, Bonnie Joseph of Yekooche First Nation, missing from near Vanderhoof since 2008, Ramona Wilson of Gitxan First Nation, who went missing in 1994 and whose remains were found near Smithers in 1995. Her murder remains unsolved. They also mentioned Madison Scott and the ongoing search for justice in her case. Scott had been missing since 2011 and her remains were found earlier this year near Vanderhoof, but no charges have yet been laid as the investigation is ongoing.\n\nAnyone with any information can contact Vanderhoof RCMP at 250-567-2222 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.\n\nREAD MORE: Mother of missing Vanderhoof woman says she would never just take off\n\nREAD MORE: RCMP renews public assistance call to locate missing man\n\nREAD MORE: Search continues for missing Vanderhoof woman Chelsey Quaw\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Ruth Lloyd\n\nI moved back to my hometown of Williams Lake after living away and joined the amazing team at the Williams Lake Tribune in 2021.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tNorthwest B.C. author pens book about logging\n\t\tTeen dies after overdose involving fentanyl in northern B.C.: RCMP\n\t\t'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\n\t\tMan dies throwing candy during Alberta Canada Day parade\n\t\tTom Havard is this year\u2019s Hudson Bay Mountain Legendary Local\nFacebook Comments (0) \nMan who stabbed Mexican tourist at B.C. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/one-man-s-journey-on-the-highway-of-tears-1.2344200", "title": "One man\u2019s journey on the Highway of Tears - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 19.6 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nOne man\u2019s journey on the Highway of Tears\nHe might forget the words he wants to use to express himself and can't recall the name of a friend he just mentioned moments ago but Highway of Tears walker Brett Merchant, 56, never loses focus on why he's on the road.\nChristine Hinzmann\nSep 14, 2016 10:18 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nBrett Merchant and his dog Kura are walking the Highway of Tears from the B.C.-Alberta border to Haida Gwaii to help raise awareness about the murdered and missing women along the route. Merchant and Kura were in Prince George on Wednesday.Brent Braaten, Photographer\n\nHe might forget the words he wants to use to express himself and can't recall the name of a friend he just mentioned moments ago but Highway of Tears walker Brett Merchant, 56, never loses focus on why he's on the road.\n\n\"This is for the young women who are missing and murdered on the Highway of Tears,\" said the Kimberley resident on Wednesday afternoon as he stopped in Prince George during his solo trek from the B.C-Alberta border on Highway 16 to Haida Gwaii. He began the 1,236 kilometre journey on Sept. 1 at noon.\n\n\"Yes, thanks, I hear 'you're a great guy, good job for doing this' and thanks again very much but that's not what this is about for me - it's about keeping the awareness going for the safety of aboriginal women,\" said Merchant, who suffers from SLE lupus, early onset dementia and diabetes. He knew if he didn't do something quick, he would lose the physical ability to do anything at all.\n\nHe watched the Highway of Tears documentary on Nextflix recently and decided to go, leaving his care home and not knowing if he has a home to go back to when the time comes to return to Kimberley in the new year.\n\nMerchant brought Kura, his 10-year-old Siberian husky-wolf cross, who is in perfect health.\n\nMerchant's veterinarian OK'd Kura for the trip before they left, and again here in Prince George.\n\nThe vet will be back in a month to check on Kura again.\n\nMerchant, who has a tremor that affects his whole body continuously, is planning on ending his journey in Haida Gwaii on Dec. 31 at midnight, because then he starts the new year off knowing he completed the journey.\n\n\"Kura and I, we're winter. It was too hot yesterday (it reached about 20 degrees and was sunny) and when it rained all week before that was OK, we just kept walking because it's too hard to pack up and carry wet gear,\" said Merchant about the first leg of the trip.\n\nAs the dog draws attention at the Visitor Centre, Merchant explains again that this is not about him.\n\n\"Everybody is the same, we are all equal and we need to change society,\" said Merchant. \"The First Nations people were hit down, knocked to the ground and we have to help them up, not because they're native, but because we are the ones that knocked them down. And the whole world has to do that not just me or you but everyone.\"\n\nMerchant grew up in Cranbrook where his parents owned a downtown shoe store. When Merchant went to work on a Saturday with his dad, Robert, his job was to wake the men who were sleeping in the alley out back. When the men woke up, his dad would put them to work, shoveling snow, sweeping the sidewalk or taking out the garbage, but no money changed hands. Merchant was sent to the burger joint across the street with the men who would get a coffee and breakfast or a burger for lunch depending on the time of day. Merchant learned early that a hand up was much better than a hand out.\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nMerchant has always had a close connection to First Nations people and understands their plight.\n\n\"You ask yourself what's wrong and you realize it's the whole picture,\" said Merchant. \"It's not just one thing. Countries come over - even today, right now - and kick you off your land and then put you on a little block and say there, that's yours now, so you're broken right there. Your culture is busted.\"\n\nResidential schools were pure hell, even for some people that he knows, Merchant said.\n\n\"So you're either taken by the government away from your home or sometimes your mom and dad hear it's a good thing so they take you to the school and they take you to this school and then they take you to another school and your parents don't even know where you went. Some were beaten and raped and you don't get to talk your language and you have to learn a new one and learn to write and lose your heritage and lose everything and now you're down right here on the floor. Then you come out of there and how can you even learn to love a dog, when you were not shown love even though you went to this so-called good thing but it's crap. Some people made it out - I don't know how - they're stronger than I would ever be.\"\n\nSo everybody needs to help them, he added.\n\n\"I cannot undo the murders that have occurred along the Highway of Tears,\" said Merchant on his gofundme.com/highwayoftears page, trying to raise money for women's shelter projects.\n\n\"I hope that by raising awareness during my 1,236 km walk I can help prevent further injustices from happening.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. Spartz, of Indiana, charged with bringing gun through airport security, officials say\nMan with 14 warrants arrested after standoff with Monterey police\nWoman pushed into oncoming BART train in Bay Area dies, suspect arrested\nPedestrian killed in suspected Santa Cruz DUI crash\nTribal leaders honor missing and murdered indigenous women in Seaside\nShare\n  \nUpdated: 12:05 PM PDT May 8, 2023\nInfinite Scroll Enabled\nChristian Balderas   \nAnchor/Reporter\nPlay Video\nSEASIDE, Calif. \u2014\n\nTribal leaders and community members gathered in Seaside, Saturday to honor missing and murdered indigenous women.\n\n\"We are always on indigenous land\u2014everywhere we go\u2014and no flag will erase our presence. Acknowledgement is the first step for reconciliation and with that our healing can commence today,\" Andrew MacDonald, the Youth Tribal Chairman for the Esselen Tribe of Monterey County.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe morning started off with prayer and song followed by panel discussions on current issues plaguing indigenous communities across California.\n\n\"As you have more people that become aware, which is why I think these events are so important, change happens,\" the Tribal Council Chairperson for the Picayune Rancheria of the Chukchansi Indians, located in Madera County.\n\nThe event follows Missing and Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day, which is observed on May 5 and was formally recognized by President Joe Biden in 2021.\n\nIt's also known as Red Dress Day, named after an ongoing Canadian public art instillation that started in 2010, which commemorates missing and murdered indigenous women by hanging red dresses in various environments.\n\nFollowing the theme, red clothing was hung along the walls of Oldmeyer Center at the May 6 event in Seaside.\n\nRecommended\n1 dead in East Salinas shooting, 2 juveniles arrested\n\n\"Our women are sacred, our grandmothers, our mothers, our sister\u2014Where are you?\" a drummer said before breaking into song.\n\n[related id='5788573e-3a6a-4d2e-8256-c37a2c514a80' align='center'][/related]\n\nSand City Mayor Mary Ann Carbone and member of the Chumash tribe organized the event.\n\n\"I know of five [women] who were killed, murdered in the city of Seaside,\" Carbone said referring to the case of Courtney Ann Turney, a 33-year-old woman and member of the Comanche Nation who was imprisoned, tortured and murdered in 2017.\n\n\"She ended up living with a lady. The lady kept her hostage in an apartment for ten years and manually used her for trafficking and collecting her tribal check that came every month,\" she said.\n\nThe murder of Turney was just one of multiple harrowing stories spotlighted Saturday.\n\nNatalie Smith of the Manchester-Point Arena Band of Pomo Indians traveled to Seaside from Montecito wearing a red hoodie with her deceased sister's face printed on the front.\n\n\"My sister Nicole Smith was my younger sister and she has three kids. She was murdered in November of 2017 on the Manchester Rancheria at my sister's house. And the police didn't come for over an hour and we still have no leads. It's just been a long road working with the county,\" Smith said.\n\n[related id='35cea803-cb65-4abc-91c0-5006454e0ff0' align='center'][/related]\n\nThere are an estimated 4,200 missing and murdered cases that have gone unsolved, according to the U.S. Bureau of Indian Affairs. And federal health statistics estimate that Native American and Alaska Native women are murdered 10 times more than the national rate.\n\n\"Yeah, it's tiring educating the public, but we do it because we have to,\" Carbone said fighting tears.\n\nTOP PICKS\nRossen Reports: Do this one thing to build your emergency savings\nPatrick Bertoletti of Chicago wins his first men\u2019s title at annual Nathan\u2019s hot dog eating contest\nWhat causes fireworks colors?\nVideo shows a runaway boat going in circles on a lake\nKSBW MONTEREY\n  \nContact Us\nNews Team\nApps & Social\nEmail Alerts\nCareers\nInternships\nAdvertise with KSBW\nAdvertise with Estrella\nDigital Advertising Terms & Conditions\nBroadcast Terms & Conditions\nRSS\nEEO Reports\nCaptioning Contacts\nPublic Inspection File\nPublic File Assistance\nFCC Applications\nNews Policy Statements\n\nHearst Television participates in various affiliate marketing programs, which means we may get paid commissions on editorially chosen products purchased through our links to retailer sites.\n\n\u00a92024, Monterey Hearst Television Inc. on behalf of KSBW-TV.\nPrivacy Notice\nCA Notice at Collection\nYour CA Privacy Rights/Shine the Light\nDAA Industry Opt-Out\nTerms of Use\nSite Map\nYour Privacy Choices/(Opt-Out of Sale/Targeted Ads)"},

{"url": "https://www.wltribune.com/local-news/it-ignites-the-conversation-williams-lake-red-dress-ceremony-7354591", "title": "\u2018It ignites the conversation\u2019: Williams Lake Red Dress ceremony - The Williams Lake Tribune", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.7 \u00b0C\nHome Local News\n\u2018It ignites the conversation\u2019: Williams Lake Red Dress ceremony\nCariboo Friendship Society organized event to honour MMIWG\n\tMonica Lamb-Yorski\n\nMay 6, 2024 4:50 PM\nMay 6, 2024 4:53 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 11 Cariboo Friendship Society executive director Rosanna McGregor, left, and Williams Lake First Nation Chief Willie Sellars during the MMIWG ceremony in Williams Lake Monday, May 6. (Monica Lamb-Yorski photo - Williams Lake Tribune)\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:03:26\n\nEach year the Cariboo Friendship Society hosts a ceremony in Williams Lake to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThis year it was held on Monday, May 6, in the parking lot above the Stampede Grounds, drawing more than 100 people for food, drumming and singing, and a sacred fire.\n\n\u201cI know it is an emotional event for friends and family,\u201d said CFS executive director Rosanna McGregor. \u201cBut we hold this each year in hopes of bringing peace, love and understanding.\u201d\n\nChiwid Transition House is operated by the CFS as a place for women and children to flee domestic abuse.\n\nMcGregor said \u201csadly\u201d the program continues to be needed.\n\nLast November, all transition houses in B.C. did a count in one day that showed there were 2,022 women in the houses and another 825 who could not get into one.\n\n\u201cDrugs and alcohol abuse are sadly involved in some form for 80 per cent of domestic abuse cases,\u201d she said.\n\nMissing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Day is an opportunity to raise awareness about the issue and the \u201csad state of the world today,\u201d McGregor said and acknowledged there are also cases in the region of missing and murdered men.\n\n\u201cI want to encourage our communities to continue to break cycles,\u201d she said.\n\nWilliams Lake First Nation Chief Willie Sellars acknowledged McGregor and the CFS for putting on the event.\n\n\u201cIt ignites the conversation and puts into perspective how close our communities are,\u201d Sellars said, acknowledging there were leaders from various communities, including the municipality of Williams Lake present.\n\nWhile the day can trigger trauma, Sellars said it is about trying to find balance and healing.\n\n\u201cI am always thankful to participate and welcome you to the traditional territory,\u201d he said.\n\nRecalling a conversation with a community member Sunday, May 5, Sellars said they talked about the importance of putting the healing of First Nations people on the forefront.\n\nPeter Arnold Log Homes Ltd. of Williams Lake has donated a new wooden bench for the CFS memory garden at 624 Oliver Street.\n\nThe bench was on display at the ceremony and people were enjoying sitting on it.\n\nMcGregor said the new bench will be for people to sit and reflect and add a red rock to the memory garden if they want.\n\nCFS staff had a table with homemade cookies, bannock, chili and water bottles, as well as some reusable bags and pin featuring the red dress design created by Satsi Naziel for the Aboriginal Housing Management Association.\n\nNaziel uses the form line of northwest coast native art for the design.\n\n\u201cOvoid, S-shapes, and U-shapes are put together in a way they create a red dress. Inside the dress you can find simple house motifs to represent the work AMHA does with Indigenous communities regarding housing,\u201d Naziel said in a statement.\n\nREAD MORE: Red dresses at B.C fashion show honour missing and murdered Indigenous women\n\nREAD MORE: \u2018I just about became a missing, murdered woman\u2019: Kelowna Red Dress march\n\nDon\u2019t miss out on reading the latest local, provincial and national news offered at the Williams Lake Tribune. PHOTO BY DARRYL DYCK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\nArticle content\n\nA woman who disappeared from a First Nations community in central British Columbia last month has been found dead.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nVanderhoof RCMP and the Saik\u2019uz First Nation say the remains of Chelsey Quaw, who was reported missing on Oct. 11, were found in a wooded area on the Indigenous community\u2019s territory.\n\nPolice say the B.C. Coroners Service is investigating the cause of death, and no further details on the case are available at this time.\n\nQuaw was one of two community members missing from the First Nation \u2014 located 100 kilometres west of Prince George along Highway 16 \u2014 this year.\n\nThe stretch of highway between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears because dozens of people have vanished or been killed along it over the last few decades.\n\nFirst Nations leaders and family members last week called for more action from police and the public in locating both Quaw and Jay Preston Raphael, who was reported missing Feb. 26 after walking away from a residence at the Saik\u2019uz First Nation.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nQuaw\u2019s family issued a statement through the Saik\u2019uz First Nation and Carrier Sekani Family Services, thanking all people involved in the search and reminding them to keep up the continued search for Raphael.\n\nBookmark our website and support our journalism: Don\u2019t miss the news you need to know \u2014 add VancouverSun.com and TheProvince.com to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here.\n\nYou can also support our journalism by becoming a digital subscriber: For just $14 a month, you can get unlimited, ad-lite access to The Vancouver Sun, The Province, National Post and 13 other Canadian news sites. {"url": "https://thevarsity.ca/2024/05/06/breaking-utsu-issues-statement-of-solidarity-with-the-student-encampment-as-it-enters-fourth-day/", "title": "UTSU issues statement of solidarity with the student encampment as it enters fourth day \u2013 The Varsity", "body": "ABOUT US GET INVOLVED ADVERTISE TIPS\n   \n\nThe University of Toronto\u2019s Student Newspaper Since 1880\nHome\nNews\nBusiness & Labour\nFeatures\nOpinion\nArts & Culture\nScience\nSports\nPhotos\nIllustrations\nVideo\nMagazine\nGames\nENCAMPMENT, NEWS\nStudent encampment on day four with Palestinian flags along the fence. ESHNIKA SINGH/THE VARSITY\nUTSU issues statement of solidarity with the student encampment as it enters fourth day\n\nProtesters honour Red Dress Day, set up a makeshift barricade\n\nBy James Bullanoff \u2014 Published May 6, 2024\n\nAs students continue to protest at King\u2019s College Circle calling on U of T to divest funding from companies that supply the Israeli military, the University of Toronto Students\u2019 Union (UTSU) issued a statement in solidarity with the ongoing encampment.\u00a0\n\nOn May 5, the encampment, referred to by the protesters\u2019 as \u201cPeoples Circle for Palestine,\u201d entered its fourth day after an estimated 200 people stayed in King\u2019s College Circle overnight.\u00a0\n\nAs the encampment continues, students honoured Red Dress Day and set up a makeshift barrier within the enclosed area.\u00a0\n\nRed Dress Day\n\nThe student protesters\u2019 main event of honoring Red Dress Day \u2014 the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) \u2014 began with the protesters laying out red dresses on the fences across the camp.\n\nELEANOR YUNEUN PARK/THE VARSITY\n\nRed Dress Day was inspired by Winnipeg-based M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black\u2019s 2010 art installation of red dresses to bring awareness to MMIWG.\n\nAccording to the Assembly of First Nations, Indigenous women in Canada are four times more likely to be victims of violence than non-Indigenous women. They also make up 16 per cent of all female homicide victims.\u00a0\n\nKalliop\u00e9 Anvar McCall, a fourth-year student and spokesperson from UofT Occupy for Palestine (O4P) \u2014 the group of students organizing the protest \u2014 spoke to The Varsity about some of the parallels between Palestine and Turtle Island.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re one [in] the same. And in order for us to sustain an encampment here, there has to be a strong solidarity between the Indigenous elders who have been welcomed into our encampment, of course, because after all, we\u2019re on their land\u2026and between the Palestinian organizers.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAt 1:45 pm, a crowd of about 50 to 60 people walked up King\u2019s College Road and around\u00a0King\u2019s College Circle chanting \u201cno more stolen sisters.\u201d They eventually entered the gates and collectively chanted \u201cno peace on stolen land.\u201d At 1:57 pm, protesters formed a large circle in the encampment, where those part of the MMIWG group gave speeches.\u00a0\n\nCounter protest\n\nAmidst the MMIWG speeches inside the fences, the Canadian Women Against Antisemitism \u2014 a group of Jewish women against antisemitism and that denounces Jewish hatred \u2014 organized a \u201cStand with Students\u201d counter protest, after publishing on their website that \u201cstudents are in danger.\u201d Israel Now \u2014 a group that claims to restore the \u201cpride and integrity within the consciousness of the Jewish people\u201d \u2014 organized another counter protest outside King\u2019s College Circle.\u00a0\n\nAbout 10 counter protesters gathered outside the fences at 2:30 pm, with Campus Safety standing between them and the protesters. Toronto Police Service officers also stood by on the scene, but did not enter the encampment.\u00a0\n\nUnions and organization\u00a0\n\nOn May 5, the UTSU issued a statement on Instagram expressing its solidarity with students on the ongoing encampment.\u00a0\n\nThe statement mentioned that the UTSU \u201cstands firmly in support of the student encampment on our campus, our student\u2019s right to engage in peaceful protest, and the demands set forth by the parties involved.\u201d\u00a0\n\nThese demands include to disclose the universities financial holdings, divest from investments supporting the Israeli military, and terminate partnerships with Israeli academic institutions.\u00a0\n\nThe statement also said the UTSU wants to join \u201calongside other students unions\u201d the call to ensure safety of the students in the encampment, and that members of their executive committee have visited the encampment, observing \u201cthe sense of community fostered by those involved.\u201d\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are proud of our students and stand alongside them in peacefully advocating for their demands, and for the freedom of Palestine.\u201d\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nESHNIKA SINGH/THE VARSITY\n\nThe Muslim Students\u2019 Association (MSA) branches of UTSG, UTM, and UTSC also sent an email calling on student leaders and clubs to sign an open-letter to President Meric Gertler and Vice-Provost, Students Sandy Welsh, calling on the university administration to uphold freedom of expression policies.\u00a0\n\n\u201cOur university administration has taken a clear and bold stance against students\u2019 rights to peacefully assemble and express themselves,\u201d wrote MSA. \u201cThis is appalling to say the least.\u201d\u00a0\n\nThey are asking student clubs to sign the letter by May 6 to be included in its first release.\u00a0\n\nMakeshift barrier\u00a0\n\nAt around 10:14 pm, O4P protesters started to build a temporary barrier of tarps encircling the tents within the enclosed area of King\u2019s College Circle. The barrier forms a secondary wall surrounding their camp, with gaps in between them.\n\nO4P has not mentioned the purpose of setting up the barrier in time for publication.\n\nWith files from Eshnika Singh and Eleanor Yuneun Park\n\n\u00a0\n\nShare your thoughts\n\n\n\n\n0 Comments\nView all comments\n\nNo comments to display.\n\nTags: encampment, Meric Gertler, Muslim Students Association, Red Dress Day, University of Toronto, uoft, UTSU\n\nRelated articles\nFollowing the \u201cPeople\u2019s Circle for Palestine\u201d\nEditorial: Encampment protesters are not the issue \u2014 U of T\u2019s policies and protocols are\nStudent protesters argue for their right to protest on second day of injunction hearing\n\u201cDisclose, divest\u201d: Students camp out at King\u2019s College Circle demanding that U of T cut ties with Israel\n\u201cThe encampment must end\u201d: U of T gives students 24 hours to accept offer\nU of T raises safety concerns as student encampment enters second day\nQUICK LINKS\nHome\nAdvertise\nGet Involved\nBoard of Directors\nPrint Edition\nCode of Journalistic Ethics\nMORE LINKS\nContact\nMasthead\nTips\nEquity Guide\nPartners\nCommunity Guidelines\nFOLLOW US\n \u00a0theVarsity\n \u00a0thevarsitynewspaper\n \u00a0the.varsity\n \u00a0the.varsity\n \u00a0Issuu\nNEWSLETTER\n\nSubscribe to our newsletter to receive news and updates directly from The Varsity.\n\nEmail\n \n\nWe would like to acknowledge that The Varsity's office is built on the traditional territory of several First Nations, including the Huron-Wendat, the Petun First Nations, the Seneca, and most recently, the Mississaugas of the Credit. {"url": "https://www.drumhellermail.com/news/34527-community-shows-support-for-red-dress-day", "title": "Community shows support for Red Dress Day | DrumhellerMail", "body": "07\n04\n2024\nLast updateThu, 04 Jul 2024 9am\nHOME\nNEWS\nOBITS\nCLASSIFIEDS\nCRIME MAP\nFEATURED\nTOURISM\nSPORTS\nREAL ESTATE\nJOBS\nSTATIONERY\nABOUT\nCommunity shows support for Red Dress Day\n\u00a0Print\u00a0\n \n Email\n10 May 2022\n Written by Lacie Nairn- Local Journalism Initiative Reporter\n\nBig Country Anti-Violence Association (BCAVA) and the Drumheller Community Business Association (CBA) encouraged Drumheller businesses and community members to hang red dresses on Thursday, May 5 in support of National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People (MMIWG2S), better known as Red Dress Day. Red Dress Day is held in honour of and to bring awareness to the ongoing MMIWG2S crisis in Canada. Indigenous women, according to the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, are at a disproportionately high risk of homicide, representing about 10 per cent of all homicides against women in Canada, while only making up about three per cent of the country\u2019s female population. Red dresses were donated and hung at Angel\u2019s Corner near the Gordon Taylor Bridge as a visual representation of the missing, and a smudge and ceremony were held with Elder John Sinclair saying a prayer and singing a song of healing. About 20 attended the ceremony, including Town of Drumheller administration, members of BCAVA, and the Drumheller RCMP. Among those who attended the ceremony were (l-r) Elder Sinclair, Indigenous liaison Lynn Fabrick, and Drumheller Chief Administrative Officer Darryl Drohomerski.\n\n Prev\nNext \n\nThe Drumheller Mail encourages commenting on our stories but due to our harassment policy we must remove any comments that are offensive, or don\u2019t meet the guidelines of our commenting policy.\n\nAdvertise here\nAdvertise here\n\nBusiness Directory\nHome\nContact Us\nSearch\nLogin\nTop\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 DrumhellerMail. {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/local-news/highway-of-tears-victims-featured-in-documentary-6951766", "title": "Highway of Tears victims featured in documentary - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 19.6 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nHighway of Tears victims featured in documentary\n\u201cWe must always take the time to honour and acknowledge those among us who were taken so tragically and their families and communities.\"\n\tChristine Dalgleish\n\nMay 4, 2023 10:03 AM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nThe Prince George screening of the documentary that featured family members of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women along the Highway of Tears was screened on May 3.Adaawk documentary image\nListen to this article\n00:02:22\n\nIt was the fifth anniversary of the day Colten Fleury went missing and on his mother\u2019s face was etched each day\u2019s pain of her loss as Phyllis Fleury shared her story\u00a0with those seated before her.\n\nThe audience was at Famous Players Wednesday night in Prince George to see a documentary that looks\u00a0into the lives of those who have lost loved ones along the Highway of Tears. The documentary aired in time to acknowledge Red Dress Day to honour murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls.\n\nLorna Brown is director/producer of the documentary and not only included the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls but also the murdered and missing Indigenous men as well and that is why Colten Fleury was included in the documentary.\n\nPhyllis Fleury has dedicated her life to helping the unhoused in Prince George as an outreach worker for the Central Interior Native Health Society in the heart of downtown.\n\n\u201cI do my outreach because if my son is out there then somebody is helping him,\u201d Fleury said.\n\nCarrier Sekani Family Services (CSFS), in partnership with the Indian Residential School Survivors\u2019 Society (IRSSS), hosted the special screening of the film called Adaawk\u00a0(pronounced a-dow-ick), which means oral history in English.\n\nProducer/director Brown said the purpose behind her film is to put names and faces to the Indigenous women, girls, two-spirited and gender diverse people who have gone missing along the Highway of Tears, and to honour their families.\n\nIn the documentary, family members shared their stories of grief and loss addressing the fact that not all families have gotten closure as the young women in their families remain missing.\n\nThe documentary showed how impactful it was to see the raising of the Grandmother Commemoration Memorial and Healing Pole near Terrace, that acknowledges their loss and grief.\n\n\u201cWe must always take the time to honour and acknowledge those among us who were taken so tragically and their families and communities,\u201d Julie Daum, CSFS Executive Director of Justice, said as the master of ceremonies at the screening.\n\n\u201cWe must remember and take the time to reflect on who and what we lost. I appreciate all those who work to commemorate them.\u201d\n\nFor more information about the documentary visit www.adaawkfilm.com/.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has been shared 19 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tWater main break forces closure of Prince George street\n\tNew bus shelters coming to Prince George\n\tFoodie Fridays back for the summer in downtown Prince George\nPrince George - Featured\nBC's forest cutting permit process handcuffing industry, says Lheidli T'enneh, Simpcw chiefs\nRead More\nCOMMUNITY POLL\nParticipate in our next community poll.\nDo you watch or listen to CBC News once a week or more?\n Always\n Rarely\n Often\n Sometimes\n Never\n\nVOTE RESULTS > ARCHIVES >\n\nTRENDING TODAY\n1\t\nCarrier Lumber president backs First Nations' plea to restore local forest policy decision-making\n\n2\t\nRCMP search for witnesses and footage from June 29 fatal accident\n\n3\t\nRCMP provides update on wanted persons that have now been located\n\n4\t\nRCMP: 16-year-old youth who overdosed last week has died\n\n5\t\nDeciduous Heroes visit Prince George with a message: Forests are at risk\nNews\nHighlights\nLocal News\nLocal Sports\nBritish Columbia\nCanada\nWorld\nAnimal Stories\nOpinion\nOpinion\nSend us a letter\nArts & Life\nLocal Arts\nPhotos and Videos\nFeatures\nGas Prices\nSpecial Features\nWeather\nDigital Edition\nDigital Archive\nSponsored Content\nObituaries\nConnect\nContact Us\nAdvertise with Us\nDaily Headlines Email\nSupport Local News\nCitizen Box Locations\nLocal Events\nAbout\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Service\nPolitical Ads Registry\nSpecial Features\nDigital Archive\nReaders Choice\n\n\u00a9 2024 Prince George Citizen"},
{"url": "http://www.wltribune.com/news/sisters-in-spirit-walk-honours-women-lost-to-violence/", "title": "Sisters in Spirit Walk honours women lost to violence - The Williams Lake Tribune", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.7 \u00b0C\nHome News\nSisters in Spirit Walk honours women lost to violence\nWilliams Lake residents participated in a vigil and walk Friday to show solidarity for the families who have lost women to violence.\n\tMonica Lamb-Yorski\n\nOct 23, 2017 9:45 AM\nOct 23, 2017 10:05 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nLinda Hunlin (left) and Cora Fraleigh at a heart circle of red rocks where Fraleigh said the public is encouraged to add the name or initials of a family member who was lost to violence or write what love means on one of the rocks which are placed in downtown Williams Lake. Monica Lamb-Yorski photo\n\nWomen who have been lost to violence were honoured during a Sisters in Spirit Vigil and Walk Friday evening in downtown Williams Lake.\n\n\u201cWe want to show some solidarity with sisters that we\u2019ve lost to violence,\u201d said Cora Fraleigh, the Aboriginal Wellness Co-ordinator for the Cariboo Friendship Society who organized the event. \u201cThroughout Canada today there are various vigils being held in First Nations, Inuit and M\u00e9tis communities as well as rural and urban centres.\u201d\n\nSisters in Spirit Vigils are a movement for social change that centres on families of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and those of two-spirited people, Fraleigh said.\n\n\u201cWe acknowledge that division exists around the inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and respect families choices to participate in whichever way is meaningful for you,\u201d she said. \u201cEven if you choose not to participate we respect that as well.\u201d\n\nFraleigh encouraged everyone to listen and if necessary advocate on behalf of others by contacting politicians, signing petitions, or showing up at court dates to support women, families and children that are affected by violence in relationships.\n\nBefore the walk from the Purple House to the Eagles Nest began, Fraleigh encouraged participants to write the name or initials of someone they know who was lost to violence on one of dozens of red rocks that are placed inside the shape of a large heart on the lawn. She also said if people want, they can write what love means to them instead.\n\nFraleigh moved back to Williams Lake with family in February from Fort St. John where she was part of similar vigils there for 12 years, she said.\n\nAs she bent down to write on a rock, Linda Hunlin said she was there to honour her sister who is a survivor of a violent relationship.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Monica Lamb-Yorski\n\nA B.C. gal, I was born in Alert Bay, raised in Nelson, graduated from the University of Winnipeg, and wrote my first-ever article for the Prince Rupert Daily News.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tInternist enjoys working in Williams Lake area\n\t\tPHOTOS: 96th Annual Williams Lake Stampede wraps on Canada Day\n\t\tCanada Day celebrated in Boitanio Park in Williams Lake\n\t\tPHOTOS: Day 3 96th annual Williams Lake Stampede done, dusted\n\t\tMen provide some helping hands at Williams Lake community garden\nFacebook Comments (0) \nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. The art exhibit contains 200 handmade clay hearts; each in honour of an Indigenous person who is missing or was murdered. PHOTO BY KAYLE NEIS /Regina Leader-Post\nArticle content\n\nCheryl Ring remembers feeling frustrated by news coverage of the national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nRing, an artist and self-described fourth generation settler, felt the coverage was cringe-worthy as \u201can army of women and girls\u201d were being reduced to a simple acronym: MMIWG.\n\n\u201cI pondered that and I felt, as an average Canadian, that I was losing touch with the truth of the real matter, that within this acronym there are people, families, women,\u201d Ring said on Friday at the Legislative Building in Regina.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nFive concert events to see in Saskatoon in July\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'Significant, widespread' rain drenched Sask. farms: crop report\nVictim impact statements expected at Gregory Fertuck sentencing hearing\nArticle content\n\nRing turned off the TV and began thinking to herself about what she could do to raise awareness about the issue. It was then that she had an idea, so she went to the principal of Prince Albert\u2019s Carlton Comprehensive High School, who offered her space for the project.\n\nThe goal was to make 1,200 clay hearts, to coincide with an RCMP report which indicated there were 1,186 cases of Indigenous women who had gone missing or had been killed.\n\n\u201cWe all know in this room, a quick search does not do that number justice,\u201d Ring said.\n\nMay 5 is National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People, also known as Red Dress Day, which commemorates and raises awareness of the disproportionate number of Indigenous people who are impacted by gender-based violence.\n\nDozens gathered in the Qu\u2019Appelle Gallery of the Legislative Building, surrounded by portraits of governor generals of Saskatchewan\u2019s past, for the opening of the Heart Spirits Project.\n\nIt\u2019s an exhibit by Ring, a Prince Albert-based artist, which displays 200 of the handmade clay hearts that symbolize and honour an Indigenous person who is missing or was murdered.\n\nAfternoon Headlines\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe hearts were constructed over multiple one-hour workshops by many people, including students and community groups. The work shops were an opportunity for people to come together and contemplate their thoughts and feelings on the matter, Ring said.\n\n\u201cIt was a true community effort. The feedback I received was overwhelming,\u201d Ring recalled. \u201cI honestly don\u2019t think there was a day that I didn\u2019t cry or experience tears in the sessions.\u201d\n\nDignitaries and guests sit in the front row during the opening of Saskatchewan artist Cheryl Ring\u2019s project The Heart Spirits Project inside the Saskatchewan Legislative Building on Friday, May 5, 2023 in Regina. PHOTO BY KAYLE NEIS /Regina Leader-Post\n\nRing said elder Liz Settee sat in on many of the workshops, led sharing circles, and smudged the venues and clay hearts.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just kind of overwhelmed with the project, the day and the meaning,\u201d Settee said.\n\n\u201cSo many lost loved ones are still out there that we need to continue to work together on finding.\u201d\n\nDanielle Carrier, a provincial government worker within the family liaison unit,\u00a0mentioned she had worked in corrections, where she learned of the effects systemic racism, cultural genocide and trauma have on Indigenous people and communities.\n\nOne interaction still lingers in her mind: an offender who had committed a \u201cheinous crime\u201d against an Indigenous woman said he did it just because he could.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cAccording to many Indigenous beliefs and cultures, women are sacred, they are life givers and they hold a lot of power in culture and households. What happened? Why are we here now and how did we get here?\u201d Carrier said.\n\n\u201cAll of these are questions society has tried to answer but what is important is to find a solution, to work together to find a solution, so we can have our mothers, daughters, sisters, aunties, cousins be sacred again and forever more.\u201d\n\nThe art exhibit will be open to the public at the Legislative Building\u2019s Cumberland Gallery throughout the month of May.\u00a0\n\ncrmartell@postmedia.com\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nArt exhibit opens, Red Dress Day commemorated at Saskatchewan Legislature\nSaskatchewan government announces $400,000 for MMIWG+ community response fund\n\nThe news seems to be flying at us faster all the time. {"url": "https://www.yesmagazine.org/social-justice/2021/05/19/deb-haaland-missing-murdered-indigenous-people", "title": "Is Justice on the Horizon for Missing and Murdered Indigenous People? - YES! Magazine Solutions Journalism", "body": "Skip to content\nSOCIAL JUSTICE\nENVIRONMENT\nHEALTH & HAPPINESS\nECONOMY\nDEMOCRACY\nDONATE\nDONATE\nPLAN A GIFT IN YOUR WILL\nSUBSCRIBE\nSUBSCRIBE\nGET YES! EMAILS\nGIVE A GIFT SUBSCRIPTION\nORDER BULK MAGAZINES\nMORE\nABOUT YES!\nEVENTS\nTEACHER RESOURCES\nMY ACCOUNT\nMAGAZINE\nCURRENT ISSUE\nThe \u201cAccess\u201d Issue\nSUMMER 2024\nALL ISSUES\nGIVE A GIFT SUBSCRIPTION\nTrending:\nYES! Presents: Rising Up with Sonali\nPalestine\nClimate Crisis\nReparations\nYES! Crossword\nNEWS\nNATIVE RIGHTSCRIMINAL JUSTICE REFORMGENDER JUSTICE\u00a0\nIs Justice on the Horizon for Missing and Murdered Indigenous\u00a0People?\n\n\n \nMicaela Iron Shell has painted red hands over their mouth to show solidarity for missing and murdered Indigenous, black and migrant women and children during a rally at Civic Center Park, on Oct. 11, 2019, in Denver.\nPHOTO BY RJ SANGOSTI / MEDIANEWS GROUP / THE DENVER POST / GETTY IMAGES\n\n\nIndigenous activists see Deb Haaland\u2019s leadership as an opportunity to re-imagine justice and safety in the\u00a0U.S.\n Why you can trust us\nBY NIKKI ROJAS\n 6 MIN READ\nMAY 19, 2021\n\nSupport stories that are silenced elsewhere.\u00a0Donate\u00a0to our nonprofit newsroom.\n\nHanna Harris had planned to watch fireworks with friends when she disappeared from the Northern Cheyenne Reservation in Lame Deer, Montana, on July 3, 2013. Her family frantically searched for the 21-year-old mother, but struggled to get help from local law enforcement. Days later, on July 8, Harris\u2019 decomposed body was discovered in a ditch near the rodeo grounds on the reservation.\u00a0\n\nHarris\u2019 mother and sister spoke to the Billings Gazette months after Harris\u2019 death about their desperate hope for answers. How would they explain her death to her then-18-month-old son Jeremiah Harris?\n\n\u201cI\u2019m supposed to be the auntie,\u201d Harris\u2019 sister, Rose Harris, told the newspaper. \u201cWhat am I going to tell him about his mom?\u201d\u00a0\n\nIt would take nearly a year for Harris\u2019 killers to be arrested and charged with her murder and sexual assault. Eugenia Ann Rowland and Garrett Sidney Henderson Wadda were later found guilty of killing Harris, though her cause of death could not be determined because of the body\u2019s decomposition, the Billings Gazette reported.\u00a0\n\nHarris\u2019 case is part of an ongoing crisis affecting Native communities across the United States and Canada. On April 29, 2021, the U.S. Senate cited Harris\u2019 case in a resolution that designated May 5 as \u201cNational Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Native Women and Girls.\u201d The date was chosen to honor Harris, who was born on May 5, 1992.\u00a0\n\nPeople attend a Red Dress Day event outside the City Hall in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, on May 5, 2021, to commemorate missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. May 5 is the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, an ongoing crisis affecting Native communities across the United States and Canada. Photo by Liang Sen/Xinhua/Getty Images.\n\nWhile the crisis has finally been acknowledged by Congress, the federal government has historically remained silent on the issue. For years, Indigenous leaders have warned that violence against Native communities has reached epidemic levels, with violence against Indigenous women particularly prevalent. In the U.S., Indigenous women are murdered at a rate 10 times higher than other ethnicities.\n\nNow, grieving loved ones like Harris\u2019 have a new champion who is prepared to address this crisis: Interior Secretary Deb Haaland. In one of her first acts, the first Native American to hold a cabinet position established a unit to investigate missing and murdered Indigenous people in the Bureau of Indian Affairs.\n\n\u201cViolence against Indigenous people is a crisis that has been underfunded for decades. Far too often, murders and missing persons cases in Indian country go unsolved and unaddressed, leaving families and communities devastated,\u201d Haaland said in an April 1 statement announcing the new unit.\n\nThe Missing and Murdered Unit aims to \u201cput the full weight of the federal government\u201d into investigating cases involving missing and murdered Indigenous people and marshal resources across federal and tribal agencies. According to Haaland\u2019s announcement, the unit will also work with tribal, BIA, and FBI investigators on active missing and murdered investigations \u201cto hold people accountable, keep our communities safe, and provide closure for families.\u201d\u00a0\u00a0\n\nRenewed Hope for Justice\n\nActivists say that after years of relentlessly pushing for justice, the new unit gives them renewed hope. Chase Iron Eyes is a member of the Oglala Nation and lead counsel for the Lakota People\u2019s Law Project, which works to protect Lakota people from threats such as the Dakota Access pipeline and foster care abuse of Native children. Iron Eyes says he is encouraged by the announcement and notes Haaland\u2019s unique position, as a Native woman, in understanding the crisis. Haaland, a member of the Laguna Pueblo, has pledged to make the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous people one of her top priorities as secretary of the interior.\n\nU.S. Secretary of the Interior Deb Haaland speaks during a daily press briefing at the White House on April 23, 2021, in Washington, D.C. Photo by Alex Wong/Getty Images.\n\nThe National Crime Information Center has about 1,500 active missing Indigenous people cases in its database, while 2,700 others cases of murder and non-negligent homicide were reported to the federal government\u2019s Uniform Crime Reporting Program.\n\nAnnita Lucchesi is the executive director of Sovereign Bodies Institute, an Indigenous-led organization that gathers and disseminates research on gender and sexual violence against Indigenous people. She welcomed the new unit as a good idea but noted that it will need proper execution for it to make a real impact.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s easy to get our hopes up, but I\u2019m also trying to be cautious about it, with the understanding that this issue is systemic, and one unit can\u2019t really fix that systemic nature of it,\u201d says Lucchesi, who is of Cheyenne descent and lives on Wiyot territory.\u00a0\n\nLucchesi notes that past federal initiatives have \u201creally missed the mark,\u201d calling them insensitive, ineffective, and re-traumatizing for families. This includes the Trump administration task force dubbed Operation Lady Justice, which aimed to improve the way law enforcement agencies address new and unsolved cases of missing or murdered Indigenous people but \u201creally didn\u2019t do any outreach to families to provide testimony,\u201d Lucchesi says. She says the task force assumed that Native families could easily access and figure out the process to participate. When these families were able to join, the task force reportedly limited their testimonies to just three and a half minutes.\u00a0\n\n\u201cTo me, it\u2019s just not trauma-informed and, also, it was really just unfair,\u201d Lucchesi says. \u201cIt really doesn\u2019t communicate to families that [the U.S. government is] actually interested in family perspectives and experiences or in making the system more responsive to family needs.\u201d\u00a0\u00a0\n\nActivists say they hope the Missing and Murdered Unit will be both accessible and responsive to families and that there will be cooperation and collaboration among different law enforcement agencies. Lucchesi notes that many families have faced law enforcement agencies that have not only been inaccessible to them but have completely failed them.\n\nIn Harris\u2019 case, local law enforcement refused to help her family when they reported Harris missing on July 5. Instead, police told Harris\u2019 mother, Malinda Harris Limberhand, that her daughter was probably out drinking and would eventually turn up, the Billings Gazette reported. Local police and other agencies eventually joined the search on July 8. Harris\u2019 body was discovered that night.\u00a0\n\nDuring the federal investigation that followed, investigators kept Limberhand largely in the dark, she told reporters. \u201cAll they keep telling me is that it\u2019s an ongoing investigation and that they\u2019re looking into leads,\u201d she said in an interview with the Billings Gazette two months before Harris\u2019 killers were charged.\u00a0\n\nPeople who have lost Native and Indigenous women in their lives stand as the student group First Nations, in collaboration with Indigenous Sisters Resistance and the ASUW Womxn\u2019s Action Committee, hosted the third annual Missing and Murdered Indigenous Woman\u2019s candlelight memorial vigil on Feb. 14, 2019, at the University of Washington campus, in Seattle. Photo by Genna Martin/San Francisco Chronicle/Getty Images.\nAn Opportunity for Real Change\n\nDespite potential challenges the Missing and Murdered Unit faces, including the large volume of cases along with communication and cooperation between different agencies, Lucchesi and Iron Eyes say they believe the nation is in a good place to unpack and address the murder and abuse of Indigenous people. Iron Eyes cites the very founding of America by European colonizers as the reason it has taken the federal government so long to address issues affecting Native communities.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are a great experiment as a country,\u201d Iron Eyes says. \u201cSo it\u2019s taken this long to finally have a truthful reckoning with ourselves. It\u2019s not going to take that much longer because we\u2019ve also reached a critical mass of people who recognize that justice is not blind here. Justice sees color here. Justice sees sex. And justice is highly discriminatory here, even though we don\u2019t want to say it is.\u201d\n\nLucchesi says the U.S. is fortunate to be living in a time of \u201crobust national dialogue\u201d on issues including racial violence, police bias, and the failures of the American justice system. Those issues are contributing factors to the missing and murdered Indigenous people crisis, she says, and she hopes the public is able to connect them to a broader conversation on the re-imagining of justice and safety.\u00a0\n\nLucchesi notes that the public needs to understand that these issues don\u2019t just affect Native communities. \u201cI think the most important thing to understand is that this isn\u2019t just a Native issue or just a women\u2019s issue,\u201d she says. \u201cThis is an everybody issue because it\u2019s an issue of public safety and an issue of justice.\u201d\n\nWE NEED YOUR SUPPORT.\n\nFor 30 years, YES! Media has been at the forefront of people power, documenting community solutions that will free us all from unjust systems. As we barrel towards a pivotal election, there is a growing need for journalism like ours.\u00a0\n\n\n\n\nBut we need more monthly support to go on.\u00a0\n\n\n\n\nOnly 3 out of every 100 readers donate monthly, and we urgently need more readers like you to donate to keep our journalism alive.\u00a0\n\nPlease join the movement.\u00a0\n\nGive what you can for the media we need.\n\n\n\t\nNIKKI ROJAS is the former senior writer for The North Star and co-host of its American politics podcast, \"America the Voiceless.\" She specializes in social justice & immigrant communities. She has published in several publications, including Newsweek, MTV News, GlobalPost, IHS Jane\u2019s Defence Weekly and the Long Island Post. (Greta Cooper photo)\n\nDeanna Wertz, Caitlin Potts, Ashley Simpson and Nicole Bell \u2014 they may be missing, but they are not forgotten.\n\nTo remember all murdered and missing women, the Splatsin Nation and MMIW Drone Search Team are hosting a Red Dress Walk beginning in downtown Enderby Thursday, Oct. 4.\n\n\u201cPlease share the word, hang red dresses in your yard and join Splatsin and the MMIW Drone Search Team on this walk and ceremony to remember all the murdered and missing women,\u201d said Wendy Mohr, vice president of the search team.\n\nRelated: Community searches for answers\n\nRelated: Standing together\n\nRelated: Search continues for missing North Okanagan-Shuswap women\n\nThe women the ceremony seeks to remember \u2013 Potts, Simpson, Wertz, Bell and Traci Genereaux, whose remains were found on a Salmon River Road farm in Silver Creek in October 2017 \u2013 were all reported missing from the area in 2016 and 2017.\n\n\u201cWe will search until the women are found,\u201d Mohr said in a past interview with The Morning Star. \u201cThey deserve our support. These women have family. Their lives matter.\u201d\n\nSpeakers for the event, which begins at 11 a.m. on the east side of the Len Bawtree Bridge, include the Neskonlith Indian Band Chief and Jody Leon of the Drone Search Team. Lunch will be served at the Community Centre following the speakers.\n\nThe Red Dress Campaign is a nation-wide initiative that seeks to inform the public about Canada\u2019s high number of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls. MONTH\nBOOK YOUR AD\nDIGITAL SUBSCRIPTION\nNEW LANGUAGE\nHome  Arts  \u201cMusic for the Mind\u201d shows importance of music to mental health\nArtsNews\n\u201cMusic for the Mind\u201d shows importance of music to mental health\nBy Michael Oleksyn, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter -\nMay 5, 2023\nMichael Oleksyn/Daily Herald Heartwarming performed at Music for the Mind at PACI on Friday afternoon.\n\n\u201c\n\nTo celebrate Mental Health Week, the grounds of Prince Albert Collegiate Institute (PACI) hosted to the inaugural Music for the Mind music festival.\n\nThe event aims to spread awareness about mental health through a concert organized by the PACI Mental Health Capacity Building team.\n\nThe Mental Health Capacity program is a three-year pilot program run through the Saskatchewan Health Authority. Regan Jacobson, the mental health capacity building coordinator with PACI and St. John\u2019s School, said they\u2019re trying to provide awareness, promote good health, and build capacity around mental health issues.\n\n\u201cOur mental health professionals are like the firefighters and we are like Smokey the Bear,\u201d Jacobson said. \u201cWe are doing prevention.\u201d\n\nThe idea was to be preventative and share the positive impact music can have.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to teach a variety of different strategies and a lot of self-regulation tools that are easy, that work for students,\u201d she explained. \u201c(The) community connection, music itself, and all of this has to do with that.\u201d\n\nThe event coincided with Red Dress Day, which is held in remembrance of MMIWG2S (Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two Spirit people), so there was red dresses incorporated into the grounds.\n\nMichael Oleksyn/Daily Herald Elder Pearl Morin did a prayer to open Music for the Mind at PACI on Friday afternoon.\n\nElder and Knowledge Keeper Pearl Morin gave the festival a prayer while red dresses hung in the flowers.\n\nJacobson said it\u2019s important to recognize the two events, because poor mental health can be a factor in missing persons cases.\n\n\u201cMental health that\u2019s a huge connection and so I think juts being aware and taking a moment and recognizing they exist together is a really great thing as well,\u201d she said.\n\nThe emcee for the afternoon was PACI Principal Dave Leuchinger. Jacobson and her associate, Jaime Smith-Windsor, discussed their program before the concert.\n\nMichael Oleksyn/Daily Herald (L to R) Mental Health Capacity Building workers Jaime Smith-Windsor and Regan Jacobson spoke during Music for the Mind at PACI on Friday afternoon.\n\nThe performers were LJ Tyson and Heartwarming. Both bands have connections to PACI.\n\n\u201cBoth of them are PACI alumni bands, so that was really great and Mike Mogg, the Garage Band teacher, was able to organize the bands to come out for us. Everyone was just happy to be a part of it, I think, and ready to get summer started. It\u2019s just a feel-good festival.\u201d\n\nStudents from elementary schools from around the division were in attendance.\n\n(in italics) Editor\u2019s Note: the Jaime Smith-Windsor mentioned in this story is not the Jaimie Smith-Windsor who serves as a trustee on the Sask. Rivers School Board.\n\nmichael.oleksyn@paherald.sk.ca\n\n-Advertisement-\nTAGS\nPrince Albert\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedin\nCopy URL\nPrevious article\nCooke Municipal opens for 2023 golf season\nNext article\nHoax RCMP call in Indian Head leads to massive deployment\nMichael Oleksyn, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter\nMichael Oleksyn covers regional civic affairs including RMs, city council and local school divisions. {"url": "https://www.vermilionstandard.com:443/news/council-orders-dogar-to-apologize-for-comments-made-to-indigenous-people-in-second-incident", "title": "Dogar ordered to apologize for comments made to Indigenous people | Vermilion Standard", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nAdvertise with Us\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nCouncil orders Dogar to apologize for comments made to Indigenous people in second incident\nAuthor of the article:\nVincent McDermott\nPublished Feb 24, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Feb 25, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nA screenshot of Councillor Shafiq Dogar during an RMWB council meeting at the Jubilee Centre in Fort McMurray on Tuesday, May 24, 2022.\nArticle content\n\nCouncillor Shafiq Dogar has been ordered by council to complete awareness training and apologize for comments he made about Indigenous people last summer. Dogar argues he did nothing wrong, but will apologize \u201cto appease.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe order follows a report from the integrity commissioner that was presented to council during a private meeting on Feb. 15. The report concluded Dogar violated council\u2019s code of conduct on treating people \u201cwith courtesy, dignity and respect and without abuse, bullying or intimidation.\u201d Dogar had a right to have legal counsel at the meeting, but did not.\n\nCouncil has condemned Dogar\u2019s public behaviour at least four times since he was elected in Oct. 2021. This is the second incident involving comments made towards Indigenous people.\n\nThe report says at a June 28 meeting, Dogar left a presentation on supporting the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG). The complaint says Dogar missed key moments from presenters and during a break, he spoke to presenters and their supporters in \u201can antagonizing tone.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCouncil voted\u00a0Dogar must apologize to the complainant and attend Indigenous Awareness training. He must report on his progress to council within three months. Only Dogar opposed the motion.\n\nThe report is not public and a public summary of the meeting does not mention what Dogar is accused of saying or doing. Dogar denied doing or saying anything inappropriate and said he left the meeting to use the washroom. He insists he \u201cjust wanted to say hello, hi and what is going on,\u201d and left because \u201cthey were not very friendly.\u201d\n\n\u201cI told council I\u2019m not going to apologize as a mistake. But if anybody is knowingly or unknowingly takes some offence, I am honoured\u00a0to make them happy or to appease, mitigate any annoyance,\u201d he said. \u201cSince they are girls, females\u2026 I\u2019m very, very docile or lenient with the females. If they felt anything wrong, I openly and in front of the integrity commissioner I voluntarily said I can apologize. Not as a fault.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nPeople march down Franklin Avenue for Red Dress Day in Fort McMurray, Alta. on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The day marks a national day of mourning and awareness for missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples (MMEIP). Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\nDogar wants province to investigate past incidents\n\nThe first time Dogar angered Indigenous leaders was in a Feb. 2022 meeting when he was was\u00a0accused of minimizing the missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited people (MMIWG2S) crisis.\n\nDogar said in the meeting there was no\u00a0\u201ccampaign against the Indigenous people\u201d and the issue was not a municipal matter.\u00a0He later admitted his English-speaking skills are poor and\u00a0have caused \u201cmisunderstandings at times.\u201d\n\nThere have been at least nine Indigenous women from the Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo region that have been murdered or reported missing since 2004.\n\nThe integrity commissioner also found Dogar violated\u00a0multiple codes of conduct in two separate incidents with municipal employees in Oct. 2021, and regarding Facebook posts he made in Dec. 2021.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThose two reports have also not been made public, but Dogar was found to have violated the\u00a0code of conduct sections on discriminatory comments, attempting to influence administrative staff and disclosing confidential information.\n\nDogar apologized for those incidents, but said in an interview he did nothing wrong. He also wants Municipal Affairs Minister Rebecca Schulz to overturn the integrity commissioner\u2019s reports and launch new investigations into those complaints. The ministry can only do this following a request from council or a judge\u2019s order. A spokesperson for Schulz did not respond to comment.\n\nvmcdermott@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR VERMILION\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/sisters-in-spirit-halifax-event-honours-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-1.6096662", "title": "Sisters in Spirit event held in downtown Halifax | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News At Six\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nATLANTIC\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nATLANTIC\nNews\nSisters in Spirit: Halifax event honours missing and murdered Indigenous women\nNatalie Lombard\nCTVNewsAtlantic.ca Digital Coordinator\nContact\nUpdated Oct. 5, 2022 7:24 a.m. MDT\nPublished Oct. 5, 2022 6:33 a.m. MDT\nShare\n\nAbout 40 people gathered in downtown Halifax on Tuesday as part of a Canada-wide movement called Sisters in Spirit.\n\nAttendees dressed in red, made signs, prayed and drummed to honour the lives of all Indigenous people, including murdered and missing Indigenous women, girls, gender-diverse, two-spirit and transgender people.\n\nSimilar events were held in cities across Canada, including Ottawa, Gatineau, Que., and Edmonton.\n\nOrganizers say it is a subject that affects everyone.\n\nRELATED STORIES\n'Kokum won't forget you': Sask. Elder finds hope for MMIWG through Sisters in Spirit walk\nFamilies of missing and murdered Indigenous women seek change ahead of Oct. 4 vigils\nThis massive newspaper contains 'cover stories' of hundreds of MMIWG to spur national action\nAdvocates frustrated with inaction over missing and murdered Indigenous women\nFederal government made little progress in addressing MMIWG: advocacy group\n\n\"You may not have lost someone, but when you hear on the news of someone who is missing or murdered, you can't not be touched by it,\u201d says Denise John, a victim support navigator with the Mi'kmaw Native Friendship Centre in Halifax. \u201cYou may have something going on in your life that we feel is very important to bring awareness together in our communities, no matter if you're Indigenous or not.\u201d\n\nJohn adds that the event is held to help families grieving a missing loved one. The event is personal for John, whose cousin was murdered\n(opens in a new tab)\n in a small, rural First Nation community in Newfoundland in 2019.\n\nMore than 1,000 Indigenous women and girls were killed or went missing between 1980 and 2012, according to the RCMP. However, experts believe the true number is closer to 4,000, according to the Native Women's Association of Canada.\n\nStatistics Canada has found that the average homicide rate involving Indigenous victims was six-times higher than those involving a non-Indigenous victim.\n\nOn June 3, 2019, the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls published its final report\n(opens in a new tab)\n on the matter, titled \u201cReclaiming Power and Place.\u201d\n\nThe national inquiry called the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Canada a \"genocide\"\n(opens in a new tab)\n and included 231 \"calls for justice\" in its report.\n\nHowever, Indigenous groups like the Native Women's Association of Canada have criticized the federal government, saying that little progress has been made to end violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people, since the report was released.\n\nOttawa has said some progress has been made, but has acknowledged that more work needs to be done.\n\nWith files from CTVNews.ca\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nA Sisters in Spirit event was held in downtown Halifax on Oct. 4, 2022.\nReport
