{"url": "https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/07/abortion-supreme-court-republicans-week-in-patriarchy", "title": "To Reasonable Rational People counseling calm about abortion: Aaaarrggh! | Arwa Mahdawi | The Guardian", "body": "Skip to main content\nSkip to navigation\nSkip to navigation\nPrint subscriptions\nSign in\nSearch jobs\nSearch\nInternational edition\nThe Guardian - Back to home\nThe Guardian\nSupport the Guardian\nFund independent journalism with $15 per month\nSupport us\nNews\nOpinion\nSport\nCulture\nLifestyle\nShow\nMore\nThe Guardian view\nColumnists\nCartoons\nOpinion videos\nLetters\nView image in fullscreen\nUC Berkeley Students protest in response to leaked draft supreme court's opinion to overturn the Roe v Wade in Berkeley, California. Photograph: Chris Tuite/ImageSpace/Rex/Shutterstock\nOpinion\nAbortion\n This article is more than 2 years old\nTo Reasonable Rational People counseling calm about abortion: Aaaarrggh!\nThis article is more than 2 years old\nArwa Mahdawi\n\nWorried the Republicans will follow up their attack on reproductive rights by taking our other rights? You should be\n\nSat 7 May 2022 14.00 BST\nShare\nSign up to receive the latest US opinion pieces every weekday\nAaaaaaaaaaarrrrrrrrrgggggh\n\nI tried to think of a pithy introduction to this week\u2019s newsletter. Something witty, something drily poking fun at the dystopic week we\u2019ve had. Something that was not yet another reference to Gilead and the Handmaid\u2019s Tale. But, unfortunately, all jokes were drowned out with internal existential screaming: aaaarggh.\n\nAccording to one Republican, pregnancy from rape is \u2018an opportunity\u2019\nArwa Mahdawi\nRead more\n\nFirst, there was the bombshell leak on Monday night of a draft supreme court opinion that appeared to show the court is ready to overturn Roe v Wade and the federal right to an abortion. While this was a shock it wasn\u2019t exactly a surprise. When Donald Trump was elected plenty of people were worried about the future of reproductive rights in the US. Calm down, dear, we were told by Reasonable Rational People\u2122. You\u2019re being alarmist!\n\nLike clockwork, the Reasonable Rational People\u2122 emerged right after the supreme court leak to chide anyone worried that Republicans are not going to stop at overturning Roe but want to take away even more of our rights. \u201cI think the people catastrophizing about contraception or interracial marriage being next after Roe sincerely believe it,\u201d a (female) Washington Post columnist snarked on Twitter on Wednesday. \u201cBut I\u2019m sorry, I cannot take this seriously.\u201d\n\nI\u2019m sorry, we should all be taking this very seriously indeed. On the same day that prominent columnists were telling people to calm down \u2013 and less than 48 hours after the leaked supreme court opinion \u2013 Republicans in Louisiana advanced a bill that would redefine personhood to begin at the moment of fertilization and make abortion a crime of murder. Yes, you read that right: the moment of fertilization. I\u2019m sure the people involved in drafting this law have no idea about how reproduction actually works (they like controlling female bodies, not learning about them), but between one-third and one-half of all fertilized eggs never fully implant. Which means someone in Louisiana needs to arrest God \u2013 he\u2019s responsible for a hell of a lot of abortions! This incredibly broad definition of personhood also means that anyone experiencing an ectopic pregnancy (which are not viable and very dangerous) in Louisiana has only two choices: go to prison or die. And that\u2019s not all: experts are worried that the law would criminalize in vitro fertilization as well as some forms of birth control.\n\nThere\u2019s a reason I brought God up just now. There\u2019s supposed to be a division between church and state in the US but the people who drafted the Louisiana law seemingly forgot about that. The proposal contains a line about \u201cthe sanctity of innocent human life, created in the image of God\u201d. This is clearly unconstitutional \u2013 but that doesn\u2019t bother the bill\u2019s creators who have made it very clear that they don\u2019t care about democratic norms. Indeed, the bill\u2019s text states that the state should enforce the law \u201cwithout regard to the opinions and judgments of the Supreme Court of the United States\u201d on abortion.\n\nIt\u2019s unclear whether the Louisiana bill will become law anytime soon. But what is clear is that we are going to see more and more extreme proposals like this. As I discussed in a previous Week in Patriarchy, radicalized Christian nationalism is a growing threat in the US; a small but very organised group of people are intent on turning the country into a modern theocracy. A few years ago a researcher called Frederick Clarkson exposed a Christian supremacist initiative called Project Blitz, whose mission is undermining the separation of church and state. You know what one major component of their strategy is? Flooding state legislatures with so many bills that trying to fight them becomes a game of \u201cWhac-A-Mole\u201d. And as liberals are busy playing Whac-A-Mole with proposals like this Louisiana bill, extremists and evangelicals are busy consolidating power. So don\u2019t let anyone tell you that you\u2019re \u201ccatastrophizing\u201d.\n\nData broker sells locations of people who visit abortion clinics\n\nAccording to Motherboard, a company called SafeGraph obtains location data from ordinary apps on people\u2019s phones and sells it on. Planned Parenthood is classified by SafeGraph as a \u201cbrand\u201d that can be tracked; Motherboard was able to get a week\u2019s worth of data on where people who visited Planned Parenthood came from, and where they went afterwards for just $160.\n\nFox host says he doesn\u2019t know why people would hire pregnant women for important jobs\n\nBrian Kilmeade was referencing Nina Jankowicz, who was recently appointed to lead a newly created advisory board on misinformation at the Department of Homeland Security. She is eight months pregnant. Kilmeade, by the way, is a father of three. For some reason he doesn\u2019t seem to think that becoming a father had any impact on his ability to do his job. (Then again, a racist potato could do his job, so that\u2019s not saying much.)\n\nMissing and murdered Indigenous women remembered\n\nThursday marked Missing and Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day in the US and Red Dress Day in Canada. As CNN reports: \u201cNationally, there were 764 unresolved cases of missing Native American people as of March 2022, according to data from the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System. But advocates and experts have said those figures do not reflect the full extent of the issue due to the lack of comprehensive data.\u201d\n\nMenopausal women lack basic support, UK study finds\n\nAbout 80% of women surveyed said their workplaces have no policies or help in place; 41% said menopause symptoms were treated as a joke by colleagues; 45% said they avoid speaking to their doctor due to stigma.\n\nThe week in pac-triarchy\n\nThe World Video Game Hall of Fame announced its latest inductees on Thursday; among the four \u201ciconic\u201d games are Ms Pac-Man. The 41-year-old arcade game is munching its way into the Hall of Fame seven years after Pac-Man.\n\nExplore more on these topics\nAbortion\nOpinion\ncomment\nShare\nReuse this content\nMost viewed\nHurricane Beryl barrels through Cayman Islands after battering Jamaica\nUK general election results 2024: live tracker\nCoffee, eggs and white rice linked to higher levels of PFAS in human body\nTrump calls Biden \u2018broken-down\u2019 and claims he quit 2024 race in leaked video\nMillions go to the polls in general election \u2013 as it happened\nMost viewed\nThe Guardian view\nColumnists\nCartoons\nOpinion videos\nLetters\nNews\nOpinion\nSport\nCulture\nLifestyle\nOriginal reporting and incisive analysis, direct from the Guardian every morning\nSign up for our email\nHelp\nComplaints & corrections\nSecureDrop\nWork for us\n\u00a0\nPrivacy policy\nCookie policy\nTerms & conditions\nContact us\nAll topics\nAll writers\nDigital newspaper archive\nFacebook\nYouTube\nInstagram\nLinkedIn\nX\nNewsletters\nAdvertise with us\nSearch UK jobs\nBack to top\n\u00a9 2024 Guardian News & Media Limited or its affiliated companies. {"url": "http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/dozens-of-women-vanish-on-canada-s-highway-of-tears-1.2660100", "title": "Dozens of women vanish on Canada\u2019s Highway of Tears \u2013 The Irish Times", "body": "Sections\nSubscribe\nSign In\nHome\nLatest\nSubscriber Only\nIreland\nPolitics\nOpinion\nBusiness\nWorld\nSport\nYour Money\nCrime & Law\nProperty\nFood\nHealth\nLife & Style\nCulture\nEnvironment\nTechnology\nScience\nMedia\nAbroad\nObituaries\nTransport\nMotors\nListen\nPodcasts\nVideo\nPhotography\nHistory\nTuarasc\u00e1il\nStudent Hub\nOffbeat\nCrosswords & Puzzles\nFamily Notices\n(Opens in new window)\nSponsored\nSubscriber Rewards\nCompetitions\nWeather Forecast\nWorld\nDozens of women vanish on Canada\u2019s Highway of Tears\nFailure to investigate disappearances of aboriginal women has become political scandal\n\nA sign along Highway 16 outside Smithers, Canada, warning girls against hitchhiking and displaying photos of some victims. Photograph: Ruth Fremson/New York Times\n\nDan Levin in British Columbia\nWed May 25 2016 - 11:58\n\nLess than a year after her 15-year-old cousin vanished, Delphine Nikal (16) was last seen hitchhiking from Smithers, an isolated northern Canadian town on a spring morning in 1990.\n\nRamona Wilson (16), a member of her high school baseball team, left home one Saturday night in June 1994 to attend a dance a few towns away. She never arrived. Her remains were found 10 months later near the local airport.\n\nTamara Chipman (22) disappeared in 2005, leaving behind a toddler. \"She's still missing,\" Gladys Radek, her aunt, said. \"It'll be 11 years in September.\"\n\nExpand\nAutoplay\nImage\n1 of 3\n\nMatilda Wilson wipes leaves off of her daughter Ramona\u2019s gravestone \u2013 she was murdered at age 16 in 1994, her body found in a shallow grave behind the town\u2019s airport \u2013 in Smithers, Canada. Photograph: Ruth Fremson/New York Times\n\nDozens of Canadian women and girls, most of them indigenous, have disappeared or been murdered near Highway 16, a remote ribbon of asphalt that bisects British Columbia and snakes past thick forests, logging towns and impoverished Indian reserves on its way to the Pacific Ocean. So many women and girls have vanished or turned up dead along one stretch of the road that residents call it the Highway of Tears.\n\nREAD MORE\n\n\n\nA special unit formed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police officially linked 18 such cases from 1969 to 2006 to this part of the highway and two connecting arteries. More women have vanished since then, and community activists and relatives of the missing say they believe the total is closer to 50. Almost all the cases remain unsolved.\n\nThe Highway of Tears and the disappearances of the indigenous women have become a political scandal in British Columbia. But those cases are just a small fraction of the number who have been murdered or disappeared nationwide. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have officially counted about 1,200 cases over the past three decades, but research by the Native Women's Association of Canada suggests the total number could be as high as 4,000.\n\nIn December, after years of refusal by his conservative predecessor, prime minister Justin Trudeau announced a long-awaited national inquiry into the disappearances and murders of indigenous women. The inquiry, set to cost 40 million Canadian dollars (\u20ac27 million), is part of Trudeau's promise of a \"total renewal\" of Canada's relationship with its indigenous citizens, and it comes at a critical time.\n\nPolice racism\n\nAboriginal women and girls make up about 4 per cent of the total female population of Canada but 16 per cent of all female homicides, according to government statistics.\n\nCarolyn Bennett, the minister of indigenous and northern affairs, has spent months travelling across the country to consult with indigenous communities. During her meetings, families and survivors have complained of racism and sexism by the police, who she said treated the deaths of indigenous women \"as inevitable, as if their lives mattered less\".\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s clear is the uneven application of justice,\u201d Bennett said. One reason to doubt the estimate by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, she said, is that the police often immediately deemed the women\u2019s deaths to be suicides, drug overdoses or accidents, over the protests of relatives who suspected foul play. \u201cThere was no investigation,\u201d she said, citing one recent case. \u201cThe file folder\u2019s empty.\u201d\n\nA United Nations report last year described measures by the previous government to protect aboriginal women from harm as \"inadequate\" and said that the lack of an inquiry into the murders and disappearances constituted \"grave violations\" of the women's human rights. Failures by law enforcement, it added, had \"resulted in impunity\".\n\nRadek, a co-founder of Tears4Justice, an advocacy organisation, said, \u201cWhen it comes to the missing, racism runs deep.\u201d The federal government has allocated 8.4 billion Canadian dollars (\u20ac5.7 billion) over five years to aid indigenous communities, which have disproportionately high levels of poverty, incarceration, alcoholism and substance abuse, and often lack basic necessities like safe drinking water.\n\nBennett said the breakdown in aboriginal communities was the product of generations of socioeconomic marginalisation and trauma tied to government policies. Particularly damaging was a state-financed, church-run boarding school system for aboriginal children who were forcibly taken from their families by officers of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Many of the 150,000 children who were sent to residential schools over a century became victims of physical and sexual abuse. The programme was fully shut down in the mid-1990s.\n\nCovering 450 miles between the city of Prince George and the Pacific port of Prince Rupert, the Highway of Tears is both a microcosm of Canada's painful indigenous legacy and a serious test for Trudeau as he tries to repair the country's relationship with aboriginal people.\n\nOn a recent journey along Highway 16, scenes of stunning wilderness were flecked by indigenous communities reeling from economic decay and the anguished memories of missing and murdered women. A few miles outside Prince George, the highway plunges into thick forests veined with logging roads and the occasional \u201cmoose crossing\u201d sign. \u201cGirls Don\u2019t Hitchhike on the Highway of Tears,\u201d reads a large yellow billboard alongside the road farther north. \u201cKiller on the Loose!\u201d\n\nDesperate people\n\nAs a bald eagle soared overhead, Brenda Wilson (49), the Highway of Tears co-ordinator for Carrier Sekani Family Services and the sister of one of the victims, gestured to the wall of evergreens that flank the road. \"The trees are really dense here, so if you're looking for someone, it's pretty hard to find them,\" she said, listing the names of several women who are still missing.\n\nThe perils do not stop desperate people from thumbing rides. Just outside the village of Burns Lake, Drucella Joseph (25), an unemployed aboriginal woman, eagerly climbed into the back of a passing car along with her boyfriend, Corey Coombes. \u201cFriends will drive me when I really need a ride, but other than that, we just hitchhike,\u201d she told the driver. The couple gets by on his disability payments and on donated food from food banks. Neither has a mobile phone. When hitchhiking, Coombes says he protects himself by carrying a club or a screwdriver.\n\nBritish Columbia is infamous for serial killers and criminals who often targeted aboriginal women. In 2007, Robert William Pickton, a pig farmer, was convicted of killing six women, though the DNA or remains of 33 women were discovered on his land. Many of them were aboriginal.\n\nOne of Canada's youngest serial killers, Cody Legebokoff, was 24 when he was convicted in 2014 of killing four women near the Highway of Tears. David Ramsay, a former Prince George provincial court judge and convicted paedophile, was imprisoned in 2004 for sexually and physically assaulting indigenous girls as young as 12.\n\nAnguished family members said they received little help from the authorities, a sharp contrast to the cases of missing white women. After Chipman vanished in 2005, her aunt, Radek, said the police objected to the family putting up its own \u201cmissing\u201d posters. \u201cThey knew we were searching day and night, and they did nothing to help us,\u201d she said. The next day, she said, a white woman disappeared near Vancouver \u201cand the police were out in the streets putting up posters\u201d.\n\nAfter her daughter Ramona disappeared in 1994, the police refused to act, said Matilda Wilson, a member of the Gitxsan First Nation. \u201cThey gave us all these different excuses that she might be back tomorrow or next week,\u201d Wilson said. \u201cThere was no hurry or alarm about it, so we started looking ourselves.\u201d\n\nMemorial walk\n\nDespite multiple searches, Wilson, a single mother of six who is now 65, said there was no sign of Ramona until she had been gone for seven months, when Wilson received an anonymous phone call telling her that the girl\u2019s body was near the airport.\n\nPolice officers searched the area but found nothing, she said. In April 1995, two men riding all-terrain vehicles by the airport discovered Ramona\u2019s remains buried under some trees. Plastic flowers and a glass cross now decorate her grave in a Smithers cemetery, a few blocks from Wilson\u2019s tidy trailer-park home.\n\nAngry with the police for failing to find the teenager or to alert people to the history of missing women near Highway 16, Wilson and her family organised a memorial walk in June 1995 that has become an annual event, garnering attention from the media and inspiring activism from families of other missing women.\n\n\u201cWe want closure, and we\u2019re not going to give up,\u201d Wilson said as she swept leaves from her daughter\u2019s gravestone.\n\nOne recent afternoon, three young aboriginal sisters and their female cousin were walking across the Moricetown Indian Reserve, which abuts the highway. Asked about the Highway of Tears, one of the women, Rochelle Joseph, an unemployed 21-year-old, said the sisters never hitchhiked because they grew up hearing about the victims, including their cousin, Chipman.\n\nStill, the menace of the highway haunts their lives. \u201cThe stories made us cautious,\u201d Joseph said quietly, voicing their fear of a serial killer lurking behind the steering wheel of any strange car. \u201cHe\u2019s probably still out there.\u201d\n\nNew York Times\n\nCanadian Mounted Police\nNative Women S Association Of Canada\nUnited Nations\nBrenda Wilson\nCarolyn Bennett\nCody Legebokoff\nDavid Ramsay\nDelphine Nikal\nGladys Radek\nJustin Trudeau\nRamona Wilson\nRobert William Pickton\nTamara Chipman\nIN THIS SECTION\nBritain awaits 10pm election exit poll as Labour tries to win back power\nHizbullah fires 200 rockets at Israel to avenge killing of commander\nCelebrated journalist Robert Fisk\u2019s last book launched in Dublin\n\u2018We\u2019ve been lucky so far\u2019: Scientists continue working in Ukraine\u2019s bomb-scarred second city\nSome 30,000 police to be deployed across France on Sunday following runoff of election\nMOST READ\nSouth Dublin school\u2019s plans to create \u2018private Aviva\u2019 in Rathgar square face local backlash\nUL chief officer launches defamation case against head of commercial operations and wife\nCo Westmeath crashes: US tourist killed and wife seriously injured while driving to airport\n\u2018Historic\u2019 pension Bill passes with only Minister for Social Protection and Ceann Comhairle in D\u00e1il chamber\nAnother crime added to long list by GAAGo\nLATEST STORIES\n\u2018Tears won\u2019t bring you back because I\u2019ve cried. MONTH\nBOOK YOUR AD\nDIGITAL SUBSCRIPTION\nNEW LANGUAGE\nHome  News  Red Dress Day recognized with ceremony on Prince Albert riverbank\nNewsTop Stories\nRed Dress Day recognized with ceremony on Prince Albert riverbank\nBy Michael Oleksyn, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter -\nMay 6, 2024\nMichael Oleksyn/Daily Herald Wendy Mirasty became emotional as she spoke during the Red Dress Day ceremony at the riverbank in Prince Albert on Sunday.\n\nThe Sisters in Spirit monument on the riverbank in Prince Albert was the site of a ceremony on Sunday to remember local women, girls, and two-spirit individuals who had been murdered or gone missing.\n\nThe Prince Albert Grand Council (PAGC) put together the event in honour of Red Dress Day, which is held every year on May 5. Shirley Woods of PAGC Health and Social Development said the event is a way to make sure residents are aware of the high number of missing and murdered individuals.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s really important for education and awareness because it is an issue in our society and it went a long time without anybody acknowledging it,\u201d Woods said. \u201cAs we move forward, you always need to start with awareness before you can bring about change, and really, that\u2019s what we\u2019re looking for is a change.\u201d\n\nWoods co-organized Sunday\u2019s event with Penny Constant. Constant said the PAGC has always tried to pay tribute even before Red Dress Day became so wide-spread. She said it was important to show the lives of those who went missing or were murdered still\nmatter today.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be ongoing and I think the more awareness that we bring\u2014not only on this day\u2014but throughout, and create awareness for not only Indigenous women, but young women who are not accustomed to this society\u2019s expectations,\u201d Constant added.\n\nMay 5 marks the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People (MMIWG2S). Every year on that day, red dresses are hung on display to honour the victims, survivors, and those impacted by the ongoing crisis of gender\u0002based and racialized violence faced by Canada\u2019s Indigenous population.\n\nElder Shirley Sanderson opened and closed the ceremony with a prayer in her own language.\n\n\u201cI hope that these gatherings will get bigger,\u201d Sanderson said. \u201cOur young people need to know and to show them what we are doing here, to show them what love and care and forgiveness is.\u201d\n\nGeorge Mirasty, who served as emcee led a moment of silence. Mirasty also acknowledged the family of Drew Ballantyne who were holding missing person signs throughout the event.\n\nOne of the closing speakers was the mother of 34-year-old Ballantyne, Loretta, who spoke on day 665 since Ballantyne went missing. She was joined at the podium by Drew\u2019s son and her grandson, Daniel, where she shared the struggles and pain of her son being missing and highlighted some questions about the ongoing crisis, adding it\u2019s not just Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cWe have to ask ourselves, why does this keep happening? What changes need to happen?\u201d she said. \u201cWe see a lot of homeless people out there, we see a lot of addicts out there, we see a lot of gang members out there \u2013 there needs to be a way to get them out of that.\n\u201cThere needs to be a stop \u2013 we need to put a stop to it,\u201d she continued.\n\n\u201cYou need to look at the justice system, what\u2019s happening in the jails\u2026 a lot of the men who go to jail have no choice but to join a gang to survive. Think about those things, think about the hard reality \u2013 I am a parent, a mother of a son who went missing because of a gang.\u201d\n\nAnother speaker who has been directly impacted was Wendy Mirasty, the cousin of Danielle Dobersheck who was murdered in Melfort in March. Her long-term partner was charged with second-degree murder following an investigation. Mirasty opened by reading from Dobersheck\u2019s obituary. Mirasty became visibly emotional as she described the pain she and the family have been dealing with since Danielle was taken from them.\n\u201cWhen she died she suffered and when they had the viewing she was unrecognizable,\u201d Mirasty said. \u201cOur family is still very much grieving, and I don\u2019t think that the grief will ever go away with how she left us.\n\n\u201cWe ask that you say a prayer and continue those ongoing prayers because we are all still grieving.\u201d\n\nMirasty said she invited Doborsheck\u2019s sister to come, but it was too difficult for her. Prince Albert Deputy Police Chief Farica Prince spoke on behalf of the Prince Albert Police Service.\n\n\u201cWe know that Indigenous women are 12 times more likely to go missing or be murdered than anyone else in this country,\u201d she said. \u201cThe most difficult and most dangerous life to live in this country right now is an Indigenous woman, and that\u2019s not okay. It\u2019s time for us to hold\neach other accountable and stop hurting each other.\n\n\u201cYesterday we just announced our first homicide of 2024 and it broke my heart just like I am sure it broke all of yours. I just want to share a message that it\u2019s time for us to start taking care of one another and stop hurting each other,\u201d Prince said.\n\nPAGC Women\u2019s Commission acting chair Anita Parenteau spoke and noted that former chair of the Women\u2019s Commission Shirley Henderson was missed.\n\n\u201cShe did a lot of hard work for the families in surrounding communities and all of the bands from PAGC and all walks of life,\u201d Parenteau said. \u201cI just want to acknowledge her and she did so much work. I hope I can do some of that work and continue with that work she was doing.\n\n\u201cMy message to you is to keep loving one another and keep communicating.\u201d\n\nDrumming group Iron Swing performed the opening Honour Song and closing round dance song. PAGC executive director Al Ducharme brought a message on behalf of PAGC and the 12 chiefs. MLA Alana Ross also spoke but noted she was speaking as a person, not as a legislature member.\n\nStaff Sergeant Brian Kelly of the RCMP Indigenous Policing Services spoke and said that there are places where the force needs to improve to address this problem.\n\nIn 2014, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) released a report stating that a total of 1,181 Indigenous women and girls were killed or went missing in Canada between 1980 and 2012, based on incidents reported to all police jurisdictions across Canada.\n\nDr. Lalita Malholtra also spoke as a supporter of the event and said a prayer in her language before speaking from the heart. Constant, Woods and Edith Kadachuk of Health and Social Development also spoke.\n\nThe ceremony ended with everyone in attendance participating in a round dance.\n\nRed Dress Day was first commemorated in 2010, to pay respect to the victims, and call on all levels of government to take action to address the racialized and gendered violence inflicted on Indigenous peoples\n\n-Advertisement-\nTAGS\nMMIWG2S\nPAGC\nPrince Albert\nRed dress day\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedin\nCopy URL\nPrevious article\nPrince Albert Police identify suspect and victim in murder case\nNext article\nPredators remain undefeated with weekend sweep in Regina\nMichael Oleksyn, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter\nMichael Oleksyn covers regional civic affairs including RMs, city council and local school divisions. {"url": "https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/hundreds-march-as-red-dress-day-is-marked-across-manitoba-1.6385868", "title": "Red Dress Day being marked in Manitoba | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nWINNIPEG\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nWINNIPEG\nNews\nHundreds march as Red Dress Day is marked across Manitoba\n03:29\nRed Dress Day in Winnipeg\n01:38\nRed Dress Day marked in Manitoba\n04:51\nThe importance of Red Dress Day\nTaylor Brock\nCTV Winnipeg Late Anchor\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2023 6:37 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2023 10:19 a.m. MDT\nShare\n\nIn a powerful moment in Downtown Winnipeg, hundreds of people walked hand-in-hand to the beat of traditional drums and signing, honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people.\n\nThe National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), otherwise known as Red Dress Day was marked in Winnipeg, Manitoba and across the country.\n\nDrums beat, singers chanted and a round dance began at Portage Avenue and Main Street in memory of the missing and murdered.\n\n\"I lost my mother 21 years ago now, and we're not collectively seeing action being taken to address this and put a stop to it,\" said Tammy Wolfe.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nA lifetime of agony: Families of missing, murdered Inuit women call for answers\n'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\nWinnipeg landfill search feasibility study completed\nIndigenous women more likely to face violence if they were a child in care: report\nNDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women\n\n\"The work that we do is in honour and memory of our loved ones so to say that we're going to stop fighting for that - that's just not going to happen.\"\n\nThe sea of people dressed in red marched through Downtown Winnipeg, pouring into a gathering at The Forks. There people showed their support for those with missing or murdered family and friends.\n\n\"I remember at nine years old, my sister became a poster child for being murdered and missing,\" said Elroy Fontaine, the brother of Tina Fontaine.\n\nTina's body was found in the Red River in 2014, wrapped in a duvet that was weighed down with rocks. She was 15 years old when she was killed.\n\nElroy says he often goes to MMIWG2S marches in honour of his sister.\n\n\"To try and change something, to try and change this ongoing genocide,\" he said.\n\nThe rally encouraged people to write to their local politicians, calling for action.\n\n\"We do these marches to try and open people's eyes. We have opened people's eyes, but not the right ones,\" Elroy said.\n\nHUNDREDS MARCH IN SAGKEENG FIRST NATION WHERE MORE THAN 20 CASES REMAIN UNSOLVED\n\nIn Sagkeeng First Nation, hundreds took part in a march to mark the day.\n\nIt comes after the chief of Sagkeeng voiced his disappointment earlier this week for a lack of government resources to address the 231 calls for justice outlined in the national inquiry report.\n\nSagkeeng has the most unsolved cases of missing or murdered Indigenous women and girls in Manitoba - resulting in Friday's walk taking on a personal meaning for many.\n\n\"If we suffer just one day walking for them, imagine what they go through on a daily basis. Not knowing where they are, not understanding what is happening, not realizing that there are so many other missing and murdered women too,\" said Mary Swampy, a resident of the First Nation. \"If I can do this, I'm very grateful for it.\"\n\nCurrently there are more than 20 cases of unsolved missing Indigenous women and girls from Sagkeeng First Nation.\n\nDISPLAY TO BE SET UP OVER THE WEEKEND AT HUMAN RIGHTS MUSEUM\n\nThe Canadian Museum for Human Rights is opening a display in recognition of the day. The display includes items from selected community members who have been impacted by MMIWG2S+.\n\nThe display will be set up throughout the weekend and free for people to see.\n\nIn a joint statement from Premier Heather Stefanson, Indigenous and Reconciliation and Northern Relations Minister Eileen Clarke and Families Minister Rochelle Squires, they encouraged Manitobans to join in honouring the memories of MMIWG.\n\n\"Today, we remember those who have lost their lives to gender-based violence, and we honour the healing journeys of families and communities that live with the ongoing grief of losing a loved one,\" the statement read.\n\nThe Legislative Building will be lit with an image of the red dress, which the province says is a sign to continue dialogue and bring attention to the issue.\n\n-With files from CTV's Jill Macyshon and Devon McKendrick\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nCrowds march through Downtown Winnipeg on Red Dress Day on May 5, 2023, honouring murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people. {"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/local-news/red-dress-day-is-today-not-sugarcoating-while-not-traumatizing-8699699", "title": "Red Dress Day is marked every year on May 5 - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n21.8 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Local News\nRed Dress Day: Not sugarcoating while not traumatizing\nMultiple events on the South Island will mark Red Dress Day today, the national day of awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\tMichael John Lo\n\nMay 5, 2024 4:05 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nSooke School District elementary and middle school students participate Red Dress Day events on Friday at Veterans Memorial Park in Langford. DARREN STONE, TIMES COLONIST\nListen to this article\n00:04:06\n\nOn Friday, Doreen Scow had a five-minute speech ready for the Red Dress Day ceremony in Langford that was attended by hundreds of students from the Sooke School District.\n\nBut she quickly strayed off her prepared remarks.\n\n\u201cI felt like I had to mention my late cousin Carsyn [Seaweed] too, because since her passing, Red Dress [Day] has been a lot more significant to me,\u201d Scow said.\n\nCarsyn Seaweed, 15, was found in a semi-conscious state last May, covered in twigs, leaves and a wooden pallet behind a Super 8 motel in Duncan. She later died in hospital.\n\nAfter her speech, Scow briefly chatted with a number of students, including a few who knew Seaweed personally.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m still trying to process everything that happened yesterday,\u201d she said in an interview Saturday. \u201cHearing what they had to say just really, really shook me to the core.\u201d\n\nScow, who is Kwakwaka\u2019wakw and a member of the Tlowitsis First Nation, said the ongoing issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls is important to teach to the next generation.\n\nStudents from Ruth King Elementary, Savory Elementary, Spencer Middle School, and David Cameron Elementary attended Friday\u2019s Red Dress Day event at Veterans Memorial Park.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve learned over the years that there\u2019s ways to not sugarcoat it, but also not traumatize the students,\u201d said Scow, who does cultural teachings for the school district.\n\nIn memory of Seaweed \u2014 who was in Duncan the day before her death for a soccer tournament \u2014 the family has put together a soccer team named Forever 15 that will play in her memory at the June Sports soccer tournament in Alert Bay this summer, she said.\n\nMultiple events on the South Island will mark Red Dress Day today, the national day of awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nEvents include a prayer circle in Duncan at Station Street Park, and in Greater Victoria, a 10 a.m. walk starting at the intersection of Hallowell Road and Admirals Road in part co-organized by the Songhees and Esquimalt Nations, and a march and rally at 1:30 p.m. at the \u023d\u00c1U,WEL\u1e48EW\u0331 Tribal School in Brentwood Bay.\n\nTwo Indigenous women are organizing an overnight vigil at the B.C. legislature, that will begin today at 5 p.m. and end on Monday at 7 p.m.\n\nThe event, which is open to the public, will be streamed on social media.\n\nCo-organizer Priscilla Omulo, who is a member of the Tsartlip First Nation, said the process of reporting a missing person, putting up posters, and searching for a missing family member is hard to convey to people who haven\u2019t experienced it. \u201cUntil it happens to you, you don\u2019t really understand the challenge.\u201d\n\nRecently, one of her family members went missing but was, fortunately, located alive a month later, she said.\n\nIndigenous people searching for their missing loved ones have to contend with the additional challenge of anti-Indigenous racism that\u2019s still entrenched in society today, she said, adding that systemic injustices facing Indigenous people did not go away when residential schools were abolished.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had a family member who has been shot and killed by RCMP. We have a family member who was murdered, whose assailants have not been brought to justice,\u201d she said.\n\nOmulo\u2019s voice becomes tinged with emotion when she speaks about why the colour red is used in events.\n\n\u201cRed is supposed to be the colour that people on the other side \u2014 the spirits \u2014 can see. It\u2019s calling them back home.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about being able to say that we see that your spirit is there. We see that you haven\u2019t received the justice you deserve yet \u2014 and that we are doing the best we can to remember you in a good way.\u201d\n\nElected officials at the legislature are welcome to drop by the 28-hour vigil, Omulo said. \u201cThese are real mothers, real cousins, real family members that are missing and murdered.\u201d\n\nmjlo@timescolonist.com\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has been shared 2 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tNanaimo RCMP find illicit drugs, weapons after stopping suspected prohibited driver\n\tPolice seize 20 guns, 20,000 rounds of ammo in raid on Bear Mountain home\n\tMLA Rob Fleming says he won't run in fall provincial election\nTimes Colonist - Featured\nInjuries reported in Highway 4 crashes on Canada Day weekend\nRead More\nTRENDING TODAY\n6303\t\nFirst heat wave of the summer on the way to Vancouver Island and B.C.\n\n2625\t\nFairway grocery store closing at Westshore Town Centre\n\n2555\t\nSuspect's pants catch fire in arson attempt gone wrong: B.C. {"url": "https://www.kincardinenews.com:443/news/local-news/live-together-as-brothers-and-sisters-red-dress-day-gathering-told", "title": "'Live together as brothers and sisters,\" Red Dress Day gathering told | Kincardine News", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\n'Live together as brothers and sisters,' Red Dress Day gathering told\nAuthor of the article:\nScott Dunn\nPublished May 05, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 05, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nRed Dress Day singers and drummers from the M'Wikwedong Hand Drumming Group in Owen Sound, Ont. on Friday, May 5, 2023. (Scott Dunn/The Sun Times/Postmedia Network)\nArticle content\n\nIt was a solemn day and people were warned hard truths might trigger emotions on Red Dress Day.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBut the nationally recognized day to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people had a mix of respectful silence, enthusiastic cheers and some laughter too.\n\nSusan Staves\u2019 opening prayer encouraged the \u201cmindful intention\u201d of having \u201cone heart and one mind to walk forward together on the path of healing.\u201d She pointed out someone designated who would sit with anyone feeling overcome with emotion.\n\nShe called on the Creator for help to be \u201cstrong, humble, understanding and gentle with one another.\u201d\n\nAbout 100 people assembled for the ceremony near the mouth of the Pottawatomi River, at the Giche Namewikwedong Reconciliation Garden circle in Nawash Park, which is close to the original Nawash settlement in what is now Owen Sound.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nA fire was kept by Billy Bannick and his five-year-old nephew, Declan Abitont. Women of the M\u2019Wikwedong Hand Drumming Group stood in a circle around it and sang songs with Ojibwa words, often sung with smiles.\n\nColleen Purdon, an anti-violence advocate, called it \u201can important day of memory but also an important day for moving forward.\u201d The day acknowledges people who \u201ccould not get help\u201d from society but \u201cwe are changing that.\u201d\n\nPeople watched Ken Albert perform a pipe ceremony, then Chippewas of Saugeen First Nation elder Shirley John offered prayers and shared some laughter too. She thanked someone for displaying red dresses, symbols for absent women.\n\n\u201cO Great Spirit who dwells in the sky. Lead us to the path of peace and understanding,\u201d she said. \u201cLet all of us live together as brothers and sisters. Our lives are so short here.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe read a poem which contained the words \u201cshe is laughing, more than the men who beat her . . . she is singing louder than the men who raped her . . . she is holding the light more than who despise her, she is holding flowers in her movement.\u201d\n\nJohn, whose Ojibwa name is Strong White Buffalo Woman, encouraged people to be thankful for their \u201ccountless blessings.\u201d She called on people to give thanks first thing in the morning because \u201cthat sets our intention for the day.\u201d\n\nSaugeen Elder Shirley John blesses people with water at a Red Dress Day gathering in the Reconciliation Garden in Owen Sound, Ont. on Friday, May 5, 2023. (Scott Dunn/The Sun Times/Postmedia Network)\n\nShe blessed everyone in the circle with water, then she and Sheila Robson walked to the water\u2019s edge, where Robson removed her shoes and socks, entered the water and tossed strawberries, or medicinal \u201cheart berries,\u201d into the river as an offering.\n\nChief Veronica Smith of the Chippewas of Nawash Unceded First Nation told the gathering that May 5 was the birthday of Hanna Harris, a Northern Cree woman who was murdered on a reserve in Montana in 2013.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCanadian Metis Jamie Black created the Red Dress Project as a response to the more than 1,000 missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada, she said. She has taken her exhibit across Canada and the United States and inspired calls for change.\n\n\u201cWhat is Canada doing? The National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Woman and Girls ended in June, 2019,\u201d she said. Among the calls to justice was for all levels of government to build a national action plan with partners, she said.\n\n\u201cWe need to continue protecting our women and our girls and our two-spirited people,\u201d she said and particularly calling for implementation of inquiry recommendations concerning police and community protection.\n\nSmith said many know someone or has a relative who has been murdered or is missing and she expressed deepest sympathies to people who are grieving and healing.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKathie Cole, a crisis counsellor at The Women Centre (Grey & Bruce), said Indigenous woman are more likely to experience intimate partner violence than are non-Indigenous women.\n\nMore than 44 per cent of Indigenous women have experienced physical or sexual violence by an intimate partner in their lifetime, compared with 25 per cent for non-Indigenous women.\n\nKaren Houle, a M\u2019Wikwedong Indigenous Friendship Centre gender diversity counsellor, challenged everyone to do something and suggested everyone read the calls to justice in the inquiry report.\n\nShe said none of the 231 calls to justice for all levels of government have been implemented.\n\nThe inquiry concluded that violence against Indigenous women and girls amounted to genocide. A national action plan to end violence against Indigenous women and girls was released in 2021.\n\nIn January, Crown-Indigenous Relations Minister Marc Miller\u2019s announced the appointment of a ministerial special representative to provide advice and recommendations to create an Indigenous human rights ombudsman.\n\nThat and creation of a related a national Indigenous and human rights tribunal are recommendations among the calls to justice.\n\nThe National Family and Survivors Circle has criticized the pace of implementing the calls to justice.\n\nBilly Bannick and Declan Abiton, 5, toss cedar into the sacred fire they kept during a Red Dress Day gathering in Owen Sound, Ont. on Friday, May 5, 2023. (Scott Dunn/The Sun Times/Postmedia Network)\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR KINCARDINE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

PHOTO BY MICHELLE BERG /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\nArticle content\n\nWhat started in one city as a way to bring attention to the the high rates of murder and violence against Indigenous females and two-spirited people has become an annual event across Canada. Here are a few things to know about Red Dress Day and what to plan for around Saskatoon \u2026\n\nWHAT IS RED DRESS DAY?\n\nRed Dress Day takes place annually on May 5, the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nWoman charged after altercation on city bus in Saskatoon's Confederation Park neighbourhood\nPolice investigating two stabbings in Saskatoon in two days\nMandryk: Sask. Party has turned truth telling into an election issue\nArticle content\n\nRed Dress Day dates back to 2010 and was inspired by a public art installation in Winnipeg by Metis artist Jaime Black, in which red dresses were displayed to bring attention to and represent MMIWG.\n\nIn Saskatoon, there is a permanent red dress installation in the lobby of City Hall.\n\nWHY WAS IT NECESSARY?\n\nIndigenous women, girls and two-spirit people are at a massively higher risk of abuse and violence than other groups. The National Inquiry for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls found that Indigenous women and girls are five times more likely to experience violence than any other population in Canada, and 12 times more likely to be murdered or to go missing.\n\nIndigenous women are also disproportionately represented in rates of police-reported intimate partner homicide \u2014 and nowhere in Canada are those rates higher than in Saskatchewan.\n\nWHAT EVENTS ARE TAKING PLACE IN SASKATOON?\n\nSeveral events are scheduled in the city between Friday and Sunday.\n\n* A calling home ceremony is set for Friday at 9 a.m. at city police headquarters. The event will include a pipe ceremony and gathering.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n* The Office of the Treaty Commissioner hosts an MMIWG education session Friday from 2 p.m. to 3 p.m. on Zoom.\n\n* Also on Friday, a red dress installation takes place from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. in the campus bowl at the University of Saskatchewan. The day will include hands-on activities and making red dress pins. Parts of the display will be moved to Gordon Oakes Red Bear Student Centre for the weekend.\n\n* Wanuskewin will host a beaded red dress earrings workshop from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Sunday.\n\n* A screening of \u201cK\u00edmmapiiyipitssini: The Meaning of Empathy\u201d runs Sunday from 12:30 p.m. to 2 p.m. at Remai Modern.\n\nWHEN IS THE AWARENESS WALK?\n\nThe annual awareness walk takes place Sunday at 2 p.m., starting and ending at the Vimy Memorial along the riverbank. The event is organized and led by community members, with notable support from the University of Saskatchewan, City of Saskatoon, Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations and Metis Nation-Saskatchewan.\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nSaskatoon students raise awareness of Red Dress Day\n'A piece of our soul goes with them': Saskatoon holds MMIWG memorial for Red Dress Day\n\nWith some online platforms blocking access to the news upon which you depend, our website is your destination for up-to-the-minute news, so make sure to bookmark\u00a0thestarphoenix.com\u00a0and sign up for our newsletters\u00a0here\u00a0so we can keep you informed.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nThree arrested after drug trafficking investigation in Saskatoon\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nLawyer for trucker who caused deadly Broncos crash says families have no right to sue\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nSeniors Are Getting Free Hearing Tests (Here's how)\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nAt 67, woman turns to ancestral vitamin and ends years of back pain and sciatica\nSciatic Institute\n|\nSponsored\nHigh blood sugar is not from sweets! {"url": "https://panow.com/2020/05/14/wanuskewin-welcomes-first-generation-of-baby-bison-born-on-land-in-nearly-150-years/", "title": "Wanuskewin welcomes first generation of baby bison born on land in nearly 150 years | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\nSPORTS\nWEATHER\nNEWS\nOBITUARIES\nCLASSIFIEDS\nLIFESTYLE\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\n(Submitted photo/Wanuskewin)\nBy Alison Sandstrom\nNEW LIFE\nWanuskewin welcomes first generation of baby bison born on land in nearly 150 years\nMay 14, 2020 | 2:00 PM\n\n\n\nWanuskewin Heritage Park is announcing the births of four baby bison, the first calves born on the land since the signing of Treaty 6 in 1876.\n\nWhile nearly 30 million bison once roamed the Great Plains, their number dwindled to near extinction in the late 1800s with only around 1000 left. Descendants of these last remaining animals found a new home at Wanuskewin in December as part of a conservation herd.\n\n(Submitted/Wanuskewin)\n\nThe new generation of bison born in the last month is made up of three females and one male. Their auspicious birthdays are being hailed as a powerful sign by park leadership.\n\nThe eldest arrived on Earth Day, the third on Red Dress Day, and the youngest calf on Mother\u2019s Day.\n\n\u201cAlready, based on their birthdays we know these bison have an incredible sense of timing,\u201d Wanuskewin CEO Darelene Brander said in a media release. \u201cIt is an honour for our park to welcome these magnificent creatures back to their natural territory. We lay down tobacco to give thanks for their arrival and look forward to sharing this herd with all of the world. They have become a powerful symbol of hope and resilience during these trying times of isolation.\u201d\n\n(Submitted/Wanuskewin)\n\nThe bison herd is an important part of Wanuskein\u2019s Grasslands restoration project that seeks to revive the critically endangered Native Prairie Grasslands ecosystem. The project has already reclaimed a section of land previously used for agriculture within the park boundary.\n\n\u201cBy introducing bison back to the land we will be adding that essential element needed for balance in both a cultural and scientific sense,\u201d Wanuskewin Board Chair and co-Chair of the Thundering Ahead Capital Campaign, Felix Thomas said. \u201cWe aim to grow the park to act as a natural oasis within the city limits that will offer a place for families to come and connect with the land once again.\u201d\n\nWanuskewin\u2019s trails and facilities remain closed to the public due to COVID-19, they are scheduled to re-open during phase four of the Re-Open Saskatchewan Plan.\n\n(Submitted/Wanuskewin)\n\n\u2013\n\npanews@jpbg.ca\n\nOn Twitter: @princealbertnow\n\nby Alison Sandstrom\nAround the Web\nWrinkles on the Neck? {"url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/sisters-in-spirit-vigil-held-in-edmonton-1.4625562", "title": "Sisters in Spirit vigil held in Edmonton | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFollow on\n\n  \n\nAdvertisement\n\nEDMONTON\nSisters in Spirit vigil held in Edmonton\nCTV News Edmonton\n\nErin Bezovie\nCTVNewsEdmonton.ca Digital Producer\n\nContact\n\nPublished Saturday, October 5, 2019 7:08AM MDT\n\nVigil for Sisters in Spirit day. Oct. 4, 2019. (CTV News Edmonton)\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nEDMONTON -- A special vigil was held in Edmonton Friday evening to remember Canada\u2019s missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nNearly 200 people showed up to the ceremony at Boyle Street Community Centre.\n\nAn RCMP report found 1,200 Aboriginal women were killed or went missing in Canada between 1980 and 2012.\n\nFriday\u2019s vigil was a way to pay respect to the affected families and raise awareness.\n\n\u201cWe see the effects in the children, we see the effects in the systems that are supposed to be set up to support them and they aren\u2019t working, so that\u2019s one of the reasons why we want everyone to hear us and try to do what they can to make changes,\u201d said Rachelle Venne with the Institute for the Advancement of Aboriginal Women.\n\n\u201cThere has been a lot of injustice done to those women, and there\u2019s still families that grieve for them in many, many ways,\u201d said Francis Whiskeyjack.\n\nWhiskeyjack works as a counsellor and mentor to youth, and says that these vigils are a chance for the community to get together and support the families of the murdered and missing women.\n\n\u201cA lot of the abuse whether it was sexual, physical, mental, emotional, have been left unanswered. So the memory itself\u2014that is very sacred and this is why you\u2019ll see so many people to honour them and support the families that are still grieving.\u201d\n\nWhiskeyjack says that a lot of people take the attitude of \u201cthe past is the past,\u201d but he says in order to reach reconciliation people need to talk about their experiences.\n\n\u201cWhen we speak the truth, it\u2019s very meaningful because I\u2019ve experienced it, other people have experienced it. We can forgive but we can\u2019t forget,\u201d said Whiskeyjack. \u201cIt\u2019s a serious issue, and it needs to be addressed in a kind way, and also to maintain the dignity of First Nations.\u201d\n\n\u201cEvery missing or murdered Indigenous woman and girl is a person to be honoured and mourned, and belongs to a family that needs answers, and a community that needs resolution,\u201d said Minister of Culture Leela Sharon Aheer in a statement.\n\n\u201cWe commit to building an Alberta where Indigenous women and girls are valued, respected and safe to live lives filled with hope and promise.\u201d\n\nThe ceremony was one of many across the country on Sisters in Spirit Day.\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport Error\nEditorial standards and\u00a0policies\nWhy you can trust CTV\u00a0News\nWATCH MORE FROM CTV NEWS\nfalse\nLIVE: Tracking the path of Hurricane Beryl\nfalse\nJosh Classen recaps the week in wild weather\nfalse\nCanadian vying to become top dog\nfalse\nHigh-speed police chase ends in collision\nfalse\nParents advocate for non-smart phones\nfalse\nFunds for transitioning from coal\nEDMONTON TOP STORIES\nWildfire burns out of control near Suncor's Firebag oilsands site\nViolent sexual offender to be released in Edmonton again: police\nAutopsy confirms death of woman found in Mill Creek Ravine was homicide\nWays to spend this weekend in Edmonton\nGunshots heard near Londonderry School during youth soccer game; PHOTO BY MICHELLE BERG /Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nWhile far from a point of pride, Winnipeg is the epicentre of the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirited People, from the project that lead to its alternate title of Red Dress Day to the call for a national state of emergency from local MP Leah Gazan to the history of people like Helen Betty Osborne and Tina Fontaine and a list that, unfortunately, keeps going on and on.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe occasion was marked with a Full Moon Ceremony on Thursday night at The Fork\u2019s Oodena Celebration Circle, leading into Friday\u2019s official day recognizing, as the final report of the national inquiry did, \u201ca national tragedy of epic proportion.\u201d\n\nGiganawenimaanaanig, the MMIWG2S+ implementation committee, is holding a Red Dress Round Dance at Portage Avenue and Main Street at noon, followed by a memorial march to The Forks at 12:30 p.m.\n\nThe Forks is the starting point for a third annual walk for MMIWG2S+ hosted by activists Travis Barsy and Cambria Harris, whose mother Morgan is one of four Indigenous women police believe was killed by Jeremy Skibicki.\n\nThe walk was renamed MMIWG2S+ Walk for Justice, from MMIWG2S+ Walk the Red, to reflect the 231 calls for justice and kicks off at 6:30 p.m.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Canadian Museum for Human Rights will have items from the sacred bundle \u2014 hundreds of artistic expressions of the national inquiry, among other exhibits, as part of a special display to mark the day.\n\nGhosted\n\nMay 5 also marks Cinco de Mayo, which doesn\u2019t seem to be a significant holiday in either Mexico or Canada, but an annual celebration of Mexican-American culture in the United States.\n\nOn Friday, the Good Will Social Club is hosting Reclaiming 5 De Mayo, a concert featuring Mariachi Ghost and guests which is raising funds for medical and legal bills for migrant farm workers in Manitoba.\n\nThe Migrant Workers Solidarity Network says temporary workers play a critical role in the agricultural and cattle industries, but face exploitation, poor housing situations and a lack of medical care. Ticket sales help pay for medical expenses, legal guidance and an annual event dedicated to the workers.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMariachi Ghost singer/guitarist Jorge Requena Ramos, born and raised in Mexico, is also asking for donations of sunglasses \u2013 a simple act of assistance in combating pterygium (or surfer\u2019s eye), a disease common to workers who spend long hours outside in sun, wind and dust.\n\nThe Mariachi Ghost play a show in support of migrant farm workers from Mexico, at the Good Will Social Club on Cinco De Mayo, May 5, 2023. {"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/islander/our-community-red-dress-raises-awareness-shows-student-s-metalwork-skills-1.24268570", "title": "Our Community: 'Red dress' raises awareness, shows student's metalwork skills - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n21.8 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Islander\nOur Community: 'Red dress' raises awareness, shows student's metalwork skills\nA class metalworking project at a Sooke school has turned into an opportunity to raise awareness of missing and murdered Aboriginal women in Canada.\nPedro Arrais\nJan 17, 2021 6:00 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 3 Pyper Phillips cuts a metal \u201cdress\u201d sculpture inspired by a design by First Nations artist Karver Everson. EDWARD MILNE COMMUNITY SCHOOL\nExpand\n\nA class metalworking project at a Sooke school has turned into an opportunity to raise awareness of missing and murdered Aboriginal women in Canada.\n\nPyper Phillips, a 16-year-old Metis student at Edward Milne Community School, created a red metal dress sculpture that is both a testament to her skill using a plasma cutter \u2014 a device for cutting through metal \u2014 and a contribution to dialogue on the issue.\n\nWinnipeg-based Metis artist Jaime Black initially conceived the REDress Project, an art installation where hundreds of red dresses are hung in public places to represent the more than 1,000 missing and murdered Aboriginal women in Canada. It is a permanent exhibit at the Canadian Museum of Human Rights.\n\nOn Vancouver Island, the Lil\u2019 Dress Project grew from a conversation around the kitchen table on how the local Aboriginal community could bring more awareness to the issue in the region.\n\nThe logo for the Comox-based grassroots group, designed by First Nations artist Karver Everson, served as the template for the dress made from aluminum by Phillips.\n\n\u201cI am happy to be able to support the project,\u201d said Phillips. \u201cWorking on it has certainly increased my understanding of the issue.\u201d\n\nShe used a plasma cutter to cut out the design of the metal dress sculpture, which measures 110 centimetres tall, 66 cm wide and three millimetres thick.\n\nThe sculpture is powder-coated to give it colour and a durable finish.\n\nPhillips is enrolled in TASK (Trades Awareness Skills and Knowledge), a hands-on trades program. The program, a partnership between the Sooke School District 62 and Camosun College, gives high-school or college students the opportunity to explore five different trades.\n\nThey can choose from carpentry, electrical, plumbing, sheet metal and welding.\n\nAt Edward Milne Community School, Grade 11 and 12 students who enroll in the metal TASK program learn about metal fabrication through class, shop instruction and work experience.\n\nPhillips has created two dresses, one of which will be hung in the school, where it will be used as a learning tool. The second dress will be donated to the Lil\u2019 Dress Project, as a thank-you for allowing the school to use its design.\n\nWhile Phillips downplays her role, her instructor says she deserves recognition.\n\n\u201cShe has inspired other students by her work,\u201d said Matt Harmeson, TASK program head as well as metal fabrication teacher at the school.\n\nHarmeson said the plan is to create smaller versions of the dress for sale, donating the proceeds to the Lil\u2019 Red Dress Project.\n\nSalvation Army Christmas Kettle Campaign tops $350,000\n\nVictorians responded to the Salvation Army\u2019s Christmas Kettle Campaign over the holidays, raising more than $350,000 for local programs and services for the community\u2019s most vulnerable.\n\nThe non-profit had asked for the public\u2019s support for the annual campaign, as the COVID-19 pandemic had resulted in a significant increase in people asking for help leading up to the holidays.\n\n\u201cWe let people know there was an increase in demand and they responded,\u201d said spokeswoman Patricia Mamic. \u201cThere was an incredible outpouring of support from people in this community and those funds will stay right here to help feed, clothe and shelter those in need, while helping others escape violence and addiction.\n\nAlthough there were fewer people out and about this holiday season, they were more generous, as this year\u2019s donation total represents a $100,000 increase from last year.\n\nProvincially, the campaign raised $5.3 million.\n\nThe Canadian arm of the Salvation Army began its work in 1882 and is one of the largest providers of social services in the country. It has a presence in more than 55 communities in B.C. and 400 communities across Canada.\n\nFor more information, go to salvationarmy.ca.\n\nFriends of Uplands Park to tackle carpet burweed\n\nJoin the Friends of Uplands Park on a Carpet Burweed Crawl at Uplands Park, every Sunday from today until May.\n\nThe extremely invasive carpet burweed can destroy rare wildflowers.\n\nThe event is in partnership with Oak Bay\u2019s parks department.\n\nThe event is free to join. It runs from 1 to 3 p.m. every Sunday until May from the marine kiosk at Cattle Point in the park, off Dallas Road.\n\nFor more information, go to friendsofuplandspark.org.\n\nGot an idea for a project under Victoria\u2019s strategic plan?\n\nThe City of Victoria is accepting applications for the city\u2019s strategic plan grants, with $500,000 worth of funding available. Non-profit and community organizations are invited to submit applications for projects or programs that support the actions and outcomes of the City of Victoria\u2019s Strategic Plan and build community resilience.\n\n\u201cWe know that our community has been hit hard over the past year,\u201d said Mayor Lisa Helps. \u201cThese grants are one way that council can support local groups to create and enhance greater resilience in the community so we are better prepared and more resilient as a community as future challenges come our way.\u201d\n\nPreviously funded projects have included programs to help prevent youth homelessness, support Indigenous healing, educate renters about their legal rights and responsibilities, create a neighbourhood tool-share program, and advise newcomers on educational and financial-assistance opportunities.\n\nSince the program began in 2015, the city\u2019s annual strategic plan grants have funded 286 projects, investing $3.1 million in the community. The deadline for applications is Jan. 31. For more information, go to victoria.ca/grants.\n\nNominations open for Victoria leadership awards\n\nNominations are now open for the Victoria Community Leadership Awards, presented by Leadership Victoria.\n\nNominations are open in 10 categories. Nominees are typically leaders who see an opportunity in the community and jump in with both feet to make a difference.\n\nLeadership Victoria is an organization that grows community leadership. This is the 17th year of the awards.\n\nNominations are open to everyone. For more information, go to leadershipvictoria.ca.\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/news/no-more-stolen-sisters-red-dress-walk-honours-missing-indigenous-women-in-b-c/", "title": "\u2018No more stolen sisters\u2019: Red Dress Walk honours missing Indigenous women in B.C. - Comox Valley Record", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n19.8 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\n\u2018No more stolen sisters\u2019: Red Dress Walk honours missing Indigenous women in B.C.\nDeanna Wertz, Caitlin Potts, Ashley Simpson and Nicole Bell \u2014 missing, but not forgotten.\nBrieanna Charlebois\nOct 4, 2018 4:00 PM\nOct 4, 2018 4:41 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 12 (Brieanna Charlebois/ Morning Star)\nExpand\n\nUnmistakable chants of \u201cGone but not forgotten\u201d and \u201cNo more stolen sisters\u201d rang out across the river in Enderby Thursday morning to honour all murdered and missing women.\n\nFrom across the Len Bawtree Bridge, passersby couldn\u2019t miss the sea of about two-dozen people sporting red-coloured clothing or miss the sound of the drum. Smoke rose over the water. Upon a closer look, you could spot dresses, all red in colour, hanging from the branches of the trees behind them.\n\nRelated: Red Dress Walk honours, remembers missing North Okanagan women\n\nRelated: Red dresses send a message\n\nTo remember all murdered and missing women, the Splatsin Nation and MMIW Drone Search Team hosted a Red Dress Walk \u2014 a nation-wide initiative that seeks to inform the public about Canada\u2019s high number of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls. As part of the campaign, people within the community are asked to hang a red dress.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of missing women right across B.C. and we search for them all,\u201d said Jody Leon of the Splatsin First Nation. \u201cIt\u2019s important for people to continue to talk about the women within the Splatsin First Nation area \u2014 and for all women \u2014 and to go forward and not allow their names or their stories to be forgotten because out of that answers will come out to the RCMP and that will give closure to the families.\u201d\n\nThe women the ceremony seeks to remember include Potts, Simpson, Wertz, Bell and Traci Genereaux, whose remains were found on a Salmon River Road farm in Silver Creek in October 2017. They were all reported missing from the area in 2016 and 2017.\n\nSpeakers for the event, which began at 11 a.m. on the east side of the Len Bawtree Bridge, included the Neskonlith Indian Band Chief and Jody Leon of the Drone Search Team. A police escort in tow, the group made their way through the streets bearing signs that read, \u201cMissing but never forgotten\u201d, \u201cNo more violence against women\u201d, and \u201cNo more stolen sisters\u201d, among others.\n\nThe group eventually made their way to the Community Centre where lunch was served to participants following more speakers.\n\n\u201cWe want people to be involved and to continue to speak out,\u201d said Leon. \u201cWe want everyone to know that we will continue to look for missing women and we won\u2019t give up.\u201d\n\nRelated: Family remembers mother at Red Dress Walk\n\nRelated: Indigenous children still being treated unequally by provinces: advocate\n\nRelated: Search for missing women to continue\n\nTo report a typo, email:\nnewstips@vernonmorningstar.com.\n\n\nFollow me on Twitter @BrieChar\nEmail me brieanna.charlebois@vernonmorningstar.com\nLike us on\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tRobots, technology take care in Comox's innovative new dementia village\n\t\tComox Valley Ducky 500 winners announced\n\t\tCVRD, Clean BC to offer heat pump and electrical upgrade rebates\n\t\t'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\n\t\tComox Valley RCMP investigating fatal overnight collision involving pedestrian\nFacebook Comments (0) \nComox Valley RCMP investigating fatal overnight collision involving pedestrian\nBlack Press Media\nDriver airlifted to hospital after Vancouver Island crash\nBlack Press Media\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nReview: Captain Cooks Casino is the Real Deal\nTrust Pilot Rating and Review: I did what any savvy person would do. {"url": "https://www.whitecourtstar.com/news/death-of-ellie-herman-a-reminder-mmiwg2s-an-issue-people-cant-ignore", "title": "Death of Ellie Herman a reminder MMIWG2S an issue 'people can't ignore' | Whitecourt Star", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nAdvertise with Us\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nDeath of Ellie Herman a reminder MMIWG2S an issue 'people can't ignore'\nAuthor of the article:\nSarah Williscraft \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Local Journalism Initiative\nPublished Apr 27, 2021 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Apr 28, 2021 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 4 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nA picture of Ellie Herman supplied by the Wood Buffalo RCMP.\nArticle content\n\nDaniel Herman started getting worried in late September 2019 when he stopped hearing from his daughter, Ellie Herman. It wasn\u2019t like her to disappear, and Herman was reported missing a few weeks later on Oct. 17.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI was worried about her seven days a week and 24 hours a day,\u201d said Daniel. \u201cI could barely eat and I didn\u2019t even know what I was going through at the time.\u201d\n\nHerman, a member of the Chipewyan Prairie Dene First Nation, was found on March 20 at 1:49 p.m. People on a trail by the Rotary Club Gazebo at Thicket Drive and Silin Forest Road found her remains, which were brought to Edmonton for an autopsy. A cause of death was not determined, but doctors confirmed Herman\u2019s identity.\n\nDaniel said he is grateful to the people who found his daughter and has had no issues with Wood Buffalo RCMP. But, he still wants to know what happened to his daughter and wants to honour her memory.\n\n\u201cShe was a happy girl all the time just like me,\u201d said Daniel, who described Herman as a mother and daughter connected to her family. \u201cShe was a dependable, reliable and a good person and she would always reach out to anyone who ever needed help.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHerman is one of eight Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit people (MMIWG2S), who have been reported missing or murdered in the Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo area since 2004.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s something that people can\u2019t ignore and pretend isn\u2019t happening,\u201d said Mayor Don Scott. \u201cIt\u2019s certainly something that affects a lot of families.\u201d\n\nTootsie Tuccaro and her son Paul comfort each other before taking media questions. Deputy Commissioner Curtis Zablocki, Commanding Officer of RCMP \u201cK\u201d Division, issued a public apology on behalf of the RCMP to the family of Amber Tuccaro on July 25, 2019. Tuccaro was murdered in 2010 in Leduc county. Photo by Shaughn Butts / Postmedia PHOTO BY SHAUGHN BUTTS /Postmedia\n\nElaine Alook was last seen in May 2004. Shirley Waquan was last seen in July 2007. Shelly Dene was last seen in July 2013. Betty Ann Deltess was last seen in Janvier in April 2018.\n\nAmber Tuccaro was reported missing in Aug. 2010 while visiting Nisku. Her remains were found in a Leduc field two years later. The RCMP admitted in July 2019 the investigation of her death was mishandled by investigators and apologized. The family refused to accept the apology.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nJanice Desjarlais was last seen climbing into a dumpster with her boyfriend near the downtown McDonald\u2019s to stay warm on Oct. 1, 2010. When her boyfriend left to get breakfast the next morning, a garbage truck emptied the dumpster. Desjarlais was likely smothered under other people\u2019s garbage and buried in the Fort McMurray landfill. Her body was never found.\n\nAudrey Bignose was found deceased outside an Eagle Ridge home on Christmas 2019.\n\nRosie Keating, executive director at Centre of Hope, said Herman, Desjarlais, Deltess and Bignose were all patrons of the organization. Keating said she had fond memories of Herman.\n\n\u201cEllie was a wonderful girl and she loved her children dearly,\u201d said Keating. \u201cShe was always pleasant and respectful when she came into the centre.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKeating said the issue of MMIWG2S is not investigated enough and needs to be taken more seriously locally.\n\n\u201cA lot of these women seem to fall through the cracks of the justice system and we need to bring awareness to it because every person matters,\u201d said Keating.\n\nProtesters march down Franklin Avenue on Saturday afternoon, demanding a federal inquiry into missing and murdered aboriginal women. Vincent McDermott/Today staff\n\nLisa Marie Bourque, president of the Nistawoyou Friendship Centre, said Bignose\u2019s 2019 death was a tragedy felt by the organization. Bignose frequented the Friendship Centre and was well known by staff and patrons.\n\n\u201cShe was talented, she was an artist, she could write in ancient syllabic and she brought value to this Earth,\u201d said Bourque. \u201cShe was found dead, frozen and possibly murdered, and what have they done to look into it further? I don\u2019t think we ever got an update.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBourque said discrimination against Indigenous women is a serious issue in the region. She hears frequent allegations of women harassed or mistreated by local law enforcement.\n\n\u201cIf something is happening to you, sometimes you don\u2019t even want to call for help,\u201d said Bourque. \u201cWhen they look at you, all they see is just another Native and don\u2019t think you need to be taken seriously.\u201d\n\nSara Loutitt, a local M\u00e9tis activist, said a large transient workforce with few ties to the region puts marginalized communities at risk of abuse. Indigenous leaders call this \u201cenvironmental violence.\u201d Rural communities also have limited resources for people fleeing domestic or sexual violence.\n\n\u201cThings have slowed down in the past few years and the number of transient workers coming to work in Fort McMurray has slowed down but we can\u2019t somehow think that the sexual exploitation of Indigenous women has disappeared,\u201d said Loutitt.\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMay 5 is Red Dress Day, a national annual event honouring and raising awareness of MMIWG2S people. Jes Croucher, of Paw\u00e2miw Creative, is arranging a local event with First Nations, M\u00e9tis Locals and other local Indigenous organizations.\n\nThere will be a Facebook Live panel hosted by the Athabasca Tribal Council, a walk at 1 p.m. through Centre of Hope. The Saline Creek footbridge will be lit red to honour MMIWG2S people.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just a day, this is an ongoing effort,\u201d said Croucher. \u201cYou have to continue to educate yourself and realize this is a personal issue for everybody. Even if you are non-Indigenous, you have Indigenous friends, co-workers and this is happening within your community.\u201d\n\nWood Buffalo RCMP secure a trail, located near Silin Forest Road and Thicket Drive, on Sunday, March 21, 2021 after the remains of Ellie Herman were found in the area. Sarah Williscraft/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\nA red dress, which has become a symbol of missing and murdered Indigenous women, hangs outside a home on the Fort McMurray #468 First Nation on September 16, 2020. Sarah Williscraft/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nA woman gets her face painted to raise awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women at the Centre of Hope in downtown Fort McMurray as a part of the Sisters in Spirit vigil on Friday, October 4, 2019.
