{"url": "https://www.vernonmorningstar.com/news/red-dress-walk-strolls-through-enderby/", "title": "\u2018No more stolen sisters\u2019: Red Dress Walk honours missing Indigenous women - Vernon Morning Star", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n26.9 \u00b0C\nHome News\n\u2018No more stolen sisters\u2019: Red Dress Walk honours missing Indigenous women\nDeanna Wertz, Caitlin Potts, Ashley Simpson and Nicole Bell \u2014 missing, but not forgotten.\nBrieanna Charlebois\nOct 4, 2018 3:30 PM\nOct 4, 2018 4:40 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 12 (Brieanna Charlebois/ Morning Star)\nExpand\n\nUnmistakable chants of \u201cGone but not forgotten\u201d and \u201cNo more stolen sisters\u201d rang out across the river in Enderby Thursday morning to honour all murdered and missing women.\n\nFrom across the Len Bawtree Bridge, passersby couldn\u2019t miss the sea of about two-dozen people sporting red-coloured clothing or miss the sound of the drum. Smoke rose over the water. Upon a closer look, you could spot dresses, all red in colour, hanging from the branches of the trees behind them.\n\nRelated: Red Dress Walk honours, remembers missing North Okanagan women\n\nRelated: Red dresses send a message\n\nTo remember all murdered and missing women, the Splatsin Nation and MMIW Drone Search Team hosted a Red Dress Walk \u2014 a nation-wide initiative that seeks to inform the public about Canada\u2019s high number of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls. As part of the campaign, people within the community are asked to hang a red dress.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of missing women right across B.C. and we search for them all,\u201d said Jody Leon of the Splatsin First Nation. \u201cIt\u2019s important for people to continue to talk about the women within the Splatsin First Nation area \u2014 and for all women \u2014 and to go forward and not allow their names or their stories to be forgotten because out of that answers will come out to the RCMP and that will give closure to the families.\u201d\n\nThe women the ceremony seeks to remember include Potts, Simpson, Wertz, Bell and Traci Genereaux, whose remains were found on a Salmon River Road farm in Silver Creek in October 2017. They were all reported missing from the area in 2016 and 2017.\n\nSpeakers for the event, which began at 11 a.m. on the east side of the Len Bawtree Bridge, included the Neskonlith Indian Band Chief and Jody Leon of the Drone Search Team. A police escort in tow, the group made their way through the streets bearing signs that read, \u201cMissing but never forgotten\u201d, \u201cNo more violence against women\u201d, and \u201cNo more stolen sisters\u201d, among others.\n\nThe group eventually made their way to the Community Centre where lunch was served to participants following more speakers.\n\n\u201cWe want people to be involved and to continue to speak out,\u201d said Leon. \u201cWe want everyone to know that we will continue to look for missing women and we won\u2019t give up.\u201d\n\nRelated: Family remembers mother at Red Dress Walk\n\nRelated: Indigenous children still being treated unequally by provinces: advocate\n\nRelated: Search for missing women to continue\n\nTo report a typo, email:\nnewstips@vernonmorningstar.com.\n\n\nFollow me on Twitter @BrieChar\nEmail me brieanna.charlebois@vernonmorningstar.com\nLike us on\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tVernon cowgirl ropes in B.C. {"url": "https://whatsnew2day.com/brother-of-environment-minister-kevin-klein-contradicts-his-metis-identity-says-manitoba-metis-federation/", "title": "Spencer Matthews Reveals Secret Pain Behind His Made In Chelsea 'bad Boy' Act: MIC Star Says 'anger' At 'those He Held Responsible' For His Brother Michael's Death On Mount Everest Was At Root Of His Alcoholism", "body": "SEARCH\nHOME\nUS\nAUSTRALIA\nWORLD\nPOLITICS\nTECH\nSPORTS\nESPORTS\nENTERTAINMENT\nHEALTH\nLIFE STYLE\nMONEY\nTRAVEL\nThursday, July 4, 2024\n \n \n \nHOME\nCONTACT US\nPRIVACY POLICY\nCopyright 2021 - All Right Reserved\nHome Entertainment Spencer Matthews reveals secret pain behind his Made in Chelsea \u2018bad boy\u2019 act: MIC star says \u2018anger\u2019 at \u2018those he held responsible\u2019 for his brother Michael\u2019s death on Mount Everest was at root of his alcoholism\nEntertainment\nSpencer Matthews reveals secret pain behind his Made in Chelsea \u2018bad boy\u2019 act: MIC star says \u2018anger\u2019 at \u2018those he held responsible\u2019 for his brother Michael\u2019s death on Mount Everest was at root of his alcoholism\nwritten by Merry March 28, 2024 0 comment\nSHARE 0FacebookTwitterPinterestLinkedinTumblrReddit\n\nBy Dolly Busby, entertainment reporter\n\nPublished: 11:54 EDT, March 28, 2024 | Updated: 15:16 EDT, March 28, 2024\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013 <!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\nFor years he was known as the Made In Chelsea \u2018bad boy\u2019 who partied excessively in high-end nightclubs.\n\nBut Spencer Matthews has revealed that it was the anger he harbored at losing his brother at the age of ten that led him to begin abusing alcohol at a young age.\n\nIn an emotional interview in the new edition of the Mail. Podcast Everything I Know About MeThe star said he rejects the term \u201cchildhood trauma\u201d and that the therapy he sought after his brother disappeared descending Mount Everest 25 years ago made him feel \u201cuncomfortable.\u201d\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nMatthews, 35, whose older brother James is married to Pippa Middleton, said: \u201cI harbored a lot of anger for many years and terrible feelings towards people who I believed had made mistakes that led to my brother\u2019s death.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s how I felt growing up, I would get drunk, talk about it and let off steam by getting really angry from time to time.\n\nSpencer Matthews has revealed the \u201canger\u201d he felt over his brother Michael\u2019s death on Everest and how it caused him problems with alcohol when he was \u201cvery young\u201d.\n\nIn an emotional interview on the Mail\u2019s new Everything I Know About Me podcast, the star said he rejects the term \u201cchildhood trauma\u201d and that the therapy he sought after his brother disappeared descending Mount Everest 15 years ago made him feel \u201d uncomfortable\u201d.\n\n\u201cIt was a really strange time in my life where I was drinking heavily, often at a very young age.\u201d\n\nMatthews, who is married to Irish influencer Vogue Williams, remained on Made in Chelsea for ten seasons from 2011 to 2015 before seeking therapy for his alcoholism in 2018 and, a father of three, has been teetotal ever since.\n\nReflecting on his therapy during the podcast, he said: \u2018I\u2019ve sought help for my alcoholism and what keeps coming back is this trauma that I suffered as a child.\n\n\u2018I don\u2019t like the idea that something happened to me and therefore I became a certain way.\n\n\u2018I have always felt uncomfortable when I went to therapy and they asked me what your parents were like. And I\u2019m like, my parents are great, leave them alone.\n\nHe continued: \u2018I hate blaming circumstances beyond my control for my alcohol abuse. I\u2019ve always felt uncomfortable with that. My decision to abuse alcohol for many years was my decision and I was conscious when I did so.\u2019\n\nMatthews\u2019 older brother Michael became the youngest Briton to conquer Mount Everest in 1999 at the age of 23, but fell to his death while descending alone in a 100mph snowstorm.\n\nHis father, David Matthews,\u2019s attempt to bring a manslaughter case against three Everest guides for negligence on the mountain was rejected in 2006.\n\nMatthews\u2019 older brother Michael became the youngest Briton to conquer Mount Everest in 1999 at the age of 23, but fell to his death while descending alone in a 100mph snowstorm.\n\nSpencer shares children Theodore, five, Gigi, three, and Otto, 18 months, with Vogue Williams. Last year, Spencer starred in Finding Michael, a documentary about his brother\u2019s unfortunate journey.\n\nSpencer headlined Finding Michael, a documentary about her brother\u2019s ill-fated journey, last year.\n\nHe said: \u201cI can tell you how it made me feel, I grew up believing throughout my teenage years that Mike had been murdered by someone who made mistakes.\u201d\n\n\u201cThese particular people made mistakes that led to my brother\u2019s death.\u201d\n\nMatthews shares his children Theodore, five, Gigi, three, and Otto, 18 months, with Ms Williams.\n\nThe Mail\u2019s latest podcast, Everything I Know About Me, explores the lives of some of our most fascinating public figures, the highs, lows and in-betweens told in their own words.\n\nShare or comment on this article: {"url": "https://winnipegsun.com/news/provincial/manitoba-cabinet-minister-says-he-is-metis-on-a-personal-journey-about-his-family", "title": "Cabinet minister defends Metis ancestry after brother questions claim | Winnipeg Sun", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nePaper\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nJets add to depth with two-way signings\nTRENDING\nPlayers hearing it from fans: What's up with Bombers?\nTRENDING\nBILLECK: Jets' direction fuzzy, confusing after free agency opens\nTRENDING\nManitoba launches Orange Shirt Day Fund to support truth and reconciliation efforts\nTRENDING\nManitoba First Nation reports 150 anomalies at residential school site\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nWinnipegNewsManitoba\nManitoba cabinet minister defends Indigenous ancestry after brother questions claim\n\nAuthor of the article:\n\nNational Post\nTyler Dawson\nPublished Jul 31, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Jul 31, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 5 minute read\n38 Comments\nManitoba Environment Minister Kevin Klein speaks to reporters in Winnipeg on Monday, July 31, 2023. He is facing questions about his claim of being Metis. PHOTO BY STEVE LAMBERT /The Canadian Press\nArticle content\n\nManitoba\u2019s environment minister is facing scrutiny over his identification as a \u201cproud M\u00e9tis Canadian,\u201d the latest in a number of prominent Canadians who\u2019ve been accused of claiming Indigenous ancestry without sufficient evidence.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKevin Klein has said he\u2019s a member of the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis, but his brother and the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation have questioned his claims.\n\n\u201cIt saddened me and it brought up a lot of emotions. It brought up a lot of history,\u201d said Klein, when reached Monday morning by National Post.\n\nKlein has been a provincial legislator since 2022, and before that he served on Winnipeg\u2019s city council. At various points in his political career, he has mentioned his Indigenous ancestry \u2014 specifically in relation to his mother, Joanne Winacott, who was murdered by her second husband in 1991.\n\nIn December 2021, Klein spoke in Winnipeg council, during a debate about the police budget. He said, \u201cI have very little to say on this one, but I want to speak from a place that no one else on council can speak from.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHe went on to speak about police response times.\n\n\u201cMy Indigenous mother was murdered because the police didn\u2019t respond to the initial call. That is on record in, and it\u2019s in the court documents,\u201d Klein said at the time.\n\nKlein referenced his mother\u2019s identity again on May 5, 2022, in an Instagram video for Red Dress Day, also known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\n\u201cMy mother was murdered by her partner, and she was Indigenous,\u201d he said.\n\nI'm not self-identifying, nor am I using it, nor am I mentioning it every time I open my mouth\n\nKlein\u2019s brother, Christopher Rout, has firmly rejected the characterization that his family has Indigenous heritage.\n\n\u201cHe never grew up M\u00e9tis. My grandparents never told us we were M\u00e9tis. I never heard anything about us being M\u00e9tis,\u201d said Rout in an interview with the National Post. \u201cThe net bottom line is we are not Aboriginal at all.\u201d\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKlein, who\u2019s a Progressive Conservative MLA, told National Post that he first learned of his purported M\u00e9tis ancestry when speaking with his uncle Dave. They were going through old photo albums, and his uncle asked him if he had his M\u00e9tis card, Klein said.\n\n\u201cI said \u2018No, I don\u2019t think I\u2019m M\u00e9tis,'\u201d Klein recalled. \u201cHe pulled out his card and said \u2018We are. You need to get your M\u00e9tis card because your mom never had the chance to.\u2019 \u201d\n\nKlein then applied to the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis. His understanding was that they did their own research before issuing a card.\n\n\u201cIt excited me because it\u2019s a connection I never knew,\u201d he said. \u201cI went with it because of my uncle, who I loved dearly.\u201d\n\nThe uncle, said Rout, has since died.\n\nThe allegations against Klein \u2014 that his claims of Indigenous ancestry are disputed \u2014 were first reported by CBC News, which used census records to build Klein\u2019s family tree. It found no evidence of an Indigenous ancestor.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKlein said what he knows of it came from his uncle, and that the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis did their own genealogical research.\n\n\u201cThere are many Indigenous and non-(Indigenous) who are looking for clarity on their story of origin, their family history,\u201d said Klein. \u201cAnd this is something I will continue to do as a personal journey for as long as I live.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, there have been a number of prominent Canadians who have had their claims to Indigenous identity questioned, including Ellen Turpel-Lafond, who claimed to be the first Cree judge. Her claims to be a \u201cTreaty Indian\u201d have been highly disputed.\n\nThe novelist Joseph Boyden, who\u2019s best known for writing about Indigenous culture, has long claimed Indigenous ancestry, but various news reports have since disputed his claims.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn the case of Klein, his political biographies have, at various times, identified him as M\u00e9tis, although the term has recently been dropped from some of his social media accounts, CBC reported.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not self-identifying, nor am I using it, nor am I mentioning it every time I open my mouth. It is a family issue for me and a connection to my mother,\u201d Klein told CBC last fall.\n\nManitoba M\u00e9tis Federation President David Chartrand told CBC that Klein does not meet their criteria to identify as M\u00e9tis.\n\n\u201cWe do not recognize the Painted Feather Woodlands M\u00e9tis or any other group that claims M\u00e9tis identity outside our definition. This is no different than any of the other cases where groups or individuals are calling themselves M\u00e9tis when they really mean mixed heritage,\u201d Chartrand said in an email.\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOn Monday, Klein told the Post he has dropped the identifier in some places because, \u201cI don\u2019t mean to insult anybody. It really was a proud moment for me to believe that my family had that M\u00e9tis status.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a personal journey. I don\u2019t want to insult anybody, but I am going to follow my personal journey. And that\u2019s how we got here today,\u201d Klein said.\n\n\u201cI got into public life to serve, not to offend. To help people, not degrade them. It was never, has never, was never an attempt to make a false claim.\u201d\n\nKlein, who was the publisher and CEO of the Winnipeg Sun newspaper between 2007 and 2013, which is now owned by Postmedia Network Inc., speculated that a \u201cLiberal-NDP-funded government employee\u201d raised questions about his identity in order to harm his reputation ahead of the provincial election. Manitobans go to the polls in October.\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI can only assume it was to hurt us, to attempt to hurt us in the election when really all it did was cause more pain and sorrow for my family,\u201d Klein said.\n\nKlein\u2019s official biography, from when he was appointed to Premier Heather Stefanson\u2019s cabinet, said Klein \u201ccontinues to explore, working with Elders in Manitoba to research his connections to Indigenous community. This exploration has heightened his desire to work with Indigenous communities.\u201d\n\nA profile in What\u2019s up Winnipeg, a local magazine, reports that Klein took courses in Cree and M\u00e9tis history at the University of Alberta during COVID-19 to learn more about his roots, which he\u2019d learned about from his mother\u2019s older brother.\n\n\u201cBlond and blue-eyed Indigenous people were not uncommon among certain groups in middle America,\u201d the profile says. \u201cHis family says his roots are evident in his cheekbones, which Kevin says he could never produce a proper beard!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 9\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nWhen reached by National Post on Monday, Rout also objected to Klein\u2019s use of their mother\u2019s experience with domestic violence, and said Klein wasn\u2019t even living at home when the domestic violence and murder occurred.\n\n\u201cAs a son, you shouldn\u2019t be trying to profit or benefit from your mom\u2019s death,\u201d said Rout.\n\nKlein said he hasn\u2019t spoken to his brother in more than 25 years. He does, however, have a relationship with their other brother, Duane.\n\nIn an email provided to the National Post by Klein\u2019s office, Duane purportedly writes that he can confirm that Klein and their Uncle Dave had a M\u00e9tis card \u2014 although the email does not go so far as to confirm Indigenous ancestry in the family.\n\n\u201cNo one knows the full history of my immediate family. I am not going into any detail because I strongly believe family matters are just that, between family,\u201d the email says. \u201cI pray my mom can Rest In Peace again.\u201d\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nBombers' Collaros to miss first start of season vs Redblacks\nWinnipeg Sun\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. PHOTO BY UNIVERSAL PICTURES\nArticle content\n\nA sequel to The Fall Guy has already been written, but it\u2019s unlikely that it will ever get made after the film flopped at the box office this past weekend, opening below expectations with $28.5 million.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn an interview with Fast Company, star Ryan Gosling said he hopes to keep telling the story of his character Colt Seavers, a stuntman who is hired to track down the missing actor who is the star of his ex-girlfriend\u2019s (Emily Blunt) directorial debut.\n\n\u201cThe sequel sort of wrote itself,\u201d Gosling told the outlet. \u201cWe already know (the story) intimately. We\u2019re just hoping that people like this movie enough that we get to keep telling the story of these characters. We love them so much, and we love this world, and I feel confident that we can do it.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cThese days everyone always hopes their movie can become a franchise.\u201d\n\nBut Gosling\u2019s ode to stunt performers underperformed at the box office opening with a paltry $28.5 million at North American theatres, effectively dashing his hopes for a sequel.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Universal Pictures film kicked off summer moviegoing on the May weekend that Marvel has dominated with $100 million-plus launches for over a decade. (On the same weekend in 2023, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 debuted with $118 million.) But last year\u2019s strikes delayed Deadpool & Wolverine, which was originally slated to open on the first Friday in May.\n\nGoing into the weekend, early forecasts had The Fall Guy opening in the $30 million to $40 million range.\n\nThe action-comedy now faces a steep uphill battle to recoup its $130-million production budget.\n\n\u201cWe love these characters so much that we wanted to know, just for ourselves, what happens to Colt and (Blunt\u2019s character) Jody after the movie ends?\u201d Gosling said hopefully in his interview with Fast Company.\u00a0\u201cWhat\u2019s the next phase for them? And we know exactly what it is. So hopefully the audience wants to know, too.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nStill, Jim Orr, distribution chief for Universal, remains bullish on the film despite its lackluster first weekend results.\n\n\u201cWe had a very solid opening,\u201d Orr told the Associated Press, trying to put a positive spin on the muted results. \u201cWe\u2019re looking forward to a very long, very robust, very successful run throughout the domestic box office for literally weeks if not months to come.\u201d\n\nBut despite featuring two of the stars of last summer\u2019s \u201cBarbenheimer\u201d phenomenon (Gosling starred in Barbie and Blunt appeared in Oppenheimer), The Fall Guy\u2019s faceplant likely means the film will be one-and-done. Next weekend, Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes will open in theatres and a new Mad Max movie, Furiosa, is waiting in the wings later this month.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cUniversal spent money with The Fall Guy like they were delivering \u2018Barbenheimer 2.0.\u2019 But in reality what they got was a sequel to (the Sandra Bullock-Channing Tatum adventure comedy) The Lost City,\u201d Jeff Bock, a senior box office analyst with Exhibitor Relations, tells Postmedia. \u201cIt\u2019s a tall task to open the summer season in Hollywood and The Fall Guy fell noticeably short. Unfortunately, in real life, there is no second take. You get one shot at an opening weekend. Now Universal will have to pray (the film has) legs.\u201d\n\n\u201cGiven the high profile cast and its position as the kickoff film of the summer season, high expectations were placed on The Fall Guy, so its debut has been seen as a disappointment,\u201d says Paul Dergarabedian, senior media analyst for Comscore. But he thinks there\u2019s still a chance the film can build some momentum over time.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cFor most audiences this was seen as an original film and not based on massively known IP, particularly amongst younger moviegoers. So it will take some time for word of mouth and buzz to kick in,\u201d Dergarabedian says.\n\nIronically, during the press cycle for The Fall Guy, Gosling was asked why his 2016 action-comedy The Nice Guys also fell short of expectations and didn\u2019t land a follow-up.\n\n\u201cSo much of a sequel, I think, is decided by the opening weekend of a movie, and we opened up against Angry Birds,\u201d Gosling explained in an interview with ComicBook.com. \u201cSo Angry Birds just, just destroyed us. Angry Birds got a sequel.\u201d\n\nThe Nice Guys also faced competition on its opening weekend from Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising\u00a0and\u00a0Captain America: Civil War.\n\nAt the end of its box office run,\u00a0The Nice Guys, which co-starred Russell Crowe, managed to gross an estimated $62 million on a $50-million budget.\n\nmdaniell@postmedia.com\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nEmily Blunt struggled doing action scenes in a corset for Amazon's 'The English'\nHow 'Barbenheimer' conquered the box office and brought moviegoers back to theatres\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\nArticle content\n\nHundreds of people gathered Sunday for the fourth annual Red Ribbon Day, to honour Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nA National Day of Awareness, the event is also known as Red Dress or Red Shirt Day. Sunday\u2019s event was held near the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses in Calgary.\n\nDeborah Green-Gopher, MC for Sunday\u2019s event and MMEIP advocate said that red is very symbolic for MMEIP, because red is the colour that spirits see.\n\nThe many red ribbons, dresses, and shirts affixed to trees along Memorial Drive have the names of loved ones, each \u201ccarrying the spirit\u201d of that loved one.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a march or a rally, it\u2019s a healing gathering for families and survivors, and for non-Indigenous education and awareness,\u201d said Green-Gopher.\n\nIndigenous and M\u00e9tis women perform at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\nThe day holds high significance for Green-Gopher and her family, as her sister is on the list of missing and murdered Indigenous people.\n\nCalgary Sun Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe are still being murdered, being exploited, facing violence at alarming rates compared to non-Indigenous people in Canada,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cAnybody that has a significant loss in their family, you have to go through a grieving period,\u201d she said. \u201cFor my family, justice has never been found; however, we did have a healing ceremony on Tsuut\u2019ina Nation.\u201d\n\nWith different people in different stages of their healing journey, she said this event is meant to bring the healing to them.\n\n\u201cWe have dancers, singers, and an opportunity for families to just share what they need to share from their hearts.\u201d\n\nA performer drums at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\n\u2018We need action on the 231 Calls for Justice\u2019\n\nGreen-Gopher spoke about the 231 Calls for Justice and the actions within them, which are meant to be taken by all Canadians.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe need action on the 231 Calls for Justice in this country. Since the report released in 2019, it\u2019s been pretty dismal,\u201d she said. \u201cThe statistics of Indigenous people being murdered or going missing are actually increasing.\u201d\n\nShe believes those who call Canada \u2014 or \u201cTurtle Island\u201d \u2014 home should read the 231 calls. \u201cIf that\u2019s the only thing they do, that would be great. Other than that, they can hang a red dress, they can show up to these gatherings.\u201d\n\nAn Indigenous elder speaks at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\n\u2018The truth \u2026 needs to be daylighted\u2019: mayor\n\nSpeaking at Sunday\u2019s event, Mayor Jyoti Gondek said, \u201cWe all owe a debt of gratitude to Indigenous peoples who stewarded these lands, and allowed us to come and settle here.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs part of that gratitude, it is incumbent upon us to at least learn a little bit of language \u2014 and to promote the fact that these languages were stripped away from people.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMayor Jyoti Gondek speaks with attendees at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\nGondek spoke about there still being many things to learn, in particular the truth as we move toward reconciliation.\n\n\u201cMany of us, myself included, we\u2019re not ready for that,\u201d she said. \u201cThe truth is painful, the truth is haunting, it\u2019s horrible, and it is something that needs to be daylighted.\u201d\n\nJason Gordon, a citizen of the M\u00e9tis Nation of Alberta, creates memorial roses for families of MMEIP, which he believes serve as a powerful symbol.\n\nM\u00e9tis artist Jason Gordon speaks at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\nGreen-Gopher has a rose of her own. \u201cIt\u2019s very powerful, I keep mine in my sacred medicine room,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIf we were a reconciled country, we would have revamped systems, we wouldn\u2019t have a need to do these gatherings, because our people would be safe.\u201d\n\nA dress is seen for Red Ribbon Day at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/highway-of-tears-bus-starts-rolling-on-30-minute-trips-in-bcs-northwest/it39130", "title": "Highway of Tears bus starts rolling on 30-minute trips in B.C.'s northwest | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kamloops, Merritt and Areas|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 27.7\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nVernon News\nHighway of Tears bus starts rolling on 30-minute trips in B.C.'s northwest\nEighteen women have disappeared or been murdered on BC Highway 16, between Prince George and Prince Rupert, since the 1970s.\nImage Credit: Google Street View\nJanuary 28, 2017 - 9:00 PM\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. - A new bus service between Smithers and the First Nations village of Moricetown in northwestern B.C. will only take about 30 minutes, but the ride along the so-called Highway of Tears has been years in the making.\n\nThe service that starts Monday is along a small section of Highway 16, the route that stretches between Prince George and Prince Rupert where 18 women have disappeared or been murdered since the 1970s.\n\nJohn Rustad, B.C.'s minister of aboriginal relations and reconciliation, says part of the service plan involves working with First Nations communities to train bus drivers and operate transit services between their villages and major communities along the highway.\n\nFirst Nations, social-service agencies and women\u2019s groups have been calling for a shuttle bus service in the area for several years to provide safe transportation for people who live in communities along the 750-kilometre route.\n\nMoricetown Band Chief Duane Mitchell says the community is excited about the opportunity for safe and reliable transportation for their membership.\n\nThe federal and provincial governments announced a $5 million transportation plan last year that aims to improve travel and safety options along the highway and to the many remote First Nations communities in the area.\n\nRustad, who was in Smithers for the bus announcement on Friday, says the transit plan was a long time in coming.\n\nHe says further bus route expansion announcements are planned for the coming months.\n\n\"There's a real challenge in trying to provide the standard type of transit option that we think about when we think of Vancouver or Victoria,\" Rustad says.\n\n\"I know there are a lot of people who would have liked to have seen this happen more quickly, but working with families and communities to make sure we get this right was important.\"\n\nRustad says his Nechako Lakes riding in north central B.C. represents a 280-kilometre stretch of Highway 16 and includes the communities of Vanderhoof, Burns Lake and Houston.\n\nSmithers Mayor Taylor Bachrach says in a news release that the council is thrilled to see the new service.\n\n\"Not only will it help ensure the safety of residents travelling between our communities, it also marks the first partnership of its kind between the Moricetown Band and Smithers.\"\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2017\n\n\nMore News One of these women was Krista Shore, who\u2019s mother Barbara was murdered on February 6, 1996. Shore attends the vigil every year, and for her it\u2019s an opportunity to heal.\n\n\u201cMy mother was murdered in a bad way, but I just wanted to bring some attention to all the violence and oppression my mother faced before life was taken from her,\u201d said Krista.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\nThe ceremony ended with a reading of all of Saskatchewan\u2019s lost women. Jodie Woodward read a portion of the names. It was emotional for her because in 2012 she nearly became a part of the list.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\u201cI\u2026what happened to me was [I was] driven outside of Saskatoon on the outskirts and I was beaten and left there,\u201d said Woodward.\n\nShe had to take a \u2018compassionate leave\u2019 as a student at FNUNIV due to depression that followed her ordeal. Now she dedicates her time to battling systemic racism.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re the ones who are hurting. We\u2019re the ones who have to face racism on a daily basis because of our skin colour,\u201d said Woodward.\n\nThe vigil is also used as an opportunity to call on government leaders to take action and stem the tide against the number of missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada.\n\nMORE ON CANADA\nHurricane Beryl forces Canadian airlines to cancel flights. newsletterYour Business Sign in or register  \nHomeNews\nMore\nObituaries\nClassifieds\nShop\nFlyers\nHomes\nJobs\nAuto\nGames\n23.7 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nONWA holds Sisters in Spirit Vigil\nAssembly of First Nations National Chief RoseAnne Archibald visited Thunder Bay for the vigil, which aims to offer healing for families who have experienced loss due to gender-based violence.\nTBnewsWatch.com Staff\nOct 4, 2022 3:30 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nAssembly of First Nations National Chief RoseAnne Archibald (left) and Ontario Native Women's Assn executive director Cora McGuire-Cyrette participated in the Sisters in Spirit Vigil in Thunder Bay on Oct. 4, 2022 (Mike Lang/TBTV photo)\nListen to this article\n00:02:24\n\nTHUNDER BAY\u00a0\u2014 Assembly of First Nations National Chief RoseAnne Archibald was a special guest Tuesday at the Sisters in Spirit Vigil held in Thunder Bay.\n\nHeld on the National Day of Action for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, and Girls, the vigil provides education about the high levels of violence against Indigenous females, but is also designed to help families who have experienced loss due to gender-based violence heal.\n\nThe Ontario Native Women's Association (ONWA) conducts\u00a0the event each year to support and honour the stories, experiences and lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThe vigil at the ONWA offices on Ray Boulevard began with the planting of \"forget-me-not\" flowers by in-person participants.\n\nPeople who were unable to attend had the opportunity to participate virtually.\n\nONWA executive director Cora McGuire-Cyrette delivered the keynote address.\n\nShe said the vigil is important because it gives people space to honour those who are no longer here, as well as to honour the families who are in crisis due to the murder or disappearance of a loved one.\n\n\"It's that opportunity that began in order to bring awareness to this issue, which is how we ended up with a national inquiry... But that was only the beginning of the work,\" she said.\n\nTBnewswatch Latest News\n\nMcGuire-Cyrette said that's because it's still not safe to be an Indigenous woman in Thunder Bay, or anywhere else in Canada.\n\n\"We need to be looking at how to create community safety, changing the systems, to work collectively together. This is not just an Indigenous issue.\"\n\nShe added \"It's taken all of us to get to where we are today, and it's going to take an entire community to make this change.\"\n\nMcGuire-Cyrette believes a good place to start is with accountability, as many families are still waiting for answers and for justice for the individuals who have been lost.\n\nShe said the Sisters in Spirit Vigil allows family members to gather to discuss progress that has been made.\n\n\"When we began this work, probably 15 years ago, there was only a handful of us that were actually coming together on Oct. 4.\u00a0 Now you can see communities all across Canada coming together\u00a0and talking about the issue, wanting to make change....and looking at how we can make our communities safer.\"\n\nSee a PHOTO BY STEVE BOSCH /Vancouver Sun\nArticle content\n\nThe last First Nation without cellular service along the infamous Highway of Tears in northern B.C. will finally get access to wireless coverage, the provincial government said Friday.\n\nA new cell tower will be built in the Witset First Nation, so people can now make phone calls along the highway between Smithers and New Hazelton. Construction began in September and is to be completed in the next few months.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nB.C. expands heat-pump rebates to encourage more people to switch\nVancouver radio station AM 730 fizzles out, long after its glorious LG73 heyday\nWhere do chefs dine? It is one of three northern roadways along which 18 girls and women disappeared\u00a0between 1969 and 2006. Most of the cases remain unsolved.\n\nMany of the victims were hitchhiking, which prompted family and community members to advocate for better bus service and phone coverage along the remote highway, which stretches from Prince Rupert to Prince George and through to Edmonton.\n\nBus service has since been improved.\n\nBringing new wireless service to the area will also enhance the delivery of education and health care, and support businesses, Sims said.\n\nlculbert@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nRoofers Tested 17 Gutter Guards\u2026 Here\u2019s What They Discovered\nThe Actual Cost of Gutter Guards in 2024 May Surprise You\nLeafFilter Partner\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nBikers' sentencing delayed by Indigenous connections claim\nVancouver Sun\nBoy, 15, fatally attacked while walking dog with mom in north Edmonton, man in custody\nVancouver Sun\nStop scratching these, and try this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly!\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nStop scanning your lottery ticket, do this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nSeniors Are Getting Free Hearing Tests (Here's how)\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\n\nPostmedia is committed to maintaining a lively but civil forum for discussion. This is just north of Smithers. PHOTO BY STEVE BOSCH /Vancouver Sun\nArticle content\n\nThe last First Nation without cellular service along the infamous Highway of Tears in northern B.C. will finally get access to wireless coverage, the provincial government said Friday.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nA new cell tower will be built in the Witset First Nation, so people can now make phone calls along the highway between Smithers and New Hazelton. Construction began in September and is to be completed in the next few months.\n\n\u201cThis new cell tower will make it much easier for people to call for help during an emergency and is another essential element to further improve safety along Highway 16,\u201d said Minister of Citizens\u2019 Services Jinny Sims.\n\n\u201cAfter the Rogers cell tower is in service, every Indigenous community along the Highway of Tears will have access to modern cellular connectivity,\u201d Sims said.\n\nSafety along Highway 16, dubbed the Highway of Tears, has long been a concern. It is one of three northern roadways along which 18 girls and women disappeared\u00a0between 1969 and 2006. Most of the cases remain unsolved.\n\nMany of the victims were hitchhiking, which prompted family and community members to advocate for better bus service and phone coverage along the remote highway, which stretches from Prince Rupert to Prince George and through to Edmonton.\n\nBus service has since been improved.\n\nBringing new wireless service to the area will also enhance the delivery of education and health care, and support businesses, Sims said.\n\nlculbert@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop scratching these, and try this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nCanucks: Nikita Zadorov\u2019s agent takes blistering shot at Vancouver reporter\nThe Province\nCanucks: After coach's criticism, the Elias Pettersson question looms large\nThe Province\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nBetter than scratching, why you should try this\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://www.wltribune.com/news/more-tears-shed-as-plea-made-to-find-2-more-missing-on-bcs-highway-of-tears-6831629", "title": "More tears shed as plea made to find 2 more missing on B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears - The Williams Lake Tribune", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.7 \u00b0C\nHome News\nMore tears shed as plea made to find 2 more missing on B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears\nMary Teegee of Carrier Sekani Child & Family Services says society must do better\n\tRuth Lloyd\n\nNov 3, 2023 3:47 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 8 Chief Priscilla Mueller, with mic, of Saik\u2019uz First Nation, speaks at a press conference calling for more action and resources to help find two young people missing from the community west of Prince George, while family members of the missing, other leaders, sit nearby. (Carrier Sekani Child & Family Services photo)\nExpand\n\nFirst Nations leaders and the parents of two missing members of the Saik\u2019uz First Nation are calling for more resources and action to find the missing young people. Indigenous leaders and family spoke at a press conference in Vanderhoof today to request information and action by government.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been 24 days since my daughter Chelsea went missing, and we still don\u2019t have any answers,\u201d said a tearful Pam Heron, mother of missing woman Chelsey Quaw (Heron).\n\n\u201cI\u2019m trying as hard as I can. I have to fight just because his boys deserve to know where he\u2019s at,\u201d said Angie Raphael, mother of missing man Jay Raphael.\n\nChelsey Quaw (Heron) and Jay Preston Raphael are both missing members of the Saik\u2019uz First Nation, located 120 km west of Prince George, just outside Vanderhoof, B.C. and just 14 km south of Highway 16.\n\nHighway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears, due to the high number of missing and murdered women in the area, the majority of whom over the years have been Indigenous.\n\nCommunity leaders also shed tears as they spoke at a press conference in Vanderhoof, urging for more resources to be brought to the investigation into the two missing young people.\n\nChief Priscilla Mueller of Saik\u2019uz First Nation thanked all the volunteers who came to participate in the search so far, and said the Saik\u2019uz community had taken the search to Prince George and Vanderhoof as well.\n\nBut she said more needs to be done and more resources are needed.\n\n\u201cThere is only so much the local RCMP can do,\u201d she said, noting they need help from government.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not too sure how we\u2019re going to move forward with the search,\u201d she said.\n\nMary Teegee, executive director of Carrier Sekani Child & Family Service expressed frustration at the lack of action on the 33 recommendations from the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium Report, which she was also a part of.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m upset that we have to be here again,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThere are things we need to think about as a society, how much value are we placing on our Indigenous women, our Indigenous men.\u201d\n\nShe called for more action from both the government, law enforcement and the media to help draw attention to the ongoing issues surrounding missing and murdered Indigenous women and the Highway of Tears. She also referenced the missing women in Manitoba whose remains are believed to be in a landfill.\n\n\u201cIn Canada we\u2019re having to check the landfills for bodies of our missing Indigenous women. Think about that. As a society we have to do better.\u201d\n\nChelsey Quaw is a 29-year-old Indigenous woman with brown hair, brown eyes who vanished from her community last month.\n\nShe stands five feet, 10 inches tall and weighs about 120 pounds. She was possibly wearing blue jeans and a purple winter jacket when she went missing in the early morning hours of Oct. 11, 2023 from a residence on the Saik\u2019uz First Nation.\n\nSeveral search and rescue teams as well as community groups formed search parties to look for Quaw with no results.\n\nJay Preston Raphael has been missing from the community just over eight months.\n\nRaphael is a 28-year-old male with black hair and brown eyes, and unique tattoos on his neck, chest and arm.\n\nHe is five feet, nine inches tall and weighs approximately 143 pounds.\n\nRaphael was last seen on Feb. 25, 2023 at Saik\u2019uz First Nation wearing a black coat, blue jeans black runners and a baseball hat.\n\nSaik\u2019uz First Nation has an on-reserve population of about 400.\n\nLeaders also frequently referenced other missing women from the area. This included Mackie Basil, missing from Tl\u2019azt\u2019en Nation Nation, since 2013, Bonnie Joseph of Yekooche First Nation, missing from near Vanderhoof since 2008, Ramona Wilson of Gitxan First Nation, who went missing in 1994 and whose remains were found near Smithers in 1995. Her murder remains unsolved. They also mentioned Madison Scott and the ongoing search for justice in her case. Scott had been missing since 2011 and her remains were found earlier this year near Vanderhoof, but no charges have yet been laid as the investigation is ongoing.\n\nAnyone with any information can contact Vanderhoof RCMP at 250-567-2222 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.\n\nREAD MORE: Mother of missing Vanderhoof woman says she would never just take off\n\nREAD MORE: RCMP renews public assistance call to locate missing man\n\nREAD MORE: Search continues for missing Vanderhoof woman Chelsey Quaw\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Ruth Lloyd\n\nI moved back to my hometown of Williams Lake after living away and joined the amazing team at the Williams Lake Tribune in 2021.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tInternist enjoys working in Williams Lake area\n\t\tPHOTOS: 96th Annual Williams Lake Stampede wraps on Canada Day\n\t\tCanada Day celebrated in Boitanio Park in Williams Lake\n\t\tPHOTOS: Day 3 96th annual Williams Lake Stampede done, dusted\n\t\tMen provide some helping hands at Williams Lake community garden\nFacebook Comments (0) \nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. {"url": "https://www.interior-news.com/news/new-cell-service-coming-to-highway-of-tears/", "title": "New cell service coming to Highway of Tears - The Smithers Interior News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAutos\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.3 \u00b0C\nHome News\nNew cell service coming to Highway of Tears\nWitset was the only First Nation along Hwy 16 still without full cell service.\nChris Gareau\nOct 26, 2018 11:30 AM\nOct 29, 2018 2:23 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nWitset students hear the news Friday that their cell phones will finally work without interruption after a new provincially-funded Rogers tower is installed. Chris Gareau photo\n\nThe loss of cell service on the stretch of Highway 16 between Smithers and the Hazeltons will soon be a thing of the past.\n\nConstruction of a Rogers cell tower began in late September and is expected to be completed in the coming months.\n\nWitset will be the last First Nation along the northern stretch of the TransCanada Highway to not have cell service, according to a release from the B.C. Ministry of Citizen\u2019 Services.\n\nB.C. Citizens\u2019 Services Minister Jinny Sims was in Witset to make the announcement Friday.\n\n\u201cWe have to look at reducing the digital divide because without reducing the digital divide, the economic participation cannot be there,\u201d Sims told the gathered crowd.\n\n\u201cWhen I travel through areas around the province, I hear about everyday challenges about having cell service. When there\u2019s an emergency on the highway or a loved one is dealing with a crisis such as the threat of forest fires or flash flooding, the last thing they want to see \u2014 which we saw on the drive to here \u2014 was no service,\u201d added Sims.\n\nProvincial and local leaders hope this will help end the notoriety of the artery for northern B.C., dubbed the Highway of Tears because of the many women \u2014 mostly Indigenous women \u2014 who have been murdered or disappeared from Prince George to Prince Rupert.\n\nWitset Chief Victor Jim said even just having the ability to call for a ride instead of being forced to hitchhike should help make things safer.\n\nPriscilla Naziel, a first responder and social development manager in Witset, gave moving examples of how not having that connectivity affected her and the people she tries to help.\n\nShe described what they had to deal with during the search and rescue operation to try to find missing mushroom picker Frances Brown.\n\nREAD MORE: Searchers from across BC seek Frances Brown north of Smithers\n\n\u201cOur [handheld fire department] radios didn\u2019t go all the way up \u2026 and people had to travel all the way down basically to the CN tracks before we could use the cell service. And that was done for a while until the inReach [satellite communication] came in. And I was also told that because their was no cell service they couldn\u2019t use their GPS to find that cell that [Brown] had,\u201d said Naziel.\n\nWhile she acknowledged poverty was a problem in the community that kept people from having communication devices \u2014 even landline phones \u2014 there was a harrowing incident that suggested even one person in a crowd with a working cell phone could be life saving, and the over reliance on handheld radios.\n\nIn this case, people were lucky to have survived without it.\n\n\u201cThere was a possible four-person overdose, and our radios were kicking in and out. But people did get their medical attention and none passed away, for which I\u2019m thankful for,\u201d said Naziel.\n\nAnother example she listed a person who was injured and a passerby who couldn\u2019t find a working landline nearby, eventually reaching the rec centre to call for help.\n\n\u201cIt was actually an assault and the person had a broken shin. So I just don\u2019t know how long that person was bleeding out,\u201d said Naziel, pointing out this person was again lucky to get the medical attention they needed, but that time frame was a problem.\n\nThere were more specific stories to make her point, but then she discussed more general considerations.\n\n\u201cThere are 76 elders in our community, and some are disabled,\u201d she said.\n\nWitset considered getting LifeLine buttons for them, but she pointed out that requires a phone or cable hooked up.\n\n\u201cAgain, the poverty comes into it, and paying for this LifeLine,\u201d said Naziel.\n\nSafety was also top of mind to help first responders who drive around trying to get a signal if they don\u2019t have a radio on them. Another example was the flood this year that had Witset staff going door to door instead of being able to reach people quickly on their phone or via a mass notification similar to the one Smithers has through Everbridge.\n\nREAD MORE: Smithers launches emergency notification system\n\n\u201cJust last May, 11 homes were directly affected by an evacuation due to a flood \u2026 Our sewer station was down so all the other houses were affected, too. But the incident operations commander had to go up the road to do his texting, do his phoning \u2014 go back down, go back up, go back down,\u201d described Naziel.\n\n\u201cIt took time away from the actual incident.\u201d\n\nChastity Davis, chair of the minister\u2019s advisory council on Indigenous women, said in a media release that cell service will end isolation for women travelling along the highway.\n\n\u201cBetter cell phone coverage means women can reach loved ones or emergency services in times of need, and it will create security and reassurance to everyone travelling on Highway 16,\u201d Davis said.\n\nStikine MLA and Rural Development Minister Doug Donaldson acknowledged the safety aspect before giving an example of how important this is economically.\n\n\u201cA few years ago I was at the finger joint mill doing the tour and talking to some of the folks there and they were saying \u2014 I think some of the machinery is from Germany \u2014 and some of the technicians come and when there\u2019s some troubleshooting to do they actually phone in to an office \u2026 and as they\u2019re looking at the machine they\u2019re getting guidance on how to \u2026 fix the problem. They were kind of blown away that they couldn\u2019t do that. Even walking to the church to get reception doesn\u2019t work because they need the machine in front of the as they\u2019re trying to troubleshoot,\u201d said Donaldson.\n\nChief Jim said the connectivity would benefit the newly upgraded RV park and campground by the museum.\n\n\u201cThe people that stay there will be appy to hear that they can phone home and let their loved ones know that they\u2019re safe, and that they\u2019re in the best RV park in the Bulkley Valley,\u201d said Jim.\n\nWhen operational, the cell tower will enable voice, data and text services via high-speed wireless and internet coverage on 4G and LTE networks for Rogers and Fido customers. Customers using other providers will be able to dial 911 in the community and along the highway.\n\nThe new tower is providing wireless coverage to an additional 22 kilometres along the highway.\n\nRick Sellers, B.C. president for Rogers Communications, experienced the lack of service firsthand as he drove from Smithers to Witset.\n\n\u201cOn the way here, [it was] very sporadic. Eventually, we didn\u2019t have coverage during the trip from the airport, so not great. That will change in another two months,\u201d said Sellers.\n\nHe gave his perspective as a visitor on why that connection was so important.\n\n\u201cWe live in a mobile world. Reality is, gone are the days where people are stuck in their offices and have a land line that somebody\u2019s used to calling and you can pick up the phone and say hello. We\u2019re in a world now \u2026 where we now need our devices to stay connected, to stay connected to our families, etc.; so having that was something you take for granted, but when you don\u2019t have it you realize how much dependency you have on those devices,\u201d said Sellers.\n\nHe added that this is not the end of working with the Province to connect northern B.C.\n\n\u201cWe understand it\u2019s important, obviously, to do our part as a corporate citizen. At the same time with the provincial government, it\u2019s one of their clear mandates to make sure we connect remote communities; so we\u2019re making sure we work with them, identifying areas that make sense for us to work together and then roll out as much as we can to connect remote communities,\u201d said Sellers.\n\nThe project is being funded with a $1.2-million grant from the Province through Northern Development Initiative Trust.\n\nUp to six local jobs will be created during construction of the cell tower.\n\neditor@interior-news.com\n\nB.C. Citizens\u2019 Services Minister Jinny Sims and Witset Chief Victor Jim during the announcement of a new Rogers cell tower closing the cell service gap between Smithers and the Hazeltons. Chris Gareau photo\nPriscilla Naziel, a first responder and social development manager in Witset, speaks of the importance the new cell tower will have in the community as Stikine MLA Doug Donaldson (right) and Witset students listen. Chris Gareau photo\nB.C. Citizens\u2019 Services Minister Jinny Sims warms up the crowd with Witset Chief Victor Jim during the announcement of a new Rogers cell tower closing the cell service gap between Smithers and the Hazeltons. the territory\nwritten by Elijah March 26, 2024 0 comment\nSHARE 0FacebookTwitterPinterestLinkedinTumblrReddit\nHamas has said: \u201cWe call for an immediate end to the airdrop operation and demand the immediate and rapid opening of the land crossings to allow humanitarian aid to reach our Palestinian people.\u201d\n\nBy Jamie Shapiro\n\nPublished: 07:39 EDT, March 26, 2024 | Updated: 07:50 EDT, March 26, 2024\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013 <!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\n<!\u2013\n\nHamas on Tuesday called for an end to airdrops of aid to Gaza after saying 12 people drowned and six died in stampedes trying to reach food parcels.\n\nThe deaths occurred on Monday in the starving north of the besieged territory, as people rushed to collect packages dropped from planes along Gaza\u2019s Mediterranean coast.\n\nHamas said: \u201cWe call for an immediate end to the airdrop operation and demand the immediate and rapid opening of the land crossings to allow humanitarian aid to reach our Palestinian people.\u201d\n\nThis brings the Palestinian death toll to 32,531 since the war broke out in October.\n\n12 people have drowned and six have died in stampedes trying to reach food packages\n\nPalestinians gather on a beach while collecting aid dropped from a plane, in the midst of the current conflict between Israel and Hamas, in the northern Gaza Strip.\n\nThe IDF\u2019s bombing of Gaza has led to a severe lack of aid reaching the area.\n\nThere have been numerous cases of mass shootings of Palestinians waiting for the IDF to deliver aid by road.\n\nThe desperation of starving Palestinians has led them to risk their lives to collect incoming food parcels, but this is dangerous as they are dropped from planes on the coast.\n\nAid groups say only a fraction of the supplies needed to meet basic humanitarian needs have arrived in Gaza since October.\n\nIt is much more dangerous to have to swim to collect help than to receive it by road\n\nThe UN warns of famine.\n\nAid entering the Gaza Strip by land is well below pre-war levels, around 150 vehicles a day compared to at least 500 before the war, according to UNRWA, the UN aid agency. First Nation found dead | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nVANCOUVER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nVANCOUVER\nNews\nWoman missing from B.C. First Nation along Highway of Tears found dead\nBecca Clarkson\nBecca Clarkson\nCTVNewsVancouver.ca Reporter\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated Dec. 6, 2023 4:42 p.m.\nPublished Nov. 7, 2023 8:40 a.m.\nShare\n\nAn Indigenous community in central B.C. is reeling after the remains of a 29-year-old woman were discovered, nearly one month after she was reported missing.\n\nThe family of Chelsey Quaw confirmed the tragic discovery in Saik\u2019uz First Nation Territory on Monday, writing in a statement \u201cwe will not rest until we get answers.\u201d\n\nQuaw, who also used the surname Heron, was last seen in the early morning of Oct. 10 and was reported missing the following day.\n\nVanderhoof RCMP and the Saik'uz First Nation say her remains were found in a wooded area on the Indigenous community's territory, located 100 kilometres west of Prince George along Highway 16, on Monday afternoon.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nHeiltsuk Nation excited about expanding restorative justice program to at-risk girls and women\nFamily of Cree teen who died in B.C. group home worries inquest recommendations won\u2019t be implemented soon enough\nIndigenous women dramatically overrepresented among victims of violence in Vancouver on national day of awareness\nSupporters in Vancouver add to calls to search Winnipeg landfills for Indigenous homicide victims\n\nPam Heron described her daughter in a statement as someone with \u201cthe most amazing spirit, beautiful strength and independence.\u201d\n\nMary Teegee, executive director of child and family services with Carrier Sekani Family Services, shared similar sentiments with CTV News on Tuesday, saying Quaw had a \u201cbeautiful soul, beautiful smile and beautiful spirit.\u201d\n\nShe believes the response to Quaw\u2019s disappearance would have been different if she was a white woman.\n\n\u201cWhat would happen if this was a non-Indigenous, blonde, blue-eyed little girl that was missing out of West Vancouver? We wouldn\u2019t be having this conversation,\u201d Teegee told CTV News Tuesday. \u201cEveryone would have been up in arms\u2014the community, the municipality, businesses\u2014everyone would have been rallying around. That isn\u2019t the same response we have when there\u2019s a young Indigenous woman.\u201d\n\nTeegee called on the government to implement the 33 calls for actions outlined in 2006 by the Highway of Tears Symposium, which remain unfulfilled, as do the 231 calls for justice delivered by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in 2019.\n\n\u201cThe issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls is not a B.C. problem \u2013 it\u2019s a Canada-wide one,\u201d says Teegee. \u201cWe really need to come together to address what\u2019s going on.\u201d\n\nQuaw was one of two community members missing from the First Nation this year.\n\nJay Raphael, 28, was reported missing on Feb. 26 after walking away from a residence.\n\nThe Heron-Quaw family addressed his absence in their statement, urging the public to contact Vanderhoof RCMP with file #2023-477 with any information on his whereabouts.\n\n\u201cWe support all search efforts to bring Jay home,\u201d wrote the family.\n\nAnyone with information about Quaw\u2019s disappearance and death is asked to contact Mounties at the same number and quote file #2023-2794.\n\nAnonymous tips can be made to Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.\n\nHer family is thanking everyone who helped with the search, including the Nechako Search and Rescue Team; the chiefs, councils and communities of Saik\u2019uz and Stellat\u2019en First Nations; CSFS and the RCMP.\n\nWith files from CTV News Vancouver's Spencer Harwood and The Canadian Press\u00a0\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nThis photo of Chelsey Quaw was shared on Facebook with a statement from her family. {"url": "https://www.myalgomamanitoulinnow.com/40901/amk-mp-carol-hughes-advocates-for-the-redress-project/", "title": "AMK MP, Carol Hughes advocates for the REDress Project - My Algoma Manitoulin Now", "body": "Home\nNews\nNews Alerts Sign Up!\nRegional News\nSubmit News Tip\nWin\nEvents\nCommunity Calendar\nSubmit an Event\nListen Live\nOn Air\nLocal Connections\nNEWS\nWIN\nEVENTS\nCONTACT US\nADVERTISE\nWE\u2019RE HIRING!\nSUBSCRIBE TO LOCAL NEWS\n\u25ba Listen Live\nHome\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nListen Live\nOn Air\nLocal Connections\nHomeNewsAMK MP, Carol Hughes advocates for the REDress Project\nNews\nAMK MP, Carol Hughes advocates for the REDress Project\nBy\nRosalind Russell\nMonday, May. 3rd, 2021\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nRed Dress Day is this Wednesday. Wear a red dress or red shirt to remember Missing or Murdered Indigenous Women in Canada. Photo provided\n- Advertisement -\n\nIt is that time of year again when First Nations and supporters draw together to remember the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women in Canada as part of the REDress Project.\n\nAlgoma-Manitoulin Kapuskasing MP Carol Hughes says the movement started in Colombia and has spread to other countries including Canada and now the United States.\n\nShe says since its inception, she was impressed by how the advocates used such a simple object, a red dress, to symbolize loss and grief and the importance of not forgetting the women lost to violence.\n\nHughes points out it is now being used to amplify the other voices of those who are marginalized including those in the LGBTQ2+ and Indigenous communities.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nHughes adds she will do her part to mark Red Dress Day this Wednesday, May 5th.\n\nThe brainchild of visual artist Jamie Black, the REDress Project is rooted in political action that the artist witnessed in Colombia in 2010.\u00a0That\u2019s when she saw a group of women wearing red dresses and demonstrating over missing family members who have been \u2018disappeared\u2019, a consistent feature of that country\u2019s decades-long struggle with armed conflict.\n\nBlack recognized the parallel between those Colombian women and the families of Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women (MMIW) in Canada.\n\nThis was also at the same time as the Truth and Reconciliation Commission was starting to hold events across the country.\u00a0The project dovetailed nicely with the spirit of the times and soon grew beyond Black\u2019s installations taking on a life of its own in public spaces and on social media.\n\nSince its inception, I have been more than impressed with the energy and determination attached to the REDress Project. This important and symbolic campaign uses a simple object to convey so many concepts along with strong emotions.\n\nNow, it is also being used to amplify other voices that have been marginalized, specifically two-spirit, lesbian, gay, trans, bisexual, queer, questioning, intersex and asexual individuals who have faced similar discriminatory and violent behaviour.\n\nThe project is also transcending borders with red dresses being displayed in this manner in the United States too.\u00a0The MMIW crisis is similar in that country with Indigenous women being murdered at a rate of ten times the national average.\n\nGiven America\u2019s long history, it is incredible to consider that the current administration is the first to include a Native American, Deb Haaland who is serving as Secretary of the Interior.\u00a0She recently announced the US will set up a special unit to investigate MMIW.\n\nIn Canada, we have undertaken a National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls which only concluded with its report a few years back in 2019.\u00a0The legacy of that work can be tied to the work of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and may represent a real turn in the road for our country.\u00a0The website for the National Inquiry is a treasure trove of information and includes a Gallery of Artistic Expression which showcases an incredible range of talent and multiple works rooted in loss and the MMIW phenomenon.\n\nWhile viewing the gallery I was reminded of the work of Espanola resident Christie Belcourt. Already recognized as a talented artist, she is the creator and lead coordinator of Walking With Our Sisters, a 2012 art installation commemorating the MMIW of Canada and the United States. Like Black\u2019s work, this project has toured North America with the help of local activists and continues to inspire action.\n\nPart of the ingenuity of the REDress project is its simplicity and the use of the dress as a motif has certainly grown to the point that we mark Red Dress Day on May 5.\u00a0\n\nIn 2018, it was central to the inception of the Lil\u2019 Red Dress Campaign that sold red dress-shaped pins to raise money towards the costs of creating and installing missing person signage on Vancouver Island.\u00a0The dresses also show up in beadwork, paintings, photographs, and other forms of artistic expression.\u00a0\n\nBy hanging red dresses in public spaces, we can challenge society to come to terms with violence that should never be allowed to define us.\u00a0In a sense, these dresses are revoking permission from abusers and reclaiming public spaces, one dress at a time.\n\nThis is an important step on our journey towards reconciliation, which can\u2019t even begin without understanding.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nNews\nAncient burial grounds found on {"url": "https://www.chroniclejournal.com/prairies/bc/woman-missing-from-b-c-first-nation-along-highway-of-tears-found-dead/article_33c424d9-8dee-55f7-bd64-c30699dfeb10.html", "title": "Woman missing from B.C. First Nation along Highway of Tears found dead | Bc | chroniclejournal.com", "body": "Skip to main content\nAboutContactSubscribee-Edition\nMake Home Page\nSign UpLog In\nFacebook\n \nTwitter\nHome\nNews\nSports\nBusiness\nOpinion\nA & E\nLife\nSpecials\nClassifieds\nWeather\nObituaries\n2024 Auction\n2024 Readers\u2019 Choice Awards\nWoman missing from B.C. First Nation along Highway of Tears found dead\nWoman missing from B.C. First Nation found dead\nNov 6, 2023 \nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nCopy article link\nSave\n\nVANDERHOOF, B.C. - A woman who disappeared from a First Nations community in central British Columbia last month has been found dead.\n\nVanderhoof RCMP and the Saik'uz First Nation say the remains of Chelsey Quaw, who was first reported missing on Oct. 11, were found in a wooded area on the Indigenous community's territory.\n\nPolice say the BC Coroners Service is investigating the cause of death, and no further details on the case are available at this time.\n\nQuaw was one of two community members missing from the First Nation \u2014 located 100 kilometres west of Prince George along Highway 16 \u2014 this year.\n\nThe stretch of highway between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears after dozens have vanished or been killed along it over the last few decades.\n\nFirst Nations leaders and family members last week called for more action from police and the public in locating both Quaw and Jay Preston Raphael, who was reported missing Feb. 26 after walking away from a residence at the Saik'uz First Nation.\n\nQuaw's family has issued a statement through the Saik'uz First Nation and Carrier Sekani Family Services, thanking all people involved in the search and reminding them to keep up the continued search for Raphael.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Nov. 6, 2023.\n\nThe Canadian Press.
