{"url": "https://theconversation.com/beyond-a-technical-bug-biased-algorithms-and-moderation-are-censoring-activists-on-social-media-160669", "title": "Beyond a technical bug: Biased algorithms and moderation are censoring activists on social media", "body": "Edition:\nAvailable editions\nCanada\nDonate\nGet newsletter\nBecome an author\nSign up as a reader\nSign in\nAcademic rigour, journalistic flair\nPodcasts\nArts\nBusiness + Economy\nCulture + Society\nEducation\nEnvironment + Energy\nHealth\nPolitics\nScience + Tech\nEn fran\u00e7ais\nActivists, influencers raise alarm after MMIWG content disappears from Instagram on Red Dress Day. (Solen Feyissa/Unsplash)\nBeyond a technical bug: Biased algorithms and moderation are censoring activists on social\u00a0media\nPublished: May 16, 2021 8.17am EDT\nAuthors\nMerlyna Lim\n\nCanada Research Chair in Digital Media & Global Network Society and Founding Director of ALiGN Media Lab, Carleton University\n\nGhadah Alrasheed\n\nPost-doctoral Fellow, Interim co-Director of ALiGN Media Lab, Carleton University\n\nDisclosure statement\n\nMerlyna Lim receives funding from Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC).\n\nGhadah Alrasheed does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.\n\nPartners\n\n\t\n\nCarleton University provides funding as a member of The Conversation CA.\n\nCarleton University provides funding as a member of The Conversation CA-FR.\n\nView all partners\n\nWe believe in the free flow of information\nRepublish our articles for free, online or in print, under Creative Commons licence.\nRepublish this article\n Email\n X (Twitter)\n33\n Facebook\n174\n LinkedIn\n Print\n\nFollowing Red Dress Day on May 5, a day aimed to raise awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), Indigenous activists and supporters of the campaign found posts about MMIWG had disappeared from their Instagram accounts. In response, Instagram released a tweet saying that this was \u201ca widespread global technical issue not related to any particular topic,\u201d followed by an apology explaining that the platform \u201cexperienced a technical bug, which impacted millions of people\u2019s stories, highlights and archives around the world.\u201d\n\nCreators, however, said that not all stories were affected.\n\nAnd this is not the first time social media platforms have been under scrutiny because of their erroneous censoring of grassroots activists and racial minorities.\n\nMany Black Lives Matter (BLM) activists were similarly frustrated when Facebook flagged their accounts, but didn\u2019t do enough to stop racism and hate speech against Black people on their platform.\n\nSo were these really about technical glitches? Or did they result from the platforms\u2019 discriminatory and biased policies and practices? The answer lies somewhere in between.\n\nTowards automated content moderation\n\nEvery time an activist\u2019s post is wrongly removed, there are at least three possible scenarios.\n\nFirst, sometimes the platform deliberately takes down activists\u2019 posts and accounts, usually at request of and/or in co-ordination with the government. This happened when Facebook and Instagram removed posts and accounts of Iranians who expressed support for the Iranian general Qassem Soleiman.\n\nIn some countries and disputed territories, such as Kashmir, Crimea, Western Sahara and Palestinian territories, platforms censored activists and journalists to allegedly maintain their market access or to protect themselves from legal liabilities.\n\nSecond, a post can be removed through a user-reporting mechanism. To handle unlawful or prohibited communication, social media platforms have indeed primarily relied on users reporting.\n\nApplying community standards developed by the platform, content moderators would then review reported content and determine whether a violation had occurred. If it had, the content would be removed, and, in the case of serious or repeat infringements, the user may be temporarily suspended or permanently banned.\n\nThis mechanism is problematic. Due to the sheer volume of reports received on a daily basis, there are simply not enough moderators to review each report adequately. Also, complexities and subtleties of language pose real challenges. Meanwhile, marginalized groups reclaiming abusive terms for public awareness, such as BLM and MMIWG, can be misinterpreted as being abusive.\n\nFurther, in flagging content, users tend to rely on partisanship and ideology. User reporting approach is driven by popular opinion of a platform\u2019s users while potentially repressing the right to unpopular speech.\n\nSuch approach also emboldens freedom to hate, where users exercise their right to voice their opinions while actively silencing others. A notable example is the removal by Facebook of \u201cFreedom for Palestine,\u201d a multi-artist collaboration posted by Coldplay, after a number of users reported the song as \u201cabusive.\u201d\n\nThird, platforms are increasingly using artificial intelligence (AI) to help identify and remove prohibited content. The idea is that complex algorithms that use natural language processing can flag racist or violent content faster and better than humans possibly can. During the COVID-19 pandemic, social media companies are relying more on AI to cover for tens of thousands of human moderators who were sent home. Now, more than ever, algorithms decide what users can and cannot post online.\n\nAlgorithmic biases\n\nThere\u2019s an inherent belief that AI systems are less biased and can scale better than human beings. In practice, however, they\u2019re easily disposed to error and can impose bias on a colossal systemic scale.\n\nIn two 2019 computational linguistic studies, researchers discovered that AI intended to identify hate speech may actually end up amplifying racial bias.\n\nIn one study, researchers found that tweets written in African American English commonly spoken by Black Americans are up to twice more likely to be flagged as offensive compared to others. Using a dataset of 155,800 tweets, another study found a similar widespread racial bias against Black speeches.\n\nWhat\u2019s considered offensive is bound to social context; terms that are slurs when used in some settings may not be in others. Algorithmic systems lack an ability to capture nuances and contextual particularities, which may not be understood by human moderators who test data used to train these algorithms either. This means natural language processing which is often perceived as an objective tool to identify offensive content can amplify the same biases that human beings have.\n\nAlgorithmic bias may jeopardize some people who are already at risk by wrongly categorizing them as offensive, criminals or even terrorists. In mid 2020, Facebook deleted at least 35 accounts of Syrian journalists and activists on the pretext of terrorism while in reality, they were campaigning against violence and terrorism.\n\nProtesters gather in Winnipeg the day after the jury delivered a not-guilty verdict in the second degree murder trial of Raymond Cormier, the man accused of killing Tina Fontaine. MMIWG activists had their posts removed from Instagram on a day to raise awareness. THE CANADIAN PRESS/John Woods\n\nMMIWG, BLM and the Syrian cases exemplify the dynamic of \u201calgorithms of opression\u201d where algorithms reinforce older oppressive social relations and re-install new modes of racism and discrimination.\n\nWhile AI is celebrated as autonomous technology that can develop away from human intervention, it is inherently biased. The inequalities that underpin bias already exist in society and influence who gets the opportunity to build algorithms and their databases, and for what purpose. As such, algorithms do not intrinsically provide ways for marginalized people to escape discrimination, but they also reproduce new forms of inequality along social, racial and political lines.\n\nDespite the apparent problems, algorithms are here to stay. There is no silver bullet, but one can take steps to minimize bias. First is to recognize that there\u2019s a problem. Then, making a strong commitment to root out algorithmic biases.\n\nBias can infiltrate the process anywhere in designing algorithms.\n\nThe inclusion of more people from diverse backgrounds within this process \u2014 Indigenous, racial minorities, women and other historically marginalized groups \u2014 is one of important steps to help mitigate the bias. In the meantime, it is important to push platforms to allow for as much transparency and public oversight as possible.\n\nArtificial intelligence (AI)\nFacebook\nSocial media\nAlgorithm\nInstagram\nBlack Lives Matter\nBLM\nMonitoring\nmissing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\nMMIWG\nWant to write?\n\nWrite an article and join a growing community of more than 186,300 academics and researchers from 4,990 institutions.\n\nRegister now\n\nEditorial Policies\nCommunity standards\nRepublishing guidelines\nAnalytics\nOur feeds\nGet newsletter\nWho we are\nOur charter\nOur team\nOur blog\nPartners and funders\nResource for media\nContact us\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\nPrivacy policy\nTerms and conditions\nCorrections\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2010\u20132024, Academic Journalism Society"},

{"url": "http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/what-to-do-about-safety-on-highway-of-tears-bc-already-has-its-answer/article27170780/", "title": "What to do about safety on Highway of Tears? B.C. already has its answer - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nWhat to do about safety on Highway of Tears? B.C. already has its answer\nJUSTINE HUNTER\nVICTORIA\nPUBLISHED NOVEMBER 8, 2015\n\nThis article was published more than 8 years ago. Some information may no longer be current.\n\nCOMMENTS\nSHARE\n\nTodd Stone, the B.C. Minister of Transportation, wants to hear from residents who live along the Highway 16 corridor in the north. His ministry is hosting a symposium in Smithers, B.C., on Nov. 24 to ask First Nations communities to help him find solutions to the well-documented challenges of keeping women and girls safe along what is known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe reasons for this round of consultation are inexplicable.\n\nMr. Stone already has a shelf full of reports and documents \u2013 internal and public \u2013 to guide him, much of it based on extensive consultation over the past decade.\n\nHe could start by looking at the findings of his ministry's 2006 Transportation Symposium. The resulting report is dedicated to nine young women and teenaged girls who disappeared or were found murdered along the highway. Most were aboriginal and most were last seen hitchhiking along Highway 16. The total number of victims is unknown but at least 18 women and girls have vanished in the region since 1969.\n\nNine years ago, the transportation ministry was urged to provide a free shuttle-bus system to connect nearby communities so that vulnerable women would have an alternative to hitchhiking.\n\nMr. Stone could also find some answers in the 2012 Missing Women Commission of Inquiry report. The inquiry held seven meetings in the region. The commission heard a \"generalized frustration about the government's lack of action to address the factors that contribute to the vulnerability of girls and young women along Highway 16: poverty and lack of transportation. We were told that the government continually conducts studies and surveys, but nothing is ever done with the information.\"\n\nIn its final report tabled three years ago, the commission called for urgent action by the B.C. government \"to develop and implement an enhanced public-transit system to provide a safer travel option connecting the Northern communities, particularly along Highway 16.\"\n\nWhile most British Columbians have access to public transit, the ministry seems confounded by the challenges of serving this remote region. There are 23 First Nations communities living along that 724-kilometre stretch of highway struggling to access recreation, medical treatment or other services.\n\nIn the summer of 2014, the ministry launched another round of consultation. From that, Mr. Stone concluded that public transportation was not a practical solution.\n\n\"We knew this couldn't be true because my colleagues and I drove that highway, met with community members along that highway and were told first-hand the very opposite of what the minister has said,\" NDP MLA Maurine Karagianis told the legislature last week. The NDP filed a Freedom of Information request, which took a year to extract from the government. \"Guess what? We were correct. The FOI shows that the people in the northwest actually did tell this government that they wanted public transportation.\"\n\nTerry Teegee, chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council, also questioned the ministry's claims about what the community wants. He said the message from First Nations in the region has been consistent: They believe a reliable, safe transportation system is an essential service. But the ministry insisted the region no longer considered public transit a priority. His organization asked for the consultation report but got nothing back.\n\nMr. Stone's ministry deserves the skepticism. The province's independent privacy commissioner has asked the RCMP to investigate how his ministry responded to information requests on the Highway of Tears by deleting documents.\n\nWhy is it so hard to accept that the community along Highway 16 wants access to some form of public transit? The only reasonable conclusion is that the stakeholders in the region haven't said what Mr. Stone wants to hear.\n\nThe government has estimated the cost of running a free shuttle service at $1-million a year. Coming from a government that has cooked up a $3-billion plan for the George Massey tunnel replacement in Metro Vancouver without bothering to produce a business plan, it is disgraceful that the province is applying such rigorous penny-pinching while young women are at risk.\n\nSign up for the B.C. Insider Newsletter.\n\nB.C. {"url": "https://www.ckom.com/2024/05/06/red-dress-day-workshop-at-wanuskewin-honours-mmiw/", "title": "Red Dress Day workshop at Wanuskewin honours MMIW | 650 CKOM", "body": "Skip to Content\nLISTEN LIVE\nNEWS\nLocal\nProvincial\nCanada & World\nTHE EVAN BRAY SHOW\nSHOWS\nShow Schedule\nCKOM Morning Show\nThe Evan Bray Show\nSaskatchewan Afternoon with Justin Blackwell\nThe Green Zone with Jamie and Drew\nRoy Green Show\nGarden Talk\nReal Ag on the Weekend\nMoney Sense\nThe Sport Market\nSPORTS\nProvincial Sports\nRiders\nThe Green Zone\nThe Sport Market\nPROMOTIONS\n650 CKOM Adopt-A-Family\nContests\nConcerts\nEvents\nCKOM News Cruiser\nON DEMAND\nShows\nCommentaries\nThe Shell Lake Massacre\nRed Dress Day workshop at Wanuskewin honours MMIW\nSaskatoon / 650 CKOM\nBrittany Caffet\nMay 6, 2024 | 6:07 AM\n\nElder Maria Linklater attended the Red Dress Day workshop at Wanuskewin on Sunday. She opened the event with a prayer and stayed for the duration of the workshop. (Brittany Caffet/650 CKOM)\n\n\n\n\n\nFor Chanelle Gamble, Red Dress Day is far more than just another day.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very passionate about this, because I\u2019ve had some of my family members who have gone missing and who have been murdered as well,\u201d she said.\n\nThe National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People \u2014 otherwise known as Red Dress Day \u2014 is held annually on May 5.\n\nA Statistics Canada report from last year showed that Indigenous women and girls were murdered at a rate six times higher than those who were not Indigenous.\n\nGamble, a 23-year-old Plains Cree woman who works at Wanuskewin Heritage Park as an Interpretive Guide and a fancy shawl dancer, said the statistics surrounding missing and murdered Indigenous women have left a sense of fear hanging over her as she navigates life.\n\n\u201cIt makes me fearful to even go anywhere by myself,\u201d she said.\n\nShe led her very first workshop at Wanuskewin on Sunday, honouring the cause that is so close to her heart by sharing her knowledge and teaching a group of people how to create beaded red dress earrings.\n\n\u201cI taught myself how to make this design in support of the cause, and I wanted to be able to teach other people,\u201d she said, adding that the earrings are great conversation starters.\n\n\u201cWearing a piece of jewelry that shows the red dress makes people curious. They wonder \u2018What does that mean? Why the red dress?'\u201d\n\nChanelle Gamble, 23, works at Wanuskewin Heritage Park as an Interpretive Guide and a Fancy Shawl Dancer. On Sunday she led her very first workshop at the park, teaching attendees how to make beaded red dress earrings. (Brittany Caffet/650 CKOM)\n\nThe first Red Dress Day took place in 2014, inspired by the work of Canadian M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black.\n\nBlack took hundreds of red dresses and hung them in public places to represent missing and murdered Indigenous women. The art installation turned the red dress into a symbol that represents the epidemic of missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cIt represents how the women should be wearing that dress,\u201d said Gamble. \u201cThey shouldn\u2019t be missing. They shouldn\u2019t be murdered.\u201d\n\nOver the years, many people have expressed their support on Red Dress Day by hanging red dresses outside of their homes or wearing articles of clothing or jewelry to commemorate the day.\n\nThanks to Gamble, the group of women who attended the workshop now have their own red dress earrings to wear.\n\nThose taking part in the workshop said they were grateful for the opportunity to learn, and will be wearing their new earrings with pride.\n\nThe group made beaded red dress earrings in honour of the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. (Brittany Caffet/650 CKOM)\n\nGamble said she believes items created in recognition of Red Dress Day are for everyone to wear, not just those of Indigenous heritage.\n\n\u201cIf you want to wear red dress earrings or a ribbon skirt, by all means wear a ribbon skirt. Just showing that support is really what\u2019s important,\u201d she said.\n\nShe also said these items should be worn year round \u2014 not only on May 5 \u2014 to help raise awareness of the issue.\n\n\u201cThose women should be honoured every single day,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s the goal of this project.\u201d\n\nDiscover more on CKOM.com\nSask. Along with many others who\u2019ve lost their loved ones, she spends the day remembering her sister who went missing in 2008.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s still a lot of women that are going missing and being murdered. And we know that there\u2019s a lot of men as well, Indigenous men going missing,\u201d said Smith. \u201cI think it\u2019s important for Canadians \u2026 to know that no one\u2019s immune to this.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day is an annual event that is dedicated to honouring Canada\u2019s missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirited people. Red dresses are hung to symbolize the lives lost.\n\nCarol McBride, head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, said this is an ongoing emergency.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a mother. I\u2019m a sister. The display can be viewed for free until May 7.\n\nThe items on display include red dresses, quilts, and banners, and are part of a bundle from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cIn order for this to change, it\u2019s going to take societal change in how we treat one another, support one another, and make sure that those supports are there for folks that need (them),\u201d said Smith.\n\nSmith is a member of provincial parliament representing Point Douglas and is one of the founders of Drag the Red, a volunteer organization that searches in and around the Red River for missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nA report that looked into those who were missing and murdered was released in 2019. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING /Winnipeg Sun\nArticle content\n\nWhat started as a one-off community event that organizers hoped would attract a few hundred runners, the Foodfare-Winnipeg Police Service Half Marathon celebrated its 20th running on Sunday, blessed by perfect weather.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt got to 400, 500, 600 and we stopped selling (registrations) at 1,000 and then we realized that it was such a good fundraiser for the cancer society that we just needed to keep going,\u201d recalled race director Nick Paulet, who organized the first race with his wife and a couple of friends. \u201cWhat really keeps us all going is this day. In the week leading up (to race day), it\u2019s a very long week for the team with a lot of long days and I tell the new guys, \u2018Just wait until Sunday.\u2019 Sunday comes and everybody is hugging, they\u2019re happy with each other. Year One I definitely didn\u2019t think so (that it would last) but it all makes sense now.\u201d\n\nThe Foodfare-WPS Half Marathon, Two-Person Relay and 5K event officially kicks off Manitoba\u2019s running season. This year, more than 2,000 runners took part.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nParticipants are shown support during the 20th running of the Winnipeg Police Service half marathon on Sunday, May 5, 2024. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING /Winnipeg Sun\n\n\u201cThe 20th is obviously an incredible mile marker for us, no pun intended being that it\u2019s a half marathon,\u201d said Paulet. \u201cBut I think what we really look at right now is the fact that we have 2,000 runners post-COVID coming back. The entire running community is strong and for us especially as police officers it\u2019s a great reminder and a chance to engage with the community to show just how positive a community and support we have. It\u2019s also for the cause of cancer research and that\u2019s what really binds us all together.\u201d\n\nAll monies raised from this year\u2019s event go to the Canadian Cancer Society to support research in Manitoba to help children affected by brain cancer.\n\n\u201c(Cancer is) unfortunately one of those things that ties us all together and it\u2019s fortunately one of those things that ties us all together,\u201d said Paulet. \u201cIt allows us to come together on a day like today and unify behind a cause.\u201d\n\nRunners are shown support during the 20th Winnipeg Police Service half marathon on Sunday, May 5, 2024. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING /Winnipeg Sun\n\nFoodfare has been a main sponsor from the very beginning.\n\n\u201cWe were honoured to be asked in the beginning,\u201d said Foodfare\u2019s Munther Zeid. \u201cBeing one of small guys to be asked to participate in something like this, we were very honoured. We sort of understand the feeling of somebody starting new and wanting support and being backed for something like this. After 20 years, it\u2019s good to know that this event from the start of it to now has been supported and funded by Winnipeggers and Manitobans only.\u201d\n\nLike many of the runners and many families in Manitoba, Zeid\u2019s family has been touched by cancer. First Nation along Highway of Tears found dead - North Shore News", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\nPublic Notices\n21.9 \u00b0C\nHOME B.C. NEWS\nWoman missing from B.C. First Nation along Highway of Tears found dead\nVANDERHOOF, B.C. \u2014 A woman who disappeared from a First Nations community in central British Columbia last month has been found dead. Vanderhoof RCMP and the Saik'uz First Nation say the remains of Chelsey Quaw, who was first reported missing on Oct.\nCanadian Press\nNov 6, 2023 7:35 PM\nNov 6, 2023 8:05 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nThe RCMP logo is seen outside Royal Canadian Mounted Police \"E\" Division Headquarters, in Surrey, B.C., on Friday April 13, 2018. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Darryl Dyck\nListen to this article\n00:01:29\n\nVANDERHOOF, B.C. \u2014 A woman who disappeared from a First Nations community in central British Columbia last month has been found dead.\n\nVanderhoof RCMP and the Saik'uz First Nation say the remains of Chelsey Quaw, who was first reported missing on Oct. 11, were found in a wooded area on the Indigenous community's territory.\n\nPolice say the BC Coroners Service is investigating the cause of death, and no further details on the case are available at this time.\n\n\u00a0\n\nQuaw was one of two community members missing from the First Nation \u2014 located 100 kilometres west of Prince George along Highway 16 \u2014 this year.\n\nThe stretch of highway between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears after dozens have vanished or been killed along it over the last few decades.\n\nFirst Nations leaders and family members last week called for more action from police and the public in locating both Quaw and Jay Preston Raphael, who was reported missing Feb. 26 after walking away from a residence at the Saik'uz First Nation.\n\nQuaw's family has issued a statement through the Saik'uz First Nation and Carrier Sekani Family Services, thanking all people involved in the search and reminding them to keep up the continued search for Raphael.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Nov. 6, 2023.\n\nThe Canadian Press\n\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. He said in a Wednesday meeting he no longer believed they would benefit the community.\n\n\u201cAlthough it\u2019s something a lot of community members want and see it in other communities like Calgary, the health professionals that presented, presented a different picture that may not be the healthiest towards our community,\u201d he said.\n\nThe healthcare workers argued lounges and patios with hookah\u2014a waterpipe also referred to as shisha\u2014put workers and the public at risk of health problems from second-hand smoke. This\u00a0includes cancer, cardiovascular problems and lung diseases.\n\nGP Herald Tribune Newsletter\n\nSign up now and stay connected to all the latest GP Herald Tribune news.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAll provinces and territories have bans on indoor smoking in public places.\u00a0However, provincial governments have left regulating tobacco-free herbal shisha up to municipalities.\n\nDr. Brent Friesen, medical officer of health with Alberta Health Services, said nicotine-free shisha is still harmful to people. One pipe is equivalent to smoking 40 to 100 cigarettes, he said.\n\n\u201cThe issue is with the actual act of combustion in terms of burning and heating the shisha product,\u201d he said. \u201cEven though it doesn\u2019t necessarily contain nicotine, we still see all those harmful combustion products from the heating of the shisha, as well as the charcoal that is used for the heating process.\u201d\n\nDr. Jack Pang, north zone medical officer of health for AHS, said public smoking increases smoking\u2019s appeal for youth and young adults. The shared use of a waterpipe also leads to higher risk of infectious diseases.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe recognize the numerous challenges we\u2019ve all had to face for the past two years and are still facing today,\u201d he said. \u201cHowever, we certainly should not sacrifice health of the public for economic recovery and growth.\u201d\n\nVentilation systems with the technology to eliminate contaminants such as environmental smoke do not exist, said Norma Bruins, a public health inspector with AHS North Zone.\n\nOnly one presenter supported the motion, though.\u00a0Fort McMurray resident Zakaria Tahlil argued there is demand for hookah lounges in the community and wants to open one. He said restrictions like age limits could be put in place to protect the public.\n\n\u201cThose risks\u2026 they\u2019re there, but these are for people who come into facility and purchase these shisha\u2026 these are people who want to smoke,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCouncillor Ken Ball said he is a smoker and cannot smoke in any indoor public places. Despite testimony from healthcare workers, he argued shisha smoking is not dangerous.\n\n\u201cIt has a cultural background\u2026 people sit around it, share their good feelings, share knowledge, spend some good time,\u201d he said.\n\nThe motion was defeated, with only Dogar voting in favour.\n\nPeople march down Franklin Avenue for Red Dress Day in Fort McMurray, Alta. on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The taskforce has created an action plan that includes developing a resource toolkit, healing circles, community gatherings, educational panels and awareness campaigns.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAllison Flett of the Mikisew Cree First Nation said violence committed against Indigenous people\u2014including boys, men and gender-diverse people\u2014needs to be acknowledged.\n\n\u201cThis epidemic is so big and so tough\u2026 we need to spread the awareness through the region. {"url": "https://www.dailyheraldtribune.com:443/news/local-news/hundreds-march-through-downtown-fort-mcmurray-to-mark-red-dress-day", "title": "Hundreds march through downtown Fort McMurray to mark Red Dress Day | Grande Prairie Daily Herald Tribune", "body": "Skip to Content\nIntroducing Puzzmo's new Pile-Up Poker, where poker meets solitaire. The day marks a national day of mourning and awareness for missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples (MMEIP). Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nFranklin Avenue became a sea of red as more than 300 people marched from the Centre of Hope to Jubilee Plaza to mark Red Dress Day.\u00a0The day marks a national day of mourning and awareness for missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples (MMEIP).\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMany people held signs and banners calling for justice, or including the names and photos of victims from their communities. Red dresses could be found hanging along Franklin Avenue, while others had red handprints painted over their mouths. Both have become symbols of the movement.\n\n\u201cThis is also a call to action to our elected officials. The more awareness we raise in the community, the more people are going to start taking and demanding action,\u201d said Cindy Bourque Punko, treasurer of McMurray M\u00e9tis. \u201cIt surprises me how people don\u2019t know about this or the residential schools, including people who are born and raised in Fort McMurray,\u201d\n\nThe rally was organized by the Athabasca Tribal Council, Fort McMurray First Nation #468, the Centre of Hope, the Wood Buffalo Wellness Society and the municipality.\n\nGP Herald Tribune Newsletter\n\nSign up now and stay connected to all the latest GP Herald Tribune news.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOrganizers said they were happy with the turnout, but more work is needed to spread awareness of the crisis. Some protesters said there were many bystanders watching the march that asked people what was happening and for more information about MMEIP.\n\n\u201cI live in Thickwood and I can guarantee that on my street, maybe 1-in-20 people know what\u2019s going on. The rally is to bring that awareness,\u201d said Brian Ross of Fort McMurray First Nation #468.\n\nThere have been nine women who have been reported missing or murdered in the Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo region.\n\nSherri Lynn Flett, a member of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation (ACFN), was murdered in Fort McMurray in January. Timothy Andrew McDougall, 37, of Fort McMurray has been charged with second-degree murder.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe murders of Amber Tuccaro, Audrey Bignose and Ellie Herman remain unsolved. Police are still searching for Elaine Alook, Shirley Ann Waquan, Shelly Dene, Betty Ann Deltess and Janice Desjarlais.\n\nAn independent review of Tuccaro\u2019s murder investigation found\u00a0RCMP mishandled the case from the start. Alberta RCMP apologized to the family, but the Tuccaro family\u2014who are part of the Mikisew Cree First Nation\u2014refused to accept their apology.\n\n\u201cWhen something isn\u2019t happening to you personally then we tend to not pay attention to it. We all do that. But this is something that is happening here,\u201d said Bourque Punko.\n\nPeople march down Franklin Avenue for Red Dress Day in Fort McMurray, Alta. on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The day marks a national day of mourning and awareness for missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples (MMEIP). Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nJoanne Peckham of the Wood Buffalo Wellness Society said awareness is key to fighting the MMEIP crisis. Solutions, however, must begin at a community level that focus on quality of life.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nPeckham says this includes improving housing, food security and educational opportunities in rural and Indigenous communities. It also includes supports for social profits, mental health and addiction programs, and family violence counselling.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s always more work that needs to be done in raising awareness, but I do thing that the tide is turning,\u201d said Peckham. \u201cIn general, a lot of people don\u2019t understand that these systems still exist.\u201d\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada reports Indigenous women are more likely to report physical and sexual violence as a child than men (14 per cent versus five per cent) and three times more likely to report spousal violence than non-Indigenous women.\n\nThe National Inquiry into the MMIWGS2 crisis found perpetrators are often \u201cpartners, casual acquaintances and serial killers.\u201d\n\nStatistics Canada found even with other risk factors, \u201cIndigenous identity itself remained a risk factor for violent victimization of women which was not found for men.\u201d Indigenous LGBTQ2S+ peoples also report high rates of physical and sexual violence.\n\n\u201cThis is all happening across the country and right here in our community,\u201d said Allan Adam, chief of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation and president of the Athabasca Tribal Council. \u201cThis is about making sure people aren\u2019t ignoring it.\u201d\n\nPeople march down Franklin Avenue for Red Dress Day in Fort McMurray, Alta. on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The day marks a national day of mourning and awareness for missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples (MMEIP). Everyone To Be an Ally on Red Dress Day and Beyond\nPush Mitteilungen\nACCESSWIRE\n11.05.2023 17:26 Uhr\n495 Leser\nArtikel bewerten:\n(2)\nSuncor Energy: Suncor Indigenous Employees, Lana and Joy Want Everyone To Be an Ally on Red Dress Day and Beyond\n\nNORTHAMPTON, MA / ACCESSWIRE / May 11, 2023 / Suncor Energy\n\n\nOriginally published on May 5, 2023\n\nLana Hill, who is a trusted advisor to many young Indigenous people in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo, holds her own teenage daughter closer each time the name of another missing Indigenous person is released. Joy Flett is the knowledge keeper for her close and extended relatives, but pieces of her family tree have been stolen, and she feels a heartache that is shared by countless other Indigenous families across Canada. Both women will be wearing red on May 5.\n\nAlso known as Red Dress Day, May 5 marks a day to honour, remember and create awareness and action for Missing, Murdered and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP) in Canada. The statistics are startling -Indigenous women in Canada today are seven times more likely than non-Indigenous women to be a murder victim, and three times more likely to be violently or sexually assaulted.\n\nLana, originally from Cowessess First Nation in Saskatchewan, and Joy, from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation in Alberta, are part of Suncor's Indigenous and Community Relations team in Fort McMurray, Alta. They both agree that more action is needed to end the MMEIP crisis.\n\n\"Since the time of residential schools and everything leading to today, we've been stripped of our names, our languages, our hair. To be able to take back our power and voice, we need to keep speaking out against what is happening,\" says Joy. \"There are so many Indigenous people who've gone missing or have been murdered in our own city. We need to continue to say their names. They are important to somebody. We can all play a role in ending the violence.\"\n\nOne of the national organizations helping to move the needle with this progress is the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC). For almost 50 years NWAC has played a lead role in advocating for the rights of Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit, transgender and gender-diverse people, which includes critical advocacy on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG2S+) and reconciliation. The organization has been pressing the federal government to act since the National Inquiry issued the 231 Calls for Justice in 2019.\n\nWhen reflecting on Red Dress Day, NWAC urges Canadians to consider the many aspects of colonization that continue to affect Indigenous people. NWAC's Chief Executive Officer, Lynne Groulx, believes that a critical component to reconciliation is acknowledging the past.\n\n\"We invite everyone across the country to play an active role in reconciliation through education and raising awareness, as well as learning about Indigenous knowledge systems and the impacts of colonialism and racism that face many Indigenous people,\" says Lynne. \"We have taken urgent and significant action to increase awareness and address the 231 Calls for Justice and have been working hard to implement our own MMIWG2S+ Action Plan.\"\n\nNWAC's Action Plan includes 66 concrete actions they will take to help end the MMEIP. Last year NWAC reported progress on over 85 per cent of the proposed actions. This includes the Safe Passage Platform - a national reporting tool that maps cases of MMIWG2S+ and provides information on resources and services available across the country.\n\nLynne also suggests reading books, listening to podcasts or participating in educational programs created by Indigenous authors and media to see the world through their lens. She also encourages people to help amplify messages and initiatives from Indigenous voices to ensure they are being heard.\n\nOn May 5 and beyond, both Lana and Joy will be found honouring and remembering - the missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples - in their own way of healing and active support.\n\n\"Through my mom's experience growing up of being called a dirty Indian, to now my 15-year-old daughter who is able to stand proud and march to the beat of her own drum, we can see there has been a lot of progress for Indigenous people to feel seen and accepted,\" says Lana. \"But we also must acknowledge the pain and trauma that is still prevalent today. We are not victims, we are survivors.\"\n\nView additional multimedia and more ESG storytelling from Suncor Energy on 3blmedia.com.\n\nContact Info:\nSpokesperson: Suncor Energy\nWebsite: https://www.3blmedia.com/profiles/suncor-energy\nEmail: info@3blmedia.com\n\nSOURCE: Suncor Energy\n\nView source version on accesswire.com:\nhttps://www.accesswire.com/754300/Suncor-Indigenous-Employees-Lana-and-Joy-Want-Everyone-To-Be-an-Ally-on-Red-Dress-Day-and-Beyond\n\n\n\u00a9\u00a02023\u00a0ACCESSWIRE\nSie erhalten auf FinanzNachrichten.de kostenlose Realtime-Aktienkurse von  und .\nFNRD-2.627.0\nWie bewerten Sie die aktuell angezeigte Seite?\nsehr gut123456schlechtProblem melden\nWerbehinweise: Die Billigung des Basisprospekts durch die BaFin ist nicht als ihre Bef\u00fcrwortung der angebotenen Wertpapiere zu verstehen. Wir empfehlen Interessenten und potenziellen Anlegern den Basisprospekt und die Endg\u00fcltigen Bedingungen zu lesen, bevor sie eine Anlageentscheidung treffen, um sich m\u00f6glichst umfassend zu informieren, insbesondere \u00fcber die potenziellen Risiken und Chancen des Wertpapiers. Sie sind im Begriff, ein Produkt zu erwerben, das nicht einfach ist und schwer zu verstehen sein kann.\nDAXXetra-OrderbuchAd hoc-MitteilungenNachrichten B\u00f6rsenAktien-EmpfehlungenBranchenMedienNachrichten-ArchivRSS-News von FinanzNachrichten.de\nPresse\nImpressum | AGB | Disclaimer | Datenschutz\nDatenschutzeinstellungen\nMediadaten"},

(Abbotsford News file photo)\nListen to this article\n00:01:15\n\nThe Fraser Valley Metis Association (FVMA) and the City of Abbotsford host the third annual Red Dress Day event on Sunday, May 5.\n\nThe event is held outside the old Abbotsford courthouse at 32203 South Fraser Way. It gets underway at 10 a.m. with an awareness walk and runs until 3:30 p.m.\n\nThe public is invited to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls by hanging a red dress.\n\nThe FVMA also wants to bring awareness to the over-representation of Indigenous women and girls within the justice system.\n\nThe event includes information, supports and resources that shed light on the ongoing challenges faced by Indigenous communities, as well as drumming, free food and smudging.\n\nMay 5 marks the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People in Canada.\n\nIt is also known as Red Dress Day, a campaign led by REDress, a project by artist Jaime Black in which red dresses were hung to honour those who have been lost.\n\nVisit fvma.ca for more information.\n\nRELATED: 2023 Red Dress Day in Abbotsford\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nFacebook {"url": "https://www.sprucegroveexaminer.com:443/news/storytelling-and-fun-at-the-fort-saskatchewan-community-round-dance", "title": "Storytelling and fun at the Fort Saskatchewan Community Round Dance | Spruce Grove Examiner", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nAdvertise with Us\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nStorytelling and fun at the Fort Saskatchewan Community Round Dance\nAuthor of the article:\nJames Bonnell\nPublished Mar 23, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nMembers of the Indigenous Society of Fort Saskatchewan stand at the Mar. 19 Community Round Dance. Photo supplied.\nArticle content\n\nJust under 200 people showed up to The Legion on Sunday, March 19 for the Fort Saskatchewan Community Round Dance, hosted by the Indigenous Society of Fort Saskatchewan, Family and Community Support Services (FCSS) and the City of Fort Saskatchewan.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCommunity members filled the Normandy Room at the Legion to listen, learn, and participate in the Community Round Dance. In addition to the round dance the Indigenous Society held a Pipe Ceremony and a feast of soup and bannock.\n\n\u201cIt went really well,\u201d said Colleen Dollfusz, Indigenous Society of Fort Saskatchewan. \u201cOne of our volunteers went around and counted 181 people at one point in the night. We had prepared to serve for 200 people and all of the soup and bannock was eaten, so that was awesome. It was well received and a lot of fun.\u201d\n\nDollfusz says that events like the Community Round Dance help Indigenous people living in the City to connect with their culture.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m new to this, and that\u2019s why we are trying to bring this into our community, because there are a lot of people here like myself, who we call \u2018Urban Native\u2019, and we\u2019ve lost our culture. So this pipe ceremony that we brought together on Sunday was the first pipe ceremony that I\u2019ve been to for many, many years.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re bringing it back into our community for the Urban Native,\u201d explained Dollfusz. \u201cWe\u2019ve lost a lot of our culture because we moved into the cities and away from our communities so that we could get a better education and a better lifestyle \u2014 and a lot of us actually weren\u2019t even raised in Aboriginal communities, like myself. There wasn\u2019t an everyday cultural thing, so we lost it. We lost our language, we lost our culture, and we lost our way of life. So to bring it back into the Fort Saskatchewan community where there wasn\u2019t a real aboriginal culture, us Urban Natives can reconnect with our culture and to Creator.\u201d\n\nThe Indigenous Society of Fort Saskatchewan was founded by Colleen Dollusz and Tamara Pawlick to create a space in the community for Indigenous people to come together and have space to practice their culture.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cTammy approached me with idea to start the Society because there was a gap in our community,\u201d said Dollfusz. \u201cThere wasn\u2019t anything significantly going on with the culture, and we wanted to bring it back into our community.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat we really wanted to do was get a cultural centre and space into our community. We\u2019ve been working with the City on trying to find a permanent space where Aboriginal people can come together\u201d\n\nThe Indigenous Society of Fort Saskatchewan is currently hosting Pow Wow dancing celebrations every Wednesday, 6pm at the \u00c9cole Parc \u00c9l\u00e9mentaire gymnasium, and ribbon skirt and shirt sewing classes every Sunday, 2pm at the Bridge Wellness Hub. To get involved with the Indigenous Society and their upcoming events, visit their Facebook page.\n\nFrom May 3-5, the Indigenous Society will be hanging red dresses in Legacy Park to raise awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous Women. Also known as Red Dress Day, May 5 honours the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, 2 spirit, and gender diverse people in Canada by encouraging learning and building awareness. The Society will be hosting a storytelling event and ceremony at Legacy Park starting at 4pm. All are welcome to attend.\n\njbonnell@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR SPRUCE GROVE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

{"url": "https://www.abbynews.com/community/red-dress-day-event-underway-in-abbotsford/", "title": "Red Dress Day event underway in Abbotsford - The Abbotsford News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.3 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Community\nRed Dress Day event underway in Abbotsford\nEvent honours missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\n\tVikki Hopes\n\nMay 5, 2023 12:52 PM\nMay 5, 2023 2:34 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 7 The Fraser Valley Metis Association holds a Red Dress Day event on Friday (May 5) in front of the former courthouse on South Fraser Way, adjacent to city hall. In addition to hanging red dresses, the public could pin up miniature cutouts in a tent displaying the Metis flag. (Vikki Hopes/Abbotsford News)\nExpand\n\nThe second annual Red Dress Day event in Abbotsford is underway on Friday (May 5), hosted by the Fraser Valley Metis Association (FVMA) and the City of Abbotsford.\n\nThe event runs from 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. outside the old Abbotsford courthouse at 32203 South Fraser Way. The main speeches start at 3:30 p.m.\n\nThe public is invited to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls by hanging a red dress.\n\nThe FVMA also wants to bring awareness to the over-representation of Indigenous women and girls within the justice system.\n\nRELATED: \u2018We are in a crisis\u2019: Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\n\nThe event includes free food, drumming, smudging and a ceremony.\n\nMay 5 marks the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People in Canada.\n\nIt is also known as Red Dress Day, a campaign led by REDress, a project by artist Jaime Black in which red dresses were hung to honour those who have been lost.\n\nVisit fvma.ca for more information.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Vikki Hopes\n\nI have been a journalist for almost 40 years, and have been at the Abbotsford News since 1991.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\t4-vehicle crash snarls Hwy. 1 traffic at Chilliwack-Abbotsford border\n\t\tAbbotsford homeless encampment protest moves to city hall\n\t\tLots to see and do at annual Berry Fest in Abbotsford\n\t\tMan dies throwing candy during Alberta Canada Day parade\n\t\tAccidental firefighting foam spill leads to disaster in Abbotsford creek\nFacebook Comments (0) \nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/entertainment/local-a-e/gouchie-celebrates-new-single-1.2305733", "title": "Gouchie celebrates new single - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 19.6 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local Arts\nGouchie celebrates new single\nThe song is new, it signals the coming of a new album, and it calls out to put our collective thoughts to the Highway Of Tears once and for all.\nFrank Peebles\nJul 19, 2016 9:14 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKym Gouchie sings a song about the Highway of Tears during Aboriginal Day on June 21 at Lheidli T\u0092enneh Memorial Park.Brent Braaten, Photographer\n\nThe song is new, it signals the coming of a new album, and it calls out to put our collective thoughts to the Highway Of Tears once and for all.\n\nKym Gouchie will hold a celebration Wednesday night for her new single In The Hearts of You & Me, a song that draws a rich purple tone across cello strings as it opens, then gives way to the poetry and drive of Gouchie's ringing voice as she tells the simple story of a woman who stuck out her thumb for a ride and was never seen or heard from again.\n\n\"It is about the Highway of Tears, it is about right here,\" Gouchie said.\n\nThe message of this one song is indicative of the messages that always accompany a Kym Gouchie track. She takes her life's lessons seriously, and considers them gifts she is compelled to share. In The Hearts of You & Me carries that weight, but she doesn't swing it like a hammer. The same could be said for her compositions looking at residential schools, domestic abuse, the simple being of aboriginal descent in a colonial society, and all the other issues that come to her in song because they come to her in life.\n\n\"Whenever I am performing and I see people crying in the audience, or when people come up to me to talk about how something I sang moved them somehow, that's when I know for sure I am a messenger,\" said Gouchie. \"I take care of myself, I try to live a healthy life and make good life decisions so I can do this work, because it opens up a lot of doors, a lot of subject matter, that people don't want to talk about. I'm not here to sing happy sunshiny ditties. There is happiness in my songs, the message is always positive, but I'm here to tell stories, I'm here to talk about real topics, using my music.\"\n\nThis authenticity, and her well honed talent (she is a member of a Lheidli T'enneh First Nation family famous for their music. Her brothers Buddy and Mike are also accomplished singer-songwriters) caught the attention of some angel investors. Dean and Diane Ravelli saw her perform in concert and were so impressed, the brother-sister investors became the sponsors of her next album. That album is being recorded now with a fall release as her target.\n\nThe recording process is being done with acclaimed sound engineer Thurein Myint at the controls, in his analog studio in Summerland. In The Hearts of You & Me is the first one completed, and it is already getting radio and download action despite being released to the world only recently.\n\nGouchie will perform the song, give a sneak peek of the upcoming album, and bring in some of her past favourites at a concert on Thursday night at Knox United Church. The church self-sponsored the event, along with UNBC's campus station CFUR, Gouchie herself who is donating most of the proceeds to the Highway Of Tears Initiative, and a grant from the Lheidli T'enneh First Nation.\n\nThe master of ceremonies at the concert will be Highway Of Tears co-ordinator Brenda Wilson, sister of one of the victims of the highway's tragic history, Ramona Wilson. In honour of her sister, and all the other women who have gone missing or been confirmed murdered over the years, Wilson held a walk from Prince Rupert to Prince George and Gouchie, without knowing her, volunteered to walk some of the distance on that journey.\n\n\"A drum song came to me on that walk, and I will be performing it on Thursday with the Khast'an Drummers. Brenda Wilson also helped contribute some of the words to the song, so she will be there too,\" Gouchie said.\n\nOther performers on stage sharing the artistry of the evening will be singer/rapper Tessa Fraser and singer-songwriter Julia Young.\n\n\"I saw Tessa perform at Aboriginal Day and she blew me away,\" Gouchie said. \"She has such an energy. She's not only beautiful, but captivating. She has this powerful presence and you can't take your eyes off her. So I hope this is the beginning of something; I want to work on songs with her.\"\n\nYoung is the daughter of a dear friend Gouchie recently lost to cancer. She pledged to help the aspiring 15-year-old.\n\n\"Music for me has been healing and I strongly feel it will play a big role in Julia's life,\" she said. \"I was a pretty lost teenager myself, I didn't know how to find help or what help even looked like, so now I want to take Julia under my musical wing.\"\n\nFood and refreshments are served at 6 p.m., the music begins at 7 p.m. tomorrow night at the historic church hall at 1448 Fifth Ave. \"There's not a bad seat in the house and the acoustics are amazing,\" Gouchie said.\n\nTickets are available in advance from Angelique's Native Arts (335 Dominion Street) and Carrier Sekani Family Services (987 Fourth Ave), or at the door while supplies last. Prices are $15 in advance or $20 at the door.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.cfnrfm.ca/2021/04/07/full-cellular-coverage-for-highway-of-tears/", "title": "Full Cellular Coverage for Highway of Tears | CFNR Network", "body": " Menu\nListen Live\nNews\nOn-Air\nWin\nEvents\nFeatured\nNOW PLAYING\nROCKSTAR\nNICKELBACK\nFull Cellular Coverage for Highway of Tears\nBy Gene Law\nApr 7, 2021 | 12:51 PM\n\nWalk for MMIWG in Terrace, Feb. 14th, 2021.\n\nComplete cellular coverage is finally coming to Highway 16, also known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe announcement was made this morning, just over 15 years after the Highway of Tears Symposium ended in Prince George. One of the 33 recommendations from the symposium was to have cellular coverage along the highway as a safety measure.\n\nThe provincial and federal governments are providing $11.6-million for the entire project. Rogers will get $4.5-million of that funding. The project will include twelve new towers that will provide 252-kilometres of coverage that will close the remaining gaps, and boost signal strength. The Boulder Creek, Basalt Creek, and Saunderson Point rest areas will also get cellular coverage.\n\nJennifer Rice, MLA for North Coast, said the funding from the province\u2019s Economic Recovery Fund.\n\nAudio Player\n00:00\n00:00\nUse Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.\n\nFor Barbara Ward-Burkitt, the executive director of the Prince George Native Friendship Centre, the announcement comes at a critical moment.\n\n\u201cThis extended cell phone coverage is so critical at this time as the past year has been especially hard for everyone, but for some, it\u2019s been a time of increased violence and fear,\u201d she told CFNR News in a statement. \u201cSince the COVID-19 pandemic, Indigenous women who are already vulnerable to isolation and partner abuse are experiencing added trauma, increasing levels of violence and abuse from their partners, and economic instability. Indigenous women and children experiencing violence need help now more than ever.\u201d\n\nShe also notes gender-based violence is increasing at alarming rates, but especially so for Indigenous women and girls in northern British Columbia.\n\nRice said the province is working with the federal government to develop a national action plan, and part of that includes going through the MMWIG report, to see what more can be done.\n\nAudio Player\n00:00\n00:00\nUse Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.\n\nRice said the province will hold engagement sessions to develop a plan specifically for B.C., but has no details yet.\n\nA statement from the province said having full cellular coverage is key to ensuring women, particularly Indigenous women and girls, are able to receive the services they need for their safety and security.\n\nThe project is scheduled to be completed next fall.\n\nComments\nLeave a Reply\n\nYou must be logged in to post a comment.\n\nLatest\nEnvironment and Climate Change Canada Issues Heat Warning for North Coast-Inland Region\nAs temperatures soar in the North Coast-inland region, including Terrace and Kitimat, Environment and Climate Change Canada has issued a heat warning effective from Saturday through Tuesday night. {"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/red-dress-day-near-and-dear-to-campbell-river-woman-1.24315256", "title": "Red Dress Day 'near and dear' to Campbell River woman - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n22.2 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Local News\nRed Dress Day 'near and dear' to Campbell River woman\nFor Stephanie Rivers Elickus, a driving force behind the many red dresses hanging along Island highways, Red Dress Day is about reminding people why she hangs those dresses.\nRoxanne Egan-Elliott\nMay 5, 2021 6:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nStephanie Rivers Elickus has a collection of red dresses on her fence waiting to be picked up by families of missing or murdered Indigenous women who will hang them in honour of their loved ones. SUBMITTED BY STEPHANIE RIVERS ELICKUS\n\nFor Stephanie Rivers Elickus, a driving force behind the many red dresses hanging along Island highways, Red Dress Day is about reminding people why she hangs those dresses.\n\nToday is National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada, or Red Dress Day. The dresses have become a symbol of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in North America.\n\nViolence against Indigenous women and girls is \u201csystemic and a national crisis,\u201d says the Assembly of First Nations, which represents about 900,000 First Nations people in Canada.\n\nIndigenous women and girls are five times more likely to experience violence than any other population in Canada, and Indigenous women make up 16 per cent of all female homicide victims and 11 per cent of \u00admissing women, despite representing just 4.3 per cent of the population, the organization says.\n\nMay 5 is also a day of personal significance for Elickus \u2014 the 29th anniversary of her sister\u2019s murder.\n\n\u201cSo this is really important to me. And it\u2019s really near and dear to me that people get their justice, or they get some action,\u201d she said.\n\nElickus hung 45 red dresses in Campbell River to make a statement marking the day and has planned a vigil in a downtown park to remember the women who never came home.\n\nElickus said she hung her first red dress in the early 2000s and has placed more than 100 along highways from \u00adVictoria to Port Hardy just this year.\n\nWith the help of a network of volunteers, dresses have also been hung on the Gulf Islands and the Sunshine Coast.\n\nThe red dresses act as a symbol of solidarity and are intended to raise awareness.\n\nWhen she hangs a dress, Elickus says a prayer and asks the spirits to call the missing women home.\n\n\u201cFor me, it\u2019s speaking for the ones that can\u2019t speak anymore, you know, the silenced,\u201d she said.\n\nShe started a Facebook page this year dedicated to the cause, where she shares stories of women who are missing and photos of red dresses \u00adhanging all over the Island, and tries to raise awareness about the meaning behind the dresses.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s still so many that don\u2019t have a clue,\u201d she said.\n\nregan-elliott@timescolonist.com\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has been shared 2 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tRental truck impounded after speeding driver turns out to be impaired\n\tNanaimo RCMP find illicit drugs, weapons after stopping suspected prohibited driver\n\tPolice seize 20 guns, 20,000 rounds of ammo in raid on Bear Mountain home\nTimes Colonist - Featured\nInjuries reported in Highway 4 crashes on Canada Day weekend\nRead More\nTRENDING TODAY\n6303\t\nFirst heat wave of the summer on the way to Vancouver Island and B.C.\n\n2625\t\nFairway grocery store closing at Westshore Town Centre\n\n2555\t\nSuspect's pants catch fire in arson attempt gone wrong: B.C. {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/families-walk-highway-of-tears-to-honour-missing-murdered-indigenous-women/it46249", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kelowna and Area|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nSunny\u00a0 26.4\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nKelowna News\nFamilies walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women\nLaura Kane\nTamara Chipman, who went missing in Prince Rupert, B.C. in 2005, will be honoured at an annual walk along the Highway of Tears.\nImage Credit: THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO-Gladys Radek\nSeptember 20, 2017 - 2:30 PM\n\nVANCOUVER - When Gladys Radek walks the Highway of Tears, she says she can feel the spirits of women who are missing or have been murdered walking beside her.\n\nDozens have vanished or been killed along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 in central British Columbia. On Thursday, Radek will honour the 12th anniversary of the disappearance of her niece, Tamara Lynn Chipman, by walking the route once again.\n\n\"You can feel the pain of the families when they're walking with you,\" she said. \"It's really, really hard to describe.\"\n\nThe annual journey, made by Radek and others who have lost loved ones, will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers. Vehicles will accompany the walkers who will cover sections of the route in a relay fashion.\n\nCommissioners of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls are set to join the walk on Sept. 25 before community hearings are held from Sept. 26 to 28 in Smithers. This is the second set of hearings held to date by the inquiry, after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nSince then, the inquiry's executive director, Michele Moreau, and one of its commissioners, Marilyn Poitras, have quit and the Native Women's Association of Ontario has pulled its support. The inquiry has faced growing calls for resignations and a restart.\n\nAsked whether commissioners feel added pressure to ensure these hearings are successful, Chief Commissioner Marion Buller said they feel that obligation regardless.\n\n\"They have to be (successful), not only for our purposes, but more so for the families who come forward and share their stories with us. It's the success from their perspective that's the most important aspect for us,\" she said.\n\n\"We're always under scrutiny. Always. And we always will be,\" she added. \"I'm always open to constructive, informed criticism, as are the other commissioners. It's part of our work.\"\n\nThe federal government launched the inquiry last year to examine the systemic issues behind the high number of Indigenous women who have been killed or disappeared over the last four decades in Canada. It is expected to take two years and cost almost $54 million.\n\nBuller said the commission will ask for more money and time but it is still conducting an internal analysis before making the request.\n\nAbout 25 people, including family members and survivors of violence, are expected to testify publicly or privately at the Dze L K'Ant Friendship Centre next week. A statement-taker will be available for anyone who wishes to speak, with no pre-registration needed, said Buller.\n\nRadek will testify about Chipman, who disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert on Sept. 21, 2005. The 22-year-old was a beautiful, charming free spirit who had a young son, she recalled.\n\nCritics of the inquiry don't understand how much ground it has to cover, said Radek, who sits on its national family advisory circle.\n\n\"It's not as simple as two years of work. These people, these commissioners and the staff that they have working right now, they are uncovering the stones that should have been turned a long time ago,\" she said.\n\nPeople living along the Highway of Tears had to wait years for the provincial government to carry out a key recommendation of the B.C. inquiry into missing and murdered women, said Terry Tegee, tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council.\n\nThe recommendation \u2014 reliable public transit along the route \u2014 was finally implemented earlier this year. But the experience has led Teegee to call for the federal inquiry to have more teeth. Like the missing inquiry in B.C., the recommendations from the national inquiry will be non-binding.\n\nTeegee also said he's concerned that people in small communities that still lack transit won't be able to participate in the Smithers hearings.\n\nBuller said staff have visited nearby towns in recent weeks to reach out to families and it is able to help cover travel costs including mileage and meals, she said.\n\nThe hearings will be the first of nine this fall, with other stops in Winnipeg, Halifax, Edmonton, Yellowknife, Saskatoon, Sask., Maliotenam, Que., Thunder Bay, Ont., and Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2017\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are emailed reader responses to {"url": "https://www.fairviewpost.com:443/news/more-work-to-be-done-hundreds-march-through-fort-mcmurray-on-red-dress-day", "title": "Hundreds march through Fort McMurray on Red Dress Day | Fairview Post", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nAdvertise with Us\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\n'More work to be done': Hundreds march through Fort McMurray on Red Dress Day\n\nOrganizers say the crisis of missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous people in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo is bigger than people realize.\n\nAuthor of the article:\nVincent McDermott\nPublished May 07, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 09, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nA woman marches through downtown Fort McMurray while carrying the names of with the names of Amber Tuccaro, Sherri Flett and Ellie Herman on Red Dress Day on May 5, 2024. The day honours missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous people. Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nAt Red Dress Day ceremonies in Fort McMurray, Stephanie Harpe feels there\u2019s still plenty of work to fight the crisis of missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous people (MMEIP). It\u2019s a crisis that many organizers of Sunday\u2019s event said is still not being taken seriously by many people.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThis day is for our murdered, our missing, our human trafficked, our loved ones that are surviving,\u201d said Harpe, a member of the Fort McKay First Nation and an advocate for MMEIP. \u201cHere in the daytime we exist, but nighttime is when our people have to survive. Red Dress Day is every single day until we are safe and can walk down the street and feel OK.\u201d\n\nHarpe wishes more people would talk about human trafficking in Canada, and what police and governments are doing and not doing about the crisis. She also wishes more grassroots movements allowed larger leadership and advisory roles for survivors and families of victims.\n\nIt\u2019s a cause that has impacted her personally. Harpe struggled with addictions at 14, and was stalked and nearly murdered in Edmonton. Her mother, Ruby Anne McDonald, was murdered in Edmonton in 1999.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWhen I got well, I just knew I had a responsibility to share this truth of surviving the streets, gangs, crime syndicates. As a survivor, I can speak to it,\u201d said Harpe. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of things we\u2019re still not talking about. This is a day of awareness of elevating the voices that are silenced.\u201d\n\nStephanie Harpe, an activist for missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous people, at a Red Dress Day round dance at Kiyam Community Park in downtown Fort McMurray on May 5, 2024. Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nRed Dress Day is held every year on May 5. It began as a way to honour the memories of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people (MMIWG2S). In the Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo region, some organizers have embraced the MMEIP acronym.\n\nIn Fort McMurray, people met at Kiyam Community Park. Hundreds of Indigenous and non-Indigenous people marched up Morrison Street, along Selby Avenue and down Hardin Street towards Franklin Avenue. The rest of the day included a public community lunch and a memorial round dance with drummers.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe names of victims were on signs, banners and clothing. Red dresses could be found hanging from trees, buildings and signs across the region.\n\nPeople march through downtown Fort McMurray on May 5, 2024. Red Dress Day honours missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous people. Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nMMEIP bigger local crisis than people realize\n\nJes Croucher, president of the Nistawoyou Association Friendship Centre,\u00a0says the crisis is much larger in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo than people realize. A local database dating back to the early 1970s has the names of 55 Indigenous people who are murdered or missing in the region.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of work to be done. This crisis is the result of historical, intergenerational and present-day trauma. We need supports in all different ways to allow us to be who we are and heal in our own way,\u201d she said.\n\nThe most recent Statistics Canada data from 2022 found Indigenous people represented 27 per cent of homicide victims reported that year. The National Inquiry into the MMIWGS2 crisis found perpetrators are often \u201cpartners, casual acquaintances and serial killers.\u201d\n\nStatistics Canada also notes \u201cIndigenous identity itself remained a risk factor for violent victimization of women which was not found for men.\u201d Indigenous 2SLGBTQI+ peoples also report high rates of physical and sexual violence.\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada reports Indigenous women are more likely to report physical and sexual violence as a child than men (14 per cent versus five per cent) and three times more likely to report spousal violence than non-Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cI hope people realize how much of a hotspot Fort McMurray is for this,\u201d said Mitchel Bowers, chair of Pride YMM and a two-spirit Metis person. \u201cThere\u2019s always more work to be done.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\nToggle full screen mode\nPrevious Gallery Image\nA woman marches through downtown Fort McMurray while carrying the names of with the names of Amber Tuccaro, Sherri Flett and Ellie Herman on Red Dress Day on May 5, 2024. {"url": "https://calgary.ctvnews.ca/cannot-be-silenced-hundreds-gather-for-sisters-in-spirit-walk-and-vigil-in-lethbridge-1.6590666", "title": "Lethbridge Spirit Walk and Vigil addresses issue of missing and murdered women | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nCALGARY\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nCALGARY\nNews\n\u2018Cannot be silenced\u2019, hundreds gather for Sisters in Spirit Walk and Vigil in Lethbridge\nThe Native\u2019s Women Association of Canada says more than 4,000 Indigenous woman were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\nKarsen Marczuk\nCTV News Lethbridge Video Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPublished Oct. 5, 2023 2:48 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nHundreds sang, chanted and drummed from city hall to Galt Gardens Wednesday evening for the 17th annual Sisters in Spirit Vigil and Memorial March.\n\nTheir voices carried through the streets of downtown, with calls to address missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit peoples.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very important that everyone comes out and shows their support, especially for the families and everyone to come together as a community to create that reconciliation,\u201d said Selena Medicine Shield, who was the emcee of the event.\n\nThe annual walk is to honour of missing Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people across Canada.\n\nThe annual walk is to honour of missing Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people across Canada.\n\nMedicine Shield took part in the evening to honour her grandmother Gloria Black Plume who was murdered in 1999.\n\n\u201cShe never got justice so I go around and advocate in her honour and I make sure that children are aware of their surroundings,\u201d she said. \u201cI think it's vital for them to be cared for and their well-being because they\u2019re our next generations to come.\u201d\n\nOrganizers say homicide rates are five times higher for Indigenous women compared to non-indigenous women.\n\nThe Native\u2019s Women Association of Canada says more than 4,000 Indigenous woman were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\n\u201cTo me, it really means a lot as someone who has been sexually assaulted and to be a victim to someone getting lost in my family,\u201d said Lenn Crowshoe, who spoke at the vigil and is Jr. Miss Piikani Princess. \u201cWatching everyone else enjoy my speech and just them being here, I couldn't ask for more.\u201d\n\nThose in attendance wore red - a colour calling on the creator to bring those missing or murdered home.\n\n\u201cWe cannot be silenced,\u201d Crowshoe said. \u201cAs a First Nations person, we are still here and we are still thriving and we are still dealing with this trauma.\u201d\n\nPrayers, songs and story telling took place throughout the evening. Medicine Shield says the awareness shouldn't just happen on October 4.\n\n\u201cToday is not the only day that their (families are) going to be grieving, it's going to be for the rest of the year so we need to offer that support,\u201d Medicine Shield said.\n\nIn 2021, the City of Lethbridge proclaimed October 4 as Sisters in Spirit Day to help bring awareness to these tragedies.\n\nReport an
