Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nHundreds march through Fort McMurray on Red Dress Day\n\nHundreds of Indigenous and non-Indigenous people as they marched through downtown Fort McMurray for Red Dress Day.\n\nEvery May 5, Red Dress Day\u00a0honours the memories of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people (MMIWG2S). In the Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo region, some organizers have embraced the MMEIP acronym\u2014missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous people.\n\nJes Croucher, president of the Nistawoyou Association Friendship Centre,\u00a0says the crisis is much larger in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo than people realize. A local database dating back to the early 1970s has the names of 55 Indigenous people who are murdered or missing in the region.\n\nGP Herald Tribune Newsletter\n\nSign up now and stay connected to all the latest GP Herald Tribune news.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe most recent Statistics Canada data from 2022 found Indigenous people represented 27 per cent of homicide victims reported that year.\u00a0The National Inquiry into the MMIWGS2 crisis found perpetrators are often \u201cpartners, casual acquaintances and serial killers.\u201d\n\n\u201cI hope people realize how much of a hotspot Fort McMurray is for this,\u201d said Mitchel Bowers, chair of Pride YMM and a two-spirit Metis person. \u201cThere\u2019s always more work to be done.\u201d\n\nMore photos of the gathering are\u00a0in the article.\n\nCouncillor Keith McGrath at Shell Place for the swearing-in ceremony of the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo\u2019s council on Oct. 25, 2021. Photo by Greg Halinda of Greg Halinda Photography for the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo jpg, FM\n\nMcGrath chairing interim FMWBEDT board, Weidlich out as CEO and president\n\nCouncillor Keith McGrath has been elected chair of an interim board for the region\u2019s economic development group after council unanimously voted last month to fire the old board.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKevin Weidlich, who served as\u00a0president and CEO of the group since 2018, is no longer with Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo Economic Development and Tourism (FMWBEDT).\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s been a more critical time that we actually not just promote our community, but use the assets we have,\u201d said McGrath in an interview. \u201cThe old board had a wonderful bunch of people but it was time for council to take some responsibility for a return to our ratepayers.\u201d\n\nIt was McGrath who proposed the motion to\u00a0fire the previous board of directors at an April 9 council meeting. In recent years, McGrath has accused FMWBEDT of underdelivering on promises to bring investment at a time when it\u2019s desperately needed for Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn an April interview, Weidlich defended FMWBEDT\u2019s economic record. He also argued building relationships with investors and promoting the region\u2019s brand is a long-term process. Many councillors, however, said they were frustrated with FMWBEDT\u2019s progress during the April 9 meeting.\n\nCouncillor Stu Wigle will be vice chair. RMWB CAO Henry Hunter has been appointed director. Mayor Sandy Bowman is ex officio director. The board will continue reporting updates to council. Dennis Vroom, an RMWB senior strategic advisor, is guiding operations on an interim basis. McGrath says a permanent board will be appointed \u201cin due time.\u201d\n\nAn aerial view of Suncor\u2019s tailings pond 5 at their oilsands mining and upgrading facility north of Fort McMurray, Alta. on June 18, 2013. Ryan Jackson/Postmedia Network\n\nTany Yao chairing committee to hasten reclaiming oilsands tailings ponds\n\nA committee to hasten reclamation efforts of oilsands tailings ponds will be chaired by Tany Yao, UCP MLA for Fort McMurray-Wood Buffalo, and include Jim Boucher, the former chief of the Fort McKay First Nation.\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe committee has been tasked with studying and proposing policies to allow tailings reclamation to be done as quickly and safely as possible.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going to be doing a very thorough and very robust investigation into tailings pond water and how we remediate that,\u201d said Yao. \u201cWater is such a valuable resource and we need to treat it like gold.\u201d\n\nThe Alberta government says oilsands operators have cut the amount of fresh water used per barrel by 23 per cent since 2017. All operators came in below approved volume limits in 2022. But for now, the ponds hold roughly 1.6 trillion litres of liquid waste and cover roughly 300 square kilometres, or nearly half the size of Edmonton.\n\nA delivery truck with the Wood Buffalo Food Bank outside the food bank\u2019s Centennial Drive location in downtown Fort McMurray on Thursday, July 22, 2021. Scott McLean/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network jpg, FM\n\nWood Buffalo Food Bank hosts 10th spring food drive as demand rises\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Wood Buffalo Food Bank collected enough food to equal the weight of one of the municipality\u2019s public transit busses during their annual spring food drive. So far this year, the food bank has handed out enough food to people to equal the weight of roughly two more busses.\n\nVolunteers outside grocery stores across Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo collected 20,503 lbs of food and raised $20,730. The annual food drive comes as the food bank faces record demand for its services in the region.\n\nSince January, 40,313 lbs of food has been given to 12,146 people. About 34.46 per cent of recipients are children and 11.04 per cent are seniors. The monthly value of the food given out to people is roughly $141,901.\n\nBurnco said Thursday that it has entered a share purchase agreement with Brookfield Business Partners to acquire Calgary-based Hammerstone Infrastructure Materials Ltd. Photo by Darren Makowichuk/Postmedia Network\n\nCalgary-based Burnco acquires large Fort McMurray limestone quarry\n\nAdvertisement 9\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOne of Western Canada\u2019s largest limestone quarries is now owned by Calgary-based Burnco Rock Products Ltd. after the company announced Thursday that it had acquired a Calgary-based company owned by a New York-based private equity firm.\n\nUntil Thursday, Hammerstone owned the Hammerstone Quarry, a limestone deposit located north of Fort McMurray.\n\nThe quarry has more than 750-million tonnes of limestone reserves, \u201crepresenting generations of supply,\u201d BURNCO said in a release.\n\nBurnco, a private company, did not disclose the sale price or financial details around the acquisition. However, the acquisition means a Canadian company will be in full control of Hammerstone Quarry.\n\nHammerstone currently employs 110 people.\n\nAdvertisement 10\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSuncor Energy\u2019s base plant with upgraders north of Fort McMurray, Alta. on Wednesday September 27, 2017. Vincent McDermott/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network PHOTO BY VINCE MCDERMOTT /Vince Mcdermott/Today Staff\n\nSuncor aims to gain \u2018unique\u2019 advantage from Trans Mountain pipeline\n\nSuncor says it hopes to remove middlemen and directly negotiate with new customers for a \u201cunique\u201d advantage once it starts shipping to new markets through the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion.\n\nThe Alberta-based company recently reported net earnings of $1.6 billion and an all-time high in\u00a0oilsands\u00a0production during the first quarter of 2024.\n\nDave Oldreive, Suncor\u2019s executive vice-president of downstream, said\u00a0the company has leased vessels operating in the Pacific Ocean, which will give it an advantage in terms of shipping costs.\n\nHe expects crude oil in the pipeline to reach markets in California and Asia. He added Suncor\u2019s trading offices are working to \u201cstrengthen relationships\u201d with those markets so the company can directly negotiate with customers and get better deals.\n\nAdvertisement 11\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOther oil producers including Cenovus, MEG Energy and Canadian Natural Resources have also said they expect the pipeline to improve conditions for Canadian companies.\n\nOne of 27 municipal bus shelters that were damaged during a weekend vandalism spree in Fort McMurray. Image by the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo\n\nPolice investigating weekend vandalism spree to 27 bus\u00a0shelters:\u00a0The RMWB says this type of vandalism is becoming more common and repairs will get more expensive. The RMWB has spent more than $63,800 repairing vandalized bus shelters during the last two years.\n\nMan pleads guilty to making threats about planes arriving at airport:\u00a0Bradley Love, 65, plead guilty to uttering threats. Love was arrested in August after making threatening comments about planes arriving at the Fort McMurray International Airport. Love, who has a history of hate crime and harassment convictions, was angry Indigenous people fleeing wildfires were coming to the community.\n\nAdvertisement 12\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShots fired near Fort Chipewyan Airport actually from pellet gun:\u00a0No one was injured in a shooting at the Fort Chipewyan Airport last week because the incident allegedly involved a pellet gun. In both incidents, no injuries were reported. The man had shot the home after midnight and ran away. A police dog tracked him down and an emergency response team contained the area. The man surrendered to police without incident. No injuries were reported.\n\nAlberta Roundup\n\nPremier Danielle Smith shares in some multicoloured celebrations during the Hindu celebration of Holi in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. Photo by Brent Calver/Postmedia Network\n\nDoggone hero:\u00a0Craig Campbell was hiking with his Doberman outside Cochrane when they\u00a0accidentally bumped into a grizzly bear and her cubs. Campbell, 70, had bear spray but it was stuck under his jacket. His dog, Night, silently charged the bear. The bear and her cubs left. Campbell rewarded night with an extra raw chicken leg. Alberta Fish and Wildlife warns hikers and hunters that\u00a0bear spray and other deterrents should always be easy to grab in an emergency.\nBag ban banned:\u00a0Calgary\u2019s city council has\u00a0repealed a bylaw charging customers for plastic bags and other single-use items. The 12-3 vote ends a bylaw that was passed in January, although private businesses are still allowed to charge people if they choose. The RMWB passed its ban on most plastic bags in 2009.\nPainful realization:\u00a0The 2022 plan to buy five million bottles of Turkish acetaminophen and ibuprofen cost Alberta $80 million. But by the time the medication arrived, the shortage in medications had been resolved. It turns out\u00a0AHS warned the Alberta government about this exact scenario. AHS also told hospitals to\u00a0stop using the medication\u00a0last July because of quality concerns. The province does not know what to do with the surplus, most of which expires in January 2026.\nElection timing:\u00a0Alberta\u2019s fixed election date could\u00a0move to October. Current legislation calls for provincial elections to be held between March and May. But this means elections could happen during wildfires or floods. {"url": "https://www.mapleridgenews.com/community/maple-ridge-students-walk-550-kms-in-support-of-dtes-women-7361020", "title": "Maple Ridge students walk 550 kms in support of DTES women - Maple Ridge-Pitt Meadows News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.7 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Community\nMaple Ridge students walk 550 kms in support of DTES women\nThe Garibaldi Secondary fundraiser was in honour of Red Dress Day\n\tColleen Flanagan\n\nMay 16, 2024 6:00 PM\nMay 16, 2024 6:01 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nGaribaldi Secondary students wore the names of murdered and missing Indigenous women as they walked laps in honour of Red Dress Day. (Special to The News)\nListen to this article\n00:03:15\n\nStudents at Garibaldi Secondary School collectively walked about the distance between Prince George and Terrace to raise money for women and those who identify as women on the Downtown Eastside.\n\nThe fundraiser was in honour of Red Dress Day, a national day of awareness for murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls on May 5, and included a presentation on the history of the day, and a history of the Highway of Tears.\n\nSystemic failures and barriers that many Indigenous women and their families experience when reporting and dealing with police were also discussed.\n\nStudents researched the names of women, girls, those who identify as two-spirit, and others who are part of the murdered and missing Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit crisis. They wrote the names of the people they researched on little red dresses which they pinned to their clothing as they walked 1,352 laps around the school\u2019s track \u2013 about 550 kilometres.\n\n\u201cWe included a video of one of the walks on the Highway of Tears to ensure the students could hear directly from the community. Due to the significance of the day, it was important to us to meaningfully front-load the classes and students to assist with an overall understanding of why we are choosing to work together as a community to bring awareness to the national issue, said Sofie Van De Keere, a French teacher at the school and one of four organizers of the event. Other organizers included Beth MacDougall, Emma Daignault, and Becky Chappell-Moss \u2013 all members of the school\u2019s Anti-Racism and Equity Committee, formed in October 2022. The committee works to create initiatives throughout the school year in hopes of celebrating the diverse natures of students and staff like Cultural Days, guest speakers, and awareness for problems of inequity in our community.\n\nRELATED: First Nations leaders in B.C. call for action on Red Dress Day\n\nVan De Keere said both the research and walk helped students understand the crisis on a human level, as opposed to focusing on the numbers of women who have gone missing or been murdered.\n\nThis was the first year that Garibaldi Secondary had a mandatory school-wide initiative.\n\n\u201cThis was an especially significant day for many of our staff, as some of us are personally connected to this crisis \u2013 teachers in our school have taught girls who are now a part of the MMIWG2S crisis. It was also a healing experience for many staff and students through a drumming circle led by one of our colleagues, in which they sang the Women\u2019s Warrior Song, and Men\u2019s Warrior Song,\u201d explained Van De Keere.\n\nALSO: Red dresses honour murdered and missing Indigenous women\n\nThe walk took place over the course of a week and students were able to raise more than $500 for the Downtown Eastside Women\u2019s Centre, which provides staff support, meals, counseling, advocacy, and programs for self-identifying women who live on the Downtown Eastside.\n\nVan De Keere said the centre was a perfect place to donate the money because the centre empowers and uplifts women, girls and two-spirit individuals.\n\n\u201cNot only this, but the centre also provides very specific programming to Indigenous women through the Indigenous Women\u2019s Project,\u201d said Van De Keere.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Colleen Flanagan\n\nI got my start with Black Press Media in 2003 as a photojournalist.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tMaple Ridge woman sentenced to probation for fatal crash\n\t\tPolice have Maple Ridge stabbing suspect in custody\n\t\tMaple Ridge Walmart closed by teen stabbing on Canada Day\n\t\tMaple Ridge doctors honoured with annual awards\n\t\tMetro Parks department brings forest bathing to Maple Ridge\nFacebook Comments (0) \nShare this content:\nBlack Press Media\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nUse This and Never Have to Change Your Whipper Snipper Line Again\nUltraCut\n|\nSponsored\nWrap Foil Around Door knobs When Alone, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians Born 1944 - {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/highway-of-tears-walk/cp1165705073", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Vernon, S|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\n26.9\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nFamilies walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women\nLaura Kane\nTamara Chipman, who went missing in Prince Rupert, B.C. in 2005, will be honoured at an annual walk along the Highway of Tears. THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO-Gladys Radek MANDATORY CREDIT\nRepublished September 20, 2017 - 8:56 AM\nOriginal Publication Date September 20, 2017 - 7:56 AM\n\nVANCOUVER - When Gladys Radek walks the Highway of Tears, she says she can feel the spirits of women who are missing or have been murdered walking beside her.\n\nDozens have vanished or been killed along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 in central British Columbia. On Thursday, Radek will honour the 12th anniversary of the disappearance of her niece, Tamara Lynn Chipman, by walking the route once again.\n\n\"You can feel the pain of the families when they're walking with you,\" she said. \"It's really, really hard to describe.\"\n\nThe annual journey, made by Radek and others who have lost loved ones, will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers. Vehicles will accompany the walkers who will cover sections of the route in a relay fashion.\n\nCommissioners of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls are set to join the walk on Sept. 25 before community hearings are held from Sept. 26 to 28 in Smithers. This is the second set of hearings held to date by the inquiry, after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nSince then, the inquiry's executive director, Michele Moreau, and one of its commissioners, Marilyn Poitras, have quit and the Native Women's Association of Ontario has pulled its support. The inquiry has faced growing calls for resignations and a restart.\n\nAsked whether commissioners feel added pressure to ensure these hearings are successful, Chief Commissioner Marion Buller said they feel that obligation regardless.\n\n\"They have to be (successful), not only for our purposes, but more so for the families who come forward and share their stories with us. It's the success from their perspective that's the most important aspect for us,\" she said.\n\n\"We're always under scrutiny. Always. And we always will be,\" she added. \"I'm always open to constructive, informed criticism, as are the other commissioners. It's part of our work.\"\n\nThe federal government launched the inquiry last year to examine the systemic issues behind the high number of Indigenous women who have been killed or disappeared over the last four decades in Canada. It is expected to take two years and cost almost $54 million.\n\nBuller said the commission will ask for more money and time but it is still conducting an internal analysis before making the request.\n\nAbout 25 people, including family members and survivors of violence, are expected to testify publicly or privately at the Dze L K'Ant Friendship Centre next week. A statement-taker will be available for anyone who wishes to speak, with no pre-registration needed, said Buller.\n\nRadek will testify about Chipman, who disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert on Sept. 21, 2005. The 22-year-old was a beautiful, charming free spirit who had a young son, she recalled.\n\nCritics of the inquiry don't understand how much ground it has to cover, said Radek, who sits on its national family advisory circle.\n\n\"It's not as simple as two years of work. These people, these commissioners and the staff that they have working right now, they are uncovering the stones that should have been turned a long time ago,\" she said.\n\nPeople living along the Highway of Tears had to wait years for the provincial government to carry out a key recommendation of the B.C. inquiry into missing and murdered women, said Terry Tegee, tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council.\n\nThe recommendation \u2014 reliable public transit along the route \u2014 was finally implemented earlier this year. But the experience has led Teegee to call for the federal inquiry to have more teeth. Like the missing inquiry in B.C., the recommendations from the national inquiry will be non-binding.\n\nTeegee also said he's concerned that people in small communities that still lack transit won't be able to participate in the Smithers hearings.\n\nBuller said staff have visited nearby towns in recent weeks to reach out to families and it is able to help cover travel costs including mileage and meals, she said.\n\nThe hearings will be the first of nine this fall, with other stops in Winnipeg, Halifax, Edmonton, Yellowknife, Saskatoon, Sask., Maliotenam, Que., Thunder Bay, Ont., and Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2017\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are emailed reader responses to {"url": "http://www.680news.com/2017/09/20/families-walk-highway-of-tears-to-honour-missing-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women", "body": "Toronto\nAbout\nContact\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nTraffic\nGas Prices\nContests & Events\nWATCH LIVE\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nFamilies walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women\n\nBy Laura Kane, The Canadian Press\n\nPosted September 20, 2017 10:52 am.\n\n \n\nLast Updated September 20, 2017 12:20 pm.\n\nThis article is more than 5 years old.\n\nVANCOUVER \u2013 When Gladys Radek walks the Highway of Tears, she says she can feel the spirits of women who are missing or have been murdered walking beside her.\n\nDozens have vanished or been killed along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 in central British Columbia. On Thursday, Radek will honour the 12th anniversary of the disappearance of her niece, Tamara Lynn Chipman, by walking the route once again.\n\n\u201cYou can feel the pain of the families when they\u2019re walking with you,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s really, really hard to describe.\u201d\n\nThe annual journey, made by Radek and others who have lost loved ones, will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers. Vehicles will accompany the walkers who will cover sections of the route in a relay fashion.\n\nCommissioners of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls are set to join the walk on Sept. 25 before community hearings are held from Sept. 26 to 28 in Smithers. This is the second set of hearings held to date by the inquiry, after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nSince then, the inquiry\u2019s executive director, Michele Moreau, and one of its commissioners, Marilyn Poitras, have quit and the Native Women\u2019s Association of Ontario has pulled its support. The inquiry has faced growing calls for resignations and a restart.\n\nAsked whether commissioners feel added pressure to ensure these hearings are successful, Chief Commissioner Marion Buller said they feel that obligation regardless.\n\n\u201cThey have to be (successful), not only for our purposes, but more so for the families who come forward and share their stories with us. It\u2019s the success from their perspective that\u2019s the most important aspect for us,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always under scrutiny. Always. And we always will be,\u201d she added. \u201cI\u2019m always open to constructive, informed criticism, as are the other commissioners. It\u2019s part of our work.\u201d\n\nThe federal government launched the inquiry last year to examine the systemic issues behind the high number of Indigenous women who have been killed or disappeared over the last four decades in Canada. It is expected to take two years and cost almost $54 million.\n\nBuller said the commission will ask for more money and time but it is still conducting an internal analysis before making the request.\n\nAbout 25 people, including family members and survivors of violence, are expected to testify publicly or privately at the Dze L K\u2019Ant Friendship Centre next week. A statement-taker will be available for anyone who wishes to speak, with no pre-registration needed, said Buller.\n\nRadek will testify about Chipman, who disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert on Sept. 21, 2005. The 22-year-old was a beautiful, charming free spirit who had a young son, she recalled.\n\nCritics of the inquiry don\u2019t understand how much ground it has to cover, said Radek, who sits on its national family advisory circle.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not as simple as two years of work. These people, these commissioners and the staff that they have working right now, they are uncovering the stones that should have been turned a long time ago,\u201d she said.\n\nPeople living along the Highway of Tears had to wait years for the provincial government to carry out a key recommendation of the B.C. inquiry into missing and murdered women, said Terry Tegee, tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council.\n\nThe recommendation \u2014 reliable public transit along the route \u2014 was finally implemented earlier this year. But the experience has led Teegee to call for the federal inquiry to have more teeth. Like the missing inquiry in B.C., the recommendations from the national inquiry will be non-binding.\n\nTeegee also said he\u2019s concerned that people in small communities that still lack transit won\u2019t be able to participate in the Smithers hearings.\n\nBuller said staff have visited nearby towns in recent weeks to reach out to families and it is able to help cover travel costs including mileage and meals, she said.\n\nThe hearings will be the first of nine this fall, with other stops in Winnipeg, Halifax, Edmonton, Yellowknife, Saskatoon, Sask., Maliotenam, Que., Thunder Bay, Ont., and Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nTorontonians can now toss their used coffee cups in the blue bin\n1 dead, 2 others injured in crash on eastbound Gardiner\nToronto daycare rolls back staff wage raises, blames Ontario's funding model\nThe 680 NewsRadio Toronto Weather Guarantee\u2122\nFirst GST/HST credit payment from 2023 tax returns set to arrive July 5\nTop Stories\nLCBO, union still 'very far apart' as Friday strike looms\n\n1h ago\n\nTorontonians can now toss their used coffee cups in the blue bin\n\n28m ago\n\nThe Spadina Sprint: A CityNews experiment\n\n4h ago\n\nWeekend need-to-know: Summerlicious begins and salsa takes over St. Clair\n\n1h ago\n\nMost Watched Today\n3:28\nUnion, province remain far apart in LCBO negotiations\n\nWith less than 24 hours away from a possible strike at LCBO stores across Ontario, the union says they are still far from reaching a deal in negotiations with\u00a0the province. (Jonathan Hayward / THE CANADIAN PRESS)\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nVANCOUVER -- When Gladys Radek walks the Highway of Tears, she says she can feel the spirits of women who are missing or have been murdered walking beside her.\n\nDozens have vanished or been killed along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 in central British Columbia. On Thursday, Radek will honour the 12th anniversary of the disappearance of her niece, Tamara Lynn Chipman, by walking the route once again.\n\n\"You can feel the pain of the families when they're walking with you,\" she said. \"It's really, really hard to describe.\"\n\nRelated Stories\nB.C. teaching material that uses derogatory term pulled for review\nWorkers to support families for missing and murdered Indigenous women inquiry\nTrudeau splits Indigenous file, two rookies appointed to front bench in cabinet shuffle\n\nThe annual journey, made by Radek and others who have lost loved ones, will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers. Vehicles will accompany the walkers who will cover sections of the route in a relay fashion.\n\nCommissioners of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls are set to join the walk on Sept. 25 before community hearings are held from Sept. 26 to 28 in Smithers. This is the second set of hearings held to date by the inquiry, after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nSince then, the inquiry's executive director, Michele Moreau, and one of its commissioners, Marilyn Poitras, have quit and the Native Women's Association of Ontario has pulled its support. The inquiry has faced growing calls for resignations and a restart.\n\nAsked whether commissioners feel added pressure to ensure these hearings are successful, Chief Commissioner Marion Buller said they feel that obligation regardless.\n\n\"They have to be (successful), not only for our purposes, but more so for the families who come forward and share their stories with us. It's the success from their perspective that's the most important aspect for us,\" she said.\n\n\"We're always under scrutiny. Always. And we always will be,\" she added. \"I'm always open to constructive, informed criticism, as are the other commissioners. It's part of our work.\"\n\nThe federal government launched the inquiry last year to examine the systemic issues behind the high number of Indigenous women who have been killed or disappeared over the last four decades in Canada. It is expected to take two years and cost almost $54 million.\n\nBuller said the commission will ask for more money and time but it is still conducting an internal analysis before making the request.\n\nAbout 25 people, including family members and survivors of violence, are expected to testify publicly or privately at the Dze L K'Ant Friendship Centre next week. A statement-taker will be available for anyone who wishes to speak, with no pre-registration needed, said Buller.\n\nRadek will testify about Chipman, who disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert on Sept. 21, 2005. The 22-year-old was a beautiful, charming free spirit who had a young son, she recalled.\n\nCritics of the inquiry don't understand how much ground it has to cover, said Radek, who sits on its national family advisory circle.\n\n\"It's not as simple as two years of work. These people, these commissioners and the staff that they have working right now, they are uncovering the stones that should have been turned a long time ago,\" she said.\n\nPeople living along the Highway of Tears had to wait years for the provincial government to carry out a key recommendation of the B.C. inquiry into missing and murdered women, said Terry Tegee, tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council.\n\nThe recommendation -- reliable public transit along the route -- was finally implemented earlier this year. But the experience has led Teegee to call for the federal inquiry to have more teeth. Like the missing inquiry in B.C., the recommendations from the national inquiry will be non-binding.\n\nTeegee also said he's concerned that people in small communities that still lack transit won't be able to participate in the Smithers hearings.\n\nBuller said staff have visited nearby towns in recent weeks to reach out to families and it is able to help cover travel costs including mileage and meals, she said.\n\nThe hearings will be the first of nine this fall, with other stops in Winnipeg, Halifax, Edmonton, Yellowknife, Saskatoon, Sask., Maliotenam, Que., Thunder Bay, Ont., and Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport an error\nEditorial standards and\u00a0policies\nWhy you can trust CTV\u00a0News\nMORE NEWS FROM CANADA\nBorder workers who nearly went on strike in June ratify new contract\n'Finally I know who I am': Holocaust survivor\u2019s daughter reunited with long lost brother in Poland\n'It's a lot to digest': Calgary man wins $66M on Lotto 6-49 draw\n'Not my finest moment:' Police called to dispute between Ottawa city councillor and daycare owner\nWhat you need to know about a possible LCBO strike on Friday\nInstant noodle products sold in B.C., Alta., Ont. recalled due to undeclared peanut\nTOP VIDEOS\nfalse\nQue. students accuse teacher of profiting off their artwork\nfalse\nCar thefts in Canada: Insurance companies face criticism\nfalse\n$50K reward offered in case of missing Barrie, Ont. woman\nCTVNEWS.CA TOP STORIES\nTrying to sell or buy a home this summer? Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women\nAuthor of the article:\nLaura Kane \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 The Canadian Press\nPublished Sep 20, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nTamara Chipman, who went missing in Prince Rupert, B.C. in 2005, will be honoured at an annual walk along the Highway of Tears. PHOTO BY GLADYS RADEK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\nArticle content\n\nWhen Gladys Radek walks the Highway of Tears, she says she can feel the spirits of women who are missing or have been murdered walking beside her.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nDozens have vanished or been killed along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 in central British Columbia. On Thursday, Radek will honour the 12th anniversary of the disappearance of her niece, Tamara Lynn Chipman, by walking the route once again.\n\n\u201cYou can feel the pain of the families when they\u2019re walking with you,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s really, really hard to describe.\u201d\n\nThe annual journey, made by Radek and others who have lost loved ones, will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers. Vehicles will accompany the walkers who will cover sections of the route in a relay fashion.\n\nCommissioners of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls are set to join the walk on Sept. 25 before community hearings are held from Sept. 26 to 28 in Smithers. This is the second set of hearings held to date by the inquiry, after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nCanucks Report\n\nEssential reading for hockey fans who eat, sleep, Canucks, repeat.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSince then, the inquiry\u2019s executive director, Michele Moreau, and one of its commissioners, Marilyn Poitras, have quit and the Native Women\u2019s Association of Ontario has pulled its support. The inquiry has faced growing calls for resignations and a restart.\n\nAsked whether commissioners feel added pressure to ensure these hearings are successful, Chief Commissioner Marion Buller said they feel that obligation regardless.\n\n\u201cThey have to be (successful), not only for our purposes, but more so for the families who come forward and share their stories with us. It\u2019s the success from their perspective that\u2019s the most important aspect for us,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always under scrutiny. Always. And we always will be,\u201d she added. \u201cI\u2019m always open to constructive, informed criticism, as are the other commissioners. It\u2019s part of our work.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe federal government launched the inquiry last year to examine the systemic issues behind the high number of Indigenous women who have been killed or disappeared over the last four decades in Canada. It is expected to take two years and cost almost $54 million.\n\nBuller said the commission will ask for more money and time but it is still conducting an internal analysis before making the request.\n\nAbout 25 people, including family members and survivors of violence, are expected to testify publicly or privately at the Dze L K\u2019Ant Friendship Centre next week. A statement-taker will be available for anyone who wishes to speak, with no pre-registration needed, said Buller.\n\nBillboard warning girls not to hitchhike on the Highway of Tears (Highway 16) where many young women have gone missing. This is just north of Smithers. PHOTO BY STEVE BOSCH /Vancouver Sun\n\nRadek will testify about Chipman, who disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert on Sept. 21, 2005. The 22-year-old was a beautiful, charming free spirit who had a young son, she recalled.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCritics of the inquiry don\u2019t understand how much ground it has to cover, said Radek, who sits on its national family advisory circle.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not as simple as two years of work. These people, these commissioners and the staff that they have working right now, they are uncovering the stones that should have been turned a long time ago,\u201d she said.\n\nPeople living along the Highway of Tears had to wait years for the provincial government to carry out a key recommendation of the B.C. inquiry into missing and murdered women, said Terry Tegee, tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council.\n\nThe recommendation \u2014 reliable public transit along the route \u2014 was finally implemented earlier this year. But the experience has led Teegee to call for the federal inquiry to have more teeth. Like the missing inquiry in B.C., the recommendations from the national inquiry will be non-binding.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nTeegee also said he\u2019s concerned that people in small communities that still lack transit won\u2019t be able to participate in the Smithers hearings.\n\nBuller said staff have visited nearby towns in recent weeks to reach out to families and it is able to help cover travel costs including mileage and meals, she said.\n\nThe hearings will be the first of nine this fall, with other stops in Winnipeg, Halifax, Edmonton, Yellowknife, Saskatoon, Sask., Maliotenam, Que., Thunder Bay, Ont., and Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Vernon/422479/Indigenous-showcases-coming-to-an-end-in-Vernon-for-now", "title": "Indigenous showcases coming to an end in Vernon - for now - Vernon News - Castanet.net", "body": "26\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nVernon\u00a0\u00a0\nIndigenous showcases coming to an end in Vernon - for now\nSHOWCASES COME TO A CLOSE\nChelsey Mutter - Apr 24, 2023 / 2:25 pm | Story: 422479\nPhoto: Glohaven Community Events\n\nVernon\u2019s Indigenous showcases are coming to a close.\n\nHost Glohaven Community Events, says it has been unable to secure a grant to keep the project going.\n\nThe May 2 showcase will \u201cunfortunately be the last in this series (for now),\u201d says co-founder Angela Case.\n\nThe final event will again take place at the Towne Theatre, with doors open at 5:30 and the showcase at 6 p.m.\n\nThe 19-plus event will raise awareness of the missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit issue. It comes just before Red Dress Day on May 5, a national day of recognition.\n\nTickets are $11 and can be purchased here.\n\nChelssie Baker, Glohaven\u2019s indigenous relations and content manager, says she\u2019s emotional about them ending.\n\n\u201cWe put in so much hard work and effort, and the community has just been amazing, too. It's really sad.\u201d\n\n\u201cI believe that there's so many more amazing things that we're going to do. This is not goodbye, it's just the beginning.\u201d\n\nAuroara Leigh, a victim of human trafficking, will share her healing journey with the audience.\n\n\u201cIn her songs, she reflects on her trauma, but through healing,\u201d says Baker.\n\nThe documentary Adaawk will run after Leigh\u2019s performance. In the film, families share their stories of loved ones missing and murdered along B.C.'s infamous Highway of Tears. The content may be upsetting to some.\n\nThere will also be a wine bar with selections from Indigenous World Winery, and vendors on site with a variety of First Nation goods, including Leigh\u2019s book IndigenEyes.\n\n\u201cAny money that we make on that day is going to Jewels of HOPE,\u201d says Baker.\n\nJewels of HOPE says it's mission it to: \u201ccreate a context for marginalized women in the Okanagan to gather in a safe place to make jewellery, which will then be sold online and in retail stores.\u201d\n\nGlohaven says the showcases may return in a different form at varying locations.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n11\nShares\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Vernon News\n\n\n\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in prison for murder\nAbbotsford - 1:39 pm\nA parade of aches and pains\nCalgary - 1:27 pm\nPower restored in Aberdeen\nKamloops - 1:16 pm\nMore Top Stories >\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReal Estate\n#16-644 Lequime Road\n4 bedrooms 4 baths\n$818,000\nmore details\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSalmon Arm SPCA Featured Pet\n\n\nPiper\nSalmon Arm SPCA >\n\n\n\n\n\nBody transformation journeys\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\nVanessa Hudgens gives birth\nShowbiz | July 04, 2024\nBaseball playing pup\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nMischievous Beagle caught tearing up the toilet paper\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nVintage bathrooms\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\n\n\n\nNorth Okanagan Quick Links\nCity of Vernon\nVernon Discussion Forum\nDistrict of Coldstream\nVillage of Lumby\nCity of Armstrong\nCity of Enderby\nDistrict of Sicamous\nInterior Health\nOkanagan Regional Library\n\u00a9 2024 Castanet.net Make Castanet Your Homepage News Tips Advertising Contact Us"},

Ceremonies were held across the country, including in Halifax where people gathered to honour lost loved ones and push for change. Megan King has more \u2013 May 5, 2023\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nA crowd gathered at Halifax\u2019s Grand Parade on Friday to observe Red Dress Day \u2014 a day of remembrance for Canada\u2019s missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\n\n\u201cThe red dress\u2026is so important because we want people to remember that these women mean something to us,\u201d Denise John told Global News.\n\nJohn, a victim support navigator with the Mi\u2019Kmaw Native Friendship Centre, experienced the loss of a loved one first hand in 2019 \u2014 the death of Chantel John in southern Newfoundland.\n\n\u201cIn my own community, Chantel got murdered. And in the small community that I\u2019m from, we would never see that,\u201d said John.\n\n\u201cWhen I heard that she got murdered, and it was a horrific act of violence, it changed us forever.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nJohn says there are as many as 4,000 Indigenous women that have gone missing or have been murdered across Canada, including ongoing cases across the country.\n\n\u201cWe have these ladies, these sisters, in Winnipeg that were found in a landfill. And the families are the ones out there on the ground.\u201d\n\nThe latest health and medical news emailed to you every Sunday.\n\nDenise Pictou-Maloney is another advocate who knows what it\u2019s like to lose someone \u2014 her mother was murdered 47 years ago in South Dakota.\n\nView image in full screen\nDenise Pictou-Maloney is remembering her mother on Red Dress Day, who was murdered 47 years ago. She now fights for accountability and change for Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people. Megan King / Global News\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter how many shelters we put up, it doesn\u2019t matter how many alert systems we put out there. If we\u2019re not addressing the violence in our own back yards and the reason why our women are leaving our communities and becoming high risk, then we\u2019re always going to continue to go missing and murdered,\u201d Pictou-Maloney said.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nIn June of 2021, the federal government launched its national action plan to end violence against Indigenous women and girls which contained 231 calls for justice.\n\n\u201cIt seems to be quite organizationally transactional, politically based and, unfortunately, economically challenged,\u201d Pictou-Maloney says. \u201cSo that, unfortunately, impacts our women\u2019s lives because we continue to go missing and murdered, as long as we have those parameters in place.\u201d\n\nJohn continues to worry for her loved ones as the issue persists.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m an auntie. I wouldn\u2019t want something like this happening to my niece or anyone that I love,\u201d John says. \u201cI want to make sure these women are never ever forgotten and that they are honoured.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s why wearing the symbolic and sacred colour red while calling for change works to honour their loved ones.\n\n\u201cSomeone has to, you know, take the first step and hold someone accountable,\u201d Pictou-Maloney says. \u201cWe don\u2019t have an accountability mechanism and we\u2019re going to continue this cycle.\u201d\n\n\u2013With files from Ella MacDonald\n\n1:08\nRed dress day 2023: Liberal MP calls for implementation of alert system ahead of MMIWG2S\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2023 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nDavid Vigneault, director of Canada\u2019s spy agency, to retire\nCanada Post worker saves the day after child forgets stamp on postcard to grandma\nADVERTISEMENT\n630 CHED Afternoons with Bryn Griffiths & Reid Wilkins\n2:00 PM - 5:00 PM\n630CHED\nTrending\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. {"url": "https://www.vicnews.com/community/photos-red-dress-day-honoured-by-langford-schools-with-march-down-goldstream/", "title": "PHOTOS: Red Dress Day honoured by Langford schools with march down Goldstream - Greater Victoria News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.8 \u00b0C\nHome Community\nPHOTOS: Red Dress Day honoured by Langford schools with march down Goldstream\nStudents march from Ruth King to Savory to raise awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women\nBailey Moreton\nMay 5, 2023 12:50 PM\nMay 5, 2023 1:08 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 6 Students from three Langford schools marched along Goldstrem Avenue for Red Dress Day. (Bailey Moreton/News Staff)\nExpand\n\nStudents from three Langford schools marched to commemorate Red Dress Day, a national day of awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people, on Friday (May 5).\n\nThey sang and banged drums as they walked along Goldstrem Avenue from Ruth King Elementary School to Savory Elementary School. Students from the two elementary schools and Spencer Middle School took part.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s time that our younger kids learn more about Indigenous people and their issues,\u201d said Marlene Clifton, a Gitksan woman who works with the Sooke School District. \u201cI think by teaching them in schools, and not watering it down\u2026 (it) is a great thing. I think it\u2019s important because when I went to school, when my children went to school, there was absolutely nothing about Indigenous people. I think the time is right and that\u2019s the way Indigenous people are, everything is a time for things, a time for everything. So this is the right time.\u201d\n\nAfter arriving at Savory there was a ceremony held where elders told stories before bannock was served.\n\nJo-Ina Young, Metis elder with SD62, said she hoped by seeing diversity and inclusion taught in schools there wouldn\u2019t be a need for Red Dress marches in the future.\n\n\u201cSeeing the children come out no matter what nationality they are, they all are expressing their concern for the Indigenous women of Canada. It just raises our hearts and our emotions and our complete pride in being Indigenous people.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day started in 2010 after artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress project inspired the movement to pay respect to the Indigenous victims of racialized and gendered violence in Canada.\n\n\u201cWe also want to share and celebrate the strength of Indigenous women and relay how honoured women are in Indigenous culture and communities,\u201d principal of Savory Elementary School Renee Hislop said in a previous interview with Black Press Media.\n\n\u201cIt is important in our work towards truth and reconciliation, that we teach this to our young people in a way that tells the story of Indigenous peoples both past and present. It\u2019s really important to us that we share this truth in a way that honours but does not traumatize children. Our children are our future, and they are going to make the difference.\u201d\n\n- With files from Ella Matte\n\nREAD MORE: Langford students to hang red dresses to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women\n\n@moreton_bailey\n\n\nbailey.moreton@goldstreamgazette.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tGroup of Langford kids taking Greater Victoria music scene by storm\n\t\tVIDEO: Whales off Greater Victoria captivate shoreline photographers\n\t\tNew group aims to take a run at Sooke's traffic woes\n\t\t5 earthquakes reported off Vancouver Island: USGS\n\t\tUniversity of Victoria to shut down campus pool after a half-century\nFacebook Comments (0) \n'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\nBlack Press Media\nMan charged in ponzi scheme identified as Okanagan drowning victim\nBlack Press Media\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nScatter Soap in Your Yard, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nDiscover the Last Trimmer Head You\u2019ll Ever Need\nUltraCut\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nMan dies throwing candy during Alberta Canada Day parade\nBlack Press Media\nJuly verdict expected for Island woman accused of murdering, cutting up ex\nBlack Press Media\nAlways Keep a Bread Clip in Your Wallet, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians Born 1944 - 1983 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nThis German Nozzle Makes the Water Pressure 15x Stronger\nPowerJet\n|\nSponsored\nFairway Market in Westshore is closing, say staff\nBlack Press Media\nHead-on crash kills 2, blocks access to BC Ferries terminal\nBlack Press Media\nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. {"url": "https://www.theobserver.ca/news/local-news/sarnia-school-participates-in-redress-project", "title": "Sarnia school participates in REDress project | The Sarnia Observer", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nLocal News\nSarnia school participates in REDress project\n\nRed dresses hung at Great Lakes Secondary Friday to raise awareness about missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\n\nAuthor of the article:\nTyler Kula\nPublished Nov 02, 2018 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nGreat Lakes Secondary teacher Andrea Grondin stands by red dresses hung outside the school Friday. Great Lakes was participating in Red Dress Day to draw attention to murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls in Canada. (Tyler Kula/Sarnia Observer)\nArticle content\n\nEmpty red dresses hung from the trees and in the windows at Great Lakes Secondary School Friday, acknowledging the harm Indigenous women and girls have faced in Canada.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Sarnia high school\u2019s 18 crimson articles were up in homage to Winnipeg-base artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project and Red Dress Day, calling attention to the more-than 1,000 murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls, and the national inquiry that\u2019s heard from more than 1,200 families and survivors.\n\n\u201cThe original (awareness) day is on Oct. 4 but it was our homecoming, so we pushed it to now so we could give it proper awareness,\u201d said Andrea Grondin, an Ojibwe and family studies teacher at Great Lakes. The school community includes several students from Aamjiwnaang First Nation, she said.\n\nIt\u2019s the school\u2019s first time participating, said Grondin, also an Aamjiwnaang member, who spearheaded adopting the initiative at Great Lakes.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s part of our healing, part of our past,\u201d she said about the importance of taking part.\n\nThe empty dresses symbolize lives lost and those who are missing.\n\nThe national inquiry finished hearing testimony in October and a final report and recommendations are expected to be submitted to the federal government in April.\n\nStudents in Grondin\u2019s class, she said, helped her gather dress donations, used morning announcements to talk about Red Dress Day, and created a presentation highlighting the disproportionate number of Indigenous women and girls murdered in Canada, despite making up a small part of the overall population.\n\nStudents are getting the message, Grondin said.\n\n\u201cWe watched documentaries, (learned about) specific cases, followed it through the news, the media \u2013 it\u2019s been great,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Lambton Kent District School Board (LKDSB), of which Great Lakes is part, announced Friday its students and staff will be marking Treaties Recognition Week Nov. 5-9, learning about treaties and treaty relationships in Canada.\n\n\u201cThe LKDSB remains committed to supporting the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada: Calls to Action as they relate to education, including furthering our understanding and education about Indigenous histories and perspectives,\u201d board director Jim Costello said, in a statement.\n\nHopes are to grow the REDress project at Great Lakes every year, Grondin said.\n\nGreat Lakes is also encouraging students and staff to wear moccasins on Rock your Mocs Day Nov. 15, she said.\n\u201cThere\u2019s a big push for \u2026 recognizing and spreading awareness through different initiatives through the school board,\u201d she said.\n\ntkula@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social {"url": "http://calgaryherald.com/news/national/families-walk-highway-of-tears-ahead-of-missing-murdered-indigenous-women-hearing", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears ahead of missing, murdered Indigenous women hearing | Calgary Herald", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\nBusiness\nSports\nOpinion\nArts\nLife\nShopping\nUpcoming Events\nNewsletters\nPuzzmo\nDriving\nePaper\nRemembering\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNational\nFamilies walk Highway of Tears ahead of missing, murdered Indigenous women hearing\nAuthor of the article:\nLaura Kane, Postmedia News\nPublished Sep 25, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Sep 26, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nfamily members and advocates of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls walk along the so-called Highway of Tears, in Moricetown, B.C., on Sept. 25, 2017. PHOTO BY DARRYL DYCK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\nArticle content\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2014 Gladys Radek raised a fist in the air and wept as she reached the end of her 350-kilometre journey along British Columbia\u2019s Highway of Tears.\n\nThe Indigenous grandmother finished her walk along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 for the seventh and final time on Monday. It is the same highway where her beloved niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nCalgary martial arts instructor charged with child porn, luring offences\nATCO, AltaLink building 130-kilometre transmission line in central Alberta\nNew E. coli case at daycare chain struck by massive 2023 outbreak\nBell: Calgary councillors and even Gondek blow up pipe probe plans\n'Surreal': Construction worker says $66-million lottery jackpot is gift from God\nArticle content\n\nOutside a community centre in Smithers, her voice shook as she spoke to those who had walked alongside her, including commissioners from the national inquiry into missing and murdered women.\n\n\u201cI want to thank you all for standing so proud and loud, to show our commissioners that we have love for our missing and murdered women,\u201d she said through tears.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very proud of this moment right now because when Tamara went missing, nobody cared. When Tamara went missing, there were many others who were already missing, many others who had been murdered.\u201d\n\nDozens of women have disappeared or been killed along the highway between Prince Rupert and Prince George in central B.C.\n\nRadek and other family members and advocates left Prince Rupert on Thursday and arrived Monday in Smithers, where the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls will hold hearings starting Tuesday.\n\nThe walkers were accompanied by vehicles and have covered sections of the route in a relay fashion, allowing them to complete the walk of hundreds of kilometres over the span of a few days.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nDuring the final stretch through the town of Smithers, Radek, who is missing a leg, drove a car covered in photographs of women who have disappeared or been killed. She wept behind the wheel as passersby waved and honked their horns.\n\nInquiry commissioner Michele Audette joined the group three days ago, while Chief Commissioner Marion Buller joined on Monday. Commissioner Qajaq Robinson was supposed to attend the hearings but had to bow out due to a family emergency.\n\nAudette said she walked to honour the resilience and strength of the families who will be speaking for the first time to the inquiry. The hearings will be powerful, she said.\n\n\u201cI feel it since I arrived; there\u2019s a lot of emotion, lots of anxiety also or stress, because it\u2019s the first time for them,\u201d she said. \u201cJust being there beside them and listening, maybe it\u2019s helped.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry has been plagued by controversy, including the resignation of commissioner Marilyn Poitras this summer and complaints from families about poor communications and delays.\n\nBuller told a Senate committee last week that the inquiry\u2019s work has been hampered by federal bureaucracy.\n\nRhonda Lee McIsaac, who lives in Haida Gwaii and has Ojibway heritage, participated in the walk for the first time and said it was a moving experience.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m walking for everybody who cannot walk,\u201d said McIsaac. \u201cI have lost a loved one. I grew up in foster care and I was adopted out. This is part of my story.\u201d\n\nMore than 40 people have signed up to speak at the Smithers hearings, which run through Thursday. They are the second hearings held by the inquiry after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nRoofers Tested 17 Gutter Guards\u2026 Here\u2019s What They Discovered\nThe Actual Cost of Gutter Guards in 2024 May Surprise You\nLeafFilter Partner\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\n'It was kismet:' How Calgary artist became a co-writer of Beyonce's historic country hit, Texas Hold 'Em\nCalgary Herald\nEx-Flames defenceman Zadorov takes shot at Calgary: \u2018Not even the No. 1 team in Alberta\u2019\nCalgary Herald\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nAlberta Pensioners Are Eligible For Invisible Hearing Aids\nBest Hearing Aids\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nSeniors Are Getting Free Hearing Tests (Here's how)\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nOne Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before, You Will Fit In Your Pants Again!\nBurn Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nStop scanning your lottery ticket, do this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nAlberta Seniors Born Before 1971 Wanted To Test Hearing Aids\nBest Hearing Aids\n|\nSponsored\nNeurologists Approve: These Barefoot Shoes Alleviate Pain Instantly\nBarefoot Vitality\n|\nSponsored\nMOST POPULAR\nCanadian accused of abandoning two kids in Cancun told police she couldn't afford them\nCalgary Herald\nMOST POPULAR\nCharges pending after police identify woman suspected in hate-motivated assault\nCalgary Herald\nEdmonton: Casino Secret They Don't Want You To Know\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nREAD NEXT\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://panow.com/2022/05/05/indigenous-declaration-passes-families-pack-gallery-for-red-dress-day/", "title": "Indigenous declaration passes, families pack gallery for Red Dress Day | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\nSPORTS\nWEATHER\nNEWS\nOBITUARIES\nCLASSIFIEDS\nLIFESTYLE\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\nFSIN Vice-Chief Aly Bear speaks on Red Dress Day about the importance of action on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit Peoples on May 5, 2022. (Lisa Schick/980 CJME)\nBy Lisa Schick/CJME News\nIndigenous declaration passes, families pack gallery for Red Dress Day\nMay 5, 2022 | 4:54 PM\n\n\n\nThe gallery at the Saskatchewan Legislative Building was filled with women wearing red and ribbon skirts Thursday morning.\n\nThey were there to push the government for action on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People \u2014 and they got it, in a way.\n\nIn an emergency debate, the Assembly voted unanimously to pass and adopt the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations\u2019 Declaration to Honour Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nAhead of the proceedings, the women and leaders gathered to share their stories.\n\n\u201cMy daughter was only 19 years old when she was taken. It took two years and 10 months for us to find her remains and we only found 42 per cent of her remains,\u201d said Gwenda Yuzicappi, her voice full of emotion.\n\nYuzicappi\u2019s daughter was Amber Redman.\n\n\u201cTwo years and 10 months not knowing where your daughter is? That\u2019s a lot of pain, that\u2019s a lot of emotions \u2014 depression, (thoughts of) suicide. I went through so many emotions, it was very, very hard (and) difficult,\u201d explained Yuzicappi.\n\nLoretta Henderson\u2019s daughter, Krista Kenny, went missing in May 2009 and was found dead a few days later.\n\n\u201cShe was kind, she was loving (and) she helped out so many people,\u201d Henderson said of her daughter. \u201cEven though it was 13 years ago, it\u2019s still so hard. Every day we talk about her (and) always mention her because she was my only daughter.\u201d\n\nJoyce Keepness is Tamara Keepness\u2019 grandmother; the five-year-old went missing without a trace in 2004.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s something that you never forget; it stays with you. Every day there\u2019s something that comes up that reminds you that this little person was never found. This little person, are we ever going to find her? Is she out there?\u201d Joyce Keepness said.\n\nLooking at the women around her, Keepness said she was glad to see the gathering and was proud of the leadership for putting together the show of support on Red Dress Day.\n\nFSIN Vice-Chief Aly Bear stood tall in her headdress and ribbon skirt in front of the other women, her voice full of purpose.\n\n\u201cWe have women going missing every day and it\u2019s not taken seriously,\u201d Bear said.\n\nBear said they were standing in solidarity with all the families of those missing and murdered and what they\u2019re going through. She said they were at the legislature to support and uplift the families, but also to push for the adoption of the declaration.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re here to continue to stand up and let you know that we are still here, and we\u2019re here to continue to protect each other and we want you to stand with us as well in solidarity,\u201d said Bear.\n\nBear said the conversation needs to continue longer than just one day, that talking about the problem is the only way to find solutions to it.\n\n\u201cEvery day is Red Dress Day. We Indigenous women endure disproportionate levels of violence that are affected far too often by government\u2019s failure to act, a failure to intervene, a failure to stand up for those who need it most,\u201d said Betty Nippi-Albright, the NDP\u2019s critic for Indigenous issues.\n\nNippi-Albright said if communities keep losing Indigenous women to murder and disappearances, they\u2019re losing a very important member of society.\n\n\u201cWhen it comes to Indigenous women, we don\u2019t get the attention that non-Indigenous women get when we go missing, or when we go murdered. And we need to change that and it changes by imploring our elected officials to act and stop giving lip service,\u201d said Nippi-Albright.\n\nThe declaration\n\nThe Saskatchewan Party and NDP voted in favour of adopting the FSIN\u2019s declaration, which consists of five articles.\n\n\u2014 \u201cThe Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations and its governing and organizational structures will take responsibility and action to address the disproportionate victimization of Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIn matters of governance and politics, Indigenous women have the right to participate at all levels of governance, including the Nation, tribal council, provincial and national levels, free from discrimination, physical, verbal, spiritual or emotional abuse and harassment, and with respect for both individual autonomy and democratic principles.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIndigenous women and girls have the right to partake in ceremonial practices, access safe and accessible childcare, education, health, recreation, resource stewardship, economic development, land protection and livelihood activities with full consideration for their important roles and responsibilities as life-givers of our Nations, free from disparagement, racism, sexual innuendo, harassment or assault; and with reasonable expectations of physical, mental, spiritual and emotional safety.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIndigenous women and girls have the right to physical, mental, emotional and spiritual protection. It is incumbent upon all persons to ensure the safety of women and girls.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIndigenous women and girls have the right to access independent and culturally relevant and safe processes to investigate and meaningfully address any and all complaints of gender-based violence. Indigenous women and girls who experience gender-based violence have the right to redress and accountability from those responsible.\u201d\n\nDuring the emergency debate, Don Morgan \u2014 the minister responsible for First Nations, Metis and Northern Affairs \u2014 said there was nothing in those five articles a person could disagree with. He talked about the government\u2019s commitment to lessening violence against everyone in the province, including Indigenous women and girls.\n\nIn her remarks during debate, Nippi-Albright talked about past action from the government on such issues.\n\n\u201cThis government has sent the message to us as Indigenous women (that) they do not care. This government does not care,\u201d said Nippi-Albright.\n\nAnd the NDP critic talked about needing the government to not just give lip service to this issue and asked whether there would be clear reporting on measurements of success.\n\n\u201cOr is it just a document you\u2019re going to say, \u2018Yeah, we approved it. We put it on the website\u2019?\u201d Nippi-Albright said as she slammed her hand down on the desk. \u201cAnd remember, not all Indigenous people have access to internet.\u201d\n\nAmong actions requested were for the government to adopt the 231 recommendations from the National Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and to offer more support to relevant community-based organizations.\n\nby Lisa Schick/CJME News\nAround the Web\nAll Canadians Aged 40-80 May Qualify for This $250,000 Tax-free Life Benefit\nDollarGuardian\nWrinkles Around the Mouth? {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/artist-brings-red-dress-campaign-home-1.23852842", "title": "Artist brings Red Dress Campaign home - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 19.6 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nArtist brings Red Dress Campaign home\nHeather Potts is a fibre artist who knows the power of a dress. The First Nations clothing designer specializes in the colours black and red.\nFrank Peebles\nJun 11, 2019 9:26 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nHeather Potts and the public art red dress display she has installed on her front yard at her Hart Highlands home.Brent Braaten, Photographer\n\nHeather Potts is a fibre artist who knows the power of a dress. The First Nations clothing designer specializes in the colours black and red.\n\nAfter the final report was released from the National Inquiry Into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Potts felt moved to create. She was already well aware of the Red Dress Campaign (also known as the REDress Project), a visual touchstone across Canada that draws attention to the issue of too many female victims of violence. As someone who works with fabrics and fashions dresses, this billowed in her mind along with the personal grief she suffers.\n\nIt all blew out onto her front yard this week. Her Killarney Drive home is now a backdrop for a piece of public art, acting as a visual response.\n\n\"I have been thinking about this, turning it over in my mind, for quite some time,\" she said, and even purchased a red dress she saw one day that had the elegance she was looking for to accomplish her artistic purpose. \"It finally came to me. I put the red dress out on a stand I had for displaying clothing. I put it between two birch trees. One arm is outstretched, lifted up to the Creator. The Canadian flag is wrapped behind her because Trudeau said he would help. I'm taking him at his word. He has to respond. The Canadians have suffered, too, not just First Nations. It's mostly First Nations victims, but not all, and it affects us all. We are all together in our suffering. We must be all together in solutions. I put all this out there, then lo and behold, I looked down and saw that it was all above some lily of the valley. Jesus has sometimes been symbolized by the lily of the valley, so I took that to mean Jesus was holding all of this up.\"\n\nThe public art expression has a mental meaning to Potts as an Indigenous elder and longtime fibre artist, but it also has a direct streak of pain that comes from her heart. Her niece Amber Potts-Jaffary was last seen in 1988 after a teenaged conflict with her parents. The Etobicoke teen flagged down a stranger for a ride, following a rebellious argument and was never again seen or heard of by her loved ones.\n\nIt happened right in the midst of a serial rapist spree in that same area that turned out to be perpetrated by Paul Bernardo. Was Potts-Jaffary one of this killer's victims?\n\nOr, as in the case of the Highway of Tears experience, it is possible there were multiple predators at work.\n\n\"Both her father and her mother have passed on, now,\" said Potts. \"She has been heavy in my heart. She was so young when she went missing, and it has been more than 30 years now.\"\n\nThe empty red dress represents the missing girl who would now be a woman in Potts' life, just as the red dresses all across Canada in the national campaign represent the shocking numbers of missing and murdered women and girls, all too predominantly Indigenous.\n\nThe project began in 2014 in Winnipeg by Metis multimedia artist Jaime Black who asked for 600 red dresses be donated to her creative vision that involved them being placed in numerous public spaces around that city, and beyond.\n\n\"It is an installation art project based on an aesthetic response to this critical national issue,\" said Black, who sought to establish an unforgettable \"visual reminder of the staggering number of women who are no longer with us. Through the installation I hope to draw attention to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Aboriginal women and to evoke a presence through the marking of absence.\"\n\nIt was given nationwide life when it was taken on as an ongoing call to action by the Public Service Alliance of Canada.\n\nPotts has given it its most personal and intimate voice here in Prince George. It was coincidental, said Potts, that the Prince George Fibre Arts Guild was hosting the Association of Northwest Weavers' Guilds conference here in this city, opening on the same day as her unveiling of the red dress. Potts considered it a happy accident that underscores the power of fibre, fabric and fashion to make statements on life's most important issues and concerns.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. Women\n\n\n\nDate\n\n5/5/2022 1:00:50 PM  \nShare on Facebook  Tweet on Twitter  \n\n(MENAFN- EIN Presswire)\n\nJack Henderson\n\nJack Henderson Wrote Song Inspired by the REDress Project Created to Raise Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\n\nLONDON, UNITED KINGDOM, May 5, 2022 /EINPresswire.com / -- When British musician Jack Henderson first heard of the REDress Project in 2019, he was driven to write the song\u201cRed Dress\u201d about missing native American women from Canada and the United States and the international abuse and exploitation of women.\n\n\nIn 2010, the Native Canadian artist Jaime Black instituted the REDress Project where she hung red dresses in public spaces and university campuses around Canada and the United States to raise awareness around the issue of missing or murdered Aboriginal women across Canada. The aim of her installations was to provide,\u201ca visual reminder of the staggering number of women who are no longer with us ... and evoke a presence through the marking of absence.\u201d\n\nThe song is being released Thursday, May 5 on Fretsore Records and a portion of the proceeds will be donated to charity. Red Dress Day is observed on Thursday, May 5, in Canada.\n\n\u201cTragically, the abuse and exploitation of women remains an international problem,\u201d Henderson said.\u201c'Red Dress' extends the symbol of the red dress used in Black's work to raise awareness of murdered and missing indigenous women to raise a voice for women who have been abused, trafficked or murdered everywhere.\u201d\n\nHenderson was gigging to promote his most recent album, Where's The Revolution, released on Fretsore Records, when the label's managing director Ian Sephton heard Jack perform\u201cRed Dress\u201d in the set.\n\n\n'I was immediately moved by the melody and lyrics when I heard it. I insisted we recorded it at the earliest opportunity. It had not been recorded during the Where's The Revolution sessions, so his solo powerful live performance of the song was my first exposure to it. The audience loved it too,' Sephton said.\n\nThe initial mix, recorded at his studio in Scotland, had Henderson singing all the vocals. On reflection, he decided to ask his friend Karin Bergquist of Cincinnati band Over The Rhine to contribute backing vocals.\n\n\nBergquist's backing vocals had to be recorded remotely in the U.S. and sent to Jack due to pandemic travel bans.\n\nHenderson, best known for his years touring with Over The Rhine and Canadian outfit Cowboy Junkies, sings, plays guitars and Hammond B3 on the haunting, contemporary ballad. The recording also features Canadian Mattie Foulds (Karine Polwart, Kate Rusby), on drums and Scottish bass player Kevin McGuire (Eddi Reader, Karen Matheson).\n\n\u201cI'm only too pleased if in some small way this song helps keep the issue in the public awareness. I'm not trying to be sanctimonious and am acutely aware that violence and abuse against women is a serious cultural issue within many of our societies. A red dress has specific implications to Indigenous American cultures, but I also want to extend Jaime Black's powerful symbolism to the wider cultural issue,\u201d Henderson said.\n\nThe video for Red Dress can be viewed here: .\n\nFor more information about Jack Henderson, visit .\n\nFor more information about Fretsore Records, visit fretsorerecords.com .\n\n-30-\n\nJay Nachman\nPress Releases, Etc.\n+1 215-868-8057\nemail us here\n\nMENAFN05052022003118003196ID1104165393\n\n\n\n\nLegal Disclaimer:\nMENAFN provides the information \u201cas is\u201d without warranty of any kind.
