{"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/students-focus-in-on-the-highway-of-tears-for-documentary-1.20086692", "title": "Students focus in on the Highway of Tears for documentary - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 19.6 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nStudents focus in on the Highway of Tears for documentary\nCar wheels and documentary cameras were rolling along the Highway Of Tears this week.\nFrank Peebles\nMay 19, 2017 9:37 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nStudent documentary director Tennessa Wild and videographer Alex Antoneshyn were in Prince George this week, after rolling cameras along the Highway Of Tears.Citizen photo by Frank Peebles\n\nCar wheels and documentary cameras were rolling along the Highway Of Tears this week.\n\nTwo students of journalism, director Tennessa Wild and videographer Alex Antoneshyn were travelling the infamous stretch of Highway 16 between Prince Rupert and Prince George, stopping along the way to look at the cases of missing and murdered women from over the years.\n\nThey were specifically interested in transportation availability and hitchhiking culture - two underlying factors in why so many vulnerable women were in a position to be violently apprehended by predators.\n\nThe students looked at the Highway Of Tears Symposium Report as their starting point, zeroing in on the recommendation that a transportation system be created to service the First Nations communities along the highway.\n\nThat 2006 report flowed from the forum held at CN Centre that brought together levels of government, law enforcement, community service agencies, grassroots advocates and, for the first time ever, the families of the many victims. A public dialogue was held and the report was the written representation of that discussion.\n\nIt said, \"Many of the First Nation Communities (Reserves) along Highway 16 are situated many miles from town and city centers. A majority of these First Nation communities do not have the business, recreation, or other services that are available in the towns and cities. Poverty, coupled with the need to buy essential items such as food and clothing, requires travel from these communities to the nearest town or city.\"\n\nThe report also said in another excerpt, \"The first and most significant contributing factor for many of the aboriginal women being on the highway is poverty. Young aboriginal women are placing themselves at risk by hitchhiking because they simply have no other transportation options. They have very little money, and vehicles are considered a luxury item that many families cannot afford. The percentage of families living at, or below, the poverty line in First Nations communities is disproportionately higher than any other population segment in Canadian society. Moreover, poverty in some aboriginal families is intergenerational and is persistently present through many generations of the families. Some predators know that profound poverty exists within First Nation family units.\"\n\nNoting that only the thin Greyhound bus service exists as a public transit option anywhere between Prince Rupert and Prince George, the Victim Prevention section of the report's first recommendation was \"That a shuttle bus transportation system be established between each town and city located along the entire length of Highway 16, defined as the 'The Highway of Tears.'\"\n\n\"This is an accountability piece,\" said Wild, who is using this documentary as her Masters of Journalism thesis at the University of Regina. \"It's looking at the B.C. government's inaction.\"\n\nWild is originally from Houston and is aware that a tendering process has been underway for many months to establish transportation links in these areas. No single transportation agency offered to take on the job, as far as has been publicly disclosed from this process so far. The east-west distance is more than 700 kilometres, and the north-south branches off that Highway 16 tree are legion, making transportation logistics a significant challenge.\n\nThe provincial government has publicly stated in the past that the preferred method of addressing people in poverty turning to hitchhiking as a travel alternative is by raising people out of poverty. Hence, intense focus was put on gaps in the system leading to imbalances in aboriginal education outcomes, economic enhancement projects and programs, etc.\n\nWild said these points weren't enough. \"Definitely not. That definitely doesn't change the focus at all.\"\n\nShe intends to speak with the premier on camera and felt dodged so far, since the requests for an interview were made \"months ago\" to no avail so far.\n\nThe government member with the most literal hands on the issue is MLA John Rustad, being the elected member for the largest stretch of that Highway 16 span, a lifelong resident who knows of the Highway Of Tears cases from personal memory and is also the Minister of Aboriginal Relations and Reconciliation. Wild said she felt sure she could get an interview with Rustad but said \"he's not en pointe\" for the purposes of her film and only the premier's presence would satisfy her.\n\nWhen asked if the documentary was balanced journalism, in keeping with the university degree to which it is associated, she said it was not.\n\n\"Objectivity is a requirement in journalism,\" she said, \"In documentary, there are allowances made for subjectivity.\"\n\nMany documentaries - both filmed and written - have been done on the Highway Of Tears topic. The first was directed by Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy (winner of two Oscars and six Emmy Awards, named by Time Magazine as one of the 100 most influential people in the world) in 2006. The most widely viewed was directed by Matt Smiley, co-produced by Carly Pope and Prince George's Mary Teegee in 2015. It was narrated by Nathan Fillion, made its debut at the Toronto International Film Festival, and is available on Netflix.\n\n\"Oh yes, I've seen all of them,\" said Wild. She considered hers to be different. The bulk of the past work was \"documenting the history, the circumstances, but not evoking change. We are still at a stalemate on what these communities require, what these communities are asking for.\"\n\nShe and Antoneshyn both expressed gratitude and inspiration at all the support their project has received. The filming portion still needs some footage from Vancouver and Victoria, than it's into the post-production phase. Editing the raw footage into the story she wants to tell will be an onerous task, she said, but her confidence in the advocacy she is doing will be a sure guide.\n\nThe film's deadline for her thesis purposes is Aug. 15 for a complete 22-minute television-style program. After that - a process she anticipates being a year to 18 months - she will explore the possibilities of getting it into film festivals, online viewing platforms, or even expanding it to a longer form.\n\nShe especially hopes to return to the area to show the finished film in the places that helped create it.\n\n\"I want to spark more interest in this topic, help influence others to strive towards these goals,\" she said. \"I hear a lot of 'I'm just one person, what can I do?' but we want to show people that you can do something as one person. This could be my life's work. It has that potential.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. MONTH\nBOOK YOUR AD\nDIGITAL SUBSCRIPTION\nNEW LANGUAGE\nHome  News  Prince Albert non-profit delivers safety lessons ahead of National Day for Missing...\nNewsTop Stories\nPrince Albert non-profit delivers safety lessons ahead of National Day for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\nBy Jason Kerr -\nMay 3, 2024\nJason Kerr/Daily Herald. Halo Mirasty holds up a sign during the Prince Albert Aboriginal Head Start honour walk Thursday morning.\n\nKnow who you can go to for help if you ever find yourself in danger.\n\nThat was the message when Prince Albert Aboriginal Head Start hosted an honour gathering on Thursday ahead of Red Shirt Day.\n\nThe annual event raises awareness about the large number of Indigenous women who are missing or murdered ever year. Head Start executive director Trena Larocque said the goal is to teach children how to spot danger and make safe choices.\n\n\u201cOur kids are very young, so I\u2019m hoping they don\u2019t have that issue, but we\u2019re instilling that knowledge in them right now,\u201d Larocque said. \u201cHopefully that will (continue) with them when they become teenagers and have a little bit more freedom.\u201d\n\nRed Shirt Day, also known as Red Dress Day or the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, is held annually on May 5. This year, that date falls on a Sunday, when children who are part of the program will be at home with their families.\n\nLarocque said they wanted to recognize the day on Thursday to emphasize the importance of safety.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very important that these children know that they need to be safe, so we decided that we would do a walk to honour and make sure they were aware of how important this day is,\u201d she explained.\n\nChildren involved in the head start program were part of march around downtown Prince Albert Thursday morning. They then took part in activities designed to teach them what to do if they feel threatened or in danger.\n\nLarocque said they hope students will learn that it\u2019s okay to ask for help when they are in trouble. Staff also emphasize the importance of knowing who to go to when they feel threatened. That list includes parents, relatives, and police officers.\n\nLarocque said knowing where your children are, especially at night, is also important for keeping them safe.\n\n\u201c(It\u2019s) being aware that when they are outside if they feel threatened and they\u2019re young, to stay close to mom and dad, to stay close to their grandparents, to their relatives, (and) that they shouldn\u2019t be wandering off too far on their own,\u201d she said. \u201cIf they do feel in danger and if they are on their own, yell and get attention from someone so hopefully they can be taken care of and be brought back home.\u201d\n\nThe Prince Albert Aboriginal Head Start Program is a non-profit preschool program that focuses on language development and cultural engagement. The program has space for 20 students at its 10th Street East location, plus another 25 spaces available as part of its home visit program.\n\nThe organization plans to host a community BBQ on Monday to give families a chance to check out the program.\n\nCorrection: This story has been updated to remove a sentence about families knowing where their children are that was incorrectly transcribed. PHOTO BY DARRYL DYCK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\nArticle content\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2014 Gladys Radek raised a fist in the air and wept as she reached the end of her 350-kilometre journey along British Columbia\u2019s Highway of Tears.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Indigenous grandmother finished her walk along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 for the seventh and final time on Monday. It is the same highway where her beloved niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared.\n\nOutside a community centre in Smithers, her voice shook as she spoke to those who had walked alongside her, including commissioners from the national inquiry into missing and murdered women.\n\n\u201cI want to thank you all for standing so proud and loud, to show our commissioners that we have love for our missing and murdered women,\u201d she said through tears.\n\nIndigenous women sing before walking with a group of family members and advocates of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls along the Highway of Tears, in Moricetown, B.C., on Monday. PHOTO BY DARRYL DYCK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very proud of this moment right now because when Tamara went missing, nobody cared. When Tamara went missing, there were many others who were already missing, many others who had been murdered.\u201d\n\nCanucks Report\n\nEssential reading for hockey fans who eat, sleep, Canucks, repeat.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nDozens of women have disappeared or been killed along the highway between Prince Rupert and Prince George in central B.C.\n\nRadek and other family members and advocates left Prince Rupert on Thursday and arrived Monday in Smithers, where the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls will hold hearings starting Tuesday.\n\nThe walkers were accompanied by vehicles and have covered sections of the route in a relay fashion, allowing them to complete the walk of hundreds of kilometres over the span of a few days.\n\nMarion Buller, centre, chief commissioner of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, dances with hereditary chiefs after a group of family members and advocates arrived in Smithers, B.C. on Monday. PHOTO BY DARRYL DYCK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\n\nDuring the final stretch through the town of Smithers, Radek, who is missing a leg, drove a car covered in photographs of women who have disappeared or been killed. She wept behind the wheel as passersby waved and honked their horns.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nInquiry commissioner Michele Audette joined the group three days ago, while Chief Commissioner Marion Buller joined on Monday. Commissioner Qajaq Robinson was supposed to attend the hearings but had to bow out due to a family emergency.\n\nAudette said she walked to honour the resilience and strength of the families who will be speaking for the first time to the inquiry. The hearings will be powerful, she said.\n\n\u201cI feel it since I arrived; there\u2019s a lot of emotion, lots of anxiety also or stress, because it\u2019s the first time for them,\u201d she said. \u201cJust being there beside them and listening, maybe it\u2019s helped.\u201d\n\nGladys Radek becomes emotional as she speaks after a group of family members and advocates of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls arrived in Smithers. She helped organize the commemorative walk. PHOTO BY DARRYL DYCK /THE CANADIAN PRESS\n\nThe inquiry has been plagued by controversy, including the resignation of commissioner Marilyn Poitras this summer and complaints from families about poor communications and delays.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBuller told a Senate committee last week that the inquiry\u2019s work has been hampered by federal bureaucracy.\n\nRhonda Lee McIsaac, who lives in Haida Gwaii and has Ojibway heritage, participated in the walk for the first time and said it was a moving experience.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m walking for everybody who cannot walk,\u201d said McIsaac. \u201cI have lost a loved one. I grew up in foster care and I was adopted out. This is part of my story.\u201d\n\nMore than 40 people have signed up to speak at the Smithers hearings, which run through Thursday. They are the second hearings held by the inquiry after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nThe inquiry is set to visit nine communities this fall, including Edmonton, Winnipeg and Thunder Bay, Ont.\n\ntwitter.com/ellekane\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop scratching these, and try this instead\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nCanucks: Nikita Zadorov\u2019s agent takes blistering shot at Vancouver reporter\nThe Province\nCanucks: After coach's criticism, the Elias Pettersson question looms large\nThe Province\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nBetter than scratching, why you should try this\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nOne Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before, You Will Fit In Your Pants Again!\nBurn Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. Participants will then march from Brunel Road to Main Street and back.\n\nCrone says the walk was named for traditional Indigenous Moccasins, and although they\u2019re the recommended footwear, showing up is more important.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had so many people come up to me to say \u2018what can I do, how can I help\u2019,\u201d says Crone. \u201cSo this is really an act of solidarity, an act toward stepping up to that line and saying \u2018I\u2019m going to support this\u2019.\u201d\n\nThe event is in honour of Red Dress Day, with Crone also encouraging participants to wear red or carry a red dress, symbolic of the missing and murdered women. \u201cWe all bleed red. On the outside, we are all different colours but on the inside, we are all the same,\u201c says Crone.\n\nAccording to Crone, Indigenous Women are 12 times more likely to go missing or be murdered, and four times more likely to be the victim of physical or sexual abuse. She notes that from 1980 to 2012, nearly 2,000 Indigenous women were murdered in Canada, with 225 of those remaining unsolved.\n\n\u201cIt seems like we\u2019re treading water because we know this isn\u2019t just historical, that this continues to happen,\u201d says Crone. \u201cWe have women and girls who have gone missing, and women who have been murdered. Their families are still mourning their deaths because their bodies are still out there somewhere.\u201d\n\nHowever, Crone says with adversity comes resilience. On May 7, Hope Arises will host a \u201cCircle of Strength\u201d ribbon skirt workshop at the Huntsville Public Library from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.\n\n\u201cIn a circle, we are all equal,\u201d says Crone. \u201cWhich means whether you\u2019re Indigenous or not, we should be inclusive, accepting, and we should stand together in moving forward.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement Photo by Stephen Petrick, Moose FM.\n\nMembers and supporters of Bancroft\u2019s Indigenous Community walked through the town drumming and singing Friday morning.\u00a0\n\nWhen they hit Millennium Park they gathered around the pebble mosaic for a smudging ceremony, ate strawberries for healing and held a moment of silence. Many Canadians now wear red and hang red dresses in public places on the day to express concern that a disproportionate number of missing persons and murder cases in Canada are linked to Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited people. \u00a0\n\nDiane Martin, of the Algonquin Inodewiziwin Centre, says public displays like this are important to raise awareness.\u00a0\u00a0\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cWe still need to educate people that this is a crisis in Canada,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s still ongoing; there are still Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited Indigenous women that go missing on a regular basis. I think it\u2019s important that we still bring awareness and have demonstrations that are peaceful.\u201d\u00a0\n\nMartin says we can play a role in addressing the crisis, by writing letters to politicians that express our concern and holding Red Dress Day ceremonies every year, to ensure \u201cthe women are not forgotten.\u201d\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\n- Advertisement {"url": "https://www.pr-inside.com/suncor-indigenous-employees-lana-and-joy-want-everyone-to-be-an-ally-r4919882.htm", "title": "Suncor Indigenous Employees, Lana and Joy Want Everyone To Be an Ally ... 2023-05-11", "body": "Today: July 4, 2024, 11:07 pm\n\ufeff \nHOME SIGN UP! NEW PRESS RELEASE CATEGORIES\nYour current selected language is German\nClick below to switsch to English\n \n\ufeff \n\ufeff \nMedia & Entertainment\n\nSuncor Indigenous Employees, Lana and Joy Want Everyone To Be an Ally ...\nPR-Inside.com: 2023-05-11 17:17:30\nNORTHAMPTON, MA / ACCESSWIRE / May 11, 2023 / Suncor Energy\n\nOriginally published on May 5, 2023\n\nLana Hill, who is a trusted advisor to many young Indigenous people in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo, holds her own teenage daughter closer each time the name of another missing Indigenous person is released. Joy Flett is the knowledge keeper for her close and extended relatives, but pieces of her family tree have been stolen, and she feels a heartache that is shared by countless other Indigenous families across Canada. Both women will be wearing red on May 5.\n\n\nAlso known as Red Dress Day, May 5 marks a day to honour, remember and create awareness and action for Missing, Murdered and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP) in Canada. The statistics are startling -Indigenous women in Canada today are seven times more likely than non-Indigenous women to be a murder victim, and three times more likely to be violently or sexually assaulted.\n\nLana, originally from Cowessess First Nation in Saskatchewan, and Joy, from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation in Alberta, are part of Suncor's Indigenous and Community Relations team in Fort McMurray, Alta. They both agree that more action is needed to end the MMEIP crisis.\n\n\"Since the time of residential schools and everything leading to today, we've been stripped of our names, our languages, our hair. To be able to take back our power and voice, we need to keep speaking out against what is happening,\" says Joy. \"There are so many Indigenous people who've gone missing or have been murdered in our own city. We need to continue to say their names. They are important to somebody. We can all play a role in ending the violence.\"\n\nOne of the national organizations helping to move the needle with this progress is the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC). For almost 50 years NWAC has played a lead role in advocating for the rights of Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit, transgender and gender-diverse people, which includes critical advocacy on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG2S+) and reconciliation. The organization has been pressing the federal government to act since the National Inquiry issued the 231 Calls for Justice in 2019.\n\nWhen reflecting on Red Dress Day, NWAC urges Canadians to consider the many aspects of colonization that continue to affect Indigenous people. NWAC's Chief Executive Officer, Lynne Groulx, believes that a critical component to reconciliation is acknowledging the past.\n\n\"We invite everyone across the country to play an active role in reconciliation through education and raising awareness, as well as learning about Indigenous knowledge systems and the impacts of colonialism and racism that face many Indigenous people,\" says Lynne. \"We have taken urgent and significant action to increase awareness and address the 231 Calls for Justice and have been working hard to implement our own MMIWG2S+ Action Plan.\"\n\nNWAC's Action Plan includes 66 concrete actions they will take to help end the MMEIP. Last year NWAC reported progress on over 85 per cent of the proposed actions. This includes the Safe Passage Platform - a national reporting tool that maps cases of MMIWG2S+ and provides information on resources and services available across the country.\n\nLynne also suggests reading books, listening to podcasts or participating in educational programs created by Indigenous authors and media to see the world through their lens. She also encourages people to help amplify messages and initiatives from Indigenous voices to ensure they are being heard.\n\nOn May 5 and beyond, both Lana and Joy will be found honouring and remembering - the missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples - in their own way of healing and active support.\n\n\"Through my mom's experience growing up of being called a dirty Indian, to now my 15-year-old daughter who is able to stand proud and march to the beat of her own drum, we can see there has been a lot of progress for Indigenous people to feel seen and accepted,\" says Lana. \"But we also must acknowledge the pain and trauma that is still prevalent today. We are not victims, we are survivors.\"\n\nView additional multimedia and more ESG storytelling from Suncor Energy on 3blmedia.com.\n\nContact Info:\n\nSpokesperson: Suncor Energy\n\nWebsite: https://www.3blmedia.com/profiles/suncor-energy\n\nEmail: info@3blmedia.com\n\nSOURCE: Suncor Energy\n\n\nPress Information\n\n\nPublished by\nACCESSWIRE News Network\n888.952.4446\ne-mail\nhttp://www.accesswire.com\n\n\n\n# 713 Words\n\nRelated Articles\n\nDisclaimer: If you have any questions regarding information in this press release please contact the company added in the press release. {"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Business/388005/Indigenous-leaders-want-corporate-reconciliation-efforts-to-extend-beyond-Sept-30", "title": "Indigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30 - Business News - Castanet.net", "body": "26\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nBusiness\u00a0\u00a0\nIndigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30\nCORPORATE SUPPORT LACKING\nTara Deschamps, The Canadian Press - Sep 30, 2022 / 8:49 am | Story: 388005\nPhoto: The Canadian Press\nKrystal Abotossaway, president of the Indigenous Professional Association of Canada.\n\nChelsee Pettit spent much of the summer collaborating with designers to create and manufacture apparel reflective of the Indigenous values she hoped would be on people's minds when Canada marks its second National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.\n\nBut in the days leading up to Sept. 30, she noticed many companies had not had the same forethought and were scrambling to place bulk orders with her store, Aaniin.\n\n\"It's just a little funny how last-minute other organizations that are all non-Indigenous are, and they're pushing that (work) back onto Indigenous people,\" said Pettit, an Anishinaabe woman.\n\n\"We're not like big box stores that just have disposable T-shirts and are at everybody's beck and call. Working with us ahead of time as opposed to just laying it on us a week before the day, I think would be super helpful.\"\n\nPettit has tried her best to accommodate last-minute orders, but she and other members of the Indigenous business community see the trend as a sign of how much more work corporate Canada has to do to turn support for Indigenous communities into a 365-day-a-year effort.\n\nWhile many businesses encourage staff to don orange shirts \u2014 a tradition started by residential school survivor Phyllis Webstad in 2013 \u2014 or to sell wares in the bright hue on Sept. 30, those efforts quickly fade. Companies often don't do much more to elevate Indigenous voices and causes.\n\n\"It is positive that we are seeing education happen and awareness-building happen, but it can be quite triggering and harmful for Indigenous Peoples who see it as one day of performative action and nothing throughout the rest of the year,\" said Tabatha Bull, president and chief executive of the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business.\n\nBull and Pettit say if an employer is looking to make a mark on truth and reconciliation goals, they should also be doing that work all year round.\n\nThose efforts should begin with educating staff about both long-standing and new traumas Indigenous Peoplesface and how to support those affected.\n\nPettit recallsbeing at work in 2021, when the remains of 215 children were found at a former residential school site in British Columbia.\n\n\"My boss at the time was like, 'Oh, well, everybody knew about that already' and just like kind of brushed it off, but I was feeling very emotional that day for obvious reasons, so there's tons of work that has to be done,\" she said.\n\nThat's borne out in studies too.\n\nA 2021 report from equity organization Catalyst Canada found about 52 per cent of the 86 Indigenous respondents surveyed are \u201con guard\u201d at work and about 60 per cent feel psychologically unsafe on the job.\n\nThe study was based on a survey of 820 Canadian workers from various under-represented groups, but Catalyst isolated results from Indigenous respondents for this report because their need to feel on guard was so significant.\n\nKrystal Abotossaway, president of the Indigenous Professional Association of Canada, said she has seen more companies move toward reflecting on what they can do to improve their corporate culture and support Indigenous communities in recent years.\n\nLand acknowledgments, which note which Indigenous Peoples lived and took care of a site events are being held on, are an increasingly common and good start, she said.\n\nBull counts at least 200 companies, including Bank of Montreal, Uber, Walmart and Rogers, as members of the CCAB's Progressive Aboriginal Relation program \u2014 an initiative helping them build cultural awareness and make progress on reconciliation plans.\n\nOthers have yet to take on such work. Bull thinks they're slower to act because they feel overwhelmed and afraid of having difficult conversations.\n\n\"Some corporations are just not even knowing what the right question is to ask,\" she said. \"I think we need to move beyond that, if we're going to really progress as a country.\"\n\nAbotossaway said they can start by marking other Indigenous days and use them as an opportunity to educate.\n\nAmong those she suggested are Red Dress Day, which commemorates the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and International Inuit Day, National Indigenous Peoples Day and Louis Riel Day, which celebrates the life of the late M\u00e9tis leader.\n\nThe efforts shouldn't stop there, she added. Companies should reflect on how their governance structures, hiring policies, talent pipelines and workforce education programs align with Indigenous needs, she said.\n\n\"We've seen a lot of learning and development content come out, but that's usually just one course and it might be just an hour long,\" she said.\n\n\"Is it mandatory or is it not mandatory? And then how many of your employees or workforce are participating in it?\"\n\nAbotossaway and Bull agree any corporate actions on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation or other days should involve Indigenous Peoples at every step \u2014 even if the action is selling orange apparel.\n\nBull said, \"If you're going to create an orange shirt, ensure that you're working with an Indigenous artist, ensure that the Orange Shirt Society or an Indigenous organization benefits from that and you're not making a profit off of the orange shirt or Sept. 30.\"\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Business News\n\n\n\nOkanagan Companies\nCantex\t0.135\t0.01\nMetalex Ventures\t0.01\t0\nRussel Metals\t36.76\t-0.05\nDecisive Dividend Corp\t7.43\t0.18\nDiamcor Mining\t0.045\t0\nGGX Gold Corp\t0.025\t0\nCryptocurrencies\nBitcoin\t79435.7\t-3.21%\nEthereum\t4274.77\t-4.83%\nDash\t30.74\t-7.94%\nLitecoin\t91.81\t-6.56%\nRipple\t0.6053\t-4.87%\nEOS\t0.703\t-8.11%\nDogecoin\t0.1477\t-8.09%\nCardano\t0.5147\t-7.22%\nData from CryptoCompare\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in prison for murder\nAbbotsford - 1:39 pm\nA parade of aches and pains\nCalgary - 1:27 pm\nPower restored in Aberdeen\nKamloops - 1:16 pm\nMore Top Stories >\nReal Estate\nUnit #105, 2250 Majoros Road\n2 bedrooms 2 baths\n$440,000\nmore details\n\n\u00a9 2024 Castanet.net Make Castanet Your Homepage News Tips Advertising Contact Us"},
{"url": "https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a37926931/missing-native-women-indigenous-peoples-day/", "title": "Say the Names of Missing Native Women on Indigenous Peoples' Day", "body": "Skip to Content\nFASHION\nBEAUTY\nCULTURE\nNEWS & POLITICS\nHOROSCOPES\nSubscribe\nSIGN IN\nOpinion\nCultureNews & Politics\nSay the Names of Missing Native Women This Indigenous Peoples\u2019 Day\n\n\u201cNative women and girls... continue to be left out of conversations and decisions,\u201d writes Allie Young, a citizen of the Din\u00e9 community.\n\nBY ALLIE YOUNG, FOUNDER, PROTECT THE SACREDPUBLISHED: OCT 11, 2021 3:50 PM EDT\nSave Article\nKELLY SULLIVAN\n\nToday marks the first national celebration and observance of Indigenous Peoples\u2019 Day in U.S. history. Today is also International Day of the Girl, a day to support increased awareness of global gender inequalities. On this convergence, it seems only appropriate to shine a light on Native American girls and the erasure of Native women across mainstream media.\n\nAs part of my work with Protect the Sacred, a program from Harness to educate and empower the next generation of Native American leaders, I listen carefully to the priorities of our youth. Considering a lack of protection at local, state, and federal levels, our young leaders have expressed grave concern about the safety of our Native girls. In light of the national coverage of Gabby Petito\u2019s case, more of the Native community is doubling down on demands around this concern and asking: What about us?\n\nTwo weeks after going missing while on a road trip with her fianc\u00e9, Petito was found murdered. I send my prayers and condolences to her family and loved ones; I prayed for a different outcome. While the investigation into her death continues, her case still dominates headlines. The attention and amount of coverage Petito\u2019s case has received over the last month certainly reveals racial disparities that we, as Indigenous peoples, have known and felt repeatedly for years\u2014and it continues to be heartbreaking for our community.\n\n\nXINHUA NEWS AGENCY//GETTY IMAGES\nDemonstrators gathered in Vancouver, British Columbia, to honor National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, also known as Red Dress Day, on May 5, 2021.\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\n\nIn Wyoming, the state where Petito\u2019s body was found, a Missing and Murdered Indigenous People Task Force report found that 710 Indigenous people\u2014mostly girls\u2014have gone missing since 2011. Their stories receive little to no coverage, and hardly ever lead the news cycle. When a case does get coverage, it is often filled with stereotypes and victim-blaming language. Indigenous victims and other victims of color should receive the same level of coverage and support as Gabby Petito, because all girls on this planet are daughters, granddaughters, sisters, nieces, and cousins. No family should ever have to deal with the trauma of losing their children without support.\n\nBeyond Wyoming, there is a much larger #MMIWG (Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls) and #MMIR (Missing and Murdered Indigenous Relatives) movement to call attention to horrific statistics that are, unfortunately, a reality for many Native communities across the country: Indigenous women and girls are ten times more likely to be killed than the national murder rate; Murder is the third leading cause of death for Native American and Alaskan Native women; Native American women under the age of 35 experience a higher murder risk than any other demographic.\n\n\nNative women and girls know these numbers like the backs of our hands. We\u2019re raised to be cautious and hyperaware. We\u2019re told stories about our mothers, aunties, and sisters who went missing and were later found murdered\u2014or who went missing and were never found at all. Even though we journey through life with acute awareness, many of us still experience situations that send our nerves into the stratosphere.\n\n\nI can\u2019t tell you how many times alarms have gone off in my head because of ignorant men whose ideas of Native women are clearly set in fantasy. In not-so-original fashion, I\u2019ve been shouted at by men who wanted me to be their Pocahontas. The ones who didn\u2019t realize I was Native and then found out I am would say things I didn\u2019t know people were even allowed to say in the 21st century. Sadly, I know I\u2019m not alone. Nearly all of the women in my family can recount similar stories of their own.\n\nEven though we journey through life with acute awareness, many of us still experience situations that send our nerves into the stratosphere.\n\nThis treatment can stem from stereotypes portrayed in pop culture and mainstream media. Often, instead of positive portrayals, Native women are hyper sexualized and victim-blamed. A prime example is Adam Sandler\u2019s The Ridiculous 6, a 2015 film that degrades Native women, starting with the female character names: Smoking Fox, Beaver Breath, and Never Wears Bra. That sort of narrative has a detrimental effect on Native girls. We become targets. In addition to high murder rates, more than one in two Native women will be raped or sexually assaulted in their lifetime, according to the Indian Law Resource Center. I\u2019m part of that statistic, and so are many women in my family. In fact, the majority of Native women I know are part of that statistic.\n\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\n\nOne of the solutions to protect Native girls is to always stand against this kind of representation and advocate for accurate, positive representation of Native women. Another solution is to create space for Native women to share and uplift their stories, and to amplify and support the cases of missing Native women.\n\nSARAH MORRIS//GETTY IMAGES\nActivists march for missing and murdered Indigenous women at the Los Angeles Women\u2019s March in 2019.\n\nAccording to a report by the Urban Indian Health Institute entitled \u201cMissing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls,\u201d 5,712 cases of MMIWG were reported in 2016 and only 116 of them were logged in the Department of Justice database. It is for this reason that one of Sec. Deb Haaland\u2019s first acts as Secretary of the Interior was to establish and launch the Missing and Murdered Unit to pursue justice for missing or murdered Native Americans and Alaska Natives. The Indigenous community commends Sec. Haaland for the formation of this unit to support Native women and girls who continue to be left out of conversations and decisions, and whose stories aren\u2019t uplifted by the media.\n\n\nI hope you\u2019ll join me today, on this first Indigenous Peoples\u2019 Day and International Day of the Girl, in saying the names and sharing the stories of some of these Native women and girls who are either still missing or whose cases haven\u2019t been solved:\n\n\nMisty Upham: A rising Hollywood actress whose body was found in Auburn, Washington, in 2014, after she went missing while visiting her sister. The 32-year-old died of blunt-force injuries to her head and torso, according to a report. The Native community has supported Misty\u2019s family as they continue to search for answers in her untimely death.\nKaysera Stops Pretty Places: An 18-year-old who was murdered in August 2019 in Big Horn County, Montana.\n\nCecelia Barber Finona: A U.S. Army Veteran, whose body was located in Clark County, Nevada, in February 2021 after a nearly two-year search.\n\nPepita Redhair: A 27-year-old who was reported missing in March 2020. She is still missing, and her family continues to search for her. She was last seen in Albuquerque, New Mexico.\nElla Mae Begay: A 62-year-old a professional weaver who went missing from Sweetwater, Arizona, on June 15, 2021. Navajo Nation Police Department made contact with their person of interest, Preston Tolth, who was reportedly arrested on charges unrelated to Begay\u2019s disappearance. There has been no update in her case since the summer, and our Din\u00e9 (Navajo) community is seeking justice. Begay has brown eyes, weighs 110-120 pounds, and stands at just over five-feet-tall. She may be in a Silver 2005 Ford F-150 with Arizona license plate AFE7101. The Navajo Nation Police Department Shiprock District is asking anyone with information to call 505-368-1350 or 505-368-1351.\n\nTo support the ongoing search for many of our missing relatives and to help increase awareness of the #MMIWG and #MMIR movement, you can follow these accounts on Instagram: Missing & Murdered Dine\u0301 Relatives, MMIP | Who Is Missing, Missing & Murdered Native Americans, SacredMMIWG / FFADAsacr\u00e9es, Rising Hearts, and the National Indigenous Women's Resource Center.\n\nMore information on the the #MMIWG and #MMIR movement can be found on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women USA, National Indigenous Women\u2019s Resource Center, and Urban Indian Health Institute.\n\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\nNews & Politics\n\nJane\u00e9 Kassanavoid Found Her Purpose Off the Field\n\nSen. Well over 100 attended the walk to lend support to the cause. Friendship Centre executive director Carol Hanlon read a statement before the walk. \u201cOct. 4 is a day we honour the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, men, boys, and gender diverse people by showing our support for grieving families and creating a safe space to share and come together. The day reminds us all that we must continue to stand up in solidarity to prevent violence and create safer communities. Today we participate in a nationwide endeavour to raise awareness and ends this national tragedy. By having the conversations Sisters in Spirit creates, together we can make a difference by putting an end to violence against Indigenous women, girls, men, boys and gender diverse.\u201d The statistics from 2015 do not lie and tell a solemn tale. Indigenous women account for four per cent of the female population but 24 per cent of female homicides in Canada. Indigenous women report rates of violence 3.5 times per cent times higher than non-Indigenous women and girls, and incidents of violence and death from violence occurs at rates five times higher than the national average.\n\nGrandmother Lorna Grammer poses with three of her grandchildren. Left-right are Arthur Smith, Grammer, Jordan Emard and Lyla Verhage. The red handprints over their faces are symbolic and represent the thousands of women who have been silenced.\nMany people gathered indoors to warm up before the walk. Taya Fast reports. \u2013 Jun 14, 2023\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nOver 100 students from Oliver and Osoyoos, B.C., were invited to paint a teepee in honour of Indigenous Peoples\u2019 Day.\n\nWednesday\u2019s event was a part of the We Will Recover Society\u2019s Unbroken Together initiative, an opportunity for the community to come together on a path to recovery, resistance and reconciliation.\n\n\u201cThe trauma that the Indigenous children and families suffered was horrible and those impacts are still very obvious today and we need to work with our Indigenous community and support one another,\u201d said We Will Recover Society executive director Lori Vrebosch.\n\n\u201cWhat this teepee represents, is what we can achieve when we work together and raise awareness and actual truth and reconciliation.\u201d\n\n2:30\nCanada\u2019s 1st graduates in Indigenous Language Fluency\n\nOn Wednesday students from Oliver Elementary, Tuk El Nuit, and Sen\u2019Pok\u2019Chin were given the opportunity to leave an orange handprint on the teepee\u00a0 canvas\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe public was also invited to participate in the painting however organizers say it was important for them to first involve local students.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\n\u201cOur goal is 500 hands because we believe that Oliver and Osoyoos and this community care deeply about recovery and reconciliation,\u201d said Vrebosch.\n\n\u201cThe significance and having the children paint is that the orange hand represents the children who were taken into residential schools through the awful history that Canada has and how we treated our Indigenous people.\u201d\n\n2:17\nIndigenous Cop camp returns to West Kelowna school\n\nHelen Gallagher, School District 53 Teacher of Indigenous Education, said she feels a lot of pride in seeing her students participate in the event.\n\n\u201cThey are learning about the true history of the residential schools of Canada, and what has happened to some of their ancestors. And being aware of who they are and where they come from, which is really important for them,\u201d said Gallagher.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cA lot of pride \u2013 the kids become more aware of what is going on and become more respectful to not only themselves but to their elders and community.\u201d\n\nOnce the teepee is finished, We Will Recover plans to raise it throughout the South Okanagan on significant days, and at significant events and celebrations.\n\n\u201cWhen this teepee is completed in its entirety, we will have a teepee transfer ceremony and blessing and we will raise the teepee for the first time on Indigenous Peoples\u2019 Day, June 21, followed by Canada Day in Osoyoos at the Nk\u2019Mip campground,\u201d said Vrebosh.\n\n\u201cThen there will be other important days where we\u2019ll also raise the teepee, for example, International Overdose Awareness Day and National Day of Truth and Reconciliation on September 30.\u201d\n\n2:15\nKelowna marks Red Dress Day with downtown march\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2023 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nDavid Vigneault, director of Canada\u2019s spy agency, to retire\nCanada Post worker saves the day after child forgets stamp on postcard to grandma\nADVERTISEMENT\n630 CHED Afternoons with Bryn Griffiths & Reid Wilkins\n2:00 PM - 5:00 PM\n630CHED\nTrending\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. The majority of them say \u2018dead\u201d: KARE on indigenous Alberta women\u00a0\n\nThe Alberta government said it\u2019s working directly with families to find the best ways to move forward and offering funding for support services.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nBut an advocate for missing and murdered aboriginal women said there should be more of those services available.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\nLee Anne Sharp Adze believes a new Canada-wide agency could help families find missing loved ones and offer information and counselling.\n\n\u201cHaving that support or that advocate is what they need, so they really need that office developed,\u201d Sharp Adze, who is with the national initiative Sisters In Spirit, said.\n\nREAD MORE:\u00a0Murder victim\u2019s family highlights risks faced by aboriginal women\n\nIt\u2019s the kind of service Kaily Bird\u2019s family could have benefitted from after her mother was murdered in an alley in Calgary\u2019s Inglewood neighbourhood in 1999.\n\nBird said Gloria Black Plume accepted a ride home from the bar with two young men because it was a long walk.\n\n\u201cThey brought her to a back alley and beat her, they beat her to death,\u201d Bird said.\n\n\u201cThey stomped on her face. At the funeral we couldn\u2019t even open the coffin because her face was so bad.\u201d\n\nTWEET THIS\nCLICK TO SHARE QUOTE ON TWITTER: \"THEY STOMPED ON HER FACE. AT THE FUNERAL WE COULDN'T EVEN OPEN THE COFFIN BECAUSE HER FACE WAS SO BAD.\"\n\nOne of the men was later convicted of boot-stomping her to death, based on the other\u2019s testimony. He was acquitted in a re-trial.\n\nHis lawyer said it was because of overwhelming evidence that he didn\u2019t kill Black Plume. The Defence showed the man\u2019s footwear did not match marks left on her face.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe other man was never charged because police considered the case solved.\n\nThat outcome shattered Black Plume\u2019s loved ones, who felt doubly victimized by the justice system.\n\n\u201cOur family had a lot of anger. My brothers had a lot of anger because these people can just walk away free,\u201d Bird said.\n\nTWEET THIS\nCLICK TO SHARE QUOTE ON TWITTER: \"OUR FAMILY HAD A LOT OF ANGER. MY BROTHERS HAD A LOT OF ANGER BECAUSE THESE PEOPLE CAN JUST WALK AWAY FREE,\" BIRD SAID.\n\nToday, Black Plume\u2019s children still have no justice or closure.\n\nBird believes that fuelled the addiction and subsequent deaths of three of her brothers, further devastating the family.\n\nFor her, the solution lies in awareness.\n\n\u201cIt still affects me and I still miss her a lot,\u201d Bird said, fighting back tears.\n\nShe has vowed to keep re-telling the painful story of her mother\u2019s murder so Black Plume and other aboriginal women won\u2019t be forgotten.\n\nRELATED NEWS\n\u2018Where do you see yourself in 5 years? {"url": "https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/statement-honouring-the-sisters-in-spirit-vigils-across-canada-852188358.html", "title": "Statement honouring the Sisters in Spirit vigils across Canada", "body": "Resources\nBlog\nJournalists\nWebcasts\nData Privacy\nFran\u00e7ais\nmy CNW\u00a0 \nClient Login\u00a0 \nSign Up\nSend a Release\nNews\nProducts\nContact\nSearch\nStatement honouring the Sisters in Spirit vigils across Canada Fran\u00e7ais\n\nNEWS PROVIDED BY\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs Canada \n\nOct 04, 2021, 13:52 ET\n\nSHARE THIS ARTICLE\n    \n\nOTTAWA, ON, Oct. 4, 2021 /CNW/ - The Minister of Crown\u2013Indigenous Relations,\u00a0Carolyn Bennett, issued the following statement today:\n\n\"I urge all Canadians to take time today to honour the Indigenous women, girls and Two Spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, intersex and asexual (2SLGBTQQIA+) people who are missing or have been murdered. We offer support to the families and communities who bear the grief of their loss and to the survivors whose lives have been forever changed.\n\nEnding this violence is a shared responsibility of all levels of government, as well as of law enforcement agencies, the justice system and civil society. Guided by the 2021 National Action Plan: Ending Violence Against Indigenous Women, Girls And 2SLGBTQQIA+ People, including the Federal Pathway,\u00a0we will continue working together with families and Survivors, as well as with Indigenous\u00a0and federal, provincial and territorial governments to protect the rights, freedoms and safety of Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people.\n\nWe are thankful for the tireless work of all the families and Survivors and the Indigenous organizations that\u00a0began to raise awareness in 2005 of this ongoing violence. The annual October 4 Sisters in Spirit vigils continue to grow across the country, bringing Canadians together to support the fight to end racially and sexually based violence.\n\nToday, join us by reflecting on the concrete actions we can take to raise awareness and end this national tragedy. Light a candle in your window this evening; talk about it with your family, friends and neighbours; and post about it on social media. Together, we can make a difference and put an end to the systemic violence against Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people.\"\n\nStay connected\n\nJoin the conversation about Indigenous Peoples in Canada:\n\nTwitter: @GCIndigenous\u00a0\nFacebook: @GCIndigenous\u00a0\nInstagram: @gcindigenous\n\nYou can subscribe to receive our news releases and speeches via RSS feeds. {"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Vernon/423981/Vernon-Indigenous-Showcase-to-feature-human-trafficking-survivor-Highway-of-Tears-documentary", "title": "Vernon Indigenous Showcase to feature human trafficking survivor, Highway of Tears documentary. - Vernon News - Castanet.net", "body": "26\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nVernon\u00a0\u00a0\nVernon Indigenous Showcase to feature human trafficking survivor, Highway of Tears documentary.\nNARROW ESCAPE FROM EVIL\nDarren Handschuh - May 1, 2023 / 4:00 am | Story: 423981\nPhoto: Facebook\n\nA woman who lived through a traumatic childhood and narrowly escaped the dark world of human trafficking will share her message of hope in Vernon on Tuesday.\n\nAuroara Leigh will sing and speak at the Indigenous Showcase at Vernon's Towne Theatre. Doors open at 5:30 p.m., with the show starting at 6 p.m.\n\nLeigh is an Indigenous singer-songwriter, educational consultant, and activist.\n\nWhen Leigh talks about overcoming hardships and challenges, she knows that of which she speaks.\n\nGrowing up in a remote community in Northern B.C., Leigh endured a childhood fraught with abuse.\n\n\u201cEarly on, there was domestic violence,\u201d she said. \u201cI have childhood trauma, brain injuries and stuff like that.\u201d\n\nWhen she was 14, Leigh was groomed by a family in Prince Rupert who targeted her for human trafficking.\n\nLeigh said she was on her way to Vancouver, likely to be shipped overseas, when \u201cwe were intercepted (by authorities) and I didn't actually end up being raped and trafficked. I was found in time. I wouldn't have survived.\u201d\n\nThe road they were on was B.C.'s notorious Highway 16, better known as the Highway of Tears, where many women have gone missing.\n\nThe feature movie at Tuesday's showcase is Adaawk, which shines a light on Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women along the Highway of Tears.\n\n\u201cBeing 34 now, that happened to me 20 years ago and there were girls going missing back then,\u201d Leigh says. \u201cThe family that targeted me were a Vietnamese family, and there were girls going missing all the time.\u201d\n\nLeigh will share her story to let others know they are not alone and don't have to suffer in silence.\n\nLeigh has written many songs about her challenges.\n\nLeigh says she realized \u201cwomen are scared to come forward because they don't know that they will be supported. When I was a counsellor, I was hoping that people would know that it is safe to come forward, but I needed to walk the talk. So I took a step back from counselling to immerse myself into my music.\u201d\n\nAt the showcase, she will perform several of her original songs as she spreads her message of hope.\n\n\u201cMy music is in response to wanting to create safe spaces in group environments,\u201d she says, adding music is a way to address difficult topics like abuse and addiction.\n\n\u201cJust the power of listening to others who are sharing can help to plant seeds or water an element of courage and safety rather than shame, because usually those with trauma have shame coupled in with that, and that's what makes it so hard for people to come forward.\u201d\n\nRepresentatives from various agencies that can offer support will also be at the showcase\n\n\u201cKnow if you are just starting this journey there are people out there,\u201d she said. \u201cYou are not alone.\u201d\n\nTickets are $11. Along with Leigh and the movie Adaawk, there will be guest speakers and an artisan market.\n\nSupport for this initiative has been provided by Glohaven Community Hub, Tourism Vernon and the Province of BC.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n27\nShares\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Vernon News\n\n\n\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in prison for murder\nAbbotsford - 1:39 pm\nA parade of aches and pains\nCalgary - 1:27 pm\nPower restored in Aberdeen\nKamloops - 1:16 pm\nMore Top Stories >\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReal Estate\nUnit #105, 2250 Majoros Road\n2 bedrooms 2 baths\n$440,000\nmore details\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSalmon Arm SPCA Featured Pet\n\n\nPiper\nSalmon Arm SPCA >\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBody transformation journeys\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\nVanessa Hudgens gives birth\nShowbiz | July 04, 2024\nBaseball playing pup\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nMischievous Beagle caught tearing up the toilet paper\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nVintage bathrooms\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\n\n\n\nNorth Okanagan Quick Links\nCity of Vernon\nVernon Discussion Forum\nDistrict of Coldstream\nVillage of Lumby\nCity of Armstrong\nCity of Enderby\nDistrict of Sicamous\nInterior Health\nOkanagan Regional Library\n\u00a9 2024 Castanet.net Make Castanet Your Homepage News Tips Advertising Contact Us"},
{"url": "https://infotel.ca/newsitem/national-reconciliation-day-corporate/cp2120467292", "title": "Indigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30 | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Ka|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 27.7\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nIndigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30\nTara Deschamps\nKrystal Abotossaway poses for a photograph in Toronto's financial district on Monday, Feb. 8, 2020. Abotossaway, president of the Indigenous Professional Association of Canada, and other Indigenous business leaders want corporate support around National Day for Truth and Reconciliation to extend all year round and transform companies, so they're more supportive of Indigenous staff every day. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Tijana Martin\nSeptember 30, 2022 - 8:32 AM\n\nTORONTO - Chelsee Pettit spent much of the summer collaborating with designers to create and manufacture apparel reflective of the Indigenous values she hoped would be on people's minds when Canada marks its second National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.\n\nBut in the days leading up to Sept. 30, she noticed many companies had not had the same forethought and were scrambling to place bulk orders with her store, Aaniin.\n\n\"It's just a little funny how last-minute other organizations that are all non-Indigenous are, and they're pushing that (work) back onto Indigenous people,\" said Pettit, an Anishinaabe woman.\n\n\"We're not like big box stores that just have disposable T-shirts and are at everybody's beck and call. Working with us ahead of time as opposed to just laying it on us a week before the day, I think would be super helpful.\"\n\nPettit has tried her best to accommodate last-minute orders, but she and other members of the Indigenous business community see the trend as a sign of how much more work corporate Canada has to do to turn support for Indigenous communities into a 365-day-a-year effort.\n\nWhile many businesses encourage staff to don orange shirts \u2014 a tradition started by residential school survivor Phyllis Webstad in 2013 \u2014 or to sell wares in the bright hue on Sept. 30, those efforts quickly fade. Companies often don't do much more to elevate Indigenous voices and causes.\n\n\"It is positive that we are seeing education happen and awareness-building happen, but it can be quite triggering and harmful for Indigenous Peoples who see it as one day of performative action and nothing throughout the rest of the year,\" said Tabatha Bull, president and chief executive of the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business (CCAB).\n\nBull and Pettit say if an employer is looking to make a mark on truth and reconciliation goals, they should also be doing that work all year round.\n\nThose efforts should begin with educating staff about both long-standing and new traumas Indigenous Peoplesface and how to support those affected.\n\nPettit recallsbeing at work in 2021, when the remains of 215 children were found at a former residential school site in British Columbia.\n\n\"My boss at the time was like, 'Oh, well, everybody knew about that already' and just like kind of brushed it off, but I was feeling very emotional that day for obvious reasons, so there's tons of work that has to be done,\" she said.\n\nThat's borne out in studies too.\n\nA 2021 report from equity organization Catalyst Canada found about 52 per cent of the 86 Indigenous respondents surveyed are \u201con guard\u201d at work and about 60 per cent feel psychologically unsafe on the job.\n\nThe study was based on a survey of 820 Canadian workers from various under-represented groups, but Catalyst isolated results from Indigenous respondents for this report because their need to feel on guard was so significant.\n\nKrystal Abotossaway, president of the Indigenous Professional Association of Canada, said she has seen more companies move toward reflecting on what they can do to improve their corporate culture and support Indigenous communities in recent years.\n\nLand acknowledgments, which note which Indigenous Peoples lived and took care of a site events are being held on, are an increasingly common and good start, she said.\n\nBull counts at least 200 companies, including Bank of Montreal, Uber, Walmart and Rogers, as members of the CCAB's Progressive Aboriginal Relation program \u2014 an initiative helping them build cultural awareness and make progress on reconciliation plans.\n\nOthers have yet to take on such work. Bull thinks they're slower to act because they feel overwhelmed and afraid of having difficult conversations.\n\n\"Some corporations are just not even knowing what the right question is to ask,\" she said. \"I think we need to move beyond that, if we're going to really progress as a country.\"\n\nAbotossaway said they can start by marking other Indigenous days and use them as an opportunity to educate.\n\nAmong those she suggested are Red Dress Day, which commemorates the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and International Inuit Day, National Indigenous Peoples Day and Louis Riel Day, which celebrates the life of the late M\u00e9tis leader.\n\nThe efforts shouldn't stop there, she added. Companies should reflect on how their governance structures, hiring policies, talent pipelines and workforce education programs align with Indigenous needs, she said.\n\n\"We've seen a lot of learning and development content come out, but that's usually just one course and it might be just an hour long,\" she said.\n\n\"Is it mandatory or is it not mandatory? And then how many of your employees or workforce are participating in it?\"\n\nAbotossaway and Bull agree any corporate actions on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation or other days should involve Indigenous Peoples at every step \u2014 even if the action is selling orange apparel.\n\nBull said, \"If you're going to create an orange shirt, ensure that you're working with an Indigenous artist, ensure that the Orange Shirt Society or an Indigenous organization benefits from that and you're not making a profit off of the orange shirt or Sept. 30.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Sept. 30, 2022.\n\nCompanies in this story: (TSX:BMO, TSX:RCI)\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2022\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are {"url": "https://www.humboldtjournal.ca/news/red-dress-project-founder-speaks-out-1.24097301", "title": "Red dress project founder speaks out - SaskToday.ca", "body": "Skip to content\nSign in or register for your free account  \nHomeWest Central & North\nEast Central\nSouthwest\nSoutheast\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nConnect\nHOME NORTH LOCAL NEWS\nRed dress project founder speaks out\nMELFORT\u2014 Jaime Black, the creator of the red dress project, spoke about red dress displays being defaced, answering an audience question, following it happening in Nipawin.\nJessica R. Durling\nMar 13, 2020 11:27 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nJaime Black said when the red dress displays are defaced, it can be used as an educational opportunity about the violence Indigenous women and girls are facing. Photo by Jessica R. Durling\n\nMELFORT\u2014 Jaime Black, the creator of the red dress project, spoke about red dress displays being defaced, answering an audience question, following it happening in Nipawin.\n\n\u201cI think that when actions like that happen, we really get to see what\u2019s happening,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIt sort of brings forward what\u2019s really going on underneath the surface in people\u2019s minds in our communities, and I think it\u2019s really a potential for a learning opportunity and creating a space for having conversations about why we\u2019re talking about Indigenous women and not all women. Of course all human life is valuable and important, but Indigenous women specifically are being targeted through these colonial systems in a way white women aren\u2019t. \u201d\n\nBlack visited the region during the Melfort\u2019s annual Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls conference on March 10.\n\nFirst started in 2009, the red dresses are an installation art project designed to draw attention to missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nBlack said that while the dresses are a commemoration project, they are also a call to action.\n\n\u201cThe idea of the dresses is to get people learning about what\u2019s going on if they don\u2019t know, but also to get active and change how they relate to people, and break down these barriers created by racism and colonialism.\u201d\n\nAn example of the barriers includes a low response time by the RCMP when investigating missing Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u201cI heard from a family that they called about their missing daughter, and the police told them, \u2018they don\u2019t do family reunions\u2019 and hung up the phone on them.\u201d\n\nGlenda Yuzicappi knows this personally. Her daughter, Amber Redman went missing in 2005.\n\nYuzicappi told her daughter\u2019s story at the conference.\n\n\u201cI did face the delay with the police,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cNot only the police, the media\u2026 She wasn\u2019t a priority. If it was a non-First Nations woman they would have been out there. I see it in the public\u2019s view, I see it happening.\u201d\n\nRedman went missing on a Thursday. Yuzicappi said that due to her own panic and denial she delayed contacting the police until Monday. Even then, Yuzicappi feels the police delayed the search further, not starting an active search until the family initiated one Wednesday.\n\n\u201cI phoned the police Wednesday morning and then I said \u2018we\u2019re starting a search\u2019 and that\u2019s when they came on board.\u201d\n\nYuzicappi said the issue is still continuing today. She advocates all women learn self-defensive, go in a buddy system, and let people know when they\u2019re leaving.\n\n\u201cOur women are still in danger from being taken, being abducted and I will continue to share my daughter\u2019s story. If it can help one person, then that\u2019s my purpose for today,\u201d Yuzicappi said.\n\n\u00a0\u201cAlways be observant of your area and where you\u2019re at\u2014 the parking lot, anywhere, grocery store, movie theatre\u2014 anywhere. People, men and even women can take you.\u201d\n\nAccording to Statistics Canada, nine per cent of female homicide victims in 1980 were Indigenous. By 2015, Indigenous women made up 24 per cent of homicide victims in Canada. This was noted in the federal government\u2019s 2018 interim report for the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nThe 2018 interim report shows that while homicide rates for non-Indigenous women have gone down over the decades, homicide rates for Indigenous women have been going up. Indigenous women are 12 times more likely to be murdered or missing than any other women in Canada, and 16 times more likely than Caucasian women.\n\nIn Manitoba or Saskatchewan, they are 19 more times likely than Caucasian women to be murdered or missing.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s on a street level, people are facing racism on a day to day basis still in our country, but it\u2019s also in the institutions,\u201d Black said.\n\n\u201cThe voices of Indigenous people are not being brought to the forefront and there\u2019s no space for Indigenous voices to be heard.\u201d\n\nBlack said often times being an ally is thought of as overcomplicated.\n\n\u201cIt can be as simple as really showing care and compassion to each other on a day to day basis and really reaching out to people when you feel like they need support. It sounds trite and sort of cute or whatever, but it\u2019s real. I think that showing care for each other is a really powerful way of fighting against these systems that are trying to tear us down.\u201d\n\nDuring the conference, Black also discussed the Wet'suwet'en First Nation in British Columbia, whose matriarchs were arrested in an RCMP raid\u2014after the women refused to leave their land for a pipeline to be built.\n\nBlack said to be an ally means being present in fighting alongside Indigenous people and protecting the land and water.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really an opportunity for non-Indigenous people to show their care for not just Indigenous culture but also the land they live on and I think we get really political with all these stuff. Yes it is political, but with me I just go back to what I stand for and what\u2019s important to me living on this land,\u201d she said\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s protecting the land and making sure it\u2019s able to provide for generations to come, and not abused through industry.\u201d\n\nBlack said it can be a scary time for Indigenous people, as the more the community stands up and speaks out the more racist backlash there is.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of pushback towards us speaking out, but I think if we do that together hopefully we can remain as safe as possible as we stand up and do this work.\u201d\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nGet your daily Saskatchewan news briefing\nEmail\nSign Up\nThis has not been shared. Be the first!\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tSpeed limits imposed on Saskatoon neighbourhood bikeways\n\tStudent bus pass increase needs another look: Sask Rivers\n\tFlexible Learning Initiative empowers students\nAROUND SASKTODAY\nStatistics Canada says merchandise trade deficit widened to $1.9B in May\nHow to find \u2014 and use \u2014 a budgeting app that works best for you\nSaskatchewan Skies: Mars rises a little after midnight in July\nFifteen provincial parks celebrate Canada Day\nOutdoor flea market appeared like travel in time \n\nMORE AROUND SASKTODAY >\n\nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nParticipate in our next community poll.\nAre you proud of Canada?\n Yes\n No\n\nVote Results > Archives >\n\nWest Central & North\nNews\nIn the Community\nBusiness\nAgriculture\nOil & Gas\nSports\nNorth Region Newspapers\nNorth Digital Editions\nEast Central\nNews\nIn the Community\nBusiness\nSports\nAgriculture\nOil & Gas\nCentral Region Newspapers\nCentral Digital Editions\nSouthwest\nNews\nBusiness\nIn the Community\nAgriculture\nSports\nSoutheast\nNews\nIn the Community\nBusiness\nAgriculture\nOil & Gas\nSports\nSouth Region Newspapers\nSouth Digital Editions\nOpinion\nSouth Opinion\nCentral Opinion\nNorth Opinion\nArts & Life\nSouth Arts\nCentral Arts\nNorth Arts\nEverybody has a story\nEvent Calendar\nThe Mix\nSouth Photos and Videos\nCentral Photos and Videos\nNorth Photos and Videos\nFeatures\nSouth Gas Prices\nCentral Gas Prices\nNorth Gas Prices\nSpotlight\nConnect\nDaily Headlines Newsletter\nAbout\nAbout SaskToday.ca\nAdvertise with Us\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of service\nPolitical Ad Registry\nVisit our network of sites:\n   \nRadio brands:\n\tEdmonton | Fort McMurray\nSaskatoon | Yorkton\n\tEdmonton | Fort McMurray\nRed Deer | Regina\n\tCalgary | Red Deer\n\tRegina\n\tRegina\n\tYorkton\n\n\u00a9 2024 SaskToday.ca"},

LOCAL NEWS\nRed dresses create powerful symbol at Douglas College\nIt\u2019s not laundry day at Douglas College The 24 red dresses hung from trees at the school\u2019s Coquitlam campus and blowing in the gentle late-spring breeze are a symbol of something much more serious.\nMario Bartel\nJun 18, 2019 9:17 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 2 Douglas College instructor Teresa Howell stands amidst some of the 24 red dresses hung in trees on the Coquitlam campus by students in her third year psychology class to help raise awareness around the issue of murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls.MARIO BARTEL/THE TRI-CITY NEWS\nExpand\n\nIt\u2019s not laundry day at Douglas College\n\nThe 24 red dresses hung from trees at the school\u2019s Coquitlam campus and blowing in the gentle late-spring breeze are a symbol of something much more serious.\n\nThe dresses, which range from a fancy prom gown to a simple child\u2019s frock, are a local take on the REDress Project, an art installation initiated in 2014 by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black to commemorate more than 1,000 missing and murdered Indigenous women across Canada.\n\nThe garments were gathered and hung by students in Teresa Howell\u2019s third-year psychology course at Douglas that focusses on cultural competency and counselling in Indigenous communities.\n\nHowell said the students\u2019 display is a way to create deeper understanding of issues like racism and oppression of Indigenous people by showing, in a real way, their consequences.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s looking at the bigger picture of systemic racism and how it can be detrimental to everybody,\u201d Howell said.\n\nThe dresses are hung in trees along the school\u2019s main walk from Pinetree Way that passes right by its Indigenous garden, as well as around the plaza to the main entrance. An explanatory card is pinned to each one.\n\n\u201cI wanted it to be easy for people to know what it is about,\u201d Howell said.\n\nThe timing of the dresses\u2019 appearance is no accident, either. The installation began June 7, just four days after the federal government released the final report from its inquiry into the social, economic, cultural and historical causes of violence against Indigenous women and girls that launched in 2016.\n\nWhile one of the report\u2019s conclusions was there was no reliable way to determine how many Indigenous women have been murdered or gone missing over the years, it did say the murder rate for Indigenous women in Canada was almost six times higher from 2001 to \u201915 than it was for non-Indigenous women. The report blamed \u201cpersistent and deliberate human and Indigenous rights violations and abuses,\u201d and recommended \u201cdismantling the structure of colonialism within Canadian society.\u201d\n\nHowell said the dresses make the statistics and bureaucratic statements more real, driving the issue home to young people when they\u2019re still seeking their place in the world.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re at such a pivotal age to gain awareness and to look at the world in a different way,\u201d she said, adding she\u2019s confident at least one or two might heed the message of the dresses as a call to action to begin volunteering or even alter their career path.\n\n\u201cPeople learn quite viscerally.\u201d\n\nHowell said she hopes the dresses will remain in place through the school\u2019s summer semester, beckoning curiosity from passersby and, hopefully, sparking a dialogue, not only amongst students but across the community.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s powerful.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Friday is National Indigenous Peoples\u2019 Day and there are several events in the Tri-Cities, including a student festival at Rocky Point Park in Port Moody hosted by students and staff of School District 43\u2019s Aboriginal Education program. The event, which runs from 9:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m., will also include a free drop-in lacrosse for beginners and advanced players. From 6 to 9:30 p.m., there will be a water blessing ceremony with Elder Ta7ah Amy George and Charlene Aleck from Tsleil Waututh First Nation as well as a feast at 7:30 p.m. and entertainment beginning at 8 p.m.\n\nGet your daily Coquitlam news briefing\nEmail\nSign Up\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nMore Local News\n\tCOVID-19 taught us 'how intensely the arts\u00a0is needed': PoMoArts ED\n\tB.C. salmon are struggling.
