{"url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/terese-marie-mailhot/if-im-murdered-or-go-missing-dont-hang-a-red-dress-for-me_a_23019892/", "title": "If I'm Murdered Or Go Missing, Don't Hang A Red Dress For Me | HuffPost Life", "body": "Skip to Main Content\nWHAT'S HOT\nConservative Commentator Says Trump\u2019s Post-Debate Move Is \u2018Freaking A Lot Of People Out\u2019\nKristi Noem\u2019s Shot At Kamala Harris Backfires Immediately\nAuthoritarianism Expert Exposes Chilling \u2018Codeword\u2019 In \u2018Project 2025\u2019 Plan For Trump\nJames Carville Issues Blunt Plea To Democratic Donors About Ditching Biden\n\u2018Pile Of Crap\u2019: Trump Rails Against Biden, Harris In Unhinged Rant Caught On Video\nTrump Spokesperson\u2019s Insane Call For \u2018Total Surrender\u2019 Shot Down On Newsmax\nChristina Applegate Shares 2 Things She Wants To Do In 'The Days I Have Left'\nThe Economist Burns Joe Biden With Brutal Cover Showing A Walker\nThis Doctor Has Treated Thousands Of Skin Cancer Cases. Here Are 9 Things He'd Never Do.\nVan Jones Reveals \u2018Behind The Scenes\u2019 Moves That Could End Biden Campaign\nMary Trump Sounds The Alarm On MAGA: \u2018Spreading Like A Virus\u2019\nWhy Any Biden Replacement Besides Harris Would Face A Major Fundraising Hassle\nLog In\nSUPPORT US\nNEWS\nPOLITICS\nENTERTAINMENT\nLIFE\nPERSONAL\nVOICES\nSHOPPING\n\ud83c\udfc6 PLAY PYRAMID SCHEME \ud83c\udfc6\nU.S. Edition\nOpen editions submenu\nThis HuffPost Canada page is maintained as part of an online archive.\nLIFE\nBLOGS\nINDIGENOUS RIGHTS\nINDIGENOUS WOMEN\nIf I'm Murdered Or Go Missing, Don't Hang A Red Dress For Me\nI think about it all and wonder if there are enough dresses or symbols in the world to signify that pain and distress for Indigenous people.\nBy\u00a0\nTerese Marie Mailhot, Contributor\nEssayist, Columnist, Indigenous Mother\nJul 7, 2017, 11:30 AM EDT\n|Updated Jul 7, 2017\nThis post was published on the now-closed HuffPost Contributor platform. Contributors control their own work and posted freely to our site. If you need to flag this entry as abusive, send us an email.\n\nPreviously Published at Indian Country Today.\n\nI've seen red dresses hung on trees, on campuses and elsewhere to honour murdered and missing Indigenous women. The aesthetic response is artistically stunning, but it's inanimate and pretty, and it's simultaneously disturbing when I consider the symbol isn't ascribed the value of purity or innocence. I support artistic endeavors to memorialize or create symbols, but I don't provide blind support to anything. If I'm beaten to death or go missing, don't hang a red dress for me.\n\nM\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black created the installation: \"I'm allowing people to critically think about the issue... it's amazing how... powerful it is to see these dresses just hanging there, and when you walk by them it feels like you are walking by someone but no one is in them. It really works as a kind of visceral reminder of these women.\"\n\nANDREW FRANCIS WALLACE VIA GETTY IMAGESRed dresses were seen hanging from the trees on the University of Toronto campus as part of the Red Dress Project, which brings attention to Canada's missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThe red dress appears ghostly and impersonal, especially after it's become so familiar and synonymous -- I have come to resent when editors choose the red dress over a human face for stories about murdered and missing women, because I wonder about the danger and benefit of giving a cause to protect human life an image with no features, or life, or blood, or viscera.\n\nArt isn't enough when it's meant for an active audience.\n\nIt isn't Black's fault that there is something amiss with the way in which Indigenous women are treated in North America. It's not her fault that the tally of women missing and murdered grows as the inquiry encounters set back after set back. The work served as an aesthetic reminder that there is a blaring, unsightly, crazy-making problem and if people cannot acknowledge the inherent racism, indignity and hatred Indian women face, they will at least have to acknowledge these images: a red dress in a stagnant winter forest, or the dresses picking up a cool breeze in the spring on a peaceful day...\n\nIt's what people do with the reminder that has fallen short. It's that art isn't enough when it's meant for an active audience.\n\nArtwork like this doesn't need to be perpetuated for years without critical thought or discussion. The work is supposed to be talked about. Without that it becomes something static. The implication of a red dress signifying the absence of an Indian woman might be too much. Red doesn't symbolize promiscuity or sex work where I'm from. It's used to create positive and negative spaces, so I see the appeal in the dresses, but to majority culture the red dress doesn't signify power typically, or purity, or healing, but when have I ever cared about the average audience? Only when I'm trying to discern something's worth, or why it underwhelms me, or why I believe it might have a negative impact over its intent.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nIt's necessary to consider these things when I know I've witnessed enough domestic violence, sexual violence and brutality to where those artistic gestures hold personal value -- this work is close to me. Someone could hang a dress for me someday, god forbid. God forbid they would choose that aesthetic response to my death.\n\nI'd prefer an effigy of my culprit to burn, hanging. I'd prefer something more than a dress, considering how rare it is I wear them. What about leggings, or a sign, \"Death to my enemies.\" I entertain these morbid things when I consider the desperation of injustice. That it doesn't come sometimes, and all I can do is wonder what will any of us do if we lose another one. Can we keep hanging red dresses? It feels like pining for justice -- it feels like laying down a rose for something unrequited, and I guess that's what symbolic gestures are, because there's absence-- something we can't exact, and we try to make something tangible to memorialize -- physicalize our grief, yearning, idea or memory.\n\nI wonder if there are enough dresses or symbols in the world to signify that pain and distress for Indigenous people.\n\nI was poolside on the Fourth of July when I received news Barbara Kentner died. The woman, my age -- a mother, too, was hit by a trailer hitch in Thunder Bay. The white man who hit her shouted, \"I got one,\" and drove away, and now she's gone. It mattered that I was enjoying my life that moment before, because I felt untouchable in some way. The news, every time another woman dies, breaks me hard.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nI think about all the women who died that way, and others who worked their whole lives to the bone, and left behind debt, and deserved better; and I think about the men who died violently, too; and I think about my father, who was beaten to death, and I consider the violence he inflicted himself. I think about it all and wonder if there are enough dresses or symbols in the world to signify that pain and distress for Indigenous people.\n\nWith all the good intentions of the dress, or a tobacco tie, or any one single good thing -- I fear it pales to the willful ignorance of passersby, who won't engage -- not with a dress, or our bodies. I fear so much of our well-intended work pales, even our writing, to the men who abuse their power, or social workers who cannot be bothered to regard us, or to people who would prefer we be replaced with dresses. To what end, I think, every time I see a dress instead of the woman who should be there on that campus, or in that forest with her children, or in the breeze, anywhere but absent and unheard -- a dress.\n\nFollow HuffPost Canada Blogs on Facebook\n\nAlso on HuffPost:\n\nRELATED\nBLOGS\nINDIGENOUS RIGHTS\nINDIGENOUS WOMEN\nLIVING\nMISSING MURDERED ABORIGINAL WOMEN\nSuggest a correction\nFROM OUR PARTNER\nRecommended by\nThis HuffPost Canada page is maintained as part of an online archive. {"url": "https://blog.hootsuite.com/brands-support-indigenous-communities-on-social/", "title": "How Brands Can Support Indigenous Communities on Social\u2014the Right Way - Social Media Marketing & Management Dashboard", "body": "Skip to content\nWhy Hootsuite\nWhat We Do\nPricing\nResources\nNeed help?\nLog In\nSign up\nBlog\nStrategy\nHootsuite HQ\nExperiments\nFree Tools\nHootsuite HQ\nHow Brands Can Support Indigenous Communities on Social\u2014the Right Way\n\nIt\u2019s important for businesses to show up on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation. The NWAC\u2019s CEO explains how to get it right.\n\nLynne Groulx\nSeptember 23, 2022\n\nThere is a growing interest among businesses, large and small, to add their voices to the nationwide acknowledgment of the trauma inflicted upon Indigenous children at Canada\u2019s Indian Residential Schools.\n\nThis was amplified in 2021 with the location of nearly a thousand unmarked graves at sites of the now-shuttered institutions\u2014and we know thousands more have yet to be discovered.\n\nOn National Day for Truth and Reconciliation, it\u2019s important for Indigenous people (and, frankly, for non-Indigenous people) to see businesses and brands honour those who lost their lives through the 165-year program of assimilation.\n\nIt\u2019s also important for us as Indigenous people to see them pay tribute to those who survived their years at the notorious schools.\n\nBut deploying the hashtag #TruthAndReconciliation or #EveryChildMatters can be a risky undertaking. There are many ways to make a well-meaning blunder that will prompt eye rolls throughout Indigenous Canada or, worse, to accidentally post something that\u2019s outright offensive.\n\nThat\u2019s why I wrote this blog post. I\u2019m a M\u00e9tis woman and lawyer who has been the CEO of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC), the largest organization representing Indigenous women in Canada, since 2017.\n\nI, and other Indigenous women who follow social media, brace ourselves as September 30 rolls around, waiting for the inevitable ham-fisted attempt by non-Indigenous actors to be part of the commemoration.\n\nPlease don\u2019t misunderstand. We want you to be there with us as we grieve and as we remember and as we honour. We just want you to do so respectfully. So here are some guidelines.\n\nWhat is the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation? How is it different from Orange Shirt Day? And what should we call it on social media?\n\nThe National Day for Truth and Reconciliation was declared by the Canadian government in 2021, after the graves were found at Indian Residential Schools.\n\n(Please note: \u201cIndian Residential Schools\u201d is the official name for the schools and a construct of the colonial mindset of 19th Century Canada. In any other context, the word Indian is extremely offensive when used to refer to the Indigenous people of Turtle Island.)\n\nNational Day for Truth and Reconciliation is a day for honouring the victims and celebrating the survivors of the schools. And it\u2019s a federal statutory holiday, so it applies to all federally regulated workplaces. But it\u2019s been left to provinces and territories to choose whether it is marked within their own jurisdictions.\n\nWe note that it took Canada\u2019s federal Liberal government (which came to power in 2015 promising to act on all 94 Calls to Action of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission) nearly seven years to meet the relatively simple Call Number 80. It urged the creation of the holiday \u201cto ensure that public commemoration of the history and legacy of residential schools remains a vital component of the reconciliation process.\u201d\n\nThere is no doubt that the discovery of the graves\u2014which the Truth and Reconciliation report said would be found if an effort was made to look for them\u2014bolstered public support for such a day.\n\nSeptember 30 should be thought of as our Remembrance Day, and it should be referred to by its official name: the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation. Any other name fails to communicate the sombreness of the occasion, just as it minimizes Remembrance Day to call it Poppy Day.\n\nSeptember 30 is also Orange Shirt Day, reminding us of the day in 1973 when six-year-old Phyllis Webstad from the Stswecem\u2019c Xgat\u2019tem First Nation arrived at the St. Joseph Mission Residential School, just outside Williams Lake, B.C.\n\nShe was wearing a vibrant orange shirt her grandmother bought her to match her excitement for her first day of school. But the shirt was immediately taken from her by school authorities and never returned\u2014an event that marked the beginning of the year of atrocities and torment she experienced at the institution.\n\nWe wear orange shirts on September 30 as a reminder of the traumas inflicted by residential schools. If you\u2019re specifically referring to Phyllis\u2019 story on social media, then it is appropriate to call it Orange Shirt Day.\n\nBut the holiday is the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation, and should be referred to as such.\n\nWhat terms should you use when you refer to Indigenous people? (Terminology 101)\n\nSpeaking of terminology, when is it appropriate to refer to someone as First Nations, M\u00e9tis, or Inuit, and when is it appropriate to refer to someone as Indigenous?\n\nFirst up, here\u2019s what those different terms actually mean:\n\nFirst Nations: The largest Indigenous group in Canada, these are members of the 634 First Nations spread across the country\nM\u00e9tis: A distinct group of people who have an ancestral connection to a group of French Canadian traders and Indigenous women who settled in the Red River Valley of Manitoba and the Prairies\nInuit: The Indigenous people of the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions\nIndigenous: The First Peoples of North America whose ancestors were here before the arrival of the Europeans\n\nNext, where to use them: It\u2019s always best to be as specific as you possibly can when describing us on social media.\n\nHere\u2019s a quick reference on the best way to refer to Indigenous individuals:\n\nReference the person\u2019s specific first nation and its location\nReference the person\u2019s nation and ethno-cultural group\nReference their ethno-cultural group\nRefer to them as First Nations, M\u00e8tis, or Inuit\nRefer to the person as Indigenous\n\nSo, if someone is a Cree from the Cree First Nation of Waswanipi, say that. Second best would be to call them a Waswanipi Cree. Third best would be to call them a Cree. Fourth best would be to call them a First Nations member.\n\nAnd fifth best would be to call them Indigenous, which is a catch-all phrase that includes all First Nations, M\u00e9tis, and Inuit. But it also includes all Indigenous people around the world. The M\u0101ori of New Zealand are Indigenous.\n\nSaying someone is Indigenous is like calling a Chinese person Asian. It\u2019s true. But it misses a lot of detail.\n\nIf you don\u2019t know how best to describe someone, ask us. Preferences vary from individual to individual.\n\nBut please, despite the fact that my organization is called the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, which is a holdover from a much earlier time (NWAC was formed in 1974), please do not call Indigenous people \u2018native.\u2019\n\nWhat role should brands play on social media on September 30?\n\nAt NWAC, our hashtag for the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation is #RememberHonourAct. We think those are good guidelines for everyone\u2014individuals and businesses alike\u2014on September 30 and, indeed, year-round.\n\nRemember the survivors of the residential schools, honour them, and act to strengthen the relationship between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people.\n\nIf yours is a local business, pay tribute to the Indigenous people in your area. Acknowledge their traditional territory. Recognize that your operations are taking place on the land that they have shared with you, and that you and your employees are benefitting from that.\n\nIf you are a national brand, turn the spotlight back on the First Nations communities. Highlight the achievements and the contributions that First Nations people have made to Canadian prosperity.\n\nYes, September 30 is a sombre day of remembrance. But we don\u2019t want pity. We want acknowledgments of past wrongs and promises that they will not be repeated, but we also want to embrace the promise of a better future in which Indigenous people can enjoy prosperous and happy lives free of historical trauma.\n\nAre there other notable days for brands to keep in mind for Indigenous people?\n\nYes.\n\nThere are other sombre days.\n\nLess than a week after the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation, Indigenous women across Canada will gather at Sisters in Spirit Vigils to honour the women, girls, and gender-diverse people who have lost their lives in the ongoing genocide that targets us for violence. This is an annual event created to give support and comfort to the families and friends who have been left to mourn their loved ones.\n\nOn February 14, Valentine\u2019s Day, annual Women\u2019s Memorial Marches are held in cities and towns across Canada and the United States. They too are meant to honour Indigenous women and girls who have been murdered or who have gone missing.\n\nAnd on May 5, we mark Red Dress Day, a day on which red dresses are hung in windows and in public spaces around Canada, again to honour the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nBut there are also joyous occasions.\n\nAlthough there is not a specific date set aside, summer is the time for gathering. It is powwow season. Fall is the time that we traditionally rejoice in the bounty of the hunt.\n\nOn June 21, the Summer Solstice, we celebrate National Indigenous Peoples Day. This is a day for rejoicing in our heritage, our diverse cultures, and the contributions that Indigenous people are making to the complex fabric of Canadian life.\n\nWhat social media mistakes do brands make on September 30?\n\nThe most egregious examples of brand behaviour around the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation are attempts to monetize our pain for financial gain.\n\nIf you own a clothing company, please don\u2019t print a batch of orange shirts and sell them for profit. And don\u2019t promote the sales of your shirts on social media. This happens every year and it is offensive in the extreme.\n\nOn the other hand, printing and selling orange shirts and then turning the profits over to Indigenous causes is a wonderful gesture of support.\n\nAnd it\u2019s not just the small brands that are doing this. Walmart, for instance, promises to donate 100% of the profits from its Every Child Matters t-shirts, which have been designed by an Indigenous artist, to the Orange Shirt Society.\n\nBe the brand that does something like that.\n\nIn all of your social media posts, be mindful that this is our history. Every Indigenous person in Canada has been touched by the residential school experience, whether or not we or our ancestors attended one of the institutions. Be mindful of the traumas that can be brought to the fore with a thoughtless twist of words.\n\nAnd again, Indigenous people are at a place where we don\u2019t need or want pity. We need people to celebrate our accomplishments. We need to feel part of a society that is eager to include us.\n\nWhat opportunities are there for intersections between Indigenous people and other social movements?\n\nIn a simple word: lots.\n\nIf there is a social justice issue being championed\u2014whether that is Pride in the gender-diverse community, or climate justice, or prisoners\u2019 rights, or racial equality\u2014you\u2019ll find Indigenous people at the forefront.\n\nMy organization is an example of that. We have whole units of staff working on all of those things.\n\nReach out to us, or other national Indigenous organizations (we list a few later on), to ask about ways you can get involved, projects you can promote, and causes you can stand behind.\n\nThis is a prime opportunity to collaborate with Indigenous creators who are passionate about the larger social issue at hand.\n\nHow can brands work with Indigenous content creators?\n\nFind them and ask them. There are plenty out there. Any search engine will quickly turn up hundreds of names of Indigenous content creators and influencers, and many will be eager to collaborate with you.\n\nHere are some examples of places to look:\n\nTikTok Accelerator for Indigenous Creators\nAPTN Profile of Indigenous Creators\nPBS Article on Indigenous Creators\nTeenVogue Roundup of Indigenous Creators\nCBC Profile on Indigenous Creators\nWhat Indigenous organizations can brands support or partner with?\n\nMost of the National Indigenous Organizations are looking for partners. We, at NWAC, have terrific partnerships with brands like Sephora, Hootsuite, and TikTok.\n\nBut there are also smaller groups out there who would be delighted to hear from you.\n\nOne example that immediately springs to mind is Project Forest in Alberta which is working in partnership with Indigenous communities to restore sacred lands so that medicinal plants and native species will thrive again in First Nations communities.\n\nThere is also a range of organizations that are working tirelessly to improve the lives of the First Nations, M\u00e9tis, and Inuit.\n\nI would point to the First Nations Child and Family Caring Society of Canada, Susan Aglukark\u2019s Arctic Rose Foundation, The Martin Family Initiative, or the Indian Residential School Survivors Society.\n\nThose are just a few. And of course, there is NWAC\u2014we work tirelessly for the well-being of Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people.\n\nWhat are some examples of brands that are supporting and/or highlighting Indigenous communities the right way?\n\nMany brands are doing things right. I will again mention beauty company Sephora partnered with the NWAC to run a roundtable on Indigenous beauty to find out where they could improve. And they\u2019ve acted on their learnings.\n\nTikTok, likewise, has taken the time to reach out to us to ask for guidance on how to get engaged with Indigenous people and communities. And, over the past few years, we have worked closely with Hootsuite, providing advice and information.\n\nBut others are also making great strides.\n\nI would point to the National Hockey League which has been unreservedly vocal in denouncing the racism directed at Indigenous hockey players. The Calgary Flames opened their season with a land acknowledgement.\n\nThis would not have happened 10, or maybe even five, years ago. But society is changing, corporate behaviour is changing, the world is changing. And social media has had, and will have, much to do with that.\n\nContent creation\nBecome a better social marketer.\n\nGet expert social media advice delivered straight to your inbox.\n\nEmail address\nSign up\nBy Lynne Groulx\n\nLynne is a M\u00e9tis lawyer and Chief Executive Officer of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) who works 24/7 on behalf of Indigenous women in Canada. News\nHighway of Tears: Terrace-to-Hazeltons bus service starts today\nAn extension from Terrace to the Hazeltons of B.C. Transit's service along Highway 16 starts Monday.\nVictoria Times-Colonist Staff\nNov 20, 2017 6:01 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nA B.C. Transit bus picks up passengers in Prince George before heading to Burns Lake this summer.\n\n\u00a0\n\nAn extension from Terrace to the Hazeltons of B.C. Transit's service along Highway 16 starts Monday.\n\n\"This new route will provide some communities with public transportation for the first time, meaning safe and reliable transportation so people can get to appointments, access services and visit friends and family,\" Transportation and Infrastructure Minister Claire Trevena said in a media release.\n\nIt is the fourth service to begin this year on Highway, also known as the Highway of Tears. B.C. Transit is also running buses between Smithers and Moricetown, between Burns Lake and Smithers, and between Burns Lake and Prince George.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or have disappeared on Highway 16 and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nThe BC Transit route 164 Kispiox/Terrace will make round-trips on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday.\n\nIn addition, the 163 Kispiox/Smithers (formerly route number 2) will add an additional day of service and will operate on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.\n\nA new route number 32 West Connector will be introduced, operating on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays between Hazelton and Gitwangak.\n\nThe route 31 Kispiox/Gitsegukla (formerly route number 1) will change the days it operates and will now run on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.\n\nThe standard one-way fare is $5, while seniors and students will pay $4 each way.\n\nThe B.C. government has committed to $6.4 million over five years to the entire Highway 16 service, covering the full cost of the buses and two-thirds of the operating cost, with local governments and First Nations contributing the rest.\n\u00a0\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.nsnews.com/local-news/red-dress-day-tsleil-waututh-nation-8690463", "title": "Commemorating MMIW this Red Dress Day - North Shore News", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\nPublic Notices\n21.9 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nCommemorating murdered and missing Indigenous women this Red Dress Day\nThe Tsleil-Waututh Nation\u2019s Charlene Aleck calls for honour and acknowledgement this May 5.\n\tMina Kerr-Lazenby, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter\n\nMay 2, 2024 3:56 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRed Dress Day, May 5, raises awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women. | North Shore News files\nListen to this article\n00:03:21\n\nIt\u2019s been 14 years since Canadian M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black hung red dresses in public spaces, raising awareness of the staggering number of Indigenous women missing and murdered across the country.\n\nThe striking exhibition has since transformed into a full-fledged movement, with an annual event each year that provokes thought and honour from the public. Red Dress Day has ballooned in scale, but its message still remains as clear as it did that spring of 2010.\n\n\u201cRed Dress Day is about raising awareness and recognition of violence against women, and honouring those who didn\u2019t have a voice back then,\u201d said s\u0259lilw\u0259ta\u026c\u00a0(Tsleil-Waututh Nation) elected councillor Charlene Aleck.\n\n\u201cIt is an important day, but for First Nations communities it is especially significant because it relates to a lot of our ancestors and our relations. We are directly affected by our grandmothers and aunties being murdered, going missing, or even being mistreated,\u201d she said.\n\n\u00a0\n\nEach year rallies and marches mark the event as communities call on the government to take more action, something that has gained even further momentum since a 2019 inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women pushed for more action to end the endemic violence.\n\nThe inquiry found that Indigenous women and girls were 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than those from any other demographic, and 16 times more likely to go missing. The final, 1,200-page report included 231 actions, or \u201ccalls for justice,\u201d\u00a0that need to be taken by governments and Canadians.\n\nLocally, there are efforts being made from within First Nations communities to raise awareness on what the inquiry describes as\u00a0gender-based genocide. In previous years the Tsleil-Waututh Nation in particular has held ceremonies, marches, public events and poetry readings.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s been women\u2019s groups, where women come and bring their red dress. We say our prayers and lay out mementos to give ourselves strength to move on,\u201d said Aleck.\n\n\u201cThe Red Dress movement really speaks to a lot of the work that the Tsleil-Waututh Nation does, in trying to heal the land in order to heal the people,\u201d she added. \u201cWe\u2019re so committed as a Nation to reviving our language, continuing our ceremonies and healing the land. With that we\u2019re hoping to give our grandmother\u2019s the voice that they didn\u2019t have, to recognize the harm that was done to them and to heal.\u201d\n\nEach year the Tsleil-Waututh Nation also works in collaboration with the City of North Vancouver to bring about its Red Dress Day honouring ceremony, where the crowds gather at the Strength and Remembrance Pole in the plaza in front of North Vancouver RCMP detachment. This year the ceremony will take place May 3, from 11 a.m until noon.\n\n\u201cThe biggest response that we\u2019re hoping for with events like this is empathy,\u201d said Aleck. \u201cThere needs to be more empathy, and that seeps into relationships: The relationship of our community and the relationship of our leadership. It\u2019s that relationship that can help create change.\u201d\n\nMina Kerr-Lazenby is the North Shore News\u2019 Indigenous and civic affairs reporter. This reporting beat is made possible by the Local Journalism Initiative.\n\nMKerrLazenby@nsnews.com\ntwitter.com/MinaKerrLazenby\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a {"url": "http://www.weyburnthisweek.com/news/red-dress-campaign-raises-awareness-1.20359403", "title": "Red Dress campaign raises awareness - SaskToday.ca", "body": "Skip to content\nSign in or register for your free account  \nHomeWest Central & North\nEast Central\nSouthwest\nSoutheast\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nConnect\nHOME SOUTHEAST LOCAL NEWS\nRed Dress campaign raises awareness\nThe bright red colours of dresses will symbolize a very important message.\nSaskToday\nJun 5, 2017 7:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nThe bright red colours of dresses will symbolize a very important message.\u00a0 The CUPE local 5999 Aboriginal Council is collecting red dresses, with the ultimate goal of collecting 1,200 in total, to represent the number of murdered or missing Indigenous women in Canada.\n\u201cOnce we have those dresses, we are going to take them to a rally in Toronto during the CUPE convention and hopefully display them there,\u201d said Jodi Gosselin, chair of the CUPE local 5999 Aboriginal Council.\nAlternate plans for the red dresses are to have a demonstration either in Weyburn or Regina on Tuesday, October 24, which is the vigil for missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\u201cWith each dress that we collect, I would also like to display the name and the picture of a missing or murdered Indigenous woman,\u201d said Gosselin.\nThe Aboriginal Council is also planning for their upcoming celebration in honour of National Aboriginal Day, which will be held in Estevan on Wednesday, June 21. The event will celebrate the culture, traditions and contributions of First Nation, M\u00e9tis and Inuit people. Local schools have been invited to attend the National Aboriginal Day celebrations. The event will run at Centennial Park, located at 811 Souris Avenue in Estevan, from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m.\nThe Government of Canada has proclaimed June 21 as National Day of recognition for the Indigenous people of the country. This day also marks the summer solstice and the longest day of the year. It holds great significance to the Indigenous people of Canada and is often the day that many ceremonies and gatherings occur.\nThe Aboriginal Council is also promoting the New Dawn Sisters, a foundation that collects sanitary products for young girls who live on northern reserves who don\u2019t have access to these products, or cannot afford them. \u201cOften times, these girls are missing school because they don\u2019t have the proper products,\u201d said Gosselin. \u201cThere are many times when these girls have to make a decision of \u2018do I eat?\u2019 or purchasing these sanitary products.\u201d\nAny donations of sanitary products can be dropped off at the CUPE Local 5999 office on Third Street downtown Weyburn.\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nGet your daily Saskatchewan news briefing\nEmail\nSign Up\nThis has been shared 0 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local there waiting for hours.\u201d\n\nJessica Patrick was reported missing on September 3rd and a vigil was held by her family on Sunday.\n\nBefore arriving in Smithers, the Patricks are making a stop at the Lake Babine First Nation, where Jessica was a member.\n\nJessica Patrick\u2019s family, transporting what they say are her remains, will also be stopping in #BurnsLakeBC, where the 18yo was a {"url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/terese-marie-mailhot/dont-hang-a-red-dress-for-me_a_23019892/", "title": "If I'm Murdered Or Go Missing, Don't Hang A Red Dress For Me | HuffPost Life", "body": "Skip to Main Content\nWHAT'S HOT\nConservative Commentator Says Trump\u2019s Post-Debate Move Is \u2018Freaking A Lot Of People Out\u2019\nKristi Noem\u2019s Shot At Kamala Harris Backfires Immediately\nAuthoritarianism Expert Exposes Chilling \u2018Codeword\u2019 In \u2018Project 2025\u2019 Plan For Trump\nJames Carville Issues Blunt Plea To Democratic Donors About Ditching Biden\n\u2018Pile Of Crap\u2019: Trump Rails Against Biden, Harris In Unhinged Rant Caught On Video\nTrump Spokesperson\u2019s Insane Call For \u2018Total Surrender\u2019 Shot Down On Newsmax\nChristina Applegate Shares 2 Things She Wants To Do In 'The Days I Have Left'\nThe Economist Burns Joe Biden With Brutal Cover Showing A Walker\nThis Doctor Has Treated Thousands Of Skin Cancer Cases. Here Are 9 Things He'd Never Do.\nVan Jones Reveals \u2018Behind The Scenes\u2019 Moves That Could End Biden Campaign\nMary Trump Sounds The Alarm On MAGA: \u2018Spreading Like A Virus\u2019\nWhy Any Biden Replacement Besides Harris Would Face A Major Fundraising Hassle\nLog In\nSUPPORT US\nNEWS\nPOLITICS\nENTERTAINMENT\nLIFE\nPERSONAL\nVOICES\nSHOPPING\n\ud83c\udfc6 PLAY PYRAMID SCHEME \ud83c\udfc6\nU.S. Edition\nOpen editions submenu\nThis HuffPost Canada page is maintained as part of an online archive.\nLIFE\nBLOGS\nINDIGENOUS RIGHTS\nINDIGENOUS WOMEN\nIf I'm Murdered Or Go Missing, Don't Hang A Red Dress For Me\nI think about it all and wonder if there are enough dresses or symbols in the world to signify that pain and distress for Indigenous people.\nBy\u00a0\nTerese Marie Mailhot, Contributor\nEssayist, Columnist, Indigenous Mother\nJul 7, 2017, 11:30 AM EDT\n|Updated Jul 7, 2017\nThis post was published on the now-closed HuffPost Contributor platform. Contributors control their own work and posted freely to our site. If you need to flag this entry as abusive, send us an email.\n\nPreviously Published at Indian Country Today.\n\nI've seen red dresses hung on trees, on campuses and elsewhere to honour murdered and missing Indigenous women. The aesthetic response is artistically stunning, but it's inanimate and pretty, and it's simultaneously disturbing when I consider the symbol isn't ascribed the value of purity or innocence. I support artistic endeavors to memorialize or create symbols, but I don't provide blind support to anything. If I'm beaten to death or go missing, don't hang a red dress for me.\n\nM\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black created the installation: \"I'm allowing people to critically think about the issue... it's amazing how... powerful it is to see these dresses just hanging there, and when you walk by them it feels like you are walking by someone but no one is in them. It really works as a kind of visceral reminder of these women.\"\n\nANDREW FRANCIS WALLACE VIA GETTY IMAGESRed dresses were seen hanging from the trees on the University of Toronto campus as part of the Red Dress Project, which brings attention to Canada's missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThe red dress appears ghostly and impersonal, especially after it's become so familiar and synonymous -- I have come to resent when editors choose the red dress over a human face for stories about murdered and missing women, because I wonder about the danger and benefit of giving a cause to protect human life an image with no features, or life, or blood, or viscera.\n\nArt isn't enough when it's meant for an active audience.\n\nIt isn't Black's fault that there is something amiss with the way in which Indigenous women are treated in North America. It's not her fault that the tally of women missing and murdered grows as the inquiry encounters set back after set back. The work served as an aesthetic reminder that there is a blaring, unsightly, crazy-making problem and if people cannot acknowledge the inherent racism, indignity and hatred Indian women face, they will at least have to acknowledge these images: a red dress in a stagnant winter forest, or the dresses picking up a cool breeze in the spring on a peaceful day...\n\nIt's what people do with the reminder that has fallen short. It's that art isn't enough when it's meant for an active audience.\n\nArtwork like this doesn't need to be perpetuated for years without critical thought or discussion. The work is supposed to be talked about. Without that it becomes something static. The implication of a red dress signifying the absence of an Indian woman might be too much. Red doesn't symbolize promiscuity or sex work where I'm from. It's used to create positive and negative spaces, so I see the appeal in the dresses, but to majority culture the red dress doesn't signify power typically, or purity, or healing, but when have I ever cared about the average audience? Only when I'm trying to discern something's worth, or why it underwhelms me, or why I believe it might have a negative impact over its intent.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nIt's necessary to consider these things when I know I've witnessed enough domestic violence, sexual violence and brutality to where those artistic gestures hold personal value -- this work is close to me. Someone could hang a dress for me someday, god forbid. God forbid they would choose that aesthetic response to my death.\n\nI'd prefer an effigy of my culprit to burn, hanging. I'd prefer something more than a dress, considering how rare it is I wear them. What about leggings, or a sign, \"Death to my enemies.\" I entertain these morbid things when I consider the desperation of injustice. That it doesn't come sometimes, and all I can do is wonder what will any of us do if we lose another one. Can we keep hanging red dresses? It feels like pining for justice -- it feels like laying down a rose for something unrequited, and I guess that's what symbolic gestures are, because there's absence-- something we can't exact, and we try to make something tangible to memorialize -- physicalize our grief, yearning, idea or memory.\n\nI wonder if there are enough dresses or symbols in the world to signify that pain and distress for Indigenous people.\n\nI was poolside on the Fourth of July when I received news Barbara Kentner died. The woman, my age -- a mother, too, was hit by a trailer hitch in Thunder Bay. The white man who hit her shouted, \"I got one,\" and drove away, and now she's gone. It mattered that I was enjoying my life that moment before, because I felt untouchable in some way. The news, every time another woman dies, breaks me hard.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nI think about all the women who died that way, and others who worked their whole lives to the bone, and left behind debt, and deserved better; and I think about the men who died violently, too; and I think about my father, who was beaten to death, and I consider the violence he inflicted himself. I think about it all and wonder if there are enough dresses or symbols in the world to signify that pain and distress for Indigenous people.\n\nWith all the good intentions of the dress, or a tobacco tie, or any one single good thing -- I fear it pales to the willful ignorance of passersby, who won't engage -- not with a dress, or our bodies. I fear so much of our well-intended work pales, even our writing, to the men who abuse their power, or social workers who cannot be bothered to regard us, or to people who would prefer we be replaced with dresses. To what end, I think, every time I see a dress instead of the woman who should be there on that campus, or in that forest with her children, or in the breeze, anywhere but absent and unheard -- a dress.\n\nFollow HuffPost Canada Blogs on Facebook\n\nAlso on HuffPost:\n\nRELATED\nBLOGS\nINDIGENOUS RIGHTS\nINDIGENOUS WOMEN\nLIVING\nMISSING MURDERED ABORIGINAL WOMEN\nSuggest a correction\nFROM OUR PARTNER\nRecommended by\nThis HuffPost Canada page is maintained as part of an online archive. {"url": "http://www.news1130.com/2017/10/01/more-public-transit-still-needed-on-highway-of-tears-community-members-say/", "title": "More public transit still needed on Highway of Tears, community members say", "body": "Vancouver\nAbout\nContact\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nTraffic\nContests & Events\nWATCH LIVE\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nMore public transit still needed on Highway of Tears, community members say\n\nBy News Staff\n\nPosted October 1, 2017 4:00 am.\n\n \n\nLast Updated October 1, 2017 4:40 am.\n\nThis article is more than 5 years old.\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2013 On a recent crisp fall morning, a compact white shuttle bus rolled to a stop just off the Yellowhead Highway. Four people hastily exited and began to walk briskly toward their destinations.\n\nAfter all, it was 9:38 a.m., giving them just over five hours in Smithers before the bus departed again at 3 p.m.\n\nOne of the passengers was Joe Scheck, 50, who catches the bus from Houston three times a week to do yard work in Smithers. His boss would like him to work full time, but the bus only runs on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.\n\n\u201cIf I could, I would do it five times a week,\u201d said Scheck, standing next to his rusty Jeep bicycle, his only other form of transportation.\n\nScheck, like many residents of small communities along Highway 16 in central British Columbia, can\u2019t afford to live in Smithers but also can\u2019t find work \u2014 or even buy groceries \u2014 in his town. If he were able to work five days a week, he estimates he\u2019d take home an extra $400 a month.\n\nThe province launched the $5-a-trip bus route from Burns Lake to Smithers in June. It also started a route from Prince George to Burns Lake, which operates Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. A route that connects Smithers and nearby Moricetown has operated since January.\n\nStill, advocates say the service is only a patchwork, and it arrived more than a decade after families and Indigenous advocates called on the government to provide public transportation along a notorious stretch of Highway 16 known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe RCMP says 18 women have gone missing or have been murdered on the route between Prince Rupert and Prince George, but advocates argue the real number is more than 40. Many of the women disappeared while hitchhiking in remote areas with poor or no cell service.\n\nAt hearings held by the national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women in Smithers last week, the lack of adequate transportation in the region came up repeatedly.\n\nGladys Radek, whose 22-year-old niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert in 2005, told the inquiry she knows people who have to hitchhike just to go to work. There should be a free shuttle bus service, she said.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve even picked up a young lady, just outside of Smithers, to take her back to Moricetown because she had to go see a doctor. She was nine months pregnant,\u201d she said.\n\nThe community is also reeling from the news that Greyhound Canada has applied to provincial regulators to cancel its route from Prince George to Prince Rupert, said Radek.\n\nGreyhound said the deaths and disappearances of women in the area are tragic but that the new publicly subsidized routes have \u201cliterally put us out of business\u201d in this corridor.\n\nVIA Rail also operates a train along the route. Last August, it was widely reported the company was in talks with the B.C. government to offer $5 fares to \u201cvulnerable\u201d riders, but the idea has yet to materialize. VIA Rail said it is still discussing the matter.\n\nThe call for a shuttle bus that visits every reserve and route along the route dates back to 2006, when First Nations leaders, families and advocacy groups held a Highway of Tears Symposium that produced 33 recommendations.\n\nIn 2012, Wally Oppal completed his final report after leading a provincial inquiry into missing and murdered women. The former B.C. attorney general urged the province to immediately commit to his recommendation that it implement public transit along the highway.\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t until 2015 that the former Liberal government announced a $3-million plan for transportation along the Highway of Tears, including transit expansion, First Nations driver training and a community vehicle grant program.\n\nLiberal spokesman Shane Mills said the safety of women along Highway 16 was a priority for the government.\n\n\u201cImproving transportation was done in consultation with First Nations and local governments,\u201d he said in an email.\n\nThe NDP regularly criticized the government on the issue while in Opposition, but did not commit any new funds to public transit on Highway 16 in its recent fiscal update. Transportation Minister Claire Trevena couldn\u2019t be reached for comment.\n\nOppal declined to offer an opinion on the province\u2019s response to his recommendation, but he said it\u2019s clear there must be satisfactory transportation on the route that discourages hitchhiking.\n\n\u201cWe owe it to the women,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nNorth Vancouver family stuck in Mexico amid WestJet strike\nSurrey RCMP seeks voyeurism suspect\nKiteboarder dies in Squamish\nPolice say two shoplifters will be deported after serving time in B.C.\nVancouver police looking for 2 men after sudden death in West End\nTop Stories\nVancouver police looking for 2 men after sudden death in West End\n\nUPDATED\n\n2h ago\n\nMan sentenced to life after murdering wife in Abbotsford in 2022\n\n57m ago\n\nKiteboarder dies in Squamish\n\n1h ago\n\nECCC issues Heat Warning for eastern Vancouver Island\n\n1h ago\n\nMost Watched Today\n1:37\nVancouver's Science World dome to receive $19 million in upgrades\n\nFunding from the federal government of $19 million to retrofit an iconic Vancouver landmark, Science World, was announced Wednesday. {"url": "http://www.news957.com/national/2017/10/01/more-public-transit-still-needed-on-highway-of-tears-community-members-say/", "title": "More public transit still needed on Highway of Tears, community members say", "body": "Halifax\nAbout\nContact\nNewsletters\nNews Insiders\nNews\nWatch\nListen\nWeather\nContests\nCommunity\nLISTEN LIVE\n   \nMore public transit still needed on Highway of Tears, community members say\n\nBy Laura Kane, The Canadian Press\n\nPosted Oct 1, 2017 08:00:03 AM.\n\n \n\nLast Updated Oct 1, 2017 08:40:12 AM.\n\nThis article is more than 5 years old.\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2013 On a recent crisp fall morning, a compact white shuttle bus rolled to a stop just off the Yellowhead Highway. Four people hastily exited and began to walk briskly toward their destinations.\n\nAfter all, it was 9:38 a.m., giving them just over five hours in Smithers before the bus departed again at 3 p.m.\n\nOne of the passengers was Joe Scheck, 50, who catches the bus from Houston three times a week to do yard work in Smithers. His boss would like him to work full time, but the bus only runs on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.\n\n\u201cIf I could, I would do it five times a week,\u201d said Scheck, standing next to his rusty Jeep bicycle, his only other form of transportation.\n\nScheck, like many residents of small communities along Highway 16 in central British Columbia, can\u2019t afford to live in Smithers but also can\u2019t find work \u2014 or even buy groceries \u2014 in his town. If he were able to work five days a week, he estimates he\u2019d take home an extra $400 a month.\n\nThe province launched the $5-a-trip bus route from Burns Lake to Smithers in June. It also started a route from Prince George to Burns Lake, which operates Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. A route that connects Smithers and nearby Moricetown has operated since January.\n\nStill, advocates say the service is only a patchwork, and it arrived more than a decade after families and Indigenous advocates called on the government to provide public transportation along a notorious stretch of Highway 16 known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe RCMP says 18 women have gone missing or have been murdered on the route between Prince Rupert and Prince George, but advocates argue the real number is more than 40. Many of the women disappeared while hitchhiking in remote areas with poor or no cell service.\n\nAt hearings held by the national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women in Smithers last week, the lack of adequate transportation in the region came up repeatedly.\n\nGladys Radek, whose 22-year-old niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert in 2005, told the inquiry she knows people who have to hitchhike just to go to work. There should be a free shuttle bus service, she said.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve even picked up a young lady, just outside of Smithers, to take her back to Moricetown because she had to go see a doctor. She was nine months pregnant,\u201d she said.\n\nThe community is also reeling from the news that Greyhound Canada has applied to provincial regulators to cancel its route from Prince George to Prince Rupert, said Radek.\n\nGreyhound said the deaths and disappearances of women in the area are tragic but that the new publicly subsidized routes have \u201cliterally put us out of business\u201d in this corridor.\n\nVIA Rail also operates a train along the route. Last August, it was widely reported the company was in talks with the B.C. government to offer $5 fares to \u201cvulnerable\u201d riders, but the idea has yet to materialize. VIA Rail said it is still discussing the matter.\n\nThe call for a shuttle bus that visits every reserve and route along the route dates back to 2006, when First Nations leaders, families and advocacy groups held a Highway of Tears Symposium that produced 33 recommendations.\n\nIn 2012, Wally Oppal completed his final report after leading a provincial inquiry into missing and murdered women. The former B.C. attorney general urged the province to immediately commit to his recommendation that it implement public transit along the highway.\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t until 2015 that the former Liberal government announced a $3-million plan for transportation along the Highway of Tears, including transit expansion, First Nations driver training and a community vehicle grant program.\n\nLiberal spokesman Shane Mills said the safety of women along Highway 16 was a priority for the government.\n\n\u201cImproving transportation was done in consultation with First Nations and local governments,\u201d he said in an email.\n\nThe NDP regularly criticized the government on the issue while in Opposition, but did not commit any new funds to public transit on Highway 16 in its recent fiscal update. Transportation Minister Claire Trevena couldn\u2019t be reached for comment.\n\nOppal declined to offer an opinion on the province\u2019s response to his recommendation, but he said it\u2019s clear there must be satisfactory transportation on the route that discourages hitchhiking.\n\n\u201cWe owe it to the women,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nSubmit a Correction\nAccessibility Feedback\nLive Radio\nConnect with CityNews\nTrending Now\nImpaired youth arrested after ATV ended up in a ditch, passenger injured\nFire at popular Halifax deli\nThe todd veinotte show july 4th 11am\nFailing to show up to court, police track man down and lay charges\nHurricane Beryl churns toward Mexico after leaving destruction in Jamaica and eastern Caribbean\nTop Stories\nImpaired youth arrested after ATV ended up in a ditch, passenger injured\n\n1h ago\n\nWentworth man wanted on two province-wide arrest warrants\n\n1h ago\n\nFire at popular Halifax deli\n\n54m ago\n\nBirch Cove and Shubie Park beaches closed to swimmers\n\n5h ago\n\nMost Watched Today\n2:32\nCanada risks \u201cmuch more censored & surveilled\u201d internet\n\nThe suite of internet regulation bills in Parliament are intended to protect people - but activists warn it could mean a much more surveilled & censored internet. {"url": "http://saskatoon.ctvnews.ca/red-dresses-bring-missing-murdered-aboriginal-women-to-forefront-1.2012351", "title": "Red dresses bring missing, murdered aboriginal women to forefront | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFollow on\n\n  \n\nAdvertisement\n\nSASKATOON\nRed dresses bring missing, murdered aboriginal women to forefront\nCTV Saskatoon\nPublished Wednesday, September 17, 2014 8:04PM CST\nLast Updated Wednesday, September 17, 2014 8:05PM CST\nCTV Saskatoon: Red dresses scatter U of S\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nAround 130 dresses scattered across the University of Saskatchewan campus are a critical response to missing and murdered\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nEmpty red dresses sway from trees and hang in hallways on the University of Saskatchewan campus. Students say they give the campus a haunting vibe.\n\n\u201cI was walking on campus and noticed all these red dresses. It\u2019s really eerie,\u201d one student commented.\n\nThe reaction is what artist Jamie Black was hoping for with her REDress Project. The dresses represent aboriginal women who have gone missing or have been murdered in Canada.\n\n\u201cI want people to be a little but haunted by the violence that Indigenous women are facing every day in our communities, and just the fact that they don\u2019t feel safe,\u201d said Black.\n\nAn RCMP report released in May said aboriginal women have been much more prone to violent deaths than non-native women in Canada. The last federal budget earmarked $25 million over five years to address crimes against aboriginal women and girls, and recently, calls for a public inquiry into Canada\u2019s many missing and murdered aboriginal women were renewed.\n\nUniversity staff helped bring the project to campus, noting the message hits home with at least one recent case.\n\nDaleen Bosse, an education student at the university and member of the Onion Lake First Nation, went missing in 2004. Her body was found four years later. The man accused of her murder is currently on trial.\n\nAround 130 dresses are up \u2014 all of them donated from people across the country. The project is meant to raise awareness and to motivate young people to discover more about the issue.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really powerful \u2014 especially the ones outside hanging from the trees,\u201d one student noted.\n\nThe dresses will be on display until Oct. 5.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n\nArtist Jamie Black sets up a red dress inside the University of Saskatchewan's Education {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/spoke-and-hub-transit-model-may-be-workable-for-highway-of-tears-says-rustad-1.2120146", "title": "Spoke and hub transit model may be workable for Highway of Tears, says Rustad - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nSpoke and hub transit model may be workable for Highway of Tears, says Rustad\nNechako-Lakes MLA John Rustad says he favours a \"spoke and hub\" model of transportation along Highway 16 West, signaling a full-blown, publicly-run transit service from Prince George to Prince Rupert remains off the table as far as the provincial gov\nMark Nielsen\nNov 25, 2015 9:42 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nNechako-Lakes MLA John Rustad says he favours a \"spoke and hub\" model of transportation along Highway 16 West, signaling a full-blown, publicly-run transit service from Prince George to Prince Rupert remains off the table as far as the provincial government is concerned.\n\n\"I think when you're looking at the highway, it doesn't make sense in my mind to be thinking a comprehensive transportation system like the Lower Mainland has that's going to go from Prince Rupert to Prince George,\" Rustad said Wednesday. \"But what does make sense is how to support the local communities and there is a lot of talk about a sort of spoke and hub type model around how transportation can work. I'm not sure if that will be where it all goes but like I say, some of the ideas that came forward were quite innovative.\"\n\nRustad, who is the provincial government's aboriginal affairs minister, attended about half of a one-day symposium held in Smithers this week where community leaders gathered to discuss options for improving transportation along Highway 16 West. The stretch has gained the moniker Highway of Tears because of the number of young women, many aboriginal, who've gone missing or were murdered while hitchhiking along the corridor. Rustad described the get-together as a \"great discussion.\"\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone, who did not attend the meeting, said in a press release the next step will be to \"turn the discussion into action and to work on a plan that provides an effective model for transportation as quickly as possible.\"\n\nA number of \"community-based transportation options, which could service the First Nations communities located along the Highway 16 corridor,\" were discussed according to the press release.\n\nExamples raised included the Fort St. James \"Seniors Helping Seniors,\" the First Nations community-led transportation service in Lake Babine, as well as the Northern Health Authority's Northern Health Connections bus service for out-of-town people with medical appointments.\n\nCarrier-Sekani Family Services executive director Mary Teegee, who helped give a presentation on the Highway of Tears Initiative at the gathering, was disappointed no action was taken on the work that has been done already.\n\nA shuttle service from Prince George to Prince Rupert was the top recommendation to come out of the Highway of Tears Symposium held 10 years ago and the idea was once again endorsed by Wally Oppal, the commissioner for the Missing and Murdered Women Inquiry, three years ago, Teegee noted.\n\n\"I would have liked to have seen something more concrete and some government funding and commitment tied to that,\" Teegee said.\n\nFunding for the Highway of Tears Initiative will run out at the end of December, Teegee added.\n\nAccording to a government estimate, a six-day a week service from Prince George to Prince Rupert would cost $1 million a year.\n\nNorth Coast New Democrat MLA Jennifer Rice said that's a \"drop in the bucket\" given the provincial government's annual budget is $46 billion a year.\n\n\"And considering northern British Columbia is a big part of our economy, where the resources we have here are producing so much and have historically, I think it's a small contribution that could be invested in order to help families here thrive,\" Rice said.\n\nRice suggested the event was held to divert attention away from the scandal over the \"triple-deleting\" of government emails related to the Highway of Tears but remains hopeful something productive will come out.\n\n\"I'm suspicious of the timing of the symposium, I'm thinking that it's an attempt at saving face,\" Rice said. \"If in the end that's what it takes to see concrete action, so be it...We're not holding our breath, I guess.\"\n\nIn a press release headlined \"Highway of Hope: Transportation Symposium Sets Stage for Wide-Ranging Collaboration,\" North Central Local Government Association vice president Laurey-Anne Roodenburg called the meeting a \"genesis of a new relationship, of working together in partnership.\"\n\n\"At the grassroots level, northern communities have realized for quite some time that we need to work together to solve big-ticket items,\" Roodenburg continued.\n\n\"Obviously, transportation along the Highway 16 corridor is one of those. All of us in the north, both aboriginal and non-aboriginal, need to put our heads together and come up with some practical, doable, collaborative solutions.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. Life Skills also did the pins (of a red dress). The large photo of the girl was done by the Indigenous Studies class. If you look up close, it is all the women in Canada who went missing that make up that picture. They were able to put their own spin on it.\u201d\n\nCorcoran added plans were to have the display within the school originally.\n\n\u201cThe goal is that it would have been in our school, and people could have come in, and our kids would have been able to see it,\u201d Corcoran said. \u201cBut the fact that we are online now and we can\u2019t have the public in our building right now for extended periods of time, we did move it into an outside feature. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING/POSTMEDIA/FILE\nArticle content\n\nManitoba\u2019s environment minister is facing scrutiny over his identification as a \u201cproud M\u00e9tis Canadian,\u201d the latest in a number of prominent Canadians who\u2019ve been accused of claiming Indigenous ancestry without sufficient evidence.\n\nKevin Klein has said he\u2019s a member of the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis, but his brother and the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation have questioned his claims.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt saddened me and it brought up a lot of emotions. It brought up a lot of history,\u201d said Klein, when reached Monday morning by National Post.\n\nKlein has been a provincial legislator since 2022, and before that he served on Winnipeg\u2019s city council. At various points in his political career, he has mentioned his Indigenous ancestry \u2014 specifically in relation to his mother, Joanne Winacott, who was murdered by her second husband in 1991.\n\nIn December 2021, Klein spoke in Winnipeg council, during a debate about the police budget. He said, \u201cI have very little to say on this one, but I want to speak from a place that no one else on council can speak from.\u201d\n\nHe went on to speak about police response times.\n\n\u201cMy Indigenous mother was murdered because the police didn\u2019t respond to the initial call. That is on record in, and it\u2019s in the court documents,\u201d Klein said at the time.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKlein referenced his mother\u2019s identity again on May 5, 2022, in an Instagram video for Red Dress Day, also known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\n\u201cMy mother was murdered by her partner, and she was Indigenous,\u201d he said.\n\nI'm not self-identifying, nor am I using it, nor am I mentioning it every time I open my mouth\n\nKlein\u2019s brother, Christopher Rout, has firmly rejected the characterization that his family has Indigenous heritage.\n\n\u201cHe never grew up M\u00e9tis. My grandparents never told us we were M\u00e9tis. I never heard anything about us being M\u00e9tis,\u201d said Rout in an interview with the National Post. \u201cThe net bottom line is we are not Aboriginal at all.\u201d\n\nKlein, who\u2019s a Progressive Conservative MLA, told National Post that he first learned of his purported M\u00e9tis ancestry when speaking with his uncle Dave. They were going through old photo albums, and his uncle asked him if he had his M\u00e9tis card, Klein said.\n\nTravel Time\n\nPlan your next getaway with Travel Time, featuring travel deals, destinations and gear.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI said \u2018No, I don\u2019t think I\u2019m M\u00e9tis,'\u201d Klein recalled. \u201cHe pulled out his card and said \u2018We are. You need to get your M\u00e9tis card because your mom never had the chance to.'\u201d\n\nKlein then applied to the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis. His understanding was that they did their own research before issuing a card.\n\n\u201cIt excited me because it\u2019s a connection I never knew,\u201d he said. \u201cI went with it because of my uncle, who I loved dearly.\u201d\n\nThe uncle, said Rout, has since died.\n\nThe allegations against Klein \u2014 that his claims of Indigenous ancestry are disputed \u2014 were first reported by CBC News, which used census records to build Klein\u2019s family tree. It found no evidence of an Indigenous ancestor.\n\nKlein said what he knows of it came from his uncle, and that the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis did their own genealogical research.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThere are many Indigenous and non-(Indigenous) who are looking for clarity on their story of origin, their family history,\u201d said Klein. \u201cAnd this is something I will continue to do as a personal journey for as long as I live.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, there have been a number of prominent Canadians who have had their claims to Indigenous identity questioned, including Ellen Turpel-Lafond, who claimed to be the first Cree judge. Her claims to be a \u201cTreaty Indian\u201d have been highly disputed.\n\nThe novelist Joseph Boyden, who\u2019s best known for writing about Indigenous culture, has long claimed Indigenous ancestry, but various news reports have since disputed his claims.\n\nIn the case of Klein, his political biographies have, at various times, identified him as M\u00e9tis, although the term has recently been dropped from some of his social media accounts, CBC reported.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not self-identifying, nor am I using it, nor am I mentioning it every time I open my mouth. It is a family issue for me and a connection to my mother,\u201d Klein told CBC last fall.\n\nManitoba M\u00e9tis Federation President David Chartrand told CBC that Klein does not meet their criteria to identify as M\u00e9tis.\n\n\u201cWe do not recognize the Painted Feather Woodlands M\u00e9tis or any other group that claims M\u00e9tis identity outside our definition. This is no different than any of the other cases where groups or individuals are calling themselves M\u00e9tis when they really mean mixed heritage,\u201d Chartrand said in an email.\n\nOn Monday, Klein told the Post he has dropped the identifier in some places because, \u201cI don\u2019t mean to insult anybody. It really was a proud moment for me to believe that my family had that M\u00e9tis status.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a personal journey. I don\u2019t want to insult anybody, but I am going to follow my personal journey. And that\u2019s how we got here today,\u201d Klein said.\n\n\u201cI got into public life to serve, not to offend. To help people, not degrade them. It was never, has never, was never an attempt to make a false claim.\u201d\n\nKlein, who was the publisher and CEO of the Winnipeg Sun newspaper between 2007 and 2013, which is now owned by Postmedia Network Inc., speculated that a \u201cLiberal-NDP-funded government employee\u201d raised questions about his identity in order to harm his reputation ahead of the provincial election. Manitobans go to the polls in October.\n\n\u201cI can only assume it was to hurt us, to attempt to hurt us in the election when really all it did was cause more pain and sorrow for my family,\u201d Klein said.\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKlein\u2019s official biography, from when he was appointed to Premier Heather Stefanson\u2019s cabinet, said Klein \u201ccontinues to explore, working with Elders in Manitoba to research his connections to Indigenous community. This exploration has heightened his desire to work with Indigenous communities.\u201d\n\nA profile in What\u2019s up Winnipeg, a local magazine, reports that Klein took courses in Cree and M\u00e9tis history at the University of Alberta during COVID-19 to learn more about his roots, which he\u2019d learned about from his mother\u2019s older brother.\n\n\u201cBlond and blue-eyed Indigenous people were not uncommon among certain groups in middle America,\u201d the profile says. \u201cHis family says his roots are evident in his cheekbones, which Kevin says he could never produce a proper beard!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 9\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nWhen reached by National Post on Monday, Rout also objected to Klein\u2019s use of their mother\u2019s experience with domestic violence, and said Klein wasn\u2019t even living at home when the domestic violence and murder occurred.\n\n\u201cAs a son, you shouldn\u2019t be trying to profit or benefit from your mom\u2019s death,\u201d said Rout.\n\nKlein said he hasn\u2019t spoken to his brother in more than 25 years. He does, however, have a relationship with their other brother, Duane.\n\nIn an email provided to the National Post by Klein\u2019s office, Duane purportedly writes that he can confirm that Klein and their Uncle Dave had a M\u00e9tis card \u2014 although the email does not go so far as to confirm Indigenous ancestry in the family.\n\n\u201cNo one knows the full history of my immediate family. I am not going into any detail because I strongly believe family matters are just that, between family,\u201d the email says. \u201cI pray my mom can Rest In Peace again.\u201d\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nCanada's little-known contributions to the atomic bomb\nPierre Poilievre apologizes for calling $539K Niagara home a 'tiny little shack'\n\nOur website is the place for the latest breaking news, exclusive scoops, longreads and provocative commentary. {"url": "http://leaderpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/more-public-transit-still-needed-on-highway-of-tears-community-members-say/wcm/252325cd-9cd7-4c7d-b0c6-016ed7232c23", "title": "More public transit still needed on Highway of Tears, community members say | Regina Leader Post", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\n2024 Saskatchewan wildfires\nSports\nOpinion\nBusiness\nArts\nLife\nShopping\nPuzzmo\nHealthing\nDriving\nePaper\nRemembering\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nMore public transit still needed on Highway of Tears, community members say\nAuthor of the article:\nThe Canadian Press\nPublished Oct 01, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Oct 01, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nArticle content\n\nSMITHERS, B.C. \u2014 On a recent crisp fall morning, a compact white shuttle bus rolled to a stop just off the Yellowhead Highway. Four people hastily exited and began to walk briskly toward their destinations.\n\nAfter all, it was 9:38 a.m., giving them just over five hours in Smithers before the bus departed again at 3 p.m.\n\nOne of the passengers was Joe Scheck, 50, who catches the bus from Houston three times a week to do yard work in Smithers. His boss would like him to work full time, but the bus only runs on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nSask. files injunction to block feds from reclaiming missed carbon tax payments\nFlight cancelled due to the WestJet strike? Here's what you can do\nWho's running for city council in Regina this fall?\nHockey Regina's Blair Watson is retiring to the golf course, far away from those 'over-zealous' parents\nMandryk: Sask. Party has turned truth telling into an election issue\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIf I could, I would do it five times a week,\u201d said Scheck, standing next to his rusty Jeep bicycle, his only other form of transportation.\n\nScheck, like many residents of small communities along Highway 16 in central British Columbia, can\u2019t afford to live in Smithers but also can\u2019t find work \u2014 or even buy groceries \u2014 in his town. If he were able to work five days a week, he estimates he\u2019d take home an extra $400 a month.\n\nThe province launched the $5-a-trip bus route from Burns Lake to Smithers in June. It also started a route from Prince George to Burns Lake, which operates Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. A route that connects Smithers and nearby Moricetown has operated since January.\n\nStill, advocates say the service is only a patchwork, and it arrived more than a decade after families and Indigenous advocates called on the government to provide public transportation along a notorious stretch of Highway 16 known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe RCMP says 18 women have gone missing or have been murdered on the route between Prince Rupert and Prince George, but advocates argue the real number is more than 40. Many of the women disappeared while hitchhiking in remote areas with poor or no cell service.\n\nHeadline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAt hearings held by the national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women in Smithers last week, the lack of adequate transportation in the region came up repeatedly.\n\nGladys Radek, whose 22-year-old niece Tamara Lynn Chipman disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert in 2005, told the inquiry she knows people who have to hitchhike just to go to work. There should be a free shuttle bus service, she said.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve even picked up a young lady, just outside of Smithers, to take her back to Moricetown because she had to go see a doctor. She was nine months pregnant,\u201d she said.\n\nThe community is also reeling from the news that Greyhound Canada has applied to provincial regulators to cancel its route from Prince George to Prince Rupert, said Radek.\n\nGreyhound said the deaths and disappearances of women in the area are tragic but that the new publicly subsidized routes have \u201cliterally put us out of business\u201d in this corridor.\n\nVIA Rail also operates a train along the route. Last August, it was widely reported the company was in talks with the B.C. government to offer $5 fares to \u201cvulnerable\u201d riders, but the idea has yet to materialize. VIA Rail said it is still discussing the matter.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe call for a shuttle bus that visits every reserve and route along the route dates back to 2006, when First Nations leaders, families and advocacy groups held a Highway of Tears Symposium that produced 33 recommendations.\n\nIn 2012, Wally Oppal completed his final report after leading a provincial inquiry into missing and murdered women. The former B.C. attorney general urged the province to immediately commit to his recommendation that it implement public transit along the highway.\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t until 2015 that the former Liberal government announced a $3-million plan for transportation along the Highway of Tears, including transit expansion, First Nations driver training and a community vehicle grant program.\n\nLiberal spokesman Shane Mills said the safety of women along Highway 16 was a priority for the government.\n\n\u201cImproving transportation was done in consultation with First Nations and local governments,\u201d he said in an email.\n\nThe NDP regularly criticized the government on the issue while in Opposition, but did not commit any new funds to public transit on Highway 16 in its recent fiscal update. Transportation Minister Claire Trevena couldn\u2019t be reached for comment.\n\nOppal declined to offer an opinion on the province\u2019s response to his recommendation, but he said it\u2019s clear there must be satisfactory transportation on the route that discourages hitchhiking.\n\n\u201cWe owe it to the women,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2014 Follow @ellekane on Twitter.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nSask. The senile octogenarian, a mere puppet of his addlebrained ventriloquists, is now all in for Hamas.\n\nBy acceding to his young and hyper-online campaign staffers who have imbibed the woke catechism and thus view Hamas jihadists as \u201coppressed\u201d victims of Israeli \u201coppressors,\u201d the president \u2014 or \u201cDr.\u201d Jill Biden, or whoever else controls Uncle Joe \u2014 is setting himself up for failure. By making such a strong play for states like Michigan, Biden is strapping on a political suicide vest and positioning himself to be a shahid for radicals in Dearborn, Michigan, who will never be appeased and who will continue to protest \u201cgenocide Joe\u201d through election day. Meanwhile, Democrats\u2019 pampering of an Islamist death cult abroad and failure to crack down on supportive, fifth-column anarchists at home only alienate the vast majority of swing-state voters who are not virulently anti-Israel or anti-Semitic.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBiden\u2019s initial rhetorical support for Israel in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 Hamas pogrom is now a distant memory. Biden and his loathsome Secretary of State Antony Blinken have continuously sought to impose premature ceasefires, hamstringing the Jewish state\u2019s righteous attempt to eradicate the Hamas cancer. They have constantly threatened to withhold weapons shipments unless more \u201chumanitarian aid\u201d \u2014 inevitably gobbled up by Hamas \u2014 is delivered to Gaza. Biden has imposed sanctions on Israeli \u201csettlers\u201d in Judea and Samaria. Media will focus on him being deep underwater (19/81) on the issue among young voters, pushing the narrative that he\u2019s still seen as too pro-Israel. But he definitely isn\u2019t setting himself up to win over white working-class or middle-class voters across Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Georgia, Arizona or Nevada \u2014 the vast majority of whom would prefer a clearer campaign focus on our southern border crisis and stubborn inflation metrics, and virtually none of whom prefer Hamas-style Islamofascism over Israel.\n\nBiden\u2019s political calculus, in short, is just as misguided as his moral calculus.
