{"url": "https://winnipegsun.com/news/world/israeli-army-tells-palestinians-to-evacuate-parts-of-rafah-ahead-of-expected-assault/wcm/9aab98f7-9190-4b8f-8d50-9c3149fefdfe", "title": "Hamas accepts a Gaza cease-fire proposal, but Israel says framework isn't what it proposed | Winnipeg Sun", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nePaper\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nJets add to depth with two-way signings\nTRENDING\nBombers' Collaros to miss first start of season vs Redblacks\nTRENDING\nTrump trashes \u2018broken down pile of crap\u2019 Biden in viral video\nTRENDING\nPlayers hearing it from fans: What's up with Bombers?\nTRENDING\nManitoba First Nation reports 150 anomalies at residential school site\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nWorld\nHamas accepts a Gaza cease-fire proposal, but Israel says framework isn't what it proposed\n\nAuthor of the article:\n\nAssociated Press\nSam Mednick, Josef Federman And Bassem Mroue\nPublished May 06, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 06, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 5 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nDisplaced Palestinians who left with their belongings from Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip following an evacuation order by the Israeli army, arrive to Khan Yunis on May 6, 2024. PHOTO BY STRINGER /AFP via Getty Images\nArticle content\n\nJERUSALEM (AP) \u2014 Hamas announced its acceptance Monday of an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal, but Israel said the deal did not meet its \u201ccore demands\u201d and that it was pushing ahead with an assault on the southern Gaza town of Rafah. Still, Israel said it would continue negotiations.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe high-stakes diplomatic moves and military brinkmanship left a glimmer of hope alive \u2014 but only barely \u2014 for an accord that could bring at least a pause in the 7-month-old war that has devastated the Gaza Strip. Hanging over the wrangling was the threat of an all-out Israeli assault on Rafah, a move the United States strongly opposes and that aid groups warn will be disastrous for some 1.4 million Palestinians taking refuge there.\n\nHamas\u2019s abrupt acceptance of the cease-fire deal came hours after Israel ordered an evacuation of some 100,000 Palestinians from eastern neighborhoods of Rafah, signaling an invasion was imminent.\n\nIsrael\u2019s War Cabinet decided to continue the Rafah operation, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu\u2019s office said. At the same time, it said that while the proposal Hamas agreed to \u201cis far from meeting Israel\u2019s core demands,\u201d it would send negotiators to Egypt to work on a deal.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Israeli military said it was conducting \u201ctargeted strikes\u201d against Hamas in eastern Rafah. The nature of the strikes was not immediately known, but the move appeared aimed at keeping the pressure on as talks continue.\n\nPresident Joe Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and reiterated U.S. concerns about an invasion of Rafah. U.S. State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said American officials were reviewing the Hamas response \u201cand discussing it with our partners in the region.\u201d An American official said the U.S. was examining whether what Hamas agreed to was the version signed off to by Israel and international negotiators or something else.\n\nIt was not immediately known if the proposal Hamas agreed to was substantially different from one that U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken pressed the militant group to accept last week, which Blinken said included significant Israeli concessions.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nEgyptian officials said that proposal called for a cease-fire of multiple stages starting with a limited hostage release and partial Israeli troop pullbacks within Gaza. The two sides would also negotiate a \u201cpermanent calm\u201d that would lead to a full hostage release and greater Israeli withdrawal out of the territory, they said.\n\nHamas sought clearer guarantees for its key demand of an end to the war and complete Israeli withdrawal in return for the release of all hostages, but it wasn\u2019t clear if any changes were made.\n\nIsraeli leaders have repeatedly rejected that trade-off, vowing to keep up their campaign until Hamas is destroyed after its Oct. 7 attack on Israel that triggered the war.\n\nNetanyahu is under pressure from hard-line partners in his coalition who demand an attack on Rafah and could collapse his government if he signs onto a deal. But he also faces pressure from the families of hostages to reach a deal for their release.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThousands of Israelis rallied around the country Monday night calling for an immediate agreement. About a thousand protesters swelled near the defense headquarters in Tel Aviv, where police tried to clear the road. In Jerusalem, about a hundred protesters marched toward Netanyahu\u2019s residence with a banner reading, \u201cThe blood is on your hands.\u201c\n\nIsrael says Rafah is the last significant Hamas stronghold in Gaza, and Netanyahu said Monday that the offensive against the town was vital to ensuring the militants can\u2019t rebuild their military capabilities.\n\nBut he faces strong American opposition. Miller said Monday the U.S. has not seen a credible and implementable plan to protect Palestinian civilians. \u201cWe cannot support an operation in Rafah as it is currently envisioned,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe looming operation has raised global alarm. Aid agencies have warned that an offensive will bring a surge of more civilian deaths in an Israeli campaign that has already killed 34,000 people and devastated the territory. It could also wreck the humanitarian aid operation based out of Rafah that is keeping Palestinians across the Gaza Strip alive, they say.\n\nU.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Turk on Monday called the evacuation order \u201cinhumane.\u201d\n\n\u201cGazans continue to be hit with bombs, disease, and even famine. And today, they have been told that they must relocate yet again,\u201d he said. \u201cIt will only expose them to more danger and misery.\u201d\n\nIsraeli leaflets, text messages and radio broadcasts ordered Palestinians to evacuate eastern neighborhoods of Rafah, warning that an attack was imminent and anyone who stays \u201cputs themselves and their family members in danger.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe military told people to move to an Israel-declared humanitarian zone called Muwasi, a makeshift camp on the coast. It said Israel has expanded the size of the zone and that it included tents, food, water and field hospitals.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t immediately clear, however, if that was already in place.\n\nAround 450,000 displaced Palestinians already are sheltering in Muwasi. The U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA, said it has been providing them with aid. But conditions are squalid, with few sanitation facilities in the largely rural area, forcing families to dig private latrines.\n\nJan Egeland, secretary-general of the Norwegian Refugee Council, condemned the \u201cforced, unlawful\u201d evacuation order to Muwasi.\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe area is already overstretched and devoid of vital services,\u201d Egeland said.\n\nThe evacuation order left Palestinians in Rafah wrestling with having to uproot their families once again for an unknown fate, exhausted after months living in sprawling tent camps or crammed into schools or other shelters in and around the city. Israeli airstrikes on Rafah early Monday killed 22 people, including children and two infants.\n\nMohammed Jindiyah said that at the beginning of the war, he tried to hold out in his home in northern Gaza under heavy bombardment before fleeing to Rafah.\n\nHe is complying with Israel\u2019s evacuation order this time, but was unsure whether to move to Muwasi or elsewhere.\n\n\u201cWe are 12 families, and we don\u2019t know where to go. There is no safe area in Gaza,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement 9\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSahar Abu Nahel, who fled to Rafah with 20 family members, including her children and grandchildren, wiped tears from her cheeks, despairing at a new move.\n\n\u201cI have no money or anything. I am seriously tired, as are the children,\u201d she said. \u201cMaybe it\u2019s more honorable for us to die. {"url": "https://www.judicialwatch.org/bulletins/highway-of-tears-the-murders-in-indian-country/", "title": "Highway of Tears (The Murders in Indian Country) | Judicial Watch", "body": "Skip to content\nDONATE\nShare\nINVESTIGATIVE BULLETIN\n|\nFEBRUARY 27, 2019\nHighway of Tears (The Murders in Indian Country)\n\nIn January, Judicial Watch published a short report, \u201cThe Murders in Indian Country,\u201d outlining the shocking rate of murders and assaults inflicted on Native American and Alaska Native women. While accurate information is scarce, surveys suggest that the women are murdered at a rate ten times the national average. The response to the Judicial Watch report was tremendous. The story bounced around social media for weeks and prompted a stream of emails.\n\nWe noted that Congress had dropped the ball last year, allowing \u201cSavanna\u2019s Act\u201d to die in the House of Representatives. The bill had strong bipartisan support and would have forged new ties between law-enforcement agencies and improved data collection related to crimes against Native Americans and Alaska Natives. The bill was named for 22-year-old Savanna LaFontaine-Graywind, brutally murdered in North Dakota in 2017.\n\nNow, Savanna\u2019s Act is back, reintroduced in the Senate by Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada. There is an \u201cepidemic of murdered and missing Native women and girls,\u201d the senators said in a joint press release.\n\nSpecifically, they noted, Savanna\u2019s Act \u201caims to bridge the gap of the limited data on the number of missing Native women by directing the U.S. Department of Justice to formulate new guidelines for the reporting of violent crimes against indigenous people. The bill improves tribal access to certain federal crime information databases by mandating that the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Interior consult with Indian tribes on how to further improve these databases and access to them. It also requires certain federal agencies to solicit recommendations from tribes on enhancing the safety of Native women.\u201d\n\nThe bill mandates \u201cthe creation of standardized guidelines for responding to cases of missing and murdered Native Americans, in consultations with tribes, which will include guidance on inter-jurisdictional cooperation among tribes and federal, state, and local law enforcement.\u201d It requires \u201cstatistics on missing and murdered Native women, and recommendations on how to improve data collection, to be included in an annual report to Congress.\u201d\n\nMany of the responses to the Judicial Watch story came from Canada. \u201cMy daughter is Ojibway and I am scared to death for her safety,\u201d a reader wrote. \u201cTeenage girls are most likely to go missing. The public must know the facts on the staggering number of missing or dead Native youth.\u201d This mother urged us to \u201clook into the numbers in Canada, especially out west.\u201d\n\nCanada? That was news to us. So we took a look. Our readers in Canada were right. It\u2019s a disgrace and a scandal.\n\nMany killings and disappearances in Canada center around Highway 16, the so-called \u201cHighway of Tears,\u201d a 450-mile stretch of desolate roadway in British Columbia. \u201cDozens of Canadian women and girls, most of them indigenous, have disappeared or been murdered near Highway 16,\u201d reports the New York Times, \u201ca remote ribbon of asphalt that bisects British Columbia and snakes past thick forests, logging towns and impoverished Indian reserves on its way to the Pacific Ocean.\u201d\n\nAs in the U.S., there is no clear accounting of the missing and dead. A special unit of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police connected 18 cases to the Highway of Tears, the Times reported. But community activists \u201cbelieve the total is closer to 50.\u201d A detailed chart posted on Wikipedia puts the count at over 70. The numbers controversy extends to the entire country, where estimates of missing and dead women of indigenous descent range from 1,200 to more than 4,000.\n\nThe Highway of Tears is a symbol of the evil fortune fallen to indigenous women in North America in the 21st century. It also has become \u201ca political scandal in British Columbia,\u201d the Times noted. A national inquiry was launched in 2017, but it appears to be going nowhere. Meanwhile, the disappearances and deaths continue. In August, 18-year-old Jessica Patrick went missing in Smithers, British Columbia\u2014a bucolic mountain town along the Highway of Tears. In September, her body was found in the forest. Exactly a year earlier, the national inquiry commission had been in Smithers for three days of hearings, seeking answers and hearing pain.\n\n***\n\nMicah Morrison is chief investigative reporter for Judicial Watch. {"url": "https://www.indiantime.net/story/2023/06/15/news/alaska-red-dress-installation-for-mmip-damaged/42467.html", "title": "Alaska Red Dress Installation For MMIP Damaged - Indian Time", "body": "STOREABOUTCONTACTADVERTISEFREE TRIALSUBSCRIBESIGN IN\n\nA VOICE FROM THE EASTERN DOOR\n\nHome\nNews \nSports \nObituaries \nHealth \nEnvironment \nCulture \nOpinion \nLifestyle \nCommunity \nClassifieds\nAlaska Red Dress Installation For MMIP Damaged\nJun 15, 20230\nShare\nX\nShare\n\nCrafted by the Ketchikan Indian Community (KIC), an evocative installation emerged at Ward Lake in Southeast Alaska's Revillagigedo Island. Consisting of 60 red dresses elegantly suspended from trees, this powerful exhibit symbolized the missing or murdered Indigenous individuals from Ketchikan, Saxman, Prince of Wales Island, and Metlakatla.\n\nCommencing on May 15, the installation stood as a tribute during MMIP (Missing and Murdered Indigenous People) Awareness Month, operating under a permit granted by the U.S. Forestry Service. However, as the installation's scheduled conclusion approached on May 31, distressing reports emerged-48 of the dresses had vanished without a trace. Disturbingly, social media platforms began showcasing photographs in recent days, revealing some of the dresses crumpled along the lakeside trail, partially buried, or callously abandoned near drain pipes.\n\n\"It's just disrespectful,\" Michael Toole, Ketchikan Indian Community's victim services program coordinator, told KRBD. \"It's a terrible way to discount the reality of the lives of some of these people who were missing relatives who haven't received justice.\"\n\nThe tribal council released a declaration denouncing \"a hurtful and disrespectful act that undermines the endeavors to foster understanding and increase awareness of the MMIP crisis.\"\n\nThroughout May, similar installations are showcased across Canada and the United States, intending to shed light on the excessive number of Indigenous individuals who become victims of violent crimes or disappear.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, homicide ranks as the third most common cause of death among Native women, and the murder rate for those living on reservations is a staggering ten times higher than the national average. In 2021, Alaska registered 229 cases of missing and murdered Indigenous people - 149 missing and 80 murdered.\n\nGloria Burns, Vice President of KIC and Chair of the Social Services Committee, conveyed to local radio station KRBD that the tribe intentionally displayed the dresses as a symbol of remembrance and purpose, with the goal of creating a \"safe space.\"\n\n\"And so, in the midst of trying to establish a safe space, when it's deliberately made to feel unsafe, it very much feels like a violation,\" Burns told KRBD. \"I believe the challenging part is that the issue of missing and murdered indigenous people has been ongoing since colonization, but it's a topic we have largely left unaddressed. We have really not communicated these issues to the wider community.\"\n\nYOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:\nThe Benefits of Nature\nJudicial Oversight Commissioner Lorraine White Sworn into Office\nCommunity Input Sought for New HAVFD Fire Station\nIroquois Museum Presents \u2013 The Mush Hole: Truth, Acknowledgement, Resilience\nAMBE Tom Longboat Run 2024!\n\u00a0\nMOST POPULAR\nThe Benefits of Nature\nJudicial Oversight Commissioner Lorraine White Sworn into Office\nCommunity Input Sought for New HAVFD Fire Station\nAlberta Residents Born Before 1984 With No Life Insurance Can Get a $250,000\nDollarGuardian\nREADER COMMENTS(0)\nLog in to add your comment \n\u00a0\n\u00a0\nSections\nNews\nSports\nObituaries\nHealth\nEnvironment\nCulture\nOpinion\nLifestyle\nCommunity\nClassifieds\nNewspaper\nContact\nSubscribe\nAbout\nStore\nWebsite\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nSitemap\nConnect With Us\nLocated in Akwesasne\nU.S.: (518) 358-9531\nCanada: (613) 575-2063\ninfo@indiantime.net\n\u00a9 2024 Indian Time Newspaper\nFollow Us\nRSS\n\nPowered by ROAR Online Publication Software from Lions Light Corporation\n\u00a9 Copyright 2024\n\nRendered 06/18/2024 14:33"},
{"url": "https://www.ottawaxpress.ca/the-manitoba-metis-federation-and-kevin-kleins-brother-criticized-his-claim-to-be-metis/", "title": "The Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation and Kevin Klein's brother criticized his claim to be M\u00e9tis : Ottawa Express", "body": "Skip to content\nHomepage\nBest Online Casino Games\nPayments in Online Casinos\nBest of Ottawa\nTHE MANITOBA M\u00c9TIS FEDERATION AND KEVIN KLEIN\u2019S BROTHER CRITICIZED HIS CLAIM TO BE M\u00c9TIS\n\nPremier Heather Stefanson said that Klein is one of her caucus\u2019s two Indigenous members\n\nThe website for the Manitoba government still says that Environment Minister Kevin Klein is M\u00e9tis, even though the president of the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation, a well-known M\u00e9tis lawyer, and Klein\u2019s own brother all say that this is not true.\n\nRelated Posts:\nMeeting with the premier about the search for women's bodies in a landfill felt\u2026\nBoxer says Boxing Ontario didn't look into allegations of abuse by Ottawa coach\u2026\nSingers-to-be say that former pop star Danny Fernandes scammed them out of\u2026\n\nA spokesperson for Premier Heather Stefanson wrote in January that Mr. Klein is considered Indigenous because he has said in public that he is a Canadian M\u00e9tis.\n\nKlein says that he is a member of the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis tribe. The Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation and the M\u00e9tis Nation of Ontario do not recognize the group. It is a business that makes money and is based out of a single-family home near Bancroft, Ontario, which is about 250 km northeast of Toronto.\u00a0\n\nKlein says that he claims to be M\u00e9tis because of his Indigenous mother, who died before he was born.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t self-identify, I don\u2019t use it, and I don\u2019t talk about it every time I speak. \u201cIt has to do with my mother and my family,\u201d Klein said in an interview last fall when he was running for mayor.\n\nWhen CBC News talked to Klein\u2019s brother, Christopher Rout, he said that he, his brother, and their mother are not M\u00e9tis.\n\n\u201cIn school, I learned about the M\u00e9tis. I thought I would have been taught something and told something, but neither happened. \u201cNo, we\u2019re not M\u00e9tis,\u201d Rout told CBC News in an interview. He said that if he could, he would try to become a M\u00e9tis citizen.\n\nKlein\u2019s younger brother is named Rout. Their parents are the same, but their last names are different. The marriage certificate shows that Klein changed his name from Harold Kevin Rout Jr. to Kevin Elvis Klein before his second marriage in 1994.\u00a0\n\nDavid Chartrand, the president of the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation, told CBC that Klein\u2019s claim to be M\u00e9tis is not true.\n\n\u201cKevin Klein does not meet any of our requirements. We don\u2019t recognize the Painted Feather Woodlands M\u00e9tis or any other group that claims to be M\u00e9tis but doesn\u2019t fit our definition. This is the same as all the other times when people or groups say they are M\u00e9tis when they really have a mixed background, Chartrand told CBC News in an email.\u00a0\n\nCBC News did research on Klein\u2019s mother\u2019s family tree, some of which went back five generations. They did not find any evidence that Klein\u2019s mother has a M\u00e9tis or other Indigenous ancestor.\n\nMost of Klein\u2019s mother\u2019s ancestors came to Canada from England or Ireland, according to the census and other historical records.\n\nHis great-grandfather, who was born in 1889 and came from Jersey, one of the British Islands, was the last person he knew who moved to Canada. Two of his great-grandmother\u2019s grandparents were born in England, and the other two were born in Ireland.\n\nKlein\u2019s great-grandmother, who was born in 1875 and whose death certificate said she was English, was the only ancestor whose roots could not be found in another country. In the 1861 census, all four of her grandparents, three of whom were born in the U.S. and one in Canada, said they were not \u201cIndian.\u201d\n\nIn an interview in January, Premier Stefanson said that Klein is one of two Indigenous MLAs in the Progressive Conservative caucus. She also talked about how important it was for her party to have Indigenous people in it so that it better reflected the province\u2019s population.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe need to get more Indigenous candidates, and we\u2019re working on that,\u201d Stefanson said. \u201cWe need more diversity in how we choose candidates.\u201d\n\nWhen told that there was no proof of Klein\u2019s M\u00e9tis ancestry and that Chartrand and Klein\u2019s brother had said things, a spokesperson for Stefanson wouldn\u2019t say if the premier still thought Klein was a member of the Indigenous PC caucus.\n\n\u201cBecause we have worked hard to become the most diverse party in Manitoba, we are proud to have the first Muslim minister of the Crown, the first Black minister, and the first woman premier in our caucus. \u201cMinister Klein has made it clear that he is on a personal journey and that he is not using his ancestry to get ahead in politics,\u201d the spokesperson wrote.\n\nThe spokesperson said that the premier is happy with how PC Party candidates are vetted, but he questioned whether New Democrats are happy with how their candidates are vetted after it came out in 2017 that NDP Leader Wab Kinew had been convicted of crimes and had domestic violence charges against him dropped from about 20 years ago.\n\nJean Teillet, a M\u00e9tis lawyer and Louis Riel\u2019s great-grandniece, says that universities, governments, and other organizations are currently trying to hire Indigenous people. This could help a candidate who says they are Indigenous in an interview.\n\nTeillet said that it helps the PC party as well.\n\n\u201cThey stand up and say, \u2018We have Indigenous people in our party, so you can see we\u2019re not against Indigenous people. Look, they speak for their people.'\u201d\n\n\u2018M\u00e9tis\u2019 disappear\n\nThis past year, Klein ran two campaigns in Winnipeg, which according to Statistics Canada data from 2021 has the most Indigenous people living there than any other city in Canada.\u00a0\n\nAfter failing to become mayor, he won the Kirkfield Park provincial byelection.\u00a0\n\nKlein called himself a \u201cproud M\u00e9tis Canadian\u201d on his X account, which used to be called Twitter, and on his website at different times during the campaigns.\n\nOver the past few months, the word \u201cM\u00e9tis\u201d has been taken out of Klein\u2019s personal accounts, first from his X biography and then from his personal website, but the government record hasn\u2019t changed.\n\nWhen Klein was named to cabinet at the end of January, the government sent out a news release with background information. It said, \u201cKlein is a proud M\u00e9tis Canadian and continues to explore, working with Elders in Manitoba to research his connections to the Indigenous community.\u201d That exact phrase is also in his bio on the government website and on the Progressive Conservative Party website.\n\nWhen CBC News asked Klein for an interview to talk about his biography in the province\u2019s news release, his press secretary said he is not available and that his \u201cbio seems to explain itself.\u201d\n\nWhen CBC News asked why the word \u201cM\u00e9tis\u201d was taken off of Klein\u2019s personal website, Klein\u2019s press secretary wrote, \u201cAs Minister Klein has said before, \u2018This is a private and personal journey.'\u201d\n\nSince then, his personal website has changed again. It now says, \u201cConnecting with my Indigenous heritage helps put life into perspective,\u201d and at the top it says, \u201cRe-elect Kevin Klein.\u201d\u00a0\n\nKlein, who is 58 years old, has talked to the media in the past about his membership card from the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis, a group that is not recognized by the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation or the M\u00e9tis Nation of Ontario.\u00a0\n\nThe Government of Canada says that only the M\u00e9tis Nation of Alberta, the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation, the M\u00e9tis Nation of Saskatchewan, the M\u00e9tis Nation of British Columbia, and the M\u00e9tis Nation of Ontario are allowed to decide who is a M\u00e9tis with rights under the Constitution.\n\nTwo candidates want to be the second Indigenous mayor of Winnipeg.\nThe M\u00e9tis Nation of Ontario votes to kick out people whose files aren\u2019t complete.\n\nTeillet won a case before the Supreme Court of Canada in 2003. The court said that a person can be considered M\u00e9tis and have rights under Section 35 of the Constitution if they pass a test called the Powley test. Section 35 recognizes the \u201caboriginal and treaty rights of the Aboriginal people of Canada,\u201d but it doesn\u2019t say what those rights are.\n\nPart of the Powley test tells you what you need to do to be eligible: you must say you are M\u00e9tis, be accepted as a member of a modern M\u00e9tis community, and have ties to a historic M\u00e9tis community.\n\nWho are the M\u00e9tis and what are their rights? This is part of a unit on identity.\n\nPainted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis doesn\u2019t agree with what it calls \u201coverly restrictive and unfair\u201d definitions of who is M\u00e9tis. Instead, it says its definition is \u201csimple: anyone with an aboriginal ancestor,\u201d according to the company\u2019s website, which also lists fees for membership for adults ranging from $57 to $320, plus provincial sales tax.\n\nIn the past, Painted Feather turned down an interview request and sent CBC News to its website to find out more.\n\nKlein has said that he didn\u2019t say he was M\u00e9tis for political reasons, and he got his membership card before he got into politics.\n\nIndigenous ancestry is a complicated topic, so CBC News did its research with the help of Indigenous experts and journalists.\u00a0\n\nAs an elected minister in the Manitoba government, Klein\u2019s claims will be looked at by journalists in the same way they look at the claims of other high-ranking elected officials.\n\nKlein\u2019s lawyer says the matter is \u201cprivate.\n\nSince becoming a cabinet minister, Klein has turned down CBC News\u2019s request to talk to them about new information they have about his claim to be M\u00e9tis.\n\nKlein\u2019s lawyer, Sacha Paul of Thompson Dorfman Sweatman, sent a letter to CBC News in April asking them to stop asking about Klein\u2019s background and to stop talking to his family about it.\n\nPaul wrote, \u201cMr. Klein has told me that the issue of his Indigenous heritage is a personal one and that his campaign materials do not emphasize his connection to his Indigenous ancestry.\u201d\n\nRed flag\n\nJean Teillet said, \u201cOnce we can all say we\u2019re Indigenous for any reason, there won\u2019t be any Indigenous people left, because we\u2019ll all be Indigenous.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe says it\u2019s bad because it\u2019s another step toward getting rid of Indigenous people. She calls this \u201creverse assimilation.\u201d\n\nTeillet was hired by the University of Saskatchewan as an independent investigator to figure out how to stop false claims of Indigenous ancestry. This was done after professor Carrie Bourassa was put on leave and then resigned after a CBC investigation found no proof that she was Indigenous.\n\nThe Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis is one of many groups that have \u201csprung up\u201d since 2002. Teillet said that these groups \u201chave a very, very loose definition of what they call M\u00e9tis, which is basically anyone who has even a tiny bit of Indigenous ancestry.\u201d\n\nIn academia, people are encouraged to lie about being indigenous. Here\u2019s how to fix it.\n\nTeillet\u2019s report for the University of Saskatchewan, called \u201cIndigenous Identity Fraud,\u201d found similarities between different cases of false claims of Indigeneity, which she calls \u201cred flags.\u201d\n\nKlein told What\u2019s Up Winnipeg reporter Dorothy Dobbie during his run for mayor that he took an Indigenous course at the University of Alberta \u201cto learn more about his M\u00e9tis and Cree background.\u201d\n\n\u201cSome Native American groups in the middle of the country had a lot of people with blonde hair and blue eyes. His family says that you can see his roots in his cheekbones, but Kevin says he could never grow a real beard!\u201d wrote Dobbie, a former Progressive Conservative MP who wrote the profile of Klein before the civic election.\n\nTeillet wrote in her report for the University of Saskatchewan that the changing identities of Indigenous people should be a red flag.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThey changed their stories when people didn\u2019t believe them. One great example is Joseph Boyden. Teillet said in an interview, \u201cI think he changed his name about 10 times over the years.\u201d\n\nAn investigation by APTN found no proof that Boyden, who has written about Indigenous people and culture in his books, has any Indigenous ancestors.\n\nTeillet said, \u201cIf [Klein] follows the pattern that everyone else has followed, he\u2019ll keep changing his stories over and over again.\u201d\n\nAfter an investigation, author Joseph Boyden stands up for Indigenous culture.\nIndigenous identity and Joseph Boyden\u2019s case;\n\nTeillet said that when people who say they are Indigenous but can\u2019t prove it speak for Indigenous people, Indigenous people aren\u2019t heard.\u00a0\n\n\u201cEvery time someone like that speaks on behalf of Indigenous people, they take the microphone away from real Indigenous people,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about my mom and family,\u201d I said\n\nKlein told CBC News last year, when he was running for mayor, that his claim to M\u00e9tis heritage was a way for him to connect with his late mother, Joanne Winacott.\n\nIn 1991, when she was 45 years old, her second husband killed her in her Oshawa home.\n\nKlein was 26 years old.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not trying to claim any rights or think that this will help me in any way. In an interview in September, Klein said, \u201cIt\u2019s about my mom and my family.\u201d\n\nKlein has spoken out about the murder of his mother. He still has a section of his personal website, which he used to run for office, that is about his mother.\n\nOn April 5, the day of his mother\u2019s birthday, he talked about her death and domestic violence in the legislature.\n\nWhen Klein was a city councillor for Charleswood-Tuxedo-Westwood, he talked about the death of his mother during a debate about the budget for the Winnipeg Police Service:\n\n\u201cI want to talk about something that no one else in the council can talk about. \u201cMy Native mother was killed,\u201d Klein said at a meeting of the Winnipeg city council in December 2021.\n\nOn Red Dress Day, May 5, 2022, the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Klein posted a video to Instagram saying, \u201cMy mother was killed by her partner, and she was Indigenous,\u201d in front of the red dresses that were on display at Winnipeg City Hall for the event.\n\nKlein\u2019s lawyer said in a letter from April that the media, including CBC, can ask about Klein\u2019s record and what he has done for his constituents, but not about \u201cpersonal matters.\u201d\n\nPaul wrote, \u201cFrom our client\u2019s point of view, his heritage is one of the few ties he has to his late mother, who was taken from him when he was a child.\u201d\n\nIn a second email sent in the middle of July, Paul said that Klein is \u201ca firm believer in the freedom of the press and responsible journalism.\u201d\n\n\u201cHowever, it is not responsible journalism to keep bringing up a personal matter that has to do with the sad death of my client\u2019s mother,\u201d Paul wrote.\n\nThe lawyer wanted to know for sure that CBC News \u201cwill not run this story now or in the future.\u201d\n\nTeillet\u2019s report also says that it\u2019s a red flag when people talk about Indigenous trauma in public places more than once.\n\n\u201cSomeone killed his mother. Teillet said in an interview, \u201cThat\u2019s real trauma, but it has nothing to do with Indigenous identity.\u201d \u201cIt is a sad story about how his mother was killed.\u201d\n\nTeillet doesn\u2019t understand why Klein ties his claim to M\u00e9tis heritage to his mother\u2019s death.\n\n\u201cIs he saying, \u2018Oh, she was murdered, you know, she\u2019s part of that murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls story,\u2019 and that if you can show trauma in your life, that\u2019s a good reason to identify as Indigenous?'\u201d\n\nIn her report for the University of Saskatchewan, Teillet finds a pattern in the cases she looked at.\n\n\u201cIndigenous identity thieves often rely heavily on stereotypes about being disconnected from their culture and heritage, intergenerational trauma, family violence, addictions, racism, and poverty. By doing this, the scammers are \u201cmarketing trauma\u201d by using \u201cstolen trauma and stolen valour.\u201d She used research done by Sherry Farrell Racette in her report.\n\nRout says he doesn\u2019t like how Klein talks about the death of their mother in public.\n\nKlein started his Instagram account right before he ran for city council in 2018. It has at least 15 posts about the murder of his mother, as well as ads for his campaigns for city councillor, mayor, and MLA in 2022.\n\nHe also talks about his mother\u2019s murder on his\u00a0personal site, which he also uses for campaign purposes.\n\nRout said he dislikes the way Klein uses his mother\u2019s memory in his public posts.\n\n\u201cTo me, a son\u2019s job is to defend their mom, defend their mom\u2019s story, not exploit it for any gain. So I will stand and defend it all day long,\u201d Rout, a paramedic with Alberta Health Services, said in an interview with CBC News.\n\nIndigenous identity requires connectio\n\nKlein completed the University of Alberta\u2019s Indigenous Canada course in 2020\u00a0and posted the certificate on his website. The free online instruction program covers the histories and current perspectives of Indigenous Peoples in Canada.\n\nEarly in the course,\u00a0University of Alberta professor Kim TallBear\u00a0says having an Indigenous relative does not make you Indigenous.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t just have the right as an individual to go claim to be a member of a community that does not know you, within which you have not been socialized and that does not claim you,\u201d TallBear said in a module of the course.\n\nKlein is adamant that his M\u00e9tis heritage is a private and personal journey, but Teillet says that\u2019s not how it works.\n\n\u201cThis idea that it\u2019s a personal journey and no one can question it \u2026 it\u2019s BS, right? We shouldn\u2019t give it credit. And so if he\u2019s on a personal journey for six to eight years, trying to find an Indigenous identity somewhere, then personally, I think he should shut up about it until he figures it out,\u201d Teillet said.\n\nPREV\nNEXT\n\nWe covers local, national and international news and offers columns and commentary from a variety of sources.\n\nKnow More\nSince 2019, 14 whales and 1 dolphin have died at Marineland, according to documents from the ministry\nHow motion-activated cameras may reveal the secrets of a healthy herd of caribou in Manitob\nFan Expo Canada is back, and it\u2019s more important than ever that it\u2019s led by women\n2024 Ottawa Express"},

It\u2019s a day to raise awareness and remember those who have been lost over the years.\n\nRed Dress Day started in 2010 as REDress project established by Indigenous artist Jamie Black.\n\nAt the Ki-Lo-Na Friendship Society, the event included an opening prayer from an elder and singing and drumming led by Krystal Lezard.\n\nParticipants then planned to march to the Kelowna courthouse.\n\nSimilar events were held across the country and many posts on social media featured Indigenous women with red handprints across their mouths to symbolize solidarity with MMIWG and represent the thousands who have been silenced.\n\nSimilar events were held across the country.\n\nThe final report of the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls was released in June 2019. It found that persistent and deliberate human and Indigenous rights violations and abuses are the root cause behind Canada\u2019s staggering rates of violence against Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA people.\n\nThe two-volume report called for transformative legal and social changes to resolve the crisis, but many of the recommendations have not yet been acted on.\n\nPhoto: Regina Police\nJingle Dancers took part in a Red Dress Day Ceremony outside Regina Police headquarters.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Kelowna News\n\n\n\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in prison for murder\nAbbotsford - 1:39 pm\nA parade of aches and pains\nCalgary - 1:27 pm\nPower restored in Aberdeen\nKamloops - 1:16 pm\nMore Top Stories >\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReal Estate\n667 Burne Ave\n3 bedrooms 2 baths\n$895,000\nmore details\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nKelowna SPCA Featured Pet\n\n\nJerry\nKelowna SPCA >\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBody transformation journeys\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\nVanessa Hudgens gives birth\nShowbiz | July 04, 2024\nBaseball playing pup\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nMischievous Beagle caught tearing up the toilet paper\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nVintage bathrooms\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\nOkanagan Quick Links\nCity of Kelowna\nAirport Arrivals\nAirport Departures\nKelowna Discussion Forum\nKelowna Transit\nKelowna Road Closures\nTourism Kelowna\nCentral Okanagan Regional District\nDistrict of Peachland\nDistrict of Lake Country\nInterior Health\nUBC Okanagan\nOkanagan College\nSchool District 23\nOkanagan Regional Library\nKelowna Road Report\n\u00a9 2024 Castanet.net Make Castanet Your Homepage News Tips Advertising Contact Us"},
{"url": "https://www.northislandgazette.com/community/photos-kwakiutl-first-nation-hosts-gathering-at-gukwdzi-to-honour-red-dress-day/", "title": "PHOTOS: Gathering at Kwakiutl First Nation\u2019s \u2018Gukwdzi\u2019 honours Red Dress Day - North Island Gazette", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n14.8 \u00b0C\nHome Community\nPHOTOS: Gathering at Kwakiutl First Nation\u2019s \u2018Gukwdzi\u2019 honours Red Dress Day\nCanada continues to take steps towards truth and reconciliation\n\tBlack Press Media Staff\n\nMay 9, 2023 9:24 AM\nJul 11, 2023 3:28 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 5 The Kwakiutl First Nation hosted a gathering at their Gukwdzi in Fort Rupert on Red Dress Day, May 5, to remember, educate, and raise awareness for all the women, girls, men, boys, and two-spirited that have gone missing. See the full story and photos on page nine. (Tyson Whitney - North Island Gazette)\nExpand\n\nMay 5 marked Red Dress Day. A day where hearts hang heavy as red dresses drape with honour, and pride throughout numerous communities across the nation to remember and raise awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, and Girls (MMIWG) who were taken too soon, and lost to the hands of violence.\n\nA gathering was held at the Kwakiutl First Nation\u2019s Gukwdzi (Big House) to remember, educate, and raise awareness for all the women, girls, men, boys, and two-spirited that have gone missing. With over 200 people coming out to show their support, most of whom were wearing red, the event opened around 1:30 p.m. with introductory speeches and then cultural songs and dances.\n\nEveryone that came out for the gathering was invited to stay for food, performances, and closing remarks and prayers.\n\nRed Dress Day, also known as the Red Dress Campaign, sparked from the REDress Project which was first conceived on May 5, 2010 in Winnipeg, Manitoba through the inspired work of M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black. When Black was told by one of her Indigenous friends that red is the only colour spirits can see, and that is actually a callback for spirits to be among us again, a red dress became the catalyst for her display at the University of Winnipeg. It featured many hung empty to honour and symbolize all Indigenous women and girls lost to violence.\n\nThe annually recognized Red Dress Day draws attention to more than 1,000 Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada.\n\nThe country continues to take steps towards truth and reconciliation. It was earlier this week on May 2, that the House of Commons adopted a motion to declare ongoing violence against Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people a national emergency.\n\n\nchadd.cawson@cowichanvalleycitizen.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Black Press Media Staff\n\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tPort Hardy RCMP seize large quantity of drugs and cash\n\t\tSurviving the flu really makes you appreciate being healthy\n\t\t'We should be in crisis mode': B.C. wildfire ecologist\n\t\tTri-Port celebrates Canada Day\n\t\tFaster internet now available for 5 more island communities\nFacebook Comments (0) \nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. {"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/community-hangs-red-dresses-back-up-after-two-people-filmed-taking-them-down-in-ladysmith-1.24310031", "title": "Community hangs red dresses back up after two people filmed taking them down in Ladysmith - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n22.2 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Local News\nCommunity hangs red dresses back up after two people filmed taking them down in Ladysmith\nA Ladysmith-area First Nation joined forces with the town\u2019s council, firefighters and other residents on Saturday to replace red dresses hanging by the Island Highway that were taken down in an incident caught on video.\nAnna Mckenzie,Local Journalism Initiative\nApr 21, 2021 11:29 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nA red dress hanging off of the side of the highway, close to the Snaw-Naw-As (Nanoose) Nation. ANNA McKENZIE, THE DISCOURSE\n\nA Ladysmith-area First Nation joined forces with the town\u2019s council, firefighters and other residents on Saturday to replace red dresses hanging by the Island Highway that were taken down in an incident caught on video.\n\nMore than 100 red dresses had been hung along the highway on Family Day, from Victoria to Port Hardy, in honour of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, trans and Two Spirit people.\n\nNanaimo resident Tina Henderson says she had just finished work and was waiting for her sushi order at Sushi Wara in Ladysmith on April 10 when she noticed two people on the opposite side of the highway using large sticks to take down red dresses and hoisting them out of sight, into the bush.\n\n\u201cWe have to as a community, as people, stand up for our missing and murdered Indigenous women, men and children, and to me, that was like a huge violation,\u201d says Henderson.\n\nShe says she considered driving across the highway, so she could yell and honk at them, but she figured it was more important to capture what was happening on video.\n\nInitially, she wasn\u2019t sure what to do with the video, so she talked with her \u201cgo-to\u201d activist friend, Stephanie Goudie, who posted it on Facebook.\n\nThe use of the red dress was originally inspired by the REDress Project, which was initiated by Anishnaabe artist Jaime Black as an \u201caesthetic response to this critical national issue,\u201d according to Black\u2019s website.\n\nThe video has prompted anger, sadness and outrage in the community.\n\nRoxanne Harris, chief of the Stz\u2019uminus First Nation, says she was shocked and disheartened when the video clip was brought to her attention. After viewing it, she called the mayor of Ladysmith, Aaron Stone.\n\n\u201cWe have a good working relationship,\u201d she says.\n\nLadysmith town council and the Stz\u2019uminus chief and council gathered on Saturday to put red dresses up where they were taken down.\n\nHarris says other community members also lent a hand, including the Ladysmith Fire Department and the people behind the Ladysmith Festival of Lights.\n\n\u201cWe are working together to try and remedy the situation,\u201d says Harris, adding that people who want to contribute can drop off red dresses at Ladysmith City Hall. May 5 is recognized nationally as Red Dress Day.\n\nSnuneymuxw Elder Yvonne Rigsby-Jones, who helped to hang the red dresses, says this was an opportunity to re-educate the public about what the dresses represent.\n\n\u201cThose red dresses are hung in memory of people,\u201d says Rigsby-Jones, the former executive director of Tsow-Tun Le Lum Society. \u201cThere\u2019s love and meaning behind them.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know why those men took those dresses down, so they need to know what they signified.\u201d\n\nAccording to an oft-cited report published by the RCMP in 2014, there are 1,181 police-recorded homicides and unresolved cases of missing Indigenous women in Canada.\n\nRigsby-Jones believes the number is much higher.\n\nIn June 2019, a two-volume report was released by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls after a series of cross-country public hearings and evidence gathering, including testimonies shared over two years from \u201c2,380 family members, survivors of violence, experts and Knowledge Keepers,\u201d according to the inquiry.\n\nOne of the inquiry\u2019s recommendations was for police to put together a national strategy to ensure consistency in mechanisms for reporting missing Indigenous women and girls, and to implement a national database.\n\nThe report also calls for a special investigation into failures to investigate cases and police misconduct.\n\nRigsby-Jones works with the Indian Residential School Survivors Society, where she offers counselling support to individuals and families.\n\n\u201cTo hear from families that services aren\u2019t protecting them is devastatingly sad and wrong,\u201d she says.\n\nHarris says the plan is not simply to replace the dresses that were taken down, but to extend their reach, hanging dresses from Ladysmith all the way to Stz\u2019uminus territory.\n\n\u201cWe will be making a big statement.\u201d\n\n\u2014 The Discourse\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.wallstreet-online.de/nachricht/16922818-suncor-indigenous-employees-lana-and-joy-want-everyone-to-be-ally-on-red-dress-day-and-beyond", "title": "Suncor Indigenous Employees, Lana and Joy Want Everyone To Be an Ally on Red Dress Day and Beyond - 11.05.2023", "body": "DAX18.452,26+0,28\u00a0%\tGold2.356,370,00\u00a0%\t\u00d6l (Brent)87,74+0,64\u00a0%\tDow Jones39.364,74+0,22\u00a0%\tUS Tech 10020.174,08-0,09\u00a0%\tEUR/USD1,08118+0,25\u00a0%\t\nLogin\nPush-Kurse\nAktien\nCommunity\nNachrichten\nIndizes\nFonds\nETFs\nAnleihen\nZertifikate\nRohstoffe\nKrypto\nDevisen\nUnsere Services\nDepot\n+++ N\u00e4chster Hype in Anmarsch: Nach der sensationellen KI-Rallye startet bei dieser Tech-Aktie jetzt der n\u00e4chste Boom +++\nAnzeige\nNEWS TICKER\nStartseite\u00a0>\u00a0Aktien\u00a0>\u00a0Suncor Energy Aktie\u00a0>\u00a0Nachrichten zu Suncor Energy\n\u00a0129 \u00a00\u00a0Kommentare\nSuncor Indigenous Employees, Lana and Joy Want Everyone To Be an Ally on Red Dress Day and Beyond\n\nNORTHAMPTON, MA / ACCESSWIRE / May 11, 2023 / Suncor EnergyOriginally published on May 5, 2023Lana Hill, who is a trusted advisor to many young Indigenous people in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo, holds her own teenage daughter closer each time the name \u2026\n\nNORTHAMPTON, MA / ACCESSWIRE / May 11, 2023 / Suncor Energy\n\n\nFoto: Accesswire\nAnzeige\u00a0\nHandeln Sie Ihre Einsch\u00e4tzung zu Suncor Energy (New)!\nLong\n36,17\u20ac\nBasispreis\n3,32\nAsk\n\u00d7 10,90\nHebel\nZum Produkt\nShort\n42,52\u20ac\nBasispreis\n0,36\nAsk\n\u00d7 10,05\nHebel\nZum Produkt\n\nDen Basisprospekt sowie die Endg\u00fcltigen Bedingungen und die Basisinformationsbl\u00e4tter erhalten Sie bei Klick auf das Disclaimer Dokument. Beachten Sie auch die weiteren Hinweise zu dieser Werbung.\n\nOriginally published on May 5, 2023\n\nLana Hill, who is a trusted advisor to many young Indigenous people in Fort McMurray Wood Buffalo, holds her own teenage daughter closer each time the name of another missing Indigenous person is released. Joy Flett is the knowledge keeper for her close and extended relatives, but pieces of her family tree have been stolen, and she feels a heartache that is shared by countless other Indigenous families across Canada. Both women will be wearing red on May 5.\n\nAlso known as Red Dress Day, May 5 marks a day to honour, remember and create awareness and action for Missing, Murdered and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP) in Canada. The statistics are startling -Indigenous women in Canada today are seven times more likely than non-Indigenous women to be a murder victim, and three times more likely to be violently or sexually assaulted.\n\nLana, originally from Cowessess First Nation in Saskatchewan, and Joy, from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation in Alberta, are part of Suncor's Indigenous and Community Relations team in Fort McMurray, Alta. They both agree that more action is needed to end the MMEIP crisis.\n\n\"Since the time of residential schools and everything leading to today, we've been stripped of our names, our languages, our hair. To be able to take back our power and voice, we need to keep speaking out against what is happening,\" says Joy. \"There are so many Indigenous people who've gone missing or have been murdered in our own city. We need to continue to say their names. They are important to somebody. We can all play a role in ending the violence.\"\n\nOne of the national organizations helping to move the needle with this progress is the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC). For almost 50 years NWAC has played a lead role in advocating for the rights of Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit, transgender and gender-diverse people, which includes critical advocacy on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG2S+) and reconciliation. The organization has been pressing the federal government to act since the National Inquiry issued the 231 Calls for Justice in 2019.\n\nLesen Sie auch\n\u00d6lpreis vor Neubewertung\nBrent \u00d6l knackt Widerstand und startet durch\n02.07.24, 17:21\nAttraktive Bewertungslage\nEnergieaktien bieten Chancen trotz \u2013 oder wegen \u2013 Rezessions\u00e4ngsten\n02.07.24, 05:32\nEnergiewende ad\u00e9\nBP verschiebt Fokus zur\u00fcck auf \u00d6l und Gas \u2013 Schock und Jubel zugleich!\n27.06.24, 10:31\nGute Aussichten f\u00fcr Nebenwerte\nKleine Unternehmen vor gro\u00dfem Aufschwung\n26.06.24, 11:44\n\nWhen reflecting on Red Dress Day, NWAC urges Canadians to consider the many aspects of colonization that continue to affect Indigenous people. NWAC's Chief Executive Officer, Lynne Groulx, believes that a critical component to reconciliation is acknowledging the past.\n\n\"We invite everyone across the country to play an active role in reconciliation through education and raising awareness, as well as learning about Indigenous knowledge systems and the impacts of colonialism and racism that face many Indigenous people,\" says Lynne. \"We have taken urgent and significant action to increase awareness and address the 231 Calls for Justice and have been working hard to implement our own MMIWG2S+ Action Plan.\"\n\nNWAC's Action Plan includes 66 concrete actions they will take to help end the MMEIP. Last year NWAC reported progress on over 85 per cent of the proposed actions. This includes the Safe Passage Platform - a national reporting tool that maps cases of MMIWG2S+ and provides information on resources and services available across the country.\n\nLynne also suggests reading books, listening to podcasts or participating in educational programs created by Indigenous authors and media to see the world through their lens. She also encourages people to help amplify messages and initiatives from Indigenous voices to ensure they are being heard.\n\nOn May 5 and beyond, both Lana and Joy will be found honouring and remembering - the missing, murdered and exploited Indigenous peoples - in their own way of healing and active support.\n\n\"Through my mom's experience growing up of being called a dirty Indian, to now my 15-year-old daughter who is able to stand proud and march to the beat of her own drum, we can see there has been a lot of progress for Indigenous people to feel seen and accepted,\" says Lana. \"But we also must acknowledge the pain and trauma that is still prevalent today. We are not victims, we are survivors.\"\n\nView additional multimedia and more ESG storytelling from Suncor Energy on 3blmedia.com.\n\nContact Info:\nSpokesperson: Suncor Energy\nWebsite: https://www.3blmedia.com/profiles/suncor-energy\nEmail: info@3blmedia.com\n\nSOURCE: Suncor Energy\n\n\n\nView source version on accesswire.com:\nhttps://www.accesswire.com/754300/Suncor-Indigenous-Employees-Lana-and ...\n\n\nThe Suncor Energy Stock at the time of publication of the news with a fall of -1,26\u00a0% to 39,18CAD on Toronto stock exchange (10. {"url": "https://www.pentictonherald.ca/news/article_a24ebe04-026d-11ef-b231-07f9361e4527.html", "title": "Red dresses sought for haunting display | News | pentictonherald.ca", "body": "Skip to main content\nAboutContactReal Estate TodayBusiness DirectorySpecial Editions\nMake Home Page\nSign UpLog In\nFacebook\n \nTwitter\n \nLinkedIn\nThursday, July 4, 2024\nHome\nNews\nSports\nBusiness\nFeatures\nOpinion\nClassifieds\nSubscribe\nContests\ne-Edition\nFEATURED\nRed dresses sought for haunting display\nJOE FRIES Apr 25, 2024 \nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\n\nPart of the scene during Red Dress Day 2023 events in Penticton.\n\nSpecial to The Herald\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nCopy article link\nSave\n\nThree local Indigenous groups are asking for donations of red dresses for a haunting memorial set for May 5 in Penticton.\n\nThe garments will be hung from lampposts along Lakeshore Drive on what is Red Dress Day, an annual event now recognized across Canada to acknowledge missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u201cIn Cree culture, it\u2019s the only colour spirits can see, so that\u2019s why red was chosen,\u201d explained one of the organizers, Jamie-Lee Keith of the South Okanagan Similkameen M\u00e9tis Association, in an interview this week.\n\nHer group is partnering on the project with the Penticton Indian Band and Ooknakane Friendship Centre.\n\nDetails of the event are still being finalized, but it promises to be powerful.\n\n\u201cThis walk transcends a mere memorial; it serves as a rallying cry for the entire community to unite in support of Indigenous women, while also raising awareness about the disproportionate violence they endure,\u201d explains a press release from the organizers.\n\n\u201cWhile we warmly invite everyone to participate and contribute to this cause, it's crucial to remember that the focus of our collective action remains on Indigenous women, who are most directly affected by this issue. We are hopeful for a significant turnout, demonstrating a community-wide commitment to addressing and combating this violence.\u201d\n\nRed dresses of any size and style may be dropped off at the front desk of the Ashnola Building at the Okanagan College campus in Penticton.\n\nRed Dress Day was first observed in Winnipeg in 2010, when Metis artist Jamie Black hung hundreds of the garments in public places to call attention to the plight of Indigenous women.\n\nIndigenous women account for 16% of all female homicide victims and 11% of missing women, but Indigenous people make up only about 4.3% of Canada\u2019s population, according to the Assembly of First Nations.\n\nApproximately 13% of Indigenous people experience intimate partner violence, compared to 5.7% of the total population.\n\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nCopy article link\nSave\nTags\nClothing Ethnology Crime\nRecommended for you\nMost Popular\n Articles\nCelebrating July 1 in the South Okanagan\n700 cars in Penticton, here are the winners...\nPen-Hi Scholarships and Bursaries\nNHL star lists Lake Huron mansion for $7.9M: 'Takes your breath away'\nHave you seen this person?\nPedophilic Summerland lifeguard returned to jail after reviving 'crime cycle'\nPrincess Margaret celebrates graduates\nCanada Day Quiz: Okanagan edition\nMa-and-pa market focuses on mediterranean meals\nLetters to the Editor (8): Friday, June 28, 2024\nSubmit Your News\n\nWe're always interested in hearing about news in our community. {"url": "https://www.timminspress.com:443/news/local-news/no-more-stolen-sisters", "title": "'No more stolen sisters' | The Daily Press", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\n'No more stolen sisters'\n\nRed Dress event in Sudbury remembers and honours Canada's missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\n\nAuthor of the article:\nMia Jensen\nPublished May 05, 2022 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 06, 2022 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nAnishnaabe Kweok Singers perform at a ceremony at the unveiling of the Red Dress Art Reveal at the N'Swakamok Native Friendship Centre in Sudbury, Ont. on Thursday May 5, 2022. The event was held on the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit people. The art was created by Kathryn Corbiere, of One Kwe Modern Fabrications, and commissioned through the Looking Ahead to Build the Spirit of Our Women Learning to Live Free from Violence project in collaboration with the N'Swakamok Native Friendship Centre. John Lappa/Sudbury Star/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nOutside the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre Thursday afternoon, a crowd dressed in red shirts and ribbon skirts gathered to watch as two men on an aerial lift removed the tarp from over top of a brand new sculpture on the front of the building.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMore than twice the men\u2019s size, the brilliant red art piece is in the shape of a dress, adorned with two rows of feathers, red and yellow ribbons, and a pattern of leaves decorating the hem. At its centre, it reads, in silver capital letters, \u201cNO MORE STOLEN SISTERS.\u201d\n\nThe Red Dress artwork was created by M\u2019Chigeeng First Nation artist Kathryn Corbiere of One Kwe Modern Fabrications. The piece was commissioned through the \u201cLooking Ahead to Build the Spirit of Our Women \u2013 Learning to Live Free From Violence\u201d project, a collaborative partnership between the Friendship Centre and the Greater Sudbury Police Service.\n\nJohn Vallely (Nootchtai) takes part in a ceremony at the unveiling of the Red Dress Art Reveal at the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre in Sudbury, Ont. on Thursday May 5, 2022. The event was held on the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit people. The art was created by Kathryn Corbiere, of One Kwe Modern Fabrications, and commissioned through the Looking Ahead to Build the Spirit of Our Women Learning to Live Free from Violence project in collaboration with the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre. John Lappa/Sudbury Star/Postmedia Network PHOTO BY JOHN LAPPA /John Lappa/Sudbury Star\n\nThe unveiling took place on Red Dress Day, which is held annually on May 5 to recognize and honour missing and murdered Indigenous Women and Girls across Canada, and raise awareness of the impact of gendered and radicalized violence. The red dress has come to symbolize those who have been lost over the centuries-long tragedy.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI think everyone\u2019s overwhelmed with the unveiling of the art,\u201d said N\u2019Swakamok executive director Marie Meawasige. \u201cI think everybody is very proud of the art that will be there forever.\u201d\n\nThe event featured a gathering of Indigenous community members, elders, and family members of MMIWG, as well as local supporters, including Mayor Brian Bigger, Sudbury MPP Jamie West, and members of the police service.\n\nSeveral speakers took the time to address the crowd about the impact violence against Indigenous women has had on their lives.\n\nOne of the speakers, Juliette Wemigwans, who lost her sister in 2002, said she sees the Red Dress artwork as more than just a symbol.\n\n\u201cI think having this dress here gives voice to people,\u201d she said in her emotional speech. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot to be said about \u2018out of sight, out of mind.\u2019 When the community and the family bring forth this dress, it\u2019s no longer out of sight; it\u2019s no longer out of mind.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAccording to the police service\u2019s Indigenous Liaison Officer, Darrell Rivers, the Red Dress art is meant to serve as a commemorative art piece to raise awareness about MMIWG and show support to affected family members in the community.\n\nThe partnership between the Friendship Centre and the police service began in 2015, as a means to improve collaboration in addressing the needs of the local Indigenous community. The artwork is part of that project.\n\nThe relationship between Indigenous communities and police can often be difficult, with improvements to accountability an important part of the Calls to Justice in Final Report on MMIWG, released in 2021.\n\nRivers said change within the police service takes time, but it\u2019s something they\u2019re to which they are committee.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe work hard to make ourselves better as a police service and we welcome the opportunity to learn,\u201d Rivers said. \u201cI think the ongoing partnerships with all the Indigenous organizations, especially the Friendship Centre, it just goes to show that we as a police service are trying to change and make things better.\u201d\n\nMeawasige said she hopes the new sculpture will provide an important visual reminder to the whole community.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019ll be very much available for everyone to see, day or night,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re just hoping that there\u2019s a better understanding of why the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre and the Greater Sudbury Police have worked together to promote awareness and to continue to work so there\u2019ll be (fewer) murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls in our communities, not just in Sudbury, but all over Canada.\u201d\n\nThe Local Journalism Initiative is made possible through funding from the federal government.\n\nmjensen@postmedia.com\n\nTwitter: @mia_rjensen\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR TIMMINS\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://www.stettlerindependent.com/news/the-violence-pandemic-continues-mps-declare-mmiwg2s-a-national-emergency/", "title": "\u2018The violence pandemic continues\u2019: MPs declare MMIWG2S a national emergency - The Stettler Independent", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nJobs\nObituaries\nHome News\n\u2018The violence pandemic continues\u2019: MPs declare MMIWG2S a national emergency\nBy Matteo Cimellaro, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter, Canada\u2019s National Observer\nLocal Journalism Initiative\nMay 3, 2023 11:20 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nLeah Gazan, NDP critic for women and gender equality, demands action on murdered and missing Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited people. (Photo by Matteo Cimellaro/Canada\u2019s National Observer)\n\nBy Matteo Cimellaro, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter, Canada\u2019s National Observer\n\nWARNING: This story contains distressing details.\n\nOn May 2, the House of Commons unanimously passed a motion declaring the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people a national emergency.\n\nThe motion was tabled by Leah Gazan, NDP critic for women and gender equity, and arrived just before Red Dress Day on May 5.\n\nThe adopted motion included a call to provide immediate and substantial investment in a red dress alert system to help notify the public when an Indigenous woman, girl or two-spirit person goes missing.\n\nAt a press conference on the morning of the motion, Gazan was flanked by several grassroots First Nation, M\u00e9tis and Inuit advocates and activists. She emphasized during the press conference that structures are in place to create the alert system immediately.\n\nGazan has met with Public Safety Minister Bill Blair to discuss a path forward, she told Canada\u2019s National Observer. But her patience is running out.\n\n\u201cThey just need to come to the table and then act,\u201d Gazan said. \u201cI\u2019m done with meeting for the sake of meeting.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s beyond \u201cfeel-good stuff\u201d \u2014 action needs to happen, she added.\n\nCurrently, the government has earmarked $2.5 million over five years to implement the missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited National Action Plan, but Gazan says action needs to happen now, pointing to the recent discovery of the remains of an eight-year-old girl from Samson Cree Nation and the death of a woman from Sandy Bay First Nation over the weekend.\n\nREAD MORE: Possible remains of allegedly murdered eight-year-old discovered in Maskwacis\n\nBut this year\u2019s federal budget notably clawed back $150 million of funding for women\u2019s shelters, a move that \u201creally, really worries\u201d Carol McBride, president of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada.\n\n\u201cI hope this resolution means that [the federal government] will be looking at that funding that they\u2019re planning on clawing back.\u201d\n\nIn question period, the Liberals pointed to the end of the pandemic as a reason to cut the shelter funds, Gazan said.\n\n\u201cThe pandemic is over, but not the violence pandemic \u2026 The violence pandemic continues,\u201d Gazan said.\n\nAt the press conference, Ellen Gabriel, an activist and filmmaker from Kanehsat\u00e0:ke, directly blamed politicians and bureaucrats for inaction.\n\n\u201cIt becomes a matter of economics. It goes to the Treasury Board, rather than looking at educating you leaders, your politicians, about what human rights actually means,\u201d Gabriel said.\n\n\u201cEvery single one of us knows what it is to breathe, everyone knows what it means to lose a loved one. Why can\u2019t politicians and bureaucrats understand that Indigenous Peoples are human beings as well?\u201d\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tStettler man takes to the road to raise money for a local specialty ranch\n\t\t'Old-style country fair' held in Red Willow\n\t\tAlberta man charged after teen shot, wounded on his rural property\n\t\tPaintearth County announces internet partnership\n\t\tTrudeau missing Calgary Stampede this summer, his only absence outside COVID-19 years\nFacebook Comments (0) \nYOUR VOTE MATTERS\nLooks like you have voted in all of our community polls. {"url": "https://cfweradio.ca/2023/05/09/red-dress-day-recognized-across-alberta-on-may-5/", "title": "Red Dress Day recognized across Alberta on May 5 | CFWE FM", "body": " Menu\nListen Live\nON-AIR\nAdvertising\nConcerts & Events\nBingo\nContact Us\nRed Dress Day recognized across Alberta on May 5\nMay 9, 2023 | 2:18 PM\n\nA red dress hangs from a tree at Legacy Park in Fort Saskatchewan (Photo credits - Ryan Hunt)\n\nOn May 5, many municipalities around Alberta observed Red Dress Day, also known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\nThe day brings awareness to the thousands of Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people who have been subject to disproportionate violence all over Canada.\n\n\u00a0\n\nThree women embrace at the Red Dress Day event in Fort Saskatchewan. (Photo credits \u2013 Ryan Hunt)\n\nRed Dress Day was partly inspired by an art installation by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project, where she hung red dresses to represent the missing and murdered women. Red dresses have since become symbolic of the crisis because of her installation.\n\nMany events were held across the province, where people would wear red, hang red dresses in parks, and march in solidarity for their loved one affected by violence.\n\n\u00a0\n\nA lady and her child stand and watch the Red Dress Day event unfold in Calgary (Photo credits \u2013 Daniel Barker-Tremblay)\n\nAt a Red Dress Day event and walk in Fort Saskatchewan Friday, Colleen Dollfusz, co-founder of the Indigenous Society of Fort Saskatchewan and the organizer of the event, spoke about what the evening had in store.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to be taking a walk from Legacy Park, up 99th Ave to 95th Street, then back to the park. We\u2019ll be honoring our missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls,\u201d Dollfusz said.\n\n\u00a0\n\nA group of people marching through downtown Red Deer for Red Dress Day (Photo credits \u2013 Jeremy Harpe)\n\nShe also mentioned there would be food, blessing from elders, dancers, and special guests.\n\nThe guests consisted of Mayor Gale Katchur, some child powwow dancers, seven drummers, and other speakers to share their stories and insight to the crowd gathered in Legacy Park in Fort Saskatchewan.\n\n\u00a0\n\nA group of people start their march between Spruce Grove and Stoney Plain for Red Dress Day (Photo credits -Brooklin Brittain)\n\nWhen asked what Red Dress Day meant to her, Dollfusz said that there are a lot of women whose cases are being neglected.\n\n\u201cThere is a huge number of women who are not being looked for. It\u2019s over 64 per cent of the Indigenous women population who have suffered, passed away, have gone missing, or have been assaulted in all different ways. Nothing has been done for it.\u201d\n\n\u201cI know a few women who have gone missing, and I\u2019ve worked in the community\u2026it\u2019s quite significant [to me]\u201d, she added.\n\n\u00a0\n\nA woman marching in downtown Edmonton for Red Dress Day (Photo credits \u2013 Keith Driver)\n\nListen to the full interview with Colleen Dollfusz below:\n\nAudio Player\n00:00\n00:00\nUse Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.\n\nDo you have a story idea?
