Supplied\nArticle content\n\nA virtual book launch for Red Dresses on Bare Trees: Stories and Reflections on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, by Michael Hankard, PhD and Elder Joyce Dillen and released through J. Charlton Publishing Ltd., will be held on Jan. 18 at 2 p.m. via Zoom.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe book deals with missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, an extremely painful topic \u2014 one that we struggled at times to write or think about, and it raises some painful memories and feelings, not only for us but particularly those whose stories and reflections are within it,\u201d the publisher said in a release.\n\n\u201cIncluded are essays and reflections by both men and women, because it seeks to help bring balance to our collective, equally important and unique, roles and responsibilities. It hopes to incorporate Indigenous knowledge principles about relationships and love in the hope that we can begin to emulate and live our lives in balance.\n\n\u201cIn this circle, we begin in the eastern direction with respect \u2014 seeing someone from all sides, and having \u20181,000 cups of tea\u2019 with them; moving into a time in the south where we must physically, mentally and spiritually sit and spend time with someone; then to empathy or feeling in the west where our connection to a person is strong enough so we hurt when they are hurting; then finally, into the gift of movement, where caring behaviour in the northern direction drives us to actually do something about it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHankard, PhD, is an associate professor of Indigenous studies at the University of Sudbury. He is also an associate director and co-investigator on Indigenous homelessness through Laurentian University\u2019s Centre for Research in Social Justice and Policy project on poverty, homelessness and migration.\n\nJoyce Dillen is an Elder of the Serpent River First Nation in northeastern Ontario.\n\nTo attend the launch, visit Zoom, www.zoom.us and download the client, then enter meeting ID 844-3755-1072 and passcode 193929.\n\nTo order Red Dresses on Bare Trees, visit www.jcharltonpublishing.com.\n\n\u00a0\n\nsud.editorial@sunmedia.ca\n\nTwitter: @SudburyStar\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nNEWS NEAR SUDBURY\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/lethbridge-news/2020/12/31/2020-year-in-review-october/", "title": "2020 year in review: October", "body": "e-EditionObituariesSpecial SectionsSpecial OccasionsContact Us\nSubscribeLogin to CommentRegister\n\n\nJULY 4TH, 2024\n \nJOBS\nBEST OF BEST\n\n\nHomeNewsSportsBusinessEntertainmentCommentaryClassifiedsHot Summer Guide\nLOCAL NEWSPROVINCIAL NEWSNATIONAL NEWSWORLD NEWSCOMMUNITY\n\n\nPoll\n\nDoes the federal Liberal party need a new leader?\n\nYes\nNo\n\nVIEW RESULTS\n\nSponsored\n\n\n\n\nFollow @Leth_Herald on twitter\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2031\n\n2020 year in review: October\n\n\n\nBY HERALD ON DECEMBER 31, 2020.\n\nSupporters form a human wall around the side of the Lethbridge Overdose Prevention Society tent after a protestor attempted to dismantle it at a media event at London Road Park. Herald file photo by Ian Martens @IMartensHerald\n\nThe Herald takes a look back at the Lethbridge stories that made headlines in 2020 in a month by month series running through this week to New Year\u2019s Eve\n\nOCTOBER\n\nOPS appears at Police Commission\nRepresentatives of the Lethbridge Overdose Prevention Society made a brief presentation to the Lethbridge Police Commission about what their purposes are in the community, and what they intend to do going forward. Group spokesperson Kaley Ann Beaudoin told commissioners they have applied for a legal exemption from Health Canada to offer sanctioned overdose prevention services in Lethbridge, but in the meantime would continue to operate as an unsanctioned OPS site despite some community opposition.\n\nLPS won\u2019t support Phillips\u2019 appeal\nLethbridge Chief of Police Shahin Mehdizadeh says the Lethbridge Police Service will not be supporting Lethbridge-West MLA Shannon Phillips\u2019 appeal to the Law Enforcement Review Board (LERB), nor her request for a public hearing, on a discipline decision made against two LPS officers who admitted to undertaking an unauthorized surveillance of her in 2017 when she was Alberta\u2019s Minister of Environment.\n\nVigil sheds light on missing and murdered Indigenous women\nIndigenous women and girls who have gone missing and murdered were remembered in a vigil. The Sisters In Spirit Vigil honoured the lives of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two Spirited and brought awareness to the violence experienced by Indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nU of L moves up to second in Maclean\u2019s rankings\nThe University of Lethbridge has achieved its highest-ever position in the annual Maclean\u2019s University Rankings Report, placing second overall in the primarily undergraduate classification. Moving up three spots from its fifth-place ranking a year ago, the U of L bettered its previous best standing, a third-place ranking that it occupied for six consecutive years, 2013-2017.\n\nMorning fire damages westside apartment building\nResidents of a large westside apartment complex on the 300 block of Highlands Boulevard West will be seeking temporary shelter this weekend after an early morning fire did substantial damage to their building. According to the Lethbridge fire department, the blaze began just before 8 a.m. on a second-storey outside balcony of one unit in the complex and quickly spread up to the third floor into the attic, eventually fully engulfing the roof of one whole section of the building.\n\nMan charged in fatal highway crash back in custody\nA Lethbridge man for whom police have been searching since he disappeared while on bail in June is back in jail after being arrested late last month. Wesley Brian Phillips, who is in custody at the Calgary Remand Centre, was wanted in connection with a fatal car collision last year. A warrant was issued June 12 when he failed to show up for court, even though he had, through his previous lawyer, been ordered to attend court after he was a no-show for a docket appearance the week before.\n\nShandro won\u2019t overturn decision\nMinister of Health Tyler Shandro will not intervene in an Alberta Health Services decision to end its local EMS dispatch contracts in Lethbridge, Calgary, Wood Buffalo and Red Deer. \u201cMy decision is not to overturn the AHS decision,\u201d he writes, \u201cand I look forward to supporting them and your municipalities during the transition to ensure that emergency health services can improve.\n\nLPS chief makes pitch for programs\nThe Lethbridge Police Service presented its quarterly report to city council on Monday, but also took the opportunity to get in an extra pitch to retain three programs brought in over the past few years for trial runs: The Watch program; the Community Peace Officer program; and the PACT (Police and Crisis Team).\n\nVersteeg set to do \u2018Battle\u2019 on the ice\nKris Versteeg is lacing up the skates to do battle again but this time it won\u2019t be in front of 20,000 fans at a National Hockey League game. Instead, the retired 34-year-old Stanley Cup champion and Lethbridge native will be skating for a televised audience in the CBC series \u201cBattle of the Blades.\u201d Versteeg and his professional skating partner Carlotta Edwards are among eight teams competing in the series for a $100,000 grand prize which will go to the winner\u2019s charity of choice.\n\nAlberta health-care workers walk off job to protest cuts during pandemic\nHospital and other health-care workers across Alberta, including Lethbridge, walked off the job Monday to protest recent cuts by the United Conservative government during the COVID-19 pandemic. Guy Smith, president of the Alberta Union of Provincial Employees, said in a news release that members are trying to defend jobs and protect the public health-care system.\n\nVocal opposition against coal mine\nOpposition is heating up against the proposed Benga mining company Grassy Mountain coal mine near Blairmore as the Joint Review panel starts to consider whether or not to approve the project with the opening of a public hearing.\n\nCoaldale council rejects mask bylaw\nCoaldale Town Council strongly suggested local residents and business owners should consider wearing a mask or face covering when out in public as COVID-19 cases continue to rise in the region, but stopped short of implementing a mandatory face covering bylaw by a vote of 6-1.\n\nCity tops national crime index\nLethbridge once again ranked first in the annual Crime Severity Index (CSI) for Canada in 2019. Although the city did not have the highest score for violent crime in the country, and is ranked as the 26th-worst urban jurisdiction for crime in Canada, (down from 15th in 2018), Lethbridge did see an overall increase in crime of about 2.23 per cent in 2019 compared to 2018.\n\nShare this story:\n\n16\n-15\n\nComments are closed.\n\n\n\n\n\nMore ways to get to us\n Facebook\n Twitter\n\nePaper Login\nSubscribe\nSubscription Services\nArchive\nAbout Us\nThe Lethbridge Herald\nOther Publications\nContact\nCareers\nContact the Lethbridge Herald\n\n504 - 7th Street South\nLethbridge, AB T1J 3Z7\n\n[P] (403) 328-4411\n[F] (403)328-4536\n\nPrint Advertising: (403) 328-4410\nNational Advertising: (403) 380-7581\nOnline Advertising: (403)380-7581\nClassifieds: (403) 328-4433\n\n\n\u00a9 1996-2024 The Lethbridge Herald\nAdvertisingTerms and Conditions & Privacy Policy\n\n"},

{"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/entertainment/local-a-e/gouchie-at-one-with-the-universe-1.17168048", "title": "Gouchie at one with the universe - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local Arts\nGouchie at one with the universe\nKym Gouchie has a name to live up to. Firstly, she is a Gouchie, which is synonymous with Lhiedli T'enneh First Nations artistry and leadership. Secondly, she has another name and it is emblazoned on her brand new album Northern Shining Star Woman.\nFrank Peebles\nApr 26, 2017 10:50 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKym Gouchie poses for a photo on April 19.Brent Braaten, Photographer\n\nKym Gouchie has a name to live up to.\n\nFirstly, she is a Gouchie, which is synonymous with Lhiedli T'enneh First Nations artistry and leadership.\n\nSecondly, she has another name and it is emblazoned on her brand new album Northern Shining Star Woman. It's who she is, in title and in deed.\n\n\"That name was given to me at a sweat lodge ceremony about 20 years ago,\" said the singer-songwriter-activist who splits her time between birth territory Prince George and adopted second home Penticton.\n\n\"Lee Claremont is a Mohawk artist and she did a painting called At One With the Universe that she told me was done with me in mind, so I knew a long time ago that I wanted that painting and that name to be the basis of an album. It's finally done.\"\n\nGouchie has a knack for attracting musicians to collaborate with her, producers to agonize over the details of her recordings, and painters to lay brush on canvas in her likeness. This past weekend she was in Vancouver playing a concert at the Wise Hall as the headliner alongside Prince George's Naomi Kavka, with Joey Only from Wells also on the bill, and other acts as well.\n\nThe new record is also a collection of interior B.C. power-players.\n\nThe mastering was done by famed mix-finisher Greg Reely (Sarah McLachlan, Coldplay, Skinny Puppy, Fear Factory, Juno Award nominee for his work with Spirit Of The West) who now operates out of nearby Osoyoos.\n\nThe main producer was Thurein Myint who runs Ellis Avenue Analogue Studio out of Summerland. This is not the first time Myint and Gouchie have put their musical heads together. She loves his new-age musical views that boil down to his strictly old-school form of recording. Gouchie is a living symbol of the ancient cultural roots of Western Canada, and she is from a generational musical dynasty in Lhiedli T'enneh territory, so it might not be surprising to learn she was attracted to the magnetic warmth of mylar recording tools.\n\n\"It wasn't that way at all, actually,\" she said. She was in the flow of digital recording conditions. \"How it happened was, I was approached to start a band. I knew about Thurein because he was teaching my daughter (Shayna Desjarlais, who joined in on some of the recording sessions) guitar lessons and I knew he was just wonderful on guitar. I just wanted him to be the guitar player in this band. He said yes.\"\n\nThe band never really took off, but Gouchie and Myint now had a working relationship, and all her recording plans shifted to his studio and his production mind.\n\n\"We work so well together,\" she said. \"He'd take things so far above and beyond my expectations, way more than anything I was used to from a producer. A lot of the success of the sound was all to do with him.\n\n\"And having Greg just an hour down the road was the beauty of it. Thurein could drive him the tapes and preserve that analogue process right up to the final point of transferring it to CDs.\"\n\nOne track on the album, the final song in the sequence entitled Cleansing The Highway, was a collaboration of a wholly different sort. She is never shy about staring social issues in the eyes, with her performance art. She sings stories about residential school inspired by her family members' survival of systemic abuse. She has written about cancer, based on the many people in her life who have battled the disease and its resonant effects. She has written about domestic abuse, gleaned from the observations of life.\n\nCleansing The Highway also came from realities that splattered across her brain like wounds slashed across northern B.C. along the Highway Of Tears. The excruciatingly numerous cases of missing and murdered women in the region was her motivation for taking part in one of the commemorative walks of Highway 16 between Prince Rupert and Prince George. Along the road, she beat her hand drum and chanted.\n\nThose rhythms and vocal themes began to form into musical themes. She took it to local artist and hand-drummer Jennifer Pighin and her group The Khast'an Drummers for their compositional input. Brenda Wilson, mother of Highway Of Tears victim Ramona Wilson and an outspoken advocate for social reform, also consulted with Gouchie on the song.\n\nWhen CBC Radio program The Current came to Prince George to broadcast a special national forum on the issue of missing and murdered women, Gouchie was invited to perform the song in its form to that date. It ended up forming the closing sounds of the broadcast and it was noticed by Toronto listener Angela Rudden, the principal violist for the National Ballet of Canada Orchestra.\n\nRudden contacted Gouchie and offered a unique affiliation. With Gouchie's enthusiastic support, Rudden scored a string accompaniment for the Highway Of Tears song, recorded the parts in Ontario conducted by Eric Paetkau, and emailed the finished product to Gouchie.\n\nGouchie then took those bed recordings into the recording studio of CFUR with Fraser Hayes at the control board. She added vocals to cap off this journey of a composition.\n\n\"It was a cross-Canada collaboration, and it came from the earth,\" said Gouchie. \"When I listen to it, when I play it, I feel the presence of the missing and murdered and stolen women.\"\n\nGouchie also got to incorporate the ethereal past into this record. On the song I Am she got her grandmother Mary Gouchie to provide vocals in her Lheidli dialect of the Dakelh language.\n\n\"She is one of the few who speak it fluently, and I want to do something to bring it to light, keep the language alive,\" Gouchie said.\n\nAnd the song Waniska is also from the murky waters of time. It is a traditional Cree song, in honour of Gouchie's partially Cree heritage.\n\n\"We have never been able to pinpoint an origin other than it is traditional, and it means morning. It would be sung in the teepee villages to welcome the new day. I learned it a long, long time ago, and I just love it,\" Gouchie said.\n\nAn album release concert is in the works for Prince George, but dates have not been announced. The CD is available for download on Gouchie's website (www.kymgouchie.com) and for purchase at Exploration Place, Books & Company, Angelique's Native Arts, and Ave Maria. It is also in participating retailers along the highways of the region.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/lethbridge-news/2020/10/06/vigil-sheds-light-on-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Vigil sheds light on missing and murdered Indigenous women", "body": "e-EditionObituariesSpecial SectionsSpecial OccasionsContact Us\nSubscribeLogin to CommentRegister\n\n\nJULY 4TH, 2024\n \nJOBS\nBEST OF BEST\n\n\nHomeNewsSportsBusinessEntertainmentCommentaryClassifiedsHot Summer Guide\nLOCAL NEWSPROVINCIAL NEWSNATIONAL NEWSWORLD NEWSCOMMUNITY\n\n\nPoll\n\nDoes the federal Liberal party need a new leader?\n\nYes\nNo\n\nVIEW RESULTS\n\nSponsored\n\n\n\n\nFollow @Leth_Herald on twitter\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2787\n\nVigil sheds light on missing and murdered Indigenous women\n\n\n\nBY LETHBRIDGE HERALD ON OCTOBER 6, 2020.\n\nHerald photo by Dale Woodard The Sisters In Spirit Vigil makes its way down Fourth Avenue from Lethbridge City Hall to Galt Gardens Sunday night.\n\nDale Woodard\n\nLethbridge Herald\n\nIndigenous women and girls who have gone missing and murdered were remembered in a vigil Sunday night.\u00a0\n\nThe Sisters In Spirit Vigil honoured the lives of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two Spirited and brought awareness to the violence experienced by Indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nAt Lethbridge City Hall, Elder Wendy English gave a prayer followed by a song before the ceremony moved down 4 Avenue South to Galt Gardens for more speakers and a candlelight vigil.\n\nFor the member of Piikani Nation, the Sisters In Spirit Vigil hits close to home for English.\n\n\u201cI had a couple of grandchildren that were brutally murdered five years ago and since I\u2019ve been participating in this event,\u201d she said. \u201cAlso, I had a niece that was also brutally killed in Calgary. Her body was dismembered and some of her parts were at the landfill and all over the banks of Calgary and they didn\u2019t find all her body. The guy that murdered her got away. He got so many years and now he\u2019s walking a free man.\u201d\n\nThe vigils take place in communities across Canada as well as internationally.\n\n\u201cThis is our 14th annual,\u201d said Amanda Scout, a Sisters In Spirit Vigil planning committee member.\n\n\u201cWe are honouring the missing and murdered Indigenous women and reminding people to keep that in mind that there have been inquiries and recommendations, but after that, no action.\u201d\n\nScout is also on the Reconciliation Committee and has worked with the City of Lethbridge.\n\n\u201cWe have gone through the recommendations thoroughly and we\u2019ve brought them to city council. There are 25 we feel that the City of Lethbridge can act on. It\u2019s just about creating safe spaces and getting the resources for women who might be at risk.\u201d\n\nScout said she believes the word is getting out.\n\n\u201cOf course, it could always be better and we would like to see more action. But it\u2019s being addressed and we have groups here in the city that are working with vulnerable women and trying to empower them. We\u2019re very hopeful and we\u2019ll keep walking.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday night en route to Galt Gardens from city hall vigil attendants held signs aloft proclaiming \u201cNo more stolen sisters\u201d\u2008and \u201cMissing, but not forgotten.\u201d\n\nMore speakers followed at Galt Gardens complete with a candlelight vigil that lit up the stage area as night fell.\n\nIt was a particularly busy weekend for English\u2019s family, who were also part of a walk from the Piikani Nation to Calgary to raise further awareness.\n\nThe walk started on Thursday.\n\n\u201cMy niece spearheaded it, it was her daughter that was brutally killed in Calgary,\u201d\u2008said English. \u201cWe walked from there to Nanton and they slept overnight and the next night they walked all the way to Calgary and to downtown Calgary.\u201d\n\nThe Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls inquiry was a 1,200-page report and also 230 calls to action for the police and institutions to be educated more on Indigenous people, their cultures, values, spirituality and beliefs, said English.\u00a0\n\n\u201cPart of the Missing and Murdered and the Truth in Reconciliation is for us to start reconciling with each other and start working together, be accepting of each other and live peacefully and prosper with each other and start loving each other for who we are. We\u2019re all human beings and we can\u2019t treat other nationalities as animals. We\u2019re human and we all want to be treated human and equally. Indigenous women have been treated brutally and abused. It\u2019s been going on and we want to make awareness to stop it. We want to be heard and we want people to know what\u2019s happening and to work with us as a community.\u201d\n\nFollow @DWoodardHerald on Twitter\n\nShare this story:\n\n23\n-22\n1 COMMENT\nOldest \newingbt\n 3 years ago\n\nI stand with you as you suffer from your losses and hope this evil shall cease stealing your people from you.\nI do understand you have your cultures, your values and spirituality and beliefs as may cultures do, but you must look at some of the reasons you have high rates of domestic violence, violent crimes, addictions and suicides. Your culture is colliding with the cultures of most of the world, as you move into non-FN communities. Many young on FN communities end up being brought up by aunties, grandmas or grandparents if they are lucky to have someone take them. The homes in your commmunities have been devasted, the family units. {"url": "https://calgary.ctvnews.ca/we-re-all-equal-red-dress-day-honoured-in-southern-alberta-1.5890868", "title": "Lethbridge residents come together to mark Red Dress Day | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nCALGARY\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nCALGARY\nNews\n'We're all equal': Red Dress Day honoured in southern Alberta\nA gathering to mark Red Dress Day was held at the Lethbridge Public Library on Thursday.\nKarsen Marczuk\nCTV News Lethbridge Video Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 5, 2022 4:33 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nCommunity members in Lethbridge gathered at the Lethbridge Public Library on Thursday to honour national Red Dress Day.\n\nIt\u2019s a day that's marked across the country, bringing awareness and calls on all Canadians to speak out on violence against Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited people. The day is especially important for Marilyn Contois, a technician and Indigenous services worker at the library, as she almost feel victim herself.\n\n\u201cWhat happened here today, wouldn\u2019t have happened maybe 20 years ago, and (things are) taking time, two steps forward, one step back sometimes,\u201d said Contois.\n\n\u201cI was approached when I was seven years old and I could've went missing along the Highway of Tears, but thank God that my Grade 3 teacher taught us kids, they really did a good job about teaching us about strangers,\u201d she said.\n\nContois said she was excited to bring events to the library to mark the day, which included a round dance, honour song and different events throughout the week.\n\nArtist Debbie Kelman taught a beading class, while also having her painting called \u2018Her Hands: a tribute to Anna Mae Pictou Aquash' symbolizing the red dress hung in the library.\n\n\u201cAfter I did the painting, I stood back and I looked at it and I knew once I seen it that now I have to make the dress. And, so it was very powerful, spiritual experience making the dress,\u201d said Kelman.\n\nThe dresses are empty to representing the women and girls who should be wearing them.\n\nIt\u2019s not exactly known how many Indigenous females have been murdered or have disappeared, but the Native Women's Association of Canada believes it's at least 4,000.\n\nKelman says her grandmother always told her to think of everyone as equal.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re all equal no matter what the situation in our life is, we\u2019re all equal and that everybody has human dignity and for everyone to treat every person with human dignity,\u201d said Kelman.\n\nThose in attendance on Thursday say the event should be more than just one day.\n\n\u201cEveryday could a be a day that we remember the murdered and missing Indigenous women and two spirit as well as men and also being an ally,\u201d said Contois.\n\nReport an error\nEditorial standards & policies\nWhy you can trust CTV On the National Day of Action for the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, Trans, and Two Spirited people (MMIWG2S), families and activists urged the federal government and Manitoba\u2019s government to search the landfill believed to be the site of unmarked graves of Indigenous women. Urban Indigenous leaders are calling for the city to make room for spaces that allow for healing to happen. They want the city to remove statues like the Queen Victoria statue in Gore Park, they feel are stark reminders of Canada\u2019s long history of colonialism. {"url": "https://www.mylloydminsternow.com/57971/featured/remembering-loved-ones-on-red-dress-day/", "title": "Remembering loved ones on Red Dress Day - My Lloydminster Now", "body": "Home\nNews\nNews Alerts Sign Up!\nWin\nEvents\nCommunity Calendar\nSubmit Event\nListen Live\nOn Air\nPodcast\nGOAT CHRISTMAS WISH\nLocal Connections\nNEWS\nWIN\nEVENTS\nCONTACT US\nADVERTISE\nWE\u2019RE HIRING\n\n\u25ba Listen Live\n\nHome\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nListen Live\nOn Air\nPodcast\nGOAT CHRISTMAS WISH\nLocal Connections\n- Advertisement -\nHomeNewsRemembering loved ones on Red Dress Day\nNews\nRemembering loved ones on Red Dress Day\nBy\nGerry Lampow\nMonday, May. 1st, 2023\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nRed dresses on trees near the Hope statue at Lloydminster City Hall. [Photo: Gerry Lampow 106.1 The Goat/Vista Radio]\n- Advertisement -\n\nTaking the time to remember and honour the missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and Two-Spirit people will be at the heart of Friday\u2019s observances at the Lloydminster Native Friendship Centre.\n\nThe National Day of Awareness or Red Dress Day on May 5 will see families who have lost loved ones being encouraged, supported and perhaps share from their hearts explains Patsy Waskewitch executive director at the centre.\n\n\u201cI come from Onion Lake actually. And we have had a few of women who have gone missing from the Lloydminster area \u2013 and I knew them. Even that itself \u2013 it\u2019s hard to fathom. But its affects everybody \u2013 the whole community,\u201d says Waskewitch.\n\nFriday\u2019s event will begin with Pipe Ceremony at 10 a.m. at the centre, then a memorial walk at noon from city hall to the clock tower and back to the centre. A lunch will be served from 1 p.m. and several speakers will be sharing. The Prairie Thunder Boys drummers from the public school division will also be on hand over the luncheon session.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nWaskewitch who is marking her second year at the helm of the centre for Red Dress Day, explains the day\u2019s significance.\n\n\u201cRed Dress Day \u2013 it means a lot to a lot of women, moms, daughters and sisters. It\u2019s losing a loved one.\u201d\n\nThe day will end with a vigil at 7 p.m. at the gazebo on the city hall grounds.\n\nOrganizers are thankful to all their community partners for support including the LRHF, Learning Council, Heart of Treaty Six, M\u00e9tis Nation of Saskatchewan and United Way.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- {"url": "https://southpeacenews.com/sisters-in-spirit-walks-held-around-region/", "title": "Sisters in Spirit Walks held around region -", "body": "HOME\nSUBMIT NEWS\nNOTICES / EMPLOYMENT / SERVICES / PROMOTIONAL\nHOROSCOPES\nCLASSIFIEDS\nNews\nSports\nOpinion\nEvents\nObituaries\nExtras\nToday in HP\nNorthern Sunrise County Newsletter\nSELECT Tool of the Week Contest\nHOME  EVENTS, NEWS  SISTERS IN SPIRIT WALKS HELD AROUND REGION\nSisters in Spirit Walks held around region\nOctober 15, 2019 \u00b7 by Admin2015 \u00b7  0\nLaura Giroux holds up a red dress sign of her late sister, Donna Giroux.\nDriftpile remembers\n\nChris Clegg\nSouth Peace News\n\nSadly, like many others, Laura Giroux knows first-hand the purpose of the Sisters in Spirit Walk.\n\n\u201cThat was my late sister,\u201d she says referring to the name on a paper red dress she carried during the walk.\n\nHer late sister was Donna Giroux, who passed away in November 2014 in a fire. The fire was not caused by her husband, but still an act of violence.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s why I\u2019m stepping up,\u201d she says.\n\nNancy Chalifoux works for Driftpile First Nation and organized the Sisters in Spirit Walk, the first held in the community. She contacted the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women organization and they sent her a package to prepare for the walk.\n\nIn addition, 13 red dresses were hung in the Driftpile Community Hall. She explains one red dress represents 100 reported cases but she added another to represent the many more not reported.\n\n\u201cThe government says there are 1,200 [cases] but we know it\u2019s more than that.\u201d\n\nRed is the chosen colour to represent the walk and the cause.\n\nWhen she addressed the 100 attending before the walk, she urged all parties to \u201cbreak the violence\u201d.\n\n\u201cIt is our hope [this walk] continues each Oct. 4,\u201d she said. \u201cWe must never forget.\n\n\u201cWe have families here who need our support. We need to honour and support the families each and every day of the year.\n\n\u201cWe need to grieve and heal,\u201d she concluded.\n\nShe then went into details of her mother\u2019s death. Despite the death occurring in 2001, no investigation took place until 2017.\n\n\u201cThere was blood in her truck. Her wallet was discovered in a shed in this community. Thankfully, [Lesser Slave Regional Police Service] took up the investigation. No one has ever been charged.\u201d\n\nCharmaine Larsen spoke, fresh off a 16,000 km motorcycle ride to bring awareness to the issue.\n\n\u201cNo more stolen sisters,\u201d she said.\n\nAvis Giroux\u2019s sister lost her son, Rupert, in a distracted driving accident.\n\n\u201cAn innocent child,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s taken a long time for his mother to come back from this trauma.\u201d\n\nGuest speaker Henry Watchmaker spoke and offered words of comfort.\n\n\u201cYou can never kill the spirit when a life ends,\u201d he said. \u201cKeep on living, keep on surviving.\u201d\n\nNancy Chalifoux holds up a sign of her late mother, who passed away in 2001.\nThe Driftpile Cree Singers sang songs before the walk. Left-right are Willis Isadore, J.R. Coleman, Laurent Isadore and Elder George Isadore.\nNahachick remembered in Peace River\n\nPeace River celebrated its 17th annual Sisters in Spirit Walk Oct. 4. Above, a closing round dance highlighted the walk. Peace River Mayor Tom Tarpey spoke at the event, while Northern Sunrise County Reeve Carolyn Kolebaba and deputy reeve Norm Duval attended. Melissa Cardinal spoke on behalf of her sister Brittany about Jordan Nahachik, who went missing from Peace River last December. Men are now being included in the Sisters in Spirit ceremonies.\n\nUnited front shown in High Prairie\nRed hands are \u201cpainted\u201d over Lisa Roberts, left, and Lennon Cardinal. The red hands signify a hand being over the mouth so the victim cannot speak. Roberts lost her mother, Evelyn Roberts, in 1978. The case remains unsolved.\n\nChris Clegg\nSouth Peace News\n\nOn such a sad and somber occasion, Belinda Willier could not have been more pleased.\n\nWillier literally gushed with pride about how the Sisters in Spirit movement has grown locally since the High Prairie Friendship Centre started the first walk 11 years ago.\n\n\u201cWe are growing,\u201d she says. \u201cThe word is spreading!\u201d\n\nThe first walks attracted less than a dozen people. Well over 50 attended the High Prairie walk, over 150 in Kinuso and 100 in Driftpile. Other walks were held in Peace River, Slave Lake and Valleyview. Another is planned for Peavine.\n\nThe Sisters in Spirit Walks bring awareness to missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cAs part of our commitment to the issue and to the countless families who are still in need of justice, the Native Wowen\u2019s Association of Canada is a lead organizer in the Sisters in Spirit vigils,\u201d says Willier.\n\n\u201cWe gather to honor our lost sisters and their families.\n\n\u201cWe gather to show we are a united front.\n\n\u201cWe gather to shed light on a crisis that affects every Canadian and we gather to pressure all levels of government to act and act now!\u201d\n\nA video was shown highlighting the loss of local Indigenous women including Brenda Moreside, Agnes Rose Chalifoux, Carmen L\u2019Hirondelle, Angeline Willier, Nina Joseph and Jackie Murdock. It is updated each year.\n\nWillier reminds everyone that the Sucker Creek Women\u2019s Shelter offers a safe and supportive environment for battered women and their children, women in crisis, or other women in need of emergency accommodations.\n\nSchools lead the walk at Kinuso\nDrummers lead the Sisters in Spirit Walk at Kinuso on Oct. 4. Students from Swan River First Nation School and Kinsuo School [Grades 7-10] participated.\n\nPearl Lorentzen\nFor South Peace News\n\nRiver of Silence writer Petie Chalifoux was part of the Sisters in Spirit event held by Swan River and Kinuso Schools.\n\nChalifoux\u2019s grandmother is one of the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women in Canada. Petie\u2019s grandmother\u2019s case is unsolved, but has been reopened.\n\nPetie is a film writer, hoop dancer and Swan River First Nations School graduate. She wrote Rivers of Silence, which is a film about a family\u2019s search for their missing daughter.\n\nThe film was shot in 2016. The world premiere of the film was at the 2018 Skins Film Festival in Los Angeles. The film hasn\u2019t been released widely in Canada. Stan Isadore from Driftpile First Nation is one of the main actors.\n\nStudents in Kinuso walked from the Kinuso School to the Swan River School at 11 a.m. Oct. 4, to raise awareness about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women. The event was organized by Swan River and Kinuso Schools.\n\nDrummers drummed the whole walk and did an honour song while Petie performed a hoop dance.\n\nNancy Chalifoux, Petie\u2019s mother, spoke about her mother\u2019s murder. The message was to look out for each other and the hope that this never happens to anyone else.\n\nLunch was served at Swan River School and the school showed River of Silence.\n\nAround 150 people attended, including all of the Swan River students and Grades 7-10 from Kinuso School.\n\n\u00a0This informed me50%\u00a0This not needed50%\nFiled in: Events, News\nTags: featured\nShare this post\nTWITTER\nFACEBOOK\nGOOGLE+\nLINKEDIN\nPINTEREST\nEMAIL\nRecommended for You\nGirouxville Museum opens for season\nConcert series continues July 3 at 12-Foot Davis\nGrand opening of Grimshaw Splash Park\nBig Lakes County hosts annual barbecue\nPost Comment\n\nComment *\n\nName * \n\nEmail * \n\nWebsite \n\nHIGH PRAIRIE - PEACE RIVER\n23\u00b0\nfew clouds\n56% humidity\nwind: 6m/s WSW\nH 23 \u2022 L 23\n23\u00b0\nFRI\n24\u00b0\nSAT\n27\u00b0\nSUN\n28\u00b0\nMON\n29\u00b0\nTUE\n31\u00b0\nWED\n28\u00b0\nTHU\n25\u00b0\nFRI\n24\u00b0\nSAT\n24\u00b0\nSUN\n\n Environment Canada Forecast \n\n Alberta 511 Road Reports \n\n Alberta Wildfire Status Map \n\nRecent Comments\nPeter Milne on\nDifferent rules for different councillors? {"url": "https://thestarphoenix.com:443/opinion/columnists/opinion-as-saskatoon-continues-to-grow-we-must-not-miss-the-bus", "title": "Opinion: As Saskatoon continues to grow, we must not miss the bus | The Star Phoenix", "body": "Skip to Content\nLIMITED-TIME SALE! Unlimited access for only $3 for 3 months. Act Now>>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\n2024 Saskatchewan wildfires\nSend a Letter to the Editor\nSports\nOpinion\nBusiness\nArts\nLife\nShopping\nNewsletters\nBridges\nPuzzmo\nDriving\nePaper\nRemembering\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nColumnists\nOpinion: As Saskatoon continues to grow, we must not miss the bus\n\nA Saskatoon immigrant from India says the fast-growing city will need to improve its transit system or face growing traffic gridlock.\n\nAuthor of the article:\nGuest column\nPublished May 03, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 03, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 4 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nCity of Saskatoon transit buses at the downtown bus mall in Saskatoon, SK in March of 2020. PHOTO BY LIAM RICHARDS /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\nArticle content\n\nI have a beef with Saskatoon Transit.\u00a0Don\u2019t get me wrong. I love the public transport system. But not its slightly errant ways.\n\nHaving lived my entire life in massive Indian cities with a population upward of a million, I am used to decent public transport. In comparison, Saskatoon, where the population crossed 300,000 last year, is an outlier.\n\nEven then, one of the first things I noticed after arriving this winter was the good transit layout and network here.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nWoman charged after altercation on city bus in Saskatoon's Confederation Park neighbourhood\nMandryk: Sask. Party has turned truth telling into an election issue\nPolice investigating two stabbings in Saskatoon in two days\nArticle content\n\nOf course, it\u2019s not all rosy. Otherwise, transit would have clocked way more than 4.89 million \u201celectronic\u201d rides in 2022, the last year for which the annual report has been published.\n\nI live in Stonebridge, and the best bus to take me downtown, for instance, is number 83. Never mind the weather outside, it\u2019s a glide once you are in \u2014 40 minutes and you are ready to disembark.\u00a0If you get the bus, that is.\n\nIt arrives every half an hour, which is fine. But it does not run after 6.30 p.m., which is not fine. And not on weekends, which is anything but fine.\n\nTake this Saturday. I had to go downtown for a volunteer shift. You guessed it \u2014 there was no 83. The option? Walk 25 minutes or so, get a different bus, and then a second one.\n\nTruth be told, it was a nice walk; the weather was great. But what about days with bad weather? Besides, how many others will make the effort, if they have a vehicle?\n\nAt the end of the day, it is a municipality\u2019s responsibility that more people take public transport. Especially in a country that takes \u2014 justifiable \u2014 pride in working on sustainability.\n\n\u201cThe government is taking action to help Canadians \u2026 adapt to the effects of climate change, and make life more affordable on the track to net-zero. We\u2019re building a Canada-wide network of charging stations \u2026 and investing in public transit, rail and ferries \u2026\u201d\n\nAfternoon Headlines\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThat\u2019s from the federal budget, announced last month.\n\nAlthough the budget has proposed a push for zero-emission electric vehicles and has \u201ccommitted more than $1 billion to build charging stations,\u201d it\u2019s going to take time. The government\u2019s own national target of 100 per cent zero-emission vehicles is 2035.\n\nAs population and demand increase in the intervening years, the world is bound to get foggier \u2014 I should know; I come from Delhi, where the sky is clouded by haze half the year.\n\nSo, yes, making the bus on Route 83 more frequent will keep the smog at bay for a tiny second more by offering people an option other than driving.\n\nOne argument often bandied around is Saskatoon\u2019s relatively small population and its harsh winter conditions. It\u2019s argued the money spent is just not worth the effort.\n\nMy concerns aside, as one of the fastest-growing Canadian cities, Saskatoon needs better transit for sure. Last year, the city added nearly 14,000 new residents, a large portion of that immigrants.\n\nBesides catering to internal migration from other provinces as housing costs head northward elsewhere, Saskatoon is also a university town, and will always have an influx of students \u2014 from within the province and outside, including international students.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nFrom all accounts, those annual numbers are unlikely to dive back to four figures in the near future. Most of them will be forced to get cars eventually, which will evidently lead to relatively more choked roads. Is the city road network and infrastructure ready to handle a few thousand vehicles more each year?\n\nOr \u2014 and I look back again at my India experience \u2014 are we looking at gridlocks, sooner rather than later?\n\nWhich brings us to the point about harsh winters. A valid point. But if European cities can do it, so can we. All we need are bus shelters \u2014 and lots of them \u2014 and increased frequency. The two main reasons that deter more people from using transit.\n\nShantanu Datta is a freelance writer and editor based in Saskatoon who previously worked with The Indian Express publications in New Delhi.\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nPhil Tank: Saskatoon city council opts to save $1.5M a year ... maybe\nPhil Tank: Debate on Saskatoon cycling safety undergoes radical shift\n\nShare your views\n\nThe StarPhoenix welcomes opinion articles. {"url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-evening-update-liberals-unveil-foreign-interference-registry/", "title": "Evening Update: Liberals unveil foreign interference registry - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nEvening Update: Liberals unveil foreign interference registry\nPUBLISHED MAY 6, 2024\n1 COMMENTS\nSHARE\nBOOKMARK\nLISTEN TO THIS ARTICLE\n\nGood evening, let\u2019s start with today\u2019s top stories:\n\nFederal legislation aimed at combatting foreign interference in Canada includes a new a registry of foreign agents and proposes giving Canada\u2019s spy agency more authority to combat threats.\n\nLong-awaited legislation unveiled by the Liberal government today would create a Foreign Influence Transparency Commissioner, who would be appointed after consultation with House of Commons and Senate leadership.\n\nThe individual would hold investigative powers and oversee a new mandatory registry of names for people conducting \u201cinfluence activity\u201d for foreign entities in provincial and federal politics and governments, as well as in Indigenous governments or councils.\n\nThe Countering Foreign Interference Act follows a federal inquiry into the issue that found foreign interference may have impeded the last two federal elections in Canada, though it didn\u2019t change the overall outcome. Commissioner Marie-Jos\u00e9e Hogue in a report last week called in foreign meddling a threat to Canadian democracy, and called for measures to tackle it.\n\nIt\u2019s unlikely the foreign registry announced Monday will be in place for the next federal election in 2025, the government said.\n\nIsrael rejects ceasefire proposal accepted by Hamas as Rafah invasion looms\n\nIsrael appeared poised to launch a long-threatened invasion of Rafah in southern Gaza, against the urging of humanitarian aid groups and allies, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu\u2019s government rejected the terms of a ceasefire accepted by the Hamas leadership.\n\nVideos and photos show long lines of Palestinians departing the city that had previous been declared a safe zone after the Israeli military used text messages and leaflets to warn residents in eastern Rafah to leave the area.\n\nHours after Israel sent the evacuation warning, Ismail Haniyeh, the Qatar-based political leader of Hamas, said he had accepted a ceasefire brokered by Egypt and Qatar. Any deal would involve the release of some of the 100 hostages Hamas has been holding in Gaza since Oct. 7. Netanyahu\u2019s office said it would carry out the military operation in Rafah in parallel with negotiations.\n\nHumanitarian groups have reacted with alarm to the evacuation order. Meanwhile, families some of the Israeli hostages are calling on their government to explain why the ceasefire negotiations fell apart.\n\nOpen this photo in gallery:\n\nDisplaced Palestinians who fled Rafah after the Israeli military began evacuating civilians from the eastern parts of the southern Gazan city travel on a vehicle in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip on May 6, 2024.\nRAMADAN ABED/REUTERS\n\nManitoba man admits to killing four women, defence to argue he is not criminally responsible\n\nThe Winnipeg trial of a man accused of killing four First Nations women and dumping their bodies in a landfill will hinge on his mental state and the intention behind the killings.\n\nJeremy Skibicki\u2019s lawyers told a Manitoba superior court today that their client killed the women in 2022, and they intend to argue he was not criminally responsible because of mental illness. The defence\u2019s legal strategy means the trial will be heard in front of a judge alone, rather than a jury, when arguments get under way on Wednesday. The 12-person jury selected to hear the case will be dismissed.\n\nPolice have alleged that Skibicki is a serial killer who murdered 26-year-old Marcedes Myran, 39-year-old Morgan Harris, 24-year-old Rebecca Contois, and an unidentified woman whom Indigenous elders have named Mashkode Bizhiki\u2019ikwe, or Buffalo Woman. Skibicki was arrested in 2022 for the killings.\n\nThe development in the high-profile case comes a day after Red Dress Day, marked annually to bring awareness to the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nFines mounting for violations in Canada\u2019s temporary foreign worker programs\n\nThe federal government set a record high for fines related to non-compliance with Canada\u2019s temporary foreign worker rules in 2023 \u2013 and this year is shaping up to be even worse, according to a Globe analysis of government figures.\n\nInfractions include wage theft and workplace abuse. Ottawa handed out $2.7-million in penalties against non-compliant employers last year, with an average fine of $13,800 per decision.\n\nSo far in 2024, the average fine is nearly $29,000, according to data reviewed by The Globe as of late April. That\u2019s significantly higher than the roughly $3,200 average fine from 2019.\n\nCanadian companies have been hiring temporary foreign workers in greater numbers in recent years, aided by policy changes aimed at addressing labour shortages. But the trend has sparked concerns about the potential for worker exploitation.\n\nALSO ON OUR RADAR\n\nCampus protests: Columbia University is cancelling its main graduation ceremony after weeks of protests over the war in Gaza. The Ivy League school, one of several postsecondary campuses across Canada and the United States where pro-Palestinian protests have popped up, says it will hold smaller, school-based graduation events. Meanwhile, Ontario\u2019s premier says universities should start clearing protest encampments.\n\nGovernment procurement: Ottawa went years without launching after-the-fact audits of companies that received contracts from an Indigenous procurement program.\n\nMining: Panama elected a pro-business president over the weekend and the outcome is raising hopes for Canadian mining company First Quantum. The company\u2019s financial situation has deteriorated after its Cobre Panama copper mine \u2013 which used to account for half its revenue \u2013 was ordered closed by the country\u2019s departing president last year.\n\nFish farms: Canada\u2019s Public Sector Integrity Commissioner is launching an investigation into allegations that federal fisheries officials tried to silence scientists who were researching environmental threats related to open-net fish farms in the Pacific Ocean.\n\nKeffiyeh ban: The Speaker of the Ontario legislature has partially eased a ban on the keffiyeh, allowing it to be worn inside Queen\u2019s Park, but not in the legislative chamber. The Speaker banned the checkered scarf this year, arguing it is being worn to make a political statement about the Israel-Gaza war. Independent member Sarah Jama was asked to leave Question Period today after putting on the scarf inside the chamber.\n\nMARKET WATCH\n\nNorth American stock markets rise on renewed U.S. rate cut bets\n\nMarkets in Canada and the U.S. closed higher on Monday on fresh hopes of a potential U.S. rate cut.\n\nCanada\u2019s main stock index closed its highest in over three weeks, boosted by energy stocks and renewed bets from investors on U.S. rate cuts some time this year.\n\nU.S. stock indexes also ended higher on their third straight session of advances, though they underperformed the S&P/TSX composite index, which closed up 312.06 points, or 1.42 per cent, at 22,259.47.\n\nThe Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 176.59 points or 0.46 per cent to 38,852.27, the S&P 500 gained 52.95 points or 1.03 per cent to 5,180.74 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 192.92 points or 1.19 per cent to 16,349.25.\n\nThe Canadian dollar was trading at 73.18 US cents.\n\nGot a news tip that you\u2019d like us to look into? Reach out via SecureDrop.\n\nTALKING POINTS\n\nIn the beef between Drake and Kendrick Lamar, no one\u2019s a winner\n\n\u201cThis beef is no longer about who\u2019s at the top of the rap game. It\u2019s about who can race to the bottom fastest.\u201d - Adrian Lee\n\nOntario\u2019s keffiyeh ban dares to define the scarf\u2019s meaning for everyone\n\n\u201cAsking a Palestinian to remove the keffiyeh is like asking a Muslim woman to remove her hijab or an Indigenous person to remove their headdress. It is an article of clothing deeply embedded with one\u2019s culture and identity.\u201d - Sheema Khan\n\nPutting migrants in federal prisons is unjustified and unjust\n\n\u201cRather than using more humane (and less expensive) alternatives to detention that allow for people to live in the community, the CBSA opted to detain thousands of migrants, even though every year, the agency monitors thousands of people in the community, and it is rare that any of them abscond.\u201d - Lloyd Axworthy and Allan Rock\n\nIn Canada, we bank where we buy\n\n\u201cParticipating in slick marketing programs that allow you to engage in lite banking activity seems contradictory and foolish. It\u2019s a little bit silly, just like Canadian Tire money was.\u201d - Vass Bednar\n\nUkraine\u2019s push to conscript men abroad won\u2019t do much to win the war\n\n\u201cUkrainians living abroad who are opposed to fighting are unlikely to be lured back, in particular those who were already in other countries before the war started and children who are coming of age abroad. Instead, many may choose to cut ties with Ukraine entirely.\u201d - Lidiia Karpenko\n\nLIVING BETTER\n\nNeed more fibre? Add these six high-fibre foods to your diet\n\nOpen this photo in gallery:\n\nThere are two types of fibre: soluble and insoluble. Both are present in varying proportions in different foods, but some foods can be rich in one or the other.\nTED JOHNS/GETTY IMAGES/ISTOCKPHOTO\n\nFibre is an oft overlooked nutrient that comes with a whole host of health benefits. A diet high in fibre is associated with a lower risk of heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, colorectal cancer, breast cancer and diverticulitis. Research suggests that eating fibre-rich food can help you live a longer life in good health. Read more here on how to up the fibre in your daily meals.\n\nTODAY\u2019S LONG READ\n\nAt war with the censors\n\nOpen this photo in gallery:\n\nLate at night on Sept. 3, 1939, crowds of Torontonians waited outside the Globe and Mail building to read the latest news about Britain\u2019s declaration of war on Nazi Germany. Canada followed suit a week later, with a war proclamation from Ottawa that appeared in the Sept. 11 Globe.\nTHE GLOBE AND MAIL\n\nIn the Second World War, the first global war of a truly mass-media era, The Globe and Mail took some of the first steps in defying the federal government\u2019s censorship machinery. The Globe\u2019s publisher at the time, George McCullagh, even risked a prison sentence in the paper\u2019s fight for the right to report on military blunders. {"url": "http://thestarphoenix.com/opinion/letters/letter-of-the-day-saskatchewan-highway-of-tears", "title": "StarPhoenix Letter of the Day: Saskatchewan Highway of Tears? June 20 | The Star Phoenix", "body": "Skip to Content\nLIMITED-TIME SALE! Unlimited access for only $3 for 3 months. Act Now>>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\n2024 Saskatchewan wildfires\nSend a Letter to the Editor\nSports\nOpinion\nBusiness\nArts\nLife\nShopping\nNewsletters\nBridges\nPuzzmo\nDriving\nePaper\nRemembering\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nLetters\nLetter of the Day: Saskatchewan Highway of Tears?\nAuthor of the article:\nReader Letters\nPublished Jun 20, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Jun 20, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 1 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nArticle content\n\nSaskatchewan Highway of Tears?\n\nWhen Lionel Peyachew\u2019s memorial to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in this province was unveiled outside the Saskatoon Police Service building, Justice Minister Gordon Wyant suggested he understood the terrible cost to families when someone goes missing or is found murdered. Yet despite the heightened vulnerability of indigenous females to often lethal violence when safe public transportation is not available, Wyant and his cabinet peers have failed to learn the painful lessons taught out in British Columbia along a stretch of northern road known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nFive concert events to see in Saskatoon in July\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'Significant, widespread' rain drenched Sask. farms: crop report\nVictim impact statements expected at Gregory Fertuck sentencing hearing\nArticle content\n\nThe lack of bus service along its nearly 800 kilometres has meant that hitchhiking is sometimes the only way for those who live along it to get around. At least 18 females, mostly indigenous, have gone missing or turned up dead along the highway since 1970. Still, it took nearly 10 long years of activism by indigenous people and allies to get the B.C. and federal governments to work together to institute bus service.\n\nB.C. Liberal Aboriginal Affairs and Reconciliation Minister John Rustad announced that 30 kilometres of the highway would have service six days a week starting Jan. 30, 2017. He added that work is underway to set up more comprehensive service before summer\u2019s end.\n\nWhen STC is shut down at month\u2019s end, how long will it be before this province has its own Highway of Tears? How many will have to go missing or be found dead before the Wall government learns what its B.C. counterpart finally did?\n\nSusan Gingell\n\nSaskatoon\n\nSHARE YOUR VIEWS\n\nThe StarPhoenix welcomes letters, which are limited to 250 words and must include the writer\u2019s name, street address and phone number.\n\nSubmissions will be verified and edited before publication.\nWe publish the names and community of all letter writers.\nDo not send email attachments.\nWriting more than one letter a month is discouraged and \u201copen\u201d letters are not accepted.\n\nSend to: 204 Fifth Ave. N., Saskatoon, Sask., S7K 2P1\n\nFax: 306-657-6437\n\nEmail: letters@thestarphoenix.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nThree arrested after drug trafficking investigation in Saskatoon\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nLawyer for trucker who caused deadly Broncos crash says families have no right to sue\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nSeniors Are Getting Free Hearing Tests (Here's how)\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians In Alberta With No Life Insurance Are Taking Advantage Of This\nCovered For Life\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nOne Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before, You Will Fit In Your Pants Again!\nBurn Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\n\nPostmedia is committed to maintaining a lively but civil forum for discussion. {"url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-globe-climate-can-floating-nuclear-power-plants-serve-remote-northern/", "title": "Globe Climate: Can floating nuclear power plants serve remote Northern communities? - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nGLOBE CLIMATE NEWSLETTER\nGlobe Climate: Can floating nuclear power plants serve remote Northern communities?\nSIERRA BEIN\nPUBLISHED MAY 6, 2024\nCOMMENTS\nSHARE\nBOOKMARK\nLISTEN TO THIS ARTICLE\n\nIf you\u2019re reading this on the web or someone forwarded this e-mail newsletter to you, you can sign up for Globe Climate and all Globe newsletters here.\n\nGood afternoon, and welcome to Globe Climate, a newsletter about climate change, environment and resources in Canada.\n\nThe Ehattesaht First Nation was immersed in the drama surrounding a trapped, orphan killer whale calf. But for Ashley John, travelling to the lagoon to meet the whale named Kwiisahi?is wove together her need to help the lost young animal with her grief for her lost sister, Kayla.\n\nThe Ehattesaht are part of the Nuu-chah-nulth tribe, which is guided by the principle of hishuk ish tsawalk, or \u201ceverything is one.\u201d Feeling a spiritual connection with all living things is at the core of their culture. Deep meaning is felt in the timing of Kwiisahi?is\u2019s departure with the anniversary of Kayla\u2019s death.\n\n\u201cI had this incredible feeling of her being free, and Kwiisahi?is being free as well,\u201d Ms. John said. \u201cMy heart is happy.\u201d\n\nYesterday, the community gathered for a march as part of Red Dress Day, which honours the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nNow, let\u2019s catch you up on other news.\n\nOpen this photo in gallery:\n\nAshley John, left, an elected council member of the Ehattesaht First Nation band council, and community member Auntie Victoria Wells hold seal meat for the young orca whale that was stuck in a lagoon near the village of Zeballos, B.C.\nASHLEY JOHN/ASHLEY JOHN\n\nNoteworthy reporting this week:\nPlastic treaty: Plastic production cap remains contentious as treaty talks open door for agreement\nTMX pipeline: After years of delays and cost overruns, the $34-billion Trans Mountain pipeline expansion project finally opens\nPower projects: Carbon capture plan faces doubts after Capital Power cancels $2.4-billion project\nEmissions: Greenhouse-gas emissions falling, but oil-sands emissions continue to climb, federal report says\nFirefighting: Wildland firefighters call for change on frontlines of forest fire fight as season ramps up\nAnalysis: Endless freeze of federal clean-tech agency is crushing Canadian startups\nElectricity: EVs aren\u2019t burdening Canada\u2019s electricity grids \u2013 yet\nGreen investing: Imperial Oil shareholders reject proposal to disclose effects of energy transition\nThe Narwhal explains: B.C.\u2019s second-largest LNG project is one you\u2019ve probably never heard of\nA deeper dive\nCan floating nuclear power plants help solve Northern Canada\u2019s energy woes?\n\nThe nuclear industry is seeking to establish a beachhead in Canada\u2019s North with a proposed floating nuclear power plant to serve remote Indigenous communities.\n\nDiesel is the only way to keep the lights on in many remote Arctic towns. Diesel-fired plants can respond rapidly to shifting demand and have also proved dependable in harsh environments.\n\nBut diesel is unpopular because of its high emissions and the challenges with shipping it to far-flung places. The plants emit sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter \u2013 impairing local air quality \u2013 along with greenhouse gases. Leaks and accidental spills occur frequently.\n\nThis nuclear project wants to offer a greener option \u2013 but first it has to assuage safety and cost concerns and compete with renewables.\n\nWestinghouse, a U.S.-based reactor vendor, has partnered with Prodigy Clean Energy, a Montreal-based company, to develop a transportable nuclear power plant. They market it as a solution for delivering small modular reactors (SMRs) for coastal applications. Prodigy\u2019s plant promises to address many of diesel\u2019s shortcomings \u2013 emissions, in particular \u2013 while replicating its desirable features.\n\nIn March, Prodigy announced it had reached an agreement with Des N\u00ebdh\u00e9 Group, a development corporation of the English River First Nation in northern Saskatchewan. Des N\u00ebdh\u00e9's task will be to engage with First Nations, Inuit and M\u00e9tis across Canada on potential installations.\n\nBut even as Prodigy moves ahead, many questions remain.\n\nFor example, SMRs are often marketed as producers of clean energy, but this overlooks their radioactive wastes: Being saddled with a floating radiological hazard on its shoreline could be a worst-case scenario for a Northern community. If radioactive waste did become stranded in the North, or a serious accident occurred, who would be responsible?\n\nAlso, there are still no cost estimates available. How would a community afford one of the most expensive options for generating power? How would they manage security of the plant? How far can renewables even can go in replacing diesel?\n\nAs the two nuclear partners race to commercialize their transportable nuclear plant, a few Northern communities are already using renewables such as wind and solar to reduce diesel consumption. Will floating nuclear power plants be ready in time, or is it just a nuclear energy fairy tale?\n\nOpen this photo in gallery:\n\nAn illustration of a Transportable Nuclear Power Plant deployed in a protected harbour in an Arctic setting. Credit: Prodigy Clean Energy.\nSUPPLIED\n\nWhat else you missed\nG7 offers leeway to Germany, Japan in deal to quit coal by 2035\nEnvironmental groups criticize Ottawa walk-back on pollution impact assessment\nOver 500 baby sea turtles washed ashore in a big storm off South Africa. Great-West, the insurance provider, is also a subsidiary of Power Corp., the holding company of Montreal\u2019s Desmarais family.\n\nUnder the deal, Great-West will commit to investing in Power Sustainable\u2019s funds in the coming years, the companies said in a statement. Power Corp. will remain the majority owner of the sustainable-investing enterprise, which is led by Olivier Desmarais, its chairman and chief executive officer.\n\nAdvisory Glass Lewis recommends Shell investors oppose shareholder climate resolution at AGM\nWarren Buffett\u2019s PacifiCorp utility singed by wildfires\nMaking waves\n\nDo you know an engaged individual? {"url": "https://www.merrittherald.com/lnib-to-host-red-dress-awareness-walk/", "title": "LNIB to host Red Dress awareness walk - Merritt Herald", "body": "NEWS\nSPORTS\nCOMMUNITY\nJUNIOR REPORTERS\nOPINION\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nLNIB to host Red Dress awareness walk\n\nPosted by Izaiah Reyes | May 4, 2022 | News, Community, Aboriginal, Events, Trending | 0 \n\nPhoto/ Izaiah Reyes\n\nOn Thursday, May 5, the Lower Nicola Indian Band will be hosting a walk in honor of the MMIWG2S National Awareness Day.\n\nThe walk will take place from Shulus Hall to Shulus Arbor and will be in honor of the murdered and missing Indigenous women, girls, and two spirt. MMIWG2S has been an ongoing issue that the Indigenous community have been facing in Canada.\n\n\u201cWe want to show support and awareness for the MMIWG2S,\u201d said Carole Basil, organizer of the LNIB Red Dress Walk.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s been numerous MMIWG2S in our community and it\u2019s very heartbreaking.\u201d\n\nBasil shares how LNIB decided to organize a Red Dress walk.\n\n\u201cI became aware of the Red Dress movement around 2017,\u201d said Basil.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always wanted to show support and we were planning something for 2019 but COVID came so we weren\u2019t able to do anything.\u201d\n\nLNIB hosted a similar event back in March 15. This was the band\u2019s first organized Red Dress walk and dozens of people walked to Shulus Arbor dressed in red. Red is the color that symbolizes the MMIWG2S movement.\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t have a lot of time to plan it,\u201d Basil explained the March 15 walk.\n\n\u201cThere were still restrictions but we still had really good support and had about 65 people in attendance. \u201d\n\nThe band has invited other organizations to join in the walk, such as; Scwexmx Child and Family Services, NVIT, Merritt Secondary School, and Nlaka\u2019pamux Health Services.\n\nParticipants are set to meet up at Shulus Hall at 10:30 am on May 5. People are once again encouraged to wear red in honor of the movement.\n\n\u201cWe want to show support and awareness for the MMIWG2S,\u201d said Basil.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s been numerous MMIWG2S in our community and it\u2019s very heartbreaking.\u201d\n\nOnce the people have made it to the Arbor, There will be a program taking place which includes prayer, hand drumming, guest speakers, songs, and dance.\n\nFor more information please contact Carole Basil at (250) 315-9158.\n\nSHARE:\n\n \nPREVIOUS\nBC records all time high toxic drug deaths 18 months in a row\nNEXT\nMonic Charity hosts a book drive for Merritt Central Elementary\nNEWSLETTER\n\nFirst Name \n\nLast Name \n\nEmail address: \n\nCLASSIFIEDS\nMedical Office Assistant Position June 19, 2024\nSales Person/Office Admin May 15, 2024\nNVCL April 4, 2024\nRECENT OBITUARIES\nAlan Norman Clarence Taylor June 19, 2024\nFay Sturney June 19, 2024\nBeverly Jean Malchuk June 19, 2024\nSister Newspapers\nBowen Island Undercurrent\nBurnaby Now\nBusiness in Vancouver\nCastanet\nCoast Reporter\nDelta Optimist\nLethbridge Herald\nMedicine Hat News\nMoose Jaw Today\nNew West Record\nNorth Shore News\nPique Newsmagazine\nPowell River Peak\nPrince George Citizen\nREW.ca\nRichmond News\nSaskToday.ca\nSquamish Chief\nThe Orca\nTimes Colonist\nTriCity News\nVancouver is Awesome\nWestern Investor\nAirdrie Today\nAlberta Prime Times\nCochrane Today\nLakeland Today\nMountain View Today\nOkotoks Today\nRocky Mountain Outlook\nSt. Albert Gazette\nTown and Country Today\nOther Sections\nAbout Us\n\nAdvertise\n\nReal Estate\n\nClassifieds\n\nEvents\n\nMagazines\n\nSubscribe\n\nContact Us\n\nConnect\n\nMerritt Herald\n#201- 1951 Garcia Street,\nMerritt, BC V1K 1B8\n\nPhone\n1-250-378-4241\n\nAberdeen Publishing \u00a9 Copyright \u00ae\u00a02020.\u00a0\u00a0All rights reserved. {"url": "https://panow.com/2024/04/11/sask-advocates-hope-proposed-red-dress-alert-becomes-reality/", "title": "Sask. advocates hope proposed Red Dress Alert becomes reality | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\nSPORTS\nWEATHER\nNEWS\nOBITUARIES\nCLASSIFIEDS\nLIFESTYLE\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\nRed dresses, red ribbons, and various words to describe a woman in front of John Diefenbaker School. (Logan Lehmann/paNOW Staff)\nBy Derek Craddock\nMMIWG\nSask. advocates hope proposed Red Dress Alert becomes reality\nApr 11, 2024 | 5:00 PM\n\n\n\nIt could mean the difference between life and death for Indigenous women across Canada and advocates in Saskatchewan are praying it happens.\n\nLast week, a Manitoba MP called for the creation of an Alert System for missing Indigenous women known as the Red Dress Alerts. The system would follow the same model as the Amber Alerts which are sent out for children who are missing and deemed at risk.\n\n\u201cThis is a critical initiative,\u201d New Democrat MP Leah Gazan, who represents the riding of Winnipeg Centre, said last month as a House of Commons committee began studying her \u201cRed Dress Alert\u201d proposal.\n\n\u201cThis is an initiative that will save lives.\u201d\n\nGazan\u2019s fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. The motion also called for funding for a new alert system similar to those that exist for missing children and seniors.\n\nNow, MPs are discussing with experts and stakeholders about how to implement such a system across the country.\n\nIt\u2019s an initiative that\u2019s long overdue according to Lori Campbell, the Associate Vice-President of Indigenous Engagement at the University of Regina.\n\nThe member of Montreal Lake Cree Nation said Indigenous women have, historically and currently, been mistreated and undervalued across the country and hopes the discussions around the Red Dress Alert system to change that narrative.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve seen with the Amber Alerts that 80 per cent of the children that have gone out through the Amber Alert have been located,\u201d she said. \u201cThe longer it takes to get the information out there, the more challenging and unlikely it is that we\u2019ll be able to locate them and bring them home safely.\u201d\n\nA 2019 report from a national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls found deliberate rights violations at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to-date \u2014 particularly on the federal side.\n\nMichelle LeClair, the Vice-President of the Metis Nation Saskatchewan (MN-S) said governments have not been taking those Calls to Action seriously.\n\n\u201cI think the alert system is great, but it also adds to the conversation that needs to be had again and again and that\u2019s about the safety of our Indigenous women,\u201d she said. \u201cThe general citizen needs to be concerned about the number of women that go missing, the number of our women that are being murdered and we\u2019re not really addressing it in a meaningful way.\u201d\n\nBetween 2009 and 2021, the homicide rate among Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than for their non-Indigenous counterparts, Statistics Canada concluded in a report released last year.\n\nThat report also found that homicides involving Indigenous women and girls are less likely to result in the most serious murder charges than cases in which victims were non-Indigenous.\n\nAnother Saskatchewan advocate in favour of the Red Dress Alert system is Krista Fox from North Battleford.\n\n\u201cThis is something I have been pushing for for years,\u201d she said in a statement to paNOW. \u201cI am a huge MMIP (Missing and Murdered Indigenous Peoples) advocate and have voiced my concerns over an alert for some time.\u201d\n\nIn 2022, Fox walked across Canada to raise awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG).\n\nFox walked to draw attention to the crisis of all MMIW in Canada and to raise awareness of missing North Battleford woman Ashley Morin, who disappeared in July of 2018. RCMP believe Morin, a 31-year-old woman from Ahtahkakoop Cree Nation, was the victim of a homicide.\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state\u2019s \u201cMissing Indigenous Person\u201d system, which coexists with the existing Amber Alert and Silver Alert programs.\n\nIn Canada, there are alert systems for individual First Nations including the James Smith Cree Nation which launched its system earlier this year.\n\nThe new feature is on the Talking Stick app, which is an anonymous chat app developed by the company in partnership with the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations (FSIN).\n\nThe app is designed to allow First Nations leaders to issue emergency alerts about missing persons, public safety emergencies, or natural disasters.\n\nThe Union of Nova Scotia Mi\u2019kmaq has a similar system for its member First Nations while Aboriginal Alert, a website providing details on missing Indigenous peoples, has existed for some time. As of early March, the website has more than 340 Indigenous women, girls, boys and men reported missing, with a large number in the prairies.\n\n(Credit/Aboriginal Alert)\n\nWhile the Metis Nation does not have its own system, LeClair noted that once a citizen goes missing, information is quickly posted on social media and shared by thousands of people.\n\nWhile the news of the potential alert system is good for Campbell, she wants to make sure it is done correctly.\n\n\u201cGood intentions sometimes can cause unintentional harm and I think this is another instance where we also need to ensure that it\u2019s Indigenous-led so that Indigenous people feel confident in it and feel like it is a positive resource for them because we haven\u2019t had a lot of trust and historically there\u2019s reasons for that.\u201d\n\nLeClair added that the Red Dress Alert should follow the same criteria as the Amber Alert which is issued if a child is deemed to be in grave danger, something she said every Indigenous woman faces.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always in grave danger because of just being Indigenous and I\u2019m really hopeful that if we do have an alert system, that it\u2019s done in a meaningful, impactful way,\u201d she said.\n\nGazan\u2019s Red Dress Alert proposal is being examined by the House of Commons Status of Women committee, which has already heard testimony from several experts calling for the initiative to be Indigenous-led.\n\nSuch a model, they say, would mitigate the problem of police inaction, as well as bureaucratic red tape, to better ensure members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\n-With files from Angela Brown and The Canadian Press\n\nby Derek Craddock\nAround the Web\nAlberta Residents Born Before 1984 With No Life Insurance Can Get a $250,000\nDollarGuardian\nWrinkles Around the Mouth?
