{"url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-manitoba-to-develop-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous/", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nALESSIA PASSAFIUME\nOTTAWA\nTHE CANADIAN PRESS\nPUBLISHED MAY 3, 2024\nUPDATED MAY 6, 2024\nOpen this photo in gallery:\n\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an Indigenous-led alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced today in Winnipeg.\nSPENCER COLBY/THE CANADIAN PRESS\n\n1 COMMENTS\nSHARE\nBOOKMARK\nLISTEN TO THIS ARTICLE\n\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\u201cThis is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\u201d said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has lead federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\u201cAnd while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\u201d\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nIt will be funded through monies set aside in this year\u2019s federal and provincial budgets.\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba\u2019s Minister for Women and Gender Equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u201cWe look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\u201d\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2013 and Manitoba writ large \u2013 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not the only solution, but it\u2019s a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\u201d\n\nGazan\u2019s efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state\u2019s Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry\u2019s 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2013 at least for now.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s going to be bumps in the road \u2013 there\u2019s going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\u201d she said. \u201cInevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\u201d\n\nBut it\u2019s the starting point that matters, she said. \u201cI think it\u2019s high time.\u201d\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, Ms. North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \u201cfor so long,\u201d and the deaths \u201care a result of it.\u201d\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat\u2019s in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi\u2019kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September, 2020, Ms. Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2013 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\u201cBecause this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\u201d Ms. Jesty said.\n\n\u201cThere has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\u201d\n\nSign up for our redesigned Morning Update newsletter.\n\nStart your day with context and insight on the biggest stories shaping our lives, written by Danielle Groen\n\nREGISTER TO SIGN UP\nEXPLORE {"url": "https://www.coastreporter.net/highlights/sisters-in-spirit-vigil-returns-to-whistler-after-four-year-hiatus-to-mark-national-day-of-action-for-mmiwg2s-7615699", "title": "Sisters in Spirit vigil returns to Whistler after four-year hiatus to mark National Day of Action for MMIWG2S - Coast Reporter", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\n18.3 \u00b0C\nHOME HIGHLIGHTS\nSisters in Spirit vigil returns to Whistler after four-year hiatus to mark National Day of Action for MMIWG2S\nLinda Epp presents two days of programming on Oct. 4 and 5 to acknowledge challenges Indigenous women face and highlight their achievements\n\tMegan Lalonde\n\nOct 2, 2023 7:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nSisters in Spirit organizer Linda Epp (left) stands alongside Lorna K. Leo at the Squamish Lil'wat Cultural Centre following the Sisters in Spirit Vigil in October 2018. File photo by Joel Barde\nListen to this article\n00:04:58\n\nLinda Epp hasn\u2019t lived in Whistler since 2021.\n\nThat trivial fact isn\u2019t stopping the activist from bringing the Sisters in Spirit Vigil back to the resort for the first time since before the COVID-19 pandemic. Epp founded the powerful event in 2015 to honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirited (MMIWG2S). That was one year before the federal government launched a national inquiry, formally acknowledging the dark reality First Nations communities had been calling attention to for decades: Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA people are murdered, abused, and disappear at shockingly high rates.\n\n\u201cThis is still happening,\u201d Epp said, even if \u201cthe world is now more aware of what Indigenous people in Canada have gone through.\u201d\n\nEpp is a member of the sh\u00edsh\u00e1lh (Sechelt) Nation, but was raised by a Canadian-German Mennonite family after she and her twin sister were separated from their birth parents during the Sixties Scoop. She landed in Whistler in 1997, where she stayed until the housing crisis and work opportunities prompted her return to Vancouver two-and-a-half years ago.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just so attached to [Whistler\u2019s] community and the people\u2014the Lil\u2019wat and Squamish people, but the community members as well, and the allies,\u201d she said. \u201cI say Vancouver is my home city, but Whistler is my hometown \u2026 I\u2019ve done a lot of hard work in the past there, and I think I can still continue to do so. Even if I\u2019m in Vancouver, I think there\u2019s still powerful work to do in the Sea to Sky corridor.\u201d\n\nAs usual, Sisters in Spirit invites participants together on Oct. 4\u2014the National Day of Action for MMIWG2S\u2014to hear from individuals and families impacted by this epidemic, share in their heartache, and advocate for change.\n\nThis year, however, marks the first time Epp is expanding the event to take place over two days.\n\nThe Sisters in Spirit Vigil walk begins at 11 a.m. on Wednesday. All are invited to meet at the Welcome Totem Pole, in Whistler Village Common by Mongolie Grill and Shoppers Drug Mart, before journeying together down the Village Stroll. (Unless weather fails to cooperate, that is, in which case an indoor gathering at the Maury Young Arts Centre will replace the walk.)\n\nIt\u2019s a heavy topic, Epp acknowledged\u2014one she\u2019s tried to lighten in previous years by concluding the walk with uplifting singing and drumming. \u201cThis year, I want to do something even better,\u201d she said.\n\nSpecifically, Epp wanted to wrap up the sombre National Day of Action by shining light on Indigenous success. So, she reached out to some friends to join her.\n\nSisters in Spirit will continue Wednesday evening with a presentation and Q&A with Lorimer Shenher at the Maury Young Arts Centre from 7 to 8 p.m.\n\nThe author, speaker, and advocate was the first Vancouver Police Department detective assigned to investigate missing and murdered Indigenous women in Vancouver. He detailed his role in that investigation in That Lonely Section of Hell, an acclaimed memoir that also recounts his years-long struggle with post-traumatic stress disorder resulting from his work on the case.\n\nWednesday\u2019s event continues with a Spirits Rising Drumming Session at 8:30 p.m., led by Epp alongside Bill Helin, the Tsimshian/Norwegian artist, author and children\u2019s educator who has visited classrooms to share his ancestors\u2019 teachings through story drumming since 1990. Their goal is \u201cto elevate the women to come out of the ground and fly high among the Eagles, and have the ancestors welcome them,\u201d Epp said.\n\nWith that in mind, the aptly-named Spirits Rising Fashion Show will follow on Thursday evening, Oct. 5. Locals and visitors are invited back to the Maury Young Arts Centre to celebrate the creativity of Himikalas Pamela Baker, a fashion designer who grew up on the Capilano Indian \u201cXwemelch\u2019stn\u201d reserve in West Vancouver and is known to take inspiration from her Squamish, Kwakiutl, Tlingit and Haida ancestry. Ten Indigenous models will take to the runway wearing 30 of Baker\u2019s breathtakingly-intricate contemporary Indigenous textile designs.\n\nDoors open at 6:30 p.m. before the show kicks off at 7 p.m. The event will conclude with a post-show reception and Q&A with the designer.\n\nIn the lead-up to next week\u2019s event, Epp travelled up the Sea to Sky highway to continue her tradition of hanging red dresses in a growing number of local businesses.\n\nA striking symbol of MMIWG2S, the dresses \u201cprovoke discussion,\u201d said Epp, \u201cand not just with the locals, but the people that are coming into the community and that are tourists. Because in the beginning, in reality, it was considered political.\u201d\n\nEntry to Wednesday evening\u2019s programming costs $5 per person, while tickets to Thursday\u2019s Spirits Rising Fashion Show are on sale for $10 each. Tickets are available for purchase at the Maury Young Arts Centre. Doors open at 6:30 p.m. on both Oct. 4 and 5. Wednesday morning\u2019s walk is free to attend.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has been shared 2 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on MMIWG2S+ has been an ongoing issue that the Indigenous community have been facing in Canada.\n\n\u201cWe reached out to community members in the Nicola Valley, especially the ones that have lost somebody,\u201d said Carole Basil, organizer of the LNIB Red Dress Walk. \u201cI know our band has gone through that in the past few years and it seems to come up in Merritt a little more often now.\u201d\n\nBasil added that the walk is very important not only to those who know a missing or murdered Indigenous woman or girl, but for the community as a whole.\n\n\u201cI know it\u2019s very traumatizing to the family and the community and we just want to let the people that are impacted know that we care and we remember,\u201d she added,\n\nShe reflects that people can continue to honour the memories of those who went missing or murdered on other occasions as well.\n\n\u201cEspecially on the anniversary of their disappearance or, you know, the anniversary of their murder,\u201d\n\nThose who wish to participate are set to meet up at Shulus Hall at 10:30 a.m. on Tuesday, May 7. Participants are encouraged to wear red in honour of the movement.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a 20-minute walk from Shulus Hall to the Arbor,\u201d she added. \u201cWe sing a few songs, if anybody wants to say anything we don\u2019t get really in depth because we don\u2019t want to really trigger anybody.\u201d\n\nBasil hopes the event will bring the Lower Nicola Indian Band community together and neighbouring communities as well.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s so many people that are impacted with even just one person going missing, like the family, the community, their friends,\u201d Basil said. \u201cThis walk is for anybody. {"url": "https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/legislature-to-be-lit-up-thursday-to-mark-red-dress-day-1.5889659", "title": "'I don't want to be forgotten': Students march Thursday to mark Red Dress Day | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nWINNIPEG\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nWINNIPEG\nNews\n'I don't want to be forgotten': Students march Thursday to mark Red Dress Day\nA group of students in Winnipeg marked the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls by marching on May 5, 2022. (Source: Jamie Dowsett/ CTV News Winnipeg)\nKatherine Dow\nCTV News Winnipeg\nKatherine Dow\nCTV News Anchor/Editorial Producer\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2022 4:21 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2022 7:06 a.m. MDT\nShare\nWINNIPEG -\n\n Symbolic red dresses have been put up around the city to shine a light on the disproportionate violence that Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people face.\n\nThursday marks the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, also known as Red Dress Day.\n\nA group of students in Winnipeg marked the day by marching to ensure people don't forget what is happening to Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people.\n\n\"It seems like my people just seem to be forgotten. I don't want to be forgotten,\" said Honey Flett, a Grade 10 student who was in the march.\n\n\"This was really overwhelming to see how many people decided to participate. I never expected so many.\"\n\nTara Tuchscherer, a teacher at St. James Collegiate, told CTV News the march is part of an entire week at the school meant to bring awareness to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and raise funds for Drag the Red.\n\n\"A lot of people are unaware of the number of girls and women that are missing,\" Tuchscherer said. \"We don't know what happened to them and their families are having to take it upon themselves to look for them and they need closure.\"\n\nThe province, which is set to project a red dress on the Manitoba Legislative Building Thursday night, said it is an occasion to remember those tragically taken by gender-based violence and to honour the ongoing healing of survivors, their families and communities who have lost loved ones.\n\nTo mark the occasion, people are encouraged to wear red or hang red dresses and ribbons as a visual reminder of the lives lost and to raise awareness about the ongoing fight against gender-based violence.\n\nThe Stefanson government noted in a news release its 2021 commitment to address violence against Indigenous women and girls by introducing amendments to the Path to Reconciliation Act, which established calls for justice from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cAddressing violence, in particular the incidences of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, is a priority for the province and it is our government's intent to continue to take action to prevent and combat gender-based violence of all forms,\u201d the province said in a news release.\n\nCITY TO HANG RED DRESSES, HOLD CEREMONIAL FIRE\n\nMeanwhile, the City of Winnipeg said it will mark the occasion with red dress displays at all Winnipeg Public Libraries until May 16.\n\nAdditionally, the city said it will host a ceremonial fire at Winnipeg City Hall from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m.\n\n\u201cWe would like to acknowledge the tireless heart-work of the MMIWG2S+ Advisory Committee, and Implementation Team for their guidance as we find our way to walk together to stop and prevent violence to Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+,\u201d the city wrote on its website.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nA group of students in Winnipeg marked the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls by marching on May 5, 2022. {"url": "https://www.stratfordbeaconherald.com/news/local-news/stratford-sisters-in-spirit-vigil-set-for-oct-4", "title": "Stratford Sisters in Spirit vigil set for Oct. 4 | The Stratford Beacon Herald", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nLocal News\nStratford Sisters in Spirit vigil set for Oct. 4\n\nMembers of the Native Women's Association of Canada are hosting Sisters in Spirit events all day Oct. 4 in Stratford, ending with a vigil in Market Square.\n\nAuthor of the article:\nGalen Simmons\nPublished Sep 26, 2019 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Sep 30, 2019 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nIn support of the Sisters in Spirit vigil in Stratford's Market Square Thursday evening, many downtown businesses displayed red dresses in their front windows, honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada. The displays were inspired by the REDress Project by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black. (Galen Simmons/The Beacon Herald)\nArticle content\n\nIndigenous community members are calling on Stratford and area residents to stand in solidarity with them next Friday in Market Square as part of the national Sisters in Spirit movement honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThroughout the day on Oct. 4, local supporters of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada will host a series of events, beginning with the lighting of a sacred fire at 7:30 a.m. and ending with a Sisters in Spirit vigil at 7 p.m.\n\nThis year\u2019s vigil will feature two speakers, Patsy Day and chef Winona Sands.\n\nDay, a teacher and member of the Turtle Clan, Oneida Nation, will discuss her full-circle journey to reconnect with \u2013 and share \u2013 her language and culture as an adult after she was orphaned at age six through the government assimilation policies of the Indian Act.\n\nSands, part of the Bkejwanong Band on the Walpole Island First Nations Reserve on Lake Erie, will discuss her work as an addictions counsellor, social worker, support worker for First Nations women and children, and as a women\u2019s advocate before she finally signed on as community chef at the Local Community Food Centre in Stratford.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWith missing and murdered women, for me it\u2019s not just about the women, it\u2019s about all native people in general because men are missing their culture, women are missing their culture,\u201d Sands said. \u201cI myself, being part of the \u201d60s Scoop,\u2019 am also missing who I am, and my culture and language.\n\n\u201c\u2026 I don\u2019t know who I am. It\u2019s been 50 years in the making of who I am and I want to know exactly who I am, and my culture \u2013 something I can hand down to my grandchildren \u2013 and make people aware of what has really happened\u2026 and is still happening.\u201d\n\nAt the vigil, Sands said volunteers will be handing out squares of moose hide to men and boys who are willing to stand up against violence toward women and children as part of the national Moose Hide Campaign. For more information on the campaign, visit www.moosehidecampaign.ca.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn addition to the vigil, more than 25 local businesses and organizations will display red dresses throughout the day to raise awareness of missing and murdered Indigenous women, an act inspired by the REDress Project by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s just so visual and symbolic,\u201d said Pamela Coneybeare, owner of La Osa Jewelry and Vintage, one of the participating businesses. \u201cI think it has a lot of impact that way. \u2026 It\u2019s a very powerful image when you see something like that. \u2026 It symbolizes women, it symbolizes death, it\u2019s just a very powerful image.\u201d\n\nInformation cards on each of the red dresses displayed will invite the public to attend the vigil. The cards will also feature an image of Stratford artist and residential school survivor Maxine Noel\u2019s painting, Not Forgotten. Noel has been donating all the royalties earned from sales of the painting to the Sisters in Spirit Campaign.\n\nAccording to the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, Indigenous women and girls in Canada \u2013 whether living on reserve or in an urban area, and regardless of age or socio-economic status \u2013 are at least three times more likely to experience violence, and at least six times more likely to be murdered than any other woman or girl in the country.\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has worked for more than four decades to document systemic violence impacting Indigenous women, girls, their families, and communities.\n\ngsimmons@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR STRATFORD\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

{"url": "https://nowtoronto.com/culture/books/best-fall-books-2019/", "title": "17 must-read books for fall 2019 - NOW Toronto", "body": "ADVERTISEMENT\n\nNow\nNEWS\nCULTURE\nREVIEWS\nREAL ESTATE\nLIFESTYLE\nEVENTS\nSearch\nOpen Menu\nClose Menu\nNEWS\nCULTURE\nREVIEWS\nREAL ESTATE\nLIFESTYLE\nEVENTS\nABOUT\nMASTHEAD\nEDITORIAL MANDATE\nJOBS\nADVERTISE\nCONTESTS\nCONTACT\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYoutube\nTiktok\nBOOKS\nCULTURE\n17 must-read books for fall 2019\n\nSEPTEMBER 3, 2019SUSAN G. COLE\n\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nCopy current article link\n\nThe heavy hitters \u2013 writing both fiction and non-fiction \u2013 are coming out this season with works that take on climate change, sexual assault, slavery and an array of other themes that cannot be ignored. Here\u2019s a look at what to read in the coming months.\n\nTHE TESTAMENTS by Margaret Atwood (McClelland & Stewart)\n\nAll right, the novel probably doesn\u2019t need the plug, but The Testaments is far and away the most highly anticipated book of the year. Readers deeply unsatisfied with Atwood\u2019s vague epilogue in The Handmaid\u2019s Tale \u2013 and the TV series\u2019 version of events \u2013 are hungry to hear what the Toronto author says happens to Offred after she rejects a path to freedom and remains in Gilead. Three narrators give their version of events in what\u2019s guaranteed to roar to the top of bestseller lists. September 10 and Atwood appears at Bluma Appel Theatre on September 16.\n\nHAD IT COMING: WHAT\u2019S FAIR IN THE AGE OF #METOO? by Robyn Doolittle (Allen Lane)\n\nSince playing a major role in exposing Rob Ford\u2019s epic failings, Doolittle has deployed her journalistic expertise to the issue of sexual assault, already uncovering the distressingly low conviction rate of perpetrators in her Unfounded series. Her new book follows that up with deep research into why, despite governments stepping up and in with money and education, our justice system continues to fail survivors. Her major discovery is that judges and police know almost nothing about how trauma affects victims\u2019 memories and, worse, they don\u2019t understand the meaning of consent. September 24 and Doolittle appears at Hot Docs Cinema on September 26.\n\nCHASING PAINTED HORSES, by Drew Hayden Taylor (Cormorant)\n\nFrequent NOW contributor Taylor\u2019s uncanny ability to combine poignancy and humour has made his stories of Indigenous people an important contribution to the First Nations canon. Here, three teenagers try to figure out how and why their odd schoolmate has created an unusual painting of a horse. The image draws them into her fantasy world until they realize something seriously wrong may be behind the painting and try to help the girl. September 21 and Taylor appears at the Toronto International Festival of Authors on October 22.\n\nFEMINIST CITY: A FIELD GUIDE by Leslie Kern (Between the Lines)\n\nSlowly, we\u2019re becoming more aware of how many products are created without women in mind. Scientists do medical research using male subjects only, cars are designed without taking into account the female body. Now, in a series of trenchant essays, geographer Leslie Kern looks at the way cities are designed, examining everything from rape culture to snow removal and imagining a future where urban planning isn\u2019t so hopelessly gendered. October 14\n\nAKIN by Emma Donoghue (HarperCollins)\n\nRetired professor Noah\u2019s life is upended when he adopts his grand-nephew and takes him on a trip to France. Though the two have trouble connecting at first, the boy\u2019s ease with technology leads Noah to uncover surprising details about his mother\u2019s war-time past. In this, the first contemporary novel she\u2019s written since the spectacularly successful Room, Emma Donoghue again demonstrates her facility for tension-ridden storytelling and unusual empathy. September 3 and Donoghue appears at the Toronto Reference Library on September 9.\n\nFRANKISSTEIN, by Jeanette Winterston (Knopf)\n\nA synopsis of Winterston\u2019s latest bold and ambitious novel sounds like she\u2019s all over the place. One thread follows Mary Shelley as she first imagines Frankenstein. Another features a transgender doctor in Brexit Britain who falls in love with a famous expert in artificial intelligence. A third looks at a designer of sex dolls and a fourth explores a cryogenics facility where the dead are waiting to come alive. But Winterston, enraged, outraged and sometimes very funny, has the skill to bring it all together in this strange love story. October 1\n\nFACE IT by Debbie Harry (HarperCollins)\n\nA memoir from Debbie Harry has many things going for it. For starters, the Blondie singer is super smart. For another, while she hung out with musicians from the Ramones to David Bowie, she was also deeply into New York\u2019s art scene and its prime creators, including Jean-Michel Basquiat and Marina Abramovic. Plus, she made over 30 films with the likes of John Waters (Hairspray) and David Cronenberg (Videodrome). All of that experience makes for one of the must-read memoirs of the year. October 1\n\nGIRL by Edna O\u2019Brien (Farrar, Straus and Giroux/Raincoast) CILKA\u2019S JOURNEY by Heather Morris (St. Martin\u2019s/Raincoast)\n\nTwo books by two exceptional authors cover similar brutal experiences of women who have been imprisoned, sexually assaulted and then released only to be re-victimized by their original communities. Both books probe the essential ethical issues faced by hopelessly disempowered people. In Girl, O\u2019Brien\u2019s hotly anticipated new novel, a kidnap victim of Boko Haram escapes and returns home with her child, the product of her rapist, and is mercilessly shamed. Morris follows up The Tattooist Of Auschwitz with another Holocaust story, this one about a girl who sleeps with her concentration camp commandant in order to survive, only to be charged as a collaborator and assaulted again in a Soviet prison when the camp is freed. October 15 and October 1.\n\nQUICHOTTE by Salman Rushdie (Knopf)\n\nRushdie\u2019s Booker Prize-shortlisted follow-up to his superb The Golden House takes another swipe at Trump\u2019s America, this time reimagining the story of Don Quixote. Quichotte and his imagined sidekick Sancho travel an infinitely corrupt U.S. in search of the gorgeous Salma R (get it?) in what turns out to be a novel within a novel, punctuated with splashes of magic realism. Chaotic, funny and driven by Rushdie\u2019s passion for pop culture, Quichotte is literary pandemonium at its wildest. September 3 and Rushdie appears at the Art Gallery of Ontario on September 30.\n\nON FIRE: THE BURNING CASE FOR A GREEN NEW DEAL by Naomi Klein (Knopf)\n\nKlein, now the inaugural Gloria Steinem Endowed Chair in Media, Culture, and Feminist Studies at Rutgers University, is using her influence to back the Green New Deal just as Canada goes to the polls and the U.S. follows suit a year later. Pairing older essays with new works detailing what\u2019s at stake as humans continue to trash the earth, Klein makes the case for a global commitment to a sustainable \u2013 both politically and economically \u2013 path to planetary rescue. September 17 and Klein appears at the Art Gallery of Ontario on September 20.\n\nTHE MAN WHO SAW EVERYTHING by Deborah Levy (Hamish Hamilton)\n\nLevy, twice Booker-shortlisted, delivers a delicately poetic puzzle piece of a book about a man who pays a trip to East Berlin before the wall crumbles and just after he has a strange accident on the famous crosswalk at Abbey Road. This is a meditation on art, beauty, love and sexuality like nothing else. October 15 and Levy appears at Type Books on November 7\n\nTHE WATER DANCER by Ta-Nehisi Coates (One World)\n\nThe debut novel from one of America\u2019s most influential Black writers (Between The World And Me) is a major event. Coates\u2019s slave narrative follows Hiram as he escapes his masters and near death by harnessing his magical powers, then joins a guerrilla cell in the South and later the Underground Railroad movement in the North. What\u2019s new in this narrative is its focus on the all-out war between the slavers and the enslaved. September 24\n\nFIVE WIVES by Joan Thomas (HarperCollins)\n\nJoan Thomas eviscerates the myth of the benevolent missionary in this fictionalized account of how evangelicals descended on the Waorani, an Ecuadorean Indigenous community, devastating their culture and lives. Thomas, who won the Amazon First Novel Award and the Commonwealth Writers\u2019 Prize for Reading By Lightning, delves into the ways the Waorani, who had no previous contact with the outside world, were sacrificed to religious imperialism and capitalist greed by intruders who saw themselves as saviours. September 3\n\nTHE WAGERS by Sean Michaels (Random House)\n\nMichaels has become famous for packing his stories with huge themes. His Giller-winning Us Conductors (my top book of 2015) covers jazz, espionage, science, Soviet prison camps and the unusual beauty of the theremin. In this long-awaited follow-up, he boldly explores the impact of luck and questions its essential worth in a tale about love, life, magic and gambling. September 24\n\nDEATH AND THE SEASIDE by Alison Moore (Biblioasis)\n\nAn aspiring writer with self-esteem issues \u2013 abandoning a PhD thesis will do that to you \u2013 takes a first apartment with a manipulative landlady in this psychological thriller that has all the qualities of a powerful page-turner: an insecure protagonist, a predator who knows how to press her buttons and a holiday location with its own very creepy connotations. October 8\n\nWATCHING YOU WITHOUT ME by Lynn Coady (Anansi)\n\nAfter her mother dies, Karen returns to her Nova Scotia hometown laden with guilt. Living the high life in Toronto, she hasn\u2019t paid much attention to her mother or her developmentally disabled older sister Kelli and now she has to make all the family decisions. At first she appreciates the advice and concern of caregiver Trevor, who\u2019s been assisting the family. But he seems not to understand the meaning of boundaries. This is a taut, intense story about love and manipulation from one of Canada\u2019s best writers. September 24\n\nALSO ON THE HORIZON\n\nSontag by Benjamin Moser (Ecco, September 17), a definitive biography based on Susan Sontag\u2019s previously restricted archives Grand Union, stories by Zadie Smith (Hamish Hamilton, October 8) Find Me by Andr\u00e9 Aciman (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, October 29), revisiting his characters in Call Me By Your Name Olive, Again by Elizabeth Strout (Random House, October 15), again featuring Strout\u2019s irresistible Olive Kittredge Highway Of Tears by Jessica McDiarmid (Doubleday, September 24), meticulously researched non-fiction stories of missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\n@susangcole\n\nSUSAN G. COLE\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYoutube\nTiktok\n\nFollow us\n@nowtoronto\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nWHAT\u2019S TRENDING\nPOSTED 2 DAYS AGO\n\nViral video shows people lined up for hours at Mandarin restaurants for its free buffet on Canada Day. concert\u00a0\n\nPOSTED 2 DAYS AGO\n\nScarborough\u2019s favourite street festival returns for its 20th anniversary in July\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nLIFESTYLE\n\u201cYou don\u2019t need a fancy gym,\u2019 Some Torontonians are sick of paying hundreds of dollars for gym memberships\n\nPOSTED 18 MINS AGOROVEENA JASSAL\n\nGoodlife is a common choice amongst Torontonians who want a fully-equipped gym without having to pay three figures a month (Courtesy: UNITY and Goodlife).\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nCopy current article link\n\n\u00a0\n\nMore Torontonians are opting for cheaper fitness options as gym prices appear to be soaring in the city.\n\nEven though luxury fitness clubs like Sweat and Tonic, Altea Active, and recently UNITY fitness have gained popularity in the city, some Torontonians are concerned with their high prices.\u00a0\n\nSweat and Tonic memberships range from $180 to $1,250 a month while Altea Active offers summer rates that start at $74.95 every other week.\u00a0\n\nSimilar to other higher-end gyms in Toronto, UNITY offers a membership with open fitness space, unlimited group exercise classes, a saltwater pool, pickleball and basketball courts, a HIIT cardio area with 90-feet of performance turf, a cycling studio, a hot yoga studio, and a members\u2019 lounge for $95 a month.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThis is an amazing price considering it gives you access to our 45,000 sq ft state-of-the-art fitness facility,\u201d Head of Strategy and Operations at UNITY Fitness & Hospitality Adam Reynolds told Now Toronto in an email statement.\u00a0\n\nAlthough gyms seem to be getting more luxurious, more Torontonians seem to be\u00a0 shying away from expensive places to get a sweat on.\u00a0\n\nFitness TikToker @chrispoletek posted a video earlier this year on how he left his $200 per month gym for Goodlife because he could never finish a solid workout due to how busy it was.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt was a clout show. It was all just about fashion, the nicest outfits. Every guy is in matching Gymshark shorts\u2026. [Goodlife] has everything you need. You don\u2019t need a fancy gym to get a good workout in,\u201d he said.\u00a0\n\nGoodlife is a common choice amongst Torontonians who want a fully-equipped gym without having to pay three figures a month.\u00a0\n\nAnother Toronto TikToker (@vlad.zamriifit) posted a list rating Toronto gyms with Goodlife ranking as 8.5 out of 10.\u00a0\n\nAlthough Goodlife is considered to be a bit more affordable, it still ends up being over $50 a month for new members.\u00a0\n\nSmaller boutique gyms around the city, like Fuzion Fitness, offer a variety of fitness classes, full equipment, and even a designated women\u2019s only area for $30 a month.\u00a0\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Body Buster Fitness (@bodybusterfitness)\n\nIn the warmer months, plenty of affordable fitness groups in the city advocate exercising outdoors, such as Body Buster Fitness.\u00a0\n\nThese classes are often more inclusive of all fitness levels and use more bodyweight exercises.\n\nHowever, the most affordable gyms in the city are provided by the city themselves. FitnessTO has a year-long membership ranging from $190 to $300, which includes access to over 40 weight rooms and 30 indoor pools across the city.\u00a0\n\nThere\u2019s also an entire list of gyms with weight rooms, cardio machines, fitness classes, and public pools around the city that are free of cost to all residents.\u00a0\n\nROVEENA JASSAL\n\nWRITER / REPORTER\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYoutube\nTiktok\n\nFollow us\n@nowtoronto\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nWHAT\u2019S TRENDING\nPOSTED 2 DAYS AGO\n\nViral video shows people lined up for hours at Mandarin restaurants for its free buffet on Canada Day. Was it worth it?\n\nPOSTED 2 DAYS AGO\n\n\u2018Traffic\u2019s too crazy in Toronto, so I\u2019m walking to the venue\u2019 Former One Direction singer Niall Horan forced to walk to his own concert\u00a0\n\nPOSTED 2 DAYS AGO\n\nScarborough\u2019s favourite street festival returns for its 20th anniversary in July\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nNEWS\nThis Toronto developer is making it easier for unhoused people to access shelter spaces and meals\n\nPOSTED 51 MINS AGOJANIECE CAMPBELL\n\nThrough a new online resource called Respitely, users can find a list providing daily updates on bed and room availability in often overcrowded shelters. (Courtesy: Joel Muniz/Unsplash)\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nCopy current article link\n\nWhen Toronto-based web developer Arjun Sahjpaul completed his software engineering program, he wanted to apply his newly acquired skills into something he was most passionate about: helping people in need.\u00a0\n\nSahjpaul is the creator of Respitely, an online resource for people experiencing or at risk of homelessness in Toronto with an aim to modernize access to their basic needs.\u00a0\n\nThrough Respitely, users can find a list providing daily updates on bed and room availability in often overcrowded shelters. It also contains details on each shelter, including the age demographic it serves, type of shelter (i.e. emergency, transitional) and total capacity.\u00a0\n\nThe site also displays a live drop-in meal tracker, where users can pinpoint the closest centres serving food which are categorized by breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks.\u00a0\n\nThe inspiration for creating this resource came from Sahjpaul being directly engaged in his late mother\u2019s benevolency at a young age, where he and his three siblings would participate in activities such as gathering donations for women\u2019s shelters.\u00a0\n\nHe told Now Toronto that many of his vivid memories include accompanying her on long drives to visit an uncle who struggled with mental health issues, usually bringing clothes and food over.\u00a0\n\n\u201cOver time, these visits helped me understand that those of us who are fortunate to have food and housing have a duty to help those who do not,\u201d Sahjpaul said.\u00a0\n\n\u201cHer insistence on recognizing the struggles faced by others instilled in me the desire and passion to create this platform, with the hope of improving accessibility and connecting those in need with the basics of life.\u201d\n\nA significant challenge for people experiencing homelessness can be the digital divide, where many don\u2019t have access to technology like smartphones or internet access. Sahjpaul admits that while the company\u2019s resources will never be accessible to every Torontonian in need, Respitely aims to digitally connect with as many individuals as possible.\u00a0\n\n\u201cSome studies suggest that the divide may not be as wide as previously thought, with a significant portion of homeless populations (80 to 90 per cent according to one study) having access to cell phones and technology,\u201d he explained.\u00a0\n\nSahjpaul also suggests for people experiencing or at risk of homelessness to utilize the free internet that Toronto Public Library (TPL) offers, where residents can obtain a library card for easy access to computers. As of July 3, customers without internet at home can also receive free take-home Wi-Fi hotspots at select library locations, according to TPL\u2019s website.\u00a0\n\nRespitely hopes to partner with more municipalities across Toronto, and eventually cities across Canada and the rest of the world. For now, the site filters its information directly from the City of Toronto\u2019s Daily Shelter Occupancy system and configures it into a central database, an initiative that Ward 9-Davenport City Councillor Alejandra Bravo finds commendable.\u00a0\n\n\u201cTorontonians care deeply about looking out for one another, and I thank everyone who shows care for our unhoused neighbours,\u201d Bravo told Now Toronto.\n\nJANIECE CAMPBELL\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYoutube\nTiktok\n\nFollow us\n@nowtoronto\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nWHAT\u2019S TRENDING\nPOSTED 2 DAYS AGO\n\nViral video shows people lined up for hours at Mandarin restaurants for its free buffet on Canada Day. (Courtesy: A&W)\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nCopy current article link\n\nCanadians can score some free root beer this Saturday at A&W restaurants across the country!\n\nA&W\u2019s Free Root Beer Day is back for one day only at all restaurant locations and on the mobile app, with a limit of one per guest.\u00a0\n\nA&W opened its first restaurant in Winnipeg, Manitoba back in 1956. Since then, its root beer has become a pop favourite amongst Canadians. higher tax location than their official home offices (Courtesy: Taylor Borden / Linkedin).\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nCopy current article link\n\nMore Canadian companies are interested in introducing a work from anywhere (WFA) policy as a new study down south reveals nearly half of U.S. employees have admitted to quiet vacationing.\u00a0\n\nThe study found 48 per cent\u00a0 of American employees have \u201cquiet vacationed\u201d around the July 4th holiday, meaning they\u2019ve switched from their usual WFH location to elsewhere without telling their employers.\u00a0\n\nAlthough Canadian workers are also moving to different parts of the world while staying productive, they\u2019re hesitant to tell employers about their plans, Courtney Lee, vice president of People at HR platform Humi, told Now Toronto.\n\n\u201cEven credible employees may feel apprehension that their manager or peers will assume they\u2019re less productive if they\u2019re working from a location that isn\u2019t their home office\u2026Employees sometimes take the \u2018ask for forgiveness, not permission\u2019 approach, believing it may be frowned upon or the request declined if they outright ask,\u201d Humi said.\n\nThere\u2019s also the issue of taxes, where employees might not disclose if they\u2019re working from a higher tax location than their official home offices.\u00a0\n\nHowever, Lee explains a WFA policy could help address this issue by having employees and employers both be diligent with location tracking.\n\n\u201cEnsure the policy is clear that employees are responsible for any personal tax implications incurred by working from a location outside their designated home office and securing work authorization requirements in countries they choose to work from,\u201d she said.\u00a0\n\nCanadian WFA policy should also include if employees are responsible for funding their own access to wifi, accommodation costs, and the impact of timezones for work hours, according to Lee.\n\nROVEENA JASSAL\n\nWRITER / REPORTER\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYoutube\nTiktok\n\nFollow us\n@nowtoronto\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nWHAT\u2019S TRENDING\nPOSTED 2 DAYS The day is established by the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada\u00a0(NWAC) and observed through vigils, walks, or marches that honour the memory of those lost to violence. Laura Beamish/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nDozens of community members gathered to honour and remember missing and murdered Indigenous women, as well as to support the victim\u2019s families, at a Sisters in Spirit vigil held Thursday at McMurray M\u00e9tis.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want this to be the memory of them,\u201d said Melissa Herman, a co-organizer of the event.\n\nIn the municipality of Wood Buffalo, there are currently six Indigenous women who have gone missing or been murdered, including Amber Tuccaro, Shirley Waquan, Lisa Alook, Shelly Dene, Janice Desjarlais and most recently Betty Anne Deltess, who was last seen on April 11.\n\nTuccaro\u2019s remains were found in a field in Leduc in 2012 two years after she went missing. In 2014, her family filed a complaint against the RCMP and the handling of the case, and just last month received the report.\n\nFort McMurray was just one of many communities who took a moment to remember all the Indigenous women who have are missing and murdered.\n\nPremier Rachel Notley said in a statement that the provincial government cares deeply about the issue.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cOur greatest hope is that these vigils, along with better supports for women, the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Alberta\u2019s Taking Action Against Racism plan and resolute efforts at every level of society, will help achieve meaningful action to ensure the safety and security of Indigenous women and girls here in Alberta and across Canada,\u201d she said.\n\nMelissa Herman speaks to community members who have gathered at McMurray M\u00c3\u00a9tis to honour and remember missing and murdered Indigenous women on Oct. 4, 2018. Laura Beamish/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nMany at the gathering in Fort McMurray spoke, shared stories and different supports available to victims and families, including the Family Information Liaison Unit and Waypoints.\n\nNicole Greville, domestic violence outreach manager at Waypoints, also spoke to the importance of being present.\n\n\u201cI want you all to recognize the power that you hold in standing here,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is not an Indigenous issue and this is not a women\u2019s issue, this is a human rights issue.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMembers of the Wood Buffalo RCMP were also there to show their support, including Sergeant Elizabeth McDonald, who spoke about that ongoing support in the community.\n\n\u201cEveryone, no matter what their background is, deserves justice,\u201d she said.\n\nSergeant Elizabeth McDonald speaks with community members who are gathered at McMurray M\u00c3\u00a9tis to honour and remember missing and murdered Indigenous women on Oct. 4, 2018. Laura Beamish/Fort McMurray Today/Postmedia Network\n\nHerman said it was encouraging to see such support from organizations and community members.\n\n\u201cI think there\u2019s a disconnection between missing and murdered Indigenous women and the rest of the country because oftentimes we\u2019re not empathizing with each other,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cTo see such a healthy mix of Indigenous and non-Indigenous people here in honour of the women missing from here, it\u2019s really encouraging and I hope that it\u2019s like this moving forward and I hope that we build on this moment.\u201d\n\nMoving forward, Herman said it\u2019s important for people to be aware of what is going on around them.\n\n\u201cBeing self aware of the issue and not always depending on media or families that have to tell their story, but just recognize that it\u2019s happening and that there\u2019s a role that everybody plays. Christina Max jpg, WK\nArticle content\n\nChristina Max\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIt has taken 39 years for Shirley Soosay to be found and brought home and she is only one of the missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirits in Canada.\n\nLast week on May 5, Red Dress Day, Soosay\u2019s niece Violet shared the story of how her aunt had gone from being a hard-working woman to having her children taken away from her, to using alcohol and drugs and losing contact with her family in 1980 and the promise Violet made to her grandma, Soosay\u2019s mother, \u201cto find her and bring her home.\u201d\n\nAfter nearly four decades, of travelling from Alberta to Vancouver and Seattle,visiting hospitals, hostels, and cemeteries while on work trips in hopes of finding anything about her aunt\u2019s whereabouts. Soosay\u2019s remains, which were located in California .\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe had been murdered in July 1980, near Bakersfield, California and remained a Jane Doe until 2020 when a DNA connection identified her as Soosay.\n\nHer reamins will be returned to Maskwaics where a ceremony will be held.\n\nHer story recently aired on A&E\u2019s Cold Case Files and is part of a documentary currently being filmed \u2014 but it is only one of the stories impacting the Four Nations of Maskwacis.\n\nDuring a walk from the Lucky Dollar Store to the NOK Building in Ermineskin last week, family and friends of missing and murdered women carried photos of their loved ones with others carrying signs demanding action to address the issue.\n\nFollowing the walk, which began with a pipe ceremony, several speakers shared their stories, including Two-Spirit activist Chevi Rabbit,\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe, as a people are continuing to be exploited,\u201d said Rabbit. \u201cWe have to look out for each other.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m honoured to walk with you,\u201d said Jason Makinaw, president of the Ermineskin Women\u2019s Shelter. \u201cWe all know someone who has been impacted by this.\u201d\n\nSamson Cree Coun. Ryan Lightning said he recently participated in a walk along Hwy. 803 near Morinville to mark the one-year anniversary of the discovery of the remains of Billie Johnson, who disappeared Dec. 24, 2020 and whose remains were found in April 23, 2021.\n\n\u201cAs you walked, along that highway there\u2019s crosses there for other women in the same situation,\u201d he said. \u201cLove each other. Tell our young girls we love them. They\u2019re important and they\u2019re a part of this earth for a reason.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSamson Cree Chief Vernon Saddleback said, \u201cToday, I come in support of all of you. All of you showing up matters\u2026I want to make sure the future for our granddaughters matter.\u201d\n\nMaskwacis RCMP Insp. Leanne MacMillan was also in attendance and outlined a plan to bring a restorative justice program to Maskwacis; add more Indigenous members to the local detachment (there is currently four) and work on educating all members on domestic violence issues and how to handle these files.\n\n\u201cForty-two per cent of Indigenous women have been physically abused by an adult when they were a child,\u201d she said, noting the number is 29 per cent for non-Indigenous women. \u201cThese statistics are saddening and shocking at the same time.\u201d\n\nHaving been involved in many of the cases of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirits, MacMillan said each of these cases is important.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAfter hanging dozens of red dresses in Diamond Jubilee Park and By-the-Lake Park the previous weekend, in Wetaskiwin, a small group gathered at the Peace Cairn May 5.\n\nImmanuel Anglican Church Reconciliation Committee member Fiona Brownlee said, \u201cThis is an important day, not just for Indigenous folks, but for those of us who are allies. It is our job to talk about it \u2014\u00a0to not be silent, so that\u2019s what we\u2019re doing.\u201d\n\nAs non-Indigenous people, Brownlee said, she has been told it is up to \u201csettlers\u201d to speak out as their voices are louder.\n\n\u201cAs we talk about this and raise this issue, it will not just be an Indigenous issue, it will be a Canadian issue and would not just be talked about in Indigenous circles.\n\n\u201cWe have to have a very huge voice,\u201d said Committee member Bonny Graham. \u201cThere is very little information out there so the louder we get, the more attention this draws, there more information will come.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSamson Cree Coun. Ryan Lightning was also in attendance in Wetaskiwin.\n\n\u201cIt takes us as a whole to work through this,\u201d he said. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter what race you ware. We do it for our kids so they grow up and become wise and I thank you for doing this and for this day. It takes us, as a whole community, to come together to make a better future.\u201d\n\nThe ceremony culminated with sisters Melissa Moonias and Cheryl Montour singing a pair of Honour Songs.\n\nRed Dress Day honours the memories of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada.\n\nPrior to last week\u2019s events, Ermineskin Women\u2019s Shelter child support worker Sheila Johansen said, \u201cIt\u2019s an emotional time, but it\u2019s a step we have to take. It\u2019s the ones who are left behind that it\u2019s heart-breaking for and for the family of the missing, they are in limbo. There is no closure.\u201d\n\nShe also noted it is time for action to be taken to prevent more tragedies.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR EDMONTON\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/wanuskewin-celebrates-mothers-day-with-birth-of-bison/", "title": "Wanuskewin adds to conservation herd with Mother's Day bison birth | The Star Phoenix", "body": "Skip to Content\nLIMITED-TIME SALE! Act Now>>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\n2024 Saskatchewan wildfires\nSend a Letter to the Editor\nSports\nOpinion\nBusiness\nArts\nLife\nShopping\nNewsletters\nBridges\nPuzzmo\nDriving\nePaper\nRemembering\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nLocal News\nWanuskewin adds to conservation herd with Mother's Day bison birth\n\nFor Wanuskewin Heritage Park, the birth of four plains bison calves this spring is the beginning of a conservation herd and the end of decades of work.\n\nAuthor of the article:\nAmanda Short\nPublished May 13, 2020 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nThe herd of plains bison at Wanuskewin has grown. Four new calves have been born at the Heritage Park. Photo taken on Tuesday, May 12, 2020. PHOTO BY MATT SMITH /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\nArticle content\nA total of four new calves have been born at Wanuskewin Heritage Park. PHOTO BY MATT SMITH /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\n\nWhen the last of Wanuskewin\u2019s four pregnant bison cows gave birth on Mother\u2019s Day, CEO Darlene Brander found it a fitting end to a journey that had already been full of pleasant surprises.\n\nSunday\u2019s calf, the only male, wasn\u2019t the only one born on a significant date. One of his siblings was born on Earth Day (April 22) and the other on Red Dress Day (May 5), the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nWoman charged after altercation on city bus in Saskatoon's Confederation Park neighbourhood\nPolice investigating two stabbings in Saskatoon in two days\nMandryk: Sask. Party has turned truth telling into an election issue\nArticle content\n\nIn early December, six calves from Grasslands National Park set foot on the land for the first time since the species\u2019 near-extirpation more than a century ago.\n\nThe park\u2019s leadership wasn\u2019t expecting that in a few weeks everything would be in place for a second group of bison \u2014 a bull and four pregnant cows \u2014 to arrive from the United States.\n\nThe bull, from a wild herd in Yellowstone National Park, makes Wanuskewin the first place in Canada where two bison populations have interacted since they were wild.\n\nDeveloping a burgeoning conservation herd of plains bison at Wanuskewin Heritage Park has been one of its goals since the park\u2019s conception, Brander said.\n\n\u201cThis has been in the making 40 years, from when the elders first envisioned it,\u201d Brander said. \u201cFor it to come to fruition and for the bison to get here in December and then for the babies to be born healthy \u2014 and three of them on really special days \u2014 is all really significant.\u201d\n\nSince 2016, Wanuskewin has been working toward UNESCO World Heritage Site designation through its $40-million Thundering Ahead Campaign.\n\nBison have always played an integral role in the cultural revitalization at its core.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThey form the future herd of Wanuskewin, and the foundation of the herd, too,\u201d Brander said. \u201cSo we\u2019re just thrilled and tickled pink that we\u2019ve been blessed with the bison babies.\u201d\n\nWahpeton Dakota Nation Elder Cy Standing is part of an elder advisory group for Wanuskewin. Standing said having the bison so close to the city provides an important educational opportunity.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been working for many years to get bison back, and finally they\u2019re there,\u201d he said. \u201cFor our First Nations culture, the bison is very important to us; they\u2019re our relatives.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s good for children to see the bison and to learn about it, how we relate.\u201d\n\nThe two groups are currently in separate pens, but will be allowed to come together in 2021 once the calves are older. Over time, the herd is expected to naturally grow to about 50 animals.\n\nWhile the park remains closed due to restrictions around COVID-19, Brander said she looks forward to opening back up to the public in the coming weeks.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s amazing,\u201d she said. \u201cIt gives me hope with this COVID period that we\u2019re in, and I think it gives a lot of other people hope too, that there\u2019s better days to look forward to.\u201d\n\namshort@postmedia.com\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\n'Circle of life': First baby bison born on Wanuskewin land since before 1876\nA piece of history: Bison reintroduced to Wanuskewin Heritage Park site\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nThree arrested after drug trafficking investigation in Saskatoon\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nLawyer for trucker who caused deadly Broncos crash says families have no right to sue\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nSeniors Are Getting Free Hearing Tests (Here's how)\nConnect Hearing\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians In Alberta With No Life Insurance Are Taking Advantage Of This\nCovered For Life\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nOne Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before, You Will Fit In Your Pants Again!\nBurn Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\n\nPostmedia is committed to maintaining a lively but civil forum for discussion. {"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/highway-of-tears/cp35472306", "title": "B.C. transportation minister says Highway of Tears changes coming | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kelowna and Area|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nSunny\u00a0 27.4\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nB.C. transportation minister says Highway of Tears changes coming\nDirk Meissner\nRepublished November 26, 2015 - 4:45 PM\nOriginal Publication Date November 26, 2015 - 11:15 AM\n\nVICTORIA - British Columbia is set to announce transportation service upgrades along the so-called Highway of Tears, but the minister responsible says a region-wide shuttle bus sought by First Nations won't be part of the plan.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone said he's considering options such as supporting volunteer-driven vans that link First Nations reserves with communities, improving existing transit schedules and expanding use of a bus that takes people to and from medical appointments.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or disappeared along Highway 16 and adjacent routes since the 1970s. The highway stretches about 750 kilometres across the centre of the province from Prince George to Prince Rupert.\n\n\"My intentions are to develop and launch a provincial strategy on this that will represent our next steps to enhance transportation services in the corridor, and to do so fairly quickly,\" Stone said Thursday.\n\nHe said he expects to announce changes within weeks.\n\n\"This is one of the top priorities on my desk at the moment and there has been a lot of valuable discussion, lots of goodwill demonstrated by everyone involved, so my goal is to act as quickly as I possibly can.\"\n\nHe said transportation options were discussed earlier this week at meetings in Smithers, with almost 100 people attending, including First Nations, community leaders and government officials.\n\nStone said he's reviewing proposals including improvement of existing B.C. Transit schedules between neighbouring communities such as Houston and Smithers and Terrace and Prince Rupert. He's also considering suggestions to open a health appointment bus in the north to passengers in general.\n\n\"Let's see if we can't get more butts into the seats,\" Stone said.\n\nThe minister said he's on board with expanding a current volunteer transit service that links First Nations communities in the Fort St. James area with neighbouring communities of Vanderhoof and Prince George.\n\n\"This community-based van service, I think there's a winner there,\" Stone said. \"I think there's an opportunity to take that best practice and replicate it in other areas through the corridor.\"\n\nStone said he remains adamant that a regional shuttle bus service favoured by many First Nations is a non-starter. Government documents released recently pegged annual operating costs of a regular shuttle service between Prince George and Prince Rupert at less than $1 million.\n\n\"These are all potentially practical, sustainable solutions,\" Stone said. \"They don't involve establishing a scheduled shuttle bus from Prince Rupert to Prince George.\n\nOpposition New Democrat Jennifer Rice, who represents the Prince Rupert area, said she's disappointed that Stone continues to reject a regional shuttle bus.\n\nRice said she attended the Smithers meeting and spoke with people who have lost family members along the highway. They were disappointed a shuttle bus is being giving short shrift, she said.\n\n\"People have been calling for that for quite a long time. We spend more money on twinning highways.\"\n\nRice said she's awaiting further details of Stone's plans.\n\nStone recently said the highway issue could be part of an inquiry the federal government may call into Canada's murdered and missing women.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2015\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are emailed reader responses to stories or letters to...\nChefs mourn for Okanagan's peaches but adapt to stone {"url": "https://winnipegsun.com/opinion/columnists/opinion-trudeau-and-ford-should-attach-personal-fortunes-to-ev-corporate-welfare/wcm/11d3a6d2-794b-496c-bf03-21c77f9e890e", "title": "OPINION: Trudeau and Ford should attach personal fortunes to EV corporate welfare | Winnipeg Sun", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nePaper\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nJets add to depth with two-way signings\nTRENDING\nBombers' Collaros to miss first start of season vs Redblacks\nTRENDING\nTrump trashes \u2018broken down pile of crap\u2019 Biden in viral video\nTRENDING\nPlayers hearing it from fans: What's up with Bombers?\nTRENDING\nManitoba First Nation reports 150 anomalies at residential school site\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nColumnists\nOPINION: Trudeau and Ford should attach personal fortunes to EV corporate welfare\nAuthor of the article:\nTegan Hill, Jason Clemens\nPublished May 05, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 05, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau shakes hands with Ontario Premier Doug Ford during an event at the Honda of Canada Manufacturing Plant 2 in Alliston, Ont., on April 25, 2024 where it was announced that Japanese automaker Honda will make the largest automotive investment in Canada's history worth $15 billion electric vehicle investment in Ontario that will see four new manufacturing plants built in the province. PHOTO BY PETER POWER /AFP via Getty Images\nArticle content\n\nLast week, with their latest tranche of corporate welfare for the electric vehicle (EV) sector, the Trudeau and Ford governments announced a $5.0 billion subsidy for Honda to help build an EV battery plant and ultimately manufacture EVs in Ontario. Here\u2019s a challenge: if politicians in both governments truly believe these measures are in the public interest, they should tie their personal fortunes with the outcomes of these subsidies (a.k.a. corporate welfare).\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOne of the major challenges with corporate welfare is the horrendous economic incentives. The politicians and bureaucrats who distribute corporate welfare have no vested financial interest in the outcome of the program. Whether these programs are spectacularly successful (or more likely spectacular failures), the politicians and bureaucrats experience no direct financial gain or loss. Simply put, they\u2019re investing taxpayer money, not their own.\n\nPut differently, the discipline imposed on investors in private markets, such as the risk of losing money or even going out of business, is wholly absent in the government sector. Indeed, the history of corporate welfare in Canada, at both the federal and provincial levels, is rife with abject failures due in large measure to the absence of this investing discipline.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn the last 12 months in Ontario, automakers have been major beneficiaries of corporate welfare. The $5.0 billion for Honda is on top of $13.2 billion to Volkswagen and $15.0 billion to Stellantis. That equates to roughly $979 per taxpayer nationally for federal subsidies and an additional $1,372 for Ontario taxpayers. And these figures do not include the debt interest costs that will be incurred as both governments are borrowing money to finance the subsidies.\n\nAnd there\u2019s legitimate reason to be skeptical already of the potential success of these large-scale industrial interventions by the federal (Liberal) and Ontario (Conservative) governments. EV sales in both Canada and the United States have not grown as expected by governments despite purchase subsidies. Disappointing EV sales have led several auto manufacturers including Toyota and Ford to scale back their EV production plans.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThere are also real concerns about the practical ability of EV manufacturers to secure required materials. Consider the minerals needed for EV batteries. According to a recent study, 388 new mines\u2014including 50 lithium mines, 60 nickel mines and 17 cobalt mines\u2014would be required by 2030 to meet EV adoption commitments by various governments. For perspective, there were a total of 340 metal mines operating across Canada and the U.S. in 2021. The massive task of finding, constructing and developing this level of new mines seems impractical and unattainable, meaning that EV plants being built now will struggle to secure needed inputs. Indeed, depending on the type of mine, it takes anywhere from six to 18 years to develop.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nWhich brings us back to the Trudeau and Ford governments. Given the economic incentive problems and practical challenges to a large-scale transition to EVs, would members of the Trudeau and Ford governments\u2014including the prime minister and premier\u2014want to attach a portion of their personal pensions to the success of these corporate welfare programs?\n\nMore specifically, assume an arrangement whereby those politicians would share the benefits of the program\u2019s success but also share any losses through the value of their pensions. If the programs work as marketed, the politicians would enjoy higher valued pensions. But if the programs disappoint or even fail, their pensions would be reduced or even cancelled. Would these politicians still support billions in corporate handouts if their personal financial wellbeing was tied to the outcomes?\n\nAs the funding of private companies to develop the EV sector in Ontario continues with the support of taxpayer subsidies, Ontarians and all Canadians should consider the misalignment of economic incentives underpinning these subsidies and the practical challenges to the success of this industrial intervention.\n\nJason Clemens and Tegan Hill are economists with the Fraser Institute.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. MONTH\nBOOK YOUR AD\nDIGITAL SUBSCRIPTION\nNEW LANGUAGE\nHome  News  Sask. offering funding for local projects that support Indigenous women and girls\nNews\nSask. offering funding for local projects that support Indigenous women and girls\nBy Daily Herald -\nSeptember 6, 2023\nMary Ann Morin participates in a Red Dress Day demonstration at the corner of 15th Street and Sixth Avenue East. \u2013 Peter Lozinski/Daily Herald\n\nGrassroots efforts to prevent violence against Indigenous women and girls may be eligible for financial support from the provincial government.\n\nThe deadline to apply for the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls+ (MMIWG) Community Response Fund is Oct. 4.\u00a0\n\nApplicants across Saskatchewan can receive up to $40,000 for projects that foster awareness, empowerment and healing of Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people.\n\n\u201cOur province has been guided by the voices of Indigenous women,\u201d said Don McMorris, minister responsible for First Nations, Metis and Northern Affairs.\n\nAccording to a news release, the government developed the fund with Indigenous women who have \u201clived experience in violence prevention, advocacy and mental health.\u201d\n\nMcMorris said the province\u2019s support for these projects is intended to address issues raised in the MMIWG national inquiry.\n\n\u201cLast year, 12 community-led projects received support through this fund. Our government continues to be committed to meaningful and lasting reconciliation for the benefit of all Saskatchewan residents and I encourage communities and organizations to apply,\u201d he said.\n\nLori Whiteman is from Standing Buffalo First Nation in southern Saskatchewan, and is the daughter of a long-time missing person.\n\n\u201cThose of us who designed the fund were not focused on just raising awareness about murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls, but supporting those who work directly with survivors,\u201d said Whiteman.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to make sure the resources were available to do the work.\u201d\n\nThe Saskatchewan government has set aside $400,000 to distribute to local grassroots Indigenous groups, non-profits and municipalities looking to partner with Indigenous communities, and non-Indigenous non-profits with Indigenous involvement.\n\nFor more information, visit the MMIWG Community Response Fund page on the Government of Saskatchewan\u2019s website.\n\n-Advertisement-\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedin\nCopy URL\nPrevious article\nThe Metro strike could redefine Canada\u2019s grocery industry\nNext article\nTrudeau carbon taxes undermine his claims he\u2019s making life more affordable\nDaily Herald\nhttps://paherald.sk.ca\nFOLLOW US\n\nAccess our archives, 1910 to today's date, with your digital subscription. {"url": "https://www.pentictonherald.ca/spare_news/article_e8757ac6-d56c-5212-ae1f-0290cb169af1.html", "title": "Red Dress Day | Spare News | pentictonherald.ca", "body": "Skip to main content\nAboutContactReal Estate TodayBusiness DirectorySpecial Editions\nMake Home Page\nSign UpLog In\nFacebook\n \nTwitter\n \nLinkedIn\nThursday, July 4, 2024\nHome\nNews\nSports\nBusiness\nFeatures\nOpinion\nClassifieds\nSubscribe\nContests\ne-Edition\nRed Dress Day\nJulia Archelene Magsombol, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter The Columbia Valley Pioneer May 5, 2023 \nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nCopy article link\nSave\n\n\"It's sadness,\" said Monica Fisher, the president of the Columbia Valley Met\u00eds Association, whenever she hears news about the murdered Indigenous women in different communities.\n\nThe first-ever Red Dress Day was held on May 5, 2010. This day raises awareness for the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada.\n\nhttps://www.edmonton.ca/city_government/indigenous-relations-office/red-dress-day\n\n\"It's important that we are raising awareness and gaining understanding as to why Indigenous women and girls are disproportionately victims to abuse and violence,\" Fisher said.\n\nNative Women's Association of Canada (NWAC) created a database on murdered Indigenous women in 2010. The data shows NWAC has gathered information on about 582 confirmed deaths:\n\n\u2022 67 per cent are murder cases\n\n\u2022 20 per cent are cases of missing women and girls\n\n\u2022 4 per cent are cases of suspicious death\n\n\u2022 9 per cent are unknown cases\n\nBased on a 2017 report of the Department of Justice Canada (DOJ), the number of murdered Indigenous women has increased. Between 1980 and 2014, police reported almost 7,000 female homicide cases \u201416 per cent were Indigenous women. The DOJ summarized how those homicide cases have grown or have remained relatively stable:\n\nhttps://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/rp-pr/jr/jf-pf/2017/july04.html\n\nLast April, a 33-year-old First Nation woman, Linda Mary Beardy, was found dead at the Winnipeg landfill. Based on a CBC report, an autopsy confirmed that she had injuries on her body. The case is still being investigated. But the medical examiner suggested that \u201cnone of Beardy's injuries suggested foul play and police are \"satisfied that this is not a homicide.\u201d Read the story at\n\nhttps://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/linda-beardy-family-statement-1.6803873\n\n\"There should be equity in regard to the same response that's happening for non-Indigenous people,\u201d said Fisher. \u201cThis should be the same response for Indigenous people.\u201d She noted that \"there could be more\u201d done when it comes to the jobs of the officials.\n\nFisher believes that raising awareness is important, but it is also important to \"support individuals who are struggling within communities . . . with violence and individuals who suffer from trauma.\" She said that solutions to these problems could be steps for justice.\n\nCommemorations for Red Dress Day are different in each community. But during this day, people wear red and hang red dresses on trees. For more background visit https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/red-dress-day\n\n\"Wearing red and understanding each of the movements are important,\" Fisher said. \u201cWithout any action, there is no change. It is all our responsibilities to keep our women, our children, and our community safe.\"\n\nIf you need help on the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women or girls, call 1-844-413-6649 for assistance.\n\n\"I think being vulnerable and telling our stories is important,\" Fisher said.\n\nThe Canadian Press.
