{"url": "https://www.vernonmorningstar.com/news/penticton-walks-to-raise-awareness-for-missing-murdered-indigenous-women-7354535", "title": "Penticton walks to raise awareness for Missing Murdered Indigenous Women - Vernon Morning Star", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n28.0 \u00b0C\nHome News\nPenticton walks to raise awareness for Missing Murdered Indigenous Women\nThis year was particularly poignant as this year brought an ugly reminder\n\tBrennan Phillips\n\nMay 6, 2024 3:30 PM\nMay 6, 2024 3:37 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 9 Around 200 people joined the Walk for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Children and Two-Spirited Individuals on Red Dress Day in Penticton. (Brennan Phillips - Western News)\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:03:34\n\nThis article discusses topics which may negatively impact the reader due to its subject matter. If you are affected by the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQI+ people and require support, call 1-844-413-6649 or visit the Government of Canada website for more resources.\n\nAbout 200 people, marched together along Penticton\u2019s waterfront to raise awareness for Missing Murdered Indigenous Women, Children and Two-Spirit+ individuals.\n\nThe walk was one of many taking place across the country on Red Dress Day, May 5, which is dedicated to ending the killing and disappearing of vulnerable Indigenous people.\n\nA year after 50 people showed their commitment to change by walking together in 2023, dozens more joined together to walk from the S.S. Sicamous to Gyro Park along a path lined with donated red dresses.\n\nThe red dress has become a symbol that embodies the lives lost and serves as a powerful reminder of the work that still lies ahead to achieve justice and equity for all.\n\nIn Gyro Park, dignitaries spoke to the importance of the day and the need to see changes brought about. The walk was organized by the Penticton Indian Band, Okanagan Nation Alliance, South Okanagan Metis Society and the City of Penticton and all had representatives who spoke.\n\nAccording to the final report on the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Indigenous women, girls and Two-Spirited individuals have 12 times the likelihood of going missing or being murdered.\n\n\u201cThere are so many lives that have been lost and so many lives we fear that will continue to be lost. We have members of our own community that have now gone and joined with their ancestors because of these kinds of tragedies,\u201d said Penticton Indian Band Chief Greg Gabriel. \u201cThe fight is not over, but the message has to remain strong.\u201d\n\nThis year\u2019s walk was made more poignant by the reminder of the suffering the local community has faced this year, as a number of those who joined the walk were outside Penticton\u2019s courthouse in January after news broke that Grace Robotti would be granted day parole.\n\nRobotti received a life sentence for killing Roxanne Louie in 2015 by beating her 26 times with a crowbar, while her brother Pier received a 27-month sentence for helping cover up the killing by dumping Louie\u2019s body on a forest service road.\n\nREAD ALSO: Anger after day parole for Penticton woman who killed great-grandson\u2019s mom\n\n\u201cThe family of our syilx person has to see her and worry about that, and that is unacceptable,\u201d said Jennifer Lewis, the Okanagan Nation Alliance wellness manager. \u201cIt\u2019s a complete disregard and lack of consequences for the justice system. We\u2019ve seen the justice system continue to prioritize offenders over victims and we\u2019ve seen a trend in the Okanagan of probation orders and protective orders given rather than jail time.\n\nThe final report following the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls delivered 231 calls for action and change. Those who joined the walk on Sunday are still waiting for those calls to be fully enacted.\n\nThe dignitaries echoed the call to keep the pressure up on elected officials and the government to make those changes and to teach and share the importance of the day and its cause.\n\nThe walk and speeches ended with a moment of silence and a performance of the Jingle Dance, a healing and prayer dance.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Brennan Phillips\n\nBrennan was raised in the Okanagan and is thankful every day that he gets to live and work in one of the most beautiful places in Canada.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tVernon cowgirl ropes in B.C. [Photo: Saskatchewan RCMP, supplied]\n- Advertisement -\n\nWith the theme, \u201cStories not Statistics\u201d, the 11th Missing Persons Week being observed in Saskatchewan is aiming to see the people and the stories of their lives.\n\nThe Saskatchewan RCMP is honouring the thousands of people who go missing each year in the province by bringing the humanity of their lives to the fore.\n\nStill, it notes that last year, 2,533 individuals were reported missing to detachments. Of the 550 missing males, 450 missing females and 1,150 youths reported missing in 2023, Kristopher Billette of Buffalo River Dene Nation, Byron Watson of Maple Creek, and William \u201cMichael\u201d Neuman of Canora remain missing. More details on Saskatchewan\u2019s long-term missing persons are available online.\n\nThe province held its second Walk to Honour the Missing in Wascana Park on Monday.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cSaskatchewan\u2019s long-term missing are more than just statistics in police files,\u201d said Justice Minister and Attorney General Bronwyn Eyre. \u201cThey are loved and deeply missed by their families and friends, and we hope that, as we mark Missing Persons Week, we can help support loved ones, while raising awareness about missing person cases in Saskatchewan.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, in Lloydminster, the Native Friendship Centre will host events to mark Red Dress Day beginning at 10:30 a.m. The group will lead a walk downtown from City Hall at noon. A luncheon will follow at which a family will share about their missing loved one.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nNews\nLashburn gets $83K SGI grant for pathway for recreation facility\nNews\nCity property inspections north of 44 Street this summer\nNews\nMen\u2019s Shelter head to run across Alberta, Saskatchewan in August fundraiser\nNews\nAlberta, Saskatchewan premiers to discuss energy at Lloydminster Heavy Oil Show in September\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nLashburn gets $83K SGI grant for pathway for recreation facility\n \nCity property inspections north of 44 Street this summer\n \nMen\u2019s Shelter head to run across Alberta, Saskatchewan in August fundraiser\n \nAlberta, Saskatchewan premiers to discuss energy at Lloydminster Heavy Oil Show in September\n \nLocal trio score Synergy Shares Scholarships\nAlberta and Saskatchewan discuss healthcare in Lloydminster\n \nOccupied RV hijacked and crashed at Weaver Park Campground\n \nAlberta health minister meets Saskatchewan health minister in Lloydminster\n \nLloydminster hosts U11 Girls Advanced Provincials\n \nLloydminster golfers take their shot at RBC PGA Scramble, Jul. 13\nLoon Lake RCMP seek suspect\n \nOn average seven people die in July due to impaired driving: SGI\n \nLakeland College Rustlers teams hosting conference finals in 2025\n \nPolice seek Jordan Keenan-Quewezance, advise do not approach\n \nPublic meeting to discuss Lloydminster Library on Aug. 8\nThe GOAT\u2019s Christmas Wish\n \nEXCLUSIVE: Lloyd Homeless Issued $580 Fines, Evictions\n \nCanadian Indigenous Music\n \nDONATE TO THE GOAT\u2019S CHRISTMAS WISH \u2013 OCTOBER 19\n \nGoat Christmas Wish Radiothon\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nContact Us\nAdvertise\nWe\u2019re Hiring"},
{"url": "http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/bc-transportation-minister-says-highway-of-tears-changes-coming/article27495518/", "title": "B.C. transportation minister says changes coming to Highway of Tears - The Globe and Mail", "body": "Skip to main content\nSEARCH\nNEWSLETTERS\nWATCHLIST\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nHOME\nFOR YOU\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nINVESTING\nPERSONAL FINANCE\nOPINION\nPOLITICS\nSPORTS\nLIFE\nARTS\nDRIVE\nREAL ESTATE\nB.C. transportation minister says changes coming to Highway of Tears\nVICTORIA\nTHE CANADIAN PRESS\nPUBLISHED NOVEMBER 26, 2015\n\nThis article was published more than 8 years ago. Some information may no longer be current.\n\nA sign warning residents and visitiors that a killer is at work along the Highway of Tears stands in Moricetown, British Columbia, in this 2011 file photo.\nRAFAL GERSZAK\n\nCOMMENTS\nSHARE\n\nBritish Columbia is set to announce transportation service upgrades along the so-called Highway of Tears, but the minister responsible says a region-wide shuttle bus sought by First Nations won't be part of the plan.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone said he's considering options such as supporting volunteer-driven vans that link First Nations reserves with communities, improving existing transit schedules and expanding use of a bus that takes people to and from medical appointments.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or disappeared along Highway 16 and adjacent routes since the 1970s. The highway stretches about 750 kilometres across the centre of the province from Prince George to Prince Rupert.\n\n\"My intentions are to develop and launch a provincial strategy on this that will represent our next steps to enhance transportation services in the corridor, and to do so fairly quickly,\" Mr. Stone said Thursday.\n\nHe said he expects to announce changes within weeks.\n\n\"This is one of the top priorities on my desk at the moment and there has been a lot of valuable discussion, lots of goodwill demonstrated by everyone involved, so my goal is to act as quickly as I possibly can.\"\n\nHe said transportation options were discussed earlier this week at meetings in Smithers, with almost 100 people attending, including First Nations, community leaders and government officials.\n\nMr. Stone said he's reviewing proposals including improvement of existing BC Transit schedules between neighbouring communities such as Houston and Smithers and Terrace and Prince Rupert. He's also considering suggestions to open a health-appointment bus in the north to passengers in general.\n\n\"Let's see if we can't get more butts into the seats,\" Mr. Stone said.\n\nThe minister said he's on board with expanding a current volunteer transit service that links First Nations communities in the Fort St. James area with neighbouring communities of Vanderhoof and Prince George.\n\n\"This community-based van service, I think there's a winner there,\" Mr. Stone said. \"I think there's an opportunity to take that best practice and replicate it in other areas through the corridor.\"\n\nMr. Stone said he remains adamant that a regional shuttle bus service favoured by many First Nations is a non-starter. Government documents released recently pegged annual operating costs of a regular shuttle service between Prince George and Prince Rupert at less than $1-million.\n\n\"These are all potentially practical, sustainable solutions,\" Mr. Stone said. \"They don't involve establishing a scheduled shuttle bus from Prince Rupert to Prince George.\n\nOpposition New Democrat Jennifer Rice, who represents the Prince Rupert area, said she's disappointed that Mr. Stone continues to reject a regional shuttle bus.\n\nMs. Rice said she attended the Smithers meeting and spoke with people who have lost family members along the highway. They were disappointed a shuttle bus is being giving short shrift, she said.\n\n\"People have been calling for that for quite a long time. We spend more money on twinning highways.\"\n\nMs. Rice said she's awaiting further details of Mr. Stone's plans.\n\nMr. Stone recently said the highway issue could be part of an inquiry the federal government may call into Canada's murdered and missing women.\n\nAn RCMP report last year stated nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nSign up for the B.C. (Brennan Phillips - Western News)\n\nThrough pelting rain, more than 50 people in Penticton came out to show their commitment to remembering and honouring the man Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirited Individuals.\n\nIndigenous and non-Indigenous people alike participated in the Red Dress Day walk. The sound of hand drums led the way from the Ooknakane Friendship Centre to Gyro Park, where dignitaries spoke about the importance of the day.\n\nThe red dress has become a symbol that embodies the lives lost and to serve as a powerful reminder of the work that still lies ahead to achieve justice and equity for all.\n\n\u201cMany North American Indigenous peoples believe that red is the only colour spirits can see, and we wear red as a way of calling the spirits of the missing and murdered women and girls back to their loved ones,\u201d said Ooknakane Friendship Centre executive director Shauna Fox.\n\nREAD MORE: Penticton Secondary students honour lost Indigenous lives with Red Dress Day\n\nMayor Julius Bloomfield, MLA Dan Ashton and MP Richard Cannings all expressed their support, both personally and on behalf of their respective levels of government, for recognizing the many lost Indigenous lives and for the need to move towards a more inclusive future society.\n\nAccording to the final report on the National Inquiring into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, Indigenous women, girls and Two-Spirited individuals have 12 times the likelihood of going missing or being murdered.\n\nMore than six out of every 10 Indigenous women have experienced physical assault, and Indigenous women are almost six times more likely than non-Indigenous women to have ever been under the legal responsibility of the government, with 81 per cent of all those who were having experienced violent victimization.\n\nThe Walk for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirited individuals made their way through Penticton on Friday, May 5, otherwise known as Red Dress Day. (Supplied photo)\nArticle content\n\nHOSTAGE SQUARE, TEL AVIV \u2014 They haven\u2019t missed it. They\u2019ve seen what\u2019s happening on our campuses.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThey\u2019ve seen and read the news reports \u2014 reports showing over-privileged white Gen Z and millennial types in keffiyahs, demanding if the visitors to their campus encampments, their \u201cLittle Gazas,\u201d are Jews. They\u2019ve seen the chanted tributes to Hamas and Iran and the horrors of Oct. 7. They\u2019ve seen all that.\n\nAnd they\u2019re disgusted. They\u2019re shocked. They\u2019re appalled.\n\nThey\u2019re absolutely baffled why young Canadians \u2014 and young Americans, and young Europeans \u2014 are openly expressing so much contempt towards the Jewish state.\n\nIn other circumstances, at other times, Israelis are used to seeing protests against them in Canada and the United States and Europe. Those protests have been happening, more or less continuously, since Israel was founded in 1948. They\u2019re not new.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBut the anti-Israel encampments at places of higher learning in North America \u2014 the pro-Hamas, pro-Iran, pro-terror encampments, in too many cases? That, they can\u2019t believe. That is new.\n\nAt a table selling T-shirts and bracelets to raise funds for the families of the 128 Oct. 7th hostages, Judy Goldman shakes her head. Goldman is a former Montrealer, and still has family in Toronto and the Vancouver area.\n\nShe\u2019s present this day with a dark-haired friend, whose son, 23-year-old Yosef Haim Ohana, is still being held hostage by Hamas. Her friend doesn\u2019t want to talk about politics, she says. But Judy does. She has a few things to get off her mind.\n\n\u201cI am shocked by what I have seen at these campuses,\u201d she says. \u201cShocked. It is pure anti-Semitism.\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cAnti-Semitism is always there. It bubbles underneath the surface. Any excuse can bring it out. But I\u2019m very surprised to see what young Canadians, at universities in places like Toronto, are doing.\u201d She shakes her head again.\n\nRecommended video\n\nShe continues: \u201cIt\u2019s shocking, because universities are supposed to be places where morality is taught. And what\u2019s happening in those places is just outlandish. It shouldn\u2019t be happening! At places like McGill, too, which I know well.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s normal for young people to be preoccupied with issues like climate change or the future, says Judy. But to praise Hamas, who slaughtered 1,200 men, women, children and babies on Oct. 7, 2023? \u201cIt is absolutely beyond words,\u201d says Judy.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nA few feet away, at a booth that has been set up for the hostages taken from the kibbutz Nahal Oz, Iris Shellhav Nahal is talking to whoever will listen. She\u2019s wearing a T-shirt bearing the images of some of her neighbours who were killed or kidnapped on Oct. 7.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s terrible,\u201d she says of the encampments and protests.\u00a0 \u201cWhat I have seen? It\u2019s not good. Where did [the students] get these terrible ideas? They\u2019re ignorant. They don\u2019t know history \u2014 they don\u2019t know what Hamas means to us!\u201d\n\nIris softens a bit and leans back in her chair. \u201cSome of the students, I\u2019m sure they\u2019re not bad people,\u201d she says, pausing. \u201cBut how can they say we are so terrible when we are the ones who were attacked first? It\u2019s just terrible.\u201d\n\nNext door, there is a booth to promote the memory of the victims of the Re\u2019im Music Festival on the 7th. There\u2019s an older man sitting there, but he doesn\u2019t speak English.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nTwo women who are present, Liora and Aziza \u2014 they speak a little English, but not so well, they say \u2014 won\u2019t give their last names. \u201cIt makes me mad,\u201d says Liora of the encampments. Says Aziza: \u201cWe know kids who were killed at the music festival. Why don\u2019t these kids in Canada and America understand? They look like our kids.\u201d\n\nAsked why they think young people in Western universities have embraced the hateful rhetoric of Hamas and its ilk, all of\u00a0 the women have theories about that, too. They speculate that there are many anti-Israel Muslims or Arabs at North American universities who have manipulated the protests they see in TV. They also wonder if the ones camped out have been brainwashed by their professors.\n\nAt the same booth where Judy Goldman volunteers, a lovely woman from Manchester is working. Her name is Sara Omer, and she still has a thick Manchurian accent.\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSara explains she has three sons in the Israel Defence Force, one stationed this day in southern Gaza. He\u2019s been sleeping under the stars, she says, and he\u2019s excited that some toilets and showers have finally been shipped in. She smiles when she talks about him.\n\nSara\u2019s husband was killed in military action a few years back, and she works with the hostage families, she says, because she understands what it means to lose someone to the fight for Israel.\n\nShe doesn\u2019t, however, understand how any North American young person can raise their voice in support of a racist, hateful death cult like Hamas.\n\nAdvertisement 9\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI read the New York Times every day,\u201d Sara says.\u00a0 \u201cI read over the weekend that in Columbia University, 60% at the encampments are just outsiders. They\u2019re not students. They\u2019re outsiders, and they\u2019re coming, and they\u2019re firing up the others.\n\nShe goes on: \u201cAnd some of the students who were interviewed \u2014\u00a0 they don\u2019t even know what they\u2019re protesting. They don\u2019t understand.\n\n\u201cIt makes my blood boil.\u201d\n\nTwo things to conclude with: Everyone here \u2014 everyone this writer spoke to \u2014 is here because they want to be. Not only do they not work for the Netanyahu government, they\u2019re furious with the Netanyahu government. They want the hostages home, now, and feel the Israeli Prime Minister has botched the job.\n\nThe other thing: Everyone here is carefully watching what is happening in North America, at supposed places of higher education. They haven\u2019t missed it.\n\nAnd they don\u2019t understand it. {"url": "https://kitchener.ctvnews.ca/event-in-kitchener-honours-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-people-on-red-dress-day-1.6874462", "title": "Event in Kitchener honours Missing and Murdered Indigenous people on Red Dress Day | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News At Five\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nKITCHENER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nKITCHENER\nNews\nEvent in Kitchener honours Missing and Murdered Indigenous people on Red Dress Day\nHannah Schmidt\nCTV News Kitchener Videographer\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 5, 2024 4:05 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nThe sound of drums and chants rang throughout downtown Kitchener Sunday.\n\nIt was part of a solemn occasion to remember Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit people across the country.\n\n\u201cIf you know somebody who's missing and murdered, this is your opportunity to allow them to travel in peace and say your goodbyes,\u201d said Donna Dubie, executive director of The Healing of the Seven Generations.\n\nA crowd, adorned in red, marched through the streets of Kitchener to acknowledge the country\u2019s dark history and the healing that still needs to be done.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nShirt stolen from Indigenous memorial in Kitchener\nRed Dresses displayed at University of Waterloo to honour MMIWG2S\nHow a dance program is encouraging Indigenous youth to complete high school\n\n\u201cWe've been calling for it for a couple of years now - to search the landfills because we know that some of our women are there and they haven't done it,\u201d Dubie said.\n\nPeople marched through Kitchener on May 5, 2024 in honour of Red Dress Day. (Hannah Schmidt/CTV News)\n\nIt was an especially emotional day for Serena Wesley who says she was nine-years-old when her mother was killed by her boyfriend in 1986.\n\n\u201cI walk for my mom, Roberta Chafe Wesley. She was a part of the residential school, a day school survivor, and I understand her more now as an adult than I ever did as a child,\u201d she said.\n\nWhen Red Dress Day comes around each year on May 5, Wesley still thinks of her mother, but also of all the other victims that have died or are still missing.\n\n\u201cIt is literally a worry for me every day that Indigenous young girls, you know, they can walk out the door and possibly not come back.\u201d\n\n150 red dresses and pants were displayed throughout Kitchener\u2019s Victoria Park to serve as a tribute to the lives lost.\n\n\u201cSometimes I feel hopeless and at other times I feel all you can do is try to do what you can do and to live your life as an ally, to support and try to help create change one voice at a time,\u201d said attendee Mark Wotton.\n\nThe significance of Red Dress Day extends beyond just one day of remembrance. It's a call to action for groups to address the root causes of violence against Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit individuals.\n\n\u201cIf they understand where our fears come from and why we are the way we are and generational trauma they can maybe understand it, they can help break the cycle,\u201d Wesley explained.\n\n\u201cI'm honoured to be a part of it and I also feel that it's my responsibility because, yes, the community has become involved, but it's a small part of the community,\u201d Wotton said. \u201cThere's so many people that are either indifferent to it or don't support it. The governments have not been as proactive or active and just focusing on the harm that has already happened to Indigenous people, but not the harm that happens every day.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day comes just days after The Healing of the Seven Generations reported a theft from their cultural display to police.\n\n\u201cThis year we got vandalized and it's just an indicator to say where people are in their own mindset to have to come in and vandalize something that was a memorial. Why would they do that?\u201d Dubie questioned.\n\nRegional police are continuing to investigate the matter and encourage anyone with information to contact them.\n\nFor the Indigenous community in Waterloo Region, their narrative remains the same.\n\n\u201cThings need to step up,\u201d Dubie said. \u201cThe safety of our children and the safety of our kids depends on that.\u201d\n\n\u201cI hope that if my mom was here today, she would be proud to embrace her culture like we\u2019re proud to live it and teach it and to make sure that she's a part of her granddaughters\u2019 lives and helping them grow and learn that culture and not let that residential school kill her spirit,\u201d Wesley said.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nCut outs of red clothing are displayed on the lawn of Victoria Park in Kitchener, each baring the name of a murdered or missing Indigenous person. May 5, 2024. 2021\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nChiefDolleen Logan (Photo provided by by Kevin Brown)\n- Advertisement -\n\nToday was declared \u2018Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People Awareness Day\u2019 in Prince George.\n\nOn a national level, May 5th is \u2018Red Dress Day\u2019 across Canada, which signifies awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada.\n\nLheidli T\u2019enneh Chief Dolleen Logan says today is particularly important for Northern BC, given the region\u2019s long, dark history with the Highway of Tears.\n\n\u201cWhile it\u2019s a national problem, most Indigenous nations and communities have had members go missing, the majority of course of those being women, but the national spotlight on this issue is often here in BC and into Alberta,\u201d explained Logan.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nShe says that while it\u2019s unfortunate that the Highway of Tears is located in BC, it only amplifies the need for recognition across the province.\n\nChief Logan also says that this day provides an opportunity to emphasize a very important lesson to women and girls in Northern BC.\n\n\u201cWe want to get the word out to these young girls, please do not hitchhike, and please do not be alone,\u201d added Chief Logan.\n\nShe noted people in more rural Northern communities often have to rely on hitchhiking to get to where they need to be, simply because there are no other transportation options available.\n\n\u201cPeople hitch-hike, they\u2019ll take rides and unfortunately we don\u2019t have a Greyhound anymore and people will continue to take rides, it\u2019s scary,\u201d she stated.\n\nGreyhound ceased operations across Northern BC in 2018, which eliminated routes between Prince George, Dawson Creek, Prince Rupert and Valemount.\n\nSince then, BC Bus North has attempted to fill the gap in transportation opportunities in the North, however, there is still a dire need for services in the region.\n\nSomething going on in the Prince George area you think people should know about?\nSend us a news tip by emailing pgnews@vistaradio.ca.\n\n- Advertisement The students and staff arranged a display at the entrance of the school with a red dress, a basket of moosehide pins and cards of information about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Woman and Girls (MMIWG) pinned to the dress.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nSome of the information on the dress displayed at EHS includes that Indigenous women are 12 times more likely to go missing or be murdered than other women, requests to the readers to educate themselves on the subject, that 34% of Indigenous women will be sexually violated, that 40% of Indigenous women will experience violence from their partner, and other facts. The basket of pins from the Moose Hide tag Campaign are symbols showing that the wearer opposes violence against women and all those in the gender continuum.\n\nThe National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls started in 2010. It is a solemn event marked by displays, marches and processions each year and is a call to action.\n\nOn May 4, Roseanne Archibald, the Assembly of First Nations National Chief, spoke with King Charles III in London about supporting the results of Canada\u2019s National Inquiry into MMIWG.\n\nDisplaying a red dress is encouraged on Red Dress Day and the hanging of empty dresses are visual reminders of the thousands of missing women and girls. Students and staff at EHS have shown their support for the losses of the women and the pain felt by their families.\n\nPhoto credit to Jayson StewartTo honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, students and staff placed a red dress with information and a basket of moose hide tags in the foyer of Espanola High School.\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR KIRKLAND LAKE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://nativenewsonline.net/currents/mmip-red-dress-installation-vandalized-in-alaska", "title": "MMIP Red Dress Installation Vandalized in Alaska | Currents", "body": "Skip to main content\nEnable accessibility for visually impaired\nOpen the accessibility menu\nOpen the Accessible Navigation Menu\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\nDONATE\nGET NEWSLETTER\nHOME\n  \nCURRENTS\n \nOPINION\n \nSOVEREIGNTY\n \nEDUCATION\n \nA & E\n \nHEALTH\n \nENVIRONMENT\n \nADVERTISE \n \nCLASSIFIEDS\n \nIMPACT\n \nHERITAGE UNBOUND\n\u00a0\nMMIP Red Dress Installation Vandalized in Alaska\nYahoo News\n\n(photo:Facebook)\n\nBY ELYSE WILD  JUNE 06, 2023\nA Missing and Murdered Indigenous People (MMIP) installation in Alaska was vandalized late last month,\u00a0a local radio station reported.\n\n\u00a0\nThe installation was created by the Ketchikan Indian Community (KIC). It featured 60 red dresses hung from trees around Ward Lake \u2014 located in Southeast Alaska on Revillagigedo Island \u2014 each representing an Indigenous person from\u00a0Ketchikan, Saxman, Prince of Wales Island, and Metlakatla\u00a0 who is missing or has been murdered.\n\u00a0\n\nThe garments were installed on May 15 to commemorate MMIP Awareness Month under a permit KIC held from the U.S. Forestry Service. By the time the installation was scheduled to come down on May 31, 48 of the dresses were missing. In recent days, photos have been surfacing on social media\u00a0showing some of the dresses crumpled near the lakeside trail, half buried or discarded in piles near drain pipes.\n\nNever miss Indian Country\u2019s biggest stories and breaking news.\u00a0Sign up to get our reporting sent straight to your inbox every weekday morning.\u00a0\n\u00a0\nEnter your email\n\u00a0\n\nThe tribe\u2019s council issued a statement condemning \u201ca hurtful and disrespectful act that undermines the efforts to bring understanding and raise awareness about the MMIP epidemic.\u201d\u00a0\n\nSimilar installations are featured throughout Canada and the United States during May to bring awareness to the disproportionate number of Indigenous people who are victims of violent crimes or go missing.\u00a0\n\nMurder is the third leading cause of death for Native women, with the murder rate ten times higher than the national average for women living on reservations,\u00a0according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\u00a0In 2021,\u00a0Alaska reported\u00a0229 cases of missing and murdered Indigenous persons \u2014 149 missing and 80 murdered.\n\nGloria Burns, KIC\u2019s vice president and the chair of the social services committee, told\u00a0local radio station KRBD\u00a0that the tribe hung the dresses with remembrance and intention in an effort to create a \u201csafe space.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\u201cAnd so when you\u2019re going through that process of trying to create a safe space, and then it\u2019s intentionally made unsafe, it feels very much like a violation,\u201d Burns told KRBD. \u201cI think, you know, the hard part is that missing and murdered indigenous people, it\u2019s been happening since colonization, we really don\u2019t talk about it. We really haven\u2019t spoken those to the outside community.\u201d\n\nAnyone with information on the vandalization is encouraged to contact local law enforcement.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nMore Stories Like This\nWe Asked, You Answered: How Indian Country is Celebrating the Fourth of July\nRep. {"url": "https://www.miragenews.com/ministers-issue-statement-for-red-dress-day-2024-1228359/", "title": "Ministers Issue Statement for Red Dress Day 2024 | Mirage News", "body": "National\nWorld\nLocal\nBusiness\nTechnology\nScience\nLife\nTimeline\nLATEST\nWoman Charged Over Unauthorised Protest in Hunter Valley 5 July\nGov't Response to Job Reform Blueprint Ignores Key Issues\nMan Charged With Murder Conspiracy\nMinisters Announce Investments to Support Canadian Athletes\nWHISE Appoints New CEO, Thanks Outgoing Leadership\nCanada Urged to Act Fast on Undocumented Migrants' Legal Status\nNew Bill Proposes Human Right to Housing: How It Works\nNSW Urged to Buy Toll Roads Amid High Fees, Shortages\nElectric Trucks Lead Hydrogen in Australia's Freight Decarbonization\nResearch Suggests Better Thyroid Cancer Detection\nWorld\n05 MAY 2024 11:03 PM AEST\nShare\nMinisters Issue Statement for Red Dress Day 2024\nCrown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs Canada\n\nThe Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Crisis Line is a national, toll-free, 24/7 crisis call line that provides support for anyone who requires emotional assistance related to the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people. For assistance, call 1-844-413-6649.\n\nTrauma-informed support is also available to all those impacted by the ongoing crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people through the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Health and Cultural Support Program. The program funds access to cultural support (e.g., Elders, Knowledge Holders, and Traditional Healers), emotional support (e.g., community-based health workers, peer supports), and registered mental health counsellors (e.g., psychologists, and social workers).\n\nOttawa, Ontario (May 5, 2024) - Traditional unceded Algonquin Territory\n\nToday, the Honourable Gary Anandasangaree, Minister of Crown-Indigenous Relations; the Honourable Patty Hajdu, Minister of Indigenous Services and Minister responsible for FedNor; the Honourable Dan Vandal, Minister of Northern Affairs; and the Honourable Marci Ien, Minister for Women and Gender Equality and Youth; issued the following statement:\n\n\"Since M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black began the REDress Project in 2010, red dresses hanging in public spaces have become a stark visual reminder of every Indigenous woman, girl, Two-Spirit, and gender-diverse person in Canada who has gone missing or been murdered.\n\n\"Today, on Red Dress Day, we honour every First Nation, Inuit, and M\u00e9tis life lost to this crisis, and we reaffirm our efforts to bring the missing home. Ahead of Red Dress Day, the governments of Canada and Manitoba announced a partnership to co-develop a pilot Red Dress Alert system together with Indigenous partners. This was made possible by the $1.3 million investment included in Budget 2024. Alert systems can help ensure that when an Indigenous woman, girl, Two-Spirit or gender-diverse person goes missing, they are found.\n\n\"We stand united in affirming our unwavering commitment to addressing this national crisis and collectively working toward a secure, violence-free future for all Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people. We also recognize that means supporting grassroots, Indigenous-led and community-driven change through housing, shelters, policing, and infrastructure initiatives, such as the Inuvialuit Family Wellness Centre that provides shelter for Indigenous women and families in Inuvik, the Indigenous Victim and Family Liaison Program that helps individuals and family members navigate culturally-appropriate health and wellbeing supports, and new rural public transit studies to better connect communities undertaken by the Nahanni Butte First Nation, Yellowknives Dene First Nation, and the Hay River M\u00e9tis Government.\n\n\"The work to end the national crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit, and gender diverse people is ongoing, and a lot more remains to be done. The federal government is committed to learning from Indigenous partners in a way that respects our shared priorities. We will continue to use the Federal Pathway, the National Action Plan\n\n/Public Release. {"url": "https://rabble.ca/indigenous/red-dress-alert-motion-receives-unanimous-support-from-mps/", "title": "Red Dress Alert motion receives unanimous support from MPs", "body": "Skip to content\nHOME\nABOUT RABBLE.CA\nIN CAHOOTS PARTNERS\nADVERTISE\nCONTACT\nFACEBOOK\nTWITTER\nINSTAGRAM\nLINKEDIN\nYOUTUBE\nSPOTIFY\n\nrabble.ca\n\nDONATE FREE \nPOLITICS\nCANADIAN POLITICS\nUS POLITICS\nWORLD POLITICS\nKARL NERENBERG\n LABOUR ENVIRONMENT INDIGENOUS ACTIVISM\nACTIVIST TOOLKIT\n PODCASTS\nRABBLE RADIO\nRADIOLABOUR\nNEEDS NO INTRODUCTION\n RABBLETV MORE\nCOLUMNISTS\nBOOKS\nLGBTIQ\nHUMAN RIGHTS\nFEMINISM\nTECHNOLOGY\nHEALTH\nECONOMY\nEDUCATION\nOpen Search\nHome \u00bb Indigenous \u00bb Red Dress Alert motion receives unanimous support from MPs\nNEWS\nPOSTED IN\nINDIGENOUSCA\nRed Dress Alert motion receives unanimous support from MPs\nby Nick Seebruch\nMay 5, 2023\n\nMPs have backed the idea of creating a Red Dress Alert system, but the federal government has historically moved slowly on addressing the crisis of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit persons.\n\nWinnipeg Centre NDP MP Leah Gazan speaking to the media after the vote on her motion for a national Red Dress Alert system on Tuesday, May 2, 2023. Credit: CPAC Credit: CPAC\n\nContent warning: The following story contains details of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. Individuals impacted by the issue of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls can contact the MMIWG Crisis Line toll-free at 1-844-413-6649.\n\nMay 5 is Red Dress Day, a day where Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit persons (MMIWG2S) are recognized and remembered.\n\nOn May 2, the House of Commons voted unanimously in favour of declaring\u00a0MMIWG2S a nation-wide emergency and also agreed to provide funding for an alert system to inform the public when an Indigenous person is missing.\n\nWinnipeg Centre NDP MP Leah Gazan has long called for a national Red Dress Alert system, and it was her motion that received universal backing from her colleagues in the House of Commons.\n\n\u201cThis is a crisis,\u201d said Gazan on Tuesday. \u201cPeople are going murdered and missing everyday. We are precious. We are valuable. We are loved and we are not garbage.\u201d\n\nGazan was referring in her statement to the bodies of Indigenous women from her riding being found in a Winnipeg landfill in late 2022 and early 2023.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI\u2019m standing alongside my sisters today, to support their calls on the government to fully support a Canada-wide Emergency, and immediately support the development of a Canada-wide Red Dress Alert system without delay,\u201d Gazan added.\n\nIn addition to the Canada-wide emergency and Red Dress Alert system, Gazan also called on the government for a housing and social support system for children aging out of the childcare system. She has also been calling for a guaranteed livable basic income and is asking the government to carry out prevention initiatives that honour the rights of Indigenous women and girls and two-spirit peoples.\n\nMMIWG2S an ongoing crisis\n\nIndigenous peoples make up five per cent of Canada\u2019s total population, but according to Canada\u2019s own Ministry of Justice, in 2017 Indigenous women accounted for 10 per cent of all missing Canadian women. In 2014, Indigenous women accounted for 21 per cent of all murdered women in Canada.\n\nEven in the same week where the Red Dress Alert initiative found strong political support in Ottawa, stories of assault against Indigenous women continued to appear in headlines in Canada.\n\nThe body of an eight-year-old Indigenous girl was found near Samson Cree First Nation in Alberta, the autopsy concluding the girl was a victim of homicide.\n\nSandra Delaronde of the Cross Lake First Nation and co-chair of Manitoba\u2019s MMIWG2S Coalition spoke at a press conference alongside Gazan after the House of Commons vote.\n\n\u201cWe have no time to waste. Everyday that goes by, we have at least two women and girls that go missing,\u201d she said. \u201cWe have on a weekly basis, our Indigenous sisters, mothers, daughters and granddaughters that go murdered. The time to wait is gone.\u201d\n\nGovernment has been slow to respond to MMIWG2S crisis\n\nIn 2021, the federal government announced a national action plan to address 231 calls to action that were issued by a national inquiry into MMIWG2S, however, one year after it was introduced, the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) found that few of the calls to action had been implemented.\n\nREAD MORE: One year after introducing action plan, feds continue to abandon MMIWG\n\nIn a press release sent by the NWAC to media prior to Tuesday\u2019s vote, Mel Critch co-chair of Manitoba Moon Voices Inc. blasted the federal government for their continued lack of action.\n\n\u201cThis is alarming and needs to be addressed immediately due to the on-going genocide, compounded by the lack of implementation of the 231 Calls for Justice and therefore lack of human security our Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples face,\u201d said Critch.\n\nThe unanimous consent motion introduced by Gazan and passed in the House of Commons was non-binding, but Gazan said that this massive show of support from MPs should push the government to take steps to make a Red Dress Alert system a reality.\n\n\u201cWhen I put forward that unanimous consent motion today, if members of Parliament and this House really care about gender-based violence; if this government really cares about gender-based violence, I will feel affirmed to know that there will be nobody opposing in the House. And we will be watching. This genocide needs to end. We are not garbage,\u201d Gazan said.\n\nSupport rabble today!\n\nWe\u2019re so glad you stopped by! These women were children one time too, and they were mothers. Mothers that lost their children.\"\n\nThe walk was organized by the Jane Paul Centre, a not-for-profit community organization that tries to help Indigenous women living in the city.\n\nOrganizer Heidi Marshall says many in the community deal with homelessness, violence, poverty and addiction, and more help is needed.\n\n\"All our services and programs are made and developed from a colonial perspective,\u201d said Marshall.\n\n\"We need to ensure that our peoples' voices are being heard in any type of service that we're providing these women, girls and our people as well.\"\n\nRELATED {"url": "https://www.coastreporter.net/local-news/shishalh-nation-honours-red-dress-day-6960448", "title": "sh\u00edsh\u00e1lh Nation honours Red Dress Day - Coast Reporter", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\n18.5 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nsh\u00edsh\u00e1lh Nation honours Red Dress Day\nMay 5 is a day of awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People\n\tKeili Bartlett\n\nMay 5, 2023 3:00 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 2 sh\u00edsh\u00e1lh Nation placed 10 red dresses to honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People.Keili Bartlett\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:04:24\n\nOn May 5, 10 red dresses were hung from the rafters of the sh\u00edsh\u00e1lh Nation administration building, their colourful fabric twirling in the wind as they carry a powerful message: \u201cNo more stolen sisters.\u201d\u00a0\n\nIt\u2019s the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), also known as Red Dress Day. Ceremonies and similar displays will be taking place across the country.\n\nThe dresses were raised by a boom lift and come from the Pathways to Higher Learning students, sh\u00edsh\u00e1lh Nation said in a social media post. The students were inspired after attending the MMIWG March in Vancouver\u00a0on Feb. 14.\n\n\"The event in Vancouver is especially important to our community as it was started to remember and honour the loss of one of our own community members. Our students were so moved by the event, that they wanted to do more and from that came the Red Dress project you see in front of our Nation buildings. Each dress is a personal work of art, created by our students to express their feelings,\"\u00a0sh\u00edsh\u00e1lh Nation's post said.\u00a0\n\n\"The dresses are hung to represent the women who have not made it home, who are missing and murdered. We want to show the world that they matter. Great Gratitude to leadership for standing behind this project and helping to make it a reality. Great Gratitude to our students for the beautiful, meaningful and impactful works of art now hanging from the eaves of the Nation offices.\"\n\nCalls to action\n\nOn May 2, the House of Commons unanimously backed a motion to declare the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. That motion also calls for funding a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nEven though the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls was released four years ago not much has changed, said Carol McBride, the head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada. \u201cWe are in a crisis.\u201d\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has created the website SafePassage, a \"community-driven, trauma-informed, and survivor centred initiative\" that \"tracks cases of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, transgender, gender-diverse, and Two-Spirit people (MMIWG2S+), monitors ongoing safety concerns, provides distinctions-based safety resources, educates the public and media about the MMIWG2S+ genocide, and commemorates and honours our stolen loved ones.\"\n\nThe report\n\nThe final report of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\u00a0was released in June 2019 and came after two years of public hearings and evidence gathering across the country where the inquiry heard from more than 2,380 \"family members, survivors of violence, experts and Knowledge Keepers,\"\u00a0according to the inquiry website. The final report identified 231 calls for justice for \"governments, institutions, social service providers, industries and all Canadians\" under themes\u00a0of\u00a0culture, health and wellness, human security, and justice.\n\n\"The truths shared in these National Inquiry hearings tell the story \u2013 or, more accurately, thousands of stories \u2013 of acts of genocide against First Nations, Inuit and M\u00e9tis women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA people,\" says the introduction to the final report's executive summary. \"This violence amounts to a race-based genocide of Indigenous Peoples, including First Nations, Inuit, and M\u00e9tis, which especially targets women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA people.\n\n\"This genocide has been empowered by colonial structures, evidenced notably by the Indian Act, the Sixties Scoop, residential schools, and breaches of human and Inuit, M\u00e9tis and First Nations rights, leading directly to the current increased rates of violence, death, and suicide in Indigenous populations.\"\n\nFollowing the report's release, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised to develop and implement a national action plan to address MMIWG2S+, which was released in 2021.\u00a0A\u00a0progress report was\u00a0produced\u00a0in 2022.\u00a0\n\nWith files from Kelly Geraldine Malone, The Canadian Press\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the {"url": "https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/red-dress-day-events-taking-place-across-manitoba-1.6385868", "title": "Red Dress Day being marked in Manitoba | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nWINNIPEG\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nWINNIPEG\nNews\nHundreds march as Red Dress Day is marked across Manitoba\n03:29\nRed Dress Day in Winnipeg\n01:38\nRed Dress Day marked in Manitoba\n04:51\nThe importance of Red Dress Day\nTaylor Brock\nCTV Winnipeg Late Anchor\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2023 6:37 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2023 10:19 a.m. MDT\nShare\n\nIn a powerful moment in Downtown Winnipeg, hundreds of people walked hand-in-hand to the beat of traditional drums and signing, honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people.\n\nThe National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), otherwise known as Red Dress Day was marked in Winnipeg, Manitoba and across the country.\n\nDrums beat, singers chanted and a round dance began at Portage Avenue and Main Street in memory of the missing and murdered.\n\n\"I lost my mother 21 years ago now, and we're not collectively seeing action being taken to address this and put a stop to it,\" said Tammy Wolfe.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nA lifetime of agony: Families of missing, murdered Inuit women call for answers\n'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\nWinnipeg landfill search feasibility study completed\nIndigenous women more likely to face violence if they were a child in care: report\nNDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women\n\n\"The work that we do is in honour and memory of our loved ones so to say that we're going to stop fighting for that - that's just not going to happen.\"\n\nThe sea of people dressed in red marched through Downtown Winnipeg, pouring into a gathering at The Forks. There people showed their support for those with missing or murdered family and friends.\n\n\"I remember at nine years old, my sister became a poster child for being murdered and missing,\" said Elroy Fontaine, the brother of Tina Fontaine.\n\nTina's body was found in the Red River in 2014, wrapped in a duvet that was weighed down with rocks. She was 15 years old when she was killed.\n\nElroy says he often goes to MMIWG2S marches in honour of his sister.\n\n\"To try and change something, to try and change this ongoing genocide,\" he said.\n\nThe rally encouraged people to write to their local politicians, calling for action.\n\n\"We do these marches to try and open people's eyes. We have opened people's eyes, but not the right ones,\" Elroy said.\n\nHUNDREDS MARCH IN SAGKEENG FIRST NATION WHERE MORE THAN 20 CASES REMAIN UNSOLVED\n\nIn Sagkeeng First Nation, hundreds took part in a march to mark the day.\n\nIt comes after the chief of Sagkeeng voiced his disappointment earlier this week for a lack of government resources to address the 231 calls for justice outlined in the national inquiry report.\n\nSagkeeng has the most unsolved cases of missing or murdered Indigenous women and girls in Manitoba - resulting in Friday's walk taking on a personal meaning for many.\n\n\"If we suffer just one day walking for them, imagine what they go through on a daily basis. Not knowing where they are, not understanding what is happening, not realizing that there are so many other missing and murdered women too,\" said Mary Swampy, a resident of the First Nation. \"If I can do this, I'm very grateful for it.\"\n\nCurrently there are more than 20 cases of unsolved missing Indigenous women and girls from Sagkeeng First Nation.\n\nDISPLAY TO BE SET UP OVER THE WEEKEND AT HUMAN RIGHTS MUSEUM\n\nThe Canadian Museum for Human Rights is opening a display in recognition of the day. The display includes items from selected community members who have been impacted by MMIWG2S+.\n\nThe display will be set up throughout the weekend and free for people to see.\n\nIn a joint statement from Premier Heather Stefanson, Indigenous and Reconciliation and Northern Relations Minister Eileen Clarke and Families Minister Rochelle Squires, they encouraged Manitobans to join in honouring the memories of MMIWG.\n\n\"Today, we remember those who have lost their lives to gender-based violence, and we honour the healing journeys of families and communities that live with the ongoing grief of losing a loved one,\" the statement read.\n\nThe Legislative Building will be lit with an image of the red dress, which the province says is a sign to continue dialogue and bring attention to the issue.\n\n-With files from CTV's Jill Macyshon and Devon McKendrick\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nCrowds march through Downtown Winnipeg on Red Dress Day on May 5, 2023, honouring murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people. {"url": "https://www.castanetkamloops.net/news/Canada/485664/Canada-Manitoba-to-develop-Red-Dress-Alert-for-missing-Indigenous-women-and-girls", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls - Canada News - CastanetKamloops.net", "body": "29\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nFLYERSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOBITS\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nCanada\u00a0\u00a0\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nRED DRESS ALERT PLANNED\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press - May 3, 2024 / 4:13 pm | Story: 485664\nPhoto: The Canadian Press\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an Indigenous-led alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced today in Winnipeg. A red dress is hangs on a light fixture on National Day of Awareness for the prevention of violence against Indigenous women, also known as the Red Dress Day in Ottawa, Friday, May 5, 2023. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Spencer Colby\n\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\u00a0\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\u00a0\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\"This is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\" said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has lead federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\"And while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\"\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\u00a0\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year's federal and provincial budgets.\u00a0\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba's minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\n\n\"We look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\"\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2014 and Manitoba writ large \u2014 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\"It's not the only solution, but it's a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\"\n\nGazan's efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\u00a0\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\u00a0\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state's Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry's 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2014 at least for now.\n\n\"There's going to be bumps in the road \u2014 there's going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\" she said. \"Inevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\"\n\nBut it's the starting point that matters, she said. \"I think it's high time.\"\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \"for so long,\" and the deaths \"are a result of it.\"\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat's in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September 2020, Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2014 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\"Because this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\" Jesty said.\n\n\"There has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\"\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Canada News\n\n\n\nCanada\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in Parker Collegiate students and staff walked from the school to the Miles Hart Bridge to tie ribbons and make tobacco offerings in honour of those whose lives have been lost.\n\nEarlier in the day, also known as Red Dress Day. Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak hosted an awareness walk starting form their office on Selkirk Avenue.\n\n\"My heart hurts for all those who have been impacted by the nationwide crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender diverse people,\u201d said MKO Grand Chief Garrison Settee in a news release. \u201cOn behalf of MKO First Nations, I will continue to advocate for all levels of government to continue to implement the 231 Calls for Justice stemming from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. I urge other MKO citizens to stand with me in solidarity and work to end gender-based violence in our communities.\u201d\n\nMKO\u2019s call for implementation of the MMIWG inquiry\u2019s Calls for Justice was echoed by the Assembly of Manitoba Chiefs.\n\n\u201cToday is a time to take time to pause, reflect and gather in a good way to commemorate the day with ceremony, walks and gatherings,\u201d said AMC women\u2019s council chair and War Lake First Nation Chief Betsy Kennedy. \u201cWe continue to call on Canada to meaningfully involve First Nations in Manitoba to implement the outstanding recommendations of the MMIWG national inquiry as they identified ways to better protect First Nation women, girls and gender-diverse people. All First Nations women and future generations deserve to live life protected from the fear of violence or being taken.\u201d\n\nIn Winnipeg, the legislative building was due to be lit\u00a0with a symbolic red dress to shine light on the issue of MMIWG.\n\n\u201cAddressing violence, in particular the incidences of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, is a priority for the province and it is our government\u2019s intent to continue to take action to prevent and combat gender-based violence of all forms,\u201d said a statement from Manitoba Premier Heather Stefanson and Alan Lagimodiere, minister of Indigenous reconciliation and northern relations.\n\nThe North West Company, which operates Northern and NorthMart stores in many Fist Nations in northern Canada, was selling red\u00a0t-shirts in its stores to raise money for the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada. The shirts were produced by Dreamcatcher Promotions, an Indigenous-owned promo and apparel company, from a design by a 14-year-old Indigenous youth whose family has been impacted by MMIWG.\n\n\u201cThis issue affects our employees, customer and the communities served by Northern and NorthMart stores,\" said North West Company CEO Dan McConnell. \u201cWe want to do our part to help raise awareness, honour the murdered and missing and stand in solidarity with their families and friends.\u201d\n\nIn addition to selling the shirts, North West\u2019s stores, warehouses and offices were hosting a live-streamed presentation and encouraging staff to wear red, reflect, share and learn.\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis {"url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/indigenous-leaders-want-corporate-reconciliation-efforts-to-extend-beyond-sept-30-1.6091052", "title": "Sept. 30: Indigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts extended | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nPower Play\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nLOCAL\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nSHOPPING TRENDS\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nBUSINESS\nNews\nIndigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30\nFILE - Krystal Abotossaway, TD Bank Group's senior manager of diversity and inclusion, poses for a photograph in Toronto's financial district on Monday, February 8, 2020. THE CANADIAN PRESS/ Tijana Martin\nTara Deschamps\nThe Canadian Press\nStaff\nContact\nPublished Sept. 30, 2022 9:42 a.m. MDT\nShare\nTORONTO -\n\n Chelsee Pettit spent much of the summer collaborating with designers to create and manufacture apparel reflective of the Indigenous values she hoped would be on people's minds when Canada marks its second National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.\n\nBut in the days leading up to Sept. 30, she noticed many companies had not had the same forethought and were scrambling to place bulk orders with her store, Aaniin.\n\n\"It's just a little funny how last-minute other organizations that are all non-Indigenous are, and they're pushing that (work) back onto Indigenous people,\" said Pettit, an Anishinaabe woman.\n\n'Sadness and hope': Indigenous leaders, academics speak on Sept. 30 as commitments go unfulfilled\nCanadians reflect about residential schools on Truth and Reconciliation Day\nRacism blamed in death of man on Northern Ontario First Nation\nProvinces, territories face calls to make Day for Truth and Reconciliation a holiday\nNo single fix for anti-Indigenous racism in Canada's health-care system: doctor\nIndigenous leaders want corporate reconciliation efforts to extend beyond Sept. 30\nCanada Posts launches four stamps recognizing residential schools and reconciliation\nCanadian Museums Association recommends 10 ways to decolonize heritage sector\n'We shouldn't have to push people': Most provinces have not made Sept. 30 a stat holiday\nWhat each province, territory is doing on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation\nWhy it matters where you buy an orange shirt ahead of the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation\nYoung Indigenous leaders offer senators new ideas to mark National Day for Truth and Reconciliation\n\n\"We're not like big box stores that just have disposable T-shirts and are at everybody's beck and call. Working with us ahead of time as opposed to just laying it on us a week before the day, I think would be super helpful.\"\n\nPettit has tried her best to accommodate last-minute orders, but she and other members of the Indigenous business community see the trend as a sign of how much more work corporate Canada has to do to turn support for Indigenous communities into a 365-day-a-year effort.\n\nWhile many businesses encourage staff to don orange shirts -- a tradition started by residential school survivor Phyllis Webstad in 2013 -- or to sell wares in the bright hue on Sept. 30, those efforts quickly fade. Companies often don't do much more to elevate Indigenous voices and causes.\n\n\"It is positive that we are seeing education happen and awareness-building happen, but it can be quite triggering and harmful for Indigenous Peoples who see it as one day of performative action and nothing throughout the rest of the year,\" said Tabatha Bull, president and chief executive of the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business (CCAB).\n\nBull and Pettit say if an employer is looking to make a mark on truth and reconciliation goals, they should also be doing that work all year round.\n\nThose efforts should begin with educating staff about both long-standing and new traumas Indigenous Peoplesface and how to support those affected.\n\nPettit recallsbeing at work in 2021, when the remains of 215 children were found at a former residential school site in British Columbia.\n\n\"My boss at the time was like, 'Oh, well, everybody knew about that already' and just like kind of brushed it off, but I was feeling very emotional that day for obvious reasons, so there's tons of work that has to be done,\" she said.\n\nThat's borne out in studies too.\n\nA 2021 report from equity organization Catalyst Canada found about 52 per cent of the 86 Indigenous respondents surveyed are \"on guard\" at work and about 60 per cent feel psychologically unsafe on the job.\n\nThe study was based on a survey of 820 Canadian workers from various under-represented groups, but Catalyst isolated results from Indigenous respondents for this report because their need to feel on guard was so significant.\n\nKrystal Abotossaway, president of the Indigenous Professional Association of Canada, said she has seen more companies move toward reflecting on what they can do to improve their corporate culture and support Indigenous communities in recent years.\n\nLand acknowledgments, which note which Indigenous Peoples lived and took care of a site events are being held on, are an increasingly common and good start, she said.\n\nBull counts at least 200 companies, including Bank of Montreal, Uber, Walmart and Rogers, as members of the CCAB's Progressive Aboriginal Relation program -- an initiative helping them build cultural awareness and make progress on reconciliation plans.\n\nOthers have yet to take on such work. Bull thinks they're slower to act because they feel overwhelmed and afraid of having difficult conversations.\n\n\"Some corporations are just not even knowing what the right question is to ask,\" she said. \"I think we need to move beyond that, if we're going to really progress as a country.\"\n\nAbotossaway said they can start by marking other Indigenous days and use them as an opportunity to educate.\n\nAmong those she suggested are Red Dress Day, which commemorates the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and International Inuit Day, National Indigenous Peoples Day and Louis Riel Day, which celebrates the life of the late Metis leader.\n\nThe efforts shouldn't stop there, she added. Companies should reflect on how their governance structures, hiring policies, talent pipelines and workforce education programs align with Indigenous needs, she said.\n\n\"We've seen a lot of learning and development content come out, but that's usually just one course and it might be just an hour long,\" she said.\n\n\"Is it mandatory or is it not mandatory? And then how many of your employees or workforce are participating in it?\"\n\nAbotossaway and Bull agree any corporate actions on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation or other days should involve Indigenous Peoples at every step -- even if the action is selling orange apparel.\n\nBull said, \"If you're going to create an orange shirt, ensure that you're working with an Indigenous artist, ensure that the Orange Shirt Society or an Indigenous organization benefits from that and you're not making a profit off of the orange shirt or Sept. 30.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Sept. 30, 2022.\n\nReport an error\nEditorial standards & policies\nWhy you can trust CTV News\nADVERTISEMENT\nADVERTISEMENT\nTOP VIDEOS\n\nHurricane Beryl: Devastation as Jamaica braces for impact\n\nStunning acquittal sees doctor accused of murder walk free\n\n'You just left us': Passengers stranded abroad by WestJet\n\nTeen behind the wheel in fatal crash sentenced to probation\n\nShooting in B.C. was a result of road rage, say police\n\nPresidential debate, SCOTUS ruling upend U.S. politics\n\nHow a MLB shortstop ended up with a top hit on iTunes\n\nHeading to the nation's capital? {"url": "https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/we-re-going-to-be-doing-this-no-matter-what-frustration-remains-over-murdered-and-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls-on-red-dress-day-1.6386669", "title": "Red Dress Day frustration | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News At Six\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nATLANTIC\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nATLANTIC\nNews\n'We\u2019re going to be doing this, no matter what': Frustration remains over murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls on Red Dress Day\nHeidi Petracek\nCTV News Atlantic Reporter\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 5, 2023 5:17 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nCeremonies marking Canada\u2019s National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People included the reading of the names of those whose lives have been taken.\n\nAlso known as Red Dress Day, the event has been marked on May 5th since 2010.\n\nThe long list of names read out is testament to the personal pain behind the day, with red dresses prominently displayed in an act of remembrance.\n\nEvents were held throughout the Maritimes, where community members gathered not only to remember, but to hold governments to account after a 2019 federal inquiry report called the violence experienced by indigenous women and girls \u201ca genocide.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo say their name gives them their moment, to be heard and to be seen,\u201d said Natasha Ward of the Metepenagiag First Nation at the event in Saint John, \u201cbecause these women who are being dumped in dumpsters (and) landfills, you don\u2019t say their name, they\u2019re regarded as trash, and they\u2019re devalued.\u201d\n\nIn Halifax, Denise John of the Mi\u2019kmaw Native Friendship Centre spoke to the crowd about the murder of her cousin, Chantel John, in Conne River, Newfoundland.\n\nThe 28-year-old died in 2019. Her former partner, Kirk Keeping, has been charged in her death and is set for trial in 2024.\n\n\u201cIt was like a shock to my system,\u201d Denise said.\n\n\u201cEvery day you're woken up to the fact that they're no longer there, so I want to be able to honour all these women, in some way,\u201d she said.\n\nMi\u2019kmaq lawyer, author, and write Patricia Doyle-Bedwell says governments have been too slow in acting on the 231 Calls for Justice laid out in the final report of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cAt least there's one day where people are talking about this, for a long time, nobody talked about it,\u201d she said, \u201c(but) the federal governments and the provincial governments are not making progress\u2026.I think they\u2019ve done two.\n\n\u201cWe still see the injustice and we have a missing and indigenous Mi\u2019kmaw woman in Halifax, Tanya Brooks, and her case hasn't been solved in ten years,\u201d she adds, \u201cI wonder what are they (police) doing? Why don't they care?\u201d\n\nWhile the House of Commons has unanimously declared the disappearances and deaths a national emergency, and has called for a new system to alert the public when an indigenous person goes missing, Doyle-Bedwell says the root causes of violence, such as lack of housing and healthcare, have not been fully addressed.\n\nAt the Halifax red dress event, John says she is frustrated by government inaction, but remains determined.\n\n\u201cA lot of work needs to be done still, and I have to be hopeful,\u201d she says, \u201cbut we're still going to be doing this, no matter what.\u201d\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 3\nMi\u2019kmaq lawyer, writer, and Dalhousie Unversity associate professor Patricia Doyle-Bedwell.\nReport an error\nEditorial standards & policies\nWhy you (City of Pitt Meadows/Special to The News)\nListen to this article\n00:02:19\n\nA ceremony recognizing the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit people in Canada took place in Pitt Meadows on Sunday.\n\nAround 80 people assembled in Spirit Square on May 5, including: city councilors Mike Manion, Gwen O\u2019Connell, Mike Hayes, Alison Evans, and Tracy Elke; members of City staff; members of Katzie First Nation; members of Golden Ears Metis Society; members of Fraser River Indigenous Society; the MLA for Maple Ridge-Pitt Meadows Lisa Beare, and school board trustee, Katie Sullivan.\n\nAlso known as Red Dress Day, after a project by Metis artist Jaime Black where empty red dresses were displayed in honour and as a visual reminder of the sheer numbers of Indigenous women who have died \u2013 red dresses were also hung from trees in the square.\n\nDeputy Mayor and City Councillor Manion opened the event, while Katzie First Nation elder Coleen Pierre performed the official welcome and blessing.\n\nDanica Berard performed a Red River Jig, and Jane Wylie performed a Haida and Scottish hoop and jingle dance.\n\nREAD MORE: Red dresses at B.C fashion show honour missing and murdered Indigenous women\n\nKatzie First Nation\u2019s Coleen Pierre, her daughter Mavis Pierre, and Francine Sylvester performed the Women\u2019s Warrior Song, before leading the public on a community walk with drumming and rattles.\n\nThe ceremony, remarked City of Pitt Meadows Mayor Nicole MacDonald, honours and remembers the many who have lost their lives to violence and recognizes their families and communities that live with the grief of losing loved ones.\n\nALSO: Workers nursing health care to positive outcomes for B.C. Indigenous patients\n\nAn original art piece created by Katzie First Nation artist Rain Pierre will be showcased in the lobby of city hall as a tribute to those who have been lost, embodying the beauty of the Indigenous people throughout the month of May.\n\nA ceremony took place in Pitt Meadows recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit (MMIWG2S) people in Canada\u0097also known as Red Dress Day.
