{"url": "https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/i-don-t-want-to-be-forgotten-students-march-thursday-to-mark-red-dress-day-1.5889659", "title": "'I don't want to be forgotten': Students march Thursday to mark Red Dress Day | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nWINNIPEG\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nWINNIPEG\nNews\n'I don't want to be forgotten': Students march Thursday to mark Red Dress Day\nA group of students in Winnipeg marked the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls by marching on May 5, 2022. (Source: Jamie Dowsett/ CTV News Winnipeg)\nKatherine Dow\nCTV News Winnipeg\nKatherine Dow\nCTV News Anchor/Editorial Producer\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2022 4:21 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2022 7:06 a.m. MDT\nShare\nWINNIPEG -\n\n Symbolic red dresses have been put up around the city to shine a light on the disproportionate violence that Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people face.\n\nThursday marks the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, also known as Red Dress Day.\n\nA group of students in Winnipeg marked the day by marching to ensure people don't forget what is happening to Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited people.\n\n\"It seems like my people just seem to be forgotten. I don't want to be forgotten,\" said Honey Flett, a Grade 10 student who was in the march.\n\n\"This was really overwhelming to see how many people decided to participate. I never expected so many.\"\n\nTara Tuchscherer, a teacher at St. James Collegiate, told CTV News the march is part of an entire week at the school meant to bring awareness to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and raise funds for Drag the Red.\n\n\"A lot of people are unaware of the number of girls and women that are missing,\" Tuchscherer said. \"We don't know what happened to them and their families are having to take it upon themselves to look for them and they need closure.\"\n\nThe province, which is set to project a red dress on the Manitoba Legislative Building Thursday night, said it is an occasion to remember those tragically taken by gender-based violence and to honour the ongoing healing of survivors, their families and communities who have lost loved ones.\n\nTo mark the occasion, people are encouraged to wear red or hang red dresses and ribbons as a visual reminder of the lives lost and to raise awareness about the ongoing fight against gender-based violence.\n\nThe Stefanson government noted in a news release its 2021 commitment to address violence against Indigenous women and girls by introducing amendments to the Path to Reconciliation Act, which established calls for justice from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cAddressing violence, in particular the incidences of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, is a priority for the province and it is our government's intent to continue to take action to prevent and combat gender-based violence of all forms,\u201d the province said in a news release.\n\nCITY TO HANG RED DRESSES, HOLD CEREMONIAL FIRE\n\nMeanwhile, the City of Winnipeg said it will mark the occasion with red dress displays at all Winnipeg Public Libraries until May 16.\n\nAdditionally, the city said it will host a ceremonial fire at Winnipeg City Hall from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m.\n\n\u201cWe would like to acknowledge the tireless heart-work of the MMIWG2S+ Advisory Committee, and Implementation Team for their guidance as we find our way to walk together to stop and prevent violence to Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+,\u201d the city wrote on its website.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nA group of students in Winnipeg marked the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls by marching on May 5, 2022. {"url": "https://www.merrittherald.com/recap-of-lnibs-red-dress-memorial-walk/", "title": "Recap of LNIB\u2019s Red Dress memorial walk - Merritt Herald", "body": "NEWS\nSPORTS\nCOMMUNITY\nJUNIOR REPORTERS\nOPINION\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nRecap of LNIB\u2019s Red Dress memorial walk\n\nPosted by Marius Auer | May 12, 2022 | News, Community, Events, Trending, MMIWG2S+, Indigenous | 0 \n\nPhoto/Marius Auer\n\nCommunity members and local organizations commemorated the National Day of Awareness and Action for Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls, and 2 Spirit (MMIWG2S) on May 5, with over 100 people walking along Highway 8 from Shulus Community Hall to Shulus Arbor.\n\nParticipants of the walk included students, local organization, community members, and the families of those affected by or lost to the ongoing MMIWG2S crisis in Canada, which has seen as many as 4000 Indigenous women and girls missing or murdered.\n\nThe crowd left Shulus Community Hall just after 10:30am, the rain holding out until participants were mostly under cover at Shulus Arbor. Traditional hand-drumming, an opening prayer, and an \u201chonour\u201d song and dance honouring those impacted by the MMIWG2S were in store at the arbor.\n\nThe walk was organized by the Lower Nicola Indian Band\u2019s (LNIB) Carole Basil, who says the community banded together to bring awareness to the ongoing MMIWG crisis.\n\n\u201cWe want to show support and awareness for the MMIWG2S,\u201d said Basil, who facilitates LNIB\u2019s Cultural Revitalization program. \u201cThere\u2019s been numerous MMIWG2S in our community and it\u2019s very heartbreaking.\u201d\n\nMultiple members of Merritt\u2019s RCMP were also in attendance, facilitating the traffic control as walk participants made their way to Shulus Arbor and showing their support for the event.\n\n\u201cI feel it\u2019s important for the police to participate and acknowledge our part in the history of colonization and the trauma. We need to come out and support our Indigenous communities and recognize that MMIWG2S is still going on today,\u201d said Constable Tracy Dunsmore.\n\n\u201cWe need to protect our women, girls, and everybody.\u201d\n\nPhoto/Marius Auer\nPhoto/Marius Auer\nPhoto/Marius Auer\n\n\nPhoto/Marius Auer\nPhoto/Marius Auer\nPhoto/Marius Auer\n\n\n\nSHARE:\n\n \nPREVIOUS\nPlans for new NVIT campus move forward\nNEXT\nThe first Nicola Valley General Hospital nursing graduate\nNEWSLETTER\n\nFirst Name \n\nLast Name \n\nEmail address: \n\nCLASSIFIEDS\nMedical Office Assistant Position June 19, 2024\nSales Person/Office Admin May 15, 2024\nNVCL April 4, 2024\nRECENT OBITUARIES\nAlan Norman Clarence Taylor June 19, 2024\nFay Sturney June 19, 2024\nBeverly Jean Malchuk June 19, 2024\nSister Newspapers\nBowen Island Undercurrent\nBurnaby Now\nBusiness in Vancouver\nCastanet\nCoast Reporter\nDelta Optimist\nLethbridge Herald\nMedicine Hat News\nMoose Jaw Today\nNew West Record\nNorth Shore News\nPique Newsmagazine\nPowell River Peak\nPrince George Citizen\nREW.ca\nRichmond News\nSaskToday.ca\nSquamish Chief\nThe Orca\nTimes Colonist\nTriCity News\nVancouver is Awesome\nWestern Investor\nAirdrie Today\nAlberta Prime Times\nCochrane Today\nLakeland Today\nMountain View Today\nOkotoks Today\nRocky Mountain Outlook\nSt. Albert Gazette\nTown and Country Today\nOther Sections\nAbout Us\n\nAdvertise\n\nReal Estate\n\nClassifieds\n\nEvents\n\nMagazines\n\nSubscribe\n\nContact Us\n\nConnect\n\nMerritt Herald\n#201- 1951 Garcia Street,\nMerritt, BC V1K 1B8\n\nPhone\n1-250-378-4241\n\nAberdeen Publishing \u00a9 Copyright \u00ae\u00a02020.\u00a0\u00a0All rights reserved. {"url": "https://www.benzinga.com/pressreleases/23/05/n32202683/funding-for-pauktuutit-inuit-women-of-canada-to-address-root-causes-of-gender-based-violence", "title": "Funding for Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada to address root causes of Gender-based Violence - Benzinga", "body": "Get Benzinga Pro\nDATA & APIS\nEVENTS\nMARKETFY\nPREMARKET\nBOOST\nADVERTISE\nContribute\nSIGN IN\nOur Services\nNews\nMarkets\nOptions\nRatings\nIdeas\nMoney\nCrypto\nCannabis\nJobs\nRESEARCH\nMy Stocks\nTools\nRecent\nMarkets\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\nFunding for Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada to address root causes of Gender-based Violence\nby\nPRNewswire\nMay 3, 2023 7:35 PM | 4 min read | Make a Comment\nLoading...\n\nOTTAWA, ON, May 3, 2023 /CNW/ - The National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls highlighted the underlying systemic causes of ongoing violence against Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people. The COVID-19 pandemic also created unprecedented challenges for victims and survivors seeking help and the frontline organizations that support them.\n\nToday, the Honourable Mona Fortier, President of the Treasury Board and Member of Parliament for Ottawa-Vanier, on behalf of the Honourable Marci Ien, Minister for Women and Gender Equality and Youth,\u00a0announced $750,000 in funding for Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada.\n\nIncreasing the capacity of Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada will provide Inuit-specific solutions to preventing and addressing gender-based violence, which will help Indigenous women, 2SLGBTQQIA+ people, and their communities prosper now and in the future.\n\nIn November 2022, the Federal, Provincial, and Territorial Forum of Ministers Responsible for the Status of Women launched the 10-year National Action Plan to End Gender-based Violence. This is a strategic framework for addressing gender-based violence. The National Action Plan includes five pillars:\u00a0support for victims, survivors, and their families; prevention; a responsive justice system; implementing Indigenous-led approaches; and social infrastructure and an enabling environment.\n\nQuote\n\n\"The high rates of violence against Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQI+ people are alarming. Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada is doing critical work to prevent and address gender-based violence, and supporting these efforts remains a top priority for the Government of Canada. The funding announced today will help this organization build their capacity to address the root causes of gender-based violence and continue to build prosperous Inuit communities. This Friday, May 5, we mark Red Dress Day, which reminds us to uphold and honour the memory and spirits of all missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls (MMIWG) as well as Two-Spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, and additional sexually and gender-diverse (2SLGBTQI+) people.\"\n\nThe Honourable Mona Fortier, President of the Treasury Board and Member of Parliament for Ottawa-Vanier\n\nQuick facts\nThis funding is part of the approximately $601.3 million that the Government of Canada committed through Budget 2021 to increase efforts to end gender-based violence.\nThis announcement builds on previous Women and Gender Equality Canada funding of over $13 million for more than 100 commemoration projects to help honour the lives and legacies of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people.\nThe National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence, particularly Pillar 4, supports Indigenous-led approaches. The National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence is aligned with and complements the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ People National Action Plan, and the Federal Pathway to Address Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ People (Federal Pathway).\nThe Federal Pathway is the Government of Canada's contribution to the 2021 Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ People National Action Plan: Ending Violence Against Indigenous Women, Girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ People. It outlines the Government of Canada's efforts, now and in the future, to end the gender-based violence and systemic racism responsible for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people.\nA recent study by Statistics Canada indicates that while only 5% of the female population in Canada identified as Indigenous in 2021, 21% of all gender-related homicides involved Indigenous women and girls.\nAssociated links\nNational Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence\nNews release \u2013 Call for proposals: Indigenous women and 2SLGBTQQIA+ organizations to further address gender-based violence\nFederal Pathway to Address Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ People\n\nFollow Women and Gender Equality Canada:\n\nWebsite\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nInstagram\nYouTube\n\nSOURCE Women and Gender Equality Canada\n\nMarket News and Data brought to you by Benzinga APIs\n\n\u00a9 2024 Benzinga.com. {"url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/red-dresses-raise-awareness-for-missing-murdered-native-american-women/4874985.html", "title": "Red Dresses Raise Awareness for Missing, Murdered Native American Women", "body": "Accessibility links\nSkip to main content\nSkip to main Navigation\nSkip to Search\nLink has been copied to clipboard\nHOME\nUNITED STATES\nU.S. NEWS\nALL ABOUT AMERICA\nSILICON VALLEY & TECHNOLOGY\nIMMIGRATION\nWORLD\nAFRICA\nTHE AMERICAS\nEAST ASIA\nEUROPE\nMIDDLE EAST\nSOUTH & CENTRAL ASIA\nUKRAINE\nPRESS FREEDOM\nCHINA\nIRAN\nBROADCAST PROGRAMS\nFOLLOW US\n Languages\nSearch\nARTS & CULTURE\n\u00a0\nRed Dresses Raise Awareness for Missing, Murdered Native American Women\nshare\nRed Dresses Raise Awareness for Missing, Murdered Native American Women\nApril 14, 2019 6:00 AM\nBy Julie Taboh\n EMBED\n SHARE\nThe REDress Project Highlights Missing, Murdered Native American Women\n EMBED\n SHARE\nThe code has been copied to your clipboard.\n \nwidth  px height  px\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nThe URL has been copied to your clipboard\n \n\nNo media source currently available\n\n0:00\n0:02:55\n0:00\n Download \n\nForty red dresses hang outside of the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington. They're present 24 hours a day, in all weather, to draw attention to the plight of missing and murdered indigenous women who experience violence at a higher rate than non-indigenous women.\n\nShare\n\n Print\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014\u00a0\n\nForty red dresses hang outside of the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington, a short distance from the U.S. Capitol.\n\nThey\u2019re strategically placed near trees and waterfalls alongside the Riverwalk located in the museum\u2019s Native landscape.\n\nThey\u2019re present 24 hours a day, in all weather, to draw attention to the plight of missing and murdered indigenous women who experience violence at a much higher rate than non-indigenous women.\n\nOn this day, they snap furiously in a wicked wind, commanding attention.\n\nThe powerful installation is the creative brainchild of visual artist Jaime Black, whose goal is to raise awareness about the high rate of violence against native women.\n\n\u201cWhat I do is I put up empty red dresses in public spaces so that people can connect to the absence of these women, but also to the power and presence of the women through the red dress,\u201d she says.\n\nThe color red\n\nHer choice of the color red was deliberate.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s our sacred life blood, it\u2019s where vitality comes from, and our energy, and our power as human beings, but it\u2019s also an allusion to the violence and the loss of that sacred life blood through violence,\u201d she says.\n\nPaying homage\n\nOn this freezing day outside the museum, Black honors the women the dresses represent \u2014 with a special performance.\n\nAs a Native American elder beats on a drum, the artist, barefoot and all in black except for a red silk scarf around her neck, kneels and rubs clay on the ground near the entrance to the museum. It\u2019s been raining hard all morning. But it stops as Black starts her performance.\n\nSpectators gather round as she clutches her pot of clay and walks slowly toward the dresses. She winds her way around the ledge of a curved pool and wades into the cool water, smearing some of the dresses with the mudlike substance.\n\n\u201cI really wanted to use my talents and my gifts to further the voices of a lot of people who are silenced,\u201d she says, \u201cand indigenous women are really facing this epidemic of silence.\u201d\n\nWhile Black\u2019s work has focused mostly on Canadian women so far, she\u2019s brought her project to the U.S. for the first time, to address an issue that spans the entire Western hemisphere.\n\nREDress project\n\nShe calls her installation \u201cThe REDress Project,\u201d or \u201cThe re-dress project.\u201d\n\n\u201cRedress is a word that means to put right a wrong, and indigenous women have been facing injustice in North America for hundreds of years,\u201d she says. \u201cEver since settlers came to North America, there\u2019s been a violent relationship between settlers and indigenous people and I feel like that violent relationship carries on still today.\u201d\n\nShe calls that systemic discrimination, The Colonial Project.\n\n\u201cThe Colonial Project is basically interested in erasing certain voices in favor of a certain system,\u201d she explains. \u201cSo the legal frameworks, the political frameworks, these things were built by non-indigenous people to silence indigenous people, and so all of these systems have created a space where indigenous women are erased.\u201d\n\nBut more and more Native women are refusing to be silenced and are becoming proactive, leading movements, participating in protests and petitioning their governments for more recognition.\n\n\u201cI think in these ways and these movements, like Standing Rock and Idle No More movement, we see the strength of indigenous women to really maintain culture in the face of such colonial violence,\u201d Black says.\n\nHope for change\n\nBlack \u2014 and other supporters, including Machel Monenerkit, deputy director of the museum \u2014 are also encouraged by the presence of two Native American women in Congress now; Debra Anne Haaland, serving as the U.S. Representative for New Mexico\u2019s 1st congressional district, and Sharice Lynnette Davids, serving as the U.S. Representative for Kansas\u2019s 3rd congressional district.\n\n\u201cI think the 2019 Congress for women was exceptional in the numbers that we now have in Congress, but for Native people having two indigenous women represent Kansas and New Mexico is obviously something we\u2019ve not seen before, and hopefully we\u2019ll be able to bring attention to Native issues,\u201d Monenerkit says.\n\nIn the meantime, Black hopes the red dresses, all of which are donated, will have an impact on all who get to see them.\n\n\u201cWhat I think that the artwork and creativity can really do is really hit people in the heart, \u201cshe says. \u201cPeople who walk by those dresses \u2026 they can\u2019t unsee that. That\u2019s going to sit in their memory for a very long time, and I think it has a really emotional impact on people even before they know what the dresses are even there for.\u201d\n\nMore Art & Culture News\nTrafficked Cambodian artifacts returned from US\nFrance's renowned Arles photo fest goes 'beneath the surface'\nWhat was the 'first American novel'? On this Independence Day, a look at what it started\nRobert Towne, Oscar-winning writer of 'Chinatown,' dies at 89\nLGBTQ+ Pride Month culminates with parades in New York, San Francisco and beyond\nThe Day in Photos\nJuly 4, 2024\n.\n\u200b\nFOLLOW US\nUNITED STATES\nUS News\nImmigration\nAll About America\nSilicon Valley & Technology\nWORLD\nAfrica\nThe Americas\nEast Asia Pacific\nEurope\nMiddle East\nSouth & Central Asia\nSECTIONS\nVOA Programs\nSpecial projects\nDay in Photos\nPress Freedom\nRefugees\nVOA News on Iran\nVOA News on China\nArts & Culture\nEconomy & Business\nHealth\nExtremism Watch\nStudent Union\n52 Documentary\nVideos\nMORE FROM VOA\nVOAAfrica.com Programs\nVOA Learning English\nPolygraph.info\nEditorials\nABOUT THIS SITE\nTerms of Use & Privacy Notice\nAbout VOA\nGet VOA+\nVOA Around the World\nContact VOA\nMedia Relations\nUsage Requests\nVOA Pronunciation Guide\n\nMD\nLG"},
{"url": "https://uwaterloo.ca/daily-bulletin/2022-06-30", "title": "Thursday, June 30, 2022 | Daily Bulletin | University of Waterloo", "body": "Skip to main\nSkip to footer\nUniversity of Waterloo\nADMISSIONS ABOUT WATERLOO FACULTIES & ACADEMICS OFFICES & SERVICES SUPPORT WATERLOO COVID-19\nSEARCH\nDAILY BULLETIN\nDaily Bulletin home\nAbout the Daily Bulletin\nArchives\nSearch the Daily Bulletin\nDaily Bulletin on Twitter\nBeyond the Bulletin Podcast\nSubscribe to the e-newsletter\nWhen and Where to get Support\nDaily Bulletin\nThursday, June 30, 2022\nPrevious | Next | Current\n\nDAILY BULLETIN FEED\nCelebration, reflection and the summer ahead\nNew course alert: the Wicked Problem of Climate Change\nPlanting the seeds of reconciliation\nQ and A with the experts: Reclaiming Indigenous histories\nEngineering's Elder in Residence offers courses and counselling grounded in his Indigenous background\nWhat's open and closed this weekend\n\nEditor:\nBrandon Sweet\nUniversity Communications\nbulletin@uwaterloo.ca\n\n\n\nCelebration, reflection and the summer ahead\n\nA message from Vivek Goel.\n\nLast week I shared a blog post with the community reflecting on the enormous success of our week of Convocation. I wanted to take a moment, though, to write to you all directly to reflect on the year so far \u2013 the end of my first year here at Waterloo \u2013 and what lies ahead.\n\u00a0\nThis June has been filled with wonderful opportunities to celebrate our community. At the heart of our celebrations was the largest Convocation we have ever seen. From June 11 to June 18, we celebrated alongside a total of 8,320 graduates and 18,522 guests in person here in Waterloo.\u00a0\n\u00a0\nWe owe an enormous thank you to the people who made it possible to welcome back graduands and alumni from 2020, 2021 and 2022. More than 350 employees from across our campus communities came together with 200 student ushers, and another 275 volunteers to make this Convocation truly a once-in-a-lifetime event.\n\u00a0\nFor so many people, Convocation was amongst the first opportunities we have had to connect in person with our friends and colleagues. The events really brought the campus alive and I know our students appreciate the return to in person experiences. The connections and communities that we develop on our campuses and beyond are the foundation of a positive student experience and what makes the University of Waterloo so special.\u00a0\n\u00a0\nThis month we have also celebrated Pride and National Indigenous History month. I am so pleased that our students from the GLOW centre were able to attend Toronto\u2019s Pride March on Sunday. And if you haven\u2019t had an opportunity to attend one of the many Indigenous events on campus this month, I encourage you to attend\u00a0Bmaadziwin: An Indigenous Perspective of Life\u00a0later today to learn from Elder Myeengun Henry.\n\u00a0\nAs we reach the Canada Day long weekend, I hope the day away from the University gives you an opportunity to rest and relax. No matter how you mark the day, I encourage you to celebrate how diverse communities and individuals add richness and vibrancy to our campuses and Canadian society. We can also reflect on how we can do better to break down barriers for marginalized voices, and work toward Truth and Reconciliation.\u00a0\n\u00a0\nAs I approach the end of my first year at Waterloo, I\u2019m reflecting on what I have heard in the many consultations and conversations I have had as part of the Waterloo at 100 project. I have heard your motivation to think about the longer-term future for Waterloo, your openness to working in new ways and your pride in our institution. I\u2019m grateful for your input and look forward to sharing more with you in the Fall. Until then, you can continue to\u00a0share your perspectives and stay up to date with the project online.\n\u00a0\nI do hope that over the next couple of months you will make some time for you, your friends, family and loved ones. \u00a0Thank you for everything you do for the University of Waterloo.\u00a0\n\u00a0\nHave a great summer.\u00a0I look forward to seeing you all on campus this Fall.\n\nNew course alert: the Wicked Problem of Climate Change\n\nA message from GSPA.\n\nIn winter 2023 a\u00a0pilot, interdisciplinary undergraduate course will be taught by a group of\u00a0doctoral candidates from the University of Waterloo. It will focus on the Wicked Problem\u00a0of Climate Change and will provide undergraduate students with a classroom experience where the academic content spans disciplinary boundaries.\n\nThe team will spend the fall 2022 term designing the course by working with each other and with mentors in the Beta Teaching Innovation Incubator (up to 10 hours a week, equivalent to a TAship).\n\nPhD candidates researching in the area of climate change are invited to apply for this pilot. The intention is to select up to six doctoral student researchers, with diverse representation from across the faculties.\u00a0 For more information, visit\u00a0The Wicked Problem of Climate Change course web page. The deadline to apply\u00a0is July 12.\n\nPlanting the seeds of reconciliation\n\nBy Eugenia Xenos Anderson.\u00a0This article was originally featured on Waterloo News.\n\nEven before the commitment was made on paper and then solidified in ceremony, talk of Indigenous reconciliation had been taking place in the University of Waterloo\u2019s\u00a0Faculty of Health. However, it took the hire of an Indigenous Knowledge Keeper to give shape to a process that is sometimes not well understood and often difficult to begin.\n\nThat Indigenous Knowledge Keeper is\u00a0Elder Myeengun Henry, formerly\u00a0Chief of the Chippewas of the Thames First Nation\u00a0and Indigenous leader at Conestoga College. His voice is soothing but forceful, and he looks like a man who has found his calling. Part grandfather, part sage, part friendly neighbour, he is a healer who came to Waterloo at just the right time.\u00a0\n\nElder Henry is at a stage in his life where he wants to share his knowledge, experiences, language and culture. He wants to\u00a0offset the damage of more than one hundred years when Indigenous culture, identity and languages were stifled, prohibited and criminalized. He tirelessly spreads the word through learning circles, ceremonies and even attending every single one of the 20 convocation ceremonies this spring. He does it patiently and cheerfully, but also pointedly when necessary.\u00a0\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe had to have a starting point,\u201d said Elder Henry at the Faculty of Health\u2019s inaugural Commitment Ceremony this week. In this case, the starting point was the inclusion of a signature commitment to create \u201can environment that invites and respects Indigenous ways of knowing\u201d in the Faculty\u2019s latest strategic plan, made formal by the ceremony.\n\n\u201cThe vision was there, so today we make that full commitment by planting a cedar tree as a point of celebration,\u201d he said. He and Dean Lili Liu also exchanged gifts: a sacred eagle feather for the Faculty, and a one-of-a-kind beaded medallion for Elder Henry. They also unveiled a Wampum Belt that will hang in the Health Expansion building.\n\n\u201cI am overwhelmed by the support and love I\u2019ve felt since I came to help build this up,\u201d Henry says. \u201cI know there is honour and respect of Indigenous people in this Faculty. We\u2019ll find our struggles now and then and have differences of opinion, but I think overall, our commitment is here and is strong.\u00a0\n\nThe feeling is mutual. Dean Lili Liu is grateful for the leadership and counsel Elder Henry is providing. \u201cNot only has Elder Henry shared deep knowledge and wonderful ideas for how to help make our spaces and actions more inviting and welcoming, but he has quickly become a part of our\u00a0Faculty\u00a0family.\u201d\n\nWhile the Faculty\u2019s reconciliation efforts have started with events such as a Red Dress Day commemoration and the Commitment Ceremony, they are also creating spaces that can be used by Indigenous students and others, installing Indigenous artwork to make students feel comfortable and accepted,\u00a0and including Indigenous knowledge into the curriculum to make a difference in how we practice and deliver health programs and services.\n\n\u201cGive students a place to congregate, celebrate, smudge and be proud to be an Indigenous student in the Faculty of Health,\u201d Elder Henry says. \u201cI see a vision coming true, a formal commitment to making this come true. It will be longer than the life of a strategic plan.\u201d\n\nOf course, there is good reason Elder Henry is motivated to teach about Indigenous history and culture: \u201cWe did ceremonies on this land. We walked this land and we fed our families on this land. It\u2019s important for Indigenous people to know that we are still here.\u201d\n\nYou can hear more from Elder Henry on the\u00a0Beyond the Bulletin podcast\u00a0where he shares his goals and motivation as he approaches his work at Waterloo.\n\nQ and A with the experts: Reclaiming Indigenous histories\n\nThis article was originally featured on Waterloo News.\n\nDuring National Indigenous History Month and as we celebrate National Indigenous Peoples Day on June 21, University of Waterloo historian and anthropologist\u00a0Talena Atfield\u00a0answers questions about the recovery and regeneration of Indigenous artifacts, practices and knowledges. Professor Atfield is a member of the\u00a0Kanien'keh\u00e1:ka Nation of the Six Nations of the Grand River.\n\nWhat do people need to understand about the repatriation and preservation of Indigenous histories and artifacts?\n\nI believe that people should learn how and why Indigenous museum and archival collections were made, the impacts these practices continue to have on communities, and why repatriation can be an important tool for conciliation and healing. Most collections were built on agendas of extermination, land theft, the erasure of Indigenous presence, and literally, on Indigenous physical bodies. The perpetuation of anti-Indigenous sentiments, such as a hierarchical scale of human evolution, in which European settlers were at the top and Indigenous Peoples worldwide occupied various stages below, enabled land theft and resource extraction. This was further supported through pseudoscientific practices that boasted the ability to determine levels of intelligence and moral character through skeletal morphologies, which were used to argue Indigenous peoples had not reached the pinnacle of human evolution.\n\nThese ideas were combined with the false notion of the \u201cvanishing race,\u201d which posited that \u201cauthentic\u201d or \u201creal\u201d Indigenous people only existed in a \u201cpure\u201d and \u201cuncontaminated\u201d past. Contact with European colonizers resulted in outside influences that doomed \u201creal\u201d Indigenous Peoples to extinction. This, in turn, enabled the widescale extraction of Indigenous material cultures and promoted the erasure of Indigenous presence and contributions to what is now Canada. This extraction en masse saw the removal of items essential to the continuation of some spiritual and ceremonial practices. Many Indigenous individuals and communities are still trying to recover and regenerate knowledges and practices that were affected by these histories. \u00a0\u00a0\n\nHow is intangible Indigenous knowledges preserved?\n\nHodinohso:ni people have continued to preserve intangible knowledges through stories, oral histories, and mnemonic devices such as wampum. Stories are a rich source of information, and the act of storytelling and listening to stories has played an integral role in teaching generations of Hodinohso:ni people what it means to be Hodinohso:ni. Intangible knowledges are also preserved in language, Hodinohso:ni languages are rich with information detailing how ideas or objects fit into Hodinohso:ni ethos; much of this information becomes lost in translation, which is why it is so important to support and promote Indigenous language initiatives.\n\nWhat is the most pressing work yet to be done to preserve and share Indigenous histories?\u00a0\n\nMaking collections accessible to the communities from which they originated would be very impactful. Currently, there are archives full of audio recordings, photographs, and detailed field notes, as well as storage rooms full of material culture, much of which has not been available to the community since it was taken over 100 years ago. Many communities and individuals don\u2019t know how or where to find information related to these collections or how to access them. Items are located all over the world, everywhere but where they are needed most. The most pressing work, in my opinion, is ensuring that institutions have adequate funds and staff to carry out digitization and dissemination of this archival information, as well as decentralizing of the collections back to home communities where possible, so information that has been extracted from communities can be regenerated into practice.\n\nHow can people support repatriation, preservation, and knowledge sharing?\n\nI recommend people learn Indigenous histories, on the land they occupy, at the very least. There is incredible diversity within and among Indigenous Nations in what is now Canada. Until recently, Indigenous perspectives and narratives have been entirely absent from the Canadian curriculum. This has played a large role in perpetuating violence against Indigenous peoples. I recommend people attend appropriate cultural events, learn the history of the treaties \u2014 or lack thereof \u2014 in the areas they live and visit, take courses, and read Indigenous-authored books. There are so many free digital learning opportunities available that uplift Indigenous Peoples' voices from across Canada that people could engage.\n\nEngineering's Elder in Residence offers courses and counselling grounded in his Indigenous background\n\nBy Carol Truemner. This is an exceprt of an article\u00a0originally featured on Waterloo News.\n\nPassionate about\u00a0sharing his Indigenous heritage, an adjunct architecture professor named a\u00a0new course after the ceremony his ancestors have used for thousands of years to welcome visitors to their homeland \u2014 At the Woods Edge.\n\nThis semester,\u00a0William Woodworth, also known as Elder Bill, started teaching the course focused\u00a0on the relationships between Indigenous peoples and settlers from the 16th century to today, and how those associations have affected both engineering and architecture.\n\nWoodworth\u2019s offering draws, in part, on his background as a member of the Lower Mohawk Kanien'keh\u00e1:ka Nation of Six Nations of the Grand River in the Bear Clan.\n\nIn the mid-1990s, he had the opportunity to\u00a0apprentice\u00a0with Cayuga Chief Jacob Ezra Thomas Deyohonwedah of the Six Nations of the Grand River Territory where he was immersed in the Haudenosaunee practices and culture.\n\nBorn in the United States, Woodworth completed an architecture degree at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor.\n\nBuilding on his architectural education, he launched William Woodworth Architect in Toronto in 1980 and practiced as a member of the Ontario Association of Architects, and the Royal Architectural Institute of Canada.\n\n\u00a0In 1993, he took a sabbatical to teach at the Lawrence Technological University outside of Detroit. From there, he began doctoral studies at the California Institute of Integral Studies in the program Recovery of the Indigenous mind and graduated in 2001.\n\nRead the rest of the article on Waterloo News.\n\nWhat's open and closed this weekend\n\nThe University will be closed on Friday, July 1 for Canada Day. Many, if not most, campus operations will be closed, or have modified operating hours, during the holiday long weekend.\n\nThe\u00a0Student Life Centre, including the Turnkey Desk,\u00a0is open all day. {"url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/canada-genocide-murdered-missing-women-girls-indigenous-inquiry-report-a8939646.html", "title": "Murdered and missing women and girls in Canada tragedy is genocide rooted in colonialism, official inquiry finds | The Independent | The Independent", "body": "Jump to content\nUK EDITION\nCHANGE\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nLOG IN / REGISTER\nIndependent\nGeneral election\nIndyBest\nNEWS\nNEWS\nSPORT\nSPORT\nVOICES\nVOICES\nCULTURE\nCULTURE\nLIFESTYLE\nLIFESTYLE\nTRAVEL\nTRAVEL\nPREMIUM\nPREMIUM\nMORE\nMORE\nNewsWorldAmericas\nMurdered and missing women and girls in Canada tragedy is genocide rooted in colonialism, official inquiry finds\n\nState \u2018actions and inactions and ideology\u2019 blamed for allowing attackers to get away with violence over nearly 50 years\n\nJane Dalton\nMonday 10 June 2019 15:38 BST\nComments\nWomen demonstrate at the trial in 2007 of Canadian Robert Pickton, who told police he killed 49 women and was jailed for life (AFP)\nThe latest headlines from our reporters across the US sent straight to your inbox each weekday\nSIGN UP\nI would like to be emailed about offers, events and updates from The Independent. Read our\u00a0privacy policy\n\nThousands of Canadian women and girls were murdered or disappeared over nearly half a century in a \u201cgenocide\u201d, according to a leaked report of a government inquiry.\n\nIndigenous females face disproportionate violence largely because of \u201cstate actions and inactions rooted in colonialism and colonial ideologies\u201d, the document states.\n\nRights groups have for decades pointed to cases of women and girls vanishing or being killed. A study by the National Institute of Justice found 84 per cent of Native American and Alaska native women have experienced violence in their lifetime and more than half have endured the violence at the hands of an intimate partner.\n\nThe inquiry report, due out on Monday but seen in advance by CBC News, says: \u201cWe do know that thousands of indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA (two-spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgendered, queer, questioning, intersex and asexual) people have been lost to the Canadian genocide to date.\u201d\n\nIt adds: \u201cThe fact that First Nations, Inuit, and M\u00e9tis peoples are still here and that the population is growing should not discount the charge of genocide.\u201d\n\nMurdered and missing indigenous women in US and Canada\nShow all 11\n\nThe report, entitled \u201cReclaiming Power and Place\u201d, says that \u201cdue to the gravity of this issue,\u201d the inquiry is preparing a \u201csupplementary report on the Canadian genocide of indigenous peoples according to the legal definition of genocide,\u201d which will be posted at a later date on the inquiry website, CBC News reported.\n\nRunning to over 1,200 pages it carries at least 230 recommendations.\n\nIt comes after two and a half years of work by the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, ordered by Justin Trudeau, the Canadian prime minister.\n\nEstimates have put the number of indigenous women and girls who have disappeared or been murdered in Canada since the 1970s at up to 4,000, but the inquiry report says the true number may be impossible to establish.\n\nFrom 2005 to 2010, the Sisters In Spirit Initiative said it confirmed 582 cases of missing and/or murdered indigenous women and girls over 20 years.\n\nThe murder of 15-year-old Tina Fontaine in the summer of 2014 gave fresh impetus to calls for a national inquiry. By 2015, the UN backed a public inquiry.\n\nTo produce the new report, the inquiry held 24 sessions, attended by at least 2,380 people, including family members of those killed or missing.\n\nThe missing and murdered indigenous women (MMIW) issue involves indigenous people in Canada and the US, including the First Nations, Inuit, M\u00e9tis and Native American communities.\n\nSupport free-thinking journalism and attend Independent events\n\nThe inquiry website says: \u201cShining a light on all the causes of violence, murders and disappearances is a daunting task. But it is a necessary one. We are exposing hard truths about the devastating impacts of colonisation, racism and sexism \u2013 aspects of Canadian society that many Canadians are reluctant to accept.\u201d\n\nRobert Pickton, one of the world\u2019s most notorious serial killers, who was jailed in 2007, said he butchered 49 women at his farm near Vancouver.\n\nIt was claimed that police had not taken the disappearances seriously because the women were sex workers and mostly from Canada\u2019s indigenous community.\n\nThe death in 1971 of Helen Betty Osborne, 19, a Cree Aboriginal woman who was abducted and murdered in the street in Manitoba, prompted the wave of campaigning that finally culminated in the inquiry\u2019s launch.\n\nIn her wake came thousands of cases of deaths and disappearances that activists say were not properly investigated.\n\nThey range from the deaths of Gloria Moody, 27, in 1969 to that of 14-year-old Aielah Saric-Auger in 2006. The Sisters in Spirit movement published a report in 2009 of the personal stories of the women and girls.\n\nCBC News has a database of 308 cases, including 66 since 2019.\n\nMore aboutCanadaNative AmericansmurderJustin Trudeau\nJoin our commenting forum\n\nJoin thought-provoking conversations, follow other Independent readers and see their replies\n\nComments\nMost Popular\nGeneral election - live: Huge voter turnout at polls today\nGeneral election results: When will key seats be announced tonight?\nGoFundMe for Stormy Daniels tops $800k after she reveals threats faced\nJay Slater could have survived \u2018drinking rainwater\u2019, investigator says\nPaedophile teacher caught smirking buying teenage victim Gucci belt\nPopular videos\nEd Davey casts vote in general election: \u2018Lovely day isn\u2019t it?\u2019\nCount Binface promises 99 ice creams to remain 99p in election plea\nMiriam Margolyes causes chaos as she swears live on Loose Women\nSponsored Features\nGET IN TOUCH\nContact us\nOUR PRODUCTS\nSubscribe\nRegister\nNewsletters\nToday\u2019s Edition\nInstall our app\nArchive\nOTHER PUBLICATIONS\nInternational editions\nIndependent en Espa\u00f1ol\nIndependent Arabia\nIndependent Turkish\nIndependent Persian\nIndependent Urdu\nEvening Standard\nEXTRAS\nAdvisor\nPuzzles\nAll topics\nBetting Offers\nVoucher codes\nCompetitions and offers\nIndependent Advertising\nIndependent Ignite\nSyndication\nWorking at The Independent\nLEGAL\nCode of conduct and complaints\nContributors\nCookie policy\nPrivacy notice\nUser policies\nModern Slavery Act"},

May. 5th, 2021\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nMayor Lyn Hall and Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-spirit people awareness day proclamation (Photo by Dione Wearmouth, mypgnow.com)\n- Advertisement -\nRed Dress hanging on a tree on the side of Highway 16 (Photo by Dione Wearmouth, myppgnow.com)\n\nIt is National Red Dress Day, the one day a year where Canadians honour the Missing and Murdered Indigenous women and girls across the country.\n\nToday (Wednesday), a proclamation signed by Mayor Lyn Hall was presented at a drum circle on the corner of Highway 16 and Ferry Ave declaring May 5th as \u2018Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People awareness day\u2019 in Prince George.\n\nThis comes as Indigenous women are much more likely to become a homicide victim compared to their non-Indigenous counterparts.\n\nAccording to Statistics Canada, Indigenous women are almost six times more likely than non-Indigenous women to become homicide victims.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nWesley Mitchell is a Prince George resident that has first-hand experience with these morbid statistics, he\u2019s the co-organizer of a couple of events being hosted today (Wednesday).\n\n\u201cFor me it means, it\u2019s a landmark day, it\u2019s the start of a future for more awareness so we can make a change,\u201d Mitchell added.\n\nHe says this issue has impacted his family immensely and one day a year is not enough.\n\nMitchell participates in these events for his lost family members, including his relative Frances Brown, who went missing in 2017 while mushroom picking North of Smithers.\n\nJessica Patrick (Photo provided by Wes Mitchell)\n\n\u201cThen the very next year my brother and niece lost their sister-in-law Jessica Patrick, who was murdered in Smithers,\u201d he added.\n\nHe\u2019s been participating in events since 2015 when he walked for Ramona Wilson, who was killed in Smithers.\n\nThe day also recognizes the lives of non-Indigenous souls lost in Northern BC.\n\n\u201cWe also have in our hearts the non-Indigenous souls lost like the Madison Scott\u2019s and the Nicole Hoar\u2019s,\u201d added Mitchell.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nMadison Scott has been missing since she was last seen at Hogback Lake in 2011, while Nicole Hoar was last seen in Prince George in 2002.\n\n\u201cWe have no justice,\u201d stated Mitchell,\u201d we have no justice or answers for Frances, no justice for Jessica, no justice for Ramona and this includes the men like Colton Fleury.\u201d\n\nColton Fleury was 16-years-old when he went vanished from Prince George in 2018.\n\nThere will be a ceremony honoring victims at Cottonwood Park this evening at 6 pm.\n\nSomething going on in the Prince George area you {"url": "https://www.mbcradio.com/2021/05/fsin-calling-for-greater-supports-of-indigenous-women-on-national-red-dress-day", "title": "FSIN calling for greater supports of Indigenous women on National Red Dress Day - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nFSIN calling for greater supports of Indigenous women on National Red Dress Day\n\nby MBC News | May 5, 2021 | Current News\n\n(Crystal in La Loche wears red to remember her mother Janet Sylvestre. Janet was 37 years old when she was last seen in Saskatoon on October 12, 1994. Her remains were found in a rural area outside of Saskatoon on October 13, 1994. Credit the Sask RCMP Twitter.)\n\nAs the country marks today as National Red Dress Day, Indigenous Peoples are calling for immediate supports for women and girls, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nRed Dress Day was created to raise awareness to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and gender-based violence, including violence towards two-spirited people.\n\n\u201cThis government continues to pat itself on the back, claiming to be doing all that they can. But I\u2019m calling that bluff. For 14 years, the SaskParty has put First Nations and M\u00e9tis issues on the back burner, or they use them to divide Saskatchewan people to score cheap political points.\u201d said NDP MLA Betty Nippi-Albright.\n\nSaskatchewan RCMP said officers are currently investigating 27 open cases of Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, adding each case in equally important.\n\nThe province says it has taken action on addressing gender-based violence through ending birth alerts earlier this year and funding First Nations and M\u00e9tis projects. \u201cIn December of 2020, we announced $400,000 for the First Nation and M\u00e9tis projects to finish focus on issues raised by that National Inquiry,\u201d explained Social Services Minister Lori Carr, who answered in the Legislature Wednesday as Minister of Government Relations, Minister Responsible for First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Northern Affairs Don McMorris was absent.\n\nHowever, the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations is seeking greater investment for services to women in need.\n\n\u201cThe number of women and families being turned away from emergency shelters because they are at full capacity, heightened food insecurities, as well as inadequate housing are compounding factors that are maintaining high levels of violence and persistent hardships\u201d Vice Chief Bear said.\u00a0 \u201cAs leaders and government agencies, we must ensure there is adequate supports during and after this pandemic.\u201d\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},

THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\u00a0\n\nRed\u00a0dresses are set\u00a0to\u00a0be\u00a0on display across the country Friday\u00a0to\u00a0recognize the National\u00a0Day\u00a0of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known\u00a0as\u00a0Red\u00a0Dress\u00a0Day\u00a0and the empty garments serve\u00a0as\u00a0a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are\u00a0more\u00a0events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\u201cI'm a mother. I'm a sister. I'm an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I'm just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times\u00a0more\u00a0likely\u00a0to\u00a0be\u00a0murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\u00a0\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted\u00a0to\u00a0genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\u00a0\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due\u00a0to\u00a0violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\u00a0\n\nA group hung 101\u00a0red\u00a0dresses along a chain-link fence outside a landfill in the Manitoba capital over the winter. Winnipeg police have said the bodies of four Indigenous women were disposed of in landfills last year.\u00a0\n\nThe remains of three of the women have not been found. A man has been charged with first-degree murder in the killings of the four women.\n\nThe remains of another Indigenous woman were also found in a landfill earlier this year. Police said her death is not a homicide.\u00a0\n\n\"When I think (about it), I cry,\" DeLaronde said. \"I have\u00a0to\u00a0focus on the thousands of women and girls that are still here and how we can keep them safe.\"\n\nDeLaronde said it's important\u00a0to\u00a0recognize that Indigenous people are sacred, and they should not only\u00a0be\u00a0honoured\u00a0when they are gone.\n\nThe House of Commons unanimously backed a motion Tuesday declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. It also called for funding a new system\u00a0to\u00a0alert the public when someone goes missing.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThe truth is the truth,\u201d said Leah Gazan, the Winnipeg member of Parliament who presented the motion. \u201cIt's one thing\u00a0to\u00a0acknowledge truth. It's another thing\u00a0to\u00a0act on it.\u201d\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has criticized the federal government for not doing\u00a0more\u00a0or acting fast enough. McBride said Tuesday\u2019s motion was an important step, but there is\u00a0more\u00a0to\u00a0do.\n\nMost of the money announced\u00a0to\u00a0fulfil the inquiry's 231 calls\u00a0to\u00a0justice became stuck in government bureaucracy, DeLaronde said, and it has not made it\u00a0to\u00a0the front lines and the Indigenous women and families who need it.\n\nDeLaronde added that all Canadians should use\u00a0Red\u00a0Dress\u00a0Day\u00a0to\u00a0reflect on what they can do\u00a0to\u00a0create change.\u00a0\n\n\"Red\u00a0Dress\u00a0is a movement that people can get behind, because it's an {"url": "https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a43519171/native-american-women-deserve-to-be-counted/", "title": "Native American Women Deserve to Be Counted", "body": "Skip to Content\nFASHION\nBEAUTY\nCULTURE\nNEWS & POLITICS\nHOROSCOPES\nSubscribe\nSIGN IN\nCultureNews & Politics\nNative American Women Deserve to Be Counted\n\nWe have no idea how many Native women and girls are missing and murdered each year.\n\nBY MONA GABLEPUBLISHED: APR 26, 2023 10:00 AM EDT\nSave Article\nNURPHOTO//GETTY IMAGES\n\nEvery item on this page was chosen by an ELLE editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.\n\nNo one knows how many Native American women and girls are missing and murdered each year. Yet everyone concedes there is a crisis, a \u201chidden epidemic,\u201d as former Democratic senator Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota has called it. Although the federal government keeps data on virtually everything, it does not collect statistics on missing and murdered Native women and girls. It has no national database where tribes can report such crimes, no way for families or tribal investigators to seek information.\n\n\u201cThe problem has been going on for hundreds of years with little or no intervention by the federal government,\u201d Sarah Deer, a professor of women, gender, and sexuality studies at the University of Kansas, told me. \u201cIt\u2019s getting attention now, but the problem is not new.\u201d\n\nEven without exact numbers, the statistics that do exist on the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\u2019s (MMIW) crisis are staggering. In 2016, the Federal Bureau of Investigation\u2019s National Crime Information Center (NCIC), which tracks missing persons, pegged the total number of missing Native American and Alaska Native women and girls at 5,712. Yet this figure was undoubtedly low. Only 116 of these reports were logged into the Department of Justice\u2019s federal missing persons\u2019 database, a resource that allows law enforcement agencies to share information.\n\nAlthough the 2015 Tribal Access Program (TAP) was supposed to effect tribes\u2019 access to NCIC, that has been slow to happen. As of 2019, only 47 of the 573 federally recognized tribes in the United States were participating. That lack of access, due in part to the costs of updating computers, is critical. It means that many crimes go unreported, and tribal investigators who are called to a crime scene have a limited ability to pull up information on potential suspects. As a result, many cases go uninvestigated, unsolved.\n\nLEILA NAVIDI/STAR TRIBUNE VIA AP\nMissy Jackson, 23, of Minneapolis, attends a prayer circle for Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind, who was abducted and killed in 2017 near Fargo, North Dakota. People wore green ribbons to honor Savanna, her favorite color.\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\n\nThe cost isn\u2019t supposed to be a hurdle. The US Crime Victims Fund, a pot of billions of dollars drawn entirely from fines and penalties incurred by offenders, is intended to make resources available to local police forces for computer updates. It is also, significantly, supposed to pay for rehabilitation and preventive services, for victim compensation, and for victim services.\n\nBut every year tribes have had to fight for their share, mostly because they rely on states to disperse the money. According to a Department of Justice report released in 2017, \u201cfrom 2010 through 2014, state governments passed only 0.5 percent of the available funds to programs serving tribal victims, leaving a significant unmet need in most tribal communities.\u201d\n\nNationally, Native women are more than twice as likely to be raped or sexually assaulted as any other group of females in the country.\n\nEven those tribes with access to the NCIC database frequently don\u2019t enter records. Native advocates say that a lack of staff is part of the problem. But there\u2019s also a deeper, historical reason for the absence of reliable data. Distrust of law enforcement, fear they won\u2019t be believed, that nothing will result, ensure many Native women and girls don\u2019t report. The result is a climate of such pervasive unpunished crime that it is difficult to comprehend. In 2016, a report from the National Institute of Justice painted a jarring picture of this violence. Nationally, Native women are more than twice as likely to be raped or sexually assaulted as any other group of females in the country. On some reservations, Native women are murdered at more than ten times the national average. Nearly one in three Native American and Alaska Native women will experience rape or attempted rape in her lifetime. Native women also suffer intolerably high rates of physical violence\u201490 percent of it committed by non-Native intimate partners.\n\nThe reasons for this singular violence against Native women are complex. But they amount to, in essence, a level of racism so ancient and entrenched in America that it continues to poison how Native women are perceived today\u2014as inferior exotic beings, as sexualized objects. \u201cWe\u2019re targeted for who we are, what we represent, as Indian women and our sovereign nation,\u201d Lisa Brunner, a member of the White Earth Ojibwe Nation, and co-director of the Indigenous Women\u2019s Human Rights Collective, Inc., told me.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t take much to conjure an example of this racist mentality. It saturates American culture, from fashion to sports, to seemingly benign childhood rituals like Halloween, when young non-Native women mindlessly don Pocahontas costumes. Native advocates with decades of experience helping victims of domestic violence, sexual assault, and sex trafficking have found these stereotypes to be not just offensive but exceedingly dangerous. \u201cOftentimes we get romanticized,\u201d Brunner, who has repeatedly testified before Congress on the need to pass meaningful legislation to protect Native women and girls, said to me. \u201cVictoria\u2019s Secret plays a role in that. When you have models going down the runway wearing headdresses, it continues to foster that romanticism and increases the level of violence perpetuated against us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\nARTUR WIDAK/NURPHOTO VIA GETTY//GETTY IMAGES\nHundreds of women participated in the annual Red Dress Day march in downtown Edmonton, to commemorate the lives of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls across Canada.\n\nThe crisis is also inextricably tied to the confusing matrix of laws governing Indian Country. \u201cIt is often perceived as easier to \u2018get away\u2019 with certain crimes on reservations because there is a lack of tribal policing and lack of tribal jurisdiction,\u201d Cheryl Redhorse Bennett, an assistant professor of American Indian Studies at Arizona State University, told me. Although reservations are sovereign nations, the 1978 Supreme Court case Oliphant v. Suquamish Indian Tribe stripped tribes of their authority to punish non-Natives on tribal lands. This means that federal, tribal, and state agencies split jurisdiction. So when a crime occurs, it can be baffling to deter- mine who is supposed to be leading the investigation.\n\n\nSay a Native woman is sexually assaulted. Where did it happen? On the reservation or off? If her attacker is Native and it occurred on the reservation, then tribal police and courts have jurisdiction. If her attacker is non-Native, then the FBI or state investigates. If she is assaulted off the reservation, the state is supposed to act.\n\n\nAs for felonies like murder, rape, and kidnapping, if they happen on tribal lands, the Department of Justice is supposed to prosecute. But the reality is the agency often doesn\u2019t. In recent years, the Department of Justice has pursued prosecution in only about half of murder cases on reservations and in a little over a third of cases of sexual assault. In 2017, under mounting pressure to address this crisis, the department still declined more than one-third of the cases referred to them by reservation authorities.\n\nIndigenous women who are missing or murdered disappear not just once, but three times: \u201cin life, in the media, in the data.\u201d\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\n\nBut what of Native women and girls who go missing in American cities? More than 70 percent of American Indian and Alaska Natives live in urban enclaves, where crimes are investigated by local law enforcement authorities. Still, no one knows how many Native women and girls have disappeared or been murdered in cities in the United States, because there\u2019s been little effort by police departments or other law enforcement agencies to keep track.\n\nIn 2018, Abigail Echo-Hawk, director of the Urban Indian Health Institute (UIHI) in Seattle, and Annita Lucchesi, a doctoral intern at the UIHI, tried to provide an answer. After contacting police departments in seventy- one cities across the country, they got a telling and sobering response. In their report, released that November, the Native American researchers found nearly 60 percent of police departments either did not respond to the request, or returned incomplete or faulty data. The indifference, the incompetence, didn\u2019t end there. Some cities reported being unable to even identify Native victims. Others put down a woman\u2019s race based on memory.\n\nIn several instances, cities couldn\u2019t search for Native American, American Indian, or Alaskan Native victims within their databases because their computer systems simply weren\u2019t built for it. The police department in Fargo, North Dakota, which has a fairly sizable Native American population, was typical. If a victim\u2019s race was not indicated, the city\u2019s record system \u201cdefaults to white,\u201d the researchers were told. Other cities turned in data that confused Native Americans with Indian Americans, with surnames such as \u201cSingh.\u201d In some cases, police departments did not distinguish between missing or murdered victims.\n\nWith such shoddy police reporting, Echo-Hawk and Lucchesi turned elsewhere. They combed media outlets for accounts of missing and murdered women, and spoke with them about their reporting. They spoke with local Indigenous communities. As a result, they uncovered more than 150 missing and murdered women whom police had failed to identify.\n\n$14 at Amazon\n\nThere\u2019s a refrain you hear from Native American advocates about this stark invisibility. As the researchers wrote in their report, Indigenous women who are missing or murdered disappear not just once, but three times: \u201cin life, in the media, in the data.\u201d\n\nMy book, Searching for Savanna, is the story of one woman in one tribe, but her life and her death illuminate this ongoing crisis and the efforts by Native women to resolve it. Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind, who was eight months pregnant when she was murdered, and all the missing and murdered Native women like her, deserve to be remembered and counted.\n\nAdapted from the book Searching for Savanna: The Murder of One Native American Woman and the Violence Against the Many by Mona Gable. Copyright \u00a9 2023. Available from Atria Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nMary Peltola Is a Voice for Native People\nSay the Names of Missing Native Women\nThe Only U.S. Abortion Fund for Native Americans\n\n\n\n\nAdvertisement - Continue Reading Below\nNews & Politics\n\nJane\u00e9 Kassanavoid Found Her Purpose Off the Field\n\nSen. According to a news release, Groulx is \u201cleaving to pursue a new opportunity.\u201d \u2013 Apr 12, 2024\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nEditor\u2019s note: This article has been updated after the federal Indigenous Services Minister clarified the type of audit the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada is undergoing, as well as after the departure of CEO Lynne Groulx\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) is reeling after Ottawa cut $48 million from the advocacy organization, resulting in a staff of 75 being reduced to 30.\n\n\u201cLeaving us to start the fiscal year with $10 million \u2014 that\u2019s a very significant decrease,\u201d CEO Lynne Groulx told Global News.\n\nOn Friday, April 12, the organization also announced the departure of Groulx after 6.5 years. Groulx, a lawyer and former Canadian Human Rights Commission adviser, is \u201cleaving to pursue a new opportunity,\u201d NWAC said.\n\nA national apprenticeship program and several smaller programs administered by NWAC ended in March and with that ended the federal funding.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nGroulx said NWAC has long lobbied for stable core funding to operate, and not just project funding, which comes and goes.\n\nThe organization has found itself in the crosshairs of critics over how it has spent money in recent years, renovating its head office in Gatineau to include high-end event rental spaces, opening luxury \u201cresiliency lodges\u201d in Quebec and New Brunswick, and until this funding cut, planned to start a boutique hotel.\n\n\u201cHow does that serve grassroots women?\u201d said Crystal Semaganis, who worked at NWAC from 2021 to 2023 but left citing a toxic workplace. \u201cHow does that make a difference in our life?\u201d\n\nMORE ON CANADA\nHurricane Beryl forces Canadian airlines to cancel flights. Now it\u2019s been declared world\u2019s smartest\n5 ideas for greening your outdoor space for a potential mood boost\n\nGroulx said those business ventures will eventually pay for the advocacy work NWAC does, leaving it better positioned to withstand the funding whims of Ottawa.\n\nThe daily email you need for Edmonton's top news stories.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re doing our best to supplement our revenues and one of the ways is generating our own-source revenue,\u201d said Groulx, \u201cand lessen our dependency on taxpayer dollars and government funding.\u201d\n\nBut the ventures are just two years old and not making enough to offset the nearly $50-million cut.\n\nIndigenous Services Minister Patty Hajdu wouldn\u2019t comment on why the tap was turned off or if it will be turned back on. She noted NWAC is undergoing an audit to discover if all aspects of the funding agreement between the organization and the federal government were met.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll have more to say once that\u2019s complete,\u201d Hajdu said.\n\nGroulx pointed to seven years of audits publicly available on the NWAC website.\n\n\u201cOnce that audit is complete, I\u2019m fully convinced NWAC has complied with the rules, and that audit will be on our website as well.\u201d\n\nAside from the controversial foray into luxury businesses, Semaganis is part of a chorus who believe NWAC lost its way as a powerful advocacy group after the Sisters In Spirit project wrapped in 2010. The campaign began in 2004 and is largely credited with putting the issue of Missing and Murdered Indigenous women on the national agenda.\n\nBridget Tolley was involved in that project but parted ways with NWAC, often publicly criticizing it for not supporting families of the missing and murdered.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy this happened,\u201d Tolley said of the defunding. \u201cBecause we deserve a lot more, a lot better treatment because so many have been hurt by everything that\u2019s happened over there.\u201d\n\nView image in full screen\nBridget Tolley is a Missing and Murdered Women advocate who believes the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has lost its way. Global News\n\nShe\u2019s referring to nearly a decade of headlines about infighting, leadership coups and allegations of a toxic workplace at NWAC, along with criticism that too many non-Indigenous people were taking up space in the Indigenous organization.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\nView image in full screen\nCrystal Semaganis left the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada is among the many former workers who call it a toxic workplace. Crystal Semaganis\n\n\u201cA lot of dysfunction, a lot of mismanagement, and the administrative follow through of what they were actually trying to do \u2014 just was not there,\u201d Semaganis said.\n\nShe and Tolley hope this isn\u2019t the end for NWAC, but rather a pause ahead of a restructuring.\n\n\u201cThere should be fixing,\u201d Semaganis said. \u201cThere should be meaningful Indigenous engagement.\u201d\n\nAddressing her departure from the organization, Groulx said, \u201cLeaving the role you love is always difficult. It has been an honour and incredible journey leading NWAC and contributing to its success. I am immensely proud of what we have accomplished together and am confident in NWAC\u2019s future.\n\n\u201cIt was a privilege to have served in this role. That said, I am very excited about the prospects of my new role, leading a new enterprise that focuses on social business and Indigenous prosperity.\u201d\n\nADVERTISEMENT\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2024 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nChilcotin hunting guides say government backtracking on compensation pledge\nChild welfare resolutions barred from upcoming AFN assembly\nADVERTISEMENT\n630 CHED Afternoons with Bryn Griffiths & Reid Wilkins\n2:00 PM - 5:00 PM\n630CHED\nTrending\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. {"url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/we-are-in-a-crisis-red-dress-day-honoured-as-leaders-say-more-work-to-be-done-1.6385283", "title": "Red Dress Day for missing, murdered Indigenous women, girls | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nPower Play\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nLOCAL\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nSHOPPING TRENDS\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nCANADA\nNews\n'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\nKnaika wears a jacket she made with artwork that says 'No More Stolen Sisters' during a Red Dress Day ceremony marking the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirited people in Canada, on May 5, 2022. (Darryl Dyck / THE CANADIAN PRESS)\nKelly Geraldine Malone\nThe Canadian Press\nStaff\nContact\nPublished May 5, 2023 3:59 a.m. MDT\nShare\n\nThe head of the Native Women's Association of Canada says it's clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\n\n\"We are in a crisis,\" said Carol McBride.\n\nDownload our app to get alerts to your device\nGet the latest newsletters right to your inbox\n\nRed dresses are set to be on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nNDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women\nThis massive newspaper contains 'cover stories' of hundreds of MMIWG to spur national action\nIndigenous women more likely to face violence if they were a child in care: report\nOttawa moves toward creating Indigenous and human rights ombudsperson role\nA lifetime of agony: Families of missing, murdered Inuit women call for answers\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\"I'm a mother. I'm a sister. I'm an aunt,\" she said. \"And I'm just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\"\n\nThe inquiry's final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\n\nA group hung 101 red dresses along a chain-link fence outside a landfill in the Manitoba capital over the winter. Winnipeg police have said the bodies of four Indigenous women were disposed of in landfills last year.\n\nThe remains of three of the women have not been found. A man has been charged with first-degree murder in the killings of the four women.\n\nThe remains of another Indigenous woman were also found in a landfill earlier this year. Police said her death is not a homicide.\n\n\"When I think (about it), I cry,\" DeLaronde said. \"I have to focus on the thousands of women and girls that are still here and how we can keep them safe.\"\n\nDeLaronde said it's important to recognize that Indigenous people are sacred, and they should not only be honoured when they are gone.\n\nThe House of Commons unanimously backed a motion Tuesday declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. It also called for funding a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\n\n\"The truth is the truth,\" said Leah Gazan, the Winnipeg member of Parliament who presented the motion. \"It's one thing to acknowledge truth. It's another thing to act on it.\"\n\nThe Native Women's Association of Canada has criticized the federal government for not doing more or acting fast enough. McBride said Tuesday's motion was an important step, but there is more to do.\n\nCapital Dispatch: Sign up for in-depth political coverage of Parliament Hill\n(opens in a new tab)\n\nMost of the money announced to fulfil the inquiry's 231 calls to justice became stuck in government bureaucracy, DeLaronde said, and it has not made it to the front lines and the Indigenous women and families who need it.\n\nDeLaronde added that all Canadians should use Red Dress Day to reflect on what they can do to create change.\n\n\"Red Dress is a movement that people can get behind, because it's an opportunity to transform the very fabric of this country.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 5, 2023\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nRed dresses are hung from trees during a Red Dress Day ceremony in Vancouver, B.C., on May 5, 2022.
