{"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/425154/We-are-in-a-crisis-Red-Dress-Day-honoured-as-leaders-say-more-work-to-be-done", "title": "'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done - Canada News - Castanet.net", "body": "27\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nCanada\u00a0\u00a0\n'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\nRED DRESS DAY: CRISIS LINGERS\nThe Canadian Press - May 5, 2023 / 6:22 am | Story: 425154\nPhoto: The Canadian Press\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\n\nRed dresses are set to be on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\u201cI'm a mother. I'm a sister. I'm an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I'm just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\n\nA group hung 101 red dresses along a chain-link fence outside a landfill in the Manitoba capital over the winter. Winnipeg police have said the bodies of four Indigenous women were disposed of in landfills last year.\n\nThe remains of three of the women have not been found. A man has been charged with first-degree murder in the killings of the four women.\n\nThe remains of another Indigenous woman were also found in a landfill earlier this year. Police said her death is not a homicide.\n\n\"When I think (about it), I cry,\" DeLaronde said. \"I have to focus on the thousands of women and girls that are still here and how we can keep them safe.\"\n\nDeLaronde said it's important to recognize that Indigenous people are sacred, and they should not only be honoured when they are gone.\n\nThe House of Commons unanimously backed a motion Tuesday declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. It also called for funding a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\n\n\u201cThe truth is the truth,\u201d said Leah Gazan, the Winnipeg member of Parliament who presented the motion. \u201cIt's one thing to acknowledge truth. It's another thing to act on it.\u201d\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has criticized the federal government for not doing more or acting fast enough. McBride said Tuesday\u2019s motion was an important step, but there is more to do.\n\nMost of the money announced to fulfil the inquiry's 231 calls to justice became stuck in government bureaucracy, DeLaronde said, and it has not made it to the front lines and the Indigenous women and families who need it.\n\nDeLaronde added that all Canadians should use Red Dress Day to reflect on what they can do to create change.\n\n\"Red Dress is a movement that people can get behind, because it's an opportunity to transform the very fabric of this country.\"\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n8\nShares\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Canada News\n\n\n\nCanada\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in prison for murder\nAbbotsford - 1:39 pm\nA parade of aches and pains\nCalgary - 1:27 pm\nPower restored in Aberdeen\nKamloops - 1:16 pm\nMore Top Stories >\nCanada Quick Links\nCanada Discussion Forum\nGovernment of Canada\nService Canada\nCanada Revenue Agency\nStatistics Canada\nStrategis\nCanada Post\nEnvironment Canada\n\n\n\n\nBody transformation journeys\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\nVanessa Hudgens gives birth\nShowbiz | July 04, 2024\nBaseball playing pup\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nMischievous Beagle caught tearing up the toilet paper\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nVintage bathrooms\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\n\n\n\u00a9 2024 Castanet.net Make Castanet Your Homepage News Tips Advertising Contact Us"},
{"url": "https://ottawa.ctvnews.ca/observance-at-ottawa-city-hall-meant-to-give-time-to-process-meaning-of-national-red-dress-day-1.6873116", "title": "Red Dress Day: Observance held in advance of May 5 | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News At Five\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nOTTAWA\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nADVERTISEMENT\nOTTAWA\nNews\nObservance at Ottawa City Hall meant to give time to process meaning of National Red Dress Day\nSam Houpt\nCTV News Ottawa Multi-Skilled Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 3, 2024 4:56 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nIn advance of National Red Dress Day on Sunday, May 5, the Ottawa Aboriginal Coalition (OAC) held its own observance at City Hall Friday.\n\nThe day is meant to shine a light on the suffering of Indigenous women and girls in Canada, who have statistically been higher-than-average victims of violence, sexual assault, and murder. OAC officials say the reasoning behind holding an early event was to give attendees time to process the day's meaning ahead of May 5.\n\nSign up now for daily CTV News Ottawa newsletters\nThe information you need to know, sent directly to you: Download the CTV News App\n\n\"I hope that people will walk away with an understanding and awareness of the severity of what First Nations, Inuit and M\u00e9tis women, girls, and children have had to endure,\" said OAC co-chair Stephanie (Mikki) Adams on Friday.\n\nThe Ottawa River Singers bookended the ceremony with a drum circle, while Indigenous leaders read opening prayers.\n\nAs attendees crafted miniature red dresses to put up on poster boards, they were invited to present offerings to ones on display that bear the names of woman and girls who never made it home.\n\nFor event artist Orianna Elijah-Brown, who contributed seven dresses for the day, she says it was a difficult project to undertake.\n\n\"I was pretty down because I was listening to a lot of the stories of the some of the missing and murdered Indigenous women,\" Elijah-Brown recalled. \"I heard stories similar to like myself - some of the girls were sewers and artists and it was really emotional listening to those stories while making the dresses.\"\n\nAt the far side of the venue was a gallery detailing the suffering and achievements of Indigenous peoples.\n\nPhotos detail the chronology, from settlers arriving on Turtle Island in the 15th century, to the systematic oppression of First Nation, Inuit, and M\u00e9tis communities, to the discovery of mass graves resulting from residential schools.\n\n\"It's touching me profoundly, actually, to see it, and I've known about it for a long time, but to actually see images like that is very powerful,\" said resident Liz Wigfull.\n\n\"It really speaks to what people have suffered over such a long time,\" said Wendy Muckle. \"It's hard to imagine how long it's going to take us to make it right.\"\n\nWhile the day highlighted the nation's dark history, it also focused on the healing work that has been accomplished in the community, including the establishing of the Indigenous Women's Safety Table.\n\n\"You've got community leadership happening here in Ottawa, where the local Indigenous community comes together and works collectively towards building Ottawa to be a safer place,\" said Ontario Native Women's Association CEO Cora McGuire-Cyrrette.\u00a0\n\n----------\n\nHope for Wellness Help Line 24/7 1-855-242-3310\n\nNational Residential School Crisis Line: 1-866-925-4419\n\nMental Health Crisis Line (24 hours a day/7 days a week) at 613-722-6914 or if outside Ottawa toll-free at 1-866-996-0991\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nA photo gallery at a Red Dress Day event at Ottawa City Hall depicts the chronology from settlers arriving on Turtle Island in the 15th century, to the recent discovery of mass graves resulting from residential schools. The vigil aims to raise awareness of the alarmingly high rates of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Canada; between 1,000 and 4,000 women and girls have gone missing or have been murdered since the 1970s. {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/new-cell-service-coming-to-highway-of-tears-1.23477732", "title": "New cell service coming to Highway of Tears - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nNew cell service coming to Highway of Tears\nNew wireless coverage is on its way to a neglected portion of the Highway of Tears.\nCitizen Staff\nOct 26, 2018 11:23 AM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nMetro Creative image\n\nNew wireless coverage is on its way to a neglected portion of the Highway of Tears.\n\nConstruction of a cell tower that began in September should be completed within the next few months and once it is, continuous coverage along 22 kilometres from New Hazelton to Smithers will be in place, the provincial government said Friday.\n\n\"This new cell tower will make it much easier for people to call for help during an emergency and is another essential element to further improve safety along Highway 16,\" said Citizens' Services Minister Jinny Sims in a news release.\n\nHighway 16 West, from Prince George to Prince Rupert, has been known as the Highway of Tears for the number of women who have gone missing or have been murdered along the stretch.\n\nThe provincial government provided a one-time $1.2-million grant for the project. It was administered by Northern Development Initiative Trust which selected Rogers Communications for the project following an open-procurement process.\n\nWhen operational, the tower will enable voice, data and text services via high-speed wireless and internet coverage on 4G and LTE networks for Rogers and Fido customers. Customers using other providers will be able to dial 911 in the community and along the highway.\n\nIt will also bring service to the Witset First Nation, the only band along the corridor without cell coverage. Formerly known as the Moricetown Band, it is located 34 kilometres north of Smithers and along the Bulkley River Valley. Witset comprises seven First Nation communities adding up to about 900 people.\n\nA further 5,000 Smithers-and-area residents will also benefit, the provincial government said.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.yorktonthisweek.com/news/red-dresses-hang-in-the-trees-at-niagara-s-post-secondary-institutions-1.24280367", "title": "Red dresses hang in the trees at Niagara\u2019s post-secondary institutions - SaskToday.ca", "body": "Skip to content\nSign in or register for your free account  \nHomeWest Central & North\nEast Central\nSouthwest\nSoutheast\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nConnect\nHOME CENTRAL LOCAL NEWS\nRed dresses hang in the trees at Niagara\u2019s post-secondary institutions\nto symbolize missing and murdered Indigenous women\nSean Vanderklis\nFeb 10, 2021 2:24 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\u00a0\nIn conjunction with Niagara College, Brock University is hosting a weeklong event to bring attention to the violence that plagues Indigenous women.\n\u00a0\nThe REDress Project, originated at University of Winnepeg in 2011 by M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black, has since been replicated nationwide.\n\u00a0\nEmpty red dresses signify the loss of life of thousands of Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit, lesbian, gay, trans, bisexual, queer, questioning, intersex and asexual people over the past 40 years to colonial violence.\n\u00a0\nSince 2019, red dresses have been visible on Brock\u2019s campus.\n\u00a0\nFor Ashley Buck, Indigenous student success leader at Niagara College, the art installation is personal.\n\u00a0\n\u201cIt\u2019s tough. These are our friends and our family members,\u201d she said.\n\u00a0\n\u201cThe process of hanging red dresses is to evoke emotion and address a lived reality for many Indigenous communities,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was designed to serve as a reminder of how deep this affects our communities.\n\u00a0\n\u201cMany Indigenous people know more than one woman or child who has lost their life or has mysteriously vanished.\u201d\n\u00a0\nThe REDress event kicked off on Monday. The theme of Monday\u2019s event was Families of MMIWG. Local Indigenous activist and community member Linda John shared her family\u2019s experiences.\n\u00a0\nThe event will culminate on Friday with the screening of \u201cOur Sisters in Spirit.\u201d It is a paid event with all proceeds going to Abbey House; a St. Catharines-based Indigenous women\u2019s transitional home.\n\u00a0\nThis year, due to novel coronavirus, the university elected to transition to an online format. The REDress Project will bring together speakers from across the country to highlight some of the issues affecting Indigenous women.\n\u00a0\nFour of five panel discussions will be broadcast on Niagara College and Brock social media platforms. The exception being Wednesday\u2019s event, Brock\u2019s Decolonial Reading Circle hosts Helen Knott. All interested participants will have to register.\n\u00a0\nBrock\u2019s acting vice-provost, Indigenous engagement, Robyn Bourgeois said continuing to raise awareness of the longstanding injustices Indigenous women face is of critical importance.\n\u00a0\n\u201cViolence against Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGTBQQIA people has always been a part of colonialism in Canada, and it continues to be a part of Canadian society because Canada remains a colonial country,\u201d she said in a statement.\n\u00a0\n\u201cWhile Canada undertook a formal inquiry into this violence, the government has yet to respond to its findings and, more importantly, take action to protect Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGTBQQIA people from violence. This inaction comes with a tremendous cost for Indigenous Peoples.\u201d\n\u00a0\nFor information on the event, visit Brock\u2019s website: https://bit.ly/3aTNvAq.\n\u00a0\nSean Vanderklis is a Niagara-based reporter for the Niagara Falls Review. His reporting is funded by the Canadian government through its Local Journalism Initiative. {"url": "https://www.newwestrecord.ca/local-news/new-west-honours-red-dress-day-with-display-of-red-dresses-6905140", "title": "What is happening in New Westminster BC for Red Dress Day? - New West Record", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\nReaders Choice\n25.6 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nNew West honours Red Dress Day with display of red dresses\nHere\u2019s what New Westminster is doing for Red Dress Day - and how you can get involved\n\tTheresa McManus\n\nApr 25, 2023 9:00 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nThe City of New Westminster created a display in Queen's Park in 2021 for Red Dress Day. Displays are being planned for 2023. photo Theresa McManus\nListen to this article\n00:03:28\n\nA display of red dresses around the community is one of the ways New Westminster is commemorating Red Dress Day.\n\nMay 5 is Red Dress Day, a day that honours the memory and lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people across Canada and the United States. As part of this year\u2019s campaign, the City of New Westminster will be creating a display of red dresses in the community.\n\nAnyone wishing to donate an adult-sized red dress (no logos) can drop them off until Thursday, April 27 at the front desk of Anvil Centre, Centennial Community Centre, Century House, New Westminster City Hall, the #1 fire hall at Sixth and McBride, the police station, the main branch of the New Westminster Public Library, Queensborough Community Centre and Queen\u2019s Park Arena.\n\nNew Westminster City Hall will also be lit up in red in hour of Red Dress Day on May 5.\n\nMayor Patrick Johnstone has proclaimed May 5 as Red Dress Day in New Westminster.\n\n\u201cM\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black helped inspire the red dress movement where red dresses are hung from windows and trees as a representation of the pain and loss felt by loved ones and survivors,\u201d said the proclamation. \u201cIndigenous women and girls are five times more likely to experience violence than any other population in Canada. This is a national crisis that requires urgent, informed and collaborative action.\u201d\n\nThe proclamation said the Red Dress Campaign is being organized jointly by the Spirit of the Children Society and the City of New Westminster. It stated that non-Indigenous people have a role to play in the fight for justice for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender diverse people in this country.\n\nCoun. Nadine Nakagawa said some people may think the issue has gone away since the federal government did a national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u201cIt very clearly hasn\u2019t,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s nonstop news reports across Canada, including our larger Metro Vancouver community, about Indigenous women and girls and two-spirit folks going missing and being murdered.\u201d\n\nLaunched in September 2016, the national inquiry published its final report in June 2019.\n\n\u201cThere are actions for all levels of government, including us, to take from that report,\u201d Nakagawa said. \u201cThat report was created with literally, quite literally, blood and tears. And I just really want to emphasize that.\u201d\n\nIn 2019, New Westminster city council approved a series of actions in response to Reclaiming Power and Place: The Final Report of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. The report contains 231 calls to justice.\n\n\u201cThis is an important day for the community to reflect on the rights of Indigenous women and girls whose lives are just at so much more risk than myself as a non-Indigenous person,\u201d Nakagawa said. \u201cSo, again, if you haven\u2019t read the murdered and missing Indigenous women report from 2019, it\u2019s still there, it\u2019s still available; the calls are still relevant, and I encourage us all to take a look at the calls for justice and commit to moving them forward.\u201d\n\nThe proclamation noted the City of New Westminster has declared A Year of Truth, and encourages New West residents to join the city on its reconciliation journey.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nReader Feedback 1\n\tShow\nThis has been shared 2 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nRelated\n\tNew West: A B.C. leader in acting on TRC Calls to Action\n\tUnmarked Qayqayt graves get markers more than 100 years after burials\n\tIndigenous relations advisor to help New West with its reconciliation efforts\n\tQayqayt First Nation Chief: \u201cPeople across Canada have listened\u201d\n\nCOMMUNITY POLL\nParticipate in our next community poll.\nDo you think New West city council should sign a carbon emission declaration and pledge form?\nview related story\n No, it's an invasion of privacy.\n No, the climate change focus should be on policy, not on personal choices.\n No, it's unfair to those who may have mobility or other challenges.\n No, for another reason not listed here.\n Yes, councillors should lead by example.\n Yes, personal responsibility and policy change can co-exist in the fight against climate change.\n Yes, it would make a symbolic statement.\n Yes, for another reason not listed here.\n Don't know/don't care.\n\nVote Results > Archives >\n\nTRENDING TODAY\n1\t\nUptown Live 2024: Bye-bye beer gardens, hello site-wide licensing\n\n2\t\nCommunity mourns popular New West DJ, Starbucks barista Holly Kang\n\n3\t\nStudy claims New West is one of the most health conscious cities in Canada\n\n4\t\nWhat's happening? A Red Dress Day event is planned for May 5, 2024. photo Theresa McManus\nListen to this article\n00:03:23\n\nNew West residents are invited to commemorate Red Dress Day on May 5.\n\nThe City of New Westminster, in partnership with the Spirit of the Children Society, is hosting a Red Dress Day event in Hyack Square on Sunday, May 5 from 1 to 3 p.m. It includes: a red dress display; a ceremony hosted by Spirit of the Children Society; free red dress pins (available while supplies last); family-friendly activities; and free snacks and beverages (while supplies last).\n\nA notice about the event invites community members to come together and honour the memory and lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people across Canada and the USA.\n\n\u201cStarted in 2010 by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black, the movement educates, creates awareness, and calls for systemic change,\u201d said the notice. \u201cRed Dress Day will be recognized throughout May via displays, learning opportunities, and community events. Come together, wear red and show your support in honour of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and 2-Spirit+ people.\u201d\n\nThe City of New Westminster has proclaimed May 5 as Red Dress Day in the city.\n\nCoun. Nadine Nakagawa said the day is important as it commemorates missing and murdered Indigenous women. She invites all community members to attend the event.\n\nThe National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls released its 1,200-page report, Reclaiming Power and Place, in June 2019. It included 231 actions, or \u201ccalls for justice,\u201d for governments and Canadians.\n\n\u201cThere are calls for justice in that report \u2013 they are not calls for action, they are calls for justice, targeted at all levels of government,\u201d Nakagawa said. \u201cI want to remind us that that report was written with the blood and tears, literally, of Indigenous women and girls.\u201d\n\nWhile it\u2019s important to remember the violence that\u2019s taken place against Indigenous women and girls, Nakagawa said it\u2019s critical that those calls for justice be met \u2013 something that has yet to happen.\n\nAt its April 22 meeting, Coun. Daniel Fontaine thanked Nakagawa for pulling the Red Dress Day proclamation from council\u2019s consent agenda. (Items are only discussed if they\u2019re \u201cpulled\u201d from the consent agenda for discussion by a member of council).\n\n\u201cI want to also recognize \u2013 as a M\u00e9tis person myself, the only indigenous person on council \u2013 that it was M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black that helped inspire the Red Dess movement itself,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd that's something that is both a subject of pride and of great sadness in terms of the impact of so many Indigenous women across, not only British Columbia but across Canada.\u201d\n\nThe City of New Westminster\u2019s Red Dress Day proclamation states that non-Indigenous people have a role to play in the fight for justice for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people in Canada. The city and the Spirit of the Children Society are organizing a Red Dress campaign in New West from May 1 to 31.\n\n\u201cIndigenous women and girls are five times more likely to experience violence than any other population in Canada,\u201d said the proclamation. \u201cThis is a national crisis that requires urgent, informed and collaborative action.\u201d\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has been shared 1 time\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nRelated\n\tNew Westminster and District Labour Council appeals for safe work now\n\tLike a Taylor Swift concert, the New West tree sale is a hot ticket in town\n\tNew West council rejects proposal to add dentist office in Sapperton\n\nCOMMUNITY POLL\nParticipate in our next community poll.\nDo you think New West city council should sign a carbon emission declaration and pledge form?\nview related story\n No, it's an invasion of privacy.\n No, the climate change focus should be on policy, not on personal choices.\n No, it's unfair to those who may have mobility or other challenges.\n No, for another reason not listed here.\n Yes, councillors should lead by example.\n Yes, personal responsibility and policy change can co-exist in the fight against climate change.\n Yes, it would make a symbolic statement.\n Yes, for another reason not listed here.\n Don't know/don't care.\n\nVote Results > Archives >\n\nTRENDING TODAY\n1\t\nUptown Live 2024: Bye-bye beer gardens, hello site-wide licensing\n\n2\t\nCommunity mourns popular New West DJ, Starbucks barista Holly Kang\n\n3\t\nStudy claims New West is one of the most health conscious cities in Canada\n\n4\t\nWhat's happening? {"url": "https://menafn.com/1104166478/Red-Dress-Day-National-Day-Of-Awareness-Of-Missing-And-Murdered-Indigenous-Women&source=24", "title": "Red Dress Day: National Day Of Awareness Of Missing And Murdered Indigenous Women", "body": "We use cookies\n\nWe use cookies and other tracking technologies to improve your browsing experience on our website, to show you personalized content and targeted ads, to analyze our website traffic, and to understand where our visitors are coming from.\n\nI agreeI declineChange my preferences\n\t\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\t\t\nHOME NEWS PRESS DISTRIBUTION MARKET DATA RESEARCH COUNTRIES SECTIONS\n\n\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 US \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Europe \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Arab \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Asia \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Africa \u00a0 \u00a0\n| \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Politics \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Economy \u00a0 \u00a0 Oil&Energy \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Entertainment \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Sport\nRed Dress Day: National Day Of Awareness Of Missing And Murdered Indigenous Women\n\n\n\nDate\n\n5/5/2022 3:37:26 PM  \nShare on Facebook  Tweet on Twitter  \n\n(MENAFN- Caribbean News Global)\n\nDear Sir\n\nToday, May 5, is Red Dress Day,\u00a0the name and visual representation of the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and 2-Spirit people in Canada.\n\nThis national day of awareness first began back in 2010 by Indigenous artist Jamie Black,\u00a0as a way to raise visibility around the issue. Now in 2022, the day is commemorated in both Canada and the United States with ceremonies honouring these individuals, wearing red as a show of solidarity, and hanging a red dress in front of homes and establishments.\n\nWe are all emotionally connected in this effort, whether we are angered, fearful, hopeful, embarrassed, outraged, curious, impartial or directly involved as a victim, a victim's family member or a victimizer.\n\nOutraged by the discovery of multiple infant gravesites throughout North America, we can further center our attention, determination and energy towards further discoveries of Indigenous oppression. Decades have passed, as many indigenous women, children and family members have disappeared or been found murdered, while the attention of our police forces and public authorities have centered upon these events only to not fully close these multiple criminal cases, which remain cold and forgotten.\n\nNational investigations have been carried out by The Harper-Trudeau administrations in Canada, while the public energy in America has been hindered by inter-State conflict and jurisdiction. Canada's RCMP has continued to investigate these cases, solving a mere 11 percent of these cases. Yes, many of these cases are historic and difficult to solve, but public determination maybe able to pressure our governments to create distinct, uniquely Indigenous centered forces that will investigate each case to a successful completion.\n\nThis movement does not need to be just Indigenous Centered. 50 percent of our population are Women. Women are victimized 45 percent more than their male counterparts. This can be about the private, public and national victimization of what many societies view as the\u201cWeaker Sex\u201d, Womanhood. In the past, women were seen as the focal point of Indigenous culture.\n\nThe governments of the time centered their destructive efforts upon attacks directed towards the family, children and Women. Society's efforts to maintain full employment. Society took women out of the workforce placing them at home. Women have been the scapegoat of many societal ills as well. Feminism became a target to many and not a logical ally. Empowered Women have been feared by the masculine portion of society, not honoured allies but people to compete with.\n\nRed Dress Day creates the important momentum needed to ally Indigenous and Non-Indigenous Societies to become a single powerful lobby calling for Transparency, Accountability and Justice for all Women.\n\nSteven Kaszab\n\nBradford, Ontario\n\nMENAFN05052022000232011072ID1104166478\n\n\n\n\nLegal Disclaimer:\nMENAFN provides the information \u201cas is\u201d without warranty of any kind. {"url": "https://www.merrittherald.com/nvit-spreads-red-dress-awareness-through-different-installations/", "title": "NVIT spreads Red Dress awareness through different installations - Merritt Herald", "body": "NEWS\nSPORTS\nCOMMUNITY\nJUNIOR REPORTERS\nOPINION\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nNVIT spreads Red Dress awareness through different installations\n\nPosted by Marius Auer | May 9, 2022 | News, Trending, Indigenous | 0 \n\nNVIT\u2019s MMIWG2S+ Memorial Garden project is ongoing, and one of many initiatives the school is undertaking to raise awareness. Marius Auer/Herald\n\nThe Nicola Valley Institute of Technology (NVIT) is focused on supporting the wellness of students and community members alike, as many continue to be affected by the ongoing Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) crisis.\n\n\u201cNVIT has a number of items within our campus where we\u2019re bringing awareness to MMIWG2S+ issues,\u201d said Sue Sterling-Bur, vice president for students at NVIT\u2019s Merritt campus.\n\n\u201cOur students come from across Canada. 80 percent of our student population is Indigenous, so that tells us that every single student in the building is connected to someone that has a family member or knows someone that is missing or murdered. It really does impact our entire student population, as it does our staff as well.\u201d\n\nThe school\u2019s most recent initiative is their new memorial garden, honouring all those impacted by MMIWG issues. According to the Assembly of First Nations, Indigenous women make up 16 percent of all female homicide victims and 11 percent of missing women, despite only making up 4.3 percent of the population.\n\nWith so many in the community feeling the weight of these issues, NVIT created the garden as a space of reflection.\n\n\u201cWe created and built the MMIWG2S+ Memorial Garden here. It\u2019s located in the central area of NVIT. It was to represent a coming of home for people who are within that missing and murdered category. We wanted a safe place for people who have family members in that category to go reflect, sit, listen, and remember their people.\u201d\n\nStudents from NVIT\u2019s carpentry class built the bright red structure at the centre of the memorial garden, representing the colour attributed to the MMIWG movement. The structure was built to represent a s7\u00edstken, which is a traditional pithouse for the local Nlaka\u2019pamux nations.\n\nIn addition to the s7\u00edstken and benches already there, the school hopes to add solar-powered lighting and a water feature in collaboration with Conayt Friendship Society, who has supplied funding to the project.\n\n\u201cWater for Nlaka\u2019pamux and Sylix territory representing healing. To add a water feature will add that other aspect of water and healing for families.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s also a space where we can host events. If a community is doing a walk they are more than welcome to come and end their walks here. Or they\u2019re welcome to connect with our campus and book the site.\u201d\n\nIn addition to the memorial garden, the school also recently commissioned a local carpenter to build a cabinet which now moves throughout the campus, housing a red dress adorned with paddles and the NVIT logo. This dressed is used to represent the presence of those missing and murdered during school ceremonies and events.\n\n\u201cOur Indigenization Committee and Elders Committee wanted to have a red dress inside the building to represent the missing and murdered ingidenous girls and women.\u201d\n\nStudents at NVIT regularly receive communications regarding the institution\u2019s sexual violence policy, highlighting the importance of adressing topics such as consent and sexual assault. The school also offers a plethora of mental health support for students who require it, maintaining a contract with Nicola Family Therapy. Sterling-Bur says educating the community and creating awareness are key.\n\n\u201cThis is happening. Not only for Indigenous women and girls and two-spirited, but for young men and men within our territory. It\u2019s quite prominent and very scary.\u201d\n\nConnecting with those who may be more vulnerable, such as individuals struggling with addiction and mental health issues, may help to reduce their risk of becoming a victim of the MMIWG crisis, says Sterling-Bur, adding that these groups aren\u2019t exclusively targeted but have higher risk factors.\n\nThose interested in more information about NVIT\u2019s new memorial garden and other initiatives should call 250-378-3300, or visit their website at www.nvit.ca.\n\nSHARE:\n\n \nPREVIOUS\nNicola Mining to assist in Lower Nicola infrastructure repairs\nNEXT\nDana Cooke places 5th in Kentucky 3 Day Event\nNEWSLETTER\n\nFirst Name \n\nLast Name \n\nEmail address: \n\nCLASSIFIEDS\nMedical Office Assistant Position June 19, 2024\nSales Person/Office Admin May 15, 2024\nNVCL April 4, 2024\nRECENT OBITUARIES\nAlan Norman Clarence Taylor June 19, 2024\nFay Sturney June 19, 2024\nBeverly Jean Malchuk June 19, 2024\nSister Newspapers\nBowen Island Undercurrent\nBurnaby Now\nBusiness in Vancouver\nCastanet\nCoast Reporter\nDelta Optimist\nLethbridge Herald\nMedicine Hat News\nMoose Jaw Today\nNew West Record\nNorth Shore News\nPique Newsmagazine\nPowell River Peak\nPrince George Citizen\nREW.ca\nRichmond News\nSaskToday.ca\nSquamish Chief\nThe Orca\nTimes Colonist\nTriCity News\nVancouver is Awesome\nWestern Investor\nAirdrie Today\nAlberta Prime Times\nCochrane Today\nLakeland Today\nMountain View Today\nOkotoks Today\nRocky Mountain Outlook\nSt. Albert Gazette\nTown and Country Today\nOther Sections\nAbout Us\n\nAdvertise\n\nReal Estate\n\nClassifieds\n\nEvents\n\nMagazines\n\nSubscribe\n\nContact Us\n\nConnect\n\nMerritt Herald\n#201- 1951 Garcia Street,\nMerritt, BC V1K 1B8\n\nPhone\n1-250-378-4241\n\nAberdeen Publishing \u00a9 Copyright \u00ae\u00a02020.\u00a0\u00a0All rights reserved. {"url": "https://www.humboldtjournal.ca/news/nipawin-red-dress-display-defaced-1.24095680", "title": "Nipawin red dress display defaced - SaskToday.ca", "body": "Skip to content\nSign in or register for your free account  \nHomeWest Central & North\nEast Central\nSouthwest\nSoutheast\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nConnect\nHOME NORTH LOCAL NEWS\nNipawin red dress display defaced\nNIPAWIN \u2014 It was an noticeable \u2013 and unwanted \u2013 addition to a red dress display memorializing missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\nJessica R. Durling\nMar 11, 2020 4:26 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nStock photo\n\nNIPAWIN \u2014 It was an noticeable \u2013 and unwanted \u2013 addition to a red dress display memorializing missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nA single white dress with a sign saying \u201cwhite people die too\u201d was placed amongst the red dresses in the overnight hours.\n\nBrandie Trew, a member of the Nipawin Reconciliation committee, said she hung the dresses at Cumberland College in Nipawin on March 6, to raise awareness of the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nOn March 10, Trew came into work and saw there was a white dress hanging with the others.\n\nWhen she approached the dress, she noticed there was a large sign which read \u201cwhite people die too.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe reason I feel it\u2019s disrespectful is that white people are put first in the justice system, they\u2019re put first in the police system,\u201d Trew said. \u201cIt is a Canadian and international epidemic that Indigenous women and girls are lost in the system even when they\u2019re missing.\u201d\n\nAccording to Statistics Canada, nine per cent of female homicide victims in 1980 were Indigenous. By 2015, Indigenous women made up 24 per cent of homicide victims in Canada. This was noted in the federal government\u2019s 2018 interim report for the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nThe 2018 interim report shows that while homicide rates for non-Indigenous women have gone down over the decades, homicide rates for Indigenous women have been going up. Indigenous women are 12 times more likely to be murdered or missing than any other women in Canada, and 16 times more likely than Caucasian women.\n\nIn Manitoba or Saskatchewan, they are 19 more times likely than Caucasian women to be murdered or missing.\n\n\u201cAs a white settler, I know that if my child were to go missing, the police action would be immediate. But I don\u2019t feel my Indigenous friends receive the same respect,\u201d Trew said.\n\n\u201cBy them doing that they\u2019re saying and they\u2019re reinforcing that missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls don\u2019t need the attention that they\u2019re getting.\u201d\n\nShe said the disruption to the display made her feel \u201chorrible.\u201d\n\n\u201cI have lots of work and private relationships with First Nations people and I know many women who have gone missing or have been murdered. So when I hang the dresses, I think of them.\u201d\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nGet your daily Saskatchewan news briefing\nEmail\nSign Up\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.richmond-news.com/national-news/we-are-in-a-crisis-red-dress-day-honoured-as-leaders-say-more-work-to-be-done-6956411", "title": "'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done - Richmond News", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\nBest of Richmond\n26.6 \u00b0C\nHOME NATIONAL NEWS\n'We are in a crisis': Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released. \u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\nKelly Geraldine Malone, The Canadian Press\nMay 5, 2023 1:00 AM\nMay 5, 2023 1:20 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPeople gather on Parliament Hill for the National Day of Awareness for Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls in Ottawa on Tuesday, Oct. 4, 2022. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\u00a0\n\nRed dresses are set to be on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\u201cI'm a mother. I'm a sister. I'm an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I'm just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\u00a0\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\u00a0\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\u00a0\n\nA group hung 101 red dresses along a chain-link fence outside a landfill in the Manitoba capital over the winter. Winnipeg police have said the bodies of four Indigenous women were disposed of in landfills last year.\u00a0\n\nThe remains of three of the women have not been found. A man has been charged with first-degree murder in the killings of the four women.\n\nThe remains of another Indigenous woman were also found in a landfill earlier this year. Police said her death is not a homicide.\u00a0\n\n\"When I think (about it), I cry,\" DeLaronde said. \"I have to focus on the thousands of women and girls that are still here and how we can keep them safe.\"\n\nDeLaronde said it's important to recognize that Indigenous people are sacred, and they should not only be honoured when they are gone.\n\nThe House of Commons unanimously backed a motion Tuesday declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. It also called for funding a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThe truth is the truth,\u201d said Leah Gazan, the Winnipeg member of Parliament who presented the motion. \u201cIt's one thing to acknowledge truth. It's another thing to act on it.\u201d\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has criticized the federal government for not doing more or acting fast enough. McBride said Tuesday\u2019s motion was an important step, but there is more to do.\n\nMost of the money announced to fulfil the inquiry's 231 calls to justice became stuck in government bureaucracy, DeLaronde said, and it has not made it to the front lines and the Indigenous women and families who need it.\n\nDeLaronde added that all Canadians should use Red Dress Day to reflect on what they can do to create change.\u00a0\n\n\"Red Dress is a movement that people can get behind, because it's an opportunity to transform the very fabric of this country.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 5, 2023.\u00a0\n\nKelly Geraldine Malone, The Canadian Press\n\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. The Public is encouraged to wear red this Sunday in memory of missing and murdered Indigenous members, or to hand a red dress outside their home or business. Photo by Jayson Stewart.\n- Advertisement -\n\nCommunities across Canada including those on the North Shore Corridor and the Manitoulin Island will mark Red Dress Day this weekend.\n\nThis Sunday, First Nation communities will mark the day, which is also known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\nRed Dress Day was inspired by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project installation, in which she hung empty, red dresses to represent the missing and murdered women.\n\nWiikwemikoong Unceded Territory will host a community gathering with a Sunrise Ceremony, and a community walk followed by a social gathering and potluck dinner.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nToby Pickering of Sagamok Anishnawbek First Nation says the Child & Youth Program and the Mental Health and Addictions Team are collaborating to host a gathering from 10 am until 2 pm.\n\nShe says the gathering will take place at their Multi-Educational Centre with keynote speakers from the Manitoulin Victim Services, followed by a luncheon.\n\nThe public is encouraged to either hang or wear a red dress to honour the day.\n\n- {"url": "https://www.mylloydminsternow.com/46713/onion-lake-lloydminster-communities-gather-for-red-dress-day/", "title": "Onion Lake, Lloydminster communities gather for Red Dress Day - My Lloydminster Now", "body": "Home\nNews\nNews Alerts Sign Up!\nWin\nEvents\nCommunity Calendar\nSubmit Event\nListen Live\nOn Air\nPodcast\nGOAT CHRISTMAS WISH\nLocal Connections\nNEWS\nWIN\nEVENTS\nCONTACT US\nADVERTISE\nWE\u2019RE HIRING\n\n\u25ba Listen Live\n\nHome\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nListen Live\nOn Air\nPodcast\nGOAT CHRISTMAS WISH\nLocal Connections\n- Advertisement -\nHomeNewsOnion Lake, Lloydminster communities gather for Red Dress Day\nNews\nOnion Lake, Lloydminster communities gather for Red Dress Day\nBy\nDan Soul\nWednesday, May. 5th, 2021\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nSupporters gather in Onion Lake on Red Dress Day. [Onion Lake Cree Nation, Facebook.]\n- Advertisement -\n\nPeople in both Lloydminster and The Onion Lake Cree Nation joined the rest of Canada in honouring Red Dress Day.\n\nThe day, May 5th, marks the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, a day that commemorates the victims of and highlights the ongoing violence against Indigenous women, girls and two-sprit peoples.\n\nAccording to data from Statistics Canada, Indigenous women are almost six times more likely to be victims of homicide than non-Indigenous women and are at higher risk of having violence of any kind perpetrated against them.\n\nSupporters gathered in Onion Lake on May 5th to commemorate all people from their community who have been victims of this violence. People gave speeches, held vigil, gave prayers and sang traditional songs to honour their friends, loved ones and family members impacted.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nOnion Lake Chief Henry Lewis says for many people in his community, this day is about rebuilding lives as well.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not an easy thing when you lose somebody, even under normal circumstances, but in these cases, it takes a lot of time for people to heal. This is all about our healing when we do this, honouring our missing women. It also helps the people who were affected, who lost their loved ones.\u201d\n\nHere in Lloydminster, a gathering was held as well to acknowledge, support the families of and pay respects to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Peoples.\n\nPut on by Lloydminster & Vermilion For Equality, the event started with a traditional pipe ceremony at City Hall, followed by speeches and stories, traditional prayers and songs and then a solidarity march around the area.\n\nWhile they did have to take precautions due to COVID-19, Tigra-Lee Campbell with LVFE says there was good attendance and important conversations held.\u00a0 She says this was an important step in our community for honouring these victims and fostering an ongoing conversation about awareness.\n\n\u201cThis should not be just on one day a year. The awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous peoples needs to happen all year, 365 days a year.\u201d\n\nThe RedDress project originally began life as an art installation in Manitoba in 2011, but quickly became a way for people across Canada to raise awareness.\n\nVideo from the rally in Lloydminster [LVFE, Facebook]\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- {"url": "https://fftimes.com/news/district-news/opp-honour-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-and-girls/", "title": "OPP honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls - Fort Frances Times", "body": "Skip to content\nFeatured\n#Ukraine\n#findajob\n#COVID-19\n#Get-The-Times!\nThursday, Jul 4, 2024\nMy Profile\nFort Frances Times\n\nLocal News From Across The Rainy River District\n\nNews\nFeatures\nJobs & Classifieds\nSpecial Sections\nAbout Us\nContact the Times\nSubscribe Today!\nDigital Editions\nHome\nNews\nDistrict News\nOPP honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\nDistrict News\nOPP honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\n 5 May 2022\nPress release\n\n(Orillia, ON) \u2013 Members of the Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) Indigenous Policing Bureau (IPB) will show their support for Red Dress Day on May 5, 2022, as well as their ongoing commitment to address the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) Calls for Justice.\n\nThe main hallway of OPP General Headquarters is lined with over 100 red dresses in remembrance of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. This display, which includes images of the women and girls, acts as a powerful visual representation of the pain and loss felt by the families and friends of victims as well as survivors. IPB asks members of the OPP as well as the public to reflect and learn more about this ongoing national tragedy. Everyone is encouraged to honour MMIWG by working together to embrace and support community healing.\n\nIn 2019, Vanessa Willow, a resident of Rama First Nation, created and donated a red dress painting to the OPP in honour of the ongoing commitment to address the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. This painting is currently on display as part of the Red Dress Day recognition.\n\nThose passing by OPP General Headquarters (777 Memorial Avenue, Orillia) in the evening hours will see the building lit up in red. Please take the opportunity to pause, reflect and be reminded of the love of the families and communities that grieve for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nJoin our Newsletter\n\n\n\n\nSIGN-UP\n\nPosted in District News\nSearch\nSearch\nPoll - July 3, 2024\nLeft leaning parties in both the United States and Canada are seemingly in crises of leadership with elections looming. {"url": "https://citizen.on.ca/2022-year-in-review-1-2/", "title": "2022 Year in Review 1/2\u00a0|\u00a0Orangeville Citizen", "body": "Members Login: \u00a0 \u00a0 Log in\nOrangevilleCitizen\n\u00a0\nHome\nNews/Entertainment\nHeadline News\nGeneral News\nSports\nArts and Entertainment\nOur Issues\nCurrent Issue\nArchived Issues\nReal Estate\nResale Homes Collections\nCommunity Notices\nCommunity Links\nOrangeville Notice Board\nOur Papers\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nArchive\n2022 Year in Review 1/2\n\nJanuary 5, 2023 \u00a0\u00a0\u00b7\u00a0\u00a0 0 Comments\n\nAttention Readers!\n\nFor our first edition of the Orangeville Citizen in 2023, we\u2019re taking you through all of the highs and lows over the first six months of 2022.\n\nThe first half of our 2022 Year in Review will share some of the most significant stories impacting our readers from Jan. 6 to June 30.\n\nNext week we will publish the second half of our Year in Review with all of the highlights from July 7 to Dec. 22.\u00a0\n\nNow, without any further ado, here\u2019s a look at the year that was!\n\nJan. 6\n\nOntario reintroduces COVID-19 restrictions on Jan. 3 in response to cases of Omicron rising exponentially. In-person learning and indoor dining was shut down. Social gathering limits and capacity at public events was limited to five people.\u00a0\n\nEmployers were tasked with ensuring their employees worked remotely where possible. Weddings, funerals, religious services, rites and ceremonies were permitted at 50 per cent capacity, along with shopping malls and public libraries. Indoor concert venues, theatres, cinemas, museums, galleries, historic sites and tour guide services were also shut down.\u00a0\n\nThe Upper Grand District School Board announced plans for a shift to remote learning from Jan. 5 to 17.\u00a0\nThe first baby of 2022 is born at Headwaters Health Care Centre at 1:11 a.m. on Jan. 1, weighing 7 pounds, 15 ounces. In 2020 there were almost 900 deliveries at Headwaters.\n\nJan. 13\n\nFive acres of land associated with the Orangeville Railway Development Corporation was sold to the City of Brampton for $24.24 million. In 2020, Orangeville Council, as the lone shareholder of ORDC, directed the board to sell or lease rail line assets.\nA local company aimed at reducing plastic waste, EcoTank, launched its first windshield wiper fluid refill station at the local 7-Eleven. The refill station eliminates the need for plastic jugs that hold windshield washing fluid, in turn helping the environment.\nHeadwaters pauses non-emergent surgeries/procedures, non-urgent diagnostic imaging and ambulatory clinical activity in response to the province\u2019s directives to combat a sharp rise in COVID-19 cases due to Omicron. The pause in non-emergent surgeries was intended to preserve hospital bed capacity and health human resources.\nFamily Transition Place received $22,500 and Kerry\u2019s Place received $116,700 from the provincial government for upgrades and repairs.\n\nJan. 20\n\nUpper Grand District School Board (UGDSB) students have returned to the classroom for the first time since winter break and despite high cases of the Omicron COVID-19 variant, the region\u2019s top doctor has said the benefits of reopening schools outweigh the short-term risk.\n\nNicola Mercer released a statement last Friday (Jan. 14) ahead of the scheduled return to in-person learning on Jan. 17, noting the importance of in-person learning on children, their families, and the community as a whole.\n\nMichelle Hanson, the 38-year-old Amaranth mother who plead guilty to criminal negligence causing death in the 2018 drowning of her three-year-old Kaden Young, received a two-year conditional sentence.\n\nHanson appear in an Orangeville courtroom via video conference on Jan. 18 for her sentencing hearing. The courtroom heard that Hanson will serve the first 18 months of her two-year conditional sentence under house arrest. A three-year driving probation is also to take effect following the completion of the conditional sentence. Hanson will be required to attend grief and substance abuse counselling over the two years of the house arrest and during her one year of probation.\n\nShortly before 1 a.m. on Feb. 21, 2018, Hanson\u2019s vehicle was pulled into the Grand River during a period of heavy flooding which saw river water rise up onto the road. Hanson had taken her three-year-old son Kaden, who was having trouble sleeping, for a drive into Grand Valley where she planned to attend a convenience store.\n\nWithin minutes of leaving her home, Hanson drove her vehicle around a road-closed barrier on the 10th Line of Amaranth onto a flooded section of the road, resulting in the vehicle being swept into the river. Hanson was able to escape the vehicle with Kaden, but lost grip of him as they were pushed down the river by the strong current. She was pulled from the river by EMS.\n\nAn agreed statement of facts said paramedics attending to Hanson detected an odour of alcohol and blood samples obtained at the hospital showed a blood alcohol concentration of 60 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood. Oxycodone was also detected but was noted to be a concentration associated with a \u2018therapeutic range\u2019\n\nIn the weeks following, hundreds of volunteers from the community searched the banks of the Grand River for Kaden\u2019s body. On April, 2021, two months to the day of the incident, Kaden\u2019s body was recovered in Belwood Lake.\n\n\u00a0Hanson was charged in October of 2018, and ordered to stand trial on counts of impaired driving causing death and criminal negligence causing death following a preliminary inquiry in 2019.\n\nHanson plead guilty to criminal negligence causing death in November of 2021, and the charge of impaired driving causing death was dropped as part of the plea deal.\n\nIsland Lake Family Park in Mono was hit with graffiti, leaving much of the playground equipment and some park benches tagged with spray paint. On. Jan. 11 Dufferin OPP received a report of mischief from a concerned citizen regarding graffiti at the park, at which time an officer arrived at the scene and an investigation commenced.\n\nJan. 27\n\nA convoy of big rigs and motor vehicles will be rolling through Orangeville tomorrow (Jan. 28) in support of a nationwide protest against vaccine mandates for truckers and all Canadians.\n\nThe convoy, which organizers estimate will be roughly 50 vehicles long, with more than a dozen semis, will roll through town at 11 a.m., coming down Highway 10 before turning onto Highway 9 towards Highway 400 South and then onto Highway 401 East to Ottawa, with Parliament Hill as the final destination for Saturday (Jan. 29).\n\nThere they will be joined by tens of thousands of truckers and supporters that left from Vancouver on Jan. 23 and Nova Scotia today (Jan. 27), in addition to countless informal convoys across the country for a massive protest. The convoys that began in Vancouver and Nova Scotia grow larger with each city they pass through, as supporters and fellow truckers across Canada join in.\n\nThe County of Dufferin proposes a 0.96 per cent budget increase for 2022.\nOrangeville council considers crisis care beds and a warming centre for the winter season at a Jan. 24 council meeting. The Orangeville Fire Hall on Dawson Rd. is being considered for the location of crisis beds as it will be vacant when the town\u2019s new fire hall opens in the spring of 2024.\nThe 2nd Annual Food Bank Street Challenge (FBSC) officially wrapped up last weekend and the numbers are in. Nearly 7,500 lbs of non-perishable food was collected and donated since the challenge kicked off in early October, with about half being kept in Orangeville.\n\nMono resident Jaylen Padayachee, 13, with the help of his dad Koven, created the challenge in November of 2020 when he realized the local food bank wasn\u2019t receiving as many donations as normal due to the COVID-19 pandemic. While this year\u2019s challenge didn\u2019t raise as many donations as last year, which topped 30,000 lbs, organizers are still happy that the 7,500 lbs of food will go out to those who need it most.\n\nMono Council\u2019s 2022 Draft Budget is currently at a 2.4 per cent tax levy increase, much lower than the originally proposed 10.9 per cent increase from staff, during a meeting on Tuesday (Jan. 25).\n\nCouncil members struggled to keep the tax levy increase to 2.4 per cent, they examined the budget document line by line seeking to reduce it by some $700,000 to reach the 2.4 per cent target. It was an arduous meeting, which saw Council reduce a number of capital reserves in their efforts to keep the tax levy increase low.\n\nThe Ontario government has announced the gradual easing of COVID-19 public health measures with the first step in a three-step plan. Starting Jan. 31, social gathering limits will increase to up to 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. A number of indoor businesses and setting will be permitted to reopen with a capacity limit of 50 per cent, including restaurants, bars, retailers, shopping malls, grocery stores, pharmacies, gyms, cinemas, museums, galleries, casinos, and religious services. Ontario will enter the final step of its reopening plan on March 14 with a lifting of capacity limits in all indoor public settings.\nA 44-year-old Orangeville man wanted on an arrest warrant in connection to the murder of a women in Shelburne has been found dead. Dufferin OPP announced on Jan. 20 that the body of Scott Pinney had been discovered inside his abandoned vehicle in a secluded area near Hearst, Ont. on Jan. 17 by a passerby. The death has not been deemed suspicious or a suicide, according to police.\n\nFeb. 3\n\nHundreds of Orangeville residents lined Highway 10 despite the -34\u00b0C wind chill last Friday (Jan. 28), holding up signs of support as a convoy of over 100 vehicles, led by big rigs, rolled through town on its way to Ottawa.\n\nIn the morning, every few vehicles that passed by honked their horns in support of the protestors, until the convoy arrived around noon, a little behind schedule. Despite the holdup, hundreds of the convoy supporters didn\u2019t budge and braved the cold for well over an hour, with a common goal of ending vaccine mandates and other COVID-19 restrictions.\n\nProtestors said they want people who lost their jobs over COVID vaccine mandates to be reinstated, noting people who are vaccinated can spread the virus just as easily. Protestors also said they were opposed to their kids being unable to play sports and the shutting down of schools.\n\nThe trucks in the local convoy started in Owen Sound and joined a larger convoy of vehicles in Belleville before heading to Parliament Hill. There they joined thousands of truckers and people through the weekend, protesting vaccine mandates.\n\nDufferin OPP say they did not encounter any issues with the people participating in the convoy or anyone that assembled to view the convoy. No roads were closed but police did momentarily block traffic in Shelburne and Orangeville to facilitate the safe movement of the general public and the convoy through Dufferin County.\n\nDufferin\u2013Caledon MP Kyle Seeback expressed his support for the Freedom Convoy and penned a letter to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, asking that he reverse the federal government\u2019s decision to require cross-border truckers to be vaccinated against COVID-19. The policy came into effect Jan. 15, and is expected to ground 26,000 of the 160,00 trucker drivers who make regular cross-border trips.\n\nSeeback told the Citizen the policy won\u2019t make a difference with the Omicron variant, as it has already travelled widely across the world, and forcing more truckers to get vaccinated won\u2019t stop the spread.\n\nThe fire department will lose about 20 per cent of its volunteer members on Feb. 11 for failing to comply with the Town\u2019s COVID-19 vaccination policy. This represents four of 21 volunteers.\u00a0\nThousands of protestors united against COVID-19 mandates gathered at the Nation\u2019s Capital over the weekend to protest against vaccine mandates for truckers and all industries, along with other COVID-19 restrictions.\n\nSaskatchewan Premiere Scott Moe released a statement during the height of the \u201cFreedom Rally\u201d last Saturday, saying he\u2019s against the vaccine mandates for truckers, citing that they don\u2019t stop transmission. He added that this is the reason why his government will soon be ending the proof-of-vaccination system for Saskatchewan.\n\nFeb. 10\n\nIn one of many Jordanian refugee camps sits roughly 200,000 displaced Syrians, who\u2019s homes and lives have been destroyed through a civil war that started in 2011. Sadly, most of the Syrian refugees will never make out of the camp, but a local non-profit group, First Line for Syria, is working to create a difference one family at a time.\n\nLast October, after much fundraising and four years of trying to bring eight members of the Al Diri family to the region, the group was successful and reconnected them with their relatives who live locally.\n\nWhile the volunteers at First Line for Syria are ecstatic they were able to reconnect several members of the Al Diri family, their two brothers, two sisters-in-law and nine children (nieces/nephews/cousins) have been left behind. To reconnect the 13 remaining relatives of the Al Diri family, First Line for Syria needs to raise $160,000, so it recently launched a fundraiser with Mochaberry Coffee (177 Broadway).\n\nFirst Line for Syria started in 2015 and welcomed their first Syrian refugee family, the Huseyin Alos\u2019s, to Dufferin County in February of 2016.\n\nThe 5th Annual Coldest Night of the Year fundraiser is returning to Orangeville Feb. 26 and will be running in-person for the first time since 2020. The event is a family-friendly walk, featuring 2km and 5km routes, with the goal of raising $75,000 this year for the Orangeville Food Bank. So far about $43,000 has been donated, with 40 teams and almost 200 walkers registered.\nThe Rotary Club of Orangeville Highlands is again inviting the public to help them help choose which local charities and nonprofits will receive one of five \u201cno strings attached\u201d $1,000 grants. Nominations are open from Feb. 14 to 28 and people can nominate any charity or non-profit that serves the local community.\nCanadian flags and signs calling for an end to COVID-19 restrictions/mandates filled Orangeville\u2019s Canadian Tire parking lot (95 First Street) on Feb. 5. Close to 100 vehicles and half a dozen big rigs were lined up for the local \u201cFreedom Convoy\u201d, which left for Queens Park in Toronto around 11 a.m. There, participants of the convoy met with thousands of protestors to voice their opposition to COVID-19 restrictions and vaccine mandates.\nOntario has begun to ease visiting restrictions at long-term care homes as public health indicators for COVID-19 continue to trend downward. The National Day of Awareness for MMIWG2S, also known as Red Dress Day, was marked locally on May 5 with a walk and smudging ceremony at the Mino Kamik Medicine Wheel Garden in Bravery Park.\u00a0\n\nThe event was held by the Dufferin County Cultural Resource Circle (DCCRC), and attended by local politicians, municipal representatives, heads of organizations and community members.\n\nDCCRC chair, Debbie Egerton, who founded the organization in 2014, said more needs to be done on the issue of Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit people going missing or being murdered at disproportionate rates compared to non-indigenous people. The homicide rate for Indigenous women in Canada was almost six times higher than non-Indigenous women from 2001 to 2015.\n\nVoting in the provincial election has started at the Orangeville Curling Club. Located at 76 Fifth Ave, the club is now accepting special ballot voting for those in the Dufferin\u2013Caledon riding.\nMono Council heard from the Credit Valley Conversation (CVC) on Tuesday (May 19) about issues relating to Monora Park. A delegation to Council lead by CVC CAO Quentin Hanchard and director of watershed management, John Sinnige, shared that the existing pond at Monora Park will be drained and the dam creating it is being removed in 2023.\n\nStudies show that the dam is in danger of collapse, and has reached the end of its useful life, while a new dam is far too expensive to build. The plan to eliminate the dam will remove the risk to public safety, remove environmental impacts such as fish passage and creek temperature, restore the stream and wetland habitat in the pond basin, and maintain the trail connectivity for recreational purposes.\n\nThe cost will be approximately $320,000 and the funding is in place now with construction expected to run from June 1 to Sept. 30, 2023.\n\nThe Town of Orangeville will soon be taking a new approach to transit. The three-day event, which ran June 3-5, saw over 40,000 attendees, representing a 10 per cent increase in attendance over 2019 when the festival was held last.\nDufferin\u2013Caledon MP Kyle Seeback has changed the candidate he\u2019s supporting in the Conservative Leadership Race. Seeback had initially backed Brampton Mayor Patrick Brown, who joined the Conservative Party in 2006 as a Member of Parliament, as the next leader of the Conservative Party of Canada, but announced last week his support has changed to Pierre Poilievre.\nFood banks and programs in Dufferin County are getting a massive boost in funding. The 9th Annual Compass Run for Food, held by the Compass Community Church on Saturday (June 11) exceeded its goal of $75,000, which will go a long way in combatting food insecurity locally. After two years without an in-person event, it was great to see hundreds of people unite under a common goal of ensuring people in Dufferin County don\u2019t go hungry, said event organizer David Marshall.\nLinda Banks gets recognized as Orangeville\u2019s 2022 Senior of the Year.\nSome Caledon residents and Orangeville councillor Lisa Post are expressing dismay that a mural celebrating the contributions of Post\u2019s grandfather, Alex Raeburn, has been painted over at Caledon Central Public School.\u00a0\n\nRaeburn (1912-2012) was a fourth-generation resident of Caledon Village and involved in many projects in the community. He served on the local school board, was a charter member of Caledon Town Council and Peel Regional Council, and served two terms on the Niagara Escarpment Commission, among other community involvements. Perhaps most relevant to this story is the big part he played in getting Caledon Central Public School built.\n\nAccording to Peel District School Board trustee Stan Cameron, just before 10 a.m. on June 3 he received a call from Caledon Central\u2019s principal letting him know the mural of Raeburn \u2014 located in the library at Caledon Central that\u2019s named after him \u2014 had been painted over. Cameron said in the call, he asked why it was painted over and never got a solid reason. He also asked what the plan for the wall was now that it\u2019s a blank slate again, and the response was that there wasn\u2019t a definitive plan yet.\n\nHeadwaters Health Care Centre president and CEO, Kim Delahunt released the following statement last Friday (June 10) regarding the hospital\u2019s decision to maintain mask requirements after the mandate expired last Saturday (June 11).\n\nJune 23\n\nAn in-person celebration of all backgrounds, ages, religions and sexual orientations returned to Mill Street on Saturday (June 18) for Celebrate Your Awesome\u2019s annual Pride and Diversity Day. It\u2019s the first time in two years a celebration\u2019s been held at Mill Street, with the annual event being marked virtually in 2020 and 2021 due to the pandemic. This year\u2019s turnout was fantastic, surpassing attendance numbers from 2018 and 2019.\u00a0\nRoughly 3,000 to 4,000 people filled out the stands at the Orangeville Fairgrounds on June 18 and 19, as they enjoyed a variety of competitions, including bull riding, barrel racing, bucking horse, steer riding and pole bending for Ram Rodeo. But the two-day event wasn\u2019t just for entertainment, the event also generated around $10,000, split between Tuff Therapeutic Riding in Mono and the 85 Tornado Squadron Air Cadets of Grand Valley.\nHeadwater\u2019s Health Care Centre (HHCC) honoured two award recipients for their commitment to service at the local hospital during their Annual General Meeting held on Tuesday (June 21). HHCC Board of Directors vice chair, Shelley Scriver presented the 23rd annual Dr. David Scott Award to the laboratory team at Headwaters for their service during the pandemic processing swabs for COVID-19.\nOrangeville Council recently approved the site and floor plan for its nearly 30,000 sq. ft fire station that\u2019s being built at the corner of Commerce and Centennial Road.\n\nIn a unanimous vote on June 13, Council also directed Town staff to prepare an application for capital funding in the amount of $5 million from the Federation of Canadian Municipalities Green Municipal Fund Program to design the new fire station to net zero standards. As well, Council directed staff to include $5 million in additional funds for the fire station project for their 2023-24 capital budget.\n\nThe expected completion date of the fire station is the spring of 2024, with an 18-month construction timeline.\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph (WDG) Public Health has reported the first case of monkeypox in the region. In a press release issued on June 16, the local health unit said they had received confirmation of the first local case of the virus, and that the affected individual is a male aged 20 to 30 who lives in Guelph.\n\nJune 30\n\nParking on both sides of the street will soon be a thing of the past for many roadways currently allowing it in Orangeville. Council unanimously approved a motion that restricts parking to one side of the street during a meeting on Monday (June 27).\n\nStreets that currently do not allow parking on either side or are already restricted to one side won\u2019t be impacted. Same with streets that have parking stalls.\n\nDufferin-Caledon MPP Sylvia Jones has been appointed as Ontario\u2019s newest Health Minister. Premier Doug Ford unveiled his 30-person cabinet last Friday (June 24) during his swearing-in ceremony at Queen\u2019s Park as the 26th premier of the province. Jones is taking over the role of minister of health from Christine Elliott, who did not seek re-election. Jones was also named deputy premier.\n\n\n\nReaders Comments (0)\n\n\n\nName (required)\n\n\nEmail Address (required)\n\n\nWebsite (optional)\n\n\nPlease note: Comment moderation is enabled and may delay your comment.
