Unlimited access for only $3 for 3 months. Act Now>>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNewsletters\nCanada\nWorld\nFinancial Post\nNP Comment\nLongreads\nPuzzmo\nLife\nShopping\nEpaper\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nPMN PoliticsPMN News\nFrom red dresses to memory stones: Collaborative and replicable activism can help causes gain momentum\n\nAuthor of the article:\n\nThe Canadian Press\nPublished May 05, 2022 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 4 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nArticle content\n\nTHE CONVERSATION\n\nThis article was originally published on The Conversation, an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts. Disclosure information is available on the original site.\n\n\u2014\u2014\n\nAuthor: Nicolette Little, Critical Media Studies Instructor and PhD Candidate, University of Calgary\n\nWe\u2019ve all heard of #MeToo, founded by Tarana Burke. And in 2017, actress Alyssa Milano tweeted, \u201cif you\u2019ve been sexually harassed or assaulted write \u2018me too\u2019 as a reply to this tweet.\u201d Her tweet sparked a whirlwind of social media posts that highlighted a gender-based violence crisis.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nPoilievre would repeal online harms bill after PBO report finds $200 million in new bureaucracy\nCanada Revenue Agency posts, then deletes, series of tweets related to animated film series\nJustin Bieber set to earn $10M performing at pre-wedding bash in India\nHow Nova Scotia nearly got away to become part of the United States\nBruce Pardy: Corporate Canada betrayed capitalism. Now it has been betrayed\nArticle content\n\nWhile hashtag activism and Hollywood are synonymous with gender-based violence advocacy, there are dynamic projects raising awareness across Canada. Metis artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project and Leah Parsons\u2019 Memory Stones Project are examples of such creative and collaborative anti-violence efforts.\n\nThe REDress Project sees red dresses suspended where you would least expect them. Black is an artist-activist \u2014 or \u201cartivist\u201d \u2014 from Winnipeg, Man., who started the project in order to call attention to Canada\u2019s Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) crisis. The crisis has seen thousands of Indigenous women go missing or be killed since the 1970s.\n\nIn the Memory Stones Project, Parsons collects stones from the shores of the Atlantic Ocean, then paints them with bright colours and cheerful symbols to honour her daughter, Rehtaeh. Rehtaeh died by suicide after she was allegedly sexually assaulted by four boys and relentlessly victim-blamed. Each memory stone is hidden outdoors with a note that describes Rehtaeh\u2019s experience. It urges anyone who finds the stone to \u201cshow kindness not hate\u201d to survivors and \u201cleave the stone\u201d to share Rehtaeh\u2019s message with others.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAs the Government of Canada points out, certain people including \u201cwomen; young women and girls; Indigenous women and girls; LGBTQIA2S+; transgender and gender diverse people; women living in Northern, rural and remote communities; and, women living with disabilities\u201d are more likely to experience gender-based violence.\n\nIn Canada, one in four women report gender-based violence to authorities, while many cases go unreported due to fear of stigma and victim-blaming. Indigenous women in particular face gender-based violence 16 times more than white women in Canada do. They also experience more severe assaults.\n\nAfter interviewing Black and Parsons for my research, studying their projects and speaking with people who engaged with them, what stands out is how both projects attract eager co-operation from everyday people \u2014 which is important for raising awareness.\n\nWhen activists use materials that anyone can acquire, and invite citizens to co-create alongside them, it inspires people to jump on board.\n\nCollaborative activism\n\nDuring my conversations with Black and Parsons, they both mentioned being fed up with the normalization of gender-based violence, so they struck out on their own to address it. While these acts appear to be singular undertakings, they\u2019ve both inspired impressive participation.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe REDress Project gained international attention, but its collaborative origins are little known. In 2010, Black called on Canadians to donate dresses and received over 600 garments. She told me that people have donated every dress she\u2019s used since.\n\nREDress-inspired projects regularly pop up. An Edmontonian started a \u201cREDress Photography Project\u201d in 2015, while Inuit installed a Red Amautiit Project in Nunavut in 2019. These creators, who were inspired by Black\u2019s work, ensured first that she would be comfortable with them building on her idea. In fact, Black tells me she believes in \u201cdecolonizing the idea of art being exclusive.\u201d She believes that this helps it \u201cgrow and evolve beyond its maker.\u201d\n\nParsons\u2019 Memory Stones Project also inspires engagement. After seeing memory stones on the Angel Rehtaeh Parsons Facebook page, people request stones so they can place them too.\n\nParsons tells me she\u2019s painted thousands of memory stones to date, mailing them to people in \u201cmany places \u00e2\u0080\u00a6 Africa, China, Alaska, British Columbia, California, Germany, New Zealand, Dakar, Cambodia and more\u201d. She instructs recipients to place the stone somewhere that speaks to them and send Parsons a photograph.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMy interviews with people who have come across Parsons\u2019 stones revealed that finding the stone helped them reflect on the importance of consent. By placing stones and sharing Rehtaeh\u2019s story, people are helping draw attention to gender-based violence.\n\nReplicability\n\nThese activisms\u2019 uptake, in part, relies on the fact that they are easy to replicate. Black uses an everyday item, dresses, to raise awareness. Parsons uses stones, paint and varnish, which are easily acquired.\n\nThese projects demonstrate that with inspiration, people can use accessible objects and skills they already have to participate in anti-violence activism.\n\nBlack\u2019s and Parsons\u2019 initiatives were meant to inspire involvement. Black invites Canadians to hang their own red dresses to raise awareness and Parsons not only provides stones to people who request them, but encourages them to get involved through social media. On her Facebook page, she gives a blessing and instructions to those who want to paint stones at home and asks people to post photos online.\n\nBecause gender-based violence kills a woman every second day in Canada, it can feel overwhelming to try to address it. This is one of the reasons projects that are easy to participate in and reproduce, and that make people feel like they are part of a community that cares, are important.\n\n\u2014\u2014\n\nNicolette Little receives funding from the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC)\n\n\u2014\u2014\n\nThis article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Disclosure information is available on the original site. {"url": "https://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/marketplace/fighting-the-toxic-drug-crisis-7357697", "title": "Fighting the toxic drug crisis - Comox Valley Record", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.1 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Impress\nSPONSORED CONTENT\nFighting the toxic drug crisis\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nVolunteers Sarah Lewis, Ashawna Woodcock and her daughter attend a community event to raise awareness of the toxic drug crisis.\nListen to this article\n00:03:40\n\nPatti Alvarado leads a group of staff and volunteers committed to saving lives in the Comox Valley.\n\nUnbroken Chain, an Indigenous-led harm reduction program at the Indigenous Women\u2019s Sharing Society, supports a growing list of individuals and family members affected by the toxic drug overdose crisis.\n\nSupports include Indigenous harm-reduction education and support, naloxone training, peer support, community education and more.\n\nMost weeks, staff and volunteers support multiple people, having conversations through difficult days and nights, safety planning, providing support to families who have lost loved ones, advocacy in community meetings or connecting people to healthcare and support services.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to help people stay alive, as well as mitigate the impacts and harm of the toxic drug poisoning epidemic,\u201d Alvarado said. \u201cThe feedback we get from participants is that we have helped save their lives. So, for us, this funding from the Comox Valley Community Foundation, has been a lifesaver.\u201d\n\nUnbroken Chain ensures people with lived or living experience and their families and friends, have a listening ear when they need it most and receive trauma-informed and culturally safe support. The practice reduces harm and creates a judgment-free environment that facilitates and promotes empowerment, self-autonomy, and healing.\n\nUnbroken Chain hosts awareness events and participates in community action meetings to ensure Indigenous voices and those with lived experience are a part of local solutions, a key factor to reducing stigma and harm.\n\nThe toxic drug epidemic affects the entire community.\n\nIn February, the First Nations Health Authority released information showing COVID-19 pandemic and the toxic drug public health emergency shortened the life expectancy of Indigenous people in B.C. by 7.1 years, between 2015 to 2021.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing illicit substance use more visibly now due to the supply of illicit substances becoming increasingly more and more toxic since the pandemic, but it\u2019s always been there and often behind closed doors,\u201d she said. \u201cDozens and dozens of people have died in our community. You are fortunate if you haven\u2019t had a family member or loved one affected by it.\u201d\n\nIn the last year, the Society\u2019s events have seen an increase of families wanting to ensure they \u2014 and their children \u2014 know how to use naloxone.\n\nAlvarado encourages the community to attend awareness events, such as Red Dress Day, May 5.\n\n\u201cBeing a part of the Indigenous Women\u2019s Sharing Society has been a very welcoming experience. We have a lot of circles and activities where we welcome anyone to join us.\u201d\n\nWith additional funding, volunteers and capacity building, Alvarado hopes to expand toxic drug crisis support services locally and on the North Island.\n\n\u201cUnbroken Chain does have a waiting list,\u201d she said. \u201cUnfortunately, we\u2019re not able to help everyone due to the limited resources and the need is great.\u201d\n\nTo learn more about the Indigenous Women\u2019s Sharing Society, follow them on social media, or call 250-338-3455.\n\nWHAT YOU CAN DO\n\n\u2022 Fight the stigma. Read reliable sources to understand the causes of the toxic drug poisoning epidemic.\n\n\u2022 Talk to people. Attend events, listen to people with lived experience.\n\n\u2022 Volunteer. Take part in training and volunteer to help people in your community.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n \nComox Valley Record\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nAdvertising\nSupport Centre\nTerms of Service\nPrivacy Policy\nJoin our Team\nNews\nLocal News\nNewsletters\nSubscribe\nToday in BC\nCanadian News\nWorld News\nEntertainment\nSports\nBusiness\nTrending Now\nOpinion\nSubmit News Tips\nNeighbours\nCampbell River Mirror\nNorth Island Gazette\nMore\nOur Community\nPublic Notices\nVideo\nPhoto Galleries\nTravel\nWest Coast Traveller\nCannabis\nToday's Home\nPodcasts\nFood\nLife\nContact Us\nContests\nPuzzles\nContests\nShop\nImpress Stories\nSavvy Shopper\nImpress TV\nAdd Your Business\nE-Editions\nClassifieds\nAll Classifieds\nBook a Print Ad\nAuto\nToday's Drive\nAuto Showcase\nJobs\nLocalWork\nJoin Our Team\nObituaries\nCelebrations of Life\nFuneral Care Services\nIn Memory\nPlace an Obituary\nGood News\nLocal Good News\nSocial Media\nComox Valley Live\nToday in BC\nYoutube\nI love British Columbia\nI love Alberta\nI love Nunavut\nI love Yukon\nI love Northwest Territories\n\u00a9 2024 Comox Valley Record and Black Press Media Publications Contact"},

EDT\n\n**CHIEFS OF ONTARIO NEWS RELEASE**\n\nToday, Ontario Regional Chief RoseAnne Archibald and Chiefs of Ontario stand in support and honour the lives of Missing and Murder Indigenous Women, Girls, Two Spirit, and Trans and their families and communities this October 4th, the 13th Annual Sisters in Spirit Day.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0Sisters in Spirit vigils are being held across Canada today to commemorate and raise awareness for those Indigenous women that have gone missing or murdered. The high rates of Missing and Murder Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada are staggering and have tremendous emotional and spiritual impacts on First Nations families, youth and communities. October 4th is not only devoted to educational awareness, but also a day for our communities and nations to come together and heal.\n\n\u201cWe are standing behind the families today as we keep the MMIWG2ST in our hearts. We must continue this dialogue and support each other as we make space for families to grieve and acknowledge that these women are loved,\u201d said Regional Chief Archibald. \u201cI continue to hold a vision of our women and girls being safe and protected and always treated with dignity and respect.\u00a0 We want our girls to grow up knowing they are valued and that they can reach their highest and full potential. I encourage each Canadian to attend a \u201cSisters in Spirit\u201d vigil today to honour the legacies these women have left behind and to also remember, Indigenous women are strong and resilient. We are not alone.\u201d\n\nThe First Nations Women\u2019s Caucus, coordinated through the Chiefs of Ontario, support the vigils honouring the lives of these daughters, sisters, mothers, aunties and their grieving families who are also victims.\n\n\u201cWe are calling for accountability and responsibility today and praying for justice for these young women and girls,\u201d stated Donna Debassige, of the First Nations Women\u2019s Caucus. \u201cTonight, we will light our candles and acknowledge our lost and stolen sisters, and shine a light in for them and work to ensure they receive the justice they deserve.\u201d\n\nOntario Regional Chief RoseAnne Archibald\n\nGet Social with KiSS 99.3 Timmins\n\n \nGet the app\n\nListen live on your mobile device anytime and anywhere\n\n\n \nJoin In\nFacebook\nTwitter\nRadioplayer \u2013 iOS\nRadioplayer \u2013 Android\n \nOur Station\nContact Us\nHow to Listen\nPrize Pick Up\nContest Rules & Regulations\nRecently Played\nAdvertise With Us\nOur Partners\nSocial Media Terms of Use\nAccessibility Feedback\nPolitical Ads Registry\n\n260 Second Ave Timmins, Ontario P4N 8A4.\u00a0\u00a9 2003-2024 Rogers Media. {"url": "https://www.kamloopsbcnow.com/watercooler/news/news/Okanagan/Friends_of_Roxanne_Louie_seek_reversal_of_decision_to_grant_her_murderer_day_parole/", "title": "Friends of Roxanne Louie seek reversal of decision to grant her murderer day parole", "body": "Food & Drink\nBiz+Tech\nTravel & Lifestyle\nArts & Culture\nNews & City Info\nCannabis\nWebcams\nAdvertise\nReal Estate\nContests\nBest Of the city\nFaces of Kamloops\nMore\nReal Estate Listings\nNewsletter Subscription\n\u00a0\n  \n\n\n\nWant to contribute?\n\nLOGIN\nREGISTER\n\n\nFOOD & DRINK\nBIZ+TECH\nTRAVEL & LIFESTYLE\nARTS & CULTURE\nNEWS & CITY INFO\nCANNABIS\nWEBCAMS\nADVERTISE\nREAL ESTATE\nCONTESTS\nBEST OF THE CITY\nFACES OF KAMLOOPS\nMORE\nREAL ESTATE LISTINGS\nNEWSLETTER SUBSCRIPTION\nOkanagan \u00a0 posted Feb 2, 2024 @ 02:10pm by \u00a0 Aaron Hemens - Local Journalism Initiative - IndigiNews\nFriends of Roxanne Louie seek reversal of decision to grant her murderer day parole\n\nMore than 300 people have signed a petition demanding that the Parole Board of Canada reverse a decision to grant six-month day parole to a woman serving life in prison for murdering syilx mother Roxanne Louie.\n\nLaurie Wilson, a syilx community member and friend of Louie, created the petition which says the Parole Board\u2019s process has been \u201cpatently unfair and discriminatory against the family of Roxanne Louie and the Okanagan Nation at large.\u201d\n\nShe writes that Louie\u2019s family and community were not notified or given an opportunity to provide input when killer Grace Robotti was in the process of being granted conditional release.\n\n\u201cWe, the undersigned, demand that the Parole Board of Canada rescind the granting of any parole to Grace Robotti because of the lack of input from (Roxanne\u2019s) family and community,\u201d the petition states.\n\n\u201cA decision in this matter should be delayed until the submissions from family and community can be heard, recorded and considered.\u201d\n\nPhoto Credit: Kelsie Kilawna\nA red dress symbolizing MMIWG+ hangs in syilx Okanagan territory on Red Dress Day in 2021.\n\nParole board says Robotti has \u2018expressed genuine remorse\u2019\n\nRobotti, now 73, was sentenced to life in prison in 2017 with no eligibility for parole after 10 years for killing Louie in 2015. She was charged with second-degree murder and indignity to a dead body.\n\nLouie, a member of Osoyoos Indian Band (OIB), was 26 years old and the mother of Robotti\u2019s great-grandson. Robotti is originally from Italy.\n\nAccording to the Parole Board of Canada\u2019s decision in granting Robotti day parole \u2014 which was made official in December 2023 \u2014 Robotti struck Louie multiple times in the head with a crowbar following a dispute over the care of Louie\u2019s child, which occurred in the presence of the child at Robotti\u2019s home in snpink\u2019tn (Penticton).\n\n\u201cYou struck the victim multiple times to the head and face, more than what was necessary to merely provide for your own safety,\u201d the Parole Board wrote to Robotti in their decision.\n\nAfter the incident, Robotti enlisted the help of her brother, Pier, to hide Louie\u2019s body. A court heard during her trial that the siblings carried Louie\u2019s body into a car, drove to a secluded forested area in the nearby community of Naramata, and dumped her body down an embankment.\n\nThe Parole Board\u2019s decision goes on to tell Robotti: \u201cFrom the outset of your sentence, you have expressed genuine remorse for your actions. Through successful completion of programming, you have made significant gains in your ability to take responsibility and accountability.\u201d\n\nA special condition for her day parole was imposed, where she is not to have any direct or indirect contact with Louie\u2019s family, \u201cunless with the prior written authorization of your Parole Officer,\u201d the decision states.\n\n\u201cYou were able to identify how your offence is likely to have undermined the sense of safety Indigenous people may feel.\u201d\n\nThe Parole Board ultimately decided that Robotti\u2019s risk to society while on day parole \u201cwould not be undue\u201d and would \u201ccontribute to your reintegration as a law-abiding citizen.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a result of your good institutional behaviour and your program performance you also improved upon your correctional plan ratings. Your progress is a risk mitigating consideration,\u201d the decision adds.\n\nWhen Robotti was sentenced in 2017, the court ruled that she would not be eligible for parole for 10 years. Yet, the Parole Board\u2019s decision in granting day parole to Robotti comes six years into her sentence.\n\n\u201cUnder the law, all offenders in federal custody, including those serving life sentences, are eligible for parole consideration at some point in their sentence,\u201d the Parole Board of Canada wrote in a statement to IndigiNews.\n\nThe statement attributed to Lisa Saether, the Parole Board\u2019s Pacific regional manager of community relations, also noted that people serving life sentences are eligible to apply for day parole three years before their full parole eligibility date.\n\nThe Parole Board had also approved multiple escorted temporary absences (ETAs) for Robotti in July 2021 and December 2022. She was assessed as a minimum-security offender in February 2022, and has been housed at a minimum-security institution since March 2022. Prior to being granted day parole, she was accepted for day parole destinations at two undisclosed local community residential facilities.\n\nIn making decisions, the Parole Board said that their members \u201cconsider all relevant available information related to the offender\u2019s case,\u201d such as the nature and gravity of the offence; information obtained from victims, the offender and other components of the criminal justice system; and including assessments provided by correctional authorities.\n\nHowever, in Wilson\u2019s petition, she writes that the decision to grant parole was \u201cbased only on (Robotti\u2019s) own self serving submissions and behaviour in a restricted environment \u201c\n\n\u201cFamily and community are outraged at the circumstances that allowed Ms. Robotti to make submissions while the family was not notified or given an opportunity to make submissions,\u201d she writes.\n\nMany syilx community members, including Marty Marchand, learned about Robotti\u2019s granted day parole through local media coverage.\n\n\u201c(The Parole Board) never even contacted any of Roxanne\u2019s family or any of those who had a victim impact letter,\u201d said Marchand, who was a friend of Louie.\n\n\u201cThey never even contacted one person to inform them that Grace was applying for day parole and then was granted it.\u201d\n\nWilson called it \u201cthe height of incompetence and of insults.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how they can justify making that decision based on her submissions only,\u201d she said. \u201cI would\u2019ve picked up the phone and talked to someone in the family.\u201d\n\nIndividuals have to be registered as victims in order to receive information about the offender who harmed them \u2014 such as parole date hearings, which they are able to attend virtually or in-person, the Parole Board\u2019s statement said.\n\nAt parole hearings, victims can outline any \u201ccontinuing physical, emotional or financial impact the offence has had on them.\u201d They can also request that the Parole Board consider that certain special conditions be imposed on the offender\u2019s release.\n\nThe Parole Board\u2019s statement pointed out that people can register as victims through the Parole Board\u2019s online \u201cVictims Portal,\u201d or by completing a registration form with the Parole Board or Correctional Service Canada.\n\n\u201cVictims may provide information to the PBC at any time related to safety concerns, the offender\u2019s risk to re-offend and/or the effect the crime has had on them, their family, or the community,\u201d the Parole Board\u2019s statement added.\n\n\u201cWhile I can appreciate how concerning it can be to victims, their family and the community when an offender is granted a form of conditional release, I can assure you that public safety is always the paramount consideration in all PBC decisions.\u201d\n\n\u2018Disgrace for the criminal justice system\u2019\n\nOn January 5, around 70 people from the community came together, drummed and marched to the snpink\u2019tn courthouse to denounce the Parole Board\u2019s decision. syilx leadership and local government joined family members in expressing \u201cdisgrace for the criminal justice system.\u201d\n\nAt the time of her murder, Louie had been living in \u201cVancouver\u201d and was visiting family and friends in snpink\u2019tn for the holidays.\n\n\u201cIt was her first year down there for fashion school,\u201d said Wilson.\n\n\u201cAs a little girl, that\u2019s all she did was draw \u2014 draw pretty dresses and look at pretty dresses.\u201d\n\nShe remembers how her daughters, with their kids, would regularly go to the beach in snpink\u2019tn with Louie and her child when she was living there.\n\n\u201cShe was just a joy,\u201d said Wilson.\n\n\u201cAnd then you see her with her kid, you go, \u2018Wow, I just love seeing that.\u2019 I just loved seeing it.\u201d\n\nIn 2013, Louie and her child\u2019s father Dylan Spence, who is the grandson of Robotti, became \u201cestranged after a violent incident,\u201d according to local media coverage of the trial, leading to a bitter custody battle between the two families over the child.\n\nWilson said she spent years helping Louie by acting as her legal advisor as she was dealing with such issues.\n\n\u201cWe knew for years (Robotti) was threatening her. I advised her during all the times that they applied for custody, when they called the Ministry of Children and Family Development (MCFD) on her,\u201d said Wilson, who launched the petition shortly after the rally for Louie.\n\n\u201cI was her legal advocate at that time, so I knew what she was afraid of.\u201d\n\nThe goal of Wilson\u2019s petition is 500 signatures, and even if that\u2019s met, she said that she has little faith in the Parole Board reversing their day parole decision for Robotti.\n\n\u201cShe isn\u2019t a danger to any other white person, so they\u2019ll forget about her. There will be no impact, not even a ripple, for what she did in her circles,\u201d she said.\n\nAfter Louie\u2019s death, a court heard that the Robottis scattered her belongings and the murder weapon in dumpsters strewn throughout the city, before reporting her missing. About a week later, they turned themselves into the police when Pier revealed the offence to multiple people.\n\nFriends and family of Louie believe that she might have still been alive during the ordeal.\n\n\u201cThere were handprints on the tree, like she was trying to get up and get out. This is the treatment of our people,\u201d said Marchand, who organized the rally in her honour last month.\n\nThe night before she died, Wilson said Louie had told her cousin that, \u201cthe only thing they have left to do is kill me, because they want the boy.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis was the end of that fight \u2013 (Louie) had to go to court to be able to take her son to Vancouver. And (the Robottis) lost that. So her fears \u2014 and my fears as her advocate \u2014 went sky high when that happened.\u201d\n\nWilson said that she wasn\u2019t surprised by the Parole Board\u2019s outcome, calling it a reflection of systemic issues within the \u201cCanadian\u201d justice system.\n\n\u201cThe two-tier system is really, really evident sometimes,\u201d she said.\n\nShe also criticized the Parole Board\u2019s tender treatment of Robotti, arguing that had the roles been reversed, Louie would have no chance at parole.\n\n\u201cThis would not happen to an Indian. This just would not happen if this was an Indian person. Everybody knows that,\u201d she said.\n\nMarchand shared similar sentiments.\n\n\u201cIf I committed that crime, we wouldn\u2019t be getting that treatment. And I know that because my skin is brown,\u201d said Marchand.\n\nBoth Wilson and Marchand said that they intend on keeping Louie\u2019s memory alive and calling attention to the injustices towards her.\n\nWilson said she wants to leave copies of the petition at local band offices, and hopes to meet with chiefs and councils across the Okanagan to discuss justice for Louie.\n\n\u201cJust the pain of losing a bright light. It\u2019s someone you look at and smile. You go, \u2018Man \u2026 she\u2019s done good for herself,\u201d said Wilson.\n\n\u201cShe was just different.\u201d\n\n\n\n Share Tweet Share Email Share\nSend your comments, news tips, typos, letter {"url": "https://winnipegsun.com/travel/usa/oh-say-you-can-see-lots-in-baltimore-maryland", "title": "Things to see in Baltimore, Maryland | Winnipeg Sun", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nePaper\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nJets add to depth with two-way signings\nTRENDING\nBombers' Collaros to miss first start of season vs Redblacks\nTRENDING\nTrump trashes \u2018broken down pile of crap\u2019 Biden in viral video\nTRENDING\nEmergency responders rescue individual from Assiniboine River\nTRENDING\nManitoba First Nation reports 150 anomalies at residential school site\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nTravel USATravel\nOh say you can see lots in Baltimore, Maryland\nAuthor of the article:\nLance Hornby\nPublished May 03, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 04, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 4 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nThe first incarnation of a rail passenger carriage, not really far from a stagecoach, from the early to mid-1800s is seen here at the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Museum in downtown Baltimore. PHOTO BY LANCE HORNBY /Toronto Sun/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nWhere are Babe Ruth\u2019s booming bat, the bombs bursting in air and birth of the B&O based?\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nRight here in Baltimore, near the Inner Harbour attractions that make Maryland\u2019s \u2018Charm City\u2019 a must for Canadians coming through to watch the baseball Orioles, the football Ravens or diverting from D.C. for a different American history lesson.\n\n\u2018Smalltimore,\u2019 just past the half-million mark in population, is ideal to explore for a day out or extended stay this spring and summer.\n\nBABE RUTH BIRTHPLACE AND MUSEUM\n\nOld Yankee Stadium was called the House That Ruth Built, but humble Emory Street is where the Babe\u2019s legend was born.\n\nFrom the O\u2019s diamond at Camden Yards, first of MLB\u2019s retro stadiums three decades ago, follow the 60 baseballs painted on the sidewalks in honour of his record home run total in 1927 to this shrine and an adjoining house, saved from demolition by the city in the \u201870s.\n\nTravel Time\n\nPlan your next getaway with Travel Time, featuring travel deals, destinations and gear.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe extra space preserves two storeys of family rooms along with many sports and personal artifacts, with old video clips (did he really call his shot before a \u201832 World Series homer?) and contemporary touches such as a baseball card collecting display.\n\nFORT MCHENRY\n\nA London gentlemen\u2019s club drinking song \u2018To Anacreon in Heaven\u2019 is the musical inspiration of The Star-Spangled Banner. But Francis Scott Key was deeply moved to pen the lyrics from his eyewitness account of the harbour fort being bombarded by the British fleet through the day and night of Sept. 13, 1814.\n\nKey, aboard a truce ship trying to gain release of a captured civilian friend, had to wait with the anxious citizenry until the dawn\u2019s early light to see the fort\u2019s 15-star flag yet wave.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn McHenry\u2019s visitors centre and museum, a short film detailing the Battle of Baltimore during the War of 1812 and Key\u2019s personal story precede the screen lifting to dramatically reveal the preserved fort and current flag a short walk at the water\u2019s edge. The anthem, evolution of the flag and later uses of the fort are detailed. McHenry is a 12-minute drive from downtown.\n\nOne of the many vintage locomotives situated in the 1884 Baldwin Roundhouse, the star attraction of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Museum in downtown Baltimore. PHOTO BY LANCE HORNBY /Toronto Sun/Postmedia Network\n\nB&O RAILROAD MUSEUM\n\nA bit bigger than its well-known home on the Monopoly board, this 1,400-square-metre behemoth has everything the rail aficionado can choo-choo choose from, kids to seniors.\n\nWe were awed inside and out by the Baltimore & Ohio Line\u2019s 22-sided Roundhouse, built in 1884, its 18-metre turntable still in use today. It\u2019s surrounded by lovingly preserved locomotives and carriages from the 19th and early 20th century. You can ride the first mile of track ever laid in the U.S. in 1827, which began with cars drawn by horses, which were swapped out every 24 kilometres. To compete with the Erie Canal, it grew to America\u2019s largest network with a profound effect on life through the Civil War and economic boom times as a freight and passenger service until the company was absorbed in the 1980s.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIn and about the Roundhouse, volunteers and guides explain the trains, miniature models, repair shops and the harrowing history of the Underground Railroad.\n\nOne tale is that of runaway slave Henry \u2018Box\u2019 Brown, who shipped himself to freedom on the B&O from Virginia in a cramped crate simply marked \u2018This Side Up.\u2019\n\nBALTIMORE INNER HARBOR\n\nEn route to the ball games via Pratt Street and the waterfront are the National Aquarium, Maryland Science Centre and the Port Discovery Children\u2019s Museum.\n\nFor one ticket, also check out four moored vessels with diverse nautical history, a U.S. Navy tall ship from 1854, a Coast Guard lightship from the 1930s, a submarine and the Taney, last ship afloat that fought in the attack on Pearl Harbor.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThere are harbour cruises of every description, electric mini-pirate ship that can accommodate six people or two-person pedal boats.\n\nWHERE TO EAT\n\nIt took a while to decide what to have on the large and tempting brunch menu at bustling Miss Shirley\u2019s Caf\u00e9 on Pratt, sampling the three-egg omelets, grilled cakes and the Smalltimore Smash Burger.\n\nSeveral chain restaurants dot the downtown and harbour, while a choice of smaller neighbourhood diners and bars are handy at the Power Plant entertainment district.\n\nWHERE TO STAY\n\nThe Revival, a boutique hotel not far from the harbour at Mount Vernon, has 107 restored guest rooms with locally curated art in the suites and throughout the premises. A rooftop lounge is next to the George Washington monument, the first one erected for the inaugural president. Its 227 steps can be climbed for even better views of the local 19th-century architecture and city panorama.\n\nIF YOU GO\n\nAir Canada has direct daily flights to Baltimore from Toronto Pearson and more options if you choose to arrive or depart from Washington, D.C.\u2019s two airports.\n\nFor more information, head to visitmaryland.org.\n\nlhornby@postmedia.com\n\nX: @sunhornby\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://pembinavalleyonline.com/articles/pembina-valley-red-dress-project-brings-awareness-to-murdered-and-missing-indigenous-women-in-a-series-of-exhibits", "title": "Pembina Valley Red Dress Project brings awareness to Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women in a series of exhibits\u00a0 - PembinaValleyOnline.com - Local news, Weather, Sports, Free Classifieds and Business Listings for the Pembina Valley, Manitoba", "body": "24\u00b0\nDOWNLOAD THE APP\nADVERTISE WITH US\nSUBMIT NEWS\nNEWS\nLocal News\nFuneral Announcements\nLocal Sports\nAg News\nCommunity\nNational News\nSponsored\nWeather\nWeather Radar\nLISTEN\nFEATURES\nEvents\nLocalJobShop\nHelloGoodBuy Classifieds\nGarage Sales\nCFAM Program Guide\nRoad Reports & Cancellations\nCONTESTS\nCountry 88 Contests\nSummer Shedtacular\nFarmer Appreciation Lunch\nThe Eagle 935 Contests\nCONNECT\nContact Us\nSubmit News\nMeet the Team\nApp\nFacebook\nYouTube\nStreaming\nRSS\nAdvertise With Us\nCareers\nContest Rules\nAccessibility\nTerms Of Use Agreement\nPrivacy Policy\nJournalistic Standards\n24\u00b0\nNEWS\nWEATHER\nEVENTS\n LISTEN\nWhat\u2019s Happening This Summer??\n\nFind upcoming events on our website at altona.ca\n\nNext\nLOCAL NEWS\nPembina Valley Red Dress Project brings awareness to Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women in a series of exhibits\u00a0\nWritten by Robyn Wiebe Tuesday, May 17 2022, 12:14 PM\nShare:\nCopied!\nArticle continues below advertisement \u21b4\n\n\u00a0\n\nThe Pembina Valley Red Dress Project (PVRDP) was bigger this year with over 100 Red Dresses hung from trees or displayed on the ground, representing the hundreds of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and girls in Manitoba. \u00a0Last Saturday, the exhibit was in Morden Park where Albert Meekis, originally from Sandy Lake First nation in Ontario, shared his thoughts of walking through the display.\u00a0\n\n\"The red dresses we see here, they all come with question marks. Questions, and uncertainty, and darkness about them. We all would like to know, we'd like to like find them, if possible, but the reality of it is, they\u2019re not coming back. Seeing this here too, kind of opens your eyes as to what's going on even in our own communities that we live in - that we feel safe in.\"\u00a0\n\nHe added there is a call to action to work towards reconciliation coming from this kind of representation of marginalized people who often find themselves in vulnerable situations to make ends meet. \u00a0\n\n\"I think this red dress representation speaks to us to look after our young women, and to try to find where they are, and to respect them. They carry the community, from what I'm taught in my culture. Women are the givers of the world.\"\u00a0\n\nAs an Educational Assistant in Maple Leaf School, Meekis was thrilled to see the artwork and student involvement added to the exhibit.\u00a0\n\n\"The part that I like about it is, you teach children at an early age to do something, it sticks with them all their lives, and they learn that respect and they learn to respect each other, they learn to treat each other in a certain way. If we could reach one child with what we're doing today, I think we can say that we're making this world a better place. \"\u00a0\n\nThis year, a section of local people who are murdered or missing was added to the display, including dresses with names embroidered on them and a table sharing the story of one woman and her unborn child, who were murdered.\u00a0\n\nOne of the PVRDP organizers, Carolyn Wiebe, acknowledged there are more names out there.\u00a0\n\n\"I think one of the things that we wanted to come out of this as well, is that there's probably other families out there that we don't realize that they have a missing or murdered loved one, and hopefully they'll come forward.\" \u00a0\n\nAdded to the event this year was an outdoor classroom made of tree stumps covered in Orange T-Shirts with children's shoes and boots lining the perimeter with an Every Child Matters flag blowing in the wind.\u00a0\n\nTrish Meekis teaches a grade 5/6 split class at Ecole Morden Middle School. They learned about MMIW in school and added work to the exhibit. \u00a0\n\n\"As a class, we have had numerous discussions about Indigenous issues over the last year together. Some of my students have connections to share and they are all open to learning and contributing to the idea of reconciliation. My students each created an art piece with an outline of a woman in a red dress and wrote some messages of strength on them. They were very proud of their work and the fact that they would be added to such a powerful exhibit at Morden Park. It is so amazing to see the compassion and concern they have, as well as the willingness to be open to learning more about our Canadian history. I hope the learning will continue for all of the students, and that they will carry the lessons taught with them throughout their lives. The Red Dress Exhibit is such an important event and I am so proud to be a part of this year!\" \u00a0\n\nGenesis House had a representative at the Red Dress Project, and submitted a statement of support for the exhibit and what it means to them. \u00a0\n\n\"Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls is a human rights crisis. It disproportionately affects Indigenous peoples across Canada and the United States. \u00a0They are disproportionately affected by all forms of violence. At Genesis House, we consider physical, emotional and sexual violence towards another should be the concern of all members of society. Genesis House will stand alongside our community and nation as an ally.\" \u00a0\n\nThe next installment of the PV Red Dress Project will be in Winkler at the Winkler Arts and Culture building on Saturday May 21st from 10am-3pm, then in Killarney and Crystal City the following weekends. To learn more or to support this project go to the Red Dress Pembina Valley Facebook page.\u00a0\n\nNEXT STORY\nLegends Car Club Plan Fundraising BBQ for South Central Cancer Resource\nLATEST IN LOCAL NEWS\nStreetlight falls on car in Morden\u2003\nReeve welcomes proposed changes to Manitoba's Medical First Response model\nGo Morden Mud Hens! - {"url": "https://www.mbcradio.com/2019/04/red-dress-campaign-to-raise-funds-for-families-of-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-and-children", "title": "Red Dress Campaign to raise funds for families of missing and murdered Indigenous women and children - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nRed Dress Campaign to raise funds for families of missing and murdered Indigenous women and children\n\nby MBC News | Apr 28, 2019 | Current News | 0 comments\n\nA Saskatoon woman, originally from Pelican Lake First Nation, has decided to start a program in support of families of missing and murdered Indigenous woman and children with the Red Dress Campaign.\n\nAfter learning about Happy Charles, who went missing on April 3, 2017, Debbie Thomas became involved with search efforts that primarily took place between Prince Albert and La Ronge.\n\nShe became frustrated when only six people showed up to take part in one of the searches.\n\nIt was then that Thomas created the Red Dress Campaign to better organize and advertise search events.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re very limited as to how much you can search,\u201d Thomas says. \u201cSome of the ground searches involve really big fields that would be better off using ATVs. We don\u2019t have the equipment for people to go out and look.\u201d\n\nThe fundraising efforts will give participating stores and businesses a stack of paper red dress cut-outs that will be offered to customers during the time of payment.\n\nIf a customer would like to donate, they can buy a dress, sign it and the establishment will hang it on display.\n\nThe inaugural funds will go towards search efforts for Charles, who is a mother of four daughters, then hopefully branch off to support other families.\n\n\u201cMy long term vision for missing and murdered women is setting up a missing persons office,\u201d Thomas says.\n\nShe adds she would like to see First Nations youth work at the facility to take tips from anyone who has information.\n\n\u201cThey can have some sort of liaison that is always involved with the families and the tips that are coming in. There\u2019s probably some people that want to talk and tell where they (a missing or murdered person) are. They don\u2019t know who to talk to; they aren\u2019t always willing to talk to the RCMP or city police because of the communication barrier.\u201d\n\nThomas would like to see the campaign become an annual event.\n\nIdeally, small local companies and big corporations would take part in the efforts.\n\nShe says that any business that would like to take part can fill out an order form and she and other volunteers will hand cut the dresses to be offered to customers.\n\nOnce the campaign has concluded, the participating businesses will send the Happy Mary Charles fundraiser a cheque for the donations.\n\nThe second annual Happy Charles Awareness and Healing walk is slated to take place May 4 \u2013 12 where Charles\u2019 family members will walk from Prince Albert to La Ronge.\n\nThey are accepting donations of food and water during their walk north on Highway 2.\n\nThe group will walk 30 kilometres a day and sleep in tents during the night.\n\n\u201cHappy\u2019s daughters are always in tears because they miss their mom,\u201d Thomas says. \u201cI\u2019m hoping that by having this Red Dress (campaign) that there is always some sort of funds or some sort of awareness.\u201d\n\n(PHOTO: Red dress cut outs from the 2nd Annual Awareness Walk for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women. The walk started at the Far Reserve and ended at the Urban Reserve in April 2019. Photo by Katrina Cameron)\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},
{"url": "https://infotel.ca/newsitem/friends-of-roxanne-louie-seek-reversal-of-decision-to-grant-her-murderer-day-parole/it103015", "title": "Friends of Roxanne Louie seek reversal of decision to grant her murderer day parole | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Penticton, South Okanagan &|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 28.4\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nPenticton News\nFriends of Roxanne Louie seek reversal of decision to grant her murderer day parole\nAaron Hemens, Local Journalism Initiative\nA red dress symbolizing MMIWG+ hangs in syilx Okanagan territory on Red Dress Day in 2021.\nImage Credit: Photo by Kelsie Kilawna\nFebruary 02, 2024 - 7:00 PM\n\nCONTENT ADVISORY\n\nMore than 300 people have signed a petition demanding the Parole Board of Canada reverse a decision to grant six-month day parole to a woman serving life in prison for murdering syilx mother Roxanne Louie.\n\nLaurie Wilson, a syilx community member and friend of Louie, created the petition which says the Parole Board\u2019s process has been \u201cpatently unfair and discriminatory against the family of Roxanne Louie and the Okanagan Nation at large.\u201d\n\nShe writes that Louie\u2019s family and community were not notified or given an opportunity to provide input when killer Grace Robotti was in the process of being granted conditional release.\n\n\u201cWe, the undersigned, demand that the Parole Board of Canada rescind the granting of any parole to Grace Robotti because of the lack of input from (Roxanne\u2019s) family and community,\u201d the petition states.\u00a0\n\n\u201cA decision in this matter should be delayed until the submissions from family and community can be heard, recorded and considered.\u201d\n\nParole board says Robotti has 'expressed genuine remorse\u2019\n\nRobotti, now 73, was sentenced to life in prison in 2017 with no eligibility for parole after 10 years for killing Louie in 2015. She was charged with second-degree murder and indignity to a dead body.\u00a0\n\nLouie, a member of Osoyoos Indian Band (OIB), was 26 years old and the mother of Robotti\u2019s great-grandson. Robotti is originally from Italy.\n\nAccording to the Parole Board of Canada\u2019s decision in granting Robotti day parole \u2014 which was made official in December 2023 \u2014 Robotti struck Louie multiple times in the head with a crowbar following a dispute over the care of Louie\u2019s child, which occurred in the presence of the child at Robotti\u2019s home in Penticton (snpink\u2019tn).\n\n\u201cYou struck the victim multiple times to the head and face, more than what was necessary to merely provide for your own safety,\u201d the Parole Board wrote to Robotti in their decision.\n\nAfter the incident, Robotti enlisted the help of her brother, Pier, to hide Louie\u2019s body. A court heard during her trial that the siblings carried Louie\u2019s body into a car, drove to a secluded forested area in the nearby community of Naramata, and dumped her body down an embankment.\u00a0\n\nThe Parole Board\u2019s decision goes on to tell Robotti: \u201cFrom the outset of your sentence, you have expressed genuine remorse for your actions. Through successful completion of programming, you have made significant gains in your ability to take responsibility and accountability.\u201d\n\nA special condition for her day parole was imposed, where she is not to have any direct or indirect contact with Louie\u2019s family, \u201cunless with the prior written authorization of your Parole Officer,\u201d the decision states.\n\n\u201cYou were able to identify how your offence is likely to have undermined the sense of safety Indigenous people may feel.\u201d\n\nThe Parole Board ultimately decided that Robotti\u2019s risk to society while on day parole \u201cwould not be undue\u201d and would \u201ccontribute to your reintegration as a law-abiding citizen.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a result of your good institutional behaviour and your program performance you also improved upon your correctional plan ratings. Your progress is a risk mitigating consideration,\u201d the decision adds.\n\nWhen Robotti was sentenced in 2017, the court ruled that she would not be eligible for parole for 10 years. Yet, the Parole Board\u2019s decision in granting day parole to Robotti comes six years into her sentence.\u00a0\n\n\u201cUnder the law, all offenders in federal custody, including those serving life sentences, are eligible for parole consideration at some point in their sentence,\u201d the Parole Board of Canada wrote in a statement to IndigiNews.\n\nThe statement attributed to Lisa Saether, the Parole Board\u2019s Pacific regional manager of community relations, also noted that people serving life sentences are eligible to apply for day parole three years before their full parole eligibility date.\n\nThe Parole Board had also approved multiple escorted temporary absences (ETAs) for Robotti in July 2021 and December 2022. She was assessed as a minimum-security offender in February 2022, and has been housed at a minimum-security institution since March 2022. Prior to being granted day parole, she was accepted for day parole destinations at two undisclosed local community residential facilities.\n\nIn making decisions, the Parole Board said that their members \u201cconsider all relevant available information related to the offender\u2019s case,\u201d such as the nature and gravity of the offence; information obtained from victims, the offender and other components of the criminal justice system; and including assessments provided by correctional authorities.\n\nHowever, in Wilson\u2019s petition, she writes that the decision to grant parole was \u201cbased only on (Robotti\u2019s) own self serving submissions and behaviour in a restricted environment \u201c\n\n\u201cFamily and community are outraged at the circumstances that allowed Ms. Robotti to make submissions while the family was not notified or given an opportunity to make submissions,\u201d she writes.\n\nMany syilx community members, including Marty Marchand, learned about Robotti\u2019s granted day parole through local media coverage.\u00a0\n\n\u201c(The Parole Board) never even contacted any of Roxanne\u2019s family or any of those who had a victim impact letter,\u201d said Marchand, who was a friend of Louie.\n\n\u201cThey never even contacted one person to inform them that Grace was applying for day parole and then was granted it.\u201d\n\nWilson called it \u201cthe height of incompetence and of insults.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how they can justify making that decision based on her submissions only,\u201d she said. \u201cI would\u2019ve picked up the phone and talked to someone in the family.\u201d\n\nIndividuals have to be registered as victims in order to receive information about the offender who harmed them \u2014 such as parole date hearings, which they are able to attend virtually or in-person, the Parole Board\u2019s statement said.\n\nAt parole hearings, victims can outline any \u201ccontinuing physical, emotional or financial impact the offence has had on them.\u201d They can also request that the Parole Board consider that certain special conditions be imposed on the offender\u2019s release.\n\nThe Parole Board\u2019s statement pointed out that people can register as victims through the Parole Board\u2019s online \u201cVictims Portal,\u201d or by completing a registration form with the Parole Board or Correctional Service Canada. \u00a0\n\n\u201cVictims may provide information to the PBC at any time related to safety concerns, the offender\u2019s risk to re-offend and/or the effect the crime has had on them, their family, or the community,\u201d the Parole Board\u2019s statement added.\n\n\u201cWhile I can appreciate how concerning it can be to victims, their family and the community when an offender is granted a form of conditional release, I can assure you that public safety is always the paramount consideration in all PBC decisions.\u201d\n\n\u2018Disgrace for the criminal justice system\u2019\n\nOn January 5, around 70 people from the community came together, drummed and marched to the Penticton (snpink\u2019tn) courthouse to denounce the Parole Board\u2019s decision. syilx leadership and local government joined family members in expressing \u201cdisgrace for the criminal justice system.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAt the time of her murder, Louie had been living in Vancouver and was visiting family and friends in the city for the holidays.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt was her first year down there for fashion school,\u201d said Wilson.\n\n\u201cAs a little girl, that\u2019s all she did was draw \u2014 draw pretty dresses and look at pretty dresses.\u201d\n\nShe remembers how her daughters, with their kids, would regularly go to the beach with Louie and her child when she was living there.\u00a0\n\n\u201cShe was just a joy,\u201d said Wilson.\n\n\u201cAnd then you see her with her kid, you go, \u2018Wow, I just love seeing that.\u2019 I just loved seeing it.\u201d\n\nIn 2013, Louie and her child\u2019s father Dylan Spence, who is the grandson of Robotti, became \u201cestranged after a violent incident,\u201d according to local media coverage of the trial, leading to a bitter custody battle between the two families over the child.\n\nWilson said she spent years helping Louie by acting as her legal advisor as she was dealing with such issues.\n\n\u201cWe knew for years (Robotti) was threatening her. I advised her during all the times that they applied for custody, when they called the Ministry of Children and Family Development (MCFD) on her,\u201d said Wilson, who launched the petition shortly after the rally for Louie.\n\n\u201cI was her legal advocate at that time, so I knew what she was afraid of.\u201d\n\nThe goal of Wilson\u2019s petition is 500 signatures, and even if that\u2019s met, she said that she has little faith in the Parole Board reversing their day parole decision for Robotti.\n\n\u201cShe isn\u2019t a danger to any other white person, so they\u2019ll forget about her. There will be no impact, not even a ripple, for what she did in her circles,\u201d she said.\n\nAfter Louie\u2019s death, a court heard that the Robottis scattered her belongings and the murder weapon in dumpsters strewn throughout the city, before reporting her missing. About a week later, they turned themselves into the police when Pier revealed the offence to multiple people.\u00a0\n\nFriends and family of Louie believe that she might have still been alive during the ordeal.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThere were handprints on the tree, like she was trying to get up and get out. This is the treatment of our people,\u201d said Marchand, who organized the rally in her honour last month.\n\nThe night before she died, Wilson said Louie had told her cousin that, \u201cthe only thing they have left to do is kill me, because they want the boy.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis was the end of that fight \u2013 (Louie) had to go to court to be able to take her son to Vancouver. And (the Robottis) lost that. So her fears \u2014 and my fears as her advocate \u2014 went sky high when that happened.\u201d\n\nWilson said that she wasn\u2019t surprised by the Parole Board\u2019s outcome, calling it a reflection of systemic issues within the \u201cCanadian\u201d justice system.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThe two-tier system is really, really evident sometimes,\u201d she said.\u00a0\n\nShe also criticized the Parole Board\u2019s tender treatment of Robotti, arguing that had the roles been reversed, Louie would have no chance at parole.\n\n\u201cThis would not happen to an Indian. This just would not happen if this was an Indian person. Everybody knows that,\u201d she said.\n\nMarchand shared similar sentiments.\n\n\u201cIf I committed that crime, we wouldn\u2019t be getting that treatment. And I know that because my skin is brown,\u201d said Marchand.\n\nBoth Wilson and Marchand said that they intend on keeping Louie\u2019s memory alive and calling attention to the injustices towards her.\u00a0\n\nWilson said she wants to leave copies of the petition at local band offices, and hopes to meet with chiefs and councils across the Okanagan to discuss justice for Louie.\u00a0\n\n\u201cJust the pain of losing a bright light. It\u2019s someone you look at and smile. You go, \u2018Man \u2026 she\u2019s done good for herself,\u201d said Wilson.\u00a0\n\n\u201cShe was just different.\u201d\n\n\u2014 This story was originally published by\u00a0IndigiNews.\n\nNews It is our government's responsibility to ensure justice for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit people,\" the Native Women\u2019s Association said in a statement on social media Wednesday.\n\nThe report also outlines how homicides of Indigenous women and girls moved through the court system, how they were treated at crucial decision points along the way, and how their outcomes compared with the homicides of non-Indigenous women and girls.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n9\nShares\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Penticton News\n\n\n\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - {"url": "https://www.barrietoday.com/local-news/opp-marks-red-dress-day-with-poignant-display-at-headquarters-6-photos-5330425", "title": "OPP marks Red Dress Day with poignant display at headquarters (6 photos) - Barrie News", "body": "Skip to content\nYour Business Join BarrieToday+  \nHomeNews\nMore\nObituaries\nShop\nFlyersClassifieds\nJobsConnect\nEvents\ud83d\udc9b\n26.6 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nOPP marks Red Dress Day with poignant display at headquarters (6 photos)\nDisplay is in honour of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\nOrilliaMatters Staff\nMay 5, 2022 8:30 AM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 6 OPP General Headquarters in Orillia will be lit up in red Thursday evening to mark Red Dress Day.Ontario Provincial Police photo\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:01:30\n\nNEWS RELEASE\nONTARIO PROVINCIAL POLICE\n*************************\nMembers of the Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) Indigenous Policing Bureau (IPB) will show their support for Red Dress Day on May 5, as well as their ongoing commitment to address the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) Calls for Justice.\n\nThe main hallway of OPP General Headquarters is lined with over 100 red dresses in remembrance of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. This display, which includes images of the women and girls, acts as a powerful visual representation of the pain and loss felt by the families and friends of victims as well as survivors.\n\nIPB asks members of the OPP as well as the public to reflect and learn more about this ongoing national tragedy. Everyone is encouraged to honour MMIWG by working together to embrace and support community healing.\n\nIn 2019, Vanessa Willow, a resident of Rama First Nation, created and donated a red dress painting to the OPP in honour of the ongoing commitment to address the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. This painting is currently on display as part of the Red Dress Day recognition.\n\nThose passing by OPP General Headquarters (777 Memorial Ave., Orillia) in the evening hours will see the building lit up in red. Please take the opportunity to pause, reflect and be reminded of the love of the families and communities that grieve for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\n*************************\n\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\t'Nightmare': Cyber-attack throws wrench into dealerships' {"url": "https://www.vernonmorningstar.com/community/photos-penticton-high-school-students-honour-lost-indigenous-lives-with-red-dress-day/", "title": "PHOTOS: Penticton high school students honour lost Indigenous lives with Red Dress Day - Vernon Morning Star", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n28.0 \u00b0C\nHome Community\nPHOTOS: Penticton high school students honour lost Indigenous lives with Red Dress Day\nMay 5 is National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\nLogan Lockhart\nMay 6, 2022 10:55 AM\nMay 6, 2022 4:15 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 6 Students at Penticton Secondary recognized National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls on Thursday, May 5, for the first time in the school\u2019s history. (Photo: Eva Koch)\nExpand\n\nIt wasn\u2019t just an ordinary day at school for students at Penticton Secondary on Thursday, May 5 \u2014 it was an opportunity to take action on truth and reconciliation.\n\nA total of 25 red dresses were displayed outside of the school to mark the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and Two-Spirit People.\n\nA conversation about the importance of the occasion among 18 students enrolled in the Land Learn Program began in the classroom, and then continued with the school\u2019s first-ever outdoor Indigenous-themed story walk.\n\n\u201cThey read individual stories in front of each other about people who have lost a loved one, whether it was a daughter, sister, mother, or auntie,\u201d said Patricia Collins, a teacher at Penticton Secondary and leader of the Land Learn Program.\n\nOn a somber, rainy morning in Penticton, students were given the opportunity to not only take action on reconciliation but to also share their personal stories that have been hidden for far too long.\n\n\u201cMultiple students brought a red dress from home to symbolize the violence Indigenous women face,\u201d Collins said.\n\n\u201cAt the end of the story walk, students were coming up and telling their own experiences related to violence.\u201d\n\nThe Land Learn Program launched in February as a way to introduce students to Indigenous history through the studying of multiple subjects, like English, math, science and even physical education.\n\nNationally, May 5 is recognized as a day to raise awareness about the lives Indigenous women have lost because of violence \u2014 it is also known as Red Dress Day.\n\nIt\u2019s a day that not many at Penticton Secondary were aware of prior to this week.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know about this day until a few days ago,\u201d said Bella Keith, a student in Grade 11. \u201cSadness comes from me because this isn\u2019t being spread around as much as it should be but I think the conversations that we\u2019re having about what\u2019s happened in the past and what still happens to this day is very important.\u201d\n\nRaising awareness about those who have lost their lives due to violence was a priority throughout the day, with the set up of an information booth headlining the cause. Local teachers Eva Koch, Lisa Stephens, Chris Ward and Russ Reid set up the booth inside the school, making sure the message of truth and reconciliation resonated with more than just those in the Land Learn Program.\n\n\u201cI think a lot more students need to understand what\u2019s going on in the world,\u201d Faythe Berglund said, a Grade 12 student. \u201cFor us to see what these women and their families have gone through\u2026we got to a certain point where I did end up crying.\u201d\n\nThursday marked the first time Penticton Secondary recognized the occasion. Koch, a social studies teacher, said that the school has plans to expand the event over the next five years, with the additions of art exhibits and walking stations among the top ideas.\n\nAn RCMP-led study in 2013 revealed that at that point in time there were 225 unsolved cases of missing or murdered Indigenous females.\n\n\u201cSo many people have gone missing and we don\u2019t talk about them, or even think about them,\u201d said Kaslo Stevenson, a Grade 11 student.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a serious problem. Today gave me an opportunity to reflect on the tragedy, and it\u2019s appropriate that we think about it.\u201d\n\nREAD MORE: \u2018These are criminal acts\u2019: Penticton Indian Band Chief on residential school discoveries\n\n@lgllockhart\nlogan.lockhart@pentictonwesternnews.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\nAbout the Author: Logan Lockhart\n\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tVernon cowgirl ropes in B.C. {"url": "https://www.pentictonherald.ca/spare_news/article_9f9f7701-b709-538d-a532-dd4e468c7a69.html", "title": "No more stolen sisters - Nuu-chah-nulth-aht march to raise awareness of loved ones lost | Spare News | pentictonherald.ca", "body": "Skip to main content\nAboutContactReal Estate TodayBusiness DirectorySpecial Editions\nMake Home Page\nSign UpLog In\nFacebook\n \nTwitter\n \nLinkedIn\nThursday, July 4, 2024\nHome\nNews\nSports\nBusiness\nFeatures\nOpinion\nClassifieds\nSubscribe\nContests\ne-Edition\nNo more stolen sisters - Nuu-chah-nulth-aht march to raise awareness of loved ones lost\nAlexandra Mehl, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter Ha-Shilth-Sa May 8, 2023 \nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nCopy article link\nSave\n\nPort Alberni, BC \u2013 It was at 10 a.m. that the color red, along with posters of missing and murdered loved ones, began to fill the parking lot at n\u0313aasn\u0313aas\u0294aqsa totem pole, near the Victoria Quay.\n\nMay 5th marks National Red Dress Day, where, in Port Alberni, Nuu-chah-nulth-aht and community members gathered to raise awareness of MMIWG2S+ and remember their missing and murdered loved ones.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re gathered here today in remembrance of our family members,\u201d said Irene Robinson, of Tseshaht, one of the opening speakers. \u201cWho we will always miss, who we will always love, who we will always think about and remember.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe gathered here to support the families of these loved ones, the families who walk, always, with the memories of their loved ones,\u201d she continued.\n\nThe walk was led by Tla-o-qui-aht along Victoria Quay, River Road, and ending at Maht Mah\u2019s where families and friends would speak the names of their loved ones to the crowd and share a meal together.\n\nFor Nuu-chah-nulth there are 53 women who have been murdered or died under suspicious circumstances, while two remain missing.\n\nLisa Watts, NTC MMIWG2S+ support worker, added two more names to that list.\n\nWatts said that she regrets not asking the crowd of people who had been affected by MMIWG2S+. She predicted that the entire room of over 200 people would have stood.\n\n\u201cOur communities are so close knit,\u201d said Watts.\n\nAmong those that are missing is Lisa Marie Young of Tla-o-qui-aht who went missing in 2002 from Nanaimo. May 5 is the date of her birthday, while this year marks twenty-one years since her disappearance; the same age she was when she went missing.\n\n\u201cWe had people express exactly the needs and the calls to action from the Nuu-chah-nulth people,\u201d said Watts. \u201cEverybody's getting their voices back.\u201d\n\nWatts said that Tla-o-qui-aht challenged Nuu-chah-nulth to make their own list and calls for action.\n\nAccording to a statement from Jagmeet Singh, leader of the federal NDP party since 2017, a total of 247 Indigenous women were murdered in Canada.\n\n\u201cDespite promising to act, the rate of homicide against Indigenous women has not decreased under the current government\u2019s watch,\u201d reads the statement.\n\n\u201cEvery day the government delays the implementation of the 231 Calls for Justice from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls is a day families risk losing a loved one,\u201d the statement continued.\n\n\u201cI want, so bad, to get to a world where we don't have to do this,\u201d said Watts.\n\n-30-\n\nThe Canadian Press. The history of the Red Dress was shared with the students, explaining it was first observed on May 5th, 2010, and it now happens every year.\n\nEach student learned some safety tips, received a colouring sheet along with a 7 Teachings colouring book, Bear Clan stickers, and an Indigenous Culture Card. The kids were able to look at samples of beading and practiced saying the word \"Miigwech\" which means \"thank you\" in Ojibwa.\n\nWhen asked what they could do for Red Dress Day on May 5th, the students quickly answered \"Wear red and place a red dress in your window\".\n\nNEXT STORY\n2023 is \"middling\" with start-time for producers\nLATEST IN LOCAL NEWS\nLocal daycare receives Diversity and Inclusion grant for Indigenous-style artwork\nMPI adding temporary hail estimating centre\nAnnual planting day at Lions Prairie Manor sees residents enjoy outdoors\nFlooding potential in Portage, with up to 60 mm of rainfall coming\nLATEST STORIES ON PORTAGEONLINE\nScoreboard/Lineup - This ongoing tragedy has become deeply embedded in our country\u2019s history, a haunting refrain that echoes in our hearts and minds.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nAn opening reception will be held from 10:30 to 11:30 at the downtown branch on Saturday morning (September 9), and will feature performances from the Khast\u2019an Drummers, and Kym Gouchie and Method Dance Society, as speeches from local Indigenous leaders.\n\nThe exhibit will be on display until September 29.\n\nSomething going on in the Prince George area you think people should know about?\nSend us a news tip by emailing pgnews@vistaradio.ca.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nNews\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\nNews\nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\nNews\nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\nNews\nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\n \nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\n \nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\n \nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\n \nSeven week old Cariboo Regional District strike is now over\nCity of Quesnel responds to petition filed against it by Mayor Ron Paull\n \nBC Transit to provide new bus shelters in PG\n \nTimberwolves land Spanish shooting guard\n \nFour Rivers Co-op cardlock locations fully operational after cybersecurity incident\n \nBrendan\u2019s Sports Shorts;
