{"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/local-news/prince-george-red-dress-campaign-to-take-place-sunday-7522497", "title": "Prince George Red Dress Campaign 2023 takes place Sunday - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nPrince George Red Dress Campaign to take place Sunday\nThe event will begin at the Red Dress Monument and continue at Lheidli T\u2019enneh Memorial Park\n\tHanna Petersen\n\nSep 9, 2023 5:15 AM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 2 Red Dresses will be hung at Lheidli T'enneh Memorial Park to honour loved ones. Tammy Miese\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:02:27\n\nThe annual Prince George Red Dress Campaign, which honours Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, will take place this Sunday.\n\nThe event will take place on Sunday, Sept. 10, starting at 1 p.m. at the Red Dress Monument located on Highway 16 and Ferry Avenue.\n\n\u201cThere will be some drumming and then we will have the stand-in where we hold our dresses in memory and to honour our loved ones that didn't get to come home,\u201d said Tammy Miese, president of the Prince George Red Dress Society.\n\n\u201cFrom there, we will all go together as a convoy to Lheidli T\u2019enneh Memorial Park where we will have entertainment and there's going to be food, refreshments, and guest speakers.\u201d\n\nAt 2 p.m. at Lheildi T\u2019enneh Memorial Park Pavillion, located behind Exploration Place, there will be hanging of the dresses, guest speakers and performances featuring Kym Gouchie, PG Tapestry Singers, Khast\u2019an Drummers, traditional dancers and crafts before a candlelight vigil.\n\nRed dresses have been widely adopted as a symbol to raise awareness for murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls since M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black\u2019s 2010 art project and Red Dress events have been happening in the city since 2015.\n\nMiese added that it\u2019s special the event can take place at the Red Dress Monument, which was installed and unveiled last year as part of the annual Red Dress Campaign.\n\nThe monument is a larger-than-life-size red dress and in front of the dress is a black silhouette of a regalia dancer, which sits facing Highway 16, also known as the Highway of Tears.\n\n\u201cSome of the feedback that I have gotten from families that have that came and attended last year, is that it's really nice to be able to go to one location where it truly is a place of honour for their loved ones.\u201d\n\nMiese also note that through her time as the president of the Prince George Red Dress Society, she has been astounded at how many people have been affected, not only just women and girls but men and boys as well.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all walks of life of all nationalities,\u201d she said, and encourages everyone to come and participate in the event.\n\n\u201cIt is such an amazing experience. Everybody's in their own place in their journey of healing and if you've never come, please come and be a part of it. If you don't have a red dress, we have dresses that you can hold in honour of your loved one.\u201d\n\nMore information on the event is available on the Red Dress Society\u2019s Facebook Page.\n\n\u00a0\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nReader Feedback 1\n\tSHOW\nThis has been shared 1 time\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tWater main break forces closure of Prince George street\n\tNew bus shelters coming to Prince George\n\tFoodie Fridays back for the summer in downtown Prince George\nPrince George - Featured\nBC's forest cutting permit process handcuffing industry, says Lheidli T'enneh, Simpcw chiefs\nRead More\nCOMMUNITY POLL\nParticipate in our next community poll.\nDo you watch or listen to CBC News once a week or more?\n Always\n Sometimes\n Never\n Often\n Rarely\n\nVOTE RESULTS > ARCHIVES >\n\nTRENDING TODAY\n1\t\nCarrier Lumber president backs First Nations' plea to restore local forest policy decision-making\n\n2\t\nRCMP search for witnesses and footage from June 29 fatal accident\n\n3\t\nRCMP provides update on wanted persons that have now been located\n\n4\t\nRCMP: 16-year-old youth who overdosed last week has died\n\n5\t\nDeciduous Heroes visit Prince George with a message: Forests are at risk\nNews\nHighlights\nLocal News\nLocal Sports\nBritish Columbia\nCanada\nWorld\nAnimal Stories\nOpinion\nOpinion\nSend us a letter\nArts & Life\nLocal Arts\nPhotos and Videos\nFeatures\nGas Prices\nSpecial Features\nWeather\nDigital Edition\nDigital Archive\nSponsored Content\nObituaries\nConnect\nContact Us\nAdvertise with Us\nDaily Headlines Email\nSupport Local News\nCitizen Box Locations\nLocal Events\nAbout\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Service\nPolitical Ads Registry\nSpecial Features\nDigital Archive\nReaders Choice\n\n\u00a9 2024 Prince George Citizen"},
{"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/b-c-announces-highway-of-tears-plan-1.2132688", "title": "B.C. announces Highway of Tears plan - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nB.C. announces Highway of Tears plan\nThe B.C. government unveiled a $3-million plan to improve safety along the so-called Highway of Tears between Prince George and Prince Rupert on Monday. The funding is broken down into four commitments, the largest being $1.\nMark Nielsen\nDec 14, 2015 1:45 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone speaks at an announcement unveiling a new $3-million plan to enhance transportation safety along the Highway 16 corridor from Prince Rupert to Prince George.Don Craig | Government Communications\n\nThe B.C. government unveiled a $3-million plan to improve safety along the so-called Highway of Tears between Prince George and Prince Rupert on Monday.\n\nThe funding is broken down into four commitments, the largest being $1.6 million over two years to expand transit along the 750-km stretch.\n\nDetails are still to be worked out, but Transportation Minister Todd Stone suggested it will fund three different routes: Burns Lake-Houston-Telkwa-Smithers, Hazelton-Gitsegukla-Kitwanga-Terrace and Burns Lake-Fraser Lake-Vanderhoof-Prince George.\n\nThe money would be spent on a cost-sharing basis, with B.C. Transit covering two-thirds and participating communities the remaining one-third. Stone said that's \"exceptionally generous\" when compared to the more typical arrangement that sees communities cover 45 per cent.\n\nIn addition, $750,000 over three years will be earmarked for a grant program to purchase and operate vehicles; $150,000 over three years for a First Nations driver education program; and $500,000 over two years for safety improvements, including webcams and transit shelters.\n\nThe plan, unveiled in Victoria three weeks after a symposium on the issue was held in Smithers, also calls for an effort to better synchronize schedules and expand user eligibility criteria for existing services.\n\nDetails on how the plan will be implemented will be worked out over the next couple months with the help of a nine-person advisory committee that includes Carrier Sekani Family Services executive director Mary Teegee.\n\nTeegee called the announcement a \"start\" and noted the idea of providing a shuttle service along Highway 16 West was first raised in 2006 in a final report from a previous symposium held in Prince George. It was echoed six years later in the final report from Missing Women Inquiry commissioner Wally Oppal.\n\n\"It's been 10 years where very little has been done so I'm hopeful that this is a beginning,\" Teegee said.\u00a0\n\nIt also remains a far cry from a full-fledged transit system along Highway 16 in Teegee's view.\n\n\"It's not just First Nations people who should be up in arms,\" Teegee said. \"It should be every resident in northern B.C. because it's [about] your right and access to services.\"\n\nStone reiterated the provincial government's position that the idea is a nonstarter.\n\n\"Many have called for more simplistic solutions \u2013 a bus running from one end of the corridor to the other \u2013 that is simply not practical,\" Stone said.\u00a0\n\n\"We were hearing consistently [during the Smithers symposium] from folks along the corridor that what they really need, what they really wanted to see were solutions that were tailored to the needs of their specific community.\"\n\nHe referred to a service operated by the Nak'azdli First Nation in Fort St. James that transports about five people a day, five days a week, to Vanderhoof for medical appointments. Stone said it's used by First Nations and non-First Nations alike and is coordinated by Nak'azdli with \"tremendous support by the local government and the regional district.\"\n\n\"That's a solution that is working very, very well for the communities,\" Stone said.\u00a0\n\nHe said the time taken was \"needed to go through this rigorous process\" and now expects to see the various actions \"either fully in place or well their way\" by April.\u00a0\n\nFunding of $75,000 per year to Carrier Sekani Family Services for the Highway of Tears Initiative will also run out at the end of this year. \"Amazing things\" have been done through the initiative, Teegee said, such as developing a community safety took kit, first responders training and support for victims during the Cody Legebokoff trial.\n\nTeegee is hoping to get funding through the province's civil forfeiture proceeds to keep the program running.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/local-news/prince-george-marking-red-dress-day-6946618", "title": "Prince George to honour 2023 Red Dress Day on May 5 - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nPrince George marking Red Dress Day\nRed Dress Day raises awareness for Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls\n\tHanna Petersen\n\nMay 3, 2023 3:00 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nMr. PG waves the Prince George Red Dress Society Flag for the 2023 Day of Awareness on May 5. Hanna Petersen\nListen to this article\n00:02:18\n\nMotorists passing the intersection of Highway 16 and 97 will now be able to see Mr. PG waving the Prince George Red Dress Society's flag.\n\nThis is to recognize\u00a0May 5, which is the \u201cDay of Awareness\u00a0for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-spirit People.\u201d\n\nTwo years ago, the City of Prince George officially proclaimed May 5 as a \"Day of Awareness\u00a0for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-spirit People\" as an act of solidarity with the community of Ladysmith, B.C. where a red dress installation was vandalized.\n\nRed Dresses have been widely adopted as a symbol to raise awareness for murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls since M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black\u2019s 2010 art project.\n\n\u201cWe've raised the flag in support of that, not only to bring awareness within our own community, to be able to hold space for people and to say that's not okay,\u201d said Tammy Miese, president of the Prince George Red Dress Society, who lost her\u00a0childhood best friend Kari Anne Gordon when she went missing and was found murdered in 1998.\n\nMiese has been organizing Red Dress events in Prince George since 2016.\n\n\u201cI have to say that I fills my heart that I'm able to stand here and bring awareness, and it's not just awareness for you and I it's awareness for everybody,\u201d said Miese.\n\n\u201cSo many people don't have a voice to bring that their loved one\u2019s pictures forward, or their names or anything like that. They're still grieving, and they're still getting used getting used to the idea that their loved one is murdered or is missing,\u201d said Brenda Wilson John who has been an advocate for MMIWG for 29 years.\n\n\u201cSo, to have a day where there's awareness\u00a0\u2014\u00a0they can hang a dress up in the window, they can go on walks, or vigils, or they can go to the monument to remember their loved one.\u201d\n\nIn September 2022, the Red Dress Society installed a monument dedicated to MMIWG on the Highway of Tears at the corner of Highway 16 and Ferry Avenue, as part of the annual Red Dress Campaign.\n\nAn awareness 5km walk to mark Red Dress day will also take place on May 5 at 3 p.m. starting at the RCMP detachment on Victoria Street and ending at Cottonwood Island Park.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nReader Feedback 6\n\tSHOW\nThis has been shared 20 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nRelated\n\tDocumentary to screen in Prince George for Red Dress Day\n\t\u2018We're not alone anymore\u2019: Prince George unveils Red Dress Society monument\n\tPrince George student bakery raises money for the Red Dress Society\n\tPrince George gives Red Dress Day an official proclamation\n\tPrince George Cougars partnering with Red Dress Society to raise awareness\nPrince George - {"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/BC/354697/Rogers-expanding-cell-service-along-Highway-of-Tears", "title": "Rogers expanding cell service along Highway of Tears - BC News - Castanet.net", "body": "27\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nBC\u00a0\u00a0\nRogers expanding cell service along Highway of Tears\nCELL SERVICE ON HWY OF TEARS\nPG Citizen staff - Dec 15, 2021 / 12:09 pm | Story: 354697\nPhoto: Rogers Communications\nRogers Communications has started construction of 12 new cell towers which will provide service to more than 250 km of Highway 16.\n\nRogers Communications has started construction on the first of 12 planned cellular towers along Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert, the company announced on Wednesday.\n\nOnce complete, the project will provide cellphone coverage to an additional 252 kilometres of the highway, also known as the Highway of Tears.\n\n\u201cAt Rogers, we are deeply committed to reconciliation and to using our technology to help connect rural, remote and Indigenous communities,\u201d Rogers chief technology officer Jorge Fernandes said in a press release. \u201cIt is our hope that by providing the safety of wireless connectivity along Highway 16, we can honour survivors, victims and their families and communities by taking action to address the tragic crisis of murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls here for the past many decades.\u201d\n\nThe project is expected to provide continuous cellphone coverage along the 720 km stretch between Prince George and Prince Rupert, fulfilling one of the recommendations of the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium report.\n\n\u201cIt means the world to me and our women to connect with others and keep in touch, especially on this highway \u2013 anything can happen at any given time,\u201d said Gladys Radek, an activist working to raise awareness about the missing and murdered women along Highway 16 and across Canada. \u201cThis tower and project will bring a lifeline to all of us who travel along Highway 16 regularly and will bring a sense of safety and security that will help us prevent future tragedies.\u201d\n\nIn addition, Rogers is sponsoring two totem poles to be placed at each end of the Highway of Tears. The Two Sisters totem poles will be erected in Prince George and Prince Rupert at part of the Highway of Tears Commemoration and Healing Totem Pole series.\n\nThe totem pole series, initiated by the families of missing and murdered women and the Indian Residential Schools Survivors Society, will provide places where families can commemorate lost loved ones.\n\nA portion of the funding for the project was provided by the provincial and federal governments, though the federal Universal Broadband Fund and the Connecting British Columbia program.\n\n\u201cAs a local resident and frequent traveller on Highway 16, I know how important this project is for people living, working and travelling along this route,\u201d North Coast MLA Jennifer Rice said in a press release. \u201cOur government is pleased to be able to help fund this project, which helps fulfil recommendations from the\n\nHighway of Tears Symposium, and completion of the project will be a welcome reassurance for families and communities in our region.\u201d\n\nIn November, Rogers announced a partnership with the Coastal First Nations to develop five new cell towers on Haida Gwaii. The towers will provide 100 km of additional coverage along Highway 16 from Masset to Port Clements to Queen Charlotte.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore BC News\n\n\n\nBC\nVancouver Webcam\nWebcam provided by windy.com\nRECENT STORIES\nAmbushed in failed hit job\nKamloops - 1:46 pm\nHeat warnings issued\nBC Coast - 1:43 pm\nLife in prison for murder\nAbbotsford - 1:39 pm\nA parade of aches and pains\nCalgary - 1:27 pm\nPower restored in Aberdeen\nKamloops - 1:16 pm\nMore Top Stories >\nBC Quick Links\nBC Discussion Forum\nGovernment of BC\nBC Wildfire Service\nProvincial Emergency Program\nHealthLink BC\nDrive BC\nBC Ferries\n\n\n\n\nBody transformation journeys\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\nVanessa Hudgens gives birth\nShowbiz | July 04, 2024\nBaseball playing pup\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nMischievous Beagle caught tearing up the toilet paper\nMust Watch | July 04, 2024\nVintage bathrooms\nGalleries | July 04, 2024\n\n\n\u00a9 2024 Castanet.net Make Castanet Your Homepage News Tips Advertising Contact Us"},
{"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/highway-of-tears/cp710869424", "title": "Highway of Tears bus service to run from Prince George to Prince Rupert | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Vernon, Salmon Arm, Revelstoke and Areas|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\n28.0\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nHighway of Tears bus service to run from Prince George to Prince Rupert\nHighway 16 near Prince George, B.C. is shown on Monday, Oct. 8, 2012. A bus service that links communities along a notorious stretch of highway in northern British Columbia known as the Highway of Tears will carry passengers by the end of the year, the province's transportation minister said Wednesday. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jonathan Hayward\nRepublished June 16, 2016 - 5:51 AM\nOriginal Publication Date June 15, 2016 - 2:10 PM\n\nPRINCE GEORGE, B.C. - A bus service that links communities along a notorious stretch of highway in northern British Columbia known as the Highway of Tears will carry passengers by the end of the year, the province's transportation minister said Wednesday.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or have disappeared along Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nFirst Nations, social service agencies and women's groups have been calling for a shuttle bus service in the area for several years to provide regular transportation for people who live in communities along the 750-kilometre route.\n\nThe highway cuts through the centre of the province and follows rivers and mountains, passing through numerous small communities, including Houston, Smithers and Burns Lake. The route also provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nMost cases of murdered and missing women remain unsolved, though investigators don't believe a single killer is responsible.\n\nTransportation Minister Todd Stone says agreements between 16 communities along the highway will allow B.C. Transit to operate a scheduled bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert.\n\n\"Absolutely, this initiative is all about safety,\" he said.\n\nHe said the communities, the province and B.C. Transit must still develop service schedules and provide extra buses for the route.\n\nStone said plans for the Highway 16 area also include offering bus driver training programs for First Nations to provide transportation service from their remote villages to other major communities along the highway.\n\nChief Corrina Leween of the Cheslatta Carrier Nation said the bus service helps many living in towns on or near the highway, but it offers little comfort to those off the main road.\n\n\"The work they are doing for the core group on the corridor is good, but for us it really doesn't work because we're off the beaten trail,\" she said.\n\nLeween said the main Cheslatta community of about 300 people is located about 25 kilometres south of Burns Lake and getting to the highway requires a ferry trip and travel on a dirt road.\n\nFive Cheslatta people, including a family of four and a male elder, have disappeared from the area over the years, she said.\n\nNew Democrat Maurine Karagianis, the Opposition's critic for women, said area residents and local politicians have called for improved transportation services for years, but the government has been stalling while many people hitchhike for rides with strangers.\n\n\"I say get on with it,\" she said.\n\nFirst Nations advocate Mary Teegee said a decade ago, dozens of people walked from Prince Rupert to Prince George to call for better transportation service along the highway.\n\n\"It has been 10 years since of the Highway of Tears recommendations report came out and we are finally making progress,\" she said in a statement. \"I view transportation as a human rights issue in the north and we are working toward making sure everyone has access.\"\n\n\u2014 By Dirk Meissner in Victoria\n\nNews from \u00a9 The She was not murdered along the Highway of Tears but she nevertheless was the victim to violence.\u201d\n\nEarlier this week, Ottawa endorsed a Red Dress Alert proposal that was tabled by Skeena-Bulkley MP Taylor Bachrach and fellow NDP MP Leah Gazan.\n\nThe alert would be like the current Amber Alert system for abducted children.\u00a0\n\nTheir discussion came after Tuesday\u2019s announcement that the federal government adopted Gazan\u2019s motion to declare ongoing violence against Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people a national emergency.\u00a0\n\nIn addition, BC Assembly of First Nations Regional Chief Terry Teegee remembers and honours those who have been lost to systemic violence and calls for concrete improvements to prevention and response measures to create lasting change.\n\n\u201cIndigenous people are affected by the national crisis of MMIWG2S+ and we all have an important role to play in keeping our families, friends and communities safe. All Canadians and levels of government must also take steps to dismantle and address colonialism, racism, and sexism, which are the underlying causes of the disproportionate violence against Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people. In particular, I\u2019m calling on the governments of BC and Canada to partner with First Nations, families, and advocates to ensure that concrete and meaningful progress is made on each of the immediate and short-term priorities identified in the National Action Plan, and for sustainable and adequate capacity funding for all Indigenous partners so that this work can be advanced in alignment with the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples,\u201d\n\nSomething going on in the Prince George area you think people should know about?\nSend us a news tip by emailing pgnews@vistaradio.ca.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nNews\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\nNews\nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\nNews\nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\nNews\nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\n \nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\n \nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\n \nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\n \nSeven week old Cariboo Regional District strike is now over\nCity of Quesnel responds to petition filed against it by Mayor Ron Paull\n \nBC Transit to provide new bus shelters in PG\n \nTimberwolves land Spanish shooting guard\n \nFour Rivers Co-op cardlock locations fully operational after cybersecurity incident\n \nBrendan\u2019s Sports Shorts; {"url": "http://www.timescolonist.com/news/b-c/highway-of-tears-bus-service-starts-this-week-1.20664119", "title": "\u2018Highway of Tears\u2019 bus service starts this week - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n22.2 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome B.C. News\n\u2018Highway of Tears\u2019 bus service starts this week\nNew B.C. Transit services connecting Prince George to Burns Lake and Smithers on Highway 16 will hit the road this week.\nMark Nielsen\nJun 19, 2017 6:26 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nNew B.C. Transit services connecting Prince George to Burns Lake and Smithers on Highway 16 hit the road this week.\n\nNew B.C. Transit services connecting Prince George to Burns Lake and Smithers on Highway 16 will hit the road this week.\n\nThe services are the latest edition to what proponents hope is a service stretching the entire length of Highway 16 West, from Prince George to Prince Rupert.\n\nEighteen women have been murdered or have disappeared along the stretch \u2014 also known as the Highway of Tears \u2014 and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\n\"We are extremely pleased that there are more safe travel options for the north,\" said Carrier Sekani Family Services executive director Mary Teegee in a statement. \"I applaud the work of municipalities, First Nations and government to launch the new transit services. This is a good example of true partnership and effective collaboration.\"\n\nFederal, provincial and local governments have committed $6.4 million over three years to the plan to connect 21 communities along the 750-kilometre stretch.\n\nIt also includes a grant program to help communities north and south of the highway buy shuttle vehicles, a First Nations driver education program \u2014 to boost the number of Class 4 and 5 drivers in those communities \u2014 as well as webcams and bus shelters.\n\nThe first leg, between Smithers and Moricetown, began running on Jan. 30 and B.C. Transit said it is being used daily by many passengers.\n\nTrips between Prince George and Burns Lake will run on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays. The run from Burns Lake to Prince George will be in the morning, starting at 7 a.m. at the Wet'suwet'en First Nation just west of the community and cover the 230-kilometre distance in 3 1/2 hours.\n\nThe trip back to Burns Lake starts at 3 p.m. Pickup points in the city are at 7th and Dominion, University Hospital of Northern B.C., Pine Centre and Westgate.\n\nThe routes between Burns Lake and Smithers will operate on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. The bus will leave Burns Lake at 6:46 a.m. and arrive in Houston at 8:33 a.m. and Smithers at 9:38 a.m.\n\nThe bus will complete a midday round trip from Smithers to Houston then back to Smithers, starting at 11:30 a.m. It leaves Smithers once again 3 p.m. and goes all the way back to Burns Lake, arriving there at 5:53 p.m.\n\nThe one-way fare will be $5 per segment.\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/shuttle-options-considered-for-highway-of-tears-1.2094483", "title": "Shuttle options considered for Highway of Tears - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nShuttle options considered for Highway of Tears\nIt could cost more than $1 million each year to operate a shuttle bus along the Highway of Tears, according to government documents.\nBethany Lindsay\nOct 23, 2015 9:57 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nIt could cost more than $1 million each year to operate a shuttle bus along the Highway of Tears, according to government documents.\n\nThe Ministry of Transportation documents, released through a freedom of information request, suggest that three or four heavy-duty highway coaches would be necessary to ensure service six days a week along the 700-kilometre stretch of Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert. Each of those buses would cost close to $1 million to purchase, and altogether, they would run for a total of 6,900 hours each year.\n\nUnder the BC Transit funding model, the province is responsible for 46.69 per cent of operating costs and most capital costs for conventional transit, while local governments cover the rest.\n\nThe government documents also include a number of transportation options that wouldn't require expensive heavy-duty highway coaches, including shuttle services provided by 23-seater buses or even smaller vans. These would come with much lower initial costs of $40,000 to $120,000 to purchase each vehicle.\n\nThe ministry was unable to answer if operating costs for those options had been estimated, or to say whether the province is still considering a shuttle bus along the Highway of Tears.\n\nSafe and reliable public transit was one of the immediate priorities pushed by Commissioner Wally Oppal in his November 2012 report on B.C.'s missing women. He wrote that a shuttle bus was particularly important along Highway 16, where 18 girls and women disappeared or were murdered between 1969 and 2006.\n\nBut community and First Nations leaders in the region charge that the province is dragging its feet on that recommendation while they're left with an unreliable patchwork of services that leaves many vulnerable women with no alternative but to hitchhike.\n\nIn fact, when the government released its final report on the Missing Women Inquiry last December, there was no mention of a shuttle bus.\n\nOther possible solutions to the transportation gap outlined in the documents include ride sharing programs, taxi supplements and coupons, or a volunteer transportation network.\n\nThe First Nations Health Authority and B.C. Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure will be hosting a symposium on the issue in Smithers on Nov. 23.\n\nIn the lead up, a survey for First Nations communities along the Highway 16 corridor can be found online at http://bit.ly/fnhatransportationsurvey.\n\nRoughly $4.7 million has been budgeted for Prince George's transit system this year.\n\nThe documents were released in response to an Freedom of Information request from the media that asked for a wide array of reports, studies and communications about the Highway of Tears written by transportation ministry staffers between May and December of 2014.\n\nHowever, it's possible the documents are incomplete. A former ministry employee has alleged he was ordered last year to delete emails and documents related to government consultation with local communities about safety along Highway 16 after receiving an FOI request from the NDP.\n\nB.C. Information and Privacy Commissioner Elizabeth Denham released her investigation report on the alleged destruction on Thursday and forwarded her findings to the RCMP for a possible criminal investigation.\n\n- with files from Mark Nielsen, Prince George Citizen\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has been shared 0 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tWater main break forces closure of Prince George street\n\tNew bus shelters coming to Prince George\n\tFoodie Fridays back for the summer in downtown Prince George\nPrince George - Featured\nBC's forest cutting permit process handcuffing industry, says Lheidli T'enneh, Simpcw chiefs\nRead More\nCOMMUNITY POLL\nParticipate in our next community poll.\nDo you watch or listen to CBC News once a week or more?\n Often\n Never\n Rarely\n Sometimes\n Always\n\nVOTE RESULTS > ARCHIVES >\n\nTRENDING TODAY\n1\t\nCarrier Lumber president backs First Nations' plea to restore local forest policy decision-making\n\n2\t\nRCMP search for witnesses and footage from June 29 fatal accident\n\n3\t\nRCMP provides update on wanted persons that have now been located\n\n4\t\nRCMP: 16-year-old youth who overdosed last week has died\n\n5\t\nDeciduous Heroes visit Prince George with a message: Forests are at risk\nNews\nHighlights\nLocal News\nLocal Sports\nBritish Columbia\nCanada\nWorld\nAnimal Stories\nOpinion\nOpinion\nSend us a letter\nArts & Life\nLocal Arts\nPhotos and Videos\nFeatures\nGas Prices\nSpecial Features\nWeather\nDigital Edition\nDigital Archive\nSponsored Content\nObituaries\nConnect\nContact Us\nAdvertise with Us\nDaily Headlines Email\nSupport Local News\nCitizen Box Locations\nLocal Events\nAbout\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Service\nPolitical Ads Registry\nSpecial Features\nDigital Archive\nReaders Choice\n\n\u00a9 2024 Prince George Citizen"},
{"url": "http://infotel.ca/newsitem/highway-of-tears/cp35687926", "title": "B.C. commits $3M to improve transportation safety along Highway of Tears | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kamloops, Merritt and Areas|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 29.4\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nB.C. commits $3M to improve transportation safety along Highway of Tears\nRepublished December 14, 2015 - 4:31 PM\nOriginal Publication Date December 14, 2015 - 12:45 PM\n\nVICTORIA - Enhanced transit routes, expanded driver-training programs and more roadside webcams make up the core of a multimillion-dollar plan aimed at improving safety along a stretch of British Columbia highway renowned for missing and murdered women.\n\nB.C.'s Transport Minister Todd Stone announced a long-awaited $3-million strategy for the so-called Highway of Tears on Monday, saying delays in government action were the result of extensive consultation with local stakeholders.\n\n\"I would have liked to have been making this announcement many, many, many months ago, but we needed to go through this rigorous process of engagement and discussion,\" said Stone. \"Today is about transitioning from the discussion to action.\"\n\nEighteen women, many of them aboriginal, have disappeared or been murdered along Highway 16 or adjacent routes since the 1970s. The infamous 750-kilometre span of road meanders through an isolated region of B.C.'s Interior, between Prince Rupert and Prince George.\n\nStone's announcement comes shortly after the federal government went public with plans to launch a national inquiry into missing and murdered indigenous women. Many who have called for the inquiry have highlighted the tragic history of the Highway of Tears.\n\nAn RCMP report stated last year nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing across Canada between 1980 and 2012.\n\nMonday's announcement in B.C. committed $1.6 million over two years on a cost-sharing basis with communities to extend pre-existing transit along Highway 16.\n\nAn additional $750,000 over three years will go towards helping communities buy and operate transit vehicles, as well as $150,000 over three years to increase the number of licensed drivers in First Nations communities.\n\nThe province earmarked a final $500,000 in infrastructure funding over two years to install more transit shelters and highway webcams.\n\n\"In addition to enhancing the actual transportation options that people have in the corridor, we want people to also know that we have an eye on safety as well,\" said Stone.\n\nOverseeing the program's implementation is an advisory panel, made up of representatives from the province, local governments, health authorities and First Nations.\n\nBurns Lake Mayor Luke Strimbold, who is part of the advisory group, said the $3-million funding announcement marks historic progress in improving safety along Highway 16.\n\n\"Our communities now have a framework we can work towards to implement transportation solutions,\" said Strimbold.\n\nFirst Nations Health Authority spokesman Richard Jock is also on the board and shared Strimbold's optimism. He emphasized the opportunity to improve access to health care for people living in remote communities.\n\n\"We're looking forward to working in particular with our northern health partners to see how this can really be part of effective transportation response in the North,\" he said.\n\nSmithers Mayor Taylor Bachrach spoke positively about the government's plan, but at the same time raised concerns.\n\n\"The key question is whether the amount of resources that are being put on the table are going to be adequate to fix the problem,\" he said.\n\n\"I'm not sure that $1.6 million over two years is going to provide affordable, accessible transportation for all of the small communities in our region. The problem is somewhat larger.\"\n\nNew Democrat member of the legislature and northern health critic Jennifer Rice questioned if the plan's cost-sharing approach would be financially feasible for all northern communities.\n\n\"Families of murdered and missing women have been waiting for some action for well over a decade,\" she said.\n\n\"But having some money put towards improving transportation in the North is positive.\"\n\nStone said the government will have a better idea about how the funding will be distributed after the advisory panel meets with local groups and reports back to him by early March.\n\n\u2014 By Geordon Omand in Vancouver\n\n\u2014 Follow @gwomand on Twitter\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2015\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have {"url": "https://www.merrittherald.com/red-dress-day-a-history-of-the-highway-of-tears/", "title": "RED DRESS DAY: A history of the Highway of Tears - Merritt Herald", "body": "NEWS\nSPORTS\nCOMMUNITY\nJUNIOR REPORTERS\nOPINION\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nRED DRESS DAY: A history of the Highway of Tears\n\nPosted by Morgan Hampton | May 5, 2021 | News | 0 \n\nA billboard warns of the dangers of hitchhiking along the Highway of Tears. (Flickr)\n\n\u00a0\n\nThe Highway of Tears is a 725-km. stretch of road that connects Prince George and Prince Rupert in central BC. Officially known as Highway 16, the name \u2018Highway of Tears\u2019 was coined by Florence Naziel during a vigil held in 1998 to commemorate the women, many of them Indigenous, who had gone missing along the route.\u00a0\n\nNaziel had observed the families of those missing crying over the disappearance of their loved ones, and their tears were strongly connected to Hwy 16.\u00a0\n\nFor more than 50 years, the route through rural BC has been the site of numerous abductions and murders.\u00a0\n\nAn RCMP task force, E-Pana, was created in 2005 with the purpose of solving cases of those missing and murdered along Hwy 16. Within a year, the scope of the investigations expanded to include Highways 5, 24 and 97.\u00a0\n\nBetween 1970 and today, the E-Pana list recognizes fewer than 18 victims. However, according to Aboriginal organizations, the number of missing and murdered women could exceed 40, beginning earlier than 1970. Taking into account all potential cases on all routes, the number of victims could be more than 80, beginning with the unsolved murder of 26-year-old Gloria Levine Moody near Williams Lake in 1969.\u00a0\n\nThere has been much speculation over the years as to whether the murders are the work of several perpetrators, sadistic opportunists, or whether a serial killer may be operating in the region. \u00a0\n\nA billboard erected along the route reads: \u201cGirls don\u2019t Hitchhike on the Highway of Tears. Killer on the loose!\u201d\u00a0\n\nMany of the victims were known to frequently hitchhike, or went missing while hitchhiking along the highway, due mainly to poverty, lack of car ownership or access to reliable transit. In order to leave situations of domestic violence, visit friends and family, travel for work or school or to attend medical appointments, many women have no alternative, despite the dangers.\u00a0\n\nRCMP believe there are several factors which have lead to this area becoming a hotspot for criminal activity, including the remoteness of the area, reducing the likelihood of being interrupted while committing a crime such as sexual assault or murder, soft soil in which to dispose of evidence, and the prevalence of carnivorous scavengers such as birds, wolves, bears, and coyotes.\u00a0\n\nOn June 16, 2006 the Highway of Tears Symposium Recommendation Report was issued, a 35-page report which made 33 recommendations intended to be a call to action for Victim Prevention, Emergency Planning and Team Response, Victim Family Counselling and Support and Community Development and Support.\u00a0\n\nRecommendation #8 included a request for increased cell service along the route.\u00a0\n\n\u201cTelus Mobility should be approached to look into the feasibility of increasing cell phone coverage along the entire length of the highway thus minimizing or eliminating no signal areas.\u201d\n\nOver the last decade, TELUS has provided 70% of Highway 16 between Prince Rupert and Prince George with a reliable wireless signal, connecting more than 500 kilometres of Highway 16 to new wireless service, giving residents and visitors the ability to make phone calls from the highway, and enhancing safety by providing fast access to 911 in the event of an emergency.\n\nNow, 15 years later, this recommendation is being put into full practice as the entire route from Prince George to Prince Rupert will have complete cellular coverage, thanks to both federal and provincial investments.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe must continue to do everything in our power to prevent violence against Indigenous women and girls to ensure they are safe to travel anywhere in our province, but especially between communities along Highway 16,\u201d said Barb Ward-Burkitt, executive director, Prince George Native Friendship Centre.\u00a0\n\n\u201c\u2026it serves as an important step\u00a0of reconciliation and honouring for murdered and missing sisters, daughters, mothers, aunties and their families.\u201d\n\nBy implementing this recommendation, it is hoped that those women or girls who find themselves in a dangerous situation along the highway will be able to call for help, thus potentially reducing the number of victims.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThis project will provide continuous cellular coverage along the whole of the highway corridor, which will improve overall safety for this area,\u201d said Murray Rankin, B.C.\u2019s Minister of Indigenous Relations and Reconciliation.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt honours the memory of both survivors and the friends and family members of the Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people who have gone missing, been murdered or experienced other forms of violence along Highway 16.\u201d\n\nRogers will install twelve cellular towers, providing 252 km of new highway cellular coverage, eliminating several \u2018dead zones\u2019 where no service currently exists.\u00a0\n\nThe project is scheduled to be completed in the fall of 2022.\u00a0 \u00a0\n\nSHARE:\n\n \nPREVIOUS\nNVIT to erect permanent Red Dress exhibit\nNEXT\nLogan Lake RCMP arrest auto theft suspect after breakdown on highway\nRELATED POSTS\nNDP moves to limit local election money\n\nOctober 31, 2017\n\nPolice Report: RCMP break up house party, respond to theft\n\nSeptember 4, 2012\n\nIHA monitoring glue spill cleanup\n\nNovember 19, 2015\n\nSANTA\u2019S HELPERS\n\nNovember 28, 2011\n\nNEWSLETTER\n\nFirst Name \n\nLast Name \n\nEmail He emphasized the opportunity to improve access to health care for people living in remote communities.\n\n\"We're looking forward to working in particular with our northern health partners to see how this can really be part of effective transportation response in the North,\" he said.\n\nSmithers Mayor Taylor Bachrach spoke positively about the government's plan, but at the same time raised concerns.\n\n\"The key question is whether the amount of resources that are being put on the table are going to be adequate to fix the problem,\" he said.\n\n\"I'm not sure that $1.6 million over two years is going to provide affordable, accessible transportation for all of the small communities in our region. The problem is somewhat larger.\"\n\nNew Democrat member of the legislature and northern health critic Jennifer Rice questioned if the plan's cost-sharing approach would be financially feasible for all northern communities.\n\n\"Families of murdered and missing women have been waiting for some action for well over a decade,\" she said.\n\n\"But having some money put towards improving transportation in the North is positive.\"\n\nStone said the government will have a better idea about how the funding will be distributed after the advisory panel meets with local groups and reports back to him by early March.\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport Error\nEditorial standards and\u00a0policies\nWhy you can trust CTV\u00a0News\nDON'T MISS\nfalse\nPet chicken from B.C. is now a Guinness World Record holder\nfalse\nOnt. woman says black widow spider was inside bag of grapes\nfalse\nThis Calgary man is trying to climb 21 mountains in 21 days\nVANCOUVER TOP STORIES\nAbbotsford man who killed his wife sentenced for second-degree murder\nIncoming heat may trigger warnings in Metro Vancouver, Fraser Valley: ECCC\nCluster of earthquakes off B.C. coast 'business as usual,' seismologist says\n'Like urban warfare': Community-led police oversight project launched in Vancouver\nPolice ask for help identifying man who allegedly filmed woman in Surrey bathroom stall\nB.C. {"url": "http://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/news/families-walk-highway-of-tears-to-honour-missing-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Families walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women - Comox Valley Record", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.1 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nFamilies walk Highway of Tears to honour missing, murdered Indigenous women\nThe annual journey will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers\nThe Canadian Press\nSep 20, 2017 1:30 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nWhen Gladys Radek walks the Highway of Tears, she says she can feel the spirits of women who are missing or have been murdered walking beside her.\n\nDozens have vanished or been killed along the notorious stretch of Highway 16 in central B.C.. On Thursday, Radek will honour the 12th anniversary of the disappearance of her niece, Tamara Lynn Chipman, by walking the route once again.\n\n\u201cYou can feel the pain of the families when they\u2019re walking with you,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s really, really hard to describe.\u201d\n\nThe annual journey, made by Radek and others who have lost loved ones, will span five days this year and cover 350 kilometres between Prince Rupert and Smithers. Vehicles will accompany the walkers who will cover sections of the route in a relay fashion.\n\nCommissioners of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls are set to join the walk on Sept. 25 before community hearings are held from Sept. 26 to 28 in Smithers. This is the second set of hearings held to date by the inquiry, after it visited Whitehorse in May.\n\nSince then, the inquiry\u2019s executive director, Michele Moreau, and one of its commissioners, Marilyn Poitras, have quit and the Native Women\u2019s Association of Ontario has pulled its support. The inquiry has faced growing calls for resignations and a restart.\n\nAsked whether commissioners feel added pressure to ensure these hearings are successful, Chief Commissioner Marion Buller said they feel that obligation regardless.\n\n\u201cThey have to be (successful), not only for our purposes, but more so for the families who come forward and share their stories with us. It\u2019s the success from their perspective that\u2019s the most important aspect for us,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always under scrutiny. Always. And we always will be,\u201d she added. \u201cI\u2019m always open to constructive, informed criticism, as are the other commissioners. It\u2019s part of our work.\u201d\n\nThe federal government launched the inquiry last year to examine the systemic issues behind the high number of Indigenous women who have been killed or disappeared over the last four decades in Canada. It is expected to take two years and cost almost $54 million.\n\nREAD MORE: Highway of Tears bus starts rolling on 30-minute trips on Hwy. 16\n\nVIDEO: Take back the highway\n\nBuller said the commission will ask for more money and time but it is still conducting an internal analysis before making the request.\n\nAbout 25 people, including family members and survivors of violence, are expected to testify publicly or privately at the Dze L K\u2019Ant Friendship Centre next week. A statement-taker will be available for anyone who wishes to speak, with no pre-registration needed, said Buller.\n\nRadek will testify about Chipman, who disappeared while hitchhiking in Prince Rupert on Sept. 21, 2005. The 22-year-old was a beautiful, charming free spirit who had a young son, she recalled.\n\nCritics of the inquiry don\u2019t understand how much ground it has to cover, said Radek, who sits on its national family advisory circle.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not as simple as two years of work. These people, these commissioners and the staff that they have working right now, they are uncovering the stones that should have been turned a long time ago,\u201d she said.\n\nPeople living along the Highway of Tears had to wait years for the provincial government to carry out a key recommendation of the B.C. inquiry into missing and murdered women, said Terry Tegee, tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council.\n\nThe recommendation \u2014 reliable public transit along the route \u2014 was finally implemented earlier this year. But the experience has led Teegee to call for the federal inquiry to have more teeth. Like the missing inquiry in B.C., the recommendations from the national inquiry will be non-binding.\n\nTeegee also said he\u2019s concerned that people in small communities that still lack transit won\u2019t be able to participate in the Smithers hearings.\n\nBuller said staff have visited nearby towns in recent weeks to reach out to families and it is able to help cover travel costs including mileage and meals, she said.\n\nThe hearings will be the first of nine this fall, with other stops in Winnipeg, Halifax, Edmonton, Yellowknife, Saskatoon, Sask., Maliotenam, Que., Thunder Bay, Ont., and Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.\n\nLaura Kane, The Canadian Press\n\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tRobots, technology take care in Comox's innovative new dementia village\n\t\tComox Valley Ducky 500 winners announced\n\t\tCVRD, Clean BC to offer heat pump and electrical upgrade rebates\n\t\tComox Valley RCMP investigating fatal overnight collision involving pedestrian\n\t\t'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\nFacebook Comments (0) \nComox Valley RCMP investigating fatal overnight collision involving pedestrian\nBlack Press Media\nDriver airlifted to hospital after Vancouver Island crash\nBlack Press Media\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nReview: Captain Cooks Casino is the Real Deal\nTrust Pilot Rating and Review: I did what any savvy person would do. {"url": "https://www.terracestandard.com/news/walking-the-highway-of-tears-for-a-woman-who-went-missing-12-years-ago-from-prince-rupert/", "title": "VIDEO: Walking the Highway of Tears for a woman who went missing 12 years ago from Prince Rupert - Terrace Standard", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.5 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nVIDEO: Walking the Highway of Tears for a woman who went missing 12 years ago from Prince Rupert\nGladys Radek walks with family and friends from Prince Rupert to Smithers starting Sept. 21\nShannon Lough\nSep 20, 2017 4:30 PM\nSep 25, 2017 8:49 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n(Shannon Lough / The Northern View) Tamara\u2019s Walk began on the morning of Sept. 21 in Prince Rupert, and will end this week in Smithers for the National Inquiry of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. Families and friends will share stories off loss with five commissioners who will hear from Indigenous people across the country. The commissioners will look for the patterns and underlying factors behind so much violence against Indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nGladys Radek has been walking epic distances ever since her niece disappeared on Highway 16 east of Prince Rupert.\n\nSept. 21 marks the 12 year anniversary of when Tamara Lynn Chipman went missing, last seen hitchhiking on the highway across from the industrial park entrance. At 8 a.m., from the same location, Radek and more than 20 other families and friends joined her in a walk that will end in Smithers for the National Inquiry of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cThis walk is for the family. For my family, for Tamara and for the missing and murdered women across Canada. I\u2019ve discovered there\u2019s thousands of other Tamaras out there,\u201d Radek said.\n\nHighway 16, from Prince Rupert to Prince George, is known as the Highway of Tears for more than 19 women, and men, who have been murdered or gone missing over the years. Tamara was 22 years old and a mother to her two-year-old son when she disappeared.\n\nShe won\u2019t be walking the 150 kilometre distance alone. Family members from the northern area will be joining her, as well as elders and activists coming from Vancouver and some of the original walkers who have been with her since the beginning.\n\nTamara\u2019s father, Tom and her now teenage son, also participated in part of the walk. The night before their departure, Tom, family and friends placed a \u201cmemory stone\u201d on the side of the hill next to where Tamara was last seen.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s pretty emotional. It\u2019s been 12 years. Every time we do one of these walks it brings back memories again of course. It\u2019s kind of hard to deal with in a way but it does make you feel a little bit better seeing all the people and all the support that we\u2019re getting from family and friends and a lot of people came as far as Vancouver,\u201d Tom said, who will be at the inquiry in Smithers.\n\nIn 2006, Radek\u2019s cousin organized a walk from Prince Rupert to Prince George, which set the template for her walks across the country. She has co-organized walks through the organizations Walk4Justice and Tears4Justice, including a national trek from Vancouver to Ottawa, Vancouver to Prince Rupert, Kamloops to Winnipeg and Nova Scotia to Prince Rupert in 2013.\n\n\u201cIt brings a little bit of healing and it brings other family members together and helps us to walk and feel the spirits of the women. It gives us hope and it makes our family realize we are truly not alone,\u201d Radek said.\n\nArnie Sankey is one of the volunteers from Prince Rupert who has been supporting Radek\u2019s efforts in previous walks, and this year\u2019s walk. He helped coordinate a send off feast Wednesday night at the Nisga\u2019a Hall.\n\n\u201cTamara went missing 12 years ago, which happens to be my birthday. I drive by to and from there every day \u2014 the last place she was seen, across industrial park. It hit home so I started volunteering then,\u201d Sankey said.\n\nBefore the group started walking down the highway, they sang happy birthday to Sankey, thanking him for all his volunteer efforts.\n\nVolunteers in vehicles will support the walkers, who expected to reach their final destination in Smithers in time for the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls community hearings on Sept. 26-28.\n\nA memorial stone was placed next to where Tamara Lynn Chapman was last seen next to the industrial park entrance along Highway 16 east of Prince Rupert. Feb 22, 2023 / 8:58 am | Story: 412682\nPhoto: The Canadian Press\nNDP MP Leah Gazan.\n\nAn NDP member of Parliament is asking the federal government to establish a system that would send the public a phone notification when an Indigenous woman goes missing.\n\nLeah Gazan penned a letter to Public Safety Minister Marco Mendicino last Friday urging the government fund what she and other advocates call a \"Red Dress Alert\" program.\n\nGazan says it would be similar to the Amber Alert, which is an emergency notification people receive on their phones when a child in their region has been abducted or is believed to be in danger.\n\nThe Winnipeg MP says that if the public is better informed when Indigenous women and girls disappear, it will increase the likelihood that they are found.\n\nIn her letter, she points to the disappearances and deaths of at least four First Nations women who Winnipeg police believe were murdered by the same man.\n\nGazan says that because Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has recognized the crisis in missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls as a genocide, he must act urgently to better protect them.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Canada News\n\n\n\nCanada\nRECENT STORIES\nWrong way driver arrested\nKelowna - {"url": "https://www.squamishchief.com/indigenous/ndp-mp-urges-feds-to-create-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-6592266", "title": "NDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women - Squamish Chief", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\n22.5 \u00b0C\nHOME HIGHLIGHTS\nNDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women\nOttawa should establish a system that would send the public a phone notification when an Indigenous woman goes missing to ensure that their disappearances stop being \"normalized,\" says an NDP member of Parliament.\nStephanie Taylor, The Canadian Press\nFeb 22, 2023 1:14 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nNDP MP Leah Gazan rises during question period in the House of Commons on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Monday, June 21, 2021. Gazan is requesting the federal government establish a system where the public receives a phone notification when Indigenous women go missing. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\nListen to this article\n00:01:14\n\nOttawa should establish a system that would send the public a phone notification when an Indigenous woman goes missing to ensure that their disappearances stop being \"normalized,\" says an NDP member of Parliament.\u00a0\n\nLeah Gazan penned a letter to Public Safety Minister Marco Mendicino on Friday urging the government to fund what she and other advocates call a \"Red Dress Alert\" program. His office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\u00a0\n\nGazan says that while details of the program would have to be negotiated, she imagines it would operate similarly to the Amber Alert, which is an emergency notification people receive on their phones when a child in their region has been abducted or is believed to be in danger.\u00a0\n\n\"We shouldn't have to beg for our safety,\" Gazan said in an interview Wednesday. \"In Canada, we are still begging for safety and to live in dignity as Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\"\u00a0\n\nResearch from across the country, including the 2019 final report from the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, shows that Indigenous people, and women in particular, disappear at a higher rate than people who are not Indigenous.\n\nGazan said that for years, advocates and the families of missing and murdered women and girls have said there needs to be a faster response by police and other authorities in their cases.\u00a0\n\nAnd because Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has recognized the crisis in missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls as a genocide, he must act urgently to better protect them, Gazan said.\n\nIt's \"almost as if our disappearances (have) become so normalized that nobody looks for us,\" she added.Setting up a specialized alert system, she said, \"acknowledges the urgency.\"\n\nThe Winnipeg MP said that if the public is better informed when Indigenous women and girls disappear, it will increase the likelihood that they are found.\n\n\"We know that the sooner cases start, the sooner searches start when somebody goes missing, the more likely they are to be found,\" she said, pointing to the success of emergency notification programs for children.\u00a0\n\nCalls to set up a \"Red Dress Alert\" in Canada are not new, and some advocates have established grassroots-led efforts on their own, such as the Aboriginal Alert website, which publishes timely information and photos of Indigenous people who are missing.\u00a0\n\nLast year, Washington state established the \"Missing Indigenous Person Alert System,\" adding it to an existing alert system in place to broadcast the disappearances of children and seniors.\u00a0\n\nWhile its state patrol says that not every Indigenous person who is missing will qualify for the program, those that do are individuals who go missing under unexplained or suspicious circumstances and appear to be vulnerable due to reasons such as age and health.\u00a0\n\nIn her letter sent last week, Gazan pointed to the disappearances and deaths of at least four First Nations women who Winnipeg police believe were murdered by the same man.\u00a0\n\nJeremy Skibicki has been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of Morgan Harris, Marcedes Myran, Rebecca Contois and an unidentified woman whom local Indigenous leaders have been referring to as Mashkode Bizhiki'ikwe, or Buffalo Woman.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Feb. 22, 2023.\u00a0\n\nStephanie Taylor, The Canadian Press\n\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the {"url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/ndp-mp-urges-feds-to-create-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-1.6284206", "title": "Missing Indigenous women need 'Red Dress Alert': MP | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nPower Play\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nLOCAL\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nSHOPPING TRENDS\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nPOLITICS\nNews\nNDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women\n02:04\nCTV National News: Pain behind Red Dress Day\n03:22\nRed Dress Day sparks conversation about Indigenous women\n02:03\nRed Dress Day marked in Edmonton\n02:16\nRed Dress Day calls for more awareness on MMIWG\n01:04\nStudents march on Red Dress Day\nStephanie Taylor\nThe Canadian Press\nStaff\nContact\nUpdated Feb. 22, 2023 2:23 p.m. MST\nPublished Feb. 22, 2023 9:10 a.m. MST\nShare\nOTTAWA -\n\n Ottawa should establish a system that would send the public a phone notification when an Indigenous woman goes missing to ensure that their disappearances stop being \"normalized,\" says an NDP member of Parliament.\n\nLeah Gazan penned a letter to Public Safety Minister Marco Mendicino on Friday urging the government to fund what she and other advocates call a \"Red Dress Alert\" program. His office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nGazan says that while details of the program would have to be negotiated, she imagines it would operate similarly to the Amber Alert, which is an emergency notification people receive on their phones when a child in their region has been abducted or is believed to be in danger.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nFeds' hiring of international group to advise on unmarked graves called 'misstep'\n'Thunder Bay' series from Ryan McMahon looks at systemic racism, police in the city\nOttawa moves toward creating Indigenous and human rights ombudsperson role\nThis massive newspaper contains 'cover stories' of hundreds of MMIWG to spur national action\nAdvocates frustrated with inaction over missing and murdered Indigenous women\nCapital Dispatch: Sign up for in-depth political coverage of Parliament Hill\n(opens in a new tab)\n\n\"We shouldn't have to beg for our safety,\" Gazan said in an interview Wednesday. \"In Canada, we are still begging for safety and to live in dignity as Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\"\n\nResearch from across the country, including the 2019 final report from the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, shows that Indigenous people, and women in particular, disappear at a higher rate than people who are not Indigenous.\n\nGazan said that for years, advocates and the families of missing and murdered women and girls have said there needs to be a faster response by police and other authorities in their cases.\n\nAnd because Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has recognized the crisis in missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls as a genocide, he must act urgently to better protect them, Gazan said.\n\nIt's \"almost as if our disappearances (have) become so normalized that nobody looks for us,\" she added.Setting up a specialized alert system, she said, \"acknowledges the urgency.\"\n\nThe Winnipeg MP said that if the public is better informed when Indigenous women and girls disappear, it will increase the likelihood that they are found.\n\n\"We know that the sooner cases start, the sooner searches start when somebody goes missing, the more likely they are to be found,\" she said, pointing to the success of emergency notification programs for children.\n\nCalls to set up a \"Red Dress Alert\" in Canada are not new, and some advocates have established grassroots-led efforts on their own, such as the Aboriginal Alert website, which publishes timely information and photos of Indigenous people who are missing.\n\nLast year, Washington state established the \"Missing Indigenous Person Alert System,\" adding it to an existing alert system in place to broadcast the disappearances of children and seniors.\n\nWhile its state patrol says that not every Indigenous person who is missing will qualify for the program, those that do are individuals who go missing under unexplained or suspicious circumstances and appear to be vulnerable due to reasons such as age and health.\n\nIn her letter sent last week, Gazan pointed to the disappearances and deaths of at least four First Nations women who Winnipeg police believe were murdered by the same man.\n\nJeremy Skibicki has been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of Morgan Harris, Marcedes Myran, Rebecca Contois and an unidentified woman whom local Indigenous leaders have been referring to as Mashkode Bizhiki'ikwe, or Buffalo Woman.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Feb. 22, 2023.\n\nRELATED {"url": "https://www.outsideonline.com/2405441/highway-of-tears-jessica-mcdiarmid-book-review", "title": "A New Book Investigates B.C.'s Missing Native Women", "body": "Outside uses cookies and similar technologies to help our site function, as well as the placement of cookies and similar technologies on behalf of Outside and our third-party partners for tailored advertising and marketing. By clicking \u201cACCEPT\u201d you consent to placement of such cookies. Want to know more or manage your preferences? Click \"Manage Cookie Preferences\" in the footer of any Outside website.\n\nACCEPT\nSkip to content\n\nTHE TOUR DE FRANCE DAILY NEWSLETTER\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOutside Online\nOutside Feed\nGear\nRun\nAdventure\nHealth\nTravel\nCulture\nLong Reads\nVideos\nPodcasts\nTour de France\nCulture\nBooks & Media\nA New Book Investigates B.C.\u2019s Missing Native Women\n\n'Highway of Tears' tells the story of the dozens of indigenous women and girls who have gone missing or been found murdered along Canada's Highway 16\n\nMona Gable\nPublished Nov 19, 2019\n\nDon't miss a moment of the 2024 Tour de France! Get recaps, insights, and exclusive takes with Velo's daily newsletter. Sign up today!.\n\nIn June 1994, Ramona Wilson disappeared from Smithers, a small town in northern British Columbia. She was 16, about to start a summer job as a peer counselor. For decades her mother, Matilda, would remember the night her \u201cbright, bubbly\u201d daughter went out the door. Ramona was headed to a dance, then staying the night at her best friend\u2019s. She never arrived at the dance.\n\nSo begins Highway of Tears: A True Story of Racism, Indifference, and the Pursuit of Justice for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls ($28, Atria), Jessica McDiarmid\u2019s chronicle of those who vanished or were found murdered along a remote stretch of Canada\u2019s Highway 16 between Prince George, in eastern British Columbia, and the coastal town of Prince Rupert. The first known case near the highway was in 1989. Three decades later, that number has grown to more than a dozen, and that\u2019s just a microcosm of the rest of the country. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) conservatively puts the number of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls across Canada at nearly 1,200. Yet the crimes didn\u2019t draw international attention until a scathing Amnesty International report in 2004. A couple of years later, a national multiagency task force was created to investigate the cases (many of them bungled or unsolved), and finally, in 2015, Canadian prime minister Justin Trudeau launched\u00a0a national inquiry, which just concluded this summer. But it took the courageous efforts of a community of women\u2014the victims\u2019 mothers, aunties, sisters, cousins, grandmothers, and friends\u2014to make people care.\n\nSimilar Reads\n\u201cCocaine and Surfing\u201d Is the Funniest Surfing Book Ever\nThe Mountain Biker Who Vanished Without a Trace\nThe Most Gruesome National Parks Book Series\nOur Favorite Books and Movies About Mount Everest\n\nMcDiarmid is a Canadian journalist and well suited to tell this complicated narrative. She grew up in Smithers and recalls being ten years old and seeing posters of Ramona blanketing the town. She later discovered that Ramona was among several indigenous girls to go missing around that time. Some, like Roxanne Thiara and Alishia Germaine, turned up dead. In the extensively reported book, McDiarmid jumps between their stories and those of several other girls and women, the region\u2019s history, the investigations, the media\u2019s role, the activism of the victims\u2019 families trying to wrest justice, and the landscape framing Highway 16.\n\nShe knows the terrain well: One moment her descriptions of the isolated 450-mile road are vividly beautiful, with their dark green forests, snowcapped peaks, and glacial valleys. The next they convey a preternatural menace. \u201cThe air grows heavier as the highway draws closer to the Pacific,\u201d she writes, \u201cclinging to a ledge above the Skeena River blasted from the mountainsides to make way for trains and trucks, where the margin of error is only a few feet in either direction.\u201d\n\nSometimes the book\u2019s structure hampers the narrative, and her thoroughness makes it tough to absorb everything. But she fills in an important, overlooked era in Canada\u2019s history, putting a critical lens on the forces that have led to indigenous girls and women being targeted. McDiarmid traces the legacy of colonialism in British Columbia, how it stripped indigenous nations of their land and their livelihood, effectively dooming many to poverty. She also shows how the horrific abuse that children suffered at \u201cresidential schools\u201d\u2014boarding schools designed to eliminate Native students\u2019 language and identity in the name of assimilation\u2014decimated First Nations families. For instance, Ramona\u2019s mother, Matilda, was taken away from her parents at age five and dispatched by train to a residential school called Lejac, where she \u201cwas assigned a number in place of her birth name. They were at Lejac to learn the white man\u2019s ways, to have the \u2018savage\u2019 within them extinguished.\u201d\n\nMcDiarmid also details how racism and trauma still haunt the present, and she connects them to the girls\u2019 struggles. Some of them skip school to hang out on the rough streets of Smithers with friends. Others have been put in juvenile-detention facilities for minor crimes, like Delphine, a 15-year-old whose dad died and whose mother lies ill in a hospital hours away from home. Delphine is jailed for theft, mischief, and breaking and entering. Because there\u2019s no public transportation along Highway 16, most of the teens hitchhike to get around. Others, like Roxanne, who is also 15, bounce around homeless and are sexually exploited in Prince George, a cesspool of drugs and crime. So when the girls go missing, the response is often judgmental. \u201cIt was not unusual in the 1990s to hear comments about the \u2018error\u2019 a girl must have committed to encounter such a fate, whether it was hitchhiking, prostitution, drinking, or walking alone at night,\u201d McDiarmid writes.\n\nWhat is most notable about these families, though, is their strength and their ferocious love.\n\nThe vast distances between towns on the highway have another tragic effect. When 19-year-old Lana Derrick doesn\u2019t come home, her family assumes she spent the night with friends in Terrace, hours away. But when she fails to show up for her college classes, they know something is wrong. That delay was critical as they searched for her\u2014they lost three days. Such delays are compounded by varying police response to the crimes. For the most part, it\u2019s infuriating and familiar: the indifference, the incompetence, a lack of resources and experience, a lack of transparency. Files get misplaced, evidence gets tossed. It\u2019s refreshing when we meet a few investigators who are good guys, devoted to finding the girls and their killers. But there\u2019s also pervasive racism and a history of bad relations between the RCMP and many First Nations communities. In the case of Lana, McDiarmid tells us, \u201cInitially, the family felt the RCMP brushed them off, suggesting she was probably out on a bender or shacked up with a boyfriend for a few days. Her family knew that wasn\u2019t the case.\u201d\n\nThe girls\u2019 families do trust McDiarmid, though, and that serves an essential purpose. It allows readers to know the impact of these devastating crimes. Years later, the families whose daughters, sisters, and nieces have never been found continue to suffer. These, I thought, were some of most affecting moments in the book. I cried when I read that one despondent mother, after years of searching for her daughter and trying to compel public attention for her case, slowly drank herself to death. Their guilt is heartbreaking. As McDiarmid writes about a man named Francis, whose sister, Alberta, was murdered, \u201cIt was a closed-casket funeral. It had to be. Francis always wondered what might have happened if he had gone to Bogey\u2019s [a club] that night when Alberta asked him to come. He was her big brother; if he had been there, he could have protected her.\u201d\n\nWhat is most notable about these families, though, is their strength and their ferocious love. Despite their grief and the lack of any support, the mothers refuse to give up on their daughters who have been murdered or remain missing. They march along the highway, demanding action and igniting an entire movement and a national inquiry into missing and murdered indigenous women and girls. They are still fighting.\n\nCorrections: (07/04/2024) The original version of this story misidentified Justin Trudeau as the president of Canada. The story has been updated to reflect he is Canada's prime minister. Outside regrets the error.\nFiled to: Books  British Columbia  Canada  Media  Road Trips\n\nWhen you buy something using the retail links in our stories, we may earn a small commission.
