{"url": "http://www.tv-eh.com/2016/09/16/taken-highway-of-tears-ramona-wilson-and-alberta-williams/", "title": "Taken: Highway of Tears \u00e2\u20ac\u201d Ramona Wilson and Alberta Williams | TV, eh?", "body": "Search\nSKIP TO CONTENT\nHOME\nABOUT\nCALENDARS\nCONTACT\nPODCAST\nSPONSORS\nADVERTISING\nFEATURED, REALITY, LIFESTYLE & DOCUMENTARY\nTAKEN: HIGHWAY OF TEARS \u00c2\u20ac\u201d RAMONA WILSON AND ALBERTA WILLIAMS\nSEPTEMBER 16, 2016 CAROLYN POTTS\n\nEpisode 2 of Taken features The Highway of Tears; a stretch of Highway 16 located in northern British Columbia. Countless Indigenous women and girls have either gone missing or been murdered, but all have one link: this stretch of highway from Prince Rupert to Prince George.\u00c2\u00a0The topography in this area is especially suited for concealment; it is a neverending network of logging roads, ravines and rivers. However, as host Lisa Meeches points out, \u201cthese crimes of opportunity are about more than location. They reveal dark underlying truths about society.\u201d\n\nTonight, Taken focuses on two separate cases from the Highway of Tears: Ramona Wilson and Alberta Williams. Both led happy lives surrounded by family and friends. Their murders devastated their families and in each case, remain unsolved.\n\nAlberta Williams, 24, had been at\u00c2\u00a0a local pub on August 15, 1989, with family and friends, celebrating a last night with visiting friends. It\u00c2\u00a0was the last time she\u00c2\u00a0was seen alive; her body was found a little over month later\u00c2\u00a0near the Tyee overpass. She had been strangled and sexually assaulted. In addition to the officers working the case, Alberta\u2019s sister enlisted the aid of private investigator, former RCMP officer Ray Michalko to try and find her sister\u2019s killer\n\nRamona Wilson, meanwhile, was a well-loved child, active in sports and would often lose herself while composing poetry. On the\u00c2\u00a0 evening of June 11, 1994, at the age of 16, Ramona left home to go to a dance with her friends in a neighbouring town. She never arrived. It was not until April 10, 1995\u00e2\u20ac\u201dalmost a year later\u00e2\u20ac\u201dthat Ramona\u2019s remains were found with her clothing neatly placed nearby. RCMP staff sergeant\u00c2\u00a0 Wayne Clary still believes Ramona\u2019s case is very solvable. Many suspects have been eliminated but to date it\u00c2\u00a0remains unsolved.\n\nThese two cases highlight a social issue many communities face today: a lack of affordable transportation. How do you get from an isolated community to a neighbouring urban centre? Chief Terry Teegee of Carrier Segani Tribal Council\u00e2\u20ac\u201dand cousin of Ramona\u00e2\u20ac\u201dreminds us this complicates lives for many. Appointments may be missed, steady employment is difficult, it is hard\u00c2\u00a0to attend school, or to even get an adequate education. Due to the remoteness of northern communities, there are fewer opportunities for economic development. This results in a lack of affordable transportation, so many community members resort to hitchhiking despite the danger.\n\nCraig Benjamin of Amnesty International Canada explains further: \u201cThe very fact that we are looking at rates of violence seven or eight times higher than all other women and girls in Canada means that this violence does not come from a single source but is pervasive \u2026 the very fact that this violence could go on year after year tells us that there is something fundamentally wrong here.\u201d\n\nOnce again, I need to repeat, this program is not designed to entertain us, but rather is about sharing information. I do like the way each case has been chosen to highlight larger systemic problems. Many Indigenous communities face these issues that are a direct result of colonizing policy and practices still prevalent in Canada today. I am also very pleased APTN airs each episode twice in each time zone. If you missed it last week, you have the opportunity to see it again the following week.\n\nViewers are asked to visit the Taken website if they have any information.\n\nTaken\u00c2\u00a0airs Fridays at 7 and 7:30 p.m. ET on APTN.\n\nRelated\n\nHighway Thru Hell season 3 premieres Sept. 2 on Discovery\nAugust 7, 2014\nSimilar post\n\nTonight: Highway Thru Hell premiere, Amazing Race {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/bc-news/ndp-mp-urges-feds-to-create-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-6592266", "title": "NDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome BC News\nNDP MP urges feds to create 'Red Dress Alert' for missing Indigenous women\nOttawa should establish a system that would send the public a phone notification when an Indigenous woman goes missing to ensure that their disappearances stop being \"normalized,\" says an NDP member of Parliament.\nStephanie Taylor, The Canadian Press\nFeb 22, 2023 1:14 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nNDP MP Leah Gazan rises during question period in the House of Commons on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Monday, June 21, 2021. Gazan is requesting the federal government establish a system where the public receives a phone notification when Indigenous women go missing. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\nListen to this article\n00:01:14\n\nOttawa should establish a system that would send the public a phone notification when an Indigenous woman goes missing to ensure that their disappearances stop being \"normalized,\" says an NDP member of Parliament.\u00a0\n\nLeah Gazan penned a letter to Public Safety Minister Marco Mendicino on Friday urging the government to fund what she and other advocates call a \"Red Dress Alert\" program. His office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\u00a0\n\nGazan says that while details of the program would have to be negotiated, she imagines it would operate similarly to the Amber Alert, which is an emergency notification people receive on their phones when a child in their region has been abducted or is believed to be in danger.\u00a0\n\n\"We shouldn't have to beg for our safety,\" Gazan said in an interview Wednesday. \"In Canada, we are still begging for safety and to live in dignity as Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\"\u00a0\n\nResearch from across the country, including the 2019 final report from the National Inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls, shows that Indigenous people, and women in particular, disappear at a higher rate than people who are not Indigenous.\n\nGazan said that for years, advocates and the families of missing and murdered women and girls have said there needs to be a faster response by police and other authorities in their cases.\u00a0\n\nAnd because Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has recognized the crisis in missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls as a genocide, he must act urgently to better protect them, Gazan said.\n\nIt's \"almost as if our disappearances (have) become so normalized that nobody looks for us,\" she added.Setting up a specialized alert system, she said, \"acknowledges the urgency.\"\n\nThe Winnipeg MP said that if the public is better informed when Indigenous women and girls disappear, it will increase the likelihood that they are found.\n\n\"We know that the sooner cases start, the sooner searches start when somebody goes missing, the more likely they are to be found,\" she said, pointing to the success of emergency notification programs for children.\u00a0\n\nCalls to set up a \"Red Dress Alert\" in Canada are not new, and some advocates have established grassroots-led efforts on their own, such as the Aboriginal Alert website, which publishes timely information and photos of Indigenous people who are missing.\u00a0\n\nLast year, Washington state established the \"Missing Indigenous Person Alert System,\" adding it to an existing alert system in place to broadcast the disappearances of children and seniors.\u00a0\n\nWhile its state patrol says that not every Indigenous person who is missing will qualify for the program, those that do are individuals who go missing under unexplained or suspicious circumstances and appear to be vulnerable due to reasons such as age and health.\u00a0\n\nIn her letter sent last week, Gazan pointed to the disappearances and deaths of at least four First Nations women who Winnipeg police believe were murdered by the same man.\u00a0\n\nJeremy Skibicki has been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of Morgan Harris, Marcedes Myran, Rebecca Contois and an unidentified woman whom local Indigenous leaders have been referring to as Mashkode Bizhiki'ikwe, or Buffalo Woman.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Feb. 22, 2023.\u00a0\n\nStephanie Taylor, The Canadian Press\n\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.quesnelobserver.com/news/seeing-red-in-quesnel-over-violence-to-indigenous-women/", "title": "Seeing red in Quesnel over violence to Indigenous women - Quesnel Cariboo Observer", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n22.6 \u00b0C\nHome News\nSeeing red in Quesnel over violence to Indigenous women\nSchools and community face the facts about colonial violence\nFrank Peebles\nMay 15, 2023 5:30 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 12\nExpand\n\nRecognizing Red Dress Day is one way the public can acknowledge the pain of colonial pressures put on the many Indigenous nations across what is now Canada.\n\nAnother major component of correcting the cultural damage that turned into layers of deeply personal damage, is to inform new generations about the effects.\n\nLike may schools across School District 28, Quesnel Junior School (QJS) put effort into teaching the history of prejudice and violence faced by Aboriginal peoples at the hands of Euro-centric governments, communities, and individuals set on marginalizing those descended from the original cultures of this land. One of the cascading consequences is the vulnerabilities and disconnections that leave Indigenous women and girls open to violence.\n\n\u201cThe significance of the dresses is that they are empty,\u201d said Dorine Greene of the Quesnel Tillicum Society-Native Friendship Centre. \u201cThe significance of the dresses being red is, in Indigenous culture, red is the only colour spirits can see, so by hanging the red dresses in honour of MMIWG2+, it\u2019s a way of reuniting spirits with their loved ones, to have them close.\u201d\n\nStaff members at QJS like Tracey Telford and Rae Lee Tresierra brought that information to light, as is happening in schools the length and breadth of B.C. Red dress displays were made, and lessons were taught that described former policies that led to suffering and pain for Indigenous people right up into modern times.\n\n\u201cWe talk a lot about truth and reconciliation, but in order to have reconciliation we first have to acknowledge the truth,\u201d said Tresierra, who teaches English to the Grade 8 and 9 students at QJS. \u201cThis is the first generation of schooling to be brought up in this culture of truth and reconciliation.\u201d\n\nInformation on the red dress campaign, the moosehide campaign (raising awareness of violence against women and children), and the Highway of Tears inspired the English students to write poetry about their thoughts and impressions. The poems, and other artistic touches were all pinned to a red dress put on display as a class statement that went with other Red Dress Day acknowledgements around the school.\n\nAbbi White, Lexi Tresierra, Ewan Lackey, Molly Leung, and Lauren Gittens were some of the students who took part and talked with The Observer about their work.\n\n\u201cThis wasn\u2019t a concept that was talked about for a very long time. It was really pushed to the side,\u201d said Lackey. \u201cIt\u2019s still going on today, and the Highway of Tears is right near here. If you don\u2019t know about it, you can\u2019t do anything.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe last residential schools closed in super modern times,\u201d said Gittens. \u201cI was talking with my mom about it, and she said she never knew any stories about residential schools, she\u2019s just learning about it now.\u201d\n\nLeung said her poem \u201cis mostly about how ignorant we are as to what Indigenous people have faced, because it wasn\u2019t taught in school, and I\u2019m very grateful that it\u2019s being taught right now, but up until this year I didn\u2019t really have knowledge of what they went through. This is spreading education, and education is what we need right now.\u201d\n\nNot long ago, Indigenous students were not positively or accurately reflected in any part of school learning. That had an impact on Tresierra, who buried her own First Nations background. She is now working to restore her personal Indigenous identity, and taking part in Red Dress Day activities with the students is a learning and growing opportunity for her, personally as well as on a professional basis.\n\n\u201cWhat we discussed, as well, is how it\u2019s also new for teachers,\u201d Tresierra said. \u201cWe are learning. Even though I come from a strong First Nations background, I also grew up with a temporary loss of identity because I obviously have white privilege (indicating her relatively light skin tone) and I tried to hide behind that, growing up. I was already susceptible to bullying, and I didn\u2019t want to be bullied for another reason as well. It sometimes takes a long time to regain that culture aspect.\u201d\n\nREAD MORE: PHOTOS: Quesnel Takes Back the Night against gender-based violence\n\nREAD MORE: Red Dress Day marked in PHOTO RANDY VANDERVEEN\nNext Gallery Image\nToggle gallery captions\nView All 9 Photos\n\n1 of 9\n\nA drive-by art display at St. John Paul II Catholic High School put the issue of missing women and girls\u00a0 into the spotlight on May 5.\n\nThe installation was the brainchild of Rachelle Bell, the Indigenous liaison at the school, to commemorate Red Dress Day, the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nRed Dress Day was a project started by Jamie Black, a M\u00e9tis artist in Winnipeg, to provoke conversation about absence by hanging a red dress to instigate discussion and raise questions about the issue.\n\n\u201cI took (Black\u2019s) idea and brought it to staff and said \u2018Since we are an arts-based school, I would love to do a large-scale art installation using this as a basis,\u2019\u201d Bell said. \u201cSo, our options classes, most of them, and our English classes were on board.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nStudents from Grades 8-12 took part in creating the project.\n\n\u201cThe trees, on the end, were made by Construction and Fab,\u201d Bell explained. \u201cThe dresses were made by the (grade) 8/9 art classes and Life Skills. Life Skills also did the pins (of a red dress). The large photo of the girl was done by the Indigenous Studies class. If you look up close, it is all the women in Canada who went missing that make up that picture. The (artwork) on the table was done by the English class.\u201d\n\nSchool principal Julia Corcoran was also on board, adding the project weaved its way through several different classes students are taking.\n\n\u201cThe project lends itself to lots of curricular outcomes,\u201d Corcoran said. \u201cJust being able to use art as a vehicle to share knowledge and make a change. As Rachelle said, we have a strong arts program here and a strong options program, and we do have a strong focus on Indigenous studies.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt was able to get a lot of kids involved, share a message and just do something that kids really could enjoy doing while learning.\u201d\n\nBell said getting teachers and students sold on the project was fairly easy.\n\n\u201cTeachers are always looking for ways to embed Indigenous culture and Indigenous ways of knowing into their classes,\u201d Bell said. \u201cSo, bringing them a project like this, where there is kind of a basis and let\u2019s see what you can do with it in your creative mind, it was great. They were able to put their own spin on it.\u201d\n\nCorcoran added plans were to have the display within the school originally.\n\n\u201cThe goal is that it would have been in our school, and people could have come in, and our kids would have been able to see it,\u201d Corcoran said. \u201cBut the fact that we are online now and we can\u2019t have the public in our building right now for extended periods of time, we did move it into an outside feature. We hope that people will take a look at the amazing work our students have done.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nWorking on the display opened up the opportunity to delve deeper into a topic that needs to come to light.\n\n\u201cIt is just starting the discussion about hard topics and being able to be comfortable having these hard conversations and being able to acknowledge that this is an issue in our country,\u201d Bell said. \u201cI think that is super important that having these conversations, even getting high school students just to discuss, is a step forward.\n\n\u201cJust being able to have a conversation about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women in a classroom is a step forward. Not everyone is going to agree, and not everyone is going to believe that this is an issue and that is okay. That is your perspective, but even just that conversation, I believe, changes a person\u2019s view on things. We are just trying to get people engaged and comfortable having hard conversations. \u201d\n\nPrincipal Corcoran believes the impact on the 100-120 students taking part will be long-term.\n\n\u201cI think every time you do a project if it opens one more person\u2019s eyes to something they didn\u2019t know about before, regardless of what project we do,\u201d Corcoran said. \u201cI am sure that there is at least one student who walked away and said, \u201cHey, I didn\u2019t know this before.\u2019 Or they had limited knowledge, and now they have a little bit more. I think we all take away from that.\u201d\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR PEACE RIVER\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://www.cjvr.com/2023/05/04/red-shirt-day-set-to-be-recognized-again-in-nipawin/", "title": "Red Shirt Day set to be recognized again in Nipawin | CJVR Today's Best Country", "body": "Skip to Content\nListen Live \n Sign In \nOn Air\nGabby\nKim Johnston\nCristy Beggs\nCody Kells\nContests\nPipe Dreams\nBirthday Bash!\nContest Rules\nMusic & More\nDad Jokes!\nSaskatchewan Country Closeup\nDownload Our App!\nRecently Played\nEvents Guide\nRed Shirt Day set to be recognized again in Nipawin\nMelfort, SK, Canada / CJVR Today's Best Country\nRachel May\nMay 4, 2023 | 1:00 AM\n\n\n\n\nReconciliation Nipawin is aiming to raise awareness of the racism, discrimination, and violence faced by Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people.\n\nNational Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit (MMIWG2S) is May 5 and they, along with Cumberland College, have brought back the Red Dress Day project to the community.\n\n\u201c(We\u2019ll) hang red dresses in the park beside Cumberland College. It\u2019s quite a moving display. Having the red dresses hanging, it\u2019s a symbol of a woman taken too soon,\u201d said Denise Blomquist, Co-chair of Reconciliation Nipawin.\n\nAccording to Taken the Series, which tells the real-life stories of missing and murdered women, Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people are 12 times more likely to be victims of violence than any other woman. That rate jumps to 19 times in Saskatchewan.\n\nBlomquist said Red Dress Day is a way to highlight this issue as well as foster an environment for healing, justice, and reconciliation.\n\n\u201cI think the first step is just acknowledging the past. Canada has a very shady past when it comes to indigenous people and colonization. It really put an entire group of people at a huge disadvantage.\u201d\n\nAfter observing the red dresses hanging in the park, people can head inside Cumberland College to learn more about MMIWG2S as well as support those affected by the subject matter.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve put up a display area in our lobby and it has a whole bunch of resources there,\u201d added Blomquist. \u201cWe\u2019ve put out different supports and if we can\u2019t provide support services we definitely can refer people to different phone numbers or support services.\u201d\n\nThere will be a walk from Town Square to the park starting at 12 p.m.\n\nThe dress display went up on May 1 and will be taken down around the May long weekend.\n\n\u2013\n\nRachel.May@pattisonmedia.com\n\nOn Twitter: @RachelMayFM\n\nGet Social\nON AIR NOW\nCristy Beggs\n2:00 PM - 6:00 PM\nWEATHER\nMelfort, SK, Canada\n23 \u00b0C Sunny\nNipawin, SK, Canada\n24 \u00b0C Sunny\nHumboldt, SK, Canada\n23 \u00b0C Sunny\n\nEXTENDED FORECAST\n\nGabby's Country Poll\nCurrent Past\nBuzz Buzz\n\nWhich summer bugs would you be okay with disappearing for good?\n\nMosquitoes\n71% Vote\nWasps\n0% Vote\nHorse flies\n14% Vote\nSpruce Beetles (their bites are mean)\n0% Vote\nTicks\n14% Vote\nVoting Ends: Jul 8, 2024 | 12:00 PM\nRecently Played\nToby Keith\nI Wanna Talk About Me\n2 minutes ago\nDallas Smith\nFixer Upper\n7 minutes ago\nLuke Combs\nGoing, Going, Gone\n10 minutes ago\nOwen Riegling\nOld Dirt Roads\n14 minutes ago\nBrett Kissel\nAnthem\n17 minutes ago\nMore\nAccessibilityContact UsContest RulesPrivacy PolicyTerms Of Service\nCopyright \u00a9 2024. {"url": "https://www.chvnradio.com/articles/canada-manitoba-to-develop-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls - CHVNRadio: Southern Manitoba's hub for local and Christian news, and adult contemporary Christian programming.", "body": "17\u00b0\nSEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNIN...\nDOWNLOAD THE APP\nADVERTISE WITH US\nSUBMIT NEWS\nNEWS\nChristian News\nCommunity\nLocal News\nDevotionals\nVerse of the Day\nLocal Sports\nNational News\nArts & Culture\nAg News\nSponsored\nFuneral Announcements\nWeather\nWeather Radar\nLISTEN\nFEATURES\nEvents\nLocalJobShop\nGarage Sales\nMade in Manitoba\nMornings on CHVN\nPetra\nConnections\nRoad Reports and Cancellations\nVerse of the Day\nOn-Air Schedule\nCONTESTS\nSummer Shedtacular\nTicket Window\nCONNECT\nContact Us\nSubmit News\nMeet the Team\nApp\nFacebook\nInstagram\nX\nYouTube\nStreaming\nRSS\nAdvertise With Us\nCareers\nContest Rules\nAccessibility\nTerms Of Use Agreement\nPrivacy Policy\nJournalistic Standards\n17\u00b0\nSEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNIN...\nNEWS\nWEATHER\nEVENTS\n LISTEN\nNATIONAL NEWS\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nWritten by Alessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press Saturday, May 04 2024, 9:12 AM\nShare:\nCopied!\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an Indigenous-led alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced today in Winnipeg. A red dress hangs on a light fixture on National Day of Awareness for the prevention of violence against Indigenous women, also known as the Red Dress Day in Ottawa, Friday, May 5, 2023. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Spencer Colby\n\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\u00a0\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\u00a0\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\"This is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\" said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has lead federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\"And while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\"\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\u00a0\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year's federal and provincial budgets.\u00a0\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba's minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\n\n\"We look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\"\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2014 and Manitoba writ large \u2014 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\"It's not the only solution, but it's a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\"\n\nGazan's efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\u00a0\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\u00a0\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state's Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry's 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2014 at least for now.\n\n\"There's going to be bumps in the road \u2014 there's going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\" she said. \"Inevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\"\n\nBut it's the starting point that matters, she said. \"I think it's high time.\"\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \"for so long,\" and the deaths \"are a result of it.\"\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat's in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September 2020, Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2014 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\"Because this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\" Jesty said.\n\n\"There has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 3, 2024.\n\n\u2014 With files from Brittany Hobson in Winnipeg.\n\nNEXT STORY\nNewest addition to fire department is a good boy, will help arson investigations\nLATEST IN NATIONAL NEWS\nCanadians feel grocery inflation getting worse, 18% are {"url": "https://www.tricitynews.com/national-news/canada-manitoba-to-develop-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls-8695599", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls - Tri-City News", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\nA-ListPublic Notices\n24.1 \u00b0C\nHOME NATIONAL NEWS\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nOTTAWA \u2014 Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press\nMay 3, 2024 2:55 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an Indigenous-led alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced today in Winnipeg. A red dress is hangs on a light fixture on National Day of Awareness for the prevention of violence against Indigenous women, also known as the Red Dress Day in Ottawa, Friday, May 5, 2023. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Spencer Colby\nListen to this article\n00:05:08\n\nOTTAWA \u2014 Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\u00a0\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\u00a0\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\"This is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\" said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has led federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\"And while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\"\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\u00a0\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year's federal and provincial budgets.\u00a0\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba's minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\n\n\"We look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\"\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2014 and Manitoba writ large \u2014 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\"It's not the only solution, but it's a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\"\n\nGazan's efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\u00a0\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\u00a0\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state's Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry's 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2014 at least for now.\n\n\"There's going to be bumps in the road \u2014 there's going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\" she said. \"Inevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\"\n\nBut it's the starting point that matters, she said. \"I think it's high time.\"\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \"for so long,\" and the deaths \"are a result of it.\"\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat's in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September 2020, Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2014 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\"Because this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\" Jesty said.\n\n\"There has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 3, 2024.\n\n\u2014 With files from Brittany Hobson in Winnipeg.\n\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press\n\nGet your daily Coquitlam news briefing\nEmail\nSign alert going out.\n\n\"Because this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\" Jesty said.\n\n\"There has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 3, 2024.\n\n\u2014 With files from Brittany Hobson in Winnipeg.\n\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press\n\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share {"url": "https://www.coastreporter.net/national-news/canada-manitoba-to-develop-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls-8695599", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls - Coast Reporter", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\n19.1 \u00b0C\nHOME NATIONAL NEWS\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nOTTAWA \u2014 Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press\nMay 3, 2024 2:55 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an Indigenous-led alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced today in Winnipeg. A red dress is hangs on a light fixture on National Day of Awareness for the prevention of violence against Indigenous women, also known as the Red Dress Day in Ottawa, Friday, May 5, 2023. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Spencer Colby\nListen to this article\n00:05:08\n\nOTTAWA \u2014 Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\u00a0\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\u00a0\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\"This is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\" said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has led federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\"And while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\"\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\u00a0\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year's federal and provincial budgets.\u00a0\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba's minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\n\n\"We look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\"\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2014 and Manitoba writ large \u2014 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\"It's not the only solution, but it's a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\"\n\nGazan's efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\u00a0\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\u00a0\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state's Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry's 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2014 at least for now.\n\n\"There's going to be bumps in the road \u2014 there's going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\" she said. \"Inevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\"\n\nBut it's the starting point that matters, she said. \"I think it's high time.\"\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \"for so long,\" and the deaths \"are a result of it.\"\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat's in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September 2020, Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2014 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\"Because this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\" Jesty said.\n\n\"There has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 3, 2024.\n\n\u2014 With files from Brittany Hobson in Winnipeg.\n\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press\n\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Spencer Colby\n\nOTTAWA \u2013 Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\u201cIn the lead-up to Red Dress Day, we keep those who have been stolen from their communities and this world in our thoughts, and we centre them in our action,\u201d said Crown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree.\n\n\u201cToday, as we announce this partnership to co-develop a Red Dress Alert system with Indigenous partners, we take the next steps toward bringing more Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit and gender-diverse people home.\u201d\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year\u2019s federal and provincial budgets.\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba\u2019s minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help put Indigenous women and girls at less risk.\n\n\u201cWe look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\u201d\n\nNDP MP Leah Gazan, whose efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system, called the announcement a small but significant step.\n\nGazan\u2019s fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system similar to Amber Alerts.\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state\u2019s Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry\u2019s 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published {"url": "https://www.reddeeradvocate.com/news/sisters-in-spirit-walk-draws-more-than-100/", "title": "Funding a cinch if we get what was promised - Greater Victoria News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n22.2 \u00b0C\nHome Opinion\nFunding a cinch if we get what was promised\nBlack Press Media\nMay 6, 2011 7:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nThe total project cost (downtown Victoria through a hub at Saanich\u2019s Uptown to Station Avenue in Langford) is estimated at $950 million. Ending the rail line at Six Mile (the junction with the E&N) would be $770 million. In my view, the critical passenger mass \u2013 where the train would collect the largest number of passengers \u2013 is at Six Mile. The track from Six Mile to Station Avenue can be considered for a future phase.\n\nB.C. Transit also revealed just maintaining its current bus-based service would cost $250 million. A rapid bus service would cost about $550 million, but would need to be converted to LRT within 10 to 15 years. That\u2019s twice the cost for the same outcome.\n\nSo far, the provincial government has offered little more than platitudes when it comes to pitching in funds. Interestingly, when the Evergreen Line (Coquitlam to Vancouver) was announced, senior governments pledged over $800 million toward the $1.3-billion project.\n\nThe long-ago announced $14-billion Provincial Transit Plan ear-marked close to $1 billion for the Capital Region. An LRT system that will cut emissions and double ridership is a perfect candidate.\n\nAs the federal government emerges from the election campaign, it must step up to the plate as well. Its willingness to chip in for the Canada Line and Evergreen Line on the Lower Mainland should extend to LRT in the CRD.\n\nThe two-thirds funding from senior governments brings the local share of Victoria-to-Six Mile LRT to $257 million. That\u2019s equal to the cost of doing nothing \u2013 a cost taxpayers would bear alone.\n\nIt\u2019s time for the provincial government to step up and deliver on its promised Transit Plan funding. Let\u2019s get our federal partner at the table as well. Their combined support for transit helped Lower Mainland commuters out of traffic congestion and home to their families sooner. Surely Capital Region residents deserve the same.\n\nDean Murdock\n\nSaanich councillor\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tGroup of Langford kids taking Greater Victoria music scene by storm\n\t\tVIDEO: Whales off Greater Victoria captivate shoreline photographers\n\t\tNew group aims to take a run at Sooke's traffic woes\n\t\t5 earthquakes reported off Vancouver Island: USGS\n\t\tUniversity of Victoria to shut down campus pool after a half-century\nFacebook Comments (0) \n'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\nBlack Press Media\nMan charged in ponzi scheme identified as Okanagan drowning victim\nBlack Press Media\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nScatter Soap in Your Yard, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nDiscover the Last Trimmer Head You\u2019ll Ever Need\nUltraCut\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nMan dies throwing candy during Alberta Canada Day parade\nBlack Press Media\nJuly verdict expected for Island woman accused of murdering, cutting up ex\nBlack Press Media\nAlways Keep a Bread Clip in Your Wallet, Here's Why\nLifeHackGuru\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians Born 1944 - 1983 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nBothered by Broken Whipper Snipper Lines? THE CANADIAN PRESS/Spencer Colby\nRepublished May 06, 2024 - 9:20 AM\nOriginal Publication Date May 03, 2024 - 1:26 PM\n\nOTTAWA - Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\"This is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\" said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has led federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\"And while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\"\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year's federal and provincial budgets.\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba's minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\"We look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\"\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2014 and Manitoba writ large \u2014 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\"It's not the only solution, but it's a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\"\n\nGazan's efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state's Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry's 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2014 at least for now.\n\n\"There's going to be bumps in the road \u2014 there's going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\" she said. \"Inevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\"\n\nBut it's the starting point that matters, she said. \"I think it's high time.\"\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \"for so long,\" and the deaths \"are a result of it.\"\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat's in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September 2020, Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2014 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\"Because this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\" Jesty said.\n\n\"There has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 3, 2024.\n\n\u2014 With files from Brittany Hobson in Winnipeg.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2024\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are {"url": "https://www.mbcradio.com/2022/05/families-remember-missing-or-murdered-loved-one-on-red-dress-day", "title": "Families remember missing or murdered loved one on Red Dress Day - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nFamilies remember missing or murdered loved one on Red Dress Day\n\nby MBC News | May 5, 2022 | Current News\n\nThe families of missing or murdered Indigenous women and girls in Saskatchewan marked Red Dress Day, by honouring their loved ones, urging for more supports in preventing violence against women and for affected loved ones.\n\nKrista Kenny was 16, when she was murdered in Prince Albert in May 2009. The teen, who was a mother to a six-month-old daughter, was to go to the movies with her friends that night, instead went to a local park where others would join her.\n\n\u201cShe was still going to school. She wanted to become a teacher she had tons of friends she was kind, she was loving, she helped out so many people,\u201d said her mother Loretta Henderson. \u201cEven though it was 13 years ago, it\u2019s still so hard.\u201d\n\nHenderson is now raising her granddaughter and speaks fondly of Krista each day. \u201cThere needs to be more awareness of missing and murdered women from all over, especially the North. It\u2019s harder for them to get the help that they need,\u201d explained Henderson.\n\nCody Halkett was sentenced in 2010 to life in prison for manslaughter in Krista\u2019s death.\n\nFor Gwenda Yuzicappi, not knowing where her daughter Amber Redman was for nearly three years was very difficult. Redman of the Standing Buffalo First Nation was last seen in Fort Qu\u2019Appelle in July 2005.\n\n\u201cHer remains were located two years and 10 months, not knowing where your daughter is, it\u2019s a lot of pain. It\u2019s a lot of emotion, depression and suicide,\u201d Yuzicappi said. \u201cAs a mother I went through so many emotions, it was very, very hard, difficult, but what I found strength in was my culture. Praying and asking for that strength, that pettiness, that humbleness as a mother, that emptiness of not knowing where your loved one is. I would not wish that on anyone at all.\u201d\n\nRedman\u2019s remains were discovered on the Little Black Bear First Nation, with Albert Patrick Bellegarde being sentenced in 2009 to life in prison for second-degree murder.\n\n\u201cI tell you, we need this to stop. I come here as a mother. I come here to speak for my daughter. I am my daughter\u2019s voice and I will continue to be her voice,\u201d Yuzicappi said.\n\nOne of the most puzzling disappearances in Regina history, which continues to stump investigators is the whereabouts of Tamra Keepness.\n\nJuly 5, will mark the 16th anniversary of when Tamra of the White Bear First Nation went missing. Each summer, the family, community and police gather in Pepsi Park to continue to raise awareness for Tamra.\n\n\u201cShe was just five-years-old when she disappeared. And it\u2019s something that you\u2019ll never forget. It stays with you. Everyday, there\u2019s something that comes up that reminds you that this little person was never found. Are we ever going to find her,\u201d Joyce Keepness, Tamra\u2019s grandmother asked.\n\nWhile Regina Police state they are actively following up on all new tips and leads, there is very little information on the disappearance.\n\nThe Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations tabled a five-article approach to honouring Indigenous women and girls, in hoping to end all forms of violence First Nations People face daily. That declaration was debated Thursday by lawmakers in the Legislature.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s important to remember that while we remember these individuals today, we need to be remembering them each and every day of the year,\u201d said Justice Minister Gordon Wyant. \u201cWe\u2019re committed to addressing this issue to end violence against individuals in this province, particularly Indigenous women and girls.\u201d\n\nNDP MLA Betty Nippi-Albright explained there are actions the province can adopt to make change. \u201cThe call upon all levels of government to adopt principles of change, including a focus on substantial equality and human and indigenous rights are a decolonization approach, an indigenous led solutions, recognizing distinction, cultural safety, and adoption of a trauma informed approach,\u201d explained Nippi-Albright.\n\nRed Dress Day, which started in 2010, encourages people to wear a red dress or display it, as it acts a symbol to raise awareness to the violence Indigenous women face daily.\n\n(Photo of Tamra Keepness)\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},

SIZE\n\nWork is moving forward on the Red Dress Alert \u2014 an Amber Alert-like system for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nOn Tuesday morning, the House of Commons\u2019 status of women committee started a study looking into the proposal.\n\nMember of Parliament for Winnipeg Centre Leah Gazan\u00a0said the study will integrate themes from coast-to-coast community consultations that have been ongoing since December 2023.\n\n\u201cThere was a very common sentiment that was expressed by some of the expert witnesses that the oversight of a Red Dress Alert needs to be done by the community, by organizations that have led the charge around addressing the crisis of murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls,\u201d Gazan said.\n\n\u201cAlthough there was an indication that police need to have some sort of involvement, there is a growing call to have the community make decisions when a red dress should be issued.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nA New Democratic Party of Canada press release said funding was secured for consultations in the 2023 federal budget, after Gazan first urged Ottawa to implement the program.\n\nEvery province and territory has been consulted so far, Gazan said, but noted there are still efforts being made to meet with representatives in Nunavut.\n\nThe daily email you need for Edmonton's top news stories.\n\nDuring a press conference, the MP said communities on the East Coast and several organizations have already put together their own form of Red Dress Alert. Those have been consulted for best practices and lessons learned, she said.\n\nMORE ON CANADA\nHurricane Beryl forces Canadian airlines to cancel flights. But in the cases of, for example, women, sometimes people don\u2019t want to be found. Women that are fleeing, for example, domestic violence that don\u2019t want to be found by their perpetrator.\n\n\u201cWe need to do this as quickly as possible in a way that is safe,\u201d Gazan said. \u201c(Even so,) I want to push the Liberals to get this moving.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cWe know that every day we wait, another woman, girl or two-spirit person goes missing. We cannot support that. We need action now. We need a Red Dress (Alert) now.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to wait forever. We are in an emergency. There needs to be a very clear deadline.\u201d\n\nIn May 2023, The Canadian Press reported that the House of Commons unanimously supported a motion to declare the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. That motion also supported a call for funding for the Red Dress Alert system.\n\nIn June 2023, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said his government is \u201cworking to implement a Red Dress Alert.\u201d\n\nIn an emailed statement to Global News, a spokesperson for Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs Canada (CIRNAC) said, \u201cCIRNAC provided the Committee with background documents, including those that supported discussions at the National Indigenous-Federal-Provincial-Territorial Roundtable on MMIWG and 2SLGBTQI+ People held earlier in 2024, and discussions held across the country with Survivors, academics, Indigenous organizations, provincial/territorial governments and others in December 2023 and January 2024.\n\n\u201cIn total, 16 engagement sessions on a Red Dress Alert (were) led by Hilda Anderson-Pyrz, the Chair of the National Family and Survivor\u2019s Circle Inc., and Sandra DeLaronde, Chair of Manitoba\u2019s MMIWG Implementation Committee, as well as Members of Parliament Leah Gazan and Pam Damoff.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n2:02\nCanada begins consultations on alert system for missing Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2024 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nCanada\u2019s digital services tax is here. {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/red-dress-campaign-takes-to-the-highway-1.23425841", "title": "Red Dress Campaign takes to the highway - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nRed Dress Campaign takes to the highway\nShe seemed a bit surprised at her own tears as she listed those murdered and missing women who she was honouring Sunday afternoon during the Red Dress Campaign which started with a stand in at the junction of Highways 16 and 97 on Sunday afternoon.\nChristine Hinzmann\nSep 9, 2018 4:25 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKelsey Abraham performs a men's Northern traditional dance on Sunday afternoon at Lheidli T'enneh Memorial Park as part of the third annual Prince George Red Dress Campaign. Abraham had incorporated photos of some of the missing and murdered women into his regalia.Citizen Photo by James Doyle\n\nShe seemed a bit surprised at her own tears as she listed those murdered and missing women who she was honouring Sunday afternoon during the Red Dress Campaign which started with a stand in at the junction of Highways 16 and 97 on Sunday afternoon.\n\nSandra McArthur remembers her high school chum Doreen Jack who went missing from Prince George with her entire family, including husband Ronald and children Ryan and Russell on Aug. 1, 1989. McArthur remembers Madison Scott who went missing in 2011 from the Vanderhoof area. Then as she spoke of her distant cousin Mackie Basil of Fort St. James who went missing in 2013 that's when the tears filled her eyes.\n\n\"Where is she? She's out there,\" McArthur said. \"This event is about bringing the awareness to these people - some of them have been missing for 29 years and we need them to come home.\"\n\nMcArthur said it's the overwhelming reality of it that brings the tears even after so many years.\n\n\"This event isn't just for Indigenous women but for all women,\" McArthur said.\n\nThe issue to fight is the perception that women are dispensable beings, she added.\n\nLooking around at the 60 or so people who were in attendance at the highway event that began at Mr. P.G., McArthur said it felt empowering to see the support as the majority of people were holding a red dress to symbolize the vibrant life of each woman, which had now been taken away.\n\nDuring the event at the highway there was a prayer and singing as everyone stood in a circle. Then in a long procession people stood along Highway 97 with dresses raised in solidarity of their fallen sisters as the Khast'an Drummers performed.\n\nThe event then moved to the Lheidli T'enneh Memorial Park pavilion behind Exploration Place where organizer Tammy Meise said a few words of welcome and she and others spoke about their personal experiences that led them to the Red Dress Campaign.\n\nDuring the event Kelsey Abraham and his seven-year-old daughter Bella Rain performed traditional dances.\n\nAbraham said this event is especially important to recognize all missing and murdered women but it really brought it home as they honoured their family members who have been murdered and missing.\n\n\"My daughter is seven years old and her style of dance is one of healing - the junior girl's jingle,\" Abraham explained.\n\nAbraham takes opportunities like the Prince George Red Dress Campaign to talk to Bella about her personal safety as she would like to walk home alone from school. Dad doesn't think it's a good idea.\n\nTo keep the murdered and missing women in their hearts Abraham said his daughter honours them often.\n\n\"So we say her little prayers for the murdered and missing women - not only Indigenous, but women in general. To me that's important,\" Abraham said, who was dressed in traditional First Nations dance regalia. \"To always remember them we attend important events like this one and we have placed pictures of the murdered and missing women on my regalia and on Bella Rain's dress, as well. We need to keep praying for the murdered and missing women. My prayers are with my family today and all the other missing and murdered women and the families out there who need these prayers.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. In\nHome\nNews\nSport\nBusiness\nInnovation\nCulture\nTravel\nEarth\nVideo\nLive\nWinnipeg murders: Families of murdered indigenous women call for landfill search\n12 December 2022\nShare\nNurPhoto via Getty Images\nThe Winnipeg case has brought renewed focus to the issue of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nPolice in the Canadian city of Winnipeg are under increasing pressure to search for the bodies of murdered indigenous women in a city landfill.\n\nBodies of three out of four women killed earlier this year by an alleged serial killer have not yet been recovered.\n\nWinnipeg police said they believe the remains of two of the women are in a landfill called Prairie Green.\n\nThey say logistical challenges have made the search extremely difficult.\n\nWarning: Readers may find the details in this story distressing\n\nThe decision not to search the landfill has been met by protests from indigenous advocates and the families of the women, who have since travelled to Ottawa to call for renewed attention to the issue of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nThey have also called on the Winnipeg police chief to resign, and have asked Canada's government to help fund the search for the bodies of the three murdered women in Winnipeg.\n\n\"How many other women are they not looking for?\" said Cambria Harris at a protest in Winnipeg on Sunday.\n\nCanada 'complicit in race-based genocide' of indigenous women\n\nPolice believe the remains of Cambria's mother, Morgan Beatrice Harris, 39, are at the Prairie Green landfill, alongside the remains of Marcedes Myran, 26.\n\nBoth women were killed in May, police said, and are members of the Long Plain First Nation.\n\nPolice, however, said they will not search the landfill to recover their bodies because too much time has passed and because the scale of the area is too big.\n\n\"We have no starting point,\" said Winnipeg police chief Danny Smyth on 2 December. \"It wouldn't be feasible at this point.\"\n\nMr Smyth later said in a statement that he will not resign from his position as police chief amid calls for him to do so, and that he is committed to delivering justice for the families of the murdered women.\n\nThe Prairie Green landfill has paused its operations as of Thursday as calls for a search of the two women intensify.\n\nThe remains of another woman, 24-year-old Rebecca Contois from O-Chi-Chak-Ko-Sipi First Nation in the province of Manitoba, were found in a separate Winnipeg landfill called Brady Road in May.\n\nPolice said the search for Ms Contois was possible because they could narrow down an area where her remains were believed to be, and because she was found closer to her time of death.\n\nThe families of Ms Harris and Ms Myran have publicly decried police's decision not to search for the women's remains.\n\n\"I feel very wronged, and I am so heartbroken,\" said Ms Harris' daughter, Cambria, at a press conference in Ottawa on 6 December.\n\n\"I should not have to stand here and beg so that you will find and bring our loved ones home,\" she said.\n\nIndigenous leaders have joined the families' calls for a proper search, including the chief of Long Plain First Nation, where Ms Harris and Ms Myran were from.\n\n\"The message you are sending to the greater community, to the non-Indigenous community is that Indigenous women don't matter,\" said chief Kyra Wilson.\n\nA fourth victim, also believed to be an indigenous woman, has yet to be identified and the whereabouts of her body remain unknown. The local indigenous community has given her the name Buffalo Woman (Mashkode Bizhiki'ikwe).\n\nPolice believe all four women were killed by Jeremy Skibicki of Winnipeg, who was charged with four counts of first-degree murder. The 35-year-old is now in police custody. His lawyer has told Canadian media that he intends to plead not guilty.\n\nThe murders have brought renewed attention to Canada's history of disproportionate violence faced by indigenous women, which was called a \"genocide\" by a national public inquiry in 2019.\n\nA report by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) in 2016 estimated that around 1,200 First Nations women had been killed or gone missing between 1980 and 2012.\n\nBut the National Inquiry into Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls concluded that there is \"no reliable estimate\", and added that the RCMP's figure is narrow in scope.\n\nCanadian man accused of killing four indigenous women\nGiving a voice to missing and murdered women\nIndigenous women deaths 'a Canadian genocide'\nIndigenous Canadians\nCanada\nRelated\nSacred headdress handed over to Siksika Nation\n5 Jun 2024\nEngland\nAccused Canadian serial killer trial opens in Winnipeg\n8 May 2024\nUS & Canada\nCanadians switched at birth get an apology 70 years on\n21 Mar 2024\nUS & Canada\nMore\n1 day ago\nMessi struggling, Nunez firing - (2dayFM Staff)\n\nPeople across Canada, including the Kootenays, gathered on Sunday\u00a0 to hold a Red Dress Day vigil to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nThe event is held every year on May 5 to bring awareness to the disproportionate rates of violence against Indigenous women girls and 2SLGBTQIA+ people.\n\n\u201cWe feel like women who are reporting violence, sexual violence and crimes are not being believed and heard due to the many social issues we\u2019re facing today, such as mental health and addiction issues,\u201d said Jennifer McNally, Red Dress March community volunteer.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a lot of trauma to deal with and I don\u2019t think the police forces and some laws are supporting how to move forward with taking interviews properly, treating victims with respect and dignity and actually getting some real action into finding out what\u2019s going on with missing and murdered Indigenous women.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nIn Cranbrook, vigil attendees marched from Street Angels to Rotary Park.\n\nAccording to a statement from the B.C. government, 490 Indigenous women and girls were victims of homicide in Canada from 2009 to 2021.\n\n\u201cIn this timeframe, the rate of homicide of First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit women and girls was six times higher than the rate among their non-Indigenous counterparts,\u201d said a written statement from Kelli Paddon, Parliamentary Secretary for Gender Equity.\n\n\u201cIn Canada, Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or missing than any other women in Canada.\u201d\n\nMcNally hopes governments and officials will act to tackle the high rates of violence against Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cI think we need to get our MPs and politicians together to find some ways to force law enforcement to take proper, appropriate training,\u201d said McNally. \u201cOur first responders are a key essential service that we rely on every day, and I believe they\u2019d like more training.\u201d\n\nWant to get your business noticed? {"url": "https://www.lelezard.com/en/news-21363157.html", "title": "Ministers Anandasangaree, Hajdu, Vandal, and Ien issue statement on Red Dress Day 2024", "body": "Le L\u00e9zard\nHome\nSections\nFran\u00e7ais\n\t\n\t\nClassified in: Health\nSubjects: WOM, NTA, CFG\nMinisters Anandasangaree, Hajdu, Vandal, and Ien issue statement on Red Dress Day 2024\n\n\n\nOTTAWA, TRADITIONAL UNCEDED ALGONQUIN TERRITORY, ON, May 5, 2024 /CNW/ - Today, the Honourable Gary Anandasangaree, Minister of Crown-Indigenous Relations; the Honourable Patty Hajdu, Minister of Indigenous Services\u00a0and Minister responsible for FedNor; the Honourable Dan Vandal, Minister of Northern Affairs; and the Honourable Marci Ien, Minister for Women and Gender Equality and Youth; issued the following statement:\n\n\"Since M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black began the REDress Project\u00a0in 2010, red dresses hanging in public spaces have become a stark visual reminder of every Indigenous woman, girl, Two-Spirit, and gender-diverse person in Canada who has gone missing or been murdered.\n\n\"Today, on Red Dress Day, we honour every First Nation, Inuit, and M\u00e9tis life lost to this crisis, and we reaffirm our efforts to bring the missing home. Ahead of Red Dress Day, the governments of Canada and Manitoba announced a partnership to co-develop a pilot Red Dress Alert system together with Indigenous partners. This was made possible by the $1.3 million investment included in Budget 2024. Alert systems can help ensure that when an Indigenous woman, girl, Two-Spirit or gender-diverse person goes missing, they are found.\u00a0\n\n\"We stand united in affirming our unwavering commitment to addressing this national crisis and collectively working toward a secure, violence-free future for all Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people. We also recognize that means supporting grassroots, Indigenous-led and community-driven change through housing, shelters, policing, and infrastructure initiatives, such as the Inuvialuit Family Wellness Centre that provides shelter for Indigenous women and families in Inuvik, the Indigenous Victim and Family Liaison Program\u00a0that helps individuals and family members navigate culturally-appropriate health and wellbeing supports, and new rural public transit studies to better connect communities undertaken by the Nahanni Butte First Nation, Yellowknives Dene First Nation, and the Hay River M\u00e9tis Government.\n\n\"The work to end the national crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit, and gender diverse people is ongoing, and a lot more remains to be done.\u00a0The federal government is committed to learning from Indigenous partners in a way that respects our shared priorities. We will continue to use the Federal Pathway, the National Action Plan, the National Inquiry's Calls for Justice, and the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence to lay the path forward for our work. Today, as we honour these lives, we continue our efforts to dismantle the systems that put Indigenous people in danger, and to create transformative change that will ensure every Indigenous woman, girl, Two-Spirit, and gender-diverse person in Canada has a future free from fear and violence, where their rights are protected, and respected.\"\n\nTaking Care\n\nThe Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Crisis Line is a national, toll-free, 24/7 crisis call line that provides support for anyone who requires emotional assistance related to the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people. For assistance, call 1-844-413-6649.\n\nTrauma-informed support is also available to all those impacted by the ongoing crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people through the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Health and Cultural Support Program. The program funds access to cultural support (e.g., Elders, Knowledge Holders, and Traditional Healers), emotional support (e.g., community-based health workers, peer supports), and registered mental health counsellors (e.g., psychologists, and social workers).\n\nStay connected\n\nJoin the conversation about Indigenous Peoples in Canada:\n\nX: @GCIndigenous\nFacebook: @GCIndigenous\nInstagram: @gcindigenous\n\nYou can subscribe to receive our news releases and speeches via RSS feeds.
