PHOTO BY DARREN MAKOWICHUK /Postmedia\nArticle content\n\nRed ribbons and dresses will hang along a stretch of Memorial Drive on Friday, as people gather for the third annual Mohkinstis Red Dress Day ceremony.\n\nAt the Field of Crosses at 200 Memorial Drive N.W., Calgarians will acknowledge the National Day of Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, two-spirit and LGBTQ+ people between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nBell: Calgary councillors and even Gondek blow up pipe probe plans\n'Surreal': Construction worker says $66-million lottery jackpot is gift from God\nATCO, AltaLink building 130-kilometre transmission line in central Alberta\nCouncillors shoot down city officials' proposed approach to third-party review panel selection\n'We have a story that\u2019s rooted in truth': Calgary reveals new Blue Sky City logo\nArticle content\n\nThe day is meant to honour the memory of those missing and murdered, but also raise awareness of the disproportionate rate of violence that Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit face in Canada.\n\nThe Bear Clan Patrol said in a statement that Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people make up five per cent of the population, yet a quarter of homicide victims. In Alberta, between 1980 and 2012, 206 Indigenous women were killed \u2014 accounting for 28 per cent of all female homicide victims during that time.\n\n\u201cWe put up our red dresses when one of us is stolen. Give us the chance to take them down,\u201d said the Bear Clan Patrol. \u201cIt is rare to meet an Indigenous person who has not lost a mother, auntie, daughter or niece to violence in Canada.\u201d\n\nThe Stardale Girl Drummers practice at Bridgeland park for Friday\u2019s Red Dress Day Ceremony in Calgary on May 3. PHOTO BY DARREN MAKOWICHUK /Postmedia\nDay raises awareness of disproportionate violence Indigenous women face\n\nM\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black helped inspire the red dress movement, representing the pain and loss of loved ones and survivors of those who have gone missing or been killed.\n\nJacquie Meyer, the founder of HER Victory, said it\u2019s imperative to raise awareness of the disproportionate violence that Indigenous women face.\n\nNoon News Roundup\n\nYour weekday lunchtime roundup of curated links, news highlights, analysis and features.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHER Victory works as an outreach centre to advocate for and serve those in the sex trade, including those at risk of being trafficked. It has a location in Forest Lawn and also works out of Calgary\u2019s Women\u2019s Remand Centre, and Meyer estimates about 70 per cent of the women the centre works with are Indigenous.\n\nThe Stardale Girl Drummers practice at Bridgeland park for Friday\u2019s Red Dress Day Ceremony in Calgary on May 3. PHOTO BY DARREN MAKOWICHUK /Postmedia\n\n\u201cWe see a lot of Indigenous women come to our doors. It\u2019s important to be a part of this day and honour the missing and murdered Indigenous women and honour their families who are still grieving,\u201d Meyer said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important to recognize the awareness part of this day, and acknowledge the disproportionately vulnerable group that\u2019s affected by violence and murder, which is tied to exploitation and trafficking.\u201d\n\n\u2018We deal with this on a weekly basis\u2019\n\nAs the city grapples with the recent news that Calgary police charged a man with kidnapping and assaulting local sex workers, Meyer said it\u2019s important people recognize these types of crimes happen here.\n\n\u201cTo Indigenous and non-Indigenous women, this is happening. We deal with this on a weekly basis,\u201d she said. \u201cDays like Red Dress Day are unfortunately just one day, but we need to realize that this is something that is happening every single day.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe encourages people to wear red on Friday in honour of victims.\n\nThe Stardale Girl Drummers practice at Bridgeland park for Friday\u2019s Red Dress Day Ceremony in Calgary on May 3. PHOTO BY DARREN MAKOWICHUK /Postmedia\n\nRed dresses will also be hang in other areas of the city, including at Mount Royal University.\n\nThe post-secondary institution is planning to display red dresses around campus on Friday to raise awareness and stand in solidarity with those who have lost their lives or gone missing.\n\nFollowing the National Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls report in 2019, the Alberta government formed a joint working group to develop recommendations for the province. At the beginning of 2022, the group released its recommendations and the province launched a premier\u2019s council.\n\nIn June 2022, Alberta\u2019s MMIWG Roadmap was created to guide government action to reduce violence and increase safety and economic security for Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit and LGBTQ+ people.\n\nThe Stardale Girl Drummers practice at Bridgeland park for Friday\u2019s Red Dress Day Ceremony in Calgary on May 3. PHOTO BY DARREN MAKOWICHUK /Postmedia\n\nAt Friday\u2019s ceremony, a group of Indigenous drummers from Stardale Women\u2019s Group will perform. Helen McPhaden, executive director of Stardale Women\u2019s Group, said the drumming group is one-of-a-kind in Canada because it\u2019s made up of more than 20 women and girls.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s pivotal seeing the young girls and young voices giving rise to the cause of remembering the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls,\u201d said McPhaden.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard sometimes for some of the people in the community to look at because it\u2019s opening up old wounds that have been created through a history of destruction . . . But it\u2019s for all of us to come together to understand that trauma and to try to give voice to the situation and not swipe it away under the carpet.\u201d\n\nA group of nursing students at Mount Royal University carry red dresses to hang around the campus prior to national day of awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women (MMIW) on Thursday, May 4. PHOTO BY AZIN GHAFFARI /Postmedia\n\nMcPhaden said Red Dress Day is about grieving the heavy loss of Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people to violence.\n\n\u201cThis is one event, but there\u2019s so much more going on behind the scenes in the community here in Calgary to bring awareness to this and to change the systems through justice, social services, health and education, so people will start to talk about what\u2019s going on,\u201d she said.\n\nFor Red Dress Day, Stardale Women\u2019s Group is screening online its award-winning short film, The Road. The film touches on the legacy and intergenerational effect of colonialism in Canada and missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. The virtual screening is available through Eventbrite.\n\nNursing student Emilie Ferguson along with her fellow nursing students at Mount Royal University hang red dresses around the campus prior to the national day of awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women (MMIW) on Thursday, May 4. {"url": "https://energeticcity.ca/2024/04/30/metis-society-of-fort-st-john-to-host-first-ever-red-dress-day-event/", "title": "Metis Society of Fort St. John to host first-ever Red Dress Day event", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us\nLogin\nNews\nVideos\nSports\nObituaries\nPodcasts\nNewsletters\nEvents\nWin\nNews Tips\nAdvertise\nAbout Us\nADVERTISEMENT\nHome \u00bb News \u00bb Metis Society of Fort St. John to host first-ever Red Dress Day event\nMetis Society of Fort St. John to host first-ever Red Dress Day event\nThe Metis Society of Fort St. John is hosting its first-ever Red Dress Day event, highlighting local Metis and Indigenous vendors and entrepreneurs through an artisan market.\nBY ED HITCHINS, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE REPORTER \u25cf FORT ST. JOHN, INDIGENOUS VOICES, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE, NEWS, PEACE REGION \u25cf APRIL 30, 2024 \u25cf 2 MINUTES OF READING\nRed Dress Day, highlighting and honouring murdered and missing Indigenous Women and Girls was first recognized in 2010. (Dave Jeffers, Facebook)\n\nFORT ST. JOHN, B.C. \u2014 The Metis Society of Fort St. John is hosting its first-ever Red Dress Day event, highlighting local Metis and Indigenous vendors and entrepreneurs through an artisan market.\n\nMetis Society board member Bailey Copeland says the event came to fruition after the organization\u2019s board, elected in 2023, started discussing how to recognize the significant day.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe decided it would be a really good idea to bring some sort of a public event to Fort St. John that brings awareness and helps move us towards reconciliation,\u201d said Copeland.\n\nNever Miss a Story\n\nDownload our app today! Available on Android and iOS devices\n\nLearn More\n\n\u201cI hope that people will attend the event, speak to some of the vendors, maybe learn their stories, and potentially learn who they\u2019ve lost because most indigenous people have lost somebody.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day began as an art project by Indigenous artist Jaime Black. In 2010, Black displayed an installation at the University of Winnipeg that included red dresses symbolizing the growing number of Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) nationwide.\n\n\u201cJust like the visual of the red dress itself,\u00a0 [this event] provides us with an opportunity to consider the pain and loss experienced by Indigenous people,\u201d says Copeland.\n\nAccording to Statistics Canada, 490 Indigenous women and girls were killed between 2009 and 2021. Of those who were murdered, 60 per cent were First Nations, eight per cent were Inuit, and seven per cent were M\u00e9tis.\u00a0\n\nLatest Stories\nEnvironment Canada issues multiple warnings as B.C. braces for weekend heat\nSilverberry Secure Landfill to possibly undergo new management\nB.C. NDP ministers Bains, Ralston and Fleming won\u2019t seek re-election\nB.C. seniors advocate seeks tenancy protection for residents of retirement homes\n\nLocally, the Indigenous community can point to the disappearances of Renee Didier and Darlyn Supernant, who were last seen in Dawson Creek in 2023.\u00a0\n\nCopeland says there is the hope that more will come involved as the date draws near.\n\n\u201cBead workers and individuals from Indigenous businesses will come and display their products,\u201d said Copeland. \u201cSeveral Indigenous businesses are in town, so we\u2019re still reaching out and hoping for more sign-ups.\u201d\n\nThe market will be available on May 5th at Festival Plaza (Fort St. John Metis Society)\n\nShe wants the event to open up conversations between the community, non-Indigenous and Indigenous, as people in Canada strive toward reconciliation.\u00a0\n\nAccording to Copeland, she feels that listening and sharing their stories allows non-Indigenous people to experience a bit of what Indigenous people have lost.\n\n\u201cEvery event that we have in the public just makes our community more culturally diverse,\u201d said Copeland.\n\nThe market will occur from noon to 3:00 p.m. at the Festival Plaza at 96th Avenue and 100th Street in Fort St. John.\n\nReport a typo or an error\n\nRead our guiding principles\n\nStay connected with local news\n\nMake us your\n\nhome page\n\nDownload\n\nour App\n\nJoin our\n\nNewsletter\n\nGet news\n\ntexted to you\n\nAuthor\nED HITCHINS, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE REPORTER\n\nA guy who found his calling later in life, Edward Hitchins is a professional storyteller with a colourful and extensive history.\n\nBeginning his journey into journalism in 2012 at Seneca College, Edward also graduated from Humber College with an Advanced Diploma in Print and Broadcast Journalism in 2018.\u00a0 After time off from his career and venturing into other vocations, he started his career proper in 2022 in Campbell River, B.C.\n\nEdward was attracted to the position of Indigenous Voices reporter with Energeticcity as a challenge.\u00a0 Having not been around First Nations for the majority of his life, he hopes to learn about their culture through meaningful conversations while properly telling their stories.\u00a0\n\nIn a way, he hopes this position will allow both himself and Energeticcity to grow as a collective unit as his career moves forward and evolves into the next step.\n\nHe looks forward to growing both as a reporter and as a human being while being posted in Fort St. John.\n\nThis {"url": "https://www.mbcradio.com/2023/05/red-dress-day-commemorated-in-saskatchewan", "title": "Red Dress Day commemorated in Saskatchewan - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nRed Dress Day commemorated in Saskatchewan\n\nby MBC News | May 5, 2023 | Current News\n\nRed Dress Day, also known as the National Day for Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People, is taking place in many communities across the country.\n\nToday\u2019s focus is to recognize and raise awareness of the disproportionate violence directed towards Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people in Canada.\n\nLori Campbell, Associate Vice President of Indigenous Engagement at the University of Regina, said the day was originally inspired by a M\u00e9tis artist in 2010. \u201cIt originally started with a project that an Indigenous artist named Jaime Black did where she gathered red dresses and was hanging them up for display. The importance of the red dress is to bring attention to people about the ongoing genocide that\u2019s happening currently to Indigenous women and girls and two spirit people across the country and has been happening for a very long time, and just to bring a visual to the absence of those who are missing,\u201d said Campbell.\n\nCampbell explained that the colour red is very significant in many Indigenous cultures. \u201cIt is said in many of our Indigenous cultures that the spirits see the bright colours the best, with red being probably one of the brightest colours that we have. It is said that the spirits can see the red, and for those that are lost and haven\u2019t been found yet, the red will help their spirits find their way home to their loved ones, where they will know that they\u2019re missed, that they are loved, that they are cared for, and that we are wanting their spirits to be laid to rest,\u201d Campbell said. \u201cIt has definitely grown; there is more public awareness now, and that\u2019s been important. We do see more people that are aware; some of that has actually come about because of the recent public awareness around the gravesite discoveries at residential school sites and with the walks and things that are happening. It used to be that it was just Indigenous peoples who would come together, but we do see more public engagement in wanting to show their support and come out to events, and we encourage that because it\u2019s not just an Indigenous issue; it should be an issue that every person in Canada wants to have changed.\u201d\n\nThose who want to demonstrate their support for Red Dress Day are encouraged to wear a piece of red clothing.\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},

{"url": "https://cfweradio.ca/2024/05/01/red-dress-day/", "title": "Red Dress Day | CFWE FM", "body": " Menu\nListen Live\nON-AIR\nAdvertising\nConcerts & Events\nBingo\nContact Us\nRed Dress Day\nBy Digital Editor\nMay 1, 2024 | 8:24 PM\n\n\u00a0\n\nRed Dress Day \u2013 the National Day of Awareness and Action for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People (MMIWG2S) \u2013 marks a day of remembrance and awareness for the profound violence experienced by thousands of Indigenous women, gender-diverse people, and their communities.\n\nThis day first began in 2010 as the REDress Project, an art installation by Metis artist Jaime Black, and displayed hanging red dresses as a symbol of those lost to the ongoing violence.\n\nIn Canada, Indigenous women are overrepresented across nearly all accounts of violence. Despite only making up 4.3% of the population,\u00a0Indigenous women make up 16% of female homicide victims\u00a0and\u00a011% of missing women. Alberta is amongst the highest number of MMIWG2S cases. We know these numbers are likely much higher due to countless systemic and structural barriers including underreporting, inadequate investigations, and dismissal by officials.\n\nIn 2019, The National Inquiry for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls released a report titled\u00a0Reclaiming Power and Place: The Final Report of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\u00a0This report was created through public hearings and evidence gathering across the country and shares the truths of more than 2,380 family members, survivors, experts and Knowledge Keepers.\n\nAs we honour Red Dress Day and remember those who have been lost, we recognize the lifelong learning and action that must be taken in response. There is a collective responsibility that we share in building a world that is safe and just for Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit people. We encourage you to learn more about MMIWG2S, colonial gender-based violence, and its lasting impacts on our communities.\n\nFor more information, consider visiting the following resources below:\n\nThe National Inquiry for MMIWG Final Report\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada\nThe REDress Project\nSafe Passage\nAn interactive map of cases of MMIWG2S to collect data and help identify patterns of violence in geographic areas.\nTedTalk by Tamara Bernard: We Are More Than Missing and Murdered\n\n\u00a0\n\nIf you or someone you know needs immediate mental and emotional wellness support, call The National Inquiry into MMIWG2S Toll-Free Support Phone:\u00a01-844-413-6649\n\nComments\nLeave a Reply\n\nYou must be logged in to post a comment.\n\nFrequency Map\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms Of Service\nCopyright \u00a9 2024. {"url": "https://www.ominecaexpress.com/local-news/red-dress-day-walk-held-in-vanderhoof-7353830", "title": "Red Dress Day walk held in Vanderhoof - Vanderhoof Omineca Express", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n20.4 \u00b0C\nHome Local News\nRed Dress Day walk held in Vanderhoof\nBinny Paul\nMay 4, 2024 7:30 AM\nMay 6, 2024 10:18 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 2\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:02:19\n\nRed Dress Day events took place in Vanderhoof on May 5, which marks the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People (MMIWG2S).\n\nSaik\u2019uz First Nation hosted a memorial walk, drumming, community gathering, and other activities in the Highway park on Sudnay. Attendees wore red as a symbol of solidarity.\n\nThe event started from outside the Vanderhoof RCMP station on Columbia St., where participants gathered before embarking on a march to the Highway 16 park.\n\nThe event was open to all members of the public to join and show their support for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit people.\n\nThese community events aim to honour the lives of those who have been lost and raise awareness about this ongoing issue.\n\n\u201cPeople need to examine statistics across Canada to see how many people are missing in the country,\u201d said Saik\u2019uz Nation Chief Priscilla Mueller.\n\nLast year, Mueller\u2019s community mourned the loss of 29-year-old Chelsey Heron (Quaw), whose remains were discovered in Saik\u2019uz Territory in November, a month after her disappearance. Similarly, Nicholas John, a member of Saik\u2019uz, was found deceased near Vanderhoof five months after he was reported missing in October 2022.\n\n\u201cWe still have Jay Preston Raphael missing,\u201d Mueller added. Raphael was last seen in Saik\u2019uz in February 2023.\n\nMueller highlighted the ongoing issue of missing Indigenous women and men along Highway 16, emphasising the need for continued awareness and action.\n\n\u201cMany of our communities are located along the highway, and it appears that the issue of missing women and men along Highway 16 is not taken as seriously as we would like,\u201d Mueller said.\n\n\u201cIt is alarming. It feels as though our lives don\u2019t matter,\u201d she added.\n\nOn Red Dress Day, Mueller is calling on policymakers and community leaders to adopt more practical solutions, such as improved signage and well-lit benches, to enhance safety along Highway 16.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s crucial that in 2024, we refuse to accept the disappearance of Indigenous women as a norm,\u201d she said.\n\nHave That\u2019s about 133 a year or 3 a week.\nBecause of persistent forms of oppression (racism, colonialism, homophobia, transphobia, sexism), complaints about missing Indigenous Women, Girls, and Women, are less likely to be taken seriously or followed up.\n\nA number of events are being held locally over the next few days, including a gathering at the Civic Centre shortly before noon, followed by a ceremony raising the MMIWG flag and a walk to the Deshkan Ziibi Indigenous Hub at 495 King Street West.\n\nTomorrow, the Indigenous hub is hosting a bannock and tea and drop-in event with open conversations and teachings with an Indigenous grandmother.\n\nSunday the hub will feature drumming, giving of tobacco, and an open sharing circle.\n\nStudio Address 520 James St. Wallaceburg, ON | Main Phone 519-627-0007 | Contest Phone 519-627-0991 | News Room 519-627-0007 ext 310 news@ckxsfm.com\nListen Live\n FACEBOOK  INSTAGRAM  RSS  TWITTER  YOUTUBE\n\u00a9 2023 CKXS 99.1 - Chatham-Kent & Lambton County"},
{"url": "https://infotel.ca/newsitem/indigenous-women-health/cp1494544670", "title": "Racism partly to blame for unequal health care provided to Indigenous women: PHAC study | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for businesses in Kamloops, Merritt and Areas|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\nMainly Sunny\u00a0 29.4\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nRacism partly to blame for unequal health care provided to Indigenous women: PHAC study\nCamille Bains\nPeople attend a Red Dress Day ceremony marking the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirited people in Canada, in Vancouver, B.C., Thursday, May 5, 2022. Racism and the lack of primary care providers mean off-reserve First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit females have poorer health overall compared to their non-Indigenous counterparts, says a study by the Public Health Agency of Canada.THE CANADIAN PRESS/Darryl Dyck\nAugust 27, 2023 - 9:05 PM\n\nRacism and the lack of primary care providers mean off-reserve First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit women and girls have poorer health overall compared to their non-Indigenous counterparts, says a study by the Public Health Agency of Canada.\n\nCompared with non-Indigenous females, those in the three distinct groups reported a higher prevalence of diagnosed chronic diseases and worse mental health, including mood or anxiety disorders, says the study, which noted Canada's colonial history of residential schools, forced or coerced sterilization and destruction of traditional lands.\n\nResearchers used data for all females aged 15 to 55 from the annual Canadian Community Health Survey between 2015 and 2020. That amounted to 6,000 people from the three distinct groups and 74,760 non-Indigenous females, all in their reproductive years.\n\n\"Indigenous females waited longer for primary care, more used hospital services for non-urgent care and fewer had consultations with dental professionals,\" says the study, published Monday in the Canadian Medical Association Journal.\n\nLead researcher Sebastian Srugo said that while thousands of women across Canada lack a family doctor, \"those conversations are happening much, much more among Indigenous women.\"\n\n\"Even when we compare Indigenous women and people assigned female at birth to non-Indigenous counterparts of a similar age, similar education, income and living in the same places, we still have those gaps,\" Srugo said.\n\nWomen who were pregnant or had just given birth were worse off, and that could affect their children years later, he said.\n\n\"This is about intergenerational impacts of not having access to this care,\" Srugo said. \"It's also about a justifiable lack of trust that Indigenous communities have with the health-care system in Canada.\"\n\nPrimary care providers could support the women in their reproductive decisions and assess them for conditions including heart disease, depression and cancer, he said.\n\nMultiple studies have connected poorer health outcomes for Indigenous females compared to the wider population.\n\nBut Srugo said the PHAC study adds to limited research involving First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit, which have diverse cultures, languages and histories but are typically lumped together as Indigenous Peoples.\n\nThe study included 2,902 First Nations, 2,345 M\u00e9tis and 742 Inuit women and girls. Researchers also received input from an advisory committee specifically created for the project. Members were from four organizations \u2014 Les Femmes Michif Otipemisiwak (Women of the M\u00e9tis Nation), the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada and 2 Spirits in Motion.\n\nWhile Lee Clark, director of health for the Native Women's Association of Canada, lauded federal researchers for partnering with Indigenous organizations, she said their study should not become \"one more paper in the pile of evidence\" that has made little difference in the lives of women deprived of equitable care.\n\nResearchers themselves cited the challenges in access to care in a \"disjointed jurisdictional system, resulting in medical relocations for birthing and general health care.\"\n\nClark said she hoped the federal government would use the findings to \"hold provinces accountable\" to deliver targeted programs for women whose needs have been sidelined for too long.\n\nIndigenous communities are still deeply affected by the 2020 death of Atikamekw woman Joyce Echaquan in a Quebec hospital, where she filmed staff insulting her as she lay dying, she said.\n\n\"The majority of people I speak with in the community, we have stories of blatant racism,\" she said from Gatineau, Que. \"Colonialism isn't historic. It's ongoing. These harms are continuing and they're perpetuated still. Joyce's example is just one of the examples that was recorded.\"\n\nIn a decision earlier this month, anarbitration tribunal ordered the reinstatement of an orderly who was fired by the hospital. An arbitrator wrote that while the employee made inappropriate comments toward Echaquan, she was not responsible for most of the poor treatment the patient received compared to the \"insulting, vulgar, racist and rude remarks and behaviour'' of a nurse. That nursewas also fired for telling Echaquan that she was stupid and \"better off dead.\"\n\nClark also called on federal and provincial governments to work together to incorporate Indigenous practices in health care, including midwifery that uses traditional practices.\n\n\"Pockets of this is happening, recently in Nova Scotia. It needs to be everywhere. It needs to be more accepted. The medicalization of birth is just an outright stamp of colonialism.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published Aug. 28, 2023.\n\nCanadian Press health coverage receives support through a partnership with the Canadian Medical Association. CP is solely responsible for this content.\n\nNews from \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2023\n\n\nMore News ...\niN RESPONSE: Readers have their say\nFollowing are emailed reader responses to stories or {"url": "https://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/community/missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-girls-2-spirit-awareness-event-in-courtenay-may-5/", "title": "Offender programs fall short, auditor says - Greater Victoria News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n22.2 \u00b0C\nHome News\nOffender programs fall short, auditor says\nThe B.C. government is struggling to deal with a record caseload of nearly 24,000 convicted offenders who aren't in jail.\nTom Fletcher\nDec 8, 2011 12:00 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKamloops Regional Correctional Centre and other B.C. jails are overcrowded\n\nVICTORIA \u2013 The B.C. government is struggling to deal with a record caseload of nearly 24,000 convicted offenders who are in the community, and it needs to do a better job of delivering programs to prevent them from reoffending.\n\nThose are key conclusions of B.C. Auditor General John Doyle's latest report on the provincial corrections system.\n\nIn addition to overcrowding in B.C. jails, nearly nine out of 10 convicted offenders in B.C. are not in custody, but are serving conditional sentences on house arrest or probation with court-imposed conditions.\n\nThe auditor found that additional staff have not kept up with the caseload, which increased 28 per cent in the past six years. And only 35 per cent of interventions that are designed to reduce re-offending are ever completed.\n\nB.C. has four core programs. They focus on male offenders of spousal assault, other violent offenders, sex offenders and substance abusers.\n\nDoyle made eight recommendations, related to improved reporting on rates of re-offence and better record-keeping. He recommended a review of staffing levels but didn't prescribe what if any increase there should be to the current staff of 450 probation officers.\n\nThe B.C. public safety ministry accepted all eight recommendations. In its response to the report, the community corrections division noted that probation officers deal with adult offenders, \"many of whom are violent and high risk.\n\n\"They deliver evidence-based programming such as the Relationship Violence Prevention Program, which has been shown to reduce re-offending by up to 50 per cent.\"\n\nNDP public safety critic Kathy Corrigan said it's encouraging that a domestic violence program can have that much success, since domestic violence is the second-largest source of of offences in B.C. after impaired driving.\n\nBut Corrigan noted that Doyle found fewer than half of B.C.'s probation officers have completed the ministry's domestic violence course.\n\nDoyle surveyed a sample of 58 domestic violence case files, and found three quarters of them contained at least one alleged breach of court-imposed conditions. He said few of the cases were documented well enough to determine if breaches of probation were dealt with in court, but there were several cases where they were not.\n\nThe report identified three cases where \"the unreported breaches involved victim contact from offenders convicted of domestic violence \u2013 and in all three cases, the offender had been assessed as being at either a medium or high risk to re-offend.\"\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tGroup of Langford kids taking Greater Victoria music scene by storm\n\t\tVIDEO: Whales off Greater Victoria captivate shoreline photographers\n\t\tNew group aims to take a run at Sooke's traffic woes\n\t\t5 earthquakes reported off Vancouver Island: USGS\n\t\tUniversity of Victoria to shut down campus pool after a half-century\nFacebook Comments (0) \n'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\nBlack Press Media\nB.C. as Red Dress Day, May 5th is set aside each year to bring awareness to the disproportionate levels of violence against Indigenous women.\n\nDespite accounting for less than 5 percent of Canada\u2019s population, Indigenous women and two-spirit people make up nearly a quarter of all homicide victims.\n\nWhile the BC Assembly of First Nations encourages the gatherings, they are also calling for more government action to address the crisis.\n\nThey are calling on both BC and Ottawa to work with First Nations to address the emergency\u2019s underlying factors: colonialism, racism, and sexism.\n\nTo By using multiple empty red dresses in the installation, it is meant to illustrate the absence of the more than 1,000 missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Canada.\n\nIn Owen Sound, a Red Dress Day ceremony will be held at Kelso Beach at Nawash Park, from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the Gichi-Name M\u2019wikwedong Reconciliation Garden.\n\nAt Saugeen First Nation, a gathering for First Nation members only is planned. It will not be open to the public, but will be for band members to engage in \u201cdiscussion and planning on the continuing issues and factors that contribute to missing and murdered indigenous people and impacts on our community,\u201d says an event posting.\n\nThat conversation is expected to also include discussion about a proposed Red Dress Alert. The alert is an idea proposed by Winnipeg NDP MP Leah Gazan and would function similarly to an Amber Alert, for missing Indigenous women, girls and Two-Spirit people.\n\nStatistics on the government of Canada\u2019s department of justice website say Indigenous women represent 10 per cent of the total population of missing women in Canada. The page says \u201cin 2014, the rate of homicide of Indigenous women (3.64 per 100,000) was almost six times higher than non-Indigenous women (0.65 per 100,000).\u201d\n\nRecommended for You\nRecommended by\nLatest News\nOPP Investigate Vandalism At Several Sites In Walkerton\n10m ago\n \nHousehold Hazardous Waste Event Coming To Paisley\n3h ago\n 8 Views\nGeorgian Bluffs Council Endorses Fire Prevention Agreement With Owen Sound\n6h ago\n 20 Views\nMeaford Pair Accused Of Stealing Appliances & Furniture From Air BnB\n11h ago\n 116 Views\nMore\nON AIR NOW\nRick Ringer\n5:00 PM - 8:00 PM\nLocal Weather\n\n23.2\u00b0C\n\nMostly Cloudy\nWind: W 7 km/h\n\nObserved at: Wiarton Airport\nLast updated: Thursday July 04, 2024 at 17:00 EDT\nSource: Environment and Climate Change Canada (license)\n\n Full Forecast...\nRecently Played\nBay City Rollers\nSaturday Night\n1 minute ago\nStampeders\nOh My Lady\n6 minutes ago\nLittle Peggy March\nI Will Follow Him\n8 minutes ago\nMelissa Manchester\nYou Should Hear How She Talks About You\n12 minutes ago\nGo Go's\nWe Got The Beat\n17 minutes ago\n See More\nAccessibilityPrivacy PolicyTerms Of Service\nCopyright \u00a9 2024. (WLFN photo)\nListen to this article\n00:02:12\n\nA Red Dress Day event will be held Monday, May 6 in the parking lot above the Stampede Grounds grandstands.\n\nOrganized by Cariboo Friendship Society (CFS), the gathering begins at 1 p.m. and will honour the memory of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in B.C. and across Canada.\n\nThere will be drumming, a sacred fire and tobacco ties as well as an opportunity to paint rocks to be placed at the Red Rock Memory Garden at 624 Oliver Street, said Jennifer Schuetze an Aboriginal Wellness Coordinator at CFS who is organizing the event with Lori Winters, PEACE program counsellor at CFS.\n\nBecause the National Day of Action and Remembrance May 5 is on a Sunday this year, Schuetz said CFS decided to host the event the next day.\n\nA few years ago Cariboo Friendship Society and Aboriginal Housing Management Association(AHMA) commissioned artist, Satsi Naziel, to create the red dress design seen on the event poster.\n\nPins with the red dress design will be given out at the event.\n\nSchuetze said in response to calls for action from Indigenous families, communities and organizations, as well as non-governmental and international organizations, the Government of Canada launched an entirely independent National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in September 2016.\n\nJaimie Black, a M\u00e9tis visual artist, created the REDress Project in 2010 in response to missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Canada and the U.S.\n\nShe chose the colour red after a friend told her \u201cred is the only colour the spirits can see.\u201d\n\nSince then it is not uncommon for different communities to hand red dresses in trees, on buildings, on fences, inside business windows and other prominent places.\n\nThe Tillicum Society in Quesnel will host its Red Dress event on Sunday, May 5 beginning at noon at the entrance to the footbridge crossing the Fraser River.\n\nDon\u2019t It took the whole community to come together and everybody was searching everywhere. Months later we found her brutally beaten and murdered. Ever since they we decided that we needed answers.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nJones says her family along with many others have no closure, with many cases remaining unsolved. She and her family continue to honour her sister since she was found 46 years ago.\n\n\u201cShe was a happy-go-lucky person. She\u2019d bring the sunshine in the rainstorm,\u201d she says. \u201cShe left us two beautiful children that we treasure and we have gatherings in her name, and keep going until hopefully we find an answer.\u201d\n\nShe says they are hoping to work with the younger generations to help them prevent what has happened from happening to them.\n\n\u201cOur main goal is to work with the younger generation,\u201d says Jones. \u201cTo teach the younger generation safety and to be aware of their surroundings. Teach it to them and now and they will have a chance of survival.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nIn an effort to mitigate future incidents, she hopes that communication between RCMP and families improves when they do have to search for loved ones.\n\n\u201cCommunication is what we need between RCMP and families, and that\u2019s something that\u2019s got to change,\u201d says Jones. \u201cLike when something goes missing we can\u2019t wait 24 or 48 hours, we have to go out looking immediately.\u201d\n\nShe says that while events like Red Dress Day are helpful for awareness, people should remember that some are haunted by this issue every day.\n\n\u201cEvery day it\u2019s that way for our families, and we\u2019ll never give up,\u201d says Jones. \u201cIf anyone has any leads or clues, call the RCMP.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nEvents are being held across Vancouver Island to commemorate the day. They ask you to wear red to show your support.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nAll\nNational\nLifeLabs sold to American diagnostic firm, pledges to protect Canadian patient data\nCowichan Valley\nCVRD wraps up years long project to remove invasive plants from Memory Island\nCowichan Valley\nLadysmith RCMP seeking witnesses of July 2nd collision\nIsland & Coast\n10 earthquakes in 24 hours recorded off Island\u2019s West Coast\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nLifeLabs sold to American diagnostic firm, pledges to protect Canadian patient data\n \nCVRD wraps up years long project to remove invasive plants from Memory Island\n \nLadysmith RCMP seeking witnesses of July 2nd collision\n \n10 earthquakes in 24 hours recorded off Island\u2019s West Coast\n \nWarmer temperatures expected for Vancouver Island this week\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\n \nNew urgent primary care centre on the way for Duncan\n \nRegulations for BC hunters updated for next 2 years\n \nNew act to give workers international credit recognition in BC\n \nRCMP, Cowichan SAR on the lookout for missing man in Youbou\n\t\nSUN FM\n\nSunScribers\n \nTour de Rock\n \nMornings with Jason Hatton\n \nMiddays with Nicholas\n \nAfternoons with Justis Doucet\nHawaii of the North\n \nIn Search of Albacore\n \n5 Stunning Lighthouses To See In BC\n \nExploring the BC Bird Trail \u2013 Near You\n \nHealth and Happiness in Your Own Backyard\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nContact Us\nContest Rules\nAdvertise\nWe\u2019re Hiring"},
{"url": "https://www.885thebeach.com/2023/05/04/missing-murdered-indigenous-women-walk-and-event-scheduled-in-nanaimo/", "title": "Missing & murdered Indigenous women walk and event scheduled in Nanaimo | 88.5 The Beach", "body": "Skip to Content\nON\u00a0AIR\u00a0NOW\n2:00 PM\u00a0-\u00a06:00 PM\nJoanne Dee\n \nSign In\nNEWS\nEVENTS\nSubmit an Event\nDJS\nThe Beach Backtrack\nRecently Played\nCONTESTS\nCONTACT US\nBEACH CLUB\nBeach Birthday E-Blast\nMissing & murdered Indigenous women walk and event scheduled in Nanaimo\nParksville, BC, Canada / 88.5 The Beach\nJordan Davidson\nMay 4, 2023 | 2:19 PM\n\n\n\n\nNANAIMO \u2014 A community walk aims to raise awareness and honour missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit individuals (MMIWG2S+).\n\nFriday, May 5 marks the national MMIWG2S+ awareness day, also known as Red Dress Day, with the Nanaimo Family Life Association (NFLA) putting on the walk.\n\nThe march starts at 11:30 a.m. at the Thrifty Foods parking lot at Port Place Shopping Centre and proceeds to Maffeo Sutton Park.\n\nA formal presence will then be established at the park from noon until 3 p.m.\n\nProgram coordinator for the Indigenous informed sexual assault response program at NFLA Esther Charlie said the event is a way to commemorate those lost while working to prevent future incidents.\n\n\u201cWe will open and honour those that are missing or murdered and hold the families up in a good way, but also sharing and acknowledging not only what the City is doing (but also) organizations that are providing support and looking at addressing the high percentage of violence that women and girls experience today.\u201d\n\nInformation on different programs available within the community will be available at Maffeo Sutton Park, along with refreshments and a tent for local Indigenous elders.\n\nA crowd looks on as the NFLA unveil their plans for the May 5 walk for missing and murdered indigenous women and girls. (NFLA)\n\nOther local groups participating include Nanaimo Women Helping Women, the Haven Society of Nanaimo/Oceanside, the Nanaimo Brain Injury Society, and the Cedar Woman House.\n\nCharlie said it\u2019s important to highlight how these issues are still prominent today.\n\n\u201cPromoting awareness and helping others understand how big it is that Indigenous women, girls, are still experiencing the level of violence that is happening, and looking at how we can start and continue to support future generations to undo and be more aware.\u201d\n\nAnother march is also taking place in Ladysmith the same day starting at 11 a.m. at Elliots Beach Park towards Stz\u2019uminus Community Centre.\n\nA similar event is happening on Friday in Duncan.\n\nAccording to the final report issued by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, between 1980 and 2021 16 per cent of all female homicides in Canada were against Indigenous women and girls, despite only making up four per cent of the population.\n\nThe House of Commons recently unanimously backed a motion declaring the deaths and disappearance of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency, along with funding a nationwide public alert system.\n\nLocal news. {"url": "https://cfweradio.ca/2023/04/21/may-5-national-day-of-awareness-for-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-and-girls/", "title": "Red Dress Day 2023 | CFWE FM", "body": " Menu\nListen Live\nON-AIR\nAdvertising\nConcerts & Events\nBingo\nContact Us\nRed Dress Day 2023\nBy Digital Editor\nApr 21, 2023 | 6:54 PM\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nMay 5 is Red Dress Day, a day which honours the spirits of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit people (MMIWG2S+). The red dresses act as a visual reminder of all of the missing women, girls, and Two-Spirit people.\n\nJaime Black, a M\u00e9tis artist, was the driving force behind the Red Dress movement.\n\nHer\u00a0REDdress art installation\u00a0inspired a grassroots movement across North America that has evolved into Red Dress Day \u2014 a visual symbol of the grief and loss suffered by victims\u2019 families and survivors, bringing awareness to the genocidal crisis of Missing and Murdered Indigenous women.\n\nBlack created the art installation, which consisted of 600 community-donated crimson dresses that were placed in public areas throughout Winnipeg and later across Canada, to draw attention to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Indigenous women and to evoke a presence through the marking of absence.\n\nBlack chose the colour red after conversations with an Indigenous friend who told her red is the only colour the spirits can see.\n\n\u201cSo (red) is really a calling back of the spirits of these women and allowing them a chance to be among us and have their voices heard through their family members and community.\u201d\n\nJaime Black\n\nBlack has also suggested red \u201crelates to our lifeblood and that connection between all of us\u201d and that it symbolizes both vitality and violence. The dresses are empty, so that they evoke the missing women who should be wearing them.\n\nThe discrimination, racism and inequality left by the legacy of residential schools, the 60s scoop and ongoing colonization affect women and people of colour the most. We must move forward to end the violence against MMIWG2S+.\n\nThis day is meant to raise awareness about the ongoing harm and remembering those who have gone missing or died. Here are some of the ways you can help:\n\nStaying educated and up to date\nLearn about Indigenous Canadian history from the Indigenous perspective.\nRead the final report from the National Inquiry.\nListen to the truths shared.\nAcknowledge human and Indigenous rights violation and their impact.\nBecome an ally\nContinue to educate yourself.\nSupport others in every relationship and encounter you take part in.\nSupport the community \u2013 Amplify the voices of BIPOC.\nBe respectfully active in the community.\nActively work to break down barriers.\nSpeak out against racism, sexism, ignorance, homophobia and transphobia in the home, work, and community.\nTeach or encourage others to do the same.\nCall on your elected officials to move forward with the 231 Calls for Justice.\n\n\u00a0\n\nComments\nLeave a Reply\n\nYou must be logged in to post a comment.\n\nFrequency Map\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms Of Service\nCopyright \u00a9 2024. It\u2019s not something just in the past, it continues to happen today.\u201d\n\nWahta Mohawks First Nation will mark the occasion with a walk, speech, tobacco burning, and red dress hanging. Rusell help prepare t-shirts for National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. (Facebook/ Winnipeg School Division)\n\nMay 5 is Red Dress Day, or National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\nTo help commemorate the day, students in the graphic design lab at R.B. Russell Vocational High School, located in the heart of the North End, have prepared t-shirts with designs their classmates have created.\u00a0\n\n\u201cMy design says no more stolen sisters, which includes every murdered woman, girl and two-spirited\u00a0as well. I made a design that includes all, they\u2019re our sisters, to commemorate them,\" said grade 11 student Calliope Funk.\n\nGraphic Design teacher\u00a0John Sobkovich says they decided to create these shirts to support the community.\n\n\u201cMy spouse is Indigenous.\u00a0My mom is Indigenous.\u00a0To think they\u2019re at higher risk of something based on sex and race, that\u2019s how it hits home for me. We are a community classroom, and many people in our community have been affected by this cause (MMIWG2), so we want to be able to provide something to stand together, to be seen with the colour red, which is a homage to the red dress project.\u201d\n\nStudents and staff at R.B. Russel hope that by creating these t-shirts, they can also start a trend to have a national red shirt day.\u00a0\n\n\"One design\u00a0can make a big impact,\" said\u00a0Sobkovich.\n\nThe t-shirts went up for sale in the community on Wednesday and were sold out within a half hour.\n\nAll staff and students will be wearing the student-designed\u00a0red shirts today.\u00a0\n\n\"I plan to honour all these lost sisters who were taken too soon. It\u2019s an emotional topic, and I am humbled to see my design on all these shirts,\u201d said Calliope.\u00a0\n\nIn Winnipeg, a red dress round dance will be held at noon today at Portage and Main\u00a0to draw awareness to the day\u00a0and to honour those who are still missing. The dance will be followed by a Memorial March to The Forks.\n\nNEXT STORY\nWinnipeg Ice snatch Eastern Conference Championship\nLATEST IN LOCAL NEWS\nMore travel destinations out of Winnipeg Richardson International Airport\nTipped semi causing delays in area of Pembina and Perimeter\nProvince introduces new spinal program to improve care and reduce wait times\nMild weather gives ticks a head start\nLATEST STORIES ON CLASSIC107\n\u2018Super fresh\u2019 score in RWB world premiere: Cris Derksen and Julian Pellicano in studio\nCool Concert: Winnipeg Wind Ensemble presents Fire and Ice this Sunday, April 28th\n'Nessie' sighting vaults Canadian couple into media spotlight after photo in Scotland\nCanCan Macabre: Cellist Sophie Shao records two magnificent new works for cello\nEvents\nArt From the Attic\nSun, Jun 30, 3:00 PM\nMa-Buhay!: A New Musical\nSun, Jun 30, 7:30 PM\nDowntown Sounds Concert Series\nTue, Jul 2, 12:00 PM\nMa-Buhay!: A New Musical\nTue, Jul 2, 7:30 PM\nSIR: IAGO SPEAKS\nTue, Jul 2, 7:30 PM\nView more \nJobs\nPowered by\nHVAC Installer / Service Technician\nFull-time, Hourly, Skilled Trades\nFeatured\nSenior Years Teacher - Physical Education\nPart-time, Term, Education\nMachine Operator and Material Prepper\nFull-time, Hourly, Permanent, Labour, Manufacturing, Skilled Trades\n0.60 FTE RN, RPN (24-58W)\nPart-time, Permanent, Healthcare\n1.00FTE - Fulltime Permanent RN, RPN (24-40W)\nFull-time, Permanent, Healthcare\nView more \nClassic 107 FM\nPodcasts\nGet the App\nNEWS\nCommunity\nLocal News\nLocal Sports\nNational News\nArts & Culture\nAg News\nSponsored\nChristian News\nWeather\nFEATURES\nEvents\nLocalJobShop\nGarage Sales\nOn-Air Schedule\nRoad Reports and Cancellations\nClassic 107 Playlog\nCONNECT\nContact Us\nSubmit News\nMeet the Team\nFacebook\nX\nYouTube\nStreaming\nRSS\nAdvertise With Us\nCareers\nContest Rules\nAccessibility\nTerms Of Use Agreement\nPrivacy Policy\nJournalistic Standards"},

{"url": "https://www.coastreporter.net/local-news/red-dress-day-event-returns-to-qathet-for-sixth-year-8691120", "title": "Tla\u2019amin Nation part of MMIW walk partnership awareness plan - Coast Reporter", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\n19.1 \u00b0C\nHOME LOCAL NEWS\nRed Dress Day event returns to qathet for sixth year\nNational Day for Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People walk supports families\n\tPaul Galinski\n\nMay 3, 2024 7:46 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRAISING AWARENESS: Promoting the National Day for Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirited People are [from left]: John Louie, Ann Kurtz, organizer Cyndi Pallen, and Maggy Gisle, who will be speaking at the event. Also known as Red Dress Day, the gathering will feature a walk from Tis\u2019kwat in Townsite to Willingdon Beach on May 5. Paul Galinski photo\nListen to this article\n00:02:24\n\nMay 5 marks Red Dress Day, also known as the National Day for Awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People, which will be recognized in the qathet region.\n\nAccording to organizer Cyndi Pallen, in partnership with Tla\u2019amin Nation, qathet SAFE is helping to raise awareness of those who have experienced violence and/or loss though tragic death or have missing family members.\n\n\u201cWe ask everyone to be mindful and come together in solidarity to pay homage to families impacted,\u201d said Pallen, prior to this year\u2019s walk.\n\nThose participating in the walk are asked to be at Tis\u2019kwat, the old hospital grounds in Townsite, at 12:45 pm, with the walk to Willingdon Beach starting at 1:15 pm. Individuals can follow by car or meet at Willingdon Beach if they cannot walk the distance.\n\nFrom 3 to 4:30 pm, there will be a candlelight Kol-Neh\u2019qway\u2019 Coast Salish cultural ceremony.\n\n\u201cWe are reaching out to the community to come support us,\u201d said Pallen. \u201cThis will be the sixth year we have been hosting the walk.\n\n\u201cAs we go along, we are hearing more stories that are closer, and as time goes on people are communicating more about different things. We\u2019re hoping for a good turnout, which we have had in the past. We\u2019ve had several different walks and tried different things and we decided to stick with Townsite to Willingdon Beach.\u201d\n\nPallen said there is a need to communicate about missing and murdered Indigenous women (MMIW), girls and two-spirited people.\n\n\u201cWe are working toward supporting and lifting up affected people,\u201d she added.\n\nTo many First Nations, Pallen explained following a previous Red Dress Day walk, red is the only colour spirits can see.\n\n\u201cWhen we wear red, we are hoping to call back the missing spirits of the women and children so we can lay them to rest,\u201d she said. \u201cThere are still a lot of people who are going missing, and for our people, First Nations people across the country and Canada, it\u2019s been really challenging for their spirits.\n\n\u00a0\u201cI\u2019d like to see it stopped. This is not something that\u2019s normal for us to be doing. We shouldn\u2019t be here, standing up and talking about all of the women who went missing and their families that are suffering.\u201d\n\nJoin the\u00a0Peak's email list\u00a0for the top headlines right in your inbox Monday to Friday.\n\n\u00a0\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has been shared 1 time\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on {"url": "https://ottawa.ctvnews.ca/ottawa-marks-red-dress-day-to-honour-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-and-girls-1.6386673", "title": "Ottawa marks Red Dress Day to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nOTTAWA\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nOTTAWA\nNews\nOttawa marks Red Dress Day to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\n02:20\nThe powerful message of red dress day\n01:15\nCMHR hosting Red Dress exhibit\n02:27\nRed Dress Day marked in Timmins\n01:08\nSagkeeng First Nation Red Dress March\n01:55\nRecognizing Red Dress Day\n02:03\nRed Dress Day ceremony at Membertou First Nation\n04:48\nAwareness: Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\n01:45\nRed Dress Day marked in North Bay (2023)\n01:38\nRed Dress Day marked in Manitoba\n00:45\nRed Dress Day ceremony takes place in Halifax\n00:33\nRed Dress Day honoured as more work to be done\n05:36\nRed Dress Day\n04:51\nThe importance of Red Dress Day\nTyler Fleming\nCTV News Ottawa Multi-Skilled Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 5, 2023 5:12 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nMay 5 is Red Dress Day, the national day to honour and bring awareness to missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\n\nOn Friday, community members gathered across the national capital region to remember the lives of those who have been lost.\n\nInuk throat singing echoed through Ottawa\u2019s Centertown neighbourhood. Songs of strength, the singing for those who cannot.\u00a0\n\nRed dresses hang on trees, a symbol of lost lives, at a candlelight vigil in a park that bears the name of Inuk artist Annie Pootagook, whose death was declared suspicious by police.\n\n\"Annie Pootoogook\u00a0is such an inspiration to our communities and what message does it send with what happened to her. What message does that send to our children that no matter how high up they make it, it doesn\u2019t matter,\" says Mikka Komaksiutisak with Tungasuvvingat Inuit\n(opens in a new tab)\n. \"And that\u2019s why we\u2019re here today\u00a0to protect our children from future harm and to stop this from happening with our community. You wake up and you see on the news that the remains of a missing community member was found and that\u2019s not okay.\"\n\n\"I\u2019m here to honour the memory of my cousin David\u2019s daughter, a young lady by the name of Savanna Pikuyak who was murdered while apartment hunting in Ottawa,\" Sara Arnatsiaq said.\n\nSavanna Pikuyak, a nursing student who had moved from Nunavut, was killed on Sept. 11, 2022. She had moved into an apartment and did not know her roommate. Nikolas Ibey has been charged with first-degree murder in connection to Pikuyak's death.\n\n\"I am here to honour her memory and the other women and girls that have gone missing or have been murdered,\" Arnatsiaq said. \"This does not have to happen anymore. It should not be happening anymore, so this is a powerful way of getting the word out that this is wrong, that this has to stop.\"\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, according to a 2022 Statistics Canada report.\n\n\"This is a genocide and it stems from systemic racism within society that we have to live today,\" says Brandy Stanovich, MMIWG2S+ Manager with the Native Women's Association of Canada\n(opens in a new tab)\n.\u00a0\"It\u2019s very important to understand the history, understand the causes around it and understand the work that needs to be done.\"\n\nOn Friday, the NWAC hosted youth council members from across the country, who discuss, share and ultimately help to resolve the individual issues faced in each province and territory.\n\nA new painting unveiled, which will be added to the NWAC MMIWG2S+ Vault Exhibition Space, including a large panel of handcrafted dolls, made by family members of missing and murdered loved ones.\u00a0\n\n\"This was painted by a Mi\u2019Kmaq artist Alan Syliboy\u00a0in honour of MMIWG2S+,\" Stanovich said. \"He painted this so Creator will always find them. It\u2019s called, All Women Not in This World and it says 'They are tendered from the Creator and others will return,' and that\u00a0means they will find them all\u00a0they might not be here to talk and we might not be able to see them but they are here in spirit.\"\n\nFor Arnatsiaq, days like this are the beginning of a conversation that she says needs to continue all year long.\n\n\"Changing attitudes, changing mindsets and appreciating life,\" she says. \"More awareness and more power and the change will eventually come.\"\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nA red dress is hangs on a light fixture during on National Day of Awareness for the prevention of violence against Indigenous women, also known as the Red Dress Day in Ottawa, on Friday, May 5, 2023. {"url": "https://www.campbellrivermirror.com/news/first-nations-leaders-in-bc-call-for-action-on-red-dress-day-7354007", "title": "First Nations leaders in B.C. call for action on Red Dress Day - Campbell River Mirror", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n23.6 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nFirst Nations leaders in B.C. call for action on Red Dress Day\nSunday honours the lives of Indigenous woman and girls who have gone missing or been murdered\nJane Skrypnek\nMay 5, 2024 11:20 AM\nMay 5, 2024 11:22 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nA jacket pictured at the Red Dress Day gathering in Vancouver on May 5, 2022. Recognized Canada-wide, the day honours the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQ people. (Jane Skrypnek/Black Press Media)\nListen to this article\n00:03:48\n\nSunday marks Red Dress Day across Canada and First Nations leaders in B.C. are using it to call on the federal government to take action on the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nBetween 2009 and 2021, 490 Indigenous women and girls were killed in Canada, a number six times higher than that experienced by their non-Indigenous counterparts. Indigenous woman are also far more likely to go missing and to experience physical and sexual violence.\n\nThe systemic issues driving this crisis were highlighted in June 2019 when the National Inquiry into MMIWG released its final report, Reclaiming Power and Place. In it, the commissioners made 231 Calls for Justice, but few have been fully implemented in the nearly five years since.\n\nOn Sunday, the B.C. Assembly of First Nations, First Nations Summit and the Union of B.C. Indian Chiefs called on Canada to take action.\n\n\u201cIt is shameful that the violence and fatalities of Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ peoples continue unabated in Canada and represent a tragic ongoing crisis that highlights the systemic injustices and vulnerabilities of First Nations communities. Canada must address the related issues and establish a clear timeline for implementing the 231 Calls for Justice,\u201d BCAFN Regional Chief Terry Teegee said in a statement.\n\nREAD ALSO: Red dresses at B.C fashion show honour missing and murdered Indigenous women\n\nREAD ALSO: Indigenous domestic violence victim shares her story and her Red Dress Day display\n\nChief Marilyn Slett, the UBCIC secretary-treasurer highlighted the violence Indigenous women and girls are more likely face around labour camps. In the Reclaiming Power and Place report, commissioners said they were told by expert witnesses that \u201cresource extraction can drive violence against Indigenous women and girls in several ways, including issues related to transient workers, harassment and assault in the workplace, rotational shift work, substance abuse/addictions, and economic insecurity.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, Slett said it is essential to address these safety concerns, especially given the prevalence of labour camps in B.C.\n\nCheryl Casimer, a First Nations Summit political executive, emphasized the discrimination and mistrust Indigenous people are more likely to face when interacting with police and the justice system.\n\n\u201cThis is evident in the biased treatment, inadequate investigations, and a lack of accountability for perpetrators.\u201d\n\nShe called for urgent policing reforms.\n\nB.C.\u2019s parliamentary secretary for gender equity also marked the day with a statement.\n\n\u201cIt is imperative that we continue to uplift and listen to the voices of Indigenous people and support self-determination of Indigenous communities in taking steps towards healing and justice. We also must address the root causes of violence, including colonialism, racism and misogyny,\u201d Kelli Paddon said.\n\nB.C. responded to the National Inquiry\u2019s final report on MMIWG by developing its own strategy in June 2021 called A Path Forward, which commits to preventing, protecting and responding to violence against Indigenous women and girls. The province has funded it with $10.8 million, as of March 2023.\n\nREAD ALSO: Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women, girls\n\nREAD ALSO: \u2018I just about became a missing, murdered woman\u2019: Kelowna Red Dress march\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tEverybody loves a parade! In Regina, an event was held at the RCMP Heritage Centre to highlight the date and educate the public.\n\n\u201cThe centre has been working on a vision to be a place of discovery, exploration, reflection and reconciliation, and for us, reconciliation starts with truth,\u201d RCMP Heritage Centre CEO Sam Karikas said.\n\nVisitors of the centre had the opportunity to take part in a variety of activities including beading, a screening of the film \u2018If I Go Missing,\u2019 an interactive map of the Indigenous People\u2019s of Canada Atlas, and to simply reflect on the hundreds of people who never came home to their families.\n\nDownload the CTV News app to get breaking news alerts sent to your device\n(opens in a new tab)\nRELATED STORIES\nOttawa families, survivors remember missing and murdered on Red Dress Day\nIndigenous groups in Canada mark Red Dress Day, raising awareness of MMIWG\n\u2018This isn\u2019t acceptable\u2019: On Red Dress Day, Sask. families plead for answers in MMIWG cases\n\nKrista Sherman was one of those in attendance. She brought along her daughter to teach her about the topic.\n\n\u201cI am part Indigenous and so is she, that makes it important to know what Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls Day means so that she is just aware as she grows up,\u201d she said.\n\nStatistically, Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to go missing according to the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nThe interactive map of the Indigenous People's of Canada Atlas at the RCMP Heritage Centre in Regina. {"url": "https://www.mbcradio.com/2022/05/fsin-marks-red-dress-day-calling-for-commitment-to-end-all-forms-of-violence", "title": "FSIN marks Red Dress Day calling for commitment to end all forms of violence - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nFSIN marks Red Dress Day calling for commitment to end all forms of violence\n\nby MBC News | May 5, 2022 | Current News\n\nAs First Nations mark Red Dress Day, a day to raise awareness for missing an murdered Indigenous women and girls, the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations has updated and launched a new declaration to assert more protections for all forms of violence faced by First Nations People.\n\n\u201cWe are calling on all levels of Government and our First Nations Institutions to adopt and uphold the Declaration to ensure we are reclaiming power and place,\u201d said Vice-Chief Aly Bear. \u201cWe need our society, institutions, and workplaces to be safe spaces where we no longer live in fear for ourselves and our family\u2019s safety daily. We need to have these standards upheld so we are given the respect and dignity owed to put an end to the ongoing violence inflicted daily.\u201d\n\nThe FSIN is calling for the implementation of the 231 Calls to Action contained in the final report issued by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cOur First Nations Women and Girls must be protected from the unacceptable levels of violence experienced in Canadian society and our communities,\u201d Chief Bobby Cameron said. \u201cThe time has come to acknowledge the truths and findings in The Final Report of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Women and Girls and to strive to create safer communities for all, through education and awareness.\u201d\n\nSask. lawmakers are expected today to debate the declaration.\n\nNDP MLA Betty Nippi-Albright explained there are actions the province can adopt to make change. \u201cThe call upon all levels of government to adopt principles of change, including a focus on substantial equality and human and indigenous rights are a decolonization approach, an indigenous led solutions, recognizing distinction, cultural safety, and adoption of a trauma informed approach,\u201d explained Nippi-Albright.\n\nRed Dress Day, which started in 2010, encourages people to wear a red dress or display it, as it acts a symbol to raise awareness to the violence Indigenous women face daily.\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},

[Photo: Gerry Lampow 106.1 The Goat/Vista Radio]\n- Advertisement -\n\nTo learn more about why Red Dress Day is important, students from several schools including Bishop Lloyd visited the Lloydminster Native Friendship Centre on Friday.\u00a0\n\nRed Dress Day is observed every year on May 5 to honour the missing and murdered Indigenous women and people who have been lost by their families.\u00a0\n\nThe students took part in a pipe ceremony in the morning, then walked from City Hall to the Clock Tower, and then back to the centre for lunch. After lunch, a mother who had lost both her sister and recently her son shared through her tears the tragedy of her loss.\u00a0\n\nAurora Champagne who is in grade eight said they learned about the culture and about the numbers of Indigenous people who go missing in Canada.\u00a0\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cI personally learned how many people go missing that are Indigenous. When I was younger, I always thought that it was not that many. But it\u2019s a lot more than I thought.\u201d\u00a0\n\nIndigenous women are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered than non-Indigenous women, according to a national survey. Stats Canada noted the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for non-Indigenous.\u00a0\n\nThe 14-year-old reflected that listening to Freda share about the loss of her family members was \u201chard to listen to.\u201d\u00a0\n\n\u201cShe was talking about how her sister got murdered and so did her son. I couldn\u2019t imagine having that happen to someone in my family.\u201d\u00a0\n\nThe students also learned about the meaning of the red dress.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt symbolizes the blood of the girls who went missing and got murdered. And it also symbolizes how the family still thinks of the heart pumping in their thoughts and in their prayers.\u201d\u00a0\n\nThe day which began at 10:30 a.m. wrapped up at 2 p.m.\u00a0\n\nThe next event being planned by the centre will be Indigenous Peoples Day on June 21.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue {"url": "https://panow.com/2024/05/03/canada-manitoba-to-develop-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls/", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\nNEWS\nSPORTS\nSOFTBALL WORLD CUP\nWEATHER\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\nBy Canadian Press\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nMay 3, 2024 | 1:04 PM\n\n\n\nOTTAWA \u2014 Canada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\u201cIn the lead-up to Red Dress Day, we keep those who have been stolen from their communities and this world in our thoughts, and we centre them in our action,\u201d said Crown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree.\n\n\u201cToday, as we announce this partnership to co-develop a Red Dress Alert system with Indigenous partners, we take the next steps toward bringing more Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit and gender-diverse people home.\u201d\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year\u2019s federal and provincial budgets.\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba\u2019s minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help put Indigenous women and girls at less risk.\n\n\u201cWe look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\u201d\n\nNDP MP Leah Gazan, whose efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system, called the announcement a small but significant step.\n\nGazan\u2019s fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system similar to Amber Alerts.\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state\u2019s Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry\u2019s 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 3, 2024.\n\nAlessia Passafiume, The Canadian Press\n\nby Canadian Press\nAround the Web\nAll Canadians Aged 40-80 May Qualify for {"url": "https://www.kenoraminerandnews.com/news/national/we-are-in-a-crisis-red-dress-day-honoured-as-leaders-say-more-work-to-be-done", "title": "\u2018We are in a crisis\u2019: Red Dress Day honoured | Kenora Miner", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nCanada\n\u2018We are in a crisis\u2019: Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\u00a0\n\nRed dresses recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People\n\nAuthor of the article:\nDonald Macdonald\nPublished May 06, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nRed Dress marchers in Sudbury: The head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there\u2019s an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released. PHOTO BY GREATER SUDBURY POLICE\nArticle content\n\nBy Kelly Geraldine Malone\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there\u2019s an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\n\nRed dresses were on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a mother. I\u2019m a sister. I\u2019m an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I\u2019m just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nA group hung 101 red dresses along a chain-link fence outside a landfill in the Manitoba capital over the winter. Winnipeg police have said the bodies of four Indigenous women were disposed of in landfills last year.\n\nThe remains of three of the women have not been found. A man has been charged with first-degree murder in the killings of the four women.\n\nThe remains of another Indigenous woman were also found in a landfill earlier this year. Police said her death is not a homicide.\n\n\u201cWhen I think (about it), I cry,\u201d DeLaronde said. \u201cI have to focus on the thousands of women and girls that are still here and how we can keep them safe.\u201d\n\nDeLaronde said it\u2019s important to recognize that Indigenous people are sacred, and they should not only be honoured when they are gone.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe House of Commons unanimously backed a motion Tuesday declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency. It also called for funding a new system to alert the public when someone goes missing.\n\n\u201cThe truth is the truth,\u201d said Leah Gazan, the Winnipeg member of Parliament who presented the motion. \u201cIt\u2019s one thing to acknowledge truth. It\u2019s another thing to act on it.\u201d\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada has criticized the federal government for not doing more or acting fast enough. McBride said Tuesday\u2019s motion was an important step, but there is more to do.\n\nMost of the money announced to fulfil the inquiry\u2019s 231 calls to justice became stuck in government bureaucracy, DeLaronde said, and it has not made it to the front lines and the Indigenous women and families who need it.\n\nDeLaronde added that all Canadians should use Red Dress Day to reflect on what they can do to create change.\n\n\u201cRed Dress is a movement that people can get behind, because it\u2019s an opportunity to transform the very fabric of this country.\u201d\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 5, 2023.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nNEWS NEAR KENORA\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
