Afua Baah has the details.\n\nBy Afua Baah\n\nPosted May 5, 2024 6:57 pm.\n\nSunday marked\u00a0Red Dress Day, also known as the National Day for Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People (MMIWG2S). This year, at Toronto Metropolitan University, the school\u00a0put together their first outdoor Red Dress Day exhibit.\n\nThe pieces of scarlet clothing unearth a painful part of her family\u2019s history for one local resident.\n\n\u201cMy little sister is on the list, she was murdered in the \u201960s, and there\u2019s no justice for her,\u201d said Bernice Lengarde, who has multiple family members on the MMIWG2S list. \u201cI also have cousins who are on the list, and their murders remain unsolved.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day was inspired by an installation project by M\u00e9tis\u00a0artist Jamie Black. The stark exhibit aimed to highlight the horrors many Indigenous women and girls have had to endure in their lives.\n\n\u201cIt helps educate those who don\u2019t know about the MMIWG2S, it helps them to understand that as Indigenous people, what we\u2019ve had to live with, and what we have to go through every day, and all these things are still happening today,\u201d said Lengarde.\n\nIn a report last year, Statistics Canada said between 2009 and 2021, the homicide rate among Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than their non-Indigenous counterparts.\u00a0A national inquiry\u00a0five years ago found\u00a0that they are also 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\nMany advocates have continued to\u00a0sound the alarm\u00a0on this horrific trend for years, with little movement until last week. On Friday, Canada and Manitoba announced a partnership for a Red Dress Alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl is reported missing.\n\nLocal resident Leslie Johnston also took time on Sunday to remember the victims, saying the community and governments can do more to be better allies.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had calls to action \u2026 and yet they\u2019ve not been implemented, and it\u2019s really upsetting and disappointing. {"url": "https://www.merrittherald.com/nvit-to-erect-permanent-red-dress-exhibit/", "title": "NVIT to erect permanent Red Dress exhibit - Merritt Herald", "body": "NEWS\nSPORTS\nCOMMUNITY\nJUNIOR REPORTERS\nOPINION\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nNVIT to erect permanent Red Dress exhibit\n\nPosted by Morgan Hampton | May 5, 2021 | News | 0 \n\nHerald file photo.\n\nNVIT had planned an event for Red Dress Day on May 5 in which a red dress, a symbol commemorating Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), would be unveiled at both the Merritt and Burnaby campuses. However, due to pandemic restrictions, the ceremonial unveiling cannot take place as planned.\n\n\u201cOf course, due to COVID 19 we decided that it wasn\u2019t safe to do such an event at this time, but we didn\u2019t want to let the day go by unrecognized,\u201d said Lesley Manuel, Information Services and Support Officer.\n\n\u201cAs BC\u2019s only Indigenous public post-secondary institution we are affected by this crisis on a daily basis. We have students from all across BC and Canada, who know of the story of at least one of the victims at some point,\u201d continued Manuel.\n\n\u201cWith this unveiling, we were expecting to not only speak about this crisis, but to create awareness of the violence that is happening to our life-givers and women warriors, and that we need to come together to help the victims and their families, to be their voice. As an aboriginal institution, we feel the need to help wherever we can.\u201d\n\nDespite no official ceremony on May 5, NVIT will go ahead with placing the dresses at both campuses. At the Merritt campus, the cabinet in which the dress is displayed, will be positioned on the main floor at the entrance to the eatery, and will be a permanent fixture.\n\n\u201cThis will help honour, and let our students know that we are not forgetting these missing and murdered women,\u201d said Manuel.\n\nWhen it is safe to do so, an official ceremony will take place at both the Burnaby and Merritt campus.\n\n\u201cThe students will hopefully be back in the fall, and once our students come back and we can all gather, we\u2019ll have a ceremony and have our unveiling on both campuses,\u201d said Kris Billy, Community Education Assistant.\n\nNVIT staff encourage people to help raise awareness for MMIWG, and the issues of gendered and racialized violence, by wearing red on May 5. Billy also hopes to see the people of Merritt hang red dresses from trees and fences on the day as well, to represent the \u201cstolen sisters\u201d who have had their lives cut short and will no longer return to their families.\n\nSHARE:\n\n \nPREVIOUS\nFlorentine giving up Complex Care License\nNEXT\nRED DRESS DAY: A history of the Highway of Tears\nRELATED POSTS\nLetter of referral approved for foreign entrepreneur\n\nApril 9, 2021\n\nMerritt receives $24 million grant for flood recovery\n\nApril 14, 2022\n\nMedical marijuana users win court-ordered reprieve\n\nMarch 27, 2014\n\nLessons in debt control ? consolidate to save\n\nApril 18, 2013\n\nNEWSLETTER\n\nFirst Name \n\nLast Name \n\nEmail address: \n\nCLASSIFIEDS\nMedical Office Assistant Position June 19, 2024\nSales Person/Office Admin May 15, 2024\nNVCL April 4, 2024\nRECENT OBITUARIES\nAlan Norman Clarence Taylor June 19, 2024\nFay Sturney June 19, 2024\nBeverly Jean Malchuk June 19, 2024\nSister Newspapers\nBowen Island Undercurrent\nBurnaby Now\nBusiness in Vancouver\nCastanet\nCoast Reporter\nDelta Optimist\nLethbridge Herald\nMedicine Hat News\nMoose Jaw Today\nNew West Record\nNorth Shore News\nPique Newsmagazine\nPowell River Peak\nPrince George Citizen\nREW.ca\nRichmond News\nSaskToday.ca\nSquamish Chief\nThe Orca\nTimes Colonist\nTriCity News\nVancouver is Awesome\nWestern Investor\nAirdrie Today\nAlberta Prime Times\nCochrane Today\nLakeland Today\nMountain View Today\nOkotoks Today\nRocky Mountain Outlook\nSt. Albert Gazette\nTown and Country Today\nOther Sections\nAbout Us\n\nAdvertise\n\nReal Estate\n\nClassifieds\n\nEvents\n\nMagazines\n\nSubscribe\n\nContact Us\n\nConnect\n\nMerritt Herald\n#201- 1951 Garcia Street,\nMerritt, BC V1K 1B8\n\nPhone\n1-250-378-4241\n\nAberdeen Publishing \u00a9 Copyright \u00ae\u00a02020.\u00a0\u00a0All rights reserved. The ongoing epidemic of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people is a national tragedy that demands urgent action and attention.\n\nWe support the call by MP Leah Gazan and others to implement a public alert system to inform all Canadians when an Indigenous woman, girl, or 2S+ person goes missing. The Government of Canada has a duty to Indigenous peoples and must take a leadership role, financially and otherwise, in implementing an MMIWG2S+ \u201cRed Dress\u201d alert system.\n\nWe also call on the Federal Government to urgently address violence against Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people and stop delaying important measures like the Red Dress Alert, because every moment is critical to saving lives.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOn Red Dress Day, we remember and continue to draw strength from the resilience and courage of our loved ones who have been lost to violence. On Red Dress Day, we honor their lives and commit ourselves to the important work of ensuring that no more Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people are lost to violence.\n\nMedia Contact\nFor media interviews please contact:\nHana Sabah, CAP Communications support\nCell: (514) 834-8841\nEmail: hana@impactcanada.com\n\nBackground\n\nThe Congress of Aboriginal Peoples (CAP) is the second-oldest national aboriginal organization in Canada. It was founded in 1971, one year after the AFN. CAP represents the interests of off-reserve status and non-status Indians, M\u00e9tis and Southern Inuit Aboriginal Peoples throughout Canada. CAP is one of five national Indigenous organizations recognized by the federal government, and holds consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council.\n\nTo view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/165058\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR KINGSTON\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

Photo taken May 5, 2023 in Saskatoon. PHOTO BY ROB O'FLANAGAN /Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nYoung advocates for social justice and a better, safer future congregated in front of Saskatoon City Hall on Friday to observe Red Dress Day and contribute to awareness of violence against Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\n\nGrade 9 students from Aden Bowman\u2019s Collegiate\u2019s Collective Voice program spent the week immersed in a \u201cdeep and difficult\u201d study of the issue in this country, their teacher said.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nFive concert events to see in Saskatoon in July\nWoman charged after altercation on city bus in Saskatoon's Confederation Park neighbourhood\nLetters: Sask. should embrace oil industry helping to expand education\nArticle content\n\nThey worked together on a stirring work of art in which the face of an Indigenous woman is covered with more than 300 names of people who have been murdered or gone missing.\n\nJinnoah Smith, left, and KyLynna Linklater believe society can rid itself of injustice and violence. They were part of a group from Aden Bowman Collegiate\u2019s Collective Voice program that gathered outside Saskatoon City Hall to spread awareness of Red Dress Day on May 5, 2023 in Saskatoon. PHOTO BY ROB O'FLANAGAN /Postmedia Network\n\nKyLanna Linklater, 14, said she has experienced fear of violence when she walks the streets in Saskatoon. Indigenous people make up about five per cent of the Canadian population, but Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people are 12 times more likely to be murdered than other groups in the country, they said.\n\n\u201cNow, to be able to fight for what I believe is right, is just amazing,\u201d Linklater said. \u201cIt is very special to finally have other advocates around you and to be an activist yourself. Even though we\u2019re teenagers, I feel it is awesome that we have people who will listen to us. We can be heard, and we can help others be heard.\u201d\n\n\u201cI really take a lot of joy and happiness in being involved in the community and seeing justice happening,\u201d said student Jinnoah Smith, 15. \u201cBeing about to go out and make a difference in the societal issues we have today is so important and special to me.\u201d\n\nTeacher Naila Chaudry said Collective Voice looks at the curriculum through a social justice lens, with an eye to understanding the issues facing communities.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cOne thing we value in education is a lived curriculum,\u201d Chaudry said. \u201cEducation is not merely knowing, it\u2019s taking that knowledge and doing something with it. Collective Voice helps students to learn about their past, about our history and current situations, but also to engage in a way that is meaningful.\u201d\n\nJinnoah Smith said they were raised in a family where social justice issues were openly discussed.\n\n\u201cSo I never understood the concept of how you could hate someone for being who they are,\u201d Smith said. \u201cI always wanted to help change that. I love making a difference. I always wanted to have the passion to help the people around me and do the most that I can.\u201d\n\nWhile many see the future as bleak, Linklater sees its potential.\n\n\u201cI think anything can be resolved,\u201d they said. \u201cIt\u2019s just a matter of what we, the people, do about it. We can make change happen. We are all so motivated to make everyone equal and to make up for everything awful that happened in history.\u201d\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nArt exhibit opens, Red Dress Day commemorated at Saskatchewan Legislature\nThe strength to speak: Faith Bosse's mother was taken 19 years ago. CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nCALGARY\nNews\n'Come together': Families, survivors remember the missing and murdered on Red Dress Day in Alberta\n01:59\nRed Dress Day in Edmonton\n01:54\nRed Dress Day\nBrendan Ellis\nDigital Producer\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 5, 2024 4:22 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nEvents were held across Alberta on Sunday marking Red Dress Day to honour the memory of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThe fourth annual Mohkinstsis MMEIP (Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples) Red Dress/Ribbon/Shirt Gathering was held in Calgary on Sunday.\n\nSurvivors and families gathered at the \u201cField of Red Ribbons\u201d \u2013 located on the corner of Memorial Drive and Centre Street.\n\nThe information you need to know, sent directly to you: Download the CTV News App\n\n\u201cWe put up all these dresses and all the ribbons on the trees, and they all represent our people that are missing and murdered,\u201d Sterling Green, a co-organizer of the event, said.\n\nThe event is held each year on Red Dress Day and focuses on honouring the families affected by the deaths of Indigenous people.\n\n\u201cThis is a day for us to put down our signs and lower our voices and to just come together and celebrate the lives of those who we have lost, our mothers, our aunts, our sisters, our best friends, and most importantly, also the men in our lives, our brothers, our uncle's, our friends,\u201d Hayley Starlight, who attended the walk, said.\n\nStarlight\u2019s cousin, Colton Crowshoe,\n(opens in a new tab)\n was killed in 2014. This July will mark 10 years since his death.\n\n\u201cFor the last 10 years, this trauma has impacted me mentally, emotionally, spiritually, and most importantly, physically,\u201d Starlight said.\n\nWiley Su Provost pleaded guilty to manslaughter in Crowshoe\u2019s death in 2023.\n\n\u2018She\u2019s never forgotten\u2019\n\nA walk was also held in Edmonton, where families, survivors and supporters walked down Jasper Avenue to remember the ones they\u2019ve lost.\n\nDonna Robillard, whose daughter, Carolann Robillard\n(opens in a new tab)\n, and granddaughter, Sara (Jayden) Miller, were killed last year, was at the walk with her family.\n\nThe 35-year-old mother and her 11-year-old daughter died on May 5, 2023.\n\n\u201cToday is their anniversary,\u201d Robillard said.\n\nRobillard was surrounded by several family members at the event, who were all there to remember Carolann and Sara.\n\n\u201cI know I\u2019m going to have some tears, and we\u2019re all going to have some tears,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cWell we\u2019re a big family and we\u2019re there for each other and we\u2019ve got a lot of support.\u201d\n\nTanisha Miller, Carolanne\u2019s daughter, said her mother and sister being gone still doesn\u2019t feel real.\n\n\u201cIt feels like they\u2019re still at home, could still call them,\u201d she said.\n\nShe described her sister and mother as adventurous people.\n\n\u201cThey loved to go out on adventures and just explore, go on walks. They were just so full of life,\u201d she said.\n\nJudith Gale, the leader of the Bear Claw Beaver Hills House, an Indigenous-led community organization in Edmonton, said all Indigenous people share a similar story and lived experience.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a day that we cherish deeply as it\u2019s a day for national awareness for missing and murdered exploited Indigenous peoples, two-spirited men, boys,\u201d Gale said.\n\n\u201cIt affects every Indigenous person on Turtle Island today. It\u2019s an ongoing genocide that we would like to stop.\u201d\n\nGale said she was walking to remember her sister, who was murdered in Montreal when she was 16 years old.\n\n\u201cToday I call her spirit to us to let her know that she\u2019s never forgotten,\u201d she said.\n\nWith files from CTV News Calgary\u2019s Tyler Barrow and CTV News Edmonton\u2019s Miriam Valdes-Carletti\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nA woman holds a sign at an event marking Red Dress Day in Edmonton on May 5, 2024. {"url": "https://www.benzinga.com/pressreleases/23/05/32248257/cap-commemorates-red-dress-day-and-call-on-the-federal-government-to-implement-a-red-dress-alert", "title": "CAP Commemorates Red Dress Day and Call on the Federal Government to Implement a Red Dress Alert - Benzinga", "body": "Get Benzinga Pro\nDATA & APIS\nEVENTS\nMARKETFY\nPREMARKET\nBOOST\nADVERTISE\nContribute\nSIGN IN\nOur Services\nNews\nMarkets\nOptions\nRatings\nIdeas\nMoney\nCrypto\nCannabis\nJobs\nRESEARCH\nMy Stocks\nTools\nRecent\nMarkets\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-\nCAP Commemorates Red Dress Day and Call on the Federal Government to Implement a Red Dress Alert\nby\nNewsfile\nMay 5, 2023 4:15 PM | 2 min read | Make a Comment\nLoading...\n\nOttawa, Ontario--(Newsfile Corp. - May 5, 2023) - Today, on Red Dress Day, the Congress of Aboriginal Peoples (CAP) lifts up all Indigenous peoples and communities across Turtle Island as we remember and honour the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people, and calls on the federal government to implement a red dress alert.\n\nSystemic discrimination, racism, and violence against Indigenous people has resulted in violence against and loss of our women, girls, and 2S+ people. The ongoing epidemic of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people is a national tragedy that demands urgent action and attention.\n\nWe support the call by MP Leah Gazan and others to implement a public alert system to inform all Canadians when an Indigenous woman, girl, or 2S+ person goes missing. The Government of Canada has a duty to Indigenous peoples and must take a leadership role, financially and otherwise, in implementing an MMIWG2S+ \"Red Dress\" alert system.\n\nWe also call on the Federal Government to urgently address violence against Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people and stop delaying important measures like the Red Dress Alert, because every moment is critical to saving lives.\n\nOn Red Dress Day, we remember and continue to draw strength from the resilience and courage of our loved ones who have been lost to violence. On Red Dress Day, we honor their lives and commit ourselves to the important work of ensuring that no more Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people are lost to violence.\n\nMedia Contact\nFor media interviews please contact:\nHana Sabah, CAP Communications support\nCell: (514) 834-8841\nEmail: hana@impactcanada.com\n\nBackground\n\nThe Congress of Aboriginal Peoples (CAP) is the second-oldest national aboriginal organization in Canada. It was founded in 1971, one year after the AFN. CAP represents the interests of off-reserve status and non-status Indians, M\u00e9tis and Southern Inuit Aboriginal Peoples throughout Canada. CAP is one of five national Indigenous organizations recognized by the federal government, and holds consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council.\n\nTo view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/165058\n\nMarket News and Data brought to you by Benzinga APIs\n\n\u00a9 2024 Benzinga.com. {"url": "https://www.merrittherald.com/nvit-opens-red-dress-memorial-garden/", "title": "NVIT opens red dress memorial garden - Merritt Herald", "body": "NEWS\nSPORTS\nCOMMUNITY\nJUNIOR REPORTERS\nOPINION\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nNVIT opens red dress memorial garden\n\nPosted by Izaiah Reyes | Mar 29, 2022 | News, Aboriginal, Development, Education, Trending | 0 \n\nPhoto/ Izaiah Reyes\n\nNVIT hosted an opening ceremony for the new Red Dress Memorial Garden on Monday, March 21.\n\nThe memorial was built to honour the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls (MMIWG) and the LGBTQ2S+ individuals.\n\n\u201cThe MMIWG2S Memorial Project is a meaningful project,\u201d said NVIT Vice President for Students, Sterling-Bur. \u201cIt is important that Merritt has a space to reflect, honour and remember our lost loved one to this category.\u201d\n\nA committee consisting of representatives from parents of MMIWG, Union of BC Indian Chiefs, local chiefs, NVIT, and Conayt Friendship Society oversaw the development of the project.\n\n\u201cThe situation with the MMIWG across Canada, with the numbers being so high, it should really be a national emergency and really it isn\u2019t,\u201d said Kelly L\u2019Hirondelle, Executive Director of Conayt Friendship Society.\n\n\u201cWe really want to shed light on this issue because Indigenous women, girls and two spirit shouldn\u2019t go missing on a regular basis.\u201d\n\nThe ceremony included singing, hand drumming and prayer to bless the new space. After the blessing attendees were asked to head to the atrium by the main entrance of the NVIT building to witness the unveiling of the red dress in the cabinet display.\n\nThe cabinet for the red dress display was created by a silent volunteer who had heard about NVIT indiginization committee\u2019s planned display.\n\n\u201cIt was a complete donation and it turned out beautiful,\u201d said Lesley Manuel, assistant to VP for students at NVIT.\n\nThe memorial garden was funded by Women and Gender Equality Canada in 2019, however, due to the pandemic, operations were severely delayed.\n\nLocated at the green space by the main parking lot, the memorial consists of a pit house surrounded by five landscaping boulders, courtesy of the City of Merritt. There is also a sign that is dedicated to the MMIWG and LGBTQ2S+ individuals.\n\nThe pit house was stained red to represent the MMIWG movement and there were several red dresses hung on the surrounding trees as per the suggestion of fellow MMIWG advocate, Krista Fox.\n\nNVIT students Melissa Moses, Chelsea Johnnie, and Keaton Robinson built the pit house with the assistance of instructor, Clayton Anthony.\n\nAlthough the space is now open, NVIT is still making plans to add a water feature to the memorial. Water has spiritual significance and is symbolic for healing for the families and loved ones affected by this issue.\n\nSHARE:\n\n \nPREVIOUS\nInterior Savings waives fees and commits $5000 to support Ukrainian refugees\nNEXT\nRCMP seize sawed off rifle after assault\nNEWSLETTER\n\nFirst Name \n\nLast Name \n\nEmail address: \n\nCLASSIFIEDS\nMedical Office Assistant Position June 19, 2024\nSales Person/Office Admin May 15, 2024\nNVCL April 4, 2024\nRECENT OBITUARIES\nAlan Norman Clarence Taylor June 19, 2024\nFay Sturney June 19, 2024\nBeverly Jean Malchuk June 19, 2024\nSister Newspapers\nBowen Island Undercurrent\nBurnaby Now\nBusiness in Vancouver\nCastanet\nCoast Reporter\nDelta Optimist\nLethbridge Herald\nMedicine Hat News\nMoose Jaw Today\nNew West Record\nNorth Shore News\nPique Newsmagazine\nPowell River Peak\nPrince George Citizen\nREW.ca\nRichmond News\nSaskToday.ca\nSquamish Chief\nThe Orca\nTimes Colonist\nTriCity News\nVancouver is Awesome\nWestern Investor\nAirdrie Today\nAlberta Prime Times\nCochrane Today\nLakeland Today\nMountain View Today\nOkotoks Today\nRocky Mountain Outlook\nSt. Albert Gazette\nTown and Country Today\nOther Sections\nAbout Us\n\nAdvertise\n\nReal Estate\n\nClassifieds\n\nEvents\n\nMagazines\n\nSubscribe\n\nContact Us\n\nConnect\n\nMerritt Herald\n#201- 1951 Garcia Street,\nMerritt, BC V1K 1B8\n\nPhone\n1-250-378-4241\n\nAberdeen Publishing \u00a9 Copyright \u00ae\u00a02020.\u00a0\u00a0All rights reserved. During Monday\u2019s council meeting, Mayor Lori Acke\u2026\nBY ENERGETICCITY.CA STAFF \u25cf NEWS \u25cf APRIL 26, 2021 \u25cf 2 MINUTES OF READING\n\nFORT ST. JOHN, B.C. \u2013 A red dress has been hung in City Hall.\n\nDuring Monday\u2019s council meeting, Mayor Lori Ackerman proclaimed May 5th as National Day of Remembrance for Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People in the City of Fort St. John.\n\nAn email and video submitted by Trystan Jones to council suggested the city take part in the demonstration.\n\n\u201cI know in Trystan\u2019s letter he requested that we display [the dress] outside. I know we are expecting some hectic weather up north here again, so I\u2019m going to recommend we display the red dress prominently in our lobby,\u201d says Ackerman.\n\nThe letter highlighted the show of solidarity for the Red Dress Project in Ladysmith, and the information in the MMIWG Report indicates issues that are relevant in Fort St. John.\n\nLatest Stories\nEnvironment Canada issues multiple warnings as B.C. braces for weekend heat\nSilverberry Secure Landfill to possibly undergo new management\nB.C. NDP ministers Bains, Ralston and Fleming won\u2019t seek re-election\nB.C. seniors advocate seeks tenancy protection for residents of retirement homes\n\n\u201cThe report detailed how there was a direct correlation to resource extraction based communities and MMIWG. We as a community must be cognizant of these findings and the show of solidarity from the elected leaders at Ladysmith City Hall and its First Nations showcase what good leadership looks like,\u201d said Jones in an email.\n\nThe demonstration has become a symbol of recognition across Canada, hanging a red dress to illustrate the issue.\n\n\u201cMore than 1,200 Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people have gone missing or been murdered since 1980,\u201d says the proclamation.\n\n\u201cIndigenous women and families have been calling for awareness to be drawn to this issue by hanging a red dress as part of the Red Dress Project one week before May 5th to one week after, to honour the women, girls, and two-spirit peoples who have gone missing or been murdered.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\n\nReport a typo or an error\n\nRead our guiding principles\n\nStay connected with local news\n\nMake us your\n\nhome page\n\nDownload\n\nour App\n\nJoin our\n\nNewsletter\n\nGet news\n\ntexted to you\n\nAuthor\nENERGETICCITY.CA STAFF\nPost navigation\n\u2190 Previous Post\nNext Post \u2192\nMost Recent Stories\nSilverberry Secure Landfill to possibly undergo new management\nBY MAX BOWDER \u25cf NEWS \u25cf JULY 4, 2024\n\nSECURE Energy Services Inc. has applied to the B.C. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/red-dress-project-raising-awareness-about-missing-murdered-women-1.2350638", "title": "Red Dress Project raising awareness about missing, murdered women - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nRed Dress Project raising awareness about missing, murdered women\nA Prince George woman's childhood best friend tragically died at the hands of another.\nChristine Hinzmann\nSep 23, 2016 10:46 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nA Prince George woman's childhood best friend tragically died at the hands of another.\n\nIt's the 19th anniversary of Kari Anne Gordon's death and Tammy Meise can't seem to get off the roller coaster that rushes her through a tumult of strong emotions about it even to this day.\n\nGordon's body was discovered by hikers at Little Lillooet Lake in spring of 1998.\n\nShe went missing in fall of 1997.\n\nEver since, there have always been more questions than answers.\n\nThings came to a head for Meise during a time when life was moving full speed ahead.\n\nShe went to Vancouver in 2014 for the B.C. Federation of Labour conference as a member of the Hospital Employees' Union.\n\nWhen Meise stepped inside the convention centre what she saw literally stopped her breath.\n\nShe looked up to see a stunning display of beautiful red dresses hanging from the rafters.\n\nMeise had to take a moment to read what the display was all about. It was Jaime Black's The Red Dress Project that brings awareness to the missing and murdered aboriginal women across Canada.\n\nThe art display had a great impact on Meise and she never could shake it.\n\nThis year Meise saw how far reaching the issue of missing and murdered women is in Canada and quickly realized that because the many local women who have been lost were not all aboriginal she needed to take her idea and make it more inclusive.\n\n\"I was mulling it over and mulling it over and I realized I just had to do this,\" said Meise, who works in Northern Health's mental health and addictions department.\n\n\"The Prince George Red Dress Campaign will bring awareness and give a voice to all murdered and missing women.\"\n\nThe event will begin Monday with Mr. P.G. at the corners of Highway 16 and 97 holding a flag in honour of the occasion.\n\n\nOn Sunday, Oct. 2, about 100 people will meet at the Petro Canada west of town at 1:30 p.m., with a police escort, and line up along the highway each holding a red dress on a hanger to symbolize those lost and murdered along the Highway of Tears.\n\n\"It's an empty dress - they are no longer here - and this is to give back a voice to those that were taken so these women are not forgotten regardless of race,\" said Meise.\n\nOnce the group takes a stand, they will be attending at Lheidli T'enneh Memorial Park where the red dresses participants held along the highway will be hung in the trees around the Kiwanis bandshell in the park.\n\nAt 5 p.m. a city official will say a few words, along with a First Nations elder and chief, and performers including singer-songwriter Kym Gouchie, from the Lheidli T'enneh Nation, and traditional drummers and dancers. A candlelight vigil will follow to honour the missing and murdered.\n\n\"There was never any closure for me about Kari,\" said Meise.\n\n\"I am hoping this is my healing journey and if I can open this up to someone else to walk one step on their healing journey, well you know what? It was worth it.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. Bain, My PG Now staff)\n- Advertisement -\n\nA large gathering started at the Red Dress Monument in Prince George today, commemorating the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nThe gathering started with a stand-in at the monument, before moving to the House of Ancestors.\n\nStand in at the Red Dress Monument on Red Dress Day (D. Bain, My PG Now staff)\n\nThere, families of those who have gone missing or have been murdered shared stories of their grief and their loved ones.\n\nIn addition, it was announced there is $1.3 million over three years in the federal budget for the co-development of a regional emergency notification system with Indigenous partners.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cI will acknowledge that that is not enough, it is a first step in the right direction, and there is much more work to do,\u201d said NDP Treasurer Sussanne Skidmore.\n\n\u201cOn Friday, it was welcomed the historic announcement of a Red Dress Alert pilot program that will be happening in Winnipeg, in Manitoba. When implemented, this alert system will notify the public when an Indigenous woman, girl or gender-diverse person goes missing, so they can be brought home safely.\u201d\n\nOn Red Dress Day, New Democrats honour all who continue to work tirelessly to end the ongoing genocide of MMIWG2S+ people including families, survivors, advocates and Indigenous women.\n\nFor too long this crisis has been neglected \u2013 but, thanks to the hard work of families,\u2026\n\n\u2014 Jagmeet Singh (@theJagmeetSingh) May 5, 2024\n\nThe day ended with a walk back to the Red Dress Monument.\n\n\u00a0\n\nSomething going on in the Prince George area you think people should know about?\nSend us a news tip by emailing pgnews@vistaradio.ca.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nNews\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\nNews\nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\nNews\nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\nNews\nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\n \nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\n \nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\n \nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\n \nSeven week old Cariboo Regional District strike is now over\nCity of Quesnel responds to petition filed against it by Mayor Ron Paull\n \nBC Transit to provide new bus shelters in PG\n \nTimberwolves land Spanish shooting guard\n \nFour Rivers Co-op cardlock locations fully operational after cybersecurity incident\n \nBrendan\u2019s Sports Shorts; {"url": "https://citizen.on.ca/red-dress-exhibit-at-mod-honours-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Red Dress exhibit at MoD honours missing and murdered indigenous women\u00a0|\u00a0Orangeville Citizen", "body": "Members Login: \u00a0 \u00a0 Log in\nOrangevilleCitizen\n\u00a0\nHome\nNews/Entertainment\nHeadline News\nGeneral News\nSports\nArts and Entertainment\nOur Issues\nCurrent Issue\nArchived Issues\nReal Estate\nResale Homes Collections\nCommunity Notices\nCommunity Links\nOrangeville Notice Board\nOur Papers\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nArchive\nRed Dress exhibit at MoD honours missing and murdered indigenous women\n\nMay 11, 2023 \u00a0\u00a0\u00b7\u00a0\u00a0 0 Comments\n\nBy Paula Brown, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter\n\nThe Museum of Dufferin (MoD) is paying homage to missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited people with a red dress display.\n\n\u201cThis is the first time that we\u2019ve done a Red Dress Day display and we hope to continue to do this into the future, and that this is something that other sites, or community organizations might join in and do as well,\u201d said Sarah Robinson, interim museum services manager.\n\nThe MoD\u2019s red dress display consists of around 30 dresses that were donated to the museum by members of the community during a callout back in March. The display is located on the front lawn of the museum and includes informational signage for those who drive a loop of the museum\u2019s driveway.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one thing that we can do to participate,\u201d said Robinson. \u201cAt museums, it\u2019s our job to decolonize and create spaces where the stories and words of Indigenous people can be heard. Especially, I think, because the museum historically was found using the collections of European settlers, and so it\u2019s important to create the space for Indigenous artists and for the history of Indigenous people.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day was inspired in 2010 by Jamie Black, a M\u00e9tis artist based in Winnipeg, who hung hundreds of empty red dresses in public places to represent missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and raise awareness.\n\nRed Dress Day is held annually on May 5, the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) and Two-spirited people.\n\nAccording to Statistics Canada, the rate of homicide of Indigenous women in 2014 was almost six times higher than non-Indigenous women.\n\nAs part of their recognition of Red Dress Day, the Museum of Dufferin had a special ribbon skirt created by Sharon Rigby, a local Indigenous artist. The ribbon skirt is on display inside the museum.\n\n\u201cI am of Haudensaunee/Algonquin heritage and have spent the last three years exploring and learning many different elements of my culture. When I am creating, I am in a safe space. The noise of the world fades and the hum of good energy permeates my very being and the air around me,\u201d said Rigby. \u201cMaking this skirt was different. The hand appliques show in degrees, my grief and sadness concerning MMIWG. The first two hands are stitched on with a straight stitch and red thread. The second hand I painted a red border around the hand as I started to cry. The third hand I stitched in zigzag messily through my tears.\u201d\n\nSpeaking with the Free Press, Robinson talked about the display\u2019s community impact.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a chance for people to reflect, remember, and take action to do their own research on what Red Dress Day is and what it represents. It\u2019s for everyone to become aware of the thousands of Indigenous women, girls and two-spirted people who have been subjected to disproportionate violence in Canada.\u201d\n\nThe Red Dress Day display at the Museum of Dufferin will remain up until May 12.\n\nRobinson noted that the local museum has worked with community elder Karen Vandenberg on how the dresses will be respectfully stored after the display is taken down.\n\nSharon Rigby\u2019s ribbon skirt commemorating Red Dress Day will remain on display in the museum throughout May.\n\nFor those interested in seeing the piece in-person, the operating hours of the Museum of Dufferin are Tuesday to Saturday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.\n\n\n\nReaders Comments (0)\n\n\n\nName (required)\n\n\nEmail Address (required)\n\n\nWebsite (optional)\n\n\nPlease note: Comment moderation is enabled and may delay your comment. {"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/islander/charla-huber-red-dresses-are-a-reminder-for-us-all-1.24311364", "title": "Charla Huber: Red dresses are a reminder for us all - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n22.2 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Opinion\nCharla Huber: Red dresses are a reminder for us all\nA few weeks ago, I created a small community activity that encouraged families to decorate boats and float them in local waterways and post photos on social media.\nCharla Huber\nApr 25, 2021 6:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nA red dress hanging off of the side of the highway, close to the Snaw-Naw-As (Nanoose) Nation. ANNA McKENZIE, THE DISCOURSE, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE\n\nA few weeks ago, I created a small community activity that encouraged families to decorate boats and float them in local waterways and post photos on social media. As I delivered little wooden boats to interested participants\u2019 home, I came to one house that had a red dress hanging from a tree at the edge of the driveway.\n\nHanging red dresses honours and acknowledges missing and murdered Indigenous women. Use of this symbol began in 2010 and is known as the Red Dress Project, originating in Manitoba. Now many different initiatives and organizations promote red dresses to bring awareness to missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nWhen I drove up to the home and saw the dress intentionally hanging from a tree, I felt an emotional response. Hanging a red dress is a strong statement and it demonstrates solidarity.\n\nI am not sure why that one dress connected with me, but I think it is because I didn\u2019t expect to see it. It made me feel appreciation for the people who took the time and effort to hang the dress and make the statement. These statements spark conversations between people and make space for everyone to be reminded.\n\nRed dresses have been popping up on our highways for months now, as part of a local initiative that started on Family Day in February, and dresses continue to appear.\n\nThe red dresses bring awareness to an uncomfortable but needed conversation. These dresses represent people and their families. When I see a red dress, I know it represents someone who is gone.\n\nI was disappointed to watch the video of two men removing red dresses along the highway south of Ladysmith. The act is disrespectful and hurtful. We do not know the story behind these actions, but it undermines the work of the people who hung them. It silences this movement and sends the message that these stories should not be told.\n\nIt is not easy to see the dresses, because they are meant to remind all of us of the harsh reality that Indigenous women and families face. By having the dresses on display, it demonstrates this an issue that affects everyone, regardless of their heritage. We are all a part of the community, and everyone in our community deserves to be safe.\n\nI have spoken with people whose family members are missing or murdered. I\u2019ve known Indigenous women who have been victimized while hitchhiking along highways. These are tragedies that occur across Canada.\n\nIt was beautiful to see Stz\u2019uminus First Nation and the Town of Ladysmith come together to hang red dresses last weekend where others had been torn down. It is acts like this that demonstrate this is an issue that everyone needs to address and acknowledge together.\n\nOn Vancouver Island, red dresses can be seen hanging along the highway from Victoria to Port Hardy. We may not be travelling the highways right now, but if you see a red dress hanging in your neighbourhood, take a moment to reflect on what it represents.\n\nThis is not just an Indigenous issue, it is a community issue. Everyone has the right to be safe. There are grieving families who struggle to find answers, and hanging a red dress, or taking the time to reflect on what they symbolize, can be a step forward in working together.\n\nMay 5th is the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and is also known as Red Dress Day.\n\ncharla@makola.bc.ca\n\nCharla Huber is the Director of Communications and Indigenous Relations for M\u2019akola Housing Society.\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has not been shared. (Ethan Ready, MyPGNow staff)\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cWhen I saw that art project, it spoke to me.\u201d\n\nTammy Meise, the woman responsible for bringing the Red Dress Society to the City of Prince George, reflected on what brought on the urge to raise awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\n21 years ago, Meise\u2019s childhood friend was murdered, only to have her body later found at the high watermark of the outflow of Little Lillooet Lake. While she wasn\u2019t killed along the Highway of Tears, Meise points out that nonetheless, her friend is still a victim.\n\nThe REDress Project was initially started by a Winnipeg-based Meti artist by the name of Jaime Black nearly ten years ago.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nA group setting up at the intersection of Highway 16 and 97, honouring the victims of the Highway of Tears. #CityofPG #HighwayOfTears pic.twitter.com/fft02UZfns\n\n\u2014 Ethan Ready ?\ufe0f (@EthanReady) September 8, 2019\n\nBlack collected hundreds of donated red dresses that were then later displayed in public spaces across Canada, including the Canadian Museum of Human Rights for a one-day display.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know why I was chosen to do this,\u201d Meise told MyPGNow. \u201cI just know that I was, that I needed to be a part of something bigger than myself, to hold a safe space for other people that needed to walk their healing journey. It\u2019s where we support one another.\u201d\n\nShe added that the Red Dress Campaign acts as a way to give a voice back to all the women and girls who have been taken.\n\n\u201cWhen we do this year after year, we ensure that they\u2019re never forgotten.\u201d\n\nSunday\u2019s schedule fo events kicked off with the \u201cStand In\u201d at the intersection of Highway 16 and 97.\n\nThere, they marched together, red dresses in tow as they lined along the side of the highway.\n\nWhile the day marked the Society\u2019s schedule of events here in Prince George, it was also designed to help boost awareness for the official event, which is held on October 4th, which marks National Day of Vigils to Remember Murdered and Missing Aboriginal Women.\n\nAccording to the April 22, 2016 background on the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, from 1980 to 2012, Indigenous women and girls represented 16 per cent of all female homicides in Canada while representing only 4 per cent of the female population in Canada.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nA 2011 Statistics Canada report estimated that from 1997 and 2000, the rate of homicide for Aboriginal females was almost seven times higher than other females.\n\nThose driving by the iconic Mr PG over the next little while may notice a new flag waving in the hand of the timberman.\n\n\u201cThis flag right here, it\u2019s the Prince George Red Dress Society\u2019s actual official flag. It goes up at the beginning of the week, and that to us is the kickoff to the campaign. People see the flag and then they start the conversation, whether it\u2019s good, bad, or ugly\u2026 it starts the conversation.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\n\nSomething going on in the Prince George area you think people should know about?\nSend us a news tip by emailing pgnews@vistaradio.ca.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nNews\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\nNews\nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\nNews\nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\nNews\nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\n \nPG Chamber of Commerce critical of City for borrowing money for Aquatic Centre upgrades\n \nPG Pride Society preparing for annual pride week, ending with parade\n \nWorkSafe urging employers to be conscious as heat wave approaches\n \nSeven week old Cariboo Regional District strike is now over\nCity of Quesnel responds to petition filed against it by Mayor Ron Paull\n \nBC Transit to provide new bus shelters in PG\n \nTimberwolves land Spanish shooting guard\n \nFour Rivers Co-op cardlock locations fully operational after cybersecurity incident\n \nBrendan\u2019s Sports Shorts; Thursday, July 4th\nCanadian Indigenous Music\n \nMornings with Carol\n \nAfternoons With Tim Gavin\n \nPG SAC Voices, With Lynnell and Kendra\nCanadian Indigenous Music\n \nVinyl Power\n \nThe Morning Breath with Robert and Silvio\n \nMiddays With Kurt Flesher\n \nThe Afternoon Drive With Ryan Mitchell\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nContact Us\nContest Rules\nAdvertise\nWe\u2019re Hiring"},
{"url": "https://www.620ckrm.com/2024/05/05/what-does-red-dress-day-mean/", "title": "What Does Red Dress Day Mean? \u2013 620 CKRM", "body": "Facebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nApple Store\nGoogle Play\nAsk Alexa\nON THE AIR\nThe SportsCage\n3:00 pm - 4:00 pm\nWhat Does Red Dress Day Mean?\n\nby\n\nTanner Wallace-Scribner\n\nMay 5, 2024\n\nMay 5th marks Red Dress Day.\n\nThe day raises awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit+ people in Canada and was inspired by M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black\u2019s installation project, which saw red dresses hung in public spaces throughout Canada and the United States as visual reminders of the number of Indigenous women who have been killed or are missing.\u00a0\n\nThe movement has grown, with local communities hosting walks, events and educational gatherings.\n\nMLA for Saskatoon Centre Betti Nippi-Albright said the day serves as a constant reminder of those who are still missing.\n\n\u201cRed Dress Day is a reminder of the deep pain and trauma Indigenous communities have endured and continue to endure when those we love have been taken from us. It means remembering and honouring our loved ones that have not made it home yet and standing with my relatives and the communities that have been affected.\u201d\n\nShe said it\u2019s also a reminder of the ongoing issues surrounding\u00a0ongoing issues with gender-based violence, especially against Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit individuals.\n\n\u201cWe must take a stand for the rights of Indigenous people while underscoring the importance of equality and justice. It\u2019s also a reminder that we as a society must recognize and address the disproportionate violence and discrimination faced by Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit people as a result of colonialism, racism, and patriarchy.\u201d\n\nNippi-Albright added that people must\u00a0commit to taking meaningful action to address the systemic violence and injustice faced by Indigenous people and that we have to listen to and center the voices and experiences of Indigenous communities in our efforts to create that meaningful change.\n\nIndigenous artist Teagan Littlecheif\u00a0said Red Dress Day means a chance to highlight the struggles indigenous women face, specifically around violence.\n\n\u201cIt raises awareness about the disproportionate violence faced by Indigenous women,\u201d she said. \u201cIt honours their lives and advocates for justice.\u201d\n\nIndigenous women and girls in Canada remain highly overrepresented as victims of violence. Between 2009 and 2021, the homicide rate among Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than their non-Indigenous counterparts, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\n\nKim Coltman, organizer of the two-day Revolutions Red Dress Fashion Festival in Kamloops,\u00a0says the eight designers taking part in the festival have created items to honour Red Dress Day.\n\n\u201cFor the majority of them, they have been touched by this issue personally,\u201d Coltman says.\n\nColtman\u2019s mother was a residential school survivor from Red Pheasant Cree Nation in Saskatchewan.\u00a0\n\nColtman also describes herself as survivor. Her childhood was marred by stays in foster care. She was abducted and assaulted as a teen. She says she knows all too well the world that Indigenous women can live in.\n\nIt was fashion that empowered Coltman. She signed with a modelling agency in 1972 and later created her own.\u00a0\n\nBut the issue of violence toward Indigenous women and girls remained close to her heart.\u00a0\n\nWhen she saw the red dress movement, Coltman says she was inspired, and in 2015 she founded Fashion Speaks International. The organization has produced fashion shows in Canada, Australia and France highlighting Indigenous designers, models and artists. Each show also brings attention to missing women through stories and photos.\n\nColtman says it\u2019s powerful watching Indigenous models hold their heads high as they walk the runway. It breaks behaviours pushed on the estimated 150,000 Indigenous children who were forced to attend residential schools, she says.\n\n\u201cThe residential school taught them that they were to be seen not heard, and they were to look at their feet when they walk,\u201d she says. \u201cWe need to make our people less invisible.\u201d\n\nDarlene Okemaysim-Sicotte has been on the front lines working to end violence against Indigenous women in Saskatchewan for nearly two decades.\u00a0\n\nAs co-chair of Iskwewuk E-wichiwitochik (Women Walking Together), she has supported many families of those who have disappeared.\u00a0\n\nOkemaysim-Sicotte says red is a colour ancestors can see, so it\u2019s powerful to see red garments placed in public spaces across the country.\u00a0\n\nBut, Okemaysim-Sicotte adds, it\u2019s important people look beyond the dresses to the women they represent.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are doing this because of the missing people, and they shouldn\u2019t be forgotten,\u201d she says.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThey need to be remembered.\u201d\n\nA support line is available for those impacted by missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and Two-Spirit+ people. For immediate emotional assistance, call 1-844-413-6649.\n\nWith files from The Canadian Press\n\n\n\n\nX\nEmail\nCopy Link\nShare\nMore from 620 CKRM\nSaskatchewan files for injunction over Canada Revenue Agency collecting carbon money\nGame Day Retro!\nShowers, Thunderstorms Expected Today and Tonight\nCo-op experiencing empty shelves, shipment delays from ongoing cyberattack\nFunnel clouds possible in parts of Saskatchewan today\nRiders v Argos Primer\nAround The Web\nAll Canadians Aged 40-80 May Qualify for This $250,000 Tax-free Life Benefit\nDollarGuardian\nTop Doctor: Forget Retinol, Use This Household Item to Fill in Wrinkles!\nNeotonics\nEdmonton: Unsold 2023 Suvs Are on Sale (Take a Look at Prices)\nSUV | Search ads\nArthritis or Joint Pain? {"url": "https://www.cowichanvalleycitizen.com/community/tsow-tun-le-lum-society-and-cowichan-tribes-join-forces-for-first-time-for-red-dress-day/", "title": "Tsow-Tun Le Lum Society and Cowichan Tribes join forces for first time for Red Dress Day - Cowichan Valley Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.8 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Community\nTsow-Tun Le Lum Society and Cowichan Tribes join forces for first time for Red Dress Day\nRain did not prevent Cowichan Valley community members uniting for the Red Dress Day\nChadd Cawson\nMay 5, 2023 4:06 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nMay 5 marked Red Dress Day. A day where hearts hang heavy as red dresses drape with honour, and pride throughout numerous communities across the nation to remember and raise awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, and Girls (MMIWG) who were taken too soon, and lost to the hands of violence.\n\nTsow-Tun Le Lum Society which means \u2018helping house\u2019 partnered up with Cowichan Tribes for the first time, to hold an event to remember, educate, and raise awareness for all the women, girls, men, boys, and two-spirited that have gone missing. The rain did not stop all walks of life from coming out in droves to walk or run 5k, or 10k while creating a sense of community at 5574 River Rd. in Duncan. The event opened at noon, and the walk began shortly after 1 p.m.\n\n\u201cFor some reason, in some people\u2019s heads, our lives are not worth as much as other people\u2019s, other women\u2019s lives,\u201d said Tsow-Tun Le Lum Society executive director Nola Jeffrey. \u201cIt\u2019s our men too, and our boys that have gone missing, so it\u2019s important that we come out and that we walk together, and I mean all nations walking together to create awareness and to stop this. To say every child matters, every human being matters, every woman matters.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day, also known as the Red Dress Campaign, sparked from the REDress Project which was first conceived on May 5, 2010 in Winnipeg, Manitoba through the inspired work of M\u00e9tis artist Jamie Black. When Black was told by one of her Indigenous friends that red is the only colour spirits can see, and that is actually a callback for spirits to be among us again, a red dress became the catalyst for her display at the University of Winnipeg. It featured many hung empty to honour and symbolize all Indigenous women and girls lost to violence.\n\nREAD MORE: Red Dress Day honours Canada\u2019s missing and murdered Indigenous people\n\nThe annually recognized Red Dress Day draws attention to more than 1,000 Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada.\n\nThe country continues to take steps towards truth and reconciliation. It was earlier this week on May 2, that the House of Commons adopted a motion to declare ongoing violence against Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people a national emergency. This news was announced during the opening ceremony before the walk got underway in Duncan, inspiring applause from all in attendance. It was heartwarming to witness a large, wet crowd come together to raise awareness after years of the pandemic preventing community events. However, COVID did not cease Tsow-Tun Le Lum from continuing to raise awareness and educate the masses through their virtual event they held in 2021 which spanned 60 days.\n\n\u201cWe were already active prior to COVID, and then we did this,\u201d said Jeffrey. \u201cWe had well over 3,000 people register for the virtual walk, and people were posting their walks daily. It was just not across B.C. but all across Canada as well. We had a logo contest the year prior to design shirts, and mailed out over 3,000 shirts that year.\u201d\n\nAll that came out for the cause were invited to stay for food, performances, and closing remarks and prayers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s extremely important for the community to come together on this day,\u201d said Jeffrey. \u201cWhat the families want and really need is to be able to come together, and share their stories, and see how they can get support, and how they can get information. I think that we don\u2019t forget, that we always remember, and one of the teachings I talk about is coming from a place of love, a place of caring, a place of kindness, so that we can have respect and honour for each other. Most importantly it lets the families know that they are not alone, and that there are places like Tsow-Tun Le Lum that they can reach out to, and that we have supports for them.\u201d\n\n\nchadd.cawson@cowichanvalleycitizen.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\nAbout the Author: Chadd Cawson\n\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tEditorial: Bypass of Duncan corridor not worth it\n\t\tDuncan to get new $7-million urgent and primary care centre\n\t\tPolice ask for help to find man missing from Youbou\n\t\tBig Brothers Big Sisters Cowichan chapter forced to shut down\n\t\tCongratulations to the Cowichan Secondary Class of 2024\nFacebook Comments (0) \nStolen Duncan school backpack leads to 15-month jail sentence\nBlack Press Media\nPort Coquitlam convicted murderer dead in Greater Victoria institution\nBlack Press Media\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nCanadians Born Before Before 1972 With No Life Insurance Are Taking Advantage Of This\nCovered For Life\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nClaim Your Secret Bonus: 25 Free Spins on Top of the Usual Bonus\nReviewer reveals Trust Pilot Ratings and a Secret Bonus at Canada's Top Online Casino. {"url": "https://www.saultstar.com:443/news/red-dress-march-is-to-bring-murdered-missing-indigenous-woman-girls-into-the-light", "title": "Red Dress march is to bring murdered/missing Indigenous woman/girls into the light | Sault Star", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nRed Dress march is to bring murdered/missing Indigenous woman/girls into the light\nAuthor of the article:\nKevin McSheffrey\nPublished May 18, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 4 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREY On May 5, a group of Indigenous and non-Indigenous students at Elliot Lake Secondary School marched from the school to the Collins Hall to raise awareness of the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit People. The event was part of Red Dress Day.\nArticle content\n\nMay 5 was Indigenous Red Dress Day and students at Elliot Lake Secondary School (ELSS) wanted to public to remember the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit People.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMore than 50 Indigenous and non-Indigenous students and adults took part in the march for Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People (MMIWG2S) National Day. (Two-spirit people are gays/lesbians in the Native population.)\n\nJenifer Brousseau, Algoma District Board of Education Indigenous grad coach at ELSS, says she and the Indigenous students organized the event and opened it up to anyone who wanted to take part. As they were preparing for the march the call went out to assemble in the school\u2019s courtyard.\n\n\u201cQuite a few non-Indigenous students joined, and my heart was just so happy. That says a lot about where these students are at in understanding Truth and Reconciliation, and solidarity and how important this is. It was a beautiful thing. All the teachers were very moved.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe goal of the day is to raise awareness of the injustices against First Nations people.\n\n\u201cThe number they (government) have put out there is well below. The number they have out there has been over 4,500 women, girls and two spirits missing, but the number goes far beyond that,\u201d says Brousseau.\n\nPartner abuse and human trafficking are a big part of the murdered and missing.\n\nBrousseau wanted to bring the issue into the light because many of the girls will be heading to college and she wanted them \u201cto understand and be really aware. I was saying to them as sisters look out for each other, and with the young men that were there look out for your sisters, especially because that is really becoming a problem.\u201d\n\nThis area is targeted because of its proximity to Lake Huron.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cAnywhere a ship can come in is a place of concern. We have ships coming in all along the North Shore. This is also a huge problem in Thunder Bay. But I feel that our territory is under the radar and the speaking out about it.\n\n\u201cThey are often targeting specific demographics, especially if there are any addictions or anything like that as well. So, often they don\u2019t get reported.\u201d\n\nShe says she has heard of some women on First Nations in this area being followed.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really scary.\u201d\n\nBrousseau in one case the woman, who was riding in her car, believed she was being followed by what looked like a police car, but something didn\u2019t feel right. So, she called the police station and gave them the licence number and the police told her to drive directly to the detachment. The police caught the people in the other car.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI feel like there\u2019s something sinister that goes much deeper than we realize when it comes to human trafficking.\u201d\n\nBrousseau says prior to coming to this area, she was an actor in theatre and in a number of film productions, including the docudrama \u2018The Pig Farm\u2019. The 2009 film is about serial killer Robert Pickton who was charged in connection with the deaths of 26 women over a period of years at his pig farm in Port Coquitlam, B.C. However, he claimed to have killed 49 women (Canadian Encyclopedia).\n\nIn The Pig Farm her role was of Georgina Papin, who was murdered by Pickton.\n\n\u201cI met her daughter. The impact of playing a role of these women and then the family\u2026.\u201d\n\nIn her role she had a meat hook under her chin.\n\n\u201cIt was really, really graphic. It was traumatizing. There was no counsellor after, and I really wished that there was to process what I was a part of.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe says she wants to impart the emotions she felt while playing such roles to the students.\n\n\u201cThat was the demographic with addictions\u2026, it didn\u2019t take much to lure these women in. Some of these women realized what was happening and were able to get away, but most of them didn\u2019t.\u201d\n\nShe says acting in films like that \u201cIt was a scary role to play even when they were filming it. It\u2019s so close to home\u2026 that could be me. In hindsight I realize that many of the roles I played, I\u2019ve played missing and murdered women many times. It impacted my entire life.\u201d\n\nBrousseau plans to hold this event next year and make it bigger \u201cso that awareness is out there. These traffickers are coming around into Elliot Lake too. I want our kids safe, and I want them aware.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe adds that some might believe that because we live in Northern Ontario, they\u2019re safe.\n\n\u201cBut where the world\u2019s at right now, we just need to be aware. We can\u2019t live with blinders on, we have to make sure that we recognize there are some sick things at play out there.\u201d\n\nSome people just disappear and are never heard from again, she explained.\n\n\u201cNow here I am all these years later and I\u2019ve done a lot of amazing things as an artist, but I get to come back home and share all these things with these youth and this just happens to be one of those things that is really important to me.\u201d\n\nDuring the march, many had a red handprint on the face across their mouths. Brousseau says the red handprint on the face \u201cit speaks to Indigenous people who have been silenced by violence, and that the blood is on their hands.\u201d\n\nShe says people \u201cneed to understand that this is a real thing. And just because we\u2019re in Elliot Lake we\u2019re not immune to the possibility of going missing or something horrible happening.\u201d\n\nShe says if someone suspects they are being followed they should contact the police.\n\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREYOn May 5, a group of Indigenous and non-Indigenous students at Elliot Lake Secondary School marched from the school to the Collins Hall to raise awareness of the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit People. {"url": "https://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/news/red-dress-campaign-returning-to-the-comox-valley/", "title": "Red Dress campaign returning to the Comox Valley - Comox Valley Record", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.1 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nRed Dress campaign returning to the Comox Valley\nThe Red Dress campaign is returning to the Comox Valley this month.\n\tErin Haluschak\n\nSep 13, 2018 4:30 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nBy hanging a red dress, organizers hope all Canadians will become part of the conversation about missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. Photo by Erin Haluschak\n\nThe Red Dress campaign is returning to the Comox Valley this month.\n\nThe Red Dress Awareness Campaign seeks to recognize and inform the public about the increasingly high numbers of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls throughout Canada. The REDress Project was started in 2010 by Metis artist Jamie Black to raise awareness about the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada.\n\nThe campaign and installation are hosted by the Kumugwe Cultural Society, The IHOS Gallery and The Transition Society with support from many organizations and businesses.\n\nThis is the third year the installation will be in the Comox Valley.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just an Indigenous issue; all Canadians need to better understand the violence against Indigenous women,\u201d explained organizer Lee Everson.\n\n\u201cOur hope and vision are that other communities across B.C. and Canada hang a red dress and raise awareness.\u201d\n\nBy hanging a red dress, organizers hope all Canadians will become part of the conversation about missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nIf you would like to show your support it\u2019s as simple as hanging a red dress in a front yard or place of business or storefront. Organizers encourage everyone to share this information with friends, family, co-workers and within your community and hang a red dress.\n\nFor more information contact Lee Everson at 250-702-6740.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Erin Haluschak\n\nErin Haluschak is a journalist with the Comox Valley Record since 2008. Laurentian\u00d5s Indigenous Student Affairs (ISA) office recognized the campaign by inviting a number of guest speakers. A workshop was also held as part of the event, which was held in the Indigenous Sharing and Learning Centre\u00d5s Round Room. \u00d2The Red Dress campaign involves the hanging of red dresses to symbolize the many Indigenous women victimized by violence who are murdered and missing,\u00d3 said Roque in a press release. John Lappa/Sudbury Star/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nSince the 2010 inception of M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black\u2019s ongoing art series, The REDress Project, heightened awareness has been brought to the staggering number of murdered and missing Indigenous women across Canada.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Red Dress campaign that stems from Black\u2019s art series has been honoured by Laurentian University since 2016. This year, Laurentian\u2019s Indigenous Student Affairs (ISA) office recognized the campaign with an event held in the Indigenous Sharing and Learning Centre\u2019s Round Room on Feb. 14.\n\n\u201cThe Red Dress campaign involves the hanging of red dresses to symbolize the many Indigenous women victimized by violence who are murdered and missing,\u201d M\u00e9lanie Roque, the Indigenous Student Affairs\u2019 events and media coordinator said in a release. \u201cOn Feb. 9, red dresses were hung across campus in solidarity.\u201d\n\nHistorically and disproportionately, Indigenous women are affected by violence, organizers of the event said. They are also over-represented in statistics of Canadian women who are murdered and missing.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cTo honour the Red Dress Campaign and the spirits of murdered and missing individuals, we (invited) guest speakers to join us,\u201d said Roque.\n\nThis included members from the Greater Sudbury Police Service who discussed their efforts about the elimination of violence against women, girls and those who identify as 2SLGBTQQIA+.\n\nTanya Debassige from the Family Information Liaison Units attended virtually. She discussed this program and how it supports family members of murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls.\n\nA pre-recorded address by Navaeh Pine, a member of Garden River who advocates for missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two spirits and the Every Child Matters movement, was also screened in the Indigenous Sharing and Learning Centre\u2019. Pine is an award-winning speaker who addresses human rights issues.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKristy Corbiere, a facilitator, hosted a Red Dress workshop in the afternoon, Roque said. The completed dress will then be displayed every year at the annual Red Dress Campaign event.\n\n\u201cAs you are walking through campus and see the red dresses hanging along with our posters, it\u2019s important to note that this does not reflect the actual numbers,\u201d noted Mary Laur, director of the Indigenous Sharing and Learning Centre.\n\n\u201cWhen taking a moment to pause and reflect on the tens of thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and 2SLGBTQQIA, we have to remember that one was too many,\u201d Laur said.\n\nThe Laurentian community and the community in general were invited to attend the Red Dress Campaign event. People interested in participating in collective activism could choose to hang in their own homes or yards red dresses in memory and solidarity with the many Indigenous women whose lives have been affected by violence.\n\n\u201cThese murdered and missing Indigenous women cannot be forgotten. We remember them in spirit,\u201d organizers said.\n\n\u00a0\n\nsud.editorial@sunmedia.ca\n\nTwitter: @SudburyStar\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR NORTH BAY\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

{"url": "https://www.peacearchnews.com/news/update-canada-post-responds-after-vernon-womans-red-dress-movement-interrupts-mail-delivery/", "title": "B.C. woman\u2019s \u2018Red Dress\u2019 for missing, murdered Indigenous woman interrupts mail delivery - Peace Arch News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n25.2 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nB.C. woman\u2019s \u2018Red Dress\u2019 for missing, murdered Indigenous woman interrupts mail delivery\nWendy Chambers received a note that said the red dress hanging in her door was impeding Canada Post delivery\nBrieanna Charlebois\nJul 11, 2019 5:00 PM\nJul 12, 2019 8:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nAfter receiving a note about red dress impeding mail delivery, local woman wants to educate community on MMIWG movement. (Contributed)\n\nA Vernon woman is upset after she allegedly received a hand-written letter from a postal worker citing the red dress hanging in front of her door was impeding mail delivery to her house.\n\nWendy Chambers is a part of a local Indigenous elders group, Journey with Elders, and she wants to use this opportunity to educate people on the Red Dress movement.\n\nShe took to a popular local Facebook group, Vernon Rant and Rave, to address her concerns. She explained that she hung the dress in her doorway on May 5 for National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, where it has remained for over two months.\n\n\u201cI am completely disappointed in the letter carrier\u2019s note in my mailbox,\u201d Chambers wrote to the group. \u201cIt would seem to me that this person is completely unaware of the Red Dress movement and #MMIWG because if she was, perhaps she\u2019d have a little more understanding.\u201d\n\nRELATED: Okanagan Indian Band hosts red dress event in Vernon today\n\nRELATED: Family remembers mother at Red Dress Walk\n\nThe note in question reads, \u201cObject which is hanging impedes delivery to the mail box.\u201d\n\nIn her post, Chambers also wrote, \u201cAs a unionized, Canada Post employee, she has the right to complain but\u2026was it really necessary?\u201d\n\nChambers said that the note was left in her mailbox the morning of Wednesday, July 10 but no mail was delivered to her that day.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, Canada Post said in an emailed statement to The Morning Star that they will be apologizing to Chambers and understands the importance of the awareness campaign.\n\n\u201cThis was an unfortunate misunderstanding as the letter carrier was unaware of the significance of the Red Dress hanging in the doorway,\u201d the statement reads.\n\n\u201cWhile she had been delivering the mail to this address for weeks, the carrier decided recently to leave a note saying it had been impeding her ability to deliver. This was not the formal process, she did not mean any disrespect and deeply regrets the situation now that she is fully aware of the significance of the Red Dress.\u201d\n\nChamber\u2019s post garnered a lot of attention online with more than 170 comments, over 70 reactions and nine shares by Thursday morning.\n\nRELATED: Missing and murdered Indigenous women remembered at Vernon rally\n\nRELATED: Action imperative on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\n\n\u201cI knew when I made that post that it would cause controversy and the whole point is to raise awareness on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and educate people,\u201d Chambers told The Morning Star. \u201cPeople can\u2019t change something unless they are aware of it. Awareness and education are key.\u201d\n\nShe explained that she is very passionate about the cause.\n\n\u201cI do have a personal story about my great-grandmother and what happened to her over 100 years ago and I fail to see where much is changed,\u201d she said.\n\nShe told The Morning Star that her great-grandmother was abandoned on Kamloops government steps in 1896, when she was 15-years-old.\n\n\u201cShe had been so badly abused she had to have an eye removed and an arm amputated. They housed her in the local jail\u2026it goes on.\u201d\n\nChambers, who is working on a book which will tell the full story, also noted that a painting she created is currently being shown at the Awakening the Spirit art show at the Vernon Community Arts Centre and also speaks to the MMIWG movement.\n\nTo report a typo, email:\nnewstips@vernonmorningstar.com.\n\n\nFollow me on Twitter They represent an unimaginable loss.\n\n\u201cWhen my sister was missing, it was really hard on us,\u201c she said. \u201cWe didn't know what to do. We didn't know where to go next.\u201d\n\nThat's a tragedy that sadly is not unique to members of the indigenous community because Native women go missing 10 times more than any other group, according to the Coalition to Stop Violence Against Native Women.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\nSCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH THE CONTENT\n\nA statistic that Michele-Elise Burnett is trying to bring to light by creating this Red Dress Exhibit.\n\n\u201cAs much as it's difficult, they're finally peeling back some of those harsh realities that we've kind of tucked away,\u201d she said. \u201cBut now we're actually being able to have our voices heard and bring out their awareness. It's so needed today.\u201d\n\nThe exhibit features 13 red dresses hanging from trees, created by the loved ones of 13 murdered and missing indigenous women from Western New York and Canada, like Jenkins' sister.\n\n\u201cThis meant a lot to be able to share my story and be able to work through the trauma by having my family member being murdered and going missing,\u201d Jenkins said.\n\nIt's an important message for Western New Yorkers to understand, according to the exhibit's creator, because so much of the area's culture has been influenced by indigenous roots.\n\n\u201cI look at this, and it brings both Europeans, non-Indigenous and indigenous people together so that we can walk in the future together and strengthen our relations,\u201d Burnett said.\n\n\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\n\nRelated Articles\nUnknown Stories of WNY: Remembering the trial of Nancy Bowen and Lila Jimerson\nLocal groups react to leaked US Supreme Court draft on Roe v.
