{"url": "https://www.nugget.ca:443/news/local-news/no-more-stolen-sisters", "title": "'No more stolen sisters' | North Bay Nugget", "body": "Skip to Content\nIntroducing Puzzmo's new Pile-Up Poker, where poker meets solitaire. Play it today >>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\n'No more stolen sisters'\n\nRed Dress event in Sudbury remembers and honours Canada's missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\n\nAuthor of the article:\nMia Jensen\nPublished May 05, 2022 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 06, 2022 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nAnishnaabe Kweok Singers perform at a ceremony at the unveiling of the Red Dress Art Reveal at the N'Swakamok Native Friendship Centre in Sudbury, Ont. on Thursday May 5, 2022. The event was held on the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit people. The art was created by Kathryn Corbiere, of One Kwe Modern Fabrications, and commissioned through the Looking Ahead to Build the Spirit of Our Women Learning to Live Free from Violence project in collaboration with the N'Swakamok Native Friendship Centre. John Lappa/Sudbury Star/Postmedia Network\nArticle content\n\nOutside the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre Thursday afternoon, a crowd dressed in red shirts and ribbon skirts gathered to watch as two men on an aerial lift removed the tarp from over top of a brand new sculpture on the front of the building.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nMore than twice the men\u2019s size, the brilliant red art piece is in the shape of a dress, adorned with two rows of feathers, red and yellow ribbons, and a pattern of leaves decorating the hem. At its centre, it reads, in silver capital letters, \u201cNO MORE STOLEN SISTERS.\u201d\n\nThe Red Dress artwork was created by M\u2019Chigeeng First Nation artist Kathryn Corbiere of One Kwe Modern Fabrications. The piece was commissioned through the \u201cLooking Ahead to Build the Spirit of Our Women \u2013 Learning to Live Free From Violence\u201d project, a collaborative partnership between the Friendship Centre and the Greater Sudbury Police Service.\n\nJohn Vallely (Nootchtai) takes part in a ceremony at the unveiling of the Red Dress Art Reveal at the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre in Sudbury, Ont. on Thursday May 5, 2022. The event was held on the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit people. The art was created by Kathryn Corbiere, of One Kwe Modern Fabrications, and commissioned through the Looking Ahead to Build the Spirit of Our Women Learning to Live Free from Violence project in collaboration with the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre. John Lappa/Sudbury Star/Postmedia Network PHOTO BY JOHN LAPPA /John Lappa/Sudbury Star\n\nThe unveiling took place on Red Dress Day, which is held annually on May 5 to recognize and honour missing and murdered Indigenous Women and Girls across Canada, and raise awareness of the impact of gendered and radicalized violence. The red dress has come to symbolize those who have been lost over the centuries-long tragedy.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI think everyone\u2019s overwhelmed with the unveiling of the art,\u201d said N\u2019Swakamok executive director Marie Meawasige. \u201cI think everybody is very proud of the art that will be there forever.\u201d\n\nThe event featured a gathering of Indigenous community members, elders, and family members of MMIWG, as well as local supporters, including Mayor Brian Bigger, Sudbury MPP Jamie West, and members of the police service.\n\nSeveral speakers took the time to address the crowd about the impact violence against Indigenous women has had on their lives.\n\nOne of the speakers, Juliette Wemigwans, who lost her sister in 2002, said she sees the Red Dress artwork as more than just a symbol.\n\n\u201cI think having this dress here gives voice to people,\u201d she said in her emotional speech. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot to be said about \u2018out of sight, out of mind.\u2019 When the community and the family bring forth this dress, it\u2019s no longer out of sight; it\u2019s no longer out of mind.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAccording to the police service\u2019s Indigenous Liaison Officer, Darrell Rivers, the Red Dress art is meant to serve as a commemorative art piece to raise awareness about MMIWG and show support to affected family members in the community.\n\nThe partnership between the Friendship Centre and the police service began in 2015, as a means to improve collaboration in addressing the needs of the local Indigenous community. The artwork is part of that project.\n\nThe relationship between Indigenous communities and police can often be difficult, with improvements to accountability an important part of the Calls to Justice in Final Report on MMIWG, released in 2021.\n\nRivers said change within the police service takes time, but it\u2019s something they\u2019re to which they are committee.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe work hard to make ourselves better as a police service and we welcome the opportunity to learn,\u201d Rivers said. \u201cI think the ongoing partnerships with all the Indigenous organizations, especially the Friendship Centre, it just goes to show that we as a police service are trying to change and make things better.\u201d\n\nMeawasige said she hopes the new sculpture will provide an important visual reminder to the whole community.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019ll be very much available for everyone to see, day or night,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re just hoping that there\u2019s a better understanding of why the N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre and the Greater Sudbury Police have worked together to promote awareness and to continue to work so there\u2019ll be (fewer) murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls in our communities, not just in Sudbury, but all over Canada.\u201d\n\nThe Local Journalism Initiative is made possible through funding from the federal government.\n\nmjensen@postmedia.com\n\nTwitter: @mia_rjensen\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR NORTH BAY\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

{"url": "https://www.thesudburystar.com:443/news/indigenous-students-at-elss-mark-red-dress-day", "title": "Indigenous students at ELSS mark Red Dress Day | Sudbury Star", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nIndigenous students at ELSS mark Red Dress Day\nAuthor of the article:\nKevin McSheffrey\nPublished May 16, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 5 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREY About 40 Indigenous and non-Indigenous students at ELSS walked from the school to the Intersection of Hillside Drive North and Spine Road carrying signs to let the public know about Red Dress Day.\nArticle content\n\nAs many as 40 Indigenous and a few non-Indigenous students from Elliot Lake Secondary School participated in the walk on Friday, May 3 to remember the Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit People (MMIWG2S).\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe walk was headed up by Jenifer Brousseau, Algoma District Board of Education Indigenous grad coach at ELSS. She says the walk was to mark Indigenous Red Dress Day which was two days later on Sunday, May 5. On that day, along Highway 17 on Serpent River First Nation red dresses were hanging on trees, as a sign that the MMIWG2S were not forgotten.\u00a0\n\nThe students walked to the intersection of Hillside Drive North and Spine Road in the rain. They were holding signs with such messages as \u2018No More Stolen Sisters\u2019, \u2018Bring them Home\u2019 and \u2018Never Forgotten.\u2019\u00a0\n\nThe Standard interviewed three female ELSS Indigenous students from Serpent River First Nation.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nFirst student\u00a0\n\nThe first was 16-year-old Maddie Meawasige. She is also Junior Miss Genaabeejing, and represents the youth of her community at various events.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBeing Junior Miss Genaabeejing she says she has learned more about her culture, their history and their Ojibwe language.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThe language isn\u2019t something easy to learn now because we don\u2019t have a lot left who speak the language. So, it\u2019s really important to me that I get to learn and share it with other people\u2026 keeping our language alive.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe is part of the Indigenous culture room because it\u2019s very welcoming.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI have support here. It\u2019s really nice to get to have a place in school where I feel comfortable. The culture room does a lot for a lot of people. For a lot of us it\u2019s a safe place to go,\u201d Maddie explains.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nHowever, she does attend other classes for the subjects she takes.\u00a0\n\nShe adds those in this class have always helped her when she had struggles.\u00a0\n\nSudbury Star Morning Briefing\n\nStart your days with the latest local news, weather, sports, community updates and more.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe people in this class have always been super supportive and they\u2019ve always helped me when I needed it.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThey organize a lot of stuff that not only teaches us, but it helps educate other people. It\u2019s not just a place for us to learn our school work, it\u2019s a place for us to learn who we are as Indigenous people.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe says it\u2019s unfortunate because a lot of youth now are \u201cengaged in the culture and not a lot of youth know about our history, our traditions and who we are. That\u2019s why it\u2019s so important for me to continue our traditions and be able to share it with the next generations that follow.\u201d\u00a0\n\nMaddie explains, \u201cOur culture was suppressed for so many years, and it\u2019s not that it was a long time ago that this ended. It\u2019s still a consistent struggle for all of us, especially in regards to things like additions, our quality of life on reserves, the way we\u2019re treated in public, the systemic racism that a lot of us face every day. It\u2019s really hard because we struggle with so much, there\u2019s not always a lot of awareness as to what we as Indigenous people have to go through.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe explains that as an Indigenous woman there is a constant fear of being alone.\u00a0\n\n\u201cAfter knowing even what my relatives have gone through as Indigenous people I\u2019m scared that I\u2019ll become another part of that statistic of missing and murdered Indigenous women. I\u2019m scared to take public transit because I\u2019m scared that I\u2019ll end up like my sisters, my two-spirited family.\u201d\u00a0\n\nHowever, she has dreams after finishing high school. Maddie would like to work in the medical field.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI would like to be a nurse practitioner, but to start off I want to go into nursing.\u201d\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nSecond student\u00a0\n\nA second female a Indigenous Grade 10 student is 15-year-old Ayasha Jacobs.\u00a0\n\nShe goes to the Indigenous culture room \u201cfor the quietness and a place to work. I also get to do cultural activities like make my skirts, to bead and I\u2019m making a pair of moccasins. It\u2019s nice that they have all these activities for us since I didn\u2019t have them when I was younger.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAyasha says she too has fears of being kidnapped.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI had an experience very close to\u2026 If I had said the wrong thing I probably wouldn\u2019t be here today.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe was walking to her school bus stop on Serpent River First Nation and a man drove up beside her and asked some a few questions.\u00a0\n\n\u201cA couple of minutes later he was offering me money to get into his car; it happened in front of a store. The weird thing was it wasn\u2019t like it was the first time for him. It\u2019s like he was doing this for a while \u2013 (he offered) at least $500 in cash. I said no, he tried to get me in his car and then the bus pulled up, and he drove off,\u201d Ayasha explains.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t seen him since. There was a big investigation on it.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt was a very close situation for that happened to me. It still bugs me sometimes when I walk by there, I still think of it. Having cars stop by me is a constant fear of just getting grabbed and pulled into a car.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard that we, as women, cannot do somethings like walking around at night, or going into a city and being a little uncomfortable having someone just pass by you and try to touch you. There\u2019s always that constant fear and anxiety that lurk with it. You\u2019re not fully safe unless you\u2019re with someone.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe says her siblings were born in a city, but she was born on Serpent River First Nation.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy that I was born around my culture. My brothers were born in a city.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAyasha is starting to learn Ojibwe, and wants to delve more into it.\u00a0\n\nOn May 3, both Ayasha and Jenifer Brousseau had a painted red hand marks on their faces over their mouths.\u00a0\n\nBrouseau said the painted hand on the face \u201cis about our voices being silenced. It\u2019s about the abuse.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe red hand over the mouth has become a symbol of a growing MMIWG2S movement. It stands for all the missing sisters whose voices are not heard,\u201d she read.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nThird student\u00a0\n\nThe third student is Sitertia Pelletier, who is in Grade 11.\u00a0\n\nSitertia explained why they wear red on Indigenous Red Dress Day.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIn our culture it\u2019s believed that red is the only colour that spirits can see. Around this time we put up red dresses along the highway to bring the spirits of the relatives we lost back home.\u201d\u00a0\n\nSitertia, who grew up on the reserve, has been learning about her culture all her life. She is a \u2018fancy shawl\u2019 dancer at powwows.\u00a0\n\nSitertia also wrote an essay for her English class on how the federal government has done little for the Indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about how the Canadian government failed our missing and murdered sisters and relatives,\u201d said Sitertia.\u00a0\n\n\u201cMy family has been affected by this specific issue, and I\u2019d like to spread awareness about it. It\u2019s really personal to me.\u201d\u00a0\n\nBrousseau adds they will soon be teaching self-defense available to all the young women in the school.\u00a0\n\n\u201cSo, if ever we are in these situations we\u2019ll know how to defend ourselves.\u201d\u00a0\n\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREYAbout 40 Indigenous and non-Indigenous students at ELSS walked from the school to the Intersection of Hillside Drive North and Spine Road carrying signs to let the public know about Red Dress Day.\n\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREYThree female students at ELSS spoke about Red Dress Day to remember Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit People. awards\nBy Kyra McCague, Staff Writer \u2022 JUNE 25, 2024\nOpinion | What are the songs of this summer?\nBy Delaney Rauscher Adams, Staff Columnist \u2022 JUNE 25, 2024\nFrick Museum\u2019s \u2018Red Dress\u2019 tells global stories through embroidery\nBy Casey Carter, Staff Writer\nJANUARY 9, 2024\nListen to this article with\nKelechi Anucha | Staff Photographer\nThe Red Dress sits on display at the Frick Arts Museum of Pittsburgh in late November 2023.\n\nGallery attendees gazed upon the grandeur of the Red Dress exhibition at the Frick Art Museum of Pittsburgh in Point Breeze. The dress is the product of the collaborative embroidery of hundreds of artists around the world. Sitting at the center of the room, it invited viewers to walk around it, exploring its angles and details as a whole.\u00a0\n\nIts red fabric elegantly flowed onto the pedestal, displaying the intricate works of embroidery. The dress\u2019s measurements fit the average person by design, yet the dress felt larger than life. The creators of the Red Dress intended for its significance to surpass its physical form, conveying a larger global connection.\n\nThe Red Dress has journeyed through museums and galleries around the world since 2009, eventually arriving in the United States this year, including a stop in Pittsburgh. The exhibit at the Frick Museum will be on display until Jan. 28, and afterward will travel to the Fuller Craft Museum in Boston.\u00a0\n\nKirstie Macleod, the visionary of the project, sketched the idea of the dress on a napkin in a London cafe. It has since transformed into a collective embroidery project by women around the world, involving 380 embroiderers from 51 countries and spanning 14 years. Embroidering the dress offered a medium of expression for the artists to communicate their stories and identity. Many of the women who contributed to the project came from tragic backgrounds of war and poverty. Combining the individual embroidered pieces into a quilt-like construction, the dress symbolizes strength and unity across borders.\u00a0\n\nOne of the contributing embroiderers, Shirley Steenberg, represents her Indigenous heritage and Canadian identity through her stitching. Steenberg identifies as Inuvialuk, an Indigenous group in Canada who live along the coast of the Beaufort Sea. Her embroidery design on the dress took the shape of a medicine wheel, a symbol with a longstanding history among various Native American groups.\u00a0\n\nSteenberg wrote in her feature on the Red Dress website that, \u201c[The wheel] embodies the Four Directions (north, south, east and west), as well as Father Sky, Mother Earth, and Spirit Tree \u2014 all of which symbolize dimensions of health and the cycles of life.\u201d Steenberg\u2019s design also includes Canadian maple leaves and the words \u201cStrong and Free,\u201d quoted from the Canadian national anthem, to represent her country.\n\nAnother contributing artist, Ruriko Wyborn, said she represented family and Japanese culture in her design.\u00a0\n\n\u201cMy grandfather had a kimono business, and so my design tried to express the detail, colors and familiar images that are associated with kimono designs in Japan,\u201d Wyborn said.\u00a0\n\nSeveral of the messages and symbols in the embroidery pieces focused on social and political advocacy. A group of refugee women from Kosovo called Sister Stitch collaborated to create a design of birds, symbolizing migration, resilience and hope. The women of Sister Stitch fled their homes during the war in Kosovo in the late 1990s. They have since returned to Kosovo and, through Sister Stitch, earn money to help rebuild the lives they were forced to leave behind. Erina Sheholli, the Sister Stitch coordinator, wrote about the message behind their contribution to the dress, which they titled \u201cBirds of Peace.\u201d\n\n\u201cI hope that the message of those birds will spread all over the world. We deserve to live free as birds,\u201d Sheholli wrote.\n\nContributing embroiderer Nathalie Frost, from Wales, explained her belief in the power of embroidery.\u00a0\n\n\u201cCraft, especially stitching \u2014 so often associated with women \u2014 has been overlooked for so long. The Red Dress completely bypasses that notion,\u201d Frost said. \u201cThe experience will remain with me and hopefully send messages for future generations who are lucky enough to see and learn about the work.\u201d\n\nThe Red Dress exhibition has generated attention not only in the Pittsburgh region, but around the world, museum educator Susanne Wilkinson explained.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThe community has responded very very positively. People are drawn to [The Frick] to see the Red Dress,\u201d Wilkinson said. \u201cWe actually just said goodbye to some visitors from Paris.\u201d\u00a0\n\nWilkinson says the piece\u2019s overarching message of global unity holds the most significance to her.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWhat I like about it is there\u2019s so much detailing in it \u2014 and then the story it tells about how people from all these different countries were able to put their thoughts and ideas together and have this magnificent piece that represents the world \u2014 and that\u2019s incredible,\u201d Wilkinson said.\n\nWilkinson explained that even though she has seen the dress countless times, she still finds herself continuing to learn from it and engage with its content in different ways. She encourages others to slow down and pause when viewing the work, allowing time to absorb the details of each message in the embroidery.\u00a0\n\n\u201cEach time I view the dress, I look at something else because there\u2019s so much to see,\u201d Wilkinson said. \u201cSome messages are subtle and some aren\u2019t \u2014 it\u2019s all about looking.\u201d\n\nOne Frick attendee, Debra Kirchhof-Glazier, said the dress was enchanting. \u201cThere\u2019s no words to adequately describe it \u2026 even if you were to take a picture it wouldn\u2019t do justice to it,\u201d Kirchhof-Glazier said. \u201cAll of the intensive and emotional artisanship that went into it \u2026 I mean, it\u2019s incredible.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\n\nShare on Facebook\nShare on X\nEmail this Story\nPrint this Story\ndressembroideryfashion\nAbout the Contributor\nCasey Carter, Senior Staff Writer\nCasey Carter is a sophomore communications major with certificates in digital media and sustainability. She is a firm believer that a good walk can solve almost anything and loves the outdoors. She says the walk was to mark Indigenous Red Dress Day which was two days later on Sunday, May 5. On that day, along Highway 17 on Serpent River First Nation red dresses were hanging on trees, as a sign that the MMIWG2S were not forgotten.\u00a0\n\nThe students walked to the intersection of Hillside Drive North and Spine Road in the rain. They were holding signs with such messages as \u2018No More Stolen Sisters\u2019, \u2018Bring them Home\u2019 and \u2018Never Forgotten.\u2019\u00a0\n\nThe Standard interviewed three female ELSS Indigenous students from Serpent River First Nation.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nFirst student\u00a0\n\nThe first was 16-year-old Maddie Meawasige. She is also Junior Miss Genaabeejing, and represents the youth of her community at various events.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nBeing Junior Miss Genaabeejing she says she has learned more about her culture, their history and their Ojibwe language.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThe language isn\u2019t something easy to learn now because we don\u2019t have a lot left who speak the language. So, it\u2019s really important to me that I get to learn and share it with other people\u2026 keeping our language alive.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe is part of the Indigenous culture room because it\u2019s very welcoming.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI have support here. It\u2019s really nice to get to have a place in school where I feel comfortable. The culture room does a lot for a lot of people. For a lot of us it\u2019s a safe place to go,\u201d Maddie explains.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nHowever, she does attend other classes for the subjects she takes.\u00a0\n\nShe adds those in this class have always helped her when she had struggles.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe people in this class have always been super supportive and they\u2019ve always helped me when I needed it.\u00a0\n\n\u201cThey organize a lot of stuff that not only teaches us, but it helps educate other people. It\u2019s not just a place for us to learn our school work, it\u2019s a place for us to learn who we are as Indigenous people.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe says it\u2019s unfortunate because a lot of youth now are \u201cengaged in the culture and not a lot of youth know about our history, our traditions and who we are. That\u2019s why it\u2019s so important for me to continue our traditions and be able to share it with the next generations that follow.\u201d\u00a0\n\nMaddie explains, \u201cOur culture was suppressed for so many years, and it\u2019s not that it was a long time ago that this ended. It\u2019s still a consistent struggle for all of us, especially in regards to things like additions, our quality of life on reserves, the way we\u2019re treated in public, the systemic racism that a lot of us face every day. It\u2019s really hard because we struggle with so much, there\u2019s not always a lot of awareness as to what we as Indigenous people have to go through.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe explains that as an Indigenous woman there is a constant fear of being alone.\u00a0\n\n\u201cAfter knowing even what my relatives have gone through as Indigenous people I\u2019m scared that I\u2019ll become another part of that statistic of missing and murdered Indigenous women. I\u2019m scared to take public transit because I\u2019m scared that I\u2019ll end up like my sisters, my two-spirited family.\u201d\u00a0\n\nHowever, she has dreams after finishing high school. Maddie would like to work in the medical field.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI would like to be a nurse practitioner, but to start off I want to go into nursing.\u201d\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nSecond student\u00a0\n\nA second female a Indigenous Grade 10 student is 15-year-old Ayasha Jacobs.\u00a0\n\nShe goes to the Indigenous culture room \u201cfor the quietness and a place to work. I also get to do cultural activities like make my skirts, to bead and I\u2019m making a pair of moccasins. It\u2019s nice that they have all these activities for us since I didn\u2019t have them when I was younger.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAyasha says she too has fears of being kidnapped.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI had an experience very close to\u2026 If I had said the wrong thing I probably wouldn\u2019t be here today.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe was walking to her school bus stop on Serpent River First Nation and a man drove up beside her and asked some a few questions.\u00a0\n\n\u201cA couple of minutes later he was offering me money to get into his car; it happened in front of a store. The weird thing was it wasn\u2019t like it was the first time for him. It\u2019s like he was doing this for a while \u2013 (he offered) at least $500 in cash. I said no, he tried to get me in his car and then the bus pulled up, and he drove off,\u201d Ayasha explains.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t seen him since. There was a big investigation on it.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt was a very close situation for that happened to me. It still bugs me sometimes when I walk by there, I still think of it. Having cars stop by me is a constant fear of just getting grabbed and pulled into a car.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard that we, as women, cannot do somethings like walking around at night, or going into a city and being a little uncomfortable having someone just pass by you and try to touch you. There\u2019s always that constant fear and anxiety that lurk with it. You\u2019re not fully safe unless you\u2019re with someone.\u201d\u00a0\n\nShe says her siblings were born in a city, but she was born on Serpent River First Nation.\u00a0\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy that I was born around my culture. My brothers were born in a city.\u201d\u00a0\n\nAyasha is starting to learn Ojibwe, and wants to delve more into it.\u00a0\n\nOn May 3, both Ayasha and Jenifer Brousseau had a painted red hand marks on their faces over their mouths.\u00a0\n\nBrouseau said the painted hand on the face \u201cis about our voices being silenced. It\u2019s about the abuse.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 8\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe red hand over the mouth has become a symbol of a growing MMIWG2S movement. It stands for all the missing sisters whose voices are not heard,\u201d she read.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nThird student\u00a0\n\nThe third student is Sitertia Pelletier, who is in Grade 11.\u00a0\n\nSitertia explained why they wear red on Indigenous Red Dress Day.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIn our culture it\u2019s believed that red is the only colour that spirits can see. Around this time we put up red dresses along the highway to bring the spirits of the relatives we lost back home.\u201d\u00a0\n\nSitertia, who grew up on the reserve, has been learning about her culture all her life. She is a \u2018fancy shawl\u2019 dancer at powwows.\u00a0\n\nSitertia also wrote an essay for her English class on how the federal government has done little for the Indigenous women and girls.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about how the Canadian government failed our missing and murdered sisters and relatives,\u201d said Sitertia.\u00a0\n\n\u201cMy family has been affected by this specific issue, and I\u2019d like to spread awareness about it. It\u2019s really personal to me.\u201d\u00a0\n\nBrousseau adds they will soon be teaching self-defense available to all the young women in the school.\u00a0\n\n\u201cSo, if ever we are in these situations we\u2019ll know how to defend ourselves.\u201d\u00a0\n\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREYAbout 40 Indigenous and non-Indigenous students at ELSS walked from the school to the Intersection of Hillside Drive North and Spine Road carrying signs to let the public know about Red Dress Day.\n\nPhoto by KEVIN McSHEFFREYThree female students at ELSS spoke about Red Dress Day to remember Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women, Girls and Two Spirit People. {"url": "https://www.aldergrovestar.com/news/red-dresses-hanging-on-ubco-campus-address-nation-wide-issue/", "title": "Red dresses hanging on UBCO campus address nation wide issue - Aldergrove Star", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n25.2 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nRed dresses hanging on UBCO campus address nation wide issue\nThe REDress Project at UBCO focuses on the conversation about missing and murdered Indigenous women\nCarli Berry\nFeb 28, 2018 12:53 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRed dresses like this one could be seen on the UBCO\u2019s campus Tuesday, as part of The REDress Project and tea talk held by the Women\u2019s Resource Centre and Indigenous Students Association. - Credit: Carli Berry/Capital News\n\nRed dresses were blowing in the wind as they hung from trees, branches and poles at UBC Okanagan.\n\nTen dresses could be seen at the university as part of the REDress Project and tea talk, Tuesday Feb. 27.\n\nThe REDress Project is a nationwide event, focusing on the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s definitely for awareness. Even the people at the event don\u2019t know a lot of information on missing and murdered Indigenous women. It\u2019s generally not talked about on campus, or in everyday life,\u201d said Taya Jardine, volunteer director at UBCO\u2019s Women\u2019s Resource Centre. \u201cA lot of people don\u2019 t know how close and how strongly impacted the local community is.\u201d\n\nJardine was referring to the five women who went missing in the North Okanagan in less than two years. The body of one, Traci Genereaux, was found on a property in Salmon Arm in October.\n\nThe tea talks are held monthly on various topics throughout the year. This one featured missing and murdered Aboriginal women and approximately 20 students shared their voices on the subject.\n\n\u201cThe main aim of the tea talks is to really get information out there; to get students involved on campus in a safe space where they can talk about their feelings and opinions on different matters,\u201d said Jardine.\n\n\u201cI feel like bringing the dresses out forces that conversation out of Indigenous communities, into settler communities as well.\u201d\n\nIndigenous women of all ages are being taken and murdered, said Jardine. \u201cSome of the people we were talking about, especially Tina Fontaine, she was 15, just in the child protective system. Other ones are mothers and could be any of us really. That\u2019s why it\u2019s important to talk about.\u201d\n\nFontaine was found dead in Winnipeg\u2019s Red River in 2014. The man accused of the murder was found not guilty last week.\n\nIt\u2019s about getting the information to a generation who can make changes, she said.\n\n\u201cOn the university campus people are here to learn and aside from learning terms, it should be an environment of social learning as well.\u201d\n\nThe dress project was held by the Women\u2019s Resource Centre in partnership with the Indigenous Students Association.\n\nTo report a typo, email: edit@kelownacapnews.com.\n\n<>\n\n@carliberry_\ncarli.berry@kelownacapnews.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a {"url": "https://winnipegsun.com/news/provincial/a-number-of-local-activities-being-held-to-mark-red-dress-day", "title": "A number of local activities being held to mark Red Dress Day | Winnipeg Sun", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nePaper\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nJets add to depth with two-way signings\nTRENDING\nBombers' Collaros to miss first start of season vs Redblacks\nTRENDING\nManitoba First Nation reports 150 anomalies at residential school site\nTRENDING\nPlayers hearing it from fans: What's up with Bombers?\nTRENDING\nEmergency responders rescue individual from Assiniboine River\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsManitoba\nA number of local activities being held to mark Red Dress Day\nAuthor of the article:\nGlen Dawkins\nPublished May 04, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 04, 2024 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\n28 Comments\nAlso known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two Spirit People (MMIWG2S+), Red Dress Day is observed annually on May 5 to honour and bring awareness to the thousands of First Nations, Inuit, and Metis women, girls, two spirit, and gender-diverse people who have been subjected to gender-based violence in Canada. PHOTO BY DAVE BAXTER /Winnipeg Sun/Local Journalism Initiative\nArticle content\n\nA number of local activities are being held to honour and acknowledge Red Dress Day on Sunday.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAlso known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two Spirit People (MMIWG2S+), Red Dress Day is observed annually on May 5 to honour and bring awareness to the thousands of First Nations, Inuit, and Metis women, girls, two spirit, and gender-diverse people who have been subjected to gender-based violence in Canada.\n\n\u201cFirst and foremost on this important day of reflection and remembrance, I extend my sincerest and deepest condolences to all victims of MMIWG2S+ and their loved ones,\u201d said Southern Chiefs\u2019 Organization Grand Chief Jerry Daniels in a press release. \u201cThis day also serves as motivation, as we continue to raise our voices and advocate for change and justice for the victims and their families. It is essential we work to put an end to this ongoing national emergency, a result of the intersection of gender-based violence with anti-Indigenous racism.\u201d\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOne year ago, the House of Commons voted unanimously in favour of declaring MMIWG2S+ a nation-wide emergency and agreed to provide funding for a Red Dress Alert System to make the public aware when an Indigenous woman, girl, gender-diverse, or two spirit person goes missing. That initiative is now before the Standing Committee on the Status of Women.\n\n\u201cWhile I can appreciate that creating a new government initiative takes time, I urge the members of the standing committee, the federal government, and politicians of all parties to prioritize the implementation of this vital resource,\u201d added Sagkeeng Anicinabe First Nation Chief E.J. Fontaine. \u201cLives are literally at stake, and our women, girls, two spirit, and gender-diverse relatives are at risk every day.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCanada and Manitoba governments announced a partnership Friday for a Red Dress Alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl is reported missing. The pilot project is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nOn Thursday at the Ebb and Flow First Nation, there was a MMIWG2S+ Healing and Wellness Walk.\n\nAlso on Thursday, Red River Polytechnic held a Red Dress Special dance at its annual pow wow to honour Indigenous graduates and Indigenous student academic achievement.\n\nOn Sunday, which is officially Red Dress Day, the organizers of the University of Winnipeg\u2019s annual graduation pow wow are hosting a Red Dress Special dance. The grand entry is scheduled for 12:30 p.m. at the Duckworth Centre.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThere are events happening in many places on Sunday, with a number taking place in Winnipeg. There will be keynote speakers, drummers, and dancers at The Forks at noon, along with community members sharing about the importance of this day in honouring those who have been taken too soon and those who are still searching for loved ones.\n\nManitoba Families Minister Nahanni Fontaine and Housing, Addictions and Homelessness Minister Bernadette Smith will make an announcement on a MMIWG2S Endowment Fund at the Canadian Museum for Human Rights at 1 p.m.\n\nLater on Sunday, the fourth annual MMIWG2S+ Walk for Justice will take place, starting at 6 p.m. with participants walking from the Oodena Circle to the steps of the Manitoba Legislative Building.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe Sandy Bay Ojibway First Nation will host a walk starting from the corner of Highway 50 and Townsite Bay on Monday. The walk is scheduled to start at 10 a.m.\n\n\u201cOn Red Dress Day, and every day, I reiterate my call for all levels of government to continue working towards the implementation of the 231 Calls for Justice that came from the testimony and truths of thousands of family members and Survivors at the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls,\u201d said Daniels. \u201cLet us all continue to come together and truly build a safer society for our women, girls, two spirit, and gender-diverse people.\u201d\n\nA full list of Red Dress Day events taking place in\u00a0southern Manitoba can be found on the SCO website.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://www.nanaimobulletin.com/news/red-dresses-hanging-on-ubco-campus-address-nation-wide-issue/", "title": "Red dresses hanging on UBCO campus address nation wide issue - Nanaimo News Bulletin", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.0 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nRed dresses hanging on UBCO campus address nation wide issue\nThe REDress Project at UBCO focuses on the conversation about missing and murdered Indigenous women\nCarli Berry\nFeb 28, 2018 12:53 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRed dresses like this one could be seen on the UBCO\u2019s campus Tuesday, as part of The REDress Project and tea talk held by the Women\u2019s Resource Centre and Indigenous Students Association. - Credit: Carli Berry/Capital News\n\nRed dresses were blowing in the wind as they hung from trees, branches and poles at UBC Okanagan.\n\nTen dresses could be seen at the university as part of the REDress Project and tea talk, Tuesday Feb. 27.\n\nThe REDress Project is a nationwide event, focusing on the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s definitely for awareness. Even the people at the event don\u2019t know a lot of information on missing and murdered Indigenous women. It\u2019s generally not talked about on campus, or in everyday life,\u201d said Taya Jardine, volunteer director at UBCO\u2019s Women\u2019s Resource Centre. \u201cA lot of people don\u2019 t know how close and how strongly impacted the local community is.\u201d\n\nJardine was referring to the five women who went missing in the North Okanagan in less than two years. The body of one, Traci Genereaux, was found on a property in Salmon Arm in October.\n\nThe tea talks are held monthly on various topics throughout the year. This one featured missing and murdered Aboriginal women and approximately 20 students shared their voices on the subject.\n\n\u201cThe main aim of the tea talks is to really get information out there; to get students involved on campus in a safe space where they can talk about their feelings and opinions on different matters,\u201d said Jardine.\n\n\u201cI feel like bringing the dresses out forces that conversation out of Indigenous communities, into settler communities as well.\u201d\n\nIndigenous women of all ages are being taken and murdered, said Jardine. \u201cSome of the people we were talking about, especially Tina Fontaine, she was 15, just in the child protective system. Other ones are mothers and could be any of us really. That\u2019s why it\u2019s important to talk about.\u201d\n\nFontaine was found dead in Winnipeg\u2019s Red River in 2014. The man accused of the murder was found not guilty last week.\n\nIt\u2019s about getting the information to a generation who can make changes, she said.\n\n\u201cOn the university campus people are here to learn and aside from learning terms, it should be an environment of social learning as well.\u201d\n\nThe dress project was held by the Women\u2019s Resource Centre in partnership with the Indigenous Students Association.\n\nTo report a typo, email: edit@kelownacapnews.com.\n\n<>\n\n@carliberry_\ncarli.berry@kelownacapnews.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a {"url": "https://people.howstuffworks.com/highway-of-tears-news.htm", "title": "Indigenous Women Keep Vanishing on Canada's Highway of Tears | HowStuffWorks", "body": "___\nScience\nTech\nHome & Garden\nAuto\nCulture\nMore\nSubmit Search\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHowStuffWorks\nCulture\nPeople\nLegal System\nCrime & Crime Prevention\nIndigenous Women Keep Vanishing on Canada's Highway of Tears\nBy: John Donovan \u00a0|\u00a0 Updated: Nov 4, 2021\nA private detective's notebook shows pictures of women who have gone missing along Canada's Highway of Tears. ANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\n\nSixteen years ago, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) opened an investigation surrounding nine women and girls who had gone missing or were found murdered along a desolate stretch of roadway in northern British Columbia. The effort was dubbed Project E-PANA, named for the goddess that the Inuit people of Canada believe cares for souls before they go to heaven or are reincarnated.\n\nThe number of women that the RCMP identified in its probe soon doubled, to 18, and to keep the numbers from climbing even higher, authorities placed criteria on who would be included on the list. They had to be women or girls, they had to be involved in high-risk activities like hitchhiking, and they had to be last seen \u2014 or their bodies found \u2014 within a mile or so of Highways 16, 97 or 5 in upper British Columbia.\n\nThe Highway of Tears, as the main throughway was dubbed, instantly became a symbol for unchecked violence against Indigenous women and girls in Canada. And it remains a symbol for the violence \u2014 and the many reasons behind it \u2014 that endures today.\n\nCanada's Route 16, which connects Prince George to Prince Rupert through the province of British Columbia, has been dubbed \"Highway of Tears\" because many First Nations women and girls have been murdered or disappeared from here.\nANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/ CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\nContents\nWhat Is the Highway of Tears?\nGiving Names to the Victims\nGetting Legal Justice\nToday Along the Highway of Tears\nWhat Is the Highway of Tears?\n\nThe drive from Vancouver, B.C., (which is a little less than a three-hour ride from Seattle) to the city of Prince George in northern British Columbia takes nearly nine hours. From there, a western turn along Highway 16 to the port city of Prince Rupert is another eight hours.\n\nIt is that final 416-mile (718-kilometer) section of winding, mostly two-lane highway between those two cities \u2014 through mountain passes, dozens of tiny villages, countless lakes and a whole lot of wilderness \u2014 that has become known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe remoteness of the highway, coupled with the fact that it bisects so many remote Indigenous communities without access to adequate transportation \u2014 often used by young Indigenous women hitchhiking simply as a means of getting from one place to another along the long, lonely road \u2014 makes it a ripe ground for violence.\n\n\"It's very, very isolated. You can drive for 15 minutes and not see a car. There are rivers and mountains. It's very heavily forested,\" says Wayne Clary, a retired RCMP investigator who has been brought back to work on the E-PANA cases. \"It's interesting when we look at some of our murders along there and we think, 'Was this a traveler who came upon this girl and had the opportunity to do what he did, or a local person?' It's dark, and the winters are pretty severe. You get a young girl hitchhiking and no one's around ... there one minute, gone the next.\"\n\n(Left) Gloria Moody was the first of the 18 women identified by the RCMP in the E-PANA project; 14-year-old Aielah Saric Auger (right) was the last.\nRCMP/PROJECT E-PANA\nGiving Names to the Victims\n\nIn October 1969, Gloria Moody, a 26-year-old mother of two and a member of the Bella Coola Indian Reserve of the Nuxalk Nation, was found dead along one of the Highway of Tears roads, naked, beaten and sexually assaulted. She became the first of the 18 women identified by the RCMP in the E-PANA project.\n\nOver the next almost 40 years, 17 other women became victims along the highway. The last was 14-year-old Aielah Saric Auger of the Lheidli T'enneh First Nations community, near Prince George. Her almost-unrecognizable body was discovered on an embankment of Highway 16 in February 2006, eight days after she went missing.\n\nAt its zenith, more than 60 RCMP investigators worked the cases along the Highway of Tears. But now, more than 15 years after Auger's body was found, barely a handful of police are still actively involved. No one has been added to the list since Auger, in 2006. Project E-PANA now consists of 13 homicide investigations and five missing people's investigations.\n\nAll the files, officially, remain open. But Clary has been forthright in informing the victims' families that many of the cases may never be solved.\n\n\"We've had some success,\" Clary says, noting that DNA samples tied notorious serial killer\u00a0 Bobby Jack Fowler to 16-year-old Highway of Tears victim Colleen MacMillen, found dead along the Highway in 1974. Fowler, suspected in at least two other Highway of Tears cases, died in an Oregon prison in 2006, before the connection in the MacMillen case was solidified. In 2019, authorities also got a murder conviction in the case of Monica Jack. The 12-year-old girl went missing in 1978, but her remains weren't found until 1995. That ruling is under appeal.\n\n\"We had a couple of very strong suspects, but just don't have the evidence. And we've used everything in our toolkit that we can,\" Clary adds. \"I'd say we've probably ruled out a lot of bad guys, too. It's still ongoing, but ... a lot of water is under the bridge.\"\n\nDNA tied serial killer Bobby Fowler to the death of Colleen MacMillen (left); Garry Taylor Handlen was convicted of murdering 12-year-old Monica Jack (right).\nRCMP/PROJECT E-PANA\nGetting Legal Justice\n\nCarrier Sekani Family Services (CSFS), based in British Columbia, works to secure social and legal justice for First Nations and other Indigenous families. They began the Highway of Tears Initiative to put into action 33 recommendations made in the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium Recommendations Report.\n\nThe recommendations include measures like better transportation options, increased police patrols, the establishment of awareness and prevention programs among at-risk women and their families, a wide-ranging media campaign and emergency readiness plans.\n\nYet the violence against Indigenous women, all across Canada, continues. According to the Canadian Femicide Observatory for Justice and Accountability:\n\nBased on 15 years of Homicide Survey data (2001-2015), homicide rates for Indigenous women and girls were approximately six times higher (48.2 per million population) than rates for non-Indigenous women and girls (8.2 per million population). Other research suggests that Indigenous women are 12 times more likely to be murdered or missing than any other women in Canada and 16 times more likely than Caucasian women.\n\n\"It's far too common. Even just this year alone, we've had three former clients go missing, you know?\" says Elsie Wiebe, the Calls to Justice Coordinator with CSFS's Highway of Tears Initiative. \"Just how common it is for Indigenous women to go missing and be found dead, or not be found at all. It has a devastating impact.\"\n\nWhat still needs addressing, Wiebe and many other Indigenous peoples advocates say, are the underlying conditions that lead to the violence. A 2019 report from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls put it this way:\n\nColonial violence, as well as racism, sexism, homophobia, and transphobia against Indigenous women, girls, and , has become embedded in everyday life \u2014 whether this is through interpersonal forms of violence, through institutions like the health care system and the justice system, or in the laws, policies and structures of Canadian society. The result has been that many Indigenous people have grown up normalized to violence, while Canadian society shows an appalling apathy to addressing the issue. The National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls finds that this amounts to genocide.\n\nProject E-PANA has been the highest-profile police investigation involving missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, yet it touches on only a tiny fraction of the problem. Reliable statistics are difficult to come by, but more than 2,000 Indigenous women and girls in Canada have been reported to have gone missing or been murdered in the past three decades.\n\nSome are poor or undereducated, victims of domestic violence, drug abusers or are otherwise struggling in a larger society in which they are too often viewed as outsiders in their own lands. But Wiebe says that kind of lazy descriptor is unfair and devalues the defining characteristics of Indigenous communities who have survived immeasurable oppression, racism and targeted violence.\n\n\"The women and girls we've lost along the Highway of Tears were stopped short in the middle of their goals, dreams, education or careers. They all had full lives ahead of them and they leave behind loving families and friends who continue to look for them and wait for their return. Families and whole communities mourn them dearly,\" says Wiebe. \"Too often those who are missing or were murdered are unfairly framed as drug users or people in poverty living risky irresponsible lives and this negative stereotyping is not the true story or lived experience of those who we are missing. If the lives of each of these Indigenous women and girls had not been interrupted and taken, some would today be our teachers, psychologists, doctors, mothers, sisters, aunties, daughters, grandmothers, wives.\"\n\nSays Wiebe: \"I think it's really easy for people to think that there's something lacking in these people. Well ... it's what we stole. It's time to reexamine how we set up these people to ensure that they fail.\"\n\nA sign posted by the tribal offices warns against hitchhiking in Hazleton, British Columbia.\nANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\nToday Along the Highway of Tears\n\nThese days, billboards dot the shoulders of the Highway of Tears, warning against hitchhiking, even as the practice remains, to many underserviced Indigenous communities, a primary and necessary means of travel. Clary and other law enforcement authorities continue to talk to the media and work the Highway of Tears cases, hoping that someone, somewhere saw something or heard something and will come forward.\n\nCSFS has recently been awarded new funding in its efforts to support families of currently missing women and girls and others affected by violence against women. May 5, 2022, will again be a national day of awareness for Missing or Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) in Canada.\n\nMeanwhile, the Highway of Tears rolls on, a tragic and lasting symbol of a problem that stretches across the width and breadth of Canada, and much of the world.\n\n\"It's not just Canada. It's not just North America,\" Wiebe says. \"We need to be aware of how residential schools [the nearly century-long system that the government used to indoctrinate Indigenous children into European/Christian culture in Canada] and colonialism are not a thing of the past. There's still work to be done to undo those colonial practices. There's still policies that are absolutely unfair and biased against Indigenous people. We need to look at that ... and we need to really see and respect Indigenous people and families for their strength and beauty and resilience. We all need to take a personal look at ourselves, and identify the ways that we have bias and behaviors that are discriminatory.\"\n\nA missing poster for Mackie Basil, who disappeared in 2013, is now nearly covered in weeds near the entrance to Tachie, the small First Nation village in British Columbia.\nANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\nNow That's Interesting\n\nIn September 2020, a totem pole was raised along the Highway of Tears in Kitsumkalum Territory as a memorial to commemorate Canada's missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. Gladys Radek came up with the idea. Radek is the aunt of Tamara Chipman, a member of the Witset First Nation, who disappeared along the highway in 2005.\n\nCitation\nRelated Articles\nUp Next\nWhat to Do If a Loved One Goes Missing\nEXPLORE MORE\nPeople\n10 Serial Killers Who Have Never Been Caught\nHistory\nWho Was the Mad Trapper of Rat River?\nTV, Film & Music\nDo You Remember These Old Canadian TV Shows?\nHistory\n7 'Facts' They Got Wrong in School About Christopher Columbus\nThe World\nCan You Get More Questions Correct Than the Prime Minister of Canada?\nPeople\nThe Messy Legacy of the Columbus Day Holiday\nYou May Like\n14 People Who Vanished Without a Trace\nEXPLORE MORE\nHistory\nDid You Know There Are 23 Countries in North America?\nHistory\nThe French and Indian War Was the First 'Real' World War\nHistory\nThe Rise and Fall of the Oregon Trail\nPeople\n11 of the World's Worst Serial Killers\nHistory\n7 Most Evil Women In History\nPeople\nHaving a Cherokee Ancestor Doesn\u2019t Necessarily Make You Cherokee Too\nKeep Reading\nHow Serial Killers Work\nEXPLORE MORE\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLoading...\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNewsletter Sign Up\nSend me the latest news in science, culture and tech!\n\nLearn How Everything Works!\n\nCompany\n\nAbout\nCareers\nContact Us\nHelp\nSitemap\n\nInformation\n\nTerms\nReprints\nPrivacy Policy\nDo Not Sell My Info\n\nExplore\n\nQuizzes\nCoupons\nVideo\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 HowStuffWorks, a System1 Property"},

First Nation along Highway of Tears found dead\nMISSING WOMAN FOUND DEAD\nThe Canadian Press - Nov 6, 2023 / 7:30 pm | Story: 456064\nPhoto: The Canadian Press\nThe RCMP logo is seen outside Royal Canadian Mounted Police \"E\" Division Headquarters, in Surrey, B.C., on Friday April 13, 2018. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Darryl Dyck\n\nA woman who disappeared from a First Nations community in central British Columbia last month has been found dead.\n\nVanderhoof RCMP and the Saik'uz First Nation say the remains of Chelsey Quaw, who was first reported missing on Oct. 11, were found in a wooded area on the Indigenous community's territory.\n\nPolice say the BC Coroners Service is investigating the cause of death, and no further details on the case are available at this time.\n\nQuaw was one of two community members missing from the First Nation \u2014 located 100 kilometres west of Prince George along Highway 16 \u2014 this year.\n\nThe stretch of highway between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears after dozens have vanished or been killed along it over the last few decades.\n\nFirst Nations leaders and family members last week called for more action from police and the public in locating both Quaw and Jay Preston Raphael, who was reported missing Feb. 26 after walking away from a residence at the Saik'uz First Nation.\n\nQuaw's family has issued a statement through the Saik'uz First Nation and Carrier Sekani Family Services, thanking all people involved in the search and reminding them to keep up the continued search for Raphael.\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n257\nShares\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore BC News\n\n\n\nBC\nVancouver Webcam\nWebcam provided by windy.com\nRECENT STORIES\nMan dies in Lynn Canyon\nNorth Vancouver - {"url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/local-news/2024/04/18/mhc-to-host-day-of-awareness-event-for-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-people/", "title": "MHC to host day of awareness event for missing and murdered Indigenous people - Medicine Hat NewsMedicine Hat News", "body": "e-Edition ObituariesIn Loving MemoryMagazines\nSubscribeLogin to CommentRegister\n\n\nJULY 4TH, 2024     \nJOBS\n\n\nHome News Sports Business Entertainment Classifieds Life Commentary Contact\nLOCAL NEWS PROVINCIAL NEWS NATIONAL NEWS WORLD NEWS SOUTHERN ALBERTA NEWS\n\n\nPoll\n\nAre you concerned Legal Aid will be cut off to Albertans?\n\nYes\nNo\nI'm not sure\n\nVIEW RESULTS\n\nSponsored\n\n\n@MedicineHatNews Follow Us\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMHC to host day of awareness event for missing and murdered Indigenous people\n\nBY ANNA SMITH ON APRIL 18, 2024.\n\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nNiomi St. Paul dances at Riverside Veterans' Memorial Park in this 2019 file photo to celebrate National Indigenous Peoples Day. Medicine Hat College will be hosting its second annual day of awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous people on May 5.--NEWS FILE PHOTO\n\nasmith@medicinehatnews.com\n\nMedicine Hat College has announced its intent to host a National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People on May 5.\n\nIn partnership with several community organizations, this the second annual event surrounding this day, the college says in a press release. It will feature an Indigenous prayer, a one-kilometre awareness walk, a guest speaker and an honour song.\n\n\u201cWe need allies to help be a voice for Indigenous people as we can\u2019t do this alone,\u201d says Chasity Cairns, manager of Indigenous engagement and student support at MHC. \u201cBecoming involved helps show to the families that have been impacted that they are not alone, and their loved ones aren\u2019t forgotten.\u201d\n\nThe day began as Red Dress Day in 2010, but has since expanded to bring awareness to all the women, girls, two-spirit people and men who have gone missing or been murdered.\n\n\u201cWhen we have big events like these it brings our community together in the spirit of the cause, which can make a tragic event a place for connection and healing,\u201d adds Cairns. \u201cThis year, we also wanted to focus on how impacted families can find support in Medicine Hat so we will be having booths at the event for individuals that need support or want to know more.\u201d\n\nThe goal of the event is primarily to raise awareness, said Cairns, but also to help empower local groups in order to hopefully see some change.\n\n\u201cBasically, what\u2019s happening is Canada\u2019s Indigenous people are trying to create awareness, because there\u2019s families that have been impacted by this. And nobody is doing anything,\u201d said Cairns.\n\nShe added that many of the statistics that were initially shared on the topic have not significantly improved since information was first released.\n\n\u201cThere are students that have been impacted, who have family members who are missing or murdered, even in Medicine Hat,\u201d said Cairns. \u201cSo, when we think of that, what impact does that have on our community?\u201d\n\nWith these extended partnerships, the college hopes to bring the Indigenous organizations and non-Indigenous allies together for the day, to create conversations that will ultimately create support networks for those impacted.\n\nAttendees will be encouraged to wear red for the event, which will take place on campus from on campus from 2-4 p.m.\n\nShare this story:\n\n13\n-12\n\nComments are closed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMore ways to get to us\n Twitter\n Facebook\n Instagram\n YouTube\n Tumblr\nePaper Login\nSubscribe\nArchive\nAbout Us\nThe Medicine Hat News\nOther Publications\nContact\nContact the Medicine Hat News\n\n922 Allowance Ave SE\nMedicine Hat, AB T1A 3G7\n\n[P] 403.527.1101\n[F] 403.528.5696\n\nContact\nPrint Advertising: 403.528.5659\nNational Advertising: 403.528.5766\nOnline Advertising: 403.528.5698\nClassifieds: 403.526.7653\n\n\n\u00a9 1996-2024 The Medicine Hat News\nTerms and Conditions & Privacy policy\n\n"},
{"url": "https://people.howstuffworks.com/highway-of-tears-news.htm", "title": "Indigenous Women Keep Vanishing on Canada's Highway of Tears | HowStuffWorks", "body": "___\nScience\nTech\nHome & Garden\nAuto\nCulture\nMore\nSubmit Search\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHowStuffWorks\nCulture\nPeople\nLegal System\nCrime & Crime Prevention\nIndigenous Women Keep Vanishing on Canada's Highway of Tears\nBy: John Donovan \u00a0|\u00a0 Updated: Nov 4, 2021\nA private detective's notebook shows pictures of women who have gone missing along Canada's Highway of Tears. ANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\n\nSixteen years ago, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) opened an investigation surrounding nine women and girls who had gone missing or were found murdered along a desolate stretch of roadway in northern British Columbia. The effort was dubbed Project E-PANA, named for the goddess that the Inuit people of Canada believe cares for souls before they go to heaven or are reincarnated.\n\nThe number of women that the RCMP identified in its probe soon doubled, to 18, and to keep the numbers from climbing even higher, authorities placed criteria on who would be included on the list. They had to be women or girls, they had to be involved in high-risk activities like hitchhiking, and they had to be last seen \u2014 or their bodies found \u2014 within a mile or so of Highways 16, 97 or 5 in upper British Columbia.\n\nThe Highway of Tears, as the main throughway was dubbed, instantly became a symbol for unchecked violence against Indigenous women and girls in Canada. And it remains a symbol for the violence \u2014 and the many reasons behind it \u2014 that endures today.\n\nCanada's Route 16, which connects Prince George to Prince Rupert through the province of British Columbia, has been dubbed \"Highway of Tears\" because many First Nations women and girls have been murdered or disappeared from here.\nANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/ CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\nContents\nWhat Is the Highway of Tears?\nGiving Names to the Victims\nGetting Legal Justice\nToday Along the Highway of Tears\nWhat Is the Highway of Tears?\n\nThe drive from Vancouver, B.C., (which is a little less than a three-hour ride from Seattle) to the city of Prince George in northern British Columbia takes nearly nine hours. From there, a western turn along Highway 16 to the port city of Prince Rupert is another eight hours.\n\nIt is that final 416-mile (718-kilometer) section of winding, mostly two-lane highway between those two cities \u2014 through mountain passes, dozens of tiny villages, countless lakes and a whole lot of wilderness \u2014 that has become known as the Highway of Tears.\n\nThe remoteness of the highway, coupled with the fact that it bisects so many remote Indigenous communities without access to adequate transportation \u2014 often used by young Indigenous women hitchhiking simply as a means of getting from one place to another along the long, lonely road \u2014 makes it a ripe ground for violence.\n\n\"It's very, very isolated. You can drive for 15 minutes and not see a car. There are rivers and mountains. It's very heavily forested,\" says Wayne Clary, a retired RCMP investigator who has been brought back to work on the E-PANA cases. \"It's interesting when we look at some of our murders along there and we think, 'Was this a traveler who came upon this girl and had the opportunity to do what he did, or a local person?' It's dark, and the winters are pretty severe. You get a young girl hitchhiking and no one's around ... there one minute, gone the next.\"\n\n(Left) Gloria Moody was the first of the 18 women identified by the RCMP in the E-PANA project; 14-year-old Aielah Saric Auger (right) was the last.\nRCMP/PROJECT E-PANA\nGiving Names to the Victims\n\nIn October 1969, Gloria Moody, a 26-year-old mother of two and a member of the Bella Coola Indian Reserve of the Nuxalk Nation, was found dead along one of the Highway of Tears roads, naked, beaten and sexually assaulted. She became the first of the 18 women identified by the RCMP in the E-PANA project.\n\nOver the next almost 40 years, 17 other women became victims along the highway. The last was 14-year-old Aielah Saric Auger of the Lheidli T'enneh First Nations community, near Prince George. Her almost-unrecognizable body was discovered on an embankment of Highway 16 in February 2006, eight days after she went missing.\n\nAt its zenith, more than 60 RCMP investigators worked the cases along the Highway of Tears. But now, more than 15 years after Auger's body was found, barely a handful of police are still actively involved. No one has been added to the list since Auger, in 2006. Project E-PANA now consists of 13 homicide investigations and five missing people's investigations.\n\nAll the files, officially, remain open. But Clary has been forthright in informing the victims' families that many of the cases may never be solved.\n\n\"We've had some success,\" Clary says, noting that DNA samples tied notorious serial killer\u00a0 Bobby Jack Fowler to 16-year-old Highway of Tears victim Colleen MacMillen, found dead along the Highway in 1974. Fowler, suspected in at least two other Highway of Tears cases, died in an Oregon prison in 2006, before the connection in the MacMillen case was solidified. In 2019, authorities also got a murder conviction in the case of Monica Jack. The 12-year-old girl went missing in 1978, but her remains weren't found until 1995. That ruling is under appeal.\n\n\"We had a couple of very strong suspects, but just don't have the evidence. And we've used everything in our toolkit that we can,\" Clary adds. \"I'd say we've probably ruled out a lot of bad guys, too. It's still ongoing, but ... a lot of water is under the bridge.\"\n\nDNA tied serial killer Bobby Fowler to the death of Colleen MacMillen (left); Garry Taylor Handlen was convicted of murdering 12-year-old Monica Jack (right).\nRCMP/PROJECT E-PANA\nGetting Legal Justice\n\nCarrier Sekani Family Services (CSFS), based in British Columbia, works to secure social and legal justice for First Nations and other Indigenous families. They began the Highway of Tears Initiative to put into action 33 recommendations made in the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium Recommendations Report.\n\nThe recommendations include measures like better transportation options, increased police patrols, the establishment of awareness and prevention programs among at-risk women and their families, a wide-ranging media campaign and emergency readiness plans.\n\nYet the violence against Indigenous women, all across Canada, continues. According to the Canadian Femicide Observatory for Justice and Accountability:\n\nBased on 15 years of Homicide Survey data (2001-2015), homicide rates for Indigenous women and girls were approximately six times higher (48.2 per million population) than rates for non-Indigenous women and girls (8.2 per million population). Other research suggests that Indigenous women are 12 times more likely to be murdered or missing than any other women in Canada and 16 times more likely than Caucasian women.\n\n\"It's far too common. Even just this year alone, we've had three former clients go missing, you know?\" says Elsie Wiebe, the Calls to Justice Coordinator with CSFS's Highway of Tears Initiative. \"Just how common it is for Indigenous women to go missing and be found dead, or not be found at all. It has a devastating impact.\"\n\nWhat still needs addressing, Wiebe and many other Indigenous peoples advocates say, are the underlying conditions that lead to the violence. A 2019 report from the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls put it this way:\n\nColonial violence, as well as racism, sexism, homophobia, and transphobia against Indigenous women, girls, and , has become embedded in everyday life \u2014 whether this is through interpersonal forms of violence, through institutions like the health care system and the justice system, or in the laws, policies and structures of Canadian society. The result has been that many Indigenous people have grown up normalized to violence, while Canadian society shows an appalling apathy to addressing the issue. The National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls finds that this amounts to genocide.\n\nProject E-PANA has been the highest-profile police investigation involving missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, yet it touches on only a tiny fraction of the problem. Reliable statistics are difficult to come by, but more than 2,000 Indigenous women and girls in Canada have been reported to have gone missing or been murdered in the past three decades.\n\nSome are poor or undereducated, victims of domestic violence, drug abusers or are otherwise struggling in a larger society in which they are too often viewed as outsiders in their own lands. But Wiebe says that kind of lazy descriptor is unfair and devalues the defining characteristics of Indigenous communities who have survived immeasurable oppression, racism and targeted violence.\n\n\"The women and girls we've lost along the Highway of Tears were stopped short in the middle of their goals, dreams, education or careers. They all had full lives ahead of them and they leave behind loving families and friends who continue to look for them and wait for their return. Families and whole communities mourn them dearly,\" says Wiebe. \"Too often those who are missing or were murdered are unfairly framed as drug users or people in poverty living risky irresponsible lives and this negative stereotyping is not the true story or lived experience of those who we are missing. If the lives of each of these Indigenous women and girls had not been interrupted and taken, some would today be our teachers, psychologists, doctors, mothers, sisters, aunties, daughters, grandmothers, wives.\"\n\nSays Wiebe: \"I think it's really easy for people to think that there's something lacking in these people. Well ... it's what we stole. It's time to reexamine how we set up these people to ensure that they fail.\"\n\nA sign posted by the tribal offices warns against hitchhiking in Hazleton, British Columbia.\nANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\nToday Along the Highway of Tears\n\nThese days, billboards dot the shoulders of the Highway of Tears, warning against hitchhiking, even as the practice remains, to many underserviced Indigenous communities, a primary and necessary means of travel. Clary and other law enforcement authorities continue to talk to the media and work the Highway of Tears cases, hoping that someone, somewhere saw something or heard something and will come forward.\n\nCSFS has recently been awarded new funding in its efforts to support families of currently missing women and girls and others affected by violence against women. May 5, 2022, will again be a national day of awareness for Missing or Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) in Canada.\n\nMeanwhile, the Highway of Tears rolls on, a tragic and lasting symbol of a problem that stretches across the width and breadth of Canada, and much of the world.\n\n\"It's not just Canada. It's not just North America,\" Wiebe says. \"We need to be aware of how residential schools [the nearly century-long system that the government used to indoctrinate Indigenous children into European/Christian culture in Canada] and colonialism are not a thing of the past. There's still work to be done to undo those colonial practices. There's still policies that are absolutely unfair and biased against Indigenous people. We need to look at that ... and we need to really see and respect Indigenous people and families for their strength and beauty and resilience. We all need to take a personal look at ourselves, and identify the ways that we have bias and behaviors that are discriminatory.\"\n\nA missing poster for Mackie Basil, who disappeared in 2013, is now nearly covered in weeds near the entrance to Tachie, the small First Nation village in British Columbia.\nANDREW LICHTENSTEIN/CORBIS VIA GETTY IMAGES\nNow That's Interesting\n\nIn September 2020, a totem pole was raised along the Highway of Tears in Kitsumkalum Territory as a memorial to commemorate Canada's missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. Gladys Radek came up with the idea. Radek is the aunt of Tamara Chipman, a member of the Witset First Nation, who disappeared along the highway in 2005.\n\nCitation\nRelated Articles\nUp Next\nWhat to Do If a Loved One Goes Missing\nEXPLORE MORE\nPeople\n10 Serial Killers Who Have Never Been Caught\nHistory\nWho Was the Mad Trapper of Rat River?\nTV, Film & Music\nDo You Remember These Old Canadian TV Shows?\nHistory\n7 'Facts' They Got Wrong in School About Christopher Columbus\nThe World\nCan You Get More Questions Correct Than the Prime Minister of Canada?\nPeople\nThe Messy Legacy of the Columbus Day Holiday\nYou May Like\n14 People Who Vanished Without a Trace\nEXPLORE MORE\nHistory\nDid You Know There Are 23 Countries in North America?\nHistory\nThe French and Indian War Was the First 'Real' World War\nHistory\nThe Rise and Fall of the Oregon Trail\nPeople\n11 of the World's Worst Serial Killers\nHistory\n7 Most Evil Women In History\nPeople\nHaving a Cherokee Ancestor Doesn\u2019t Necessarily Make You Cherokee Too\nKeep Reading\nHow Serial Killers Work\nEXPLORE MORE\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLoading...\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNewsletter Sign Up\nSend me the latest news in science, culture and tech!\n\nLearn How Everything Works!\n\nCompany\n\nAbout\nCareers\nContact Us\nHelp\nSitemap\n\nInformation\n\nTerms\nReprints\nPrivacy Policy\nDo Not Sell My Info\n\nExplore\n\nQuizzes\nCoupons\nVideo\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 HowStuffWorks, a System1 Property"},
