Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\nArticle content\n\nHundreds of people gathered Sunday for the fourth annual Red Ribbon Day, to honour Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors.\n\nA National Day of Awareness, the event is also known as Red Dress or Red Shirt Day. Sunday\u2019s event was held near the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses in Calgary.\n\nDeborah Green-Gopher, MC for Sunday\u2019s event and MMEIP advocate said that red is very symbolic for MMEIP, because red is the colour that spirits see.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nCalgary martial arts instructor charged with child porn, luring offences\nBell: Calgary councillors and even Gondek blow up pipe probe plans\nNew E. coli case at daycare chain struck by massive 2023 outbreak\nGreen Line board staying mum on cost overruns, will present recommendations to council July 30\nGreen Line subcontractor loses toes in LRT project's first workplace safety incident\nArticle content\n\nThe many red ribbons, dresses, and shirts affixed to trees along Memorial Drive have the names of loved ones, each \u201ccarrying the spirit\u201d of that loved one.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a march or a rally, it\u2019s a healing gathering for families and survivors, and for non-Indigenous education and awareness,\u201d said Green-Gopher.\n\nIndigenous and M\u00e9tis women perform at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\nThe day holds high significance for Green-Gopher and her family, as her sister is on the list of missing and murdered Indigenous people.\n\n\u201cWe are still being murdered, being exploited, facing violence at alarming rates compared to non-Indigenous people in Canada,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cAnybody that has a significant loss in their family, you have to go through a grieving period,\u201d she said. \u201cFor my family, justice has never been found; however, we did have a healing ceremony on Tsuut\u2019ina Nation.\u201d\n\nWith different people in different stages of their healing journey, she said this event is meant to bring the healing to them.\n\n\u201cWe have dancers, singers, and an opportunity for families to just share what they need to share from their hearts.\u201d\n\nA performer drums at the Memorial Drive Field of Crosses for Red Ribbon Day in Calgary on Sunday, May 5, 2024. The event honours Missing, Murdered, and Exploited Indigenous Peoples (MMEIP), their families and survivors. Steven Wilhelm/Postmedia\n\n\u2018We need action on the 231 Calls for Justice\u2019\n\nNoon News Roundup\n\nYour weekday lunchtime roundup of curated links, news highlights, analysis and features.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nGreen-Gopher spoke about the 231 Calls for Justice and the actions within them, which are meant to be taken by all Canadians.\n\n\u201cWe need action on the 231 Calls for Justice in this country. Photo by Flickr user Sean_Marshall. CC BY-NC 2.0\n\nRed,\u00a0empty dresses that represent death and absence. They hang loosely and lifelessly, as if waiting to be worn\u00a0by their symbolic owners \u2014 Canada's\u00a0missing Aboriginal\u00a0women.\n\nThe\u00a0garments are\u00a0part of the\u00a0REDress Project,\u00a0an installation art project seeking to draw attention to the injustice.\u00a0About 1,200 Aboriginal\u00a0women have been murdered or gone missing since 1980, according to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.\u00a0While Aboriginal women make up only 4.3% of the Canadian population,\u00a0Aboriginal female murder victims\u00a0represented about 16% of all female murders\u00a0across Canada.\n\nOn 4\u00a0October 2015, Jamie Black,\u00a0the creator of the project, asked women to donate a red dress, hang one outside their\u00a0house\u00a0or even wear one on that day.\u00a0On Twitter, under the hashtag \u00a0#REDressProject, citizens around Canada collected haunting images of the dresses as a reminder of all the Aboriginal\u00a0Canadian women\u00a0who have been robbed of their lives.\n\nEvoking a presence through the marking of absence. #MMIW #REDressProject pic.twitter.com/cZB0aRYnQP \u2014 Feeding Nunavut (@FeedingNunavut) October 6, 2015\n\nBlack, herself a member of the indigenous M\u00e9tis community, launched the REDress Project in 2010, collaborating with the\u00a0University of Winnipeg\u2019s Institute for Women\u2019s and Gender Studies at the time to display about 100 red dresses indoors and outdoors around campus. All the dresses were donations by people from all around the country and from\u00a0different cultures.\n\nShe offered insight into what motivated her to begin the project in an interview\u00a0with\u00a0the portal Indigenous Foundations Arts:\n\nThe REDress Project was inspired by my work as a teacher in Opaskawayak Cree Nation, also known as The Pas, where Helen Betty Osborne was brutally murdered while walking home one night by two young men who were not charged or sentenced until years later. And by a group of 300 women in Colombia who had the courage to create a moving 4 hour performance piece to protest their missing and murdered loved ones in the main square in Bogota. By a female Aboriginal scholar at a Canadian Studies conference in Germany standing up to remind everyone of Canada\u2019s colonial past and present.\n\nDespite the staggering numbers of violence against Aboriginal women in Canada, many are still unaware of the ongoing\u00a0tragedy. Linda Nothing, who helped in organising the project's installation in Calgary, explained in an interview to Metro News:\n\nThe image itself can speak to a lot of people. If they aren\u2019t aware of the issue they are often shocked and surprised that it\u2019s happening in Canada because there is a lot of under education and miss-education about indigenous issues here.\n\nSee video of the project from 2011 below:\n\nThe REDress Project is currently\u00a0displayed at The Acadia University Art Gallery\u00a0until November 29.\u00a0You can follow the project's updates on its official\u00a0Facebook\u00a0page.\n\nCategories\nNorth AmericaCanada\nArts & CultureEthnicity & RaceHuman RightsIndigenousWomen & Gender\n\t\nWritten by\nElaine Rigas\n\t\nSupport our work\n\nGlobal Voices stands out as one of the earliest and strongest examples of how media committed to building community and defending human rights can positively influence how people experience events happening beyond their own communities and national borders.\n\nPlease consider making a donation to help us continue this work.\n\nDonate now\n\nRecent North America Stories\nIn Georgia, a series of legal amendments are putting the country's EU aspirations on hold\nGeorgia\u00a0 11 hours ago\nNiger: Boubacar Tour\u00e9 analyzes the withdrawal of US troops\nSub-Saharan Africa\u00a0 7 days ago\nDecolonization, the climate crisis, and improving media education in the Pacific\nOceania\u00a0 1 week ago\nMore \u00bb\nRecent stories\nA year after environmental protests rocked Azerbaijan's village of Soyudlu, it is business as usual\nAzerbaijan\u00a0 11 hours ago\nSix dishes that most represent Hong Kong\nEast Asia\u00a0 14 hours ago\nWaiting for Beryl in Jamaica\nCaribbean\u00a0 1 day ago\nStart the conversation\n\nAuthors, please log in \u00bb\n\n Name (required)\n\n Email (will not be published) (required)\n\n Website\n\n Subscribe to comments on this post via email\n\nGuidelines\nAll comments are reviewed by a moderator. {"url": "https://www.thegraphicleader.com/news/local-news/local-companies-apologize-after-sign-wars-competition-turns-sour", "title": "Local companies apologize after 'sign wars' competition turns sour | The Graphic Leader", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nLocal companies apologize after 'sign wars' competition turns sour\nAuthor of the article:\nBronson Carver\nPublished May 06, 2021 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 13, 2021 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nRoyal LePage issued an apology for a culturally insensitive sign they posted during a local \"sign wars\" competition. PHOTO BY BRONSON CARVER /Miner and News\nArticle content\n\nA competition being waged by local businesses recently took a turn for the worse after two local real estate companies added some culturally insensitive contributions to the mix.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe competition started when local radio station 89.5 The Lake challenged area businesses to put up signs jokingly slamming their competitors as a way to promote positive community engagement and a way to put smiles on peoples\u2019 faces during the pandemic.\n\nWednesday afternoon, Royal LePage Landry\u2019s for Real Estate Kenora waded into murky territory, posting their sign on Facebook that read \u201cA century ago the Royal\u2019s [sic] triumphed all over cabin country and settled in the northwest to call Kenora both home & cottage.\u201d Shortly after, Century 21 Northern Choice Realty Ltd. commented on the Facebook post, writing \u201cLove it!\u201d\n\nFollowing the backlash, both real estate companies issued apologies over Facebook. Royal LePage called their original post \u201cinsensitive\u201d and \u201ctasteless,\u201d adding that \u201cin no way did we intend to highlight or make light of the colonial past that continues to negatively affect First Nations peoples.\u201d Century 21 wrote \u201cwe understand the perspective of the post and how it was inappropriate,\u201d adding that they respect Treaty land and they are sorry to anyone who they have offended.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nVarious Canadian federal party leaders have previously recognized that the conquest of Turtle Island \u2014 or North America \u2014 was oppressive and soul wounding toward Indigenous people. The events unfolded on May 5, which is Red Dress Day and the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG).\n\nAnishinaabeg lawyer from Treaty 3 and Kenora home-lander Danielle Morrison was one of many who became outraged by the posts. According to her, the posts erase the true history behind Treaty 3 and perpetuate a narrative that is white supremacist in nature and suggests Indigenous people are \u201cless than.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe characterization that these lands were triumphed is a false narrative,\u201d Morrison said over the phone. \u201cIt\u2019s a misrepresentation of our history. Settlers were welcomed into the territory. Treaty 3 took years of negotiation and the survival of settlers and Canada\u2019s ability to expand into the west relied on signing an agreement.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cThe understanding of that relationship was that it was about a sharing of the land. So, it\u2019s disappointing to see that a business would mischaracterize our history as us being conquered peoples. These are the exact views that have existed for decades in this community [that] feed into racism and racial tensions in Kenora because they don\u2019t see how it impacts Anishinaabe people.\u201d\n\nIndigenous community advocate and politician Tania Cameron also took serious issue with the posts, calling Royal LePage\u2019s contribution a \u201cpoor attempt\u201d at getting in on the fun that left her feeling offended.\n\n\u201cKenora is surrounded by 12 First Nations, and we were actually put into our little patches of land or Indian Reserves, and I don\u2019t think Kenora should gloss over that colonial past,\u201d Cameron said. \u201cMaking light of it was in poor taste.\u201d\n\nCameron added that she feels it is important for anyone and everyone to call out these things when they see them, and that hopefully, this can be a \u201cteaching moment\u201d for all.\n\n\u201cWe have to call it out,\u201d she said. \u201cWhoever put the sign together, whoever approved it, they learned a lesson today, and that\u2019s one good take away from it.\u201d\n\nReflecting on the apologies, Cameron said both companies are on the right track, but should also take further steps in healing, such as inviting an elder into their spaces to heal and educate.\n\nbcarver@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nNEWS NEAR PORTAGE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://london.ctvnews.ca/symbolic-red-dress-theft-may-be-hate-crime-sarnia-ont-police-1.6294532", "title": "Sarnia police say red dress theft may be hate crime | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nLONDON\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nLONDON\nNews\nSymbolic red dress theft may be hate crime: Sarnia, Ont. police\nSean Irvine\nCTV News London multi-media journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPublished March 1, 2023 11:53 a.m. MST\nShare\n\nVideo from a security camera at Sarnia City Hall may not be immediately compelling. But what its lens captured has hurt the Indigenous community and angered many in Sarnia-Lambton.\n\nIn the video, a male suspect wearing a white ball cap is seen taking clothing items off trees and light posts\n(opens in a new tab)\n.\n\n12 red dresses disappeared. In an upsetting twist, they had been placed just the day before, prior to the Stolen Sisters March.\n\nIt remembers missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nRELATED STORIES\n'Inexcusable act': Sarnia police investigating after red dress display torn down at city hall\n'Project Oasis': Sarnia police announce $3.2 million drug bust on Friday\nFire victim forced into homeless shelter amid soaring rents\nWill more police officers make London safer?\nReported shooting in London leads to search for two suspects\n\n\u201cAs soon as we came down the street, you could tell something is not right,\u201d said an employee of the Sarnia-Lambton Native Friendship Centre.\n\nHe and another man had secured the dresses on Feb. 13.\n\nProgram manager Tracey LeBlond shares their shock.\n\n\u201cIt hit home with us, on a day of such significance, where we are talking about the women who go missing,\u201d LeBlond said. \u201cNow, the dresses that signify the remembrance of them were stolen.\u201d\n\nThe Sarnia Police Service are looking for the man who's responsible for vandalizing a display meant to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Sarnia, Ont. on Feb. 15, 2023. (Source: Sarnia Police Service)\n\nThe 30-year tradition of hanging red dresses to mark the missing and murdered Indigenous women began in British Columbia.\n\nNearly every indigenous person has been impacted by a loss, said Dawna Smith-Sutherland. She is the executive director of the Native Friendship Centre.\n\nShe added not all those missing and murdered are female.\n\n\u201cFor me, I\u2019ve lost a cousin and an uncle. Both were murdered. It has an impact,\u201d she said.\n\nThe red dresses were taken from city hall at about 5:30 a.m. on Feb. 14.\n\nThe Sarnia-Lambton Native Friendship Centre in Sarnia, Ont. (Sean Irvine/CTV News London)\n\nWhile they may not be of great material value, the Sarnia Police Service recognizes their greater meaning.\n\nConst. Giovanni Sotosanti said officers are actively seeking the suspect.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, we can\u2019t exclude that this may have been some sort of hate crime, or of that nature,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we can\u2019t confirm that yet either.\u201d\n\nThe public is encouraged to contact Sarnia police if they can help to identify the suspect at 510-344-8861 ext. 6197.\n\nConst. Giovanni Sotosanti of the Sarnia Police Service. (Sean Irvine/CTV News London)\n\nIf an arrest is made, LeBond said she\u2019ll want them to answer one question.\n\n\u201cWhy did you need to do that on such a day of significance to our community?\u201d she said.\n\nA day which will be even larger next year, according to Smith-Sutherland. She said it\u2019s important to come back strong while working to educate the community.\u00a0\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nTracey LeBlond and Dawna Smith-Sutherland of the Sarnia-Lambton Native Friendship Centre. Behind them is a sticker of a red dress to mark murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls. {"url": "https://london.ctvnews.ca/inexcusable-act-sarnia-police-investigating-after-red-dress-display-torn-down-at-city-hall-1.6293047", "title": "Red dress display in Sarnia vandalized, suspect sought by police | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nLONDON\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nLONDON\nNews\n'Inexcusable act': Sarnia police investigating after red dress display torn down at city hall\nThe Sarnia Police Service are looking for the man who's responsible for vandalizing a display meant to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Sarnia, Ont. on Feb. 15, 2023. (Source: Sarnia Police Service)\nAshley Hyshka\nCTVNewsLondon.ca Web Writer\nFollow |Contact\nPublished Feb. 28, 2023 2:28 p.m. MST\nShare\n\nPolice in Sarnia are investigating after a display meant to remember missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls was vandalized earlier in the month.\n\nAccording to a release from the Sarnia Police Service, as part of the \u201cMurdered and Missing Indigenous Women March\u201d a number of red dresses were put on display at Sarnia City Hall to signify and honour the lives of women and girls who were lost.\n\nPrior to the planned march however, police said an unidentified single male attended the area and stripped the dresses down from trees before stealing them at approximately 5:15 a.m. on Feb. 14.\n\n\u201cAs a result of this inexcusable act, the Sarnia Police Service was contacted to investigate the matter,\u201d police said in the release.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nEx London, Ont. cop accused of sexual assault granted bail\nFire victim forced into homeless shelter amid soaring rents\n\nAdditional footage of the suspect and the incident itself can be found on YouTube\n(opens in a new tab)\n.\u00a0\n\nPolice are now asking the public for help in identifying the suspect allegedly responsible for the vandalism. Anyone with information is asked to contact Sgt. S. Peters, at 519-344-8861, extension 6197, or Sarnia Lambton Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.\u00a0\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nThe Sarnia Police Service are looking for the man who's responsible for vandalizing a display meant to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Sarnia, Ont. on Feb. 15, 2023. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/highway-of-tears-cleansing-walk-inspires-song-1.2284204", "title": "AUDIO: Highway of Tears cleansing walk inspires song - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nAUDIO: Highway of Tears cleansing walk inspires song\nUnder the branches of a Cottonwood Kym Gouchie spoke of the surroundings that inspired her latest song - a chant that reflects a local woman's efforts to cleanse the Highway of Tears.\nSamantha Wright Allen\nJun 21, 2016 6:30 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKym Gouchie sings a song about the Highway of Tears during Aboriginal Day Tuesday in the park. Citizen photo by Brent Braaten June 21 2016Brent Braaten, Photographer\n\nUnder the branches of a Cottonwood Kym Gouchie spoke of the surroundings that inspired her latest song - a chant that reflects a local woman's efforts to cleanse the Highway of Tears.\n\n\"It felt like it came from the trees, it felt like it came from the ground and it came from the sky and it just filled the drum and the voice filled the space I was walking it,\" said Gouchie as the National Aboriginal Day entertainment thrummed in the background.\n\nGouchie joined Brenda Wilson-John on the last leg of her long journey from Prince Rupert to Prince George along Highway 16. During one five-kilometre stretch, the Lheidli T'enneh singer brought her drum.\n\n\"All of my songs come from a place that is beyond my conscious level,\" she said.\n\nThrough the minute-long song, Gouchie chants on repeat: \"We are cleansing the Highway of Tears, as we walk, as we walk.\"\n\nIt started as an incantation on the road but the song came together Sunday on the river bank, where she sat with Wilson-John and the Khast'an Drummers, who also played the song.\n\n\"Fluidly it all came together,\" said Gouchie, adding it had special meaning that Wilson-John helped finalize the piece.\n\n\"We sat down and she said this was the song that came to me,\" recalled Wilson-John, who walked more than 700 kilometres in memory of her sister, Ramona Wilson. \"First it was just the chant. It was just amazing and I was like 'Yes, that's it.'\n\n\"It's very simple and right to the point and it is very powerful at the same time.\"\n\nThe song is exudes both sadness and strength.\n\n\"Right now it's a victory, it's a success, it's a celebration, it's National Aboriginal Day, but if we were to be singing this in any other situation it would have a much sadder tone to it,\" Gouchie said. \"Having (Wilson-John) walk on the stage in her little fluorescent vest, it was very emotional but it was also very empowering... It just shows how strong we are as a people and especially as women.\"\n\nMusic is the best medium to speak to that dichotomy, both to honour the missing and murdered and empower those who remain.\n\n\"It's universal,\" said Gouchie. \"It's like a smile. Music can heal a heart. Music, especially when you have a drum and you have your voice, is the highest form of prayer.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. Polytechnic honours Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls with red dress displays - MBC Radio", "body": " \nHome\n \nLISTEN LIVE\n \nNEWS\n \nOn Demand\n \nCONTESTS\n \nRadio Bingo\n \nOn Air\n \nDial Positions\n \nAbout Us\n \nLinks\n \nContact Us\nSask. Polytechnic honours Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls with red dress displays\n\nby MBC News | May 10, 2019 | Current News | 0 comments\n\nRed dress displays have been placed at four Saskatchewan Polytechnic campuses to honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nA permanent display can be viewed at the Moose Jaw campus and displays were up from Saturday until Monday in Prince Albert, Saskatoon and Regina.\n\nIndigenous Strategy coordinator Deanna Speidel says the red dress concept was originally created by a Winnipeg-based M\u00e9tis artist.\n\n\u201cJamie Black started this initiative of displaying red dresses with her art installations,\u201d Speidel adds.\n\nThe displays were supported through Saskatchewan Polytechnic\u2019s Indigenous Strategy.\n\n\u201cSask Polytech\u2019s Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls red dress displays bring about awareness and attention to this important issue in our campus communities. These displays evoke presence through absence. The more people are talking about missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, the less we will forget. I hope that there is room for dialogue to create that space to bring about public attention to this very serious issue,\u201d said Speidel.\n\n(Photo courtesy of Saskatchewan Polytechnic.)\n\n\u00a9 Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation | Site Design by Answers IT Consulting | Powered by WordPress"},
{"url": "https://www.cjme.com/2022/05/05/indigenous-declaration-passes-families-pack-gallery-for-red-dress-day/", "title": "Indigenous declaration passes, families pack gallery for Red Dress Day | 980 CJME", "body": "Skip to Content\nLISTEN LIVE\nNEWS\nLocal\nProvincial\nCanada & World\nTHE EVAN BRAY SHOW\nSHOWS\nThe Greg Morgan Morning Show\nThe Evan Bray Show\nSaskatchewan Afternoon\nThe Green Zone\nGarden Talk\nReal Ag on the Weekend\nRoy Green Show\nSPORTS\nProvincial Sports\nRiders\nThe Green Zone with Jamie and Drew\nThe Sport Market\nPROMOTIONS\nContests\nConcerts\nCJME Auction\nEvents\nON DEMAND\nShows\nCommentaries\nThe Shell Lake Massacre\nIndigenous declaration passes, families pack gallery for Red Dress Day\nRegina / 980 CJME\nLisa Schick\nMay 5, 2022 | 3:52 PM\n\nFSIN Vice-Chief Aly Bear speaks on Red Dress Day about the importance of action on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit Peoples on May 5, 2022. (Lisa Schick/980 CJME)\n\n\n\n\n\nThe gallery at the Saskatchewan Legislative Building was filled with women wearing red and ribbon skirts Thursday morning.\n\nThey were there to push the government for action on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People \u2014 and they got it, in a way.\n\nGwenda Yuzicappi speaks on Red Dress Day about her late daughter Amber Redman and the need for action on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit Peoples on May 5, 2022. (Lisa Schick/980 CJME)\n\nIn an emergency debate, the Assembly voted unanimously to pass and adopt the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations\u2019 Declaration to Honour Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nAhead of the proceedings, the women and leaders gathered to share their stories.\n\n\u201cMy daughter was only 19 years old when she was taken. It took two years and 10 months for us to find her remains and we only found 42 per cent of her remains,\u201d said Gwenda Yuzicappi, her voice full of emotion.\n\nYuzicappi\u2019s daughter was Amber Redman.\n\n\u201cTwo years and 10 months not knowing where your daughter is? That\u2019s a lot of pain, that\u2019s a lot of emotions \u2014 depression, (thoughts of) suicide. I went through so many emotions, it was very, very hard (and) difficult,\u201d explained Yuzicappi.\n\nLoretta Henderson\u2019s daughter, Krista Kenny, went missing in May 2009 and was found dead a few days later.\n\n\u201cShe was kind, she was loving (and) she helped out so many people,\u201d Henderson said of her daughter. \u201cEven though it was 13 years ago, it\u2019s still so hard. Every day we talk about her (and) always mention her because she was my only daughter.\u201d\n\nLoretta Henderson holds a picture of her late daughter, Krista Kenny, and talks about her and her disappearance on Red Dress Day at the Legislative Building on May 5, 2022. (Lisa Schick/980 CJME)\n\nJoyce Keepness is Tamara Keepness\u2019 grandmother; the five-year-old went missing without a trace in 2004.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s something that you never forget; it stays with you. Every day there\u2019s something that comes up that reminds you that this little person was never found. This little person, are we ever going to find her? Is she out there?\u201d Joyce Keepness said.\n\nLooking at the women around her, Keepness said she was glad to see the gathering and was proud of the leadership for putting together the show of support on Red Dress Day.\n\nFSIN Vice-Chief Aly Bear stood tall in her headdress and ribbon skirt in front of the other women, her voice full of purpose.\n\n\u201cWe have women going missing every day and it\u2019s not taken seriously,\u201d Bear said.\n\nBear said they were standing in solidarity with all the families of those missing and murdered and what they\u2019re going through. She said they were at the legislature to support and uplift the families, but also to push for the adoption of the declaration.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re here to continue to stand up and let you know that we are still here, and we\u2019re here to continue to protect each other and we want you to stand with us as well in solidarity,\u201d said Bear.\n\nBear said the conversation needs to continue longer than just one day, that talking about the problem is the only way to find solutions to it.\n\n\u201cEvery day is Red Dress Day. We Indigenous women endure disproportionate levels of violence that are affected far too often by government\u2019s failure to act, a failure to intervene, a failure to stand up for those who need it most,\u201d said Betty Nippi-Albright, the NDP\u2019s critic for Indigenous issues.\n\nNippi-Albright said if communities keep losing Indigenous women to murder and disappearances, they\u2019re losing a very important member of society.\n\n\u201cWhen it comes to Indigenous women, we don\u2019t get the attention that non-Indigenous women get when we go missing, or when we go murdered. And we need to change that and it changes by imploring our elected officials to act and stop giving lip service,\u201d said Nippi-Albright.\n\nThe declaration\n\nThe Saskatchewan Party and NDP voted in favour of adopting the FSIN\u2019s declaration, which consists of five articles.\n\n\u2014 \u201cThe Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations and its governing and organizational structures will take responsibility and action to address the disproportionate victimization of Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIn matters of governance and politics, Indigenous women have the right to participate at all levels of governance, including the Nation, tribal council, provincial and national levels, free from discrimination, physical, verbal, spiritual or emotional abuse and harassment, and with respect for both individual autonomy and democratic principles.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIndigenous women and girls have the right to partake in ceremonial practices, access safe and accessible childcare, education, health, recreation, resource stewardship, economic development, land protection and livelihood activities with full consideration for their important roles and responsibilities as life-givers of our Nations, free from disparagement, racism, sexual innuendo, harassment or assault; and with reasonable expectations of physical, mental, spiritual and emotional safety.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIndigenous women and girls have the right to physical, mental, emotional and spiritual protection. It is incumbent upon all persons to ensure the safety of women and girls.\n\n\u2014 \u201cIndigenous women and girls have the right to access independent and culturally relevant and safe processes to investigate and meaningfully address any and all complaints of gender-based violence. Indigenous women and girls who experience gender-based violence have the right to redress and accountability from those responsible.\u201d\n\nDuring the emergency debate, Don Morgan \u2014 the minister responsible for First Nations, Metis and Northern Affairs \u2014 said there was nothing in those five articles a person could disagree with. He talked about the government\u2019s commitment to lessening violence against everyone in the province, including Indigenous women and girls.\n\nIn her remarks during debate, Nippi-Albright talked about past action from the government on such issues.\n\n\u201cThis government has sent the message to us as Indigenous women (that) they do not care. This government does not care,\u201d said Nippi-Albright.\n\nAnd the NDP critic talked about needing the government to not just give lip service to this issue and asked whether there would be clear reporting on measurements of success.\n\n\u201cOr is it just a document you\u2019re going to say, \u2018Yeah, we approved it. We put it on the website\u2019?\u201d Nippi-Albright said as she slammed her hand down on the desk. \u201cAnd remember, not all Indigenous people have access to internet.\u201d\n\nAmong actions requested were for the government to adopt the 231 recommendations from the National Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and to offer more support to relevant community-based organizations.\n\nDiscover more on CJME.com\nRegina man arrested, charged after two people attacked with knife at yard sale\n6h ago\n 1.6K Views\nFunnel cloud advisories issued for east-central Saskatchewan\n3h ago\n 708 Views\nSTF, gov't still working to find a teachers' contract arbitrator\n23h ago\n 672 Views\nSask gov't funds garnished over carbon tax dispute, justice minister says\n2h ago\n 610 Views\nSask. Co-op grocery shortage continues following 'IT disruption'\n23h ago\n 607 Views\nMore\nON AIR NOW\nThe Green Zone with Jamie & Drew\n2:00 PM - 6:00 PM\nSports\nTrevor Reid feeling blessed to have opportunity with Riders\n40m ago\n\"It's a blessing,\" Reid said. \"I just want to keep proving to them I can be the guy for the job.\"\nRead More\nContactAdvertise with 980 CJMEContest RulesPrivacy PolicyTerms Of Service\nRawlco Radio Ltd.\nCopyright \u00a9 2024. visiting Red Earth\n01:21\nSearch for Sask. boy continues\n01:46\nSearch for missing boy\n02:11\nHelping hand in search for boy\nBrendan Ellis\nCTVNewsRegina.ca Senior Digital Content Producer\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2022 6:55 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2022 3:07 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nSaskatchewan Premier Scott Moe said he plans on calling the chief of Red Earth Cree Nation, but would not commit to visiting the community.\n\n\u201cAnytime a leader, in any community, wants to speak to an elected official we try to make that happen,\u201d Moe said Thursday. \u201cI most certainly will reach out, as I understand that request has been made.\u201d\n\nThe community has spent the past few weeks searching for five-year-old Frank Young, who was reported missing on April 19.\n\nDuring Question Period Thursday, NDP Leader Ryan Meili said Red Earth Cree Nation\u2019s chief invited both Public Safety Minister Christine Tell and Premier Scott Moe to come and visit the community.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nSearch focuses on river as hunt for missing Sask. boy continues\nSask. community welcomes 'any and all support' in search for missing boy\n\n\u201cChief Fabian Head did however express real disappointment that no one from the government had come to visit the community and seen the reality of the challenges they face,\u201d Meili said.\n\nMeili said he and MLA Doyle Vermette visited the community this past weekend.\n\n\u201cIt was really a moving and difficult experience just to see the pain that the family is in and understand the heartbreak that the whole community has,\u201d the NDP leader said.\n\nThe premier however, said he did not know whether he will visit the community.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been in Regina for largely for the last number of months. As we know I\u2019ll be on a mission next week,\u201d Moe said. \u201cI don\u2019t know that one way or another.\u201d\n\nMoe said it is \u201chighly likely\u201d the minister attends the community, and that he has asked Carrot River Valley MLA Fred Bradshaw, the representative of the area, to reach out as well.\n\n\u201cThis is a very serious situation, this is a five-year-old boy, and the family asked, and the chief asked, and my response was yes, and I think that\u2019s what the premier should say as well,\u201d Meili said.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what we need from our leaders, is to come and see the reality of the struggles people are facing.\u201d\n\nAs of Wednesday, a 92-square-kilometre area has been covered, as RCMP and volunteers search the area around the community.\n\nYoung was last seen around noon on April 19, although he may have been spotted at a local playground around 2:30 p.m., according to police.\n\nAbduction is not suspected and his disappearance does not meet the criteria for an Amber Alert.\n\nMoe said he understands one of the concerns the community has is surrounding the lack of an Amber Alert.\n\n\u201cWhether it\u2019s an Indigenous Amber Alert, or whether its enhancements to the Amber Alert that we have, that may be a conversation our minister could have with the RCMP potentially, as there\u2019s other entities at this table,\u201d Moe said.\n\n\u201cAnytime there\u2019s opportunities for us to enhance some of the procedures around missing children, most notably on today May 5, Red Dress Day, it\u2019s worth a discussion.\u201d\n\nThe search for Frank Young entered its 17th day on Thursday. RCMP said it would be focusing on water searches in the Carrot River over the next few days.\n\nRed Earth Cree Nation is located approximately 224 kilometres east of Prince Albert, Sask.\n\nRELATED {"url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/local-news/documentary-to-screen-in-prince-george-for-red-dress-day-6912059", "title": "Free screening of MMIWG documentary coming to Prince George - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nDocumentary to screen in Prince George for Red Dress Day\n\u2018Adaawk\u2019 tells the stories of family members of the missing and murdered along the Highway of Tears\n\tHanna Petersen\n\nApr 26, 2023 1:27 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nAdaawk is directed, produced and told by family members along the Highway of Tears. Adaawk\nListen to this article\n00:01:48\n\nA documentary that gives a glimpse into the lives of loved ones that are missing and murdered along the Highway of Tears will be screened in Prince George.\n\nCarrier Sekani Family Services (CSFS), in partnership with the Indian Residential School Survivors\u2019 Society (IRSSS), is hosting a special, free screening of the film, \u2018Adaawk\u2019, in honour of Red Dress Day, and the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG).\n\nThe documentary is called, \u2018Adaawk\u2019 pronounced as \"A-Dow-ick\" (def.: Oral history) and it is directed, produced and told by family members members along the Highway of Tears.\n\nFamily members courageously share their stories, all while dealing with grief and loss, and what the raising of the \"Grandmother\" Commemoration Memorial and Healing Pole means to them.\n\nEntry for the screening is free and Julie Daum, CSFS Executive Director of Justice, will emcee the event.\n\n\u201cWe must always take the time to honour and acknowledge those among us who were taken so tragically and their families and communities,\u201d says Daum.\n\n\u201cWe must remember and take the time to reflect on who and what we lost. I appreciate all those who work to commemorate them.\u201d\n\nLorna Brown, director and producer of \u2018Adaawk,\u2019 says that the purpose behind her film is to put names and faces to the Indigenous women, girls, two-spirited and gender diverse people who have gone missing along the Highway of Tears, and to honour their families.\n\n\u201cThe public needs to hear our stories,\u201d says Brown. \u201cWe\u2019re not just a number.\u201d\n\nAnyone can register for a free ticket at adaawk.eventbrite.ca.\n\nThe screening will take place on May 3 at Prince George Cineplex Famous Players Theatre with doors opening at 5:30 p.m. and the film starting at 6 p.m.\n\nA Q&A session will follow with special guests from the film in attendance.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has been shared 41 times\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nMore Local News\n\tWater main break forces closure of Prince George street\n\tNew bus shelters coming to Prince George\n\tFoodie Fridays back for the summer in downtown Prince George\nPrince George - Kristen Robinson reports \u2013 Jun 17, 2017\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nMary Teegee has spent over two decades wondering how things could have ended up differently for her cousin if she\u2019d had access to safe transit.\n\nIn 1994, Ramona Wilson went missing while hitchhiking near the central B.C. town of Smithers. Ten months later, her body was found, adding her name to the list of 18 women since 1969 who have been killed or went missing along that same stretch of Highway 16 from Prince Rupert to Prince George \u2014 commonly referred to as the \u201cHighway of Tears.\u201d\n\nTo this day, Wilson\u2019s family is far from solving her murder, but Teegee says they\u2019re not the only ones left with a lack of closure.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019d definitely still like to find out what happened,\u201d she says, \u201cbut we can\u2019t forget the other families where they haven\u2019t found the remains of their loved ones. There\u2019s still a threat out there, and we can\u2019t forget that.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nA long-called-for transit service will hopefully bring an end to that era of death and sadness. BC Transit has announced two new bus routes that will connect Smithers to Prince George will begin service on Monday, using Burns Lake as a central hub.\n\nThe daily email you need for Edmonton's top news stories.\n\nThe service comes 11 years after\u00a0the Highway of Tears Symposium Recommendations Report, a list of 33 recommendations for improving safety along the highway and for the First Nations communities it passes through. The provincial government announced last year it was committing $6.4 million over three years to a Highway 16 transportation plan, which will eventually see bus service extend throughout the 750-kilometre highway.\n\nREAD MORE:\u00a0B.C. announces bus service for Highway of Tears\n\nMORE ON BC\n2 prominent B.C. MLAs announce they will not seek re-election this fall\nVancouver police seek 2 men for information on West End death\nCurtains for protected views? Vancouver may end \u2018view cones\u2019 to make room for housing\nVideo: Man accidentally sets himself on fire at suspected arson in Richmond\n\n\u201cThe next service, we hope to connect a little bit more on the northwest side of things,\u201d Kevin Schubert, BC Transit\u2019s director of regional transit systems said. \u201cI think the next piece is just really seeing how the service is received.\u201d\n\nThe first phase of the transit plan, a bus line connecting Smithers to Moricetown, opened in January. BC Transit says that service has seen daily use by passengers.\n\nFor Teegee, the service is a welcome announcement that she hopes will bring more safety and security to families in the community.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a personal victory for our family, as well as for everybody else,\u201d she said. \u201cIf we could prevent even one young girl\u2019s life [from being taken], it\u2019s worth the fight and worth the struggle to get to this day.\u201d\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nBut she adds that the fight for more modern services and a safer community is far from being won.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of other recommendations [in the report] that really need to be looked into and funded, as [the previous] government has committed to,\u201d Teegee said. \u201cThere\u2019s still a lot of work to be done around victims support, a relationship with the RCMP, and I think there\u2019s still [a need for] boots-on-the-ground emergency preparedness \u2014 all of those pieces of work that cannot be overlooked.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s taken 11 years for us to get here, so how many years more is it going to take?\u201d\n\nWith files from Kristen Robinson\n\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2017 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nADVERTISEMENT\n630 CHED Afternoons with Bryn Griffiths & Reid Wilkins\n2:00 PM - 5:00 PM\n630CHED\nTrending\nGreece is bringing in a 6-day work week. PHOTO BY ALEKSANDAR ANTONIJEVIC /Supplied photo\nArticle content\n\nTake some time this weekend to embrace the warmth of the spring season with a variety of comedy, pop culture, awareness and cultural events around Saskatoon.\n\n1 \u2014 Laugh along to a comedy show\n\nCanadian comedian Mike Delamont presents his one-person comedy show, God is a Scottish Drag Queen, which offers a comedic look at pop culture and humanity through the eyes of a silly, foul-mouthed Scottish deity. The show is Friday at the Broadway Theatre at 7:30 p.m. Learn more at broadwaytheatre.ca.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nFive concert events to see in Saskatoon in July\n'He was my best friend': Father remembers son killed in alleged impaired hit-and-run\nCity of Saskatoon announces new high-level executive\n'Significant, widespread' rain drenched Sask. farms: crop report\nVictim impact statements expected at Gregory Fertuck sentencing hearing\nArticle content\n\nSaskatoon musician and comedian Farideh brings her unique perspective to the stage, presenting her humorous take on parenting and marriage through catchy tunes. The concert is at the Broadway Theatre Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Learn more at broadwaytheatre.ca.\n\n2 \u2014 Enjoy a historic musical celebration\n\nThe Saskatoon Symphony Orchestra presents Beethoven 9 at 200, a celebration of the bicentennial of the composer\u2019s final and most recognized work. Guest conductor Judith Yan returns to lead the orchestra and choral guests through a memorable marking of the melody\u2019s anniversary. Guests include soloists Avery Lafrentz, Julie Nesrallah, Ian Cleary and Adam Lau, and eight regional choirs. The celebration is Saturday at TCU Place at 7:30 p.m. Learn more at saskatoonsymphony.org.\n\n3 \u2014 Explore a pop culture convention\n\nThe Saskatoon Entertainment Expo celebrates all things television, movies and pop culture. Meet celebrity guests and talented cosplay and creative artists, participate in the Cosplay Red Carpet and panel discussions, play tabletop games and shop the trade show. Guests include Brandon Routh, Cary Elwes and Adrianne Palicki. The expo runs Saturday and Sunday at Prairieland Park. Learn more at saskexpo.com.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n4 \u2014 Take part in an awareness walk\n\nJane\u2019s Walk is a series of free, volunteer-led walking tours around the city, inspired by writer and activist Jane Jacobs. Share stories and discover unseen aspects of the community as you connect with neighbours. A variety of guided walks are scheduled Friday through Sunday. Learn more at janeswalksaskatoon.ca.\n\nThreads of Life presents Steps for Life \u2014 Walking for Families of Workplace Tragedy. The family-focused, five-kilometre fundraising walk supports families affected by workplace tragedies and raises awareness to create change in workplace health and safety culture. The event starts Sunday at noon in Rotary Park. Learn more at threadsoflife.ca.\n\n5 \u2014 Celebrate spring the German way\n\nThe Concordia Junior Alpenrose Dancers and the KulturGarden Saskatoon host Maifest, a traditional German spring celebration. Enjoy live music and dance performances, German kuchen and refreshments. The festival is at Saskatchewan Hall in the Western Development Museum Sunday from 1:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Learn more at saskgermancouncil.org.\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nMaking a splash: How Persephone Theatre takes The Little Mermaid from sea to stage\nFive theatre performances to see in Saskatoon in May\n\nWith some online platforms blocking access to the news upon which you depend, our website is your destination for up-to-the-minute news, so make sure to bookmark\u00a0thestarphoenix.com\u00a0and sign up for our newsletters\u00a0here\u00a0so we can keep you informed.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nThree arrested after drug trafficking investigation in Saskatoon\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nLawyer for trucker who caused deadly Broncos crash says families have no right to sue\nSaskatoon StarPhoenix\nOne Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before, You Will Fit In Your Pants Again!\nBurn Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians In Alberta With No Life Insurance Are Taking Advantage Of This\nCovered For Life\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nAt 67, woman turns to ancestral vitamin and ends years of back pain and sciatica\nSciatic Institute\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly!\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\n\nPostmedia is committed to maintaining a lively but civil forum for discussion. Now, a hot ragtop variant is on its way to Canada for the 2025 model year.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nCalled the Mercedes-AMG CLE 53 Cabriolet, it deploys a 3.0L inline six-cylinder engine working in tandem with a 48-volt mild hybrid system to produce 443 horsepower and 413 lb-ft of torque, though drivers can briefly draw upon 443 lb-ft of twist via an overboost function if they\u2019re attempting to impress the person sitting next to them. The nine-speed transmission has been fettled by AMG and 4Matic+ all-wheel drive is part of the deal as is rear-axle steering which can yaw up to 2.5 degrees. Track is increased by 2.3 inches up front and 3.0 inches at the rear compared to an equivalent non-AMG model. Get swole, Merc.\n\nToggle full screen mode\nPrevious Gallery Image\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nNext Gallery Image\nToggle gallery captions\nView All 8 Photos\n\n1 of 8\n\nThe Winnipeg Sun's Daily Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nNote well: there is a second-gen integrated starter generator in the transmission bellhousing capable of belting out 23 horse and 151 lb-ft all on its own \u2014 but don\u2019t think you can add those sums to the values listed in the paragraph above. I mean, you can, but expect to be called out on it by anyone with even more than a passing knowledge about Mercedes powertrains. The ISG is there to assist at lower speeds and help make turbo lag a thing of the past.\n\nAs one would expect, the AMG CLE 53 Cabriolet has numerous AMG-specific design cues peppering its exterior, including a grille which would look right at home on the Daddy Warbucks SL convertible plus two strakes on the hood which give an impression the inline-six is trying to claw its way out of the engine bay. An optional Performance Studio package adds items such as a high-gloss black spoiler lip on the trunk lid and a rear diffuser panel between tailpipe trims, while various Night packages darken the brightwork to specific tastes.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nToggle full screen mode\nPrevious Gallery Image\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nPhoto by Mercedes-AMG\nNext Gallery Image\nToggle gallery captions\nView All 12 Photos\n\n1 of 12\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIts interior has the Mercedes trappings one would expect in a tri-star cabriolet, including the trick Airscarf technology (yes, that feature actually works well). A 12.3-inch screen serves as a gauge cluster while a portrait-oriented 11.9-inch tablet sits in the centre and is slightly canted towards the driver. The tilt of the central display can be electrically adjusted from 15 to 40 degrees to prevent reflections caused by sunlight when the soft top is open. Again, this is a feature we\u2019ve sampled in the two-seat SL and it is remarkable the difference it makes to one\u2019s experience when the top is down. There\u2019s about 10 cubic feet of cargo space when the roof is lowered, so pack lightly, though the rear seats are 60/40 split folding.\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\n2024 Mercedes-Benz CLE 300 Cabriolet, Mercedes-AMG CLE 53 straddle performance and daily-use\nCar Review: 2023 Mercedes-AMG C 43 4Matic\n\nStandard seats can be clad microfiber upholstery or a leather which is allegedly treated with some sort of coating to reduce surface temps by up to 53 degrees Fahrenheit compared to untreated leather. This helps when cruising with the top down in Arizona. Optional AMG performance seats have more pronounced bolsters in case you select one of the more aggressive driving modes on tap through the infotainment system, some of which are optional in an AMG Dynamic Plus package (because Mercedes). \u00a0\n\nThe roarty 2025 AMG CLE 53 Cabriolet will arrive at Canadian dealerships in 2025.\n\nSign up for our newsletter Blind-Spot Monitor and follow our social channels on Instagram ,Facebook and X to stay up to date on the latest automotive news, reviews, car culture, and vehicle shopping advice.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/news/red-dress-day-brings-awareness-to-mmiw-in-courtenay/", "title": "Red Dress Day brings awareness to MMIW in Courtenay - Comox Valley Record", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.1 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nRed Dress Day brings awareness to MMIW in Courtenay\nThe day also serves as a reminder to end violence against Indigenous and gender-diver people\n\tErin Haluschak\n\nMay 5, 2023 5:00 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 5 A red dress hangs at Simms Park Friday (May 5) at the Red Dress Day ceremonies. Photo by Erin Haluschak/Comox Valley Record\nExpand\n\nDespite the rain, a large crowd gathered at Simms Park in Courtenay Friday (May 5) afternoon surrounded by hanging dresses on trees to bring awareness to Red Dress Day, the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two Spirit People.\n\nTwo local Indigenous organizations - MIKI\u2019SIW M\u00e9tis Association and the Indigenous Women\u2019s Sharing Society - hosted the event, which included a walk, educational tables, a drumming circle and a hip-hop performance by Sirreal.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re all very, very sad to have a day like this, but it\u2019s a way to honour all of the women that we have lost over the years,\u201d explained Doris Weislein of the IWSS, who is also a freeman of the City of Courtenay and helped start the Upper Island Women of Native Ancestry.\n\nThe red dress was inspired by Metis artist Jame Black\u2019s REDress Project, which has come to symbolize loss, grief and injustice over the murder and ongoing violence against Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people in Canada.\n\nThe day also serves as a reminder in communities across the country to end violence against Indigenous and gender-diver people.\n\n\u201cLast year, we lost 184 women and girls to femicide,\u201d noted Kelli Paddon, Parliamentary Secretary for Gender Equity for the Province of British Columbia in a statement.\n\n\u201cAt least one in five were Indigenous women or girls. In many cases, they died at the hands of someone they knew. To the women, girls and families who have been harmed, have faced loss and grief, and who may be at risk, please know you are not alone.\u201d\n\nAccording to the Government of Canada Justice Research and Data page, between 1980 and 2014, there were 6,849 police-reported female homicide cases in Canada. Among the total number of female victims, 16 per cent were Indigenous women.\n\n\nphotos@comoxvalleyrecord.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Erin Haluschak\n\nErin Haluschak is a journalist with the Comox Valley Record since 2008. {"url": "https://panow.com/2024/05/04/more-that-needs-to-be-done-p-a-to-mark-red-dress-day-with-solemn-ceremony/", "title": "\u2018More that needs to be done\u2019: P.A. to mark Red Dress Day with solemn ceremony | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\n\u2018More that needs to be done\u2019: P.A. to mark Red Dress Day with solemn ceremony\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\nThe Sisters In Spirit monument is the site for the Red Dress Day ceremony in Prince Albert on May 5, 2024. (Derek Craddock/paNOW Staff)\nBy paNOW Staff\nRED DRESS DAY\n\u2018More that needs to be done\u2019: P.A. to mark Red Dress Day with solemn ceremony\nMay 4, 2024 | 12:00 PM\n\n\n\nFor more than two decades, Canadians have been coming together to remember Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nOn Sunday, during Red Dress Day, community members and special guests will carry on that tradition in Prince Albert.\n\nThe event will run from 12 p.m. to 1 p.m. at the Sisters In Spirit monument on the riverbank in downtown P.A.\n\nThe program will include drumming performances, poignant speeches, and a chance to reflect as a community. Due to trouble receiving a permit, a walk will not take place.\n\nDespite this, the Director of Health and Social Development with the Prince Albert Grand Council (PAGC), Shirley Woods anticipates many people will come.\n\nWoods said the main objective of holding this event is to continue to raise awareness and provide education on the issue and the challenges faced by families daily.\n\nRed Dress Day was first commemorated in 2010, to pay respect to the victims, and call on all levels of government to take action to address the racialized and gendered violence inflicted on Indigenous peoples.\n\nIn 2019, the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls released its final report, stating that \u201cpersistent and deliberate human and Indigenous rights violations and abuses are the root cause behind Canada\u2019s staggering rates of violence against Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA people.\u201d\n\nFrom that report, 231 Calls for Justice were given to governments, police, and public services to draw attention to and end violence against Indigenous women.\n\nWhen asked if she believes the message around MMIWG is still being heard, Woods said yes, but more needs to be done.\n\n\u201cI think that there\u2019s definitely an increased awareness amongst people about some of the challenges that are faced for women and for the families involved,\u201d she said. \u201cI still think there\u2019s a lot more that needs to be done.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\npanews@pattisonmedia.com\n\nby paNOW Staff\nAround the Web\nAll Canadians Aged 40-80 May Qualify for This $250,000 Tax-free Life Benefit\nDollarGuardian\nWrinkles in the Mouth in Old Age: This Ancient Remedy Helps\nNeotonics\nEdmonton: Unsold 2023 Suvs Are on Sale (Take a Look at Prices)\nSUV | Search ads\nRemember Tiger Woods' Ex-wife? {"url": "https://www.terracestandard.com/news/youth-take-action-for-highway-of-tears-memorial/", "title": "Terrace youth take action for Highway of Tears memorial - Terrace Standard", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.5 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nTerrace youth take action for Highway of Tears memorial\nYouth corps wants to see a memorial built for missing and murdered women\nBrittany Gervais\nJun 14, 2018 10:30 AM\nJun 14, 2018 12:09 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nMembers of the Terrace Youth Volunteer Corps (YVC) went over plans for their fundraising event on June 9, which was organized to money for a permanent memorial for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls along the Highway of Tears. (Brittany Gervais photo)\n\nAfter discovering there is no memorial to honour the missing and murdered Indigenous women of the Skeena Valley, the Youth Volunteer Corps (YVC) of Terrace have decided to take action.\n\n\u201c[A memorial] is missing all along Highway 16 and we want to bring some attention to this problem,\u201d said Thomas Lecky, a Grade-12 student at Caledonia Secondary School during a YVC meeting last Thursday.\n\nYVC is a network of affiliated organizations in the U.S. and Canada that create team-based volunteer opportunities for youth. Established last year, the group in Terrace is open to teenagers between 11 to 18 years old and is the second YVC group in Canada.\n\nCurrent plans for the memorial include a sunken garden and totem-pole monument, which will be maintained by YVC and Volunteer Terrace after its completion. Through conversations with advocates and families affected by the crisis, the teenagers said they understood the importance of giving the community a permanent place to honour the missing and murdered.\n\n\u201cThis is the first big project that we want to focus on for years to come,\u201d Lecky said.\n\n\u201cAll the people that have been affected by it now, in the past and in the future, it will be here for a long time and will serve as a reminder for all the people who have been lost.\u201d\n\nThe group had their first meeting for the project on June 1, in which the Kermode Friendship Centre, Terrace RCMP and the BC Government and Service Employees\u2019 Union (BCGEU) were present. The memorial has also gained support from the National Inquiry for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and MP Nathan Cullen, with verbal support from the City of Terrace.\n\n\u201cThe whole point of [YVC] is really to get the youth involved with the community and to learn, not just about volunteering, but how to interact with organizations,\u201d Lecky said, who also wrote a grant on behalf of YVC to help fund the memorial.\n\nWhile the location is still undetermined, the teenagers have been working diligently to find the memorial a home. The sunken garden and monument might be placed on available city-owned land, but nothing has been committed yet, according to 19-year old Hazel McDaniel, YVC team leader.\n\n\u201cCity property in front of the superstore next to Kondolas Furniture is what has been discussed,\u201d McDaniel said.\n\nFirst fundraiser\n\nCanadian filmmaker Matt Smiley also donated a screening of his award-winning documentary Highway of Tears for the memorial\u2019s first fundraiser on June 9 at the REM Lee Theatre, followed with a panel discussion.\n\nOn the panel was local advocate Gladys Radek, who\u2019s niece Tamara Chipman remains missing after 13-years, former BC Liberal candidate for the Stikine riding Wanda Good, who has been an advocate for 20 years after the disappearance of her cousin Lana Derrick, and Doug Leslie, father to 15-year-old Loren Leslie, whose body was found eight years ago in Vanderhoof, B.C.\n\nWhile there were fewer than 20 people in attendance, YVC members voiced their questions to the panel to gain a better understanding of the crisis.\n\n\u201cI thought it was wonderful, I was really, really happy with the way that it went,\u201d McDaniel said of the fundraising event. \u201cI thought the panel discussion was excellent, appropriate and respectful.\u201d\n\nAfterwards, YVC member Elijah Stephens, 18, introduced the music video for The Highway, a ballad he helped write last year with seven other students from \u2018Na Aksa Gyilak\u2019yoo School in Kitsumkalum First Nation.\n\nIn the coming weeks, Terrace YVC will be reaching out to northwest First Nations communities and organizations like the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada to make sure they are aware and kept in the loop about the project.\n\n\u201cThis is going to be a really big deal, not only for Terrace but for B.C. and hopefully for Canada as a whole to really have a monument to recognize what\u2019s happened,\u201d McDaniel said.\n\n\u201cThis affects so many people in the north, and we want our whole process to emulate the seriousness of it.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\n\n\nbrittany@terracestandard.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter\n\nGrace Davidson, Grace-Ella Beckley and Cameron Beauchamp listen to discussions about the memorial project during YVC\u2019s second meeting on June 6 at Volunteer Terrace. NEWS\nDavid Vigneault, director of Canada\u2019s spy agency, to retire\nCANADA\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nBy Alessia Passafiume  The Canadian Press\nPosted May 3, 2024 1:48 pm\n Updated May 3, 2024 7:13 pm\n 2 min read\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, government representatives said Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis \u2013 May 3, 2024\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, government representatives said Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\n\nA national inquiry reported five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or be murdered.\n\n\u201cIn the lead-up to Red Dress Day, we keep those who have been stolen from their communities and this world in our thoughts, and we centre them in our action,\u201d said Crown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cToday, as we announce this partnership to co-develop a Red Dress Alert system with Indigenous partners, we take the next steps toward bringing more Indigenous women, girls, two-spirit and gender-diverse people home.\u201d\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nIt will be funded through money set aside in this year\u2019s federal and provincial budgets.\n\nMORE ON CANADA\nHurricane Beryl forces Canadian airlines to cancel flights. Now it\u2019s been declared world\u2019s smartest\n5 ideas for greening your outdoor space for a potential mood boost\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba\u2019s minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help put Indigenous women and girls at less risk.\n\n\u201cWe look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in\u00a0Manitoba\u00a0to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\u201d\n\nNDP MP Leah Gazan, whose efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system, called the announcement a small but significant step.\n\nGazan\u2019s fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system similar to Amber Alerts.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state\u2019s Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry\u2019s 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\n0:52\nStudy for Red Dress Alert starting at committee in Ottawa\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2024 The Canadian Press\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nCanada\u2019s digital services tax is here. {"url": "https://theeyeopener.com/2016/10/sisters-in-spirit-pay-tribute-to-indigenous-women-of-canada/", "title": "Sisters in Spirit pay tribute to Indigenous women of Canada \u2013 The Eyeopener", "body": "SKIP TO THE CONTENT\nHome\nOur story\nHuman Rights Policy\nA Constitution for the TMU newspaper \u201cThe Eyeopener\u201d\nBoard of Directors\nStories We Broke\nArchives\nContact\nAdvertising\nSupport Us\nBeing an Eyeopener Source\nVolunteer With Us\nHow To Pitch To Us\nfacebook\ninsta\nSearch\nTHE EYEOPENER\n\nToronto Metropolitan University's Independent Student Newspaper Since 1967\n\nNEWS\nFEATURES\nARTS & CULTURE\nCOMMUNITIES\nSPORTS\nBUSINESS & TECH\nFUN & SATIRE\nEDITORIAL\nMULTIMEDIA\nSPECIAL ISSUES\nALL\nCOMMUNITIES\nINDIGENOUS\nSisters in Spirit pay tribute to Indigenous women of Canada\nOctober 5, 2016\n\nBy Alexis Perikleous\n\nWomen, men and children of all different ethnicities gathered Tuesday to take part in the annual Sisters in Spirit Vigil, one of many occurring across Canada.\u00a0\n\nThe event takes place every year on Oct. 4 to pay tribute to the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls of Canada.\n\nThe event took place at Allan Gardens, across the street from the Native Women\u2019s Resource Centre of Toronto. The grounds were decorated with hand-crafted paper lanterns and painted rocks, representing over 1,000 murdered and missing girls and women.\n\nAmong the crowd were Ryerson students from the Centre for Women and Trans People. Jessica Ketwaroo-Green, a fourth year politics and governance students carried a hand-made banner along with some of her classmates in support of the vigil.\n\n\u201cThis is an issue that is really prevalent in Canada and unfortunately not a lot of people speak about it or speak to it. So if I can come out and show my support and show my solidarity I think it can go a long way,\u201d said Ketwaroo-Green.\n\nThe vigil featured performances of dancing, drumming and singing. There were also guest speakers from the indigenous community. One of the speakers was Cyndy Baskin an associate professor of social work at Ryerson and chair of Ryerson\u2019s Aboriginal Education Council.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the stories, it\u2019s the truths of all these families that need to be told in many different ways before any of us will be able to reconcile,\u201d said Baskin.\n\nThe vigil had a large impact on Calvin Brook, co-founder of Brook Mcllroy architecture firm, who has been working closely with the Native Women\u2019s Resource Centre of Toronto. It was the first Sisters in Spirit Vigil he\u2019s attended, but certainly won\u2019t be his last\n\n\u201cTo me it\u2019s the most important unresolved issue in Canadian society and non-indigenous people have to fix it, it\u2019s not up to Indigenous people to fix it. So I\u2019m trying to find ways to be part of that solution,\u201d said Brook.\n\nSHARE THIS:\nClick to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)\nClick to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)\nClick Dave Baxter/Local Journalism Initiative/Winnipeg Sun\nArticle content\n\nAs Canada marked Red Dress Day, a Manitoba Grand Chief called on all levels of government to do more to keep Indigenous women and girls safe in Manitoba, and across Canada.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt is essential that governments of all levels work with First Nations on an urgent basis on this issue, as it is indeed a national emergency,\u201d Southern Chiefs\u2019 Organization Grand Chief Jerry Daniels said in a Friday media release.\n\nDaniels released that statement on Friday, as May 5 is Red Dress Day in Canada, a National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People, and a day that Daniels said holds a lot of meaning in Winnipeg, and across this province.\n\n\u201cManitoba is ground zero when it comes to MMIWG2S+,\u201d Daniels said. \u201cWe continue to wonder about the whereabouts of so many of our loved ones, while we also seek justice for those who have been taken due to violence.\n\n\u201cI stand with all those impacted by the loss of a loved one due to violence. I am especially thinking of the children who have been left behind. I extend prayers as they continue to mourn their losses.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOn Friday, Manitoba\u2019s PC Government said in a media release that the Manitoba Legislative Building would be lit in a \u201csymbolic red\u201d on Friday, and that the province hoped the move would \u201cencourage dialogue and bring attention to this issue.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn Canada, Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ peoples are disproportionately targeted for violence more so than any other group,\u201d the province said in a statement.\n\n\u201cToday, we remember those who have lost their lives to gender-based violence, and we honour the healing journeys of families and communities that live with the ongoing grief of losing a loved one.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Dave Baxter is a Local Journalism Initiative reporter who works out of the Winnipeg Sun. PHOTO BY IAN KUCERAK /Postmedia\nArticle content\n\nSomer Grandbois is setting the record straight about her brother Paul Grandbois, who was slain in January 2015.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cMy brother wasn\u2019t just another native, wasn\u2019t just another drunk,\u201d the 39-year-old said. \u201cHe was a human just like anyone else. He was married, he had three kids and for whatever reason didn\u2019t make it home that night.\u201d\n\nPaul Murray Grandbois, 36, was found near 25 Avenue and 120 Street around 6:40 a.m. on Jan. 21, 2015. Somer Grandbois said she and her family are still waiting for answers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not that it happened a long time ago, it\u2019s that somebody was taken from you abruptly,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen someone is here one day and in the next hour gone, that\u2019s a whole different kind of trauma.\u201d\n\nGrandbois shared her story of loss during the Sisters in Spirit Vigil in Edmonton on Friday where hundreds gathered at the Boyle Street Plaza to pay respects to missing and murdered Indigenous people. Similar events were held across the province and Canada.\n\nEdmonton Sun Headline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nGrandbois said these kinds of events help to bring the community together.\n\n\u201c(It) lets people know they are not alone,\u201d she added. \u201cThat\u2019s the biggest thing.\u201d\n\nThe vigil follows months after the final report by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. The two-volume report, comprised of testimony from more than 2,380 family members, survivors of violence and experts, calls for transformative legal and social changes.\n\nAmong the calls for change include establishing a national Indigenous and human rights ombudsperson and a national Indigenous and human rights tribunal and providing long-term funding for education and awareness programs related to violence prevention.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nRachelle Venne, CEO of the Institute for the Advancement of Aboriginal Women, said the report offers a roadmap to change.\n\nWith the federal election right around the corner, she said whoever forms government will have to be held accountable.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had a lot of talk and a lot of things they said they were going to change that haven\u2019t changed,\u201d she said. \u201cThere has been some progress here and there but the significant change we need hasn\u2019t happened. We\u2019re hoping that every government, every media outlet, every institution in Canada makes the changes that are necessary.\u201d\n\nOne of the changes Venne would like to see is improvements in tracking how many murdered and missing Indigenous people there are. She said there was a big push to get that information but the process has now stalled.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAlberta Indigenous Relations Minister Rick Wilson and Status of Women Minister Leela Sharon Aheer attended the vigil to offer the province\u2019s support.\n\nWilson said the UCP is the first Alberta government to declare Sisters in Spirit Day in honour of the memory of Indigenous women and girls who are missing or have been murdered.\n\n\u201cCommunity vigils are held across Alberta and Canada giving families and loved ones a way to speak out for their daughters, mothers, nieces, aunts, sisters and grandmothers, whose voices have been silenced,\u201d he said in a news release.\n\njlabine@postmedia.com\n\nTwitter.com/jefflabine\n\nArticle
