He was married, he had three kids and for whatever reason didn\u2019t make it home that night.\u201d\n\nPaul Murray Grandbois, 36, was found near 25 Avenue and 120 Street around 6:40 a.m. on Jan. 21, 2015. Somer Grandbois said she and her family are still waiting for answers.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\n'You just can't snap your fingers and move out Evander Kane': Edmonton Oilers insider\nInjured woman dies in deep southeast Edmonton, man arrested: Police\nSecret weapon helps Edmonton Oilers convince top players to sign and stay here\nBreaking down the new-look Edmonton Oilers by position for 2024-25\nMan asked two teen girls to have sex with him, punched boy: St. Albert RCMP\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not that it happened a long time ago, it\u2019s that somebody was taken from you abruptly,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen someone is here one day and in the next hour gone, that\u2019s a whole different kind of trauma.\u201d\n\nGrandbois shared her story of loss during the Sisters in Spirit Vigil in Edmonton on Friday where hundreds gathered at the Boyle Street Plaza to pay respects to missing and murdered Indigenous people. Similar events were held across the province and Canada.\n\nGrandbois said these kinds of events help to bring the community together.\n\n\u201c(It) lets people know they are not alone,\u201d she added. \u201cThat\u2019s the biggest thing.\u201d\n\nThe vigil follows months after the final report by the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. The two-volume report, comprised of testimony from more than 2,380 family members, survivors of violence and experts, calls for transformative legal and social changes.\n\nAmong the calls for change include establishing a national Indigenous and human rights ombudsperson and a national Indigenous and human rights tribunal and providing long-term funding for education and awareness programs related to violence prevention.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nRachelle Venne, CEO of the Institute for the Advancement of Aboriginal Women, said the report offers a roadmap to change.\n\nWith the federal election right around the corner, she said whoever forms government will have to be held accountable.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had a lot of talk and a lot of things they said they were going to change that haven\u2019t changed,\u201d she said. \u201cThere has been some progress here and there but the significant change we need hasn\u2019t happened. We\u2019re hoping that every government, every media outlet, every institution in Canada makes the changes that are necessary.\u201d\n\nOne of the changes Venne would like to see is improvements in tracking how many murdered and missing Indigenous people there are. She said there was a big push to get that information but the process has now stalled.\n\nAlberta Indigenous Relations Minister Rick Wilson and Status of Women Minister Leela Sharon Aheer attended the vigil to offer the province\u2019s support.\n\nWilson said the UCP is the first Alberta government to declare Sisters in Spirit Day in honour of the memory of Indigenous women and girls who are missing or have been murdered.\n\n\u201cCommunity vigils are held across Alberta and Canada giving families and loved ones a way to speak out for their daughters, mothers, nieces, aunts, sisters and grandmothers, whose voices have been silenced,\u201d he said in a news release.\n\njlabine@postmedia.com\n\nTwitter.com/jefflabine\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nAlberta Seniors Born Before 1971 Wanted To Test Hearing Aids\nBest Hearing Aids\n|\nSponsored\nEdmonton coach Kris Knoblauch hammered in Game 7 by mistake made by so many previous Oilers coaches\nEdmonton Journal\nHamas father and son confess to murder, rape and kidnapping at kibbutz: Report\nEdmonton Journal\nSwollen Legs? PHOTO BY MATT SMITH /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\nArticle content\n\nPRINCE ALBERT \u2014 On each side of the pair of statues is a face: the stages of a life, from infancy to advanced age, each marked with a red handprint.\n\nFor many of the people gathered at the riverside in Prince Albert on Wednesday afternoon, the faces represent loved ones.\n\nThe statues \u2014 in the shape of two copper feathers overlooking the North Saskatchewan \u2014 make up the Prince Albert Grand Council\u2019s Sisters in Spirit Memorial, honouring Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\n\u201cThe red warrior paint on their face is a symbol of power and strength, and the knowledge they carry,\u201d said Tristen Sanderson, who designed the memorial. \u201cThat\u2019s naturally in our blood. That\u2019s a gift from our ancestors. And that\u2019s what I wanted it to represent \u2014 that even though our vessels are no longer here, that our sisters\u2019 spirit and energy are still around.\u201d\n\nThe monument was unveiled to the public during a ceremony and speeches that started with a prayer from Regina Poitras, the mother of Happy Charles.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nSask. files injunction to block feds from reclaiming missed carbon tax payments\nFlight cancelled due to the WestJet strike? The commission was considering ending its annual walk for MMIWG, but family members came forward to express its importance for them.\n\n\u201c(They) said, \u2018No, continue your walk. It\u2019s a healing process for us. We get together, we talk to one another, we grieve together,\u2019 \u201d chair Shirley Henderson said.\n\nThe commission put out a call for artists to design a monument and ultimately selected Sanderson, from James Smith Cree Nation. Cree artist Lionel Peyachew, from Red Pheasant First Nation, sculpted the copper feathers based on Sanderson\u2019s work.\u00a0\n\nChief of Peter Ballantyne Cree Nation Karen Bird speaks to people gathered at the unveiling of the Sisters in Spirit memorial, a sculpture to honour murdered and missing Indigenous women and children created by Tristen Sanderson and Lionel Peyachew. PHOTO BY MATT SMITH /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\n\nThe memorial and the surrounding six boulders will serve as a place to pray and smudge, in the hope it that it will give a sense of healing, Henderson said.\n\nAfter the statues were unveiled, M\u00e9tis suicide prevention advocate Tristen Durocher played Amazing Grace on the violin. Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations Vice-Chief Heather Bear said that song holds a special meaning.\n\n\u201cWe sing: I was lost, but now I\u2019m found. I am blind, but now I see. And I hang on to that song, Amazing Grace,\u201d she said. \u201cBecause throughout all the sorrow and the horror, and the terrible injustices that have been done to our people, we still have our language, we still have our customs, we still have our traditions, we still have our values, we still have our kindness, we still have our generosity.\u201dAnd no evil power could ever totally beat that out of us.\u00a0Dare to believe in tomorrow.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\nThe Prince Albert Grand Council Women\u2019s Commission unveils the Sisters in Spirit memorial, a sculpture to honour murdered and missing Indigenous women and children created by Tristen Sanderson and Lionel Peyachew. Photo taken in Prince Albert on Wednesday, July 7, 2021. PHOTO BY MATT SMITH /Saskatoon StarPhoenix\n\nSanderson said she hoped to capture that strength and resilience in her work. She creates free portraits of missing and murdered women, girls and 2SLGBTQ+ people for their loves ones. As someone affected by the tragedy of MMIWG herself, Sanderson said it hits close to home being able to support people that way \u2014 art is the gift she\u2019s able to give to her people, she said.\n\nPeyachew, the sculptor behind the MMIWG memorial in Saskatoon, Wicanhpi Duta Win (Red Star Woman), echoed that sentiment.\u00a0\n\n\u201cViolence against Indigenous women and girls continues to be a systematic and national crisis and requires urgent, informed and collaborative action,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd this is why I continue to create, and help advocate \u2026\u201d\n\nPeople gather at the unveiling of the Sisters in Spirit memorial, a sculpture to honour murdered and missing Indigenous women and children, created by Tristen Sanderson and Lionel Peyachew. {"url": "http://www.agassizharrisonobserver.com/news/agassiz-united-church-to-host-fourth-local-sisters-in-spirit-vigil/", "title": "Agassiz United Church to host fourth local Sisters in Spirit Vigil - Agassiz-Harrison Observer", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n25.2 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nAgassiz United Church to host fourth local Sisters in Spirit Vigil\nMovement honours lives of missing and murdered Aboriginal women and girls\nNina Grossman\nSep 28, 2017 10:00 AM\nSep 28, 2017 1:47 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nSisters in Spirit Vigils are part of a country-wide movement led by the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada. The vigils seek to honour missing and murdered Aboriginal women, support grieving families and create a movement for social change. Residents of Agassiz, Harrison and surrounding areas are invited to gather for the fourth local Sisters in Spirit Vigil held at the Agassiz United Church on Oct. 4 at 7 p.m. (Unsplash)\n\nA local social change group is preparing for the Sisters in Spirit Vigil at 7 p.m. Oct. 4 at the Agassiz United Church.\n\nThis is the fourth year the candle-lit vigil has been put on by the group as part of a national movement run by the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) to honour missing and murdered Aboriginal women, support grieving families and provide opportunities for healing.\n\nOrganizer Debbie Hansen says she wants the vigil to help people learn what the movement is all about. Using NWAC materials and speaking notes, Hansen hopes the event will encourage participants to acknowledge, support and learn from one another.\n\n\u201cThis is a Canada-wide movement, and we\u2019re one little small piece in this one small corner of the world that also cares,\u201d she says. \u201cWe\u2019re just trying to establish a venue where people can know about this\u2026and show their empathy and learn about whats happened to the Indigenous cultures.\u201d\n\nREAD: Agassiz book study aims for discussion and education\n\nBecause the movement is national, the local Wrongs to Rights church group will focus their bi-monthly meeting on missing and murdered Aboriginal women and the national inquiry. On Oct. 4 from 1-3 p.m., the All Saints Anglican Church is open to anybody who wants to join the discussion. The talk will be followed by a 5 p.m. potluck dinner at the Agassiz United Church before the beginning of the Sisters in Spirit Vigil at 7 p.m.\n\nAfter an introductory activity, each participant is given a candle to walk out with. At the end, participants extinguish their candles and walk out in silence.\n\n\u201cUsually we highlight five or six of the missing women and talk about their lives,\u201d says Hansen. \u201cWho were they as people?\u201d\n\nAccording to NWAC\u2019s 2010 statistics, the number of missing and murdered Aboriginal woman and girls \u2013 First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit \u2013 is disproportionately high. Between 2000 and 2008, Aboriginal women and girls represented approximately 10 per cent of female homicides in Canada, yet Aboriginal women make up only three per cent of the Canadian population altogether.\n\nBringing the issue even closer to home is the fact that a majority of cases occur in Western provinces, with 28 per cent happening in B.C.\n\nREAD: First Nations have high hopes for B.C. New Democrats\n\n\u201cWe have got to try to make it better,\u201d says Hansen. \u201cThe only way you can get reconciliation is for the truth to come out.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe want to share information, support people as they go through a tough time and be part of a movement for social change in a positive way,\u201d she adds.\n\nThe Oct. 4 Wrongs to Rights study group, United Church potluck and Sisters in Spirit vigil are open to the public.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tAgassiz {"url": "https://www.agassizharrisonobserver.com/opinion/standing-in-solidarity-the-sisters-in-spirit-vigil/", "title": "Standing in solidarity: The Sisters in Spirit Vigil - Agassiz-Harrison Observer", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n25.2 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Opinion\nStanding in solidarity: The Sisters in Spirit Vigil\nI attended the annual Sisters in Spirit Vigil at the Agassiz United Church Oct. 4. \u2013 this was the second time I\u2019d gone during during my coverage in Agassiz.\nNina Grossman\nOct 12, 2018 11:50 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nI attended the annual Sisters in Spirit Vigil at the Agassiz United Church Oct. 4. \u2013 this was the second time I\u2019d gone during during my coverage in Agassiz.\n\nThe vigil is part of a national movement encouraging people to honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous women and girls (MMIWG) and to support the families they leave behind. Short speeches are made, candles are lit, names are read aloud and a moment of silence honours the thousands lost.\n\nAs I do with most events in the community, I head out with my camera, microphone, cellphone and notebook, looking for the best vantage point in the room to get some good pictures and video.\n\nBut within minutes of arriving, my \u201creporter approach\u201d dissolves. I know the media is vital in sharing the stories of these women and bringing more attention to this ongoing national crisis, but as I sit there and listen to stories of loss and heartbreak, I can\u2019t help but to simply become another human being. Another woman.\n\nMy eyes filled with tears as I listened to the story of Terry Martin-Dauthanais, a mother of three who was murdered while in a relationship that her family described as violent and abusive. Her partner, who took custody of the children \u2013 refusing to allow Terry\u2019s parents to see them after her death\u2013 was a suspect, but was never arrested.\n\nBut according to the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC), that\u2019s not all that unusual. More than half of the murder cases in NWAC\u2019s database remain unsolved, and only 53 per cent of murder cases involving Indigenous women and girls have led to homicide charges \u2013 a huge gap from Canada\u2019s 84 per cent homicide clearance rate.\n\nThe injustice of Terry\u2019s story wasn\u2019t just maddening, it was heartbreaking. And I realized that I was experiencing only a fraction of the pain and injustice experienced by the friends and family of women like Terry.\n\nWhile Terry\u2019s case remains unsolved, it\u2019s unlikely she was killed by a stranger. NWAC\u2019s database shows that 23 per cent of murders are committed by a current of former partner of the woman or girl.\n\nThat being said, Indigenous women are almost three times more likely to be killed by a stranger than non-Indigenous. And most cases occur here in Western Canada. More than a quarter (28 per cent) of NWAC\u2019s cases occurred in B.C. and 16 per cent in Alberta.\n\nWithout question, I stand in solidarity with Indigenous women, who continue to fight an incredible fight - asking the government and the RCMP for accountability and justice.\n\nI started attending Sisters in Spirit vigils as a reporter, but I will continue to attend them as an ally, as a woman and as a Canadian who is ready for change.\n\nLearn more about MMIWG at NWAC.ca.\n\nWatch a video about the Agassiz United Church\u2019s 2018 Sisters in Spirit Vigil and hear from organizer Debbie Hansen online at agassizharrisonobserver.com.\n\n\u2013Nina Grossman, the Observer\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on {"url": "https://www.mycariboonow.com/97168/featured/red-dress-day-observed-in-williams-lake/", "title": "Red Dress Day Observed In Williams Lake - My Cariboo Now", "body": "Home\nNews\nNews Alerts Sign Up!\nWin\nEvents\nView Calendar\nSubmit Event\nListen Live\nCariboo Country\nCountry 840\nThe GOAT\nOn Air\nCountry 840\nThe GOAT\nTalent\nLocal Connections\nExperience BC\nNEWS\nWIN\nEVENTS\nCONTACT US\nADVERTISE\nWE\u2019RE HIRING\nSUBSCRIBE TO LOCAL NEWS\n\n\u25ba Listen Live\n\n\u25ba Listen Live\n\n\u25ba Listen Live\n\nHome\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nListen Live\nOn Air\nLocal Connections\nExperience BC\n- Advertisement -\nHomeNewsRed Dress Day Observed In Williams Lake\nNews\nWilliams Lake\nRed Dress Day Observed In Williams Lake\nBy\nPat Matthews\nMonday, May. 6th, 2024\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nPhoto-P Matthews staff\n- Advertisement -\n\nIndigenous and non-Indigenous people came together this afternoon (Monday) outside the Stampede Grounds to observe Red Dress Day.\n\nThey gathered to honour the lives of all missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls with drumming, songs and the lighting of the Sacred Fire.\n\n\u201cI want to acknowledge that this is an emotional event for everyone for friends and family.\u201d Cariboo Friendship Society Executive Director Rosanna McGregor said, \u201cI hope that you can take away from today a little bit of peace, some love, some understanding so that we can help one another through this. And I thank every single one of you for coming out today because you\u2019re bringing awareness to this issue and as we go forward and share our experiences here today we bring awareness to what\u2019s been happening, not only to our murdered and missing Indigenous women, I know that we\u2019ve all been touched by some of our brothers that have gone missing as well and we don\u2019t know where they\u2019re at.\u201d\n\nMcGregor added it\u2019s a really sad state of where we are in our world today and we come together to pray and to hope that we can provide a little more guidance so that we have better outcomes for the work that we do.\n\nSacred Fire (Photo P Matthews staff)\n\nWilliams Lake First Nation Chief Willie Sellars also spoke to the crowd saying this really puts things into perspective how small our circles are in our communities.\n\n\u201cWe all have somebody that, or know somebody that has been impacted with what this day represents, it\u2019s a conversation that we need to keep in the mainstream and we need to continue to have, although there is a trigger and there is trauma that comes from it, it\u2019s by having this conversation how we\u2019re going to be able to break that generational gap moving forward into the future.\u201d\n\nSellars added we stand in this circle together and it brings us hope and it brings us strength.\n\n\u201cAnd really ignites that soul peace that there is hope in the future and for our future generations that we are going to be able to break that cycle. You look around the circle today and we have leadership from numerous communities, not only in Indian Country, but we have Municipality and CRD representation as well.\u201d\n\nSomething going on in {"url": "https://energeticcity.ca/2024/05/02/nawican-friendship-centre-hosting-a-walk-to-commemorate-red-dress-day/", "title": "Nawican Friendship Centre hosting a walk to commemorate Red Dress Day", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us\nLogin\nNews\nVideos\nSports\nObituaries\nPodcasts\nNewsletters\nEvents\nWin\nNews Tips\nAdvertise\nAbout Us\nADVERTISEMENT\nHome \u00bb News \u00bb Nawican Friendship Centre hosting a walk to commemorate Red Dress Day\nNawican Friendship Centre hosting a walk to commemorate Red Dress Day\nThe walk is one of multiple events taking place in the Peace region on Red Dress Day. The Metis Society of Fort St. John is hosting an artisan market, and the Treaty 8 Tribal Association will hold a vigil, walk and hair braiding workshop.\u00a0\nBY ED HITCHINS, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE REPORTER \u25cf DAWSON CREEK, FORT ST. JOHN, INDIGENOUS VOICES, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE, NEWS, PEACE REGION \u25cf MAY 2, 2024 \u25cf 2 MINUTES OF READING\nAccording to Statistics Canada, 490 Indigenous women and girls were reported missing or murdered between 2009 and 2021. (Huron Shores United Church, Facebook)\n\nDAWSON CREEK, B.C. \u2014\u00a0 The Nawican Friendship Centre in Dawson Creek will commemorate Red Dress Day on May 5th with a walk and ceremony honouring Missing\u00a0and\u00a0Murdered Indigenous Women,\u00a0Girls, and\u00a0Two-Spirit\u00a0(MMIWG2S) people in Canada.\n\nThe walk is one of multiple events taking place in the Peace region on Red Dress Day. The Metis Society of Fort St. John is hosting an artisan market, and the Treaty 8 Tribal Association will hold a vigil, walk and hair braiding workshop.\u00a0\n\nNawican\u2019s event is open to the public and begins with the walk at 3 p.m. Participants in the walk will travel from NAR Park and finish back at the centre, where prayers and a drum ceremony will take place.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nNever Miss a Story\n\nDownload our app today! Available on Android and iOS devices\n\nLearn More\n\nMMIWG2S is a subject which profoundly affects the Indigenous community. According to Statistics Canada, 490 Indigenous women and girls were reported missing or murdered between 2009 and 2021.\u00a0\n\nThe issue has impacted the Dawson Creek community after Renee Didier and Darlyn Supernant went missing in 2023.\n\nJan Atkinson, the Nawican Friendship Centre Intensive Case Manager, is urging the public to take part in the march.\n\nAtkinson, who testified at the federal government\u2019s national inquiry into Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls in 2018, says the subject should not be ignored.\n\nLatest Stories\nEnvironment Canada issues multiple warnings as B.C. braces for weekend heat\nSilverberry Secure Landfill to possibly undergo new management\nB.C. NDP ministers Bains, Ralston and Fleming won\u2019t seek re-election\nB.C. seniors advocate seeks tenancy protection for residents of retirement homes\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very personal. Violence is real,\u201d said Atkinson. \u201cGender-based violence is very real. We need to do a better job at combating violence against women and children.\u201d\n\n\u201cI encourage the public to come and understand there is much more they can do. This isn\u2019t a historical issue. We\u2019ve had two women go missing in Dawson Creek in the last year. These women were mothers, sisters and daughters. We\u2019ve got to recognize that.\u201d\n\nShe feels that the lack of education and the lack of recognition of MMIWG2S further erode the chances of some of these missing women being found.\n\nAtkinson says she has seen unwavering support from the City of Dawson Creek, such as through not having to apply for permits for the upcoming event.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe have a good relationship with the city,\u201d said Atkinson. \u201cThe biggest part in bridging the divide in the country comes from education.\u201d\n\nFor more information about the event or the Nawican Friendship Centre, call their offices at (250)782-5202.\n\nReport a typo or an error\n\nRead our guiding principles\n\nStay connected with local news\n\nMake us your\n\nhome page\n\nDownload\n\nour App\n\nJoin our\n\nNewsletter\n\nGet news\n\ntexted to you\n\nAuthor\nED HITCHINS, LOCAL JOURNALISM INITIATIVE REPORTER\n\nA guy who found his calling later in life, Edward Hitchins is a professional storyteller with a colourful and extensive history.\n\nBeginning his journey into journalism in 2012 at Seneca College, Edward also graduated from Humber College with an Advanced Diploma in Print and Broadcast Journalism in 2018.\u00a0 After time off from his career and venturing into other vocations, he started his career proper in 2022 in Campbell River, B.C.\n\nEdward was attracted to the position of Indigenous Voices reporter with Energeticcity as a challenge.\u00a0 Having not been around First Nations for the majority of his life, he hopes to learn about their culture through meaningful conversations while properly telling their stories.\u00a0\n\nIn a way, he hopes this position will allow both himself and Energeticcity to grow as a collective unit as his career moves forward and evolves into the next step.\n\nHe looks forward to growing both as a reporter and as a human being while being posted in Fort St. John.\n\nThis reporting position has been funded by the Government of {"url": "https://www.stettlerindependent.com/home/stettler-friendship-circle-hosts-drum-circle-honouring-mmiep-7355938", "title": "Stettler Friendship Circle hosts drum circle honouring MMIEP - The Stettler Independent", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nJobs\nObituaries\nHome Home\nStettler Friendship Circle hosts drum circle honouring MMIEP\nStettler Friendship Circle hosts drum cirlce\n\tKevin Sabo\n\nMay 9, 2024 12:06 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 4 Eight people took part in the drum circle honouring MMIEP on May 5. Kevin Sabo/Stettler Independent\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:02:01\n\nThe Stettler Friendship Circle hosted a drum circle at West Stettler Park on May 5 to honour the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women,\u00a0Girls, and\u00a02SLGBTQI+ people.\u00a0\n\nMore commonly known as Red Dress Day, the national day of awareness came about from a report produced by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC).\n\n\"It came about as one of 94 calls to action,\" said Carter Lindstrom, one of those attending the drum circle.\n\nThe group adorned the area of the drum circle with red dresses which hung off trees and hangers.\u00a0\n\nOn the hill in West Stettler Park, a pair of flags book-ended 23 stakes which held the photos of missing Indigenous men and women.\u00a0\n\nAccording to Stephanie Hadley, another attendee of the drum circle, the women on the stakes represent \"a fraction\" of the women murdered and missing from Alberta alone whereas the men came from around Canada.\u00a0\n\nIn addition to the stakes with the photos, 10 other stakes with information about the problem of Murdered, Missing, and Exploited Indigenous People (MMEIP) were also placed around the site.\u00a0\n\nOne stat indicated shows that Indigenous women make up four per cent of Canada's population, but 24 per cent of the nation's homicides.\n\nAnother shows that one-third of Indigenous women will experience sexual violence in their lifetime, 67 per cent of which will be conducted by a non-Indigenous perpetrator.\n\nOnce the group had the site set up, they began the drum circle with a smudging ceremony, a land acknowledgement, information on the day, read a poem by an Indigenous author, and then began drumming.\u00a0\n\nEight people took part in the drum circle.\u00a0\n\nRed Dress Day was first informally recognized in 2010 based on an art exhibit created by Indigenous artist Jaime Black and has continued since, though since the TRC report was released has been formally recognized.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Kevin Sabo\n\nI\u2019m Kevin Sabo. I\u2019ve been a resident of the Castor area for the last 12 years and counting, first coming out here in my previous career as an EMT.\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n {"url": "https://ottawa.ctvnews.ca/ottawa-families-survivors-remember-missing-and-murdered-on-red-dress-day-1.6874523", "title": "Red Dress Day: Ottawa families, survivors remember missing and murdered | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nOTTAWA\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nOTTAWA\nNews\nOttawa families, survivors remember missing and murdered on Red Dress Day\nSam Houpt\nCTV News Ottawa Multi-Skilled Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nPublished May 5, 2024 5:01 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nRed dresses swayed in the breeze at Strathcona Park in Ottawa on Sunday as an eye-catching reminder of the injustice Indigenous women and girls face in Canada.\n\nSign up now for our daily CTV News Ottawa newsletters\nThe information you need to know, sent directly to you: Download the CTV News App\n\nMay 5 is the national day of awareness for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, also known as Red Dress Day.\n\nIt is a cause near and dear to Bridget Tolley, who aided in hanging red dresses from trees and benches around the park.\n\nRELATED STORIES\nManitoba government launches $15M endowment fund for MMIWG2S families\nEvent in Kitchener honours Missing and Murdered Indigenous people on Red Dress Day\n'Come together': Families, survivors remember the missing and murdered on Red Dress Day in Alberta\n\n\"This is just a way of showing our love for them,\" she said.\n\nTolley\u2019s mother was struck and killed by a S\u00fbret\u00e9 du Qu\u00e9bec cruiser in 2001. Her case was closed three months later, with no notification to Tolley and her family.\n\n\"We never got any information, so this is why I'm still here 20 years later bringing her case up.\"\n\nShe founded Families of Sisters in Spirit in 2011, and has been fighting ever since for more accountability from the government and police, as well as expanded services for Indigenous people.\n\nWhen women and girls from First Nation, Inuit, and M\u00e9tis communities are murdered or go missing, Tolley says families can be left feeling helpless.\n\n\"These national organizations - they're not involved,\" she explained. \"They work from nine to five, and after that, who helps families? Most of the time, it's the families that have been doing their own searches.\"\n\nA 2023 study from Statistics Canada shows from 2009 to 2021, the rate of homicides against First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit women and girls was six times higher than that of non-indigenous Canadians.\n\nNine in 10 homicides involving Indigenous women and girls that were reported to police during that timespan were solved.\n\nFrom 2015 to 2021, a third of unsolved homicides involving Indigenous women and girls began with the victim being reported missing at the time of her death.\n\nMany, like Amanda Fox, only heard of the stats after a tragedy.\n\n\"My sister, she was murdered 11 years ago - that gave me awareness,\" she said. \"Learning the hard way, but now to have these events, it's really important to spread that awareness.\"\n\nThe two dozen gatherers shared a meal as Sunday\u2019s rain pelted the tents overhead \u2013 a good turnout for a damp day, but Fox says she wants to see more.\n\n\"I find people still turn a blind eye so there's a lot to be done. This park should be full and there's not many people here,\" Fox said.\n\nStrathcona Park resides in the Rideau-Vanier ward \u2013 known colloquially as \u2018Little Nunavut\u2019 for its high percentage of Indigenous residents. As a result, there exist a number of community organizations aimed at providing support to these groups.\n\n\"We have a lot of great organizations and I just think it behooves us to support them,\" said Rideau-Vanier Coun. St\u00e9phanie Plante.\n\nIndigenous individuals dealing with mental health concerns can find support 24-hours a day through the First Nations and Inuit Hope for Wellness Helpline at 1-855-242-3310.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nA red dress hangs in Strathcona Park, as residents gather for a day of mourning and awareness. {"url": "https://cornellsun.com/2019/10/22/red-dress-art-exhibition-raises-awareness-of-assault-against-indigenous-women/", "title": "Red Dress Art Exhibition Raises Awareness of Assault Against Indigenous Women - The Cornell Daily Sun", "body": "Skip to content\nThursday, July 4\nContact Us\nJoin The Sun!\nAbout The Sun\nAdvertise\n161 Things Every Cornellian Should Do\nDownload our iPhone App\nInstagram\nAlumni\nWhere Did the Comments Go?\nSupport the Sun!\nThe Cornell Daily Sun - Independent Since 1880\nNews \nOpinion \nSports \nArts & Culture \nScience & Tech \nLifestyle \nMultimedia \nSpecials\n4/20 \n\nBoris Tsang/Sun Photography Editor\n\nRed dresses were scattered across the Arts Quad on October 21st, 2019. The installation was part of the REDress Project, which hopes to raise awareness about missing or murdered Aboriginal women across Canada.\n\nOctober 22, 2019\nACTIVISM\nRed Dress Art Exhibition Raises Awareness of Assault Against Indigenous Women\nBy Justine Kim\nLIKE\nTWEET\n EMAIL\nPRINT\nMORE\n\nOn Monday, brilliant red dresses swung from the trees of Cornell\u2019s campus to raise awareness on a national crisis.\n\nThe REDress Project is an extension of an art installation by Canadian artist Jaime Black. The exhibition comments on the high rates of sexual assault and murder among Indigenous women in the United States.\n\nOn Monday afternoon, Black spoke at an event in Statler Hall organized by Native American and Indigeous Students at Cornell, where she covered REDress\u2019s initiatives and influences as well as its purpose on the Cornell campus.\n\n\u201cWe need to make space for Indigenous voices in institutions like this and we have to value and take seriously, Indigenous-led initiatives and going forward in institutions like this,\u201d Black told The Sun in an interview.\n\nThe artist said she was inspired to continue the REDress project after witnessing other works and social movements for the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\u2019s movement, such as the Kokum Scarf campaign on Instagram and Nadia Kwandiben\u2019s \u201cRed Works Photography.\u201d\n\nSimilarly, REDress reflects the red dresses hung at a memorial for Tina Fontaine, a First Nations girl whose murder instigated a multi-million dollar inquiry by the Canadian government in 2016.\n\nAccording to Black, the meaning behind her choice to use red is open to interpretation.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like to give people clear answers,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s wonderful to come at the work with your own connection with that color.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut to me, it\u2019s the sacredness of that lifeblood,\u201d Black continued. \u201c[Red] shows that sacred life blood is being spilled. It shows that there is also violence happening.\u201d\n\nAccording to Black, each dress is a memorial for Indigenous women who became victims of institutionalized acts of colonial erasure. She hoped that the red dresses could open up space for people to talk about \u201cthe politics of land here at Cornell.\u201d\n\n\u201cFor those of us who are Indigenous on campus, most of us have or know someone who has gone missing who is within our family or within our friend group,\u201d Annabel Young \u201921, co-chair of Native American and Indigenous Students at Cornell, told The Sun in an interview. \u201cMy great grandma was Ojibwa [and] was murdered by my great grandpa.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo be indigenous and to be female moving throughout the world, there is a risk of violence that is different than other groups experience,\u201d Young said.\n\nYoung said the red dresses should remind students of \u201cthe resonancy of Indigenous genocide \u2026 and remembrance that this is indigenous land wherever you go.\u201d\n\nSachem Sam George, one of the chiefs of the Cayuga Nations, and his wife, Debbie George, also attended Black\u2019s talk. Sachem George is the only chief presently living in Cayuga territory, according to Debbie George, and gave the opening words at the event to represent the missing and murdered Indigenous women of Cayuga Nations.\n\nIn her presentation, Black said that she was moved after hearing Jo-Ann Episkewnew, director of the Indigenous People\u2019s Health Research Center at the University of Regina, speak about the genocide of Indigenous women in Canada.\n\nBlack collaborated with native artists at the Urban Shaman Contemporary Aboriginal Art Gallery and contacted people around the world asking for donations of red dresses to her project. In her presentation, Black said she received over 400 red dresses in 2009 alone, many donated by non-Indigenous people.\n\nIn 2011, Black installed the first REDress exhibition in her own city at the University of Winnipeg.\u00a0\n\nSince then, the critically-acclaimed REDress project has been installed in the National Museum of the American Indian, the Canadian Museum of Human Rights and various universities around the United States. Cornell is the third installment of the REDress project in the United States.\n\nBlack is part of the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, an international coalition movement working against violence towards First Nations, Inuit, M\u00e9tis and other Native American communities.\n\n\u201cWho\u2019s allowed to take space here? Who\u2019s not allowed to take space here? Why is this colonial institution built on this land?\u201d Black said in her closing comments. \u201cMaybe that\u2019s something that you guys can work on. Let\u2019s start unpacking that.\u201d\n\n\n\n\n\nCLICK HERE TO SUPPORT THE SUN\n\nRELATED\nArt Installation on Libe Slope Sheds Light on Indigenous Tragedy\nBy Finley Williams October 17, 2021\n\nThe pile of logs blocking a path on the slope were part of an art installation aiming to draw attention to indigenous struggle.\n\nCornell\u2019s Land Grant Heritage: A Sinister Tradition?\nBy Sean O'Connell April 24, 2020\n\nalmost 1 million acres of dispossessed American Indian land, sold to form the basis of Cornell\u2019s endowment \u2014 a sum of almost $6 million by 1914, equivalent to $150 million today.\nThe sale of almost 1 million acres of dispossessed American Indian land formed the basis of Cornell\u2019s endowment \u2014 a sum of almost $6 million by 1914, equivalent to $150 million today.\n\nX\n\n\t\t\t\n\n\u00a9 Copyright 2024, The Cornell Daily Sun\n\nHome Contact Us Advertise Publication Calendar Email Subscription Download our iPhone App Staff\n\nBack to top \u2191"},

show solidarity against hate, racism - My Cowichan Valley Now", "body": "Home\nNews\nNews Alerts Sign Up!\nWin\nEvents\nCommunity Calendar\nSubmit Event\nListen Live\nOn Air\nExperience BC\nCV Capitals Hockey\nLocal Connections\nNEWS\nWIN\nEVENTS\nCONTACT US\nCONTEST RULES\nADVERTISE\nWE\u2019RE HIRING\nSUBSCRIBE TO LOCAL NEWS\n\u25ba Listen Live\nHome\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nListen Live\nOn Air\nExperience BC\nCV Capitals Hockey\nLocal Connections\n- Advertisement -\nHomeNewsLadysmith, Stz'uminus Councils hang red dresses to show solidarity against hate, racism\nNews\nLadysmith, Stz\u2019uminus Councils hang red dresses to show solidarity against hate, racism\nBy\nTroy Landreville\nMonday, Apr. 19th, 2021\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nMike Gregory photo, Town of LadySmith\n- Advertisement -\n\nThe Town of Ladysmith and Stz\u2019uminus First Nation are coming together to show solidarity against racism and hate.\n\nThis comes after videos surfaced online showing a pair removing red dresses hung along the Island Highway, near Ladysmith.\n\nOn Saturday, Ladysmith and Stz\u2019uminus took a stand to ensure the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women across Canada are not forgotten.\u00a0\n\n\u201cCouncil members commemorated the women \u2013 mothers, daughters, sisters, aunts, friends \u2013 of First Nations, Inuit, M\u00e9tis communities by hanging red dresses within view of the Trans-Canada Highway,\u201d the Town reported.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nMore than a dozen red dresses were hung up along the highway and since then, the town hung up dresses on the trees in front of city hall, and at another at a park further down the highway.\n\nThe REDress Project started over a decade ago as a public art installation by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black in response to the more than a 1,000 missing and murdered Indigenous women across our country.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nCommunities now hang red dresses in public spaces to raise awareness and draw attention to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Aboriginal women.\u00a0\n\nRed dresses were also installed by the Town in front of City Hall as well as Bob Stuart Park.\u00a0\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nThe Town is also encouraging community members to learn about the REDress Project and if moved to do so, consider hanging a red dress in their windows or trees in your yard to show their support.\n\nAfter two people were seen taking the dresses down, Campbell Riverite Stephanie Elickus \u2013 organizer of the \u2018100 Red dress project MMIWG\u2019 Facebook group \u2013 told us that \u201cto see them ripped down was disheartening, I was in tears. {"url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/islander/anny-scoones-red-dress-project-shows-shift-in-public-art-from-shocking-to-quietly-symbolic-1.24335984", "title": "Anny Scoones: Red Dress project shows shift in public art from shocking to quietly symbolic - Victoria Times Colonist", "body": "Skip to content\n22.2 \u00b0C JOIN OUR NEWSLETTER \nNEWS\nOPINION\nEVENTSLIFE & ARTS\nFEATURES\nPROPERTIESCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nCONNECT\nE-EDITION\nHome Islander\nAnny Scoones: Red Dress project shows shift in public art from shocking to quietly symbolic\nDo you enjoy public art, sculpture and monuments, and have you considered its relevance? The intent of public art is so very diverse. Some monuments and sculpture remind us to never forget the horrors and ravages of war.\nAnny Scoones\nJun 27, 2021 6:00 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nMarlene Hale takes part in Red Dress Day on the steps of the B.C. legislature in May. The Red Dress Project, a reminder of missing and murdered Indigenous women, quietly urges us to feel and to think on a deeper level, which lasts longer than being momentarily shocked, writes Anny Scoones. DARREN STONE, TIMES COLONIST\n\nDo you enjoy public art, sculpture and monuments, and have you considered its relevance?\n\nThe intent of public art is so very diverse. Some monuments and sculpture remind us to never forget the horrors and ravages of war. Other pieces might depict a heroic event, such as the Terry Fox statue at Mile Zero.\n\nSome public art may \u00adsimply be intended to bring joy to those who walk past \u2014 think of those towering, joyous colourful \u00adflowers beside the parking lot at Victoria International Airport, welcoming you home.\n\nAnd occasionally, a piece of public art or sculpture or \u00adinstallation will actually \u00adchallenge the observer, \u00adshocking us into uncomfortable and uneasy reflection.\n\nI saw two installations that I will never forget when I was a child, both in Quebec. A warning: Don\u2019t read this if you are eating.\n\nThe first was next to a \u00adrestaurant in a busy shopping mall. The towering plexiglas structure was meant to \u00adrepresent our digestive system.\n\nAt specific times of the day, the restaurant dumped its great white buckets of food waste and plates of uneaten food into its \u201cmouth\u201d at the top. The spectators then witnessed the food being slowly digested.\n\nThroughout the process, various squirts of dark green bodily fluids were added as the food churned and oozed into a brown slurry sludge into the lower winding twisted regions of the \u201cbody,\u201d which was finally (this is the part I recall the most vividly, being six years old) squeezed and squirted out with great \u00adguttural sound effects in one final purging push into a huge shiny white bowl.\n\nThe little cluster of spectators gazed at the splattered plastic contraption, perhaps in disgust or perhaps in fascination, but did not walk away until the process was completed.\n\nThe other installation I recall was in a museum. I was with my mother, and the room was dimly lit by only a bare bulb on a string. Below the bulb was an electric chair, the kind used in executions. Strapped into the chair was a lifelike man. The chair had a lever on the side and museum visitors were invited to pull the lever, thus performing the execution.\n\nI remember vividly, although I was very young, that the atmosphere was rather horrifying. This installation was exhibited during the capital-punishment debate in Canada. Mum wouldn\u2019t pull the lever and neither would I \u2014 nobody did.\n\nIf you would like to read about sculpture and public art, I suggest the book Sculpture In Canada: A History, by Canadian cultural historian Maria Tippett (2017, Douglas and McIntyre).\n\nIn this large and heavy informative book, you will find chapters on prehistoric artifacts, war memorials, First Nation and Inuit carvings, contemporary works from across the country and, yes, a chapter titled Sculpture Shock.\n\nIn this chapter, the author describes the \u201cFlesh Dress\u201d by artist Jana Sterbak, with a colour photograph: \u201cSome twenty kilograms of raw flank steak must be acquired, then sewn together and hung on a tailor\u2019s dummy ... \u00adduring the course of exhibiting \u2026 the meat dries and flakes \u2014 and smells \u2014 thereby reinforcing the themes of death, decay and the transience of life \u2026\u201d This type of sculpture is too obvious for me, but at the time, 1987, the meat dress was considered innovative and extraordinary.\n\nShocking public art is intended to provoke thought and reflection about controversial or uncomfortable issues. While it was quite common for art to provide shock at one time, I feel that shock has lost its impact \u2014 perhaps society is becoming jaded, or hopefully, gentler.\n\nA far more meaningful and profound kind of art these days uses subtle and simple symbolism, the most moving being, in my view, the Red Dress Project, which reminds us all of \u00admissing and murdered Indigenous women. This type of public art quietly urges us to feel and to think on a deeper level, and thinking on a deeper level and feeling moved lasts longer than being momentarily shocked.\n\nIf you drive up-Island, you will see the dresses, entangled amongst the roadside shrubbery, or twisting high in tree branches, perhaps freely flapping in the breeze, or draped over the banks of wild lupines and daisies that line the highway. In winter, the dresses become wind-whipped and saturated but cling on mightily, their grip strong.\n\nThe Red Dress concept, originally spelled REDress, was created by the Winnipeg M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black. There\u2019s a stunning photograph on the internet of the original exhibit of dresses hung in a grove of birches.\n\nPublic art is a unique perspective on our country, past and present. The shared grief over the unmarked graves of 215 residential school children found in Kamloops has created a very profound piece of public art on the legislative steps \u2014 silent, but there for all to see, deeply moving and relevant to our times.\n\nSee a typo/mistake?\nHave a story/tip?\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://www.richmond-news.com/national-news/in-the-news-for-may-5-a-look-at-aprils-employment-numbers-6956408", "title": "In The News for May 5 : A look at April's employment numbers - Richmond News", "body": "Skip to content\nSupport Us Sign in or register for your free account  \nHomeNews\nOpinion\nArts & Life\nFeatures\nHomesClassifieds\nObituaries\nConnect\nBest of Richmond\n27.0 \u00b0C\nHOME NATIONAL NEWS\nIn The News for May 5 : A look at April's employment numbers\nIn The News is a roundup of stories from The Canadian Press designed to kickstart your day. Here is what's on the radar of our editors for the morning of May 5 ... What we are watching in Canada ...\nCanadian Press\nMay 5, 2023 1:15 AM\nMay 5, 2023 1:20 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nStatistics Canada building and signs are pictured in Ottawa on Wednesday, July 3, 2019. Statistics Canada is set to release its April labour force survey this morning, providing updated numbers on employment levels in the country. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\n\nIn The News is a roundup of stories from The Canadian Press designed to kickstart your day. Here is what's on the radar of our editors for the morning of May 5 ...\n\nWhat we are watching in Canada ...\n\nStatistics Canada is set to release its April labour force survey this morning, providing updated numbers on employment levels in the country.\u00a0\n\nRBC says it expects 12,000 jobs were added last month, the lowest number since September. \u00a0\n\nEmployers have kept their hiring appetite in recent months, even as high interest rates make borrowing more expensive for people and businesses.\u00a0\n\nThe unemployment rate continued to sit at five per cent in March, hovering near record lows.\n\nHowever, job vacancies have been falling and the Bank of Canada's recent business outlook survey shows employers reporting less intense labour shortages.\u00a0\n\nThe Bank of Canada's aggressive rate hikes are expected to filter through to the labour market in the coming months, leading to a rise in unemployment.\u00a0\n\n---\n\nAlso this ...\n\nA United Nations initiative aimed at eliminating gender-based violence is asking Canada to put up cash to help stem a backsliding in women's rights, even though the Liberals are cutting back on foreign aid.\n\n\"Women's rights and violence against women and girls is not a side issue,\" said Nahla Valji, the UN's senior gender adviser, a position Canada pushed to have created at the agency's headquarters in New York.\n\nValji, who grew up in Burnaby, B.C., is on Parliament Hill this week asking Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to help stop an erosion of women's rights globally.\n\nShe's following up on a letter from UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed, who asked Trudeau to help fund what's called the Spotlight Initiative.\n\nThe project launched in 2017 with the European Union pledging 500 million euros, or roughly $740 million, for projects that work to curb gender-based violence and to give women a seat at the table in post-conflict negotiations.\n\nSpotlight Initiative works in two dozen of the world's poorest countries, helping local groups launch projects that provide women with employment while weeding out violence.\n\nValji's office wouldn't share the letter, but said it \"invites Canada to be a partner in scaling up the investment\" by the end of 2023, and said the letter didn't specify an amount.\n\nShe's leaning on the Liberals' rhetoric about putting women at the centre of their diplomatic efforts, such as through a feminist aid policy.\n\n\"Canada has always been a leader on the international stage, going back to Lester B. Pearson through to today, in terms of multilateralism,\" she said. \"Canada throughout history has walked the talk, in terms of the values of the (UN) charter.\"\n\nThe government says it's assessing the request. But at the same time, federal cutbacks have the development sector preparing to scale back programs.\u00a0\n\nThe Liberals insist a 15 per cent drop in funding for foreign aid is not actually a cut because it's higher than their pre-pandemic spending.\n\n---\n\nAnd this too ...\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\u00a0\n\nRed dresses are set to be on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\u201cI'm a mother. I'm a sister. I'm an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I'm just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\u00a0\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\u00a0\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\u00a0\n\n---\n\nWhat we are watching in the U.S. ...\n\nPHILADELPHIA _ Three fired police officers who pleaded guilty to misdemeanour charges in the death of an eight-year-old girl killed when they opened fire outside a high school football game near Philadelphia are set to be sentenced Friday.\n\nFormer Sharon Hill officers Brian Devaney, Devon Smith and Sean Dolan have pleaded guilty to 10 counts each of reckless endangerment. Investigators say they could not determine which officer fired the shot that killed Fanta Bility on Aug. 27, 2021. The charge carries a maximum term of up to two years in prison in Pennsylvania.\n\nProsecutors contend the officers negligently fired 25 shots at a car they mistakenly thought was involved in gunfire that broke out as spectators left the football game in 2021. Devaney was not wearing a body camera, and the other two officers did not turn their cameras on, investigators found.\n\nBility had attended the game at Academy Park High School with her mother and an older sister who was also shot but survived. In all, four people were hit by police bullets that sped past the car.\n\nThe handling of the case prompted outrage and protests from the Black community and others as District Attorney Jack Stollsteimer initially charged two Black teens who engaged in gunfire a block away _ which prompted the police response _ with the child's death. Those charges were later dropped, and, after a grand jury investigation, the officers were instead charged with voluntary and involuntary manslaughter along with the endangerment counts.\n\nThe November plea agreements that dismissed those more serious charges came after consultations with the Bility family.\n\nThe family, who belong to a community of immigrants from West Africa, said it was important that the officers take responsibility for the girl's death and the trauma they experienced. They have a federal lawsuit pending against the defendants and the Sharon Hill police department.\n\nLawyers for the ex-officers, who have been free on bail, initially called her death a tragedy caused by the teens who engaged in gunfire. The lawyers did not immediately return calls seeking comment Thursday.\n\n---\n\nWhat we are watching in the rest of the world ...\n\nBELGRADE, Serbia _ Serbian police said they have arrested a suspect in a drive-by shooting attack that killed at least eight and wounded 14, the nation's second such mass shooting in two days.\n\nIn a statement, police said that the man, identified by initials U.B., was arrested early Friday near the central Serbian town of Kragujevac, about 100 kilometres south of Belgrade.\n\nThe arrest followed an all-night search by hundreds of police, who sealed off an area south of Belgrade where the shooting took place late Thursday.\n\nThe attacker shot randomly at people in three villages near Mladenovac, some 50 kilometres south of the capital, RTS said.\n\nSerbian Interior Minister Bratislav Gasic called Thursday's drive-by shootings ``a terrorist act,'' state media reported.\n\nThe shooting came a day after a 13-year-old boy used his father's guns to kill eight fellow students and a guard at a school in Belgrade.\n\nThe bloodshed sent shockwaves through a Balkan nation scarred by wars, but unused to mass murders.\n\nThough Serbia is awash with weapons left over from the wars of the 1990s, Wednesday's school shooting was the first in the country's modern history. The last mass shooting before this week was in 2013, when a war veteran killed 13 people in a central Serbian village.\n\n---\n\nOn this day in 1950 ...\n\nWaves caused by 80-km/h winds broke through dikes surrounding Winnipeg. The water inundated the Manitoba capital, forcing one-third of the population to leave their homes. The flooding left one person dead and caused $100 million in damage.\n\n---\n\nIn entertainment ...\n\nThe family members of some of the men who died in a shipwreck in 1975 are mourning the death of Gordon Lightfoot.\u00a0\n\nThe legendary folk musician, who died Monday, immortalized the 29 crewmen in his famous song \"The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald.\"\n\nThe song was released in 1976, one year after the ship sank in Lake Superior during a storm.\n\nDeborah Champeau says when she heard the news of Lightfoot's death, it felt like finding out the ship sank again.\u00a0\n\nChampeau's father was a third assistant engineer on the vessel.\n\nLightfoot formed a relationship with many of the families over the years after he reached out to explain why he wrote the song.\u00a0\n\nLightfoot also joined families in 2015 at an event marking the 40th anniversary of the shipwreck.\n\n---\n\nDid you see this?\n\nIt may have been the greatest battle between robots and humans to ever take place inside a Saskatchewan brewery.\u00a0\n\nThe grain mash was masterful and the fermentation feisty as a brewer went head to head in a taste-off with ChatGPT to find out who, or what, can make the best beer.\u00a0\n\nThe idea for the faceoff against the artificial intelligence-powered chatbot came out of a meeting between staff at 9 Mile Legacy Brewing, a Saskatoon nanobrewery known for making craft beer and pushing boundaries.\u00a0\n\nGarrett Pederson, 9 Mile\u2019s co-founder and head brewer, said they were playing around with the explosively popular chatbot earlier this year and thought it would be fun to test the technology\u2019s usefulness when it comes to one of the oldest drinks humans have produced.\n\nChatGPT, developed by U.S.-based company OpenAI, was challenged to create an \"award-winning\" gose recipe using local ingredients. A gose is typically a sour and salty beer with origins in Germany.\n\nUnsurprisingly, it made a Saskatoon berry gose.\n\nPederson came up with his own recipe for a rhubarb ginger sour. He used the tried and true methods of researching old brew records and recipes, talking with other brewers and looking online.\u00a0\n\nThe two beers were put in front of customers for a blind taste test, and while Team Human put in a good fight, it was ultimately Team Robot that took the win with 60 per cent of the votes\n\nPederson says it was a fun experiment, but he doesn\u2019t expect to see the artificial intelligence taking over any time soon.\u00a0\n\nThere had to be a lot of help from human brewers to make it drinkable.\u00a0\n\n---\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 5, 2023.\n\nThe Canadian Press\n\nHave a story idea?\nLetter to the editor\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. Act Now>>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\nOpinion\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nShopping\nDriving\nRemembering\nePaper\nSUNShine Girls\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nPrevious\nTrudeau mocked for goofy 'Seinfeld' dance at GTA street festival: 'Embarrassing the whole country'\nTRENDING\nMan asked two teen girls to have sex with him, punched boy: St. Albert RCMP\nTRENDING\nViolent sex offender police warned of last year freed in Edmonton again\nTRENDING\nBreaking down the new-look Edmonton Oilers by position for 2024-25\nTRENDING\nInside The Oilers: Oilers add more firepower up front\nTRENDING\nNext\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nEdmontonNews\nSisters in Spirit ninth annual Stolen Sisters and Brothers Awareness Walk held in Edmonton\nAuthor of the article:\nPostmedia (Archived Content)\nPublished Oct 04, 2015 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated Oct 04, 2015 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nArticle content\n\nA large gathering at Churchill Square on Sunday for the Sisters in Spirit ninth annual Stolen Sisters and Brothers Awareness Walk put into perspective the scale of the grief suffered by those who have lost loved ones.\n\nJane L'hommecourt marched with two signs, one for her niece Shelly Dene and another for her sister-in-law Janice \"Jazz\" Desjarlais.\n\n\"It's very emotional even to talk about it,\" said L'hommecourt. \"It doesn't matter how many years go by, it still hurts. They are still gone, there are no answers, no action, no respect.\"\n\nDesjarlais, who was 35 years old when she disappeared, was last seen on a security camera climbing into a dumpster with her significant other outside of the Centre for Hope in Fort McMurray, AB, on Oct. 3, 2010. They were looking to find a place to sleep.\n\nFootage shows the man leaving the dumpster in the morning, and later a garbage truck emptying the dumpster, but after a nine-day search of the landfill her remains were never found.\n\nShelly Dene was 26 years old when she was reported missing by a family member on Nov. 8, 2013, though she had been out of contact since August 2013.\n\nL'hommecourt said the loss of two family members has left a significant void in her family, but not knowing what happened to them is even harder to bear.\n\nOver 1,017 Indigenous women and girls were murdered between 1980-2012, according to the RCMP, with 164 missing persons cases unsolved, a number that continues to grow.\n\nThe Stolen Sisters Walk, one of several held across Canada, was not only an opportunity to raise awareness of the issue of violence against first nations, aboriginal and inuit women - who experience a homicide rate four times higher than all other women - but a chance for family members left behind to support each other in their grief.\n\n\"Grief is hard, and you don't really heal from grief, but this is something we can give to families when so much has been taken,\" said lead organizer Toni Letendre.\n\n\"Part of this is a healing,\" said Tony Alexis, Treaty 6 Grande Chief and Chief of the Alexis Nakota Sioux Nation who marched with the crowd. \"It's to bring love and unity, and it's inviting everyone to join in this heartache that these families are dealing with.\"\n\nAlexis has experienced the loss in his own family, with relative Misty Potts, 37, missing since March. She was last seen in the Enoch Cree Nation on March 14, 2015, and was believed to be heading into Edmonton.\n\nBut in order to prevent more women falling victim, Alexis said the relationship between the government and indigenous communities must improve and be based in mutual repsect and understanding.\n\nLetendre echoed his concerns, saying the first step is addressing cultural biases within ourselves, prejudices that invite violence.\n\n@ClaireTheobald\n\nclaire.theobald@sunmedia.ca\n\n\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 2\nADVERTISEMENT\nArticle content\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nSUNshine Girl Tina\nEdmonton Sun\nSUNshine Girl Dannie\nEdmonton Sun\nUse This and Never Have to Change Your Whipper Snipper Line Again\nUltraCut\n|\nSponsored\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nA Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before!\nEats Your Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nThese Barefoot Shoes are Leaving Neuropathy Experts Baffled\nBarefoot Vitality\n|\nSponsored\nTRENDING\nTrudeau mocked for goofy 'Seinfeld' dance at GTA street festival: 'Embarrassing the whole country'\nMan asked two teen girls to have sex with him, punched boy: St. Albert RCMP\nViolent sex offender police warned of last year freed in Edmonton again\nBreaking down the new-look Edmonton Oilers by position for 2024-25\nInside The Oilers: Oilers add more firepower up front\nREAD NEXT\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\n\u00a0\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://www.hopestandard.com/local-news/looking-back-at-the-top-headlines-for-2023-january-to-june-7292553", "title": "Looking back at the top headlines for 2023: January to June - Hope Standard", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n26.1 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Local News\nLooking back at the top headlines for 2023: January to June\nJanuary to June is looked back on for 2023\n\tKemone Moodley\n\nJan 4, 2024 10:39 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 25 Tashme Historical Society (THS) officially announced on Jan. 2 that they were the new owners of the Hope Station House (which they gained ownership of on Nov. 4, 2022). (Kemone Moodley/Hope Standard)\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:12:19\n\nJanuary\n\n\u2022 Tashme Historical Society (THS) officially announced on Jan. 2 that they were the new owners of the Hope Station House (which they gained ownership of on Nov. 4, 2022). THS said they hoped to move the building to it\u2019s new location in spring and that they planned to turn the building into a \u201cvibrant heritage tourism and community hub.\u201d\n\n\u2022 On the evening of Jan. 9, the Cascade Lower Canyon Community Forest (CLCCF) were disappointed to discover that someone had stolen $15,000 worth of wood from them. Profit from selling the wood would have gone towards CLCCF\u2019s three partners: Yale First Nation, District of Hope, and Fraser Valley Regional District.\n\n\u2022 Fans of Highway Thru Hell were breathing a sigh of relief after Jamie Davis \u2014 one of the stars of the show and a prominent tow truck operator \u2014 came away from a multi-vehicle crash with no injuries on Jan. 8. Davis\u2019 rescue towing and hauling business is located in Hope.\n\n\u2022 Thomas Cameron became the District of Hope\u2019s new fire chief on Jan. 20. Cameron took over from Tom DeSorcy, the District of Hope\u2019s first paid fire chief, who retired after 23 years.\n\n\u2022 The 30th anniversary for Carol Schlamp, a paramedic who died on the job, was held on Jan. 26 at the Hope ambulance station, with a procession of paramedics and ambulances leading everyone to her memorial plaque in Centennial Park.\n\nFebruary\n\n\u2022 Residents asking for a traffic lights at the intersection of 6th Avenue and Old Hope-Princeton Way finally got their wish; the Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure (MOTI) announced that construction for traffic lights at the intersection would begin on Feb. 13 and be completed sometime in March.\n\n\u2022 A brazen daylight robbery on Feb. 9 had Hope RCMP looking for a man who stole a Predator 2 axe from Kerfuffle Creations. Sarah Preson, the owner of Kerfuffle, said she was disappointed and disheartened by the thief\u2019s actions and was offering a reward for any information regarding the axe.\n\n\u2022 Juno award-winning Norman Foote performed at the inaugural Sunshine Valley Snowfest on Feb. 18. The Snowfest was the first winter festival in Sunshine Valley since the arrival of COVID-19 and is the successor of the former Winterfest.\n\n\u2022 On Feb. 12, Yale First Nation (YFN) Chief Ken Hansen officially announced that he would not be re-running for chief in the upcoming September election. Hansen was chief of YFN for seven years.\n\n\u2022 On Feb. 13 the B.C. Appeals Court denied Robert Lowry\u2019s \u2014 who was found guilty of aggravated assault, kidnapping, and three other charges related to an attack in Hope \u2014 appeal/bid for freedom. The 50 year-old was charged and arrested for attacking Richard Houle at a highway pullout near the Hope Garden Centre, on Aug. 16, 2016, in a dispute over a marijuana grow op.\n\n\u2022 The Canadian military had a memorable Valentine\u2019s Day after being reunited with their Argo, an eight-wheeled utility vehicle, that had been stolen from the Keith Wilson Road area of Chilliwack on November 2021. The vehicle was discovered in a home in Flood Hope Road which prompted the arrest of a 33-year-old Chilliwack man and a 31-year-old Fraser Valley woman.\n\n\u2022 After a month of online voting, the Hope Station House placed 3rd in the Next Great Save competition and won $5,000 on Feb. 23. The Station House received 22,374 votes for the competition which was run by the National Trust for Canada.\n\nMarch\n\n\u2022 Hope, Cascades & Canyons Visitor Centre and Museum was a nominee for the 2023 Remarkable Experience award though did not win. They were nominated for the First Blood 40th anniversary which took place in October 2022. The winners were announced on Mar. 2 during the 2023 conference\u2019s Awards Gala, which was hosted by the Tourism Industry Association of BC.\n\n\u2022 Deputy Fire Chief Joshua Westcott started his first day, in his new position, on Mar. 6. Westcott has been a member of the Hope Fire Department since 2018 and was a training officer for the department in 2022.\n\n\u2022 On Mar. 9, Hope\u2019s very own Peter Bailey was named this year\u2019s Champion of Diversity for the 20th annual Fraser Valley Cultural Diversity Awards. Bailey won for his work in Hope with the Hope Inclusion Project (which was nominated for an Innovative Initiative Award) and for his lifetime work of championing diversity and equality.\n\n\u2022 In March, the Dr. E. Murakami Centre for Lyme Research, Education & Assistance Society (Hope Lyme Association) donated its remaining $60,000 towards the Ernest K. Murakami Scholarship in Medicine. The scholarship is for University of British Columbia students in the M.D. Program participating in an Infectious Disease elective.\n\n\u2022 Bronxon Shane Boxall, a 28-year-old man from Hope who bear-sprayed another man during a fight, was given a four-month conditional sentence order (including a curfew) on Mar. 16.\n\n\u2022 The Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure (MOTI) finished installing traffic light, at the intersection at 6th Avenue and Old Hope-Princeton Way, on Mar. 23.\n\n\u2022 In March, AdvantageHOPE announced four new members: Hope Coun. Angela Skoglund, Chawathil Coun. Aaron Pete, Gerry Weibe, and Laura Reid. The four members were nominated, to be part of the AdvantageHOPE board, during the Feb. 27 council meeting.\n\n\u2022 The Hope Pride Committee (HPC) found themselves disappointed after the District of Hope council voted no to raising the Pride flag during the official Pride month in June. The council voted during the Mar. 27 council meeting, with councillors Zachary Wells, Angela Skoglund, and Pauline Newbigging citing neutrality as reasons against raising the flag.\n\nApril\n\n\u2022 It was a good April Fools Day for Chawathil First Nation\u2019s Thelma Florence who the BCLC\u2019s Lotto 6/49 Guaranteed Prize of $1 million.\n\n\u2022 On April 3, the Fraser-Nicola electoral riding was re-drawn to add Agassiz and Harrison Hot Springs \u2014 and exclude Ashcroft and Cache Creek. The new proposed Fraser-Nicola is now made up of: Hope, Yale, Boston Bar, Merritt, Lytton, Logan Lake, Lillooet, and includes communities on the north bank of the Fraser River. This decision left MLA Jackie Tegart as a representative for an electoral district she does not live in as she lives in Ashcroft.\n\n\u2022 On April 3, the Honour House Society visited the Royal Canadian Legion Branch 228 (Hope Legion) as part of its \u201cTour of Honour\u201d \u2014 a fundraising tour to raise awareness about illnesses and injuries that face those in uniform.\n\n\u2022 On April 5, three homes \u2014 on at Yale Street, one at 3rd Avenue, and one at Hazel Street \u2014 were intentionally set on fire early in the morning. Lisa Rees, who lived at the house on Hazel Street, managed to save her fellow tenants and landlord after alerting them of the fire and helping them leave. The house was completely destroyed.\n\n\u2022 On April 25, one person died in a three-vehicle crash near Hunter Creek Road. A tractor trailer rear-ended a semi-truck that then struck a dump truck in front of it. The dump truck had stopped due to the traffic caused by the rock-scaling project happening in the area at the time. One of the drivers was pronounced dead at the scene.\n\n\u2022 After 40 years of service, on April 20 the Provincial Heritage Branch removed the Yale & District Historical Society (YDHS) as managers of the Yale Historic Site (YHS). They named Forager Foundation as the new managers of YHS. YDHS said it was informed of the transfer after Heritage Branch said that their application, to re-tender their contract to manage the site, had been denied.\n\nMay\n\n\u2022 In May, three families living at 67905 Fish Camp Rd found themselves in danger of being forced to abandon their home thanks to being landlocked at their farm; according to Evan Bell, the owner, the November 2021 floods washed away the main access to Fish Camp Road and they were unable to/not given permission to use roads owned by their neighbours. This culminated in the family being forced to rely on a temporary access road used by Trans Mountain that was scheduled to be taken down in the middle of May. Bell said the problem was also not being fixed immediately because no one knew who Fish Camp Road belonged to.\n\n\u2022 On May 5, April Parisian \u2014 a woman from Spuzzum First Nation who went missing in April 2020 \u2014 was remembered during the Ann Davis Transition Society\u2019s Red Dress Day event in Chilliwack. Three years later, she still hasn\u2019t been found.\n\n\u2022 Jessica Peters, a former Hope Standard reporter, took home gold and silver during the annual B.C. & Yukon community News Media Association\u2019s 2023 Ma Murray Awards on May 4. She won first place for her feature article for \u201cLife carries on at Abbotsford dairy farm where 200 cows died.\u201d\n\n\u2022 In May, B.C.\u2019s wild population of the critically endangered Northern Spotted owl took a hit when two of them were found dead in the Fraser Canyon, their native habitat. The two owls, both males, were part of the historic release that took place in Spuzzum First Nation territory back in August 2022. The owl\u2019s deaths brought the wild population back down to one.\n\n\u2022 On May 12, the Chiefs of Spuzzum, Yale, Boston Bar, and Chawathil First Nations sent a joint letter to the Yale and District Historical Society (YDHS) saying that it needed to return the Indigenous artifacts back to the Yale Historic Site\u2019s (YHS) museum. This letter came after YDHS removed the items after being removed as the managers of YHS by Heritage Branch. YDHS issued an apology letter to the First Nation communities on May 13 and agreed to return the items.\n\n\u2022 On May 23, the Hope RCMP celebrated the RCMP\u2019s 150th anniversary.\n\n\u2022 In May, locals and visitors got disappointing news when BC Parks and the Ministry of Environment said that Othello Tunnels would remain closed for the summer. The tunnels were closed after being damaged by the 2021 November floods.\n\nJune\n\n\u2022 June 1 marked a historic moment as the Hope Pride Committee held the opening ceremony for Hope\u2019s very first Pride festival. The ceremony was held at the Hope RCMP detachment and was attended by various members of the community.\n\n\u2022 On June 7 and June 8, two hate crimes \u2014 against the LGBTQIA2S+ community \u2014 were committed in Hope; the Hope Community Services office window was broken and a burning piece of wood was thrown into the office in an attempt to burn the HCS\u2019s Pride Progress flag. And Hope\u2019s very first rainbow crosswalk, painted during the first week of Hope Pride, was vandalized with hateful and violent language. Despite the hate, students of Hope Secondary School, as well as members of the community, came together to fix the crosswalk and show solidarity with the LGBTQIA2S+ community.\n\n\u2022 On June 14, Trans Mountain officially removed their temporary access road that allowed them access to Fish Camp Road. This left the three families living at 67905 Fish Camp Rd without a way to enter or leave their property.\n\n\u2022 On June 17, the Fraser River Debris Trap Co-Management Agreement was signed by the B.C. government and the Shxw\u2019owh\u00e1mel First Nation council. This agreement allows the Fraser River Debris Trap to now be co-managed by both the Province and Shxw\u2019owh\u00e1mel.\n\n\u2022 In June, the B.C.\u2019s Representative for Children and Youth (RCY) launched an investigation into the abuse of two foster children in the eastern Fraser Valley community of Lake Errock \u2014 which falls under the jurisdiction of the Ministry for Children and Families\u2019s office in Hope. The abuse led to the death of one of the children.\n\nREAD MORE: New Year\u2019s baby arrives in Chilliwack after 65 hours of labour\n\n@KemoneMoodley\nkemone.moodley@hopestandard.com\nLike us on
