{"url": "https://www.chathamthisweek.com:443/news/local-news/indigenous-student-trustee-raising-awareness-about-missing-murdered-women/wcm/fcab685a-1172-4682-88fd-c63b00f4c368", "title": "Indigenous student trustee shines light on missing, murdered women | Chatham This Week", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nIndigenous student trustee shines light on missing, murdered women\nAuthor of the article:\nHeather Rivers\nPublished May 04, 2022 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nNiigonii White-Eye stands at a monument to honour Indigenous students forced to attend the former Mount Elgin Industrial Institute residential school at Chippewas of the Thames First Nation. White-Eye is a student trustee on the Thames Valley District school board,. Photo taken Tuesday, May 3, 2022. (Derek Ruttan/The London Free Press)\nArticle content\n\nThey weren\u2019t in the wrong place, at the wrong time.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nNiigonii White-Eye, an Indigenous student trustee on the Thames Valley District school board, wants schoolkids and their teachers to understand this about why Indigenous women continue to disappear or be murdered.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a systemic issue that goes back generations,\u201d he said.\n\nPrior to Red Dress Day on Thursday, May 5, White-Eye, who lives on Chippewas of the Thames and attends Saunders secondary school, started an educational project after recognizing a gap in what his friends and other students were learning about missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nMay 5 is a day set aside to honour missing and murdered Indigenous people.\n\nAccording to the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, more than 4,000 Indigenous women have gone missing or have been murdered since 1980, acts propagated by systemic racism and poor government policy, White-Eye said.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nIndigenous women are three times more likely to be a victim of a violent crime than non-Native women, he said, adding 55 per cent of the women are younger than 31.\n\n\u201cThis is not a past tense issue; this is something present in today\u2019s society, an issue that doesn\u2019t get enough awareness as it should,\u201d White-Eye said. \u201cI didn\u2019t see a lot of missing and murdered Indigenous learning or awareness in our board. It was something I wanted awareness for.\u201d\n\nThe day is named for the artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project, an artistic response to the many missing or murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThe red dress is a symbol of the ongoing tragedy that dates back centuries, to the first interactions between native people and European settlers, White-Eye said.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nAnother symbol of the awareness campaign is a red painted hand over the mouth, representing the silence of women who have disappeared or died.\n\nWhite-Eye said his project, a Google slide show, will be sent to principals to be shared with students and staff.\n\n\u201cThey will view these slides and (learn) what the red dress signifies, what the red hand signifies,\u201d White-Eye said. \u201cIt\u2019s not something that happens in one community. It happens everywhere across Canada.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s something that has been systemic for centuries. It\u2019s inequality that is happening to Indigenous women and girls, systemic racism that goes back generations.\u201d\n\nhrivers@postmedia.com\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR CHATHAM\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://infotel.ca/newsitem/in-the-news/cp1936505875", "title": "In The News for May 5 : A look at April's employment numbers | iNFOnews | Thompson-Okanagan's News Source", "body": "Subscribe\n\nWould you like to subscribe to our newsletter?\n\nYes No\n \nSearch for business|\n \nClick here to Search All News s\nCurrent Conditions\n28.0\u00b0C\nHome\nNews\nCOVID-19\nWeather\nOpinion\nSports and\nEntertainment\nEvents\niNwordl\nBusiness Directory\nAbout\nSubsites\nMy Infotel\nKamloops\nKelowna\nPenticton\nVernon\nIn The News for May 5 : A look at April's employment numbers\nStatistics Canada building and signs are pictured in Ottawa on Wednesday, July 3, 2019. Statistics Canada is set to release its April labour force survey this morning, providing updated numbers on employment levels in the country. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick\nMay 05, 2023 - 1:15 AM\n\nIn The News is a roundup of stories from The Canadian Press designed to kickstart your day. Here is what's on the radar of our editors for the morning of May 5 ...\n\nWhat we are watching in Canada ...\n\nStatistics Canada is set to release its April labour force survey this morning, providing updated numbers on employment levels in the country.\n\nRBC says it expects 12,000 jobs were added last month, the lowest number since September.\n\nEmployers have kept their hiring appetite in recent months, even as high interest rates make borrowing more expensive for people and businesses.\n\nThe unemployment rate continued to sit at five per cent in March, hovering near record lows.\n\nHowever, job vacancies have been falling and the Bank of Canada's recent business outlook survey shows employers reporting less intense labour shortages.\n\nThe Bank of Canada's aggressive rate hikes are expected to filter through to the labour market in the coming months, leading to a rise in unemployment.\n\n---\n\nAlso this ...\n\nA United Nations initiative aimed at eliminating gender-based violence is asking Canada to put up cash to help stem a backsliding in women's rights, even though the Liberals are cutting back on foreign aid.\n\n\"Women's rights and violence against women and girls is not a side issue,\" said Nahla Valji, the UN's senior gender adviser, a position Canada pushed to have created at the agency's headquarters in New York.\n\nValji, who grew up in Burnaby, B.C., is on Parliament Hill this week asking Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to help stop an erosion of women's rights globally.\n\nShe's following up on a letter from UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed, who asked Trudeau to help fund what's called the Spotlight Initiative.\n\nThe project launched in 2017 with the European Union pledging 500 million euros, or roughly $740 million, for projects that work to curb gender-based violence and to give women a seat at the table in post-conflict negotiations.\n\nSpotlight Initiative works in two dozen of the world's poorest countries, helping local groups launch projects that provide women with employment while weeding out violence.\n\nValji's office wouldn't share the letter, but said it \"invites Canada to be a partner in scaling up the investment\" by the end of 2023, and said the letter didn't specify an amount.\n\nShe's leaning on the Liberals' rhetoric about putting women at the centre of their diplomatic efforts, such as through a feminist aid policy.\n\n\"Canada has always been a leader on the international stage, going back to Lester B. Pearson through to today, in terms of multilateralism,\" she said. \"Canada throughout history has walked the talk, in terms of the values of the (UN) charter.\"\n\nThe government says it's assessing the request. But at the same time, federal cutbacks have the development sector preparing to scale back programs.\n\nThe Liberals insist a 15 per cent drop in funding for foreign aid is not actually a cut because it's higher than their pre-pandemic spending.\n\n---\n\nAnd this too ...\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there's an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\n\nRed dresses are set to be on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\u201cI'm a mother. I'm a sister. I'm an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I'm just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\n\n---\n\nWhat we are watching in the U.S. ...\n\nPHILADELPHIA _ Three fired police officers who pleaded guilty to misdemeanour charges in the death of an eight-year-old girl killed when they opened fire outside a high school football game near Philadelphia are set to be sentenced Friday.\n\nFormer Sharon Hill officers Brian Devaney, Devon Smith and Sean Dolan have pleaded guilty to 10 counts each of reckless endangerment. Investigators say they could not determine which officer fired the shot that killed Fanta Bility on Aug. 27, 2021. The charge carries a maximum term of up to two years in prison in Pennsylvania.\n\nProsecutors contend the officers negligently fired 25 shots at a car they mistakenly thought was involved in gunfire that broke out as spectators left the football game in 2021. Devaney was not wearing a body camera, and the other two officers did not turn their cameras on, investigators found.\n\nBility had attended the game at Academy Park High School with her mother and an older sister who was also shot but survived. In all, four people were hit by police bullets that sped past the car.\n\nThe handling of the case prompted outrage and protests from the Black community and others as District Attorney Jack Stollsteimer initially charged two Black teens who engaged in gunfire a block away _ which prompted the police response _ with the child's death. Those charges were later dropped, and, after a grand jury investigation, the officers were instead charged with voluntary and involuntary manslaughter along with the endangerment counts.\n\nThe November plea agreements that dismissed those more serious charges came after consultations with the Bility family.\n\nThe family, who belong to a community of immigrants from West Africa, said it was important that the officers take responsibility for the girl's death and the trauma they experienced. They have a federal lawsuit pending against the defendants and the Sharon Hill police department.\n\nLawyers for the ex-officers, who have been free on bail, initially called her death a tragedy caused by the teens who engaged in gunfire. The lawyers did not immediately return calls seeking comment Thursday.\n\n---\n\nWhat we are watching in the rest of the world ...\n\nBELGRADE, Serbia _ Serbian police said they have arrested a suspect in a drive-by shooting attack that killed at least eight and wounded 14, the nation's second such mass shooting in two days.\n\nIn a statement, police said that the man, identified by initials U.B., was arrested early Friday near the central Serbian town of Kragujevac, about 100 kilometres south of Belgrade.\n\nThe arrest followed an all-night search by hundreds of police, who sealed off an area south of Belgrade where the shooting took place late Thursday.\n\nThe attacker shot randomly at people in three villages near Mladenovac, some 50 kilometres south of the capital, RTS said.\n\nSerbian Interior Minister Bratislav Gasic called Thursday's drive-by shootings ``a terrorist act,'' state media reported.\n\nThe shooting came a day after a 13-year-old boy used his father's guns to kill eight fellow students and a guard at a school in Belgrade.\n\nThe bloodshed sent shockwaves through a Balkan nation scarred by wars, but unused to mass murders.\n\nThough Serbia is awash with weapons left over from the wars of the 1990s, Wednesday's school shooting was the first in the country's modern history. The last mass shooting before this week was in 2013, when a war veteran killed 13 people in a central Serbian village.\n\n---\n\nOn this day in 1950 ...\n\nWaves caused by 80-km/h winds broke through dikes surrounding Winnipeg. The water inundated the Manitoba capital, forcing one-third of the population to leave their homes. The flooding left one person dead and caused $100 million in damage.\n\n---\n\nIn entertainment ...\n\nThe family members of some of the men who died in a shipwreck in 1975 are mourning the death of Gordon Lightfoot.\n\nThe legendary folk musician, who died Monday, immortalized the 29 crewmen in his famous song \"The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald.\"\n\nThe song was released in 1976, one year after the ship sank in Lake Superior during a storm.\n\nDeborah Champeau says when she heard the news of Lightfoot's death, it felt like finding out the ship sank again.\n\nChampeau's father was a third assistant engineer on the vessel.\n\nLightfoot formed a relationship with many of the families over the years after he reached out to explain why he wrote the song.\n\nLightfoot also joined families in 2015 at an event marking the 40th anniversary of the shipwreck.\n\n---\n\nDid you see this?\n\nIt may have been the greatest battle between robots and humans to ever take place inside a Saskatchewan brewery.\n\nThe grain mash was masterful and the fermentation feisty as a brewer went head to head in a taste-off with ChatGPT to find out who, or what, can make the best beer.\n\nThe idea for the faceoff against the artificial intelligence-powered chatbot came out of a meeting between staff at 9 Mile Legacy Brewing, a Saskatoon nanobrewery known for making craft beer and pushing boundaries.\n\nGarrett Pederson, 9 Mile\u2019s co-founder and head brewer, said they were playing around with the explosively popular chatbot earlier this year and thought it would be fun to test the technology\u2019s usefulness when it comes to one of the oldest drinks humans have produced.\n\nChatGPT, developed by U.S.-based company OpenAI, was challenged to create an \"award-winning\" gose recipe using local ingredients. A gose is typically a sour and salty beer with origins in Germany.\n\nUnsurprisingly, it made a Saskatoon berry gose.\n\nPederson came up with his own recipe for a rhubarb ginger sour. He used the tried and true methods of researching old brew records and recipes, talking with other brewers and looking online.\n\nThe two beers were put in front of customers for a blind taste test, and while Team Human put in a good fight, it was ultimately Team Robot that took the win with 60 per cent of the votes\n\nPederson says it was a fun experiment, but he doesn\u2019t expect to see the artificial intelligence taking over any time soon.\n\nThere had to be a lot of help from human brewers to make it drinkable.\n\n---\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 5, {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/highway-of-tears-documents-deleted-1.2093340", "title": "Highway of Tears documents deleted - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nHighway of Tears documents deleted\nVICTORIA - A political staffer in Transportation Minister Todd Stone's office deliberately deleted internal records about the Highway of Tears to prevent them from becoming public, and then lied about it to investigators, says B.C.\nRob Shaw\nOct 22, 2015 9:58 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nVICTORIA - A political staffer in Transportation Minister Todd Stone's office deliberately deleted internal records about the Highway of Tears to prevent them from becoming public, and then lied about it to investigators, says B.C.'s privacy commissioner.\n\nGeorge Gretes, a former ministerial assistant to Stone, is now under RCMP investigation for lying under oath to Information and Privacy Commissioner Elizabeth Denham.\n\nGretes has resigned, after being suspended with pay for five months.\n\nDenham said Thursday she's referred his case directly to the Mounties.\n\nThe RCMP said Thursday it has received Denham's report and is \"assessing it with respect to possible Criminal Code offenses.\"\n\nDenham released a scathing investigative report into the improperly deleted records Thursday, which outlined a litany of violations to rules, policies and B.C.'s FOI law.\n\nIt also validated complaints of whistleblower Tim Duncan, who went public in May with allegations he was pressured by Gretes to delete emails while working in Stone's office so that they couldn't be captured and released to the public through an FOI request.\n\nDuncan had said when he refused, Gretes physically took away his computer keyboard and deleted the records himself.\n\n\"I found Mr. Duncan to be a credible witness and that, on a balance of probabilities, his account of the events of Nov. 19, 2014 was truthful,\" Denham said in a news release Thursday.\n\n\"In contrast, I did not find Mr. Gretes to be a reliable witness. He admitted to giving false testimony under oath, and other aspects of his testimony was contradicted by other evidence,\" said Denham.\n\nDenham said that after one of the most resource-intensive and technical investigations her office has ever undertaken, she concluded \"that it is more likely than not that the email records were in fact deleted by ministerial assistant George Gretes.\"\n\nGretes eventually admitted he lied after his computer underwent a forensic examination, but not before also lying several times about when and how the events happened, who was involved and why it was done, Denham noted.\n\nShe said Gretes \"triple-deleted\" the emails, a practice that removes all trace from the government servers because it deletes not only the original email, but the version in the trash folder and then the version within the government's recovered deleted emails folder.\n\nDuncan said in an interview Thursday he felt vindicated by the report, but that the problem of record destruction is widespread within government among political staff and not an isolated incident.\n\n\"It's not just young 22-year-old staffers doing this, it's senior experienced people conducting themselves in this way, clearly against the law, they clearly knew better,\" he said.\n\nThe deleted emails and documents related to how the B.C. government consulted with northern communities and First Nations leaders last year to try to improve safety along the Highway of Tears.\n\nFirst Nations leaders remain unhappy at government inaction to improve transportation and safety issues on a road where women have gone missing and been murdered.\n\nDuncan had said he wasn't sure what specifically was contained in the emails because they were deleted so quickly.\n\nThe missing 36 pages of emails were ordered released by the commissioner, and the government said it would comply.\n\n\"In the course of this investigation, we uncovered negligent searches for records, a failure to keep adequate email records, a failure to document searches, and the willful destruction of records responsive to an access request,\" said Denham.\n\n\"Taken together, these practices threaten the integrity of access to information in British Columbia.\"\n\nDenham's report also zeroed in on Premier Christy Clark's deputy chief of staff, Michele Cadario, noting that she keeps almost none of her emails.\n\n\"The commissioner found that the broad interpretation given to transitory records by the deputy chief of staff, which results in her retaining almost no sent emails, effectively frustrates the Office of the Premier's ability to comply with (section six, subsection one) of FIPPA (the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act),\" wrote Denham in her report.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. JACK EVANS PHOTO jpg, BI\nArticle content\n\nJACK EVANS\n\nMore and more Canadians on drugs are crashing cars\n\u00a0\n\nFOR POSTMEDIA\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nClustered in front of the Market Square\u2019s Parrott Stage and around a sacred fire monitored by a fire keeper, residents and supporters of the Mohawks of the Bay of Quinte marked The National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and 2 Spirited People, colloquially referred to as Red Dress Day, Friday, May 5 with a respectful spell of silence and speeches by dignitaries.\n\nNumbering in excess of 100, many in the crowd wore red sweaters with the slogan:\u201dWe support our sisters,\u201d in honour of the murdered or missing Indigenous young women estimated now between 1,000 to 4,000 by different sources.\n\nKey speaker was Chief R. Donald Maracle who mentioned continuing lack of equality and lingering \u201ccolonialism\u201d for stress and misery, a lack of services and resources for Indigenous Peoples leading to circumstances that leave women more susceptible to harm and victimization.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cAll lives matter,\u201d he stressed, and noted hotbeds for the tragic loss have been British Columbia, the Prairies and Northern Ontario, but Tyendinaga has not escaped the problem.\n\nBelleville Mayor Neil Ellis remarked that \u201csadly, many women have been devalued,\u201d and society must be concerned and deal with this.\n\nMPP and Minister of Energy Todd Smith also supported the memorial activities and agreed governments and society must act to resolve the situation, including more and improved shelters and medical and mental health activities.\n\nMP Ryan Williams said there are many positive statements, \u201cbut these are just words. What we need is action. He urged indigenous peoples and all society to speak out in support to political leaders to pressure the government for more action.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe need your voice,\u201d he said.\n\nFree packets of ceremonial tobacco were available to be thrown in the sacred fire, with all the dignitaries leading the way. Candles were lit in honour and recognition of the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and 2S+ folks and for a moment to reflect.\n\nTwo young women said the horrendous loss of so many young indigenous girls has certainly affected them, in worry, stress and even loss of sleep.\n\nOrganizer of the event, Brandon Arnold, said he was pleased with the turnout which he estimated was \u201cbigger than last year,\u201d and hoped for a still bigger crowd for May 5 of next year when the event falls on a Sunday.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR NAPANEE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},
{"url": "https://www.myalgomamanitoulinnow.com/28775/eighth-sisters-in-spirit-rally/", "title": "Eighth Sisters in Spirit rally - My Algoma Manitoulin Now", "body": "Home\nNews\nNews Alerts Sign Up!\nRegional News\nSubmit News Tip\nWin\nEvents\nCommunity Calendar\nSubmit an Event\nListen Live\nOn Air\nLocal Connections\nNEWS\nWIN\nEVENTS\nCONTACT US\nADVERTISE\nWE\u2019RE HIRING!\nSUBSCRIBE TO LOCAL NEWS\n\u25ba Listen Live\nHome\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nListen Live\nOn Air\nLocal Connections\nHomeNewsEighth Sisters in Spirit rally\nNews\nEighth Sisters in Spirit rally\nBy\nRosalind Russell\nMonday, Oct. 7th, 2019\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\nThe Eighth Sisters in Spirit Rally was held in Sudbury this weekend to honour and remember not only missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, but also gender diverse peoples. Photos supplied by Greater Sudbury Police Service.\n- Advertisement -\n\nTom Davies Square in Sudbury was awash in red this weekend for a rally honouring and remembering not only missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, but also gender diverse peoples.\n\nThe Eighth Sisters in Spirit Rally was organized in partnership with the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada and the Greater Sudbury Police.\n\nThe service\u2019s Aboriginal liaison officer, Constable Shannon Agowissa says they hosted a Pipe Ceremony in Memorial Park followed by a walk to Tom Davies Square where she and others spoke of the importance of meeting the needs of those who have missing family members.\n\nShe adds they unveiled their Indigenous Women and Girls Missing Person toolkit, which assists police and families through the process when someone goes missing.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nShe says they continue to support our Looking Ahead Project in partnership with N\u2019Swakamok Native Friendship Centre, funded by the Department of Justice Canada.\n\nAgowissa told the crowd, \u201cWe are continuing a conversation that needs to be continued,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen I started doing work on the issue of missing or murdered Indigenous women, I realized how big of an issue it really is, and the root causes have been there for many, many years.\u201d\n\nA red dress serves as a symbol of all the women who are no longer there, and you will see red dresses hung at different times throughout the year, she adds.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about getting people to be aware of this issue, and the fact there\u2019s still a lot of work left to do,\u201d said Agowissa.\n\nFor more information about the toolkit and/or police programming, contact Constable Agowissa through the Greater Sudbury Police {"url": "https://nupge.ca/content/honouring-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-and-girls", "title": "Honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls | NUPGE Archives", "body": "Skip to main content \nNUPGE Archives\nMenu\n\nThis is an archive of news stories and research from the National Union of Public and General Employees. Please see our new site - https://nupge.ca - for the most current information.\u00a0\n\nHonouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls\n\nThere is an epidemic of violence against Indigenous women, Two Spirit and gender diverse people that is unacceptable. There is an epidemic of violence that is taking our loved ones from us.\n\nOttawa (10\u00a0Sept. 2018) \u2014 The Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada is pleased to announce the 13th\u00a0annual Sisters In Spirit Vigils coming this October 4.\u00a0\u00a0The violence experienced by Indigenous women and girls in Canada is a national tragedy.\u00a0\n\nUnited front supporting those who have lost loved ones; united front fighting for action and change\n\nEach year, family members, Indigenous community members, and supporters\u00a0gather on October 4\u00a0on Parliament Hill and across the country. People gather to honour the women and girls and their families\u00a0who have been impacted by violence. It is a demonstration of a\u00a0united front. There is an epidemic of violence against Indigenous women and girls, Two Spirit, and gender diverse people that is unacceptable.\u00a0\n\nThe vigils are powerful movements of social change with the number of vigils growing\u00a0from 11 in 2006 to an impressive 212 vigils in 2017.\n\nOn this day, people\u00a0link arms across Canada and throughout the world to show solidarity, demand action and change, and to provide support to each other.\n\nWhat\u00a0you can do in your community\n\nThe National Union of Public and General Employees (NUPGE) encourages its members across the country to get involved and support vigils in their community.\n\nVigils can take a variety of forms. They can be large or small in scale, and every single one is of great value. Some examples include\u00a0moments of silence\u00a0or\u00a0candlelight vigils, which can create spaces for honouring the\u00a0missing and murdered women and girls and opportunities for healing for families.\u00a0Rallies\u00a0or\u00a0marches\u00a0are powerful ways of raising public awareness and calling for legislative change.\n\nAll initiatives that support this goal are important. To register your vigil on or around October 4,\u00a0please return the registration form by September 5. Registered vigils will receive a kit that includes items that can be used at your vigil, speaking notes that can support your vigil, and an activity that you may choose to participate in.\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) produced a resource guide to help friends and supporters safely and responsibly raise awareness of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG). The\u00a0NWAC Community Resource Guide\u00a0has fact sheets on MMIWG and the causes of violence against Indigenous women and girls, and gives organizers useful tools for holding a successful SIS Vigil. On page 15, and throughout the guide,\u00a0you will have the information you need to best deliver the important messages of this community-based project.\n\nNational Union of Public and General Employees\u00a0\nWebsite: \u00a0https://nupge.ca\nArchives: https://archives.nupge.ca\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\n\n\u00a9 1995 - 2024 NUPGE."},

PHOTO BY KEVIN KING /Winnipeg Sun\nArticle content\n\nDrag the Red marked National Indigenous Peoples Day on Monday and its\u00a02021 Red River search for missing and murdered peoples with the unveiling and launch of a newly customized boat donated by Canada\u2019s largest private sector union.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWe are extremely grateful and blessed to receive a custom-built boat donated by Unifor that will last DTR for decades, and which will aid us in our work searching the Red River for our loved ones,\u201d said Drag the Red co-founder and MMIWG2S family member Bernadette Smith in a press release.\n\nSmith, the Manitoba NDP MLA for Point Douglas and Critic for Mental Health and Addictions, is the sister of Claudette Osborne, who has been missing since 2008.\n\nDrag The Red co-founder Bernadette Smith (left) and Gina Smoke, Indigenous liaison for Unifor, speaks with media as DTR launches its 2021 search for missing and murdered peoples with a new boat donated by Unifor on the Red River near the Redwood Bridge in Winnipeg on Monday. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING /Winnipeg Sun\n\n\u201cIt will be 13 years in July since Claudette disappeared from Winnipeg\u2019s North End,\u201d Smith said. \u201c13 years since our family\u2019s been searching for Claudette and other missing loved ones and seeking justice for all our families.\u201d\n\nDrag the Red began in 2014 following the murder of 15-year-old Tina Fontaine, whose body was recovered from the Red River, having been weighed down with stones, and whose case sparked a Canada-wide outcry of support for a National Inquiry into MMIWG2S.\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nWith the aim of helping to solve cases of missing and murdered peoples by searching the river and riverbank for remains or other evidence, DTR\u2019s families-driven work relies heavily on boats and other equipment, which are difficult to maintain.\n\nA piece of driftwood gets caught on a hook as Drag The Red launches its 2021 search for missing and murdered peoples with a new boat donated by Unifor on the Red River near the Redwood Bridge in Winnipeg on Monday. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING /Winnipeg Sun\n\n\u201cWhen we heard that the families had no choice but to drag the Red River themselves, we were moved by their determination. So, when their boat kept breaking down, we knew what we had to do,\u201d said Unifor National President Jerry Dias in a statement.\n\n\u201cFamilies are leading this campaign and we\u2019re happy to support them \u2014 either with the financial donation or with the volunteer hours the Unifor members and staff have put in during the last two years,\u201d added Unifor Indigenous Liaison Gina Smoke.\n\nUnifor represents 315,000 workers across the country including employees at the Winnipeg Sun.\n\ngdawkins@postmedia.com\n\nTwitter: @SunGlenDawkins\n\nClick here to sign up for our daily newsletter.\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nStop Buying Lottery Tickets & Start Doing This Instead!\nYukon\n|\nSponsored\nClick Here\nCops hunt for suspect after child sexually assaulted\nWinnipeg Sun\nManitoba RCMP shoot and kill man who was allegedly assaulting a woman\nWinnipeg Sun\nCasinos Hate You Doing This. {"url": "https://www.alberta.ca/red-dress-day.aspx", "title": "Red Dress Day | Alberta.ca", "body": "Skip to content\nAlberta.ca\nSearch Alberta.ca\nMenu\nHome\nReconciliation\nReconciliation events\nRed Dress Day\nPart of Reconciliation events\nRed Dress Day\n\nHonouring the memory of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nOn this page:\nOverviewHistoryEventsContactRelated\nOverview\n\nRed Dress Day honours the memories of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada. M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black helped inspire the red dress movement, where red dresses are hung from windows and trees to represent the pain and loss felt by loved ones and survivors.\n\nHistory\n\nOriginally starting as the REDdress art installation, Red Dress Day became a grassroots movement across Canada. The project was made up of 600 community-donated red dresses, which were later placed in public spaces throughout Winnipeg and across Canada.\n\nThe artist chose the colour red after speaking with an Indigenous friend who told her that is the only colour spirits can see. Red dresses are used to call the spirits of missing and murdered women and girls back to their loved ones. The goal was to speak to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Indigenous women and to evoke a presence by marking absence.\n\nEvents\nExpand all\nAthabasca\n \nCalgary\n \nCochrane\n \nEdmonton\n \nFort McMurray\n \nMedicine Hat\n \nRed Deer\nContact\n\nIf you have a 2024 event you would like to highlight, please contact us at ir.communications@gov.ab.ca.\n\nRelated\nAlberta Joint Working Group on MMIWG\nIndigenous Women\u2019s Initiatives\nIncreasing safety for Indigenous women and girls\nFamily Information Liaison Unit\nBack to\nSisters in Spirit Day\nLead ministry:\nIndigenous Relations\n\nWas this page helpful?\n\nYes No\nAlberta.ca\nFooter\nMinistries\nJobs\nContact government\nStaff directory\nAbout Links\nAbout Links\nUsing Alberta.ca\nDisclaimer\nPrivacy\nAccessibility\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nLinkedin\n\u00a9 2024 Government of Alberta\nBack to top"},
{"url": "https://www.workers.org/2024/05/78607/", "title": "Houston: No more stolen sisters \u2013 Workers World", "body": "HOME\nNEWS\nESPA\u00d1OL\nSUBSCRIBE\nJOIN US\nCLASSES\nBOOKS\nPDF\nVIDEOS\nDONATE\nHome \u00bb Women and oppressed genders \u00bb Houston: No more stolen sisters\nHouston: No more stolen sisters\n\nBy Gloria Rubac posted on May 10, 2024\n\nHouston\n\nAcross the United States and Canada, May 5 is set aside as Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\u2019s Day to commemorate and educate. Every year, individuals wear red, and attend marches, rallies, bike rides, fundraisers and more, to raise awareness of the MMIW cause and fight against the injustice happening to Native women and their families every day.\n\nWW Photo: Gloria Rubac\n\nIn Houston, the South East Texas Brown Berets held two rallies and a march through the predominantly Chicano community north of downtown to honor Native people.\n\nIndigenous activist Terry Spoonhunter drummed, prayed and sang songs to open the event. \u201cWe were the first people here. We had peace. We believed in nature, in the sun, in the water, in the air we breathe. And we protected this,\u201d he said.\n\nWillie Rodriguez, an organizer for the Berets, told the crowd: \u201cThis issue needs to be brought to life; it\u2019s hidden, like many things that happen with Native people. Our own people are out celebrating Cinco de Mayo with alcohol right now instead of coming together in solidarity with things that really matter. So I thank all of you for being here today.\u201d\n\nOne of the central organizers of this event, Beret Vio Nat, had a red handprint over her mouth and was holding a red dress. She explained: \u201cThe hand print is the symbol of this growing movement and stands for all the missing sisters whose voices are not heard, as well as the silence of the police and the news media. It is mostly non-Natives who attack and kill Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cA progressive event that recently happened was that, in 2013, the Violence Against Women Act was updated to allow Tribal courts to prosecute non-Indigenous offenders.\n\n\u201cThroughout Indian Country, throughout Tribal jurisdictions, and throughout reservations, actions are being held today. It is also called Red Dress Day.\u201d\n\nNat was holding a large color photo of a young girl and said: \u201cMaria Gonzales was murdered in her home here in Houston last August by someone in her apartment complex. We want to remember her as she was only 11 years old and was from Guatemala.\u201d\n\nSylina Mustang spoke on how important the issue of Indigenous women and girls is: \u201cWe are honoring the women, girls, and men. There\u2019s not enough media attention on this.\u201d Mustang was wearing a red T-shirt with a photo of Luis Jr. Martinez, a leader of the Chicano activist group of the 1960s and \u201870\u2019s, the Crusade for Justice, based in Denver. She told Workers World: \u201cMartinez was also a victim of murder 50 years ago. He was another person whose death wasn\u2019t given the attention it deserved.\u201d\n\nWW Photo: Gloria Rubec\n\nAlso speaking were representatives of Workers World Party and Party for Socialism and Liberation. Jesus Sanchez, with PSL, said; \u201cIsrael caused much destruction in Central America in the 1980\u2019s, especially toward Indigenous tribes such as the Mayan population in Guatemala. Along with the U.S., they trained forces in the genocide of the Mayans under the R\u00edos Montt regime.\u201d\n\nSpeaking for Workers World Party, this writer stated: \u201cLook at the photo of this beautiful 11-year-old girl from Guatemala. We must understand why she and her family were even here in Houston. It is because of U.S. imperialism destroying the economies and overthrowing the leadership of Central American countries that people are forced to leave their homes.\n\n\u201cIt is the U.S. that is responsible for little Maria\u2019s death. She and her family should never have been forced to be here.\u201d\n\nIndigenous women\nMurdered and missing women and girls\n\u2190 Previous article\nNext article \u2192\nStay connected\nGet Workers {"url": "https://panow.com/2023/05/05/in-the-news-for-may-5-a-look-at-aprils-employment-numbers/", "title": "In The News for May 5 : A look at April\u2019s employment numbers | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\nIn The News for May 5 : A look at April\u2019s employment numbers\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\nBy Canadian Press\nIn The News for May 5 : A look at April\u2019s employment numbers\nMay 5, 2023 | 2:16 AM\n\n\n\nIn The News is a roundup of stories from The Canadian Press designed to kickstart your day. Here is what\u2019s on the radar of our editors for the morning of May 5 \u2026\n\nWhat we are watching in Canada \u2026\n\nStatistics Canada is set to release its April labour force survey this morning, providing updated numbers on employment levels in the country.\u00a0\n\nRBC says it expects 12,000 jobs were added last month, the lowest number since September. \u00a0\n\nEmployers have kept their hiring appetite in recent months, even as high interest rates make borrowing more expensive for people and businesses.\u00a0\n\nThe unemployment rate continued to sit at five per cent in March, hovering near record lows.\n\nHowever, job vacancies have been falling and the Bank of Canada\u2019s recent business outlook survey shows employers reporting less intense labour shortages.\u00a0\n\nThe Bank of Canada\u2019s aggressive rate hikes are expected to filter through to the labour market in the coming months, leading to a rise in unemployment.\u00a0\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso this \u2026\n\nA United Nations initiative aimed at eliminating gender-based violence is asking Canada to put up cash to help stem a backsliding in women\u2019s rights, even though the Liberals are cutting back on foreign aid.\n\n\u201cWomen\u2019s rights and violence against women and girls is not a side issue,\u201d said Nahla Valji, the UN\u2019s senior gender adviser, a position Canada pushed to have created at the agency\u2019s headquarters in New York.\n\nValji, who grew up in Burnaby, B.C., is on Parliament Hill this week asking Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to help stop an erosion of women\u2019s rights globally.\n\nShe\u2019s following up on a letter from UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed, who asked Trudeau to help fund what\u2019s called the Spotlight Initiative.\n\nThe project launched in 2017 with the European Union pledging 500 million euros, or roughly $740 million, for projects that work to curb gender-based violence and to give women a seat at the table in post-conflict negotiations.\n\nSpotlight Initiative works in two dozen of the world\u2019s poorest countries, helping local groups launch projects that provide women with employment while weeding out violence.\n\nValji\u2019s office wouldn\u2019t share the letter, but said it \u201cinvites Canada to be a partner in scaling up the investment\u201d by the end of 2023, and said the letter didn\u2019t specify an amount.\n\nShe\u2019s leaning on the Liberals\u2019 rhetoric about putting women at the centre of their diplomatic efforts, such as through a feminist aid policy.\n\n\u201cCanada has always been a leader on the international stage, going back to Lester B. Pearson through to today, in terms of multilateralism,\u201d she said. \u201cCanada throughout history has walked the talk, in terms of the values of the (UN) charter.\u201d\n\nThe government says it\u2019s assessing the request. But at the same time, federal cutbacks have the development sector preparing to scale back programs.\u00a0\n\nThe Liberals insist a 15 per cent drop in funding for foreign aid is not actually a cut because it\u2019s higher than their pre-pandemic spending.\n\n\u2014\n\nAnd this too \u2026\n\nThe head of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada says it\u2019s clear there\u2019s an ongoing emergency nearly four years after the final report into missing and murdered Indigenous woman and girls was released.\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe are in a crisis,\u201d said Carol McBride.\u00a0\n\nRed dresses are set to be on display across the country Friday to recognize the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. It has become known as Red Dress Day and the empty garments serve as a symbol of lives that have been lost.\n\nEach year there are more events, rallies and art displays. Despite the increased awareness and an extensive national inquiry, McBride said the situation that Indigenous girls and women face has not substantially changed.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a mother. I\u2019m a sister. I\u2019m an aunt,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I\u2019m just imagining some of our families and our women are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nThe inquiry\u2019s final report was released in 2019 and included sweeping calls for change. It found Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group in Canada.\u00a0\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau accepted the findings of the inquiry, which said the crisis amounted to genocide.\n\nSixty-three per cent of Indigenous women have experienced violence and nearly half have experienced sexual assault, Statistics Canada said in a report last year.\u00a0\n\nWinnipeg has been called ground zero.\n\nAt least 28 Indigenous women in Manitoba have died due to violence since May 2020, said Sandra DeLaronde, team lead for the Manitoba MMIWG2S+ implementation team. The majority were in Winnipeg.\u00a0\n\n\u2014\n\nWhat we are watching in the U.S. \u2026\n\nPHILADELPHIA _ Three fired police officers who pleaded guilty to misdemeanour charges in the death of an eight-year-old girl killed when they opened fire outside a high school football game near Philadelphia are set to be sentenced Friday.\n\nFormer Sharon Hill officers Brian Devaney, Devon Smith and Sean Dolan have pleaded guilty to 10 counts each of reckless endangerment. Investigators say they could not determine which officer fired the shot that killed Fanta Bility on Aug. 27, 2021. The charge carries a maximum term of up to two years in prison in Pennsylvania.\n\nProsecutors contend the officers negligently fired 25 shots at a car they mistakenly thought was involved in gunfire that broke out as spectators left the football game in 2021. Devaney was not wearing a body camera, and the other two officers did not turn their cameras on, investigators found.\n\nBility had attended the game at Academy Park High School with her mother and an older sister who was also shot but survived. In all, four people were hit by police bullets that sped past the car.\n\nThe handling of the case prompted outrage and protests from the Black community and others as District Attorney Jack Stollsteimer initially charged two Black teens who engaged in gunfire a block away _ which prompted the police response _ with the child\u2019s death. Those charges were later dropped, and, after a grand jury investigation, the officers were instead charged with voluntary and involuntary manslaughter along with the endangerment counts.\n\nThe November plea agreements that dismissed those more serious charges came after consultations with the Bility family.\n\nThe family, who belong to a community of immigrants from West Africa, said it was important that the officers take responsibility for the girl\u2019s death and the trauma they experienced. They have a federal lawsuit pending against the defendants and the Sharon Hill police department.\n\nLawyers for the ex-officers, who have been free on bail, initially called her death a tragedy caused by the teens who engaged in gunfire. The lawyers did not immediately return calls seeking comment Thursday.\n\n\u2014\n\nWhat we are watching in the rest of the world \u2026\n\nBELGRADE, Serbia _ Serbian police said they have arrested a suspect in a drive-by shooting attack that killed at least eight and wounded 14, the nation\u2019s second such mass shooting in two days.\n\nIn a statement, police said that the man, identified by initials U.B., was arrested early Friday near the central Serbian town of Kragujevac, about 100 kilometres south of Belgrade.\n\nThe arrest followed an all-night search by hundreds of police, who sealed off an area south of Belgrade where the shooting took place late Thursday.\n\nThe attacker shot randomly at people in three villages near Mladenovac, some 50 kilometres south of the capital, RTS said.\n\nSerbian Interior Minister Bratislav Gasic called Thursday\u2019s drive-by shootings \u201ca terrorist act,\u201d state media reported.\n\nThe shooting came a day after a 13-year-old boy used his father\u2019s guns to kill eight fellow students and a guard at a school in Belgrade.\n\nThe bloodshed sent shockwaves through a Balkan nation scarred by wars, but unused to mass murders.\n\nThough Serbia is awash with weapons left over from the wars of the 1990s, Wednesday\u2019s school shooting was the first in the country\u2019s modern history. The last mass shooting before this week was in 2013, when a war veteran killed 13 people in a central Serbian village.\n\n\u2014\n\nOn this day in 1950 \u2026\n\nWaves caused by 80-km/h winds broke through dikes surrounding Winnipeg. The water inundated the Manitoba capital, forcing one-third of the population to leave their homes. The flooding left one person dead and caused $100 million in damage.\n\n\u2014\n\nIn entertainment \u2026\n\nThe family members of some of the men who died in a shipwreck in 1975 are mourning the death of Gordon Lightfoot.\u00a0\n\nThe legendary folk musician, who died Monday, immortalized the 29 crewmen in his famous song \u201cThe Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald.\u201d\n\nThe song was released in 1976, one year after the ship sank in Lake Superior during a storm.\n\nDeborah Champeau says when she heard the news of Lightfoot\u2019s death, it felt like finding out the ship sank again.\u00a0\n\nChampeau\u2019s father was a third assistant engineer on the vessel.\n\nLightfoot formed a relationship with many of the families over the years after he reached out to explain why he wrote the song.\u00a0\n\nLightfoot also joined families in 2015 at an event marking the 40th anniversary of the shipwreck.\n\n\u2014\n\nDid you see this?\n\nIt may have been the greatest battle between robots and humans to ever take place inside a Saskatchewan brewery.\u00a0\n\nThe grain mash was masterful and the fermentation feisty as a brewer went head to head in a taste-off with ChatGPT to find out who, or what, can make the best beer.\u00a0\n\nThe idea for the faceoff against the artificial intelligence-powered chatbot came out of a meeting between staff at 9 Mile Legacy Brewing, a Saskatoon nanobrewery known for making craft beer and pushing boundaries.\u00a0\n\nGarrett Pederson, 9 Mile\u2019s co-founder and head brewer, said they were playing around with the explosively popular chatbot earlier this year and thought it would be fun to test the technology\u2019s usefulness when it comes to one of the oldest drinks humans have produced.\n\nChatGPT, developed by U.S.-based company OpenAI, was challenged to create an \u201caward-winning\u201d gose recipe using local ingredients. A gose is typically a sour and salty beer with origins in Germany.\n\nUnsurprisingly, it made a Saskatoon berry gose.\n\nPederson came up with his own recipe for a rhubarb ginger sour. He used the tried and true methods of researching old brew records and recipes, talking with other brewers and looking online.\u00a0\n\nThe two beers were put in front of customers for a blind taste test, and while Team Human put in a good fight, it was ultimately Team Robot that took the win with 60 per cent of the votes\n\nPederson says it was a fun experiment, but he doesn\u2019t expect to see the artificial intelligence taking over any time soon.\u00a0\n\nThere had to be a lot of help from human brewers to make it drinkable.\u00a0\n\n\u2014\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published May 5, 2023.\n\nThe Canadian Press\n\nby Canadian Press\nAround the Web\nAlberta Residents Born Before 1984 With No Life Insurance Can Get a $250,000\nDollarGuardian\nEveryone From Edmonton: if You Have Wrinkles, Do This Before Bed!\nNeotonics\nRemember Tiger Woods' Ex-wife? {"url": "http://www.communitypress.ca/2017/05/27/red-dresses-a-reminder-of-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women", "title": "Red dresses a reminder of missing and murdered Indigenous women | The Community Press", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nBusiness Ads\nJobs\nShopping\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNews\nRed dresses a reminder of missing and murdered Indigenous women\nAuthor of the article:\nThe Belleville Intelligencer\nPublished May 27, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 27, 2017 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nArticle content\n\nSince Sunday more than a dozen red dresses have been waving in the wind and rain as they hung from trees surrounding St. Thomas' Anglican Church.\n\n\u201cRed is the colour of passion, the colour of love, and the colour of violence,\u201d stated Bill Tomlinson, a member of the church's Primate's World Relief and Development Fund (PWRDF) committee.\n\n\u201cThey wave there as a memorial to well over a thousand missing and murdered Canadian Aboriginal women,\u201d explained Tomlinson. \u201cBut more than a memorial, they wave there as a tribute to the passion, spirit, strength, creative energy and resilience of First Nations women, in spite of all they have endured, and continue to endure, over the years.\u201d\n\nThe dresses were inspired by the REDress Project, an art installation created and launched by Metis artist Jaime Black in 2011.\n\n\u201cIt is an installation art project based on an aesthetic response to this critical national issue,\u201d states Black's artistic statement on his website, http://www.redressproject.org/, adding the project is a \u201cvisual reminder of the staggering number of women who are no longer with us. Through the installation I hope to draw attention to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Aboriginal women and to evoke a presence through the marking of absence.\u201d\n\nAt St. Thomas', the hanging of the dresses was accompanied by a Sunday-morning presentation by Jennifer Davis, a parishioner who has worked extensively in the north and west with various First Nations. Davis was invited to address the congregation by the local committee of the national Anglican Primate's World Relief and Development Fund.\n\n\u201cImpressed again and again by the women she worked with, it was their strength of character in the face of sometimes difficult circumstances and systemic racism that she chose to focus her remarks on,\u201d said Tomlinson. \u201cIn doing so, she and Dorothy Flindall, her fellow presenter, introduced the congregation to nurses, social workers, academics, educators and others \u2013 all of whom had surmounted the various obstacles that often confront Indigenous people to build successful lives and careers, very often careers devoted to helping others surmount the same obstacles.\u201d\n\nWith the launching of a long-demanded national inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, Tomlinson said he hopes it's conclusions will be insightful and helpful, and that the government will be able to act on them.\n\n\u201cBut in the meantime, red dresses wave in the wind and the rain.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 2\nADVERTISEMENT\nArticle content\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR STIRLING\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

Red Dress Day began as a grassroots action in 2017, a year after Ottawa launched its National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, and it has spread across Canada and the United States. Due to the pandemic, public events were toned down this year and last, with Jacobs saying local Can-Am centre staff held morning prayers and smudging, but socially distanced.\n\n\u201cWe think of all the people out there somewhere,\u201d said Jacobs. \u201cTheir families don\u2019t have answers, their loved ones are just not there, and they can\u2019t bring their spirits home so they can rest.\u201d\n\nIn a news release, the local Can-Am Indian Friendship Centre stated: \u201cNative families, advocates and Indigenous Nations continue to rise up to challenge the silence, tolerance and limited action in response to the crisis of (murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls).\u201d\n\nThe Ontario NDP used the occasion to criticize the lack of significant progress in implementing the inquiry\u2019s recommendations for action to end the continued \u201cepidemic of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\u201d\n\ndschmidt@postmedia.com\n\ntwitter.com/schmidtcity\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nHeart Surgeon Shares 3 Min Routine For Daily Bowel Movements\nGundry MD\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nToo hot \u2014 Windsor Hudson's Bay shuts down over failed air conditioning\nWindsor Star\nWindsor police arrest two in drug bust\nWindsor Star\nRoofers Tested 17 Gutter Guards\u2026 Here\u2019s What They Discovered\nThe Actual Cost of Gutter Guards in 2024 May Surprise You\nLeafFilter Partner\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nOne Teaspoon Every Night Burns Body Fat Like Never Before, You Will Fit In Your Pants Again!\nBurn Belly Fat\n|\nSponsored\nBetter than scratching, why you should try this\nDaily Pulse\n|\nSponsored\nAlberta Pensioners Are Eligible For Invisible Hearing Aids\nBest Hearing Aids\n|\nSponsored\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\n\nPostmedia is committed to maintaining a lively but civil forum for discussion. And there\u2019s no sign as to where they\u2019ve vanished too, or if they\u2019ll ever be back.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nBut hope remains, embodied in the red dress.\n\n\u201cIn lots of tribes, it (the colour red) represents the only colour spirits can see in our culture,\u201d says Elickus. \u201cSo, you know, it hopes to call them home, the ones that are still missing.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s where the Red Dress Project comes in.\n\nIt\u2019s a project that was first launched back in 2010. And, for over a decade now, it keeps growing.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nEleven years later, red dresses continue to be hung from tree branches all over Canada, including right here on the island, in an effort to raise awareness.\n\nHowever, according to Campbell River\u2019s Elickus, many still don\u2019t know the story behind the red dress.\n\n\u201cI mean, I hear people saying, what\u2019s that red dress doing hanging there,\u201d she says. \u201cWhat\u2019s it to signify?\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s the question that sparked Elickus to get out there, lead the charge for the Red Dress Project in Campbell River, and hang more red dresses.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nIt\u2019s also very personal. She\u00a0lost her sister-in-law back in 1992, as well as her close friend, and her niece.\n\n\u201cSo it\u2019s really close to me,\u201d she says. \u201cIt\u2019s really dear to me.\u201d\n\nElickus is\u00a0now asking you to keep the significance in mind, and she\u2019s hoping it will spark something within yourself as well with the issue still ongoing.\n\nA \u2018National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\u2019 report from June 2019 found that there was no \u201creliable estimate of the numbers of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA persons in Canada.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s still happening,\u201d Elickus says.\n\n\u201cThe real sad thing is, the cases that are reported don\u2019t go down as missing people, and then families aren\u2019t strong enough to fight or speak for themselves.\u201d\n\nElickus believes it\u2019s important to speak up for people and have a strong voice. She says voices are in numbers and that we must come together.\n\n\u201cAnd then, of course, if there are people like me getting the message out as to why it\u2019s hanging out there, and you see lots of them, it brings awareness quickly,\u201d she says.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s for people. It\u2019s for the people of our nation, and it reaches out and touches so many different people across the country. It\u2019s for everyone, but for us, it\u2019s very dear.\u201d\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nElickus says the project doesn\u2019t just revolve around women and girls though, it now extends to missing and murdered indigenous men and boys this year as well.\n\nIt\u2019s an ongoing project, so there\u2019s no end date.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ll stay up,\u201d Elickus says. \u201cSome I\u2019ve seen in the past, they\u2019ve been there for years. But, you know, some communities and some people just hang them outside their houses and along the roads or in their communities.\u201d\n\nIf you hang a red piece of clothing outside, Elickus wants you to take a photo and send it to her.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\n\u201cI started an\u00a0album on my Facebook\u00a0called the \u2018Red Dress Challenge Project,\u2019 and I encourage people to hang up red. Red t-shirts, red dresses, any red if they can,\u201d she adds.\n\n- Advertisement -\nFacebookTwitterReddItWhatsAppEmail\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisment -\n- Advertisement -\nContinue Reading\nAll\nNational\nLifeLabs sold to American diagnostic firm, pledges to protect Canadian patient data\nCowichan Valley\nCVRD wraps up years long project to remove invasive plants from Memory Island\nCowichan Valley\nLadysmith RCMP seeking witnesses of July 2nd collision\nIsland & Coast\n10 earthquakes in 24 hours recorded off Island\u2019s West Coast\nLoad more\nYOU MAY ALSO LIKE\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\nIN THE NEWS\n\nLifeLabs sold to American diagnostic firm, pledges to protect Canadian patient data\n \nCVRD wraps up years long project to remove invasive plants from Memory Island\n \nLadysmith RCMP seeking witnesses of July 2nd collision\n \n10 earthquakes in 24 hours recorded off Island\u2019s West Coast\n \nWarmer temperatures expected for Vancouver Island this week\nNew website looks to protect tenants from bad faith evictions\n \nNew urgent primary care centre on the way for Duncan\n \nRegulations for BC hunters updated for next 2 years\n \nNew act to give workers international credit recognition in BC\n \nRCMP, Cowichan SAR on the lookout for missing man in Youbou\n\t\nSUN FM\n\nSunScribers\n \nTour de Rock\n \nMornings with Jason Hatton\n \nMiddays with Nicholas\n \nAfternoons with Justis Doucet\nHawaii of the North\n \nIn Search of Albacore\n \n5 Stunning Lighthouses To See In BC\n \nExploring the BC Bird Trail \u2013 Near You\n \nHealth and Happiness in Your Own Backyard\nNews\nWin\nEvents\nContact Us\nContest Rules\nAdvertise\nWe\u2019re Hiring"},

{"url": "https://bc.ctvnews.ca/rally-planned-in-vancouver-to-mark-national-day-of-awareness-for-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-and-girls-1.5889777", "title": "Red Dress Day rally held outside Vancouver City Hall | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nVANCOUVER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nVANCOUVER\nNews\n'My heart is with the families': Ceremonies held in Vancouver, Langley for Red Dress Day\n02:07\nSombre memorials for missing Indigenous women\n01:52\nRed Dress Day marked at Vancouver City Hall\nAlissa Thibault\nUpdated May 5, 2022 8:03 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2022 7:46 a.m. MDT\nShare\n\nRed dresses were hung in the rain outside Vancouver City Hall Thursday in a somber memorial for missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.\n\nThe Pacific Association of First Nations Women set up tents for speeches, prayers and songs, joined by Mayor Kennedy Stewart and Coun. Jean Swanson. Gul-Giit-Jaad of St\u2019langng Jaanas/Laanas clan in Haida Gwaii was among those who helped hang the dresses in the trees.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m wearing red in memory of my mother and my three sisters who were murdered in the Downtown Eastside,\u201d she said. \u201c(Hanging the dresses) was very profound for us because when you\u2019re hanging them it\u2019s just reflecting again, and my heart is with the families all across Canada.\u201d\n\nCeremonies were held across the country to mark the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, also known as Red Dress Day.\n\nRELATED STORIES\n'We're losing so many of them' Red Dress Day sparks conversation about missing and murdered Indigenous women\n'Our way of healing': Red Ribbon Skirt Project creates solidarity through sewing campaign\n'Shameful and disgraceful milestone': Response to MMIWG report from Vancouver\nPremier promises action after release of missing Indigenous women inquiry report\n\nAnother tent outside Vancouver City Hall was dedicated to young Indigenous woman Shaylanna Brown, who went missing from Haida Gwaii two years ago, at just 24 years old. Her aunt, Sylvia Williams, wore a T-shirt saying \u201cBring Shaylanna Home.\u201d\n\n\u201cEach days it\u2019s a hard day going through knowing a loved one is missing,\u201d Williams said. \u201cWe keep our hopes up and keep praying that they get home safely \u2013 that each and every Indigenous woman be found.\u201d\n\nDozens also marched through the rain in Langley as part of a ceremony organized by the Lower Fraser Valley Aboriginal Society.\n\nRed Dress Day is commemorated annually on May 5, which grew out of the REDress Project, created by M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black in 2010.\u00a0\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nA red dress is hung from a tree as people attend a Red Dress Day ceremony marking the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirited people in Canada, in Vancouver, B.C., on May 5, 2022. {"url": "https://panow.com/2021/04/07/b-c-and-federal-governments-promise-unbroken-cell-service-on-highway-of-tears/", "title": "B.C. and federal governments promise unbroken cell service on \u2018Highway of Tears\u2019 | paNOW", "body": " SECTIONS\nNEWS\nSPORTS\nSOFTBALL WORLD CUP\nWEATHER\nCLASSIFIEDS\nOBITUARIES\nSign up for our free daily newsletter\nBy Canadian Press\nB.C. and federal governments promise unbroken cell service on \u2018Highway of Tears\u2019\nApr 7, 2021 | 1:11 PM\n\n\n\nThe federal and British Columbia governments say seamless cellular coverage will be provided along the Highway of Tears by October 2022.\n\nSeventy per cent of Highway 16 already has some coverage, but Lisa Beare, B.C.\u2019s minister of citizens\u2019 services, says the $11.7-million project will bring cell service to the remaining 252 kilometres between Smithers and Prince Rupert.\n\nThe project is set to begin this spring and will add 12 cell towers as well as improve connectivity at three rest stops, with the province and Ottawa each contributing just over $2 million and Rogers Communications picking up the remainder of the bill.\n\nHighway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert became known as the Highway of Tears more than two decades ago, a reference to the many Indigenous women who have gone missing or been murdered along the route since the 1970s.\n\nIn a separate announcement, the B.C. government says nearly $5 million in cell service upgrades is coming to Highway 14 on Vancouver Island between Sooke and Port Renfrew, with work expected to be complete by late October.\n\nThe Highway 14 improvements will bring cell service to Port Renfrew, Shirley, Otter Point, Jordan River and some Pacheedaht First Nation communities.\n\nMaryam Monsef, the federal minister for women and gender equality and rural economic development, says the Highway 16 upgrade marks a milestone for Aboriginal communities.\n\nShe told an online news conference it is the first universal broadband cell project being funded that will \u201cprimarily benefit Indigenous communities, but it will not be the last.\u201d\u00a0\n\nBoth Beare and Monsef said better cell service makes everyone safer.\u00a0\n\n\u201cKnowing that people will be able to travel Highway 16 without worrying about gaps in coverage is exactly the kind of result we want to see on every community highway and in every rural and Indigenous community,\u201d Beare said.\n\nThe Highway of Tears Symposium Report made 33 recommendations in 2006, including solving the problem of cellular gaps between the handful of communities along the 725-kilometre corridor.\n\nRCMP files link a total of 18 murders or disappearances to the region, but Carrier Sekani Family Services in Prince George says on its website that the number likely exceeds 40.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published April 7, 2021.\n\nCompanies in this story: (TSX:RCI.B)\n\nThe {"url": "https://www.northernnews.ca:443/news/using-red-dress-day-to-send-an-important-message", "title": "Using Red Dress Day to send an important message | Northern News", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nShopping\nJobs\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNewsLocal News\nUsing Red Dress Day to send an important message\n\nMore than 100 people gathered at the Indigenous Friendship centre to using Red Dress Day to send an important message.\n\nAuthor of the article:\nGreg Estabrooks\nPublished May 05, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated May 05, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nA waterfront ceremony to end Red Dress Day on Friday. The day is utilized to bring awareness to the cause of violence against Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People. PHOTO BY GREG ESTABROOKS\nArticle content\n\nRed Dress Day is one of awareness for a national crisis, one that by many accounts is not improving.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOn May 5th, North Bay was the scene of dozens walking from the Indigenous Friendship Centre to the waterfront.\u00a0\n\nIt is to mark the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit People.\u00a0 It is also known as Red Dress Day.\u00a0\n\nIndigenous women, girls and 2SLGTQ1A+ peoples are subject to violence and abuse, resulting in a crisis of missing and murdered peoples.\u00a0 There has already been a National Inquiry into the risis of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nLinda Pope is a member of the Indigenous Friendship Centre as well as an Indigenous cultural educator.\n\n\u201cThe issue of missing and murdered women means a lot to me,\u201d says Pope.\u00a0 \u201cI\u2019m not just walking for the women; I am walking for the men and the children because I believe they are a part of it,\u201d says Pope. \u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nShe sees them as victims too, \u201cVery much so, they need support too.\u00a0 It touches my heart, and I am very proud to be here and going on this walk,\u201d says Pope.\n\nNipissing First Nation Chief Scott McLeod marched on Friday.\u00a0 McLeod says this issue goes back centuries and finally is being recognized by the Canadian government.\u00a0\n\n\u201cIt is really important to realize this has been cultivated over a century,\u201d says McLeod.\u00a0 \u201cThe Indian Act, which was drawn up in the 1870s,\u00a0 was engineered to eliminate Indigenous people.\u00a0 They (the government) knew that Indigenous women were the centre of our communities, they were the centre of our culture, they were sacred, they were revered for being life givers,\u201d says the NFN Chief.\u00a0\n\nMcLeod says the policy led to Indigenous women being denigrated.\u00a0\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cWhat the Indian Act did was start to devalue our women,\u201d says McLeod.\u00a0 \u201cIt came to a point where it is ingrained in this country that there is no value of Indigenous women.\u00a0 In our communities we are struggling to rebuild and lift our Indigenous women in our communities to where they rightfully belong,\u201d says McLeod.\u00a0\n\nThe Nipissing First Nation Chief says the result is one of apathy in the non-Indigenous community.\n\n\n\u201cThe colonial process and what they have done to Indigenous women that created an environment where people look the other way on this stuff,\u201d says McLeod.\n\nAliyah Diamond-Gunner was one of the younger women walking on Red Dress Day.\u00a0 Why did she walk?\n\n\u201cBringing awareness for \u2018Stolen Sisters \u2018, girls, Two-Spirit individuals. Showing that we are still here and that we matter,\u201d stated Diamond-Gunner.\n\nShe added that to some they do not matter as much as their white counterparts.\u00a0\n\nThe walk ended with a ceremony at North Bay\u2019s Waterfront Friday afternoon.\u00a0\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR KIRKLAND LAKE\nTHIS WEEK IN FLYERS"},

{"url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/5/5/crisis-calls-grow-to-stem-violence-against-indigenous-women", "title": "\u2018Crisis\u2019: Calls grow to stem violence against Indigenous women | women\n\nAdvocates demand urgent action on day commemorating missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in US and Canada.\n\nA red dress to symbolise missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls is seen during a march in Vancouver, Canada, last year [File: Amy Romer/Reuters]\nBy\u00a0Al Jazeera Staff\nPublished On 5 May 2023\n5 May 2023\n\nSave articles to read later and create your own reading list.\n\nCalls are once again ringing out in Canada and the United States for action to stop violence against Indigenous women and girls, a persistent problem that has devastated communities across North America for decades.\n\nFriday marks Missing or Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day in the US, while it is the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), otherwise known as Red Dress Day, in Canada.\n\nKEEP READING\nlist of 3 items\nlist 1 of 3\nSnatched away: The Indigenous women taken on the Highway of Tears\nlist 2 of 3\nCanada to Indigenous women: \u2018Our systems have failed you\u2019\nlist 3 of 3\nHope for \u2018healing\u2019 as pope joins Indigenous Lac Ste Anne pilgrims\nend of list\n\n\u201cOn Missing or Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day, we remember the many lives shattered or lost, and commit to working with Native communities to find justice, keep families safe, and help them heal,\u201d US President Joe Biden said in a statement.\n\n\u201cIndian Country has been gripped by an epidemic of missing or murdered Indigenous people, whose cases far too often go unsolved,\u201d he said, describing the issue as a \u201ccrisis\u201d.\n\n\u201cWe need to respond with urgency and the resources needed to stop the violence and reverse the legacy of inequity and neglect that often drives it.\u201d\n\nWomen hold up red dresses to raise awareness of the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women, in Montreal, Canada, October 3, 2020 [File: Christinne Muschi/Reuters]\n\nIndigenous people have sounded the alarm for years about the disproportionately high number of women, girls and two-spirit people who have been killed or disappeared in the US and Canada. Two-spirit is a term used by some Indigenous people to describe their gender and spiritual identity.\n\nAdvocates also have denounced systemic inaction on the part of government and law enforcement agencies to address the issue.\n\nIn Canada, the federal police force reported in 2014 that nearly 1,200 Indigenous women had been murdered or gone missing in Canada between 1980 and 2012 \u2013 but community members have said the real number was likely much higher.\n\nA National Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls concluded in 2019 that the violence \u201camounts to a race-based genocide of Indigenous Peoples\u201d that especially targets women, girls and members of the LGBTQ2S+ community.\n\nOn Friday, a group of Canadian ministers expressed support for all those affected by the violence.\n\nSign up for Al Jazeera\nAmericas Coverage Newsletter\nUS politics, Canada\u2019s multiculturalism, South America\u2019s geopolitical rise\u2014we bring you the stories that matter.\nSubscribe\nPlease check your email to confirm your subscription\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy\nprotected by reCAPTCHA\n\n\u201cWe are committed to working in partnership with Indigenous families, survivors, leaders, and partners, as well as with provinces and territories, to make transformational change that will end this national crisis,\u201d they said in a joint statement.\n\nBut in the lead-up to the day of commemoration, Indigenous leaders said Canada had not done enough to address the decades-long crisis.\n\nCanadian legislators unanimously passed a motion in the House of Commons on Tuesday urging Prime Minister Justin Trudeau\u2019s government to declare a national emergency. The motion also called\u00a0on Ottawa to set up a \u201cRed Dress Alert\u201d system to notify the public when an Indigenous woman, girl or two-spirit person goes missing.\n\n\u201cThis is a crisis. People are going murdered and missing every day,\u201d Canadian parliament member Leah Gazan, who spearheaded the motion, said during a news conference on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cWe are precious, we are valuable, we are loved and we are not garbage,\u201d Gazan said.\n\nHilda Anderson-Pyrz, member of the Nisichawayasihk Cree Nation and chair of the National Family and Survivors Circle, added that \u201cevery day is a fight for survival\u201d for Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people in Canada.\n\n\u201cWe are exhausted from fighting systemic and structural racism that is killing us,\u201d Anderson-Pyrz said during the news conference.\n\n\u201cCanada has a responsibility to support immediate, sustained and impactful action. In 2019, Prime Minister Trudeau stated that the government accepts that the murders and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls across Canada in recent decades amount to an act of genocide.\n\n\u201cIt is now four years later and the crisis continues, not to be met with the urgency, commitment and the prioritisation required.\u201d\n\nSOURCE: AL JAZEERA\nTop Stories\nREAD MORE\nRussian-born US citizen\nsentenced to over 12 years in prison\nAdvertisement\nAbout\nAbout Us\nCode of Ethics\nTerms and Conditions\nEU/EEA Regulatory Notice\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nCookie Preferences\nSitemap\nWork for us\nConnect\nContact Us\nUser Accounts Help\nAdvertise with us\nApps\nNewsletters\nChannel Finder\nTV Schedule\nPodcasts\nSubmit a Tip\nOur Channels\nAl Jazeera Arabic\nAl Jazeera English\nAl Jazeera Investigative Unit\nAl Jazeera Mubasher\nAl Jazeera Documentary\nAl Jazeera Balkans\nAJ+\nOur Network\nAl Jazeera Centre for Studies\nAl Jazeera Media Institute\nLearn Arabic\nAl Jazeera Centre for Public Liberties & Human Rights\nAl Jazeera Forum\nAl Jazeera Hotel Partners\n\nFollow Al Jazeera English:\n\n\u00a9 2024 Al Jazeera Media Network\nYou rely on Al Jazeera for truth and transparency\nWe use cookies and other tracking technologies to deliver and personalize content and ads, enable features, measure site performance, and enable social media sharing.
