Earlier in the day, a community walk saw participants march from the organization\u2019s office on Frederick Street to Kitchener City Hall.\n\nAt the University of Waterloo campus, 20 red dresses were hung in the trees.\n\nA vigil is held to mark Red Dress Day in Kitchener on May 5, 2022. (Terry Kelly/CTV Kitchener)\n\nRELATED STORIES\nQueen Victoria statue in Kitchener doused in red paint\n\nA 2019 national inquiry into MMIWG, found Indigenous women and girls were 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other women in Canada.\n\n\"This is our way to say we are here, we are not giving up, we are not readly to silence our voices, we are humans as well, and we deserve the same respect as everyone else,\" said organizer Amanda Trites.\n\nMyeengun Henry, former chief of the Chippewas of the Thames First Nation said he knows several women who have disappeared.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s probably every Indigenous family knows someone who was affect by this,\u201d Henry, who is also an Indigenous Knowledge Keeper at University of Waterloo, said.\n\nA vigil is held to mark Red Dress Day in Kitchener on May 5, 2022. (Terry Kelly/CTV Kitchener)\n\nHenry said when he was living in Windsor, a woman from the community was found beaten to death by the river.\n\n\u201cAt that time, still there was no investigation, at least deep enough to find somebody who did it,\u201d Henry said. \u201cAnd it just kind of become normal to us that whenever these things happened, we never found an answer to them. So we walk through life feeling that something was unfilled.\u201d\n\nHe said more needs to be done to keep Indigenous women and girls safe.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nA vigil is held to mark Red Dress Day in Kitchener on May 5, 2022. {"url": "https://www.vogue.com/article/vancouver-indigenous-fashion-week-red-dress-showcase", "title": "At Vancouver Indigenous Fashion Week, Red Dresses Carried a Powerful Message | Vogue", "body": "Skip to main content\nSUBSCRIBE\nSIGN IN\nSEARCH\nFASHION\nBEAUTY\nCULTURE\nLIVING\nWEDDINGS\nRUNWAY\nSHOPPING\nVIDEO\nVOGUE CLUB\nVOGUE WORLD\n\u200e The August issue is here featuring Jill Biden.\nSUBSCRIBE\nFASHION\nAt Vancouver Indigenous Fashion Week, Red Dresses Carried a Powerful Message\nBY CHRISTIAN ALLAIRE\nPHOTOGRAPHY BY ALANA PATERSON\nNovember 22, 2023\nPhoto: Getty Images\n\nSince 2017, the annual Vancouver Indigenous Fashion Week (VIFW) has served as a crucial platform for Indigenous designers to showcase their contemporary designs. More than just an array of fabulous fashions (though it is that, too), VIFW is a space that\u2019s created for Indigenous people by Indigenous people. Founder Joleen Mitton, who is Plains Cree, established it as an event that fosters community, collaboration, and even healing. A prime example of the latter is VIFW\u2019s annual Red Dress showcase, which was held on Monday night as this year\u2019s official kick-off event. \u201cThe Red Dress event is part of our healing process,\u201d Mitton tells Vogue. \u201cAt the opening night of every VIFW, we come together as a community and we honor our departed loved ones. We come together to remember and celebrate.\u201d\n\nVIFW\u2019s Red Dress showcase draws inspiration from M\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress Project, a national art movement in Canada that utilizes red dresses to represent the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and Two-Spirit (MMIWG2S) people in the country. Indigenous groups in Canada continue to be disproportionately affected by violence; From 2015 to 2020, the average homicide rate involving Indigenous victims was six times higher than non-Indigenous victims. At Vancouver\u2019s Queen Elizabeth Theatre, Native designers were asked to create red designs that drew attention to this ongoing epidemic. \u201cThe red dress has become a powerful symbol of remembrance and a call for justice,\u201d says Mitton. \u201cRecognizing and addressing this issue is crucial for the well-being and safety of the community.\u201d\n\nThe arresting color red boldly calls attention to the important movement, though it also has spiritual significance (in Indigenous culture, red transcends the physical world). \u201cRed represents the fire of our people\u2014a flame that can never be extinguished, no matter how hard it gets,\u201d says Yolonda Skelton, a Gitxsan designer who created a gown made of precious metals and suede. She also incorporated imagery of a phoenix onto her design. \u201cThe phoenix itself is a symbol of rebirth, resilience, and transformation. It represents the strength and resilience of Indigenous women, girls and [Two-Spirit people], and their ability to rise above adversity.\u201d\n\nA model wears a look by Helen Oro. Photographed by Alana Paterson\n\nSkelton was one of six Indigenous designers who created a special dress for this year\u2019s VIFW. Designer Rebecca Baker-Grenier (Kwakiutl/Dzawada\u02bcenuxw/Squamish) crafted a cape coat with her signature West Coast paintwork on it. It stems from her We Are Warriors collection. \u201cMy collection is inspired by our ancestral warriors, who were strong, courageous, and persistent in protecting our villages, communities, and culture in battle against colonial armies,\u201d she says. \u201cIndigenous people have always fought to resist colonization and safeguard our communities.\u201d Inuit designer April Allen also created a red shift dress, shown with traditional matching moccasins. \u201cMy design serves as a symbol of remembrance and solidarity, weaving together the significance of this movement in every stitch,\u201d says Allen.\u00a0\n\nOcean Kiana, who is Ojibway/Anishinaabe, created several red looks for the showcase, including pieces such as traditional ribbon skirts. \u201cI didn\u2019t limit myself to a single dress\u2014instead, each piece narrates distinct stories from my life, interwoven with the profound connection we have to the land,\u201d says Kiana. \u201cThe significance of the color red represents my identity as Nishinaabe (Ojibway), because it is the color that we use in ceremonies to present the Manidoo (spirit). [I also used] beautiful floral patterns, inspired from my traditional territory, Biigtigong Nishnaabeg.\u201d\n\nDancers backstage in traditional regalia before opening the Red Dress showcase. Photographed by Alana Paterson\n\nFor two of the designers featured in the showcase\u2014Helen Oro (Plains Cree) and Taalrumiq (Inuvialuit/Gwich\u2019in)\u2014the theme of the evening hit especially close to home. Both have been personally affected by the epidemic, and wanted to use their fashions as a call to action. \u201cIt was important for me to share the story of Frank Gruben, my relative who is currently missing in our home territory of the Northwest Territories since May 2023,\u201d says Taalrumiq, who created a traditional Inuvialuit design made of sealskin and wolf fur. \u201cI hope by sharing Frank\u2019s story, it encourages someone to come forward with information that can help bring him home to his mom, family, and community.\u201d\n\nDesigner Oro shares an equally poignant backstory around one of the red garments she created (her lineup of looks were entirely in red). \u201cMy 11-year old nephew and I collaborated on designing a dress,\u201d says Oro, who created all of the beaded jewelry to go with her nephew\u2019s design. \u201cHis mother, who was my little sister, was murdered about six months ago: Our collaboration together is in honor of her. His mom\u2019s name was Kehiew Iskwew Fox, and part of the material he chose to use represents her name. This has been a healing process for the both of us.\u201d\n\nIndividually, each Indigenous designer brought a sense of strength and resiliency to the showcase, and Mitton says this variety of perspectives and styles is exactly what fashion needs. \u201cShowcasing diversity in the Red Dress Event sends a powerful message about unity and solidarity,\u201d says Mitton. \u201cIt emphasizes that the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous people is a collective concern that transcends individual backgrounds.\u201d The VIFW founder hopes to make the Red Dress show an annual tradition. It\u2019s now in its fourth year running, and has no plans of stopping until the epidemic is addressed. \u201cI hope that the Red Dress movement continues to raise awareness and push for the justice that is so desperately needed,\u201d says Mitton. \u201cFashion has a unique and powerful ability to convey messages, tell stories, and evoke emotions.\u201d\n\nThe crowd at the Red Dress showcase.\nPhotographed by Alana Paterson\nDancers backstage before opening the Red Dress showcase. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nDressers backstage make adjustments on a model wearing a red look by Helen Oro. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nThe crowd at the Red Dress showcase.\nPhotographed by Alana Paterson\nDancers line up on stage before the opening the Red Dress showcase. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nPatrick Shannon, co-founder of Supernaturals Modelling agency, model Alicia Hanton, and VIFW founder Joleen Mitton backstage. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nA model wears a look by Yolonda Skelton. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nA model wears look by Ocean Kiana. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nA model walks the runway in a look by Taalrumiq. Photographed by Alana Paterson\nJoleen Mitton greets a model as they step off the runway.\nPhotographed by Alana Paterson\nChristian Allaire is the Senior Fashion and Style Writer at Vogue, where he covers celebrity style, red carpet fashion, trends, emerging designers, and more. Rights News | Al Jazeera", "body": "Advertisement\nSkip links\nSkip to Content\nNavigation menu\nNews\nShow more news sections\nIsrael War on Gaza\nFeatures\nOpinion\nSport\nVideo\nMore\nShow more sections\nLIVE\nClick here to search\nSign up\nNews\n|\nIndigenous Rights\nUS, Canada commemorate missing and murdered Indigenous women\n\nIndigenous women and girls face disproportionate rates of violence in both countries and advocates say action is needed.\n\nRed dresses symbolise Indigenous women that have gone missing or been murdered in Canada and the US over the past decades [File: Amy Romer/Reuters]\nBy\u00a0Al Jazeera Staff\nPublished On 5 May 2022\n5 May 2022\n\nSave articles to read later and create your own reading list.\n\nIndigenous rights advocates in Canada and the United States have renewed longstanding calls for concrete action to stem disproportionate rates of violence against Indigenous women and girls in both countries.\n\nThursday marks Missing and Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day in the US, while it is the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), otherwise known as Red Dress Day, in Canada.\n\nKEEP READING\nlist of 3 items\nlist 1 of 3\n\u2018Hunted\u2019: How Indigenous women are disappearing in Canada\nlist 2 of 3\nVancouver rallies for missing, murdered Indigenous women\nlist 3 of 3\nA warrior for Indigenous women and girls\nend of list\n\n\u201cThe Federal Government has an obligation to ensure that cases of missing or murdered persons are met with swift and effective action,\u201d US President Joe Biden said in a proclamation recognising the day.\n\n\u201cMy Administration is fully committed to investigating and resolving these cases through a coordinated law enforcement response, as well as intervention and prevention efforts. We are also dedicated to researching the underlying causes of this violence and to working with Native communities to address them,\u201d Biden said.\n\nIndigenous communities have sounded the alarm for years over the disproportionately high number of women, girls and two-spirit people who have been killed or disappeared in the US and Canada. Two-spirit is a term used by some Indigenous people to describe their gender and spiritual identity.\n\nAdvocates also have denounced systemic inaction on the part of government and law enforcement agencies to address the issue.\n\nIn 2014, the federal Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) reported that nearly 1,200 Indigenous women had been murdered or gone missing in Canada between 1980 and 2012 \u2013 but advocates say the real number was likely much higher.\n\nA National Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in 2019 concluded that the violence \u201camounts to a race-based genocide of Indigenous Peoples\u201d that especially targets women, girls and members of the LGBTQ2S+ community.\n\n\u201cThis genocide has been empowered by colonial structures \u2026 leading directly to the current increased rates of violence, death, and suicide in Indigenous populations,\u201d it said.\n\nBut Indigenous community advocates say too little has been done to address the problem.\n\nSign up for Al Jazeera\nAmericas Coverage Newsletter\nUS politics, Canada\u2019s multiculturalism, South America\u2019s geopolitical rise\u2014we bring you the stories that matter.\nSubscribe\nPlease check your email to confirm your subscription\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy\nprotected by reCAPTCHA\n\n\u201cAlmost three years after the National Inquiry into #MMIWG released their Final Report, we are still waiting on the concrete actions that must be taken outlined in the Calls for Justice,\u201d Lynne Groulx, CEO of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC), said on Twitter on Thursday.\n\nIn the US, the National Crime Information Center in 2016 documented 5,712 reports of missing American Indian and Alaska Native women and girls, according to a report by the Urban Indian Health Institute (PDF).\n\n\u201cThe Center[s] for Disease Control and Prevention has reported that murder is the third-leading cause of death among American Indian and Alaska Native women and that rates of violence on reservations can be up to ten times higher than the national average,\u201d the report also said.\n\nA 2016 study by the National Institute of Justice also found that 84.3 percent of American Indian and Alaska Native women have experienced violence in their lifetime, including 56.1 percent who have experienced sexual violence, the US Department of the Interior says on its website.\n\nUS interior secretary Deb Haaland, the first Indigenous person to head a cabinet agency in the history of the country, held an event on Thursday to recognise National Missing or Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day.\n\n\u201cEveryone deserves to feel safe in their community, but a lack of urgency, transparency and coordination have hampered our country\u2019s efforts to combat violence against American Indians and Alaska Natives,\u201d Haaland, a member of the Laguna Pueblo tribe, said in a statement.\n\n\u201cAs we work with the Department of Justice to prioritize the missing and murdered Indigenous people\u2019s crisis, the Not Invisible Act Commission will help address the underlying roots of the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Peoples crisis by ensuring the voices of those impacted by violence against Native people are included in our quest to implement solutions.\u201d\n\nThe US Congress signed the Not Invisible Act into law in October 2020, just months before Biden took office, and the commission aims to increase coordination and implement best practices to fight \u201cthe epidemic of missing persons, murder, and trafficking\u201d affecting Indigenous communities.\n\nIn Canada, communities are hanging red dresses on Thursday to symbolise the many Indigenous women and girls who have gone missing or been murdered in the past decades.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m wearing red on #RedDressDay to remember all the #MMIWG and to honour their families and communities. I\u2019m wearing red also because I continue to hold a vision of the future where our women and girls are protected and treated with dignity and respect always,\u201d RoseAnne Archibald, national chief of the Assembly of First Nations in Canada, tweeted.\n\n\u201cOn May 5, we will see the red dresses suspended from trees, hanging from windows, swaying in the breeze. But we will see much more than that. We will see the people who would have worn those crimson garments,\u201d Lorraine Whitman, president of NWAC, said in a statement this week.\n\n\u201cThey were our mothers, our daughters, our sisters, our aunties, our friends \u2026 We want to know what happened. How were they taken from us? And why? But mostly, we want to know that other families will be spared this pain.\u201d\n\nSOURCE: AL JAZEERA\nTop Stories\nREAD MORE\nIsrael approves three\nsettlement outposts, thousands of homes in West Bank\nAdvertisement\nAbout\nAbout Us\nCode of Ethics\nTerms and Conditions\nEU/EEA Regulatory Notice\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nCookie Preferences\nSitemap\nWork for us\nConnect\nContact Us\nUser Accounts Help\nAdvertise with us\nApps\nNewsletters\nChannel Finder\nTV Schedule\nPodcasts\nSubmit a Tip\nOur Channels\nAl Jazeera Arabic\nAl Jazeera English\nAl Jazeera Investigative Unit\nAl Jazeera Mubasher\nAl Jazeera Documentary\nAl Jazeera Balkans\nAJ+\nOur Network\nAl Jazeera Centre for Studies\nAl Jazeera Media Institute\nLearn Arabic\nAl Jazeera Centre for Public Liberties & Human Rights\nAl Jazeera Forum\nAl Jazeera Hotel Partners\n\nFollow Al Jazeera English:\n\n\u00a9 2024 Al Jazeera Media Network\nYou rely on Al Jazeera for truth and transparency\nWe use cookies and other tracking technologies to deliver and personalize content and ads, enable features, measure site performance, and enable social media sharing. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/via-rail-in-talks-to-offer-5-fares-to-at-risk-groups-along-b-c-highway-of-tears-1.2326712", "title": "Via Rail in talks to offer $5 fares to 'at risk' groups along B.C. 'highway of tears' - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nVia Rail in talks to offer $5 fares to 'at risk' groups along B.C. 'highway of tears'\nVANCOUVER - Via Rail has joined discussions with the British Columbia government, First Nations and social service agencies to offer rock-bottom fares to \"vulnerable\" people who can't afford to travel along the so-called Highway of Tears.\nCamille Bains,The Canadian Press\nAug 19, 2016 11:14 AM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nVia Rail website\n\nVANCOUVER - Via Rail has joined discussions with the British Columbia government, First Nations and social service agencies to offer rock-bottom fares to \"vulnerable\" people who can't afford to travel along the so-called Highway of Tears.\n\nThe railway is collaborating with mayors and multiple groups to determine the criteria for $5 fares along a northern B.C. corridor where 18 girls and women have been murdered or have disappeared since the 1970s.\n\nIn June, following a decade of pleas from women's groups and First Nations, B.C. Transportation Minister Todd Stone announced that bus service would begin in the area by the end of the year.\n\nChief Joseph Bevan of the Kitselas First Nation near Terrace said he's part of an advisory group concerned about the safety of people along the 750-kilometre route and that it came together for regular meetings last November after months of discussions.\n\nHe said it's common for people to take a risk and hitchhike in the notorious area because they're too poor to take the train or a Greyhound bus.\n\n\"It's non-aboriginals as well. It's everyone who is on social assistance, people with disabilities, who are having trouble moving around. It makes them vulnerable when they're jumping into a vehicle with somebody else.\"\n\nBevan said that at a meeting in March, a Via Rail official made the proposal to offer a $5 fare along the highway that stretches between Prince Rupert and Prince George.\n\nMichael Woelcke, the railway's general manager for remote services, said in minutes of the meeting held in Prince George on March 30 that the company would offer the low fare \"regardless of origin or destination along the route.\"\n\nHe said Via Rail provides train service three times a week between Prince Rupert and Prince George, and it's open to suggestions on determining eligibility for the $5 fare that would be available to \"at risk\" and \"vulnerable\" people including youth and \"elders.\"\n\n\"We need to identify who would qualify for this program, as we cannot provide everyone with these reduced fares,\" he said in the minutes.\n\nWoelcke said a minimum $75 one-way fare would be reduced by a third for aboriginal passengers.\n\nWoelcke was not available for comment, and the company said an official would provide details if and when an arrangement is worked out with the province.\n\nVia Rail said in an emailed statement that a discounted fare for \"vulnerable\" people is one of the options being studied and that discussions with the Transportation Ministry and the advisory group are ongoing.\n\nThe ministry said interconnectivity of services along Highway 16 has been part of discussions and that Via Rail was included to determine what role it could play to increase transportation options.\n\n\"We continue to engage with Via Rail on the idea of offering a discounted train fare to vulnerable First Nations people,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe group is slated to meet again next month.\n\nAs for the promised new bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert, the ministry said the first of more than 20 public information sessions hosted by BC Transit will start Saturday.\n\nBC Transit said Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada, which is part of the advisory group, has provided $1 million in funding for features including enhanced bus stop shelters and CCTV cameras to ensure passengers' safety along the corridor.\n\nThe route provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nMost of the cases of murdered and missing women remain unsolved, but police have said it's believed that more than one killer is involved.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://vancouverisland.ctvnews.ca/symbolic-red-dresses-being-rehung-in-ladysmith-after-men-filmed-taking-them-down-1.5391102", "title": "Symbolic red dresses being rehung in Ladysmith after men filmed taking them down | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFollow on\n\n  \n\nAdvertisement\n\nVANCOUVER ISLAND | News\nSymbolic red dresses being rehung in Ladysmith after men filmed taking them down\nAndrew Garland\nCTV Vancouver Island\n\n\nPublished Friday, April 16, 2021 4:47PM PDT\nRed dresses to be rehung on Vancouver Island\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nCommunity members will rehang symbolic red dresses that were taken down from an island highway in recognition of missing Indigenous women.\nSymbolic dresses removed from island highway\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nTwo men were filmed removing red dresses from a Vancouver Island highway that were intended to symbolize missing Indigenous women: (April 15, 2021)\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nNANAIMO -- The Ladysmith community, along with residents from across Vancouver Island, are coming together in support of the Lil' Red Dress Project after two men were caught on camera taking several dresses down.\n\nShawn Magnus of Sidney took the day off work and drove to Ladysmith on Friday morning to hang red dresses in the same location that the others were taken down.\n\n\u201cIt hit me like a ton of bricks,\u201d says Magnus when he saw the video. \u201cWhat they did was abhorrent and it is wrong and (this is) something that I could do to try and correct it.\u201d\n\nRelated Stories\nCaught on cam: Men remove red dresses symbolizing missing Indigenous women from island highway\n'We deserve the right to feel safe': Dozens march in Abbotsford for missing, murdered Indigenous women\n\nThe red dresses have become a symbol in raising awareness of missing murdered Indigenous women and girls (MMIWG) and can be seen along highways up and down Vancouver Island.\n\nOn Saturday morning, the Stz\u2019uminus First Nation & Council and the Town of Ladysmith will be getting together to hang new red dresses in the same location.\n\n\u201cWe want to educate and make sure everyone knows what those dresses really mean and how we can move forward in a good way,\u201d says Chief Roxanne Harris, Stz\u2019uminus First Nation.\n\nThey are also asking people to donate and drop off red dresses at Ladysmith City Hall, located at 12 Roberts St.\n\nThe dresses will then be hung along the stretch of highway starting at Coronation Mall in south Ladysmith going north to the Husky Gas Station, which is Stz\u2019uminus First Nation territory.\n\nThey hope to paint the highway with red dresses before May 5, which is Red Dress Day, a national day of awareness towards MMIWG.\n\nAccording to the Lil' Red Dress Project website, the awareness campaign was started after Indigenous people noticed that missing persons signs and billboards were being set up on island highways for a non-Indigenous person. Activists believe that many Indigenous people cannot afford to rent high-profile spaces, like billboards, to highlight missing persons, so red dresses are used to draw attention to all MMIWG.\u00a0\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n\nVancouver Islanders will be rehanging red dresses along Highway 1 in recognition of missing murdered Indigenous women and girls: (CTV News)\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport {"url": "https://gazette.mun.ca/campus-and-community/violence-no-more/", "title": "Violence no more", "body": "Go to page content\nToggle navigation\n EVENTS SUBSCRIBE ARCHIVES\nViolence no more\nEvent to address inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women\nCampus and Community\n\nAug. 8, 2016\n\nBY JANET HARRON\n\nA Violence No More: Justice for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women public panel will be held at Memorial\u2019s Bruneau Centre for Research and Innovation on the St. John\u2019s campus on Saturday, Aug.13.\n\nCo-hosted by Memorial\u2019s Department of Gender Studies, the St. John\u2019s Native Friendship Centre, and the Toronto-based No More Silence network, the event coincides with the upcoming national inquiry by the federal government into missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\nA video recording of the public panel will be available on the gender studies department\u00a0and St. John\u2019s Native Friendship Centre websites and will be steamed live from the event\u2019s Facebook page.\n\nPublic event\n\nA free public event from 6-9:30 p.m. in IIC-2001 will be preceded by a closed workshop where participants from across the country\u2014activists, academics, family members\u2014will strategize about how to hold the government accountable throughout the inquiry process.\n\n\u201cWhile the Trudeau government has engaged diverse publics in their inquiry design process, none of the 18 pre-inquiry meetings were in Newfoundland and Labrador and the few local and regional inquiries into the issue have been of limited scope or lacked meaningful participation of the most affected\u2014Indigenous women, families, communities and nations,\u201d said Dr. Carol-Lynne D\u2019Arcangelis, assistant professor, Department of Gender Studies, Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences, and a co-organizer of the event.\n\nDr. Carol-Lynne D\u2019Arcangelis\n\n\u201cIt is imperative that these voices shape the contours and implementation of the inquiry at all geographical and political levels.\u201d\n\nEvent agenda\n\nSpecific objectives of the Aug. 13 event are to raise the profile of the issue of murdered and missing Indigenous women in Newfoundland and Labrador; strengthen and broaden a national network of activists, scholars, family members, and community groups; combine participants\u2019 insights into a document for public distribution, including to inquiry commissioners; and create a collaborative space to bridge academy/community divides, and devise strategies to hold the government accountable to Indigenous women, families, communities and nations throughout the inquiry process.\n\n\u201cThis forum presents an opportunity to compile information about the specifics of the issue in this province, based on the perspectives of the Inuit, Innu, and Mi\u2019kmaq nations.\u201d\n\u2013Dr. Carol-Lynn D\u2019Arcangelis\n\n\u201cThis forum presents an opportunity to compile information about the specifics of the issue in this province, based on the perspectives of the Inuit, Innu, and Mi\u2019kmaq nations,\u201d said Dr. D\u2019Arcangelis. \u201cSuch advances are only possible when Indigenous peoples have direct influence on academic work.\u201d\n\nEnding violence\n\nThe Violence No More Newfoundland Forum builds on a series of annual events held in Toronto, Ont., since 2013, organized by No More Silence, Families of Sisters in Spirit and the Native Youth Sexual Health Network. In concert with similar groups across the country, these organizations have worked intensely to end violence against Indigenous women in Canada\u2014and specifically to raise awareness about the disproportionate numbers of missing and murdered Indigenous women across Canada.\n\nDr. Alex Wilson will participate in the panel.\n\nNotably, since 2014, a representative from the St. John\u2019s Native Friendship Centre has participated in these annual events. This year, thanks to the collaboration of the centre and Memorial University, the event in St. John\u2019s will realize No More Silence\u2019s vision of strengthening the national network.\n\nSt. John\u2019s emerged as an ideal site for the event, says Amelia Reimer, cultural support worker, St. John\u2019s Native Friendship Centre.\n\n\u201cSome Mi\u2019kmaq elders consider Newfoundland to be \u2018ground zero\u2019 for colonialism. Even the Mayflower stopped here for supplies before continuing on to Plymouth Rock.\u201d\n\nThe event is made possible with funding and support from the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC Connection Grants); Memorial University Conference Fund; and the Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences Conference Fund.\n\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nShare\n\nJanet Harron is a communications advisor with the Harris Centre. She can be reached at jharron@mun.ca.\n\nTopics\nCampus and CommunityFaculty of Humanities and Social SciencesGender StudiesPublic EngagementSocial Justice and Human Rights\n\nTo receive news from Memorial in your inbox, subscribe to Gazette Now.\n\nCampus and Community\nPublic Engagement\nResearch\nStudent Life\nTeaching and Learning\nSpecial Features\nLatest News\n\nJuly 2, 2024\n\nMemorial representation\n\nTwo Memorial youth part of historic Memorial Day events\n\nJune 28, 2024\n\nNew beginnings\n\nDr. Ashlee Cunsolo leaving a stronger Labrador Campus and community\n\nJune 28, 2024\n\nTeeth, Tentacles and Tales\n\nCreating connection through curiosity\n\nJune 27, 2024\n\nForget me not\n\nPhotos: a visual journey to the past to mark Memorial Day\n\nJune 26, 2024\n\nModelling masters\n\nThe math behind pandemics and public health policies\n\nJune 25, 2024\n\nA Coast Lines conversation\n\nQ&A with Coast Lines featured author Perry Chafe\n\nFOLLOW US\n   \nABOUT THE GAZETTE\nARCHIVE\nCONTACT\nMARKETING & COMMUNICATIONS\nMEDIA RELEASES"},

Click here for schedule\n\nLOCAL NEWS\nStudent art installation honours Red Dress Day\nWritten by Kash Knight Sunday, May 05 2024, 12:30 PM\nShare:\nCopied!\nStudent Kiera Manjo standing next to her artwork on the windows of SCCHS (photo by Kash Knight).\n\nVisual Art 30 students at the Swift Current Comprehensive High School have used their skills to share an important message throughout the school. \u00a0\n\nThis year\u2019s theme for Red Dress Day is Stories, not Statistics, bringing awareness to the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two Spirit People (MMIWG2S). \u00a0\n\nTeacher Mandy Herrick was proud of how her class absorbed and responded to her idea when she brought it forward and has since been watching them take the initiative and run with it. \u00a0\n\n\u201cThey were so attentive to it and really receptive to the information,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I was surprised by how much they knew about certain areas, and how much they were just willing to learn. \u00a0\n\n\u201cWe brainstormed a bunch of ideas ... and the next day they brought ideas way better than mine. They just blew me away. I was so excited for them to be passionate about it.\u201d\u00a0\n\nHailey Dyck and\u00a0Ma Ayisha Ron Plazo with their collaborative piece.\n\nStudents Hailey Dyck and Ma Ayisha Ron Plazo collaborated on a portrait of a woman, constructed of the names of MMIWG2S.\u00a0\n\n\"[We] didn't want to do statistics, because it dehumanizes them,\" said Ron Plazo. \"So if we did names, it shows that\u00a0there's an actual life behind all those numbers.\"\n\nThe youngest name the pair found belonged to a nine-month-old girl who had been kidnapped and remains missing.\n\nCassie Jewitt and Ryen Bauman stand on either side of their painting.\n\nAfter three days of work, Cassie Jewitt and Ryen Bauman's painting was finished and hung on the walls of the SCCHS hallways.\n\n\"We wanted to do a piece that showed what was\u00a0missing ... there's a handprint over her mouth to\u00a0show the silence,\" explained Bauman. \"I do feel like there's not enough like being spoken about what's going on.\"\n\nShae Wentworth proudly stands with her window art.\n\nThree women are portrayed staring ahead into darkness to show the feeling of being lost,\u00a0in Shae Wentworth's window art. The high schooler used pops of red to stir feelings of sorrow, while also representing blood.\n\n\"I'm Indigenous ... it was a little hard for me,\" Wentworth shared about creating art on the topic of MMIWG2S. \"I've heard stories, and it's scary for me. It leaves me vulnerable.\"\u00a0\n\nSharing the same window as Wentworth's piece\u00a0is the vibrant red handprint done by Kiera Manjo (pictured on the cover of the article).\u00a0\n\nManjo found inspiration for her piece from another artist's similar work. She chose to paint it for it's simplicity and power.\u00a0\n\n\"People notice the handprint, obviously, but then it takes a moment to find the face in it, and I think that goes to show how when you actually do take the time to learn about it and look at it, you see how it impacts people,\" Manjo said. \"I think it's\u00a0really important to show this representation and help people become more aware of it so we can all be doing what we can.\"\n\nNEXT STORY\nCelebrate Mom and win!\nLATEST IN LOCAL NEWS\nEmergency Preparedness Week begins in Swift Current\nWhat to do this weekend in Swift Current\nWood River Search and Rescue give Swift Current a heads up for tonight\nMinister for Health reacts to SEIU-West protest\nLATEST STORIES ON SWIFTCURRENTONLINE\nFamily, friends, and community walk to bring Byron Watson home\nRCMP actively working to mitigate fraud in Swift Current\nMoose Jaw RCMP investigating human remains located in the RM of Moose Jaw\nSwift Current adorns itself in red in honour of Indigenous woman and girls\nEvents\nSwift Current 57\u2019s Baseball Club Home Game\nThu, Jul 4, 7:00 PM\nPride Centre Grand Reopening!\nSat, Jul 6, 9:00 AM\nCountry Pleasures TEAHOUSE\nSat, Jul 6, 1:38 PM\nSwift Current 57\u2019s Baseball Club Home Game\nSat, Jul 6, 7:00 PM\nSaskatchewan Motocross Round 4 Located in Swift Current.\nSun, Jul 7, 9:15 AM\nView more \nJobs\nPowered by\nLumber Yard Office Manager\nFull-time, Salary, Administrative, Retail, Sales\nFeatured\nTruck or Combine Operator\nHourly, Seasonal, Agriculture, Labour\nHeavy Duty Mechanic Apprentice\nFull-time, Skilled Trades\nFarm Labourer - {"url": "https://www.comoxvalleyrecord.com/news/indigenous-members-share-their-stories-during-comox-valleys-red-dress-day-7354059", "title": "Indigenous members share their stories during Comox Valley\u2019s Red Dress Day - Comox Valley Record", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.1 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nIndigenous members share their stories during Comox Valley\u2019s Red Dress Day\nThe day also serves as a reminder to end violence against Indigenous and gender-diverse people\nOlivier Laurin\nMay 5, 2024 5:52 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 9 A red dress hangs at Simms Park Sunday (May 5) at the Red Dress Day ceremonies. (Olivier Laurin / Comox Valley Record)\nExpand\nListen to this article\n00:04:43\n\nDespite the rain, Verna Wallace slowly walked up the stage at Simms Park to share her story in front of a quiet and attentive crowd on Sunday (May 5).\n\n\u201cMy sister has been missing since 1971,\u201d said Wallace. \u201cI was away from home and I got a letter telling me that she had been missing\u2026 I would sleep on my patio every night hoping I would hear her calling me. I did that for six months.\n\n\u201cMy sister was pregnant when she was murdered\u2026 that really broke my heart. I love and miss (her) so much. My mom and dad are gone, so I think they are together now. I think they are gathering up there and I hope they\u2019re looking down on us. (Today) we\u2019re walking with our missing and murdered sisters and Two Spirit people.\u201d\n\nWallace was one of three survivors who addressed a large audience as a part of Red Dress Day, held in Courtenay\u2019s Simms Park, which takes place every year on May 5 to raise awareness of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people (MMIWG2S).\n\nOrganized by two local Indigenous organizations \u2013 MIKI\u2019SIW M\u00e9tis Association and the Indigenous Women\u2019s Sharing Society \u2013 the event included educational tables, a drumming circle, an opening ceremony at 1 p.m. and a walk at 2 p.m.\n\nCeremony at the K\u2019\u00f3moks First Nation\n\nEarlier in the day, K\u2019\u00f3moks First Nation elder Donna Mitchell extended an invitation to community members, encouraging them to share their stories.\n\n\u201cEverybody knows somebody who was (murdered or gone) missing,\u201d Mitchell said. \u201cNobody learns about what has happened (and) there\u2019s so much prejudice in our community.\n\n\u201cI want us to come together as one\u2026 I (want) more people to come out to share their stories.\u201d\n\nAt 11 a.m. on 3320 Comox Rd., a small group of people gathered and sat in a circle to partake in ceremonial dance and songs, share personal experiences and connect with other members.\n\nIn the crowd were sisters Melanie Hardy and Violet Williams, who said they found Mitchell\u2019s event to be deeply cathartic.\n\n\u201cWe come here to honour several family members. Most important to us is our mother, Abina (Angela Williams), who we lost when we were very young,\u201d Hardy said. \u201cShe was murdered when I was three years old and the case was not taken seriously. Here we are, 23 years later with no answers. Her case is still unsolved.\n\n\u201cWe were told many excuses, (one of them being) that she was gone on vacation, (but) she had three little girls at home waiting for her, and we\u2019re still waiting.\u201d\n\nBelieving in the importance of spreading awareness of the crisis of Indigenous MMIWG2S is paramount to moving things forward in a good direction, believes Hardy.\n\n\u201cFor many years I was really nervous to come out and share this trauma, but I\u2019ve become a mother in the last few years and it\u2019s really opened up how important it is to spread awareness,\u201d she said. \u201cWhat if it was my daughter who was going through this?\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day\n\nThe red dress movement was inspired by Metis artist James Black\u2019s REDress Project, which has come to symbolize loss, grief and injustice over the murder and ongoing violence against MMIWG2S.\n\nThe day also serves as a reminder in communities across the country to end violence against Indigenous and gender-diverse people.\n\n\u201cThe red dress has become a symbol of loss for those who have been taken too soon, and a call to end violence,\u201d said Kelli Paddon, B.C.\u2019s parliamentary secretary for gender equity in a statement.\n\n\u201cFrom 2009 to 2021, 490 Indigenous women and girls were victims of homicide in Canada. In this time frame, the rate of homicide of First Nations, M\u00e9tis and Inuit women and girls was six times higher than the rate among their non-Indigenous counterparts. In Canada, Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to be murdered or missing than any other women.\u201d\n\nIf you or someone you know is experiencing signs of distress, don\u2019t hesitate to reach out to services available 24/7/365:\n\nHope for Wellness Help Line (Indigenous centred): 1-855-242-3310\n\nCrisis Services Canada: (Canada-wide) 9-8-8\n\nNational Family and Survivors Circle: 1-844-413-6649\n\n- With files from Erin Haluschak\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tRobots, technology take care in Comox's innovative new dementia village\n\t\tComox Valley Ducky 500 winners announced\n\t\tCVRD, Clean BC to offer heat pump and electrical upgrade rebates\n\t\tComox Valley RCMP investigating fatal overnight collision involving pedestrian\n\t\t'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\nFacebook Comments (0) \nComox Valley RCMP investigating fatal overnight collision involving pedestrian\nBlack Press Media\nDriver airlifted to hospital after Vancouver Island crash\nBlack Press Media\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nReview: Captain Cooks Casino is the Real Deal\nCaptain Cooks Casino\n|\nSponsored\nPlay Now\nPeople Born 1944-1984 Could Get This Benefit\nSeniors Choice\n|\nSponsored\nRead More\nPort Coquitlam convicted murderer dead in Greater Victoria institution\nBlack Press Media\nCougar bites woman in Vancouver Island's Strathcona Park\nBlack Press Media\nStudent Discovers Genius Device to Wipe Out Mosquitoes Instantly!\nTop Review Picks\n|\nSponsored\nCanadians In Alberta With No Life Insurance Are Taking Advantage Of This\nCovered For Life\n|\nSponsored\nLearn More\nCanadians Born 1944 - {"url": "https://www.reddeeradvocate.com/local-news/niece-recounts-search-for-her-aunt-at-rdp-red-dress-day-7352693", "title": "Niece recounts search for her aunt at RDP Red Dress Day - Red Deer Advocate", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nJobs\nObituaries\n20.0 \u00b0C\nHome Local News\nNiece recounts search for her aunt at RDP Red Dress Day\nRed Deer Polytechnic hosts activities to bring awareness\n\tSusan Zielinski\n\nMay 2, 2024 5:12 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nViolet Soosay spoke about efforts to find her missing aunt during a presentation at Red Dress Day events held at Red Deer Polytechnic on May 2, 2024. Susan Zielinski\nListen to this article\n00:03:10\n\nIt took about 40 years for Violet Soosay to find her missing and murdered aunt.\n\n\"I grew old looking for my aunt,\" said Violet who spoke during a\u00a0Red Dress Day event held at Red Deer Polytechnic on Thursday.\n\n\"It was many years of not knowing. It kind of tears you apart bit by bit by bit.\"\n\nBut in 2021, the Kern County\u00a0sheriff\u2019s office in California identified the remains of a Jane Doe as belonging to her aunt, Shirley Ann Soosay, 35, who\u00a0had been buried in a cemetery in 1980.\n\nShe was\u00a0stabbed 26 times, and her\u00a0body was discovered dumped in\u00a0an orchard.\u00a0\n\nViolet said American investigators went out of their way to identify her aunt and that's why she was found. But in Canada, initiatives stemming from the\u00a0Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women inquiry are not providing\u00a0the assistance that families need to search and find their missing loved ones.\n\nShe said a fund is needed, which is one of the 231 Calls to Action in the MMIW report,\u00a0to pay the costs associated with searching.\n\n\"That's the one I've been paying attention to, to set up a funding agency of some kind to help these people who have missing family members.\"\n\nViolet and another aunt spent years searching in British Columbia and Seattle where her Aunt Shirley had\u00a0visited before cards and letters she regularly sent to her family suddenly stopped in 1979.\u00a0\n\nShe said in the beginning when they reached out to police they were told more than once, \"She's probably just another dead Indian.\"\n\n\"I learned early not to depend on anyone outside the family.\"\n\nShe said whenever they could pull together enough money for gas, meals and hotel they would continue the search. Some years, they didn't have the money. At one point in the mid-90s detectives were hired, but the\u00a0money ran out.\u00a0\n\n\"Because we're not rich it was\u00a0really hard. Investigations take a lot of time and money.\"\n\nThe justice system has also not been\u00a0listening, not paying attention, not helping, because they don't have the resources, she said.\u00a0\n\n\"And even if they did, remember we're not prioritized. We're Indigenous and that is the hard core reality.\u00a0I don't gloss over anything. I speak my truth and that is my truth.\n\n\"I don't mean to offend anybody. I don't mean to discourage anybody. But I only have to share from my own experience.\"\n\nThe missing are not being found, and more Indigenous people continue to go missing, she said.\u00a0\n\n\"Just in my community, there are 42 people who are missing, both men and women, from a community of about 15,000,\" said Violet about just the cases that she knew about in Maskwacis.\n\nTwo more Red Dress Day ceremonies will be held in Red Deer on May 5.\u00a0\n\nWe Walk to Remember All MMIP event begins at 8 a.m. at the Common Ground Garden Project, 5581 45 St. Participants will walk\u00a0to join\u00a0the event in City Hall Park which begins at noon.\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\u2014 with files from The Canadian Press\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Susan Zielinski\n\nSusan has been with the Red Deer Advocate since 2001. {"url": "http://www.tv-eh.com/tag/red-dress-campaign/", "title": "Red Dress Campaign | TV, eh?", "body": "Search\nSKIP TO CONTENT\nHOME\nABOUT\nCALENDARS\nCONTACT\nPODCAST\nSPONSORS\nADVERTISING\nTAG ARCHIVES: RED DRESS CAMPAIGN\nFEATURED, REALITY, LIFESTYLE & DOCUMENTARY\nWORKING IT OUT TOGETHER: DECOLONIZATION DANCE\nAUGUST 24, 2016 CAROLYN POTTS\n\nSeason 3\u00c2\u00a0ends on a high note featuring dance, and its ability to heal. Host Waneek Horn-Miller sums up the significance of dance: \u201cDance has always been an integral part of our ceremonies and traditions. It expresses our prayers, and our mythology, it celebrates our victories, and is a way to heal.\u201d\n\nHowever, colonization nearly destroyed dance. Policy forced dance underground, yet it survived and is seeing a resurgence across the land. Briana Olson, Manager, iHuman Youth Society, explains, \u201cOur ceremonies were related, and central, and fully immersed in how we raised our children, how we engaged in trade, and through our language was how we were directly connected with how we viewed our land.\u201d But to the colonizers, dance was viewed as a threat to the values they held. Thus the settlers created policy to ensure language, ceremonies and sacred dances were all banned. This form of colonization has facilitated\u00c2\u00a0 the culture of shame that, for many Indigenous people, has become a way of being.\n\nKaren J. Pheasant, Cultural Knowledge Keeper, also speaks to the tradition and importance of dance in Indigenous culture: \u201cWe always gave first and foremost recognition to the powers that be, that brought these to us and we gave them with ceremony which was song, which was offerings, and celebrate the good life. What enabled us to do that was through our dance.\u201d\n\nJames Jones, is a self described fusion dancer who, following a career altering knee injury, combined hip-hop with traditional dance styles. James, the official dancer with the popular band A Tribe Called Red, describes dancing as \u201cfood for the spirit.\u201d When not touring, he has\u00c2\u00a0 been leading youth workshops, sharing his own experiences with multi-generational trauma and how that journey has affected his life. James was able to overcome personal tragedy and in so doing claims he was healed by the power of Hoop Dancing.\n\nOne interesting final note with respect to this episode: in the segment about James\u2019 life in gangs on the streets of Edmonton,\u00c2\u00a0 there are a series of shots edited in, but never directly addressed. We see images from the Red Dress Campaign. This campaign was designed to draw attention to the plight of the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls across Canada.\n\nYou can read more about James Jones here at WIOT Zine.\n\nOverall, this season has\u00c2\u00a0 been incredibly instructive. Each episode, each facet explored, demonstrates how pervasive colonization has penetrated the lives of Indigenous people. If you are a student or a teacher wanting to understand colonization, particularly in light of the recent TRC Report and its Calls to Action, or if perhaps you are looking to add more content to your Social Studies units I HIGHLY recommend watching this season in its entirety. When viewed together, you get a real sense of the over arcing scope government and policy have played in the lives of Indigenous people in Canada. Additionally, there is a wealth of resources that could easily be adapted for classroom activities, located in the link listed above.\n\nA TRIBE CALLED REDCOLONIZATIONEDUCATIONHIPHOPHOOP {"url": "https://whitecourtpress.com/remembering-those-lost-standing-up-for-needed-action-and-coming-together-as-one-people/", "title": "Remembering those lost, standing up for needed action, and coming together as one people |", "body": "Thursday, July 04, 2024\nStay Connected\nYour voice matters\nwctpress@telus.net\nYour Local Newspaper\nValerie Winger - Owner\nHOME\nNEWS\nLocal News\nPress Digital\nJOBS\nOther\nPRINT ADS\nCONTACT US\nPAPER PDF\nRemembering those lost, standing up for needed action, and coming together as one people\nShare\n\nOn Friday, May 5, the Whitecourt Indigenous Friends Society held its first annual National Day of Awareness & Action for MMIWG2S walk at Festival Park (previously named Rotary Park). MMIWG2S stands for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirited Peoples.\n\nFaye Myshyniuk, president of the Whitecourt Indigenous Friends Society, said the board had recently met and discussed holding more events. \u201cWe were talking about different events that happen throughout the year. We decided to put together a calendar of all the different Indigenous events that go on because sometimes we forget them.\u201d\n\nAt the recent meeting, someone said they should hold a walk for MMIWG2S. With little time to plan, the group felt it was more important to do the walk and that they could amp up the community\u2019s involvement next year. \u201cWe want to put the awareness out there. It\u2019s a crucial topic that many people don\u2019t know about,\u201d said Myshyniuk.\n\n\u201cWe want to make sure that people know what it stands for. We just want to honour and remember the missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirited people. It\u2019s an epidemic. It really is.\u201d Those in attendance were asked to wear red, the movement\u2019s signature colour, which is led by a vibrant red dress.\n\n\u201cI really wanted to get red dress pins, but there wasn\u2019t any time for that so we can do that next year,\u201d added Myshyniuk. \u201cOur goal is to be out, where the public can see us and help raise awareness and education of all things related to Indigenous Peoples. That\u2019s why we want to create the calendar. There are quite a few days to remember, like Indigenous Peoples Day, Red Dress Day, Orange Shirt Day, and then there\u2019s another day in October for Indigenous Sisters. We have to remember all of these different days.\u201d\n\nIn 2014, the RCMP acknowledged in a report that more than 1,200 Indigenous women were missing or murdered between 1980 and 2012. However, different Indigenous groups say the number is much higher, closer to 4,000. Underreported violence against Indigenous women and girls is one reason for the disagreement.\n\nThe Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC) has sounded the alarm over figures from Statistics Canada that show Indigenous women are dealing with higher rates of violence. Records from 2004 show that Indigenous women fifteen years of age and older were 3.5 times more likely to experience violence than non-Indigenous women. In 2019, Statistics Canada showed that almost one in ten Indigenous women were victims of violence and that from 2015-2020, homicides with Indigenous victims were six times higher than non-Indigenous people.\n\nAn inquiry into the MMIWG was released in 2019. Over 2,300 people participated in the truth-gathering process, and 231 calls to justice were recommended. Fifteen community hearings occurred from September 2016 to 2019, and 1484 family members and survivors shared their gut-wrenching testimonies.\n\nHighway 16 in BC, near Prince George, is called the Highway of Tears by many. The 724 km stretch of the Yellowhead highway has been the site of many Indigenous victims. Twenty-three First Nations border the highway and the lack of public transportation results in high rates of hitchhiking. Human Rights Watch, a non-governmental organization focused on advocacy and research on human rights issues, said BC had the highest rate in Canada of unsolved murders of Indigenous women and girls.\n\nIn September last year, a monument was erected on Highway 16 called \u201cJourney of Hope.\u201d The memorial is of a red dress with an Indigenous dancer silhouetted in front of it. It stands atop a pole, visible to all who drive by. The monument was initiated by the Prince George\u2019s Red Dress Society.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an epidemic. There have been calls to action for so many years about this, and now people are listening. Before, those calls to action were largely ignored. Finally, in 2016, when they did the National Inquiry into this, it made it very clear that Canada has a problem and that Indigenous people are paying for it,\u201d said Myshyniuk.\n\nShe added that spreading awareness, just like the monument on the Highway of Tears, is a massive part of the conversation. \u201cIt leads along the path to truth and reconciliation. My biggest thing is that we can all be together as one nation and work together towards a better future for all mankind. None of this segregation and stuff like that. I think it\u2019s important for us to all work together as one.\u201d\n\nAround forty people took part in the walk, which ran the perimeter of Festival Park Pond. \u201cIt\u2019s a day of mourning, honouring, and taking action to end the violence, which is so important to me. Not only for the Indigenous women and the atrocities being largely ignored for all these years, but it also has much to do with domestic violence. That\u2019s one thing that I am very set against. This fits right in with that. I\u2019m really happy that several ladies from Wellspring will be joining us.\u201d\n\nMyshyniuk said she hopes that people who don\u2019t know about the issue will look into it and learn more about it. \u201cYou owe it to yourselves, and you owe it to these victims to educate yourselves and learn more about it. They didn\u2019t just die for no reason. I think it\u2019s important to honour and remember them.\u201d Myshyniuk, on behalf of the Whitecourt Friendship Society board, thanks everyone for participating. \u201cIt means a lot to all of us in society. It shows support, and that is so important.\u201d\n\nYou must be logged in to post a comment Login\n\nNEWS JOBS PRINT ADS\nCONTACT US PAPER PDF RSS\n\nLog in- Posts - Add New - Powered by WordPress - Designed Valerie Winger"},

{"url": "https://www.standard-freeholder.com/news/local-news/streets-to-be-lined-with-red-dresses-this-weekend-to-remember-the-missing/wcm/d3e1a54c-051b-450f-b2e0-360fef99b220", "title": "Hanging red dresses in Cornwall to remember missing Indigenous people | Cornwall Standard-Freeholder", "body": "Skip to Content\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nEntertainment\nLife\nOpinion\nAll Newspapers\nBusiness Ads\nJobs\nShopping\nDriving\nHealthing\nPuzzmo\nNewsletters\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nLocal News\nStreets to be lined with red clothing this weekend to remember the missing\nAuthor of the article:\nAlan S. Hale\nPublished May 02, 2019 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 Last updated 5\u00a0years ago \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 2 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nHandout Not For Resale PHOTO BY ALAN S. HALE /Supplied\nArticle content\n\nRed dresses and shirts will be hung along Water Street and Montreal Road on Saturday in anticipation of a march being organized by Akwesasne Wellness Centre for Sunday afternoon to raise awareness of missing and murdered Indigenous people.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nFamily and friends of the missing people will be standing along the road starting from 12:30 p.m. on Sunday before gathering at the aquatic centre at 1:15 to march from there to the Port Theatre, where there will be a singing of \u201cSacRED songs\u201d starting at 2 p.m. All parts of the event are open to anyone who wishes to show solidarity with the missing by putting on some red clothing and coming out to participate.\n\n\u201cThere will be women (and men) from our community with their faces painted with a hand across their mouth and a red bandana \u2013 also made of paint \u2013 across the eyes. That signifies silence no more,\u201d explained Jaimee Square, one of the organizers. \u201cSo as people drive by they will see all these bystanders wearing red and a few with their faces painted.\u201d\n\nEastern Ontario Midday Roundup\n\nYour weekday digest of the top stories from our newsrooms in Cornwall, Brockville, Kingston and Belleville.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe phenomenon of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls has been an ongoing national tragedy for decades and has prompted multiple public inquiries on provincial and federal levels. According to the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, 67 per of the hundreds of disappearances have been murders, while 20 per cent are disappearances where the missing are never heard from again.\n\nVigils and ceremonies to remember the missing are held regularly in many communities across the country, particularly in areas with large Indigenous populations. But this will be the first such event to be organized in Cornwall by the wellness centre.\n\n\u201cWe brainstormed to come up with ideas for how to try to raise awareness and get this issue out there. We had a contact at the Port Theatre and he was available that day, so we decided to bring it to Cornwall,\u201d explained Kathleen Terrance, another organizer.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nOverall, Indigenous women in Canada are much more at risk of going missing than their male counterparts, there are also Akwesasne 24 men who have gone over the past several years as well. In light of this, the wellness centre felt that the event would make a point of including the missing men as well.\n\n\u201cAs mothers, we are our sons\u2019 voice, and so we decided we would add men into our event,\u201d said Square. \u201cWe want to remember them as well.\u201d\n\nThe red dress is has been used as a symbol for the missing and murdered Indigenous women because of the dress\u2019 association with women and red being the colour of their life\u2019s blood.\n\nThe dresses that will be hung on lamp posts from the international bridge to all the way to St. Lawrence College were collected from multiple sources. Somewhere donated by community members, others came from Maison Baldwin House\u2019s Serendipity Boutique, and the Salvation Army.\n\nahale@postmedia.com\n\ntwitter.com/alan_s_hale\n\nArticle content\nShare this article in your social network\nCOMMENTS\nYou must be logged in to join the discussion or read more comments.\nCreate an Account\nSign in\nJOIN THE CONVERSATION\nLATEST NATIONAL STORIES\nNEWS NEAR CORNWALL"},

'highway of tears'\nAuthor of the article:\nCamille Bains\nPublished Aug 19, 2016 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 3 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nHighway 16 near Prince George, B.C. is shown on Oct. 8, 2012. PHOTO BY BETHANY LINDSAY /Vancouver Sun\nArticle content\n\nVia Rail has joined discussions with the British Columbia government, First Nations and social service agencies to offer rock-bottom fares to \u201cvulnerable\u201d people who can\u2019t afford to travel along the so-called Highway of Tears.\n\nThe railway is collaborating with mayors and multiple groups to determine the criteria for $5 fares along a northern B.C. corridor where 18 girls and women have been murdered or have disappeared since the 1970s.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nB.C. seniors are being threatened with eviction from retirement homes over service fee increases, says seniors advocate\nB.C. expands heat-pump rebates to encourage more people to switch\nB.C. NDP ministers Harry Bains, Bruce Ralston and Rob Fleming won\u2019t seek re-election in Oct. 19 vote\nDemand for rental units in Metro Vancouver is 'off the charts.' So why aren't more being built?\nVancouver radio station AM 730 fizzles out, long after its glorious LG73 heyday\nArticle content\n\nIn June, following a decade of pleas from women\u2019s groups and First Nations, B.C. Transportation Minister Todd Stone announced that bus service would begin in the area by the end of the year.\n\nChief Joseph Bevan of the Kitselas First Nation near Terrace said he\u2019s part of an advisory group concerned about the safety of people along the 750-kilometre route and that it came together for regular meetings last November after months of discussions.\n\nHe said it\u2019s common for people to take a risk and hitchhike in the notorious area because they\u2019re too poor to take the train or a Greyhound bus.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s non-aboriginals as well. It\u2019s everyone who is on social assistance, people with disabilities, who are having trouble moving around. It makes them vulnerable when they\u2019re jumping into a vehicle with somebody else.\u201d\n\nBevan said that at a meeting in March, a Via Rail official made the proposal to offer a $5 fare along the highway that stretches between Prince Rupert and Prince George.\n\nMichael Woelcke, the railway\u2019s general manager for remote services, said in minutes of the meeting held in Prince George on March 30 that the company would offer the low fare \u201cregardless of origin or destination along the route.\u201d\n\nSunrise\n\nStart your day with a roundup of B.C.-focused news and opinion.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nHe said Via Rail provides train service three times a week between Prince Rupert and Prince George, and it\u2019s open to suggestions on determining eligibility for the $5 fare that would be available to \u201cat risk\u201d and \u201cvulnerable\u201d people including youth and \u201celders.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe need to identify who would qualify for this program, as we cannot provide everyone with these reduced fares,\u201d he said in the minutes.\n\nWoelcke said a minimum $75 one-way fare would be reduced by a third for aboriginal passengers.\n\nWoelcke was not available for comment, and the company said an official would provide details if and when an arrangement is worked out with the province.\n\nVia Rail said in an emailed statement that a discounted fare for \u201cvulnerable\u201d people is one of the options being studied and that discussions with the Transportation Ministry and the advisory group are ongoing.\n\nThe ministry said interconnectivity of services along Highway 16 has been part of discussions and that Via Rail was included to determine what role it could play to increase transportation options.\n\n\u201cWe continue to engage with Via Rail on the idea of offering a discounted train fare to vulnerable First Nations people,\u201d the ministry said.\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe group is slated to meet again next month.\n\nAs for the promised new bus service between Prince George and Prince Rupert, the ministry said the first of more than 20 public information sessions hosted by BC Transit will start Saturday.\n\nBC Transit said Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada, which is part of the advisory group, has provided $1 million in funding for features including enhanced bus stop shelters and CCTV cameras to ensure passengers\u2019 safety along the corridor.\n\nThe route provides the main transportation link to and from remote First Nations villages located off the main highway.\n\nMost of the cases of murdered RCMP\nThe information you need to know, sent directly to you: Download the CTV News App\n\n\u201cThe chief and the band council exercised their rights under section 81 of the Indian Act and section 30 of the Indian Act to banish the individual. And at that point if they were to set foot on reserve, they should have been removed by law enforcement and charged for trespassing,\u201d said Chief Ross Perley.\n\nChief Perley is frustrated with law enforcement, but also with provincial and federal governments. He believes had decision-makers worked with the community to enforce their laws, Sabattis might be alive today.\n\n\u201cAll of our communities have been calling on law enforcement to do a better job at drug enforcement in our communities. It hasn't been happening,\u201d he said.\n\nSheri Sabattis is pictured. (Source: Oromocto Funeral Home)\nAlycia Bartlett, the province\u2019s department of Indigenous Affairs spokesperson, said in an emailed statement the Government of New Brunswick has \u201creceived a request for assistance, and we will work with the community to provide whatever support is needed during this difficult time.\u201d\n\n\u201cGovernment has engaged Indigenous leaders in how to effectively address concerns around criminal activity in their communities and will continue to work with any and all Indigenous leaders to develop solutions,\u201d she said.\n\nThis weekend marks the 14th Red Dress Day, meant to remember missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, and remind people these tragedies are still happening.\n\n\u201cWe need to do something in this country to eliminate the violence against our women,\u201d said Carol McBride, president of the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada.\n\nMcBride feels more trauma-informed policing is needed, but also hopes Canadians wrap their arms around families who\u2019ve experienced this type of loss.\n\nHer hope is for healing and change.\n\n\u201cIt's so hard on our people to keep losing our sisters. This is unacceptable,\u201d she said.\u00a0\n\nFor more New Brunswick news visit our\u00a0dedicated provincial page.\n(opens in a new tab)\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 2\nThe Wolastoqey Nation flag is pictured. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/audio-highway-of-tears-cleansing-walk-inspires-song-1.2284204", "title": "AUDIO: Highway of Tears cleansing walk inspires song - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nAUDIO: Highway of Tears cleansing walk inspires song\nUnder the branches of a Cottonwood Kym Gouchie spoke of the surroundings that inspired her latest song - a chant that reflects a local woman's efforts to cleanse the Highway of Tears.\nSamantha Wright Allen\nJun 21, 2016 6:30 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKym Gouchie sings a song about the Highway of Tears during Aboriginal Day Tuesday in the park. Citizen photo by Brent Braaten June 21 2016Brent Braaten, Photographer\n\nUnder the branches of a Cottonwood Kym Gouchie spoke of the surroundings that inspired her latest song - a chant that reflects a local woman's efforts to cleanse the Highway of Tears.\n\n\"It felt like it came from the trees, it felt like it came from the ground and it came from the sky and it just filled the drum and the voice filled the space I was walking it,\" said Gouchie as the National Aboriginal Day entertainment thrummed in the background.\n\nGouchie joined Brenda Wilson-John on the last leg of her long journey from Prince Rupert to Prince George along Highway 16. During one five-kilometre stretch, the Lheidli T'enneh singer brought her drum.\n\n\"All of my songs come from a place that is beyond my conscious level,\" she said.\n\nThrough the minute-long song, Gouchie chants on repeat: \"We are cleansing the Highway of Tears, as we walk, as we walk.\"\n\nIt started as an incantation on the road but the song came together Sunday on the river bank, where she sat with Wilson-John and the Khast'an Drummers, who also played the song.\n\n\"Fluidly it all came together,\" said Gouchie, adding it had special meaning that Wilson-John helped finalize the piece.\n\n\"We sat down and she said this was the song that came to me,\" recalled Wilson-John, who walked more than 700 kilometres in memory of her sister, Ramona Wilson. \"First it was just the chant. It was just amazing and I was like 'Yes, that's it.'\n\n\"It's very simple and right to the point and it is very powerful at the same time.\"\n\nThe song is exudes both sadness and strength.\n\n\"Right now it's a victory, it's a success, it's a celebration, it's National Aboriginal Day, but if we were to be singing this in any other situation it would have a much sadder tone to it,\" Gouchie said. \"Having (Wilson-John) walk on the stage in her little fluorescent vest, it was very emotional but it was also very empowering... It just shows how strong we are as a people and especially as women.\"\n\nMusic is the best medium to speak to that dichotomy, both to honour the missing and murdered and empower those who remain.\n\n\"It's universal,\" said Gouchie. \"It's like a smile. Music can heal a heart. Music, especially when you have a drum and you have your voice, is the highest form of prayer.\"\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/red-dresses-seek-to-draw-attention-to-missing-murdered-aboriginal-women-1.2593772", "title": "'REDress Project': Powerful display of red dresses to draw attention to missing, murdered aboriginal women | CTV News", "body": "Home\n\nFOLLOW ON\n\n    \nBREAKING NEWS\nU.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCANADA\nRed dresses seek to draw attention to missing, murdered aboriginal women\nFan-Yee Suen\nCTVNews.ca Staff\n\n\nPublished Saturday, October 3, 2015 5:53PM EDT\nLast Updated Saturday, October 3, 2015 7:04PM EDT\nCTV National News: Red dresses to remember\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nThe REDress Project is art-turned-protest aimed at drawing attention to missing and murdered aboriginal women. Janet Dirks reports.\nCTV Winnipeg: Red Dress Campaign\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nMichelle Gerwing reports on a campaign to wear or display red dresses in remembrance of Canada's missing and murdered women.\nCTV News Channel: The REDress Project\n\u00a0\nNOW PLAYING\nArtist and creator of the REDress Project Jaime Black says by hanging a red dress as a symbol, it gives the ability to talk about the issue.\nSHARE:\nReddit\n\n\n\n\nA Winnipeg-based Metis artist is asking Canadians to take part in a powerful, one-day display of red dresses to represent the country's missing and murdered aboriginal women.\n\nJaime Black created The REDress Project five years ago, describing it as an \"aesthetic response\" to the issue of violence against aboriginal women.\n\n\"I began the project because, as an artist, I was looking around and seeing that a lot of families who had lost loved ones don't have much of a platform for having their voices heard,\" Black told CTV's News Channel on Saturday.\n\nRelated Stories\nRed Deer joins communities urging missing aboriginal women inquiry\nOntario chiefs fundraise to pay for inquiry into missing women\n\nBlack collected hundreds of donated red dresses that were later displayed in public spaces across Canada, including the Canadian Museum of Human Rights. Black said her project, which has a haunting visual effect, aims to draw greater public attention to the issue of missing and murdered aboriginal women.\n\n\"I figured a way to do that was through my art work,\" Black said.\n\nCalls for a national inquiry on murdered and missing aboriginal women have been growing since the RCMP revealed last year that nearly 1,200 aboriginal women have been murdered or gone missing in Canada in the last 30 years.\n\nOn Sunday, Black is hoping to draw even more attention to the issue by opening up her project to the public. She is inviting Canadians to display their own red dresses to signal their support of indigenous women.\n\nThe striking, one-day display of red dresses will coincide with the National Day of Vigils to Remember Murdered and Missing Aboriginal Women.\n\n\"I'm hoping that the public can support indigenous women by displaying a red dress in their home or business, or coming together as a community and displaying red dresses in other public places,\" Black said.\n\nAsked why she chose the colour red, Black said it is a \"very important sacred colour\" -- not only for her, personally, but for many other indigenous groups across Canada as well.\n\nBlack said a friend of hers, who is also an aboriginal, explained that red was the only colour sprits could see.\n\n\"So (red) is really a calling back of the spirits of these women and allowing them a chance to be among us and have their voices heard through their family members and community,\" she said.\n\nBlack said she hopes her project will inspire local organizations to launch similar projects in the future.\n\n\"I'm hoping that community groups will take on and start doing public installations and using that as a tool to have the public have more of an understanding of missing and murdered women.\"\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n\nREDress Project creator Jaime Black is hoping to draw even more attention to the issue of missing and murdered aboriginal women by opening up her project to the public. She is inviting Canadians to display their own red dresses to signal their support for indigenous women.\n\nHundreds of donated red dresses have been displayed in public spaces across Canada, including the Canadian Museum of Human Rights.\n\nJaime Black created The REDress Project five years ago, describing it as an \"aesthetic response\" to the issue of violence against aboriginal women.\n\nREDress Project creator Jaime Black is hoping to draw even more attention to the issue of missing and murdered aboriginal women by opening up her project to the public. She is inviting Canadians to display their own red dresses to signal their support for indigenous women.\n\nHundreds of donated red dresses have been displayed in public spaces across Canada, including the Canadian Museum of Human Rights.\n\nSHARE:\nReddit\nReport an error\nEditorial standards and\u00a0policies\nWhy you can trust CTV\u00a0News\nMORE NEWS FROM CANADA\nBorder workers who nearly went on strike in June ratify new contract\n'Finally I know who I am': Holocaust survivor\u2019s daughter reunited with long lost brother in Poland\n'It's a lot to digest': Calgary man wins $66M on Lotto 6-49 draw\n'Not my finest moment:' Police called to dispute between Ottawa city councillor and daycare owner\nWhat you need to know about a possible LCBO strike on Friday\nInstant noodle products sold in B.C., Alta., Ont. recalled due to undeclared peanut\nTOP VIDEOS\nfalse\nQue. students accuse teacher of profiting off their artwork\nfalse\nCar thefts in Canada: Insurance companies face criticism\nfalse\n$50K reward offered in case of missing Barrie, Ont. woman\nCTVNEWS.CA TOP STORIES\nBritain's Labour on track for huge majority, exit poll suggests, amid frustration with Conservatives\nTrying to sell or buy a home this summer? They\u2019re calling on authorities to provide more cooperative support and say that support might have saved her life. Anna Mandin reports \u2013 May 7, 2024\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nSix chiefs of the Wolastoqey Nation in New Brunswick are calling on the provincial and federal governments to provide more support for First Nations banishing individuals.\n\nThis comes after Sheri Sabattis died on Oromocto First Nation on April 27. The chiefs say the man charged with second-degree murder in relation to her death was banished from the community by the council and Chief Shelley Sabattis, who is Sheri Sabattis\u2019s sister.\n\n\u201cWe no longer need a Band-Aid. We need a solution, we need legislation, and we need a law. That\u2019s what we need as Indigenous people,\u201d said Allan Polchies Jr., chief of St. Mary\u2019s First Nation and one of the six Wolastoqey chiefs, during a Red Dress Day march in Fredericton on May 5.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\nRed Dress Day raises awareness of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people.\n\nSabattis\u2019s nephew carried a poster-sized picture of her during the march.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nIn a joint news release on May 3, the chiefs said requests for provincial and federal support to enforce laws passed by First Nations fell \u201con deaf ears, leaving us in a legal void.\u201d\n\nIn his speech, Polchies Jr. called the lack of support \u2018\u201dsystemic racism.\u201d\n\nNew Brunswick\u2019s attorney general, Ted Flemming, did not respond to a request for an interview.\n\nNew Brunswick RCMP declined an interview, but in an emailed statement, a spokesperson said enforcement of band council bylaws is multifaceted.\n\n\u201cAs police, we have to work within the parameters of all our legal authorities and obligations to ensure investigations are conducted justly and fairly,\u201d Cpl. Hans Ouellette wrote in the statement.\n\nMORE ON CANADA\nHurricane Beryl forces Canadian airlines to cancel flights.
