{"url": "https://signalscv.com/2022/03/zonta-club-takes-a-stand-against-domestic-violence/", "title": "Zonta Club takes a stand against domestic violence", "body": "Skip to content\nSUBSCRIBE\nMORNING RUNDOWN\nE-EDITION\nEVENT CALENDAR\nCONTACT US\nADVERTISE\nCLASSIFIED ADS\nOBITUARIES\nFacebook\n \nTwitter\n \nYoutube\n \nInstagram\nSanta Clarita Valley's #1 Local News Source\nHOME\nNEWS\nSPORTS\nBUSINESS\nCOMMUNITY\nFOOD & ENTERTAINMENT\nEVENT CALENDAR\nPRESS RELEASES\nOPINION\nVIDEO + PODCASTS\nSPECIAL SECTIONS\nCANYON COUNTRY MAGAZINE\nSUNDAY SIGNAL\nSCV RADIO\nTHE SIGNAL\u2019S SPOTLIGHT\nSearch\nSearch\n>2022>March>Community\nZonta Club takes a stand against domestic violence\nNEWS RELEASE\nMARCH 31, 2022\n4:10 PM\nThe Zonta Red Dress Project aims to increase awareness about violence against women. Courtesy photo\nShare\n \nTweet\n \nEmail\n\nNews release\u00a0\n\nThe Zonta Club of Santa Clarita Valley aims to\u00a0spread awareness of murdered and missing indigenous women and its true meaning plus the awareness of all murdered and missing individuals. \u00a0\n\nAt various local events, as part of the Red Dress Project, the club is displaying dresses and a sweater representing the eight murdered individuals here locally from 2015 to 2017. \u00a0\u00a0\n\n\u201cWe constantly hear of another individual that was taken from us too soon,\u201d the club said in a news release. \u201cAll violence must cease.\u00a0Explaining the importance of this project will hopefully bring awareness that we must as a community work together to prevent this from continuing to happen.\u201d\u00a0\n\nThirty-five percent of women worldwide have experienced either physical and/or sexual intimate partner violence or non-partner sexual violence, the release said. Native American/Alaskan or Native Hawaiians make up 1% of our local population but 25% more have suffered than other races when it comes to violence against women. \u201cWe shall not rest until women\u2019s rights are recognized\u00a0as human rights,\u201d the club\u2019s statement said.\u00a0\n\nOn Feb. 24, Associate Attorney General Vanita Gupta delivered an announcement that two new resources for law enforcement will be provided from their office regarding violence against women. Reducing violent crimes against women has become the top priority of the Department of Justice. \u00a0\n\nOne, a new tool to help law enforcement agencies best respond to, investigate, and ultimately prevent domestic violence and intimate partner violence by delivering innovative and evolving training and technical assistance to grantees in a more efficient, effective manner. Also, a national resource center is being established, specifically designed to help areas prevent domestic violence homicides. \u00a0\n\n\u201cBy continuing the SCV Red Dress Project in spring, it allows the Zonta Club of Santa Clarita Valley to bring awareness so we may continue our mission, Zonta Says NO: Violence Against Women,\u201d the statement said.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nYou can support the Zonta Club of Santa Clarita Valley by attending one of the dates this spring where they\u00a0will be displaying the SCV Red Dress Project. With your donation, you may receive a \u201cZonta Says NO\u201d bracelet or pin, or an SCV Red Dress button or grocery bag.\u00a0\n\nThe Red Dress will be appearing at local libraries, community centers, College of the Canyons, City Hall, the Saugus Swap Meet, and at the Newhall Farmers Market. It started on Women\u2019s Day, March 8, and will continue until the National Red Dress Day, May 5.\u00a0\u00a0\n\nMay 5 has been known as the Red Dress Day since 2010 in North America. It was created for the awareness of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls.\u00a0Red Dresses will hang throughout our nation and Canada to raise awareness.\u00a0The Zonta Club of Santa Clarita Valley supports this day in honor of all indigenous and all women who have been murdered or are missing. \u00a0\n\nYou can check Zonta\u2019s website for the full schedule and the story of the SCV Red Dress Project at www.SCVZonta.org/advocacy.\u00a0\n\nNews Release\nThe Signal delivers press releases from reliable sources to provide up-to-the-minute information to our website readers. Information directly from news sources has not been vetted by The Signal news room. {"url": "https://www.sookenewsmirror.com/community/journalist-to-discuss-indigenous-issues-in-upcoming-virtual-library-talk-7347634", "title": "Journalist to discuss Indigenous issues in upcoming virtual library talk - Sooke News Mirror", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n22.2 \u00b0C\nHome Community\nJournalist to discuss Indigenous issues in upcoming virtual library talk\nAngela Sterritt will address systemic issues contributing to violence against Indigenous women\nNews Staff Sooke\nApr 19, 2024 6:00 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nAngela Sterritt is an award-winning investigative journalist and a national best-selling author. She\u2019ll present a Vancouver Island Regional virtual author talk on April 30. (VIRL/Contributed)\nListen to this article\n00:02:00\n\nAngela Sterritt, an award-winning investigative journalist and national bestselling author of \u201cUnbroken,\u201d will join the Vancouver Island Regional Library for a virtual talk on the poignant issues faced by Indigenous women and girls.\n\nSterritt\u2019s book, which is part memoir and part investigation into the murders and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls, became an instant national bestseller and is nominated for the Hilary Weston Writers\u2019 Trust Award for best non-fiction book in Canada.\n\n\u201cHaving Angela with us just days ahead of Red Dress Day on May 5 is a powerful tribute to the many Indigenous women and girls who have been victims of a system that has failed them,\u201d says VIRL librarian Dalia Levy. \u201cIt is important for everyone to hear Angela\u2019s personal stories and the stories she has reported on.\u201d\n\nSterritt is from the Wilp Wiik\u2019aax of the Gitanmaax community within the Gitxsan Nation on her father\u2019s side and from Bell Island, Newfoundland, on her mother\u2019s side. She worked as a television, radio, and digital journalist at CBC for more than a decade, hosted the award-winning CBC original podcast \u201cLand Back,\u201d and lives on the territories of the Skwxwu7mesh, Musqueam, and Tsleil-Waututh in Vancouver.\n\nParticipants attending the virtual talk, scheduled for Tuesday, April 30, from 5:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m., are advised to prepare for a session that will address trauma, systemic racism, and potentially triggering themes. The Indigenous Crisis Line will be available 24/7 toll-free at 1-800-588-8717 across B.C. to provide support for those affected.\n\nThis event is free. RSVP at virl.bc.ca/event/angela-sterritt to receive the Zoom link prior to the event.\n\nIf you cannot attend the live event on April 30, a recording will be available in early May 2024.\n\nHave a {"url": "http://www.saobserver.net/news/family-remembers-mother-at-red-dress-walk/", "title": "Family remembers mother at Red Dress Walk - Salmon Arm Observer", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.7 \u00b0C\nHome News\nFamily remembers mother at Red Dress Walk\nPeople have told Stephanie Killman that the pain of losing a loved one can fade with time, but she and her sisters, Harmony and Alicia have felt it everyday since their mother\u2019s murder last November.\nBlack Press Media\nOct 6, 2017 11:00 AM\nOct 11, 2017 12:25 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nFrom left Alicia Killman,29, Harmony Killman,13 Justice Duteau,10 and Stephanie Killman, 27 wear signs bearing the name of their beloved mother/grandmother, Treena Marie Ball, 46 who was murdered by her husband last November during the Red Dress Walk for Awareness in Enderby on October 4. (Erin Christie/Morning Star)\n\nErin Christie\n\nMorning Star Staff\n\nPeople have told Stephanie Killman that the pain of losing a loved one can fade with time, but she and her sisters, Harmony and Alicia have felt it everyday since their mother\u2019s murder last November.\n\n\u201cI was the one who found her \u2014it was the worst day of my life.\u201d\n\nHer mother, Treena Marie Ball, 46 was found dead in her home on Nov. 18, 2016. The body of her partner, Don Wayne Ball, 68, was also found in the house. According to an RCMP report a single firearm was used and the incident was confirmed by RCMP as a \u201cmurder-suicide,\u201d and there was no evidence to indicate third-party involvement.\n\n\u201cI knew the minute I got there that something wasn\u2019t right. I walked into the house and I was calling and calling and no one was answering,\u201d Killman recalled.\n\nAs the only family member with an extra set of keys to her mother\u2019s Spruce Crescent home in Enderby, Killman, 27, said she went to the house that day because her stepfather\u2019s kids asked her to \u201ccheck on things\u201d after learning he hadn\u2019t shown up for work that morning.\n\n\u201cHe murdered her, and then he killed himself,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cWe never saw them fighting or had any inkling that something might be wrong. But you never know what goes on behind closed doors.\u201d\n\nAlicia Killman, 29, echoed her younger sister, adding that as far as she knew, life at home had been \u201cnormal\u201d for her mother, and she was happy.\n\n\u201cMy mom was known around Enderby \u2014 everyone loved her,\u201d Alicia said, \u201cShe was caring and thoughtful. She wore her heart on her sleeve, and people loved that about her. I loved that about her. I think her [funeral] was one of the biggest celebrations of life I had ever seen around here.\u201d\n\nOver the past year, Killman says she and her family have struggled to cope with the loss of their mother as they learn more about the events that led to her death.\n\n\u201cI was the one who found her \u2014it was the worst day of my life.\u201d\n\n- Stephanie Killman\n\n\u201cWe heard later that she went to our band for help, to try and get out\u2026.It\u2019s hard enough to put yourself in the vulnerable position of asking for help in a situation like that\u2026I can\u2019t imagine how she must have felt.\u201d\n\nKillman says she doesn\u2019t feel comfortable describing the \u201chorrific\u201d scene that greeted her when she entered her mother\u2019s home that day, but feels it\u2019s important to share what she can in the hope that others will \u201clearn something,\u201d from her mother\u2019s story, and take action.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m still not really comfortable talking to people outside our circle of family and friends about what happened, but I\u2019m trying because it\u2019s important to get the message out into the world, not just our small community, that this stuff happens. That it\u2019s real, and it doesn\u2019t just happen where people think. It happens close to home.\u201d\n\nFor the Killmans, part of getting their message out means participating in events like The Red Dress Walk for Awareness, an annual event held to raise awareness for the untold numbers of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada. During these events, members of the public are asked to wear a red dress or to display a red dress in a public place as a symbol of hope and an acknowledgement that missing and murdered women have not been forgotten.\n\nIn Enderby, the event took place Wednesday along the shore of the Shuswap River near the Enderby Bridge, and was attended by approximately 50 people. Deanna Cook, who has organized Enderby\u2019s Red Dress Walk for the past two years, says in a small, close-knit community like hers, this particular subject hits close to home.\n\n\u201cIn the last two years we have had five women taken from our community. Two were murdered and three are still missing in our community,\u201d Cook said Wednesday morning, referring to Caitlin Potts, Ashley Simpson and Deanna Wertz.\n\n\u201cWe have these events to remember those who are missing, and to remind people to keep looking for these women \u2014 people need to know that they will not be forgotten,\u201d she said.\n\nCaitlin Potts, 27, was last seen in February, 2016. The Cree mother from Alberta was reportedly in B.C., sorting out a troubled relationship with her ex-boyfriend when she went missing. B.C. RCMP released footage of the young woman entering Orchard Park Mall in Kelowna, from a surveillance video taken on Feb. 21, 2016. It\u2019s the last time she was seen. Ashley Simpson, 27, was last seen on April 27 of last year. Deanna Wertz, 46,was last seen in the early morning of July 19, 2016 at her residence on Yankee Flats Road.\n\nAccording to data published by the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada, Indigenous women made up three per cent of the country\u2019s female population in 2008, but suffered roughly 10 per cent of all female homicides that year. More than half of the cases occurred in the western provinces, with British Columbia and Alberta home to the highest numbers.\n\nThis year, Cook added, Red Dress walks took on additional meaning against the backdrop of the hearings that took place at the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, held this summer.\n\nWhile the Red Dress Project, on which the walk is based, was initially created seven years ago by Jaime Black, a Metis artist from Winnipeg, to draw attention to missing and murdered Indigenous women specifically, Cook says she has broadened the scope of Enderby\u2019s walk to include \u201call women.\u201d\n\n\u201cAll women deserve to be safe in our communities,\u201d she said. \u201cWe need to get the message that girls, all girls, need to stay safe. You can\u2019t just walk down the road at night anymore. And we\u2019re here trying to get the message out there that we should be able walk alone and not be afraid\u2014that the way things are right now, is not OK.\u201d\n\nTo see more photos of the Red Dress Walk for Awareness, and learn more about the event, click below.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n {"url": "https://www.stettlerindependent.com/news/new-blood-dance-movement-brings-stettler-community-a-glimpse-of-blackfoot-history-7352907", "title": "\u2018New Blood\u2019 Dance Movement brings Stettler community a glimpse of Blackfoot history - The Stettler Independent", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nJobs\nObituaries\nHome News\n\u2018New Blood\u2019 Dance Movement brings Stettler community a glimpse of Blackfoot history\nBlack Press Media\nMay 2, 2024 1:54 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nNew Blood- A Story of Reconciliation was told through singing and dance. (Erika Gilbuena photo)\nListen to this article\n00:02:50\n\nBy Erika Gilbeuena\n\nFor the Stettler Independent\n\nGrade 10-12 students of Coronation School and Castor\u2019s Gus Wetter School, along with the Grade 10 students of Wm E.Hay Stettler Secondary Campus attended a play titled Blood\u2013 A Story of Reconciliation, which captures the story of surviving through residential schools and moments in history that changed the traditional way of life for the Blackfoot people.\n\nThe Indigenous musical/dance production graced the stage of Stettler Performing Arts Center to reveal the traditions and stories that were taken away from the Blackfoot people when they were placed in reservations back in the late 1800s. Deanne Bertsch, the director of the play, began the evening by recounting the events that encouraged her to stage it.\n\nAccompanied by a fusion of Blackfoot and contemporary music by Peter Gabriel, the show unfolded with Eulalia, a Blackfoot elder and an educator at Strathmore High School, reading the poem by Chief Dan George Words to a Grandchild while she watched the scenes that played out based on the events she witnessed herself. Along with Eulalia was Eddie Wolf Child, Chris Eagle Rib, who played the drums and the flute, and Sho Blunderfield, who provided the vocals.\n\n\u201cShe (Eulalia) wanted hope and healing to be the big focus of the show. So we started creating the show around those moments,\u201d said Bertsch.\n\nAmong the audience was Warren Aspenes, Clearview Division Principal, who explained that Clearview Public Schools sponsored \u201cNew Blood\u201d to let the community see history and to be able to partake in it.\n\n\u201dThe play is relevant since the Red Dress Day (National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People) is approaching,\u201d commented Nancy Aspenes, who attended the event with her husband.\n\nAfter receiving a standing ovation, Bertsch invited the crowd to stay for a talk-back session where the cast and crews answered questions from the spectators.\n\nThey discussed the origin and significance of the costumes, notably their regalias. The actresses revealed that the majority of the symbols that were embedded in their dresses were their family\u2019s emblems that were passed down from generation to generation.\n\nThey also discussed the symbolism shown in the performance.\n\nOne of the messages that the show conveyed was that the failure of the past should not impede the progress we are making toward national unity and understanding.\n\n\u201cWe can make reconciliation happen at the little corner of our homes,\u201d Bertch added.\n\n\u201cNew Blood\u201d is scheduled to perform next at Living Sky Casino in Saskatchewan on May 14, 2024.\n\nNew Blood- A Story of Reconciliation tells the story of survival in Canada\u2019s residential school system.\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on {"url": "https://www.saobserver.net/news/trek-along-the-highway-of-tears-by-okanagan-man-and-his-dog/", "title": "Okanagan man, dog treks along the Highway of Tears - Salmon Arm Observer", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.7 \u00b0C\nHome News\nOkanagan man, dog treks along the Highway of Tears\nA Penticton Indian Band member is walking along the Highway of Tears\nMark Brett\nApr 1, 2019 6:30 AM\nApr 1, 2019 9:06 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nKoda and Robin Edgar Haworth during one of their previous treks. (Submitted)\n\nOn the road again. And again\n\nRobin Edgar Haworth, the Penticton Indian Band\u2019s travelling artist, recently left on his annual summer walking tour.\n\nHaworth, with best friend and companion Koda, the Australian shepherd, are on a journey that will eventually take them along the infamous 720-kilometre corridor of Highway 16 called the Highway of Tears.\n\nThat section of road received the name from a series of murders and disappearances of between 16 and more than 40 Indigenous women.\n\nHaworth attempted the trek last year, however wildfires and smoke forced him to cut short his trip.\n\nREAD ALSO: Penticton artist one month into Right the Wrong trek\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not doing it for any kind of personal recognition we just love to walk and it\u2019s always in memory of the ones who can\u2019t walk anymore, the murdered and the missing they\u2019re always on my mind,\u201d said Haworth by cell phone just after breaking camp north of Kelowna. \u201cI know I will feel their spirits, I know a couple of them and they\u2019re never far away.\u201d\n\nIn 2015 he did a 4,500-kilometre Right the Wrong trek from Penticton to Ottawa to draw attention to those missing and murdered women.\n\nREAD ALSO: Penticton artist on walk of awareness to Ottawa\n\n\u201cMy sister is one of those people, she\u2019s not missing she was murdered back in the early 70s in Vancouver,\u201d said Haworth. \u201cIt was just another case of a dead Indian found on the street, it wasn\u2019t even investigated.\u201d\n\nThe initial part of his journey, which he expects complete sometime in September, is to Vancouver Island including the archipelago of Haida Gwaii also known as the Queen Charlotte Islands, before returning to the mainland and the Highway of Tears and then home.\n\nWalking continues to be Haworth\u2019s passion and the long journey\u2019s he makes with Koda each year are what he lives for.\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re walking along the road and you\u2019ve got no radio on no phone on it\u2019s just you and your dog and it\u2019s peaceful, your mind goes to a place where you can really do a lot of self searching and healing. We all have the little things in the back of our minds that we have to deal with.\u201d\n\nJust over a week in, so far he Koda has not had any unusual experiences, other than one at the Penticton Home Hardware store just before he left.\n\nHe had been telling some of the staff there about his trip and a customer overheard the conversation.\n\n\u201cThe lady said: \u2018oh, you\u2019re going walking, can I give you any money?\u2019 and I said no and she said: \u2018Aren\u2019t you walking because you\u2019re poor?\u2019 and I said \u2018no, I\u2019m walking because I love walking,\u2019\u201d Haworth recalled with a laugh. \u201cAnd right after that another lady came up to me and said; \u2018You\u2019re walking to Haida Gwaii, can I give you some money for your efforts,\u2019 and I said \u2018no ma\u2019am, we\u2019re good.\u2019\u201d\n\nOne part of the journey he is especially looking forward to is in the summer when his daughter Lee Denis will join him from her current home in Perth, Scotland after battling cancer.\n\n\u201cThat will be great, I haven\u2019t seen her for a long time,\u201d he said.\n\nAnd when asked just how much distance he plans to cover on his current adventure, in true Haworth fashion he replied: \u201cI have no idea. What\u2019s that old adage, it\u2019s not about the destination, it\u2019s about the journey and what you learn along the way.\u201d\n\n\u00a0\n\n@PentictonNews\nnewstips@pentictonwesternnews.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\n\u00a0MarkBrett\nSend Mark Brett an email.\nLike the Western News on Facebook.\nFollow us on Twitter.\n\nRobin Edgar Haworth and Koda at the start of their 2015 journey to Ottawa. (Western News file photo)\nTaking a break along Okanagan Lake, Koda, relaxes in the spring sunshine. (Submitted)\nKoda gets ready to break camp and head out on the road. {"url": "https://www.wltribune.com/news/more-tears-shed-as-indigenous-leaders-family-search-for-2-missing-along-highway-of-tears-6831629", "title": "More tears shed as plea made to find 2 more missing on B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears - The Williams Lake Tribune", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.6 \u00b0C\nHome News\nMore tears shed as plea made to find 2 more missing on B.C.\u2019s Highway of Tears\nMary Teegee of Carrier Sekani Child & Family Services says society must do better\n\tRuth Lloyd\n\nNov 3, 2023 3:47 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 8 Chief Priscilla Mueller, with mic, of Saik\u2019uz First Nation, speaks at a press conference calling for more action and resources to help find two young people missing from the community west of Prince George, while family members of the missing, other leaders, sit nearby. (Carrier Sekani Child & Family Services photo)\nExpand\n\nFirst Nations leaders and the parents of two missing members of the Saik\u2019uz First Nation are calling for more resources and action to find the missing young people. Indigenous leaders and family spoke at a press conference in Vanderhoof today to request information and action by government.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been 24 days since my daughter Chelsea went missing, and we still don\u2019t have any answers,\u201d said a tearful Pam Heron, mother of missing woman Chelsey Quaw (Heron).\n\n\u201cI\u2019m trying as hard as I can. I have to fight just because his boys deserve to know where he\u2019s at,\u201d said Angie Raphael, mother of missing man Jay Raphael.\n\nChelsey Quaw (Heron) and Jay Preston Raphael are both missing members of the Saik\u2019uz First Nation, located 120 km west of Prince George, just outside Vanderhoof, B.C. and just 14 km south of Highway 16.\n\nHighway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert is known as the Highway of Tears, due to the high number of missing and murdered women in the area, the majority of whom over the years have been Indigenous.\n\nCommunity leaders also shed tears as they spoke at a press conference in Vanderhoof, urging for more resources to be brought to the investigation into the two missing young people.\n\nChief Priscilla Mueller of Saik\u2019uz First Nation thanked all the volunteers who came to participate in the search so far, and said the Saik\u2019uz community had taken the search to Prince George and Vanderhoof as well.\n\nBut she said more needs to be done and more resources are needed.\n\n\u201cThere is only so much the local RCMP can do,\u201d she said, noting they need help from government.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not too sure how we\u2019re going to move forward with the search,\u201d she said.\n\nMary Teegee, executive director of Carrier Sekani Child & Family Service expressed frustration at the lack of action on the 33 recommendations from the 2006 Highway of Tears Symposium Report, which she was also a part of.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m upset that we have to be here again,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThere are things we need to think about as a society, how much value are we placing on our Indigenous women, our Indigenous men.\u201d\n\nShe called for more action from both the government, law enforcement and the media to help draw attention to the ongoing issues surrounding missing and murdered Indigenous women and the Highway of Tears. She also referenced the missing women in Manitoba whose remains are believed to be in a landfill.\n\n\u201cIn Canada we\u2019re having to check the landfills for bodies of our missing Indigenous women. Think about that. As a society we have to do better.\u201d\n\nChelsey Quaw is a 29-year-old Indigenous woman with brown hair, brown eyes who vanished from her community last month.\n\nShe stands five feet, 10 inches tall and weighs about 120 pounds. She was possibly wearing blue jeans and a purple winter jacket when she went missing in the early morning hours of Oct. 11, 2023 from a residence on the Saik\u2019uz First Nation.\n\nSeveral search and rescue teams as well as community groups formed search parties to look for Quaw with no results.\n\nJay Preston Raphael has been missing from the community just over eight months.\n\nRaphael is a 28-year-old male with black hair and brown eyes, and unique tattoos on his neck, chest and arm.\n\nHe is five feet, nine inches tall and weighs approximately 143 pounds.\n\nRaphael was last seen on Feb. 25, 2023 at Saik\u2019uz First Nation wearing a black coat, blue jeans black runners and a baseball hat.\n\nSaik\u2019uz First Nation has an on-reserve population of about 400.\n\nLeaders also frequently referenced other missing women from the area. This included Mackie Basil, missing from Tl\u2019azt\u2019en Nation Nation, since 2013, Bonnie Joseph of Yekooche First Nation, missing from near Vanderhoof since 2008, Ramona Wilson of Gitxan First Nation, who went missing in 1994 and whose remains were found near Smithers in 1995. Her murder remains unsolved. They also mentioned Madison Scott and the ongoing search for justice in her case. Scott had been missing since 2011 and her remains were found earlier this year near Vanderhoof, but no charges have yet been laid as the investigation is ongoing.\n\nAnyone with any information can contact Vanderhoof RCMP at 250-567-2222 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.\n\nREAD MORE: Mother of missing Vanderhoof woman says she would never just take off\n\nREAD MORE: RCMP renews public assistance call to locate missing man\n\nREAD MORE: Search continues for missing Vanderhoof woman Chelsey Quaw\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Ruth Lloyd\n\nI moved back to my hometown {"url": "http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/07/06/the-vanishing-of-canadas-first-nations-women-harper-trudeau-violence-highway-of-tears-indigenous/", "title": "The Vanishing of Canada\u2019s First Nations Women \u2013 Foreign Policy", "body": "By using this website, you agree to our use of cookies. This use includes personalization of content and ads, and traffic analytics. Review our Privacy Policy for more information.\n\nSkip to navigation\nSkip to search\nSkip to main content\nSkip to footer\nShow expanded website navigation\nBack to Foreign Policy Magazine home page\nLatest  Regions   Newsletters   FP Live\nSIGN IN\nSUBSCRIBE\nFEATURE\nThe Vanishing of Canada\u2019s First Nations Women\nMore than 1,000 indigenous women have gone missing or have been murdered in Canada. Meet the sisterhood trying to bring them justice.\n\nBY MARIN COGAN\n\nILLUSTRATIONS BY DIEGO PATI\u00d1O\n\nJULY 6, 2016\n\nEvery July, more than a million people descend on Calgary, Canada, for Stampede, a 10-day rodeo and festival billed as \u201cThe Greatest Outdoor Show on Earth.\u201d A prairie city just east of the Rockies, Calgary is inundated with cowboys and denim-clad wannabes looking to eat fried food and watch bull riders. Stampede is also western Canada\u2019s answer to Mardi\u00a0Gras. Patrons pack shoulder-to-shoulder into neon-lit saloons and cavernous clubs, where female bartenders in crop tops and hot pants wander dance floors bearing trays of shots. Companies with names like \u201cBust Loose!\u201d deploy hundreds of buses, equipped with booming stereos and dance poles, to carry revelers on hours-long\u00a0pub crawls.\n\nFor Canada\u2019s aboriginal people, Stampede offers another kind of celebration: a chance to showcase their cultures. (Indigenous populations include the country\u2019s 634 First Nations as well as M\u00e9tis and Inuit citizens.) At Stampede Park, the event\u2019s main grounds in downtown Calgary, native craftspeople show spectators how to raise\u00a0tipis, carve knives out of stone, and use butchered animals\u2019 stomachs as cooking vessels.\n\nOn July 11, 2007, Sandra\u00a0Manyfeathers, a local educator, dancer, and member of the Blood Tribe, was slated to participate in the festivities. Then 36,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0would join other indigenous performers at one of Stampede\u2019s Grandstand Shows, nightly entertainment extravaganzas featuring local talent. She hoped that her older sister, Jacqueline\u00a0Crazybull, would be watching.\n\nWith high, fine cheekbones and long, dark hair, the sisters \u2014 two of 12 siblings \u2014 looked alike. Crazybull\u00a0had helped raise Manyfeathers\u00a0after their mother died when they were young \u2014 20 and 12, respectively.\u00a0Crazybull\u00a0went on to have a dozen children of her own. Her life hadn\u2019t been easy; she\u2019d struggled with drug addiction and had sometimes been homeless. Still, she was lighthearted and quick to kindness, with a wide smile and a warm laugh.\u00a0She often showed up to cheer at Manyfeathers\u2019s\u00a0dance performances.\n\nBut\u00a0Crazybull\u00a0never made it. At about 4 a.m. that July 11, she and a cousin, Kirk\u00a0Steinhauer, were hungry for a snack and popped into a corner store on Calgary\u2019s Red Mile, a strip of restaurants and bars next to Stampede Park. Shortly after the two left the store, a group of young men in a sedan pulled up to the curb, rolled down a window, and asked for directions.\u00a0Crazybull\u00a0walked over to help.\u00a0Steinhauer\u00a0sat on a bus-stop bench and took his eyes off his cousin for only a moment. Then he heard her scream.\n\nThe sedan was peeling away down the street.\u00a0Crazybull\u00a0lay crumpled in pain on the pavement. Steinhauer dashed over and saw that she was alive but bleeding profusely from a stab wound to her stomach. Within minutes, Crazybull stopped\u00a0breathing. She was one of five people attacked that night in Calgary, seemingly at random, by the same men. She was the only aboriginal victim, and the only one who died.\n\nManyfeathers\u00a0heard the news that afternoon while in a trailer preparing for the Grandstand Show. She remembers feeling disbelief. It wasn\u2019t the first time heartbreak had touched her family. In 1991, another sister, Yvonne, had been beaten to death by a relative\u2019s boyfriend. Eight years later, a cousin, Gloria Blackplume, had been found in a Calgary alley, kicked to death by two male acquaintances.\n\nTheir stories are part of a larger tragedy. According to 2011 data, though Canada\u2019s 718,500 indigenous women make up just 4.3 percent of the country\u2019s female population, they represent around five times as many female homicide victims. Canadian police have found that 4.5 out of every 100,000 indigenous women die by homicide \u2014 for women overall, the figure is less than 1 \u2014 and that roughly 1,200 have been slain or have gone missing over the past three decades. Nongovernmental research, however, suggests the real number may top 4,000. How many cases have been solved is another point of dispute: The government claims nearly 90 percent, but some indigenous activists say it\u2019s closer to 50.\n\nOn the advice of tribal elders,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0decided to go ahead with her Stampede performance in her sister\u2019s honor. Dressed in a colorful beaded gown with her hair in two thick braids, she took the stage. Accompanied by a drummer and led by instinct,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0executed fast, intricate jumps and steps while twirling a shawl and spinning. She didn\u2019t register the audience. As if in a trance, she moved only for her sister that night.\n\nAfterward, she went to a nearby bathroom with another sibling, who at\u00a0Manyfeathers\u2019s\u00a0request used a pair of scissors to cut off her braids. In her culture, long hair is a sign of\u00a0well-being. Shearing it is an act of mourning but also creates room for spiritual growth.\n\nA few days later,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0placed the braids, still laced with beads and feathers, on her sister\u2019s casket as it was lowered into the earth. Their First Nation traditions would prove some of\u00a0Manyfeathers\u2019s\u00a0only sources of solace as the hunt for her sister\u2019s killers unfolded \u2014 and then sputtered to a painful halt.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t have\u00a0to feel sorry for me,\u201d\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0says. \u201cAs harsh as things are for First Nation people, we\u2019ve actually developed a skill to be able to get through things.\u201d It\u2019s the middle of April 2016, and she\u2019s sitting across from me over scrambled eggs at a diner not far from Stampede Park. At 45,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0continues to dance, and she once again wears her hair long.\n\nA cultural educator by trade,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0has the tough disposition of someone who\u2019s spent decades living a national crisis. Among the missing and slain aboriginal women, some have been felled by random crimes. Others have been sex workers strangled by johns, teenage runaways targeted by violent offenders, or victims of abusive boyfriends. Certain regions are more affected than others \u2014 a lonely stretch of mountain road in British Columbia is known as the \u201cHighway of Tears\u201d because dozens of women have died or disappeared there \u2014 but no location is immune.\n\nWhat\u00a0unites\u00a0the cases are the conditions that make native women vulnerable to violence, rooted in a colonial legacy of neglect and humiliation. Until just a few decades ago, the Canadian government tried to erase aboriginal cultures. Among other policies, the state denied natives\u00a0voting rights until 1960, unless they agreed to forgo indigenous status. Canada also forced 150,000 aboriginal children into \u201cresidential schools\u201d \u2014 state-funded boarding institutions where assimilation into white culture was mandatory. Students were beaten if they spoke in their native tongues, and an unknown number of girls\u00a0was\u00a0sterilized. The last of the 130 schools didn\u2019t close until 1996.\n\nToday, Canada\u2019s 1.4 million indigenous people suffer economically \u2014 36 percent of indigenous women live in poverty, for instance, versus 17 percent of their non-indigenous counterparts. One-third of indigenous people between the ages of 25 and 54\u00a0have\u00a0less than a high school education. Substance abuse is a rampant concern; in a 2011 national survey of First Nation adults living on reserves and in northern communities, 83 percent cited it as the biggest threat to aboriginal health. Dawn\u00a0Lavell-Harvard, president of the non-profit Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada (NWAC), says she once heard domestic abuse in aboriginal households called as normal as keeping \u201cketchup in the fridge.\u201d\n\n\u201cCanada has done a very good job of making indigenous people invisible,\u201d\u00a0Lavell-Harvard adds. \u201cRacism against indigenous people is justified, legitimized, accepted, and even ignored.\u201d According to 2016 data from the independent Canadian Institute for Identities and Migration, a quarter of the country holds a negative view of indigenous people. The only populations seen more unfavorably are Muslims (43 percent) and immigrants (28 percent).\n\nThis outlook bleeds into law enforcement, with police often misdirecting blame in cases involving missing or slain women. They claim aboriginal victims probably died of overdoses, committed suicide, or ran away from home. In some instances, they fail to follow up on leads. A recent Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) survey of more than 110 native families who\u2019ve lost female relatives found that the average performance rating for police, on a scale of one to 10, was a mere 2.8. \u201cI feel like the police are not taking interest in anything that has anything to do with the aboriginal people,\u201d Maria\u00a0Pia\u00a0Benuen, whose best friend disappeared and has never been found, told the CBC.\n\nAs far back as 1991, activists organized a march demanding justice. It would take a full decade and a handful of high-profile killings for the Canadian government to pay even modest attention, in the form of reports and other bureaucratic mechanisms. Little was done, however, to crack existing cases or to prevent future ones. As recently as 2014, then-Prime Minister Stephen Harper rejected calls for a national investigation into the roots of the crisis. \u201cIt isn\u2019t really high on our radar, to be honest,\u201d he told a television interviewer.\n\nFaced with inertia, it has fallen to native women to become protesters, scholars, advocates, and even their own protectors. They have searched for the missing when police have stopped. They have organized rallies and memorials. They have published the best data on killings and disappearances. Whether they have collaborated or worked alone, their experiences are the threads of the same story, crosshatched across Canada\u2019s vast territory. They are the catalysts\u00a0who, this year, spurred a newly elected government to commence a pioneering federal inquiry.\n\nManyfeathers\u00a0is one of these women. She shares her story not so \u201cI can have a pity party,\u201d she says, as her coffee cools in a thick-rimmed mug on the Formica table between us. \u201cI do this so there is awareness.\u201d\n\nCrazybull\u2019s\u00a0killers\u00a0were reckless. There were people at the scene of the crime, including her cousin, and four stabbing victims who survived. (Steinhauer\u00a0did not respond to an interview request sent via his\u00a0Facebook\u00a0page.) Witnesses said the sedan was a light color and that three or four young black men were inside, but no one could identify them.\n\nFour months later, in November 2007, police released surveillance footage from Mac\u2019s Convenience Store, situated across the street from where Crazybull was killed. It showed three young black men shopping just before the stabbing spree. Police stopped short of calling the trio suspects but said they might have more information about the crimes. Still, no one came forward. Nine years later, no one ever has. Manyfeathers says she hasn\u2019t heard an update from law enforcement since 2008.\n\nInspector Don Coleman of Calgary\u2019s major crimes section tells me that authorities interviewed witnesses and believe they know the perpetrators\u2019 identities. Yet they don\u2019t have sufficient evidence to make arrests. \u201cThere are reasons why we can\u2019t move the file forward at this point,\u201d Coleman says, declining to elaborate. He admits that the police could be in closer touch with Crazybull\u2019s\u00a0relatives: \u201cWe probably don\u2019t do as good a job as families or we would like.\u201d\n\nFar bigger cases have stagnated despite far worse evidence. The December after Crazybull\u2019s death, Robert Pickton, a pig farmer in British Columbia, was convicted of murdering six women, five of whom were aboriginal. Police believed that he was probably responsible for as many as 49 homicides between the early 1980s and late 2001, and that about half of his victims were indigenous sex workers. Pickton\u2019s crimes, however, might have been solved much sooner. When prostitutes began disappearing from Vancouver in the 1990s, Lorimer Shenher, a detective, received an anonymous tip suggesting that police investigate Pickton. His superiors were dismissive. \u201cThere were so many biases against these women from police,\u201d Shenher\u00a0says, \u201can attitude of \u2018You get what you paid for.\u2019\u201d\n\nPickton\u00a0was charged with attempted murder in 1997. The woman, a sex worker, had been handcuffed and stabbed multiple times before fighting him off and running away.\u00a0Pickton\u00a0suffered knife wounds and was treated at the same hospital as the woman; in his pocket, doctors found the key to the cuffs still dangling from her arm. Yet\u00a0Pickton\u00a0claimed self-defense, and charges were dismissed on the grounds that the woman, who had a history of petty crime and drug addiction, was not sufficiently credible. Police collected\u00a0Pickton\u2019s\u00a0clothing but stashed it in a storage locker for more than seven years. When they were examined in 2004, after the killer\u2019s other crimes had been exposed, police found the DNA of two missing women.\n\nFailed opportunities mounted. In a book published last year,\u00a0Shenher\u00a0recounts how police twice interviewed a woman who told a friend that she\u2019d helped\u00a0Pickton\u00a0lure a sex worker and later saw him skinning her body on a meat hook in his barn.\u00a0Shenher\u00a0says officers were biased and unprepared in the questioning. As a result, they got no actionable information \u2014 and\u00a0Pickton\u00a0wasn\u2019t arrested for three more years. \u201cIf you were in any other job you\u2019d be fired for the kind of incompetence that I encountered in this investigation every day,\u201d\u00a0Shenher\u00a0tells me. \u201cNobody cared. Literally.\u201d\n\nWatching the news of\u00a0Pickton\u2019s\u00a0trial on television in Ottawa, Maryanne Pearce, then 35, was infuriated. \u201cIt was just so horrific,\u201d the part-Mohawk woman\u00a0recalls. \u201cIt was one of those \u2018I have to do something\u2019 moments.\u201d\n\nPearce enrolled in a doctoral program in law to research missing and murdered women but soon found that \u201cthere was nothing available to the public in terms of data\u201d because police had never published national statistics. So she began a project that would become her thesis. \u201cI decided I [would] just do a database,\u201d she says, \u201cnot having any idea of what I was getting myself into.\u201d\n\nBuilding an archive of media clippings about reported deaths and disappearances dating back as far as she could find, Pearce categorized women according to several factors, including whether they were mothers, worked in the sex trade, and had attended residential schools. The files grew so vast that the boxes holding them spilled from Pearce\u2019s small home office into her dining room.\n\nUnbeknownst to\u00a0Manyfeathers, her sister\u2019s story was included in those boxes. Back in Calgary, Manyfeathers was determined to keep Crazybull\u2019s memory alive. In October 2008, the month of her sister\u2019s birthday and just over a year after her slaying, Manyfeathers organized Justice for Jackie, a march that would become an annual ritual. She gathered\u00a0Crazybull\u2019s\u00a0children, family members, and friends at the city\u2019s Rouleauville\u00a0Square and walked 10 blocks to the corner where her sister had died. They carried a banner with\u00a0Crazybull\u2019s\u00a0picture. Some sang traditional songs. Others prayed out loud for the killers to be caught.\n\nAround that time,\u00a0a new case emerged just over 800 miles east in Manitoba, Canada\u2019s geographic heartland. Claudette Osborne, a 21-year-old mother of four, disappeared from Winnipeg on July 24, 2008. She had a history of sex work and substance abuse. Social services had taken her youngest child, born 15 days before Osborne went missing, and had told her to seek drug treatment. Her last contact with her family was a phone message she left with a sibling saying that she was at Winnipeg\u2019s Lincoln Motor Hotel with a man who made her feel unsafe.\n\nOsborne\u2019s sister, Bernadette Smith, became the lost woman\u2019s staunchest advocate. Smith says police were slow to respond. \u201cShe was reported missing, but it was 10 days before her case was even looked at,\u201d Smith testified before Canada\u2019s Parliament several years later. The Winnipeg Police Department\u2019s policy on missing persons is flexible: A \u201crisk assessment\u201d is conducted, examining factors such as age and lifestyle. Then, \u201cif the assessment dictates, a uniform car will be dispatched to begin the investigation.\u201d Osborne\u2019s background seemingly would have placed her at high risk. Yet Smith claims police took the case less seriously because of it. \u201c[They] told us that they weren\u2019t going to do anything right now, that she\u2019d turn up,\u201d Smith testified. When they did start looking, security-camera footage from the Lincoln Motor Hotel on the day Osborne vanished had already been taped over.\n\nSmith wasn\u2019t a stranger to shoddy police work. It had taken 15 years for authorities to make arrests in the 1971 slaying of her cousin, Helen Betty Osborne, despite informants providing the names of three of the four men involved. (One suspect was later convicted, another was acquitted, and one received immunity for testifying. The fourth was never charged.) In 2003, another 16-year-old relative\u2019s severed arm and leg turned up in Winnipeg\u2019s Red River; that killing was never solved. Frustrated by another case going nowhere fast, Smith organized a concert and candlelight vigil on the first anniversary of her sister\u2019s disappearance, honoring missing and slain women across Manitoba. Relatives of victims leaned on one another, Smith later testified, \u201cbecause there\u2019s not enough support out there.\u201d (She has since developed an online tool kit for victims\u2019 families, including a log to record interactions with police and a customizable missing-persons poster.)\n\nThe month of the memorial concert, a Winnipeg construction crew uncovered the body of\u00a0Cherisse\u00a0Houle, 17. Just seven weeks later, the corpse of her friend, Hillary Angel Wilson, 18, was found along a dirt path. No suspects were identified. The deaths angered many native women. A friend of Wilson\u2019s told the CBC, \u201cThere is a group of us women that are going to get together \u2026 and talk about what can we do \u2026 as a community, as mothers, as sisters, as aboriginal women here, because not enough is being done.\u201d Smith and other advocates demanded that Manitoba create a police task force to investigate unsolved cases. Less than a week after Wilson was found, in late August 2009, Manitoba acquiesced. After a review of dozens of cold cases, police chose to investigate 27 involving female victims.\n\nTo date, Project Devote, as it\u2019s known, has identified just one perpetrator. When Myrna\u00a0Letandre\u00a0went missing in 2006, her family told police that she\u2019d mentioned knowing someone named\u00a0Traigo. Yet authorities didn\u2019t search the rooming house where\u00a0Letandre, unemployed and receiving government disability checks, and a man named\u00a0Traigo\u00a0Andretti had been living. Seven years later, police working for Project Devote found\u00a0Letandre\u2019s\u00a0remains in the house\u2019s basement. The same week, Andretti was charged with killing his wife in British Columbia. After being handed a life sentence for that crime, he was convicted of\u00a0Letandre\u2019s\u00a0murder. In court,\u00a0Letandre\u2019s\u00a0family issued a statement blaming police \u201cfor the loss of another life. We did our best to have this man talked to, investigated, but despite our numerous pleas, nothing \u2014 absolutely nothing \u2014 was done.\u201d\n\nFemale advocates spurred other limited actions by provincial governments. In March 2010, the NWAC announced that it had identified 582 cases of missing and slain women nationwide dating back to 1944. Several trends stood out: The chances of an aboriginal woman being killed either by a partner or by someone she knew were the same, for instance, while she was almost three times more likely than a non-indigenous woman to be killed by a stranger. The largest concentration of cases, 28 percent, was in British Columbia, a figure that demanded a public reckoning on the heels of Robert\u00a0Pickton\u2019s\u00a0shocking trial.\n\nThat fall, British Columbia launched a commission of inquiry led by a former attorney general, yet the investigation was dogged by controversy. Its mandate only encompassed cases and police work from 1997 to 2002 \u2014 Pickton\u2019s\u00a0most active years. This left many women\u2019s stories, namely those who weren\u2019t the serial killer\u2019s victims, beyond the scope. The government also declined to pay for legal representation before the commission, which many aboriginal stakeholders couldn\u2019t afford.\n\nOne lawyer, Robyn\u00a0Gervais, was appointed to represent indigenous interests, but she resigned after six months because she thought the inquiry focused too heavily on police testimony. \u201c[G]iven\u00a0that these hearings are largely about missing and murdered aboriginal women,\u201d\u00a0Gervais, a M\u00e9tis woman, told the commission, \u201cI didn\u2019t think I should fight to have their voices heard.\u201d A month later, a former commission staffer, anonymously describing sexism behind the commission\u2019s scenes, told the\u00a0National Post\u00a0that a senior colleague once referred to a sex worker as \u201cthe fat hooker.\u201d\n\nIn late 2012, the embattled commission released a report with more than 60 policy recommendations, including sensitivity training for police and frequent reviews of cold cases. Many of the items, however, were never implemented. Nearly two years on, an op-ed in the\u00a0Globe and Mail\u00a0argued that the report, titled \u201cForsaken,\u201d might as well have been called \u201cIgnored and\u00a0Forgotten.\u201d In the intervening months, Human Rights Watch (HRW) described how police in British Columbia had \u201cblamed,\u201d \u201cshamed,\u201d and even sexually assaulted some aboriginal women seeking their protection. Law enforcement responded by saying there was little it could do unless\u00a0HRW\u2019s\u00a0anonymous sources came forward with accusations.\n\nMeanwhile, indigenous activists found their work under siege nationwide. Harper\u2019s conservative government eliminated funding previously allocated to the NWAC to research violence against aboriginal women, insisting that more \u201caction\u201d was needed. Yet authorities\u2019 next step was downsizing. Over three years, starting in 2012, aboriginal groups suffered a 59 percent cut in government support, as part of the prime minister\u2019s push to balance the national budget. Moreover, Canada\u2019s department of aboriginal affairs withheld $1 billion in promised spending on social services over five years.\n\nAn agency representative told the CBC that this was \u201csimply due to timing issues.\u201d Activists saw the situation differently. The cuts were evidence of \u201ca larger government attitude that indigenous women just didn\u2019t matter,\u201d says the\u00a0NWAC\u2019s\u00a0Lavell-Harvard, \u201cand indigenous lives didn\u2019t matter.\u201d\n\nMaryanne Pearce wanted\u00a0to depict the sheer scale of the crisis in a way that couldn\u2019t be ignored. In late 2013, she published her 1,126-page thesis, \u201cAn Awkward Silence.\u201d Pearce had found 824 cases of missing and slain indigenous women spanning three decades; her files filled nine crates in her home. She released her data online in a PDF, including a searchable, 54-page index listing victims\u2019 names and demographics.\n\nThe thesis made news because its count was so much higher than any previously reported \u2014 and because an academic, not the government, had produced it. \u201cFamilies seeking loved ones hope new database will spark fresh action,\u201d the CBC reported. The day after her thesis became public, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) called Pearce and asked for access to her research materials.\n\nIn May 2014, the RCMP released its own findings with the most jarring statistics to date: 1,181 aboriginal women had vanished or had been slain between 1980 and 2012. The government report hit Canada like a cold shock. The media splashed the story across front pages and aired angry critics\u2019 voices. Cameron Alexis, a regional chief with the Assembly of First Nations, lamented \u201ca national shame and\u00a0a national tragedy.\u201d Carolyn Bennett, a liberal member of Parliament, declared, \u201cThis is not an aboriginal issue, it is not a women\u2019s issue, it is an ongoing Canadian tragedy.\u201d The office of the U.N. special\u00a0rapporteur\u00a0on the rights of indigenous peoples, HRW, and other international organizations joined the outcry. To\u00a0Lavell-Harvard, the noise was critical. \u201cThe more we got the average Canadian understanding,\u201d she says, \u201cthe more outraged they were to think this was happening in their backyards.\u201d\n\nThe Harper government said it supported improved policing and\u00a0and\u00a0more funding for protective measures such as women\u2019s shelters. Yet it dismissed calls for a national inquiry into the origins of the crisis. When two more young women were brutalized in Winnipeg later that summer, that refusal seemed all the more galling.\n\nTina Fontaine\u00a0was\u00a0a 15-year-old girl living in foster care. On Aug. 9, 2014, she ran away from the Winnipeg hotel where child services was housing her; until a recent policy change, it was a common practice in Manitoba\u2019s overcrowded foster system for authorities to put charges in hotel rooms. Eight days later, Fontaine\u2019s body was found wrapped in a duvet cover in the Red River. The man charged in her slaying, Raymond Cormier, had more than 90 criminal convictions. Police said he was an early suspect, but that they had \u201cnumerous\u201d others to eliminate first. He was finally arrested in December 2015. (Cormier\u2019s case was still in court at press time.)\n\nThree months after Fontaine\u2019s body was recovered,\u00a0Rinelle\u00a0Harper, 16, was found on the banks of the Assiniboine River. She had been sexually assaulted and thrown into the frigid water \u2014 only to crawl out and be attacked again. Unlike Fontaine, she survived. Not only were her assailants arrested within a matter of days,\u00a0but\u00a0Harper was the rare victim to speak publicly about her experience. (She is not related to Stephen Harper.) In December 2014, the shy teenager appeared before a meeting of First Nation elders and called on the Canadian government to take action. In a trembling voice barely above a whisper, Harper said, \u201cI respectfully challenge you all to call for a national inquiry into missing and murdered indigenous women.\u201d\n\nNews of her plea spread across social media \u2014 as did the prime minister\u2019s public statement that a killing was a crime, not a \u201csociological phenomenon.\u201d Holly Jarrett, the cousin of a woman slain in Halifax, posted a photo of herself online with the\u00a0hashtag\u00a0#AmINext. Within hours, aboriginal women nationwide were tweeting photos with the same caption. Veteran activist Bernadette Smith helped organize a volunteer group called Drag the Red, which used nets, chains, and hooks to search the Red River for more human remains. \u201cWe know it\u2019s going to be a challenge,\u201d Smith told the\u00a0Globe and Mail, \u201cbut we have to at least try.\u201d Drag the Red has since handed over snagged evidence, including bones and a bloody carpet, to police.\n\nIn March 2015, a U.N. committee declared that Canada had committed grave violations of indigenous women\u2019s rights by not offering them sufficient protection from violence. It, too, recommended a national inquiry.\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0agreed with the appeal \u2014 with one stipulation: Aboriginal women would need to be in charge. \u201cWe\u2019re not sitting idle,\u201d she told the CBC.\n\nTiming, for once, was on the activists\u2019 side. Public awareness peaked in an election year. Justin Trudeau, Harper\u2019s liberal rival, whose affinity for native cultures was evident in a shoulder tattoo designed by the\u00a0Haida\u00a0people, blasted the prime minister\u2019s opposition to an inquiry.\u00a0 \u201cIf people think they already know what the problem is, then why haven\u2019t they fixed it?\u201d Trudeau asked\u00a0during a\u00a0town hall meeting in October 2015.\u00a0Lavell-Harvard remarks that missing and murdered women becoming a steady part of campaign dialogue marked the first time \u201cthat people outside of the indigenous community saw indigenous issues as their issues.\u201d\n\nCanadians overwhelmingly elected Trudeau last October. One of his first acts was to announce a national inquiry. \u201cThe victims deserve justice,\u201d he told a gathering of First Nation chiefs in Gatineau, Qu\u00e9bec,\u00a0a\u00a0year after\u00a0Rinelle\u00a0Harper\u2019s speech. \u201cTheir families [deserve] an opportunity to heal and to be heard.\u201d\n\nWhen I meet with Carolyn Bennett, now Canada\u2019s minister of indigenous and northern affairs, on a rainy April morning at a hotel on New York\u2019s Upper West Side, she looks more like an activist than a bureaucrat. She\u2019s wearing a red T-shirt emblazoned with the phrase \u201cNo More Stolen Sisters,\u201d which matches her red-framed glasses and the red heart pin on her sleeve. She is slated to speak that day about Canada\u2019s missing and slain women at the Women in the World conference.\n\nBennett, whom Trudeau tapped to craft an inquiry, is in a reflective mood. She recently wrapped up a two-month road trip in which she and her colleagues \u2014 Patty\u00a0Hajdu, minister on the status of women, and Jody Wilson-Raybould, minister of justice \u2014 traveled from British Columbia to Nova Scotia to meet with indigenous communities and survivors of violence to hear what they want from an inquiry.\n\n\u201cThere were people who ran away from the\u00a0Pickton\u00a0farm,\u201d Bennett recalls. \u201cThere were people who were captured and held in a cabin and ran away and ended up in an ER department with bruises around their neck who were now prepared to tell their stories.\u201d Among participants\u2019 requests for the inquiry were that cold cases be prioritized and \u2014 echoing\u00a0Manyfeathers \u2014 that indigenous women take the lead.\n\nThe listening tour made waves when\u00a0Hajdu\u00a0told the press\u00a0that,\u00a0based on what she\u2019d heard from the NWAC and other groups, the number of missing and slain women might top 4,000. \u201cWhen you actually start to add in disputed cases,\u201d\u00a0Hajdu\u00a0said, \u201cfor example, people that it\u2019s been claimed [committed] suicide or a death due to exposure [when] in fact there are symptoms or signs that maybe it wasn\u2019t, then of course the numbers can jump.\u201d\n\nBennett\u2019s office will release a plan for the inquiry this summer, including details on the timeline and who will take the helm. Yet the ultimate goal lies further down the road. \u201cGirls are still going missing and being murdered in numbers that are inexcusable,\u201d Bennett tells me. \u201cWhat do we need to do to actually put an end to this tragedy?\u201d\n\nStemming the crisis could require a combination of police reform, job creation, educational opportunities, domestic violence prevention, substance abuse treatment, improved public transportation, and anti-racism campaigns. Recommending change is easy enough. As British Columbia\u2019s commission proved, however, implementing it is not.\n\nA March poll showed that 79 percent of Canadians\u00a0support the inquiry \u2014 estimated to cost $40 million \u2014 but 48 percent are\u00a0pessimistic that it will bring about real change. Female activists are cautiously optimistic, yet they fear the government could rehash work they\u2019ve already done. \u201cWhat I would hope is that it won\u2019t just tell us that there\u2019s a problem,\u201d says Melina\u00a0Laboucan-Massimo, whose sister\u00a0plummeted from a 36-story condominium in Toronto in 2013. The death was ruled suspicious after police, according to the victim\u2019s family, failed to secure the scene. \u201cWe know that there\u2019s a problem,\u201d\u00a0Laboucan-Massimo continues. \u201cWe don\u2019t need them to spend millions on that.\u201d\n\nAs the inquiry moves forward, many women are continuing the painstaking grassroots work that pushed the government to act.\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0is planning the ninth Justice for Jackie march and has collaborated with a niece, Lauren\u00a0Crazybull, on an audio documentary about violence against indigenous women. It was aired at special events in Calgary, Edmonton, and\u00a0Lethbridge.\n\nAfter breakfast at the diner,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0takes me to her vehicle, a black Equinox. She wants to show me a beaded breastplate she crafted in tribute to her older sister. She wears it when she dances. Standing in the parking lot,\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0unfolds the intricately stitched garment and lays it gently on her SUV\u2019s hood. She points to 12 feathers representing\u00a0Crazybull\u2019s\u00a0children. There\u2019s also a butterfly encircled by a medicine wheel set against a black backdrop with pink trim. \u201cThe black represents the way\u00a0that my\u00a0sister was murdered,\u201d\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0explains. The butterfly symbolizes the stages of grief.\n\nThere are three spots left\u00a0unbeaded, signaling an unfinished storyline. \u201cNobody has ever been charged in Jackie\u2019s murder,\u201d\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0says. \u201c[The perpetrators] continue to live in free society. Canada continues to allow them to do that. I don\u2019t know if they have children now, if they celebrate birthday parties, and Thanksgiving, and Christmas\u2026. But they took my sister\u2019s life, and she doesn\u2019t get to have them.\u201d\n\nIt took\u00a0Manyfeathers\u00a0nine months to make the breastplate. She\u2019s been wearing it for eight years. Lately, though, she\u2019s been thinking about retiring it. It\u2019s not that she\u2019s giving up on finding her sister\u2019s killers or on honoring\u00a0Crazybull\u2019s\u00a0memory. She just feels ready for a change. \u201cIt\u2019s time,\u201d she says.\n\nA version of this article originally appeared in the July/August issue of \u00a0FP\u00a0magazine under the title \u201cThe Sisterhood.\u201d\n\nMarin Cogan is a journalist living in Washington, D.C. {"url": "https://www.mapleridgenews.com/community/maple-ridge-secondary-walks-for-red-dress-day/", "title": "Maple Ridge Secondary walks for Red Dress Day - Maple Ridge-Pitt Meadows News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n25.9 \u00b0C\n!\nHome Community\nMaple Ridge Secondary walks for Red Dress Day\nA goal of walking 725 kilimetres was half complete an hour into event\n\tColleen Flanagan\n\nMay 6, 2023 6:00 PM\nMay 11, 2023 9:53 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 10 Grade 5 Golden Ears Elementary student Raphael Jo, takes part in a walk for Red Dress Day hosted by the Circle of Indigenous Youth and Allies, an Indigenous leadership group at MRSS. (Colleen Flanagan/The News)\nExpand\n\nThe rain was more like a mist \u2013 at first \u2013 before the larger droplets started falling from the sky.\n\nIt was almost as if tears literally started falling from the heavens for each lap walked and each woman\u2019s story read during Maple Ridge Secondary\u2019s Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women\u2019s walk on Friday, May 5 \u2013 commonly known as Red Dress Day in Canada and the United States.\n\nGrade 10 Maple Ridge Secondary student Nye Holmes, a member of the Circle of Indigenous Youth and Allies, an Indigenous leadership group at MRSS who was hosting the event, explained the event was not only being held to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada, but particularly those who have gone missing along what is called the Highway of Tears \u2013 a 725 kilometre stretch of Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert, along which nine young women went missing or were discovered murdered between 1989 to 2006. All but one of the women were Indigenous, according to the Carrier Sekani Family Services\u2019 Highway of Tears governing body, a group dedicated to stopping the violence along the highway.\n\nThe leadership group was hoping that the community would come together to walk the same distance as the Highway of Tears around the track at MRSS. And only an hour into the walk that was set to take place from 9-5 p.m. the group was already half way to their goal with many participants walking, even running, multiple laps of the 400 metre track.\n\nREAD MORE: Maple Ridge students asking community to march for murdered and missing Indigenous women\n\nALSO: \u2018We are in a crisis\u2019: Red Dress Day honoured as leaders say more work to be done\n\nNye explained that many women have gone missing along Highway 16 because there are no cell towers or bus routes.\n\n\u201cA lot of women go missing along this highway because there\u2019s just no way to get from one community to another without walking or hitchhiking,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cSo, we\u2019re trying to get people of our community to walk the same walk that these women did when they went missing,\u201d she said.\n\nEvery 14 kilometres walked was marked with a moccasin sticker on a map of the Highway of Tears, made by MRSS art teacher David Xavier.\n\nThe group invited other schools and community groups to participate, within Maple Ridge and surrounding communities.\n\nKelli Paddon, Parliamentary Secretary for Gender Equity in BC, said that for everyone who holds a red dress as a symbol of sorrow, outrage and action against the murder and harm of Indigenous women, girls, Two-Spirit and non-binary people on Red Dress Day, that she stands with them as a voice in the government.\n\n\u201cHarm against women, girls, Two-Spirit and non-binary people is preventable. Ending this violence means confronting biases and stereotypes. It means speaking up when someone is being treated badly. It means offering help and support when someone is unsafe or is at risk,\u201d said Paddon.\n\n\u201cWe have lost far too many women, girls, Two-Spirit and gender-diverse people to gender-based violence. We will continue to raise awareness, support survivors and families \u2014 and tackle the root causes of this violence in our communities,\u201d she said.\n\n* If you are in immediate danger, or think someone else is, call 911. You can also call, email or text VictimLink BC through its toll-free 24/7 confidential, multilingual telephone service at 1 800 563-0808 or: VictimLinkBC@bc211.ca.\n\nHave a story tip? Then those who wish to share can do so at the open mic.\n\nThe event will then move to Komasket Park on the reserve at 1 p.m. The afternoon portion will include workshops on self defense and healthy relationships. The afternoon will conclude with a community meal and screening of River of Silence.\n\nSee: $10,000 reward offered for information on missing Shuswap the Kelowna Courthouse\nPeople gathered to honour the lives of the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls\nSydney Morton\nOct 4, 2018 7:18 PM\nOct 4, 2018 7:59 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\nA sea of red marched to the Kelowna Courthouse to the sound of drums for the Sisters in Spirit march for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women.\n\nWith signs raised high with the names and faces of women that have gone missing leaving their friends and family without answers.\n\n\u201cSo many people have suffered and so many people are still suffering,\u201d said Karen Vircabs who still has no answers about her niece\u2019s death and disappearance. \u201cMy heart goes out to all the families that have suffered and for some of these (lost)women they haven\u2019t even lied yet, some of them have run away to find another place.\u201d\n\n\u201cI am walking to honour all of our sisters,\u201dsaid Ali Butler. \u201cWe have to continually bring awareness to the injustices faced for indigenous women and people and that we have to keep fighting.. for acknowledgement that this is a serious issue in Canada.\u201d\n\nHolding red dresses in the air, Charity Celesta and Raylene Alphonse hope to show people that women are still going missing.\n\n\u201cA lot of times people think that this is a thing of the past and it\u2019s something that is still alive and happening, women are still going missing,\u201d said Celesta. \u201cOur communities are so interconnected it\u2019s always someone that we know or there is a relationship there.\u201d\n\nRELATED: Red Dress Walk strolls through North Okanagan\n\nThe use of the red dresses to represent Missing and Turdered Indigenous Women and Girls was started by M\u00e9tis artist, Jamie Back in 2010.\n\n\u201cShe picked red because spirits can see red,\u201d Alphonse said. \u201cI feel like everyone knows someone that is missing.\u201d\n\n\u201cThrough the installation I hope to draw attention to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Aboriginal women and to evoke a presence through the marking of absence,\u201d reads Black\u2019s artist statement about The REDress Project.\n\n\u201cToday red dresses continue to be used across Canada as a representation of the Indigenous women and girls lost to violent crime and as a call for action to prevent future violence,\u201d reads a statement from the Government of Canada.\n\nIndigenous women are six times higher to die from homicide than that of non-Indigenous women in Canada according to Statistics Canada. Indigenous victims are over-represented in the territories and prairies, with Nunavut having the highest mortality rate.\n\nFor more information about The REDress project visit {"url": "https://www.interior-news.com/news/refuge-to-house-indigenous-women-fleeing-abuse-on-highway-of-tears/", "title": "Refuge to house Indigenous women fleeing abuse on Highway of Tears - The Smithers Interior News", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAutos\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n21.6 \u00b0C\nHome News\nRefuge to house Indigenous women fleeing abuse on Highway of Tears\nSafe house being constructed at Lake Babine Nation reserve in Burns Lake\nDavid Koch\nMay 28, 2018 10:52 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nOfficials held a groundbreaking ceremony for a safe house at Lake Babine Nation\u2019s Woyenne reserve. Pictured left to right are Rod Hill of the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, Cheslatta Carrier Nation chief Corrina Leween \u2014 who is also president of Carrier Sekani Family Services \u2014 Chief Wilf Adam of Lake Babine Nation and Burns Lake Mayor Chris Beach.\n\nIndigenous women and children fleeing violence on the Highway of Tears are expected to have access to a new shelter by early next year.\n\nOn May 25, a ceremony featuring traditional drummers took place at the planned construction site, on Lake Babine Nation\u2019s (LBN) Woyenne reserve in Burns Lake, where dignitaries placed shovels in the ground to mark the beginning of the project.\n\nThe planned facility is meant to serve as temporary housing, with seven units housing up to 23 women and children who identify as First Nations.\n\nMabel Louie, director of health services for Carrier Sekani Family Services (CSFS) \u2014 the Prince George-based organization that\u2019s partnering with LBN to build the shelter \u2014 recalled how a shelter became indispensable for a loved one fleeing violence.\n\n\u201cThey made sure she was safe, made sure the children were safe,\u201d said Louie. The safe house, which also provided counselling and other services, probably saved that woman\u2019s life, she said.\n\nAddictions services, counselling\n\n\u201cOur goal is the safety of the victims and their families,\u201d said LBN Chief Wilf Adam.\n\nAdam noted that treatment will be available for people with addictions, along with preventative services to keep people from falling into cycles of drug or alcohol abuse.\n\nCSFS said the facility will feature programming specific to the Carrier people. \u201cServices will empower women to live healthy lives and build healthy relationships and circles of support,\u201d according to the CSFS.\n\nSafe houses stigmatized\n\nAdam told the Lakes District News that stigma around people who may occupy safe houses resulted in some resistance to hosting the shelter locally.\n\nBut he said those concerns aren\u2019t warranted, and that similar facilities are \u201cthe safest places around\u201d and often impossible to distinguish from the surrounding homes. He added that the facility will have 24-hour security.\n\nCSFS said in a statement that the facility will have an unlisted address and phone number and will be ringed by fencing with secured access, along with security cameras.\n\nIndigenous-owned and operated\n\nCSFS obtained $1.89 million in federal money from the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) for the safe house. LBN will hold the mortgage, which will be gradually paid for by CSFS, said Adam.\n\nUltimately, LBN will hold the assets, making it a First Nations owned and operated facility. The building is expected to open next spring.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tNorthwest B.C. author pens book about logging\n\t\tTeen dies after overdose involving fentanyl in northern B.C.: RCMP\n\t\t'You shattered her life': 3 years for sexual assault of young Kelowna woman\n\t\tTom Havard is this year\u2019s Hudson Bay Mountain Legendary Local\n\t\tMan dies throwing candy during Alberta Canada Day parade\nFacebook Comments (0) \nMan who stabbed Mexican tourist at B.C. This day is also known as \u201cRed Dress Day\u201d.\n\nMembers of the Indigenous community and their allies wear and display red dresses to honor missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQI+ people in Canada and the United States.\n\nVANCOUVER, May 5, 2021 \u2014 People attend a Red Dress Day event to commemorate missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in front of City Hall in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, on May 5 May 2021. May 5 is National Awareness Day for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada, also known as Red Dress Day. People across Canada held events and dressed in red on Wednesday to commemorate missing and murdered Indigenous people. (Photo by Liang Sen/Xinhua via Getty Images) (Xinhua/Liang Sen via Getty Images)\n\nAccording to the Native Hope Organization, the National Crime Information Center reported 5,712 reports of missing American Indian and Alaska Native women and girls through the U.S. Department of Justice's federal missing persons database in 2016 The National Missing and Unidentified Persons System has recorded only 116 cases. .\n\nM\u00e9tis artist Jaime Black launched the red dress movement in 2010 as \u201can aesthetic response to this crucial national issue.\u201d\n\nThe commemoration includes marches, rallies, bike rides and fundraisers to raise awareness about MMIW and combat the derogatory injustice that Indigenous women face. Many allies put red paint on their hands and cover their mouths to signify how indigenous people have been silenced. Participants also held signs saying: \u201cNo more stolen sisters.\u201d\n\nSources\n\n1/ https://Google.com/\n\n2/\u00a0https://www.kron4.com/news/the-significance-of-red-dress-day/\n\nThe mention sources can contact us to remove/changing this article\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online\n\nLOS ANGELES, CA / ACCESSWIRE / June 24, 2020, / Compare-autoinsurance.Org has launched a new blog post that presents the main benefits of comparing multiple car insurance quotes. View photos The advantages of comparing online car insurance quotes are the following: Online quotes can be obtained from anywhere and at any time. Unlike physical insurance agencies, websites don't have a specific schedule and they are available at any time. Drivers that have busy working schedules, can compare quotes from anywhere and at any time, even at midnight. Multiple choices. Almost all insurance providers, no matter if they are well-known brands or just local insurers, have an online presence. Online quotes will allow policyholders the chance to discover multiple insurance companies and check their prices. Drivers are no longer required to get quotes from just a few known insurance companies. Also, local and regional insurers can provide lower insurance rates for the same services. Usually, insurance companies will do research about a potential customer before granting him coverage. Online quotes can be sorted easily. Although drivers are recommended to not choose a policy just based on its price, drivers can easily sort quotes by insurance price.
