{"url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Vernon/333039/Red-Dress-Day-marks-another-year-since-women-went-missing-in-the-North-Okanagan", "title": "Red Dress Day marks another year since women went missing in the North Okanagan - Vernon News - Castanet.net", "body": "27\u00b0C\ncity\n\u2039\n\u203a\nKelowna's Homepage\n\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\u25cf\nThursday, Jul 4\nOBITSAUTOMALLEVENTSCAMSTANGO\nHOME\nBC\nCANADA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nSPORTS\nSHOWBIZ\nCLASSIFIEDS\nREAL ESTATE\nOPINION\nOUR TOWN\nWEATHER\nVernon\u00a0\u00a0\nRed Dress Day marks another year since women went missing in the North Okanagan\n5 YEARS WITHOUT CLOSURE\nJon Manchester - May 5, 2021 / 12:22 pm | Story: 333039\nPhoto: Contributed\n\nFive years have passed since women began going missing in the rural North Okanagan.\n\nAnd, as Canada marks another National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, there has yet to be closure for the families of Nicole Bell, Deanna Wertz, Ashley Simpson and Caitlin Potts.\n\nAll four women went missing in the area between Enderby, Silver Creek and Sicamous.\n\nMay 5, also known as Red Dress Day, celebrates the memory of the more than 1,000 missing women in Canada. It started in 2010, with the bright dresses often seen hanging in doorways and windows as a visual reminder.\n\nBetween 2001 to 2015, Statistics Canada reports the homicide rate for Indigenous women was nearly six times higher than that of non-Indigenous women.\n\nCaitlin Potts went missing from the Enderby area in February, 2016.\n\nShe has not been heard from since making contact with friends on social media Feb. 26 that year.\n\nThe 27-year-old First Nations woman was reported missing March 1, 2016.\n\nAshley Simpson, 31, disappeared on April 28, 2016. She lived in the Yankee Flats area near Silver Creek.\n\nLife \"changed that day that someone took her, five years of pain and anguish, five years of hope and praying five years of searching for the answers but still nothing,\" her father, John Simpson, posted on Facebook.\n\nOn July 22, 2016, 46-year-old Deanna Mildred Wertz was reported missing from the Enderby area.\n\nShortly after her disappearance, police searched eight square kilometres by land and air, focusing on the Yankee Flats area.\n\nWertz was an experienced hiker, and investigators appealed to anyone who may have been travelling off-road near Yankee Flats on the morning of July 19.\n\nNicole Bell, 31, was reported missing Sept. 7, 2017 from the Sicamous area.\n\nHer mother, Jane Aubertin, travelled from Calgary to join a rally at the Vernon courthouse last month for the missing women.\n\nThe only publicized break in the missing women cases came in October 2017, when the remains of Vernon teen Traci Genereaux were found on a Salmon River Road farm following an extensive police investigation.\n\nGenereaux was last heard from on May 29 that year.\n\nPolice called her death suspicious, but no charges have been filed in the case.\n\nPhoto: Contributed\n\nBack to Homepage\n\nTypos\nNews Tips\nForums\n\nMUST-READ STORIES\n\nGet all the day's most vital news with our newsletter, sent every weekday.\n\n\n\nMore Vernon News\n\n\n\nRECENT STORIES\nHuge majority for Labour?\nUnited Kingdom - CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News Channel\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nCALGARY\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nLOCAL\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nCALGARY\nNews\nRed dresses honour memory of murdered and missing Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people\nStephen Hunt\nCTVNewsCalgary.ca Digital Producer\nFollow |Contact\nStephanie Thomas\nCTV News Calgary Video Journalist\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2023 7:57 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2023 7:14 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nRed dresses were waving in the wind, in windows, from trees and other special places across Canada on Friday.\n\nFriday was National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People, or Red Dress Day.\n\nAt the Field of Crosses in Calgary, people hung little red cut-outs in the shape of a dress.\n\nIt's an important symbol of Indigenous tradition, which honours the memories of missing or lost loved ones.\n\nRELATED STORIES\n'Opportunity to create awareness': Dozens gather for Red Dress Day in Lethbridge\n\nWhile it's an important day for awareness and healing, many Indigenous leaders say they want to see swift government action as well.\n\nSiksika Nation hosted an awareness walk, around the fields in the heart of the community.\n\nParticipants wore red, and ribbon skirts in honour of their loved ones.\n\n\"(Red Dress Day is meant) to educate the Canadian society (about) who we are,\" said Leanne Sleigh, Siksika Nation's traditional wellness program co-ordinator. \"The strength that we have in each of us.\"\n\nSiksika leaders said it's important to come together like they did on Friday.\n\n\"To help those people that are affected directly by a family member that has gone missing or been murdered,\" said Sleigh.\n\n\"That loss,\" she added. \"They need closure.\"\n\nSeveral Siksika members are grieving without answers about their loved ones.\n\n\"These events bring back those moments,\" said Flora Royal Old Yellow Woman, whose brother Fred has been missing since June 2011. He was last seen in Kamloops, B.C.\n\nShe said gathering with the community helps with healing.\n\n\"It helps me to know that the public, the community, are with us remembering our loved ones that are still missing and not found today.\"\n\nOver at Mount Royal University, red dresses were an important symbol for lives lost.\n\nThe final report into missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls and two-spirit people released in 2019, found that they are 12 times more likely to be murdered or go missing than any other group.\n\nBack at Siksika, leaders say they want the federal government to follow through on the 231 calls for justice \u2013 and to provide more mental health support.\n\n\"We're not done yet,\" said Sleigh.\" We're not done. We're moving forward.\"\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nAt the Field of Crosses in Calgary, people hung little red cut-outs in the shape of a dress.\nReport an error\nEditorial standards & policies\nWhy you The travelling exhibit is in the third year of bringing the powerful reality to communities across the Pembina Valley and to honour the lives of each Manitoban who has never made it home. \u00a0\n\nPembina Valley Red Dress Project (PVRDP) Member Christina Cearns said as an Indigenous woman, who was taken from her reserve and adopted into a non-Indigenous home, it was important for her to join this group.\n\n\"I have joined the Pembina Valley Red Dress Project because it is something dear to my heart, me being an Indigenous woman myself, and understanding the impact it has on the Indigenous community. Along with the children that we have as a montage.\"\u00a0\n\nPVRDP Denise Thiessen and Christina Cearns\n\nAn \"Every Child Matters\" portion of the exhibit had a tree of Orange Shirts with children's shoes leading up to the \"Every Child Matters\" banner in remembrance of the many children who never made it home from Residential Schools and the abuse of those who survived.\n\nEvery Child Matters Display\n\nEcole Morden Middle School students made dresses that hung in a tree with positive words said to indigenous women on one side and negative words on the other.\u00a0\n\nEMMS MMIWG2S Art Project\u00a0\n\nCearns explained why it is important to bring awareness to MMIGW2S.\n\n\"It's a time to grieve. It is a grieving, but it's also an honouring system as well, all in one. With suffering comes compassion. And with that, we can grow as a community on that, by sharing that, and in our history as well.\"\u00a0\n\nOne tree has several red dresses with names embroidered in them, representing families living in the Pembina Valley with a missing or murdered loved one.\u00a0\n\nCearns said she was able to share her own story with people too. \u00a0\n\n\"The impact it has had and then sharing your story with them on the whole aspect of just being adopted out off the reserve to some of the people and then listening to their stories come back. And then, having that time of healing. To cry together, to share that story, listen to what is going on, and then share the perspective of why this is important and why it's becoming a huge thing in our country.\" \u00a0\n\nCearns talks with exhibit guest\n\nExecutive Director for Genesis House Ang Braun explained why the organization took part in the exhibit.\u00a0\n\n\"Indigenous women and girls are at a significantly higher risk than the rest of the population in Canada to experience gender-based violence. And so, the more light we can shed on that whole topic; historically, what has happened and where we are today and what we need to see going forward, it's important that we're present at these events so that people know where they can go for help, but also, we can't hang red dresses every day. And so, when we're not hanging red dresses, what are we each doing in our daily lives that supports ending this tragedy?\" \u00a0\n\nCearns said learning about Indigenous culture was part of the conversations with people who took time to come through the parks. She was able to explain bead making and smudging to the many eager to learn.\u00a0\n\n\"Most of them, when they come and they talk, if they have Indigenous background, it's been the same thing on what their stories were and just not having a voice, and them seeing this and the sad reminder over here. (Pointing to the Red Dresses on display) It is sad, but in a beautiful way, we're calling them back home.\"\u00a0\n\nThe PV Red Dress Project will be in Killarney Park June 3rd and in Morden for Indigenous Day June 24th. the Fall to Honour Lives of Indigenous Women Lost on the Highway of Tears | CFNR Network", "body": " Menu\nListen Live\nNews\nOn-Air\nWin\nEvents\nFeatured\nNOW PLAYING\nBOULEVARDOFBROKENDREAMS(EDIT)\nGREEN DAY\nNew Commemorative Pillars Coming in the Fall to Honour Lives of Indigenous Women Lost on the Highway of Tears\nBy Jeff Blagden\nMay 5, 2022 | 3:32 PM\n\nA new project has been announced to commemorate the lives of Indigenous women lost along the Highway of Tears.\n\nIn honour of the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, a gathering was held to announce the project today.\n\nDubbed the Pillars of Hope and Strength, the project was introduced by the Governing Body of the Highway of Tears in Prince George today.\n\nLed by Carrier Sekani Family Services, with support from Indigenous Services Canada, the project will see two unique pillars installed along Highway 16.\n\nEach pillar will be carved by local Indigenous artists out of red cedar, under the direction of renowned Haida carver Keith Kerrigan.\n\nExpected to be raised in the fall, the Pillar of Hope will find a home in Prince George, while the Pillar of Strength will go to the other end of the Highway, in Prince Rupert.\n\nFor more information on the project, including how to help fund the project and raise awareness, visit this link.\n\nEnvironment and Climate Change Canada Issues Heat Warning for North Coast-Inland Region\n42m ago\n 1 View\nEmergency Department Service Interruption at Kitimat General Hospital Today\n4h At least 60 people assembled at Annie Pootoogook Park in Ottawa\u2019s Sandy Hill neighbourhood for an afternoon vigil to mark what is more commonly referred to as Red Dress Day. The event was organized by Tungasuvvingat Inuit, and it featured political speakers, drumming and throat singing. {"url": "http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/news/local-news/b-c-transit-seeking-public-input-on-proposed-highway-of-tears-service-1.2325325", "title": "B.C. Transit seeking public input on proposed Highway of Tears service - Prince George Citizen", "body": "Skip to content\nJOIN OUR NEWSLETTER 21.2 \u00b0C \nNEWS\nOPINION\nFEATURES\nLIFE EVENTS\nLOCAL EVENTS\nHome Local News\nB.C. Transit seeking public input on proposed Highway of Tears service\nB.C. Transit has launched an online survey to gauge public support for its proposed scheduling and stops along Highway 16 West. The survey is available through bctransit.com/highway16 until Sept. 16.\nMark Nielsen\nAug 17, 2016 4:49 PM\n\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nAn image of the proposed stops along the Prince George-Burns Lake service B.C. Transit is considering for this section of Highway 16 West.\n\nB.C. Transit has launched an online survey to gauge public support for its proposed scheduling and stops along Highway 16 West.\n\nThe survey is available through bctransit.com/highway16 until Sept. 16.\n\nOpportunities for first-hand looks at the proposed plans will also be available this Saturday at the B.C. Northern Exhibition in Prince George, 4-8 p.m. and at the Nechako Valley Exhibition in Vanderhoof, 9 a.m.-1 p.m.\n\n\"The engagement process will assist us in designing a system that will meet the needs of our customers and the communities along Highway 16,\" said B.C. Transit president and CEO Manuel Achadinha in a statement. \"It is important that we hear from as many people as possible through the engagement process.\"\n\nB.C. Transit is proposing to offer four services along the route - between Prince George and Burns Lake, Burns Lake and Smithers, between Kispiox and Terrace and between Terrace and between Terrace and Prince Rupert - with stops at various communities in between.\n\nThe proposed fare is $5 cash per trip or 10 trips for $45.\n\nRespondents are asked whether they support those routes, which two days they would like to see them run, whether the proposed schedules work for them and whether they support the proposed fares.\n\nThe federal and provincial governments have committed $5 million over three years to an \"action plan\" to improve transportation along the 725-kilometre stretch.\n\nIn addition to bus service along the main route, it includes funding for webcams and bus shelters, a grant program to help outlying First Nations communities to buy shuttle vehicles and to provide driver education to boost the number of Class 4 and 5 drivers in those communities.\n\nB.C. Transit will cover two-thirds of the cost of the bus service and participating communities the remaining one-third. The more typical arrangement sees B.C. Transit cover 55 per cent.\n\nAlso known as the Highway of Tears, 18 women have been murdered or have disappeared along Highway 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert and adjacent routes since the 1970s.\n\nB.C. Transit aims to have the first inter-city buses in service by the end of this year with the rest on the road in 2017.\n\nLeave a comment\nHave a story idea?\nReport a mistake\nThis has not been shared. {"url": "https://kitchener.ctvnews.ca/queen-victoria-statue-in-kitchener-doused-in-red-paint-1.5890256", "title": "Queen Victoria statue in Kitchener doused in red paint | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News At Five\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nKITCHENER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nKITCHENER\nNews\nQueen Victoria statue in Kitchener doused in red paint\n04:08\nKitchener says it will leave red paint on statue\n01:41\nQueen Victoria statue in Kitchener defaced\nStephanie Villella\nCTV News Kitchener Videographer\nFollow |Contact\nAlison Sandstrom\nCTVNewsKitchener.ca Digital Content Producer\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated May 5, 2022 6:07 p.m. MDT\nPublished May 5, 2022 11:06 a.m. MDT\nShare\n\nA controversial Kitchener statue has been vandalized again.\n\nRed paint was found splattered over the base of the statue of Queen Victoria at Victoria Park on Thursday.\n\nThe monument was vandalized twice over the summer as hundreds of unmarked graves were found at former residential schools across Canada. Calls have been made to remove it due to its connection to Canada\u2019s colonialist past.\n\nThe outcry prompted the city to install signage in front of the statue that reads in part: \u201cThe cultural harm and erasure inflicted on First Nations, Inuit and M\u00e9tis peoples is a direct result of this colonialism. The City of Kitchener acknowledges that the presence of this statue in Victoria Park may contribute to that ongoing harm.\u201d\n\nRELATED STORIES\nVigil marks Red Dress Day in Kitchener\nIndigenous women more likely to face violence if they were a child in care: report\nDespite new signage, advocates continue to call for removal of Queen Victoria statue in Kitchener\n\nThose signs were also covered in paint Thursday. Waterloo regional police were seen at Victoria Park investigating.\n\nWhile the exact reason why the statue was defaced at this time in not known, Thursday marked Red Dress Day, an annual day which honours Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls.\n\nCITY WILL NOT REMOVE PAINT\n\nIn a statement to CTV, the City of Kitchener said \u201cfor the time being\u201d it will not remove the paint.\n\nThe city said it acknowledges the statue and the colonial legacy it represents \u201ccontributes to the ongoing harm of Indigenous peoples.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe continue to work with municipal partners and local Indigenous, racialized and marginalized communities to move towards reconciliation and a more equitable city. This includes making decisions about our statues, place names and more,\u201d the city\u2019s statement said in part.\n\nRELATED IMAGES\n1 / 1\nThe base of the Queen Victoria statue at Victoria Park in Kitchener is seen covered in red paint on May 5, 2022. {"url": "https://kitchener.ctvnews.ca/timeline-consultation-and-controversy-over-kitchener-s-queen-victoria-statue-1.6863718", "title": "Timeline: Consultation and controversy over Kitchener's Queen Victoria statue | CTV News", "body": "Skip to main content\nLIVE\nCTV News At Five\n(OPENS IN A NEW TAB)\nKITCHENER\nNEWS\nVIDEO\nSHOWS\nABOUT\nACROSS CANADA\nSearch CTVNews.ca\nSearch\nBREAKING NEWS: U.K. Labour Party headed for landslide victory over Conservatives\nADVERTISEMENT\nKITCHENER\nNews\nTimeline: Consultation and controversy over Kitchener's Queen Victoria statue\n03:22\nThe future of Kitchener\u2019s Queen Victoria statue\n03:02\nWhat\u2019s next for the Queen Victoria statue?\n02:17\nFeedback on Queen Victoria statue needed\n02:16\nDiscussing Kitchener\u2019s Queen Victoria statue\n04:08\nKitchener says it will leave red paint on statue\n02:10\nQueen Victoria statue vandalized twice this summer\n02:32\nQueen Victoria statue covered in red paint\nKrista Simpson\nCTV News Kitchener Videographer\nFollow |Contact\nUpdated April 26, 2024 4:16 p.m. MDT\nPublished April 26, 2024 3:09 p.m. MDT\nShare\n\nNearly two years have passed since the City of Kitchener laid out a plan to determine the future of the Queen Victoria statue in Victoria Park.\n\nCommunity consultations on the controversial monument took place in November 2023, but in January 2023 the project was paused and there\u2019s been no major update since. The delay has left some local Indigenous community leaders feeling frustrated and disrespected.\u00a0\n(opens in a new tab)\n\nHere\u2019s a look back at the process so far:\n\nJuly 1, 2021 \u2013 The statue is found doused in red paint \n(opens in a new tab)\nearly in the morning on Canada Day. The city begins cleaning it the following day, but it is several days before the job is completed.\n\nRed paint doused over the Queen Victoria statue in Kitchener's Victoria Park. (Tegan Versolatto/CTV Kitchener) (July 1, 2021)\n\nAug.15, 2021 \u2013 The statue is once again covered in red paint\n(opens in a new tab)\n and is cleaned up.\n\nSept. 29, 2021 \u2013 Ahead of the first National Day for Truth and Reconciliation, the City of Kitchener installs signage next to the statue indicating that it may contribute to ongoing harm. The signs also say the city is working with local Indigenous groups towards reconciliation, including decisions on the future of such monuments.\n\nMay 5, 2022 \u2013 The statue is once again covered in red paint on Red Dress Day, a day bringing awareness to missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and two-spirit people. The City of Kitchener says it will not immediately remove the paint\n(opens in a new tab)\n this time.\n\nMay 16, 2022 \u2013 Eleven days after the latest red paint was discovered on the statue, the city removes it.\n\nPaint is seen on the Queen Victoria Statue in Victoria Park in Kitchener on May 25, 2022. (Dan Lauckner/CTV News)\n\nMay 23-25, 2022 \u2013 Sometime around Victoria Day, the statue is once again covered in red paint. It is cleaned off by the city within a couple of days.\n\nJune 8, 2022 \u2013 A City of Kitchener committee approves a recommendation from staff \n(opens in a new tab)\nto conduct a review and consultation on the statue\u2019s future.\n\nJune 20, 2022 \u2013 City Council formally ratifies the plan to begin public consultations on the statue. A decision is expected to be implemented by May or June 2023. The cost is estimated between $15,000 and $30,000. Staff are also directed to commission new temporary public artwork that recognizes Indigenous Peoples on the site while the engagement process occurs.\n\nOct. 26, 2022 \u2013 The City of Kitchener announces it has hired Jay Pitter Placemaking\n(opens in a new tab)\n to lead community consultations on the statue\u2019s future. One Instagram live and three in-person community discussions are planned between November 2022 and February 2023.\n\nNov. 1, 2022 \u2013 The Instagram Live discussion with Jay Pitter takes place. The city says some of the common questions included if the outcome of the process has already been determined, and how people can be involved in the discussions. The city says there are three options for the statue\u2019s future: removal, contextualization or the commission of another piece that would stand alongside the statue.\n\nNov. 24, 2022 \u2013 One of the in-person community forums\n(opens in a new tab)\n on the statue\u2019s future is held.\n\nDec. 1, 2023 \u2013 The city says an in-person session on the statue\u2019s future scheduled for Dec. 9 will be rescheduled to early 2023.\n\nJan. 30, 2023 \u2013 The City of Kitchener announces it has completed phase one of the consultations\n(opens in a new tab)\n, Jay Pitter has completed her work on the project, and the city will be taking a slower approach moving forward.\n\nJune 29, 2023 \u2013 For the fifth time since July 2021, the statue is found covered in red paint. The city says it will be cleaned at a cost of approximately $3,000.\n\nReport an error\nEditorial standards & policies\nWhy you can trust CTV News\nADVERTISEMENT\nADVERTISEMENT\nMUST WATCH\n\nFor King {"url": "https://www.reddeeradvocate.com/news/canada-manitoba-to-develop-red-dress-alert-for-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls-7353687", "title": "Canada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls - Red Deer Advocate", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nJobs\nObituaries\n20.0 \u00b0C\nHome News\nCanada, Manitoba to develop Red Dress Alert for missing Indigenous women and girls\nThe Canadian Press\nMay 3, 2024 4:45 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nListen to this article\n00:04:50\n\nCanada and Manitoba are partnering to launch an alert system that would inform the public when an Indigenous woman or girl goes missing, they announced Friday in Winnipeg, ahead of a national day to mark the crisis.\n\nThe long-awaited Red Dress Alert system is a bid to prevent deaths and increase safe reunions with loved ones.\n\nStatistics Canada concluded in a report last year that the homicide rate for Indigenous women and girls was six times higher than the rate for their non-Indigenous counterparts.\n\nA national inquiry concluded five years ago that they are 12 times more likely to go missing or murdered.\n\n\u201cThis is a historic moment, and a major step toward ending the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse peoples,\u201d said NDP MP Leah Gazan, who has lead federal advocacy on the alert.\n\n\u201cAnd while we celebrate this historic moment, it is critical to remember that we are not done until a Red Dress Alert is no longer needed.\u201d\n\nThe Manitoba pilot is to be designed with and led by Indigenous Peoples, and is expected to help inform an eventual national alert system.\n\nIt will be funded through moneys set aside in this year\u2019s federal and provincial budgets.\n\nNahanni Fontaine, Manitoba\u2019s minister for women and gender equity, said she has heard from community members who believe the alert system could help reduce risk for Indigenous women and girls.\n\n\u201cWe look forward to working inclusively with Indigenous partners in Manitoba to find the best path forward as we build this pilot project.\u201d\n\nCrown-Indigenous Relations Minister Gary Anandasangaree said Winnipeg \u2014 and Manitoba writ large \u2014 is the epicentre of the crisis, and launching the Red Dress Alert there will bring forward solutions that can be implemented across the country.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not the only solution, but it\u2019s a critical starting point for us to address the immediate crisis that exists.\u201d\n\nGazan\u2019s efforts on the file led a House of Commons committee to study the prospect for a national alert system.\n\nHer fellow MPs unanimously backed her motion in the House of Commons last year declaring the deaths and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls a Canada-wide emergency.\n\nThe motion also called on the federal government to fund a new alert system that would operate much like Amber Alerts.\n\nOther North American jurisdictions already have similar alert systems, including Washington state\u2019s Missing Indigenous Person system.\n\nThe national inquiry\u2019s 2019 final report found deliberate rights violations were at the heart of violence against Indigenous women, girls and gender-diverse people.\n\nWith the final report came 231 calls to justice directed toward governments, social service providers, industry and Canadians, but relatively little progress has been made to date.\n\nSheila North, former grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak and an ex-journalist, has been a vocal advocate in ending violence against Indigenous women.\n\nShe said that while news of an alert system is welcome, she hopes expectations are kept reasonable \u2014 at least for now.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s going to be bumps in the road \u2014 there\u2019s going to be challenges that maybe none of us see right now,\u201d she said. \u201cInevitably, someone is going to be disappointed.\u201d\n\nBut it\u2019s the starting point that matters, she said. \u201cI think it\u2019s high time.\u201d\n\nTo those who may not see the value in an alert system for Indigenous women, North said people of that identity have been shut out of many parts of society \u201cfor so long,\u201d and the deaths \u201care a result of it.\u201d\n\nThe House of Commons committee studying the alert has heard testimony from experts who stress any system should be Indigenous-led.\n\nThat\u2019s in part to mitigate the problems of police inaction and bureaucratic red tape, so that members of the public are notified of a disappearance promptly and efficiently.\n\nJennifer Jesty, who serves as the resiliency manager for the Union of Nova Scotia Mi\u2019kmaq, spoke to MPs about her own efforts to get an emergency alert system running for her communities and attempts to minimize police interference.\n\nSince September 2020, Jesty told the committee in late March that she sent out 183 alerts and reunited 67 people with their families as a result \u2014 the vast majority of whom were brought back together with their families within an hour of the alert going out.\n\n\u201cBecause this system was designed by us, for us, we were able to create our own protocols around when, how and why an alert should or shouldn\u2019t be sent,\u201d Jesty said.\n\n\u201cThere has not been one single request for an alert that has been denied, and every single alert has been sent out within minutes of receiving the information.\u201d\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tCougar spotted on Red Deer park trail\n\t\tVehicles collide in front of Women on Red Dress Day\nDaily Herald -\nMay 5, 2023\n 0\nA few Prince Albert residents gather for a brief ceremony at the Sisters in Spirit monument on the riverbank. -- Donna Pfeil/Daily Herald\n\nThe Sisters in Spirit monument on the riverbank in Prince Albert saw a number of people gathered for a brief ceremony Friday morning in honour of Red Dress Day.\n\nMay 5 marks the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit people (MMIWG2S). Every year on the fifth day of May, red dresses are hung on display to honour the victims, survivors, and those impacted by the ongoing crisis of gender-based and racialized violence faced by Canada\u2019s Indigenous population.\n\nRed Dress Day was inspired by Winnipeg artist Jaime Black\u2019s The REDress Project, an art installation in which red dresses were hung in public spaces around North America as a visual reminder of the absent women who will never have the chance to wear them.\n\nIn 2014, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) released a report stating that a total of 1,181 Indigenous women and girls were killed or went missing in Canada between 1980 and 2012, based on incidents reported to all police jurisdictions across Canada.\n\nHowever, research conducted by the Native Women\u2019s Association of Canada estimated that number is actually closer to 4,000.\n\nJust before Red Dress Day on May 4, the House of Commons passed a motion tabled by NDP critic for women and gender equity, Leah Gazan, declaring the crisis of MMIWG2S a national emergency.\n\nTAGS\nRed dress day\nPrevious article\nPrince Albert business community \u2018punching above its weight class\u2019 says upcoming chamber speaker\nNext article\nWatsonairs seek to lift spirits with annual spring concert\nDaily Herald\nhttps://paherald.sk.ca\nTop Stories\nSask Rivers Community Engagement Global's Daisy Woelk reports \u2013 May 2, 2024\nLEAVE A COMMENT\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON FACEBOOK\nSHARE THIS ITEM ON TWITTER\nSEND THIS PAGE TO SOMEONE VIA EMAIL\nSEE MORE SHARING OPTIONS\nDESCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\nINCREASE ARTICLE FONT SIZE\n\nAhead of Red Dress Day on Sunday, a time meant to raise awareness about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG), frustration is boiling over in Winnipeg.\n\n\u201cWhy is it OK to leave Indigenous women\u2019s remains in the landfill while non-Indigenous people are being searched for without a second hesitation?\u201d said Cambria Harris, the daughter of Morgan Harris whose remains are believed to be in Prairie Green Landfill.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s the difference?\u201d she said.\n\nWednesday, a Saskatoon landfill search began following an investigation into the disappearance of Mackenzie Lee Trottier, who has been missing for over three years.\n\n1:54\nSaskatoon landfill search begins, Mackenzie Lee Trottier disappearance\n\nIn Winnipeg, calls to have Prairie Green Landfill searched for the remains of three Indigenous women, including Harris\u2019 mother, Marcedes Myran, and Buffalo Woman, have been ongoing since spring of 2022.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nAt that time, Winnipeg\u2019s chief of police refused a search, saying too much time had passed since the remains were taken there.\n\nAssembly of Manitoba Chiefs\u2019 Grand Chief Cathy Merrick said that decision cost critical timing.\n\n\u201cIt was a very hard journey to get to where we are today, and to be able to see how another province is doing \u2014 basically \u2014 the same work that we wanted to do from the get-go is kind of disheartening.\u201d\n\n2:46\nWinnipeg police say identified victims in alleged serial murder case likely at landfill north of city\n\nHarris is feeling about the same.\n\nEdmonton's breaking news sent to your email as it happens.\n\n\u201cIt leaves me feeling incredibly disheartened and frustrated,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s telling Indigenous women that they are less than worth looking for. It\u2019s telling serial killers that it\u2019s OK to dispose of women\u2019s bodies in the landfill, and that nobody will search for them. (It) is telling Indigenous women that they are trash.\u201d\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nMerrick said, \u201call our women need to be found regardless of where they\u2019re from or regardless of who they are. We just need to find them, and we just need closure for families.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re human beings, and that\u2019s literally all we want to be treated as,\u201d Harris said.\n\nOn Thursday, Harris spoke at a Red Dress Day event at the University of Manitoba, hoping to raise awareness of the MMIWG crisis.\n\n2:02\nRed Dress Day honours memory of MMIWG2S\n\n\u201cThis is something that strikes the heart of our Indigenous people and people across Turtle Island in Canada. This is an ongoing crisis,\u201d she said.\n\nAdele Perry, the director of the University of Manitoba\u2019s Centre of Human Rights, said a combination of systemic issues often contributes to public apathy.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\n\u201cColonialism, both of the past and of the present, racism, patriarchy, (and) sexism have come together to produce a context where Indigenous women, girls and two-spirited people, have found themselves disproportionately coming to harm,\u201d Perry said.\n\n\u201cWe, as a society, have repeatedly shown ourselves kind of unable and unwilling, and often kind of a combination of both, to address those circumstances and to honour to those women and girls and two-spirited people, and their families,\u201d she added.\n\n\u201cWithout our women and without our children, we would simply and disturbingly be non-existent as a society,\u201d Harris said.\n\nA search of the landfill was promised by current Premier Wab Kinew as a part of his election campaign.\n\n2:14\nJustice for families at \u2018top of mind\u2019 for landfill search, Manitoba premier says\n\nIn February, he announced he was confident the search would take place within the year. The province said there has been no updates regarding timelines, but noted it would keep watch over what happens in Saskatoon.\n\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW ADVERTISEMENT\n\nOne month later, the provincial and federal governments have committed a collective $40 million to find the remains of the slain women.\n\nMeanwhile, alleged serial killer Jeremy Skibicki awaits a court ruling for the deaths of Morgan Harris, Marcedes Myran, Rebecca Contois and Buffalo Woman.\n\n\u201cThis fight doesn\u2019t just aim to search the landfill. It has inspired and created waves and ripples across Turtle Island, where you will now see a new wave of grassroots advocates speak their own stories,\u201d Harris said.\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s the whole point.\u201d\n\n1:25\nWinnipeg trial of man accused of killing 4 women starts with bid to toss jury\nJOURNALISTIC STANDARDS\nCOMMENT\nREPORT AN ERROR\n\u00a9 2024 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.\nSponsored content\nMore to Explore\nMORE FROM GLOBAL NEWS\nCanada\u2019s digital services tax is here. {"url": "https://www.vernonmorningstar.com/news/this-is-our-reality-kelownas-red-dress-day-brings-awareness-to-violence-against-indigenous-women/", "title": "\u2018This is our reality\u2019: Kelowna\u2019s Red Dress Day brings awareness to violence against Indigenous women - Vernon Morning Star", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n28.0 \u00b0C\nHome News\n\u2018This is our reality\u2019: Kelowna\u2019s Red Dress Day brings awareness to violence against Indigenous women\nA few hundred people walked the streets of downtown Kelowna wearing red on Friday, May 5\n\tJordy Cunningham\n\nMay 6, 2023 2:55 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nPrevious\nNext\n1 / 8 Hundreds of people marched the streets of downtown Kelowna for Red Dress Day on Friday, May 5. (Jordy Cunningham/Capital News)\nExpand\n\nWarning: This story contains graphic descriptions and images that some may find disturbing\n\nFor Carol Archie, she has lived through the reality of Red Dress Day.\n\nArchie is the niece \u2013 from her mom\u2019s side \u2013 of a murdered Indigenous woman.\n\n\u201cShe was brutally raped and murdered and the individuals that were responsible for her death, two of them were provided small fines and one was able to walk away free, none of them had jail time. This is our reality. We were born and raised with the mindset that we have to be aware of the dangers, not out in the wilderness, in community,\u201d said Archie, who spoke at Kelowna\u2019s Red Dress Day march Friday (May 5).\n\nWhile wearing red and holding signs, the group of hundreds marched from the friendship society on Leon Avenue before eventually ending up at the Kelowna Court House to bring awareness to Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) and the ongoing violent epidemic throughout North America against Indigenous women and girls.\n\nWhile Red Dress Day has been commemorated for more than a decade, Friday marked the first time the Ki-Low-Na Friendship Society held an event.\n\nIndigenous people have been targets for years and Archie still sees that today.\n\n\u201cI have the ability to be able to work for an employer that understands where I\u2019m coming from because in this day and age, my youngest daughter was followed from my work to her school,\u201d said Archie, who has two daughters, 19 and 16. \u201cI know to make certain I get to work extra early in the morning and my day ends when her day ends so that way I know I\u2019m the one driving her home and I\u2019m the one picking her up, because we are visitors on the Sylix traditional unceded territory so we don\u2019t have a lot of family here.\u201d\n\nKi-Low-Na Friendship Society executive director Edna Terbasket said it warmed her heart to see the support Friday.\n\n\u201cThe message is getting out there to many, many people,\u201d said Terbasket. \u201cWe\u2019ve lived with it for a long time as Indigenous people and when I see a lot of the folks here that are from the mainstream, I go \u2018Wow, we\u2019re getting our message out there.\u2019\u201d\n\nTerbasket explained red is symbolic because it\u2019s spiritual to Indigenous people. It also stands for the violence behind what\u2019s been happening, at the same time representing love.\n\n\u201cI think families talk more with their children about safety and even lifestyle and taking good care of themselves,\u201d said Terbasket. \u201cIt\u2019s not only Indigenous women and girls, it\u2019s all peoples. I couldn\u2019t imagine if I lost a sister or a niece or a granddaughter and she wasn\u2019t found, I couldn\u2019t imagine that. Is she alive? Is she okay? Has she been brutally assaulted or murdered?\u201d\n\nBoth Terbasket and Archie have seen tremendous growth and awareness, especially since the remains of 215 Indigenous residential school children were found in Kamloops almost two years ago.\n\n\u201cWhat we are doing here today, we\u2019re becoming stronger as a people, we are being more aware of who we are as a people and how we contribute to our families, communities, and nation,\u201d said Archie. \u201cHaving this awareness across Canada and North America is huge for us, and it all started with residential school. That ripple effect comes into today and we\u2019re answering back with our own ripple effects and it\u2019s becoming more powerful.\u201d\n\nAnd for more people who want to become aware, learn, and be a part of the solution, Terbasket and Archie say to ask questions and have open conversations.\n\n\u201cWe all have to work together, collaborate together, heal together,\u201d said Terbasket.\n\nREAD MORE: West Kelowna RCMP asking for public\u2019s help in finding missing 13-year-old boy\n\nREAD MORE: From great tips to saving lives, Kelowna Uride drives into Penticton\n\n@cunninghamjordy\njordy.cunningham@kelownacapnews.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n\nAbout the Author: Jordy Cunningham\n\nHailing from Ladner, B.C., I have been passionate about sports, especially baseball, since I was young. Federal Government to Implement a Red Dress Alert\nPush Mitteilungen\nNewsfile\n05.05.2023 22:26 Uhr\n575 Leser\nArtikel bewerten:\n(2)\nCongress of Aboriginal Peoples: CAP Commemorates Red Dress Day and Call on the Federal Government to Implement a Red Dress Alert\n\nOttawa, Ontario--(Newsfile Corp. - May 5, 2023) - Today, on Red Dress Day, the Congress of Aboriginal Peoples (CAP) lifts up all Indigenous peoples and communities across Turtle Island as we remember and honour the lives of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people, and calls on the federal government to implement a red dress alert.\n\nSystemic discrimination, racism, and violence against Indigenous people has resulted in violence against and loss of our women, girls, and 2S+ people. The ongoing epidemic of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people is a national tragedy that demands urgent action and attention.\n\nWe support the call by MP Leah Gazan and others to implement a public alert system to inform all Canadians when an Indigenous woman, girl, or 2S+ person goes missing. The Government of Canada has a duty to Indigenous peoples and must take a leadership role, financially and otherwise, in implementing an MMIWG2S+ \"Red Dress\" alert system.\n\nAnzeige\nDieser \"Fehler\" enth\u00fcllt Wachstumsaktien \u2013 20% p.a. sind m\u00f6glich.\n\n\"Eine \"falsche\" Einstellung in meiner Analyse-Software entpuppte sich als wahrer Gl\u00fccksgriff: So fand ich Aktien, die j\u00e4hrlich 20% Rendite (oder mehr) bringen. In einem kurzen Video lege ich die Karten auf den Tisch: Welche Aktien ich so gefunden habe und wie Sie mit diesen Werten ein Verm\u00f6gen aufbauen.\" Mehr >> \u00bb\n\npowered by finative\n\nWe also call on the Federal Government to urgently address violence against Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people and stop delaying important measures like the Red Dress Alert, because every moment is critical to saving lives.\n\nOn Red Dress Day, we remember and continue to draw strength from the resilience and courage of our loved ones who have been lost to violence. On Red Dress Day, we honor their lives and commit ourselves to the important work of ensuring that no more Indigenous women, girls, and 2S+ people are lost to violence.\n\nMedia Contact\nFor media interviews please contact:\nHana Sabah, CAP Communications support\nCell: (514) 834-8841\nEmail: hana@impactcanada.com\n\nBackground\n\nThe Congress of Aboriginal Peoples (CAP) is the second-oldest national aboriginal organization in Canada. It was founded in 1971, one year after the AFN. CAP represents the interests of off-reserve status and non-status Indians, M\u00e9tis and Southern Inuit Aboriginal Peoples throughout Canada. CAP is one of five national Indigenous organizations recognized by the federal government, and holds consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council.\n\nTo view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/165058\n\n\u00a9\u00a02023\u00a0Newsfile Corp.\nDiesen Artikel auf Deutsch lesen\nMeistgelesene News (24 h)\nLeser\tAktuelle Nachrichten\n3.401\tKrypto Breaking News: Der Markt bricht ein - Das Spiel ist aus\n2.183\tEvotec-Aktie: Das Comeback nimmt Formen an\n2.153\t20.180 im NASDAQ 100, die n\u00e4chste Bestmarke steht! {"url": "https://www.ladysmithchronicle.com/news/red-dresses-hanging-on-ubco-campus-address-nation-wide-issue/", "title": "Red dresses hanging on UBCO campus address nation wide issue - Ladysmith Chemainus Chronicle", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n24.0 \u00b0C\n!\nHome News\nRed dresses hanging on UBCO campus address nation wide issue\nThe REDress Project at UBCO focuses on the conversation about missing and murdered Indigenous women\nCarli Berry\nFeb 28, 2018 12:53 PM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRed dresses like this one could be seen on the UBCO\u2019s campus Tuesday, as part of The REDress Project and tea talk held by the Women\u2019s Resource Centre and Indigenous Students Association. - Credit: Carli Berry/Capital News\n\nRed dresses were blowing in the wind as they hung from trees, branches and poles at UBC Okanagan.\n\nTen dresses could be seen at the university as part of the REDress Project and tea talk, Tuesday Feb. 27.\n\nThe REDress Project is a nationwide event, focusing on the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s definitely for awareness. Even the people at the event don\u2019t know a lot of information on missing and murdered Indigenous women. It\u2019s generally not talked about on campus, or in everyday life,\u201d said Taya Jardine, volunteer director at UBCO\u2019s Women\u2019s Resource Centre. \u201cA lot of people don\u2019 t know how close and how strongly impacted the local community is.\u201d\n\nJardine was referring to the five women who went missing in the North Okanagan in less than two years. The body of one, Traci Genereaux, was found on a property in Salmon Arm in October.\n\nThe tea talks are held monthly on various topics throughout the year. This one featured missing and murdered Aboriginal women and approximately 20 students shared their voices on the subject.\n\n\u201cThe main aim of the tea talks is to really get information out there; to get students involved on campus in a safe space where they can talk about their feelings and opinions on different matters,\u201d said Jardine.\n\n\u201cI feel like bringing the dresses out forces that conversation out of Indigenous communities, into settler communities as well.\u201d\n\nIndigenous women of all ages are being taken and murdered, said Jardine. \u201cSome of the people we were talking about, especially Tina Fontaine, she was 15, just in the child protective system. Other ones are mothers and could be any of us really. That\u2019s why it\u2019s important to talk about.\u201d\n\nFontaine was found dead in Winnipeg\u2019s Red River in 2014. The man accused of the murder was found not guilty last week.\n\nIt\u2019s about getting the information to a generation who can make changes, she said.\n\n\u201cOn the university campus people are here to learn and aside from learning terms, it should be an environment of social learning as well.\u201d\n\nThe dress project was held by the Women\u2019s Resource Centre in partnership with the Indigenous Students Association.\n\nTo report a typo, email: edit@kelownacapnews.com.\n\n<>\n\n@carliberry_\ncarli.berry@kelownacapnews.com\nLike us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n Share on Facebook\n\t\n Share on X\n\t\n Share on LinkedIn\n\t\n Print\n\t\nTrending\n\t\tB.C. {"url": "https://www.sookenewsmirror.com/news/langford-students-to-hang-red-dresses-to-honour-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women/", "title": "Langford students to hang red dresses to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women - Sooke News Mirror", "body": "Skip to content\nPlayNEWSLETTER SIGNUP\n \nNews\nMore\nContests\nShop\nE-EditionsClassifieds\nAuto\nJobs\nObituaries\nGood News\n22.2 \u00b0C\nHome News\nLangford students to hang red dresses to honour missing and murdered Indigenous women\nStudents from Savory, Ruth King and Spencer schools mark Red Dress Day Friday on Goldstream Avenue\nElla Matte\nMay 3, 2023 3:30 PM\nMay 4, 2023 6:32 AM\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\nRed dress and pin for Red Dress Day, which Langford students will mark on Friday. (Courtesy of Renee Hislop)\n\nOn Friday, May 5, students from Savory and Ruth King elementary schools and Spencer Middle School will hang red dresses across Goldstream Avenue to honour and remember missing and murdered Indigenous women, children and two-spirit people.\n\nOn Red Dress Day and National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirit People, the three schools will be working alongside Na\u2019tsa\u2019maht Indigenous Education, Hulitan Family and Community Services Society, and Journeys of the Heart, an Indigenous preschool, to take time to pause and reflect.\n\n\u201cWe also want to share and celebrate the strength of Indigenous women and relay how honoured women are in Indigenous culture and communities,\u201d said Renee Hislop, principal of Savory Elementary School.\n\n\u201cIt is important in our work towards Truth and Reconciliation, that we teach this to our young people in a way that tells the story of Indigenous peoples both past and present. It\u2019s really important to us that we share this truth in a way that honours but does not traumatize children. Our children are our future, and they are going to make the difference.\u201d\n\nRed Dress Day started in 2010 after artist Jaime Black\u2019s REDress project inspired the movement to pay respect to the Indigenous victims of racialized and gendered violence in Canada.\n\nSince then, May 5 has been a day to pay respect and raise awareness for the Indigenous women, children, and two-spirit people.\n\nIn 2014, the RCMP identified 1,181 Indigenous women and girls who were murdered or went missing in Canada between 1980 and 2012.\n\nStats Canada also released a report in July 2017 stating that Indigenous women represent 10 per cent of the total population of missing women in Canada while only making up 3% of Canada\u2019s total female population.\n\nALSO READ: Prime minister calls discovery of Indigenous woman in Winnipeg landfill heartbreaking\n\nHislop expresses that this year they want to \u201cbring awareness to strong female Indigenous voices and to share that Indigenous females have not and are not always treated with kindness. We want to, as a community, stand in solidarity wearing red to send a message that this is not OK, and we will work together to change this.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn classrooms at Savory Elementary, they have been teaching the themes of connections Indigenous peoples have with generations before and how this is passed down through literacy. Connections between mothers and children, the strength of Indigenous women in family and community, connections to Indigenous identity and Indigenous world views,\u201d said Hislop.\n\nFriday, the community and schools will walk and drum together starting at Ruth King Elementary School at 9:45 a.m. and head to Savory Elementary School as red dresses will be seen on Goldstream Avenue along with red lights the City of Langford will display.\n\nOnce students and the community have arrived at Savory Elementary School, the school will have an assembly where female Indigenous voices Elder Shirley Alphonse, Breanne Bear, Marlene Clifton, Jo-Ina Young, and Doreen Scow share their stories. After the speeches, a tea, coffee and bannock time will commence.\n\n\u00a0\n\nDo you have a story tip? Email: newsroom@goldstreamgazette.com.\n\nFollow us on Twitter and Instagram, and like us on Facebook.\n\nHave a story/tip?\n\nAbout the Author: Ella Matte\n\nRead more\n\t\n Share by Email\n\t\n (Black Press Media files)\n\nSpirit Square will be the site of a solemn ceremony on Friday as community members flock down to participate in the Red Dress Day ceremony being hosted by the City of Pitt Meadows.\n\nThis national day of awareness is aimed at recognizing the many missing and murdered Indigenous women in every community across the continent, and properly honouring this event is very important for the city, said Mayor Nicole MacDonald.\n\n\u201cRed dresses have been hung up throughout \u0161x\u02b7h\u00e9k\u0313\u02b7n\u0259s (Spirit Square) as a powerful reminder of the more than 1,000 missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit people in Canada,\u201d said MacDonald.\n\n\u201cWe honour and recognize the many lives that have been lost at the hands of violence.\u201d\n\nVIDEO: Maple Ridge students asking community to march for murdered and missing Indigenous women\n\nMembers of Katzie First Nation will be at Spirit Square to sing songs, while members of the Fraser River Indigenous Society will be performing smudging.\n\nThere will be several other Indigenous art forms on display as well, explained Director of Parks, Recreation and Culture, Diane Chamberlain.\n\n\u201cThe ceremony will also include a traditional dance from the Squamish Nation Veterans Jr Powwow Princess, Sariah, from the Squamish and Sto:lo Nation, and two songs by Saquilty from Sts\u2019ailes First Nation with Sasquatch dancers, Harmony and Addy,\u201d said Chamberlain.\n\nThe Red Dress Day ceremony will take place at Spirit Square, 11985 Harris Rd., from 1 to 2 p.m. on Friday, May 5.\n\nRELATED: Pope voices willingness to return Indigenous loot, artifacts\n\nHave a story tip? Act Now>>\nSections\nSearch\nSubscribe for $3\nSign In\nNews\nSports\nLocal Sports\nOpinion\nBusiness\nArts\nLife\nShopping\nPuzzmo\nHealthing\nePaper\nDriving\nRemembering\nNewsletters\nManage Print Subscription\nAdvertisement 1\nBreadcrumb Trail Links\nNews\nManitoba environment minister defends Indigenous ancestry after brother questions claim\n\n'He never grew up M\u00e9tis. My grandparents never told us we were M\u00e9tis. I never heard anything about us being M\u00e9tis'\n\nAuthor of the article:\nTyler Dawson\nPublished Jul 31, 2023 \u00a0\u2022\u00a0 6 minute read\nJoin the conversation\nManitoba MLA Kevin Klein has speculated that a \"Liberal-NDP-funded government employee\" raised questions about his Indigenous identity in order to harm his reputation ahead of the October provincial election. PHOTO BY KEVIN KING/POSTMEDIA/FILE\nArticle content\n\nManitoba\u2019s environment minister is facing scrutiny over his identification as a \u201cproud M\u00e9tis Canadian,\u201d the latest in a number of prominent Canadians who\u2019ve been accused of claiming Indigenous ancestry without sufficient evidence.\n\nKevin Klein has said he\u2019s a member of the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis, but his brother and the Manitoba M\u00e9tis Federation have questioned his claims.\n\nAdvertisement 2\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nTRENDING\nToo hot \u2014 Windsor Hudson's Bay could open next week after shutting for air conditioning woes\nReport: Officer described 'possible suicide' on scene where Harrow family found dead\nTiny-homes company with Windsor ties wins $1M in Housing Supply Challenge\nStorm alert: Weather watcher warns over \u2018superheated\u2019 Lake Erie\nLong overdue homecoming complete as Windsor native Matwijiw joins Spitfires as goalie coach\nArticle content\n\n\u201cIt saddened me and it brought up a lot of emotions. It brought up a lot of history,\u201d said Klein, when reached Monday morning by National Post.\n\nKlein has been a provincial legislator since 2022, and before that he served on Winnipeg\u2019s city council. At various points in his political career, he has mentioned his Indigenous ancestry \u2014 specifically in relation to his mother, Joanne Winacott, who was murdered by her second husband in 1991.\n\nIn December 2021, Klein spoke in Winnipeg council, during a debate about the police budget. He said, \u201cI have very little to say on this one, but I want to speak from a place that no one else on council can speak from.\u201d\n\nHe went on to speak about police response times.\n\n\u201cMy Indigenous mother was murdered because the police didn\u2019t respond to the initial call. That is on record in, and it\u2019s in the court documents,\u201d Klein said at the time.\n\nKlein referenced his mother\u2019s identity again on May 5, 2022, in an Instagram video for Red Dress Day, also known as the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and Two-Spirit People.\n\nHeadline News\n\nGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.\n\nSign Up\n\nBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.\n\nArticle content\nAdvertisement 3\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cMy mother was murdered by her partner, and she was Indigenous,\u201d he said.\n\nI'm not self-identifying, nor am I using it, nor am I mentioning it every time I open my mouth\n\nKlein\u2019s brother, Christopher Rout, has firmly rejected the characterization that his family has Indigenous heritage.\n\n\u201cHe never grew up M\u00e9tis. My grandparents never told us we were M\u00e9tis. I never heard anything about us being M\u00e9tis,\u201d said Rout in an interview with the National Post. \u201cThe net bottom line is we are not Aboriginal at all.\u201d\n\nKlein, who\u2019s a Progressive Conservative MLA, told National Post that he first learned of his purported M\u00e9tis ancestry when speaking with his uncle Dave. They were going through old photo albums, and his uncle asked him if he had his M\u00e9tis card, Klein said.\n\n\u201cI said \u2018No, I don\u2019t think I\u2019m M\u00e9tis,'\u201d Klein recalled. \u201cHe pulled out his card and said \u2018We are. You need to get your M\u00e9tis card because your mom never had the chance to.'\u201d\n\nKlein then applied to the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis. His understanding was that they did their own research before issuing a card.\n\n\u201cIt excited me because it\u2019s a connection I never knew,\u201d he said. \u201cI went with it because of my uncle, who I loved dearly.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 4\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nThe uncle, said Rout, has since died.\n\nThe allegations against Klein \u2014 that his claims of Indigenous ancestry are disputed \u2014 were first reported by CBC News, which used census records to build Klein\u2019s family tree. It found no evidence of an Indigenous ancestor.\n\nKlein said what he knows of it came from his uncle, and that the Painted Feather Woodland M\u00e9tis did their own genealogical research.\n\n\u201cThere are many Indigenous and non-(Indigenous) who are looking for clarity on their story of origin, their family history,\u201d said Klein. \u201cAnd this is something I will continue to do as a personal journey for as long as I live.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, there have been a number of prominent Canadians who have had their claims to Indigenous identity questioned, including Ellen Turpel-Lafond, who claimed to be the first Cree judge. Her claims to be a \u201cTreaty Indian\u201d have been highly disputed.\n\nThe novelist Joseph Boyden, who\u2019s best known for writing about Indigenous culture, has long claimed Indigenous ancestry, but various news reports have since disputed his claims.\n\nIn the case of Klein, his political biographies have, at various times, identified him as M\u00e9tis, although the term has recently been dropped from some of his social media accounts, CBC reported.\n\nAdvertisement 5\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not self-identifying, nor am I using it, nor am I mentioning it every time I open my mouth. It is a family issue for me and a connection to my mother,\u201d Klein told CBC last fall.\n\nManitoba M\u00e9tis Federation President David Chartrand told CBC that Klein does not meet their criteria to identify as M\u00e9tis.\n\n\u201cWe do not recognize the Painted Feather Woodlands M\u00e9tis or any other group that claims M\u00e9tis identity outside our definition. This is no different than any of the other cases where groups or individuals are calling themselves M\u00e9tis when they really mean mixed heritage,\u201d Chartrand said in an email.\n\nOn Monday, Klein told the Post he has dropped the identifier in some places because, \u201cI don\u2019t mean to insult anybody. It really was a proud moment for me to believe that my family had that M\u00e9tis status.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a personal journey. I don\u2019t want to insult anybody, but I am going to follow my personal journey. And that\u2019s how we got here today,\u201d Klein said.\n\n\u201cI got into public life to serve, not to offend. To help people, not degrade them. It was never, has never, was never an attempt to make a false claim.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 6\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nKlein, who was the publisher and CEO of the Winnipeg Sun newspaper between 2007 and 2013, which is now owned by Postmedia Network Inc., speculated that a \u201cLiberal-NDP-funded government employee\u201d raised questions about his identity in order to harm his reputation ahead of the provincial election. Manitobans go to the polls in October.\n\n\u201cI can only assume it was to hurt us, to attempt to hurt us in the election when really all it did was cause more pain and sorrow for my family,\u201d Klein said.\n\nKlein\u2019s official biography, from when he was appointed to Premier Heather Stefanson\u2019s cabinet, said Klein \u201ccontinues to explore, working with Elders in Manitoba to research his connections to Indigenous community. This exploration has heightened his desire to work with Indigenous communities.\u201d\n\nA profile in What\u2019s up Winnipeg, a local magazine, reports that Klein took courses in Cree and M\u00e9tis history at the University of Alberta during COVID-19 to learn more about his roots, which he\u2019d learned about from his mother\u2019s older brother.\n\n\u201cBlond and blue-eyed Indigenous people were not uncommon among certain groups in middle America,\u201d the profile says. \u201cHis family says his roots are evident in his cheekbones, which Kevin says he could never produce a proper beard!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement 7\nSTORY CONTINUES BELOW\nArticle content\n\nWhen reached by National Post on Monday, Rout also objected to Klein\u2019s use of their mother\u2019s experience with domestic violence, and said Klein wasn\u2019t even living at home when the domestic violence and murder occurred.\n\n\u201cAs a son, you shouldn\u2019t be trying to profit or benefit from your mom\u2019s death,\u201d said Rout.\n\nKlein said he hasn\u2019t spoken to his brother in more than 25 years. He does, however, have a relationship with their other brother, Duane.\n\nIn an email provided to the National Post by Klein\u2019s office, Duane purportedly writes that he can confirm that Klein and their Uncle Dave had a M\u00e9tis card \u2014 although the email does not go so far as to confirm Indigenous ancestry in the family.\n\n\u201cNo one knows the full history of my immediate family. I am not going into any detail because I strongly believe family matters are just that, between family,\u201d the email says. \u201cI pray my mom can Rest In Peace again.\u201d\n\nRECOMMENDED FROM EDITORIAL\nCanada's little-known contributions to the atomic bomb\nPierre Poilievre apologizes for calling $539K Niagara home a 'tiny little shack'\n\nOur website is the place for the latest breaking news, exclusive scoops, longreads and provocative commentary.
